column2: There was a sharp contraction in values in the wholesale markets yesterday, the grains, cotton, lard, rubber, silk, hides and cocoa all losing ground. Coffee was moderately higher and sugar irregular.

Paul Claudel, French Ambassador to the United States, is due to return today on the French liner Paris, which docks this afternoon from Havre and Plymouth, The liner's list also includes Vladimir Golschmann, conductor of the St. Louis Orchestra, with his wife; Enrique Dorda, Spanish painter, and Dr. J. Bentley Squier, New York surgeon.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 5. -- Opening their annual meeting here, members of the New York State Historical Society spent the afternoon on Gardiner's Isrand, visiting the spot where Captain Kidd buried a chest full of gold, diamonds, rubies and other treasures in 1699, the historic manor house, the Gardiner family cemetery and the forests of oak trees which have been untouched by man.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Some of the telegrams of congratulation to President Hoover on his Des Moines speech were made public at the White House tonight. They were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The permanent Pan-American Conciliation Commission is awaiting Colombia's response to Peru's request, forwarded by the commission, for a neutral examination of the international disagreement which grew out of the recent seizure.

In the ups and downs and prolonged disputes and conflicts at the Democratic State Convention in Albany, one fact was lost sight of by many. It was that the choice of Colonel LEHMAN to run for Governor simply had to be made unless the Democratic party were to confess itself bankrupt and beaten in advance.

The response of the public to the announcement of the twenty concerts to be presented by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra, an ensemble of 200 unemployed players, at the Metropolitan Opera House, beginning Nov. 1, has been immediate and gratifying, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- The German, position regarding the proposed London discussion intended to extricate the Geneva disarmament conference from the morass in which it is now bogged is much more amenable than yesterday's editorial utterances had indicated.

DES MOINES, Oct. 5. -- Indications that President Hoover's Des Moines address has made a deep impression upon Iowa farmers put a new spirit today into the political campaigning in the Corn Belt. Republican leaders, who heretofore have been glum over the reputed disaffection among the farmers, were stimulated by the Hoover "fighting speech" to plunge immediately into a brisk campaign for the national ticket.

Columbia directed its attention yesterday at Baker Field toward constructing a defense against the type of attack expected from Princeton on Saturday. In a two-hour dummy scrimmage the Blue and White had an opportunity to test its defensive ability against every type of passing and running play known to be a part of the Tigers' offense.
ON BOARD PRESIDENT HOOVER'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Across Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Pennsylvania Mrs. Herbert Hoover campaigned with her husband today.

The first meeting of principals of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference, at which revision of the rate schedules of Atlantic passenger ships and other matters will be considered, will be held today to London, according to information received yesterday by American shipping men.
BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 5. -- I do not fully share the views generally expressed with reference to Germany's demand for equality in armaments.

The Citizens Budget Commission called a meeting of all civic bodies of New York City yesterday in the great hall of the State Chamber of Commerce to launch a permanent accessory organization in which it is proposed that each of the 800 bodies interested in governmental economy and reduced taxation in this city may be represented by a member.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 5. -- With two superb rounds, one of them played in the rain, and both in a wind that made low scoring a most difficult task, Willlie Klein, former Long Island open champion, today outstripped the qualifying field in the annual Metropolitan P.G.A. championship at the Old Westbury Golf Club.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- President Hoover's Des Moines speech attracted more attention in France today because of reports of the hostility of the farmers than because of what he said. In business circles, however, the Presidential campaign and words of the President have aroused great interest because of his references to debts, tariffs and the near collapse of the dollar last Spring.

DES MOINES, Oct. 5. -- The Hoover speech at Des Moines was the most beautifully staged affair which any one in this part of the country has yet seen. Admission to the Coliseum was by ticket and the great majority of the tickets were passed out to officeholders and precinct workers, and, through them, to close friends.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- President Hoover's speech last night in Des Moines, Iowa, failed to influence the grain market on the Board of Trade here today. Many operators expressed disappointment, since they saw in it no hope of an immediate upturn in price.

Fleeing through the Bronx Botanical Gardens after the theft of a woman's pocketbook in the Bronx Park station of the Third Avenue elevated at East 198th Street, the Bronx, Edward Thomsen, 40 years old, an unemployed and homeless laborer, was shot and critically wounded last night by Police Sergeant Jacob Bauer.

There is little doubt that the average hunter neglects his favorite gun, be it shotgun or rifle. When the season is over and the last bit of game has been bagged, the hunter is likely to put his gun in the corner and forget all about it. But when the next season comes he finds himself in difficulties.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- Greatly elated by his success in bringing about the nomination of Herbert H. Lehman for Governor with the aid of Governor Roosevelt, Alfred E. Smith left for New York today, ready to oppose the nomination of James J. Walker for Mayor of New York City at the meeting of the county committees in the city tomorrow night.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 5. -- Flouting orders of the Central Government and ignoring its pleas that further civil strife disgraces China in Geneva and elsewhere, the war lords of the great western province of Szechuan, which borders on Tibet, have started another large-scale civil war, the second now under way in China, in addition to anti-Communist campaigns.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The Marquess of Clydesdale, Member of Parliament for Eastern Renfrew, asked his constituents tonight for permission to absent himself on the Mount Everest Air Expedition, of which he is to be chief pilot.

Three hours after Ambrose Ratti, 42 years old, an unemployed chauffeur, committed suicide at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon by jumping in front of a B.M.T. train in the Lowery station. Queens, the body of his wife, Mrs. Margaret Ratti, 39, with the skull crushed by a blow from a hammer, was found in their locked apartment on the third floor of 45-54 Fortieth Street, Astoria.

President Hoover will carry every Atlantic seaboard State from Maine to Maryland, Senator George H. Moses of New Hampshire predicted yesterday at Republican Eastern campaign headquarters in the Waldorf. Maine, he asserted, will go Republican by 20,000, and New Hampshire will be carried for the President by 12,000 to 15,000 votes, half of the usual majority.

The Board of Estimate formally recorded yesterday the receipt of a tentative budget for 1933 showing a decrease of only $16,717,385 from the current budget, in contrast with Mayor McKee's declaration that the budget could be cut $40,000,000 next year without touching mandatory salaries or mandatory increases.

BAKERSFIELD, Cal., Oct. 5 (AP). -- President Hoover was charged by William G. McAdoo tonight with misrepresenting "completely" the position of the Democratic party "with respect to agriculture and products of the soil."

President Hoover's Des Moines speech was acclaimed by Republicans here yesterday as a masterly exposition of Republican policies and achievements, one which will materially aid in bringing about a Republican victory in November.

An invitation to become commissioner of the Western railroads, with power to curb uneconomic duplications of service, was laid before Carl R. Gray, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, at a meeting here yesterday. Mr. Gray, who has been active in pressing for the appointment of such an official, is chairman of the committee appointed by the Western lines to fill the position.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The ousting of foreign capital from Mexico was advocated today by Governor Adalberto Tejeda of the State of Vera Cruz, who is being boomed by labor groups as a candidate for the Presidency.

Word was received here today of the marriage at Bradford, Pa., on Tuesday, of Miss Cora J. Bishop, daughter of the late Noah L. Bishop of Norwich, N.Y., to Inspector Ernest L. Van Wagner of the New York City Police Department, in charge of the homicide bureau on Staten Island.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Two disturbances among unemployed in the United Kingdom today resulted in several persons being injured. One, a policeman, was seriously hurt. Four men were arrested.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Secretary Mills is an able, sincere and patriotic man. His speech in St. Louis was the best Republican campaign talk I have heard. But the tariff question is not as simple as he believes.

Unmistakable evidence of improvement in the steel business is cited in the midweek review of The Iron Age, which puts the national average of ingot production at slightly more than 18 per cent of capacity.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Economic conditions charge the American engineers with a professional responsibility unprecedented in history, declared Colonel Samuel P. Wetherill Jr. of Philadelphia, president of the Tri-State Regional Planning Committee, in an address today before the Fall meeting here of the American Society of Civil Engineers.

A decision that barred independent debenture holders from appealing the ruling under which the Irving Trust Company was elected trustee in the International Match bankruptcy was reported yesterday to Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee, by George K. Hourwich of counsel for the trustee.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 5 (AP). -- New impetus was given the Middle Western farmers' strike for better prices today, after several weeks of quiesence. In Southeastern South Dakota adherents of the National Farmers' Holiday Association were preparing, they said, to maintain a strong blockade of roads into Sioux Falls in an attempt to keep grain and live stock from the markets.
Players and the football public generally have always expected the man carrying the ball to fight for every inch of ground that he can possibly gain until the ball becomes dead.

TORONTO. Ont., Oct. 5 (AP). -- John Hampden, Assistant State's Attorney of Chicago, and a detective arrived by plane at 10:30 o'clock tonight to negotiate for the extradition of Martin J: Insull to the United States.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- Premier Harriot laid before his Cabinet today a full account of his conversation yesterday with Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, and the terms of the British proposal for an exchange of views among the powers regarding the reasons for Germany's withdrawal from the disarmament conference and the possibilities for meeting the German demand for equality to such an extent as to permit the conference to resume.

The large number of reservations for the fashion show in aid of the charitable activities of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital, to be held this afternoon and tonight in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, indicates that the auxiliary funds will be augmented greatly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- A declaration that indications of improving business were visible in many lines was made today by Secretary Chapin, who has just returned from a trip to New York and New England, where he met business and financial leaders.

Saul Price, Assistant District Attorney, and Joseph C. De Wolf, editor of The Worcester (Mass.) Telegram-Gazette, an uncle of the dead girl, expressed their belief yesterday that suicide ended the life of Miriam Elliot Jennisoa, 21-year-old student nurse from Milford, Mass., who was found dead from a pistol shot early Tuesday morning in a room in the Hotel Cadillac, Broadway and Forty-third Street.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Residents of Montgomery feel that Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic nominee for the New York Governorship, is one of the home folks, so they telegraphed him their best wishes today.

Eighty presidents and other officials of railroads in all parts of the country met at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday and authorized action to enable them to conform with President Hoover's request that they postpone moves in their effort further to reduce union wages until after Jan. 1.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation and chairman of the "share-the-work" movement in the Second Federal Reserve District, made public yesterday the names of ten regional chairmen in the campaign to encourage employers and employes to share work wherever possible.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 5. -- Activities of the Girl Scouts organizations need to be stimulated during the business depression more than ever, Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady of New York, chairman of the national board, told the Girl Scout convention which opened here today.

Permission to hold a symposium on City College grounds, at which representatives of the four leading political parties were to speak, has been denied by college authorities to the Student Forum, undergraduate liberal society, it was learned yesterday with the announcement that the League for Industrial Democracy, a non-student organization, would sponsor the meeting at noon today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5. -- In what will probably prove Yale's last hard drill before the Chicago game Saturday, the varsity today defeated the scrubs by a single touchdown from which no attempt was made to kick goal.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- Attorney General Bennett Jr., renominated by the Democrats, is to begin a campaign tour of the State tomorrow. His first Journey will take him to Mechanicville, where he is to address a Democratic gathering that night. He will stop off at several points in his tour to meet local leaders.

An issue of $15,000,000 Detroit Edison Company general and refunding mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds, Series E, due in 1952, will be offered today by a banking group headed by Coffin Burr, Inc., and including the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, Spencer Trask Co., the Bankers Trust Company and the First Detroit Company, Inc., at a price of 99 1/2 and interest, to yield more than 5 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., and Miss Peggy Wattles, Buffalo, two of the ranking women golfers of the country, ran into unexpected opposition today and were eliminated from the Berthellyn Cup tournament at Huntingdon Valley in first-round matches.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5. -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, Democratic candidate for Representative from the First district, told 300 women attending a tea in his honor at his home here today that President Hoover had devoted two hours in his address at Des Moines, Iowa, last night "to explain the inadequacy of his administration to cope with the problems confronting it."

ON BOARD PRESIDENT HOOVER'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Oct. 5. -- President Hoover, on his way back to Washington today from Des Moines, lashed out in no unmistakable manner at his Democratic opponents who had just preceded him into the Middle West.
Following is comment of newspapers in all parts of the country on the President's Des Moines speech:

An Attractive Family, but Hot-Tempered. Among the signs of world recovery may be cited an apparently successful attempt by the Rumanian royal family to recapture its pre-depression output on the front page.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. The appointment of 107 senior cadet officers of the field artillery unit of the R.O.T.C. of Princeton University was announced today by Colonel Roger W. Parrott, commanding officer.

A new aspect in the involved situation of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad appeared yesterday with the disclosure that under the road's charter the preferred stockholders are entitled to three directors to the board at the elect three directors to the board at the next annual meeting in May.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5. -- Brazil today set about cleaning up the political and business debris of three months of civil war.

The land at 82-90 Eighth Avenue, northeast corner of Fourteenth Street, on which stands the twenty-story home of the County Trust Company of New York, has been purchased by the trust company from the Estate of Bradish Johnson. The bank erected the building about two years ago and its purchase of the site gives it full control of the property.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Banks will have no justifiable reason for refusing loans on real estate after Oct. 15 because of fear of frozen assets or inability to procure ready cash, Franklin W. Fort, chairman of the board of the Federal Home Loan Bank, said today at a gathering of 500 persons here.

A possible explanation for yesterday's wide break on the Stock Exchange was the withdrawal from the market of speculative operators influenced by political uncertainties. Brokers said many of their best customers, among the Wall Street professionals, were merely standing by awaiting developments.
BERLIN, Oct. 5 (AP). -- A political libel suit which has been attracting much attention in Germany ended today in a setback for the adherents of Adolf Hitler, leader of the National Socialist party.

BUFFALO, Oct. 5. -- Acclaimed by leaders who conferred with him today and in letters and telegrams which began to flow in this morning from a host of Republicans in all parts of the State, Colonel William J. Donovan, candidate for Governor, announced this afternoon that, contrary to party practice, he would open his speaking campaign in New York City.

Jockey Jack Long and The Beasel proved a winning combination in the Belgrade Claiming Stakes, feature at Jamaica yesterday, the young rider keeping J.P. (Sammy) Smith's color-bearer going long enough to win by a length at the end of six furlongs.

AMOS ALONZO STAGG is going to bring his Chicago boys to New Haven to play a football game on Saturday. The venerable Amos Alonzo (may his shadow never grow less!) will be returning as a visiting football coach and also as an old grad. He was Lonnie Stagg when he played there "nigh onto" half a century ago and Eli historians have it that Lonnie was a good football player for those early days.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 5. -- The allocation of 227 additional building projects, mostly post offices, to be built under the emergency construction program provided in the relief act, was announced today by Arthur A. Ballantine, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, and Walter F. Brown, Postmaster General.

ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP EUROPA, at sea, Oct. 5. -- Former Mayor Walker of New York learned today of the nomination of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor, by the New York State Democratic Convention, through a brief 100-word account in the ship's newspaper, but declined to comment until fuller information was available.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 5. -- Republicans of Minnesota were talking today of "the new Hoover," and they spoke as if they meant it. Several of them heard his Des Moines speech yesterday, and they said it answered their hope that he would lambast the Democrats.

BUCHAREST, Oct. 5 (AP). -- King Carol bitterly denounced today the accusation attributed to his former wife, Princess Helen, by a London newspaper, that he had cut short the visit of Crown Prince Michael to London because of the publicity given it.

Electric power production showed a further gain in the week ended Oct. 1, but the increase fell a trifle short of the normal seasonal rise. The seasonally adjusted daily average is 212,800,000 kilowatt hours, as against 213,600,000 kilowatt hours for the preceding week and 233,700,000 kilowatt hours for the corresponding week last year.

New York's amateur boxers bowed to battlers from New Jersey last night in three of five interstate ring battles which were part of the George Washington Bicentennial amateur boxing tournament in Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 5,000 attended.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Bringing to a close the series of one-day tournaments sponsored by the WestChester Golf Association, Leonard Martin, Westchester amateur champion, captured the low-gross honors with a round of 72 at the Century Country Club today.

Speakers at the opening of the fifteenth annual conference of the Direct Mail Advertising Association yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania presented various means for speeding the departure of the economic depression. An optimistic note was struck by leaders in advertising and economics who addressed the general session, and the departmental sessions on industrial, financial and retail advertising and other topics were devoted largely to discussions of how advertising can help business improvement.

A lengthy scrimmage between teams A and C, the latter employing Rutgers plays, featured yesterday's two-hour drill of the New York University football squad at Ohio Field. The N.Y.U. team is preparing for its thirtieth meeting with Rutgers at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Bonus Expeditionary Force voted today to let a committee personally carry demands for "public recognition" to Washington after the executive committee rejected a suggestion for another march on the capital if the demands are not met.

GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- Norman H. Davis took a more doubtful attitude just before leaving here tonight for Paris in regard to the possibility of participation by the United States in potential disarmament talks in London. He expects to remain in Paris with his aides, Admiral Hepburn and Allan Dulles, for twenty-four hours, and it is still open whether he then will go immediately to London.

An early advance in cotton yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange as a result of unfavorable weather and crop advices, was followed by reactions under realizing and scattered selling promoted by weakness in the grain and stock markets.

Although the normal season for Fall house hunting has passed, brokers and renting agents of apartment buildings in Manhattan continue to report long lists of new tenants. These lists indicate an unusually strong demand for rooms on both the east and west sides, with the larger suites going to new Park Avenue residents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The curtailment of German reparation payments "in kind" is improving the competitive situation facing American machinery for certain foreign markets, W.K. Rastall, chief of the industrial machinery division of the Department of Commerce, said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Treasury's Oct. 15 financing will take the form of an issue of $450,000,000 or thereabouts in 4 1/2 year notes bearing 3 per cent interest, Acting Secretary Ballantine announced today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Jockey Monte Parke starred today at Lincoln Fields by bringing home three winners, including the two in the daily double.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Republican tariff history was described by Vice President Charles W. Curtis tonight as a chronicle of protection for the fanner.

The National City Bank issued yesterday a statement of its condition on Sept. 30 in response to the call of the Controller of the Currency for reports by the national banks as of that date. The statement showed substantial increases in deposits, resources, undivided profits and related items in the last quarter, bearing out the trend noted in reports of the State-chartered institutions thus far published.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- While the proposed extension of car ferry service by Seatrain Lines, Inc., to include the Port of New York was being debated before the Shipping Board today the Interstate Commerce Commission announced a special investigation of the proposal to determine whether it conflicts with provisions of the interstate commerce act.

Though there will perhaps be more general interest in what takes place at Baker Field this Saturday when Princeton and Columbia renew relations -- their last meeting was in 1905, if last year's charity round-robin in the rain is overlooked -- there is another game in New York City which should provide plenty of smashing football.

PARIS, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Lieutenant Edgar Guerrard Hamilton of Newcastle, Pa., the only American officer in the French Foreign Legion, was seriously wounded recently trying to save the life of one of his men in a battle with African tribesmen in the Atlas Mountains, it was learned today.

ERIE, Pa., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Pounded by heavy seas that sent walls of water over the decks, the John J. Boland Jr., a Canadian freighter, sank in Lake Erie today with three men and a woman reported trapped under her hatches.

The money market was quiet and featureless, since nothing developed to take it out of the narrow groove within which it has ruled for some time. Business was small, and quotations for all classes of accommodation were unchanged from Tuesday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Slight improvement was noted today in the condition of Myron Ubl, Minnesota halfback, who lay critically ill as saddened team-mates practiced for their opening Big Ten game, Physicians said the change was due chiefly to increased blood pressure affecting heart action.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 5. -- Despite the defeat suffered at the hands of Columbia at Baker Field on Saturday, Coach Austin late of Lehigh is far from reconciled to counting the season as a total loss.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been much discussion about the inadequate hospital facilities for maternity patients. An increase of over 1,300 cases in the first six months of this year has been cared for in city hospitals, which has necessitated discharging mothers and babies on the eighth day in order to make room for cases coming in.

GIBRALTAR, Oct. 5 (AP). -- A man who identified himself as Robert Young, a former resident of Long Beach, Cal., appeared at a hospital here today and related a story of an escape from the French Foreign Legion.

The depression is so nearly over that it makes very little difference, economically, whether Herbert Hoover or Franklin D. Roosevelt is elected President, Roger W. Babson, statistician, writes in "Washington and the Depression," published by Harpers today.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The official results of the French loan conversion operation, more favorable even than the Finance Ministry's first estimates, stimulated the Bourse today. Government issues, except the 4 per cents, which were not included in the conversion, were especially strong, but the entire list recovered, though trading remained rather scattering.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It takes courage to say a good word for the saloon. The Rev. Mr. Stelzle was not afraid to say a good word for the German saloon, because it was the workingman's club. He failed to say, however, that its function did not end there.

Jeremiah Joseph Sullivan, one of the three men ordered back to Sing Sing prison last July with Owen Madden for violation of parole, was in prison gray last night following his arrest yesterday morning in front of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Word reached here tonight from Toronto, where Assistant State's Attorney John Hampton of Cook County had gone by plane with papers for the extradition of Martin J. Insull, that the official had received a promise from the Canadian authorities to jail the former utility operator unless he agreed to return voluntarily to Illinois for trial on indictments charging embezzlement of $514,942 from two companies of the now defunct Insull system.

DETROIT, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Detroit Falcons management today announced the purchase of Goalie John Ross Roach from the New York Rangers. It was a cash deal, the announcement said, and the price was $11,000.
Establishment of a five-day, week without salary reductions was announced through The Associated Press yesterday by The News Syndicate Company, Inc., publishers of The Daily News.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 5. -- Newark's Bears drove into the lead in the little world's series by winning the fifth game today, 12 to 9, but it took forty minutes of argument and a ninth-inning home run. Minneapolis announced plans to file a protest.

LEICESTER, Oct. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Having declared its main objective to be the establishment of a socialistic State, the Labor party in annual conference here today launched a unanimous attack against armaments.

The Manhattan varsity football team lined up against the freshman eleven in an hour's scrimmage yesterday at Manhattan Field, the varsity stressing running plays in the drill for Seton Hall. The charging and blocking of the line was commended by Coach Meehan.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- Suspicion that Samuel Insull left Paris secretly last night has been growing all day, but cannot be confirmed. At 10 o'clock last evening he telephoned from a room at the Lincoln Hotel, making an appointment with newspaper men to meet him at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

The third annual small-house architectural competition conducted by Better Homes in America, Inc., was announced yesterday by the American Institute of Architects, whose president appoints a cooperating committee on awards.

ABOARD THE LINER REX AT SEA, Oct. 5. -- The Rex is gliding through the sea at 25.8 knots speed, the day's run being 625 miles. She is due at New York Friday, reaching Ambrose Light at 10 A.M. and docking at 2 P.M. She is now in the Gulf Stream and the weather is warm and showery.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Dr. Jacob Chaiken of 3,035 North Franklin Street, Philadelphia, and Horace Friedenwald of Oak Lane, Pa., were killed tonight in an auto collision twelve miles west of Manahawkin, N.J., on the State highway. Two other physicians who were in the car with Dr. Chaiken were critically injured, and another man was injured, less seriously.

After reading a discussion of the elevator problem of the tower skyscraper by CARL E. SCOTT, one lays down The Engineering News-Record convinced that the crotchety human race is a source of greater annoyance to one who would pile story on story than are motors, automatic controls, electric leveling devices and winches.
ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- Friends of Governor Roosevelt expressed the hope today that former Governor Smith would soon take an active part in the campaign in support of the Democratic national ticket.

MANAGUA, Oct. 5. -- Admiral C.H. Woodward, chairman of the United States electoral mission, announced today that complete returns from the departments of Carazo, Esteli, Jinotega, Granada, Jerez-Chontales, Nueva Segovia, Managua, Matagalpa and Masaya show a registration equal to or greater than that of 1928.

Dean Franklin DeR. Furman of Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N.J., announced yesterday that thirty-seven students of the three upper classes had been placed on the Dean's List, an honor which carries exemptions from penalties for deviations from prescribed academic routine, especially with respect to unexplained absence from classes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Returning today from a meeting of the petroleum division of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at Ponca City, Okla., Northcutt Ely, executive assistant to Secretary Wilbur, reported that the production of oil and gas could be regulated through interstate cooperation "if there is a will toward solution."

Senator HOFSTADTER, happy in two nominations for Supreme Court justice, keeps silent while the heathen rage. Tammany has paid him a gracious compliment. He has the honor of a bipartisan nomination, sometimes denied to competent and upright sitting judges.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 5. -- Twenty Grand, making the second start of a come-back after being king of the 3-year-olds last season, was defeated by the lightly regarded Cornelius V. Whitney's Mad Frump in the featured Annapolis Handicap of a mile and a sixteenth today at Laurel.

Apparently the pressure of sales, under which the stock market yielded yesterday, was of professional origin. It may have had its basis in the fact that, after the market's substantial advance of a fortnight ago, movement of prices had subsided into trivial daily variations, with greatly reduced transactions.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Army opened its soccer season today with a 4-0 victory over Bucknell.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 5. -- J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., started his title defense In the Hot Springs Fall tennis tournament by defeating Richard Stevens of New York, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, today. Hall's steady game from the tack court dominated the match.

The unfavorable weather forced a week's postponement of the boxing carnival scheduled for last night at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, in the interest of the Seventh and Eighth Masonic District Camps. The contests will be held next Wednesday night, it was announced by Promoter Humbert J. Fugazy.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Eamon de Valera left London for Dublin tonight after his scheduled conversation with members of the British Government, which had turned out well enough to result in a definite arrangement to begin negotiations between Great Britain and the Irish Free State over the land annuities dispute on Oct. 14.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Further conferences between officials of the Port of New York Authority and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation relative to the financing of a $90,000,000 tunnel under the North River from Thirty-eighth Street, New York City, to Weehawken, N.J., were held today at the offices of the corporation.

TOKYO, Oct. 5. -- The Japanese Army's first intention to preserve dignified silence regarding the Lytton report on Manchuria has been succeeded by undisguised irritation as closer study reveals stings lurking under the commission's judicial words.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am grieved to learn from THE TIMES that the New York Presbytery, not only through its decision to conduct a separate relief drive but by implicit declaration, has seen fit to put the odium of religious bias upon the truly humanitarian efforts of Harvey D. Gibson and the steering committee of the emergency unemployment relief committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Officers of the Home Loan Banks, meeting here today with the Home Loan Board to perfect the organization of the system, received pledges of cooperation from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Conference of Business and Industrial Committees.

John F. Curry, his prestige as Tammany leader impaired, returned from Albany yesterday to face another obstacle, the virtual certainty that Mayor McKee and the Bronx organization would contest in the courts the validity of any nomination for Mayor which the city convention scheduled for tonight may make.

The Federal Government, which received a setback in its campaign to dry up the city when the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last July that the proprietor of a speakeasy and not an employe must receive the summons and complaint in any valid padlock action, was defeated again yesterday in another court battle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Protective measures to minimize hazards in traffic, ranging from blind flying to automobile accidents, were discussed today during the third day's sessions of the Annual Safety Congress of the National Safety Council.

DUBLIN, Oct. 5. -- The first reaction here to the news that negotiations over the land annuities are about to be resumed was one of relief, for the economic situation throughout the Free State has become rapidly worse and the farmers are at their wits' ends to meet their ordinary obligations.

The review of the financial crisis by Secretary MILLS, in his address to the American Bankers' convention, is an economic study of more than ordinary clearness. Its analysis of the causes for the great reaction, of its successive phases, and of the manner in which its most dangerous possibilities were surmounted, is so far convincing as to make his speech a useful contribution to the history of the period.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The sinking of the freighter John J. Boland Jr. in Lake Erie today marks another cross on the rolls of Great Lakes shipping.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Two Princeton varsity football teams held long defensive drills on University Field today, spending more than an hour in dummy scrimmage against Columbia plays.

PEIPING, Oct. 5. -- Today is the second anniversary of the capture by bandits of the Rev. Bert Nelson, an American Lutheran missionary, who is still detained at a bandit camp eighty miles from Hankow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Chicago's $3,000,000 International House, on the Midway at the University of Chicago, was presented, tonight to the city by John D. Rockefeller 3d on behalf of his father, the donor. Charles S. Dewey accepted it on behalf of the university board of governors and Dr. Raymond S. Fosdick, chairman of the Rockefeller Foundation's committee on the extension of International Houses, expressed the spirit in which the building was dedicated.
LEICESTER, England, Oct. 5. -- The Labor party conference startled its managers today by adopting a resolution on policy in the face of opposition by Arthur Henderson and the National Executive.

Party leaders, delegates and alternates, returning yesterday from the Republican and Democratic State Conventions, praised their party tickets and predicted victory for their respective national and State candidates at the general election next month.

New Orders Stress Light Hues. While black and brown are still highly important, dress orders placed during the last few days show a marked trend to the brighter hues. This was said yesterday to be particularly the case in dresses for the football season, including knitted and woolen styles.
Two one-man shows are on for a fortnight at the Delphic Studios -- paintings by Hamilton Wolf and silhouettes by Sigmund Gorny.

Declines continued in the bond market yesterday, with activity increasing over the previous day's trading. The volume or transactions was $9,345,500, against $8,784,000 On Tuesday. United States Government bonds were erratic in a substantial turnover.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Harold L. Stuart, president of Halsey, Stuart Co., investment banking concern, surrendered at the Federal Building today and a warrant charging use of the mails to defraud was served upon him.
TOPEKA, Oct. 5. -- Not only the whole country, I believe, but farmers of the West particularly, were impressed by President Hoover's powerful speech at Des Moines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Awards to members of last season's varsity baseball team and varsity, freshman and combination class crews were approved at the first Fall meeting of Harvard's athletic committee, it was announced today.

One new and important point is in the statement of farm policy made by the President at Des Moines. He favors complete repeal of the "stabilization" provisions of the agricultural marketing act, under which the unfortunate Farm Board has carried on a gigantic speculation in wheat and cotton.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Testimony that Arthur Maillefert, New Jersey youth who fell afoul of the law in Florida, strangled to death in a prison sweat box and had no food for twelve hours hefore death, was given today by Dr. R.R. Killinger at the trial of two former guards charged with murdering the youth by torture.

The rate of decline in net operating income of the Class I railroads from the levels of last year diminished substantially in August, according to a report by the Bureau of Railway Economics. This showed that the net operating income of 167 Class I lines, representing 242,163 miles, was $28,368,000 in August, against $56,444,000 in August, 1931, a decline of 49.7 per cent.

Ambrose Lightship is separated by 3,200 nautical miles from Gibraltar and by 3,225 from Cherbourg. It will be nip and tuck between the Rex and her unfinished sister ship, the Conte di Savoia, on the southern course, and the Bremen and the Europa on the northern, with the advantage on the Italian side in weather and distance.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- News of the drop in the price of wheat and weakness in Wall Street yesterday resulted in sharp declines on the Paris Bourse today. Irregularity in metal prices also affected the stock market and important international stocks, which were the greatest gainers in the recent recovery, were heavy losers.

HAVANA, Oct. 6. -- The Cuban State Department was informed today by the Spanish Ambassador that Gabrial Garcia Menocal and Mario Miguel Menocal, relatives of former President Menocal, had sought protection in the embassy. The embassy is authorized by treaty to receive political refugees.

Protests against the advocacy by Governor James R. Beverley of Puerto Rico of birth control as a solution to the overpopulation problem in that island have been filed with President Hoover and Secretary of War Hurley by the executive committee of the National Catholic Alumni Federation, it was disclosed yesterday.

Although Lieut. Gov. Lehman was nominated at Albany only forty-eight hours before, some of his campaign posters -- a rush order -- decorated the tables on the platform at the Democratic convention in the Garden last night. They had his photograph and the legend: "For Governor, Herbert H. Lehman. Keep progressive government."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6. -- Malcoim Farmer, who has just become chairman of athletics under the reorganization plan which went into effect this Fall in Yale athletics, will say in the Yale Alumni Weekly tomorrow that no effort will be made to force changes in Yale athletics, and that alterations from present conditions will be made only when they are found practicable.

Former Mayor James J. Walker requested that his name be withheld from the city Democratic convention in a radio message handed to John F. Curry, Tammany leader, in Madison Square Garden at 8:30 o'clock last night. He did so, he explained in the message, "rather than jeopardize the hopes of Democracy in the nation, which I feel my candidacy might do."

Thursday, Oct. 6, 1932. Money market was quiet. The small amount of business involved brought no change in quotations in any section. Stock Exchange day loans, maturity money and business funds were all steady.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Ivan Belaieff, former Russian General, was made an honorary General today in the Paraguayan Army in recognition of his services on the Gran Chaco battlefront against Bolivian troops.

The Federal Government, which planned last Wednesday to notify all landlords of violation of the dry law when it existed on their premises, was divided yesterday on the advisability of carrying out that scheme as an answer to recent decisions of Federal courts which are admittedly embarrassing to enforcers of the law.

Satire Stumbles on Truth. The League of Nations is fated to live and prosper. This can no longer be doubted after what occurred at Geneva on Wednesday. The occasion was the annual luncheon for the high officials of the Assembly and the Council given by the newspaper men accredited to the League.

Arturo Toscanini, apparently physically reborn, as if neuritic nerves and muscles of his tortured arm of last season had never existed, stepped on the stage last night in Carnegie Hall, with the familiar direct and imperious bearing, and without ado opened the 1932-1933 season, of the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 6. -- Seeded players in the men's and women's singles of the Hot Springs Fall tennis tournament advanced to the semi-final round at the Casino courts today with only one of them, Cedric A. Major of New York, being pressed to win.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Dr. John F. Vichert, Professor of Practical Theology at the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School, who after his nomination for Governor by the Dry Law Preservation party at Syracuse Monday said he would not accept the nomination, today changed his mind and announced that he would run.

Columbia reached the peak of its training yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its contest with Princeton tomorrow. While the Blue and White went through its paces, Columbia officials announced that a capacity crowd of 40,000 would witness the contest, practically all of the tickets having been sold.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Oct. 6. -- The intensified Republican campaign which opened at Des Moines Tuesday night with a "fighting speech" by President Hoover, was resumed here tonight by Secretary Hurley.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Trade relations between the United States and Canada over a period of sixty years have been favorable to Canada and that Dominion is in a relatively good position as compared to the United States and Great Britain, according to a report by James A. Farrell, former president of the United States Steel Corporation, to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, released today.

Edward K. Mills, president of the Morristown Trust Company of Morristown, N.J., and Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, have been recommended for nomination as Class A and B directors, respectively, of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- A heavy oversubscription to the Treasury's offering of $450,000,000 in 3 per cent 4 1/2 year notes was indicated when Acting Secretary Ballantine closed the books at the end of government business today.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Into New York's parched streams and rivers tonight poured a flood of water which swept one man to his death, tore a bridge from its foundations, blocked highways and lay five feet deep in the Delaware County village of Margaretville.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Oct. 6. -- About 1,000 Republican women from all parts of the State gathered at the Women's Club here this afternoon to attend a rally and reception for Mrs. Dolly Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis. Mrs. Gann, after being introduced by Mrs. Elizabeth Harris, a Freeholder of this place, extended the personal greetings of President Hoover and Vice President Curtis to the women of Essex County.

Federal Judge John B. Sanborn of the United States District Court in Minnesota has ordered that all persons interested in the receivership of the Public Utilities Consolidated Corporation to show cause on Oct. 19 why he should not enter an order instructing the receiver to proceed to consummate his plan for reorganization of the company or such other plan as may be determined upon.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Lord Lloyd, former administrator in India and Egypt, warned the Constructive conference at Blackpool today that the attempt to force self-government on the illiterate Indian electorate would not be conducive to the welfare of India or Great Britain.
Numerous housing properties, comprising mostly small flats and one-family dwellings, were included in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.
Davenport, Iowa, Oct. 6. -- Following are excerpts from the speech delivered here this evening by Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War:

BOONVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The New York milk-shed strike at Boonville, Adams Center and Pierrepont Manor ended today in what the farmers declared was a complete victory. The embargo which started Monday was directed by 600 producers of the United Milk Products Corporation against the Eisenberg Farms, Inc., of Brooklyn, which the farmers charged, was demoralizing the market by price-cutting.

Although the task confronting the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee is more difficult this year than last year, New York will do a good job of unemployment relief, according to Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the committee, who told a meeting of chairmen and vice chairmen of business groups yesterday that the funds to be raised voluntarily, coupled with city and State appropriations, would be adequate to handle the situation.

Copyright 1932 by The Chicago Tribune. PARIS, Oct. 6. -- Definite assurance chat Samuel Insull and his son have left Paris and that they were not expected to return was given tonight by the management of the hotel where they had been living.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Criticizing the neglect of New Jersey municipalities in failing to sell properties for unpaid taxes promptly in good times, Walter R. Darby, State Commissioner of Municipal Accounts, told the tax collectors' division of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities here today that "no municipality ever got anywhere by Temporizing with financial matters. Face the facts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Mrs. Raymond Robins arrived in Washington late today to be an overnight guest of President and Mrs. Hoover at the White House. Other than for a visit with two personal friends, the purpose of Mrs. Robins's trip to Washington was to inform the President of developments in the search for her husband, who has been missing for more than a month.

Replying to Robert Goelet, financier, who announced his resignation on Wednesday from the Knickerbocker Club Post of the American Legion in protest against the Legion's demand for prepayment of the bonus, John Dwight Sullivan, county commander, said yesterday that he believed Mr. Goelet's stand could be served more effectively if he stayed within the Legion's ranks.

The Treasury Department has announced that its October financing will include an offer of $450,000,000 in 4 1/2-year notes, bearing interest at 3 per cent. This issue will increase the total interest-bearing debt to about $20,800,000,000, compared with $15,922,000,000 on June 30, 1930, when the Federal Government last succeeded in balancing its budget.

For the first time since May, the daily output of steel ingots in the United States was increased in September, according to the monthly statistics issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The average was 37,502 tons, against 30,830 in August, and 31,701 in July.

ON BOARD STEAMSHIP REX, Oct. 6. -- The Italian liner Rex, one of the fastest, largest and finest of liners afloat, arrives in New York tomorrow afternoon with 1,284 passengers after averaging 25 1/4 knots from Gibraltar.

ON BOARD STEAMSHIP EUROPA, Oct. 16. -- James J. Walter does not regard his statement refusing the Democratic nomination for Mayor as his political swan song. Discussing his withdrawal and his future plans tonight he pointed to the phrase "for time being" in the statement he radioed to John F. Curry and smiled at mention of 1933.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Fellow-convicts in black and white stripes told a jury today of threats by two former guards against young Arthur Maillefert, who was strangled to death in a prison sweatbox last June, and of the guards' callous disregard of warnings that he would never come out of the box alive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6.-- Despite the great damage done by the recent hurricane the economic outlook for Puerto Rico in the coming months is not as dark as it was after the destructive tornado of 1928, C.F. Knox of the regional division of the Department of Commerce, asserted today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Running over a muddy track, S.S. Combs's Plumage, cleverly rated by Jockey Monte Parke, apprentice rider, triumphed in the Hyde Park Purse, the feature event at Lincoln Fields today. Struggling four lengths back of the victor came Very Well.

GENEVA, Oct. 6. -- With the leading delegates scattered to their home capitals, equality of arms temporarily gave way to equality of sexes as a burning topic in the League of Nations Assembly's commissions today. It led to a fight in the First Commission over the nationality of married women.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6. -- Harvard's football army today took a hand in everything that goes with the gridiron game except hard scrimmaging.

In the belief that economic recovery is slowly getting under way, the Tri-Continental Corporation and Selected Industries, Inc., investment trusts sponsored by J. W. Seligman Co., acquired substantial additional investments in bonds and common stocks since the early part of July, according to their reports for the third quarter of the year, which were issued yesterday by Earl Bailie, chairman of the boards of both trusts.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 6. -- In the midst of a torrential downpour, after two-thirds of the program had been completed, the management of the annual Danbury Fair Horse Show called a halt this afternoon, postponing the remaining classes until 8:45 o'clock tomorrow morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The announcement of the personnel of the staff which will make a survey of the New Jersey State Government under the supervision of the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University was made today by Professor Harold W. Dodds, director of the investigation.

Emory R. Buckner, former United States Attorney, has leased from Aymar Embury 2d, architect, the furnished house at 230 East Sixty-second Street on a lot 20 by 78 feet. The lease carries a purchase option and was negotiated by Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc.

MONTREAL, Oct. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Charles A. Schneider, Assistant Attorney General for New York State, was on the stand today as the action of the State to recover $3,405,449 from the heirs of the late John F. Phillips, Queens Borough sewer contractor, was resumed in Superior Court before Justice Mercier.

Those who remember Mr. WILLIAM V. MOODY's "Ode in Time of Hesitation" may think his spirit, if not his actual facts and inferences, fitted to the dubious Mayoralty situation in New York. The decision of the Court of Appeals is explained as in strict accord with the precedent of a previous case before the same tribunal.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 6. -- The speech from the throne, read today at the opening of the Canadian Parliament, called upon that body to ratify the St. Lawrence waterway treaty after the United States Senate has so acted.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6, -- The Federal Government's moderation after its victory over the Sao Paulo rebels created a good impression among the Paulistans, who asserted the regime's reconstruction moves will not be hampered by them.

The Central Trades and Labor Council, representing 750,000 workers of the various labor unions of New York and vicinity, at a regular meeting last night at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, adopted a resolution endorsing the candidacy of Governor Roosevelt for President, and of John N. Garner for Vice President, and urging the support of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor.

A. Polhemus Cobb, one of the leaders of the zinc industry in the United States, senior vice president of the New Jersey Zinc Company and a former president of the American Zinc Institute, died yesterday morning at his home in Tarrytown, N.Y., after a long illness, at the age of 68.

PARIS, Oct. 6.-Safety and economy seem to have been the chief considerations of the automobile manufacturers who are exhibiting their latest models at the twenty-sixth annual Paris motor show which opened in the Grand Palais today. Comfort and elegance of appearance of course have not been neglected by the designers, but there is a marked tendency toward the production of cheaper and smaller cars and lower running costs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Drenching rains of the last few days over the Middle Atlantic States were said today by Weather Bureau observers to have ended a drought almost comparable to that in 1930.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The four-power conference that Prime Minister MacDonald wanted held in London next Tuesday to consider the disarmament deadlock between Germany and France has been "postponed," it was admitted tonight at the British Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Victory in the complicated, three-corner Senatorial race in California was predicted here today for Tallant Tubbs, the Republican nominee, by Richard M. Tobin, former Minister to the Netherlands and now campaign manager for Mr. Tubbs.

The Democratic City Convention opened listlessly and apathetically at Madison Square Garden last night at 7:50 o'clock, nearly an hour later than the scheduled time. The members of the county committees had been called to name a candidate for Mayor to succeed James J. Walker, who resigned Sept. 1 while charges were pending against him before Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In looking over a number of newspaper clippings today I ran across an editorial from THE TIMES entitled "Hoover and the Democrats," printed in the issue of June 17. It was one of the finest pieces of newspaper literature I have ever read, because of its style, vision, grasp of details and sense of fairness.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6. -- Predicting that the worst of the depression was over, Frank H. Sisson of New York, new president of the American Bankers' Association, told the closing session of the convention today that gradual recovery should follow.

Passengers on the Cunarder Aquilania, arriving today, include Admiral Earl Beatty, First Sea Lord of the British Navy from 1919 to 1927, who is accompanied by his son, Peter Beatty; Lord Reading, with his wife, the Marchioness of Reading, and Mrs. Patricia Kendall, author of "Come With Me to India," based on her life among the Hindus.

LA PAZ, Bolivia. Oct. 6. -- Paraguayan troops made a four-hour attack on Fort Rojas Silva (Falcon) yesterday but were beaten off by the Bolivian garrison, according to a general staff communique today. The Paraguayans are declared to have sustained numerous casualties, but the Bolivians had only two soldiers wounded.

The late William H. Baker, president of the Merritt-Chapman-Scott Corporation, one of the largest marine salvage and wrecking companies in the world, was accused in the Supreme Court yesterday of having obtained more than $700,000 life insurance for the benefit of his company by giving false answers on his applications as to previous medical treatment.

Deploring the "scandalous" conditions in the official administration of the city in recent years, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, at its monthly meeting yesterday, acclaimed unanimously a demand by one of its members that only candidates with proved ability and character be selected to run for public office.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The nomination of Surrogate John P. O'Brien by the county committees of the five boroughs at Madison Square Garden last night, coupled with the pledges of support to the national and State tickets by the Tammany-controlled meeting, did much, in the opinion of those present to end internal strife within the city's Democratic organizations.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6. -- John Ripley Freeman, noted engineer, died tonight at his home, 42 Freeman Parkway, after an illness of two days. His age was 77. He was born in West Bridgetoh, Me.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The stock markets were generally inactive at the opening today following Wall Street's weakness yesterday, with a little selling and a slightly better tendency in the afternoon. British funds failed to rally, but home industrials held up well under disturbing influences.

The American playwright must free himself from the present tyranny of colloquial speech if he is to recoveer "the masculine vigor of dramatic poetry," Lee Simonson, one of the founders and directors of the Theatre Guild, writes in "The Stage Is Set," which, will be published today by Harcourt, Brace.

Efforts to perfect the defense of the New York University football team against Rutgers plays were continued in yesterday's two-hour drill at Ohio Field, held in a driving rain. At the conclusion of the workout, Head Coach Howard G. Cann announced that the squad was ready for its engagement with Rutgers tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Back at his desk at the White House with many messages of congratulations on his Des Moines speech before him, President Hoover today began consideration of other campaign plans which probably will take him again to the West within a fortnight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6. -- Secretary of the Navy Charles Francis Adams has presented a cup to be competed for annually by the varsity crews of Harvard, United States Naval Academy and the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced today by the Harvard Athletic Association.

Southwest winds, which have been prevalent along the coast from Montauk Point to Cape May the last few weeks, have brought in the bluefish so abundantly that old-timers declare they never have seen better fishing at this time of year. Reports yesterday from Long Island indicated that, despite rain and gloomy weather conditions, bluefishing over the week-end would be unusually good.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Stanley A. Hall, 76 years old, a retired telephone company executive, who was one of the pioneers in the telephone business in Redfield, S.D., died last night at the home of his son-in-law, Ernest Hesse, an official of the World Book Company.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, at a meeting held last night in its headquarters, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, condemned State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and Judge Aron Steuer, bipartisan nominees for justices of the Supreme Court, as "unfit to hold judicial office" and called for a public investigation of their nominations by "an appropriate tribunal."

A last tribute to the magic name of Walker echoed in shrill whistling and hoarse cheers in Madison Square Garden last night as a perfectly oiled Tammany machine paused for a few brief minutes in its steady course toward setting up a new idol for the people of New York.
Purchase of Connecticut properties by two bank executives in this city was reported yesterday by the E.H. Delafield Company, broker in the deals.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. J. Bentley Squier returned yesterday on the Paris of the French Line. They had been on holiday in Europe.

Eleven contemporary American painters are represented, each by one picture, in the current exhibition at the galleries of Pascal M. Gatterdams Chauncey Ryder's "Little Round Top" is perhaps the dominating piece of the group -- a massive blue silhouette peak, with the green and gray of the foreground contributing to the brooding spirit of the piece.

ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- Declaring that the country had no need now of "some new temporary expedient" offered a month before the election to turn the minds of farmers away from "the grim fact of a consistently unfriendly attitude" of the Republican administration, Franklin D. Roosevelt today made reply to President Hoover's Des Moines speech.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Prepared to carry on as a national organization with a unit in every community, the Bonus Expeditionary Force was ready to disband tonight with an eye to Washington, where a committee will present the "demands" written by the first general convention.

The season for entertainments to augment the funds of philanthropic organizations throughout the city opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria with an elaborate fashion show, an all-day event, in aid of the charitable enterprises of the Social Service Auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital.

There has been overemphasis on supernationalism, Cardinal Hayes asserted in a letter he issued yesterday to the 452 pastors of the Archdiocese of New York, which is his annual appeal for "Peter's pence." The letter will be read in all the churches at every mass next Sunday and the offering will be received Sunday, Oct. 16.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That political leaders should differ in their economic views as to what is best for the country is proper, but the least the business public should expect is that members of the Cabinet would know their tariff history.
LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, to pounds sterling:

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Asserting that "Muscle Shoals is the testing stone of candidates," Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy, today said in an address that President Hoover has stood for "locking up such resources or turning them over to the power monopoly for option, which would pour millions into their coffers through excessive rates."

Governor ROOSEVELT is understood to have assured his political friends that he has been only waiting a fit occasion to make known his positive opposition to immediate payment of the soldier's bonus. He must be aware of the political capital which Republicans are seeking to make out of his silence on this subject.

Mayor McKee said last night that he never had any intention of testing the legality of the Democratic City Convention that named a candidate for the Mayoralty election this Fall at Madison Square Garden last night.

Assurances that Maine would go Democratic in November by an even greater majority than it did in September were brought to Roosevelt campaign headquarters in the Biltmore yesterday by Democratic leaders of that State.

With former Mayor James J. Walker withdrawing himself from consideration on the ground of poor health and a desire not to jeopardize Democratic success in the nation, the Democratic City Convention in an unprecedented gathering of the members of five county committees at Madison Square Garden nominated last night Surrogate John P. O'Brien, close personal friend of John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, for Mayor.

Benny Leonard, who, after a lapse of seven years, returned to ring war-fare thirteen months ago, takes the boldest step in his come-back campaign tonight, when he opposes Jimmy McLarnin, the baby-faced welterweight from Vancouver, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

John P. O'Brien has held the office of Surrogate of New York County, to which he was elected as the Tammany choice, since Jan. 1, 1923, but it was as Corporation Counsel of New York City that he won most public note as the spokesman of Mayor John F. Hylan in his many battles with transit and other public service corporations.

Having an extraordinary understanding of women and a cheerful disposition, Rachel Crothers has written another jovial comedy in "When Ladies Meet," which was acted at the Royale last evening. The women who meet are the wife and the honest-minded young lady who contemplates superseding her in the husband's affection.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The indifference of the general public and of the private driver to motor hazards threatens to result in an annual toll of 50,000 traffic deaths within the next few years, the National Safety Council was told today by Sidney J. Williams, director of the Public Safety Division.

Although the average football coach resents the imputation that the style of football he teaches is a copy of any other and insists at least that he has worked out his own modifications of the standard brands, there is no gainsaying that the trend of the attack is set pretty much at Palo Alto and South Bend.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The Shipping Board today approved a modification of transpacific Passenger Conference agreement 131-17, so as to restrict the granting of free roundtrip ticket and 5 per cent commission to organizers accompanying a party of fifteen or more adult roundtrip passengers to such parties traveling first, cabin, special or tourist class.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- The whereabouts of Samuel Insull and his son were a complete mystery at a late hour tonight. It is now two days since the Chicagoan, whose presence is desired in the United States to answer indictments, disappeared with his son.
OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Reaffirming his "great faith in this wonderful country," Vice President Charles Curtis tonight asserted the worst of the depression "has come and gone."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 5, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,242,000,000, a decrease of $9,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $485,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

DUBLIN, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Three officials were selected tonight to accompany President Eamon de Valera when the goes to London Oct. 14 to attempt to negotiate a settlement of the land annuities dispute between the British Government and the Irish Free State.

Describing the receiverships created by Judge Martin T. Manton of the Circuit Court of Appeals as "just so many pieces of paper," Charles Franklin, attorney for Benjamin F. Johnson, a stockholder, charged, yesterday that collusion had played a part in applications for these orders in behalf of the I.R.T. and the Manhattan Railway Company.

Since the Federal excise taxes on motor vehicles went into effect three months ago, the public has purchased a higher proportion of used cars and fewer new ones, Alvan Macauley, president of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, told members of the organization at a meeting yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- Lord Tyrrell, British Ambassador, informed Premier Herriot this afternoon that the date for the convocation of the proposed meeting to discuss Germany's claim to arms equality would be postponed from the day originally suggested. At the same time a communique from the Foreign Office added that "the conversations on this subject continue between Paris and London in a most friendly spirit."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today endorsed the banking and industrial "share-the-work" movement sponsored under the chairmanship of Walter C. Teagle, and urged labor to cooperate with employers in a joint effort to find work for millions of unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The United States has not yet decided whether it will be represented at Geneva when the Council of the League of Nations takes up the Lytton report on Manchuria on Nov. 14, but a statement issued at London today by the Earl of Lytton, chairman of the Manchurian investigating commission, cited pronouncements by Secretary Stimson that appear to bind the United States to join in that consultation.

A heavy rain forced the Fordham University football team, in preparation for its game with Bucknell at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, indoors during a greater part of yesterday's practice under Major Frank V. Cavanaugh, coach. After the rain had subsided somewhat the Rams went through a thirty-minute drill on Fordham Field.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 6. -- Entries of the Giralda Farm of Madison, N.J., owned by Mrs. Geraldine R. Dodge, captured blue ribbons in two classes as the Danbury Fair's forty-ninth annual dog show opened today, scoring in the pointer and beagle breeds.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Amos Alonzo Stagg will lead his squad of thirty-one Chicago football players into New Haven late tomorrow and on to the field of his earliest fame.

Plans for international large yacht racing on a scale never before attempted were set in motion yesterday with an announcement of conditions governing the cup offered last Winter by the North American Yacht Racing Union, ruling body of yachting in this country and Canada.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Three guards and two inmates of the Michigan State prison at Jackson, together with a sister of one inmate and a woman friend of another, were detained here tonight while police and prison officials questioned them concerning a purported prison escape plot in which dynamite was to be used.
LEICESTER, England, Oct. 6. -- The Labor party conference adopted resolutions today calling for the nationalization of farm land and national planning in agriculture.

JAMESTOWN, N.D., Oct. 6. -- As monotonously the same as this Dakota prairie country, has been the political equation as stated to me by experts in eight States thus far visited in a survey of the Presidential campaign. The views of the experts have stood up under inquiry, and they are buttressed by the straw votes which almost invariably show a majority for Franklin D. Roosevelt over Herbert Hoover.

The coordination of all forms of advertising, rather than emphasis on one alone, brings the best results, Ralph Leavenworth, advertising manager of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said yesterday at the second day's sessions of the annual conference and advertising business show of the Direct Mail Advertising Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Operatives of a special Senate elections subcommittee started out today on an independent investigation into charges of fraud and corruption in the Democratic primary in which John H. Overtoil defeated the veteran Senator Edwin S. Broussard.

Considering the number of speculative "long" commitments that were closed out on Wednesday, Wall Street was not surprised to see the share market resume yesterday its slow, measured tread. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was about 1,000,000 shares less than that which figured in the convulsive decline of the day before.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Lieut. Gov. Fred E. Sterling, acting as Chief Executive of Illinois in the absence of Governor Emmerson from Springfield, telegraphed Secretary Stimson today a request for the extradition of Samuel Insull from France and of his brother, Martin J. Insull, from Canada to stand trial in Chicago on the larceny and embezzlement indictments returned by the Cook County grand jury in the $2,000,000,000 failure of the Insull utilities system.

Richard S. Russell, vice chairman of the New England division of the National Economy League, organized recently to oppose waste in government, replied yesterday to attacks made by Brig. Gen. Milton A. Record, adjutant general of Maryland and commander of the American Legion in that State, upon Generals Pershing and Harbord, Admiral Sims and Rear Admiral Byrd following a mass meeting held by the league in Baltimore Monday.

Certainly there is no visible token of the depression at the Milch Galleries just now, where a new group exhibition of paintings by contemporary American artists has just opened. The walls are gay with color, keyed rather high, upon the whole, though never to a pitch of shrillness.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6. -- In militant fashion Secretary Mills pleaded the cause of President Hoover and his administration before a large audience in Dreamland Auditorium here tonight.

New tenants were reported taking apartments in east side houses in large numbers yesterday. Brokers and renting agents announced lists of rentals indicating an encouraging outlook in this branch of the real estate business.

Due largely to heavy monthly and quarterly settlements, together with the recent improvement evidenced in various lines of trade and industry, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday at twenty-two cities of the country were $1,000,000,000 larger than those of the preceding week, according to R.G. Dun Co.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- The note-conversion plan of the Central West Public Service has been declared operative. Checks for interest due on Aug. 1 on the notes were mailed tonight. Holders of the company's $1,416,500 of 6 per cent debentures were notified that they may present their coupons for interest due on May 1 for payment.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien sat smiling last night through the convention which nominated him for Mayor of New York City, and when the formalities were over he made his first public utterance, an appeal to the Democrats of the city to support Governor Roosevelt, Lieut. Gov. Lehman, Senator Wagner and every other member of the Democratic ticket in the forthcoming election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for financing self-liquidating projects were brought to a total of $59,594,620 today with the passage of resolutions approving advances of $5,784,000 to the Middle Rio Grande Flood-Control District, $645,620 to the city of Ogden, Utah, and $50,000 to Prescott, Ariz.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 6. -- George Washington was praised as a truly national hero and his life and reputation defended against debunkers by Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox of Columbia University, president of the New York State Historical Association, in his speech, here tonight at the association's annual meeting in Parrish Memorial Art Museum.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6. -- Yale will face Chicago Saturday with less than half the scrimmage practice originally ordered for the eleven which was unable to score against Bates. Because of this light program the Yale eleven will be in much better physical condition than when it tackled the Bobcats.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Charles H. Knapp, president of the Baltimore Orioles of the International League, announced today the release of Fritz Maisel as manager. Maisel's successor was not announced.

Two church organizations which were to have received more than $50,000 under the will of the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norris, rector emeritus of St. Matthews Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn, will receive nothing from his estate as the result of a decision by Surrogate Wingate in Brooklyn yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- The police authorities today established the falsity of numerous documents included in the evidence against Paul-Louis Weiller, director of the Gnome and Rhone Company, and Emanuel Chaumie of the French Air Ministry, accused of having conspired to cede stock in the French Aeropostale Company to the International Aerial Navigation Company and the German Lufthansa.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- J.B. Gheusi, former co-director of the Opera and previously for a time director of the Opera Comique, today was appointed as new director of the latter institution, succeeding Louis Masson who has resigned.

The value of all listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange decreased $1,047,673,138 in September, or from $27,782,501,806 on Sept. 1 to $26,734,828,668 on Oct. 1, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The decline was the first reported for a month since June.
PARIS, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
Prohibition against the use of the flying tackle and the flying block was adopted for the protection of the tackler and bocker rather than of the opponents whom they were trying to bring down.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 6. -- Of the present and past champions competing in the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship at the Old Westbury Golf Club this year not one has tasted defeat, all three coming through the first and second rounds today.

Miles Bath, who had covered Bellevue Hospital for the City News Association for the last twenty-five years and had been a district reporter in the city since 1897, died last night in the Post-Graduate Hospital after an operation performed there on Sept. 23.

The Veterans Committee for Reducing the Cost of Peace, which was organised by prominent World War veterans to oppose the movement for immediate payment of the bonus, announced yesterday that it had merged with the National Economy League, which is actively campaigning with the same object.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hindenburg's eighty-fifth birthday, along with current events, reminds one how the editorial mind goes astray.
