About eight years ago our chief editors, following the lead of George Harvey, lamented the election of Hindenburg, called him weak and flabby, without any mind or political knowledge of his own, just a mere tool and screen for capable politicians and statesmen.

JOHN CHARGES LINTHICUM, who was serving his eleventh term in Congress as Representative of the Fourth Maryland District, is probably vaguely remembered, if at all, by persons outside of his State only on account of his long activity against prohibition.

After a day spent in conference with his executive committee and prominent individuals favoring the candidacy of Mayor McKee on an independent ticket, Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, leader of the Bronx Democratic organization, went to the city convention last night determined to support John F. Curry, John H. McCooey and the other county leaders in their plan to name Surrogate John P. O'Brien as candidate for Mayor.

BURLINGTON, Wis., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Five men early this morning invaded the new $25,000 milk receiving plant of the Burlington Cooperative Milk Association, Kidnapped a watchman and destroyed the building by exploding two bombs. The watchman was not hurt.

The second defeat for the four-time stake winner Disdainful was suffered in the mud and rain at Jamaica yesterday when Cornelius V. Whitney's daughter of John P. Grier and Pandera finished far behind the Wheatley Stable's Iseult in the Hiawatha Handicap.

NEW BUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Taking no chances on possible injuries, Coach J. Wilder Tasker kept his Rutgers football players indoors today and drilled them for almost two hours in the new gymnasium. Considerable time was devoted to perfecting a defense against New York University formations, with the freshmen in possession of the ball.
ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that there must be a Mayoralty election in New York City Nov. 8 to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Mayor James J. Walker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The Shipping Board tonight announced it had granted a permit to the Seatrain Lines, Inc., to operate vessels between New York, Havana and New Orleans for six months beginning today.
LAREDO, Texas, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Archbishop Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores, Papal Delegate expelled from Mexico, expressed confidence here today that the Mexican people would judge his actions impartially.
ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's radio address today to luncheon meetings of the Roosevelt Business and Professional Men's League follows:

ALBANY, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The possible creation of a "regional markets authority" for New York State, to be financed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was the subject of a conference today between Governor Roosevelt, Mark Graves, director of the State budget, and agricultural leaders.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Opening his campaign tour of the State here today, Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, told party workers that economy la the Albany government was essential, and that he would continue to stress it as his policy.

PRINCETON, N.J. Oct. 6. -- The Princeton varsity eleven flashed a powerful attack during a thirty-minute offensive scrimmage on University Field today, scoring five times against a reserve team in the last hard practice before the Columbia game.

A one-man show by Isabel Bishop occupies the place of honor at the Midtown Galleries, which exhibits as well more than fifty oils by about thirty of the younger American painters. Some twenty of Miss Bishop's canvases are on view, including portraits, still-life and street scenes.

Despite reports of unfavorable weather for the cotton crop, buying yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here was restricted by the approach of the government's estimate of the yield, and early advances of 13 to 17 points were followed By reactions. Declines in grains and securities helped to hold the buying in check, while a little Southern selling was supplemented by realizing or liquidation at the middle of the day.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 6. -- Armed with machetes, led by a Maca Indian guide and attacking only at night, a mounted battalion of Paraguayan volunteers, calling themselves the "Death Macheteers," is spreading terror among the Bolivians garrisoning the line forts along the Pilcomayo River in the disputed Chaco region.

Both, of the State platforms are short. The voter who looks behind candidates to the parties they represent will discover here their attitude toward the problems of the day. On some important issues they are at one: approving the $30,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief, for example.

Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, at three campaign meetings yesterday attacked the Republican and Democratic State platforms. He characterized the Republican platform as "definitely dodging vital issues." He particularly stressed its failure to deal adequately with the problems of labor, unemployment insurance and control of public utilities.

LAUREL, Md.,.Oct. 6 (AP). -- W.W. Vaughan's Canron raced to a surprise victory over the well-regarded Western mare Risque in the Anne Arundel Purse, a test for fillies and mares at six furlongs, today at Laurel. Con Amore was a laboring third.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 6. -- The premiere sports event of the Autumn season will be the match on Oct. 16 between the Zane Grey polo team of Zanesville, Ohio, and the Guyan polo team of Huntington, W. Va., on the Greenbrier Field.
BATES tied Yale! The Sibyl by old Cumae's shores Was lucky that no football scores Were forecast from that vale.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Mrs. Roberta Dodd-Crawford came here about ten years ago from Houston, Texas, to study voice culture. She won a scholarship given by Samuel Insull eight years ago and went to Paris to continue her studies.

BARRIE, Ont., Oct. 6. -- Martin J. Insull, former president of the Middle West Utilities Company, under indictment in Chicago for embezzlement and larceny, tonight surrendered to Canadian authorities and was lodged in the Simcoe County jail here.

The need for a constructive plan to assure the success of marriage and the methods of meeting this need through the Institute of Family Relations were outlined yesterday afternoon at the first of a series of eight conferences under the auspices of the institute, held at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

Confidence that former Governor Smith will take an active part in his campaign and make a number of speeches in his behalf was voiced yesterday by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor.

Resources, deposits and undivided profits of the Chase National Bank on Sept. 30 showed increases compared with their levels on June 30. although continuing below the totals of a year ago, according to the statement issued yesterday in response to the call of the Controller of the Currency.

BOMBAY, Oct. 8 (Canadian Press). -- The negotiations for an agreement between Hindus and Moslems on the details of the electoral representation to be granted to the new India took an encouraging turn today. Hindu Nationalist leaders, followers of Mahatma Gandhi, accepted thirteen of the fourteen points formulated by the Moslems in private discussions between leading representatives of the two communities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- The City National Bank and Trust Company, formed by Brig. Gen. Charles Gates Dawes and associates to take over the savings, commercial and checking savings departments of the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, began business today.

Making a plea for the reduction of taxes in order to hasten improved business conditions and thus relieve unemployment, Eugene R. Grace, president, of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, in an article in the current issue of The Bethlehem Review says that taxes today are too great to be carried by industry and by the worker.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- A semi-demoralized cash trade, despite colder weather, was largely responsible for a break of 15 to 30 cents a hundred pounds today in the prices of hogs here. While offerings were not large, they were in excesse of requirements.

Reactions continued yesterday to affect many bonds on the New York Stock Exchange, but gains appeared in several of the more active leaders. The average price of domestic bonds declined .36 point for the day but foreign bonds were .23 point higher. Transactions were $9,236,500, against $9,345,500 the day before.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 6 (AP). -- From the peaceful persuasion policy of their leaders, farmers' holiday adherents near Sioux Falls, S.D., today turned to highway picketing to keep live stock and grain from reaching markets in South Dakota's largest city.

The Artists Guild, at its first dinner meeting of the season last night at the Broadmoor Restaurant, considered in closed session the revision of the code of ethics which at present governs the sale of advertising art and illustrations.

A further reduction of $6,000,000 in member bank borrowings and a further rise of $15,000,000 in member bank reserve balances was shown in tie statement of the Federal Reserve System as of Wednesday, published yesterday. These changes, indicating continued improvement of the banking position, were accomplished in the face of a rise of $44,000,000 in money in circulation and a decline of $2,000,000 in Reserve Bank holdings of United States Government securities.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 6. -- The Rev. John P. Twell of Martins Ferry. Ohio, died today while driving his automobile near Baltimore. A futile effort to stop the car was made by his wife when her husband collapsed over the steering wheel, but the car left the road and crashed into a tree. Mrs. Twell escaped injury.

Opposition to the closing of classes in the city's continuation schools for unemployed adults received impetus yesterday in an open demonstration by students at City Hall, while others voiced their protest against the elimination of the classes as an economy measure in letters to Mayor McKee and to public school authorities.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 6. -- A light signal drill tomorrow morning will mark the close of Bucknell's training for the game with Fordham in New York Saturday. The last strenuous practice session was staged today.
Governor Roosevelt has increased his lead over President Hoover in the poll conducted by The Literary Digest and now holds a clear majority of approximately 800,000 votes tabulated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note that an article appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Oct. 6, reporting remarks that I made before the Plain Talk Forum on Tuesday night, Oct. 5, quotes me as saying that I questioned Mr. Seabury's purity of purpose, due to the fact that he demanded a $100,000 fee.

The aggressive professional selling of stocks, which reached substantial proportions Wednesday, ceased on yesterday's market as suddenly as it had begun the day before. As a whole, the course of prices reverted to the idle backward and forward swing that had previously prevailed, and net changes were in most shares limited to unimportant fractions.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 6. -- Newark's Bears won the fourteenth little world's series today when their third baseman, Marvin Owen, hit a home run over the right-field fence in the ninth inning to defeat Minneapolis, 8 to 7, in the sixth game.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 6. -- The University of North Carolina won both singles and doubles championships in the fourth annual Middle Atlantic Intercollegiate tennis tournament on the Greenbrier courts today.
BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- Professors, L.F. Woodruff and E.L. Rose of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have collaborated to invent an electrical device for shuffling and dealing 5 cards at bridge.

Control of the Metropolitan Opera Company, which has undergone a period of transition in the last year, will pass from the hands of "the wealthy few" to the general public, according to Artur Bodanzky, conductor of the opera, who returned on the French liner Paris yesterday after a Summer in Europe.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6. -- The view that President Hoover has been the "victim of a panic" was challenged tonight by Bainbridge Colby with the declaration that the President had failed rather for lack of vision and leadership.

MANILA, Oct. 6. -- Representative Butler B. Hare of South Carolina in an interview today expressed some surprise over the recent strong opposition among Filipinos against the Hare bill. He said no such opposition had been voiced by Filipinos during the hearings of the Committee on Insular Affairs, but the added it was impossible to please all and believed the bill effected a reasonable compromise.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The final one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association proved to be the first golfing victory for 18-year-old Clifford Rothenberg of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that the index number of wholesale prices for the week ended Oct. 1 stands at 65.4, the same as for the two preceding weeks. This index number includes 784 commodities or price series, weighted according to the importance of each article, and is based on the average prices in 1926 as 100.0.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Liquidation and stop-loss selling swept the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today, and with the exception of the December, all wheat futures, as well as those of corn, oats and rye, dropped to new low prices for the season, December oats selling at a record bottom mark for that delivery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Speaker John N. Garner today announced the House committee to attend the funeral on Saturday of Representative J. Charles Linthicum of Maryland, who died, yesterday in Baltimore.

Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, legislative representative of the Teachers Union, attacked the Citizens Budget Commission over WABC last night as an organization formed of representatives of bankers and real estate interests who were trying to further their own financial interests at the expense of teachers and others for whom they advocated pay reduction.

George Blumenthal was honored at a dinner given at Sherry's last night by the trustees of Mount Sinai Hospital to celebrate his forty years of service as a trustee and twenty-one years as president of the hospital. James Speyer, chairman of the dinner committee, presided.

Payment in 1930 of approximately $2,400,000 toward obtaining the Turkish match monopoly, in connection with which about $14,000,000 of bonds is now held by the trustee m bankruptcy of the International Match Corporation, was by money supplied by the Kreuger Toll account with Lee, Higginson Co., it was testified yesterday at a hearing in the bankruptcy of the Kreuger Toll Company.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the executive offices of the Fifth Avenue Association there is a bronze tablet, the gift of its board of directors, on which is inscribed:

Jeanne Dusseau revealed in her recital at the Town Hall last night what taste, intelligence and perception, can do to triumph over nature, niggardly with her gifts. For this Canadian soprano's voice as a vocal instrument pure and simple is limited in various ways.

ADDIS ABABA, Abyssinia, Oct. 7 (AP). -- The great heart of Haille Selassie, Emperor of Abyssinia, King of Kings and descendant of that great Queen Balkis, the friend of Solomon, was torn once more today between gentle mercy and prudent caution.

Attended by the belated openings of two teams of major importance, Notre Dame and Nebraska, football today attains the steady pace of big-game tempo which will hold through the rest of the season. Every section at the country, including New York City, has a "Big Game Day" atmosphere about this afternoon's activities and the string will remain unbroken until the close of the campaign.

The Iona School football team tallied its second victory of the season, defeating Horace Mann School for Boys, 12 to 0, yesterday at Horace Mann Field in the latter's opening game of the campaign. Touchdowns by Hooter and Zarega in the second period accounted for Iona's triumph.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Governor Roosevelt directed District Attorney John R. Schwartz of Dutchess County today to appear before him on Tuesday at Albany to make a report on the investigation of the killing of four members of the Germond family at Standfordville, almost two years ago.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Earl Christian of Oklahoma and Paul Shuler, two jockeys hurt in falls at the Laurel race track today, were in the South Baltimore. General Hospital, while three other riders suffered minor injuries and were treated at the track.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7. -- Mgr. Pascual Diaz, the Archbishop of Mexico, was arrested this evening, it was learned at his residence, Villa Marta, on the outskirts of the capital.

The population of the United States will attain a maximum of 150,000,000 in 1970, when it will become stationary, or even show a slight excess of deaths over births, as the present generation is failing to reproduce its own numbers, according to conclusions reached by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and made public yesterday.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Gaiety Gregor, owned by F.D. Phillips of Goshen, N.Y., took the second division of the 2:15 trot in straight heats today, trotting the first two miles in 2:10 each. Laurel Nancy of the Good Time Stable, Goshen, annexed all three whirls in the 2:21 trot.

GARDEN-CITY, L.I., Oct. 7. -- Another champion was dethroned today when Paul Runyan, young Arkansas product, met defeat in the semi-final round of the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship at the Old Westbury. Golf Club.

Forty-seven scholarships have been awarded to first-year students in Columbia College and in the Columbia University Schools of Law and Engineering, it is announced today by The Columbia Alumni News. Sixteen of the recipients are entered in the freshman class of the college, eighteen in the School of Law and thirteen in the School of Engineering.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 7. -- Republican, leaders are trying to revive the religious issue, "with a little different angle," James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, told the delegates at the State convention, today.

The more liberal substitution rule which is in this year's football rules allows a player to be substituted for another at any time, but a player withdrawn from the game may not return in the same quarter in which he was withdrawn.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Reviewing in The Spectator today a book on Montagu Norman, Governor of the Bank of England, the former Chancellor of the Exchequer, Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, endorses a statement made in it that Mr. Norman, "although he has never been a politician, has been the greatest statesman of Great Britain since the war."

Stocks and bonds extended their recent declines sharply yesterday in circumstances which suggested that the markets were influenced only casually by the current news developments which, so far as finance and business are concerned, are not at all exciting.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 7 (AP). -- Edwn M. Fuller, 50 years old, a former New York broker, was in a critical condition in a hospital here tonight from an apparently self-inflicted bullet wound in the head.

Seldom has the Bar Association of the City of New York shown such indignation and taken such prompt action in protest against judicial nominations as in its denunciation of the recent exchange of courtesies between Tammany and the Republican organization of this county.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- A petition for a receiver filed early this week against the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company (the Nickel Plate lines) was denied today by Judge James H. Wilkerson in the Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Organization of the Home Loan Banks will be perfected next week when the directors of at least ten of the twelve regional institutions meet, it was announced today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

Republican county leaders in this city conferred at the Harvard Club yesterday with W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, in an endeavor to reach agreement on some available candidate for Mayor to be named in opposition to Surrogate John P. O'Brien, the Tammany nominee, when their city convention meets at the Mecca Temple this evening.
An investment exchange and a sale by a trustee in bankruptcy were among the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

PORT OP SPAIN, Trinidad, Oct. 7. -- Dr. Enrico Castelli of Italy, now with a tropical medical mission here, announced today during an official health-week lecture a discovery that opens up the possibility of early diagnosis and successful treatment of cancer by a new method of vaccination.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 7 (AP). -- Stories of brutality in the Sunbeam prison camp and of guards roaring with, laughter at a convict's agony were related today in the trial of two former camp officials charged with murdering Arthur Maillefert by slow torture in the "sweatbox."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, in an address before the Commonwealth Club today, said "Our hope of peace is of little worth unless with it goes a positive program of world organization."

The zoning committee of the First Avenue Association, of which William Warner Hoppin is chairman, announced yesterday that it had begun a survey of property owners on the avenue between Twenty-third and Thirty-fifth Streets with the aim of presenting petitions to the city to restrict the district to business uses.
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Dr. Florence Ada Stoney, pioneer in X-ray and ultra-violet light treatment, died here today at the age of 62.

To the Editor at The New York Times: I fear from Robert L. Banks's letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES that he does not fully comprehend the effort which is being made to substitute buses for surface cars in Manhattan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two letters appeared recently In THE TIMES alluding to the possibility of war with Japan. Coincidentally a Far Eastern message reports the haste with which Rashin is being built; the new Manchurian port near the Soviet border is to absorb most of the Chinese Eastern Railway's huge transit trade.
S.W. Straus Co., Inc., for many years one of the most important investment houses in the United States, was ordered into a Martin act receivership yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton.

Additional statements of condition as of Sept 30 were made public yesterday by national and State banks and trust companies in response to the calls issued by the State Superintendent of Banks and the Controller of the Currency. They continued to reflect the rising trend of resources and deposits for the last three months shown in the earlier reports.

Grahem M. Brush president of the Soatrain Lines, returned yesterday from Washington where he had spent two days in conference with the Shipping Board and the Interstate Commerce Commission on matters pertaining to the new service of his company between New York and New Orleans, via Havana.
ALBANY, Oct. 7 (AP). -- For the first time the vast Ashokan reservoir, New York City's water supply, has been overstocked with water.

Thus far 1932 has been the healthiest year on record for New York City, with 3,576 fewer deaths recorded in the first nine months of 1932 than in the same period in 1931, the Health Department announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Chicago and Yale University, rivals in tomorrow's headline intersectional football game, practiced in the Yale Bowl in secret today. The Yale squad drilled only twenty minutes. Three elevens were sent through a signal rehearsal.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Six closed Pennsylvania banks will advance a total of more than $900,000 to depositors this month.

Governor Roosevelt issued yesterday a quick and emphatic denial of a rumor that he intended calling a special session of the Legislature to cut salaries of public school teachers. He thus placed himself on record as opposed, at least for the present, to legislative interference with the mandatory schedules.

Some of the finest pheasant country in this State is located within 100 miles of New York City, reached by fine highways and hunted by great numbers of nimrods who have discovered the thick cover of this region to be ideal for the sport. The season for pheasants will not begin until Nov. 1.

Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday that he would wage a vigorous campaign for the Mayoralty in opposition to Surrogate O'Brien, Tammany nominee, and the candidate to be named by the Republicans.
Formation of the committee on Cuba of the World Trade League with the view to hastening the revival of Cuban-American trade was announced yesterday.

An appeal for the 'old-time Republican enthusiasm" coupled with an educational program to meet the 'fallacies of irrational radicalism" was made yesterday afternoon, by Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis, at a mass meeting attended by more than 800 Republican women at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 7. -- The climax of one of the most successful Worcester music festivals came tonight in Mechanics Hall with artists' night, at which Grace Moore, soprano, made her first appearance here.
ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- Albany tomorrow will welcome the Nailsea Moor, the first transatlantic ship to load a full cargo of grain for Europe. The Nailsea Moor will take on 240,000 bushels.

"WASHINGTON. Oct. 7. -- Resolutions urging continued effort in behalf of uniform traffic regulation and strong driver's license laws for all States were adopted at the closing session today of the annual Congress of the National Safety Council.

BERLIN, Oct. 7. -- The Boerse was slightly firmer and more hopeful today, the favorite securities making modest recoveries from yesterday's levels. Fixed-interest securities were in demand, as were also United States Steel, Phoenix, Rheinstahl and the electrical issues.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- With sales of $419,900 today, the remainder of the $20,000,000 City of Philadelphia bond issue offered last Spring was disposed of in the City Treasurer's office today. The issue was placed on sale "over the counter" when it had failed to attract investment bankers.

In California Secretary MILLS is calling on all true Californians to rally once more around the citadel of protection and prevent the infernal Democrats from razing it. Having a hereditary connection with the State, he tries to touch the hearts of Middle West and Texas immigrants and Native Sons.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 7. -- Sweep-stake competitions, which carried with them championship titles, were the concluding events this afternoon of the closing day of the annual Dantury Pair Horse Show, and one of the largest crowds in recent years lined the rails as one event crowded on the heels of another, the prograin being rushed through to take care of the extra classes on the program held over after the postponement of the opening day.

Practically all the better known etchings of Felix Buhot may be seen in the exhibition of that artist's work at the Keppel Galleries. About fifty examples are shown, including two of the "Westminster" and one of the "Clock Tower." The deep tones and full, rich background of certain plates contrast delightfully with some of the light states also shown.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Legal technicalities may hold up consummation of a number of self-liquidating loans which have been or may be approved by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

In a memorable address before an international meeting of "life underwriters" into which he "condensed the thinking of nearly forty "years," DARWIN P. KINGSLEY defined life insurance as "a plan that exalts life and defeats death." It asserts without peering into the realm beyond the grave that a certain helpful immortality can be assured now and on this earth to human affection and the work of human hands.

The Bronx grand jury began yesterday to inquire into labor troubles among motion-picture operators, which have been blamed for bombings and other outrages in city theatres, including the placing of a large dynamite bomb amid an audience of 3,000 in the Paradise Theatre, Grand Concourse and 188th Street, that failed to explode only because of a defective fuse.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 7. -- Playing with deadly accuracy from the back court and flashing a neat game at the net, Arthur MacPherson of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, N.Y., defeated Cedric A. Major of New York, 6 -- 3, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 1, today to advance to the final of the Hot Springs Fall tennis tournament.

In bidding farewell to JAMES J. WALKER as a public man this city feels and is expressing various kinds of regret. It will miss his personal charm and ready wit and felicity of speech on public occasions. He will take with him into private life many engaging qualities and capacities for friendship which, any politician might covet as a great asset.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Bishop Cannon and four other Southern Methodist leaders have written open letters to President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt asking what specific plans they have for preventing the return of the saloon and for pro tecting dry States in the event of a change in the present prohibition plan.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- Despite the saving effected by the rentes conversion and other governmental economies, France is facing a budgetary deficit of 5,000,000,000 francs [about $200,000,000], the Cabinet council learned today in a session devoted almost exclusively to the 1933 budget.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Griswold Thompson have returned to 375 Park Avenue from Red Roofs, their place in Ladentown, N.Y.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Temple University defeated West Virginia tonight in the Owl's Stadium, 14 to 13, in a sensational game that was in doubt up to the final whistle.

The Park Association of New York City, Inc., will recommend to the city that a council of experts and engineers be appointed to study the Administrations of the five park departments with a view to their reorganization in accordance with modern business standards, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the association's directors in the offices of J. Stewart Baker, treasurer, at 40 Wall Street.
BOWDOIN vs. Williams -- James Bowdoin was Governor of Massachusetts in 1785. R. Norris Williams was national tennis champion,in 1914. One thin vote for Williams.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- British Government funds were better today, encouraged by the improved tone in other sections of the Stock Exchange. Industrials were helped by news of the success of another capital issue. Profit-taking caused declines in Cables and Wireless.

ON BOARD THE S.S. EUROPA, Oct. 7. -- Professing himself happy at having extricated, himself from the tangled political situation without "letting the organization down," former Mayor James J. Walker was understood today to have received two new offers of employment, each carrying a salary of about $5,000 a week.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Governor Roosevelt is fully satisfied with the nomination of Surrogate O'Brien for Mayor of New York City, it was indicated here tonight.

Under a plan announced yesterday for reduction of capital, stockholders of the County Trust Company, of which Alfred E. Smith is chairman, will receive $800,000 in cash, the amount to he distributed on a prorata basis.

Engineering contracts in the United States reported during the week ended Oct. 3 totaled $27,100,000, which is considerably above the weekly average of the past two months, The Engineering News-Record reports.
YORK, Pa., Oct. 7. -- Thrilling finishes featured the nine events which made up the racing program at the York County Fair today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Upperland, a big brown gelding exhibited by Mrs. Harry Frank Jr. of Warrenville, and Margate, a brown gelding shown by Miss Claire W. Faitoute of Short Hills, were the only double winners of blues on the first day of the Orange Horse Show at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 7 (AP). -- Possession of near beer is legal in Alabama today, but the legality of its sales was wrapped in a blanket of doubt.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee refused yesterday to run as an independent or fusion candidate for Mayor, and sent a telegram of congratulation and best wishes to Surrogate John P O'Brien, who was nominated for Mayor at the Democratic City Convention Thursday night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The text of the second monthly report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the House of Representatives was made public today by the cleric of the House as follows:

Check exchanges at the principal clearings of the country in September aggregated $20,625,474,323. This was an increase of 3 per cent over the preceding month and is likewise the second month in succession that clearings showed an expansion over the previous period, the August total having exceeded July by 3.6 per cent.

New bond financing this week amounted to $78,372,000, the largest total since that of the week ended on July 15. The sum compares with $65,829,000 last week and with a single offering of $12,000,000 of Federal Intermediate Credit Bank bonds a year ago.

With the end of the civil war in Brazil, there ended a test of party strength which has been more than two years in working out. The revolt of the State of Sao Paulo last Summer against the Vargas regime was the counter-stroke to the successful Vargas uprising of just two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- A political reunion of wet and dry factions in the Republican party before Nov. 8 was predicted today as "Hoover Day" meetings were held in almost every county of Pennsylvania, before and after President Hoover made his radio address from Washington.

BLACKPOOL, England. Oct. 7. -- Having saved $30,000,000 [the pound is worth about $3.45] annually by converting its 5 per cent war loan into 3 1/2 per cent bonds, the British, Government is going to economize further in loan interest payments as soon as it gets a chance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Re-construction Finance Corporation today authorized loans of $815,000 to North Carolina, $335,715 to Florida, $213,891 to West Virginia and $110,000 to Texas for meeting emergency relief needs of those States up to Nov. 15.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- The dollar again weakened today in the foreign, exchange market, owing, according to French financial writers, to uneasiness among holders of American securities following President Hoover's campaign declarations in Iowa. Sterling also continued to fall, touching 88.

Helping Others and Ourselves Our own Department of and Health brings support to one of the paradoxes of economic depression. Never before, it reports, have the people of News York City enjoyed such excellent health as this year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The text of President Hoover's radio speech today to women who have been organizing in support of the administration in the election was as follows:

W.C. Durant, automobile manufacturer, in a cablegram made public yesterday by the Democratic National Headquarters, declared that although he is a Republican and voted for Mr. Hoover in 1928, he is interested now in Mr. Hoover's retirement to private life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- President Hoover carried his campaign today to the women of America, calling upon those who believed in the Republican cause to manifest their sentiment at the polls Nov. 8, when "the future hopes of America for many years to come" would be in the balance.

The Presidents Traffic Conference for Eastern Territory, which was formed recently by the presidents of the railroads in this region to reduce destructive rate-cutting, elected D. T. Lawrence as chairman and J. Gottschalk as secretary at a meeting in the Pennsylvania Station yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- Evidence of a great financial scandal dating back about 2,000 years before Christ was uncovered by Dr. Claude F.A. Schaeffer of the University of Strasbourg in last Summer's excavations of the royal tombs at Has Shamra in Northern Syria, he told the Academy of Sciences today.

LONDON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- The large selection offered at the wool auction today met active sales to buyers for the home trade and the Continent at full current rates for fine kinds. There were some withdrawals among scoured kinds and slipes. Most of the 2,887 bales of South Americans offered were sold.

GENEVA, Oct. 7. -- The problem of preventing the spread of false news liable to endanger peace was the main question before the League of Nations Assembly today. A long report on this subject made to the League Council at its request by the International Association of Journalists Accredited to the League of Nations was the centre of the discussion, being several times called "a remarkable study" and "a bold plan."

Men's Wear Stores More Active. Retail trade in men's clothing and furnishings Improved somewhat during the week, with the return of cooler weather, store executives reported yesterday. The general line of merchandise, including suits, top-coats, hats and accessories, was fairly active, with consumers showing a disposition to purchase goods more freely, although not on a very large scale.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Stanley Baldwin tonight defended the agreements concluded at the Ottawa, Economic Conference and told the Conservative party's annual meeting the United Kingdom intended quickly to conclude trade agreements with many foreign countries.

Grace Moore, American soprano and member of the Metropolitan Opera Company since 1928, when she made her debut as Mimi in "La Boheme," will return to the Broadway stage, the scene of her first success, late next month at the George M. Cohan Theatre in the title role of "The Dubarry," an operetta which has been successfully produced in Berlin and is now current in London, it was learned last night from an authoritative source.
Although the Increase in activity in retail and wholesale business has largely been seasonal, the improvement continues slowly but surely, according to the weekly reviews of commercial agencies.

Columbia and Princeton, pioneer rivals in the early days in Intercollegiate football, resume their relationship today at Baker Field after a lapse of twenty-seven years. A capacity throng of 40,000 is expected to witness the encounter, which conies as a sort of an early-season climax in the gridiron hopes and ambitions of the institutions.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- "Jump for your lives, I will hold her up until you are clear," was the last order that Pilot Officer Bernard Gully of the Royal Air Force gave before crashing to his death this evening in a huge Vickers-Virginia bomber that became uncontrollable 2,000 feet above Guildford in Surrey.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7. -- "Football this year will furnish, approximately $775,000 of the total sum of the receipts taken, in by the Harvard A. A., an amount, which will he in the neighborhood of $925,000," announced W.J. Bingham, director of Harvard athletics, in The Harvard Crimson this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Governor Roosevelt has been endorsed by the National Popular Government League, which by a 90 per cent referendum vote reversed its non-partisan position to support the New York Governor actively on "the issues of power, conservation of natural resources and forestry.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Governor Roosevelt's proposed "bargaining tariff" can only mean a reduced tariff on industry, which would "bargain away New Jersey's only chance for prosperity," Ambassador Walter E. Edge declared today, in an address to 300 Republican leaders from all counties in the State, who were his guests at a luncheon at Elks Club here in honor of United States Senator W. Warren Barbour.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Oct. 7 (AP). -- Mrs. Herbert, Hoover, addressing Girl Scouts today, complimented American girls for having "thought through" ways of "helping the distress about them."
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7. -- George Stark, a "dark horse" from Indianapolis, led the field today in the first round of the St. Louis $2,500 open golf tournament with a 70, one under par.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me commend the editorial in the issue of today, "Robbed of an Issue," which I consider the best expressed comment on the "deal" Which resulted in the nomination of Senator Hofstadter and Judge Steuer for the Supreme Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Leopold Stokowski carried out his promise to play a modernistic selection at the opening concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra today, in defiance of an earlier announcement of the Orchestra Association that "debatable" music would not be encouraged on this season's programs.

Foreign and domestic bonds continued to lose ground on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with trading at a moderately brisker pace, having increased in volume day by day throughout the week. The turnover yesterday was $9,563,500 against $9,236,500 on Thursday.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, who was nominated last Tuesday as Republican candidate for United States Senator, intimated last night at the Federal Building that He would issue a statement soon explaining what he intended to do about resigning or remaining in office during his campaign.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- In the darkness over Long Island Sound tonight a fleet of craft set forth in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's cruising race out around Stratford Shoal, off Bridgeport, the last of such events for the season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Several encouraging features of improved conditions in the Far East were reported in today's weekly survey of foreign business conditions by the Department of Commerce.

Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, former Secretary of the Treasury and one of the sponsors of the Federal Reserve System, took issue yesterday with the assertion of President Hoover in his Des Moines speech Tuesday that the United States at one time was within two weeks of being driven off the gold standard if no means had been taken to prevent it.

A sharp falling off in municipal financing is shown in the schedule of bond issues to be sold next week. Thirty-four communities will award $4,874,428, compared with $20,410,317 of new issues floated this week and with a weekly average for the year to date of $19,113,915.

Their hearts were with WALKER; their hatreds were for MCKEE; their hands were held out perfunctorily to O'BRIEN. Such would be a fairly accurate description of the attitude of the 32,000 delegates to the Democratic City Convention called for the purpose of nominating a Mayor.

OTTAWA, Oct. 7 (Canadian Press). -- The British Empire's new fiscal system, established at the Imperial Conference, will go into operation. Wednesday in Ottawa, London, Camberra and Dublin and will give effect to the tariff schedules negotiated at the conference.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 7. -- Many social functions were held today in connection with the playing of the semi-finals in the Fall tennis tournaments. More than 100 were at the Casino Terrace restaurant for luncheon.

A disposition to await this morning's government crop report was reflected yesterday by comparatively quiet business on the Cotton Exchange here. Opening advances in response to relatively steady cables and reports of further frosts in the South were followed by reactions under liquidation and scattered selling promoted by the action of the grain and stock markets.

With the stock market falling yesterday into new low ground for the current decline, Wall Street managed nevertheless to retain its optimistic attitude. The decline on the Stock Exchange was quite sharp and the selling was aggressive throughout the five hours of trading.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7. -- Terming the depression the greatest problem facing the United States and the world at large today, Secretary Mills in addresses here and in Oakland today gave an analysis of its causes and told what Was being done to correct it.

MODANE, France, Oct. 7. -- Samuel Insull, fugitive from extradition, missing from his Paris hotel since Wednesday morning, arrived with his son. Samuel Insull Jr., at the Hotel Palace, Turin, Italy, on Wednesday night and left there yesterday on a train for Florence.

Members of the Dugout, an organization composed entirely of disabled former service men whose disabilities are traceable directly to their war service, nave adopted unanimously a resolution opposing the passage of any legislation authorizing full payment of the bonus at the present time, it was revealed yesterday.

Continental European exchanges rallied strongly against the dollar yesterday. The movement, the widest since the European, fear for the safety of the gold standard in this country subsided last June, was ascribed variously to liquidation of foreign commitments in stock markets in the United States and to renewed fears abroad over the dollar.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP). -- Mrs. Raymond Robins sat in the White House today and reaffirmed the belief her husband was kidnapped by bootleggers when he mysteriously disappeared from New York on Sept. 1 while oh the way to keep an engagement with President Hoover.

Washington, D.C., was America's first "boom" town, but, although George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison gathered there to supervise the sale of the first lots, buyers were hard to find, A.M. Sakoiski writes in "The Great American, Land Bubble," just published by Harpers.
TOKYO, Oct. 7. -- The government departments are preparing their estimates for the next budget and, according to the newspapers, the army and navy will seek large increases, in appropriations.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 7. -- Formal charges of manslaughter were filed against Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Brogan of Jersey City here today in connection with an automobile accident in which Mrs. Bertha Williamson, 40 years old, of White Horse, was killed, and her daughter, Dorothy, 18, injured critically.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7. -- While six of the eight Mexican representatives contended among themselves, the other two suffered defeat at the hands of Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris and Isaac Kashdan of New York in the first round of the international chess masters tournament now under way under the auspices of the Club de Ajedrez.

Charles B. Stuart, vice president of the hanking and brokerage firm of Halsey, Stuart Co., and Paul M. Strickler and Leonard L. Stanley surrendered here yesterday on Federal Indictment returned in Milwaukee charging them and others with mail fraud in connection with the sale of bonds of the Wardman Realty and Construction Company.

Leaders of the bar moved swiftly yesterday to place independent candidates for the Supreme Court in the field to oppose State Senator Samuel Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer, whose bipartisan endorsement brought upon them the formal denunciation of the Association of the Bar.

With the Democratic City Convention over and party harmony restored on the surface. Tammany under the leadership of John F. Curry prepared yesterday for an intensive campaign to elect Surrogate John P. O'Brien, nominee for Mayor, beginning with a drive to get out the Democratic registration next week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- James A. Farrell, former president of the United States Steel Corporation, will become a teacher on the problems of foreign trade in the School of Foreign Service of Georgetown University. Thirteen years ago he gave to Georgetown University the first endowment for the school, the first of its kind in the United States.

An alliance between the United States and Great Britain would be "the most powerful factor in the world's history." in the opinion of the Marquess of Reading, British statesman, who arrived yesterday on the Cunard liner Aquitania.

The consistent Sun Mission, one of the best known sons of Sun Briar, captured the Peconic Purse at Jamaica yesterday. Bearing the colors of Dr. Irving Jacobs, the 6-year-old horse won by eight lengths at the end of a mile and a sixteenth with Hank Mills in the saddle.
Amid the noisy welcome of harbor whistles and the display of fireboats shooting towers of water into the air, the new Italian liner Rex steamed into the harbor yesterday.

Reports of our overseas commerce have teen discouraging for so many months that special interest will be taken in recent gains noted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. The value of exports is still far below that of a year ago.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7. -- The Soviet leaders have broken, their long silence on foreign affairs with comments on the Lytton report in the newspaper Pravda, the Kremlin mouthpiece, which views the report as an attempt to compromise "imperialist contradictions" at the expense of China and, secondarily, of the Soviet Union.
Housing properties in Manhattan have come under new control as the result of transactions announced yesterday. Most of the changes involved dwellings and tenements on the west side.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Those who vote on the Constitutional Amendment No. 1, to create new recreational facilities and modern roads in the State forests, should bear in mind these considerations:

George Gershwin will appear as pianist and conductor at the first concert of the season by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday evening, Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday. Sandor Harmati, permanent conductor of the orchestra, will open the program.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The periodical question in British politics concerning reform of the House of Lords came up again today at the annual conference of the Conservative party at Blackpool but this time with more than usual significance.

On the ground that Otto H. Kahn, banker and former chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Company, is so ill that it might be fatal for him to appear in court to testify in defense of the $250,000 libel suit brought by Rosalinda Morini, singer.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the Merchants' Association of New York and recently appointed New York City chairman of the Share-the-Work Movement, opened head-quarters yesterday at the association's offices, 233 Broadway, and, began to assemble a city-wide organization to conduct the campaign.

Money market was stagnant. Business was light and quotations unchanged for every class of accommodation. Stock Exchange day loans remained at 2 per cent, while the usual concessions were reported for loans on governments, federals and street funds.

Although the number of holders of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation, increased during the third quarter to a new high record, the gain was the smallest for any quarter since the fourth quarter of 1928, according to figures made public yesterday.
LEWISVILLE, Ind., Oct. 7 (AP). -- The First National Bank of this city was closed today and its affairs placed in the hands of a national bank examiner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am poignantly and irresistibly oppressed by the feeling that the light for the Democratic cause has not been made with sufficient aggressive vigor here in the East.

Advertising appeals based on ambition, health, vanity, novelty, efficiency and economy were more compelling this year than last, while those of emulation, fear, romance and quality have lost ground proportionately in magazines, Carroll Rheinstrom, vice president of the Liberty Publishing Corporation, told delegates at the closing session of the convention of the Direct Mail Advertising Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

The estate left by James J. Riordan, founder and president of the County Trust Company, who committed suicide on Nov. 8, 1929, is insufficient to pay his debts in full, it was disclosed yesterday in the Supreme Court when Justice Valente granted an application by the State Banking Department, which is liquidating the International-Madison Bank and Trust Company, to settle a claim of $179,935, due on notes, for $77,500.

An old-time crowd saw an old-time ring favorite battered into submission last night in Madison Square Garden when Jimmy McLarnin, puncher from Vancouver, B.C., stopped Benny Leonard, undefeated lightweight champion of another decade, in the sixth round of what was to have been a ten-round bout.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Lytton report again brings up a basic defect which has marked all arbitrational plans for the settlement of International disputes. If, as is reported, Japan, though a member of the League, rejects the findings of the Lytton commission, what then?

The New York University football team will strive for its seventh consecutive victory over Rutgers, its oldest rival, when the teams clash at the Yankee Stadium today. A crowd of more than 12,000 is expected to witness the contest.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 8. -- While conferences designed to curb the Szechwan civil war continue at Nanking, the extent of the conflict is growing. General Liu Hsiang and his allies fought a pitched battle near Chengtu yesterday with Governor Liu Wenhui's troops, who finally were the victors.

A will executed by Zachary Smith Reynolds on Aug. 21, 1931, while he was preparing for a divorce from his first. wife, Anne Cannon, was filed for probate in the surrogate's court here todays with a declaration by the Guaranty Trust Company, as executor, that there was no known codicil revising it after his second marriage on Nov. 29, 1931, to Libby Hoiman.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- Norman H. Davie arrived in London tonight for week-end, conversations with Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, and other members of the British Government concerning at least three major questions of world-wide concern. Although he said he could make no statement about his mission here or his conversations today in Paris, Mr. Davis added:

BAY CITY, Mich., Oct. 7. -- Elimination preliminaries today pruned some twenty entries from large classes in the fourth annual outboard championship regatta, the final events of which, will get under way tomorrow on the Saginaw River.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Confusion, perhaps not entirely unnatural, seems to have arisen as to the exact import of the nomination of Senator Samuel F. Hofstadter for judge of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District of the State of New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7. -- Both varsity and freshman cross-country teams of Harvard triumphed over Holy Cross rivals today. The Crimson won the 3 1/2-mile varsity race, 17 to 38, while the freshmen scored a 16-to-39 triumph in a 1 1/2-mile event.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Both Carleton College and Army held light workouts today in final preparation for their football game tomorrow. Army's drill consisted of a brief session at signals and a forward pass defensive tryout.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of the Philadelphia Country Club, and Miss Edith Quier of Reading and Huntingdon Valley reached the final round of the Berthellyn Cup golf tournament on the Huntingdon Valley Club course today.

The paintings by S. MacDonald Wright, which you will find at Mr. Stieglitz's An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, are strange paintings, very strange indeed. Nor does Mr. Wright's elucidations, available in typewritten form at the gallery, prove as helpful as one might wish.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- Before his departure for New York on Tuesday, former Mayor James J. Walker confided to friends here that he was quite prepared to retire temporarily from public life in the interest of party harmony and because of the condition of his health.
Price trend in commodities was irregularly lower yesterday. Grains, rubber, hides, tin, lead and coffee declined, while cotton, silk, sugar and cocoa turned up slightly.
PARIS, Oct. 7. -- An ingenious arrangement whereby important sums tied up in the German credit standstill agreement are being released came to light here today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 7. -- The importance of preserving local historical records as a part of the real history of the nation was impressed upon members of the New York State Historical Association, which is holding its annual convention at the Parrish Memorial Art Museum, by Dr. Alexander C. Flick of Albany, State historian of New York.

The committee headed by Calvin Coolidge which is to investigate the condition of the railroads began its work yesterday at an organization meeting in the office of Alfred E. Smith, another member of the committee, in the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Disregarding repeated protests from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, South Trimble, clerk of the House of Representatives, today made public the corporation's second monthly report to Congress, a course described by Atlee Pomerene, the chairman, as being "fraught with much danger to the borrowers."

Alfred E. Smith will campaign for the Democratic ticket in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut and New Jersey, and will make three speeches in New York, the last named during the final week of the campaign, it was reported definitely yesterday.
Prepared for its first major objective of the 1932 campaign, the Fordham University football eleven will clash with the powerful Bucknell team at the Polo Grounds at 2:30 o'clock today.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Norman H. Davis spent this afternoon with Ambassador Mellon in a long conversation going over the field he expects to discuss in the next few days with members of the British Government. That field will include disarmament, the World Economic Conference and the possibility of further naval reductions on the joint initiative of the United States and Great Britain.

TODAY. 1:00 P.M. -- WEAF -- Today's "Symphony for the Masses," under the direction of Erno Rapee, lists a group of selections by Wagner -- the overture to his "Flying Dutchman," excerpts from "Die Walkure," "Gotterdammerung," "Tristan und Isolde" and "Die Meistersinger."

HOLLYWOOD. BROADWAY may yet see Robert Benchley's name in electric lights beside those of Garbo, Dietrich and Gable. Mr. Benchley returned to New York this week, but not until he declined to become an actor.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Army overwhelmed Carleton College of Northfield, Minn., 57 to 0, today before 12,000 spectators in Michie Stadium. Army's substitutes carried the burden for three quarters of the game. The regulars left the field for good at the conclusion of the first period with the score 12 to 0.

Approximately 250 schoolboy harriers inaugurated the cross country season of the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday, competiting in three groups over the two-and-a-half-mile Van Cortlandt Park course.

ONE big bugaboo has been dispelled by this Presidential campaign. It is that the radio broadcasting facilities of the country may be used to the disadvantage of one or another of the political parties. So far no candidate has complained that he has been discriminated against in his broadcast.

OTTAWA, Oct. 6. -- The Bennett Government has lost an important by-election to the Liberals, and there is great rejoicing in the ranks of the Opposition. In South Huron, a rural constituency in Western Ontario, the Liberals have held by a greatly increased majority a seat which has been in their possession since 1925.
SAVANNAH, Oct. 6 --Three hints for fishermen, two of them in connection with bait, have reached Savannah recently from different places in South Georgia.

TOKYO, Sept. 17. -- An original matrimonial swindle, possible only in Japan, with a pathetic background, has been, uncovered by the Osaka, police. A man was found quarreling in the street with an attractive young woman. "I am your husband," he shouted, "I tell you to come home and you won't come.
BERLIN, Sept. 24 TO Alfred Grunwald a deep and heartfelt bow -- he has given us the Massary again!

THIRTY-NINE makes of passenger cars and commercial vehicles will be displayed at the forth-coming National Automobile Show, scheduled to be held at the Grand Central Palace Jan. 7-14. The cars to be exhibited, as announced by the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, are:

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6. -- Everything was moving along merrily at a dinner given for Secretary of the Treasury Mills on the occasion of his campaign visit here a few nights ago, when Governor Henry S. Caulfield, called upon to make a few extemporaneous remarks, upset the apple cart.

To The Dramatic Editor: Frequently good plays are made relatively dull by too much ballyhoo. Such has certainly been the fate of "Another Language." For months I had been hearing about this newly discovered genius, Mrs. Franken, who sends her cook away so she can write and amid her dish washing and sweeping turns out plays like this epic.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. HONORS are heaping on Boston's head. Last season, to the surprise of envious Chicago, it ranked second only to New York as the seat of flourishing theatres. This Fall it has outdone the metropolis itself.

BERLIN. ON the wall of a room in the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Brain Research in the suburban village of Buch hang side by side three diagrams showing in cross-section the brains of an ordinary person, of a feeble-minded woman and of Lenin.

Promoter Humbert J. Fugazy will make another attempt on Wednesday night to close his outdoor boxing season at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, with the program he has scheduled in the interests of the Seventh and Eighth Masonic District Camps. Frustrated in his plans for this show last week by unfavorable weather, Fugazy is hoping for smiling skies, bang-up competition and a profitable gate.

A GROUP of several hundred photographs taken long before photography had become as commonplace as it is today will go on exhibition this afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. They are the work of S.R. Stoddard, said by Thomas F. Morris, who assembled the group, to have been the first man to go into the Adirondack wilderness with a camera.

IN an unmistakably Meredithian opening the author of "Diana of the Crossways" introduces that lady as "then becoming famous for her beauty and her wit: 'an unusual combination' in the deliberate syllables of one * * * who is however, not disposed to personal irony when speaking of her."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Bank debits, outside New York City, declined during the week ended Oct. 1, and for September were below the total for August, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

IN Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and Colonel William J. Donovan the two major parties of New York State have found Gubernatorial candidates who are alike in that neither is a professional politician and that each has won a more than partisan respect and confidence.
NOTHING could more clearly prove that the contemporary world is suffering from mental indigestion than this book by Cyril Edwin Mitchinson Joad, sometimes called Joad the obscure.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The board of governors of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards will meet at the Winfield Scott Hotel here next Friday, John K. Leeds, a vice president of the State organization, announced today. The Elizabeth Real Estate Board will be host to the board.

Columbia's Lion conquered the Princeton Tiger yesterday after a lapse of more than thirty years. Playing their first regularly scheduled game since 1905. Columbia and Princeton fought for more than three hours on the green of Baker Field While a crowd of 34,00O sat jammed lose to the sidelines.

Henry H. Wehrhane, a retired banker, formerly associated with Hallgarten Co., filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against his wife, Mrs. Roma Hodgdon Wehrhane, to compel her to return to him more than $1,000,000 worth of securities and furniture and art objects valued in excess of $100,000.

BRISTOL, Conn., Oct. 8 (AP). -- Trenwith R. Ward was the grandson of the late Albert F. Rockwell, Connecticut manufacturer and philanthropist. His father, George D. Ward, left here tonight for Ithaca.

THE so-called warming-up phenomenon, hereafter designated by the letters WU, refers to those psycho-physiological conditions which condition or cause a certain observed fact found in certain work-curves, namely, the fact of a rise or increment in the early part of the curve.

Publication by the New York Public Library of Dr. EDWARD L. STEVENSON'S translation of the Geography of PTOLEMY at a time when the Western world is about to observe the 430th anniversary of the discovery of America serves the useful purpose of enabling us to appraise the achievements of COLUMBUS.
POLYTECHNICALIZATION is the new shibboleth in Russian education.

RIPON, Wis., Oct. 8 -- Secretary Hurley spoke this afternoon before Wisconsin Republicans from the porch of the little schoolhouse, on Ripon College campus, where the Republican party was born, in 1854.

John A. Hayes, special partner in the Stock-Exchange firm of Richard Whitney Co., 15 Broad Street, died suddenly on Friday at his home, 76 Fenimore Street. Brooklyn, of a stroke of apoplexy. He was 56 years old.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- After an absence of more than forty years, Alonzo Stagg returned to his alma mater today to send a fighting Chicago team on the field that frustrated Yale's second effort to score a football victory this Fall.
ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- There was a large attendance tonight at a Monte Carlo party and dance held at the Ardsley Country Club.

Recent deals of the Soviet oil syndicate in widely scattered areas of the world are not causes of much concern to the international oil companies, executives of these companies say. They hold that the transactions have virtually no political significance and predict that they will have little, if any, effect on the prices of oil products generally.

LONDON. THERE is much talk and counter-talk in Wardour Street over an impending battle-royal between American and British interests competing for supremacy in the cinema markets of this United Kingdom. Report has it that various rival organizations are grinding knives wherewith to cut each other's throats, as well as fashioning bludgeons in preparation for "big-stick" methods.

The changes in the kick-off rule which also apply to free kicks (1) allow for a drop-kick, if preferred to a place-kick, and (2) require at least five players of the receiving team to remain in a zone between their own 45-yard line and the 50-yard line until the kick-off has actually been made.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- In a second statement criticising President Hoover's recent speech made at Des Moines, Speaker Garner today asked, "When is pork not pork?" and answered his own question, with the assertion:

BUFFALO, Oct. 6. -- The assemblage of delegates and leaders which nominated a State ticket in Buffalo this week, was the most important Republican State convention ever held here. That assertion can be made with confidence because it was the only one -- at least, the only one that ever named a candidate for Governor.
TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Roosevelt High of Yonkera tallied an 8-0 triumph, over Eastchester High today.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- Another famous Paris landmark is about to disappear. This time it is the statue of the zouave, one of the group of four Second Empire soldiers which stand on the Alma Bridge over the Seine.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- It was a great relief to Premier Herriot and the French Government when Thursday afternoon Lord Tyrrell, British Ambassador, called at the Foreign office to say the government had decided to postpone sine die the four-power conference that bad been planned for the first part of the week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The directorate of the Regional Home Loan Bank at Newark was announced tonight by Chairman Franklin W. Fort of the Federal Home Loan Board.

PASSING through New York on a trip around the world, Captain Peter P. Eckersley, former chief engineer of the British Broadcasting Company, reports that in no country has he found a radio system superior to that of the United States.

Evening fashions are unusually varied this season, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Tobe, fashion and merchandise counselor. This diversity, she said, will "be a boon to business, for variety always means additional sales."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Young Joe Cronin, brilliant shortstop who will not be 26 until Wednesday, is the new manager of the Washington Senators.

BEYOND the horizon, whither many producers go before displaying their wares upon Broadway, several new plays were presented during the past week, and, with the passage of time, bid fair to swim into the local playgoers' ken.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic nominee for Mayor, announced yesterday the appointment of James J. Hoey as his campaign manager. Headquarters in rooms 170 to 178 on the second floor of the Hotel Astor will be opened officially tomorrow.

SOMETHING is always cropping up to add fuel to the fire of controversy which persists in Germany between the advocates of the so-called modern dance and those of the ballet. There is at present an unmistakable trend there among the younger dancers and students away from the modern dance and toward the ballet.

SAN JUAN, P.R. Oct. 5. -- Puerto Rico suffered the most severe blow of a century in the hurricane of Sept. 26-27. Governor James R. Beverley told a citizens' committee gathered at La Fortaleza a few days after the storm to plan relief work. He explained that he did not refer alone to the severity of the storm itself but its consequences.

Mrs. J. Cheever Goodwin, widow of the playwright, whose appelation of Mother Cheever had a familiar and cheering ring to ex-service men, died late Friday afternoon at her residence, 159 West Eighty-fourth Street. She was in her seventy-second year.

A FEW weeks ago there was an eclipse of the sun. It had been predicted more than half a century ago. Not only was it known in advance when the moon's disk would obscure the sun but the exact path over which the moon's shadow would sweep had been plotted.

WHEN Arturo Toscanini raises his baton at Carnegie Hall this afternoon, opening the third consecutive season of broadcasts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, a group of compositions new to radio listeners will be on the program.

Criticism of trustees of trust funds who permit securities belonging to a trust to remain with brokerage firms as nominees of the trustees has been made by James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, as referee in an accounting suit brought by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company as trustee under a trust established by Stella S. Housman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Gandhi's sacrificial triumph has not only aroused all India and caused England at once to proceed to change her long-established East Indian policy, but has started a sympathetic thrill in the Far East which is sure to spread with the news around the world.

IT is too early to claim victory, but our banking and credit structure has been made secure and a nonpartisan program, broad and comprehensive in its scope, has been gradually evolved to lay the foundation for and to promote recovery.
GEORGE ARLISS, who brought Disraeli to life on the screen, may perform a similar office for no less a figure of history and literature than Voltaire.

An Ether Case. It was Dr. Lewis J. Pollock of the medical faculty of Northwestern University who advanced the "labyrinthine reflex" theory at a recent clinical conference in Kansas City. Appropriately enough, Dr. Pollock is Professor of Nervous and Mental Diseases at Northwestern University. That makes it perfect. Golf falls right under his jurisdiction, the scrutiny of his microscope, the slash of his scalpel.

SCOWLING, more often than not, behind the comic mask of Thalia, there has strode upon the theatrical scene in recent years a gentleman of composite form who, to the rattle of his typewriter or the devastating thrusts of his pen, has made himself virtual master of what might ba termed a "new racket."

Sales brought $12,640 at the dispersal of Oriental rugs and carpets yesterday afternoon at the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc., 9 East Fifty-ninth Street. B.J. Mallon obtained a royal Merrehend carpet for $620 and a royal Kashan rug was sold to R.N. Cohan for $550.

Benjamin Aronson, proprietor of a jewelry store at 40 West Broadway, near Park Place, was getting ready to close up a little after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon when three men entered and asked to look at a watch. Aronson obligingly turned to pick one up to show them and when he looked again he was facing the muzzle of a pistol.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A $2,000,000 suit was on file in Suffolk Superior Court today, brought by the Shepard Stores, Inc., of Boston, against some of its directors. The store seeks to recover for the loss of all its assets by the foreclosure of its $3,800,000 notes given to John Shepard Jr. as part payment for all the stock of the Shepard Norwell Company of Boston and the Shepard Company of Providence, R.I.

TO what point, many a harassed taxpayer is asking, should the public be called upon to support a child's education? Through the junior college years, answers the distinguished commission of the Carnegic Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, which recently completed its survey of the situation in California.

The three-day decline on the Stock Exchange was continued yesterday. The day's losses as a rule were small, however, the early downward movement being partly canceled by recovery at the close. As usual, various reasons were assigned for the continuing weakness; but the decline seemed to be primarily extension of a professional movement against prices, which was supported by any kind of argument that would serve the purpose.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I ask that you contradict ugly reports to the effect that Mr. Pablo Casals of Barcelona, Spain, has suffered a stroke of paralysis and is consequently unable to continue with his art?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Reports from New York of new raids on the dollar were met here today by statements of high officials that the United States was prepared to withstand a considerable gold drain without endangering in any way our economic structure.

CANTON, Sept. 8. -- The virtual bankruptcy of Kwangtung Province has been officially announced by leaders of the Canton regime. In spite of a recent bond issue of $30,000,000, forced on the banks supposedly to furnish funds for the anti-Communist campaign, $6,000,000 taxes have been collected in advance, and now the government announces that it needs immediately another $8,000,000 for the military, $3,000,000 for administrative purposes, and $19,000,000 "for other purposes."

Municipal bonds and warrants to be paid this month and bonds and notes of large industrial and public utility companies to be retired at later dates were added last week to the list of securities called for redemption before their maturities. The total for October is now $8,760,000, compared with $25,329,300 in September and with $99,365,000 in October, 1931, at corresponding dates.

IF the career of Pedro de Alvarado is not neglected in the encyclopedias, a paragraph disposes of that conquistador and first-class fighting man of Spain's greatest period of glory. Even Prescott, in the "Conquest of Mexico, does not give him much space, although he was a useful and loyal lieutenant of Cortes.

Although there is a sign on the door of All Souls' Anthon Memorial Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St.. Nicholas Avenue, that the church is "closed for repairs," the Rev. Rollin Dodd, the rector, and his Negro parishioners will, through the solicitation of Bishop William T. Manning, hold services today in the basement of-the church, Known as All 'Souls' Lyceum Forum.

PHYLLIS BENTLEY, whose latest novel, "Inheritance," was published last month by the Macmillan Company, was bom in 1894 in Halifax a busy manufacturing town in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Her family on both sides was intimately connected with the local woolen textile industry, and she has early memories of visiting her father's mill and watching the various processes of cloth manufacture.

OUT of feathery snow and silver ice, mountains and fjords and gleaming northern skies, this tale seems woven. It is put together with such delicate fancy and such complete understanding of children that its hero, the little Norwegian boy.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor, is former Borough President of Brooklyn and former State Treasurer and has been actively identified with Republican politics in Brooklyn for twenty years. He has been busy in civic affairs in the borough for the last thirty-eight years, ever since he came to the city from the Middle West to enter the real estate business.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Announcement was made today that the Wartburg Orphans' Farm School, which provides a home for children and aged, caring for more than 450 persons each year and supported largely by the Lutheran churches in the East, will observe its sixty-sixth harvest home festival on Columbus Day, Oct. 12, on the grounds of the institution here.

The Public Schools Athletic League launched its annual series of dual meets for the senior and junior high school team championships in swimming yesterday, and the outstanding performance was achieved by Nathan Cannon of George Washington High School, who covered 50 yards breast stroke in 0:31 4-5, narrowly missing the league record.

PARIS, Oct. 8 (AP). -- Dispatches from Geneva tonight said the French delegation there had formulated a plan linking the ideas of universal security and progressive disarmament over a ten-year period.

YOU land in the free, sovereign and independent republic of Haiti and watch your luggage safely through an American-administered custom service. You ride up to your hotel in a broken-down American automobile over smooth, American-built avenues, dodging on the way an American locomotive pulling cars of cane for an American sugar mill, and passing the marine-commanded police station.

THE last three years of uncertainty and depression have not been without their effects on our colleges and universities. The effects in some cases have been grave and disturbing, but if it is true that the bottom of the economic trend has been reached the American system of higher education as a whole seems to have come through without profound dislocation.

Exports from the United States to Mexico in August amounted to $3,057,624, when Mexico again took first place among all Latin-American countries as purchaser of United States products, according to Jose Miguel Bejarano, secretary of the Mexican Chamber of Commerce here and honorary commercial attache of the Mexican Government.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: Some time ago there was a note in the Book Review section concerning my bibliography on the works of James Joyce, requesting translations and editions in foreign languages. Of the letters I have received there is one which, I believe, will be of particular interest to your readers, and I am, therefore, taking the liberty to quote it, in part.

FAR transcending in importance any other art event of the week must be esteemed the "unveiling" of a piece of archaic Greek sculpture last Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum. This statue of the "Apollo" type was fashioned (sculptor unknown) perhaps all of 2,500 years ago, about 600 B.C.
