LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 8 (AP). -- A speedy, hard-hitting Oklahoma squad -- the first in the regime of Coach Lewie Hardage -- defeated Kansas, 21 to 6, today in the opening of the Big Six Conference football season before a crowd of 7,200.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- Let It not he assumed that George Higgins Moses is sure to be returned to Washington for another term as senior Senator from New Hampshire. Prevailing opinion outside the State is founded on the fact that he had no opposition in the primary, but the nomination is one thing and this year it is certain that the election may well be something else.

PANAMA, R.P., Oct. 4. -- Both Calombia and Peru will find a common enemy in the jungles of the upper Amazon in the malaria and other tropical diseases that probably will take greater toll of life than the battles that may be fought over possession of the Colombian frontier village of Leticia, from which Colombian officials were expelled last month by an irregular force of Peruvians.

IT is an unfortunate circumstance that short factual histories of the American nation, written with true literary quality, have been few. Interpretive history has for obvious reasons proved more attractive to masters of the subject; and in such books as Woodrow Wilson's "American People," Samuel E. Morison's "Oxford History of the United States" and Charles and Mary Beard's "Rise of American Civilization" it has been brought to a high level.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- There was a marked drop in the value of the dollar this morning in unofficial trading here, the fall being 7 1/2 centimes from 25 francs 48 1/2 centimes to 25 francs 41 centimes.

Henry Hall Duncklee, who begins his thirty-third year as organist for the Collegiate Dutch Reformed Church, West End Avenue at Seventy-seventh Street, today, received only a couple of lines to that effect in the church, program last Sunday, because anniversary years are impressive, according to Mr. Duncklee, only when they are divisible by 5.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Frank McErlane, who was reputed to be Chicago's most vicious gang killer, died today of pneumonia in the Schmitt Memorial Hospital in Beardstown, Ill. Survivor of twenty years of bullet-filled warfare, McErlane was the third gangster of importance to die a natural death.
THE amateur musician and electrical musical instruments for the home came up last month at the Berlin Wireless Exhibition. The London Times published the following account on Aug. 20:

Vox Populi Runs Amuck. It has been a very bad year for the smoke-filled room. We refer, of course, to the hotel room in which half a dozen bosses smoke big cigars and decide who shall be nominated for President, Governor, Mayor, and who shall not; and that, my friends, is Democracy!

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: There are a few statements in Waldemar Kaempffert's review of Hogben's "Genetic Principles in Medicine and Social Science" which may convey an incorrect impression of the views and aims of eugenists.

BY profession Amos Petrie is a solicitor, and he admits that he is a brilliant one. He admits, furthermore, that he is a great fisherman and the best detective in Europe. What is more to the point, Scotland Yard seems to be of the same opinion, at least in so far as his detective abilities are concerned.

WITH this new novel. Mr. Faulkner has taken a tremendous stride forward. To say that "Light in August" is an agtonishing performance is not to use the word lightly. That somewhat crude and altogether brutal power which thrust itself through his previous work is in this book disciplined to a greater effectiveness than one would have believed possible in so short a time.

EACH Autumn brings a number of important intercollegiate football games to the gridirons of New York City, and the present season is no exception. Thousands of those who attend these contests will drive their cars to the local stadiums, and for these motorists the accompanying map, specially prepared, may prove of benefit.

The speech from the throne, read at the opening of the Canadian Parliament at Ottawa last week by the Earl of BESSBOROUGH, called on that body to approve the St. Lawrence waterway treaty as soon as the United States Senate had ratified it. How soon our Senate will act, and in what sense, is difficult to predict with certainty.

The Erasmus Hall High School eleven, undefeated in all eight of its games last year, registered its second triumph in as many starts this season by repulsing Brooklyn Technical High, 6 -- 0, before a crowd of 6,000 at Erasmus Field yesterday.

THE past year has not been a fruitful one for the growth of public libraries. The curtailment of incomes, both their own and those of their patrons, naturally brought about a reduction in the number and value of their acquisitions.

The maintenance of educational standards as represented by the type of teacher who can be attracted to the profession only by the assurance of a cultural wage was emphasized yesterday in the third radio appeal of the teachers to the public for support in their efforts to protect their salaries against proposed reductions.

Messages from President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt concerning the international celebration of founders' day by the Young Men's Christian Association on Tuesday, the 111th birthday of the late Sir George Williams, who organized the first association in London in 1844, were made public yesterday by the National Y.M.C.A. Headquarters here.

BERLIN, Oct. 8. -- The week-end found the Boerse listless and uneven following reactions abroad and uncertainty over the foreign political outlook. There was no unloading, however, and most of the favorites maintained yesterday's levels. Gelsenkirchen and the shipping stocks were in limited demand.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Captain E.F. Carter, former Irish champion, and A.C. Schwartz, both of the home club, won low-net prize in a Long Island amateur best-ball tournament on the Sands Point links today.

Two hundred and fifty women volunteers will begin making garments tomorrow at the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, converting the first consignment of 30,000; yards of government cotton cloth into clothes for the needy, it was announced yesterday.

Unless Francis Pappalardi, who was born in this country eighteen years ago, obtains a passport to the United States before February, 1933, he will face conscription in the Italian Army and the possible loss of his American citizenship, according to a statement yesterday of Dr. Irene Slachta, head of Immigrant Aid, an auxiliary organization of one of the divisions of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, 477 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Diplomatic, official and resident society to the number of more than 1,000 guests attended the brilliant reception given at the Egyptian Legation by Sesostris Sidarouss Pasha, Minister of Egypt, in celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of the accession of his sovereign, King Fuad I, to the throne in 1917.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The University of Alabama overpowered George Washington University today by a score of 28 to 6 before nearly 20,000 spectators, one of the largest crowds ever to see a game in Washington.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 9. -- As all diplomatic officials and foreign residents have feared, the anti-Japanese movement is now taking on a general anti-foreign aspect in many parts of China. Various guilds and organizations which have profited by barring Japanese merchandise are now embarking upon a widespread boycott against all imports, and they are infusing the "Buy China Products" with elements of bittter anti-foreignism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What do you most desire? I got an answer to that question on a recent Sunday while walking along a back street in Astoria. The street is a survival from happier times. It Is lined with mansions in the Victorian style; spacious grounds, old trees and an air of dignified wellbeing.

As a corollary step in directing the attention of consumers to quality goods, growing support is being given by many retailers to plans aimed at prolonging the seasonal period in which, such merchandise may profitably be sold. The staging of early clearances, in many cases before customers have begun to buy initial requirements for the season, is being challenged as an ill-advised procedure that should be eliminated.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 8 -- If Franklin D. Roosevelt cannot carry Washington, it would seem that he cannot win any of the Pacific Coast States. Should his predicted victory in this Commonwealth by 50,000 to 100,000 sweep in the Democratic candidate for Senator, and especially the party nominee for Congress in Seattle, the votes will sow a crop of dragon's teeth for Mr. Roosevelt as President.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- President Hoover will make his next campaign speech in Ohio, the White House announced today, stating, however, that the date and city,where the address will be delivered have not yet been decided.

CHICAGO. THE extent of the collapse of Samuel Insull's vast utility empire, which was spread across thirty-two States, is now being fully realized. More than 77,000 stockholders in two corporations he created have been completely wiped out.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., Oct. 8 -- The Stanford Indians overcame the Santa Clara Broncos by 14 -- 0 in their annual football game today. Although Stanford kept the ball a large part of the time Santa Clara fought stubbornly.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Insistent questioning by the police throughout the night disclosed here today a drama of the shifting affection of a mother from a son who had been killed to an attitude of protection for another son who is charged with the murder of his brother.

Acting Mayor McKee, United States Senator Wagner, Mrs. J. Borden Harriman and several other nationally prominent men and women will participate in a Democratic forum on major campaign issues and the Democratic platform, to be held next Wednesday and Thursday at Democratic headquarters, Hotel Biltmore, under the auspices of the Women's Democratic Union, and the Democratic National Campaign Committee.

DARIEN, Sept. 13. -- If the laws of the, land are to be taken as a criterion, the door to trade in Manchurion is wide open. One can search the statute books of Manchukuo and the Kwantung leased territory and find little or no trace of discrimination in favor of Japanese goods as against those of the United States or any other nation.

Declining trends continued in most of the principal commodities last week on the local exchanges, although firmer prices appeared in some coffee contracts. There was fair activity in cocoa, silk and rubber futures, all of which sagged, while other commodities declined in dull trading.

BECOMING curious as to what the hinterland of America is really like, Mr. Morris Markey, well known in New York as a journalist of parts, last year loaded himself and his belongings into an automobile of a humble but familiar brand and set forth to find out.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Coming back after a poor showing against Niagara, Cornell defeated the University of Richmond, 27-0, on Schoelkopf Field today. The score duplicated the tally of last year's game.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Hoover journeyed to Des Moines on Tuesday and there, in the heart of agricultural discontent, spoke his mind.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- The yo-yo furor, which was introduced into France at Deauville last month, is now at its height in Paris. The other night William K. Vanderbilt Jr. gave a dinner at which tiny gold yo-yos, double spinning tops of gyroscopic qualities, not much bigger than a dime and worked on a silk thread, were offered as favors for the women.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson was certified officially today as the Democratic nominee for Governor of Texas under a Supreme Court decision ordering her name placed on the November general election ballot.

THE departure of a group of titled political prisoners from Spain to Villa Cisneros on the African shore, close to the Sahara, is one more chapter in the tragic history of exile. Whether for political or criminal offenses, the confinement of men far from their homeland is a black record of in humanity.
Registration week for the election on Nov. 8 will start here tomorrow with both, major parties making intensive drives to get a large total of listed voters.

IF we were privileged to pay a surprise visit, let us say, to Balmoral in Scotland, where the royal family of Great Britain usually resorts for the shooting, we might happen to see two elderly men one of them with a gray beard and the other with horn-rimmed spectacles, sitting at ease in some quiet corner and evidently enjoying each other's company.

Although sales of small houses constituted the bulk of real estate activity in New Jersey yesterday, the transactions reported covered a wide variety and extended over a scattered area. The Jersey trading featured the market in the metropolitan area.

ABOARD SS. EUROPA, Oct. 8. -- With his holiday nearing an end, former Mayor James J. Walker smiled tonight in an interview with newspaper correspondents at the "novelty" of stepping ashore in his native city tomorrow in the capacity -- for the first time in twenty-three years-- of one who is neither holding public office nor seeking public office.

The National Electric Products Corporation, three of its officers and directors and A. Penn Denton, described as engineering director of the National Electrical Manufacturing Association, were named defendants yesterday in an anti-trust suit filed in United States District Court by the Circle Flexible Conduit Company, Inc.

IT cannot be said that the announcement mada by the University of Chicago to celebrate the return of Professor Arthur H. Compton to his laboratory adds anything that Professor Compton did not himself say in newspaper dispatches from the tropics and the Far North or in letters which appeared in The Physical Review.

AN exhibition of American craft work at the Art Centre presents, for the first time in New York, a view of decorative handwork which includes examples from all parts of the country. In it are represented the New York Society of Craftsmen, the Boston Society of Craftsmen, the Philadelphia Guild of Arts and Crafts, the Detroit Society of Arts and Crafts, and also craft workers on the Pacific Coast and in the Southern States.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 8 -- Canada's increasing gold output Will be an important stabilizing factor in her future finances, Charles McCrea, Minister of Mines for Ontario, said this week in an address to lawyers attending the convention here of the American Life Insurance Association.

Reference was made the other day in our Berlin correspondence to the use which HITLER is making of the doctrine of Nordic race superiority as originated by a Frenchman and developed by an Englishman. The Frenchman was Count GOBINEAU of nearly a century ago. The Englishman was HOUSTON STEWART CHAMBERLAIN, son-in-law of the great WAGNER.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 30. -- So far no official statement has been issued here indicative of the Peruvian Government's attitude toward the Leticia affair. Everything, however, points to a desire for peace, and there is no suggestion of war talk among the generality of the population of the capital, no public demonstrations, even of a minor kind, having occurred in the capital up to the present.

MORE comfortable buses probably air-conditioned; better interline connections and improved terminals were among the promises for the near future held out to the millions of bus travelers by speakers at the sixth annual convention of the National Association of Motor Bus Operators, which recently took place in Chicago.

IT would be difficult to devise a more striking tribute to the reliability of ocean travel by airship, as exemplified by the old Graf Zeppelin, than the option offered by the Hamburg-American steamship line, in connection with its recently announced triangular tours from North America to Europe and back by way of South America, of using the airship for the South Atlantic leg of the journey.

SINCE the vogue for talking pictures the screen has received much help from the stage, and an interesting instance of this is the film conception of the Clemence Dane play, "A Bill of Divorcement," which is now enjoying merited success at the Mayfair.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 8 -- Penn State lost to Waynesboro, 7 to 6, today, the visitors scoring their touchdown in the final minute of play.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 8. -- The hands of time were turned back more than 100 years here tonight when the John Drew Memorial Theatre of Guild Hall was transformed into a London theatre of a century ago and John Howard Payne's "Clari, the Maid of Milan," in which "Home, Sweet Home," was first sung, was presented by the Columbia University Players as it was produced originally in Covent Garden in 1823.
PARIS, Oct. 8. -- Increasing discontent over the decline in the price of wheat in France was manifested today in various producing regions which are demanding government action.

A demonstration of 300 cancer cases of all types that were permanently cured as the result of early diagnosis and application of surgery, radium and X-rays, held recently in various Boston hospitals as part of a campaign of public education on the vital importance of early treatment of the disease, was described here yesterday by Dr. George W. Bigelow, Health Commissioner of Massachusetts.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 8. -- The Bates eleven, which held Yale to a scoreless tie a week ago, was defeated by Tufts today, 14 to 0, before an overflow crowd on the Tufts Oval.

Further weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the result of "discouraged selling" and renewed speculative operations for the decline, in the judgment of Wall Street, as reflected in the commission house comment. The discouragement was ascribed to conditions within the market itself rather than to fresh outside influences.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Hartwick College defeated the New York Aggies, 7 to 6, in a hard-fought game today. Shaw dashed 15 yards around right end for Hartwick's touchdown in the first period and Powell hit the line for the extra point.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 8. -- The government's efficient and considerate handling of the problems born of the revolt is being favorably commented on by residents of the State of Sao Paulo, where hostilities centred. They willingly offer cooperation in order speedily to normalize the State's life.

The government of Soviet Russia is not a personal dictatorship, of Josef Stalin, Professor Harry. F. Ward of Union Theological Seminary, chairman of the American Civil liberties Union, told more than 200 guests at a luncheon in his honor at the Hotel Woodstock yesterday.

Lewis H. Pounds, the Republican candidate for Mayor, revealed last night that his wife had scolded him for accepting the nomination, and at the same time Mrs. Pounds asserted that she was "not very jubilant" over it. Mrs. Pounds intimated that she was more interested in her five grown-up children and her seven grandchildren than in her husband's political fortunes.

GENEVA, Oct. 8 -- The most impressive thing when the Lytton report was given out at 1 P.M. here Sunday was the silence that fell over the journalists. There were some sixty of them, of many nationalities, waiting for it in the lobby of the Disarmament Building.

HARTFORD, Oct. 6. -- Connecticut's small-town elections occurred this week without much political significance, and the chief event affecting the political campaign was the great handshaking tableau at Albany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended in Oct. 1 totaled 622,075 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 26,329 cars more than in the preceding week, 155,637 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 349,180 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago. Increases were reported in all commodities except live stock.

With the baseball season over, a financial survey shows an interesting parallel between conditions in ordinary commercial lines and in sports. Baseball enthusiasts had money to spend, but this year they were more particular in their purchases than usual. With less in pocket, they wanted a better article for their money, so to speak.

TALES of an enduring love are rarely met with nowadays; almost as rarely as novels whose leading male characters are gentlemen. But this new novel by A.E. W. Mason tells of a love which endured for some eighteen hundred years, and of three gallant gentlemen who were one.

To fill existing vacancies in the rank of captain in the Fire Department from, the civil service list which expired at midnight last night, Fire Commissioner Dorman promoted forty-six men yesterday to the ranks of lieutenant, captain, battalion chief and deputy fire chief.

IN developing the story of his World War service. General Peyton C. March used the utmost license in discussing both men and events. He cannot feel aggrieved, therefore, if others exercise a similar freedom in speaking of him. The careful reader of General March's story cannot fail to be impressed by its two outstanding features.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 8 -- Joseph P. Tumulty, Secretary to Woodrow Wilson, was the principal speaker at Democratic rallies at West Hartford this afternoon and at New Britain this evening. His principal theme was prohibition.

Former Governor Smith's evident intention, to campaign for the Democratic ticket in the Eastern States, in which lie the main elements of his political strength, has resulted in his lieutenants and adders falling in line to support the Roosevelt-Garner slate.

A committee of prominent lawyers was named yesterday to direct the independent campaign of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch against State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer, bipartisan nominees for the Supreme Court bench.

The largest of the decorative metal plaques which will form a part of the extensive ornamentative scheme for Rockefeller Center has been set in place on the north wall of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum sound motion picture theatre.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange decreased 133,761 shares last month to 1,800,886 shares on Oct. 3, reflecting covering operations by bears on the decline from the prices of early September, according to the monthly tabulation issued yesterday by the Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Playing the finest round of her career, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, representing the Philadelphia Country Club, defeated Miss Edith Quier of the home club, 8 and 6, in the final round of the Berthellyn Cup tournament over the Huntingdon Valley Country Club course.

Discussing the high premium rate often paid for insuring buildings against fire, Sidney J. Kovner, a real estate broker of 290 Broadway says that often a small oversight such as floors beneath stoves not properly protected, waste in the bottorn of elevator shafts, untidiness and ashes in the cellar and the presence of ash and waste cans, not of metal, with other careless factors, frequently result in the payment of high premiums.

The first of this year's students concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was conducted by Arturo Toscanini at Carnegie Hall last night. The program, the same as that of Thursday and Friday, included Bach-Schonberg's Prelude and Fugue in E-flat, Brahm's Third Symphony, Tansman's Four Polish Dances and Debussy's "La Mer."

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- Germany's acceptance of the proposed London conference on equality of rights in armaments has reopened the whole discussion between Paris and London and seems likely to continue the series of errors and misunderstandings that have characterized the past conversations until finally some agreement is reached.

To the Dramatic Editor: Will you permit me to protest mildly that the gentleman who quoted me in an interview in last Sunday's TIMES credits me with sentiments of which I am quite innocent? The interviewer says:

PRESIDENT HOOVER'S recent plea for the elimination of child labor directs attention to the steady progress of the forces which have battled this evil. Conditions a quarter of a century ago led to an organized movement to do away with the employment of minors, especially in work injurious to health.

When a new liner arrives in port, as the Rex did last Friday morning, New York rises to the occasion handsomely. Long before she is due the carnival spirit hangs over the edge of the puffing harbor bustle. The holiday bunting on the fireboat at the Battery and the line of rippling flags strung over a Coast Guard vessel at Staten Island already aunounce the main event of the day.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct 6 -- Vermont Republicans took the expected action at their State convention in Montpelier on Oct. 4 of endorsing the Republican national platform and the policies of the Hoover Administration in general. Only on the prohibition issue was any real difference of opinion expressed.
METROPOLITAN MUSEUM -- Archaic Greek statue put on view Wednesday in the Room of Recent Accessions. Comment in the art column Oct. 5 and on this page.

The port of New York is described as "as hopelessly out of date as it well could be" and the victim of archaic laws, in a discussion of port charges and pier rents in the current Maersk Fleet News, house organ of the Isbrandtsen - Moller Company, which operates ships between New York and the Far East.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Don Kellett, star three-letter athlete from Brooklyn, featured the attack for Pennsylvania as the Red and Blue trounced Swarthmore College, 54 to 0, today. A crowd of more than 25,000 was at Franklin Field and witnessed the thirty-fifth meeting between these district rivals.

DETROIT. THE Buick plants are beginning to operate on a nine-hour day, five-day week schedule, and by the middle of the month all are expected to be functioning again. The program involves the disposal of preliminaries to the introduction of the 1933 models, although no date is set for their appearance.

Leaders of the State and nation and others prominent in civic work joined with the employes of the Health Department yesterday in felicitating Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne upon the completion of Twenty-five years of service in that department.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 8. -- Rhode Island, smallest State in the Union and densest in population, is winning a ten-year battle to reduce deaths from motor accidents on its city and State highways, thronged throughout the year with heavy local and interstate traffic.

Good Advice, by Wise Counsellor front Wise Mother, was neglected completely at Jamaica yesterday, but finished first at 10 to 1 in the most thrilling finish of the meeting in the Baldwin Handicap. Under a strong ride by Robby Robertson, the Catawba Stable color-bearer nosed out the Arden Farms' Quel Jeu, which in turn was a head before Lee Rosenberg's Kerry Patch, winner of the Futurity.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 8 -- Purdue, co-champion of the Big Ten last year, served notice in terms of power today that it intends to carry on from where the 1931 fight was dropped, with a 7-to-0 victory over the University of Minnesota. A crowd of 20,000 saw the game.

The operating loss of the United Cigar Stores Company of America, which had reached $2,400,000 at the end of the first six months of this year and $3,000,000 by the end of July, was increased further by a loss of $1,417,000 in August, according to testimony yesterday at a hearing in the bankruptcy case before Referee Irwin Kurtz in the Woolworth Building.

HELSINGFORS, Sept. 27.-- At the end of a Bummer during which the heat has been above the normal, Finland views tile near future with optimism. The feeling that the worst of the depression has passed is gaining ground. The resolute stand taken by the government against the restless elements has resulted in their practical dissolution, and the political horizon is, consequently, more reassuring.

FOR ten stormy years David Graham Phlllipa lived in the white light of publicity. The author of some twenty-six challenging books, he was pre-eminently in and of the Rooseveltian decade of the Strenuous Life. His articles on "The Treason of the Senate," published in 1906 in Hearst's Cosmopolitan, evoked the epithet, "muck-raker," from the President in a famous Gridiron Club speech -- and so an era received its name because of Phillips.

A letter from Governor Roosevelt answering a question on the prohibition issue asked in a letter by the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street, was made public yesterday by Dr. Reisner, who is an ardent dry.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 8. -- Acting Governor E.J. Waddington, in the speech from the throne at the reopening of the Bermuda Parliament today, declared that the colony's financial outlook was unsatisfactory and stressed the need for the utmost government economy.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 8 -- G.E. Mole broke 99 out of 100 targets to lead a field of nineteen gunners in a registered shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- The hasty formation of the von Papen-von Schleicher "national concentration" Government last June accelerated the clamor for a revision of the Weimar Constitution, defects in which are now freely asserted by its former defenders.

RADIO is now moving into the best months for the indoor sport of tuning. The crisp air and frost of Autumn not only tint the leaves but add sparkle to the tone color of broadcasting. The Summer static is gone and unless a freak lightning storm happens to come along the programs will no longer be freckled with splashes of atmospherics.

A CLARIFYING statement of conditions in China was contained in the long-awaited Lytton commission's report, made public a few days ago, but this was overshadowed because general Interest was centred on the commission's recommendations to the League concerning Manchuria. Here is a picture of China today, based on a first-hand study in various parts of the country by the members of the commission.

Joseph W. Harriman, founder of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, and other officers of the hank were directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Shientag to testify before trial in a suit brought by Margaret Singleton against Mr. Harriman and the bank.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- After hearing speeches urging closer attention to "beginners in crime" and the social and psychological causes behind their acts, two hundred delegates to the annual conference of the State Association of Magistrates left for home tonight.
VIENNA, Sept. 30, 1932. PROPOSALS are already under consideration for next year's Salzburg Festival program. Negotiations with the artists whom it is desired to engage in 1933 begin next month.

BARRIE, Ont., Oct. 8. -- Martin J. Insull was freed from the Simcoe County jail here this evening on $50,000 bail, posted by an American surety company. He returned to the small town of Orillia, twenty-four miles from here, to join Mrs. Insull and there to await the battle against extradition for trial in Chicago on charges of embezzlement and larceny in connection with the crash of the Insull utility system.

PARIS. THERE is greatly increased activity at present at the Farman aircraft factory at Billancourt, where a monoplane designed to conquer the sky's loftier regions has been under construction for more than three years.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will open the twentieth season of the Institute of Arts and Sciences of the university on the night of Oct. 17 at the McMillin Academic Theatre with an address, on. "Ideals in American Political Thought."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Stoddard's claim that the metric system should not be brought into use because of its incompatibility with our system of circular measure is another of those statements made by both proponents and opponents of the metric system that are entirely irrelevant to the real issue.
Lewis H. Pounds of Brooklyn, former State Treasurer and former fusion President of his home borough, was nominated for Mayor last night at the Republican City Convention meeting at Mecca Temple.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Amherst scored twice in the first half to down Union College, 12-to-0, today.

Governor ROOSEVELT has been rashly accused by a Republican orator of gloating over the "miseries" of the American people, and planning to make political capital for himself out of them. Let this go for the bit of extreme partisanship which it is. There can be no doubt that the persistence of hard times and its effect upon people out of work or actually in distress must operate against the Republican party in the election.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 8 --The Colgate team started rolling up touchdowns in the second half today after being held to a single score in the first and defeated Niagara, 47 to 0. Clair Lyon, replacing Rowe at fullback, proved a human battering Ram as he made big gains through the line for the Maroon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Henry Lee Stoddard's letter showed an amazing knowledge of the history of mathematics and an equally amazing ignorance of modern mathematics. No person who has ever studied trigonometry would ever suggest that the metric system is not entirely satisfactory "in computing vertical and horizontal angles, distances and heights."

PARIS. MOST of that interesting collection of individuals known as "Tout Paris" has returned to town and the curtain has risen on the second act of the great Winter fashion show, with the style leaders of the world playing the star roles.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8 -- The Yale freshmen opened their football season under a new coach. Reggie Root, today, defeating Exeter Academy 12-7. The losing team proved a stubborn rival and checked the freshmen several times near the Exeter goal line.

BURLESQUE shows on Forty-second Street are closed, thanks to Mayor McKee; the silk-hatted barkers in the lobbies are silent; only lurid posters remain to attract gaping crowds. What significance has the closing of these theatres -- does it mean that New York has changed its ideas of morality?

The suit of the Department of Justice against the Radio Corporation of America and others, which was to have gone to trial tomorrow, has been adjourned for two weeks or more in order to afford representatives of the government and the radio group time to consider new proposals designed to meet some of the principal points at issue.

The Day of Atonement or, as it is known in the Jewish calendar, Yom Kippur, will begin at nightfall today and its celebration by Jews the world over will be continued until twilight tomorrow. The sound of the shofar, the ancient ram's horn blown only on the highest holidays of the year, will call young and old to atonement.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP). -- England's year off the gold standard appears to have brought the nation only very slight basic improvement, financial writers find alter study of government figures.

There was an aerial raid upon the peaceful sheep meadow in Central Park yesterday. More than 125 single-propeller transports, twin-propeller pusher planes and gliders zoomed and nose-dived among the crowd. But there were no casualties, for the planes were models weighing from a fraction of an ounce to two or three ounces each, and their only power was the silent impetus of untwisting rubber bands.
Former Mayor James J. Walker will be welcomed home by Tammany chieftains, district leaders and a number of personal friends when the Europa comes into the harbor this morning.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 8 -- Carroll Cook, sophomore fullback, starred in Villanova's 31-0 victory over Gettysburg today before a crowd of 15,000. Cook scored two of the Wildcats' five touchdowns, his second one being on a spectacular 24-yard run around right end to start the final period.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Cod-liver oil has been poured into British politics as a new symbolic factor in the long fight to come on economic issues. It will do its share of lubricating the swingback of the pendulum from the present Tory protectionism which is reasonably to be expected in the not too distant future.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 -- With a victory over E. Gonzalez Rojo of this city, his second in two days, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris today went into the lead after the second round of the international chess masters' tournament being held under the auspices of the Club de Ajedrez at the Press Social Centre.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 8 -- Coupling a smooth running attack with a rugged defense, Wisconsin opened its Big Ten season under its new coach, Dr. Clarence Spears, with a 34-to-0 victory over Iowa today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 8 -- J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., retained his title in the Hot Springs Fall tennis tournament at the Casino courts today by defeating Arthur MacPherson of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4.

VIENNA, Sept. 28 -- Vienna newspapers report that two women observed changing a tire on their automobile in the Hohe Markt yesterday told bystanders that they were from Cleveland and engaged in a breakneck rush round Europe. When taxi drivers offered to help them change their tire, they said: "That is just what we don't want.

Conditions in Austria, and specifically Vienna, in spite of the depression are better than they were two years ago, according to Dr. Ernst Benedikt, editor and publisher of the Neue Freie Presse, Vienna's leading Liberal daily.

The British Dominions Trust, a commercial banking house which has recently provided credit finance for re-equipment of several industries, has offered to finance new ship construction up to 60 per cent of the total cost. In a pamphlet addressed to British lines the company urges the immediate construction of new tonnage with which to meet the foreign competition for business that should develop when world-wide commercial conditions are improved.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 8 -- Fighting desperately for three quarters to protect a seven-point lead gained in the opening period, Lehigh, mainly through the excellent punting of Captain Chick Halsted, defeated an aggressive Pennsylvania Military College eleven today, 7 to 0.

MAKING her first stage appearance on these shores in Mr. McEvoy's "Americana," which opened on Wednesday night at the Shubert Theatre, is a personable young woman whose distinctly English accent somewhat belies the fact that she was born in Vancouver, B.C., a good many miles west of Broadway, yet came to New York on a boat.

Disclosures by the Hofstadter legislative committee will still be an issue in the Republican campaign to elect Lewis H. Pounds Mayor, despite the acceptance by Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter of a Tammany endorsement for Supreme Court justice, speakers at the city convention of that party at Mecca Temple indicated last evening.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 1 (By Air Mail). -- Paraguay is engaged in war with Bolivian troops in the Chaco. But there is little enthusiasm here for war.

BARCELONA, Sept. 27. -- The Catalan autonomy statute having been finally approved by the Cortes, the Catalans are giving their Immediate attention to the problems of transition and to the reorganization of the new Generalitat government which must supplant the existing provisional regime.

ANOTHER REPORTER IT appears to be a habit of English-speaking people to designate a formal report by the name of its signer or chief investigator rather thari by the subject examined. Thus, the British have had their Simon and Montagu reports on India and their May report on government finances; during the war the Bryce report on atrocities stirred up easy credulity.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Under a good breeze and the light of the October moon, fourteen yachts took part in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's final cruising race of the season. Robert Jacob's yawl Nimbus won, on corrected time, by 13 minutes and 42 seconds from George E. Roosevelt's schooner Mistress, which beat George F. Hubbard's sloop Sally IX. by 2 minutes and 15 seconds.

THIRTY YEARS have passed since Frank Norris died -- and the author of two of the most formidable books in American fiction, "McTeague" and "The Octopus." has waited until now for his first full-length biography. It has been a long wait, but it has resulted in a fairly good, conscientious job.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8. -- The University of Pittsburgh defeated Duquesne University today in the first inter-city game between the two colleges, 33 to 0. A crowd of 25,000 attended.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8 -- A versatile University of Indiana football team surprised a confident Ohio State eleven today and gained a 7-to-7 tie with the Buckeyes in the opening Western Conference game hero before 17,000 persons.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 8 -- A vastly improved Naval Academy football team came back from last week's setback by William and Mary to overpower Washington and Lee today, 33 to 0.

THIS small but authoritative book comes at a timely moment and ought to exercise a wholesome Influence in the controlling and the subjecting to reason and knowledge of the craze for sun-bathing, sun-tanning, sun-lamp treatments, nudism and the allied fads that are sweeping the country.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 8 -- A sensational second-half attack gave the Upsala College eleven a 24-to-2 victory over the Montclair State Teachers College today in the opening game of the season for the losers.

THERE are many eating places in New York, unique, interesting and charming, but nowhere is there anything quite like the Actors' Dinner Club under Loew's State Theatre, at Broadway and Forty-fifth Street.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius K.G. Billings have left the Pierre for their Winter home in Santa Barbara.

A HITHERTO unpublished letter, written forty years ago by Antonin Dvorak soon after his arrival in New York, was made public recently by the Czech author Dr. O. Scurek, in the Prague daily paper Venkov. The letter was written on Oct. 14, 1892, and is addressed to Dvorak's friends at Jaromer in Bohemia.
HERKIMER, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Former Supreme Court Justice Irving Rozelle Devendorf, who presided at the famous Chester Gillette murder case in 1906, died here today. He was 75 years old.
BERKELEY, Cal., Oct. 8. -- California's Golden Bears and St. Mary's Gaels battled to a 12-12 tie today while 45,000 fans cheered them on.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Construction of the world's largest bridge, four and a half miles across San Francisco Bay, at a cost of $70,000,000 became virtually assured today with an announcement by Harvey Couch of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that $62,000,000 in Federal funds had been provided for the purpose.

LONDON, Sept. 22. IT Is Mr. Coward's habit to do well most things to which he puts his hand and to set his distinguishing mark on all of them. His play on war, "Post-Mortem," comparable in theme with. "Miracle at Verdun," has not been performed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- An increase of 115,000 bales over last month's estimate of the 1932 cotton crop was announced by the Agriculture Department today in a report predicting a crop of 11,425,000 bales on the basis of conditions Oct. 1. Even with this increase the current year's estimated production is 5,671,000 bales under the 1931 total.

The football fortunes of Manhattan College continued to prosper yester- day as Chick Meehan's Jaspers, with a convincing show of speed and strength, overwhelmed Seton Hall College of South Orange, N.J., 31 -- 0. A crowd of 10,000 saw the contest at Ebbets Field, witnessing Manhattan's second triumph of the season.

LONDON. An author who modestly describes himself as "a third-rate novelist" has started in The Manchester Guardian a first-rate discussion on the canons of reviewing. He tells us that he published this Summer a new novel.

With scarcely an exception city pastors will be back in their pulpits this morning. With today the Summer vacation is over and the vast majority of churches are back on their full Winter schedule. Not a few of the pastors, will refer to the mayoralty situation in this city and several will devote their entire sermon to the subject.

WHILE rainy weather reduced volume somewhat, retail trade made a good showing during most of the week. Consumer buying yesterday was reported as exceptionally brisk. Purchasing centred largely on women's apparel and home furnishings, with business in men's wear registering a pick-up as compared with recent weeks.

Edward Guthrie Kennedy, art collector, and friend of James A. McNeill Whistler, who had for many years, been one of the leading dealers in prints in the city, died last night at his home, 375 Park Avenue, of arterial sclerosis, after an illness that began last April.

Unemployment insurance is one of the uppermost questions in the minds of the American public as shown by its inclusion in the platform of the Democratic party, by the passage of an Unemployment compensation act in Wisconsin, and by the investigation of its possibilities by a committee of Congress.

The recent quarterly reports of changes in the numbers of stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation and the General Motors Corporation indicate that the rapid increase in the number of shareholders of large corporations which occurred during the last three years, was checked in the third quarter of this year by the rapid rise of the stock market.

THIS is the account of a visit to a unique and fascinating village which has the distinction of being a very small kingdom and a very great power. It is ruled by modest men, now also meek, who, unlike political rulers, dislike to be quoted and refuse to admit their authority.

THE audience that witnessed the premiere of "A Bill of Divorcement" at the Mayfair recently was treated to the reasonably unique procedure of listening to John Barrymore and Billie Burke take curtain calls 3,000 miles away. George Cukor, the director, speaking over an NBC network from Hollywood, introduced Mr. Barrymore.

Mr. Curtis Is Disputed. It seems to me that the people of the East do not realize that unless the farmers prosper, everybody else must suffer. Here in Iowa oats are selling for 9 cents a bushel, when it costs 28 cents a bushel to produce them; corn is selling at 16 cents a bushel, and It costs 42 cents to raise it.

KINGSTON, R.I., Oct. 8. -- The Boston University eleven defeated Rhode Island, 7 to 0, today after a close battle, Le Guern scoring a touchdown in the final period. Clem kicked a placement for the extra point.

Active selling of United States Government bonds, especially the Treasury 3 1/8s, was attended yesterday by lower prices for most of the active series on the New York Stock Exchange. A string of forty sales of $50,000 and one of $1,000 of the 3 1/2s appeared on the tape just before the close of the market, a total of $2,001,000, occasioning a decline of 1/8 for the day.

A complete investigation into the administration of the bankruptcy statutes in the Southern District of New York will be undertaken shortly, as the result of the organization during the week of a committee on bankruptcy of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON. THE adding machines are not so busy, fewer large deposit slips are being made out in the offices of the treasurers of national political committees this year than in former Presidential campaigns.

A study of the book values of the shares of twenty-three banks in this city, as disclosed in their statements for the third quarter of the year which were issued last week, compared with current market prices of the shares, shows that the average market price is 1.23 times the average book value.

Reports from the Federal Reserve centres throughout the country last week indicated that bath retail and wholesale trade continued to expand. The statements of condition of banks, especially in the Chicago district, confirmed reports of a return of public confidence, for deposits on Sept. 30 were generally larger than at the end of June.

Two kennel events will have the attention of metropolitan district fanciers this week. First is the specialty show of the American FOX Terrier Club, combining the annual and Summer events, at the Grand Central Palace on Friday, the exhibition opening at 9 A.M. and running all day.

GERMANY'S demand for equality is natural, not only natural but essentially and fundamentally just. The desire for equality in all respects in the family of nations is inherent and inextinguishable in the hearts and minds of every self-respecting people.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 -- Johns Hopkins University triumphed, 13 to 0, over St. John's of Annapolis today. A crowd of 5,000 packed Homewood Field to witness the clash between the two Maryland rivals.

BUENOS AIRES. HAVING resorted to political and military remedies two years ago as a painless cure for its economic ills, South America is finding it extremely difficult to throw off the effects of the narcotics.

TO Patricia Collinge, an actress who was giving an excellent account of herself in local theatricals even before the days when she created the part of Pollyanna, will go the leading feminine role in "Autumn Crocus," performed in London by Fay Compton.

Major points in Acting Mayor McKee's economy program are omitted in the 1933 tentative budget, which will be considered at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning by the Board of Estimate, it was learned yesterday at City Hall.

EARLY November will offer two festive entertainments that will be among the most colorful of the Autumn -- the second annual Peacock Ball for the benefit of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor and the annual Victory Ball to aid the work of the New York County Welfare Committee.

WITH the laying of the cornerstone of the new Supreme Court Building at Washington next Thursday there will be at last a certainty that the most powerful tribunal in the world, for nearly a century and a half a tenant of outgrown legislative chambers and other even less appropriate quarters, will soon have a home of its own, fully commensurate with its dignity.

BERLIN. WHAT about the Junkers, of whom so much used to be heard? What role are they playing in the tangled affairs of present-day Germany? Well, they are still here, though in somewhat diminished numbers, and as to what they are doing it may be said that although the exigencies of the political situation recently elevated less than a dozen of them to Cabinet rank, for the most part they are waiting.
GENEVA, Oct. 8. -- The disarmament conference's bureau will not meet Monday, as previously fixed. Arthur Henderson, after he arrives tomorrow, will announce a new date, probably in mid-October.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8. -- Fumbles by Syracuse University ball carriers and a well executed aerial attack on their own part gave Ohio Wesleyan a 19-12 victory over the Orangemen today as 15,000 fans watched the game.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- West Chester State Teachers, on an intercepted pass and a 50-yard run by Guarani, defeated St. Joseph College today, 6 to 0.

THE story of the bathysphere dive of 1932 begins at 7 o'clock on the morning of Aug. 31. At that time several craft converged toward an ugly little shed of corrugated iron on a wharf to the west of St. George's, Bermuda. Little bum-boats brought engineers and carpenters, and toward the wharf steamed a huge, open-decked tug, the Freedom, which was this year, to be the mother control boat.

American manufacturers meeting at the Hotel Astor Tuesday to debate ways and means for improving Russian-American trade relations will learn that the Amtorg Trading Corporation, representative' in the United States of the Soviet, has turned down the proposal for a modified form of barter between American producers and Russia.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. S. -- Cornelius V. Whitney's The Darb, a maiden, raced to a surprise victory over eleven other 2-year-olds in the $10,000 added Richard Johnson Stakes, feature of the racing program today at Laurel.

VIENNA, Sept. 28. -- Vienna's famous "heuriger," the wine gardens, mostly situated at the foot of the low hills skirting the city, where every visitor to Vienna goes in search of gayety, are beginning to suffer severely from the economic crisis.

The demand for both gasoline and crude oil declined during August, but stocks of both these commodities were also reduced, which offset in part the adverse effect of the decreased demand, according to William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, in an anlysis of data supplied by the United States Bureau of Mines.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 6. -- As soon as results were certain in the recent primary election, Governor George W. P. Hunt, defeated In his eighth attempt for nomination for Governor, telegraphed congratulations and promise of support to Dr. B. B. Moeur of Tempe, his victorious opponent.

THERE have been books about the war, plays about the war, movies about the war, books and plays and movies portraying its many aspects. But the appalling horrors of all the others pale into something endurable beside the nightmare inferno of the German prison camp of which Sergeant Halyburton writes.

NEW YORK has grown so large that it is easy to forget that she is still a city of islands and a great seaport. Many of her sons and daughters have never been afloat upon the broad waters that enfold the five boroughs -- the Hudson, Harlem, East River, the Staten Island Kills and the majestic lower bay.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Wickham Steed is a leader in British journalism. On the affairs of Europe he is probably the greatest living authority we have in this country. His name will go down in history as that of the observer who foresaw the great war when so few people believed in it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a former critic and writer for several big New York dailies and magazines, long rather prominent on Broadway, and still active here, may I ask yon to publish what follows?

SOUTHERNERS living in New York have arranged their annual dinner and Southern Governors' Ball, which will be held under the auspices of the New York Southern Society on the night of Oct. 21, in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 -- Orville Mohler, Southern California's star quarterback, featured in a passing attack that defeated the Oregon State Beavers, 10 to 0, today at the Olympic Stadium.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Business on the Stock Exchange was small today, with transactions confined mostly to selling. Overnight news from Wall Street and disturbing Continental advices were not helpful. The only favorable trend was in British funds, which gathered strength after a hesitant opening.

SPOKANE, Oct. 8. -- For the second time in its forty-three years of Statehood, Washington will elect a Governor from the eastern part of the State. The last time was in 1908, when Samuel G. Cosgrove was chosen. Death ended his term in two months.

A mass meeting of laymen to organize for "Catholic Action" not in politics as in some foreign countries but in all social moral and religious questions, will be held Tuesday evening in the Assembly Hall of the Church of St. Francis Xavier. Sixteenth Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

POLLY has a passport!" I once heard a parrot scream on the docks of New York and, strange as it may seem, she actually had. For every bird that comes into the United States from a foreign shore has not only a ticket but a passport, and is examined by a special customs official.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Tommy Armour of Detroit, former national open champion, with a score of 143 for thirty-six holes, led the field of sixty-four survivors when the second day's play in the St. Louis open golf tournament was completed late today.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 8. -- In its opening game of the season, the Hill School eleven defeated the Yale second freshman team today, 13-6. Two forward passes in the last minutes of play, both from Jess Spaulding to Lowndes, accounted for the Hill scores. Spaulding drop kicked for the extra point.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Governor Roosevelt today opened the campaign for the election of Herbert H. Lehman to the Governorship with a glowing endorsement of the man he termed his "right arm" before a crowd of 2,000 friends who gathered at the Old Fair Grounds at Washington Hollow for a Roosevelt Neighbors' Day.

BALTIMORE. Md., Oct. 8 -- Baltimore University defeated Cooper Union, 69 to 0, before 1,000 fans at the Baltimore Stadium today. The New York team threatened at only one time during the contest, Brener recovering a Baltimore fumble on the home team's 20-yard line.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 8 -- The Haskell Indians ran the Notre Dame football gauntlet today and received their worst defeat since they were routed by Nebraska way back in 1918.

MANILA. THE United States Army Air Corps has completed successful experiment through, its units at Nichols Field just south of Manila. It has demonstrated the feasibility of operating and supplying emergency camps in the field, throughout the Philippines, independent of land or water transportation.

GILBERT CHESTERTON in an essay on Rudyard Kipling, speaking of things poetical, described the mailbox as the "sanctuary of human words," the place to which friends and lovers commit their messages, "conscious that when they have done so they are sacred, and not to be touched not only by others but even (a religious touch) by themselves," It is "the last of the temples."

ROME, Oct. 7 -- The Fascist Grand Council should have acted last Saturday on the resolution approved at the April session to consider the advisability of Italy resigning from the League of Nations. Those who believed this thorny problem finally would be settled were disappointed, for the Grand Council resolved to postpone consideration of the question till its next session, on Nov. 5.

WITH the movement some time this Fall of the Twentieth Pursuit Group from the West Coast to the new Barksdale Field, Shreveport, La., the Third Attack Wing of the United States Army Air Corps will be taking form along the lines that the heads of our air defense have been planning for years.

ANONYMOUS, old, unskillful, some verses, lost for the most part in a welter of memories, have clung to the mind by the tenuous hold of three or four lines indicating the method through which a bedridden invalid, avid for the joy of travel, made her way by the diagrams of a map and the barren descriptioris of a guide book

ANDOVEK, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Andover and the Harvard freshmen played to a scoreless tie today in a game featured by the strong defensive play of both elevens. The battle was fought between the twenty-yard lines and neither team was able to gain consistently.

EXCEPT in a period of imitation and stagnation, each new literary generation makes it its duty to eat up the last. Anatole France jeered the bureaucracy, the army, the courts, the church, many kinds of people and institutions.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: It we are to believe Mr. Hemingway, high adventure and a lust for blood fuse in the Castilian bullring. One might question wherein a bullfight differs from a dogfight, or a cocking main, or terriers in a ratpit, or shooting at pigeons from a trap, save, indeed, that a bullfight endangers human life.

The railroads have little to feat from the motor omnibus as a competitor in the carrying of passengers, L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, said recently at the annual meeting of the company's freight and ticket agents' association.

RIDGEWAY, Va., Oct. 8. -- In this little township, one of the smallest in Virginia, nobody pays any taxes, for the expense of maintaining the town is borne by liquor money taken in during pre-Volstead days.
Few changes in property control were reported in Manhattan yesterday. The sale of a Harlem flat and a few leasehold deals were announced during a day of mild activity.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8 -- Tulane's big Green wave, riding on the crest of scoring attacks in the first and third quarters, repulsed Georgia's strong finish this afternoon to gain a 34-to-25 victory in its first defense of the Southern Conference football crown.

ONE in a series of several entertainments in behalf of the Lighthouse Music School of the New York Association for the Blind, which is making a special appeal at this time for funds to carry on its charitable work, will be a recital by Albert Spalding, violinist, on the afternoon of Oct. 30 at Carnegie Hall.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. Oct. 8 -- Admirably handled by Miss Aline Rhonie, Mrs. Harry Frank Jr.'s veteran bay mare Alhaja today captured the Orange Lawn Tennis Club horse show trophy in the feature competition of the twelfth annual Orange horse show, held on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Holy Cross easily disposed of the University of Maine football team, 32 to 6, today in a game marked by the versatility of the Purple attack and the inability of the Bears to penetrate the Purple goal-line defense although gaining heavily between the 10-yard lines.

THE Soviet Union and the Five-Year Plan have produced little in the way of conscious humor or satire. "We are making history," said one Moscow editor, apropos of an American correspondent who enjoyed laughing at various Soviet manifestations, "and we must be taken seriously."
ATLANTA, Oct. 6 -- Georgia Democrats, 100 per cent de-Hooverized, met this week in a State convention not equaled for enthusiasm since the days when the Populist party threatened the True Blues.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 8. -- Dartmouth was able to produce only one touchdown today, but that lone score by Sammy Fishman in the third period was enough to turn back a strong Lafayette team, 6-0, in the first meeting between these two elevens in history.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 8. -- Dartmouth was able to produce only one touchdown today, but that lone score by Sammy Fishman in the third period was enough to turn back a strong Lafayette team, 6-0, in the first meeting between these two elevens in history.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 8 -- Brown scored a 13-to-6 victory over Springfield this afternoon in a very stubbornly-fought battle. Brown was held twice for downs inside Springfield's ten-yard line.

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 8 -- A fast Lowell Textile football team, making telling use of a passing game, vanquished City College of New York, 7 to 0, on Textile Field today. Lowell, threatening throughout, seldom was called upon to stave off a dangerous Lavender attack.

IN "A Bill of Divorcement," which with John Barrymore is at the Mayfair, Katharine Hepburn of Broadway is making her first appearance on the talking screen. When RKO officials saw the film in the projection room last month they promptly got out pen and paper and induced the young woman to attach her name to a new contract.

Sociological forces are combining with economic factors to reverse the industrial centralization process of the century prior to 1931 and are compelling a steady dissolution of highly concentrated industries. Harold V. Coes, manager of the industrial department of Ford, Bacon Davis, engineers, told THE TIMES yesterday.

ANDOVEK, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Andover and the Harvard freshmen played to a scoreless tie today in a game featured by the strong defensive play of both elevens. The battle was fought between the twenty-yard lines and neither team was able to gain consistently.

EXCEPT in a period of imitation and stagnation, each new literary generation makes it its duty to eat up the last. Anatole France jeered the bureaucracy, the army, the courts, the church, many kinds of people and institutions.

It appears that the European speculators in foreign exchange are at it again. One costly experience on the short side of the dollar was not sufficient. Foreign exchange dealers are convinced now that the sharp rally of the Continental currencies against the dollar on Thursday and Friday and yesterday was the result of bearish operations based upon a suspicious and possibly mistaken interpretation of President Hoover's Dec Moines address.

LIKE "The Band Wagon," which crystallized the new musical showmanship, "Flying Colors" skims through the evening with incomparable agility, and the reason is not far to seek. It is produced by Max Gordon, who stood godfather to "Three's a Crowd" and "The Band Wagon."

SIR JOHN FALSTAFF is one of a select company of great characters created by genius breathing upon the dust of men long dead. His original was a certain Sir John Oldcastle, under which name he appeared on the earliest playbills; but the Lollard martyr who was admired by Prince Hal was of a different bent -- an assiduous captain on the Welsh Marches in whom a fatal fanaticism grew with the years.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Evalee Hanover, owned and driven by Edward S. Canard of Glen Ridge, broke the Wecquahic Park track record for 2-year-old trotters when she stepped a mile in 2:11 at today's matinee.

WITH the return here of the majority of the members of society from a Summer season of activity elsewhere, much attention is now being given to plans for entertaining debutantes of the coming season. The early weeks of last month were marked by the usual post-Summer dances at Long Islands Westchester and New Jersey country homes and clubs, which served as a prelude to a busy Winter in New York.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 8 -- Chief Abbedale, 3-year-old black son of Abbedale, driven by his owner. J.W. Page of Pasquag. R.I., today eclipsed the field to win the 2:21 class pace in three straight heats on Danbury Fair's final racing card.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 8 -- Taking advantage of the breaks that came to them in the first and second periods, Nebraska withstood a determined Iowa State rally in the final quarter to defeat the Cyclones, 12 to 6, in the rivals' opening Big Six game of the season today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Still in the informal mood which comes when she dons the Girl Scout uniform, Mrs. Herbert Hoover today returned to the White House from Virginia Beach, where she attended the annual convention of the organization.

EXPERIMENTS made this season to provide a night air mail and later passenger service between Frankfort and Cologne and reported to the Department of Commerce by W.L. Lowrie, Consul General at Frankfort-on-Main, reveal the backward state of night flying on the Continent as compared with the United States, where the major airlines do as much as one-third of all their flying between dusk and dawn over the lighted airways.
LAREDO, Texas, Oct. 8 (AP). -- Archbishop Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores, Papal Delegate expelled this week from Mexico, said today he had expected similar expulsion of Archbishop Pascual Diaz.

Excessive taxes "which have made industry and commerce unprofitable" were held to be the cause of the depression here and throughout the world by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, in a radio talk from that city last night over the National Broadcasting Company's network.

The results of any effort made by insurance companies, savings banks and universities more than a year ago to help the railroads were said yesterday to portend success for the National Transportation Committee, the body headed by Calvin Coolidge, which recently was formed by these interests to investigate the railroad situation.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Although Willie Klein, Wheatley Hills pro, permitted his opponent, Walter Kozak, to get far in front of him in the final round of the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship at the Old Westbury Golf Club today, he managed to nip the Engineers Country Club professional at the wire.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following situation and result in a game of contract, which occurred recently, is perhaps as extraordinary as could possibly be encountered at any time:
RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Central High of Newark defeated Ridgefield Park, 13 to 0, today. Hollis Laysears and Jakes accounted for the visitors' touchdowns.
SHENANDOAH, Iowa. Oct. 8 (AP) -- Secretary Hyde told an agricultural audience here today that the tariff principles of the Democratic party would cripple the farmer's finances if put into effect.

The New York Committee of One Thousand announced yesterday that it had voted not to name an independent candidate for Mayor this year because of its inability to obtain the "consent of an available man." The announcement ended the prospect of a fusion movement.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- Honors for best dog in the fourteenth annual Bryn Mawr Kennel Club Show today were won by the wire-haired fox terrier, Ch. Lone Eagle of Earlsmoor, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City.

PARIS, Oct. 8. -- One hundred and eleven seats out of 314 in the French Senate will be filled on Oct. 16 at elections in thirty-two Departments of France proper, and in Constantine, Algeria and Martinique. The Senators thus chosen will take office early in January.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Captain Gil Berry and Pete Yanuskus, the two oldest men of Bob Zuppke's llinois football team, in point of experience, were the main springs in the sometimes errant Illini clockwork as Illinois vanquished Bradley Tech of Peoria, 20 to 0, today.
GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Coming from behind late in the fourth quarter with an effective passing attack, Kenyon College today held Hobart to a 13-13 tie on Boswell Field.

WORCESTER, Sept. 15, 1932. VERDI'S friend Muzio remarks somewhere that the English have an enormous appetite for music. They will listen, he says, to concerts lasting six hours without turning a hair." Three Choirs festival concerts last longer still.
BUDAPEST, Oct. 7. -- The number of army officers or former officers ruling the affairs of Europe was increased last week by one -- General Julius Goemboes, newly named Premier of Hungary.

The probability that the will of Zachary Smith Reynolds, filed for probate here on Friday, will be contested by his widow, Mrs. Libby Holman Reynolds, was pointed out yesterday by lawyers familiar with practice in the Surrogate's Court and with, the decedent estate law of New York.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Oct. 8. -- Spectators gasped when two horses with their riders fell in a tangled heap at the Whitemarsh Valley Hunt Club's annual Fall race meeting today. Kahler, Can-iphell Weir's entry, ridden by J.E. Ryan, tripped after gaining the lead at a jump in the twelfth running for the Pennsylvania Hunt Cup.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Bruises and scratches were found on the body of Arthur Maillefert after it was removed from a "sweatbox" at the Sunbeam prison camp, two undertakers testified today at the trial of two former guards charged with, murdering the youth from Westfield, N.J.

TOKYO, Sept. 17. -- Of the varied impressions brought back from Los Angeles by the Japanese Olympie team, the majority were pleasant but one left a sting. The story, as told in an editorial in the Japan Times, is that when members of the team attempted to enter dance halls or first-class restaurants in Los Angeles they were met at the door with "Mexieans are not admitted."

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP). -- A sensational drive in the stretch today gave J.P. Ehlhardt's Gift of Roses a nose victory over Shepherd Boy, the favorite, in the Au Revoir Purse. feature of the final day of the Lincoln Fieldo meeting.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 8 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt with her daughter, Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis 3d, and Mrs. Davis's daughter arrived at the Homestead today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 8 -- Michigan's title-hunting Wolverines, matching their defensive strength against Northwestern, won by 15 to 6 in the first football game between the two schools in seven years.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Bruises and scratches were found on the body of Arthur Maillefert after it was removed from a "sweatbox" at the Sunbeam prison camp, two undertakers testified today at the trial of two former guards charged with, murdering the youth from Westfield, N.J.

TOKYO, Sept. 17. -- Of the varied impressions brought back from Los Angeles by the Japanese Olympie team, the majority were pleasant but one left a sting. The story, as told in an editorial in the Japan Times, is that when members of the team attempted to enter dance halls or first-class restaurants in Los Angeles they were met at the door with "Mexieans are not admitted."

SHANGHAI, Oct. 8 -- With three regional civil wars continuing despite Nanking's orders and entreaties for peace, the possibilities of early development of a large-scale struggle involving the existence of the Nanking Grovennment are becoming ominous.

Duck hunters, looking ahead to the opening of the season a week from today, may gather some cheer from the fact that fifty flocks, mostly sea ducks, were sighted over Long Island Sound the past week. Many of these landed along the North Shore of Long Island and are feeding there now.

Surrounded in the House of Commons by a crowd of Tories imperceptibly edging him out, Prime Minister MACDONALD sent his congratulations to The Morning Post, highest and dryest of Tories, on the appearance of its fifty-thousandth number. That paper never hides or shades its opinions.

The speech to be delivered by former President Calvin Coolidge Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, in behalf of the Hoover-Curtis ticket, ia arousing more advance interest than the address of any Republican campaign orator, save the President himself, the Republican National Committee announced yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Picturing the "old guard" of the Republican party as taking advantage of the Hallowe'en season and resorting to "hobgoblins" in an attempt to stir up the primitive fears of the people, former Governor Cox of Ohio told a rally of fellow Democrats tonight that with one exception President Hoover's Iowa speech contained "not a single phrase which holds any assurance of a changed order."

SHANGHAI, Oct. 8 -- With three regional civil wars continuing despite Nanking's orders and entreaties for peace, the possibilities of early development of a large-scale struggle involving the existence of the Nanking Grovennment are becoming ominous.

Duck hunters, looking ahead to the opening of the season a week from today, may gather some cheer from the fact that fifty flocks, mostly sea ducks, were sighted over Long Island Sound the past week. Many of these landed along the North Shore of Long Island and are feeding there now.

Surrounded in the House of Commons by a crowd of Tories imperceptibly edging him out, Prime Minister MACDONALD sent his congratulations to The Morning Post, highest and dryest of Tories, on the appearance of its fifty-thousandth number. That paper never hides or shades its opinions.

The speech to be delivered by former President Calvin Coolidge Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, in behalf of the Hoover-Curtis ticket, ia arousing more advance interest than the address of any Republican campaign orator, save the President himself, the Republican National Committee announced yesterday.

The Women's Trade Union League, recognizing a changing type of domestic worker who demands intellectual outlet, has included in the evening courses it will offer this year what it describes as "the first academic course ever designed especially for domestics," it was announced yesterday by Miss Rose Schneiderman, president of the league.

READERS will have learned from "Ships in Harbour" and "Harvest" that they may expect good poetry from David Morton. And in "Earth's Processional" they will not be disappointed. And it is something to be able to introduce a volume of verse with the assurance that it will not disappoint.

ALOFT and alone, in her ancestral turret, there sits an old Lady of Shalott. Emperors, archdukes and knights of the Golden Fleece to whom she curtseyed with such correctitude have ridden down a dark road to death and disaster.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- L.W. Pfeil of Wausa, Neb., today received the first loan granted by any of the regional agricultural credit corporations being formed by the Reconstruction Corporation.

PLANS are being completed for a card party on the afternoon of Nov. 9 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in aid of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School for Crippled Children, and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9 -- The ruling of Secretary of Labor Doak prohibiting non-quota foreign students from obtaining employment in this country to help meet their educational expenses is believed unconstitutional by Professor Edwin S. Corwin, chairman of the department of politics at Princeton University and an authority on constitutional interpretation, in a statement made here today.
"Criminal at Large," a play by the late Edgar Wallace, will open tonight at the Belasco Theatre. Alexander Carlisle, Emlyn Williams, William Harrigan and Katherine Wilson will head the cast.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- Although current reports from German industry continue favorable, some nervousness is visible in financial circles and an unwillingness to undertake any commitments. The evident cause is the imminence of the Reichstag election, which is not expected to help political stability in the way desired by business.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9. -- The Chattanooga Lookouts evened their series with the Gallos club this morning by registering a 10-to-3 victory over the Mexican team. The Southern Association champions, also winners of the Dixie Series, clinched their victory early, scoring three runs in the first inning, three in the second and two in the third.

The calumniators of football, those who can find no excuse for the existence of the game in the American collegiate scheme, had good cause to feel chastened in spirit after taking stock of Saturday's offerings on the country's gridirons.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- As the campaign gets under way for the parliamentary election in Germany, Nov. 6, fighting of a violent nature is developing between the National Socialists and the Nationalists, who were formerly allied.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- From the viewpoint of cash subscriptions the Australian refunding loan has been a great success. Doubt exists among some bankers, however, whether the short-term 3 1/2 per cent stock offered will appeal to holders of the maturing 5 3/4 per cents.

J. Alfred Spender, former editor of The Westminster Gazette, analyzed "American Principles and European Policies" in an address broadcast yesterday from London to the United States over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Sixteen firemen, the greatest number killed in the line of duty in a single year in the history of New York City, were extolled by Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman and other speakers at the department's annual memorial service for the dead, held yesterday afternoon at the Firemen's Monument, 100th Street and Riverside Drive, to mark the beginning of Fire Prevention Week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although recognition by public authorities and the press has already been accorded Richard C. Patterson Jr., until last week Commissioner of the Department of Correction, the good tale bears telling thrice.

James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced yesterday the weekly tabulation of straw-ballot polls, which he said showed a continuously growing sentiment for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President.
