LONDON, Oct. 9 -- In place of the four-power conference in London to settle the Franco-German disarmament dispute it now seems certain there will be a conversation here this week between Prime Minister MacDonald and Premier Herriot, with the Germans and Italians left out.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 9 -- General business conditions apparently continued steadily to improved last week. A shrinkage, compared with last year, is indicated in Buenos Aires Clearing House figures for September at 2,047,000,000 pesos, compared with 2,530,000,000 last year, a decline of nearly 20 per cent.

The American Legion's demand for immediate cash payment of the bonus is embarrassing the Victory Ball committee which raises money every year for needy war veterans and their families, according to a statement issued yesterday by the executive committee of the Victory Ball committee, of which Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt is chairman.
HYDE PARK, Oct. 9 -- Governor Roosevelt will leave New York City Oct. 18 for a tour of eight days through the South, the Middle West, Pennsylvania and Western New York.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just learned of the article published in THE TIMES of Sept. 6 entitled "Ask France to Hunt African Meteorite," by James Stokley.

Service on the Eighth Avenue subway will be speeded up, beginning today, with faster running times for express and local trains and shorter headways during rush hours, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. The new schedules are based upon nearly a month of operating experience.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 9 -- Alex J. Morrison, golf writer, of New York, won low gross prize today in the Artists and Writers' Fall Golf Tournament. Winners in the first round of match play first flight were Fred Newlin Price, S.N. Pierson, Charles McAdam and Wilfred J. Funk, while winners in the second flight were Rube Goldberg, Gene Buck, Thomas Webb and D.L. Adkins.

Too many ministers wear blue glasses in the pulpit, the Very Rev. Dean Milo H. Gates said yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in a sermon criticizing the prevalence of attacks by churchmen upon religion.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Regardless whether the extradition treaty with Greece is yet in force the Cook County authorities are prepared to try another method to bring back Samuel Insull for trial.

Drafting Calvin Coolidge. Mr. COOLIDGE finds it both puzzling and amusing that Wall Street should promptly nominate him for every position of importance as it turns up But while the thing may be amusing, it is really not puzzling.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 9 -- Cutting the budget, reduction of city expenses and refinancing of subway constructions will be the principal issues he will stress in his campaign for election as Mayor, Lewis H. Pounds, Republican, candidate, declared in an interview at his country home here today.
Thrift shops in the city maintained for the benefit of charitable organizations are making a special appeal at this time for useful articles suitable for resale.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The rise of 60,000,000 francs in the Bank of France gold this week brought that reserve to the highest recorded figure. Since the end of 1931 the gold reserve has risen from 68,863,000,000 francs to 82,681,000,000, an increase of 13,818,000,000, or $552,700,000.

St. Patrick's Cathedral seeks to be 'the heart's home not only of all our Catholic people but of all others who wish to come and worship God within its walls," Mgr. Michael J. javelle, the rector, told a congregation of 3,500 that assembled yesterday to attend a pontifical mass celebrating the twenty-second anniversary of the consecration of the edifice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The unfavorable effect of low wages on the family welfare of working people is discussed in a report issued today by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor on "Welfare of Children of Maintenance of Way Employes," based on a study of 550 families with 1,674 children in ten States.

NEW YORK. The dinner dance which Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Streit are giving for their debutante daughter. Miss Nannette Streit, on Oct. 14 will take place in the ballroom of the Colony Club and not at 1,040 Park Avenue, as first intended.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Michigan, Wisconsin and Purdue threaten to provide the dynamite in the 1932 Western Conference gridiron championship race, it was indicated by the first circuit contests played yesterday.

Bach vote for Smith in the last Presidential campaign cost the Democratic campaign fund 48 cents and each vote for Hoover cost the Republicans 44 cents, Louise Overacker, Associate Professor of Political Science at Wellesley College, writes in "Money in Elections," just published by Macmillan.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Revelations of the workings of the mind of Dr. Gustav Stresemann, which are contained in papers just published in Berlin, are regarded by diplomatic experts as sensational. They show among other things that when the late Foreign Minister of Germany negotiated the Locarno pacification treaty with the late Arlstide Briand he was planning measures which were bound to provoke a quarrel with France in the future.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- The platform adopted by the Democratic State Convention last week "Is one of the greatest exhibitions of nerve I have seen in some time," said George R. Fearon, Republican majority leader in the Senate, in a statement today. He declared that many of the accomplishments of the Legislature were started by Republicans, for which, he said, the Democrats now take all the credit in their platform.

A prohibition poll among 417 candidates for Congress in twenty-three States, conducted by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, reveals that 347 candidates are for straight repeal, 42 are evasive and 28 are opposed to repeal.

Coupling praise of President Hoover with an attack upon the candidacy of Governor Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway, said in a sermon yesterday that Mr. Hoover, were he to come out vigorously for his policies, would sweep the country with a week's campaigning."

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 9 -- Oklahoma and the champion Nebraska Cornhuskers took the lead in the Big Six championship race last week-end, while Missouri received the most severe drubbing in its football history and Kansas State's scoring ace fattened his average in an easy victory over Kansas Wesleyan.

MANILA, Monday Oct. 10 -- Captain Wolgang von Gronau, making a tour of the world by plane, sent out a radio call for help this morning, saying he had been forced down by engine trouble in the Bay of Bengal, South of Rangoon.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- London markets this week seemed to be extremely sensitive not only to Wall Street movements but to commodity price fluctuations; they were therefore disturbed by the reaction in wheat. A week ago the market was hopeful, and it was anticipated that the bull pool would push wheat up again, but this view has been changed, mainly because of lack of definite signs of improvement in the American trade situation.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- The State Council of Polish Democratic Clubs and the Slovak Democratic Clubs of the State joined hands today in convention and endorsed the Democratic candidates from Governor Roosevelt down, as .well as pledging themselves to work in their behalf.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 9 -- The East probably will not wait on election night to see what Oregon has done. But Oregon politicians are not for that reason disposed to alter their opinion that this will be the barometer State of the Union to disclose whether the election is to be a landslide or a much closer contest for the Presidency.

Mr. LEWIS H. POUNDS, whom the Republicans have named as their Mayoralty candidate, began well by declaring that he accepted the nomination on the distinct understanding that he was to run "not as a Republican or as a partisan." This is in line with the deliberate purpose of the people of this State to keep city elections apart from party divisions on national or State issues.

Poly Prep's 12-to-8 defeat by twice-beaten Concordia Institute of Bronxville was the outstanding scholastic football surprise recorded during the past weekend as nine of the fifteen New York City elevens which opened their campaigns bowed. Of the other six only three came through triumphantly, a trio engaging in scoreless ties.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9. -- Walter Hagen of Detroit swept to victory in the St. Louis open golf tournament today with a sensational, par-cracking finish in which he shot a 65, six under perfect figures, on the last eighteen holes, to win from a field that included several national stars.

The address to be made tomorrow night by Calvin Coolidge at the Republican campaign rally in Madison Square Garden will be the former President's first political speech since he left the White House nearly four years ago, the Republican National Committee pointed out yesterday.

The American Bankers Association was told last week at its convention that the cost of government in the United States has reached a point where it equals a fair net return on the value of all the property in the country. This statement was made by Mr. PAUL SHOUP, vice chairman of the Southern Pacific Company.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- The report of steel ingot production in September, issued on Friday by the American Iron and Steel Institute, showed that all trade reports had understated the amount of improvement. The average daily production was 37,502 tons, against 30,830 tons in August or a 21.6 per cent increase.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 -- Football's statistically minded fans, wrestling today with figures of another Saturday free-for-all along the Pacific Coast, concluded that to try to "dope" the 1932 race would result mostly in a flock of headaches.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- An Exchange Telegraph dispatch from Dublin today quoted Scan McEntee as declaring that the government of the Irish Free State would put no barriers in the way of attainment of the ideal of a republic for all Ireland.

The largest water-front crowd within the memory of veteran policemen filled the streets and avenues approaching Pier 86, at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon as the Italian line's luxurious new 54,000-ton Rex went on public display for the first time.

Complete reorganization of the United States Intercostal Steamship Conference, governing the lines operating between the Atlantic and Pacific Coast ports, was announced yesterday. The conference members recently agreed to maintain the organization for a period of six months after several lines protested that it was ineffective and threatened to operata without regulation.

Serge Rachmaninoff, who returned yesterday on the Europa, refused to discuss the new compositions he has been working on in Switzerland this Summer. He talked freely on the subject of Ferae Grofe, young American composer who has won his admiration.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Premier Herriot, who accompanied President Lebrun at the ceremonies marking the opening of the great power plant at Kembs today, took occasion in that town in Alsace to make a reference to Germany that is being noted in Paris tonight as reflecting a more conciliatory spirit than some of his recent speeches.

Buying activity in the wholesale markets here last week slowed up slightly as stores awaited cooler weather. Requisitions, however, were fairly heavy for immediate-delivery merchandise to round out stocks. The general trend of the orders placed indicates gradual swing to better goods.

The Governors Island quartet became the first regular army unit to capture the military polo championship of the Second Corps Area when it subdued the Essex Troop four of Newark by 12 -- 11 yesterday at Governors Island in the final match of the seventh annual tournament.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Liquidation in the grain markets here last week was drastic. Eastern interests, which tried to bolster the wheat and cotton markets, suffered severe losses and unloaded their holdings, partly because of the absence of export demand for American wheat and partly because of declines in securities and cotton.

To the Editor of The New York Times: New York City is in financial trouble because it has not collected its real estate taxes. Many millions are due and unpaid. These taxes are in arrears because the city cannot compel payment. It cannot sell the tax liens until the taxes are three years in default.

Replying to a telegraphic questionnaire sent last week by the banking house of Lehman Brothers, more than 100 executives of representative industries expressed the almost unanimous conviction that the low point of the depression was passed last Summer.

The Republican nomination of Lewis H. Pounds for Mayor was attacked by Socialist leaders yesterday as a move of "the bi-partisan political ring" to suppress the issue of municipal corruption and prevent the Seabury investigation resulting in lasting good to the city.

The State of Connecticut, one of the leaders in this country in wild fowl and game conservation, will open three public duck-shooting preserves when the season starts next Sunday. The State already maintains an aggregate of about 125,000 acres of upland bird preserves designed for public shooting, and has been working for more than a year to get its duck-shooting preserves into shape.

The organization of sixty-four of the 100 major trade groups which will help raise funds for the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee was announced yesterday by H.B. Lamy Jr., executive chairman of the commerce and industry division of the committee.

Jo Rollo, one of the younger members of the Woodstock group, will open his first one-man show today at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue. Mr. Rollo studied for a time at the Art Institute in Chicago and about five years ago at the Art Students' League here under John Carroll.

MADRID, Oct. 9 -- Referring to the Socialist party program as "anticapitalistic," a special commission of the National Socialist Congress meeting here today outlined its tactics for the coming year. Part of the report says:

The passing of the Palace Theatre, famad home of vaudeville on Broadway during the past generation, into the ranks of the straight motion-picture houses was announced yesterday by the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, which controls the theatre.

More than 100,000 members of the Holy Name Society at the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark marched in parades yesterday in all of the principal communities of the diocese. The parades in each community attended open-air services where the Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament was celebrated and sermons were delivered by prominent clergymen.

BAY CITY, Mich., Oct. 9. -- Rain today interrupted the national outboard championship regatta program, but three events finally were settled. The rest will be run tomorrow and Tuesday, weather permitting.

SOMETHING new in sartorial effects at New Haven this season. The Yale Bulldog is wearing a collar with two ties. Here it is getting along toward the middle of October and Eli Yale hasn't won a football game. However, why not look on the bright side of things? Navy, Bucknell, Syracuse, Georgia and other strong teams have been thrown for losses and Yale is still among the undefeated.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Oct. 9 -- With the secession of Barga from Manchukuo, China's Kuomintang flag is flying today over more than half the area of Manchuria, while the Japanese retain in their grip the chief cities and main lines of communication.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Discovery on a golf course near Blackwood, N.J., of five teeth and several bone fragments of the woolly mammoth, constituting the largest single find of its kind ever recorded in the eastern United States, was announced today by the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.

The party organizations in New York City prepared yesterday to do their utmost to get out a large registration for the general election on Nov. 8, and the party workers will be busy all this week getting those eligible to vote to the registration places.

The "enlightened and progressive" action of the Barnard College board of trustees in granting maternity leave of a half year with full pay or a year with half pay to women members of the college faculty is highly praised by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve in her annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 7 -- In this market particularly, and in general on other European markets, the reaction in prices of securities and commodities, since the first wave of returning optimism, has modified the general attitude. The investing and speculating public was at first willing to pay high prices for securities in expectation that pronounced economic improvement was sure to come at once.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Oct. 9. -- The New York Athletic Club's annual Fall golf tournament, at the Shawnee Country Club, completed today, was one of the most successful in a number of years. A field of about 100 competed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Members of the American Bar Association began gathering here today for their fifty-fifth annual meeting, which will be addressed by a distinguished group.

Organization of a New York State Donovan Veterans Committee, with the aim of enlisting the World War veterans of the State to work for the election of Colonel William J. Danovan, Republican candidate for Governor, was announced yesterday.

There was reported a few days ago the discovery of the remains of Incan cities among the mountains and hills of Peru overlooking a vast valley that had once been densely populated, and that still bore evidence that the basis of that departed civilization was agriculture, fostered by irrigation.

Members of the Independent Nominating Committee that has offered the names of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch as opponents of City Court Justice Aron Steuer and State Senator Samuel Hofstadter for election to the Supreme Court bench met yesterday at the Bar Association to perfect plans for their campaign.

ST. GEORGE'S, Bermuda, Oct. 9 -- After another week of waiting for calm weather, yesterday permitted two more dives on the New York Zoological Society's Bermuda oceanographic expedition, one with myself and Otis Barton to 1,000 feet for intensive observation and photography and a second to the same depth with Mr. Barton and Miss Gloria Hollister for further observation in the bathysphere.
Alfred Letourner of France was crowned national motor-paced bicycle champion at the Coney Island Velodrome yesterday following the last of a series of twenty-three races.

Out of a good deal of good news that has come their way the Democrats have had none better than consent of former Governor SMITH to make speeches in behalf of the Democratic ticket in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Jersey; and just before the election, when they will count most, three speeches in his own State.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9 -- A strong Georgetown eleven had a battle on its hands today to subdue Canisius College, 14 to 6, before a crowd of 7,000. Canisius showed defensive power and halted the visitors several times within striking distance of the goal line.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- In present discussion of possible relief from the burden of international debts, one suggestion is made that such indebtedness be consolidated -- that is, that States with short-term obligations should borrow for long periods to take up the short maturities.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 9 -- Declaring that President Hoover had "failed to solve the four major problems" of his administration, Governor Ritchie of Maryland opened tonight with a speech to 2,000 Connecticut Democrats his New England campaign tour for the Roosevelt Garner ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- William Draper Lewis of Philadelphia, who supported Theodore Roosevelt for the Presidency in 1912, in announcing his entrance in the National Progressive League and his support of Governor Roosevelt, today arraigned the Republican policies on the tariff and control of public utilities.

An aroused public opinion, alive to the vital economic issues of the campaign, is necessary to bring about reform in the national, State and local governments, the Rev. Allen Clay Lambert, pastor of St. Thomas's Lutheran Church, Topping Avenue and 175th Street, the Bronx, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Trading in cotton futures was of moderate proportions last week, but it was active immediately before and after the government's crop report, issued on Saturday. From last Monday until Friday prices of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange had a slight downward trend, holding steady around 7 cents a pound for the current month.

A sharp attack upon former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri, who will deliver the Democratic answer to President Hoover's Des Moines speech, coupled with, the implied charge that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, in selecting the ex-Senator for this task, has been unfaithful to the memory of Woodrow Wilson, was contained in an official statement issued yesterday by the Republican National Committee.

A demand that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation cease tying up its unemployment relief disbursements with "mile upon mile of red tape" and speed its task of providing aid for the destitute and work for the unemployed was voiced yesterday by Senator Robert F. Wagner in a radio interview from station WOR with Merryle Stanley Rukeyser, financial writer of The American and Professor of Journalism at Columbia University.

With the nomination of Surrogate John P. O'Brien for Mayor by the Democrats and the elimination of former Mayor James J. Walker as a candidate, and with the nomination of Lewis H. Pounds, former Borough President of Brooklyn, for Mayor by the Republicans, what threatened to be a very muddled political situation in New York City and State has been cleared.

Louis Bush, Massachusetts State halfback, the pace-setter for the greater part of the 1931 season, assumed the lead in the race for Eastern individual scoring honors as the new campaign attained full force over the past week-end. Scoring on a forward pass against Middlebury, Bush sent his total to 42 points.

BRAWLEY, Cal., Oct. 9 (AP) -- A severe earthquake shock, the eighth in two days, shook Brawley and El Centro at 2:45 P.M. today at the height of an intense rainstorm which previously had resulted in the derailment of a Southern Pacific passenger train, flooding of highways and damage to irrigation canals.

DALLAS, Oct. 9 -- Conference victories of Texas Christian and Rice Universities and the stampede of the Texas University Longhorns over the University of Missouri, 65 to 0, were high lights of the Southwest's weekend gridiron program.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Increases in manufacturing, employment and distribution, of merchandise of all kinds, with a hardening tendency in prices, made last week the beat of the year in this part of the United States. The only unfavorable feature, which may retard distribution and consumption, was the decline in grain prices to the lowest levels in years, which affected particularly the farmers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Twenty-three prominent women, representing literature, sport, music, clubs, business education, aeronautics and politics, were announced today as new members of the Board of Counselors of the Women's Division of the Republican National Committee.
PARIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Paris newspapers viewed the new French progressive disarmament plan today as both demanding concessions by the United States and fitting in with American proposals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For years I have been floundering around trying to be a good American. I have read the newspapers, listened to political speeches, have gone to the polls and have voted for the man who I thought would be the best for the job.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 9 -- The cotton contract market here was rather quieter last week than it had been for several preceding weeks, largely as a result of the approach of the government's report of the crop, issued yesterday, as uncertainty always attaches to such reports.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Large supplies of cattle, with trade slow for dressed beef, made a weak and declining market here last week. Prices were 50 to 75 cents a hundred pounds lower for the general run of steers, while yearlings dropped 50 cents to $1, butchers' stock and feeders declined 25 to 75 cents and calves fell 50 cents.

Unexpected results of President HOOVER'S unfortunate reference to The gold standard in his Des Moines speech remind us afresh of the danger of saying indiscreet things in what is now the whispering gallery of the whole world. Something said for local and political effect may have a distant financial effect not at all intended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Challenging a recent statement by Senator Glass, Senator Watson, the Republican leader, declared tonight that members of Congress had been told last February by President Hoover of "the great gravity" of the situation then as to the gold standard in the nation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Today's Culiculi ambush of a Philippine Constabulary patrol had not been reported to the War Department tonight.
The first foreign artists chosen to participate in the extensive ornamentative program for the eleven buildings in Rockefeller Center were announced yesterday.

MILAN, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The only evidence of the departure of Samuel Insull from this city was his purchase of a ticket and a sleeper reservation for a fifty-hour ride across Italy, Yugoslavia and Greece. His son, Samuel Insull Jr., left here Friday night and it was assumed that he put his father aboard the Orient Express, which left for Athens at 10:20 A.M. Friday.

GENEVA, Oct. 9 -- This year began with the opening of the disarmament conference which was delayed by the Chino-Japanese conflict, and the two then simultaneously held the Geneva stage. There is good reason to believe this year will end in much the same way -- with preparations for the world's financial and economic conference, which begin here Oct. 31, thrown in.

James J. Walker returned to New York yesterday in the role of the man who came back -- too late. His friends in Tammany Hall, however, went the limit to prevent reminders of his transformation from "Mayor Jimmy" to Citizen Walker from becoming too painfully vivid.

The singing of Kol Nidre at sundown yesterday in synagogues all over the world ushered in the Day of Atonement, or Yom Kippur, day of fasting, prayer and forgiving, which continues until sundown this evening.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Miriam A. Ferguson, the only woman who has ever held the office of Governor in Texas, is the Democratic nominee on the Nov. 8 ballot, but a bolt in her own party promises bitter opposition.

Two envoys arrived yesterday from Germany on the liner Europa of the North German Lloyd. They were were Baron F.W. von Prittwitz and Gaffron, German Ambassador to the United States, and Frederick M. Sackett, United States Ambassador to Germany.

Civic and business organizations interested in the establishment of a comprehensive system of bus transportation in Manhattan will appear before the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate tomorrow to protest against Borough President Samuel Levy's plan to award one-year franchises to the present operators of "emergency" buses on six crosstown routes.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Two long-term convicts quartered in county jail as witnesses at the trial of two former prison guards for the sweat-box death of Arthur Maillefert, New Jersey youth, escaped today.

DNIEPROSTROY, U.S.S.R., Oct. 9 -- Government officials and Communist party leaders were among the thousands of persons arriving here today for the formal opening tomorrow of the world's largest hydroelectric plant. The newspapers of the nation hailed the construction of the plant as the most brilliant achievement of Soviet industry and an outstanding proof of the ability of the Socialist system to achieve its aims.

Many military organizations in New York are cooperating with members of the British Great War Veterans of America in the arrangements for their twelfth annual Armistice Day ball, to be held on the night of Nov. 11 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Among them are detachments from the United States Army.

The Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan, Moderator of the Presbytery of New York, offered his resignation yesterday morning as co-pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. He said that since the Rev. Dr. Henry Howard was leaving the pastorate and since they were called together, he felt it his duty to offer his resignation also.

OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Sing Sing's football team sustained its first gridiron casualty in two seasons this afternoon when Cy Stokes, its fleet Negro right end, was taken from the field with a dislocated shoulder during the game in which Sing Sing defeated Irwin Post, American Legion, the Bronx, by 12 to 0.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 9 -- Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte gave a tea and backgammon party at the Casino this afternoon for Sir Henry Thornton and Lady Thornton, Mr. and Mrs. James W. Thornton, the Marchese and Marchesa Carignani, Mrs. Samuel Cuppies Scudder, Mrs. S. Proctor Brady, Captain and Mrs. Cyrus R. Miller, Mrs. Carl H. Langenberg, Mrs. Walter W. Keith, Mrs. Arthur Kelly Evans, Honore Palmer and Charles Delavan Wetmore.

Wards of voluntary hospitals in New York City have 1,134 maternity beds available, sufficient to care for 25,000 mothers in a year, according to a report issued yesterday of a survey by the Hospital Information Bureau of the United Hospital Fund.

The Stapleton football team avenged itself for a defeat at the hands of the Brooklyn Dodgers earlier in the season by turning back the Brooklyn eleven in a hard tussle at Ebbets Field yesterday. A crowd of 15,000 witnessed the struggle, and saw the Stapes rally after yielding a touchdown in the first period to grain a National League triumph by the score of 7 to 6.

HECKSVILLE, L.I., Oct. 9 -- Reginald Langhorne Brooks, a nephew of Lady Astor and a skilled airplane pilot, was injured seriously this afternoon when his plane crashed at the close of a stunting exhibition at the Autumn air meet of the Long Island Aviation Country Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter published in THE TIMES expressed opposition to a general sales tax and advanced as reasons a resultant burden on industry, a curb upon consumption and a lowering of our standard of living.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- Booing from the congregation and waves of applause enlivened a political symposium at the Community Church services in Symphony Hall today, at which a Republican, a Democrat, a Socialist and a Communist each stated the case for his party.

The tentative budget for 1933 will be submitted to the Board of Estimate today, lacking virtually all of the economies which would have been incorporated if Acting Mayor McKee's budget-making powers had not been revoked by the concerted action of Controller Charles W. Berry and the Manhattan, Brooklyn and Richmond members of the board.

The musical version of "Cyrano de Bergerac," by Charles Locke and Samuel Pokrass, will be the second offering to be made by the Producing Associates, Inc., a newly formed theatrical organization, of which J. J. Shubert is president. The first attraction by the new group was "The Passing Show of 1932," which closed after a brief road engagement.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 9 -- Many of the leading steeplechase and flat racers in the East are entered in the annual Rose Tree Hunt Club Fall meeting that opens tomorrow. Races also will be held on Wednesday and Saturday.
At last the dream of Dr. ABRAHAM FLEXNER has come true. The interpretation of it was made in his hook on "Universities American, English, German" two years ago:

An independent citizens' movement is being organized in the Fifteenth Assembly District and the Seventeenth Senatorial District, directed, it was said, not against the Republican or the Democratic parties, but against the "dictorial" leadership of both.

J.P. Smith's Morfair, winner of the Burnt Hills, Campfire and Saranac Handicaps at Saratoga, gained his first victory since that meeting when he scored yesterday at Jamaica in the featured Montague Handicap.

The seven-point plan for economic recovery, sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York with the cooperation of the American Federation of Labor, took definite form yesterday in a call to 700 business, industrial and labor leaders throughout the country to participate in a national conference here on Nov. 10 and 11 to formulate a concrete program of action.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 10 (AP). -- The suicide theory of the death of Arthur Maillefert in a prison camp sweat-box last June was invented for the protection of Captain George Courson, one of two former guards on trial for murder, it was testified today by a trusty who said he was the inventor, with Courson's accord.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- After a weak opening this morning the stock market improved during the day and the trend was definitely higher at the closing of the Bourse. Premier Herriot's forthcoming visit to London was regarded as a favorable influence, giving rise to the belief that the European political situation will benefit by the French Premier's conversations in the British capital, particularly with reference to the German problem.

An increase of 15,495 tons in the unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation in September was shown in the monthly statement issued yesterday, which revealed a total of 1,985,090 tons on the books as of the end of the month, compared with 1,969,595 on Aug. 31.

Thomas L. Chadbourne submitted to Federal Judge Martin T. Manton last evening the resignation of his law firm, Chadbourne, Stanchfield Levy, as counsel for the receivers in the equity receivership of the Inter-borough Rapid Transit Company, as a result of public criticism based on Mr. Chadbourne's past connection with traction matters, especially in I.R.T. and B.M.T. stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- The Supreme Court today rejected the plea of the Moffat Tunnel Improvement District and the Moffat Tunnel Com- mission in Colorado for a review of a lower court's decision which sustained the validity of more than $6,000,000 of Moffat tunnel supplemental bonds and the law under which assessments were authorized for their payment.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the decision of the United States District Court in the Appalachian Coal case a few comments may be of interest.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien is as good as elected already, James J. Hoey, his campaign manager, said yesterday. It will be up to Tammany Hall to decide, he added, whether former Mayor Walker will make any addresses in his behalf.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Demand for hogs today were not aggressive. Prices were steady to 10 cents lower, compared with Friday, and steady to 10 cents higher, compared with Saturday. Heavy packing hogs were especially weak, dropping 15 to 25 cents from Friday, with the close at the lowest of the day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Republicans and Democrats joined today at the meeting of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors in voting unanimously for an investigation of Playland, the $6,000,000 amusement park operated by the Westchester County Park Commission at Rye.

If the object of a mystery play is the mystification of the innocent playgoer let us doff our caps to "Criminal at Large," by the late Edgar Wallace. Careless as he was with the froth of a play and perfunctory as he was with the attendant humors, he had a way with the development of gruesome drama.

Activity Gain Seen This Week. This week is expected to yield better activity in the women's garment and allied trades, comments here yesterday indicated. Resumption of business today, following the religious holiday yesterday, will be featured by a greater accumulation of fill-in orders than was the case a week ago, it was reported.

A counter attack was made yesterday against the Japanese Government's "White Book" in a statement given out here by Dr. Liang Yuen-li, former judge of the Court of Appeals at Shanghai, who charged that while, in the book, Japan had defended her actions in China, she had not even tried to justify "her conduct in thwarting the League of Nations."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10. -- Throckmorton Forman, 90 years old, former Cincinnati broker, died at Indianapolis, Ind., today after a brief illness. He was a grandson of John Chambers, second Governor of Iowa. A Civil War veteran, he was a member of George H. Thomas Post, G.A.R.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- Premier Herriot today formally accepted the invitation of Prime Minister MacDonald, conveyed through Lord Tyrrell, British Ambassador, to go to London this week to discuss the time, place and conditions of the proposed conference or other means for dealing with the German claim to recognition of the equality of right in armaments as a condition to the resumption by Germany of a place in the Geneva disarmament conference.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Hygro, sprint ace from the Nevada Stock Farm, whirled the fastest six furlongs of the meeting to score an easy victory in the featured Easton Handicap today at Laurel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The acceptance speech of Colonel Donovan before the Republican convention in Buffalo illustrates to a high degree the weakness of the position of the Republican party in this State. All that Colonel Donovan could find to criticize in the past twelve years of Democratic government was the increasing cost of the State Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Although officials at the Capitol had made elaborate preparations against a Communist demonstration, there was none as the Supreme Court this afternoon heard arguments in the Scottsboro cases involving the lives of seven Negroes accused of assaulting two white girls.

An effort to block the plan of reorganization for the New Orleans Great Northern Railroad that was put forward on July 1 was announced yesterday. The proposed plan provides for a redaction in the road's interest charges and for its lease to a corporation controlled by the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad, which has 95 per cent control of the smaller line.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- The source and the contents of four cablegrams sent to Samuel Insull while the former financier was en route from Paris to Greece were revealed to the Cook County grand jury today.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Oct. 10. -- An Ecuadorean clash with Peruvians which might swing Ecuador's support to Colombia if Colombia and Peru go to war as they threaten was reported near Machala today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- President Hoover will make the second of his major campaign speeches in the auditorium at Cleveland Saturday night, and probably will make rear platform talksat towns along the way.

BALBOA, C.Z., Oct. 10. -- The British yawl Vigilante arrived here from Cocoa Island today to obtain, two-months' supplies for the expedition which has been hunting pirates' treasure on the island for the last six months without success.

BAY CITY, Mich., Oct. 10 (AP). -- A steady downpour of rain caused another postponement today of the National Outboard Motorboat championship races. Weather permitting the program will be resumed tomorrow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -- Head Coach Stevens today opened practice for the game with Brown by delivering a talk lasting an hour and a quarter to the football squad on mistakes made in the game with Chicago Saturday.

Seventeenth-century Persian frescoes, as "reconstructed" by Sarkis Katchadourian, constitute an exhibition at the Museum, of Modern Art, which will open today to members and tomorrow to the public. These paintings will be on view (in the fourth-floor galleries) until Nov. 19, after which they will begin a tour of the country, circulated by the American Institute for Persian Art and Archaeology, under whose auspices they were brought to America.

Many encouraging signs indicated a more widespread interest in government than ever before, which is bound to result in a greater part of the electorate voting, Mrs. Ogden Reid, vice president of The New York Herald Tribune, declared yesterday afternoon in a radio address over station WOR.

The beautiful little stadium high on the cliff behind the ramparts of the United States Military Academy at West Point has its big game of the season this week when the Army plays host to the Pittsburgh team, which was such an inhospitable host to the cadets in the steel town last year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The National Alumni Association of Princeton University will meet in Detroit on Friday and Saturday Oct. 28 and 29, it was announced here today by Thurston J. Davies, Secretary of the association. The Michigan-Princeton football game at Ann Arbor, Mich., will be the main feature of Saturday's program.

MUKDEN, Manchuria (AP) Oct. 10. -- The Japanese Army opened an intensive offensive today to sweep Southern Manchuria clear of Chinese insurgents before Winter sets in, and at the same time prepared to stamp out rebellion in the Northwest.

Four public institutions were named beneficiaries in the will Of Katherine M. Carrington of 156 West Eighty-fourth Street, who died on Oct. 4, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate. The estate was formally valued at "more than $10,000."
Business in the Broadway play-houses was unusually good last night. Only seven attractions were listed just before curtain time in the cutrate ticket agency.

Republican leaders in State and nation are banking heavily on the appearance of former President Calvin Coolidge at the Madison Square Garden rally this evening in their effort to hold this State with its fortyseven votes in the Electoral College, against Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

JOLO, P.I., Oct. 10 (AP). -- With forty-two men dead and many wounded after three clashes resulting from a hostile Moro ambuscade of a Philippine constabulary detachment, preparations were made tonight for an assault on the Moro village of Tayungan as soon as the women and children there could be evacuated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- A prediction that Congress, meeting in December, would modify the Volstead act and vote Increased taxes was made here today by Senator David A. Reed, of Pennsylvania, who returned yesterday from Europe, where he conferred with French and British officials on Manchuria and other international problems.

BYRON'S "late remorse of love" has broken forth from Republican bosoms this year. So long as they thought that former Governor SMITH might interfere with the success of the Democratic national ticket, Republican journals couldn't find praise enough to bestow upon him.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 10. -- Holding that there was danger in "indiscriminate retrenchment," speakers at the meeting of the publicity and advertising section of the American Gas Association cautioned today against undue curtailment of advertising budgets as a means toward economy.

The Old Bathrobe. Benny Leonard went in there against James Archibald McLarnin, and about all the old champion had was his old courage and his old campaign blanket. He stepped through the ropes wearing the ancient bathrobe that was draped over his shoulders in his palmy days. It was frayed around the collar and at the wrists.

After formally receiving the tentative 1933 budget of $614,648,912 in a five-minute meeting yesterday, the Board of Estimate deferred discussion on the document until the first public hearing Thursday morning.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 10. -- If this generation can make public office, "a dignified and rewarding profession again and an important one," it will have put the country "back into the only form in which a republic can act," President Marion Edwards Park of Bryn Mawr College declared in an address to the students at the opening of the college's academic year today.

LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- There were 7.711 bales of wool offered at the wool auction today, of which 6,000 were sold. A superior selection was offered and met a good general demand at unchanged prices. Withdrawals were frequent among poor slipes and medium scoured grades on low bids.

The marriage of Miss Rose Hobart, stage and screen actress of this city, to William Mason Grosvenor Jr., a chemist, son of Dr. and Mrs. William M. Grosvenor of 200 West Fifty-eighth Street, took place on Sunday at the home of Joseph P. Bickerton Jr., a friend, in Mount Kisco, N.Y., it was revealed yesterday toy Mr. Grosvenor.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Making the first of a series of speeches in support of Governor Roosevelt as the Democratic nominee for President, United States Senator Pat Harrison of Mississippi, declared at a Democratic rally here tonight that President Hoover's speech at Des Moines had "cost the American people billions."

The President's remarks at Des Moines about the "gold-standard crisis" of last Autumn or last Spring elicited at Washington conflicting statements of the actual facts. Some of the statements are palpably erroneous. Mr. HOOVER named no date when "the Sec"retary of the Treasury informed "me that," unless some remedy were applied, "we could not hold to "the gold standard but two weeks "longer."

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Norman B. Collins, president of two Chicago banks, was kidnapped by gunmen this morning as he left his home in Wilmette, a suburb, and was released at 8 o'clock tonight after being held for $5,000 ransom.

The executive committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York will meet this afternoon to consider the formulation of charges in connection with the deal whereby Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, head of the legislative investigating committee that bore his name, and Aron Steuer, son of Max Steuer, one of the leading Tammany advisers, received the joint Republican and Democratic nominations for the Supreme Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To the intelligent voter, the proceedings at Madison Square Garden in the evening of Oct. 6 meant the nativity of a myriad of obtuse problems concerning the true manner in which the Democrats of this city came to nominate John P. O'Brien for the office of Mayor.

BUCHAREST, Oct. 10. -- Virgil Madgearu, Minister of Trade, who is in London, has been asked by Premier Vaida-Voivode to inform Nicolas Titulesco, former Rumanian Minister there, that the government has heard with pleasure that he is willing to accept the foreign portfolio in the Cabinet.

Another clash between Acting May-or McKee and the opposition bloc in the Board of Estimate is expected today when the committee of the whole takes up the proposals of Controller Charles W. Berry and Borough President Samuel Levy for one-year franchise grants to existing operators in Queens and Manhattan.

The Great Renunciation of Mayor WALKER may have been sent to the uneasy bosses over the radio on Thursday afternoon, but it took form several days before, on the train between the border town of Hendaye and Paris. So it is stated by The Herald Tribune correspondent who accompanied him.

At the request of county units of he State division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, a motorized corps of speakers for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment will invade dry Congressional districts throughout New York State between now and election day, it was said yesterday by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, State chairman of the organization.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 10. -- Senator Robert J. Bulkley in a speech tonight at a Democratic rally challenged the contention that President Hoover was the one man who saved or is capable of saving the country from complete financial collapse.

The New York Central Railroad reduced its net loss after taxes and charges to $852,981 in August. The net loss after these deductions in July was $3,500,519; in June. $3,068,025; in May, $3,963,796, and in April, $2,700,477. The company's best month this year was March, when a net income of $393,577 was reported.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10. -- Scattered and persistent liquidation in wheat was under way again today on the Board of Trade here and all deliveries dropped to new low marks for the season. Support was lacking and the market responded rapidly to minor advances and declines in stocks.
Following is the text of the speech of Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, last night at Jamaica, High School:
ALBANY. N.Y., Oct. 10. -- State income tax receipts of about $5,000,000 are expected to reach here by Saturday, the last day on which the year's final instalment of personal income taxes can be paid.

The other guests whom Prime Minister MACDONALD had invited to come to London to talk over disarmament having made their excuses, the party this week will be a snug little one confined to the Premier of France and Mr. MACDONALD. They may have a good deal to say to each other, but it can scarcely be new.

Despite rumors in football circles yesterday that Major Frank W. Cavanaugh had been retired as head coach at Fordham University, an official denial was made last night by Jack Coffey, graduate manager, that any such change had been made.

While the further decline in stock and bond prices commanded attention yesterday, the incident of most importance perhaps was the sharp rally of the dollar in terms of foreign exchanges as uneasiness abroad over the safety of the American gold standard was allayed.

A thrust at "the commercial past" in biography, at "the unfortunate facility in making money out of scandalous assaults upon things which the world has been taught to revere," is made by the late Gamaliel Bradford in "Biography and the Human Heart," a posthumous book published today by Houghton Mifflin.

"It's a cinch for Roosevelt," was the way the national political situation was described yesterday by Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana, who announced on his arrival here that he was going to take the stump for Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Contrary to the seasonal tendency, money in circulation declined during September, while there was a substantial addition to the country's stock of monetary gold, the Treasury announced today.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Protesting members of the newly formed Progressive Miners Union were routed by tear gas and bayonets of militiamen today when they attempted to halt operations in the coal pits of the Taylorville area.

Speaker John N. Garner, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, arrived here last night from Washington, D.C., on his way to visit Governor Roosevelt today in Albany, where his proposed speaking tour will be decided upon. Mr. Garner refused to disclose his plans or desires regarding the tour.

Charging the Hoover Administration with using the prevailing rate of wages law to cheat workers and favor Republican contractors. Daniel J. Tobin, chairman of the labor division of the Democratic National Committee, sent a letter yeserday to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, asking the latter to "go a little deeper into the records of candidates before closing its books on the 1932 campaign."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The estimated 1932 wheat production in thirty-five countries of the Northern Hemisphere, including the United States, but excluding Russia and China, was reported by the Department of Agriculture today as 3,145,555,000, compared with 3,103,809,000 in 1931, 3,142,677,000 in 1930 and 3,011.667,000 in 1929.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Two political leaders and two journalists were arrested today in the government round-up of prominent Sao Paulo citizens involved in the three months' rebellion in that State.
A distinct improvement in factory employment in New York State was reported yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Frances Perkins of the State Department of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Further slight improvement in crop prospects during September was shown by the Oct. 1 report of the Crop Reporting Board Issued today by the Department of Agriculture.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10. -- Dr. S.S. Baker, who retired as president of Washington and Jefferson College, Washington, Pa., last year, was reported missing today from his home in the East End. Members of the family asked police to search for him.

BUFFALO, Oct. 10. -- A warning that "school department budgets should not be reduced in any manner that will interfere with educational efficiency" was sounded by Dr. George D. Strayer, Professor of Educational Administration, Teachers College, Columbia University, at the opening session of the annual meeting of the Associated School Boards and Trustees of the State today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 10. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia won the medal in the women's twentieth annual Hot Springs Fall golf tournament at the Homestead course today with a 77, five over par.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- The Boerse was dull today, the Jewish holiday intensifying the general apathy. Price changes were unimportant, but an earlier downward tendency was succeeded by a firmer tone. Bonds were inactive, although there was some demand for short-term issues.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 10 -- The Abitibl Canyon project is to be completed, with work to begin at once, it was announced tonight, and J.H. Black, in charge of the construction, said that some 800 or 900 men would receive work for three or four months.

In another attempt to restore harmony among rival factions of Connecticut Democrats, James A. Farley, National Chairman, conferred yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore with Thomas J. Spellacy and Dr. Edward G. Dolan, leaders of rival groups.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 10. -- Gipsy King II and Greatorex carried off the honors in the two divisions of the J. Howard Lewis Plate Steeplechase which featured the opening of the annual Rose Tree Hunt Club's meeting today.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will make his first appearance as a speaker in this campaign at a luncheon for Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and M. William Bray of Utica, Democratic nominee for Governor and lieutenant Governor, at the Commodore Hotel on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Demands that rights of American holders of Haitian bonds must be fully guaranteed before this country withdraws its supervision of the island republic were emphasized in recent diplomatic correspondence, made public today by the State Department.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., Oct. 10. -- By the narrow margin of 8 to 7 the Women's New Jersey Golf Association defeated the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf, Association in the eighth annual team match for the Mrs. J.J. Thomson Trophy at the Green Brook Country Club today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 10. -- Brown opened its drive for the Yale game today by testing several new plays that will be worked against the Elis. The regulars had easy assignments, but the scrubs scrimmaged for more than an hour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- An over-subscription of more than eighteen times was announced today for the offering of $450,000,000 in 4 1/2-year Treasury notes bearing 3 per cent interest to go in the market Oct. 15.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The first of the Series of loan conversion operations, to which Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, referred Friday, was announced tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- To commemorate his ninetieth birthday on Aug. 24 the city of Paris today presented to Edward Tuck an illuminated copy of a municipal decree making him an honorary citizen. The decree was recently voted in recognition of Mr. Tuck's generous philanthropy.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Douglas Fairbanks arrived here today from Japan for a month's tour of China. He will participate in the China amateur golf championship tournament here Oct. 15 and 16.

The 1,578 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange appreciated $59,363,945 in value in September, according to figures made public yesterday by the Exchange. Their value on Oct. 1 was $40,132,203,281, compared with $40,072,839,336 on Sept. 1, and with their total par value of $51,780,888,000.

The vestry of Trinity Parish failed to elect a new rector for Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway, at the head of Wall Street, at a meeting yesterday afternoon. The rectorship has been vacant since the death on June 15 of the Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson.

PARIS, Oct. 10. -- The United States Embassy here received a cable message this morning telling of Samuel Insull's arrest in Athens. While the United States has not an extradition treaty with, Greece, according to authorities here, one would not be needed, it was said, if the Greek authorities decided they wanted to be helpful.
Horsepower on the Dnieper. Foremost among the debutantes of the season are H. P.'s and the kilowatts. Today Soviet Russia Introduces to the world her celebrated Dnieprostroy.

Dr. Abraham Flexner, director of the new Institute for Advanced Study, announced yesterday that Professor Albert Einstein, discoverer of the theory of relativity and widely regarded as the greatest scientific figure since Sir Isaac Newton, has accepted a life appointment as head of the institute School of Mathematics.

Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, which began at sundown Sunday, was observed until sunset yesterday by more than 1,750,000 Orthodox and Reformed Jews in all the synagogues and other Jewish institutions in this city, including hospitals, orphanages and homes for the aged and the infirm.

Sales brought $20,162.50 at the dispersal of the collection of gold coins formed by the late Giovanni Morosini, banker, at American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., yesterday afternoon. The collection was discovered stored away in boxes in the attic of the old family residence in Riverdale, the Bronx, after the death of Miss Giulia P. Morosini, the financier's daughter, last February.

The likelihood of an open battle in the Board of Estimate today on three incinerator construction contracts was foreshadowed last night When Acting Mayor McKee declared flatly that be would not vote for the second-lowest bidder favored by the Sanitation Department for the work.

GUAYAQUIL, Oct. 10 (AP). -- The government announced tonight it was taking steps to send a battalion of troops to reinforce the garrison along the Peruvian-Ecuadorean frontier after a battle near the town of Huaquillas.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10. -- A signal drill, following discussion of the New Hampshire game, was the extent of the work of Harvard's first varsity team today.

NEW YORK. Mrs. James Francis Sullivan gave a luncheon for Miss Alice Van Rensselaer yesterday in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Among the other guests were Mrs. Samuel Parrish, Miss Eleanor Livingston and Miss Sarah Gardiner, Mrs. Sullivan will return to The Woods, Radnor, Pa., today.

Speaking last night at the opening of the Chelsea branch, of Socialist campaign headquarters at 9 Barrow Street, Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, took as his text the congratulatory telegrams sent to Surrogate John P. O'Brien, after his nomination as Democratic candidate for Mayor, by Colonel Herbert H. Lehman, candidate of that party for Governor.

ATHENS, Greece, Oct. 10. -- Samuel Insull was arrested at the Grande Bretagne Hotel at noon today at the request of the United States Legation and will be detained until the question of extradition to the United States is decided.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Declaring that the vast majority of persons throughout the country seemed indifferent over the issues of the Presidential campaigns, Frederic William Wile, political observer and radio broadcaster, said here tonight that the election undoubtedly would be close and that neither candidate for President would win by more than two States in the electoral college.

In a decision handed down yesterday at special term of the Supreme Court in Jamaica, Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. denied an application by Harrison H. Boyce, head of the Boyce Motometer Company, to reduce the alimony Boyce is paying his first wife from $1,000 a month to $4,500 a year, and described the "collection of wives" as "among the most expensive of all expensive hobbies."
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 10. -- Mr. and Mrs. Gould Shaw and Mrs. Graham Davis were among those entertaining at dinners at the Greenbrier this evening.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 10. -- Medley G.B. Whelpley, president of Cosach, the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, declared today that a recent report in a newspaper here concerning the sale of United States interests in the Chilean nitrate business to European competitors was absolutely groundless, Mr. Whelpley said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Domination of American law machinery by political influence is responsible alike for the crime ratio and the inefficiency of law enforcement, Stuart H. Perry of Adrian, Mich., newspaper publisher and a director of The Associated Press, charged in an address delivered today at a conference of American Bar Association delegates gathered for the opening of their annual convention here.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 10. -- Spurred by reports of the unsettled political situation in Bolivia, Paraguay has assumed the offensive in the Chaco war and is making a determined drive against Bolivian advanced headquarters at Fort Arce, designed to prevent a Bolivian offensive against Puerto Casado.

Figures based upon investigation and verification show there are more than 500,000 men, women and children in New York City in need of some degree of community assistance, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, said yesterday in a radio address over a nation-wide hook-up from Station WABC of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- Making her first public appeal for the support of a Presidential candidate, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, leader of the woman's suffrage movement, urged the re-election of President Hoover in an address here today before about 200 members of the Women's Hoover Club of New Rochelle at the New Rochelle Women's Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Dr. Enrique Finot, the Bolivian representative, called today upon Chairman White of the Chaco neutral commission to present a memorandum covering points raised by the commission in recent conversations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Continued disarmament will progress through the years with the growth of international stability, Acting Secretary of State William R. Castle Jr. predicted tonight in a speech, in the National Radio Forum conducted by The Washington Star over the National Broadcasting Company network.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- General Pelham D. Glassford, Superintendent of Police, asked the District of Columbia Commissioners today to urge upon Congress the passage of a law that would authorize the Chief of Police to use "undisputed authority to evacuate any army of indigents after their constitutional rights of petition have been exercised."

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me a serious mistake to ignore the real indignation of intelligent people with reference to the nomination by Tammany of Samuel H. Hofstadter. Any one who followed closely the hearings of the investigation committee must have realized that there were many times when he showed a friendliness and receptiveness to the Tammany point of view.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Cable dispatches from America caused a further sharp decline in international stocks today. Otherwise the stock markets were fairly steady. British Government funds remained firm.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The automobile industry is leading the way out of the depression and will continue to set the pace if Congress will repeal some of the various taxes now levied upon the motorist, according to Ernest N. Smith, executive vice president of the American Automobile Association, who spoke today before the convention of the New York State Automobile Association.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 10. -- The annual Greenbrier Autumn lawn tennis tournament started today, with all the favorites in the men's singles advancing by means of straight-set victories.

From the Far West and the South, the Middle West and the East, came the voices of outstanding coaches yesterday, raised in a long cheer for the new rules and the manner in which they have achieved to date their object of adding safeguards against injuries in college football.

MANILA, Tuesday, Oct. 11 (AP). -- A message intercepted this morning by the station here of the Radio Corporation of America said Captain Wolfgang von Gronau and his three companions had been picked up by the steamer Karagola and were being taken to Rangoon, Burma. Later the steamer reported:

A new first-day record for registration of voters was set yesterday in the city, the five boroughs piling up a total of 273,128 registrants. In 1928, also a Presidential year, when the previous first-day record was set, the total was 270,463.

The Texas Railroad Commission yesterday ordered production of crude oil in that State to be reduced to 804,000 barrels daily, beginning on Saturday. This is a cut of more than 100,000 barrels daily, the present output there being estimated at around 910,000 barrels.
PARIS, Oct. 10. -- After opening weak, the dollar was quoted in the Paris exchange market today at 25,445 francs ($.9963), the lowest official price of the day being 25,4375 francs.

Ripping apart the asphalt pavement with irresistible force, thousands of gallons of water rushed from a break in a 48-inch main in Fortieth Street Just east of Seventh Avenue at 8:25 o'clock last night. The west side I.R.T. subway was blocked; trolley service and automobile traffic along Seventh and Eighth Avenues was halted, and the basements of many buildings were flooded.
With a young Chinese flier soaring overhead, Chinese officials joined with their countrymen at City Hall yesterday in celebrating the twenty-first anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic.
Several taxpayer deals, in addition to the more usual housing transactions, were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Contracts were signed yesterday between United Artists and Loew's, Inc., making Loew theatres in eighteen cities "exclusive-run" houses for United Artists pictures. The move was the first in a plan to divide theatres into Class A and Class B houses, whereby the best pictures will be exhibited only in the higher priced film theatres.

With the opening of the duck-hunting season next Sunday it seems appropriate that the New York State code regarding this wild water-fowl be quoted, so that enthusiastic and fortunate hunters may not find themselves entangled with the law. In endeavoring to keep in line with the Federal regulations covering migratory birds the Empire State left no loopholes in its revised code, so that it is well that one study the provisions with some care.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP). -- A sixth of the present members of Congress do not have to worry about November elections because they already have been, eliminated as contestants.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10. -- Finishing one of his two adjourned games from the second and third rounds of the International Chess Masters tournament at the Press Social Centre, Isaac Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, moved into second place today.
ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt decided today to outline his views on Federal responsibility for relief of the destitute in a radio talk Thursday night over a nationwide hook-up.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Sir Everard im Thurn, a former Colonial Governor who was well known as an explorer, anthropologist and naturalist, died today at Cokenzie House, Prestonpans, East Lothian, Scotland. He was 80 years old.

An opening advance on trade buying and covering was followed by reaction yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. December contracts, which had sold up to 6.66 cents early, broke to 6.51 cents or 3 points below Saturday's final quotation, and closed at 6.04. The general market ended steady at 2 points lower to 2 points higher on the day.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- The Earl of Lytton, whose report on Japan and Manchuria goes a long way toward hacking up the American policy in the Far East, is also a firm advocate of accepting Secretary Stimson's declaration of Aug. 8 concerning consultation as all the assurance the world now needs of the cooperation of the United States and the League of Nations.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 10. -- George T. Dunlap Jr., the Long Island amateur champion, and Stanley Remsen, assistant professional of the Garden City Country Club, were fortunate in getting an early start in the amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island Golf Association today.

MANILA, Oct. 10. -- The slaughter of twelve members of the Philippine constabulary in an ambush by Moros on Jolo Island yesterday was widely commented on in the Manila press today. The Philippines Herald observed editorially that the attack coincided exactly with the visit of Representative Hare, author of an independence bill.

The first of what is believed will be a series of sweeping changes by which the Giants hope to rehabilitate themselves for next season after the disastrous happenings of the past campaign was completed yesterday when Secretary Jim Tierney announced that Manager Bill Terry had just closed a deal with the St. Louis Cardinals involving six players.

BERLIN, Oct. 10. -- Chancellor von Papen started for Munich tonight for his first official visit to the Bavarian Government, with which he will discuss the Reich's plans for reorganizing the Federal administrative machinery, especially, its effects on the prerogatives of the federated States.

Three hundred members of the Italian Chamber of Commerce of New York, representatives of trade organizations and ship lines, were guests at an inauguration luncheon yesterday on the new liner Rex, and additional hundreds who went to her West Forty-seventh Street pier in the hope of boarding her, only to find that entrance was forbidden, stood in the streets admiring Italy's newest contribution to maritime trade.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- The United States requested today the "provisional arrest" of Samuel Insull at Athens, Greece, until proper extradition papers could be forwarded from here.
BERLIN, Oct. 10 (AP). -- The Reichs-bank statement as of Oct. 7 shows the following changes in reichs-marks:

Decreases of 9 per cent in gas sales and 7 per cent in revenues were indicated by the reports of manufactured and natural gas utilities for the first eight months of 1932, according to Paul Ryan, chief statistician of the American Gas Association, which met yesterday in convention in Atlantic City.

DNIEPROSTROY, U.S.S.R., Oct. 10 (AP). -- Bands blared the "Internationale," red flags waved and thousands of spectators cheered today as the Soviet Government dedicated the largest hydroelectric plant in the world to the cause of socialism.

Real estate dealers look for a rather quiet market this week. Many offices were closed yesterday, the Jewish Day of Atonement, and a second interruption of trading is expected tomorrow, Columbus Day, when many firms will suspend business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic floor leader, asserted today that the Republicans were in a condition of "desperation" and that this was made clear by President Hoover's assertion in Des Moines that the nation was, some months ago, within two weeks of going off the gold standard.

With the Republican cohorts of Queens making use of aerial bombs and blaring bands to lend to the occasion something of the setting appropriate to his army sobriquet of "Wild Bill," Colonel William J. Donovan. Republican Gubernatorial nominee, opened his campaign last night with an address at Jamaica High School.

With statements of their condition on Sept. 30, the two general management investment trusts sponsored by Goldman Sachs Co. announced yesterday plans to revise their capital structures. The plane are to be submitted to stockholders' meetings next month.

A class of 271 applicants for admission to the bar, including eleven women, has been called to appear before the committee on character and fitness at the Appellate Division courthouse. Examination of the applicants by the character committee is scheduled to start next Tuesday.

Except for the definitely easier undertone in commercial paper, expressed in the more general buying of choice name bills at 1 3/4 per cent, little else transpired in the money market to excite interest. Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptances were all quoted without change from preceding levels.

With the headlock that made him famous fifteen years ago, Ed (Strangler) Lewis, burly Kentuckian, last night threw Jack Sherry, who was developed in the Klondike and now makes his home here, and regained the world's heavyweight wrestling championship at Madison Square Garden.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10. -- On the Supreme Court's decision, expected next week, depends the question of whether Mexico's latest and possibly most remarkable archaeological ruins, at Monte Alban in the State of Oaxaca, will be the subject of continued research work.

ATHENS, Oct. 10 (AP). -- After two failures the United States Government succeeded today in bringing about the detention of Samuel Insull, who is wanted in Chicago to answer an indictment charging grand larceny and embezzlement growing out of the collapse of his vast utilities interests.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10 (AP). -- T.V. O'Connor, chairman of the Shipping Board, today urged friends of American shipping to prepare for "a major attack" this Winter from "those who would undermine the American merchant marine."
CINCINNATI, Oct. 10. -- John E. Kohlsaap, former Cincinnati lumberman, was found dead in bed today at his home in Santa Barbara, Cal. He was 73 years old.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 10. -- Replying to President Hoover's speech here, last week, ex-Senator James A. Reed of Missouri tonight reviewed the President's prophecies in 1928 of continued prosperity, and quoted his utterances since in declaring that the prophecies remain unfulfilled.

GENEVA, Oct. 10. -- Seven women's organizations lost ground today in the spirited fight they have been waging for two years for revision of the Hague nationality convention with a view to its recognizing the equality of the sexes. The first commission of the League of Nations Assembly lined up twenty-three to four, with two abstentions, in favor of a proposal by the Canadian member that the signatories ratify this convention as it stands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- President Hoover, on his trip to Cleveland where he will deliver his second major campaign speech Saturday, plans to make back-platform talks, stopping probably at half a dozen towns. The President's special will leave Washington late Friday night so that the trip through Ohio will be made during the day and permit the President to speak at stations on the way.

Senator REED of Pennsylvania predicts that "there will inevitably be " a tax bill next Winter, no matter " who wins" in the election. On Sept. 30 the Federal Government ended the first quarter of the new fiscal year with an excess of expenditures over receipts amounting to $402,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The success of the u150,000,000 2 per cent Treasury bond issue today, the lists for cash applications being closed an hour after they had been opened, had an electrifying effect on the Stock Exchange, British funds advanced sharply, sentiment was better generally and dealers reported an improvement in business.

GENEVA, Oct. 11. -- The prospects for agreement on a measuring stick for the reduction of effectives are improving, as evidenced today by the better tone in the committee dealing with this complicated phase of the disarmament problems.

In his address last evening Mr. COOLIDGE laid it down that deciding whom to vote for as President of the United States "ought to take on a judicial function." One wonders how many voters he has observed going about the business with the sober and impartial air of a judge.

Officials of the Emergency Work Bureau of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee requested officers of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America at a meeting yesterday to submit by tomorrow an estimate of the cost of converting about 4,000,000 yards of cotton cloth into garments for the families of 263,000 needy New Yorkers.

Expressing concern over the situation between France and Germany, particularly since Germany's withdrawal from the disarmament conference, the Marquess of Reading said yesterday he hoped that the visit of Premier Herriot to London this week would pave the way to an understanding that would bring Germany back into the conference and make possible a solution of the present disturbed condition.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad estimates that its gross revenues in September were $8,400,000, against $9,535,783 in September, 1931. Estimated net operating income was about $1,300,000, against $1,269,658. The estimate would show that the net operating income, with July, 1931, excepted, was the highest in September for any month since October, 1930, when the total was $2,165,506.

IN the Columbia-Princeton game the ball was about two yards from the goal line and about two yards from the right sideline in possession of the Lions. What was the correct play to call? Lou Little was talking about that later. He was sitting around, chatting about football with Chick Meehan, Dean Watkeys, Bill Crowley, John Clinton, Herb Kopf, Joe McKenney, Bill Kelleher, Dinny McNamara, Judge John P. Egan and other football coaches and officials.

BOGOTA, Oct. 11. -- Statements attributed to Colombia's special envoy, Laureano Garcia, on arrival by airplane at Lima exonerating the Lima Government and shifting to the residents of the Peruvian Province of Loreto all blame for the seizure of the town of Leticia on Sept. 1 are criticized by the Bogota press as unnecessary, excessively courteous, and unrepresentative of popular sentiment in Colombia toward Peru.

Tammany Hall is preparing to give loyal and effective support to Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, nominee for President, and Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, candidate for Governor, both of whom it opposed for nomination, as well as to all other Democratic candidates, according to an announcement yesterday by John Mullen, chairman of the Tammany Speakers' Bureau.

As an aftermath of raids made last month on two narcotic plants, five members of an alleged narcotic ring said to be made up of the largest wholesale distributers of drugs in the city, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on evidence presented by Paul Williams, Assistant United States Attorney.

A new organization, which will make its strongest appeal for support to the independent and younger Republican voters, has been organized under the name of the Republican Progressive League. Headquarters are maintained in Suite 1781 in the Woolworth Building.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 11. -- Against a strong freshman team in an hour's scrimmage on the secret practice field today, the three Harvard varsity football teams scored 21 points while holding the first-year, eleven scoreless. The freshman team is considered one of the best yearling elevens that has scrimmaged against the varsity in recent years.
