The Fordham football squad drilled for two hours at Fordham Field yesterday, developing its defense against an aerial attack and working on several new plays in preparation for its encounter with Lebanon Valley at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

Acting on the belief that world trade conditions never were more propitious for increasing American sales to Soviet Russia, representatives of American business interests, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor, took definite steps to eliminate obstacles now blocking a more liberal exchange of goods between this country and Russia.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- William J. Flynn, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, today lost his effort to appeal to the Court of Appeals from a decision, of the Appellate Division in a matter growing out of the Hofstadter committee hearings in New York.

Flounders have begun to run in the waters around Lindenhurst and Bay Shore, according to reports received yesterday, but they are not yet so numerous as to provide exceptional catches. The water still is too warm and the flounders have not schooled, the fishermen say.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 11. -- The Paraguayan Army "continues operating with all success in the Yucra and Cabo Castillo sectors." says a communique issued today by the Paraguayan War Ministry. "We have taken another outpost position defending Yucra, leaving only the central one still in Bolivian hands."
Department would speak for publication, it was emphasized that the matter of returning Mr. Insull to the United States would be pressed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Responsibility for the rise to affluence of gang leaders was placed at the door of prohibition today in a report to the American Bar Association, submitted by its section on criminal law and criminology.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been my custom for a number of years to take my family each Sunday on little trips on the suburban roads surrounding New York City. My observations made on these drives lead me to believe that the crying need is not for more traffic regulations but for education, if possible, of the so-called "Sunday driver," than which there is no greater menace.

Leasing of several midtown lofts, mostly for garment firms, and of stores in various parts of Manhattan was noted in the list of commercial rentals reported by brokers yester- day. Madison Avenue properties were a centre of the leasing activity.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 11. -- The Dartmouth varsity team continued its work today after a two-day rest which enabled the team to recuperate from the Lafayette game.

Calvin Coolidge declared his faith in the soundness of President Hoover's program for business recovery and attacked Governor Roosevelt's silence on payment of the veterans' bonus last night at a Republican rally in Madison Square Garden.

LONDON. Oct. 11. -- Norman H. Davis, United States representative, undertook today to convince Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, that the Hoover proposal for an all-round one-third reduction in armaments should be adopted.

A ten-day drive to enroll 10,000 new members in the Y.M.C.A. of New York City was launched at a dinner last night commemorating the 111th anniversary of the birth of Sir George Williams, who started the Y.M.C.A. movement in London in 1844.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Lieut. Gov. Lehman's career of public service and altruistic efforts along broadly developed and non-sectarian lines, which began practically on the day he left Williams College is ample justification for the things said of him editorially in THE TIMES of Oct. 6.

Legalization by Congress of the manufacture and sale of beer by next March was predicted yesterday by Speaker John N. Garner, Democratic nominee for Vice President, in an interview at Democratic national headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- The State Finance Commission announced today that a public hearing would be held next Tuesday to determine sentiment toward a proposal that North Bergen township's short-term obligations be refunded by means of a $9,000,000 bond issue.
WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 11. -- Dr. Simon S. Baker, former head of Washington and Jefferson College, was found shot to death today.

Despite a general decline in the number of business failures during the week ended Oct. 6, retail suspensions registered a gain, Bradstreet's reported yesterday. Store bankruptcies totaled 328, as compared with 312 in the previous week and 298 in the corresponding week of last year.

BAY CITY, Mich., Oct. 11. -- Favored at last by the weather man who had plagued them with wind, rain and even snow, drivers in the fourth annual national outboard regatta succeeded today in settling the last of twelve national championships.

With the season hardly more than under way and some of the traditionally strong teams yet to be put to a real test, it is idle perhaps to speculate upon which elevens will stand forth at the end of the year.

The Board of Estimate considered yesterday a communication from Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the American Steel and Iron Institute, asking that domestic steel be specified for all city construction to check the influx of lower-priced foreign steel, which, he charged, was being dumped here at less than the production cost.

The Kraushaar Gallery has long made it a custom to open a new season with an exhibition of French paintings, after that devoting itself almost exclusively to American art. This year's gesture (and it is never a gesture in any merely polite or superficial sense) opened yesterday with a group of oils, weter-colors and drawings which trill remain on view until Nov. 5.

Toward the close of the third act of "The Great Lover," which shook off its dusty cerements and marched last night upon the stage of the Waldorf Theatre, that authority in amorous intrigue, Lou Tellegen, stepped to the centre and reminded his audience of an irrefutable fact.

A request for a more even division of naval repair work, which would tend to relieve the hardship brought on the employes of the Brooklyn Navy Yard "through the Navy's actions in this respect," was made yesterday to Secretary of the Navy Adams in a letter signed by William Kennedy Jr., president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.

Despite the promises of all political parties that Federal taxes will be reduced, the fixed charges of government, including interest and amortization charges, are piling up so fast that Federal tax reduction will be impossible for the next ten years, Representative Fiorello H. La Guardia told the Kiwanis Club of New York City at its weekly luncheon at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.
The address of Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican nominee for Governor, who spoke on the same program with former President Coolidge, follows:

Christopher Columbus will be honored today by the Italian Benevolent Society with traditional ceremonies in Columbus Circle at the base of his monument. Those who prefer to remain at home may hear a radio program originating in Spain, the country which started Columbus and his tiny ships across the Atlantic 440 years ago.

A plan which would tend to eliminate the third degree was presented by Professor Raymond Moley, head of the Department of Law and Jurisdiction at Columbia University, in an address last night in the assembly hall of the Community Church, 2 East Seventy-sixth Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11. -- Bolting the Republican party tonight, Representative Charles Brand of Urbana declared his opposition to the agricultural policies of President Hoover and his belief that the party "deserves defeat and reorganization."

Coach Lou Little had the Columbia back-field combinations run through their offensive and defensive paces yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the meeting with the University of Virginia on Saturday.

Areas of empty seats dotted the floor of Madison Square Garden last night when the Republicans began their offensive there. High up in the eastern balconies the areas began -- long, wide stretches. About 18,000 New York Republicans responded to the call for their party's first important rally in the East.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP). -- A more liberal policy of permitting corporations to deduct from their gross income for tax purposes contributions to community chests and like organizations has been adopted by the Internal Revenue Bureau at the direction of David Burnet, commissioner.
The text of former President Calvin Coolidge's address last night at Madison Square Garden follows:

John F. Curry Jr., son of the leader of Tammany, made his debut in politics yesterday by accepting the chairmanship of the men's branch of the Young Voters' League for the Election of John P. O'Brien, Democratic nominee for Mayor. Miss Evelyn Sloan, daughter of John Sloan, well-known architect, is chairman of the women's branch.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Belfast was a closely guarded city tonight following a demonstration by 10,000 jobless men and women which turned into a series of riots. More than 2,000 police patrolled the streets on foot and in armored cars.

Statements denouncing former President Coolidge as "a willing and eager accomplice" of the forces that brought on the depression, and warning workers and farmers throughout the country that "coercion and downright terrorism" may be expected to be applied with increasing force and frequency from now until election day, were made yesterday by Socialist officials.

Confirming reports that he would take another playhouse in addition to the Apollo Theatre, George White completed yesterday a rental arrangement for the Casino Theatre. The contract was signed by Mr. White and William B. Symmes Jr., vice president of the 755 Seventh Avenue Corporation, which controls the house.

NAPLES, Oct. 11. -- Professor Amedeo Majuri, superintendent of antiquities, after years of patient research has found what without doubt is the true grotto of the sibyl of Cumae, whose oracles, according to Vergil, first told of the Rome that was to be founded.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, was the chief speaker at a meeting in honor of the life and work of the late Rev. Terence J. Shealy held last night in the Assembly Hall of the Church of St. Francis Xavier on Sixteenth Street.

The executive committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York met yesterday at the office of the president of the association, John W. Davis, 15 Broad Street, to consider ways to put into effect the decision of the association to bring about an investigation of the bipartisan nominations of State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer for justices of the Supreme Court.

Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Wednesday, Oct. 12. -- Sources close to the palace of Pu Yi, Chief Executive of Manchukuo, asserted today that the former "Boy Emperor" of China had received emissaries from China proper and discussed with them the possibility of restoring at least a part of the Chinese monarchy under the Manchu dynasty.

All the markets will be closed today in observance of Columbus Day, an established holiday. The banks as well as business organizations generally in the principal financial centres will be closed. Business will be resumed tomorrow as usual.

Three women and a child were injured yesterday on the ascension escalator of the 181st Street Station, in Fort Washington Avenue, of the municipally operated Eighth Avenue subway when one of the women. Mrs. Sarah Seligman, 62 years old, of 44 Pinehurst Avenue, lost her balance.

The floating supply of the United States Steel Corporation's common stock, as Indicated by the amount in brokers' names, increased 145,520 shares, or 13.2 per cent, in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday. The corporation's statistics showed also that foreign holdings had increased 29,823 shares, or 13.4 per cent.

The Republic and the Eltinge Theatres, which were closed last month to burlesque by order of Acting Mayor McKee, will reopen this afternoon. The new show at the Republic will be called the "Frolics," and that at the Eltinge the "Follies," and there will be a censor and a "czar" to watch over the entertainment.

Mr. YEATS from his mystic Fairyland and G.B.S. from the bowers of Shavia are the patrons of the lately established Irish Academy of Letters. There is a plethora of literary talent and genius to choose from; and if the purpose of the institution is to encourage writing which is Irish in theme and character, that purpose has been and is being fulfilled ably and amply.

At the close of the third act of "I Loved You Wednesday," which was acted at the Sam H. Harris last evening, the celebrated ballerina decides not to elope sinfully with her returned lover. Save for the fact that plays must never close before 11 o'clock, it is a decision that she might have made earlier in the evening, and perhaps there is less at stake than the authors imagine.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 11. -- Police from the six counties of Northern Ireland were rushed tonight to Belfast, where one man was killed and forty-eight persons, including seven policemen, were wounded in violent clashes between the police and the unemployed.

Although constructive tendencies in business have not yet completely gained the upper hand over the deeply rooted causes of the depression, there are definite signs of improvement, S.H. Logan, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Unless the State budget is slashed to the bone the 1933 Legislature will face a $100,000,000 deficit, Senator Charles J. Hewitt, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, stated today at the first open meeting of the legislative committee on economy in State government.

The new Grace liner Santa Rosa developed a speed of 20.05 knots yesterday during her sea trials off Portland, Me., according to a radiogram from E.T. Ford, president or the Panama Mail, subsidiary of the Grace Line. The ship was fog-bound when Mr. Ford's message was sent, but she had passed through all tests successfully, he said.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11. -- John H. Dillon, wholesale merchant, breeder and owner of trotting horses, died this morning at his home here of an intestinal hemorrhage with which he was stricken last Saturday. He was 75 years old and leaves his wife, a daughter, Miss Gertrude Dillon, and a son, John Dillon, a lawyer, of this city.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Conference topics which will be discussed by the members of the school of public and international affairs of Princeton University during the current season were announced here today by Roy I. Kimmel, director of conferences of the school.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11. -- By ordering eight changes today the Yale football coaches indicated the extent of their dissatisfaction with the eleven which, instead of defeating Bates College and Chicago University, could gain only tie scores.

An endowment fund of at least 1,000,000 for the relief of needy musicians will be sought after the Musicians' Emergency Aid has been transformed into a permanent organization by incorporation Jan. 1 under the name of "The Musicians' Emergency Fund."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct 11. -- All favorites advanced to the semi-final round in men's singles in the Greenbrier Autumn tennis tournament today. Three of the quarter-final matches went to three sets. In the fourth match, J. Gilbert Hall defeated Manfred Goldman in straight sets, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

Registration totals for the first two days of Registration Week, in spite of heavy increases in enrolment in Brooklyn and the Bronx, failed by 1,568 to equal the two-day record set in 1928, the last Presidential year.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The real estate broker's license issued to Brady, Cryan Colleran, Inc., of Long Island has been revoked, by A. C. MacNulty, Deputy Secretary of State and chief of the division of licenses. Mr. MacNulty also refused an application by Frank P. Nicholson for re-issue of his license as a real estate salesman in the employ of the McGolrick Realty Company.
The local outdoor boxing season will close tonight at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, with a program featuring two world's champions in non-title matches arranged in the interests of charity.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 11. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare and Miss Helen Hicks drew nearer their probable match in the final of the women's Hot Springs Fall golf tournament with easy victories at the Homestead course today.

Acting Mayor McKee denied the appeals of civic and business organizations yesterday asking the city to seek a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to build the Triborough Bridge and the proposed Thirty-eighth Street Tunnel and reiterated his opposition against looking to Washington to help the city with these projects.

ROME, Oct. 11. -- The latest Italian unemployment statistics, compiled Aug. 31, give a total of 946,000 out of work. It is certain there has been an increase since then, but it is believed the number is still below 1,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Hoover in his program for the farmers proposes a number of measures, not the least important of which is a "high protective tariff." By this method of artificial respiration he evidently hopes to preserve them at least long enough to obtain their votes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- President Hoover was called a "false-alarm statesman" today by Senator Hull of Tennessee for stating in his Des Moines speech that the United States was once within two weeks of going off the gold standard. The former chairman of the Democratic National Committee added that the "President was wholly unjustified in his grossly exaggerated reference to our gold situation."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, declared in an address here tonight that America's policy of "isolation" has prevented "Europe from becoming a modern and harmonious body of States."

The proposal of the Electrical Contractors' Association of Greater New York for a $12 a day wage scale in the new contract now under negotiation was unanimously rejected at a special meeting attended by about 3,000 members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers at the Central Opera House last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Colder weather and small receipts brought a better demand for hogs today, but the market was little affected and prices averaged somewhat lower. Compared with Monday, sales were steady to 10 cents lower, although some sales appeared as much as 10 cents higher than the inside figures of the previous day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The action of regulatory bodies of nine States in preventing railroads from collecting on intrastate traffic the Increased freight rates it authorized Jan. 4 was declared by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to be in violation of the interstate commerce act.

President HOOVER has spoken the conviction of many deeply concerned for our future in insisting upon "the "necessity of maintaining and sup"porting our schools as the first "charge on all our resources in "these times of emergency."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Five hundred disgruntled farmers have definitely planned to join the "march on Washington" for a four-day conference beginning Dec. 7, Lem Harris, executive secretary of the Farmers' National Relief Conference, said today, and he predicted that the number might reach 5,000.

The movement of practically all markets yesterday suggested that the very transparent attempt to conjure up alarm, because Mr. Hoover had talked gloomily about the "gold situation" of last Winter, had ended its very brief career. Needless to say, the whole performance was foolish, on the financial as on the political side, and the time had very evidently come for markets to talk sense again.

Merchant tonnage under construction in the shipyards of the world decreased to 901,067 tons in the quarter ended Sept. 30, dropping below the 1,000,000-ton mark for the first time in more than fifty years, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 11. -- In an outspoken program speech applauded at times by the whole Chamber, Premier Julius Goemboes announced today that the government would introduce nation-wide secret voting in the near future and establish public freedom and a free press.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 11. -- Governor Norman S. Case, Chief Executive since 1928, was renominated today by the Republican State Convention. He defeated Lieut. Gov. James G. Connolly by a vote of 251 to 33.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,173,000 barrels, compared with 2,172,000 barrels in the preceding week, an increase of 1,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 14,900 barrels in East Texas and a decline of 6,900 in California were the most important changes.

Through so experienced a spokesman as Tom Thorp, long recognized as one of the country's foremost football arbiters, gridiron officials yesterday replied to the inference of coaches that violations of one of the new rules, barring forceful use of hands by defensive linemen, were not being "called" frequently enough.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Elimination of county and town highway departments by grouping all highway maintenance and construction under the State Department of Public Works was recommended in one of ten resolutions adopted today at the annual convention of the New York State Automobile Association.

PEIPING, Oct. 11. -- The Barga Mongols were reported here today to have proclaimed a Soviet Republic, thus complicating conditions in the ill-defined border region of Manchuria and Mongolia, claimed by Manchukuo.
The address of General James G. Harbord at the Republican mass meeting in Madison Square Garden last night follows:

MULLICA HILL, N.J., Oct. 11. -- A wide search, was started by the police here today for four armed men who entered the Farmers' National Bank this afternoon, bound and gagged two bank employes and two depositors, and escaped with $9,000 from the cash drawer in a walfing automobile with a fifth man.

Parcel post packages addressed for delivery in El Salvador must have attached one dispatch note, form 2972, and two customs declarations, form 2966, Postmaster Kiely announced yesterday. Group shipments require only one set of customs declarations and one dispatch note, he stated.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 11. -- Overcome by carbon monoxide gas while in the air, four passengers of a United Air Lines tri-motored plane, piloted by B.O. Howard from Chicago, were unconscious when it landed at the Kansas City Airport this afternoon.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11. -- Gregory Zinovieff, long a holder of high Soviet offices; Leo Kameneff, brother-inlaw of Leon Trotsky, and eighteen less known Communists were expelled by the Communist party today as "traitors to the party and the working class for trying to form by underground ways a counter-revolutionary organization to re-establish capitalism in the U.S.S.R."

The adolescents' court, an experimental project of the board of city magistrates, is to start functioning in the Criminal Courts Building next Monday, Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein, one of the originators of the plan, announced yesterday.

Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, and Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis, were among speakers who greeted the Republican Committee of One Hundred, a women's group, at its first Fall meeting yesterday at the Hotel Dorset.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Representative O'Connor of New York, a wet leader, today asserted that the statement made yesterday by Senator Reed of Pennsylvania that the Volstead act would be modified at the December session of Congress was an attempt to sway wet voters to the Republican ticket.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Two Princeton varsity teams scored four touchdowns and a safety against a reserve eleven during a fifty-minute scrimmage on University Field today as the Tigers began intensive preparations for the Cornell game here Saturday.

"The Things That Are Caesar's," a play by Paul V. Carroll, will be the opening bill of the Abbey Theatre Irish Players, who will begin a four weeks' engagement at the Martin Beck Theatre next Monday evening. The play, which won a prize in a competition conducted by the Abbey Theatre in Dublin, was produced there late this Summer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Double taxation of long sales of stock where the broker must "borrow" from his own portfolio sufficient shares to complete a transaction made by an out-of-town branch would be eliminated under a recommendation submitted to David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, by General Counsel Clarence M. Charest, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- An oversold condition was disclosed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here, and aggressive buying by houses with Eastern connections absorbed the surplus in the on and made the close at about the best figures of the day, with net gains of 3/4 to 7/2 cent a bushel.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Low Pierrepont, who returned on the Champlain, have departed for a brief visit in Coronado, Cal., where their son, Lieutenant John Jay Pierrepont, is stationed on the U.S.S. Concord.

The passenger list of the French Line motorship Lafayette, due today from Havre via Plymouth, includes Mrs. Robert H. Dunlap, widow of Brig. Gen. Dunlap of the United States Marines who died some time ago at Lyons, France, in an attempt to rescue victims of a landslide.

Seven artists are represented in the current exhibition at the Caz-Delbo Gallery, 561 Madison Avenue. About half of the paintings are the work of Paul Berdanier, who has certain points of contact with influences as diverse as Monet, van Gogh and the Barbizon school.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 11. -- Eighty players turned out for the last one-day tournament of the season for members of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Garden City Country Club today.

Whirlwind campaigning by candidates on the Republican State ticket was ruled out after conference yesterday among W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, and party leaders at headquarters in the Pershing Square Building.

Television, was utilized for the first time in a political campaign last night when the stage and screen division of the Democratic National Committee broadcast a show over W2XAB from the television studio of the Columbia system, at 485 Madison Avenue.

Tuesday, Oct. 11, 1932. Money market idled through another session devoid of feature. Rates in all sections, on every class of accommodation, remained unchanged. Business was very light, representing routine requirements.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 11 (AP). -- A rise in crude oil prices spread through the entire mid-continent area today as three companies announced they would meet an increase posted last night for East Texas and the Gulf Coast area.
Several sales of housing properties by lending institutions were included in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- A preview of a motion picture on which may hinge the future relations between the Italian Government and one of the leading motion-picture companies of the United States will be held here for the inspection of Italian officials within a few days.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11. -- Captain J. Vazquez of the Mexican Army today was the opponent of Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris who, invincible thus far, appears headed for sure victory in the international chess masters tournament at the Press Social Centre.

TOWNSEND, Mass., Oct. 11. -- George Arthur "Wilder, postmaster here for ten years, former Representative and for many years town treasurer and town clerk, died today at the age of 73, after a long illness.

Columbia University's recent ruling against outdoor meetings on the campus and requiring the presence of a professor as chairman at indoor meetings open to the public has been rescinded by the committee on student organizations, it was announced yesterday by The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper.

Reiterating that he intended to make his campaign for election on the issue of economy, Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor, came out yesterday against the so-called Delaney plan of financing subway construction by the issue of four-year bonds and declared for the fifty-year bond plan favored by Controller Charles W. Berry.

General Casimir Pulaski, the Polish patriot who aided the cause of the American Revolution, was eulogized over WOR yesterday in a special half-hour, presentation in observance of Pulaski Day at which Mieczyslaw Marchlewski, the Polish Consul General in New York, was a speaker.

Manchuria is of vital importance to the political and economic existence of Japan, Hiroshi Saito, Japanese Charge d'Affaires at Washington, said yesterday afternoon in an address to students of the Columbia University School of Journalism.

As city School teachers were being advised yesterday to resist salary cuts until the true state of city finances was shown by the Board of Estimate, the Public Education Association attacked the 1933 tentative budget for levying what it called a disproportionate share of city economy, on the school system.

When Jascha Heifetz played for the first time in two years in this city last night at Carnegie Hall, he found awaiting him an audience which had exhausted the capacity of the hall and which overflowed into every available nook and cranny of the auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- American foreign policy faces a new test in the French proposals for a new plan of disarmament discussion reported in press dispatches from Paris today, in the opinion of the best-informed observers here.

PARIS, Oct. 11 (AP). -- J.M. Renaitour, a member of the Chamber of Deputies, who is attempting to obtain annulment of an order which expelled William Randolph Hearst from France two years ago, said today that he had been assured by Premier Herriot that if Mr. Hearst were to return to this country he would not be bothered by the French officials.

BURLEY, Idaho, Oct. 11. -- Senator William E. Borah, Republican, Idaho, in an address here tonight advocated a four-point program for economic recovery -- adjustment of World War problems, expansion of the currency, elimination of extravagance in government and adjustment of private debts to conform to the change in money values.

Initial showings of Winter dress collections were made here yesterday in a general showing by members of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America. Interest centred on elaborate evening and afternoon dresses in new materials, with both the fitted waistline and the new lowered waist-line of Patou important silhouette features.
BUDAPEST, Oct. 11 -- Count Kuno Klebelsberg, Minister of Education and one of the most prominent members of Count Stephen Bethlen de Bethlen's Cabinet of 1921-1931, died here today of typhoid.

Following the recommendations made last November by the Loose Milk Commission, which found "a potential health hazard" in the bulk product and urged prohibition of Its sale except under certain limitations and restrictions, the Board of Health adopted a resolution yesterday making the ban on loose milk effective June 1, 1933.

What he termed the disregard of the cost of government in this State by public servants was attacked yesterday in a brief address by Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, at a luncheon of the League of Advertising Women in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

More than 100 of the city's Democratic political leaders swung niblick and mashie yesterday over the links of the Queens Valley Golf Club, Forest Hills, Queens, when members of the National Democratic Club held the last of the season's golf tournaments.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- Within an hour of the opening of the Bank of England this morning the government had received all the cash applications it deemed necessary to meet the new 1935-1938 issue of u150,000,000 2 per cent treasury bonds [the pound is worth 3.44 1/4].

Gertrude E. Archer gave to George M. Davis a mortgage for $3,000, due Sept. 1. 1935, at 6 per cent, and to be amortized $100 semi-annually, on her dwelling at 475 W. 144th St., subject to any prior mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Georgetown football team went back to fundamentals today in a three-hour work out against New York University's offense and defense systems. Stressing the primary running plays and early season blocking and passing the varsity drilled in high winds and the chilliest weather of the Fall.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's Risque drove to a courageous victory over eight other fillies and mares in the Pocahontas Handicap, mile-and-seventy-yard feature today at Laurel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- One of the most striking revelations of census analysis, say government statisticians, is the large number of older men that are gainful workers in the United States during relatively normal times.

It is the pleasure of the returning George Fawcett, an actor known to the older generation of playgoers and to cinema fans, to play an ageing and slightly faded French diplomat and boulevardier in "Peacock", which turned up at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre last night.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan, now a justice of the Children's Court in Queens, withdrew yesterday as an independent candidate for Mayor and announced his support of Surrogate John P. O'Brien, regular Democratic nominee, who served under him as Corporation Counsel.

LAWTON, Okla., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Secretary Hurley declared tonight that Governor Roosevelt "has outlined no program" and that the "Hoover non-partisan reconstruction program" is "just now moving into action."

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting yesterday as a district judge, appointed the law firm of Hornblower, Miller, Miller Boston, of which former Governor Nathan L. Miller is the head, as counsel for the receivers of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- The Boerse opened today depressed and uncertain, and prices sagged, leading stocks like German Petroleum and Rhenish Brown Coal losing 1 to 2 per cent. After the first hour an upward turn set in and, under an increasing volume of orders, the market quickly recovered most of its losses, several stocks rising above their opening levels.

A score of Manhattan and Bronx properties were put up at court sales conducted by auctioneers yesterday. These were liquidation sales resulting from defaults on mortgage payments and arrears in interest.

The lone scholastic football game scheduled to be played in New York City today will bring together two Bronx schools, De Witt Clinton and Morris, at the George Washington High School Stadium in their annual Columbus Day contest. The opening kick-off is slated for 2:30 P.M. Morris won last year, 13 -- 0.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP). -- A defense witness in the murder trial of two former prison guards testified today in corroboration of the prosecution's claim that an effort was made to deceive authorities into believing that Arthur Maillefert, a young convict from Westfield, N.J., deliberately hanged himself in a prison sweat-box.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- Many leaders of the nation's business and industrial activity mobilized here today were told by speakers that economic conditions had shown marked improvement, aside from the burden of the cost of government, and heard from Governor Doyle E. Carlton of Florida a prediction that his State was due for an early recovery in real estate values.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity stands at 24.2 for the week ended Oct. 8, as against 22.9 for the preceding week and 40.7 for the corresponding week last year. The weekly estimates by Dow, Jones Co.; the American Metal Market, The Iron Age and Steel turned out to have been too low, on the average, for September.
FLORENCE, Italy, Oct. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Lord Somerset was a Conservative Member of Parliament for Monmouthshire from 1871 to 1880 and controller of Queen Victoria's household from 1874 to 1879.

THREE RIVERS, Que., Oct. 11 (Canadian Press). -- With the bout even after each had taken one fall, Charles Lehman, 208, New Orleans, was disqualified for rough tactics and the feature match of a wrestling card tonight awarded to George Zarynoff 200, Boston.
PARIS, Oct. 11. -- Premier Herriot will take with him to London tomorrow for his conversations with British officials two large portfolios.

Petitions bearing more than 8,300 signatures were filed last night with the Board of Elections formally placing George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch in nomination for the Supreme Court in the Manhattan-Bronx District as the candidates of the Independent Judges party.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Lieut. Col. Theodor Duesterberg, second in command of the Reich's 800,000 Stahlhelm [steel helmet] war veterans, confirmed today that he had offered to resign his post on learning recently that his ancestry was partly Jewish.

Anyhow, Who Reads Newspapers? Ex-Mayor WALKER, Anyhow, so original a figure Who Reads in many ways, is Newspapers? 100 Per cent orthodox on the subject of newspapers and politicians. He subscribes without reserve to the ancient rule that when a public official has the support of the press the newspapers are the most powerful agency for good in modern life.

Representatives of all branches of the fine arts comprise the governing board of La Boheme, "the club of the artists," which has just been organized for actors, authors, painters, musicians, dancers, sculptors and architects. The inaugural entertainment will take place Oct. 29 in the grand ballroom of the Pierce.
ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- Governor Roosevelt and Speaker Garner exchanged views today on the progress of the campaign for the ticket they head, meeting for the first time since the Governor's Western tour.

BERLIN, Oct. 11. -- Charging that the von Papen Government had violated the Constitution by refusing to answer its summons, the Reichstag's standing committee on foreign affairs today threatened the Cabinet with impeachment proceedings to be instituted by the Reichstag that is to be elected Nov. 6.

The "little accident" -- a description which Governor GARDINER gave to the disappearance of Republican majorities in Maine on Sept. 12 -- extended to Aroostook County, seat of the potato empire. This year's crop amounted to 41,760,000 bushels, and at present prices would show a loss of $13,000,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Answering the speech of ex-Senator James A. Reed in Des Moines Senator Dickinson of Iowa contradicted the Missourian's assertion that "we were never within $2,700,000,000 of the lawful suspension of gold payments."

A three-year contract "with a substantial increase" was the reward which Colonel Jacob Ruppert conferred upon Manager Joe McCarthy yesterday for his skillful piloting of the New York Yankees into an American League championship and a world's series triumph in four straight games in his second campaign as their leader.

PARIS, Oct. 11. -- The dollar improved today on the Bourse despite yesterday's unfavorable reports from Wall Street, which tended otherwise to depress the market here. The final figure was 25.48, which brought the dollar back where it had stood on last Friday.

Cornelius V. Whitney's Hell Diver, a gelded son of Peter Pan, scored in the featured Oceanus Claiming Handicap at Jamaica yesterday and helped make more secure Robby Robertson's place as the leading rider of the meeting.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Making his first campaign speech in New Jersey at a dinner of the Friends of Franklin D. Roosevelt here tonight, United States Senator Pat Harrison of Mississippi, declared that government extravagance, not only in the Federal Government but other units as well, had become a menace to the progress and economic life of the American people.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Oct. 11. -- After weeks of feverish preparatory activity the cordon of Japanese troops completely surrounding the Tungpien area started yesterday the most intensive rebel and bandit suppression campaign attempted since the Japanese occupation of Manchuria a year ago.

The controversy between the vestry of All Souls Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue and the rector, the Rev. Rollin Dodd, over holding separate services for Negro worshippers there was further complicated last night when the vestry voted to suspend all church services until repairs could be made to the interior of the edifice.

The committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to recommend the granting of one-year franchises to all existing bus operators in Manhattan and Queens, including the "emergency" lines running under the supervision of the Department of Plant and Structures.

"Roosevelt will be elected President," said James Hamilton Lewis, Senator from Illinois and veteran Democratic politician, when he landed here yesterday afternoon from the White Star liner Majestic. He still showed traces of the illness that he suffered in Paris.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 11 (AP). -- The Royal Commission on Transportation reported to the House of Commons today that Canadian railways have been indulging in wasteful competition when they should have been cooperating to meet the menace of highway traffic.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- With the convening of Congress still two months Off, the Banking Committee of the United States Senate decided in Washington tonight to delve into the tangled evidence surrounding the collapse of the Insull utilities system.

JOLO, P.I., Oct. 11 (AP). -- Failing in efforts to obtain the removal of native women from the armed Moro village of Tayungan, Lieut. Col. Luther R. Stevens of the Philippine Constabulary tonight served an ultimatum on entrenched native warriors that his forces would attack at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning.

A campaign sponsored by the banks to educate the American people to "take its medicine" in the form of readjustments necessitated by the current depression was urged yesterday by Earnest Elmo Calkins at a luncheon of the New York Financial Advertisers.

Prices for cotton rose yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here as a result of covering and trade buying, accompanied by reports of a continued tight spot situation in the South, low temperatures in the northwestern part of the cotton belt and general firmness in the stock market.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 11. -- A reorganization of the operations of the State Highway Commission to effect a saving of $979,830 was announced here today. The plan calls for retrenchments which include the laying off of 106 men, placing sixty-one others on a part-time employment basis, establishment of a five-day week in two divisions and consolidation of the Jersey City and Newark offices of the department.
ATHENS, Oct. 11 (AP). -- Samuel Insull was freed by the Greek authorities today after Prime Minister Venizelos had made inquiries to determine whether his detention was legal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- Totally unemployed persons in the United States now number, about 11,000,000, according to estimates of administrative officials based on calculations of the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the American Federation of Labor.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- The Federal Home Loan bank act was the principal subject before the Mortgage Bankers' Association of America at its annual convention today.

Buyers Hero Show Decrease. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Reports coming to the Republican National Committee headquarters at the Waldorf-Astoria from the States traversed by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt during his recent swing through the country have created a much better feeling among the Eastern campaign managers of President Hoover, it was said yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 11. -- A member of one of Westchester's prominent golfing families, Mrs. John D. Chapman of Greenwich, played a significant part today in the victory which the women's WestChester team scored in recapturing the Myra D. Paterson trophy in the annual triangular series.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Approximately $3,000,000 will be expanded by the gas industry during the next three years in a national advertising campaign to bolster business, it was announced today.

The hope that "the necessity for the creation of an inferior class of medical men as practitioners may never become obligatory in this country because of the superscientific zeal of those who direct medical education" is expressed by Dr. Francis A. Packard, editor of Annals of American History, in the preface to his two-volume "History of Medicine in the United States," published by Paul B. Hoeber.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 12 (AP). -- British troops were rushed to Belfast today after rioting, similar to that which resulted in one death and more than thirty serious injuries yesterday, broke out again shortly before noon.

MALAD, Idaho, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Denouncing the gold-standard dollar of the present as "not an honest dollar," Senator Borah tonight appealed for an expansion of currency to "give the American people a medium of circulation to replace that in hoarding."

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 12. -- Senator Carter Glass, who was Secretary of the Treasury under Wilson, gave out today the following statement in reply to administration Republicans who insist that President Hoover prevented this country from being driven off the gold standard:

ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- In its effort to find means of reducing the State budget the Joint Legislative Committee on Economy turned its attention today to the State Fair at Syracuse, which the experts have recommended Should be made self-supporting.

Patrolman John Montague of Traffic E captured a hold-up pair, Joseph Gaff and Louise Barranco, in Eighth Avenue between Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets at noon yesterday after he had been shot in the left arm and in the abdomen by Gaff.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 12 (AP). -- A convict witness for the defense in the murder trial of two former prison camp guards testified today that a "walking boss" beat Arthur Maillefert, young New Jersey convict, with a heavy stick three minutes because the youth refused to drink a second half-pint dose of castor oil.

A promise to make his campaign on five major issues was given last night by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic nominee for Governor, in a brief address before 2,000 members of the Columbian Order at a dinner at the Brooklyn Elks clubhouse.

A new radio tube, heralded as a practical source of unlimited "cold light" with which television screens can be flooded, was demonstrated yesterday by the Myers Electrical Research Laboratory in the Chrysler Building. The engineers asserted the bulb had overcome a tremendous obstacle in television by responding instantaneously and completely to the rapid fluctuations of radio waves that carry images.

The Republic and Eltinge Theatres, which received their licenses to operate on Tuesday, opened to the public yesterday. Both called their offerings "revues," for it was by the use of that term that they acquired their licenses. But both still seemed to specialize in humor of a fairly broad scope, and in dancing and farce comedy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The economic depression will bring about a revaluation of the merits of college training, Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, declares in an article written especially for The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate newspaper of Princeton University.

The first three days of registration week, completed yesterday, showed a marked falling off, as compared with the similar period in 1928, the last Presidential year. Unless enrolment materially increases today, tomorrow and Saturday, when registration closes, the total this year will be considerably less, according to present indications, than the record total of 1928.

Senator BORAH began on Tuesday the series of free-lance speeches which he had announced that he was going to make. They have no relation to the Presidential election. Mr. BORAH is to campaign for neither party, frankly expressing his dislike and distrust of both.

GENEVA. Oct. 12. -- Samuel Reber Jr., the United States' State Department's representative on the League Council's Liberian committee, told that group today the United States considered that the League's plan for Liberian construction allowed a basis for direct negotiations botween Liberia and the Finance Corporation of America.

MUNICH, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Chancellor von Papen told a group of Bavarian industrial leaders today that change in the fundamental structure of Germany was imperative in order that the stability of the government would not be jeopardized by accidental legislative majorities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Virtually dictatorial powers could be conferred upon a foreign "adviser" to Liberia, a republic established a century ago as a sanctuary for Negroes, under a plan drawn by a League of Nations committee and made public today at the State Department.

With zero hour set for 11 o'clock this morning, the forces planning attack on the 1933 tentative budget before the Board of Estimate consolidated their positions yesterday while the bloc in the board headed by Controller Charles W. Berry prepared to defend the document which shows a reduction of $16,717,385 from the city's current expenses.

An encouraging upturn in the aviation business, including large orders for planes in the export and domestic fields and increased sales in school and supply services, was reported yesterday by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation. John S. Allard, vice president of the corporation, said the export business was better than ever before.

New York had a foretaste of Winter weather yesterday with chilly temperatures that went as low as 43 degrees, brief snow flurries in Times Square and vicinity, as well as in the Bronx, and winds of gale force -- fifty miles an hour -- that caused two minor accidents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Modification of the West African Lines Conference agreement changing its name to the American West African Conference and broadening its scope, was approved today by the Shipping Board. The agreement was extended to cover traffic to and from Canadian ports and to include the Cape Verde Islands and the Islands of Fernando Po, Sao Thome and Principe off the west coast off Africa.

General John J. Pershing and other directors of the American Legion War Memorial in Paris, known as Pershing Hall, have been sued in the Supreme Court for $50,000 damages because an international contract bridge tournament, designed to raise funds for the memorial, has been abandoned, it was disclosed yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 12 -- An application to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of $1,200,000 for the construction of the Baldwin-Point Lookout causeway, had been made by the Hempstead Sauseway Authority, it became known here today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- Formal announcement of the formation here of the second post of the American Veterans, a national organization of veterans who are opposed to immediate payment of the adjusted compensation certificates and who were unable to express themselves satisfactorily through the American Legion, was made tonight by A.J. Robertson, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, who is active in the new post.

Two Insurance men, each, married and having a son of his own and one of them with his own business and a $25,000 home in Flatbush, were arrested yesterday, charged with the kidnapping of John Arthur Russel, 8-year-old son of a partner in a New York Stock Exchange firm, in Brooklyn on Sept. 19.

Writers are so busily engaged in writing for one another, so occupied with "form" and literary style, that literature is due for a long sleep, "the prey of a sterile aestheticism that substitutes the means of art for the end," unless it re-establishes its connection with the "laboring body of humanity," Van Wyck Brooks, biographer and critic, writes in "Sketches in Criticism," published today by Dutton.
ALBANY, Oct. 12. -- Governor Roosevelt will visit mid-West and border States before heading into the South on his second campaign tour, starting next Tuesday, he announced today.

Declaring that he had "made a mistake," the Rev. John Lehnert, pastor of the First Baptist Church of West New York. N.J.. urged members of his church yesterday to accept recommendations for his suspension as a pastor made by a council of the German group of Baptist Churches in Northern New Jersey, as a result of carges that Mr. Lehnert had issued fraudulent marriage certificates.

In an address at the Hotel Biltmore last night Senator Robert F. Wagner assailed the Republican administration for "the blindness, panic and futility" of its leadership and accused President Hoover of having pursued a "do nothing" policy for the past five years.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The three synods in Canada which help to comprise the United Lutheran Church in America will withdraw to form a new United Lutheran Church of Canada if the biennial convention of the denomination supports a recommendation voted by its executive committee today.

Business on all important American markets yesterday was suspended for the Columbus holiday. In Europe, returning cheerfulness was displayed on all Stock Exchanges; largely, no doubt, in response to the Wall Street recovery of Tuesday. Wheat on the foreign markets hardly changed; cotton at Liverpool advanced.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 12. -- The Paraguayan War Minister announced today the capture of the Bolivian forts Lara and Cabo Castillo, southwest of Boqueron.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 12 -- Fire Chief Louis Behrens, with a service record of fifty-six years, longer than any other fire chief in the United States, was found dead this morning in his bed in fire headquarters. He had retired the night before in unusually fine spirits and his clothing was found as usual arranged in a position to be put on quickly in case of an alarm.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 12 (AP) -- J. Fred Adams's Rehoboth, paying $23.20, was a surprise victor in the Columbus Purse of six furlongs, feature today at Laurel. Chu Chu, another outsider, was second and the well supported Curacao third in the field of eight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- A woman was killed, a man critically injured and burned and four other persons were hurt when two automobiles in which they were riding were in collision and burst into flames at 7:30 o'clock tonight on Westchester Avenue near the entrance of the Hutchinson River Parkway here.

The dry forces of the country will unite immediately after the elections to prevent the legalization and sale of beer by next March, which change was predicted on Tuesday by Speaker Garner, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, according to sentiment expressed yesterday at a conference of prohibition leaders in the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "A Stop-Gap Mayor" is hardly fair to the 32,000 delegates summoned by an order of the Court of Appeals to nominate a candidate for Mayor. "If the city has had a Mayoralty election forced upon it at the last hour and amid great confusion," it was not the fault of the delegates.

Senator WATSON emerged for a moment the other day from the darkness that has too long enveloped him and repeated certain "facts" and figures that somebody had pumped into him ahout that salvation of the gold standard which is one of the most curious additions to political mythology.

JOLO, P.I., Oct. 12. -- The Sulu Princesses Dayang-Dayang and Tarhata, who was educated in American colleges, aided today in negotiations with outlaw Moro tribesmen, who are barricaded in their village of Tayungan against 200 insular constabulary men.

Dr. William I. Sirovich, among whose best friends the dramatic critics are not numbered, has again turned to playwriting. The Democratic Representative from New York and chairman of the House Committee on Patents tentatively calls his new drama "Tin Boxes."
"Black Sheep," Elmer Rice's comedy, will open tonight at the Morosco Theatre. Mary Philips and Donald MacDonald will head the cast.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Adoption of "the voluntary domestic allotment plan" and its sales tax features would help put the farmer back on his feet, Professor M.L. Wilson of the State College of Montana told the Mortgage Bankers' Association of America today.

William N. Haskell 3d, 28 years old, son of Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York National Guard, was found shot dead in the family apartment at 1,192 Park Avenue early, last evening.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 -- The two Californias are in the last throes of a struggle which, for confusion and doubt, is not matched by any other political group in the United States today. After taking observations both north and south of the mountains which divide this Commonwealth, not only geographically but socially and politically also, these conclusions take what form any opinion can take in a maelstrom:

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are some force-sanction people in this country! And THE TIMES will give the subject some space! These are the consolatory remarks made to myself on reading Benjamin Reuben's letter appearing in your issue of Oct. 8.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Announcement of the issuance of about $75,000,000 in Treasury bills to retire an issue of substantially the same amount Oct. 19 was made today by Acting Secretary Ballantine.

Speaker GARNER agrees with Senator REED that Congress at its next session will approve a change in the Volstead act. At least, he predicts that the House will take such action; he "doesn't want to speak for the Senate." The proposal will presumably take the form of a revenue bill legalizing beer of 4 per cent and taxing it at the rate of 3 cents a pint.

For the first time in eleven years there will be an open season in hen pheasants in Massachusetts this year, it was announced yesterday by Director of Fisheries ana Game Raymond J. Kenney. The season will start Thursday, Oct. 20. Not every county in the State, however, will permit pheasant shooting.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Prime Minister MacDonald ended a busy sixty-sixth birthday by going to Victoria Station late tonight to meet Premier Herriot of France, who has come to London to discuss the disarmament deadlock with members of the British Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Nonalcoholic Imitations of famous beverages of pre-prohibition days were held today by the Internal Revenue Bureau as not subject to the tax on soft drinks.

MEXICO CITY, Oct 12. -- Still undefeated, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris and Isaac Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, added another victory apiece to their totals in the fifth round of the international chess masters' tournament at the Press Social Center today.

HAVANA, Oct. 12. -- Political differences between the Liberal and Conservative parties are blamed for the shooting at 10 o'clock this morning of Adolfo Mesa, brother-in-law of Antonio Ruiz, Governor of Havana Province and Liberal candidate for Mayor of Melena del Sur, near Havana.

The world's featherweight championship, which has had no recognized claimant in this State since January, will be the prize tonight when Kid Chocolate, the speedy Cuban boxer, and Lew Feldman of Brooklyn meet in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden.
NEW HAVEN, Conn, Oct. 12. -- Head Coach Mal Stevens today retained most of the line changes ordered yesterday as a part of the largest general shake-up of the Yale eleven since the squad reported.

The vanguard of the "Repeal Motorcade" of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform started forth yesterday on a campaign through the "dry" Congressional districts of upper New York. With an amplifier rigged up in the rumble seat of one of their cars, the purpose of the mission was announced so that all might hear.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 -- Speaking at the convention of the American Gas Association here today, Henry L. Doherty, New York utility executive, declared that if the government and social systems in this country had been administered efficiently during the last few years, "then they are a failure and we may, unless measures are taken, anticipate uprisings similar to those in other countries."

It the football rules committee has gone further than necessary in eliminating from the 1932 code features it felt were largely responsible for the unusual toll of deaths from injuries last Fall, then the sport has the assurance or William S. Longford, secretary of the committee, that revision will be considered seriously.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 12 -- Two former national champions, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia and Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., gained the final round of the Hot Springs Fall golf tournament at the Homestead course today and will meet tomorrow.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 12. -- Belfast was held today by 3,000 armed police, who on one occasion opened fire to prevent looting. The day's casualties were confined to minor injuries, caused chiefly when the police charged gatherings of the unemployed.

Crime Sources Galore. So far, at the meeting of the American Bar Association, crime and gang violence have been explained as due to elective judges, to newspaper interference with the courts and to prohibition.

Elihu Root, former Secretary of State, will serve as Honorary Chairman of the Citizens' Committee on the Unemployment Emergency Relief Bond Issue, which has been, organized by the State Charities Aid Association to inform the voters of the State that unless the $30,000,000 bond issue -- Proposition Number 1 on the ballot -- is carried, the present system of State aid to municipalities for home relief will collapse on Nov. 15.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 12. -- Five civil wars of varying sizes and importance proceeded in four provinces in China proper today, despite protests and orders from Nanking.

A symphonic band of seventy pieces, organized by the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus to give concerts here and in other cities, gave its first performance last night at Carnegie Hall to an audience of more than 1,000.

The immediate cause of the expulsion of Gregory Zinovieff and Leo Kamenev, together with twenty-two other Communist leaders, from the Russian Communist party, as reported in Moscow dispatches on Tuesday, was the dispatching of a memorandum by eighteen of the dissident leaders to the central committee of the party assailing the policies of Joseph Stalin, Soviet dictator, and demanding his removal from office, information received here yesterday revealed.

The annual memorial mass of the New York Assembly of the Catholic Daughters of America was held yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral and was followed by a luncheon at the Hotel Astor. Bishop William J. Hafey of Raleigh, N.C., national chaplain of the order, was the celebrant.

Led by former United States Attorney General George W. Wickersham, Colonel William J. Donovan, candidate for Governor of New York, and United States Senator Felix Hebert of Rhode Island, President Hoover's Eastern campaign manager, the Republicans hailed yesterday Calvin Coolidge's address for President Hoover at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night as an event which would turn the tide of the campaign and bring about the re-election of the President.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Oct. 12. -- "Oskar Daubmann" set all Germany agog last May when he returned to his native Endingen and his aged parents with a atory of having escaped from French captivity in Northern Africa, where he said he had slaved since the war.

The true grotto of the Sibyl, existent for centuries only in mythology, has now come into the news as a real place. To be sure, it has not the hundred doors and hundred "entries wide" of the vast cave described by VERGIL in the Aeneid:

All the markets will reopen this morning after having been closed yesterday in observance of Columbus Day. For the holiday there was a complete suspension of business in all financial centres. However, the foreign markets were open.

Endorsement of President Hoover's candidacy for re-election by the Allied Women, the women's branch of the Allied Forces for Prohibition, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Rushmore Patterson, head of the women's group. Mrs. Patterson said that she and the executive committee would vote for President Hoover, and "Allied Women will do its best toward his election."

TOKYO, Oct. 12. -- Japanese official representatives have approached the governments of the powers in the League of Nations to request their good offices in the forthcoming debates in the League on the Manchurian question. These overtures were made in a form, which elicited friendly replies.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- David Lloyd George was the principal speaker at the 116th annual meeting of the Peace Society at the Guildhall today, while in another place Sir Herbert Samuel, a former Minister of the National Government, attempted to rally on the issue of free trade alone what now remains of Mr. Lloyd George's once great Liberal party.

"Hit harder" was the urgent plea that went out yesterday to Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican nominee for Governor, in his Statewide campaign which he opened with speeches in Queens and at the Madison Square Garden in this city.

THE stewards at the Jamaica track quite properly disapproved of an atrocious bit of work in the line of animal painting recently. The offerings were refused for exhibition. The composition was bad; the technique was worse.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- Premier Herriot went to London today with no great expectations. He hopes to be permitted to expound the French plan that was in the outline approved by the Cabinet today, and so prepare the ground for its discussion in Geneva, with at least the benevolent good-will of Britain.

The Democratic platform as it relates to liquor is one of "bold badness," while the Republican plank is "a pitiful attempt at decent dampness -- a weasel-worded elongation of attenuated innuendoes," according to William D. Upsnaw, Presidential candidate of the Prohibition party, who was in New York yesterday to plead for a "sober Americanism."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- An appeal to the legal profession to join in a defense of the American form of government, now "on trial in the eyes of millions of our citizens," and in so doing to stand firmly against further centralization of judicial functions in the Federal establishment, was made by President Hoover tonight before the American Bar Association on the first day of its annual convention here.

A record vote will be cast in Northern New Jersey at the Presidential election next month, according to estimates of registration made yesterday by officials in the various counties. Although registration in many counties will continue until next Tuesday, estimates based on the completed registrations in large communities, where the booths closed at midnight Tuesday, indicated a general increase of about 10 per cent over the registration for the election in 1928.
PARIS, Oct. 12. -- An Important nitrate conference will be held here Friday, when France is expected to decide from whom she is going to buy about 250,000 tons of nitrate needed this year.

GENEVA, Oct. 12. -- Prospects of a further delay in disarmament work increased today when Arthur Henderson announced that Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, would be unable to come here "at present" and that the much-talked-of French security plan would not be ready for at least a fortnight.

Two men were arraigned in Gates Avenue court before Magistrate Joseph F. Maguire yesterday on a charge of malicious mischief. They pleaded not guilty and were held in $5,000 bail each for further hearing next Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 12 (AP). -- Nominations for Hollywood's highest honors, the annual awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, were announced today. Marie Dressler, adjudged the best screen actress of 1931, won the same honor this year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Foreigners are showing a little interest in North American grain markets, but not enough to inspire pronounced buying activity. Liverpool is watching news from Argentina, as weather conditions there from now on will be an important factor in all wheat markets of the world.

The steel output is increasing slowly and there is confidence that there will be a continuation of recent improvement despite the influence of the elections and changes in security prices, according to Iron Age. The publication estimates ingot production of the country at 19 per cent of capacity this week, compared 17.34 per cent for September estimated by the American, Iron and Steel Institute.

ATHENS, Greece, Oct. 12.-- The news that the United States State Department was withdrawing the passport of Samuel Insull Sr. still further complicated the situation, which left him today not only a free man but a sort of martyr in the eyes of the

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Edmund E. Day, director of Social Sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, and Professor John H. Williams of Harvard University were named today by the State Department to represent the United States on the preparatory committee of experts of the world monetary and economic conference.

The Pierre Matisse Gallery in the Fuller Building, Madison Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, has opened its second season with an exhibition of drawings by the famous French sculptor, Aristide Maillol, which will remain until Oct. 28.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Indications that the worst of the depression has passed and that business activity is now definitely on the upgrade were given in a majority of replies from nearly 200 trade associations and chambers of commerce to a questionnaire from the Commerce Department made public today by Secretary Chapin.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- The improvement in Wall Street and strength in the London market yesterday failed to influence the Bourse today. After opening fairly strong the stock market lapsed into lethargy, accompanied by a steady decline in prices. Professional traders, observing the lack of orders, turned to profit-taking, and rumors of impending budgetary troubles in France served to increase public caution.

Herbert F. Boynton of F.S. Moseley Co., chairman of the Moffat Tunnel (Col.) Supplemental Bondholders' Protective Committee, issued a statement yesterday on behalf of the committee, saying that body regarded as distinctly favorable to it the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States this week.

FRANKLIN, Ind., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy, now on a campaign tour of the Middle West in behalf of the Democratic candidates, declared here tonight that Republican campaign strategists were trying to prove "an, alibi" for what he termed the "Hoover panic."

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 12 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, drew a verbal contrast in an address here tonight of the "failures" of the Republican administration, the "promises" of the Democrats, and what he termed the constructive phases of the Socialist program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Chief Justice Hughes, in his address as presiding officer at the American Bar Association today, said:
De Witt Clinton High School's football team registered its second triumph in as many games, defeating Morris High, 21 to 0, yesterday before 3,000 at the George Washington High School Stadium.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- A hint of a possible change in the present British system of taxing automobiles at the rate of P1 per horsepower, which is estimated to have done mare to limit the importation of American cars than tariffs, was given tonight by P. J. Pybus, Minister of Transport.

The familiar Eton blue, with brown cap, which has marked the Whitney horses for three generations, was carried to victory in the Pierrepont Handicap for the first time at Jamaica yesterday when Halcyon finished first by ten lengths. The Pierrepont was inaugurated in 1904.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I know that it is low to say "I told you so" (something lyrical might be worked up from that), but even Socialist flesh is weak, and it is difficult to refrain from a wan smile at the spiritual agonies of those former supporters of Senator Samuel Hofstadter as they contemplate the clay from which their idol's feet so evidently were fashioned.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Tammany nominee for Mayor, received a pledge of support from organized labor yesterday His Republican opponent, Lewis H. Pounds, spent the day casting about for a campaign manager.

The exchange of diplomatic notes with Haiti, following rejection by her National Assembly of the new treaty signed on Sept. 3, should clear the air of misconceptions and open the way for reconsideration. The agreement was to give the Haitians control of their Government in 1934, qualified only by supervision of the liquidation of the loan underwritten in 1922.

Breaking 88 out of a possible 100 targets, R.H. Helsel won the nineteenth annual cosmopolitan championship over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. It was the beat score in a field of forty-four gunners. L.G. Moffatt, who captured the title last year, finished seventh with an 80.
Albert C. Eppinger, president of Schmidt Hygienic Trust Company and the First National Bank of West New York, died yesterday at his home, 211 Thirty-fourth Street, Union City, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The United States took the second step in its attempt to extradite Samuel Insull Sr. from Athens today by ordering the Legation at Athens to recapture Mr. Insull's passport.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12. -- The possible election of a Democratic President of the "United States is the one "great fear that overhangs the business horizon," Secretary Mills declared in a Republican campaign speech at the Minneapolis auditorium tonight.

With only a month left for the filing of applications for reductions in the tentative property assessments for 1933, realty interests have begun organizing in earnest to press for sweeping cuts in the realty valuations here.
CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- The United States Senate investigation of the Insull crash opened today with the arrival here of James E. Stewart, special investigator of the Senate Banking Committee.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Astor Drayton have come to the Weylin from Wild Horse House, their Summer place in Fort Steele, B.C.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 12 -- During the second day of the Rose Tree Hunt Club Fall meeting today, Fairbanks II, 9-year-old gelding, was killed during the running of the Bear Hill Plate, feature event. More than 5,000 persona saw the accident.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Despite unemployment and economic distress in 1931 the death rate for the nation continued to decline, and at 11.1 per thousand of population was the lowest since the bureau of the census began collecting such statistics in 1900.
Leases of several large east side apartments, in addition, to numerous west side rentals, were reported by brokers yesterday, as follows:

A letter sent out yesterday to holders of Electric Public Service Company secured bonds, Series A, B and C, by the protective committee headed by James Lee Kauffman of the law firm of Patterson, Eagle, Greenough Day replied to criticism directed against the group for opposing the methods employed in obtaining a part of the amount used to pay the interest on the Series B bonds of Sept. 30.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- According to the secret tariff schedules of the Ottawa agreement revealed tonight in London and in the capitals of the British dominions simultaneously, seventy-nine different kinds of manufactured goods from Great Britain on which Canada has imposed duties will be admitted free during the next five years, thereby giving British exporters new advantage over those of the United States.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 12. -- The Swarthmore College football team will not meet the University of Pennsylvania on the gridiron next year, or "any other large colleges."
LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Fortune smiled on nine American holders of tickets in the Irish Sweepstake on the Cesarewitch race at Newmarket today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Plans for the evacuation of 700 United States marines now in Nicaragua by next February, ending the commitment the United States undertook there in 1927, have been completed. They await only the giving of definite orders to put them into effect.

OTTAWA., Oct. 12.-- Canadian tariff walls were readjusted today to favor trade from the United Kingdom, and at the same time the Dominion Government announced steps by which the United Kingdom will give preference to the products of Canada.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (AP). -- The conspiracy which led to the expulsion of twenty-four more or less prominent members of the Communist party yesterday is said to have been headed by M. Rutin, former secretary of a Moscow district party organization. He was discredited three years ago with the opposition led by Leon Trotsky and had held no office in the party since then.
PARIS, Oct. 12. -- Twenty-three more Mayors in Franoe's wheat-growing districts resigned today in protest against the Fall price of wheat. Since Saturday 195 have resigned.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Seligman were hosts at a dinner party this evening in honor of Robert Livingstone Beeckman, former Governor of Rhode Island.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Muskogee Frank's Snowbird, a black, white and ticked pointer bitch, owned and handled by Robert Kohler of Glen Cove, today won the members' all-age stake at the Autumn Field trial of the North Shore Game Protective Association.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 12 -- Virginia's eleven today had what is expected to be the last contact work before the squad leaves Friday for the Columbia game in New York.

* * * Holiday Trade Reported Excellent. Excellent response by large throngs or holiday shoppers to retail promotions was reported here yesterday by retail executives. Not only was the dollar volume of sales the best for any day this Fall, but in a number of instances the totals exceeded the corresponding day a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Loans of $2,979,000 to finance construction of eight self-liquidating projects were approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which estimated that employment for 2,822 men would be provided on the projects for from two to eighteen months.

All evidence so far available leads to the hypothesis that cancer is inheritable and that two distinct constitutional factors are involved in its development, Professor Julius Bauer, eminent Vienna physician, told the New York Pathological Society last night at the New York Academy of Medicine.

For the second day in a row the New York University football squad was sent through a long scrimmage at Ohio Field yesterday in preparation for its battle with Georgetown at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

Reports that former Governor Alfred E. Smith had been the first choice of Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals as receiver for the Interborough were current yesterday in legal and traction circles. It was said that Mr. Smith had declined after a tentative acceptance.
