A demand from Republican leaders in many parts of the country for more speeches by former President Calvin Coolidge has been the immediate reaction to his appearance on Tuesday night in Madison Square Garden, it was said yesterday at Republican National Committee headquarters in the Waldorf-Astoria.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct 12. -- With his four-year detail at the United States Military Academy ending next June, Major Ralph I. Sasse, head coach of the Army football squad, will not return to coach the cadets next Fall. This announcement was made tonight by Major Philip B. Fleming, graduate manager of athletics at West Point.

Stephen W. McKeever, 78-year-old patriarch of baseball in Flatbush, where he is known to thousands as "the Judge," yesterday was announced as the new president of the Brooklyn Baseball Club, of which he is a half owner. The announcement followed a reorganization meeting at Ebbets Field at which Frank B. York resigned his post as president.

John N. Garner, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, chatted with newspapermen in his suite at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday afternoon, after having spent the previous day with Governor Roosevelt in Albany. The speaker declined flatly to say that he was going to take a part in the campaign.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 12 -- As the second annual New Jersey contract bridge tournament under the auspices of the Whist Club of the Oranges opened at the Hotel Suburban here today sixty-four contestants began play in the women's pair event.

MUNICH, Oct. 12.-- Before a representative assembly of Bavarian industrialists Chancellor Franz von Papen today delivered a fighting speech in which he declared that the supreme authority in Germany must be vested in the Cabinet and not in the Reichstag and handled Adolf Hitler and his National Socialists without gloves.

Members of the committee supporting the independent candidacy of Bernard S. Deutsch and George W. Alger for the Supreme Court against City Court Justice Aron Steuer and State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, bi-partisan nominee, met yesterday in the Bar Association and planned a vigorous campaign in their behalf.

Methods of cooperation by the railroads with the committee headed by Calvin Coolidge which has begun an investigation of the transportation situation will be discussed by the advisory committee of the Association of Railway Executives at their Fall meeting in Chicago tomorrow.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 12. -- Just as a year ago, Boston College defeated Centre College by means of one scoring play before a crowd of 1,500 on the new Boston College gridiron at University Heights today, 6 to 0.
Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, started his assault on the fighting Petrolle family last night by knocking out Frankie Petrolle of Schenectady, younger brother of Billy.

The sensational gains in the sales of carded cotton cloth during August were translated during September into the soundest statistical position the industry has known, it was disclosed yesterday by the monthly report, covering five weeks, of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

Dr. Newton B. Waller, a general medical practitioner in New York City for many years, committed suicide yesterday in the bathroom of his home, 83 East Eighty-second Street, by opening the jet of a small gas heater and then slashing his throat and wrists with a razor.

Despite reductions in passenger rates which were made effective last Spring by the transatlantic ship lines, the passenger traffic between the ports of the United States and Canada and Europe decreased by 50,980 from Jan. 1 to Sept. 26, according to tables compiled by the Transatlantic Passenger Conference.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The address of President Hoover at the meeting of the American Bar Association tonight was as follows:
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Governor Franklin D Roosevelt of New York, in a message from Albany tonight, extended his sympathy to Mrs. Wilson.

Eight young men of Jersey City set out Tuesday evening to sail to the Statue of Liberty in a whale boat. Since then their time has been about equally divided into three phases of nautical life. Part of it they have spent bailing water from their fragile ship.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Fall racing at picturesque Latonia, which for the second year is absorbing the dates and stakes of the Lexington and Louisville tracks, was ushered in today under most favorable conditions. The feature, the Columbus Day Handicap, witnessed a popular triumph for the Eton blue of Cornelius V. Whitney when Jimmy Moran drove home in advance of a small but select field of all-age sprinters.
Business leases reported by brokers yesterday included contracts for space in the Broadway district and for stores on Madison and Park Avenues. The day's list was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- Some of the lawyers attending the American Bar Association conference here today appraised former President Coolidge's speech in New York last night as an utterance that would be beneficial to the Republican party.

The bondholders' committee for the city of St. Petersburg, Fla., announced yesterday that negotiations were in progress looking toward a satisfactory plan for payment of the interest on the city's bonds which is now past due and which will accrue through Sept. 30, 1933.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12. -- A radio transmitting station, said to have been used for a year by a big liquor ring to communicate with rum ships off the coast, was raided here this afternoon in a two-room apartment on the fourth floor of 55 Spruce Street by prohibition agents from New York.

It would not be fair to say that the Board of Estimate had made absolutely no progress during the seven years that it has been wrestling with the bus problem. Mayor HYLAN visioned innumerable buses descending upon the city as in a great armada, summoned to war under his banner against the wicked traction interests.

Tammany corruption, unemployment relief, clearing up of slums, provision of proper housing accommodations for the poor and adequate care of the education of the city's children will be the principal issues of his campaign, Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, declared last night when he officially accepted the nomination at a meeting of the Joint City Campaign Committee of the Socialist party at the party headquarters, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 -- A proposal that foreign oil companies operating in Mexico should make advance payments on taxes originating from last October has been virtually agreed to, according to information published in the newspaper Excelsior this morning said to come from Ministry of Finance circles after a discussion last night by oil men with Ministry of Finance authorities.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The Princeton first varsity eleven scored six touchdowns against a reserve team in a thirty-minute offensive on University Field today.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 12. -- Peter Fuller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Fuller," 18 East Ninety-third Street, New York City, was fatally injured early today in an automobile collision in Newington, which also cost the life of Anthony Ponticello of Hartford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- President Hoover today laid plans for a "back-platform" campaign on his coming trip to Cleveland, during which he will appeal to the citizenry of West Virginia, Western Maryland and Western Pennsylvania, whence reports of defections from the Republican cause have come.

BUFFALO, Oct. 12 -- With his supporters assuring him that victory in Erie County is already certain. Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, returned today to Buffalo, his home city, and prepared to move on tomorrow to hoped-for conquests in adjoining territory.

How President Hoover was instrumental in saving "the national credit and banking system from Chicago to the Pacific Coast" was told in some detail in a radio address delivered last night by Frederick M. Davenport, Republican Representative of the Thirty-third Congressional District in this State.

GENEVA, Oct. 12. -- Women's organizations which have been fighting here two years for revision of the, Hague nationality convention with a view to providing for the equality of the sexes were pleased when they mustered nine votes against the recommendation the Assembly adopted today by thirty votes that the convention be promptly ratified without change.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., Oct. 12. -- Joseph Bugsik, 19 years old, a deaf mute of Lake Ronkonkoma, will be taken on a stunting flight at 10,000 feet over the Brentwood Airport on Sunday in an effort to restore his hearing and speech. The experiment was recommended by Dr. Guy M. McClean, the youth's physician.

The United States Joined with Spain and Italy on Columbus Day yesterday in celebrating the link between, the old and new worlds forged by the discoverer. Radio listeners on both sides of the Atlantic heard a commemorative program, originating on Madrid and Washington, in which the respective Ambassadors, Don Juan Francisco de Cardenas and Arwin B. Laughlin, took part.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Oct. 12. -- The annual commemoration of the anniversary of the "Virden Mine massacre" of 1898 was turned into a rout today by National Guard troops, who arrested more than 1,200 striking miners and released most of them only after they promised to leave town.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Samuel Calvin Wells, a member of the staff of the old Philadelphia Press for forty-one years and editor-in-chief for more than a third of that period died at his home here yesterday after an illness of two and a half weeks. An intestinal disorder, complicated by advanced age, caused his death.

Ever since the Interborough went into receivership, nearly two months ago, there has been lively discussion of an irregularity connected with it. This did not relate to the necessity of placing the company under the protection of the court. Its affair stood in a financial crisis which demanded that form of relief.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The estate of Moritz B. Phllipp of New York City has received an estate tax abatement of $1,149,832, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Oct. 13 -- An ominous situation developed in the Christian County coal fields tonight after Andy Ganea, a miner member of the Progressive Union, which is picketing the working mines, was shot and fatally wounded by a corporal of militia in the village of Tovey, near here.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- Assailing the relief policies of the Hoover Administration as belated and uncoordinated, Governor Roosevelt set forth tonight basic principles, of his own program for aid to the unemployed in a radio address broadcast on a hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Alien Marsters and Dr. and Mrs. J.G. William Greeff jointly will give a dinner dance on Dec. 23 in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce their respective daughters. Miss Katherine Vail Marsters and Miss Marguerite L, Greeff.

A split in the ranks of organized labor on the Mayoralty issue in this city developed yesterday when a group of labor leaders, representing unions with a total membership of more than 300,000, repudiated the published endorsement of Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Tammany candidate, by officials of the Central Trades and Labor Council and gave their approval to Morris Hillquit, Socialist nominee for Mayor.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -- The most talked-of man in the California political contest this year is not Herberl Hoover, though he is a citizen of this State. He is not Franklin D. Roosevelt, although many analysts here believe that this great Republican Commonwealth will give its electoral vote to him.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 13 -- The news that large shipbuilding orders have been received in the last twenty-four hours has gone a long way in assisting authorities here to restore order. There had been no rioting up to a late hour tonight, and it was believed the backbone of the trouble had been broken.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- Alice Roosevelt Longworth, writing in the November issue of The Ladies Home Journal, says that "without the least personal feeling against my fifth cousin," Governor Roosevelt, even if she were not a Republican, she would vote for President Hoover on Nov. 8.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The Bourse session was dull today. Although the volume of trading was reduced sharply, prices were fairly firm. This was ascribed principally to the influence of British purchases of oil, gold mine and international stocks. Suez Canal advanced briskly.

Sharp cuts in money costs, putting time funds and acceptances at record low levels, and the official day loan charge at 1 per cent, the lowest since 1908, with the exception of May 11-12, 1931, represented the highlights of the business in the money market. The abnormally low rates were a reflection of the surplus of funds seeking employment against which demand is at an extremely low ebb.

Place Rush Orders for Gloves. Cool weather has stimulated a brisk consumer demand for women's gloves, and retailers are placing rush orders of substantial size to cover needs for immediate selling. Reflecting higher skin prices, glove quotations have been advancing.

Prices for cotton declined yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here under hedging sales that had accumulated over the holiday, combined with liquidation, local selling prompted by good weather for the movement of the crop in the South and weakness in the grain and stock markets.

Both President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt could learn valuable lessons on the uses of courage in public office by studying the career of Grover Cleveland, Allan Nevins, Professor of History at Columbia University and editor of the "American Political Leaders" series of biographies, said in an interview yesterday.

Four thousand employes of the tugboat lines operating in the harbor have rejected a proposed new wage agreement and have threatened to strike if the terms should be enforced. This action caused the owners to meet yesterday at the New York Towboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place, where the situation was discussed and action postponed pending a meeting with spokesmen of the men on Monday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 13 -- Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., defeated Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia at the Homestead course today when she sank a 20-foot putt for a birdie 2 at the twentieth hole to win the women's final in the Hot Springs Fall golf tournament 1 up.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The civic and economic implications of the administration of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company concern New Yorkers. But the conduct of the Federal Judges sitting in the City of New York is a matter of moment to all who care about the maintenance of unimpaired confidence in the integrity and high traditions of the Federal judiciary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- American rubber shoe manufacturers pro tasted at a Treasury Department hearing today against alleged unfair competition by Japanese and Czechoslovak producers, seeing in it a threat against the domestic industry. At the same time Importers urged removal of the bond now required on the imports of such articles from Japan, pending termination of the anti-dumping" investigation.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor, appointed a campaign manager and an advisory council chairman yesterday, had a telephone switchboard and an operator installed in his campaign office on the seventh floor of the Pershing Square Building and issued a statement urging voters who want good government to register.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Reid gave a dinner last night at their home, 17 East Ninety-seventh Street, to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their wedding. Mrs. Reid is the former Miss Catharine E. Gallery of Philadelphia, Pa. Mr. and Mrs. Reid were married Oct. 13, 1882, in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Fifty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue, by the Rev. Thomas V. Robinson.

While Eastern hunters are not likely to be interested deeply in the size of bags that Michigan hunters have recorded since the duck-hunting season opened in that State on Oct. 1, the fact that these hunters have found northern-flight birds migrating from Canada in ever-increasing, numbers is of prime importance to duck hunters in this sector.

PARIS, Oct 13 -- The value of arms exports by French manufacturers during the first eight months of this year showed an increase of 66,281,000 francs [about $2,651,000] over the total for the corresponding period of 1931. Figures issued today show that in the period this year exports of "arms, powder and munitions" totaled 124,857,000 francs, as compared with 58,576,000 francs during the first eight months of last year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Describing Frankljn D. Roosevelt as a candidate of "vague promises" who was trying to win office "on a wave of discontent born of the depression," Secretary Mills tonight launched a great Republican effort to bring Chicago and Illinois into the Hoover column.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to THE TIMES, John T. Madden, Dean of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, pointed out recently that bond losses have been the cause of many bank closings. Without a doubt that is so.

Liam O'Flaherty, whose writings are considered brilliant by many critics here and in England, but who, so far, has had little popular success, is the author of "Skerrett," a novel published today by Ray Long and Richard R. Smith. The background of the novel is an Irish Village.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- Colonel William J. Donovan, rushing through the second day of his up-State campaign for Governor, met and partially vanquished the Republican bugbear of prohibition today in Chautauqua County, the home of grape juice and, by the same token, one of the most ardent prohibitionist areas in the State.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 13. -- The Homestead colony was occupied with golf today. Several hundred persons were in the gallery that followed the finals match, between Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare and Miss Helen L. Hicks, which Miss Hicks won on the twentieth hole.
BUHL, Idaho, .Oct. 13 (AP). --Senator Borah said in a speech here tonight that there could be no end to the depression until three major problems were settled, and he listed them as follows:
Several business properties were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

OGDEN, Utah. Oct. 13 (AP). -- Senator Smoot, Republican candidate for re-election, said in a campaign address here today he had received information "that Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic candidate for the Presidency, has assumed publicly a stand for a 20 per cent ad valorem tariff on sugar."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP). -- Reversing the color tones of the black portrait of himself and the gentler representation of Arthur Maillefert painted in previous testimony, George W. Courson told a Jury today that if the young prisoner was tortured it was by his own defiant will to escape, and when he was hanged he was his own executioner.

The Shubert Theatre Corporation, which went into an equity receivership last Fall, may be forced to borrow more than $100,000 if it is to continue without liquidating until the end of December, a report filed in Federal Court by Lee Shubert and the Irving Trust Company, receivers, indicated yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- The Boerse was bullish today, most of the list advancing in brisk trading. Public participation increased further, with the preference for fixed dividend-bearing shares, which gained an average of 3 per cent. Eisenbahn Verkehrsmittel advanced 5 1/4 per cent and A.E.G. rose 3 1/4 per cent.

One of the State's most important witnesses at the second trial of Domenico Trombetta, Italian newspaper editor, who is charged with the murder of Salvatore Arena, a painter, of 1,550 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, last July 4, following disturbances on Staten Island between Fascisti and anti-Fascisti, was ordered yesterday to the custody of the Richmond County Sheriff for questioning today.

Acting Mayor MCKEE presented to the Board of Estimate yesterday his long-awaited economy program. It goes straight to the heart of the question faced by the city. The pruning knife is used on departmental estimates to such good effect that $35,000,000 is saved outright.

Viktor Planckh, a young artist from Vienna, is holding an exhibition of oils and gouaches at the Ferargil Galleries. It will continue until Oct. 23. The oils in particular ally themselves, more or less directly, with what has come to be called the "new objectivity."

The State of North Carolina, which has reduced its debt steadily since 1930, despite declining revenues, plans to renew $7,502,371 of its outstanding notes, which will mature between now and Jan. 16, 1933, according to word received here yesterday. No definite plans for the financing will be undertaken until the State Legislature convenes in January.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman presented himself yesterday as a man who knew the business of the State "from cellar to garret" by four years of intimate experience and pledged that if elected Governor he would give the State an administration which would be at the same time genuinely economical and generous in its support of humane and social activities.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 -- A copy-righted article by Frank R. Kent to The Baltimore Sun says tonight that President Hoover is largely responsible for Secretary Wilbur withdrawing from participation in a political discussion next Monday night at Northwestern University.

The Share-the-Work movement received an impetus yesterday from two sources. The Socony Vacuun Corporation, through Herbert L. Pratt, chairman, announced that the five-day week would go into effect on Nov. 1 so far as practicable for the 30,000 employes of the company and its subsidiaries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 -- Thomas J. Mooney, serving a life term for the San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing, and Paul M. Callicotte, "hiking sailor," of Portland, Ore., who insists he unwittingly placed the bomb himself, met face to face today in a dramatic interview at San Quentin prison.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 13 (AP). -- distinct surprise marked the running of the Warsaw Purse, a mile and seventy yard dash for 3-year-olds, which featured the Latonia card today, when Thundertone, from the stable of C.H. Knebelkamp, romped home at odds of $70.40 for $2.

Registration totals which had lagged behind the record 1928 figures save for Monday, the opening day of registration week, showed material increases yesterday and as a result set a new high record for the first four days of enrolment.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- While evidence was being presented tending to show that the charges made by Andre Bouilloux-Lafont against officials of the Air Ministry were based on false documents, another angle of the investigation of the Aeropostale affair developed a "boomerang" today that charged the accusers with fraud.

Mystery surrounds the disappearance somewhere between Boston and this city of a truck containing American antique furniture, booked rugs and old New England glassware valued by the owner, Warren Weston Creamer of Waldoboro, Me., at $10,000. The antiques were consigned to the National Art Galleries at the Hotel Plaza.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 13 -- Two small children, their hands and feet bound, were hurled to their death from the eighteenth floor of the Schroeder Hotel in the downtown district soon after 5 P.M. today by Mrs. Joseph Lawrence, divorced wife of a Milwaukee contractor.

From the standpoint of the Republican party, the British Empire chose a highly inconvenient moment to make public the details of the trade agreements reached at Ottawa last Summer. Republican orators have been touring the country, insisting that the foreign tariffs which have so largely curtailed our export trade were in no way provoked by our own policy.

The estate of Martin G. McCue, Tammany leader and clerk of the Surrogate's Court, who died on Sept. 19, will not be sufficient to provide the bequests in his will, it was learned when the petition for probate was filed by his sister, Miss Mary Ellen McCue of 144 East Twenty-second Street, in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- President Hoover today laid the cornerstone of the great white marble building rising on Capitol Hill in which, after nearly a century and a half of ''living with relatives," the Supreme Court of the United States is at last to have a home of its own.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel for the Hofstadter legislative committee, will return today on the Cunarder Berengaria accompanied by Mrs. Seabury. They have been on a vacation trip. Other notables on board included SirLenthal Cheatle, English cancer specialist and Lady Cheatle, Lord Craigmyle, Countess Margaret Bethlen, Lieut. Col. Sir Waldron Sinclair and Sir William I. de Courcy Wheeler.
PARIS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 -- Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and national chairman of the "Share-the-Work" Committee, told the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce today that the fight on depression required more action and less talk.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Four men were held tonight in an investigation of suspected attempts to dispose of $1,250,000 in bonds and stocks, the loot from robberies of banks and financial institutions in half a dozen cities.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. In the subjoined comparative table all figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 (AP). -- Sundot, racing for the Western stable of Norman Church, was an easy victor of the unnamed feature of the racing program today at Laurel.

"Smilin' Through," Metro's tianscription Of the stage play, with Norma Shearer, Leslie Howard and Frederic March, opens at the Capitol today. Abe Lyman and his orchestra, the Three Keys and Gomez and Winona are on the stage show.

An English essayist, when discussing a quarter of a century ago "The Fallacy of a Young Nation," insisted that America is not young. In fact, it is "discussible" whether we are not older than England or Ireland. Some of his tests have in the intervening years failed to support his conclusions.

GENEVA, Oct. 13 -- The French question of security and the German question of equality must be treated at the same time by the disarmament conference, its president, Arthur Henderson, told its bureau today. No one objected to that procedure nor to his request to be empowered to convoke the bureau formally on Nov. 3 and the general commission in the week beginning Nov. 21.

Fallible Human Testimony. What a piece of work is man, when it comes to remembering things! On the one hand, he will remember perfectly how pale and harried LINCOLN looked when delivering the Gettysburg Address, July 4, 1863; how badly pressed were the war President's trousers as he climbed to the platform, and how, at the top step, he stumbled slightly.

The mass of the Holy Ghost, or red mass, traditionally so called because of the color of the vestments worn by the celebrant, was held at the Roman Catholic Church or St. Andrew yesterday to invoke divine blessings on the law courts at the beginning of their Fall terms.
Acting Mayor McKee's statements of policy on the formulation of next year's budget and subway financing follow:

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- New low prices for this season for all deliveries of wheat were made today on the Board of Trade here. Scattered commission-house selling disclosed a lack of support except such as came from holders of daily and weekly bids and from operators who were closing spreads with Winnipeg by buying here against sales in the Canadian market.

JOLO, P.I., Oct. 13 (AP). -- In fierce fighting today detachments of the Philippine Constabulary routed Moro outlaws from their fortified village of Tayungan. One constabularyman and six Moros were known to have been killed.
PARIS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Marquis Boni de Castellane, former husband of Anna Gould, was desperately ill today and his doctors were uncertain whether he would live.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP). -- Governor Roosevelt said he had "no comment tonight" when informed that Senator Smoot at Ogden had read correspondence published in a Cuban newspaper in which the Governor was represented as favoring a lowered tariff on sugar.

An appeal from the order placing S.W. Straus Co., Inc., investment house, in a Martin act receivership will be argued before the Appellate Division in Brooklyn Monday morning. The court adjourned until that date a hearing on a show-cause order scheduled for yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The American Bar Association today authorized its commerce committee to appear before Congressional committees in correction with anti-trust legislation. The committee's report, containing a draft of a bill to broaden the powers of the Federal Trade Commission in anti-trust proceedings, was received.
The equity receivership to which the Interborough Rapid Transit Company consented on Aug. 26 was declared null and void yesterday by Judge John M. Woolsey of the Federal District Court.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- Urging "right direction" of the Home Loan Bank plan, John Jay Hopkins, special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury, told the Mortgage Bankers of America today that they should consider it as a permanent institution with temporary credit relief aspects.

Testimony given before trial by John J. Raskob in the suits brought by the County Trust Company against Tim J. Mara for $50,000 and against Patrick F. Kenny for $20,000 on notes which Kenny and Mara contend represent contributions by the trust company to the Smith campaign fund in 19.28, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by I. Gainsburg, counsel for the defendants, on a motion for further testimony.

VIENNA, Oct. 13 -- Prince Michaelson of King Carol of Rumania, and Nicolas Titulesco, former Rumanian envoy to London, met in Vienna today. Prince Michael, who arrived from Paris in the care of Mme. Grigorescu, wife of one of King Carol's aides, went to West Station tonight to meet M. Titulescu as the latter was passing through on his way to Bucharest.

J.W.H. Hamilton, a boyhood friend and college classmate of the late Ivar Kreuger, was questioned in the bankruptcy inquiry into the affairs of the Kreuger Toll Company, which was continued yesterday before Henry K. Davis, Federal referee, at 140 Nassau Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Elbridge Rand Herron, who plunged to his death from the top of the Second Pyramid in Egypt, was the third outstanding Asiatic explorer to die this year from causes apart from the dangers they deliberately risked.

CHRIS CAGLE, Shipwreck Kelly, Eddie Mays and Albie Booth went down to Washington recently and assured President Hoover that they were right behind him. The four football stars rose to fame on the gridiron by getting behind other fellows. They were backs, all of them. Governor Roosevelt might gain some political ground on his distinguished opponent by recruiting some guards and tackles for his campaign forces.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 13 (AP) -- It is going to be Gene Tunney against Albie Booth on Connecticut's political platforms this month.
Columbia's football team had its final heavy workout yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the encounter with the University of Virginia here tomorrow.

The Annalist index of business activity for September shows a further sharp advance to the highest level since last March. It now stands seven points above the July low point, the premilinary September index being 59.2, as against 55.5 for August and 52.0 for July.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Lord Reading, the former British Ambassador to the United States, characterized the Lytton report as "a very fine document" in an interview today with newspaper correspondents on what he termed his first visit to the United States as a private individual during which he might speak his views freely.

The daily statement of gold transactions published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday showed a gain of $5,154,500 in the monetary gold stocks of the country, of which $2,720,500 came from the decrease in gold earmarked for foreign account and $2,434,000 from imports.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York expressed its disapproval of the proposed St. Lawrence-Great Lakes waterway treaty yesterday at its monthly meeting at the rooms of the Merchants' Association, when the report of a committee headed by John P. Magill of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York terming the project "economically unsound and of questionable value" was unanimously adopted.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 13 -- After seven brace had been run and two additional heats in a second series had been ordered, the judges in the annual Autumn field trials of the North Shore Game Protective Association late today announced as the winner of the open all-age stake, the leading event on the program, the white and liver pointer dog, Long Island Buddy, owned and handled by Harry Griffin of Smithtown, L.I.

The new ruling, of tha,Labor Department, which would forbid employment for wages of foreign students in the United States and which has been criticized by university executives and student groups, was attacked yesterday by former Magistrate Charles A. Oberwager at a special hearing before Assistant Secretary of Labor W.W. Husband at Ellis Island.

The names of 314 school children who have been selected as winners of medals for the best essays on "Safeguarding the Home Against Fire" in a contest held in connection with Fire Prevention Week were made public yesterday by Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman.

Representatives of eighteen hotel and restaurant owners and employes' organizations in session last, night in the Hotel Pennsylvania, were urged, in the name of repeal and the rejuvenation of the industry of catering to the dining-out trade, to support the national Democratic ticket and elect wet representatives to Congress.

Action on a resolution opposing the borrowing of funds for the construction of a vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River was deferred after a discussion by the New York Board of Trade yesterday at its monthly luncheon in the Hotel Astor. The resolution was referred back for further study by the city affairs committee of the organization.
Detailed comparisons of Great Britain's foreign trade in September preliminary figures of which were reported yesterday, are as follows:

The Lytton report on Manchuria was praised yesterday by George E. Sokolsky, writer on Far Eastern affairs, who said that if the League of Nations accomplished nothing more in the Manchurian struggle than the publication of this report it would have "fully justified its existence."

Yesterday's renewed decline in stocks was doubtless explainable by absence of any substantial outside support, a condition which invited speculative selling. Possibly, also, speculators for the rise who have carried along their older commitments, in hope of something to stimulate the market, have been closing out.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- One of the earliest forerunners of newspapers has been found in excavations at Ostia, at the mouth of the Tiber River, by Professor Calza, who discovered a fragment of an ancient "Fasti Annales," which in Roman times played the role of the modern official gazette.

A further gain of $19,000,000 in gold reserves, a decline of $7,000,000 if, Federal Reserve note circulation and a reduction of $6,000,000 in member bank indebtedness to the Reserve Banks were the principal changes shown in this week's Federal Reserve statement.

Because of added duties in the department of hygiene at the College of the City of New York, where he is an instructor, Dr. Harold J. Parker has been relieved as head coach of the Lavender football team, a position which he has held since 1924. The change occurred on Wednesday, but announcement was withheld until yesterday.

The State Superintendent of Banking is not responsible to individual bank depositors for the financial statements published by banks in the State, Supreme Court Justice Cuff in Brooklyn ruled yesterday. He held that the superintendent can only accept the bank, statements; he can neither suppress them nor "correct" them.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 -- Striving for forty-five moves to outwit each other in the sixth round of the international chess masters' tournament at the Press Social Centre, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris and Isaac Kashdan of New York played to an adjournment today without having reached a decision.
Kid Chocolate, Cuban boxer, is the world's featherweight champion as far as the State Athletic Commission is concerned.

Rockland Light and Power. Offering of an additional issue of $1,200,000 Rockland Light and Power Company 4 1/2 per cent bonds, series A, dated May 1, 1928, and due on May 1, 1958, is being made by a banking group comprising Estabrook Co., Edward M. Bradley Co., Inc., Tenney Co., H. P. Wood Co., and Putnam Co.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation was said today by Harvey C. Couch, a director, to have provided for the direct employment of 16,007 men through loans of $124,563,620 for selfliquidating projects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Comminting upon Calvin Coolidge's Nev York address, Senator Robinson of Arkansas today called the former President "still the false but platitudinous prophet of the Republican party," and quoted some of his utterances about prosperity when the country was on the threshold of the slump.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- The Princeton eleven, held its final hard practice session in preparation for Cornell on University Field today concluding the drill with an hour's scrimmage against the reserves.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The stock markets were cheerful today. There was some good investment buying, with British funds again higher under the lead of the assented war-loan stocks. Cheap money continued as the dominating factor.
Whatever the reason may be, thus far the 1932 season has not been a very happy one for colleges playing the Notre Dame style of football.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Miss Martha Parker, holder of the women's metropolitan title, showed the way in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Westchester Hills club today with a fine round of 82 over her home course.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In "Topics of the Times," under "Horsepower on the Dnieper," there is a statement that "probably one hundred times as much has been written about Dnieprostroy as about all other power developments put together."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Over a strong protest against any retrenchment of church resources at a time of "great spiritual need," the United Lutheran Church in America at its convention today readjusted its budget for the next three years through a total reduction of $1,200,000 to meet existing money values.

The Canadian and British tariff readjustments which will cost the United States millions of dollars in trade were cited as results of the Hawley-Smoot tariff by United States Senator Connally of Texas in an address last evening in the last of a series of addresses by public leaders before the Democratic Forum at the Hotel Blltmore.

Encouraged by Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee's declaration yesterday that $85,250,000 could be slashed from next year's budget, scores of embattled civic workers hammered the majority bloc in the Board of Estimate with insistent demands for rigid economy next year along the lines laid down by Mr. McKee.

A score of crayon portrait drawings in three colors, by Frederick Theodore Weber, are being shown at the Enrich Gallery. Mr. Weber has contrived to give a certain sculptural quality to his work, the bold modeling of the heads and definitive grasp of character in his subjects being characteristic of all the drawings.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday the tenth consecutive reduction in the margin by which its weekly car loadings for 1932 have fallen below last year's levels. The decrease in loadings for the week ended on Oct. 8 was 14.6 per cent, compared with the same week a year previously.

All doubt regarding the course of former Governor Alfred E. Smith in the campaign now in progress was removed yesterday when it was announced that he would make six speeches for the national ticket of his party, headed by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, in this State, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Rhode Island.

Slow pressure against the share market yesterday was the result largely of sporadic and acute weakness in a few special issues, according to the prevailing Wall Street view. Other reasons were assigned, but this reflected the consensus of the commission houses.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Three large oil companies of the mid-continent area joined today in the announcement of price increases to be effective on Saturday, bringing to eleven the total number of companies posting new schedules. The addition to the list were the Texas Corporation of Houston, the Continental Oil Company of Ponca City, and the Kansas-Oklahoma division of the Pure Oil Company of Chicago.

Sixty-two fellowships have been awarded by the Juilliard Graduate School for the current season as a result of competitive examinations held during the last ten days, Dean Ernest Hutcheson announced yesterday. Thirty-three States are represented in the group of successful candidates.

The tentative agreement in the job-printing industry, which will be placed before Typographical Union 6 at its meeting next Sunday at 2 P.M. at Stuyvesant High School, provides a wage reduction of more than $9 a week for both day and night workers, but the day men are to receive the forty-hour week, which already obtains for night workers in the commercial shops, it was reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Without a smile for the crowd at the station, Eamon de Valera, looking graver than usual, arrived from Dublin this evening. Malcolm MacDonald, the Prime Minister's son, and J.H. Thomas were in the official delegation which met him. Mr. Thomas chatted with the Free State President in his train compartment for a few minutes, then they all drove off together to a hotel.

LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- While effects of the imperial trade agreements invoiced in Canada today were still in the realm of speculation. British commercial observers expressed the belief that British trade with Canada would be increased $70,000,000 annually, mostly at the expense of the United States.

Although minority interests were overwhelmingly defeated in an attempt to censure the management of the Electric Bond and Share Company for voting to the men who comprise it a highly beneficial offering of the company's stock and then canceling the plan when the decline of the market made the plan disadvantageous, there were indications at yesterday's annual meeting of the company that the issue was not closed and that a legal battle might be started.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Two legal actions to test the constitutionality of the radio act of 1927 were terminated during the fiscal year ended June 30, according to a summary issued by the anti-trust division of the Justice Department, in charge of legislation of this character, today.

Sales Drought $13,960 at the dispersal of paintings and drawings from the art property of the late Miss Giulia P. Morosini at the sixth session at American Art Association-Anderson Galleries last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A comparison of old and new Canadiar, tariff rates, including those applying on imports from the United Kingdom, and those from non-British sources, but covering only one-third of the changes which became effective today, was issued by the Department of Commerce as follows:

A report approving In principle the proposed zoning amendment to permit the erection in business and retail districts of parking garages, with the consent of owners of only 50 per cent of the affected frontages, will be submitted to the Board of Estimate at its meeting today by John F. Sullivan, Commissioner of City Planning.

As usual, the most important, not to say startling, financial and political news of this Presidential campaign is excluded from the timid newspapers of the East. It required a bold and clarion voice like that of The Minneapolis Journal to set forth the most capacious promise ever made by a candidate for the Presidency.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article on the Adolescents' Court, to be presided over by City Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein, is of the deepest interest to the citizens. Those who know Judge Goldstein are not surprised at the organization of this most important experiment in jurisprudence under his leadership.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Amos Alonzo Stagg, grand old man of American football, was forced out as director of athletics and head football coach at the University of Chicago tonight after forty years of service.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 13 (AP)--Thomas Nelson Metcalf, appointed to succeed Amos Alonzo Stagg as athletic director at the University of Chicago, resigned from a similar post at Iowa State College today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Attacking prospective bonus legislation as the "most serious single threat to recovery on the horizon," Charles Evans Hughes Jr. of New York, in an address at a luncheon meeting of the Union League today, declared that if President Hoover were reelected such legislation would be thwarted effectly by a Presidential veto.

If Elmer Rice were not a Pulitzer laureate and the author of such an enlighted play as "The Left Bank" the mediocrity of "Black Sheep" would have very little news value. The new comedy which was acted at the Morosco last evening was actually written several years ago, and has been purchased and blandly announced by nearly every play merchant along Broadway.

BOGOTA, Oct. 13 -- Colombia has rejected Peru's proposal of Sept. 30 to arbitrate the seizure of the Colombian town of Leticia by Peruvian citizens on Sept. 1. The refusal was contained, it was learned today, in the reply to Peru's suggestion delivered yesterday to the Pan-American Conciliation Commission in Washington, but not made public there.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Charles F. Kettering, vice president of General Motors Corporation, told the American Club of Paris at its weekly luncheon today that "Americans have an idea that today's generation is the only generation which will have enough brains to plan for the future."

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Testimony to show that Martin Insull withdrew $161,222 from the treasuries of the Insull companies to cover his personal brokerage accounts, with approval of the withdrawals by Samuel Insull, was given at a hearing before Chief Justice Prystalski in Criminal Court today.

RYE, N.Y., Oct 13 -- Swinging into her game on the second nine, Mrs. L.C. DuBois of Wee Burn, the defending titleholder, finished with a stroke to spare in setting the pace in the first eighteen holes of the United States women's senior golf championship at the Westchester Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- President Hoover abruptly retired tonight in the midst of his first official reception of the year tendered to the judiciary, after shaking hands with 3,000 of the 5,500 guests in line at the White House. The guests included delegates to the convention of the American Bar Association, for whom the opening event of the season was advanced about a month.
The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production is 99.0 for the week ended Oct. 8, as against 101.1 for the preceding week and 88.7 for the corresponding week last year.

At last the Supreme Court is to have a home worthy of its momentous and unique importance. It is curious to recall that no provision for it had been made when the Government was transferred to Washington. Legislative and Executive were housed in quarters which made the pure Republicans of the period shudder at aristocratic splendor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Reforms in Federal criminal procedure to cope with the rising tide of crime were reviewed by Attorney General Mitchell today before the annual convention of the American Bar Association.

As a result of telephone conferences that began shortly after midnight yesterday morning between his counsel and the authorities, Jack Zaroff, 30 years old, pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter before Judge J.E. Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Governor Roosevelt in a radio speech tonight said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Approximately one evening out of three a persistent observer may see a curious crowd gathered about the entrance to a shop on the southwest corner of Twenty-third Street and Tenth Avenue. It might be such a crowd as gathers around the entrances to employment agencies on Sixth Avenue and elsewhere; it might be a disorganized breadline; it might even conceivably be composed of ousted speakeasy patrons.

Every good mortgage in the United States will become liquid tomorrow, and the insurance companies, savings banks and building loan associations which are now struggling to carry $20,000,000,000 in mortgages, will be under no further necessity to call and foreclose them, according to Franklin W. Fort.

The clergy of New York will be organized to cooperate with the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was decided yesterday when twenty representatives of many faiths and denominations met with Harvey L. Gibson, chairman.

The human side of the mission is "unduly weak," the greater number of missionaries are of "limited outlook and capacity" and the average missionary la too much the promoter and too little the preacher or the efficient teacher or physician that he should be, a report of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry made public yesterday declares.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 33. -- A delegation representing the Bonus Expeditionary Force, bearing a petition of censure for the forcible eviction of veterans last Summer and presenting some new demands, was received today by President Hoover at the White House.

Jockey Hank Mills scored a triple at Jamaica yesterday, his second of the meeting, and put himself back in the running for leading riding honors at the course. Mills scored on The Heathen, Euclid and Bodkin, the two first named being saddled by Trainer Hirsch Jacobs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 12, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,234,000,000, a decrease of $8,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $198,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

A schedule of thirteen regattas has been arranged for Eastern college oarsmen, it was announced yesterday after the annual meeting of the American Rowing Association at the Harvard Club. This program is subject to faculty ratification.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- United States exports to Canada may be reduced by about $75,000,000 front normal as a result of the higher tariff rates on nonBritish products made effective in the Dominion today. This is under the assumption that empire exporters will take full advantage of the increased preferences accorded them and that domestic producers will be unable to overcome the handicap by lowering production costs and other means.

Receding from the totals of the first week of this month, bank clearances throughout the country showed again for the week ended on Tuesday night a wide decline from the amounts for the corresponding time last year, according to compilations by R.G. Dun Co.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Puerto Rico's revenues exceeded expectations during the past fiscal year. Governor James R. Beverley revealed in his annual report, made public today by the War Department.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Police revealed today that Mae West, Broadway actress of "Diamond Lil" fame, was robbed two weeks ago of nearly $20,000 in jewelry and cash.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Council, arrived in London tonight to resume negotiations with leaders of the British Government on the land annuities dispute. This is his fourth visit in pursuit of economic peace and the talks may last longer than tomorrow if a favorable atmosphere is created at Prime Minister MacDonald's official residence at 10 Downing Street in the morning.

A distinct lessening of pressure for amortization payments by distressed property owners on mortgages held by leading lending institutions is reported by Hubert F. Breltwieser, vice president and senior loan officer of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, as one of the most promising signs of improvement in the general real estate outlook.

If the doubt had existed in the breasts of anxious Philharmonic-Symphony patrons as to whether or not Arturo Toscanini's health, was restored they had only to listen to the concert given by the superb orchestra and the inspired conductor last night in Carnegie Hall.

ALBANY, Oct. 13, -- Suggestions by experts that certain changes in State departments would save the State $5,000,000 a year were revealed today before the joint legislative committee named to investigate the departments with a view to effecting eppnomies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Allocations of the Treasury's Oct. 15 issue of 4 1/2-year 3 per cent notes, an hounced by Acting Secretary Ballantine today, exceeded the offering by $53,000,000, amounting to $508,338,600.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Conversations between Prime Minister MacDonald and Premier Herriot of France continued all day at 10 Downing Street in an effort to arrive at some compromise agreement between Britain and France whereby Germany could be induced to return to the disarmament conference at Geneva.

Indications that the New York University football team will rely upon its aerial attack to play a prominent part in tomorrow's battle with Georgetown at the Yankee Stadium were forecast during yesterday's drill at Ohio Field. For more than ninety minutes of a two-hour workout the Violet squad concentrated on perfecting its forward-passing offense.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- The text of Secretary Mills's speech here tonight is as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Madge Titheradge, who arrived last night from the United States for her return to the stage in a new play here, had a sudden collapse at the Carlton Hotel today. The attending physician summoned Sir John Weir, the Queens physician, who declared that she would be well in forty-eight hours.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Coach Mal Stevens today kept the Yale varsity football eleven from the scrimmage which closed heavy preparations for the Brown game Saturday. Although Stevens has shifted men in eight of the eleven positions on the team this week, he decided today to send a team against Brown with only two alterations from the eleven that started against Chicago last week.

Jascha Heifetz will be the soloist it the first of the five Madison Square concerts for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid on Nov. 26, Walter Damrosch announced yesterday. He will play Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto, with Mr. Damrosch conducting the orchestra of 200 players.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 13 -- Elbridge Rand Herron, American mountaineer, fell from the Second Pyramid at Giza near Cairo this morning and was killed instantly.

The first of a large number of murals which, will form an Important part of the decorative scheme in Rockefeller Center will be hung today in the K.K.O. Building on the Radio City Bide of the $250,000,000 midtown amusement and commercial development.

Thirty-five lots auctioned at Long Beach last Wednesday brought $20,250, an average of $579 a lot, Joseph P. Day, the auctioneer, reported yesterday. Including the present sale, Long Beach-on-the-Ocean, Inc., has sold 661 lots of its holdings for $463,345 since Mr. Day took over the agency six months ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the nations of Europe would only put all their cards on the table and deal with each other with entire frankness, without mental reservations, a lasting and mutually acceptable agreement could be reached. There is no use trying "to make the worse appear the better reason."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- With a punch at the start and another at the finish, Temple University defeated Bucknell in the Owls' stadium tonight, 12 to 0, before a crowd of 23,000 football enthusiasts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14 Teaming better than any other pair, especially on the second round, the former national open champion, Johnny Farrell of Quaker Ridge, and Joe Rich, assistant professional at the home club, carried off first prize in the professionals' Scotch foursome tournament at the Fenimore Country Club today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Two newcomers to tournament play, Mrs. Frank Sutton and Mrs. George Gibson of Montclair, N.J., carried off the women's pair championship this afternoon at the close of the three-day event at the Hotel Suburban here.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Displaying a fine brand of speed and cleverly ridden by Monte Parke, Bennet Creech's Whipper Cracker accounted for the Bond Hill Purse, feature of today's card at Latonia.

MADRID, Oct. 14.--All churches, cathedrals, episcopal palaces, seminaries, monasteries and other Catholic Church property in Spain would be confiscated by the Spanish republic under a statute for religious congregations submitted by President Alcala Zamora to the Cortes today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The text of the address delivered by Paul Reynaud, ex-Minister of Justice of France, at the American Bar Association meeting here today follows:

As a result of the increase in the market value of its securities during the first nine months of this year, the investment account of the Superheater Corporation has shown an appreciation of $310,530, it was announced yesterday. Investments of the company and its Canadian affiliate were carried at $1,903,177 in the last annual report, against which a reserve of $1,659,387 was set up.

Now that we are still stumbling about in the depression the authors of "Men Must Fight," which was acted at the Lyceum last evening, remind us that we are not yet safely out of war. Reginald Lawrence and S.K. Lauren have set their play forward to 1940 when the United States apparently goes to war with most of South America for the manliest of reasons.

Aged white horses pranced once again yesterday in their dusty stalls, awaiting only the driver's word to start with a load over to Third Avenue. For beer was in the air, both up and down the town and to the east and west. But it wasn't the dreary drink of this unhappy age; it was alcohol by weight, 3 per cent, alcohol by volume, 3.75 per cent.

The get of famous racers of another day were victors at Jamaica yesterday, three of the progeny of John P. Grier, which gave Man o' War his hardest race, being among the winners. There was no feature, but interest centred in the second race which saw the disqualification of George Boehle's Papyrograph, a gelded son of the English Derby winner Papyrus, which was defeated in this country by Zev.

The manifold benefits of air conditioning, from decreasing the prevalence of colds to saving manufacturing costs in the pill industry, were described by several engineers last night in a symposium directed by the New York section of the American Chemical Society in the Grand Central Palace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We celebrated Columbus Day by discovering the spirit of Autumn in Van Cortlandt Park. Leaving apartment-house problems and election tangles behind us, we betook ourselves to a quiet cove in Van Cortlandt Park, where a sheltering hill shut off the wind and the Yonkers trolley.

The Brooklyn Friends School football team, undefeated last year, vanquished Fieldston School, 21 to 7, yesterday at Fieldston's Field in the opening game of the season for both. Blaisdell scored fourteen of the winning eleven's points. Morton Karmel's 80-yard run for Fieldston's touchdown in the second period was one of the game's features.

Presidents and Primitives. In the same budget of daily news ALICE LONGWORTH once more calls attention to the fact that FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT is only a fourth cousin of "T.R)," and The Literary Digest poll, with 2,000,000 ballots counted, indicates that Governor ROOSEVELT will be elected by a plurality of 6,000,000.

VIENNA, Oct. 14 -- "I enjoyed my trip abroad very much, but I am delighted to return home to see daddy," Crown Prince Michael of Rumania said this evening in an exclusive interview granted through Colonel Grigorescu, King Carol's adjutant, who accompanied the Prince from London.
ELMIRA, Oct. 14 -- Colonel William J. Donovan asserted today that the country should keep President Hoover in the White House for another four years because that was sound business judgment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Internal Revenue Bureau officials have ordered a wide investigation to determine the cause for the low collections of some of the new miscellaneous taxes, which have fallen far below the estimate, and if possible to increase government revenue from that source.

The Board of Estimate adopted yesterday the resolutions approved last Tuesday by the Committee of the Whole, recommending the granting of one-year franchises to all existing bus operators in Manhattan and Queens, including the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the "emergency" operators now under supervision of the Department of Plant and Structures.
Further strides toward business recovery are reported by the commercial agencies in their weekly reviews.

Miss Annie Teller, 92 years old, a descendant of John Quincy Adams, sixth President of the United States, died yesterday in a tiny ball bedroom on the second floor at 166 East Thirty-second Street, overcome by gas that seeped from a break, in a rubber hose attached to a heater.

Giacomo de Martino, retiring Italian Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday that his aim had been "to render closer and stronger the bonds of friendship between our two nations." Addressing the Italy-America Society at a farewell luncheon in his honor at the Bankers Club, he praised the organization's efforts in the same direction.

Thursday's declines in prices on the Cotton Exchange here were followed yesterday by sharp rallies but after contracts for the December delivery had risen about 22 points to 6.63 cents a pound, prices reacted under realizing and some southern selling, the December closing at 6.47 cents, while the general market finished steady at net advances of 6 to 10 points.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 14 -- News that the sugar conference has finally reached an agreement on the basis proposed at Ostend, as reported in dispatches from The Hague, is regarded with, some alarm here as an indication that the price of imported sugar will rise.

Puerto Rico has the kind of Governor needed in the present emergency. Colonel THEODORE ROOSEVELT earned promotion to the Philippines by bringing to the attention of the American people the economic despair of the Puerto Ricans, aggravated by the effects of the cyclone of 1928.

Walter Damrosch, conducting the National Orchestra, began the fifth annual series of music appreciation concert-lectures over the radio yesterday for the school children of the nation. He was heard for an hour over the coast-to-coast networks of WEAF and WJZ, beginning at 11 A.M., Eastern Standard Time.

Reasons of economy and a desire to have Dr. Harold J. Parker develop a program of intramural athletics at the college were announced yesterday by City College officials as their motives in relieving Dr. Parker of his duties as head football coach.
BELAIR, Md., Oct. 14 -- Patriot, owned by Harry Todd of Lancaster, Pa., captured the 2:14 Class trot by taking all three heats in a field of ten today at the Harford County Fair.

RYE. N.Y., Oct. 14 -- For the second year in succession, Mrs. L.C. DuBois of the Wee Burn Club, Noroton, Conn., has won the women's senior golf championship of the United States. By returning a score of 86 today over the Westchester Country Club's south course, she compiled a 36-hole total of 173.

Each political party has for some time been banking on a formidable defection in the other. Republicans found great comfort in the prolonged silence of ex-Governor SMITH. Supposing that he would keep out of the campaign entirely, they sang his praises as a great man whom they would have been glad to support in any year except 1928, and whom his ungrateful party had ruthlessly trampled upon at the Chicago convention.

Reports from Democratic workers up-State indicate the election of Herbert H. Lehman and his colleagues on the State ticket, and the election of Democratic majorities in both the Assembly and the Senate, James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, said yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

The Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and Bishop of Rhode Island, will preach the sermon at the eleventh annual British Harvest Home Festival tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in St. Paul's Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway and Fulton Street.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, said yesterday that the latest figures from The Literary Digest's Presidential poll, which were published during the day, showed that Governor Roosevelt was "as good as elected," and had a good chance to carry all forty-eight States.

Andrew Fleming West, formerly dean of the Graduate School of Princeton University, is the author of "American General Education: A Short Study of its Present Condition and Needs," which is published today by the Princeton University Press.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Senator Smoot is of the "firm conviction that the primary object of the recent action taken at the Ottawa conference concerning the tariff is for the purpose of unifying Great Britain and Canada and not for economic purposes."

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The Telegraphen-Union, Nationalist news agency, said today that a rough draft of the proposed new Constitution for the Reich suggested a new chamber to complement the Reichstag and bound Prussian officials more closely to the Federal Government.

A Georgetown University football team will make its fifth annual appearance here against New York University at the Yankee Stadium today. As in the four previous meetings N.Y.U. will enter the game a favorite to win.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Mr. Khayyam, bearing the Catawba Stable colors, drove to a thrilling head victory over Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Poppyman in the featured Manor Purse, a test for 2-year-olds at a mile and seventy yards, today at Laurel.

ln an absorbing duel, in which the Bward was not made until after long consideration and a meticulous weighing of point against point, Champion Lone Eagle of Earlsmoor defeated Delightful Lady of Wildoaks for the title of best wire-haired at the combined annual and Summer show of the American Foxterrier Club, held yesterday in the Grand Central Palace.

One prohibition agent was committed to Bellevue Hospital for observation and another was treated for cuts on both hands as the result of a scuffle for possession of a pistol early yesterday in the squad room of prohibition headquarters on the tenth floor of the old stone building at 641 Washington Street.
Realty trading in Manhattan yesterday was featured by the sale of a building in the mercantile trades centre. This was the first outright transfer of a property there in some time.

GENEVA, Oct. 15 -- The disarmament conference committee dealing with the Hoover plan for the reduction of effectives reached the really delicate part of its job today. Rene Masstgli of France insisted that the police in Germany were so formed that they had to be considered in calculating her military forces as a measuring stick for the reduction of the forces of others.

Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray Jr., whose appointments as receivers for the Interborough were declared invalid last Thursday by Judge John M. Woolsey of the Federal District Court, conferred yesterday with counsel regarding an appeal.

The Board of Aviation Underwriters, to establish rates and underwriting rules for insurance of aircraft, has been organized as a result of a conference on aviation underwriters called by the superintendent of insurance. George S. Van Schaick, on June 10, it was announced yesterday by the State Insurance Department.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 14 -- The University of South Carolina defeated the Wofford College football team-today, 19 to 0.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The centre of activity on the Boerse today shifted to bonds, which were in brisk demand. The Young Plan issue rose 3 points, Luebeck 2 3/4 and Hilferding 2. Stocks sagged slightly in profittaking sales, but showed considerable resistance.

A method of distinguishing between normal living cells and cancerous cells by the use of a stain of trypan blue was discovered recently by Dr. R.J. Ludferd of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, Sir Lenthal Cheatle, foremost British cancer authority, said last night on arriving here aboard the Berengaria.
Numerous dwellings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- European business continues generally to show more optimism, though there is still a lack of definite signs of recovery, the Department of Commerce said today in its summary of the situation abroad.

Columbia will attempt to keep its winning streak intact today, when it opposes the University of Virginia eleven at Baker Field. Although the Lions defeated the Cavaliers, 27-0, in their initial meeting last season, the Blue and White expects a close encounter from the visitors.

One of the remembered characters in the Drumtochty stories by IAN MACLAREN was the Scottish "Domsie," the teacher, with a love for the "lad o' pairts." He had an American analogue in Professor JULIAN D. TAYLOR, who taught Latin for sixty-four years in Colby College -- up to the very last week of his life, which he quitted at 86.

One reason why Senator BORAH sometimes reaches an erroneous conclusion is that he proceeds logically from a false premise. Thus he urges governmental action in behalf of silver, recommending this as a means of developing foreign markets for American goods, because he thinks that the purchasing power of the Orient has been "virtually destroyed."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -- Replying to insistent queries from California newspaper editors. Senator Johnson issued a statement today declaring that he "cannot and will not support Mr. Hoover" for re-election.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association will stage its seventh annual meeting tomorrow on the estate of Amory L. Haskell. The affair is expected to be the largest in its history and has attracted some of the finest horses in the country, especially in the feature event, the Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup for 4-year-olds over timber.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Colton consumed during September was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 491,655 bales of lint and 61,308 of linters, compared with 402,601 of lint and 47,620 of linters in August this year and 464,335 and 64,269 in September last year.

HONGKONG, Oct. 14 -- The British steamer Helikon cams into port today after spending thirty-six hours in the hands of pirates, who distinguished themselves by according chivalrous treatment to Miss Edith Boynton, an American, and Mrs. Dirk van Driest, a Canadian, two of the passengers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Morals and manners of dwellers in the California mining camps of '49 were not nearly as bad as they have been frequently painted, according to a narrative of the times by Sarah Eleanor Royce, mother of Professor Josiah Royce of Harvard University, just published by the Yale University Press under the title "A Frontier Lady."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Challenging Republican contention that administration policies prevented the United States from going off the gold standard some months ago, Joseph P. Tumulty, secretary to President Wilson, declared today that the stability of American currency was really preserved through the Federal Reserve banking act.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Army's final preparations for the Pittsburgh game tomorrow were conducted in secret today. Only forty minutes were available for practice, which was devoted to a signal rehearsal.
St. Thomas College of Scranton, Pa., will engage Manhattan today at Ebbets Field in what promises to be an exciting contest. The game will start at 2:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- In statement summarizing the revised Canadian tariff by which the margin of preference for British Empire products is greatly increased, the Department of Commerce announced today that items affected comprised nearly a third of the Canadian tariff list.

The woodcock hunting season begins on Long Island today. There have been some wonderful seasons for this bird in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in the past, but the hunters may find the woodcock few and far between this year. The reason for this, according to veteran Long Island hunters, is that Autumn has been exceptionally dry and the woodcocK likes to land, in damp cover.

A wealthy woman, whose identity was not disclosed, saved Mile. Marthe Bastan, 35 years old, an unemployed dressmaker, who had not eaten any solid food in twenty-one days, from eviction from her three-room flat at 333 East Fifty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon.

Exporters Study Canadian Rates. Publication of some of the new rates applied by Canada on imports from outside the empire reassured the export trade to some extent yesterday. Although a large circle of executives consider the duties applying on shipments from this country as a serious threat to future trade between Canada and the United States, others insist that the tariff is no greater in most instances than manufacturers here expected.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Daily Telegraph today called the Ottawa conference agreements a "new chapter in empire history."

PITTSBUPGH, Oct. 14 -- Duquesne University defeated Oglethrope University, 21 to 6, at Forbes Field tonight. The visitors scored early in the first period when they recovered a fumble, on the one-yard line and Metrick plunged over the goal.
HAMMONTON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Governor Roosevelt's letter saying that he would soon give his position on the bonus, sent to Thomas B. Delker, read as follows:

ATHENS, Oct. 14 -- Leland B. Morris, American Charge d'Affaires, said today that a warrant for Samuel Insull's arrest existed and that the consulate's request to the Greek Government for his detention was based on an order from Washington citing it.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- A charge that funds held by the Board of Pensions of the United Lutheran Church in America had been used to "back a real estate development in Philadelphia" was made today at the biennial convention of the church by Ellwood Rabenold, a former State Senator of New York.

Operators of large ships expressed concern yesterday at the prospect of a strike of towboat and lighter employes which was threatened by the Associated Marine Workers if their wages are reduced under a new contract sponsored by the owners of towboat lines. Committees of the workers and towboat lines will meet Monday at the Towboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place, to discuss terms.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The Freshman First Honor Prize was awarded to four Princeton undergraduates here tonight by the graduate council of Princeton University. For the first time in the history of the award four men were tied for the prize, which is given annually to the student who attains the highest scholastic average during his freshman year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: ANTOFAGASTA, Oct. 14 -- You remember such a fuss one time over a country between Peru and Chile called Tacna-Arica? Well, I was there today. It takes an airplane to find it. It would be just like us going to war with somebody over Death Valley, California.
Brokers and renting agents of apartment buildings in Manhattan reported a large number of leases yesterday. Many of the larger suites were taken in houses on the east side.

Stocks advanced sharply and on a broad front yesterday as reports reached Wall Street that Governor Roosevelt would shortly express his disapproval of an outright soldiers' bonus at this time. The net gains in pivotal issues ranged from 2 to 8 points.

The Rev. Dr. Georga Alexander, for many years pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, who died Dec. 12, 1930, left an estate appraised yesterday at $21,954 gross and $14,185 net. A trust fund valued at $116,039, set up in his lifetime, was not taxed nor included in the appraisal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an address before the St. Louis Chamber of Commerce, Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said: "The prices of the securities of any company reflect conditions in that particular enterprise.

HAVANA, Oct. 14 -- An order was issued this morning by the military authorities not to issue any more permits for foreigners to leave Cuba. The edict caused consternation, and in several instances much inconvenience among foreign residents here.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The Bourse was stagnant again today, but without the resistance shown yesterday. Most of the list weakened steadily, closing at the day's lows. Among the factors in the weakness was the news of failure to transfer funds for payments on certain Yugoslav securities, which added to the Rumanian difficulties caused considerable concern in financial circles here.
WESTFIELD, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Harry Frank Jr.'s brown gelding Upperland was among the victors at the opening session of the Westfield Horse Show in the Westfield Armory tonight.

Sixteen Manhattan properties and seven in the Bronx were sold at mortgage foreclosure auctions yesterday. Plaintiffs protected their liens on the properties, comprised mostly of small tenements. Several business buildings and dwellings also were included in the offerings.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Oct. 14 (AP) -- There were reports today that the government of Manchukuo had concluded with Japan an agreement under which Manchukuo obtains control on Jan. 1 of all the railroads in Manchuria, except the South Manchuria Railway and the Russian half interest in the Chinese Eastern Railway.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The township committee announced here today the refunding of $63,000 of municipal bonds which matured on Oct. 7 by the issuance of $59,000 of assessment and improvement bonds due in 1938 and 1940 and of $4,000 of bonds due on Oct. 7, 1933.

The world faces two alternatives, according to G.D.H. Cole, author of "A Guide Through World Chaos." One is a determined attempt to reconstruct the capitalist system by removing the obvious causes of maladjustment and the other is to recognize that the capitalist system has now outlived its use, and to create in its place an economic order based on different principles and a different appeal to human motives.
