BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- Germany's rejection of Geneva as the seat of a four-power conference is wholly in conformity with her demand for a clear-cut decision on the question of her equality rights in advance of her renewed participation in disarmament conversations, it was stated today in official quarters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The government's newest machinery designed to aid economic recovery and relieve pressure on its citizens begins operations tomorrow.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Dignitaries of the Episcopal Church attended here today the consecration of the Rev. Dr. Benjamin M. Washburn as Bishop Coadjutor of the Diocese of Newark. The consecrator was the Most Rev. Dr. James De Wolf Perry of Rhode Island, presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church.

The legality of including amortization and interest charges for the Eighth Avenue subway in this year's city budget was challenged yesterday before the Board of Estimate by George McAneny, former Manhattan Borough President, who presented for the Citizens Budget Commission a recommendation that about $60,000,000 in such costs be taken bodily out of the budget.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Complete accord between the League of Nations and the American Commission of Neutrals attempting to solve the dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay over the Chaco is shown in telegraphic correspondence made public late today by the commission, of which Francis White, Assistant Secretary of State, is president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, who is in the West campaigning for the Republican ticket, recently announced the appointment of Sam M. Jones of Toledo as "civil administrative assistant to the Assistant Secretary of the Navy," at a salary of $6,500 a year, and some persons are wondering what his duties are.

About 19,000 individual investors in securities of the Central Public Service Corporation and its subsidiaries have turned in more than $51,000,000 book value of stocks, bonds and notes in exchange for new securities under a readjustment plan.

ATHENS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Reiterating his refusal to surrender his passport, Samuel Insuli, former utilities leader, wanted in Chicago to answer an indictment, declared in a letter to the United States Consul today that he would not be turned "into a scamp who can neither stay anywhere nor go anywhere."

Under the terms of the proposed $10,000,000 tax loan to the Mexican Government by foreign oil companies operating there, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, the Royal Dutch-Shell group and the Standard Oil Company of California will guarantee the payment of $3,000,000 each, while the Consolidated Oil Corporation will guarantee the payment of $1,000,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14 -- A petition in bankruptcy, listing liabilities of $2,142,778 and assets of $1,325,637, was filed in Federal court here today on behalf of John H. Stamler, Newark and Elizabeth lawyer, and president of the New Jersey National Bank and Trust Company, which is now in liquidation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Yale and Brown tomorrow win play their thirty-seventh football game in a series that has been almost annual since 1890. Brown has scored four victories and two ties in the series. It won by 7-0 in 1926.

The football seismograph shows an alarming sensitivity today. All along the Atlantic, through the South, to Birmingham and New Orleans and westward, the storm signals are out for the roughest day of action the season has witnessed.

Citizens of Westchester ought not to need urging this year to vote for RUTH TAYLOR as County Commissioner of Public Welfare. They have known her for eighteen years, ever since the day in 1914 when the late V. EVERIT MACY, father of the county's modern welfare program, retained her to help him with his work as County Superintendent of the Poor.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14 -- A revolutionary movement is under way in Chile, the Minister of the Interior admitted today, but the government la convinced it soon will be suppressed.

City Hall Park was crowded with thousands of spectators at noon yesterday while Acting Mayor McKee left the meeting of the Board of Estimate to award medals to 432 boys and girls whose essays on fire prevention were judged the best of the 5,000 previously submitted to a staff of inspectors of the Fire Prevention Bureau.

MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 14 -- A favorable balance of $7,682,686 is shown in the statement of Canadian foreign trade for September, just released by the Department of National Revenue. Compared with a year ago, exports declined approximately $6,800,000, to $42,186,815.

Earnings of 167 Class 1 railroads, including seventeen switching and terminal companies, for August and the first eight months of the year were reported yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The figures follow closely a similar compilation issued by the Bureau of Rail- way Economics recently. They follow:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Hoover will leave Washington early tomorrow for his second campaign speaking trip to the Middle West. His third formal speech of the campaign will be made at Cleveland tomorrow night.

GENOA, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Duke of Abruzzi submitted his resignation today as president of the Italia Line, into which Italian steamship companies serving both North and South America recently were combined. He gave as his reason his inability to bring about harmony among executives of companies that used to be competitive.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Samuel B. Wilson, Assistant State's Attorney, told a jury today its duty is to inflict on George Courson and Solomon Higginbotham the same death penalty the former prison guards inflicted by torture on young Arthur Maillefert.

A $89,500 second mortgage held by the E. G. Construction Co., Inc., from Fannie M. Sandberg on the six-story Stratford Avon Hall at the southeast corner of St. Nicholas Av. and 174th St., has been modified so that interest will be $250 a month for the year beginning Oct. 15. 1932, and no instalments of principal are to be paid during this term.

After several weeks of postponement the Board of Estimate approved yesterday an appropriation, to be made available through a transfer of 1932 budget funds, of $5,000 to help defray the expenses of the State convention, of the American Legion held in Brooklyn Aug. 25, 26 and 27.

Thirty communities throughout the country have scheduled new bond and note issues amounting to $7,684,122 for award next week, a sum well below the weekly average for the year to date, which is $18,766,611. This week's total of scheduled new municipal financingamounted only $4,874,428.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Following is the text of Lord Reading's speech before the American Bar Association tonight:

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- British Government funds and gold-mine shares were the centre of interest on the Stock Exchange today. In response to strong demand the former gained with unabated vigor. Boomlike conditions prevailed in gold shares. The Kaffirs were particularly strong on renewed Cape support.

Bullet Joe Simpson, for many years a star player and last season the manager of the New York American farm at New Haven, yesterday was named by William V. Dwyer as manager of the Americans in the National Hockey League for the coming season. He succeeds Eddie Gerard.
Primed for its third encounter of the 1932 campaign, the Fordham University football team will line up against Lebanon Valley at the Polo Grounds today at 2:30 P.M.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14 -- Having run up a total of 108 points against Buffalo and New Hampshire in previous games, Harvard will enter the more difficult part of its season tomorrow.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 14 -- The twentieth annual Fall golf tournament was concluded here today, with many colonists entertaining during the afternoon and evening.
The text of the radio address by John N. Garner, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, last night follows:

The freighter Registan, carrying a consignment of Arabian dates valued at $2,500,000, docked yesterday morning at Pier 7, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn. Her cargo was the first of the season's crop. Although the 32-year-old custom of racing to New York for the honor of landing the first date cargo was abolished this year, the Registan made the 10,000-mile trip in twenty-six days and reduced the previous record by twenty-four hours.
Rising prices on all markets yesterday reflected an overnight reversal in sentiment. The abrupt change was felt in stocks, bonds and commodities, all of which advanced sharply.

THE NEW YORK TIMES average of forty domestic corporation bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange showed yesterday the largest gain for a day since Sept. 21. Railroad bonds particularly made sizable recoveries. Foreign loans, on the average, were slightly higher and United States Government obligations advanced generally.

Final standings for the 1932 championship series of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, announced yesterday by Philip R. Mallory, president, reveal that Horace Havemeyer's Mouette won the twelve-meter title with a precentage of .858.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S radio appeal for relief dealt only with the unemployed and the present emergency plans for taking care of them. Rightly he laid chief stress upon the local, or what may be called the neighborly, obligation. Individuals and cities and States must do all within their power before going, as a last resort, to the Federal Government.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Who will succeed Amos Alonzo Stagg as football coach at the University of Chicago? Announcement of the retirement of the 70-year-old mentor of the Midway started speculation tonight about his successor. Professor Thomas Nelson Metcalf, the new athletic director, will not attempt to coach, although Mr. Stagg combined both positions during his 41-year career.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A ban on all advertising in Lutheran publications that "appeal to the money-making desires of church organizations" was approved today by the church's convention.

Registration of voters in the city jumped yesterday, the total for five days of registration week being 1,587,595, an increase of 96,960 over the first five days of 1928, when the previous high record was set.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- As the opening event of Rochester's music season the twenty-seventh concert in the Eastman School of Music American composers' series was given tonight in Kilbourn Hall. The performance was by the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, Dr. Howard Hanson conducting.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 14 -- The men's singles final in the Greenbrier Autumn lawn tennis tournament was won today by Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, who defeated J. Gilbert Hall of East Orange, N.J., in straight sets, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, reversing the outcome of the match they played at the Sleepy Hollow Club two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Western railroads today urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to keep freight rates on live stock at the present level or to increase them. Attorneys for the carriers, arguing before the full commission, all asserted the railroads could not afford to haul live stock for any less than the present rates, and some of them urged an increase.

Values for commodities yesterday sharply reversed the movement of Thursday, substantial price improvement being recorded in the grains, cotton, silk, hides, rubber and other staples. Practically all of the losses of the preceding day were recovered.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey, after hearing arguments yesterday by counsel for both sides, reserved decision on an application made by the defense for an order dismissing the complaint of Walter Lowenfela, poet and playwright, in which it is charged that the authors, composers and producers of "Of Thee I Sing" copied and plagiarized his play, "U.S.A. With Music."

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The vanishing point was virtually reached today for all chances of holding the four-power conference suggested by Prime Minister MacDonald as a means of settling the arms equality dispute between France and Germany, and of bringing the latter country back to the world disarmament conference at Geneva.
EAST CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Yonkers High School's football team downed Eastchester High, 13 to 7, today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- There was an abrupt halt today in the downward trend in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here. Aggressive purchases by houses with Eastern connections and by local professionals caught the market in an oversold condition and prices advanced nearly 2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish before the buying movement ran its course.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reports for the first nine months of the year net income of $110,541,623, equal to $5.92 a share on 18,661,400 average number of shares outstanding in the period, against $128,529,561, or $7.01 a share, on 18,021,760 average shares in the first nine months of 1931.

A recommendation by the Emergency Work and Relief Administration that the city plan to spend $30,000,000 on home and work relief in the six months beginning Nov. 1, almost doubling the amount it has spent for relief in the last six months, was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Controller Charles W. Berry.

FRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Princeton and Cornell will meet on the Palmer Stadium gridiron tomorrow in the twenty-second game ot a series which began in 1891. A crowd of 40,000 is expected to witness the contest.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Governor Roosevelt answered tonight a widely circulated Republican attack on him as a participant in foreign enterprises which resulted in loss to American investors.

The New York City electorate Is faced with a "choice of evils" in the Mayoralty election next month, Samuel Seabury asserted last night on his return on the Cunarder Berengaria from a six-weeks' holiday abroad. He held out hope, however, for a fusion movement to 1933 to oust the "sinister political forces" which now control the city government.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that the budget situation alone was sufficient reason for overthrowing Tammany. He declared it as a challenge that the people could not overlook.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The largest demand for seats at a Republican gathering here since the 1924 national convention has been made for President Hoover's address in the Public Auditorium tomorrownight, John D. Marshall, chairman of the local committee on arrangements, said tonight.

Once more the youth of our land is aroused. Every four years there are Republican and Democratic leagues of graduates and undergraduates. They may be presumed to attain some degree of enjoyment from their evolutions and contributions, even if their exact effect upon the result is of the shadowiest.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Opposing a movement to advance crude oil prices in the mid-continent field, which gained momentum this week with several buyers subscribing to a higher price schedule, the Standard Oil Company of Indiana announced today that it would not raise its posted prices.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 14 Three armed men, one of whom wore the uniform of a policeman with a badge, stole jewelry valued at $15,000 from the home of Augustus H. Bergmaun at 18 Surrey Road here today after they had bound Mrs. Bergmann and a Negro couple, employed as maid and chauffeur, to the bedposts in Mrs. Bergmann's room.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Concerted action by the United States, Great Britain and France in the present economic crisis as in the World War for the preservation of the ideals of democracy and the peace of the world was urged today by Paul Reynaud, former Minister of Justice of France, in an address delivered before members of the American Bar Association.

Overriding the favorable recommendations of John F. Sullivan, Commissioner of City Planning, the Board of Estimate unanimously rejected yesterday the proposed zoning amendments which would have permitted, with the consent of only 50 per cent of the affected property owners, the construction of parking garages in retail and business districts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Acting in the suggestion of Senator Smoot, chairman of the Finance Committee, more than 300 articles which are imported at prices below the cost of production in the United States were exhibited in the Finance Committee rooms today by F.X.A. Eble, Commissioner of Customs.

An easier street market, wherein day loans were made at 3/4, a fractional concession from the inside figure of 1 per cent, was all that developed in money. Following the abrupt decline in call loans, time money and acceptances on Thursday, the day's session was quiet and without feature.

To a cowboy band's variations on the theme of "The Old Gray Mare," the seventh annual World Series Rodeo opened last night at Madison Square Garden. It had as its first audience many persons of official and semi-official life, several thousand more from the Park Avenue area and many thousand more of those who just like rodeos.

Production of new life insurance in the United States in September was at a higher rate than the average for the first nine months of the year, according to a report filed yesterday with the United States Department of Commerce by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Vice Chancellor Robert H. Ingersoll in an opinion today found fraud on the part of the late Mayor Anthony M. Ruffu Jr. in negotiating loans on the property of the Garibaldi Legion, a fraternal organization of which he was a leader.

The importance of maintaining budgets sufficient to assure adequate relief for children suffering from malnutrition in the depression was emphasized yesterday in the Hotel Astor at a conference on child welfare and protection under the joint auspices of the New York State and New York City Federations of Women's Clubs.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 14 -- Opening his campaign in Long Island at a Republican rally here tonight, F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War and Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, declared that the record of the "Democratic wrecking crew" in the House of Representatives had been an "object-lesson," indicating what the country might expect if it should pass into Democratic control.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Warning that "the general public will find itself in a condition of servitude unless government costs are reduced" is made in a letter signed by former President Coolidge, Alfred E. Smith, Elihu Root, General Pershing, Newton D. Baker and Admiral Sims.

The national council of the Protestant Episcopal Church has approved a tentative budget of $3,460,000 for 1933 for the world-wide work of that communion, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the communion, 281 Fourth Avenue. This is more than $750,000 below the figures set by the triennial general convention of the church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A ten-point program for coordinating municipal transportation facilities, urging among other steps the prevention of unfair competition, was issued today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

A MHERST vs. Hamilton -- Lord Jeffrey Amherst was Governor of Virginia in the Colonial days. George Washington once pulled a watch on Alexander Hamilton and penalized him for remaining too long in a huddle. One vote for Amherst.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 -- Isaac Kashdan of New York today advanced to a tie with Dr. Alexander Alekhine, world's champion, for the lead in the international chess masters' tournament.

Vigorous advances on the Stock Exchange yesterday were accompanied by reports that Governor Roosevelt was preparing to define his position on the soldiers' bonus. It was assumed that he would express his opposition to an outright cash grant, and this was apparently the basis for the enthusiastic upswing in stock prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Department of Commerce made public today the final part of its survey of Canadian tariff changes, with comparisons between the old and the new rates. One-third of these changes were published in The New York Times this morning. The others are as follows:

NEW YORK. Walter P. Chrysler Jr. and John F. Chrysler are giving a dance tonight at the home of their parents in Great Neck, L.I., for Miss Victoria Brady, a debutante of the season. In advance of it Mr. and Mrs. George Meyer and Miss Anne Meyer will give a dinner at their home in Great Neck.
The Republican National Committee here announced last night that Henry Ford would urge the re-election of President Hoover in a radio address on Wednesday night.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 14.--Governor Roosevelt gave assurance today that he would state his position on cash payment of the bonus within a short time.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The recent scare over the strength of the dollar after President Hoover's speech at Des Moines was illogical and unjustifiable, declares The Economist in its current issue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--Railroad presidents gathered here today for two important meetings at the Blackstone Hotel. One was a session of the advisory committee of the Association of Railway Executives. The other was that of the board of directors of the American Railway Association.

DAHLONEGA, Ga., Oct. 15 (AP). -- They are digging for gold again in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Georgia, where 101 years ago a Governor sent his forces to halt devastation of the country by an army of gold-mad men.

UNION CITY, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A burglar who had been routed from the home of Alfred Modarelli, police judge of this city, dodged the police into alleys and hallways today and was captured after he had been wounded by one of about fifteen shots fired by policemen.

Years ago the sneering question was asked by the manager of a party machine: "Who ever reads a political speech? " Today, with the radio hookup, it is a matter of listening, not reading. A remorseless political orator invades the privacy of the home, sparing neither age, sex nor scheduled time.

THIS book will be a revelation to that host of readers who habitually shy from the subject of law as though it were the plague. It will show them that drama lies in the dusty tomes that fine the walls of law libraries the country over, generally considered useless for any service but that of tools for the legal practitioner.

THE Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University offers an unusually interesting program of lectures for the coming season, beginning on Oct. 17 with an address by President Nicholas Murray Butler on "Ideals in American Politics."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 3. -- General Hans Kundt, chief of staff and organizer of the Bolivian Army, startled South America when he revealed his scheme for colonizing the Amazon Valley. He plans to raise capital in Germany to finance the transportation of 1,000,000 able-bodied Germans.

RADIO has a "Tune Detective." He has studied the ancestry of music. He specializes in the family history of melody and reveals his experiences as a sleuth over WJZ on Tuesday nights at 10:15 o'clock. On the program he is listed as Sigmund Spaeth.

LONDON. ROBERT BRIDGES, our late Laureate, loved to experiment with unusual meters, and his successor. John Masefield, is also not afraid of innovation. In "A Tale of Troy" (Heinemann) he departs from convention by varying his rhythm in different sections of the poem.

His right foot pinioned beneath the rubber sheathing at the bottom of one vane of a revolving door, Allen Fitch Jr., 9 years old, was held prisoner for the better part of an hour early last evening in the front doorway of Tip Toe Inn, a restaurant at 2,363 Broadway, at Eighty-sixth Street.

Soviet Russia is gradually drifting from true communistic doctrines toward the establishment of a more stable system. Professor Herbert O. Elftman of Seth Low Junior College declared yesterday. Professor Elftman has just returned from a tour of Russia.

LIKE the name of Abou Ben Adhem, which led all the rest for reasons more pertinent than that its possessor loved his fellow-men, the names which invariably appear upon the programs of musical shows and revues directly beneath the title of the production are so placed for reasons other than that the gentlemen -- usually -- to whom they refer are expected to appear upon the stage.

Scores of diseases are transmitted by microbes visible under a microscope. Inoculate any normal man with, the proper microbe and he contracts the corresponding disease. Yet there are diseases, such as measles, smallpox, yellow fever, colds, and the foot-and-mouth disease, which can also be inoculated but are not apparently caused by a microbe.

THE breaking of a water main in Fortieth Street east of Seventh Avenue last week calls attention to the vast system of pipes that lies beneath the streets of New York. Four thousand miles of mains distribute 1,000,000,000 gallons of water daily through the five boroughs.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 13. -- Two nationally known figures, as diametrically opposed as the poles in age, politics and ambition, are stirring the political pot in Indiana this year to more than ordinary commotion.

AT the present moment the probability that any great number of motorists in this country will be driving around next year, or even the next, in automobiles powered by Diesel engines seems rather nebulous. To be sure, there has lately been talk of the introduction in 1933 of a medium-priced passenger car equipped with this type of motor, which burns fuel oil instead of gasoline.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Newton Wesley Rowell, president of the Canadian Bar Association, said in his address to the American Bar Association tonight:

SEVERAL entertainments in behalf of well-known philanthropio projects have been arranged for the early Autumn, and judging from the response by way of subscriptions there is every indication that charitable funds will be augmented greatly through them.

WEDDINGS will be the principal social events of the coming fortnight, with descendants of well-known families among the brides-to-be. They will include the Misses Helen Stuyvesant Voorhees, Mary Hill Beard, Peggy Moffett, Jeanne Knowlton Froment, Lorna Mackay, Winifred J. Howard, Mary Louise Burke, Montague Harwood Priddy, Sylvia Roe and Elizabeth Detwiller.

GENEVA, Oct. 15. -- The League of Nations Council, in private session today, decided to invite all the members of the Lytton Commission on Manchuria to assemble at Geneva from Nov. 14 to 21, when it takes up their report on the Chino-Japanese conflict.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13. -- When -- Alfred E. Smith shook hands with Franklin D. Roosevelt in Albany the other day Democratic leaders in Pennsylvania got out their adding machines and began tallying up thousands of additional votes in this State not only for Governor Roosevelt, but for the whole party ticket.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 15 (AP). -- Indiana won its first Western Conference victory of the season at the expense ot Iowa today, 12 to 0, before a home-coming crowd of 10,000.

THIS book begins with an extensive recapitulation of the practices of misrule, corruption and thievery carried on by the Tammany knaves who were exposed by Samuel Seabury in the magistrates' courts and the city-wide investigations.

OMAHA, Oct. 13. -- If prohibition is an important factor of the campaign in this and other Corn Belt States, that fact is not visible in the smoke of the conflict. The present apparent absence of interest in this question is in distinct contrast with the attention it received at the time of the conventions.

WITH college boys and girls and even preparatory school youngsters vying for heavier courses of study, for scholarships and for jobs that will help them stay in school, education in this country with the Fall of 1932 has lost its ancient guise of irksome task and become a special privilege.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 1. -- Unemployment insurance, with elimination of relief work and its scale of compensation below the prevailing wages in the labor market, is one of the main issues on the program of the Social Democrats, who swung into power in last month's elections with a majority large enough to warrant the forming of a Cabinet wholly within the party.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Displaying an impregnable defense and strong but steady attack, the Amherst varsity, held scoreless for three periods, put over two touchdowns in the last quarter to defeat a stubborn Hamilton eleven, 13-0, on Pratt Field today.

Compromise settlements under which investors are exchanging their original bonds and stocks for new issues of half the face value and gambling with debtors to salvage the remainder when business improves are enabling scores of manufacturing, real estate and other business enterprises to escape liquidation at this time, James O. McKinsey, industrial engineer and head of the organization which bears his name told THE TIMES yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 14. -- The great agricultural exhibition, recently inaugurated in connection with the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome shows the progress of the Mussolini Government's huge land-reclaiming program, which is regarded as the principal Fascist achievement and one of the greatest works ever undertaken by any government.

SIENA. OLD masters are enjoying a moment of great popularity in Italy. "The Tempest" by Giorgione, one of the most famous of privately owned pictures, has been bought by the Italian Government from Prince Alberto Giovanelli for 5,000,000 lire.

Construction of new ships in the United States must be doubled during the next twelve years to maintain the trend of expansion that the merchant marine has experienced in the last 140 years, according to J. Lyell Wilson, assistant chief surveyor of the American Bureau of Shipping.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The Monmouth County Hunt Gold Cup, renewed for the sixth time today at the seventh annual meeting of the Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association over the green-carpeted course on the estate of Amory L. Haskell near here, was captured by Mrs. T.W. Durant's famous gelding Fugitive in hollow fashion.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 15. -- Villanova ran rough shod over Seton Hall today in the Main Line Stadium. The final score was 46-0.

SUMTER, S.C., Oct. 13. -- Cooperative marketing associations for single staple crops have been doing a varying amount of business in South Carolina for some years, but the State's first County Farmers Exchange, acting as a clearing house and sales agency for all farm products, has been organized here as the initial step in a ten-year plan to stabilize farming in Sumter County.

IN "George Gershwin's Song Book" will be found eighteen of his best and most characteristic compositions. The book, beautifully printed and admirably designed, contains an introduction by the composer, some very vivacious entertainment consisting of full-page illustrations in color by Constantin Alajalov, and a brief essay of tribute to Alajalov by Samuel M. Kootz.

ARTURO TOSCANINI, conducting the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will feature the Vivaldi-Bach concerto in A Minor for four pianos and orchestra in its American radio premiere this afternoon from 3 to 5 o'clock through WABC and a coast-to-coast network.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 15. -- The New York Aggies were defeated by Trinity today, 48 to 0. The team from Farmingdale, L.I., made only one first down.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Visitors at the Capitol since Congress adjourned in July have shown more interest in a chart setting forth the comparative costs of veterans' benefits in the United States and Allied nations, than they have in the imposing statues and paintings of former members of Congress which adorn the corridors of the Capitol.

A GREAT hydraulic baling press which in a single crushing blow converts a "retired" automobile into a compressed bundle of scrap metal hardly larger than a bale of hay is now in operation at the Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company.

JOHANNESBURG, British South Africa, Oct 15 (AP). -- One of South Africa's most sensational murder trials will open here Monday when Mrs. Daisy Louise de Melker, now the wife of a leading South African rugby football player, will appear in court to answer charges that she poisoned two former husbands and her son.

THE old order, which changeth with amazing frequency along the mercurial highroad known as Broadway, bowed to the inevitable last week. Another tradition, for which the moderns have little regard, heard its death sentence pronounced.

Four gunmen burst into the Public National Bank and Trust Company's branch at 275 East 169th Street, the Bronx, yesterday morning and fired three shots into the air. Then, shouting that they meant to kill if opposed, they hurdled a counter, scooped up $12,000 to $14,000 and escaped in an automobile.
New York University's cross-country team triumphed over Columbia, 22 to 33, over a 4 1/4-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. It was the opening dual meet of the season for both teams.

THREE hundred years ago, in the rectory of East Knoyle in Wiltshire, was born Christopher Wren, the man who invented the style of architecture which ruled the English-speaking world for two centuries; the man, also, who created the accepted model of the Protestant church building which even the perfervid Gothic revival of the last fifty years has not been able utterly to dislodge from favor.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 16. -- Now that the famine is over, and the Lunghai Railway is actually being extended from the border of Honan Province to Sianfu, the provincial capital of Shensi, the Shensi provincial government has revived plans for development of the Yenchang oil fields.

The appointment of Louis Winokur as editor-in-chief of the Commerce Violet, New York University School of Commerce yearbook, was announced yesterday by Dean G. Rowland Collins, chairman of the school faculty committee on student activities.

SUMTER, S.C., Oct. 13. -- When a rejuvenated Republican organization in South Carolina announced after the Chicago convention that it would put up candidates to oppose the hitherto unopposed Democrats, and that all its candidates would be bonedry, the Democratic moguls looked on with an air of good-natured indulgence.

THE Vicomte Alein de Leche, an amiable young Frenchman who has been writing for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's French productions in Hollywood, arrived in New York last week en route to Paris. Metro is opening a studio there with a view to avoiding the stringent French laws on imported films by making pictures for the French trade on the spot.

GENEVA, Oct. 15. -- The Council of the League of Nations publicly received today through Acting President Connolly a cablegram from Francis White, chairman of the Commission of Neutrals in Washington, replying to its cablegram of Oct. 3, in which it suggested that Bolivia and Paraguay withdraw their troops in the Chaco to avoid a collision and a military commission be sent to the region to supervise the withdrawal.

Surprised in a flat on the top floor of a five-story tenement building at 235 East 120th Street yesterday afternoon, a burglar was killed and his companion slightly wounded by a policeman after one of the burglars had tried to shoot another policeman.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Dr. Theodore Tieken head of the Department of Materia Medica, Therapeutics and Toxicology and Clinical Professor of Medicine at the University of Chicago, died today of heart disease at his home.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 15. -- The twenty-fifth football encounter between West Virginia University and West Virginia Wesleyan resulted in a 14-0 victory for the University eleven.

ATHENS, Greece, Oct. 15. -- For the first time since he arrived in Athens, Samuel Insull Sr. appeared depressed and worried today. Friends ascribed this to the publication in the United States of his reply to the United States Consulate here concerning his passport, which he refused to give up as requested to do.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Upon being advised by Attorney General Stevens that immediate action was necessary, Governor Moore appointed today Supreme Court Justice Luther A. Campbell of Hackensack as Chancellor of New Jersey to succeed Edwin Robert Walker of Trenton, who died yesterday.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Sixteen pairs of contract bridge enthusiasts, the survivors of a field of ninety which started play last night, competed tonight in the final round of the pair championship for the United States Bridge Association's trophy at the Hotel Suburban here In the second annual tournament under the auspices of the Whist Club of the Oranges.

REDISTRIBUTION of traffic to avoid congestion is part of the plan for State control of all road work recommended by the New York State Automobile Association at its convention in Syracuse last week. As reported, the association advocated a plan whereby the State should take over all the road construction and maintenance activities now done by fifty-six county and 934 town highway units in the State.

MADRID, Oct. 15. -- Mgr. Frederico Tedeschini, the Papal Nuncio in Madrid, according to persons close to him, is fighting not only for the existence of the church in Spain but against reactionaries within the church who demand open resistance to the republican government.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 19. -- Successful road tests have just been completed at Changsha, in Hunan Province, of an automobile engine which operates entirely on the fumes from charcoal. At Changsha gasoline costs $1.50 a gallon in Chinese money, and careful tests are said to prove that the new charcoal engine can he operated over a stated mileage at one-tenth the cost of an automobile or motor truck propelled by a gasoline engine.
The Dickinson High eleven conquered the Ridgefield Park team in Jersey City yesterday, 19 to 0, for its third straight triumph of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- The United Lutheran Church in America, at its biennial convention today, ordered a newly created investment commission to make a full investigation of charges that the denomination's board of ministerial pensions had "backed a real estate development in Philadelphia."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The University of Baltimore gained a 7-6 victory over Canisius College today. Canisius scored in the second period after a series of line smashes by Captain Geagan but failed to convert the extra point. Baltimore trailed until the fourth period, when Mills scored on a pass from Bender.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- A safety in the fourth quarter spelled defeat for Oberlin today and enabled Rochester University to register a 2-to-0 victory over the Yeomen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Catholic University's football team defeated Chattanooga, 19 to 20 today, Chattanooga making its first appearance in Brookland Stadiunr in an important intersectional game. Heretofore Catholic University played in the former's stadium.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A furiously fighting Princeton team that was reminiscent of the Tiger in the days when he was one of the kings of the football jungles stalked across Palmer Stadium today to smother the attack of one of the vaunted teams of the East.

ONE of the social changes in the last fifteen years has been the realization among rural people of the need for and possibilities of adult education. This subject was not even mentioned in the first American Country Life Association meeting, held in 1919.
VANCOUVER, Oct. 12. -- The Canadian West is changing largely, as illustrated by a recent incident.

A PERENNIAL lure lurks about that shipload of camels that was landed on our territory on the Gulf coast of Texas seventy-five years ago, and every now and then inspires another book about the experiment. That proves to be an advantage, for each new volume adds something to the history of the scheme.

Mixing its ground and aerial plays with telling effect, the C.C.N.Y. football team gained a 13-0 victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute yesterday at the Lewisohn Stadium for its first triumph in three starts this season.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Sept. 14 (AP) (By Mail). -- A scale of "bounties" for the killing or capture of Japanese officers, soldiers and civilians in Manchuria is set forth in documents published here by the Japanese military authorities.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 15. -- Vice President Curtis's right arm and shoulder were bruised in an automobile accident near Layton, "Utah, today as he was on the way here from Ogden. He was suffering severely and did not make a scheduled talk at Layton.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 13. -- Leaders of both major parties are bending every effort toward getting out the vote. The stake is larger than in 1928, for a United States Senator will be chosen this year, as well as nine Representatives-at-Large.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 15. -- Ohio University inflicted a 14-to-0 defeat on the Naval Academy today, the score being made up by touchdowns in the second and fourth quarters, and extra points added by a drop kick and a placement.

THE "fourteen" islands that Princess Dayang, daughter of the Sultan of Sulu, claims from the United States are only seven in number, according to geographers; but a few missing islands make little difference in that quarter of the globe.

The New York Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers, bitter adversaries in professional football, will renew their rivalry at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, starting, at 2:30, when the Giants inaugurate their eighth home season. The Jewish Consumptive Relief Society will share in the proceeds.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 15. -- West triumphed over East in the twenty-second renewal of the Breeders' Futurity at Latonia today when Hal Price Headley's Technique led home a smart band of 2-year-olds, which included four Eastern inyaders.

Wall Street is finding it difficult to preserve an attitude of rigid neutrality in the national political campaign. The stock market, faithful recorder of the financial community's emotions, just won't behave. With an odd perversity, it denies to former President Coolidge the traditional tribute of respect.

LAWRENCEVELLE, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A fighting Lawrenceville eleven defeated Princeton Prep, 19 -- 7, today. The Red and Black held the game well in hand during the first three periods, but Princeton Prep opened up in the last quarter and marched 78 yards to a score.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Sept. 17. -- Less than a year after New Zealand took its nationally owned railroads out of politics, private control has turned a losing proposition into a financially sound investment. This year, for the first time since the world crash of values, the railroad corporation operated by the State and marked up as a $300,000,000 investment will not be in the red.

THROUGHOUT the world, The London Times has enjoyed a special prestige as "the Thunderer" of the British Empire. It has made and unmade statesmen, and has been regarded as a national institution, expressive of the mind of England.

SOME wit once remarked that the greatest fur-bearing animal in the world was the American woman. That was a few years ago -- when the boom was on. Oddly enough, though we are still fighting our way out of depression, the American woman is about to bedeck herself in more and better furs than before.

Six of the leading Protestant Episcopal churches will have Bishops to deliver the sermon this morning. In all Lutheran churches connected with the United Lutheran Church in America, prayers will be said for a blessing on the eighth biennial convention of that body, which is in session in Philadelphia.

AMONG historians there is a certain source-materialism or parchmentabllity that paralyzes the imagination. Unless he puts it into writing. Alfred burns no cakes. Bruce watches no spiders and Washington chops no cherry trees.

IN the face of discouraging reports from other forms of transportation, the airlines of the United States continue to show increases in the number of passengers and the pounds of express carried month by month. Only in air mail has there been a decline and this is dua to one particular cause, the increase since last year of the air mail postage rate by more than 50 per cent.
MADRID, Oct. 14. -- Strong pressure on the part of certain nations for increased censorship is obvious at the International Telegraph and Radiotelegraph joint conferences here.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 15. -- Returning here after an absence of twenty-six years, the Colgate eleven today overwhelmed Lafayette by 35 to 0.

A FEW weeks ago the eyes of the nation were turned on Washington, where leaders in philanthropic endeavors met with President Hoover. Methods were discussed whereby the relief work of private philanthropic organizations might be helped to continue at a time when the need for this work is greater than ever before, and when the resources of the organizations are less than ever before.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The Anglo-Irish negotiations to end the dispute over land annuity payments by the Irish Free State broke down completely today, and an attempt to reach a settlement was abandoned for the time being.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 15. -- Randolph-Macon College played a scoreless tie with the Hampden-Sydney eleven today before a Hampden-Sydney homecoming crowd estimated at 2,000.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 15. -- Choate overwhelmed Hopkins Grammar School of New Haven by a score of 26-0 today. The game was featured by much passing.

THAT pioneer industry, the business of transportation, has fallen on hard times. For reasons inherent partly in law and partly in economics, the railways failed to share on even terms in the prosperity enjoyed by most other basic industries for some years before 1929.

Praise for the achievements of the Fascist regime in Italy and an invitation to the scholars, scientists and artists of the world to come to see the transformations wrought were given yesterday by Senator Guglielmo Marconi in a radio address heard in the United States through stations of the National Broadcasting Company.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- The withdrawal of the Liberal Ministers has restored order, for a time, within the national government, and Mr. MacDonald can devote some attention to the problem of the relations of this country with France. Indeed the need is urgent for a decision on this point.

WHEN I was a boy one of our favorite games was "follow your leader." Nowadays, when boys of the same age drive high-powered cars, the sport seems to have changed to passing the other fellow on the road at any risk. For the last dozen years our politicians have largely indulged in the second form of sport.

PANAMA, R.P., Oct. 11. -- A possible solution for the revolutions that have afflicted the countries of Latin America for several years may be seen in the recent duel in Quito, capital of Ecuador, between the former Minister of Government Carlos Zambrano and the former Minister of War, Leonardo Sotomayor, in which both escaped unscathed.

A NEW series of concerts to take place at the Grotrian Hall on Sunday afternoons, Oct. 9, 16, 23 and 30, is giving music lovers the opportunity of hearing four of the finest performers in London, in one program, for a price considerably lower than that charged for the usual celebrity concerts.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 15. -- Although our studes of the records and observations so carefully and laboriously made by Max Cosyns and myself on our second flight into the stratosphere in August are not yet complete, we have already learned enough through our analyses to confess, with a clear conscience, that nothing has been proved so far: cosmic radiation still jealously guards its secret.

MANILA, Sept. 12. -- Political alignments in the Philippines have not been altered materialty by the recent discussion of independence in the joint session of the Legislature, sitting as the Independence Commission, nor has the issue been clarified by the institution of public hearings on the Hawes-Cutting bill.

Re-election of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner as a "staunch champion" of labor was urged yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor. The endorsement, which was made public by the Independent Citizens' Committee supporting Senator Wagner, followed a similar endorsement by the New York Federation of Labor.
The text of the address by William J. Donavan, Republican candidate for Governor, at Kismet Temple, Brooklyn, last night follows:

The growing practice of many organizations to resort to bankruptcy in order to avoid the obligations of leases was criticized here yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive director of the National Association of Credit Men. This practice, which has shown a steady increase in recent months, places an additional burden upon American industry, already overloaded by normal bankruptcy experiences, with liabilities in excess of a billion dollars a year, Mr. Heimann pointed out.

A plan for funding and extending the balance of $1,400,000 of an issue of $3,000,000 of Graham-Paige Motors Corporation 6 per cent sinking-fund debentures, Series A, has been presented by Joseph B. Graham, president, in a letter to the holders of the bonds.

ROBERT T. JONES JR., better known as Bobby, has marched once more into the motion-picture spotlight. The retired golf champion has signed a new contract with Warner Brothers, the company which produced his "How I Play Golf" series last year, and the terms of the agreement cover all his screen activities for the considerable period of five years.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 15. -- Clifford Buckman of the Ritz Towers Hotel, 465 Park Avenue, New York, is held criminally responsible in a finding issued by Coroner John J. Phelan today for the death of August Saunig, 64, of 215 West Tenth Street, New York, who was fatally injured in an automobile accident in Ridgefield.

The injection into the Presidential campaign of the question how close the United States came last Winter to being pushed off the gold standard has provoked renewed discussion in financial circles of the technical aspects of the gold standard in this country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 8 totaled 625,636 cars, the American Railway Association, announced today. This was 3,561 cars more than in the preceding week, and a new high mark for the year for the third consecutive week, but 188,182 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 329,146 can fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Quel Jeu and Glidelia, both outsiders, were the surprise winners of the Remsen and October Handicaps, features of the closing-day program of the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica yesterday, where the regular Long Island racing season came to a close.

A spectacular fire which was visible for miles swept the Hollywood Gardens, a night club in the Bronx across the Pelham Shore Road from the Pelham Bay golf links, late last night. Thousands of autoists watched firemen fight for two hours before the blaze was finally subdued, with damage estimated at $25,000.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- Wesleyan defeated Haverford, 6 to 0, in football today. The visitors showed unexpected strength and the Cardinal eleven, with Captain Schlums out of the game because of illness, was hard pressed to register a single touchdown.

Sales brought $47,800.50 at the eight and last session of the dispersal of the art property of the late Miss Giulia Morosini at American Art Association Anderson Galleries yesterday afternoon. Jewels belonging to the heiress, who was prominent socially at the close of the nineteenth century, were among the principal items sold.

The appearance of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, and former Governor Alfred E. Smith at least twice on the same platform was assured yesterday, when arrangements were made for speeches by Mr. Smith at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday evening, Nov. 4, and at Madison Square Garden on Saturday evening, Nov. 5.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I note among the letters from readers of THE TIMES one from the Rev. Henry A. Stimson, "Motion Pictures Do Harm in India."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Federal Land Banks were reported today by the Federal Farm Loan Board to be pursuing a liberal credit policy toward farmers and "carrying along" those with mortgaged farms who showed a desire to meet the obligations due.

An 8-year-old girl died last night and nine others were poisoned after a "mushroom" dinner in the home of Louis Patello, 3 Thatford Avenue, Brooklyn. The child, Concetta, the eldest of four children in the Patello family, died before she could receive medical aid.

MR. GRATTAN is as fortunate in his choice of subject as the second and third generations of jameses were in the American founder of their line. Theirs is a glorious instance of the value of leisure. Problems of religion.

FOR the first time in twenty years, the tariff is a dominant issue in a Presidential election. Prohibition, national defense, regulation of utilities, questions of taxation, cooperation for world peace -- all these are overshadowed at the moment by an issue which has not achieved such eminence since Woodrow Wilson made his campaign in 1912 on a platform calling for repudiation of protective tariffs as unjust, uneconomic and unconstitutional.
CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 15. -- Muhlenberg turned back Dickinson by 13-0 today before a crowd of 6,000.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Southern Methodist conquered Syracuse at Archbold Stadium today by 16 to 6 to a thrilling battle before 16,000.
KINGSTON, R.I., Oct. 15. -- Bates overcame Rhode Island State by 6-0 today. Dick Secor accounted for the only score of the game early in the first period.

NORTON, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Wheaton College held its ninety-eighth Founder's Day exercises today, presenting as the principal speaker, Dr. George Boas, Professor of Philosophy at Johns Hopkins University. His subject was "Philosophy and Poetry."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 15. -- Tennessee's resourceful Volunteers took advantage of a break in the last quarter today to dash Alabama's hopes of a conference championship by scoring a 7-3 victory.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Oct. 11. -- Two contrasting personalities are contesting for the office of Delegate in Congress from Alaska at the November election. First, there is James Wicker sham, Republican incumbent, affable politician of the old school, quick of wit on the platform, a one-time Federal judge in the Territory.

THE telephone is not the most perfect transmitter and receiver of speech in the world, as any one can testify who has noted the efforts of switchboard girls to distinguish "five" from "nine" by pronouncing "nine" as if it rhymed with "lion."

George S. Thomas of Hamilton, Mass., one of the best-known figures in the kennel world, will make the award of best in show at the annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club, to be held in Mechanics Building, Boston, on Feb. 21 and 22.

A HANDFUL, of book auction slipped into the arena quietly during the first weeks of October to inaugurate the new season, and having dutifully said their piece, passed into the limbo of the minor auction record. Following historic precedent these initial sales have not excited much attention from the average book buyer, who may be expected to find his stride, if at all, when the season is in full swing.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5. -- When most countries are shutting their doors tight to newcomers, an average of several hundred Japanese immigrants is entering Brazil every month. Liners of the Osaka Shoshen Kaisha steamship concern, which have regular monthly sailings between Kobe and Rio de Janeiro via the east coast of Africa, carry immigrants almost every trip, sometimes as many as 1,000 at a time.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic nominee for Mayor, who believes himself as good as elected to serve out former Mayor Walker's term, has served notice on Tammany Hall, it became known yesterday, that he expects to be a candidate for re-election next year.

LONDON. WITHIN the next few weeks the Parliaments of the British Empire will ratify the agreements reached at Ottawa, which will bring increases in customs duties and bind Great Britain for at least five years to a system of protective tariffs.

Cautious Assistant Secretary of Commerce KLEIN estimated that the new Canadian tariff would diminish American exports to the Dominion by $25,000,000 a year. Republican spellbinders, glorifying the Hawley-Smoot tariff, don't mention these insignificant details. Some of them rejoice in the import duties on copper and lumber, laid just about a month before the meeting of the Imperial Conference, as if Canada needed to be reminded of her intention to protect her own interests.

COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Oct. 15. -- Ursinus defeated Franklin and Marshall 16 to 6 today. Five thousand spectators viewed the game. Tropp twice crossed the goal line with forward passes from Eachus. The winners added to their total with a safety.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Alice Rollins, 46 years old, of 806 116th Street, College Point, was killed this afternoon in an accident on the extension of the Bronx Parkway over Annsville Creak, when Harry Smith, 60 of 103-30 Ninety-sixth Street, Ozone Park, L.I., with whom she was riding, lost control of his car and crashed into an abutment, according to the State Police.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15 (AP). -- Firstday registration up-State showed a decline in many cities from the opening day figures for 1928, the last Presidential year.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: In THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW, July 17, 1932, page 3, the commentator remarks that Magna Carta is "in form only a guarantee of the liberties of the nobility." This is an error, for at least a third of the Great Charter's provisions relate to promises and guarantees on behalf of the people.

ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 15. -- A stubborn defense by Andover failed to halt a fast Blue back field running behind a strong line, and the Yale Freshmen eleven prevailed by 25 -- 0 today. The visitors scored in every period.

The duck hunting season will be inaugurated in twenty States in this country today. A few States already have begun the season, while others will defer it until Nov. 1 or after. In New York the season beginning today does not include Long Island. Ducks cannot be taken on Long Island until Nov. 1.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Opera has moved Westward from the Civic Opera House and the auditorium to that home of rodeos, fights and political conventions, the Stadium. It has also moved downward from $6 to $2 seats. It has also moved forward in popularity.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 15. -- A crowd of 30,000 persons, gathered in four auditoriums of the great Public Hall here, cheered President Hoover tonight as, with a new brand of fight, he fired one broadside after another at his Democratic opponents.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Not in his four years of office has State's Attorney John A. Swanson registered dynamically at as high pressure as that marking his pursuit of Samuel M. and Martin J. Insull -- the one across Europe from Paris to Athens, the other over the Canadian border and into the remoter regions of Ontario.

The advance in crude oil prices last week in Texas and the midcontinent areas by several oil companies has not as yet been met by two of the largest buyers of crude oil there, the Standard Oil Companies of New Jersey and Indiana. The Indiana company issued a statement in which it said that conditions did not warrant even present prices and that it would not advance its posted prices for crude oil.

DEEMS TAYLOR is writing music for "The Rape of Lucrece," Thornton Wilder's translation of Andre Obey's "Le Viol de Lucrece," which Katharine Cornell will present in New York in December. Mr. Taylor, in addition to his operas, has composed considerable music for the theatre.

Addressing the American Bar Association in Washington. TODAY, perhaps as never before, our very form of government is on trial in the eyes of millions of our citizens. Economic stresses of unparalleled magnitude have racked our people, and in their distress some are tempted to lay the blame for their troubles upon the system of government under which they live.

IT is seldom that an American Indian has been able to interpret his people and their life to the white man, for by the time he has learned the white man's language and ways of thinking he has usually ceased to be in the real sense an Indian.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 13. -- Industrial employment in September was about 2 per cent higher in this district than in August, as against a usual slight seasonal falling off.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 15. -- Kendal Boy, owned by Fairfield Osborne Jr., and with Stanley Flagg 4th riding, was killed today at the same jump where Mrs. Gerry Redmond's Fairbanks II was killed Wednesday, the opening day of the Rose Tree Hunt Club's Fall meeting.

GENEVA, Oct. 13. -- The question as to what the nature of the relations between the League of Nations and two non-League members, the United States and Soviet Russia, should and will he when the Manchurian conflict comes up in November is causing some anxious study in League circles.
AN interesting departure in book illustration enlivens the symposium "America as Americans See It," edited by Fred J. Ringel and issued by Harcourt, Brace.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- A chain of twelve Federal Home Loan Banks, strung across the country, opened today to begin receiving applications for loans on small home mortgages.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ephraim Cheever, my elusive fellow townsman about whom neither the sagest local gossips nor the usually omniscient village postmaster has an iota of information, and whom I suspect on that account of being a lurker behind a pseudonym, has lately been writing in your Sunday columns certain of the prosier incidents in this country's early history.

WASHINGTON. THE efforts of the United States to bring Samuel Insull and his brother, Martin J. Insull, former heads of a great public utility chain, back to the United States for trial on charges of larceny and embezzlement have focused attention on extradition, the legal process through which one government surrenders a man wanted on criminal charges to another.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 15 -- In the alumni homecoming day football game on Memorial Field today Gettysburg triumphed over Swarthmore by the score of 14 to 0. The home eleven rallied in the second half to turn back the visitors, who had held them scoreless for two periods.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Colonel Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War, at the Republican national headquarters here today, issued a reply to Speaker Garner's speech of last night on the budget. He charged that if the program of the Democrats in the House had been enacted the cost of the Federal Government would have been doubled.

One reason, among several, why STALIN succeeds in beating down Opposition movements is that he has not been compelled to face a single, coherent, united Opposition. He has to deal with temporary alliances concluded between Left and Right for a special emergency and subject to all their inherent weakness.

Price trends were irregular last weeks in local commodity markets, with net changes for the most part fairly slight. Early in the week the general trend was to lower ground, but a rally late in the week lifted all groups and in some instances wiped out the losses.
LONDON. IF a farmer from Iowa or Minnesota "were to exchange confidences with farmers from Rumania, Poland, Germany and France, he would discover that their troubles were very similar to his own.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The Princeton soccer team defeated Cornell, 4 to 3, in an overtime league game on Poe Field today.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: You recently published a letter from one Hal Ellson, obviously a quavering boarding house adventurer. Ellson takes issue, forsooth, with the statement that Joseph T. Shaw has invented and perfected a sword thrust against which there is no defense.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The present moment in Great Britain presents a sharp contrast between a clear-cut economic policy and a foreign policy so vaguely revealed as to be bewildering. Events this week and next will serve to emphasize this difference.

The question of continuance of the freight surcharges now in effect, which are scheduled to expire on March 4, will be discussed at the annual meeting of the Association of Railway Executives on or about Nov. 11 in the Biltmore Hotel here. The association's advisory committee failed to agree on the matter at its meeting in Chicago on Friday.

Indications that the tide of investment in investment trusts has begun definitely to swing again from those of the fixed to those of the general management type have been noticed in the financial community recently. The most conclusive sign there is the fact that several new trusts, featuring varying degrees of management, are being launched by dealers, at least one of whom has been prominent in the distribution of shares of fixed trusts.

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- There are many people in France who are beginning to think it is not only a truce in armaments that is needed if Europe is to recover any sense of security, but also a truce to talk about armaments, disarmament and security. Out of the efforts of the past six months, it is argued, all that so far has emerged is increased tension, irritation and nervous nationalism everywhere.

The New York Historical Society has assembled its large and valuable collection of paintings, prints, photographs, posters, models and literature of early ships and steamboats, which will shortly be placed on public view for the first time in a large private dwelling at 4 West Seventy-seventh Street, near the society's building at 170 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Germany's total foreign indebtedness on Feb. 29, 1932, was 26,600,000,000 reichsmarks [about $6,330,800,000], according to a revised estimate by the German statistical bureau forwarded to the Commerce Department by the Commercial Attache at Berlin.

THE name of the author, "Pitigrilli" ("Little Crickets") -- the humorist, the satirist, and to some people the fashioner of slightly off-shade tales of love and passion -- is so well known in Italy as to be almost a byword for "naughtiness."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Increases of 3.6 per cent in employment and 2.6 per cent in payroll totals over August were reported by the Labor Department today in an analysis of industrial employment during September.

A FANCIFUL Egyptian setting has been devised for one of the first large dances of the Autumn season -- the Fall Military Ball to be given by members of the famous old Seventh Regiment on Saturday night in the regimental armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

With the Hoover campaign in the East about to enter upon its final and intensive stage, it was said yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria headquarters of the Republican National Committee, that a report from Chicago fixing the speaking date for the President in this city for Nov. 1, was premature.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 15. -- The annual Greenbrier Autumn lawn tennis tournament closed today, Miss Joan Ridley of England repeated her victory of last week at Hot Springs when she defeated Miss Virginia Rice of Boston, 6-4, 6-4, in the women's singles.

THE front of the jacket of Mr. Tunney's story of his career as a prizefighter shows the author in profile in a thoughtful, rather dreamy pose, with his hands clasped in front of him and eyes gazing into the misty distance. The back of the jacket shows him pounding the daylight out of Mr. Dempsey.

PARIS, Oct. 15. -- The Chamber of Commerce of Paris and the Textile Syndicate Union today joined a long list of important trade organizations issuing appeals to the government to take strong measures to balance the budget. Both of these associations urged salary cuts as a necessary part of any program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Cablegrams to President Hoover from the Emperor of Japan and the newspaper Hochi Shimbun expressing appreciation of efforts made by this country to find the Japanese plane lost recently on an attempted transpacific good-will flight were made public at the State Department today.

BELGRADE, Oct. 14. -- Croat discontent with the present pseudo parliamentary regime, fusing with the bandit tradition of the Dalmatian coast, has produced something like a state of guerrilla warfare against the government in Southern Croatia.

An altar in the lower Church of St. Francis Xavier, Sixteenth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, erected in honor of the new Jesuit saints, the North American Martyrs, was consecrated yesterday morning by Bishop John J. Dunn. The ritual began at 7:30 and continued an hour and a half.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Repeating his victory at Hartford, Champion Heather Reveller of Sporran, the great Scottish terrier owned by S.S. Van Dine of New York City, captured the highest honors at the all-breed show of the Somerset Kennel Club today.

CHAMPAIGN,, Ill., Oct. 15 (AP). -- Gathering speed after being held scoreless in the first period, Northwestern scored four touchdowns to defeat Illinois, 26 to 0, in their Western Conference football game today.

CHICAGO. IN the tumult that attended the breakdown of Samuel Insull's vast financial kingdom it was easy to overlook that other cataclysm which occurred at the same time -- the downfall of his family's social dominion.

An announcement that Frank L. Polk, former Under-Secretary of State and member of the law firm of Davis, Polk, Wardwell, Gardiner Read, had accepted the chairmanship of the finance committee of the Independent Citizens' Committee for the Election of Herbert H. Lehman and M. William Bray, Democratic candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor, was made yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, treasurer of the committee.

In time of depression, said former Secretary NEWTON D. BAKER a Jew days ago, the question whether any substantial part of the money spent in higher education is "socially wasted" is likely to get frank consideration. The values have to be weighed against an increased and increasing economic sacrifice.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Considerable business was done at today's short session of the Stock Exchange and most sections were firm, being helped by better American news. The strong investment demand for British funds continued. Good features include the industrials, chemicals, Unilever, Dunlop Rubber and Swedish Match B, all of which were higher.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 15. -- The Hill School football team defeated Tome by a score of 12 to 6. Tome started with a brilliant at-ss-i, but was unable to maintain it. Bissell played excellently on the line for Hill, while Durrell successfully directed the back field for the home team.

THE recent controversy in the Board of Estimate and Apportionment regarding the building of incinerators directs attention to the serious situation faced by the city in disposing of its refuse. Part of its garbage and rubbish is now dumped at sea, and the determined efforts of those interested in keeping the beaches clean resulted in a United States Supreme Court order forbidding New York to dispose of its waste in that manner after next July.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A well-drilled and wide-awake Rutgers team outplayed a veteran Delaware eleven today and scored an unexpectedly easy victory, 32 to 0.

SELINSGROVE, Pa., Oct. 15. -- Susquehanna's power plays ripped gaps in the Hartwick forward wall today and the Orange and Maroon triumphed easily, 45-0. Susquehanna's second-string eleven started the contest and tallied the first touchdown in the first three minutes of play.

Springfield, Mass. SPRINGFIELD has been conducting an experiment designed to bring relief to persons who are in mental distress, especially to those men who until the depression were successful in business and whose families were accustomed to having all the comforts of life.

PARIS, Sept. 29. THE theatrical season is taking some time to get going. Three new plays, whose production had been announced for this week, have been postponed, and several important theatres still remain closed.

ERNEST Schelling will play the piano part of his "Impressions From an Artist's Life" to be performed at the Thursday evening and Friday afternoon concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini. The work was written in 1914-15 and performed in 1929 by the orchestra under Toscanini, with the composer as soloist.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The Pittsburgh Panther fought for his life on the green turf of Michie Stadium today and found the strength and courage to turn back as gallant a bid as any team has ever made in football.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES has recently published an interview granted by President Ayala of Paraguay to the American writer Dr. Samuel Guy Inman on the Chaco controversy. Its perusal leads to the belief that President Ayala, as well as his country, is a decided advocate of settling the pending territorial dispute with Bolivia by arbitration.

Probation, workers of the Court of General Sessions met yesterday in the Criminal Court Building, in Centre Street, for the first session of the Institutes in Probation, organized to keep them in touch with the developments in sociological studies affecting their work.

A NEW Yugoslav opera, Kostana," by Peter Konjovic, was produced some weeks ago in Brno. According to The Central European Observer of Sept. 30, "it was a noteworthy production, for the work is interesting both for its subject matter and its original music."

TODAY. 1:00 P.M. -- WEAF -- Julia Glass, pianist, has selected the first movement from the Concerto in B flat minor as her solo contribution to this all-Tchaikovsky concert directed by Erno Rapee. The orchestral offerings are the "Fifth Symphony'' and the "1812 Overture."

The drive among veterans' organizations to obtain support for Colonel Herbert H. Lehman for Governor will be formally started at a luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker on Tuesday by the veterans' division of the Independent Citizens Committee for the Election of Lehman and Bray.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Calvin Coolidge journeyed from his Northampton retreat to New York on Tuesday night to plead for the re-election to the Presidency of his immediate successor in that office.
Bobby Power, a freshman, scored three touchdowns as the Wagner College football team opened its season yesterday by defeating the Cooper Union eleven, 32 to 0, at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S.I.

A SMALL town in Maryland forms the background for this strange story of love, hate, greed, jealousy and murder. The narrator is Dr. Ruth Fisher, who knows the people of the town as few others know them. It is to her that Lieutenant Joseph Kelly comes for information when he is summoned from Baltimore to Investigate the murder of Miss Nettie Wyndham.

There is taking place in Europe the most important political development since the World War -- the effort of Germany to destroy the Treaty of Versailles imposed upon her at the end of the great conflict she lost.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 15. -- Kentucky scored early and often today to defeat Washington and Lee, 53 to 7. The Wildcats thus remained at the top of the Southern Conference, with four straight victories and no defeats.

Two swimming records of the Public Schools Athletic League were shattered at the weekly series of dual meets for the league championship yesterday. In the Brooklyn encounters, conducted in the seventy five-foot James Madison pool, Ralph Urban of Manual Training covered 50 yard breast-stroke in 0:30 3-5 and broke the listed senior standard of 0:31 8-5, set by Kenneth Degnan of Commerce in November, 1930.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 15. -- Gilbert (Bud) Humphrey, a slender substitute quarterback, stopped the four-year dominance of Kent School today when he sprinted for the lone touchdown of the game in the third period to give Hotchkiss Prep a 6-0 triumph over its fourteen-year rival.

Twenty-eight governmental and civic leaders of five States will discuss the relation of taxation and economy to city planning at six sessions of a national conference on regional planning at New York University on Tuesday and Wednesday, Professor Alison Reppy, executive director of the conference, announced yesterday.

The same cycle of change which transplanted the centre of fashion from Italy to France beginning in the early part of the sixteenth century is now forcing a change from France to the United States, Miss Ethel Traphagen, head of the Traphagen School of Fashion, said here yesterday.

VARIOUS thrift shops throughout the city that are maintained for the benefit of the charitable enterprises of philanthropic organizations are making a special appeal at this time for useful articles of all sorts suitable for resale in the shops. No type of article is rejected.

MORE than fifty years have passed since William Dean Howells, then editor of The Atlantic Monthly, picked a manuscript by Henry Demarest Lloyd out of the mail and decided to print it. The article, called "The Story of a Great Monopoly," is historically important.

ROME. THE tragic death of Lieutenant Arlosto Neri, Italy's "speed wizard," has led to a delay in the preparations which are being made at Desenzano on Lake Garda to wrest from England the world's seaplane speed record, but the intention of regaining this much-sought-after honor has by no means been abandoned.

Being excerpts from, the foreword to his book, "The Stage Is Set," which are reprinted by permission of the publishers, Harcourt, Brace Co. NOTHING Is foreordained except in retrospect. Any event, once it has occurred, can be made to appear inevitable by a competent historian. This volume is to be read neither as a history nor as a prophecy of the theatre's destiny.

THE Supreme Court of the United States affirmed last weak the decision of a lower court upholding the right of the State of Tennessee to subject an airline to the State privilege tax on the sale and storage of gasoline, although the airline maintained that the fuel was to be used in interstate commerce.
NEW YORK. Lord Inverforth is arriving on the Bremen and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MANILA, Sept. 14. -- The visit of Representative Butler B. Hare to the Philippines has put the country in something of a quandary. He is the author of an independence bill and the first United States legislator to get such a measure through one of the houses of the United States Congress.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 13. -- The plight of the Republican cause in Ohio which is bringing President Hoover to Cleveland this week-end for one of his campaign expressions involves a large disaffection in the northern and more industrial half of the State which is not slow in seeping into the southern half.

IT IS the habit of the moment to indulge in comparisons and contrasts, a phrase that forms the title of an exhibition recently opened, and that forms the basis of many writings, trivial or serious, in the criticism of the present. Nothing is more interesting than this sport of the mind, and nothing is more dangerous to fair judgment.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. KANSAS CITY, Oct. 14. -- Four Kansas municipalities levy no taxes for operation of the City Government because of profits from municipally owned light and water plants. Two other towns are supported in part by the profits from their utilities.
