Department stores are gradually getting back to a more profitable operating basis, with the indications being that next year will bring the benefits of the first appreciable decline of expense in relation to sales which has occurred in this field in about a decade, according to B. Earl Puckett, president of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc.

The $250,000 libel suit brought by Rosalinda Morini, singer, against Otto H. Kahn, banker and former chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Company, was settled yesterday. The announcement of the settlement was made by Jay Leo Rothschild, counsel for Miss Morini, when asked whether the testimony of Mr. Kahn would be taken tomorrow at his home, 1,100 Fifth Avenue, as had been planned.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review. In THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW of May 15, 1932, appeared an article entitled "The Most Disgraceful Chapter in American History." This article was a review by Charles Willis Thompson of a history of the Reconstruction period, so called, in South Carolina after the Civil War by Francis Butler Simkins, Ph. D., and Robert Hilliard Woody, Ph. D., both of Chapel Hill.
MUSEUM OF MODERN ART -- Seventeenth century Persian frescoes as "reconstructed" by Sarkis Katchadourian. Opened Oct. 10. Closes Nov. 19. Reviewed Tuesday, with further comment on this page.

City Court Justice Aron Steuer has resigned from the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. By doing so he placed himself beyond the jurisdiction of the grievance committee which was preparing to investigate the so-called "deal" by which he and State Senator Samuel Hofstadter received bipartisan nominations for the Supreme Court bench.
Park Avenue and "Hoover Valley," the squatter settlement in Central Park, met last evening and, instead of shaking hands, shook fists.

The heaviest mail orders of the season were received here during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. The business reflected the first real volume obtained by retail departments featuring cold-weather items, such as coats, leather jackets, blankets, c.

If the relief needs of the nation keep on doubling as they have averaged each year since the depression started, there will be nearly sixteen times as many petitions for food and shelter in 1933 as there were in 1929, Newton D. Baker, chairman of the Welfare and Relief Mobilization of 1932, declared in a statement last night on the eve of the organization's six-weeks campaign.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL, en ruote to Cleveland, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Speaking briefly at stop after stop along his dawn-to-dusk itinerary and shaking hands, despite a bandaged hand, with some of those who came to welcome him, the President put in one of the most strenuous days of his campaign.

IN this testimonial to the labors of 145 years the strife of parties, the antagonisms of personalities, the bitterness of particular controversies are forgotten. This monument bespeaks the common cause, the unifying principle of our nation.

BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- On July 21 Mayor Curley asked the Police Commissioner to undertake an investigation of the work of the overseers of public welfare to ascertain whether public money was being wasted in their relief service. On Oct. 7 the Mayor abruptly terminated the investigation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- Headed by an intrepid leader, Harry Newman, a great Maize and Blue football team from Michigan today beat a gallant Ohio State eleven before a crowd of some 42,000 persons.

IN response to a query from this vigilant department, Leslie Howard wires from the Pacific Coast -- specifically from Beverly Hills -- that he is still planning to act in London if and when a good play turns up. In desperation, he remarks, he is now engaged in writing one.

Asserting that for more than a year cotton has played almost a major part in the general tendency of commodity prices, John A. Todd, well-known English economist asserted yesterday that the only factor that can justify a rise in prices is an increase in consumption.

APARTMENT-HOUSE terraces and roofs offer to landscape architects, decorators and designers constantly new fields for their talents. Some of them are now being converted into all-year-round play places for children, their high parapets, penthouse walls and even chimneys serving as parts of a studied whole.

It was a Spartan mother, not an Athenian, who told her son to come back with his shield or on it. For the moment the sentiment does not appear to appeal to Mr. SAMUEL INSULT, sojourning within sight of the Acropolis and Mars Hill. He is enjoying his stay in Greece, after a fashion, and has no intention of coming back home and facing his accusers -- at least until after the calends.

An order requiring the United Cigar Stores Company of America and the Irving Trust Company as trustee in bankruptcy to show cause why the United Cigar Stores bankruptcy proceedings should not be vacated has been signed by Federal Judge John M. Woolsey on application of the Court and Montague Street Realty Corporation of Brooklyn.
PARIS, Oct. 15. -- France's position following the German refusal to attend a four-power arms conference at Geneva was described authoritatively at the Foreign Office today in the following terms:

The thousands drawn to the Roosevelt and Hoover meetings have demonstrated that the radio and the talking picture have not suppressed the popular desire to see candidates -- and other public figures -- in person. The same desire is evident in the case of stage and screen stars.

Profit-taking sales and Southern selling on the Cotton Exchange here were reflected yesterday by declines from a slight opening advance in prices in a comparatively quiet market, December contracts advanced to 6.53 cents a pound at the start, but sold off to 6.40, where they closed.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 15. -- The Harvard freshman eleven subdued Exeter today by a score of 13 -- 0, the two touchdowns coming in the fourth period after the losers had twice held the collegians within the shadow of their goal posts. Francis Lane, last year's Exeter halfback, first crossed the school boys' line when he intercepted a forward pass thrown by Rexford Kidd and ran 40 yards.

Mary E. Bird, a member of the Ladies Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital, who died on Oct. 6, left her residuary estate and $7,500 to that institution, and bequests to three other Catholic institutions, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

Predicting a "tremendous Roosevelt landslide," Representative Sol Bloom told a meeting of the State Democraic Forum at the Hotel Astor yesterday that Governor Roosevelt was certain of carrying Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Illinois, with New Jersey the only State in doubt.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15. -- In the presence of a brilliant audience of 4,000 persons, the new $6,000,000 war memorial opera house, the first municipally owned opera house in the United States, was opened tonight with, a performance of Puccini's "Tosca," by the San Francisco Opera Company.
To the children of America (and to grown-ups who are still as children) WALTER DAMROSCH comes again as Ariel with the salutation,

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Ralph H. Allen, executive vice president of the Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., of West Orange, died early today in Orange Memorial Hospital, Orange, from injuries received in an automobile accident a short time before his death.

CELEBRATION of Armistice Day in New York has become in recent years an occasion for various subscription entertainments that enlist younger members of society, high military and naval officers and men and women in diplomatic life. Work is now going forward on three notable events -- the Victory Ball, the Armistice Ball of the First Division Lieutenant Jeff Feigl Post and the Armistice Ball of the British Great War Veterans of America.

The finding of an alternative to private ownership and management of the drink trade was forced upon the British Government in the Great War in connection with the manufacture of munitions, and in any consideration of the liquor problem the experience of the Carlisle State management district is interesting.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- The bulge yesterday in the prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here that carried the December up to 50 cents a bushel, the highest point of the week, proved today to be of the soda-water variety. A selling movement started about an hour before the close of trading and uncovered stop-loss orders and plunged the December down to 47 3/4 cents, a new low for the season.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13. -- Southern California has not exactly turned its back on politics, but it does give signs of being overstaffed, and is taking time out to consider other matters. Even an impending community chest drive to raise $3,500,000 for charitable purposes during the ensuing year is being accepted in a spirit of "well, if we've gotta, we've gotta."

PARIS. THE French were right to put "la mode" in the feminine gender, in their eminently logical language, for she certainly is all woman; even when, as this season, she prides herself upon having turned practical and economical with a vengeance, she is subject to a few delightful inconsistencies that are not the least among the secrets of her charm.

Bringing with it from Scranton a thirty-piece band, an enthusiastic group of supporters and an aggressive, determined football team, St. Thomas College yesterday administered to Manhattan its first gridiron reversal of the season by a 7-0 score. Fifteen thousand persons witnessed the contest at Ebbets Field.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Johns Hopkins University remained the only unbeaten Maryland team today when it scored a 12-to-6 triumph over Lehigh University at Homewood Field before 3,500 persons.

IT begins to look as if 1932, now eating into its last quarter, will pass away without giving television to the home. The research experts who have been hibernating in their laboratories through the economic depression are working behind a curtain of secrecy seldom witnessed in radio science.

GENEVA, Oct. 15. -- The League Council, in a secret session tonight, unanimously voted to nominate Joseph Avenol, a Frenchman, to succeed Sir Eric Drummond as Secretary General of the League. For constitutional reasons the Council's decision will not be made formal until after the Assembly has formally adopted on Monday the reorganization of upper posts in the Secretariat upon which the fourth commission decisively agreed today.
PEIPING, Sept. 19. -- On as extensive a scale as economic and administrative difficulties permit compulsory military training is being conducted in the schools, colleges and universities of China.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- A benefit exhibition golf match will be held tomorrow afternoon at the Siwanoy Country Club here. The proceeds will be used for the philanthropic work of the Bronxville League for Service and the Leonard S. Morange Post of the American Legion.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP). -- The jury in the Maillefert sweatbox death late today found George W. Courson guilty of manslaughter and acquitted Solomon Higginbotham.

Necessity for giving State public service commissions some authority over utility holding companies was stressed last week at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association in Washington by two lawyers who, in ordinary circumstances, would be found on opposite sides of the table in a case affecting utility rates.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15. -- With a victory over J. Brunner of this city in the seventh round, Isaac Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, today gained the lead in the international chess masters tournament at the Press Social Centre for the first time since the opening of the tournament.

Prices of bonds continued yesterday to rise on the Stock Exchange, although trading was light. In the domestic corporation list utility and railroad issues showed the best recoveries. Foreign loans closed slightly higher, on the average, and most of the United States Government bond issues improved.
Columbia encountered unexpected opposition yesterday at Baker Field from the University of Virginia football team and had to put forth its best efforts to win, 22-6, before 12,000 spectators.

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- Already proclaimed the best-dressed Chancellor since Prince von Billow, Franz von Papen, President von Hindenburg's national concentration Premier, is also winning unexpected forensic honors.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Despite a desperate last period rally that brought one touchdown and threatened another, Detroit University went down to defeat before Holy Cross today, 9 to 7.
NEW YORKERS who like to watch intercollegiate football games are especially fortunate this year in being within easy motoring distance of some of the season's most spectacular contests.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor and his Democratic opponent, Surrogate John P. O'Brien, were ordered yesterday to appear before Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn tomorrow to show cause why their names should not be stricken from the ballot.

DOGS, with Scotch terriers in the lead, figure prominently in this season's picture books. "Michael Who Missed His Train" by Dorothy and Marguerite Bryan, and Diana Thorne's ooRoughy, the Dog Who Ran Away" have already been mentioned in, this department.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 15. -- The diplomatic phase of the controversy with Peru over the seizure of the Colombian town of Leticia on Sept. 1 was closed by Colombia's note this week to Peru and the refusal to the Conciliation Commission in Washington to recognize the right of another country or any international organization to interfere in the internal affairs of Colombia, according to an editorial in El Tiemoo.

HARTFORD, Oct. 13. -- The question how the State of Connecticut will lighten the burdens placed upon the municipalities by the care of the unemployed is now rather definitely left for the regular session of the General Assembly next January to answer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- For the week ended Oct. 8 bank debits outside New York were the highest since the second week in July, according to the review of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP). -- The National Progressive League, an organization supporting Governor Roosevelt, issued a statement tonight asserting that Republicans were hiring unemployed men to broadcast "canned" statements, saying they were for the President.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14. -- "The real significance of the Lytton report is its anti-Japanese propaganda -- it mobilizes against Japan the public opinion of Europe, America, China and Manchuria and strengthens the anti-Japanese attitude of the United States," comments the shrewdest Soviet publicist, Karl Radek, in Izvestia.

JOHN BULL AND UNCLE SAM. A TRANSPOSITION of photographs last week transformed this column of fact to one of fancy and now raises a neat question of anthropology instead of typography. A few paragraphs were devoted to the sponsor of the League of Nations report upon Manchuria; accompanying them was a picture of a white-haired, bespectacled, rather round-faced, grizzled personage whose appearance did not fit the role of Lord Lytton.

Textile High School's football team ended Theodore Roosevelt High's undefeated and unscored upon record for twelve games since midway in the 1930 season by registering a 7-to-6 triumph over the Bronx eleven before 3,000 at the George Washington High School Stadium yesterday.

VENICE, Sept. 29, 1932. IT was a happy idea to incorporate the second International Music Festival of Venice with the now world-celebrated biennial Art Exposition here. The former Minister of Finance, Count Volpl di Misurata, president of the Art Exposition, a few days ago convoked the composers and music critics present at the festival to set forth the biennial program through its secretary, Antonio Maraini.

ALTHOUGH he did not penetrate into the stratosphere, Captain C.F. Unwin, in setting the new world's attitude record for Great Britain at 43,976 feet, or nearly eight and a half miles, made a number of observations which should have a direct bearing on flight in the upper air.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The 10,000-ton cruiser Indianapolis, which was launched at the New York Ship-building Company's plant here on Nov. 7, 1931, will leave her berth early tomorrow morning for Rockland, Me., to participate in tests over the official speed course.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- An alleged letter of censure declared to have been addressed by the former Crown Prince to General Wilhelm Groener, then Minister of Defense and the Interior, after the suppression of the National Socialist storm troops last Spring, was published today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: J.H. Muller is a very interesting advocate of the barge canal, and his letter in criticism of my communication published in THE TIMES is entitled to a reply. I would like, therefore, to discuss briefly the most important points that he raises.

REFERENCE was made two weeks ago in these columns to the earlier decision of the direction of the Philadelphia Orchestra -- as then made known in public prints -- to put nothing but "acknowledged masterpieces" on the orchestra's programs of the Winter.

Calls issued last week for bonds to be redeemed before they mature were principally for parts if State, municipal and foreign issues, some for payment in October, but the greater number for future months. The total of bonds called for payment in October prior to maturity is now $9,827,000, compared with $25,361,300 in September and $99,809,000 in October, 1931, at corresponding dates.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 17. -- The spectacular "war on the roof of the world" which has been waged between China and Tibet since the middle of March seems certain to be continued into 1933. The advent of the second week of September brought the first blizzard to the lofty mountainous regions in Central Asia, and it is anticipated that deep snows and below-zero temperatures will check major military movements until Spring.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a constant reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES I cannot but admire your impartial policy in regard to foreign politics. Of late, though, I have observed that this is not quite true any more.

ONE does not see why anything in this book is "not to be repeated," and its cloak of anonymity appears rather unnecessary, except perhaps in those few pages touching in passing on the morals and private lives of some minor characters.

NEARLY a century of changing political drama has passed since the tactless remark of a Democratic politician furnished the watchword for the "Hard-Cider Campaign" which swept General Harrison into the White House in 1840.

Any existing doubt concerning the potentialities of New York University's football team was dispelled yesterday at the Yankee Stadium, when Howard Cann's eleven smashed through to an impressive 39-to-0 victory over Georgetown.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Africa, Oct. 15 (AP). -- On the slopes of extinct Menagai volcano searchers guided by the advice of a native witch doctor today found the body of Miss Winifred Stevenson, a 20-year-old Glasgow girl, for whom they had been hunting for a week.

ONE story at a time in this collection is enough to keep one fully occupied for an evening. The merit of the work and the sadness and disillusionment running throughout the volume would prove to be too strong a thing to be taken in larger doses.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Demonstrating a wealth of power in the line together with back field speed, Harvard scored its third successive victory of the season by defeating Penn State today. A crowd of 15,000 persons saw the Crimson eleven survive after its goal line was threatened early in the first period to turn back the Nlttany Lions, 46 to 13.

IN the strong room of Rumania's royal castle near Sinaia -- Castle Pelesh -- there is a black agate stone, which, according to tradition, was cut by master hands when Trajan was Emperor of Rome. Through devious ways the agate came into the possession of Vlad the Impaler, Voivoid of Walachia, son of Vlad nicknamed the Devil; it was captured by the Turks and finally acquired by the Rumanian ruling hause.

Registration in the city for the November election set a new record. The total for the five boroughs, available at 3:30 this morning, was 2,334,131, more than 200,000 higher than the 1928 record of 2,029,000.

LILIAN HARVEY, the English girl who became a German film star and has now been corralled by Hollywood, will appear in "His Majesty's Car" as her first picture for the Fox Film Corporation. For her leading man, little Miss Harvey will have John Boles, and the comic of the production will be El Brendel.

WE in England have had to face unanticipated crises apart altogether from international political complications. In addition to other problems, England was confronted with a serious situation in India. I am anxious that you should understand our position in India, for we care so much for your opinion.

TWO new volumes, Thoreau's "A Week on the Concord and Merrimac Rivers" and William Cobbett's "Rural Rides," have just been added to this excellent little library devoted to memorable books dealing with nature and country life.

Unless members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, agree to accept a wage scale of $12 a day instead of the present rate of $13.20, they will be locked out tomorrow by the members of the Electrical Contractors Association of New York, it was revealed yesterday when employes were notified of the new wage scale.

IN his admirable "History of Medicine in the United States," Dr. Francis R. Packard declares that the discovery of general anesthesia is the only epoch-making discovery produced solely by American medical science. Since this work is intended to be strictly historical, little reference is made to medical achievements of the present century.

AT Philosophy Hall, Columbia University, paintings by New York members of the Southern States Art League are now on view. The exhibition was organized by H.E. Ogden Campbell and Gladys Brannigan. Recent pictures which have not previously been shown in New York are included.

Paintings, furniture and objects of art from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont at 1,618 New Hampshire Avenue, Washington, D.C., with selections from Belcourt, their Newport place, were placed on exhibition yesterday at American Art Associaion-Anderson

OVER a hundred years have passed away since Faraday, at the Royal Institution in London, began to play with electricity. He had absolutely no idea that his investigations would have any practical consequences or any theoretical consequences beyond the satisfaction of his curiosity, and yet everything that we do today with electricity is more or less closely dependent upon the unfettered investigations which Faraday was fortunately in a position to make.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 15. -- Tulane, supreme in the Southern Conference for almost two years, came its closest to defeat in Dixie since October, 1928, when the Vanderbilt Commodores held the Green wave to a 6-to-6 tie before 25,000 persons today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 15. -- Several hundred visitors, among them many well-known New Yorkers, saw today the final matches in the Greenbrier Autumn lawn tennis tournament and the presentation of trophies to the winners by Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., who defeated Mrs. Glenna Collette Vare in the women's Autumn golf tournament at Hot Springs earlier in the week and flew here with Mrs. Courtlandt Johnson of Cedarhurst, L.I.

HERE is a literary record by one of London's foremost men of letters, a book that is genial, generous and gossipy. Strictly speaking, Mr. Lucas has written an autobiography. But with reservations. Autobiography! Why, the man doesn't even tell when he was born.

THE word dynamic is being used in describing what the forthcoming Automobile Show will aim to be. That is the epithet applied by William Ullman, who is assuredly qualified to state his views upon the matter, as the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce justly proclaims in sending along his advance report.

Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, addressing a Republican rally in Kismet Temple, Brooklyn, last night, launched a slashing: attack on Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, accusing the Presidential candidate of insincerity in his solicitude for "the forgotten man" and holding him together wth Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, responsible for the ruin of thousands through bank failures in this city.

WHEN Clyde E. Elliott returned from the Malaysian wilderness where he filmed "Bring 'Em Back Alive" for Frank Buck, he found that the jungle had made an interesting impression on him. That old devil jungle seemed to have the makings of a first-class villain, with its green malarial swamps, leeches, giant spiders and snakes.

WITH the modesty becoming a free-born British citizen, a Welshman came to town last Monday night and quietly, but unmistakably, carried away a goodly share of the week's acting honors. He is, in case you did not read the reviews in Tuesday's newspapers, Emlyn Williams and he is acting for Guthrie McClintic in the late Edgar Wallace's play of the Lebanons, "Criminal at Large," at the Belasco Theatre.

IT has been known for some time that there are in existence numerous letters and notebooks of Henrik Ibsen which his family was withholding from publication. The letters are directed to his wife, are of an intimate nature, and will probably serve to throw much desired light on the relationship of this strange couple.

R.H. Helsel, a scratch gunner, and W.F. Ketcham, who shoots with a handicap of one, tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club yesterday, each finishing with 49.

STIMULATED by lower temperatures and the opportunity for family shopping provided by the Columbus Day holiday, retail trade made excellent progress during the week. Gains over a year ago were made by a number of stores here, while reports from out of town were also of encouraging tenor.

MANY prominent women of Great Neck, L.I., have arranged a series of "thrift teas" for the coming Winter, the first of which will be given next Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. John Eden, 225 Kings Point Road, Great Neck. In conjunction with the teas there will be a sale of various useful articles.

FROM the pen of Mr. Nevins we now have the full life story of a great character. Some of the gifts and attributes and evidences of greatness in a public man were denied Grover Cleveland. He was no popular orator.

MANY prominent women of Great Neck, L.I., have arranged a series of "thrift teas" for the coming Winter, the first of which will be given next Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. John Eden, 225 Kings Point Road, Great Neck. In conjunction with the teas there will be a sale of various useful articles.

FROM the pen of Mr. Nevins we now have the full life story of a great character. Some of the gifts and attributes and evidences of greatness in a public man were denied Grover Cleveland. He was no popular orator.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 15 -- George D. Widener's 6-year-old Jack High established a new track record of a mile in 1:-37 1-5 to snatch a nose victory today in the featured $5,000 added Laurel Stakes.

PARTICULAR personal interest attached to the dozen records going to make up Victor Masterpiece Set No. 138, and on their arrival they were immediately put to work. For this is the recording of J.S. Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew," the making of which, in the late Spring, we were invited to witness.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 15. -- The University of Minnesota's football team had a narrow escape today as it scored a 7-6 victory over Nebraska.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 15. -- Georgia and North Carolina, forced by continuous rain and a pond-like gridiron to hold almost exclusively to old-fashioned line plunging, today battled to a 6-to-6 tie on Sanford Field.

WASHINGTON. IN these days, when the long-awaited upturn in business is generally looked for, it is interesting to consider that department of the government which is concerned fundamentally with the promotion of the nation's industry and trade, and to obtain the viewpoint of the man who heads it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Senators Copeland and Harrison sharply criticized President Hoover today in statements issued through the Democratic National Committee.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- M. William Bray, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, returned to his home here tonight after a two-day trip through the northern tier counties of Essex, Clinton, Franklin, St. Lawrence and Jefferson, reporting indications that hundreds of independent Republicans "are supporting the Roosevelt ticket and are going to vote for Herbert Lehman and his associates in the State election."

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Moravian College of Bethlehem, Pa., defeated Upsala today, 14-13. The visitors scored in the first quarter when Leonnard got away with a hidden-ball play to gain 25 yards and reach the Upsala 10-yard line.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (Canadian Press). -- Political circles were stirred today by announcement of a new Liberal platform which included home rule for Scotland and development of trade with the Soviet Union.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Coming here for a conference with Governor Roosevelt, Senator Joseph T. Robinson, asserted today that the election of the Democratic candidate would be a mandate from the people to Congress for speedy action to legalize beer.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- M. William Bray, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, returned to his home here tonight after a two-day trip through the northern tier counties of Essex, Clinton, Franklin, St. Lawrence and Jefferson, reporting indications that hundreds of independent Republicans "are supporting the Roosevelt ticket and are going to vote for Herbert Lehman and his associates in the State election."

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Moravian College of Bethlehem, Pa., defeated Upsala today, 14-13. The visitors scored in the first quarter when Leonnard got away with a hidden-ball play to gain 25 yards and reach the Upsala 10-yard line.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (Canadian Press). -- Political circles were stirred today by announcement of a new Liberal platform which included home rule for Scotland and development of trade with the Soviet Union.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Coming here for a conference with Governor Roosevelt, Senator Joseph T. Robinson, asserted today that the election of the Democratic candidate would be a mandate from the people to Congress for speedy action to legalize beer.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15. -- Carnegie Tech and Washington and Jefferson battled to a 6-to-6 tie before 15,000 fans today at the stadium. All the scoring was done in the first half, Carnegie scoring in the opening period when George Kavel hit right tackle for a 40-yard run and a touchdown.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Modification of the Volstead act to legalize beer by the Congress meeting in December and perhaps adoption of a resolution submitting the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment to the States are promises now being held out by the more optimistic wet leaders.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 15 (AP). -- Prediction that "the first faint dawnings of a better day" were in sight and a plea that President Hoover be re-elected to carry on his work were made by Secretary Hyde before a Republican rally here tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Felix Frankfurter, Professor International Law at Harvard, today announced his preference for the Presidential candidacy of Governor Roosevelt. In an article in The Harvard Crimson, Professor Frankfurter blamed President Hoover for the Treasury deficit, charged him with opposing constructive measures, and added:

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- The wedding of Miss Ruth Francis Hatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Hatt 2d, and Morton Carter Swift of Kensington, Conn., will take place here on Nov. 5. The Rev. George A. Taylor, rector of St. Paul's Church, will perform the ceremony in the church.

SAN FRANCISCO. ADREAM held by engineers for half a century -- the bridging of San Francisco Bay from San Francisco to Oakland -- is about to reach fruition. The two California cities will be connected by a great double-decked aerial highway which will form the last link in a 1,200-mile boulevard paralleling the Pacific coast from Puget Sound to San Diego.

On the Stock Exchange, Friday's abrupt recovery was carried somewhat further in the week-end market yesterday; but trading was light and most of the early gain was lost. Nevertheless, after all the appearance of recurrent weakness in last week's stock market, the "averages" ended above the closing prices of the preceding week-end.

A.E. Smith Omits Connecticut. Half a dozen speeches by "AL" SMITH are a handsome contribution to the Roosevelt campaign. It more than redeems Mr. SMITH'S promise to help. The itinerary, as announced by the editor of The New Outlook himself, covers New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Rhode Island.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Union College steamrolled its way to an impressive 46-6 victory over the Hobart College eleven today. The Garnet scored almost at will, gaining a total of 349 yards from scrimmage to Hobart's 25 and completing a total of eight out of fourteen attempts at forward passes, two of them for touchdowns.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 15. -- Grinding out touchdowns with monotonous regularity, the Notre Dame football machine today overwhelmed a band of Drake Bulldogs by a score of 62 to 0.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 15. -- Canada's output of gold in August totaled 262,590 ounces, an increase of 5.9 per cent over the 247,894 ounces produced in July and of 15.0 per cent over the 228,248 ounces reported for August, 1931, according to the Dominion Government.

THE persecution of recusants in the reign of Queen Elizabeth affords Mrs. Filfrid Ward ample opportunity for a vividly conceived and historically Accurate novel. "Tudor Sunset" is one of those books that are in essence more true than history.

Proving itself a power bouse in offensive strength, the Fordham University football team registered its third triumph of the 1932 campaign by vanquishing Lebanon Valley, 52 to 0, at the Polo Grounds yesterday before a crowd of 10,000.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- An "immediate" legislative program has been adopted by the State Economic Council, it was announced today. The program sponsored by the organization calls for a State-wide campaign to bring about economies in government, and includes:

OTTAWA, Oct. 13. -- A chorus of approval, almost unprecedented in the case of public appointments, greeted the selection of Hector Charlesworth, Toronto editor and critic, as chairman of the new Canadian Radio Broadcasting Commission, at a salary or $10,000 a year.

IT was in the Summer that a big, lanky, red-headed chap came into Tim Mara's office on Twenty-third Street. The coal business is slow in July and August, and Mr. Mara put on his most genial smile. The stranger might be a customer. But it didn't turn out that way.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- One of the oddest seasons in Yale football history took another unforeseen twist today when a favored Eli eleven that had been held to a tie score in each of its first two games went down to defeat before a hard-driving, hard-fighting Brown team, 7-2, as 30,000 looked on in the Yale bowl.

A slightly batter than seasonal improvement in business conditions occurred in most sections of the United States last week, with buying of clothing and articles for the home showing increased retail activity and stepping up of factory operations and employment in many lines, denoting further gains in manufacturing.

HAMILTON, Mass., Oct. 15. -- A double victory by Bayard Tuckerman Jr., president of the Eastern Horse Club, and the spectacular death of the Hendrie gelding Solymon, owned by John R. Macomber of Raceland, Framingham Centre, marked the twentieth annual Myopia Hunt Club race meet here today.

PANAMA R.P., Oct. 11. -- The possibility of actual conflict between Colombia and Peru over the occupation of the Colombian frontier town of Leticia by irregular Peruvian forces raises the question of the comparative credit and financial positions of the two countries.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, is expected to get from 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 votes on election day, it was said yesterday at Thomas headquarters here, 112 East Nineteenth Street. This prediction is based on The Literary Digest poll and other polls, plus reports from Socialist campaign managers in various sections.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14. THE phantom Rialto of this city offers four diversions to the followers of the legitimate stage, as follows:

Price levels of high-grade municipal bonds were well maintained last week despite the dampening effect of declines of 3/4 to 4 points in prices of New York City issues. The meager supply of first-grade State and municipal bonds in the open market, coupled with the limited volume of issues of this rating up for award soon, has operated to impart a general tone of steadiness to the market.

THOUGH the dance season, strictly speaking, will not be opened until Vicente Escudero does the honors officially next week, the dances staged by Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman in "Americana," the superior revue at the Shubert Theatre, have opened something of greater importance than the season.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Zombro Hanover, 2:00 Newbrook Stables, pacer, owned by Stack Smith of Short Hills and driven by Hodson, set a new track pacing record when he covered a mile in 2:01 1/2 in an exhibition at Weequahic Park today. The previous record of 2:04 3/4, made by Brook Volo several years ago, was shattered.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Germany a export surplus -- essential for the maintenance of foreign debt service and the Reichsbank's foreign exchange portfolio -- went down in September to 84,000,000 marks [about $19,992,000] from the August surplus of 97,000,000 marks [about $23,086,000].
CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Assistant State's Attorneys here were instructed today to prepare the additional legal papers necessary for the issuance of a Presidential warrant for Samuel Insull Sr.

HAVANA, Oct. 15. -- The tightening of military control in Cuba despite the re-establishment of constitutional guarantees today is being done to enforce the rights granted under the electoral code, according to a statement issued at noon by President Machado.

FERDE GROFE has done so much to elevate jazz that he is called its prime minister. Today he is working on two compositions which are likely to further increase his prestige. One is a symphonic poem, "Tabloid," which Grofe says will "depict a large city through the eyes of a newspaper."

The Flushing High School football team defeated Richmond Hill, 12 to 6, before 4,000 spectators at the Flushing Memorial Field yesterday. The victory was the second for the winners in three starts, they having played to a tie in their other encounter.
Leaders of the medical profession and scientists of many nations paid tribute to Dr. Emanuel Libman last night, on his sixtieth birthday anniversary, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The powerful banking groups which saw the city through its financial crisis of last January have notified Controller Charles W. Berry that they will not provide any further aid unless the Board of Estimate makes good its pledges of strict economy by framing for 1933 a budget whose total is far below that of 1932.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- More than $1,000,000,000 was involved in financial operations at the Treasury Department today, representing principally transactions involving the public debt.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 13. -- There are three political campaigns under way in Minnesota. Each presents highly unusual features and each is distinct from the other to an extraordinary degree.

AFTER writing plays for twenty-five years Rachel Crothers ought to be able to write them well. Her distinction is that she can. Most of the good people who were wrenching the strong arm of coincidence when she began have long since abandoned the drama to the marplots who now rule the stage.

Two men were killed and three others, one a woman, were badly injured about 7 o'clock last night when the automobile in which they were driving north at high speed on the West Side express highway crashed into a lamp post and was virtually cut in two on the sharp reverse curve opposite Thompson Street.

William Nelson Cromwell, chairman of the Committee of the Bar for Hoover in this State, announced yesterday that every county in the State, with the exception of Hamilton County, where there are no lawyers, is represented on the advisory committee working for Mr. Hoover's reelection.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. PARAMOUNT is threatened with difficulties with the Italian Government over "A Farewell to Arms," which the studio has just completed with Helen Hayes. For some time nationals in this country belonging to an organization known as Sons of Italy have taken exception to certain portrayals of Italians on the screen.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Middlebury defeated Williams 18 to 7 today. The Vermont State eleven uncovered a strong attack which swept back the Berkshire players for three touchdowns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation made available today $1,038,948 in relief loans for six States to meet the emergency needs from Oct. 16 to Dec. 31. The loans approved were $529,400 to Arkansas, $193,236 to Tennessee, $182,887 to Ohio, $181,312 to Oklahoma, $95,000 to Montana and $40,000 to Michigan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Declaring that Secretary Stimson's interpretation of the Kellogg-Briand pact was of "paramount significance" as an announcement of the readiness of the United States to consult with other nations to preserve the peace of the world, Newton W. Rowell, president of the Canadian bar, paid a tribute tonight to American leadership in the settlement of international differences, in an address at the banquet which closed the American Bar Association's convention.

BELGRADE, Oct. 15. -- Four weeks after the first collisions in the Lika Mountains of Croatia between armed irregulars and government troops, which the Yugoslav press had been forbidden to mention, although it had been long known abroad, the government has decided to issue a statement.

ROGER WILLIAMS is the most lovable of the founders of New England. In an age of religious fanaticism and intolerance, he exercised a wise forbearance and charity. When cruel persecution for opinion was the order of the day, he offered asylum to those who differed from him in religious belief.

Disappointment over the fact that the weekly report of car loadings did not fully meet the enthusiastic predictions of Wall Street was cited yesterday as one of the possible causes of the moderate reaction in the second hour of trading on the Stock Exchange.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- Conclusions which seemingly go a long way toward explaining periodical variations of temperature are drawn in a pamphlet just issued by the Observatory of Talence, in the Gironde. Scientists there have been observing the sun day after day for thirty-two years, and for eighteen years previous to that also took very frequent solar and meteorological observations.

PARIS. THE month of September brought to the Paris moving-picture world a scandal of the first magnitude. It is the chief topic of conversation in film circles these days, where it has left an extremely bad taste, particularly as it is not yet cleared up.

While the Board of Estimate as a whole rested over the week-end from its labors in straightening out the 1933 tentative budget, Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee delved yesterday into the whole field of city purchases of supplies and equipment in an effort to reduce these items next year.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 15. -- Captain Richmond A. Ware entertained at a hunt breakfast this morning for more than fifty riders after the drag meet of the Bath County Hounds. The breakfast was held at Warecrest Farms.

BERLIN, Oct. 15. -- Transactions on the Boerse were in fair volume today and the tendency was bullish. Gelsenkirchen Water rose 3 points, Oberkoks 2 1/2, and Harpener 1 3/4 and Schuckert 1 3/4. The closing was firm, with the average above yesterday's levels.

The Erasmus and Madison elevens battled to a 13-13 tie in their annual clash, before 7,000 spectators at Fewster Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. It was the eighth annual meeting between the two high schools, with Erasmus still holding the edge with three victories to Madison's two, three games having resulted in ties.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 15. -- The Purdue Boilermakers scored a 7-to-6 victory today over Wisconsin, in another traditional battle staged annually by these two Western Conference teams. A crowd of 17,000 saw the game.

The Hall Johnson Negro Choir appeared last night in Town Hall in what is announced to be their only concert scheduled for the present New York season. They sang the program which will be used on all the concerts of their forthcoming transcontinental tour.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 2. -- The Hungarian Mrs. Grundy, who has in the past few years done so much to add to the gayety of nations, has succeeded in bringing laughter to artists and art students even in these days, when they are suffering perhaps more than any other class from the economic depression.

Relief work among merchant seamen, as carried on for 105 years by the American Seamen's Friend Society, is analyzed by the Rev. Dr. George Sidney Webster, its secretary, in a 200-page volume, "The Seamen's Friend," which appeared yesterday.

TOKYO, Sept. 23. -- "We need not be afraid of our present difficulties. What we need to fear is any slackening of the spirit of self-help in fighting those difficulties. We Japanese people inherited from our ancestors a character which, enables us to face dangers with composure, and this character has revealed its strength at various places where the people are steadily reconstructing their economic lives with their own strength.

Despite the reduction in the earning power of American corporations during the last three years, at least thirty-nine companies whose common shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange have continued to pay regular dividends which are equal to or greater than their regular rates paid in 1929.

DRESDEN, Oct. 1, 1932. WHEN the curtain fell on the first performance of Eugen d'Albert's posthumous three-act opera, "Mr. Wu," at the Dresden Opera House tha evening of Sept. 29, there was applause enough to call out the singers, the conductor, the scene painter and the stage manager seven or eight times, and somebody threw flowers from an upper box.

OWEN AND DONALD DAVIS are the playwrights who will share in tomorrow's first night in Fifty-second Street -- an event which promises to be of more than usual importance in that the Theatre Guild will lift the curtain, not only on "The Good Earth," the dramatization of a hugely successful novel, but on its fifteenth subscription season at the Guild Theatre.

WILLIAM POWELL, who was a villain before he was a hero in the films, is a native of Pittsburgh, where his father worked as a public accountant. After his graduation from grammar school the family moved to Kansas City, Mo., where William enrolled in the Central High School of that city and became interested in dramatics.

NEVER before in the history of Presidential elections have straw votes been so closely watched. Who will be elected -- Hoover or Roosevelt? In an attempt to answer the question, scores of newspapers and periodicals are conducting straw polls.

To the Editor of The New York Times : A short time ago seventeen young men, nominees for entrance to the Naval Academy at Annapolis, were debarred by the Navy Department from ever applying again. In an examination they had turned in seventeen identical answers.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 17. -- Important revisions of China's laws governing the disputes between labor and capital have been adopted by the Legislative Yuan at Nanking and tend to further curb strikes, lockouts and the resort to violence in labor troubles.

LONDON, Oct. 15.-A number of competent observers who have examined the new British products at the present Olympia Motor Show and discussed the prices at which they are sold here believe a wide market is still open for the American manufacturer, despite the high tariff, depreciated pound and local tax of u1 per horsepower.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 15. -- President Hoover arrived here soon, after 8 o'clock tonight, following thirteen hours of back-platform campaigning through Pennsylvania, Ohio and the tips of West Virginia and Maryland. He journeyed through what has been called the "industrial Ruhr" of America, expounding the doctrine of the protective tariff as the surest way for American workers to retain a living wage, once the policies of his administration had brought economic recovery.

Methods of widening the scope of the teletype system of communication used by the police departments of this and other States were discussed yesterday at the annual conference of Interstate Teletype Supervisors in the Hotel Lexington, Forty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 15. -- The text of President Hoover's speech here tonight follows:

During 1931 the earnings of 530 graduates of the Columbia School of Business ranged from $360 to $100,000, according to the results announced yesterday of an occupational survey made under the direction of Professor James C. Egbert. Men listed in the group of forty engaged in real estate, advertising, engineering and construction, and personnel and training, were credited with making both the highest and the lowest salaries.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The deft putting touch of Mike Brady enabled the veteran Winged Foot pro and Joe Turnesa to defeat Billy Burke, 1931 national open champion, and Jerry Travers, former amateur titleholder, in an eighteen-hole exhibition match at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

Maria Jeritza, former soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, will arrive today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to go on a cencert tour, accompanied by her husband, Baron Popper von Pedragby. Fritz Kreisler, violinist, is also coming on the liner, accompanied by Mrs. Kreisler.

Hundreds of messages praising President Hoover's Cleveland speech and declaring that it would swing millions of votes to him were received yesterday at the Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee in the Waldorf-Astoria. Hany of the messages stated that the "swing" was now to the President and that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, his Democratic opponent, was defeated.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former president of the Reichsbank, in an address today at the American Church on "Germany's Rebirth," said the signs of an awakening were already visible in the "national movement," and that a new Germany would rise from the ruins of the old.

Franklin d'Olier, first National Commander of the American Legion, announced yesterday his support of Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor. Colonel Donovan and Mr. d'Olier were among the organizers of the Legion in Paris in 1919.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Declaring that present-day church members had become "religiously sophisticated," the Rev. Dr. Rees E. Tulloss, president of Wittenberg College, told 12,000 Lutherans at a vesper service in Convention Hall this afternoon that they were facing a crucial hour in mankind's history.

The tendency of governments to encroach on the rights of individuals is increasing, with the result that men have become "absorbed by a luxury-loving, money-worshiping society," according to the Right Rev. Thomas Frank Gailor, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Tennessee, who was guest preacher at the services of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, yesterday morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16. -- No one here has attempted to express the mathematical effect in the election returns of Senator Johnson's vigorous blast of last week, in which he said: "I cannot and will not support Mr. Hoover." The immediate visible effect was consternation and anger among the regular Republicans, and jubilation among the Roosevelt forces.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Oct. 16. -- Inspector Alien left Roosevelt Field this morning about 10:30 planning to reach his home at Jonesville, N.Y., near Albany, in time for a birthday party his wife had planned in his honor tonight. He was 41 years old Wednesday, but the celebration had been deferred until tonight.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16. -- The most authoritative statement yet made about Soviet industrialization and the importance of this country as a market for foreign manufacturers has come from a group of German officials who have just completed a tour of Soviet industrial centres.

Tallying four touchdowns against Connecticut State on Saturday, Louis Bush, Massachusetts State half back, increased his lead over Cliff Montgomery of Columbia in the race for Eastern individual scoring honors.

Over the week-end the Second Avenue Theatre offered as its first play of the season the operetta, "The Big Surprise." Turning on a thumping coincidence, the said surprise need not be revealed here. Nor need very much he said about the rest of the book supplied by A. Blum, who is entitled to his commonplaces and triangles with rounded edges as is the next librettist.

OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Crime smote Law and Order on Lawes Field here today when the Sing Sing prison football team beat the Port Jervis Police Department by 7 to 0, avenging the 13-to-0 defeat suffered last November in its first engagement with the policemen.

MONTREAL, Oct. 16. -- The financing which the Canadian Government soon will undertake will be on a short-term basis, at any rate for a portion of the loan issue, according to opinions held by home investment bankers here. In view of recent developments it is felt that Canada has much to gain by arranging for a portion of her requirements on a temporary basis.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The recent comparative steadiness of sterling, before the dip in the middle of this week, was not regarded by financial London as evidence that stabilization of the pound is anywhere near at hard. The best opinion is that sterling will have to be kept stable for a very considerable period before any actual fixed rate for revaluation can be determined.

ROME, Oct. 16. -- Premier Mussolini's much-heralded speech to a meeting of 25,000 Fascist leaders massed in the Piazza Venezia was halted today by a heavy rain. Inaugurating the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the march on Rome, the Premier had hardly got as far as the statement that Fascism intends to continue its present policy of "absolute intransigeance" and to intensify the "Fascistization" of Italy when the proceedings were cut short.
ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- The New York State Economic Council moved today to put on record the attitude toward governmental retrenchment of every candidate in the State for the Legislature and Congress.

The "old-time religion" is not good enough for any one living in this age, and to say it is is an invitation to mental and spiritual indolence, the Rev. Arthur Wilde, pastor of the New Church, Swedenborgian, Thirty-fifth Street between Lexington and Park Avenues, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

It is new evidence of the heartlessness of the world that the struggle of Senator MOSES to succeed himself has got such scant notice. One saw him vaguely with his "back against the wall," but that expression might be interpreted as symbolizing his devotion to the tariff that fell from heaven.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- The Wolverines of Michigan, co-sharers of the Big Ten gridiron title for the last two years, have strengthened their claims for 1932 championship honors. Victorious over Northwestern and Ohio State, they meet Illinois at Ann Arbor next Saturday, and if they win they undoubtedly will have clear Bailing to the championship.

A procession made colorful by flags, ecclesiastical banners and the uniforms of American and British patriotic societies wound its way through the aisles of historic St. Paul's Chapel, at Broadway and Fulton Street, last evening to conclude the eleventh annual celebration of the British Harvest Festival, which was combined this year with Thanks-giving "for the birth of George Washington 200 years ago."

When the French liner Jle de France leaves this port next Thursday for Havre, she will be under the command for the last time of Captain Joceph Blancart. the commodore of the fleet, who is retiring under the age limit of 55 to became director agent, at Stc.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Oct. 16. -- Fatally injured when he was struck by an automobile on Sunrise Highway here early this morning, Thomas Dowling Jr. of 171 Congress Street, Brooklyn, died at South Nassau Communities Hospital, Rockville Centre, at 11:30 A.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- An open petition signed by 180 economists was presented to President Hoover today urging him to use his official power, under the flexible tariff provision, to "eliminate the inequalities" of the Hawley-Smoot tariff act, "especially those which are causing retaliation abroad."

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 16. -- Senator George H. Moses is engaged in the hardest battle of his career to hold his seat. For the first time since he went to the United States Senate in 1918 he will go into the final phase of a New Hampshire campaign with his Democratic opponent an odds-on favorite.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Frank Lalla, young Rye runner, won his third major race of the year when he led a field of thirty-eight in the eighth annual Port Chester marathon today. He had a fifteen-minute handicap and his actual time was 2:57:16.6.

WALLKILL, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Thomas Smith, a Brooklyn bandit, and Peter Williamson, a Manhattan forger, escaped late last night from the "medium security" prison here and are believed to have robbed Emery Tucker of Modena, of his automobile half an hour after the escape and less than three miles from the prison.
Everett Sanders, Republican national chairman, asserted yesterday that straw votes indicating Governor Roosevelt's election were wrong, and that President Hoover would be reelected.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA and The Chicago Daily News. What happens to a family when it makes no attempt to live within its income? Doesn't disaster follow, especially when the head of that family has put nothing away for the proverbial rainy day?

BERLIN, Oct. 14. -- The strengthening of the Reichsbank's reserve during the past few weeks-gold holdings having increased 15,000,000 marks since the middle of September while foreign exchange reserve decreased barely 10,000,000 -- has been due to the better working of the official exchange restrictions, to the increase in the export surplus for July and to the inflow of foreign funds for purchase of German securities.

GEORGE MCANENY is one of the six or seven living men who could be described, as he was last week, as "completely at ease in the tangled jungle of subway financing." No wonder the members of the Board of Estimate listened to him with respect, however much they might be inclined to disagree with his conclusions.

At a meetting of Typographical Union 6 (Big Six) at Stuyvesant High School yesterday, attended by more than 2,500 members, it was voted to take a referendum of the union members on the new contract negotiated between representatives of the union, headed by Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, and the Printers' League Section of the Employing Printers.

The strange laws of intuition and chance that apparently govern most phases of the book business, are dealt with by Frank Swinnerton in "Authors and the Book Trade," just published by Knopf. Mr. Swinnerton is English, the author of twenty books, and a book critic.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- Professor Albert Einstein in a lecture here tonight on cosmic space said one of its salient characteristics was that it was not static but in a process of expansion. This, he said, had been established by the most recent astronomical research, especially by admirable observations made at Pasadena, Cal., on the so-called Doppler effect -- the displacement of spectral lines in light received from distant stellar bodies.

Formation of the Independent Citizens' Committee for re-election of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner was completed yesterday, according to an announcement of George R. Van Namee, Senator Wagner's campaign manager. Robert E. Dowling, who organized the group, is permanent chairman, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the finance committee and Alfred J. Johnson, treasurer.

Plans are being made in the Department of Hospitals for a college of nursing, to be chartered by the State and to cooperate with the city hospitals, it was made known yesterday by Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Commissioner of Hospitals, who said the preliminary work in assembling data was going on under the supervision of Marian Rottman, the department's director of nursing.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 16. -- Sarah Frances from St. Croix, a cook in the home of John Lindsay 4th, was charged tonight with the murder of 8-weeks-old John Lindsay 5th by throwing him from a fifth floor apartment window. Domingo Masseri, the District Attorney, ordered a warrant issued today on what he admitted was circumstantial evidence with the motive undetermined.
PARIS, Oct. 16. -- Nearly complete returns show today's elections for 111 French Senate seats, one-third of the membership, brought no important change in the political trend of France.

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Oct. 16 (AP).--Pledged, to carry on their fight, striking coal miners in a twelve-mile motorcade convoyed the body of a fallen comrade into Taylorville for burial today after funeral services held outside Christian County to avoid a military guard.

Two plays, both based on the lives of historical figures, have been added to the list of Broadway premieres for next week. They are "The Anatomist," opening at the Bijou Theatre on Monday evening, Oct. 24, and "Carry Nation," coming to the Biltmore Theatre on Saturday night, Oct. 29.
HYDE PARK, Oct. 16. -- Governor Roosevelt spent many hours today with his research advisers in mapping out the program of speeches for his tour.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16. -- Trading in cotton contracts here last week was far from active. The market received some support early from the unseasonably cold weather that overspread the Cotton Belt. Killing frosts, both early and late in the week, struck the greater part of the belt, and the interior reported that, while further growth was stopped, the cold had caused bolls to open rapidly.
The second day of the Feast of Tabernacles was observed in Jewish places of worship in New York yesterday.

The New York Giants football team opened its home season successfully by defeating the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The New York aggregation, after rolling up 14 points in the first period, encountered stubborn opposition for the remainder of the battle, but managed to emerge triumphant by the score of 20 to 12.

Real estate interests, in "utterly unsocial" opposition to government aid for new housing, are impeding slum clearance, Robert D. Kohn, past president of the American Institute of Architects, charges in a statement issued yesterday by the institute.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Impressed and surprised by the government's 2 per cent bond offer and the Treasury's determination to take the fullest possible advantage of the excessive ease in money, sentiment on this week's financial markets was generally cheerful.

A last-period drive by the Portsmouth Spartans gained them a 7-to-7 tie with Stapleton yesterday at Thompson Stadium in Stapleton, S.I. A capacity gathering of more than 7,500 persona saw this National League game.

Alcoholic Ratios in Beer. It is a mistake to suppose that the Presidential campaign occupies people's minds and hearts to the exclusion of every other interest. There are still a few non-political topics on which men can feel strongly and write letters to the editor even more strongly.

Whether or not the Tammany-controlled bloc in the Board of Estimate will go along with Acting Mayor McKee in a budget-reduction program sufficiently drastic to persuade the city's leading bankers to float new security issues and establish new credits essential for transacting municipal business on a cash basis will be determined this morning at an executive meeting of the board called for 10 o'clock.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 (AP). -- Samuel Harden Church, president of the Carnegie Institute and a lifelong Republican, announced tonight that he would vote for Governor Roosevelt for President.

A cowgirl was thrown and slightly hurt, another taken unconscious from the saddle and a third pinned beneath an injured horse in the broncho-riding contest featuring yesterday's showing of the seventh annual world's series rodeo, being held at the Madison Square Garden for the benefit of Mrs. William Randolph Hearst's Free Milk Fund for babies.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 16. -- The second annual New Jersey residents' championships at contract bridge ended here today in the Whist Club of the Oranges with the team of the Newark Contract Club winning the main event and the Culbertson Trophy.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee has set a goal of $15,000,000 to be collected in contributions for unemployment relief here this Winter, at was announced yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the committee. The money will be used to supplement the relief work of the city and State.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 16 (AP). -- One convict was slain and twenty-four were wounded by gunfire at Speigner Prison this afternoon when an attempted escape by sixteen in-mates was followed by a general up-rising, in which over half of the prison's population of 950 took part.

Champion The Crovanspring, an English bulldog, yesterday was named best in show over 515 other dogs at the eighteenth annual exhibition of the Bronx County Kennel Club, held in the 105th Field Artillery Armory. The victory of the bulldog was the first in many years in this section for one of this breed.

The Immediate repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the cancellation or drastic reduction of war debts are urged by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College and Miss Sarah Sehuyler Butler, vice chairman of the New York Republican State Committee, in a political symposium in The Barnard Alumnae Monthly, published today.

Registration in the city for the November election, which totaled 2,334,131, breaking by 305,000 the record of 2,029,618 set in 1928, was regarded yesterday as an indication of an extremely heavy vote for the Democratic national and State tickets on Nov. 8.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Morris Douw Ferris of Lawrence, L.I., will give a dinner for their debutante daughter, Miss Dorcas O. Ferris, on Dec. 2 at the Ritz-Carlton, before the first Junior Assembly.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The public must spend its money; to restore national prosperity aha increase employment there must be an end to private economy. This, in effect, is the verdict of six leading British economists, who in a letter to The London Times tonight indicate they have ceased preaching economy.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Led by Miss Virginia Bourquardez, the all-New York field hockey team triumphed over the all-North Jersey eleven, 5 to 3, at Branch Brook Park today.
DUBLIN, Oct. 16. -- Sober opinion here is surprised, not that the London negotiations failed but that they lasted two days.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Eamon de Valera and the other Irish Free State delegates left London for Dublin tonight without any attempt to renew contact with the British Ministers with whom they found it impossible to reach an agreement on the land annuities dispute Friday and Saturday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Economy which would not hinder the completion of vital park and parkway projects originally conceived in a comprehensive plan of development is urged upon the Westchester County Board of Supervisors in the tenth annual report of the Westchester County Park Commission, just printed for distribution in booklet form with maps, illustrations and statistics.
ATLANTA, Oct. 16. -- Out of a pair of thrill-packed, rain-swept battles yesterday involving the four Southern Conference gridiron favorites, the Orange banner of Tennessee flew alone today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Confidence that a Presidential warrant for the extradition of Samuel Insull from Greece would be obtained in a few days and that Assistant State's Atorneys Charles A. Bellows and Andrew J. Vlachos would be on their way from Washington to Greece this week was expressed today by State's Attorney Swanson.

The industry of beautification will present today the modes it has prepared for tomorrow, and beauty herself will be asked to pass judgment. For with the opening of the American Beauty and Styles Exposition at the Grand Central Palace the appeal will be to the public, and not so much to the manufacturers and distributers.

A transformation of the church is needed to make Christianity a living force instead of a complicated religion of words and phrases, according to the sixth instalment of the appraisal commission of the Laymen's Foreign Missions inquiry, made public yesterday.

Albert Casey of 130 Bast 123d Street, doorman at the Griffon Rest Apartments, 77 Park Avenue, sat in the lobby there early yesterday Idly watching the two elevator operators, Max Miller of 1,070 Faile Street, the Bronx, and Rudolph Grenier of 52 East 122d Street, who were chatting.

The charge that influences are at work all over the country to "keep Catholic men and women out of high national office" and that Catholics are "mistrusted and suspected" in all their efforts to do civic good, was brought by the Rev. Henry F. Hammer yesterday in his sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SOFIA, Oct. 16. -- Bulgarian officials today refused to let two former Cabinet Members enter the country to meet sentences of death which had been passed on them for alleged subversive activities. They are MM. Athanasoff and Stoyanoff, members of the Cabinet of the late Premier Alexander Stambulisky, who fled the country after their leader was over-thrown and assassinated in 1923.

Warnings in plenty have been given to the authorities of this city that its credit is not what it has been or ought to be. The decline in the price of city bonds shows what investors and trustees are thinking. Some time ago formal notice was served by the bankers to whom the Controller had applied for a loan that further advances of money would depend upon severe retrenchment in municipal expenditures.

Delegates from all parts of the country have arrived In Boston for the first conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, which will open today and continue until Friday. Mrs. John G. Pratt of New Orleans, president of the association, will preside.

UNION CITY, N.J., Oct. 16. -- For the first time in nineteen years the Passion Players of the Holy Name Roman Catholic Church of this city appeared here today in a drama other than the Passion Play. They presented the first of a series of performances of "Quo Vadis," a dramatization from the book by Henry Sienkiewicz by the Rev. Joseph N. Griff, pastor of Holy Name Church.

Prices of cotton declined irregularly last week, the active contract months on the New York Cotton Exchange losing 13 to 16 points. The Depressing effects of lower grain security markets, together with favorable crop weather, were to a large extent offset by the increased activity of the domestic spinning industry, by a continued high basis for spot cotton and by the continued good export movement of cotton as compared with last year.

Southern women in New York have arranged a bridge party for the afternoon of Nov. 9 in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis to augment the funds that are being raised to restore and maintain Stratford Hall, the birth-place of General Robert E. Lee in Virginia.
RUSSELLVILLE, Ky., Oct. 16 (AP). -- Frank A. Mather, Federal prohibition agent, and Bluch Soyars, special deputy sheriff, were hilled in a pistol fight in a Negro cabin last night.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 16. -- Senator Reed Smoot is facing the political battle of his career in his campaign for re-election.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16. -- A total of 2,294 hospitals throughout the United States and Canada have been approved by the American College of Surgeons, according to Dr. Franklin H. Martin, director general, who arrived today for the annual clinical congress of the college, which will open here tomorrow and extend to Friday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs gave a dinner tonight at the Olde Egremont Inn, South Egremont, for Mr. and Mrs. Prentice French, who are visiting Mrs. Daniel Chester French at Chester-wood, Stockbridge, and for Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gilbert Colt and Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Russell of Pittsfield.

Happy Scot, which carries the colors of Joseph Edwards, appears likely to be favored in the featured Bedford Handicap at the opening of the twelve-day Fall meeting of the Empire City Racing Association today. The session at the Yonkers track is the last of the Jockey Club schedule.

Republican managers announced that the President would make at Cleveland a "fighting speech." He did. It was the speech of a man fighting on the defensive. With what was for him an unaccustomed warmth of indignation, he repelled the attacks made upon him by his political enemies.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 16. -- Kansas from the date of its settlement has had an inordinate appetite for martyrs. The question in this year's political campaign in the State seems to reduce itself to this: Can Kansas express devotion to more than one martyr at a time?

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Coolidge lauded John Sherman to the skies as a financier because he, as Secretary of the Treasury, resumed specie payment. In 1888 Mr. Sherman was the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for President.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Raisers of live stock are selling their holdings in a way that is fairly liberal and that easily supplies consumptive requirements. Receipts of cattle here last week were the largest for a week with one exception since Jan. 9, while the run of hogs was the smallest since July 9, and that of sheep, the lightest since the week of Aug. 20.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16. -- With the exception of the scheduled game between J. Medina of Mexico and Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, which was postponed until tomorrow, the games of the ninth and final round of the international chess tournament were played today.

Clyde Burrows's song recital, given yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall, included three groups of songs preponderantly English, among them Purcell's "Roaring Boy," Delius's "The Princess," Shaw's "Song of the Palanquin Bearers" and Stanford's "Quick, we have but a second."

PARIS, Oct. 14. -- The sharp recovery in dollar exchange this week, after last week's two-day decline, caused no surprise among responsible financial people here. They had, in fact, at no time taken seriously the decline ascribed to President Hoover's speech.

PARIS, Oct. 16 (AP). -- The swing to the Liberal Left that occurred in last May's general elections was repeated today in the Senatorial elections, and as a result the virtual majority of Premier Edouard Harriot's Liberals (Democratic Left) was assured.

OTTAWA, Oct. 16. -- Canadian trade experts estimate that the reduction of the United States' export trade to Great Britain under the Canadian-British trade agreement will be much greater than the reduction in the export trade of the United States to Canada.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Virtually all lines of business in this territory reported greater activity last week, mills increasing operations and employing more workers and executives taking a more optimistic view of the future. Low inventories were reported by most lines, calling for raw material and finished products for replacement and forecasting a better distribution of manufactured goods.

ROME, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Speaking at the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the Milan meeting which preceded the Fascist march on Rome in 1922, Premier Mussolini recalled today that that meeting had been called by him and that there the insurrection was planned.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Langenberg were hosts at a large dinner in the Colonial Room of the Homestead this evening. Among the guests were Baroness Rosenkranz, Mrs. William Clark, J.W. Banning Jr., William H. Wallace Jr., Robert Livingston Beeckman and Dr. Stuart Craig.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--Opening a series of nation-wide radio programs for the welfare and relief mobilization of the Winter of 1932-33, President Hoover tonight appealed in a speech broadcast from the White House, to each community to meet its own needs.
Several leasehold transactions involving properties in Manhattan were reported over the week-end.

If the stock market of this Autumn were assumed to be a daily indication of the economic probabilities, one would have to conclude that the financial prospect is shifting one way and the other with bewildering uncertainty. But the explanation for this professed alternation of Wall Street enthusiasm and dejection is not difficult.
Governor Roosevelt will announce opposition to immediate cash payment of the soldiers' bonus in an address at Pittsburgh on Wednesday, it was learned yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Football fandom scratched its collective head today and stared unbelievingly at the final scores that made Saturday's gridiron scramble in the Far West the biggest upset week thus far this season.

MILLINGTON, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Under a tent packed with hound enthusiasts, as darkness was closing in and the rain falling heavily, George A. Flammer of Roseland, N.J., awarded the title of best hound in the ninth annual specialty show of the New Jersey Beagle Club to champion Delco Miner, owned and shown by James W. Fox of the Delco Beagles of Darby, Pa.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 16 (AP). -- Attorneys for George W. Courson, former prison camp guard convicted of manslaughter in the sweat-box death of Arthur Maillefert, young New Jersey convict, prepared today to file a motion for a new trial.

SINAIA, Rumania, Oct. 16 (AP). -- Former Queen Elizabeth of Greece and 11-year-old Crown Prince Michael attended King Carol's thirty-ninth birthday dinner at his Summer residence here today. Dowager Queen Marie and Archduke Anton and his wife, Ileana, sister of Carol, were not present.
BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- Pre-election clashes between National Socialists and Communists in various parts of Germany today resulted in three persons being killed and many seriously wounded.

No citizen can be excused for failure to cast his or her ballot on Nov. 8, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday morning in a sermon in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. He further declared that the citizens of New York should no longer permit such political conditions in this city as they have recently tolerated.
