With warnings that the charitable institutions of New York City face unprecedented demands for help at a time when their funds are reduced to a dangerously low level, the 1932 appeal of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies for funds to complete the $3,923,000 budget was laid before 1,100 Jewish leaders of the city at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night.

With the announcement yesterday of a communication from Justin H. Moore, Dean of the City College School of Business, advising the staff of The Ticker, student newspaper at the college's Twenty-third Street division, over which Dean Moore has jurisdiction, that the publication would in future be compelled to submit all copy to faculty censorship, a strike by the undergraduate editors became imminent.

Between Jan. 1, 1929 and June 30, 1932, public relief agencies in New York City aided about 2,000,000 persons and spent a total of $183,481,502, it was disclosed yesterday, when Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare, made public statistics he had compiled and submitted to Acting Mayor McKee.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 16. -- James E. Watson's chances of being reelected to the Senate from Indiana are not very good, many political observers in this State believe.

The leaders of organized railway labor are about to submit to their memberships a proposal that they be empowered to negotiate with the managements on a continuation of the present 10 per cent wage reduction agreement beyond Feb. 1, when it otherwise would expire.

Unlucky thirteen was closely allied with two surprises recorded in New York City's scholastic football ranks on Saturday as Theodore Roosevelt High, unable to extend to thirteen games its undefeated and unscored upon streak, bowed to Textile, 7 to 6, and Erasmus Hall, thwarted several times in attempts to pass thirteen in the point-scoring column, tied with James Madison High.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A slight increase in wholesale commodity prices in September, as compared with August, was announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

John Murtha, who is about 40 years old and bears the gang nickname of The Spider, was taken for a ride yesterday morning. He was found at the entrance of a Queens cemetery with three bullet wounds in the body. He has a fair chance of recovery.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 16. -- Addresses by Robert Low Bacon, member of Congress from Long Island, and Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, Democratic candidate for the office, featured the Casimir Pulaski celebration here and the official opening of Pulaski Boulevard, the new county highway from East Northport to Huntington Station, held this afternoon and evening.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The British Board of Trade's index number of wholesale prices in Great Britain for September, based on the 1913 average as 100, is 102.1. This compares with 99.5 as the average for August and 99.2 for September, 1931. There has thus been an increase in the British price average during three successive months, and the current index number is the highest since April.

The individualism of American life is manifested by the fact "that we isolate smallpox, but we allow promoters, whose minds are pocked and made of money, to foist gangster films and films of sex on a supine public," the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 16. -- The game between the Guyan polo team of Huntingdon, W.Va., and the Zane Grey team of Zanesville, Ohio, which, was to have been played today on the Greenbrier field, was postponed because of inclement weather until next Sunday.

VIENNA, Oct. 16. -- A policeman, a National Socialist and another man were killed and thirty Hitlerites and five policemen were seriously wounded by rifle and revolver shots in a clash between Hitlerites and Socialists in the working class suburb of Simmering today.

The cod-fishing season is not so far off. In fact reports yesterday from Long Island boatmen indicated that some cod already had been seen, though they were small and were far out. It must get really cold before the cod begin to run just right. Then they provide some of tha finest fishing of the entire year and make a delectable meal, besides.

There was an increase in the buying activity in the wholesale market here last week, due to the cool weather and to the depletion of small stocks on which most of the retailers are now operating. The number of buyers here increased and reports of consumer response were encouraging.

Charles Eidlitz, director of the Credit Association of the Building Trades of New York, announces through Alien B. Beals in the current Dow Service that steps will be taken for the immediate establishment of a school for instruction in the subject of building trade credit control and laws affecting its application to all branches of the industry in New York and New Jersey.
With registration over, the Mayoralty candidates of both major parties prepared yesterday for the opening of intensive-speaking campaigns this week in their drive for votes.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- With the voters expected to ratify the proposed $30,000,000 bond issue for State unemployment relief on Nov. 8, Governor Roosevelt announced today that on Oct. 27 he would confer in Albany with Lieut. Gov. Lehman, Senator Fearon and Speaker McGinnies of the Assembly to determine whether a special session of the Legislature would be necessary to make the funds available.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- Chancellor Franz von Papen warned Germany's private foreign creditors today that obligations to them could be paid only by sale of goods and that to make this possible trade barriers would have to be lifted.

The old Bert Williams estate property at 2,309 Seventh Avenue, in Harlem, has been purchased by Dr. and Mrs. Vernon E. Ayers of 221 West 135th Street. The deal was announced by John W. Walker, broker, who said the consideration was all cash above a standing first mortgage for five years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, asserted today that "the legalization of beer before March 4 is a remote possibility," and that whether it may become a possibility after that date "will largely be determined by the results of the election on Nov. 8."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 20 per cent of plant capacity, the same as in the preceding week, after a rise of 6 points in as many weeks, or from a rate of about 14 per cent in the week ended on Aug. 27.

There are shrines where persons healed of their infirmities leave their crutches or other "votive offerings" to the saint thus commemorated. If all the "atypical," "handicapped," "ungraded" children who have been helped by the late Miss FARRELL, together with those who have worked with and under her, were to bring such symbols of their gratitude, additional rooms in the clinic, specially provided for these maladjusted little ones, would be necessary.

BUENOS AIRKS, Oct. 16. -- Public finances again attracted close attention in business circles last week. Much publicity was given the efforts of national, provincial and municipal authorities to reduce and balance budgets for the next fiscal year. Finance Minister Hueyo announced that he expected to have a balanced budget ready this week for submission to the extra session of Congress.

As football heads into the final week of the first month of play in the 1932 season, the strength and the weaknesses of the teams are beginning to take more definite shape. From now until the close of the campaign there will he less guessing, for nearly all of the larger elevens of the country have met foes well Worthy of their standing.

PADERBORN, Germany, Oct. 16 (AP). -- In his speech here today Chancellor von Papen, after having declared Germany's import quotas had been devised to save German agriculture, announced that a big advertising campaign abroad for German goods was planned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At lunch a few days ago I chanced to meet a happy-go-lucky bachelor friend who is always a joy to those who know him, because he makes light of every trouble and even cracks jokes about the present grave business depression.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16. -- Thousands of persons are homeless and many injured, although only two are known dead, as a result of tropical rains which have beaten down upon all of Mexico almost without a letup since early Friday.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, told an investigating committee of the County Lawyers' Association, it became known last night, that his party's endorsement of City Court Justice Aron Steuer, after his nomination for the Supreme Court by Tammany Hall, resulted from Mr. Macy's friendship for Max D. Steuer and was not part of a political deal.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- "Were the Canadian Government or the pools to take 100,000,000 bushels of wheat at 30 cents a bushel and dump it into the lake, they would be out $30,000,000," said Arthur W. Cutten, referring to reports from Winnipeg that the Canadian pools were sustaining he wheat market there at 50 cents a bushel for December wheat.

When the Manhattan Savings Institution sold to Harry H. Kutner the dwellings at 149 and 151 W. 119th St., at an indicated consideration of about $35,000 Mr. Kutner gave back a purchase-money mortgage for $31.000, payable in five years, at 5 per cent, with $250 to be paid off semi-annually beginning Feb. 16, 1934.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Hoover in his Des Moines speech refers to the financial world disaster and stresses the point that the "shocks of this earthquake ran from Vienna to Berlin, from Berlin to London, and from London to Asia and South America" and then to us.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- President Hoover returned to the capital today heartened by the way he had been received in Cleveland and along the way, and determined on further vigorous campaigning.

THAT was a very nice, peaceful Saturday the football players had. Nobody down except Yale, Army, Navy, Dartmouth, Syracuse, Wisconsin, Nebraska and such teams as that. What is the country coming to? Whither are we drifting?

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, commander of the Twenty-seventh Division during the World War, announced yesterday his active support of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H, Lehman, Democratic nominee for Governor, and became a vice chairman of the independent citizens' committee supporting Colonel Lehman's candidacy.

Speaking at meetings in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday, Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, assailed as "economy hysteria" the kind of retrenchment which would curtail education or reduce funds for unemployment relief.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Replying to President Hoover's assertion that conditions would be worse under a Democratic administration, Repreentative Joseph W. Byrns, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, charged today that the Hoover Administration had cost the American people $20,000,000,000.

Confronted with some of the most important problems which ever have faced it, the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners is to be opened today in Dallas, Texas. For two days the group will hold its deliberations there, and for the following two days it will move to Galveston.

The Needlework Guild of America, Inc., will start during the first week in November its annual nation-wide collection of garments for the needy, it was announced yesterday. The guild, founded nearly fifty years ago in Philadelphia by Mrs. John Wood Stewart, has become one of the largest charitable organizations in the world with branches in nearly 800 towns and cities throughout the United States and in Hawaii and Panama.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 7. -- Certain Argentine interests not associated with the government have been putting out "feelers" recently for a revolving credit of about $200,000,000 to be issued by American bankers and to be used exclusively for the payment of interest and sinking fund obligations on Argentine loans in the United States.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 17. -- The story of Missouri politics this year is the story of a boss and beer. Both are helpful to the Democrats; the boss because he has built up a powerful party machine in Kansas City and Jackson County, from which a Democratic majority is expected; beer, because that is St. Louis's chief concern, and the Democratic national platform declared in favor of immediate modification of the Volstead act.

The 180 economists who denounce the Hawley-Smoot tariff in a petition to the President cannot be charged with hindsight. All of them signed an earlier petition presented at the White House on May 4, 1930, before this tariff was enacted. They then predicted that instead of "protecting" American interests it would jeopardize our foreign trade, since other countries "cannot permanently buy from us unless they are permitted to sell."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Robert Robinson, pastor of the Presbyterian Church, Asbury, N. J., was elected Moderator of the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey at the annual meeting of the synod here today. He will succeed the Rev. Addison B. Collins, pastor of the Logan Memorial Church, Audubon, as the leader of 387 churches with a communicant membership of 137,249.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt last night stepped out of the silent role traditionally played by the wives of Presidential candidates and made at a Democratic rally in Riverdale a political speech.

With the weather decidedly unfavorable, hunters who set out up-State Sunday to start the 1932 duck-hunting season were more or less disappointed, according to all reports received yesterday. In most places where ducks land fog, rain and a high temperature kept them away.

PARIS, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Commenting today on the fall of the American dollar, Le Matin said it did not appear that the "intrinsic financial situation in the United States authorizes any serious alarm regarding the stability of American money." The dollar dropped to 25.45 francs from Friday's close of 25.4925.

A referendum by ballot to ascertain the views of the members on the various kinds of tax legislation to come before Congress and the State legislatures is being conducted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced here yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Stanley Poreda, Jersey City's contender for the heavyweight crown, hammered out an easy ten-round victory over Tommy Loughran, former world's light heavyweight champion, at the Arena tonight before a crowd of 9,000.
The text of Controller Berry's letter asking for municipal loans totaling $35,000,000 and the refusal of Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank, follow:

ATLANTA, Oct. 17. -- A combination of rain and harder opposition brought a virtual halt to scoring activities in the Southern Conference during the week-end, and Casey Kimbrell of Auburn kept first place, though he did not leave the bench.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The hockey-playing status of George Owen, former Harvard football star and Boston Bruins' defense player, was in the doubtful stage tonight as Manager Art Ross announced training plans of his club at Quebec. Owen, connected with a Boston, brokerage firm, will not decide about resuming his hockey career until Nov. 1.

MONTREAL, Oct. 17 (Canadian Press) . -- Evidence of Mrs. Clarence Paulsen of Spokane, Wash., remarried widow of the late Francis Phillips, was heard today in defense of the action taken by the Rockville Centre Trust Company of Rockville Centre, N. Y., administrators of the estate of John Phillips, against the Chase National Bank of New York, administrators of the estate of Francis Phillips.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Supreme Court decided today that the Federal Power Commission, has authority to determine "the actual legitimate investment" of power companies in hydroelectric projects built under Federal license and to require the companies to conform their books to the commission's findings.

In appointing Justice CAMPBELL of the Supreme Court as Chancellor, Governor MOORE of New Jersey doubtless had in mind the receivership scandal and the urgency of reform demanded by business men. The Governor has been criticized by Senator RICHARDS for his "unseemly rush" in filling the vacancy caused by the death of Chancellor WALKER.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Governor Ritchie of Maryland and Henry J. Allen, former Governor of Kansas, debated the political issues of 1932 tonight as the feature of a forum marking the dedication of George R. Thorne Hall, on McKinlock Campus of Northwestern University.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 17. -- Miss Ruth Taylor, commissioner of the Westchester County Department of Public Welfare and the only woman department head in Westchester County, announced today that she was running for election to the office she now holds by appointment on the sole issue of her record in office and the demonstration of her intention to carry out the principles of the late V. Everit Macy, founder of her department.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The German automotive industry won today its petition for an injunction restraining the Ford Motor Company of Germany at Cologne from designating its new "Baby Ford" as an all-German-built car.

The Democratic National Committee was preparing yesterday to throw its heavy reserves into the fight for Governor Roosevelt's election to meet the challenge of the vigorous campaign recently decided upon by President Hoover.

When all but two of the State's witnesses had testified yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Mrs. June Martin, 25 years old a show girl, accused of strangling Miss Florence Miller, 32, another show girl, last July in their room in the Hotel Richmond in West Forty-sixth Street, the defendant pleaded guilty of manslaughter in the second degree.
MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Star today publishes the following in its financial columns:

Politics is a game that brings out the finest instincts. Candidates for local and State offices and for Congress are eager to save their own bacon; only too willing, if necessary, to make a trade or deal for votes. On the other hand, when their own skins are involved, they can't say enough for the national ticket.

Places of cotton generally were tower yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here under Southern Felling, liquidation and the action of the york markets. The liquidation appeared to have been promoted by the failure of unfavorable weather reports to sumulac buying of cotton.

BELGRADE, Oct. 17. -- Great excitement was caused here this morning over the news that Dr. Matchek, leader of the Croat Peasant party, had been arrested and put in the jail at Zagreb on account of an interview printed in an English newspaper. In the interview Dr. Matchek was alleged to have said in reply to a question as to whether the Croats would employ force to free themselves from Serbian domination:

Accused of participation in a new "racket," wheneby unemployed persons with small savings were induced to invest them in a trading-stamp company in return for jobs and then deprived of their money, two men were arrested yesterday by detectives of the Attorney General's staff and locked up in Manhattan Police Headquarters.

Demonstrations of new machines desisgned to facilitate psychological tests in business and the reporting of a sharp gain in the demand for office-equipment devices since July featured the opening yesterday of the twenty-ninth annual National Business Show at the Grand Central Palace.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 17. -- At the conclusion of severe criticism in Parliament tonight of the trade agreement between Canada and Great Britain, W.L. Mackenzie King, the Liberal leader, asked the Speaker to rule whether an Opposition amendment, as read, could be moved to the motion to ratify the treaty.

Men flocked to Grand Central Palace yesterday to gaze in wonder at the transformations effected by finger wavers, eyelash pasters, manicures, hair dressers, hair dyers, wig makers and other beauty practitioners at the opening of the four-day American Beauty and Styles Exposition.

The Citizens Union put itself on record as favoring the defeat of Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic nominee for Mayor, in its rating of local candidates made public last night. The organization endorsed Lewis H. Founds, Republican nominee, and declared that Morris Hillquit, the Socialist candidate, was "qualified."

It is customary to say of an honest and upright citizen that "his word is as good as his bond." Last January the hankers were willing to take Mayor WALKER'S promises of economy and financial reform at their face value. They loaned the city millions of dollars, only to discover later that the Administration's pledge was written in water.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Police are making extensive preparations to meet the menace of a gigantic unemployed demonstration planned for tomorrow night near the County Hall, Westminster, where the London County Council will be sitting. The County Hall is on the opposite side of the Thames from the Houses of Parliament, past which several organized battalions of unemployed will march en route to their assembly place.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- With the United States experts sailing tomorrow for the meeting of the preparatory committee of the world economic conference, Chancellor von Papen's pronouncement of yesterday on Germany's private foreign indebtedness was regarded here today as likely to assume immediate importance.

The recent deal whereby the Giants traded Pitchers Walker and Mooney, Catcher O'Farrell and Outfielder Allen to the Cardinals for Catcher Mancuso and Pitcher Starr was merely the beginning of a general rebuilding of the team, it developed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Continued competition from low-priced foreign products has set up a menace to American industry and in a number of cases has forced closing of plants or curtailment of operations according to complaints filed with the Treasury Department.
The Columbia University campus, which was aroused last year by charges of alleged professionalism against its football team, is now disturbed over the eligibility of members of the university band.

At the request of defense counsel, Magistrate William A. Farrell granted yesterday an adjournment until 2 P. M. today in the cases of seven men and thirteen women arraigned in Essex Market Court on charges growing out of a demonstration on Saturday in front of the former home of Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio at 225 East Twelfth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from "Observer," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, regarding the dangerous intersection at Twenty-third Street. and Tenth Avenue corroborates the viewpoint expressed by the Twenty-third Street Association to the Police Commissioner more than three yeare ago.

A charge that The Literary Digest's Presidential poll erred in its forecast in 1916, which was contained in a statement made last Sunday by Everett Sanders, Republican National chairman was denied yesterday by William Seaver Woods, editor of that publication.

Driven to the wall yesterday by the flat refusal of bankers to lend the city more money unless the 1933 budget was reduced substantially, the Board of Estimate slashed the budget by about $75,000,000 and, in Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee's opinion, sacrificed the five-cent subway fare by abandoning the Delaney plan to make possible two-thirds of the total saving.

The steady downpour yesterday failed to keep the New York University football squad from engaging in a lengthy workout at Ohio Field, where preparations were begun for Saturday's battle with Colgate at the Yankee Stadium.

Terming himself no "stop-gap for any Mayor," Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate to fill out former Mayor Walker's unexpired term, publicly placed himself on record yesterday as a candidate for the full four-year Mayoralty term to be filled in 1933.

Those who have been wondering how "The Good Earth" Could be translated into a play have their answer now at the Guild Theatre, where the dramatic version by Owen and Donald Davis turned up last evening. Pearl S. Buck's objective novel cannot be made into a play.

ALBANY, Oct. 17.--Franklin D. Roosevelt will depart tomorrow morning for a swing into the mid-West, the border States and the South, in an effort to gather in the electoral votes of hitherto doubtful territory.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 17. -- England defeated Ireland by 1-0 in the annual soccer football match today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 (AP). -- An injury to Alfredo Harringtori, a member of Argentina's international polo squad, today lowered the chances of the South Americans to turn back the United States in the Argentine open and international series next month.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17 (AP). -- A pastoral letter by Archbishop Pascual Diaz denouncing any attempt at armed resistance by Catholics was read in all churches yesterday. All Catholics were cautioned to obey the laws of Mexico and to avoid any movement that might be construed as resistance.

The foreign missionary is serving with increasing effectiveness in China, Japan and India, Dr. Arlo A. Brown, president of Drew University, Madison, N. J., told the New York Chapter, Chaplains' Association, of the Army of the United States, at its monthly luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Taft.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noted with interest THE TIMES editorial concerning the St. Lawrence Waterway. A good summary of the report of the Chamber of Commerce at the State of New York outlining the negative view of this question was given.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my opinion, the re-election of President Hoover is absolutely essential to a speedy and effective termination of the grave depression with which our nation has been confronted.

The plea that only in the Republican party lies the way toward intelligent retrenchment in public expenditures with consequent easing of the tax burden, was made by Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, in an address last night at the Central Opera House, East Fifty-seventh Street and Third Avenue.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Professor Albert Einstein had attempted to surrender his salary and terminate his contract with the University of Berlin because of his new obligations in the United States, the Jewish Telegraphic Agency reported today, but the government refused to permit him.

Quotations and conditions in all sections of the money market at the opening of the new week started off where they had closed the preceding period-rates were maintained without change upon every class of accommodation. Business was small in all departments.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- C. E. Davison's Hot Shot, in a spectacular nose finish, conquered Miss Melody in the featured race at Sportsman's Park today. Going to the front at the break of the barrier in the five-furlong sprint, Hot Shot, piloted by Jockey E. Arcaro, made every post a winning one.

Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt, Republican nominee for re-election to Congress in the Seventeeth Congressional District, announced last night that she would support a resolution calling for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment or introduce one herself and that to bring about an immediate change in the handling of the liquor problem she would present early at the "short" session of Congress in December, a resolution calling for modification of the Volstead law along the following lines:

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- The first welfare conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America opened today at Boston Junior League headquarters, with delegates from all parts of the country registering for the five-day session. At the formal opening dinner tonight, Mrs. John G. Pratt, president of the association and principal speaker, urged the members to focus their attenion on welfare problems.

While leaders of liberal and progressive thought endorsed yesterday Morris HUlquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, labor unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, and representing more than 250,000 organized workers in this city, came to his support with a call for a conference of labor organizations, to be held on Thursday, at which action will be taken to promote his candidacy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- High on Mount St. Katherine in the Sinai Desert, on the summit of which, according to some scholars, Moses received the Ten Commandments, the astronomers of the Smithsonian Institution are about to establish a solar observatory.

Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald and Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein, in the presence of many afficials and representatives of welfare organizations, opened yesterday the initial session of the experimental Adolescents' Court.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 17 (AP). -- A voluntary petition in bankruptcy for Booth Fisheries Company, a Delaware corporation, was filed in the United States District Court today.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman will begin his active campaign for the Governorship here tonight at the National Democratic Club, in an address accepting the Democratic nomination. Since his nomination he has been confining his addresses to general statements on political issues but at his headquarters in the Chanin Building it was promised yesterday that beginning with, his acceptance speech he would wage a campaign of frank discussion of all the State issues.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17. -- The dispute between the federal government and the State of Oaxaca regarding jurisdiction over the archaeological discoveries at Monte Alban was settled this evening, when the Supreme Court judges voted 9 to 3 in favor of the central government.
ABSENT FATHER, a play in three acts, by Francis DeWitt. Staged by Lionel Bevans; setting by Yellenti; produced by James E. Kenney and Joseph Levitt. At the Vanderbilt Theatre.

The action of the Board of Estimate in adopting a program of subway financing by fifty-year bonds in place of the Delaney four-year plan was described by bankers as a good start. They made it plain, however, that this step alone would not warrant the extension of further credits to the city.

HAVANA, Oct. 17. -- The conference scheduled for today between President Machado and the directors of the Sugar Institute, the official body controlling the sugar industry, at which the figures for the 1933 sugar crop were to be decided was indefinitely postponed, according to Viriato Gutierrez, president of the institute.

GENEVA, Oct. 17. -- The thirteenth League of Nations Assembly ended today, after leaders stressed that responsibility for the present dangerous world situation lies with the dogma of national sovereignty, not with the League's doctrine of international cooperation.

Four exhibitions of particularly related interest opened yesterday. At the Art Centre the first national exhibition of photographs for commerce, industry and science opened with a private view last night and will continue through the month. It is the expressed purpose of the exhibition to present "applied photography -- photography for a specific use * * * not subjective and romantic but definitely objective and realistic."

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Polly Walker, the American actress, has been notified that she must leave England. Her permit will expire in a short time. The action of the Home Office is in accordance with normal procedure in the case of foreigners permitted to appear on the English stage.
BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The German Government is not expected to take any action for the present in regard to foreign private indebtedness.
The'text of Mr. Macy's letter to the County Lawyers' Association on the bipartisan bench deal follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Robert Vile of Norristown, Pa., defeated Harry Oswald of Pittsburgh, 100 points to 16, tonight in the second of the Eastern district qualifying matches for the world's pocket billiard championship tournament. In the opening contest, Edward McGeahean of this city triumphed over Edward Leonard of York, Pa.

FRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 17. -- Princeton held open house this afternoon at the Osborne Field House, where the new football coach Herbert O. Crisler, his assistants and athletic officials were hosts at the annual luncheon for newspaper men.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The next speech of President Hoover in his "invigorated" campaign for re-election will be delivered at Detroit Saturday night.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 17 (AP). -- A $10,000 extortion plot against Homer L. Ferguson, president of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, was believed by police to have been thwarted today with the arrest of Herbert Young, 44, a former employe of the shipyard.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 17.--A Houdon bust of George Washington, one of three known to exist and reputed to be worth $15,000, was returned today to Washington Headquarters here, from which it had been stolen last Monday night by the same thief who earlier that day had stolen Frederic Remington's statue "The Bronco Buster" from the Free Library at Gloversville, N.Y.
ATLANTA, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Rivers in three Southern States were at flood stage today, causing isolation of homes, interruption of traffic, a train accident and a threat of further overflow.

Albany, N. Y. A syndicate comprising Hallgarten Co. and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. made the high bid yesterday for an issue of $765,000 city of Albany (N. Y.) bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1932, and due from 1933 to 1952, against keen competition afforded by fourteen other bidders.

Columbia headed its undefeated football team yesterday toward its annual encounter with Cornell here a week from Saturday. A victory over the Ithaca eleven is the main hope and ambition of the Blue and White and for the next two weeks Coach Lou Little plans to concentrate on perfecting the playing of his pupils with the Cornell game in mind.

WOODMERE, L. I., Oct. 17. -- Worried by the domestic triangle in which her husband, Guy Phillips, English actor and dramatic instructor, had become involved, Mrs. Jean Phillips turned on the gas in the kitchen of the Phillips apartment at 1,074 Cedar Lane here early, this morning.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17. -- Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris and J. Medina of Zacatecas met tonight in the final game of the ninth and last round of the international chess tournament at the Press Social Centre and played to an adjournment after forty moves had been recorded.

VIENNA, Oct. 17. -- Serious fighting broke out at Vienna University this morning when Hitlerite students, with shouts of "revenge for Simmering" -- alluding to yesterday's shooting between Socialists and Hitlerites -- violently attacked Jewish students.

The Amtorg Trading Corporation, Soviet commercial agency in the United States, issued yesterday a statement rejecting the proposal for increasing trade between the United States and Soviet Russia by means of the use of Soviet import goods as collateral for commercial credits.

The Civic Council of Brooklyn, meeting yesterday in the Hotel Granada, adopted a resolution advocating the abolition of the State mandate providing minimum salary schedules for teachers and other city employes. The resolution, which was introduced by George Boochever of the New York Property Owners' Association and chairman of the council's committee on city finance, was adopted after debate, 22 to 9.

SENATOBIA, Miss., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Conflicting reports tonight said that from three to seven Negroes had been killed today by enraged posses scouring the hills of Tate County for Jesse Williams, 45-year-old Negro who killed Deputy Sheriff Walker Williams yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Crotchety as the human race may be, there is method in its madness when using elevators and but little fault can be found with its elevator habits when the service is adequate. Most elevator passengers are undoubtedly impatient because they have a definite objective and want to reach it on time.
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Prime Minister MacDonald said today: "I profoundly regret Germany's refusal to go to Geneva for reasons the substance of which it is difficult for me to detect."

BERLIN, Oct. 17.--The Boerse was quiet today, the public apparently awaiting further developments and professional traders waiting for the public to return to the market. The tone, however, was sufficiently firm to keep price changes in a narrow range, both with reference to Saturday's quotations and between today's opening and closing levels.

The failure of parents as individuals and of school systems to meet adequately the problem of child growth and training and the "fallacy of standardization" in the molding of the growing child were stressed yesterday at the opening sessions of the two-day conference of the Child Study Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

DUBLIN, Oct. 17. -- Without any demonstration, Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Council, returned here today from his futile parley on land annuities with British Ministers on Friday and Saturday. The deadlock was reflected in Bank of Ireland and Guinness shares, which fell sharply on the opening of the Dublin Stock Exchange, and business generally was almost at a standstill.

A new attack upon State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter for accepting the Democratic nomination for a Supreme Court judgeship was made yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, in a letter to the New York County Lawyers Association, urging a full investigation of the matter.

A special sale of Winter coats will be held today at the Lots for Little Shop in aid of several philanthropic enterprises. The proceeds of all sales are devoted to the needs of the Cardinal Gibbons Institute in Ridge, Md.; the Helpers of the Holy Souls, the Society of Catholic Medical Missionaries and the Barat Settlement.

"Camille," in a new version and with Lillian Gish in the title role, will begin a two-weeks' engagement at the Morosco Theatre on Oct. 31. Robert Edmond Jones has staged and designed the settings for the production which was first seen during the Summer at Central City, Col. Delos Chappell is producing the revival.

Mme. Maria Jeritza, former dramatic soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, arrived yesterday from Europe in the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to begin a concert tour and to sing over the radio for the National Broadcasting Company. Her tour will commence at Cedar Rapids, Iowa, on Oct. 24, in preparation for which she has learned many English songs.

Last week there appeared in these columns a dissertation on the nature of beer. Special reference was made to the alcoholic content of that drink, the whole being done in cadences measured by weight and volume. It now seems fitting to learn about wines and spirits.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to call attention to the situation that confronts the Brooklyn Public Library.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP). -- The Supreme Court today dealt with two cases of national importance in a rapid disposal of many actions accumulated during the Summer recess.

COMMERCE, Mo., Oct. 17.--The long-cherished desire of Denver Wright, St. Louis leather goods dealer, to participate in a lion hunt was frustrated today when Deputy Sheriff Tom Hotchkiss killed two circus lionesses which Wright had liberated on a small Mississippi River island for a hunt.

ROME, Oct. 17. -- In the midst of the gravest and most widespread crisis agriculture has ever known the eleventh meeting of the general assembly of the International Institute of Agriculture convened this morning in the Villa Borghese.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Senator Swanson, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Committee, said today that President Hoover was late in presenting the World War and its economic consequences as the administration's "alibi" for depression in the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- State's Attorney John A. Swanson today issued a reply to Athens reports that a plot was afoot to kidnap Samuel Insull and thus get him back to the United States for trial. Mr. Swanson said:

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Dominick De Lucco, who recently asked Governor Roosevelt to declare his stand on payment of the bonus, made public a letter today in which the Presidential nominee said that after cutting Federal expenditures "it will be time to consider additional expenditures from any surplus in the Treasury."

By its vote to abandon the four-year bond financing of new subways in favor of Controller Charles W. Berry's fifty-year bond method, the Tammany-controlled bloc in the Board of Estimate has paved the way for early abandonment of the 5-cent fare, Acting Mayor McKee charged last night at the close of the final hearings on the tentative budget for 1933.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- The Harvard coaches did not lose a moment today preparing their varsity football players for the Dartmouth game.

A general shift of captains of the larger ships of the French Line, including the transfer of Captain Rene Pugnet of the Paris to command the new super-liner T-6, which will be launched on Oct. 29 at the Penhoet shipyards at St. Nazaire, has been agreed upon by officials of the line in Paris.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- After a firm opening today the stock markets Weakened under profit-taking, particularly in British Government funds, where an early advance brought speculative selling. Home industrials were firm and the generally better tone was fully maintained.

There was a further decrease in automobile production last week, but the decline was only slightly greater than of normal seasonal proportions. The adjusted index consequently shows only a slight recession to 16.6 for the week ended Oct. 15 from 16.7 for the preceding week.

A charge that the New Tork Telephone Company does not permit the reserve fund accruing from depreciation costs on the new hand sets, or "French" telephones, to reduce its maintenance charges on these sets, was made yesterday by counsel for the Public Service Commission in the resumed hearing on the complaint of the City Affairs Committee against the "excessive" monthly rate of 25 cents on these telephones.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Government borrowing at the equivalent of an interest rate of .14 per cent, setting another low record, was announced by Secretary Mills today.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 18. -- Manchukuo's Foreign Minister, Hsieh Chieh-shih, arrived in Tokyo this morning.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 per cent for the best names. Friday -- per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper.

PASADENA, Cal., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Astronomers and physicists here were loath today to discuss the reports from Berlin of Dr. Albert Einstein's assertion that the birth of the earth and the beginning of the expansion of the universe occurred probably 10,000,000,000 years ago.

KINGSTON, Ont., Oct. 17. -- Order was restored behind the walls of Portsmouth penitentiary tonight, after a riot in which one-third of the 906 prisoners defiantly forced the departure of a hastily summoned military detachment by threatening to burn themselves to death unless the soldiers withdrew.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17. -- Adoption of definite standards for graduate training in every clinical surgical specialty as a prerequisite for qualification of any physician who wants to become a general surgeon or a specialist in a particular field was urged here tonight by Dr. J, Bentley Squier, Professor of Urology, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York.

LEIPZIG, Oct. 17. -- Argument in the suit of the State of Prussia and others against the Reich before the State bench of the Federal Supreme Court, which opened Oct. 10, closed this evening. Chief Justice Bumke stated he could not set a date for the decision, but he hoped it would be handed down Oct. 25, provided the court found the evidence submitted adequate.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17. -- Many persons were killed last night when a long passenger train drawn by two locomotives crashed into a train of freight cars at the station of Lublino, about seven miles from this city. The passenger train was crowded with travelers returning from Sochi, Caucasian Summer and health resort.
THE THINGS THAT ARE CAESAR'S, a tragedy in three acts, by Paul Vincent Carroll. Presented by the Abbey Theatre Irish Players under the management of Alber Wickes, Inc. At the Martin Beck Theatre.

James Butler, president of the Empire City Racing Association, which began its Fall meeting yesterday at the Yonkers oval, scored a double with Apprentice and Musing, both homebreds from his East View farm. Jockey L. Bernius piloted both winners.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Gilbert Elston, who suffered a fractured skull last Spring when his mount went down in a race at Washington Park, is riding more brilliantly than ever, and today he was at his best. In the first five races he accepted four mounts and on each occasion returned to grace the winner's circle.

The Explorers Club moved last night into its new quarters in the Majestic Apartments, at 10 West Seventy-fifth Street. Some two hundred members went there to see the decorations, talk to the parrot, "Doc," and listen to Captain Bob Bartlett tell of his Summer's trip to Greenland.

ATHENS, Oct. 17. -- Samuel Insull, under indictment for grand larceny and embezzlement in Chicago as a result of the collapse of his utilities interests, told newspaper men today he had received a cablegram warning him of a plot by the Chicago authorities to kidnap him.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Condemning by implication but not specifically the use of lotteries, card games and dances "as means of raising church funds, the United Lutheran Church in America today at its biennial convention gave its endorsement only to "the scriptural method of free-will gift."

Candidates Sadly Wanting. Socialists now speak of 2,000,000 votes for NORMAN THOMAS. Sometimes, when, one observes the behavior of President HOOVER and Governor ROOSEVELT, a protest vote of two millions would not seem excessive.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 17. -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who prefers, for the next three weeks, to be called "Cornelius Whitney, candidate for Representative from the First Congressional District," summed up the issues of his campaign at his home here tonight as "prohibition and unemployment."

The Red Raiders of the Chenango are coming to town. From the sylvan fastnesses of peaceful Hamilton, N. Y., they will descend upon Gotham in their red jerseys and red moleskins to engage New York University's powerful eleven in what shapes up as the big game of the local season thus far.

If geologists are sure of anything, it is the age of the earth's rocks. Uranium and thorium, disintegrate at a measurable rate until at last they are reduced to lead. Professor KOVARIK of Yale has therefore reached the conclusion that a uranium-bearing rock from Russia must be 1,852 million years old and the earth still older.

Miss Libby Miller, secretary to Rosa Ponselle, Metropolitan Opera star, said yesterday the singer was forced to interrupt her singing of "Home, Sweet Home" during a concert at Hartford, Conn., on Sunday because of worry over the condition of her mother.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17. -- Members of the Harvard faculty polled by The Harvard Crimson, undergraduate newspaper, have expressed their preference as follows:

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 17. -- State troopers and a civilian searching party found the wreckage of a monoplane and the bodies of two men in the undergrowth on the Kittatinny Ridge near Millbrook at noon today. The pilot was identified as W. W. Brunner, 25 years old, of Duke enter, Pa., and his passenger was Harry C. Johnson, 26 years old, of Emporium, Cameron County, Pa.

Wall Street's explanation for yesterday's moderate reaction on the Stock Exchange was that speculative operations were being conducted cautiously and that they were arousing less interest than they ordinarily do. The total turnover was small, amounting to 770,000 shares, compared with 2,019,000 shares, on Friday, the last previous five-hour day.

Prices of bonds showed minor irregularities in quiet trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange. The turnover was only 57,387,000. A feature was the strength in Canadian Government and railroad issues. Domestic rail bonds averaged slightly lower, while industrials and utilities improved somewhat.

A discovery, which, it was said, would eliminate the source of a series of previously unexplained deaths on the operating table, was announced yesterday at the opening sessions of the eleventh annual Congress of Anesthetics at the Hotel MoAlpin.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17. -- Yale football coaches today staged a half-hour signal practice for the eleven that opened against Brown on Saturday, the only changes being that Johnny Kilcullen was at right tackle, George (Gil) Wright was at left end and Johnny Overall was at right end.

The bankers and brokers' committee of the United Hospital Fund, comprising eighty-six bankers and brokers who are trustees or directors of the fifty-five hospitals identified with the fund, began yesterday its annual appeal for funds. James Speyer of Speyer Co. is chairman of the committee, and Charles H. Sabin, chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company, is associate chairman.

Declaring that at least $10,000,000 a month should be spent for public unemployment relief in New York State this Winter, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration estimated yesterday that at least 10 per cent of the population of the State would be dependent for existence on subsidies from public or private agencies.

The impact of psychology is marked in novels, biographies and histories; it has revolutionized educational methods, forced medicine to extend its horizon and seems to be leading to a "psychological revolution" that will further change and rationalize the world, Dr. Edward S. Robinson, Professor of Psychology at Yale University, writes in "Man as Psychology Sees Him," published today by Macmillan.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Taft 2d have returned to 300 Park Avenue for the season.

The Whitney Museum of American Art opened with a private view yesterday its first exhibition of the season -- a memorial show of oils, gouaches, drawings and lithographs by the late Glenn O. Coleman, well-known American artist, who died last May.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals dissolved today Judge Walter C. Lindley's injunction restraining four banks in New York from unloading on the market large blocks of stock of the Insull operating companies. The securities, with a present market value of approximately $16,000,000, were pledged as collateral by the bankrupt Corporation Securities Company and Insull Utility Investments, Inc., for loans aggregating $25,500,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Opening here tonight his coast-to-coast speaking tour in behalf of Governor Roosevelt, Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska bitterly arraigned "partisanship," without whose "sinister influence," he said, President Hoover had no chance of re-election, and then he accused leading members of the Republican party, from the President down, of practicing hypocrisy and deception in a bid for votes.

A plea for the "forgotten man in medicine" was voiced last night by Dr. John A. Hartwell, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, who urged "the more complete education of the individual doctor who is serving the public."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- In his address here tonight on "Partisanship," Senator George W. Norris, Progressive Republican of Nebraska, said:

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, arrived on the liner Europa today for a short visit, chiefly to receive the Melchett Medal at a dinner of the Fuel Institute Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Wheat met no material pressure today on the Board of Trade here and, while scattered Eastern liquidation was in evidence early, the surplus in the pit was absorbed by local shorts and professionals and a rally of around 3/4 cent a bushel followed.

The last word in the President's appeal of Sunday night must be the first word for every citizen facing the coming "Winter of want." It is not as if we could not give. Mr. BAKER'S statement accompanying the appeal of the President is full of hope:

Lewis Conger, dealers in household appliances, have leased more than 11,000 pquare feet in the Port of New York Authority's new terminal warehouse at Eighth Avenue and Sixteenth Street. E. V. Lewis, president of the company, said.

Hermann Oelrichs of 942 Fifth Avenue was initiated as a member of the patriotic Society of Tammany last night, becoming a brother of such Democrats as John F. Curry, Alfred E. Smith, James J.. Walker, George W. Olvany, John P. O'Brien and 28,000 others.

ESKIE CLARK and Arthur Sampson of the Harvard staff were on their way to Philadelphia to scout Dartmouth in the Penn game. The train was rolling along and both men were reading newspapers. Sampson looked up and said:

E. A. Pierce Co., one of the largest New York Stock Exchange firms, will announce soon the formation of a general management investment trust. It will be the first one of its type organized and sponsored by a prominent firm here since several months before the stock markets crashed late in 1929.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 17. -- Michigan State's football team tonight started preparing for the four major gridiron assignments still on the schedule. Fordham University is the first obstacle and the Spartans will make their first appearance in New York Saturday.
ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 17 (AP). -- Here is the itinerary for Governor Roosevelt's eight-day campaign tour which begins tomorrow morning:

With the smallest transactions of any full day in nearly three months, stocks declined irregularly yesterday, the largest losses for common shares being 2 or 3 points and the "averages" falling somewhat less than a point. Only about 800,000 shares were dealt in.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 17 (AP). -- W. R. Coe, New York sportsman, had his green and white silks carried to a double victory through rain and mud today at Laurel. His Polonaise defeated two other 3-year-olds over the mile and a sixteenth of the featured Fairlee Purse and his 2-year-old Pomponius won the supporting Indigo Purse.

DENVER, Oct. 17 (AP). -- Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a telegram today to Fred Cummings, Democratic candidate for Congress from the Second district, struck back at charges that he advocated a lower tariff on sugar.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18. -- Captain Carl Hageman of the Harvard varsity football team has been awarded the Francis H. Burr scholarship presented annually to the undergraduate who combines as nearly as possible Burr's remarkable qualities of character, leadership, athletic ability and scholarship, it was announced today.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Senator Robinson of Arkansis told a Kiwanis convention today that "it is high time the people be given a voice in determining how the manufacture and traffic in liquor shall be regulated or prevented."

The "strangulation' which has resulted in the present financial situation in New York City began seven years ago when James J. Walker became Mayor, Lewis H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Repeating her fine showing on the occasion of her last outing at Lincoln Fields, Racing Commissioner S.S. Combs's Plumage, 4-year-old daughter of Ballot and Glyn, accounted for the Milldale Purse, feature event at Latonia today.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- The Boerse opened listelessly today, with slight recessions from yesterday's closing quotations. Business failed to develop and the general list of stocks continued to sag, but with the exception of a few issues -- notably Bremen Wool and German Atlantic Telegraph, which lost 3 1/2 and 2 points, respectively -- the net declines averaged only around 1 point.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- To produce conditions such as Colgate will encounter Saturday when it meets the N.Y.U. team in Yankee Stadium, Coach Andy Kerr today had the varsity scrimmaging uphill against Violet plays as the climax of a long practice.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 18. -- Repeating his assertion that his Republican opponent, Robert Low Bacon, was a "pre-election wet," Cornelius Whitney, Democratic candidate for Representative from the First District, declared here tonight that he had records to show that Mr. Bacon had been endorsed as "satisfactory to the dry cause," by the Anti-Saloon League in 1928.

The estate of John Manning Van Heusen, collar manufacturer, who died on Dec. 18, 1931, leaving $1,901,702 gross and $1,622,839 net, will go eventually to six institutions, the appraisal showed yesterday.

In the slightly jaundiced settings which on Monday were used in presenting Paul V. Carroll's tragedy of a mother's malign influence, the Abbey Players last night offered a play of another sort about a dominant female. This was "The FarOff Hills," an engaging little comedy by Lennox Robinson, which entered the Abbey repertory in Dublin about four years ago amid considerable pleasant acclaim.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 18. -- It is reported here, although disavowed officially, that the Bolivian Government has submitted to the Army General Staff a Paraguayan peace proposal so that the staff must share in responsibility for whatever decision is made.

Martin T. Manton, senior judge, of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, who on Aug. 26 named Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray Jr. as equity receivers for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, instructed them yesterday to appeal promptly from the recent order of District Court Judge John M. Woolsey, vacating the receivership and nullifying not only the appointments but all other acts and orders of Judge Manton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Loans of $43,377,726.22 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for meeting emergency relief needs in thirty-two States, Territories and political subdivisions were shown in figures issued by the corporation today. The largest amount, $14,000,000, was loaned to Illinois, Pennsylvania coming second with $5,842,183, and Ohio third with $4,600,472.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (AP). -- A gain of more than a half million in Democratic registration in California for the November election, reducing to less than 400,000 the Republican lead of nearly a million in 1928, was revealed today by an Associated Press tabulation of complete, semiofficial registration figures from all but one county in the State.

Strength in United States Government bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday contrasted with Irregular prices for foreign loans and generally lower Quotations for domestic corporation issues. Trading was more active than on Monday, but was still well below the $10,000,000 mark, which is generally considered an average day's turnover.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare covered the west course of the Merion Cricket Club today in 79 strokes to assume firstround leadership in the eighth annual tournament for the Dorothy Campbell Hurd Cup.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- State's Attorney Swanson announced today that he had uncovered evidence indicating that Samuel Insull and his brother Martin had transferred $8,000,000 of Middle West Utilities money to three brokerage firms and that much of this money had been lost.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- France's plan for disarmament and security was submitted today for examination to a study commission of the Council of National Defense presided over by Premier Herirot. With Joseph Paul-Boncour, Minister of War; Georges Leygues, Minister of Marine, and Paul Painleve, Minister of Air, Generals Weygand and Gamelin and the chiefs of staff of the Ministries of War, Marine and Air took part In the discussion.

Operations of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for the two months ended on Aug. 31, including operation by the receivers from Aug. 26 to 31 inclusive, resulted in a net loss of $1,316,013 before full rental requirements on Manhattan Railway modified guarantee stock, comparing with a loss of $698,878 for the corresponding two months in 1931.

William J. Bingham, director of athletics at Harvard, placed himself on record with Malcolm Farmer of Yale last night in standing against drastic curtailment of intercollegiate athletic competition, with particular reference to football.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and United States Senator Robert F. Wagner proclaimed their devotion to a liberal theory of government in which they conceived the State as a society of free individuals cooperating for their own self-development and mutual well-being, in the ceremonies formally notifying them of their nominations at the National Democratic Club last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Speculative operations continue to dominate the wheat market on the Board of Trade here to the exclusion of the action of stocks and cotton or other influences. An advance early today of around 3/4 cent a bushel was ascribed largely to local buying, and when the pit element tried to sell out it found support lacking and the upturn was lost.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The United States, in its diplomatic policy toward the Manchurian problem, has been actuated by a desire for peace, Stanley K. Hornbeck, chief of the Far Eastern division of the State Department, said tonight in an address before the Institute of International Affairs at the College of William and Mary at Williamsburg, Va.

Despite the fact that the air in the vicinity of Sixth Avenue and Fortysecond Street was surcharged with the trade rumors involving the New York Giants, Secretary Jim Tierney yesterday flatly declared the Giants at the moment were not closing a deal with, anybody.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Following is the text of Colonel Donovan's speech here:

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- President de Valera of the Irish Free State demanded the repayment of L400,000,000 (about $1,380,000,000) and an entirely new financial settlement with Great Britain when he was in London last week, Dominions Secretary Thomas told the House of Commons today.

Baron Craigmyle, better known as Lord Shaw of Dunfermline, leaned forward yesterday in his chair at the Hotel La Salle and, as bitterly as his genial manner would permit, denounced the ultra-nationalism or "falsetto nationalism" which, he declared, had erected tariff barriers to trade, prolonged the depression and stood in the way of world peace.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Indications that Jean Harlow, film star plans to fight any claims which the heirs of Dorothy Millette may make upon the estate of Paul Bern, Miss Harlow's husband, who committed suicide in Hollywood, were seen here today when the actress retained Albert E. Sheets of Sacramento as her lawyer.

Dominick Bellizzi scored the first triple of his career yesterday in the mud and rain at Empire City when he triumphed with Character, Careful Kitty and Happen, the lastnamed being the winner of the featured race.

Hundreds of thousands of acres of farm land, abandoned each year by farmers unable to pay taxes, can be saved from foreclosure if the farmers will turn to bird and fish culture, in the opinion of Dr. Jacob Lipman, Dean of the School of Agriculture at Rutgers University.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, warmly praised the war record of his Republican opponent, Colonel William J. Donovan, yesterday in an address before more than 300 veterans at a campaign luncheon in the Hotel New Yorker.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Two Princeton varsity elevens held a fifty-five-minute offensive scrimmage drill against the freshmen on University Field today at the conclusion of a two-hour practice session.

The initial budget reductions voted by the Board of Estimate as the result of warnings from the city's bankers, are largely "bookkeeping economies insufficient to solve the city's fiscal problems at a time when the crying need is for real housekeeping savings," in the opinion of the Citizens Budget Commission.

Charles Herbert (Chuck) Klein of the Phillies and James E. (Jimmy) Foxx of the Athletics, have been selected as the most valuable players in the National and American Leagues, respectively, for the 1932 season, it was announced yesterday.

Assistant United States Attorney Frederick Peper, in charge of prosecution of offenders of the Volstead act in the office of United States Attorney Howard W. Ameli in Brooklyn, received yesterday through the mail a printed card bearing the legend "Mason's, TRiangle 5-7758.
LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The stock markets were steadier today, but British funds were less active, profit-taking causing uncertainty.
Following is the text of Senator Robert F. Wagner's address at the National Democratic Club last night at the opening of the Democratic State-wide campaign:

The first trunk line to report for September, the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, showed yesterday a net income $172,000 below the total for September, 1931, which was one of the smallest, if not the smallest, declines of its kind reported by any railroad in recent months.

The sleepy faces of some 125 clerks and managers of the city's leading cordial shops were beaming appreciatively early yesterday morning, while their owners, who had crowded into the New Harlem Casino, 100 West 116th Street, showed interest in the promises being made by a delegate of the United Cordial Store Workers Union, Local 15.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Marvin Owen, brilliant third baseman of the Newark Bears, was voted the most valuable player in the International League by a committee of the circuit's baseball writers, The St. Louis Sporting News announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- President Hoover spent the entire afternoon alone in the Lincoln study at the White House preparing short speeches to be delivered at Charleston, W.Va.; Columbus, Toledo and possibly Marion, Ohio, and Ashland, Ky.
New hope for patients in advanced stages of tuberculosis was held out at yesterday's sessions of the Congress of Anesthetists here.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 18. -- Speaking in Italian, Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, wife of Representative Bacon, who is seeking re-election on the Republican ticket, defended her husband's record on the prohibition question at a meeting of the Italian Republican Club here today.

A composite opinion of 530 representatives of business firms that "the crisis of the depression and the low point of business activity were passed early last Summer" is contained in a report of a field survey to be published, today by the Standard Statistics Company.

A two-day examination of the practical shortcomings of government in metropolitan, areas in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, 'Pennsylvania and Delaware, compared with plans formulated during the last decade by the foremost experts of those States, was begun here yesterday at a public conference organized by the faculty of New York University.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- Opening the five-day conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Edward C. Lindeman, Professor in the New York School of Social Work, told 300 delegates that the world crisis should be made by no half-way solution, either socially or economically.

Buyers' Registrations Gained. An increase in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company today was granted a "work loan." of $3,000,000 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 18. -- In a letter to County Solicitor Carlisle Higgins, made public today, W.N. Reynolds, uncle and co-guardian of Z. Smith Reynolds, 20 year-old heir to $20,000,000 who was shot to death July 6, suggested that the indictments for murder against Mrs. Libby Holman Reynolds, the widow, and Albert (Ab) Walker be dropped and stated that the Reynolds family would not oppose such action.

Among the notables who have booked passage on the Italian liner Rex leaving today are Robert Clive, artist; Miss E.D. Bond. W.B.O. Field Jr., Colonel and Mrs. A. Guglielmetti, Mr. and Mrs. R.C. Jeffcott, Captain E. Van Winkle Keen, A.P. A. Meyer, C.D. Winslow, Mr. and Mrs. E. Ducrot and Thomas Morgan.

Senator Claude A. Swanson, ranking Democratic member of the Foreign Relations Committee said yesterday that Chancellor Von Papen's statement that Germany could not pay her debts in cash emphasized the necessity for a Democratic victory to insure downward revision of the tariff.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 18. -- Prisoner 40886 will put aside his blue-gray denim uniform tomorrow or Thursday and Scarface Al Capone, Chicago's erstwhile gang chieftain, will emerge from the Atlanta Federal penitentiary to wage another legal battle for his freedom.

William H. Johnston, 52 years old, shot and killed himself yesterday forenoon in his room, in the Hotel Biltmore, just before he was to have appeared with Allen Branin, a salesman, in Judge Koenig'a part of General Sessions for trial on an indictment charging they defrauded a Philadelphia contractor of $15,000 in January, 1931, through misrepresenting the value of stock.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 18. -- The classic political phrase which in Kentucky describes in a pre-election situation that nothing conceivable will change is. "The hog's eye is sot."

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Prohibition was declared to be an underlying factor in high taxes, unemployment and the business depression by Governor Ritchie of Maryland in an address today at a Democratic organization luncheon in the Sherman Hotel.

Dr. Francis M. Schirp, 63 years old, of 3,257 Parkside Place, the Bronx, and William Rieman, 67, of 209 East 169th Street, the Bronx, who were arrested late Monday on complaint made by five former employes of the Empire Trading Corporation of 11 West Forty-second Street, with which they were associated, were arraigned yesterday in West Side Court charged with grand larceny.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18. -- This will be the last season of concerts in Baltimore by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, Miss Elizabeth Starr, counselor here for the orchestra, announced today.

COBURG, Germany, Oct. 18. -- Something of the glamour of the days when Germany had as many monarchs as the rest of Europe combined has descended upon this town where princely visitors keep arriving to grace the wedding Thursday of Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden and Princess Sybille of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha -- the first international royal "alliance" celebrated in Germany since she became a Republic.

Katharine Cornell, who has been resting on the Continent during the last few months, is due to arrive here on the Europa next Wednesday, Guthrie McClintic, her husband, said yesterday. In the meantime Mr. McClintic is preparing for Miss Cornell's next appearance on Broadway in "The Rape of Lucrece," the play by Andre Obey, which has been translated from the French by Thornton Wilder.
A score of Manhattan and Bronx properties were put up for bidding at liquidation sales conducted by auctioneers yesterday. Plaintiffs bought in the holdings to protect their liens.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his speech at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 11 Mr. Coolidge said: "An independent nation ought to keep within its own control the power to determine its own revenues and regulate its own commerce. Reciprocal trade agreements on any extended scale would involve our surrender of our independence on these two vital points."

A plan to establish Summer camps or the city's children in the wooded areas of metropolitan and suburban parks is under consideration by the Park Department, it was announced last night at the fourth annual Recreation Conference at the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of he Park Department.

William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council, and seventeen men and women representing virtually every large grouping of social agencies in New York City, urged yesterday in an appeal to the public that the existing welfare and health agencies -- public and private -- be maintained.

Parts of Jacques Deval's "Mademoiselle" are gay. Parts of it are somber. That is an excellent combination for post-prandial entertainment, particularly in the performance that appeared at The Playhouse last evening. For the gay parts fall to the lot of Alice Brady and A. E. Matthews, who bustle about the stage in the manner most approved for the acting of boulevard comedies in America.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Senator George W. Norris called upon labor tonight to oppose the re-election or President Hoover in an address which vigorously criticized "unrelenting administration opposition" to the Norris anti-injunction bill and accused the "Republican machine" of falsely claiming for the Chief Executive credit for its enactment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Officials of the Navy Department drafting the naval budget for the fiscal year 1934 are "up in the air" as to the construction program, as one high naval officer described it today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 18. -- Governor Beverley today submitted to a special session of the Legislature a preliminary report on the hurricane damage, for the first time in fairly complete form, showing property losses exceeding $30,00.0,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover was the honor guest at a reception and tea given this afternoon by the League of Republican Women, and tonight attended a performance of "H.M.S. Pinafore," given under the auspices of the Community Centre in the auditorium of the Central High School.

Some of the finest musicians in the world are walking the streets of New York in search of work, Sandor Harmati, permanent conductor of the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra, declared yesterday in telling of his experiences in building up this band of unemployed orchestral musicians, which evolved from the concerts given last year by jobless players.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18. -- A new treatment for a malignant and prevalent type of brain tumor, which constitutes from 20 to 25 per cent of all brain tumors and for which no permanent cure has hitherto been found possible, was described here tonight before a large and distinguished gathering of surgeons attending the twenty-second annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Sir Ronald Storrs, one of Great Britain's foremost colonial administrators, who as Governor of Cyprus quelled the serious, riots last year, is sailing Nov. 4 to assume his new post of Governor of Northern Rhodesia, succeeding Sir Jamea Crawford Maxwell.

Abolition of Great Britain's trade agreement with Soviet Russia was announced in the House of Commons yesterday. The reason alleged is that it was in conflict with the Ottawa treaties. While they were being framed it was known that both Canada and Australia strove for a sort of Empire agreement to exclude all Russian goods made by forced labor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Commenting today upon Henry Ford's statement to his employes urging support of President Hoover, Senator Connally said that the suffering among the industrial workers "is too real to be assuaged by any political bugaboo such as Mr. Ford and other industrial leaders will attempt to create between now and election day."

Despite reports that the banks from which the city is seeking loans aggregating $35,000,000, to be made by Oct. 28, are unwilling to purchase any city securities unless still further cuts are made in the 1933 budget, the belief was prevalent yesterday in political circles that sufficient advances would soon be made to enable Controller Charles W. Berry to meet the Nov. 1 payrolls.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, issued a statement yesterday attacking Republican leaders for enlisting leading industrialists in what he said was a movement to coerce their employes into voting for President Hoover. His statement followed publication of the bulletin of the Ford Motor Company to its employes, urging the re-election of Mr. Hoover to insure the return of prosperity.

With a total turnover of barely more than 1,000,000 shares, trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday reflected the current speculative apathy. The market was dull and steady. Brokers complained again of the indecision of their customers. Stocks were strong in the late forenoon, with pivotal issues 1 to 2 points higher.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Dominions Secretary Thomas told the House of Commons today that during recent Anglo-Irish discussions President de Valera of the Free State maintained the only real and permanent solution of the Irish difficulty would be a united Irish republic.

IT was raining at Princeton, but the inclement weather didn't seem to disturb Herbert Orrin Crisler, called Fritz. In fact, he thought a little rain might be a good thing for a change. The Tigers may have to play in the rain before the season is over, and practice in the rain would be helpful.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 18. -- Assets of all insurance companies should be listed in their financial statements at book value, responsibility being assumed of seeing to it that the book values adopted have a reasonable and genuine basis, it was recommended at the closing session in Dallas of the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The estimated $45,000,000 to be available to the Railroad Credit Corporation during 1932 for loans to enable railroads to meet their fixed-interest obligations will fail by about $55,000,000 to meet the actual requirements, E.G. Buckland, president of the corporation, told its stockholders at a meeting here today.

The Park Avenue at 128 East Fifty- , eighth Street, a lavishly appointed restaurant which was formerly conducted by Belle Livingstone under the name of the "Fifty-eighth Street Country Club" and which is suspected by the police to have been among the interests of Owen Madden, who is now in Sing Sing, was raided about 10:30 o'clock last night by seven prohibition agents.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18. -- Today I saw for the first time the airplane with which I expect to matte what has been called the last great geographical discovery possible in the Antarctic.

Ballots In the referendum to be taken today by members of Typographical Union 6 -- "Big Six" -- on proposals for a new contract submitted by the book and job printing employers' association were distributed among the 11,000 members of the union yesterday upon orders from Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, and his executive council.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Even between hurricanes poverty in Puerto Rico is proverbial. Our greatest sufferers are the little children.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the questionnaire concerning the financial condition of brokerage firms, which is submitted to every firm twice a year, had been revised to provide a closer scrutiny of the margins of customers' accounts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- An increase of more than seasonal proportions in United States foreign trade during September, bringing the month's total to $230,000,000, or $30,000,000 more than in August, was announced today by the Commerce Department.

The $50,000 damage suit brought by Gerard Schaffer and Egon A. Tropp against the American Legion Building, Paris, Inc., and the directors of the organization, including General John J.
