Pershing and Colonel Francis E. Drake ot Paris, its president, was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Hatting.

PARIS, Oct. 18. -- Widespread curiosity about what name the great new French liner would be given was satisfied today by an announcement from the Ministry of Merchant Marine that she would be called the Normandie. The 73,000-ton ship will be launched at the St. Nazaire shipyards on Oct. 29.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 (AP). -- Notebook, carrying the silks of the Wheatley Stable of Mrs. H.C. Phipps and Ogden L. Mills, coasted to an easy victory over seven other juvenile fillies in the featured Charlotte Hall Purse of six furlongs at Laurel today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Mississippi Congressional redistricting act was sustained by the Supreme Court today in an opinion handed down by Chief Justice Hughes.

Production of zinc throughout the world in September amounted to 65,463 short tons compared with 65,756 tons in August and 84,419 in September, 1931, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Production in the United States in September was 13,005 tons, against 13,404 in August.

A major share of the Eastern football interest Saturday will be centred on the Yale Bowl in New Haven, where the Eli squad, backed against the wall, faces an Army team that proved itself against Pitt. But the games of the two other members of the erstwhile Big Three promise to be almost equally interesting.

MADRID, Oct. 18. -- Foreign Minister Luis de Zulueta, commenting on the prospective visit to Spain of Premier Edouard Herriot on Oct. 31, said that "an entente between France and Spain would be desirable."

Andrew Carnegie was a genius in the art of living whose one fixed purpose was philanthropy, according to the picture of him drawn by Burton J. Hendrick, three times a Pultizer Prize winner, in "The Life of Andrew Carnegie," published today by Doubleday, Doran.

The industrialist campaign for the re-election of President Hoover took on momentum yesterday. General W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, issued a statement expressing his conviction that the re-election of Mr. Hoover would mark the shortest way to recovery.

The Chase National Bank issued yesterday a statement denying that Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of its governing board, had taken part in "a newsprint price war" or that "sharp differences of opinion were encountered" at a recent meeting of newsprint manufacturers in Montreal.

The closing sessions yesterday afternoon of the two-day conference of the Child Study Association of America were devoted to a discussion of special projects and problems of parent education and the importance of this work in relation to the child.

RUMSON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Mrs. George H. Miles, who resigned a month ago as president of the New Jersey State Women's Republican Club, admitted at her home here today that she had severed her affiliations with all Republican organizations of which she had been a member and declared her support of Franklin D. Roosevelt for President.
The text of Secretary Stimson's address last night before the National Republican Club here follows:

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Paraguay's announced capture of ten forts within one month in its undeclared war with Bolivia for possession of the Gran Chaco was acclaimed today by the chancellory as having definitely frustrated a Bolivian offensive which began on Sept. 1.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The police turned back an army of several thousand jobless men today in the poorer-class Lambeth section, but not until six or seven hours of battling in hand-to-hand fashion had disturbed the peace of ancient Lambeth. Then came looting by rowdy youths, and when order was restored around 11 P.M. scores had been injured, at least twenty of them seriously.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The National Progressive League asserted in a statement today that "it is the announced intention of the President to ignore" the 180 economists who asked President Hoover in a petition for tariff reductions. The information, the league added, came from "a White House spokesman."

Senator Love Ponders. One man who might be forgiven for doubting that reason and purpose rule this world is State Senator LOVE, from Brooklyn. A Democrat, he is now running for reelection as an independent with Republican endorsement, because Boss McCOOEY refused him a renomination.

The B.M.T.'s lease of city subways expires at midnight on Dec. 31, 1965. Its contract with the city states that until that time the company stall be "entitled to charge "for a single fare * * * the sum "of five (5) cents but not more." The contract has proved reasonably profitable to the stockholders of the company and the nickel fare is not in immediate jeopardy on its roads.

Julius Gerber, executive secretary of the New York City organization of the Socialist party, charged yesterday that "Tammany Hall is using the acute need of hundreds of thousands of unemployed workers in this city as a means of bolstering up its own political machine and swelling its vote in the coming municipal election."

The first intensive practice session in preparation for its annual encounter with Cornell was held at Baker Field yesterday by the Columbia football team. Even the rain and the wind did not dampen the Blue and White's ardor and spirit as Coach Lou Little sent his pupils through a long scrimmage in which the first team was on the offense.
VIENNA, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Socialist accusations that he aspires to become dictator of Austria are being made against Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss.

WOODMERE, L. I., Oct. 18. -- Only a small field turned out for the Long Island Golf Association's last oneday tournament today at the Woodmere Club, the steady downpour of rain dampening the ardor of all except a handful of intrepid linksmen, less than half of whom turned in cards.

The achievements of Miss Helen Keller, internationally known for her life-long struggle against the handicaps of blindness and deafness, were recognized agairuyesterday with the bestowal upon her of the $5.000 Achievement Award given annually by the Pictorial Eeview Company This award is given, according to the announcement, to an American woman, who, in the opinion of a committee of judges, has made during the last ten years the greatest contribution to American life.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Mounted policemen charged repeatedly tonight into mobs of unemployed demonstrators at the east end of Westminster Bridge, only a few hundred yards away from the Parliament Buildings, where the Winter's debates were beginning.

With President Hoover scheduled for another major speech in the Middle West and considering a tripto the Pacific Coast, his campaign managers in the East admitted yesterday that they were seeking to induce Calvin Coolidge to speak at a mass meeting in Chicago soon and also to make a radio speech over a national hook-up near the close of the Presidential campaign.

Attendance at the twenty-first annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America to be held in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., from next Saturday through the following Wednesday is expected to be the largest in the last three years, according to Hearn W. Streat of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, a member of the association's convention committee.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 18. -- Declaring that the "curse of American business" is politics, Roger W. Babson, the statistician, suggested today in a radio address over station WBS here the sending of a delegation to Washington of 2,500 persons, representing as many concerns employing an aggregate of 2,500,000 people, to act as a liason agency between the Administration and the Congress.
BUFFALO, Oct. 18. -- Following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here tonight:

The Eastern District High School interscholastic indoor track meet and relay carnival, an annual event for the past twenty-three years, has been discontinued, it was announced yesterday at the October meeting of the high school games committee of the P. S. A. L. held at the Hotel Astor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One gathers that General March wrote his recently published book to refute charges of inefficiency leveled against the military personnel of the War Department in its conduct of the Washington end of the department's role in the World War.

The new Cronyn Lowndes Galleries opened yesterday at 11 East Fifty-seventh Street. It was in these quarters that the Newhouse Galleries were established for several years prior to moving to 578 Madison Avenue. Last season Cronyn Lowndes occupied for a time the galleries on the second floor at Button's Bookstore.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 18. -- With a makeshift line, Army started preparations today for the Yale game at New Haven Saturday. Winn played left tackle in place of Lincoln, Armstrong was replaced at right tackle by Hutchinson, and Stillman was at right guard in place of Jablonsky.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18. -- Yale's most successful scrimmage offensive of the season was launched today when the regulars swept the scrubs aside for four touchdowns in a forty-minute practice game, accumulating a 25-0 score.

Arriving yesterday on the Isle de France were members of the French army horse show team and the mounts they will ride in the international military competitions at the National Horse Show, which will open in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 9.

The result of a five-year campaign directed toward the eradication of leprosy throughout the world were described last night at a dinner in the Union League Club by Perry Burgess, president of the Leonard Wood memorial in the Philippines, who spoke to a group of medical research workers, all of whom are affiliated with medical institutes, foundations or universities.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The required six months' notice has been given by Great Britain for the termination of the trade treaty with the Soviet Union, J.H. Thomas, Dominions Minister, announced in the House of Commons tonight. This is the sharpest reversal so far of British trade policy to meet the Ottawa imperial conference agreements.

The American College of Surgeons -- which includes surgeons of the United States and Canada -- announces through its director general, Dr. FRANKLIN H. MARTIN, that whereas in 1918 only eighty-nine hospitals in these two countries met the requirements formulated by this body, there are now 2,294 that have won a place on this list.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had notified A.W. Robertson, chairman of the Committee on Industrial Rehabilitation, that the Bell System's expenditures on plant for the next twelve months would be about $35,000,000.

In a letter sent to the Citizens Union yesterday, Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, challenged its endorsement of Lewis H. Pounds, the Republican candidate, and asked the union to explain how its reconciled the endorsement of Mr. Pounds with its opposition to "the partnership, if not the identity, of the two old-party rings in New York, particularly after the brazen Curry-Koenig deal on the judiciary."

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18. -- George L. Bliss, who prepared the original draft of the Federal Home Loan Bank act, assumed today his new position as executive vice president in charge of the operations of the Federal Home Loan Bank of the Second District.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- George Akerson, former secretary to President Hoover, gave his Bronxville neighbors here today an "intimate picture" of the President in an informal talk at a meeting of the political study group of the Bronxville Woman's Club.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, in the question hour in the House of Commons today explained what had happened so far in the attempt to get France, Germany, Italy and Great Britain together in a four-power conference to discuss the disarmament deadlock.

BUFFALO, Oct. 18. -- Received with almost unprecedented enthusiasm in the former Republican strongholds of Rochester and Buffalo, Governor Roosevelt today challenged Colonel Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, as an ally of the power trust.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18. -- Rain drove the Harvard football squad to the baseball cage today. Although working under cover the program was carried out just as if the team had been in the open.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18. -- Winning his adjourned game with J. Medina, champion of Zacatecas, in which he was a pawn ahead, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, world's chess champion, today tied with Isaac Kashdan, chess champion of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, for first place in the international masters' tournament at the Press Social Centre.

Abbe Ernest Dimnet, French priest, author and philosopher, whose books "The Art of Thinking" and "What We Live By" are among the world's most widely read books in the philosophical field, arrived yesterday on the He de France. He sounded a note of pessimism as to the world's social state.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Numerous indications that the crude oil industry is the first basic one "to emerge from the world depression" are cited in the fifth report of the Federal Oil Conservation Board, made public today.
The following table shows actual savings made in the 1933 tentative budget, with additional savings proposed by Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, which are awaiting final action by the Board of Estimate.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,130,650 barrels, against 2,173,000 barrels in the previous week, a decline of 42,350 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has joined the Standard Oil Company of Indiana in opposing an advance in crude oil prices. The Carter Oil Company, a subsidiary of the New Jersey company, operating in the mid-continent field, and the Humble Oil and Refining Company, an affiliated organization of the New Jersey company operating principally in Texas, announced yesterday that they would not meet the advance in these areas previously announced by other companies.
LANSING, Mich., Oct. 18. -- A workOut Wednesday will bring to a close preparations of the Michigan State College football team for its intersectional game Saturday with Fordham at New York.
An industrial deal, in addition to numerous housing transactions, was included in the New Jersey realty activity reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Arthur Henderson resigned today his shadow of leadership of the Labor party in the House of Commons, the substance of which he lost in the general election in October, 1931, when he failed to obtain re-election to Parliament.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Dr. Walter N Thayer Jr., State Commissioner of Correction, this afternoon defended before the Legislative Economy Committee his department's action in paying $141,825, or $60,000 more than the appraised value, for the site of the new Walkill Medium Security Prison.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York recommended last night that the Hofstadter legislative committee investigate its own chairman, State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, and City Court Justice Aron Steuer in regard to the manner in which they received bi-partisan nominations for the Supreme Court.

Finding it impractical to continue to hold sterling at the levels recently maintained, the Bank of England yesterday "pulled the pegs" and let the pound fall 4 1/8 cents. The break carried the exchange to a low and closing price of $3.40 3/8, the lowest quotation since Jan. 11.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 18. -- Harry Alexander, electrical engineer, committed suicide early tonight by shooting himself through the heart in the guest room of his home here while his wife was at dinner downstairs. Mrs. Alexander and a maid, Helen Myers, were the only other persons in the house at the time.

"From a careful analysis of the general business situation, the management has no hesitancy in stating that the turn for the better has been made," the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company will report to its stockholders. It expresses the belief of its executives that evidence of improvement in conditions is accumulating on every side.

A few scattering property deals in Manhattan were announced by brokers yesterday, the outstanding transaction being for an arcade of stores in the Penn zone. Details of recent contracts were shown in papers filed at the Register's Office.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- Investment methods pursued by the board of ministerial pensions and relief of the United Lutheran Church in America "may be open to question" in three particulars, the church convention was informed today in a preliminary report presented by its investment commission.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP). -- The 1933 major league baseball season will be lengthened one week, instead of shortened.

The outstanding event on yesterday's financial markets was the sudden 4-cent break in sterling. At the afternoon's low price of $3.40 1/2, the sight rate was the lowest since the 12th of last January. This year's lowest price was $3.35, on Jan. 8; the lowest since England's suspension of gold payments was $3.24 1/2, on the 7th of last December.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 18. -- The annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions began today at the First Congregational Church here. More than 500 persons attended the session, including more than fifty American missionaries serving in twelve foreign lands.

Convinced that the proposed private toll bridge across the Hudson at Fifty-Seventh Street could bring no benefit to the city at this time, the Board of Estimate, sitting in Committee of the Whole yesterday, voted unanimously to rescind all its commitments on the bridge.

A long scrimmage between, teams A and B featured yesterday's twohour drill of the New York University football squad at Ohio Field, where the Violet continued its preparations for Saturday's battle with Colgate at the Yankee Stadium.

Members of the Tammany-controlled bloc of the Board of Estimate moved yesterday to restore some of the items eliminated from the 1933 tentative budget when the board meets tomorrow for its hearing on the budget as proposed for adoption, which now stands $75,448,200 below the current budget of $631,366,297.
Lieut. Gov. Lehman's speech at the National Democratic Club last night, formally accepting the nomination for Governor, follows in full:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Government expenditures were reduced $140,000,000 during the first quarter of the 1933 fiscal year, the total outlay for all purposes having been $870,697,877, according to figures available at the Treasury today.

When the Metropolitan Savings Bank sold to the Wilieff Realty Co., Inc., William F. McMorrow, president, the seven-story apartment at 126 Riverside Drive for approximately $85,000, the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $81,000, payable five years hence, at 4 1/2 per cent.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- As a climax of a day of campaigning in Oneida and Madison Counties, Colonel William J. Donovan set forth his farm program to an enthusiastic Republican audience at the Majestic Theatre here tonight.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here this afternoon:

Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State, asserted last night in an address at the National Republican Club here that the financial panic last Winter had threatened to destroy the whole American system of banks, savings banks, insurance companies and building loan associations, and that President Hoover deserved the credit for saving our "tottering institutions."
NEW YORK. Mrs. Albert B. Strange will give a small dinner-dance on Dec. 28 at the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Elizabeth Wiley.

PARIS, Oct. 18 (AP). -- Willem Van Loon, 21-year-old son of Hendrik Willem Van Loon, the author, made his debut as a professional dancer tonight under the stage name of Willem Gerard. He danced at the Salle Rudolf Steiner, giving a program of original dances.

Money market was quiet. The Stock Exchange rate of 1 per cent for day loans and the usual concessions for outside trades, governments and Federal funds also prevailed. Time money was dull and unchanged in quotation. Business in commercial paper is at a standstill due to the lack of choice name paper.

Presentation of charges brought by Paul Blanshard, executive secretary of the City Affairs Committee, that Dr. William H. Walker, the former Mayor's brother, and four other physicians conspired to split compensation fees, was completed yesterday after a stormy all-day hearing of unsworn witnesses before a subcommittee of the medical grievance committee of the State Board of Regents.

Reactions from an opening advance on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday carried prices into new low ground for the movement, but the losses were partly recovered in the late trading. December contracts, after selling off from 6.36 cents a pound to 6.18, closed at 6.26 cents, while the general market finished steady, net unchanged to 3 points higher.

Declines in failures of retailers and manufacturers featured business defaults for the week ended Oct. 13, according to Bradstreet's. The retail delinquencies numbered 303, against 328 in the preceding week, while those manufacturers totaled 41, as against 47.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- German art dealers are agitated over a graft mystery, the threads of which also lead into France and England and ultimately on to the United States. Somebody it is said, has been defrauding American museums and private collectors for years, as well as troubling European vendors.

Before material disarmament can succeed the world must learn the "disarming of the mind," Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College and a member of the American delegation to the disarmament conference at Geneva, said yesterday at a tea in her honor at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Magistrate William A. Farrell resumed yesterday in Essex Market Court the case of twenty-two persons charged with disorderly conduct in Saturday's demonstration before the former home of Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio, 225 East Twelfth Street.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (Canadian Press). -- With benches scarcely half filled the House of Commons today continued debate on the United Kingdom's Ottawa conference trade agreements with the dominions.

PARIS, Oct. 19.--Both sterling and the dollar weakened today in the foreign exchange market and contributed to irregularity on the Paris Bourse. The sharp decline in sterling caused fear in some quarters that the foreign exchange market was entering a period of fluctuations unfavorable to the recovery of trade.

Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War under President Wilson, was named yesterday to the chairmanship of the American Council of the American Institute of Pacific Relations. He succeeds in the post Jerome D. Greene, who has just been appointed Woodrow Wilson Professor of International Politics of the University College of Wales.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Representative John J. O'Connor of New York, discussing the decision of the Supreme Court sustaining the Congressional reapportionment in Mississippi, said that he would offer a bill in the next session of Congress to re-enact the reapportionment act of 1911.
OSLO, Oct. 19. -- Former Premier Lykke and the Norwegian Minister to London, B. Vogt, are being mentioned tonight as possible leaders of the Norwegian tariff delegation, to London.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19. -- For the second successive day Harvard's varsity football team was forced to go into the baseball cage for its practice in preparation for the annual Dartmouth game on Saturday.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18. -- Following is the text of the prepared address of Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, at the Alcazar Theatre here tonight:

Further reduction in the price of college football tickets in some parts of the country has resulted from a continued drop in attendance, amounting so far this year to approximately 20 per cent, as compared with 1931 figures covering the country's major intercollegiate groups.

To those of us who are retentive enough to remember the Irish Players in "Juno and the Paycock" five years ago, the performance staged last evening at the Martin Beck by the Abbey Theatre troupe is, as Captain Jack would say, "a bit of a disappointment."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- More than three weeks ago a survey of the Ohio political prospect by this correspondent showed Governor Roosevelt commandingly in the lead. The situation as rechecked in Cincinnati today shows no fundamental change.

Republican speakers and writers keep on warning the country of the financial disasters which might easily occur under a Democratic Administration. This is second nature with them in a Presidential campaign, though it requires a good deal of nerve to revive this old argument of theirs while what happened under a Republican Administration is still rankling in the public memory.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- The Boerse was almost stagnant today, only a few stocks showing any life. Reichsbahn preferred displayed some activity. The general list, however, continued yesterday's dullness, but with the exception of Rheinische Braunkohle, Westeregeln and Lahmeyer Electric, which dropped 3 points each, the declines were small.

The East will not want for firstclass football attractions on Saturday, what with N.Y.U. meeting Colgate, Yale playing Army, Ohio State invading Pittsburgh, Harvard engaging Dartmouth and Princeton and Fordham taking on Navy and Michigan State, respectively.

Officers of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America submitted estimates yesterday to the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau on the cost of making up garments from most of the 4,000,000 yards of cotton cloth which the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee will receive from the American Red Cross.

Dealings in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday amounted to only $6,869,400, the smallest volume for a full five-hour trading day since Aug. 3, 1931, when the turnover was $6,016,000. Domestic corporation bonds were irregularly higher and foreign loans irregularly lower, while United States Government bonds finished unchanged to slightly lower.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith appeared before 2,000 shouting braves packed into Tammany Hall last night and told them he bad seen victory's "bright star shining in the East."

BUCHAREST, Oct. 19. -- Dr. Juliu Maniu, former Premier and National Peasant party leader, declared on emerging from an audience with King Carol at Sinaia this afternoon that he had finally accepted a mandate to form a government and had submitted a list of Ministers, which the King is expected to approve tomorrow morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Yale uncovered new offensive formations today in a thirty-minute scrimmage by the varsity against the scrubs. The additions to the repertoire of the varsity caught the reserves by surprise and long gains resulted.

The American Spectator, a literary newspaper, makes its first appearance on news stands today. It is edited by George Jean Nathan, Ernest Boyd, Theodore Dreiser, James Branch Cabell and Eugene O'Neill, who want to "give men who know what they are talking about a place to say anything they want to say."
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Princeton eleven tuned its defense against Navy plays in a forty-five-minute scrimmage against the scrubs today.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- The French Government has every intention and expectation of paying the war debt instalment due on Dec. 15, despite the hostile press campaign, it is authoritatively learned here today. This decision may be considered the first fruit of Premier Harriot's promise last night that France would make "no move which would put her in a bad position before any tribunal."

Elihu Root, in a statement broadcast last night over a network of the National Broadcasting Company, praised the policies of President Hoover and declared that failure to re-elect the President would be a "serious misfortune for the people," causing a setback and perhaps frustrating the revival of business activity for which the Hoover reconstruction program had prepared the way.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19. -- Secretary Mills declared tonight that "in the course of two weeks the Democratic House voted practically to double the expenditures for the fiscal year 1933, to unbalance the budget on a scale which would have threatened the credit of the government."

Although "still lacking conspicuous support" from such important consumers as the railroads, the automobile manufacturers and the construction enterprises, the steel industry, according to Iron Age, is holding the moderate gains which have heen made in recent weeks.

After listening to more than three hours of testimony, interrupted by frequent charges that he was conducting the trial unfairly, Magistrate Farrell in Essex Market Court yesterday found guilty of disorderly conduct all but one of the twenty remaining defendants held for taking part in Saturday's Communist demonstration at 225 East Twelfth Street.

More than $400 in cash, which had been seized by prohibition agents as "part of the furnishings" of the elaborately outfitted Park Avenue Club at 128 East Fifty-eighth Street, disappeared from a canvas bag in which it had been placed shortly after a raid of that club late Tuesday night, it was revealed yesterday at the Federal Building.

No substantial advance in the price of silver is expected in the immediate future but, on the other hand, there is no reason to expect a price collapse, C.W. Handy, president of Handy Harmon, said last night at a dinner symposium on the present status of silver, copper, lead and zinc, held by the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at 2 Park Avenue.
JUST about a year ago Eddie Cassy, head coach at Harvard, came down from Cambridge to talk at a dinner at the Harvard Club, and that time he had Ned Mahan behind him.

Claims filed against the International Match Corporation by the American trustee for the bankrupt Kreuger Toll Company reached $464,000,000 late yesterday afternoon with the filing with Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, of additional claims amounting to $175,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Albert Halstead, who is retiring as Consul General in London, made a plea today for more scientific and equable tariffs, rescuing them "from being the sport of politicians and selfish manufacturers.''

The campaign of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor goes into full speed today after an active day yesterday, in which he spoke at a luncheon in his honor given here by leaders in the women's apparel trade and at the Tammany Hall rally last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--Coincident with an announcement that employes of the Federal Power Commission will be barred from political activities, Joseph R. McCuen, secretary of the Power Commission, was told today to cease his work with the Republican National Committee and return to his duties here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The estimated value of building construction for which permits were issued in 353 cities during September declined 15.2 per cent under August to a total of $31,768,068, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Joseph Nemerov, attorney for the Court and Montague Street Realty Corporation of Brooklyn, withdrew yesterday his motion upon which an order granted last week by Federal Judge Woolsey required the United Cigar Stores Company of America and the Irving Trust Company, acting as its trustee, to show cause why bankruptcy proceedings should not be vacated.

Charges that the Republican were bringing pressure to bear on postmasters to make them work and vote for the election of President Hoover and other candidates on the Republican ticket were made yesterday by James A. Farley, chairman of the National and State Democratic Committees at Democratic headquarters at the Biltmore.

Captain Joseph Blancart of the French liner Ile de France was host to 150 friends at a farewell dinner last night on the liner. Most of those present have crossed the Atlantic with Captain Blancart, who will sail today, on his last trip as captain of the ship, having been retired under the French maritime ruling that officers must complete active service at the age of 55.

TOKYO, Oct. 19. -- Japan's observations on the Lytton report on Manchuria will not be ready for Yosuke Matsuoka, who departs for Geneva on Friday, but will be sent a week later by Assessor Shigeru Yoshida, who will travel from Moscow by air.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It now appears definite that the war debts owing to America are not going to be paid. This fact occasions deep concern among Europeans who think.

An opening advance on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was just about lost at the middle of the day, but prices firmed again on the strength in stocks and grain and reached their best levels in the late trading. December contracts, after easing from 6.38 cents a pound to 6.26, advanced to 6.46 in the late trading and closed at 6.40.

M.S. Szymczak, Controller of Chicago, plans to call for payment all of the city's tax warrants of 1930 now held by the public, according to word received here yesterday. This action is pursuant to the recent, decision of the United States Supreme Court not to take jurisdiction in the Chicago tax cases, so that the decision of the State Supreme Court upholding the legality of the assessments now stands.

Seventy-five years ago the first number of The Atlantic Monthly, for November, 1857, was published. News of a special anniversary issue is made public today. On the same date, by an unstudied but happy coincidence, we have from the press No. 1 of The American Spectator, a Literary Newspaper.

Chip, a vivacious canary that had brightened the home of Joseph McReddy, 52-year-old special patrolman of 221 West Fifteenth Street, for eight years with cheerful song and had been the pet since boyhood of his son, Joseph Jr., 19, a student at Manhattan College, was found dead in its cage early yesterday morning.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 19. -- Another all-day rain confronted the Dartmouth football squad today, but it was long after dark when Coach Cannell finally sent the men to the showers following a long defensive drill against Harvard formations.

The proposed central State savings bank on which a committee of the State Savings Banks Association is working was described last night by Henry R. Kinsey, president of the association, as a unique institution designed to give "constructive assistance" to members, as well as emergency aid, and to supervise savings banks in such a way that emergencies may be prevented.

BOSTON, Oct. 19. -- Nine dead, more than $100,000 worth of yachts ashore and being smashed to kindling in Marblehead Harbor alone, and property damage mounting hourly higher in the hundred of thousands of dollars was the toll tonight as northeast gales and torrential rains, which have lashed the New England coast for two days, continued with unabated fury.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 19. -- Tennis, golf and riding occupied the colony here today with informal luncheons at the Casino and several dinners tonight.

Increased unwillingness by banking groups to lend the city the $35,000,000 being sought by Controller Charles W. Berry was reported yesterday in the financial district, on the strength of persistent reports that the Tammany-controlled bloc in the Board of Estimate was planning to add millions to the 1933 budget today.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 19. -- Speaking at a Republican rally here tonight, Representative Robert Low Bacon, candidate for re-election, declared that the City of New York had been "negligent" in not applying to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for funds to construct a triborough bridge.

The application by Mrs. Katherine Rogers, a Queens taxpayer, to strike the names of John P. O'Brien and Lewis H. Pounds from the ballot as candidates for Mayor was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn. The court held that the election law was complied with because the certificates of nomination were "filed as soon as practicable."

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, indicated yesterday that he would not follow the recommendation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and Investigate the bipartisan judiciary nominations of the committee chairman.

In the list of cuts in the tentative city budget there is one that should be clearly presented in its probable, and it would seem inevitable, effect. The item appears as "Temporary "employes, Hospitals Department, "$1,000,000." The title gives the impression that these employes, of whom it is proposed to eliminate a considerable number are only temporarily engaged.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations to the voters regarding candidates for County Judge in Kings and Queens and the Municipal Court in Queens and Richmond. It is explained that "endorsed" means the union regards the subject as highly desirable; "qualified," that he is fitted for office, and "preferred," that he is rated as the best of the candidates for the office.

Interest converged again on sterling yesterday. In London's early market the rate broke 5 1/4 cents further to $3.35, which was this year's low price, reached during January, before the recovery to $3.83. This London price marked a fall of nearly 10 cents from Monday's highest; but some subsequent recovery at London caused the New York market to reopen around $3.37 3/4, a decline of 2 3/4 from Tuesday's closing.

A mortgage for $1,500 given to the Mutual Life Insurance Co. by the trustees of the will of Caroline A. Brundage has been consolidated with a prior mortgage to form one first lien of $5,500 on the five-story building at 125 E. 34th St.

Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" will open the Metropolitan opera season on Monday evening, Nov. 21, General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza announced yesterday in his annual preseason interview. The coming season will be a jubilee year in a double sense:

Citing the case of his 82-year-old mother, to whom he had applied the treatment successfully, Dr. C. William Hoeflich, president of the Associated Anesthetists of the United States and Canada, appealed yesterday to members of the Congress of Anesthetists to ease the suffering of inoperable cancer patients by the acidosis treatment suggested recently by Dr. Willy Myer.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- The text of Colonel Donovan's speech at Paddock Park here this evening follows:

The New York Athletic Club paid tribute to its Olympic champions last night when nearly 600 members attended a testimonial dinner in the N.Y.A.C. gymnasium. Leo Sexton and John Anderson, the two Olympic victors, of the Winged Foot squad, and members of the national championship track and field team, were among the guests of honor.
John D. Rockefeller Jr., in the current issues of Forbes Magazine, explains the theory which the Rockeplains the theory on which the Rocke.

Amedeo Modigliani, that tragic pioneer of the modernist ranks, who died too young to have attained bis ultimate expression, would find the banners of his creed displayed by proxy in New York this week could he visit the Eighth Street and the Marie Sterner Galleries, where Joseph de Martini and Alice Laughlin respectively are showing their work.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Oct. 19. -- Empty chairs greeted the two Democratic members of the Board of Supervisors' committee to investigate Playland, Westchester's $6,000,000 amusement park, when they appeared this morning at a meeting which they had called in defiance to the three Republican members of the committee.

MADISON, Oct. 19. -- Senator Robert M. La Follette Jr., Progressive Republican, today announced his support of Governor Roosevelt for President and of the Wisconsin Democratic nominees for Governor and United States Senator.

Calling upon the Board of Estimate to throw away its pruning shears and use an axe on the city budget, Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens' Budget Commission, asserted last night that the city administration was overriding the protests of the public and was not reducing its governmental costs to a level approximating the potential savings.

The Rev. Bernard F. McQuade, pastor of the Church of Our Lady of the Rosary in Yonkers and formerly assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral in this city, died at 8:30 o'clock last night in St. Vincent's Hospital, where he had been a patient since Sept. 28, suffering from Bright's disease.

Senator Wagner began his address last night with a prediction that on Nov. 8 a Democratic President would be sent to the White House, a Democratic Governor to Albany, a Democratic Mayor to City Hall and a Democratic United States Senator to Washington.

The resignations of the Rev. Dr. Henry Howard and the Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan as co-pastors of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church were accepted at a congregation meeting held last evening in the chapel of the church, which is at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
Several small flats and business parcels, in addition to a variety of dwellings, were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP). -- In a spectacular stretch finish, Predict, ridden by Jockey J. O'Malley, won the Grant Park Purse by a neck from Full Up, favorite, at Sportsman's Park today. Portmanteau finished third in the six-and-one-half furlong event.

The necessity of eliminating local boundaries in order to unify large communities and of eliminating the forty-eight States in order to re-divide the nation into a number of large unified regions must soon be recognized by the general public and by politicians, experts in political science declared here yesterday.

If the Board of Estimate does not reconsider its action, reducing the 1933 appropriation for the city's teachers' training colleges from $900,000 to $443,993, the three institutions will have to close before the end of the present term. This was the opinion expressed yesterday by Dr. George J. Ryan, president, and other members of the Board of Education.

The prosecutor and the defense lawyer completed their addresses to the jury yesterday in Judge Freschi's part of General Sessions at the opening of the misdemeanor trial of James H. O'Connell, 26 years old, on an indictment alleging that, on Aug. 21, 1931, he made a false statement to a depositor-stockholder that the Chatham-Phenix National Bank and Trust Company, since merged with the Manufacturers Trust Company, was in a precarious financial condition.

The "responsible" citizens of New York City have come to realize during the last few days that only by electing a Republican Mayor can they hope to have the city's financial affairs put on a businesslike basis, it was said last night by Lewie H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Charles M. Schwab, American steel industrialist, received the Melchett Medal for 1932 tonight at the annual dinner of the Institute of Fuel, at which he expressed the greatest optimism over the future.
BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- The course of the election campaign was enlivened tonight by two events with at least some flavor of novelty.

DUBLIN, Oct. 19. -- Amid the cheers of his own supporters and before packed public galleries in the Dail Eireann tonight, President Eamon de Valera accused the British Government of playing Shylock toward the Free State while at the same time seeking debt concessions from the United States.

BERLIN, Oct. 19. -- German financial circles and export interests were alarmed at today's sharp drop in sterling to the lowest point touched this year and close to the lowest since Great Britain's abandonment of the gold standard. The Berlin market for sterling cables declined to $3.36, later recovering to $3.38.

The editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 13 regarding the bus situation in New York City was timely and should merit the approval of all those who are in sympathy with improved transportation conditions. It is high time for the citizens of New York City to urge on their elected officials the necessity of a clean, safe and comprehensive bus system for Manhattan, to the end that haphazard bus operation may be discontinued.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 19. -- Mrs. Gwlady's Whitney's Rideaway, 60 to 1 shot, raced to a surprise victory in the twenty-first $5,000 added Chevy Chase Steeplechase, one of the important Fall field tests, at Laurel today. Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Green Cheese was second and William Almy Jr.'s Citron third, in the field of eight.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Carrington G. Arnold will give a luncheon Nov. 3 at Sherry's for their debutante daughter, Miss Cassandra Lee Arnold.

Swaraj Is Not Sainthood. Abbe DIMNET thinks that what this country needs is an American Gandhi, "a man of saintly and heroic character to lead the people." A heroic leader this country could very well use at the present moment; everybody will agree to that.

HONOLULU, Oct. 19. -- Reorganization of the Hawaiian Pineapple Company which, the directors believe, will enable the company to rehabilitate its business which has been badly damaged by conditions during the last two years was announced today by James D. Dole, president.

Columbia polished its offense yesterday at Baker Field by engaging the Manhattan College eleven in a scrimmage that lasted nearly two hours. The Blue and White was on the offense throughout the session, as Coach Lou Little was anxious to give his pupils as much training as possible in that department.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare won the Dorothy Campbell Hurd Cup today for the second year in succession and also set a new record for the Merion Cricket Club's eight-year-old invitation tourney.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- A1thougrh Governor Moore said he was not ready to make an announcement, it was reported today that he planned to name Harry Heher, Democratic State chairman and Trenton lawyer, to succeed Chancellor Luther A. Campbell of Hackensack as an associate justice of the Supreme Court.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 19. -- Al legations that the Pennroad Corporation was incorporated as a mere sham or device to enable the Pennsylvania Railroad, without risk or cost to itself, to purchase and acquire the securities which it was prohibited by law from acquiring and otherwise to perfect the railroad's program and to advance its interests are made in a bill of complaint asking the appointment of a temporary receiver.

That magician of science, the "electric eye," winked brightly on the stage of the Engineering Auditorium last night and performed for the benefit of the New York Electrical Society and a large audience of persons prominent in the publishing, printing and newspaper fields, feats that would have been considered miracles fifteen years ago.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- A bronze tablet bearing the names of 133 Frenchmen killed in the Battle of Yorktown while fighting with the American Revolutionary Army was formally presented to the city of Paris today by a delegation of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Republican Presidential campaign fund has reached $1,000,000, according to the report of the Republican National Committee, which was prepared today for submission to the clerk of the House. All of this amount has been expended or obligated.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 19. -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for president, assailed the private banking system of the nation tonight as the most corrupt and Incompetent feature of American life.

The city's plan for the development of Jacob Riis Park, at Neponsit, on the Rockaway peninsula, as drawn up by Julius V. Burgevin, landscape architect for the New York City Park Board, to provide recreational facilities for 250,000 men, women and children at an estimated cost of $2,500,000, was made public yesterday by Park Commissioner Albert C. Benninger of Queens.

Votes from any source are welcome, but if Governor ROOSEVELT is elected he may find the zeal of his Progressive friends a little embarrassing. The Lafollettian bigwigs have just served notice on the faithful that they will support him for President.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19. -- Governor Roosevelt spoke today in three States, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio, and was informed by party leaders that he would carry all three at the November election.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Noel G. Evans, who prior to his retirement two years ago was associated with the International Banking Corporation and the National City Bank of New York, died today at his home, 816 Third Place, here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- An itinerary for President Hoover's trip to Detroit calling for thirteen stops was worked out today. It is subject to later change.

John T. Saulter, a builder of Indianapolis, has been designated as the fifth man on an arbitration board to settle the wage and hour scale between the members of Typographical Union 6, and the newspaper publishers of New York, it was announced last night by Howard Davis, business manager of The New York Herald-Tribune and president of the Publishers Association.
WHEELING, W.Va., Oct. 19. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here today follows:

HAVANA, Oct. 19. -- A law providing the death penalty for all persons convicted by court-martial of terroristic activities or illegal possession of explosives or firearms will be enacted by Congress immediately after the Nov. 1 elections, according to information emanating from administrative sources today.

Negotiations are well advanced for the purchase by a large banking institution of the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, it was learned yesterday. The property fronts 120 feet on Fifty-ninth Street and 40 feet on Lexington Avenue and is improved with three and four story buildings.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19. -- Increase of the usual four-year high school course to six years, with a corresponding reduction in the grammar school term, is recommended in a report by Professor F.T. Spaulding of the Graduate School of Education at Harvard University made public today in The Harvard Teachers Record.

Further improvements in carloadings by individual railroads were reported yesterday. New York Central loadings were 96,865 cars last week, compared with 111,198 in the same week last year, a decrease of 12.8 per cent, which was the smallest for any week this year and which compared with a 14.6 per cent decline in the preceding week.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 19. -- The Modern Cancer Research Institute, established by the Rockefeller Foundation, the Danish New Carlsberg Foundation and the Danish Government, was opened in Copenhagen today in the presence of Premier Theodor Stauning, Frederick W.B. Coleman, the United States Minister, and eminent scientists.

Judge O'BRIEN is for "economy." He is for "rigid economy." No doubt he is also for drastic economy. He promised the Democrats assembled at the nomination ceremonies in honor of LEHMAN and WAGNER that the city's budget burden would be lightened by the Board of Estimate during the "next fourteen months."

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey reserved decision yesterday after hearing arguments on cross-motions for preliminary injunctions against the use of the name "Roxy" by either the Roxy Theatres Corporation, of which Harry G. Kosch is receiver, or by the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation.

COBURG, Germany, Oct. 19 (AP). -- The wedding day of Princess Sibylle and Prince Gustaf Adolf saw a phenomenon of nature heralded by the townfolk as an indication that happiness was in store for the royal couple, who some day may rule Sweden.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The pound sterling, which closed yesterday at $3.41, took a spectacular drop to $3.35 this morning, but with a resumption of official support it managed to close at $3.39 1/8. The early figure was the lowest since January.

Buyers Aiding Salesmen's Drive. Local buying offices have promised full cooperation in a campaign which will be launched next week by the National Council of Traveling Salesmen's Associations, it was announced here yesterday by Joseph H. Dryer, president.
Following is a stenographic report of the address of Alfred E. Smith at the Tammany rally last night:
GLASGOW, Oct. 19. -- The Scottish League defeated the Irish League, 4 to 1, today in a strenuously fought soccer match at Ibrox Park before a crowd of 9,000 spectators under ideal weather conditions.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman were hosts at a dinner here this evening in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Julian W. Robins.

BOSTON, Oct. 19. -- Eliot Norton, New York attorney and son of the late Charles Eliot Norton, Professor of the History of Fine Arts at Harvard for twenty-five years, and Susan Ridley Norton, died on Tuesday in London, according to word received here today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 19. -- The ancient bones of an animal belonging to the marsupial, or kangaroo, family, the first ever found in Africa, have been unearthed in one of the famous marine terraces of Namaqualand by Dr. W. Beetz, chief geologist of the Anglo-American Corporation of South Africa.

Charging that Colonel Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, had left the vital issues of the campaign in New York State "untouched and undiscussed" in his acceptance speech before the National Democratic Club, Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, declared yesterday that Colonel Lehman had "in addition given aid and comfort to Curryism and Tammanyism in the city and State."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Merging of all major Lutheran groups in this country into one general organization within ten years was predicted today by the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel of New York, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, after adjournment of the denomination's biennial convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- Officials of both the Pennroad Corporation and the Pennsylvania Railroad maintained silence today in connection with the filing of the receivership petition in Wilmington, Del., against the Pennroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Presenting charges of an industry wrecked by the imports of cheap products from Japan and Czechoslovakia, rug manufacturers appeared before the Customs Bureau today with a plea for anti-dumping orders to restore a business of many millions of dollars annually.

The fifty-second annual council of the New York and Philadelphia Synod of the Reformed Episcopal Church convened yesterday at the First Reformed Episcopal Church, 317 East Fiftieth Street. The Right Rev. Dr. Frank V.C. Cloak, Bishop of Chicago and former rector of Christ Memorial Church, Philadelphia, preached at the communion service that opened the sessions.

The State Board of Housing does not intend to jeopardize private real estate investments in New York by indiscriminate approval of all the low-cost projects that come before it, Darwin R. James, chairman, and George Gove, secretary, assured the members of the New York Building Congress at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- The wheat trade received a thrill late in today's session of the Board of Trade here when unconfirmed rumors were circulated that Henry Ford would announce late in the evening that he intended to buy 75,000,000 bushels of wheat at 60 cents a bushel and sell the grain to China on seven years' credit.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Last night's battles between unemployed and the police in South London had echoes in the House of Commons tonight when Sir John Gilmour, Home Secretary, charged the whole demonstration had been engineered by Communists.

The "Olympic" contract bridge tournament, in which no less than 35,000 persons were engaged, according to the estimates of the National Bridge Association, began simultaneously in many parts of this country and in Canada at 8:01 o'clock last night.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19. -- Breaking silence on the soldiers' bonus for the first time since his nomination, but recalling a statement of his position iast April, Governor Roosevelt declared against immediate payment of the bonus in an open-air speech tonight at Forbes Field, the baseball park of the Pittsburgh Pirates.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 (AP). -- George Gibson, manager of the Pittsburgh Baseball Club, tonight signed a contract to continue in his job for 1933.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- A further drop in sterling exchange on New York to $3.35 before recovering partly to $3.38 sent prices of British Government funds down sharply today. Like the pound, the gilt-edge list recovered part of the early losses. Gold-mining shares went higher until sterling improved, whereupon some of the gains were lost.
LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Lloyd George refused to attend the opening at the Kingsway Theatre tonight of Ludwig's historical play, "Versailles," showing him among the leaders in the Paris peace conference.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- Modernizing of industrial plants while material and labor costs are low was proposed today by A.W. Robertson, chairman of the district committee on industrial rehabilitation, at a joint meeting of the committee and the Illinois Manufacturers' Association.

In reply to Leopold Stokowski's plan to have the Philadelphia Orchestra, which he conducts, broadcast modernistic music to children, Walter Damrosch, composer and conductor, said yesterday that he was willing to "wager that 75 per cent of the ultra-modern works which Mr. Stokowski has given his audiences during the last ten years will never be heard again."

In his address before the National Republican Club, Secretary STIMSON found great comfort in our present tariff. It is high enough to shield us from "immense oversupplies of for"eign goods seeking a chance to be "dumped upon our market." It might have been pointed out that it is even higher than Congress intended it to be when it was enacted.

The plan for a reorganization of the midcontinent natural gas properties, formerly in the Tri-Utilities System has been completed. The terms were announced yesterday by Ferdinand Eberstadt, chairman of the protective committee for debenture holders of the American Natural Gas Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19. -- On a small group of tiny electric lamps members of the Franklin Institute tonight saw intermittent bright lines, each announcing the arrival of a cosmic ray from outer space.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Altmark, Benny Creeeh's vastly improved colt, today added another purse to his impressive string of Summer and Fall victories when he accounted for the Florence Purse through the Latonia mud.

With the date for the Hoover rally in this city still undecided, it was reported yesterday that Republican leaders in Massachusetts were bidding for an appearance of the President in Boston, while Republicans in Pennsylvania and New Jersey were said to be equally eager to have him speak at Philadelphia and at Newark, N.J.

DETROIT, Oct. 19. -- Henry Ford appealed on the radio tonight for the re-election of President Hoover, declaring in a talk from his office at Dearborn that it would be a mistake to displace a "seasoned leader" by electing a "new recruit."

The immediate reduction of the city work bureau's administrative staff was recommended yesterday by James A. Higgins, Commissioner of Accounts, and Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor, following their investigation of the bureau on charges that it had displayed discrimination and unfairness toward its employes.

Before an audience that filled the assembly hall of Riverside Church and overflowed into a chapel on the floor above to hear the address over amplifiers, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler presented last night his arguments against the Eighteenth Amendment and urged its repeal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Reports from Paris that France and Great Britain expect to meet their December debt instalments due the United States occasioned no surprise in official Washington, where it has been repeatedly insisted that the payments were expected.

Yielding to the trend of public opinion, the directors of the Manhattan Company have recommended to stockholders a plan for restoring that institution to its old status of a bank, absorbing or distributing to shareholders the various allied banking institutions which it has controlled.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech tonight at Forbes Field was as follows:

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- The Legislature Economy Committee brought out today that Dr. Walter N. Thayer Jr., Commissioner of Correction, whose salary is fixed by law at $12,000, is actually receiving the equivalent of $16,500. The $4,500 represents a maintenance allowance at the State institution for defective delinquents at Napanoch.

Wide adjustments in the classification of transatlantic ships will be considered by the Transatlantic Passenger Conference at a meeting in London on Nov. 26, shipping circles were advised yesterday. The subject was raised by the Canadian Pacific Line, which recently notified the conference that it would withdraw from membership because the Cunard Line planned to reclassify, its Class A ships Andania and Antonia as tourist ships.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt was discovered yesterday to be a member of three New York State posts of the American Legion, it was disclosed at the Legion's hall of records. As a member of the organization can only be a member of one post at a time, the Governor will be asked to specify his choice, it was said.

PARIS, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Asked before a Chamber of Deputies committee today whether France expected to pay her war debt to the United States, Premier Herriot was reported to have replied that the debt was a matter for negotiation.
SHELLEY, Idaho, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Senator Borah told an audience at a "potato day" celebration here today that the government would be justified in issuing $5,000,000,000 additional currency.

Declaring that the 1933 budget still contained provision for unnecessary positions in city departments whose administrative expenses showed little if any actual decrease. Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee prepared last night to press about $12,500,000 of his remaining economy suggestions when the Board of Estimate considers the budget today.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 19 (AP). -- Complete exoneration in the fatal shooting of Smith Reynolds, tobacco heir, was asked by his accused widow, the former Libby Holman, through her attorney today as the latter awaited Solicitor Carlisle Higgins's reaction to the suggestion by the Reynolds family that murder charges be dropped.

The Globe Theatre, one of thirteen Manhattan and Bronx properties on the auction block yesterday, was knocked down on a bid totaling $1,125,000 to the Spear Securities Corporation, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the Dillingham Theatre Company and others.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Maurice Maschke, veteran Republican chieftain of Cuyahoga County and former Republican National Committeeman, and four others were acquitted today of charges of having participated in the alleged embezzlement of $177,273 from the county treasury.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19.--Colonel William J. Donovan in a speech here tonight assailed Governor Roosevelt as a "political faker" employing "cheap political tactics" to keep the St. Lawrence waterpower development and utility regulation to the fore as issues.

A halloween celebration will be given Oct. 29 at the Carroll Club, 120 Madison Avenue, formerly the home of the Colony Club. The celebration will be in the nature of a housewarming as it is the first to be held at the club since the renovating and redecorating work has been completed Under the direction of Miss Teresa M. Fields. Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, benefactor of the Carroll Club, will be the principal guest.

The United Fruit Company notified shareholders yesterday that, on the recommendations of accountants, its technical staff and its officers, it was revising the book value of its properties to levels which it considered conservative in the light of current valuations.

In regaining the championship of the New York and New Jersey Cricket Association, the Brooklyn Cricket Club played a total of fourteen games, of which nine were won, one lost and four drawn for a total of 22 points, six more than Westchester County, the winner last year.
Called to the stand as a witness for the State in the prosecution of five men charged with robbing a truckload of furs, Harold Seabury of 26-05 Thirtieth Drive, Queens, was asked his occupation.

After falling another 2 1/2 cents to $3.37 7/8, the lowest price reached since Jan. 11, sterling exchange received official support yesterday. Help for the pound did not appear until late in the day, when it finally became evident that the Bank of England was disposed to stand aside no longer, the exchange rallied to $3.39 1/8, where it closed, down 1 1/4 cents on the day.

Firmness in the stock market yesterday was ascribed in Wall Street to a revival of speculative demand. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was somewhat larger than on the day before -- 1,303,000 shares, compared with 1,021,000. Brokers asserted confidently that not only was trading more active but that the increased buying interest obviously was based upon a belief that prices would continue to advance.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 19. -- Captain Thayer, who was missing from the Williams line-up in the Middlebury game because of an injury, will face Columbia on Saturday. He likely will be used at his old guard position, instead of at centre where he has played this season.

OMAHA, Oct. 19 (AP). -- Secretary Hurley told a farm, belt audience tonight , that more progress has been made toward creating a national inland waterway system under President Hoover's administration "than in any like period in the history of the nation."

Captain Ben Eldred sat in the comfortable cabin of his fishing boat, the Nana E., which gently swayed in the ebbing tide at Bay Shore, taking notes of the weather and wondering when some enthusiastic fishermen would come along and hire his boat for a day's sport.

Establishment of a municipal bank on the model of that long in successful operation in Birmingham, England, to do all the city's financing and as a means of liberating it from "the domination of private bankers" was advocated by Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, in an address last night at Public School 67, 179th Street and Mohegan Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- That Amos Alonzo Stagg will coach the 1938 football eleven at the University of Chicago was predicted today by James Weber Linn, Professor of English at the university and close friend of Stagg for years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your sympathetic editorial. "Overworking the President," appeals to me. May I add to your conclusions what I noted a few weeks ago while on a flying trip to Washington?

Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in President Wilson's Cabinet, visited Democratic national headquarters yesterday and promised James A. Farley, national chairman, that he would make three speeches urging the election of Governor Roosevelt to the Presidency.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19. -- The forecasts of leaders of both parties that Nassau County would have the greatest registration in its history appeared to be almost fulfilled when the board of elections made public today figures for the first two days' registration.
"Keeping Expenses Down," a comedy by Montague Glass and Dan Jarrett, will open tonight at the National Theatre. Solly Ward and Louis Sorin will head the cast.

COBURG, Germany, Oct. 19. -- The civil marriage of Princess Sibylle of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha and Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden was performed this morning at the Castle of Coburg in accordance with German law and with the same simplicity as for non-royalty.

Arthur Friedheim, noted pianist and one of the last surviving pupils of Franz Liszt, died early yesterday morning in his home at 684 Riverside Drive, where he had remained since a recent attack of a stomach ailment from which he had long suffered.

The Fordham football squad worked through a steady rain for two hours at Fordham Field yesterday, polishing its defense and perfecting its aerial attack in preparation for its contest with Michigan State at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A protest by the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company against an agreement by other lines for rates and sailings on cruises to West Indian, Central American and Northern ports of South America will be heard at a special hearing in New York City, the Shipping Board announced this afternoon.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- William F. Condon, Republican candidate for re-election to the Assembly from this city, who was criticized recently by his Democratic opponent, Frank Donahue, as a "ticket-fixer" in traffic law violations, admitted here today that he had intervened for traffic law defendants in New York City, as well as in Westchester County.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 19. -- Cancer is now a curable disease, if the disease is discovered in its early stages, a lay audience of 5,000 was told tonight by Dr. Burton J. Lee, Clinical Professor of Surgery at Cornell University Medical College and an eminent New York cancer specialist.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19. -- The forecasts of leaders of both parties that Nassau County would have the greatest registration in its history appeared to be almost fulfilled when the board of elections made public today figures for the first two days' registration.
"Keeping Expenses Down," a comedy by Montague Glass and Dan Jarrett, will open tonight at the National Theatre. Solly Ward and Louis Sorin will head the cast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- A protest by the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company against an agreement by other lines for rates and sailings on cruises to West Indian, Central American and Northern ports of South America will be heard at a special hearing in New York City, the Shipping Board announced this afternoon.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- William F. Condon, Republican candidate for re-election to the Assembly from this city, who was criticized recently by his Democratic opponent, Frank Donahue, as a "ticket-fixer" in traffic law violations, admitted here today that he had intervened for traffic law defendants in New York City, as well as in Westchester County.

Following a luncheon conference yesterday at which Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, was host to the presidents of nine Eastern railroads, it became known that steps had been taken to release large-scale buying of rails and other steel products of which the transportation industry is a major consumer.

It is a relief to turn from the tomtom beating of the politicians to the strange behavior of the bell in the clock tower of the church at Springfield, on the Morris Pike, in New Jersey. The country thereabout is steeped In Revolutionary memories. In the County of Union eighteen battles and engagements were fought between Dec. 17, 1776, and June 26, 1781.
The bulk of realty trading in Manhattan reported yesterday consisted of leasehold deals for residential and business properties.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The stock markets were quieter today and the tendency generally was easier. Sterling was steady around $3,39, slightly lower than last night's closing. Renewed profit-taking sales by speculators caused British Government funds to fall.

An advance of 1 cent a gallon in lank-car prices of gasoline at all Atlantic terminals and Tampa, Fla., and in the tank-wagon and service-station prices at all points in New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina and the District of Columbia was announced yesterday by the Sinclair Refining Company and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- In the face of a possible change in the National Administration, the National League of District Postmasters in convention here moved today to save the positions of 10,000 third-class postmasters by adopting a resolution asking that this group be put under civil service by Congressional action.

Stephana Lauzanne, editor-in-chief of Le Matin of Paris, who arrived here this week to report the Presidential campaign for his newspaper, said yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria that there was "tremendous interest" in the campaign in leading European countries, particularly in France.

For some time before, during and after the Chicago convention certain strong Democrats used stronger language. "Charges" and red-hot epithets were "hurled." But soon frighted peace found time to pant. Finally, placated by the hope of triumph, the Democrats got together.

Their names this time are not Abe Potash and Mawruss Perlmutter, but Harris Fishbein and Isaac Blintz, and they are realtors. Business is bad (it usually was in the Potash and Perlmutter comedies, too), and the office overhead has to be reduced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I supplement your editorial relating to the Audubon Association controversy? The present administration has been successful in obtaining a list of very fine names to endorse its activities. Impressive names doubtless defy criticism, nor do I mean to cast a reflection on any of them.

The village of Scarsdale, N.Y., which attracted attention last April by issuing, in connection with new financing, a composite financial statement of the village, town and school districts similar to those made by industrial corporations, has made a similar report regarding an issue of $749,000 of school bonds scheduled to be awarded on Oct. 31.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 20. --The Bolivian stronghold of Fort Arce in the Chaco region is holding out successfully against heavy odds, according to unofficial reports received here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20. -- The committee on scholarships announced today that forty Harvard freshmen are holders of scholarships from Harvard clubs. Awards are made at the nomination of each Harvard club to students from its territory who have shown promise in their school work.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Messmore Kendall of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., gave a luncheon at the Casino today for Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cutler and Mr. and Mrs. William P. Chrysler of New York.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 20. -- Torsten Kreuger, brother of the late Ivar Kreuger, who had been detained by the police here for several days, was arrested late tonight and charged with criminal offences against the bankruptcy laws by falsification of the books of the Hogbroforsen Industrie Company.

ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- Opening his up-State campaign for the Governorship here and in Troy tonight in an old-fashioned setting of brass bands and cheering voters parading through streets lined with red flares, Lieut. Gov. Lehman replied to Colonel Donovan's charges of Democratic extravagance in State government and flung the charges back at the Republicans with the statement that the vast bulk of increased expenditures had been voted by Republican legislators.

Forty-four paintings ranging in value from $600 upward were distributed last nigrht among the lay members of the Grand Central Art Galleries at the annual drawing held in the galleries. The works were all by American artists, members of the galleries, many of them prominent.

A new approach to the cancer problem on the part of research workers is necessary, two authorities on the disease said last night in papers delivered to a large audience at the New York Academy of Medicine as part of the academy's "Graduate Fortnight."

NEW YORK. Mrs. John Williams Morgan will give a luncheon today at her home, 39 West Eleventh Street, for Miss Mary Louise Burke, whose marriage to Mrs. Morgan's brother, George Frederick Burt Jr., will take place Oct. 29.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Loans made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the three months ended on Sept. 30 aggregated $500,000,000, increasing the total authorzations since the organization of the corporation on Feb. 2 to more than $1,500,000,000.

An Indication that Fordham's football team will use an aerial offensive against Michigan State at the Polo Grounds tomorrow was given yesterday when the squad drilled for more than two hours on forwards and laterals at Fordham Field.

Substantial relative improvement in bank clearings throughout the country in the week ended on Wednesday was shown in reports received by R.G. Dun Co. The total was $5,017,747,000. This was $1,662,025,000 more than in the preceding week, in which, however, there were only five business days, but the gain in the same week last year was only $104,383,000.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 20. -- If the Vare machine in Philadelphia comes through for Herbert Hoover, as the leader and his aides have assured their Western Pennsylvania Republican colleagues that it will, Franklin D. Roosevelt, straw votes or no straw votes, will not carry this three-genaration Republican State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Brig. Gen. Pelham D. Glassford, who gained prominence as superintendent of the Washington Police Department during the two-months occupation of the capital by the Bonus Expeditionary Force last Summer, resigned, today in protest against" the refusal of the District Board of Commissioners to uphold his plans to reorganize the Police Department.

Some of the reasons why 250,000 New Yorkers have disappeared from their homes during the last fifteen years are given, by Captain John H. Ayers, head of the Missing Persons Bureau of the New York Police Department, in "Missing Men," published today by Putnam.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Montagu Norman advocated tonight a system of cooperation and consultation in granting short-term foreign credits to avoid in the future the disastrous overseas loans of recent years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 20.--Indianapolis turned out today to give a rousing welcome to Governor Roosevelt which went far, in the opinion of observers, to bear out the predictions of the party leaders that he would sweep the State.

The Atlantic Keystone Petroleum Company, Ltd., a Canadian corporation with an office at 401 Broadway, and seven individuals have been named defendants in a Supreme Court order to show cause why they should not be restrained from further sale of the stock of the company, it was disclosed yesterday at the Attorney General's office.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the organization of the New York chapter of the American Veterans, a national body of World War veterans opposed to immediate cash payment of the soldier bonus. The local group is the third post of the national organization, the parent chapter having been formed in Chattanooga on Sept. 22, and the second post in Bronxville on Oct. 11.

Dr. FOSDICK said a few weeks ago to the thousands who could either see or hear him that HELEN KELLER, who can neither see nor hear, could do more for us than a strong and shining Apollo who never had a physical handicap. Her "chance to be a radiant soul" under difficult conditions does something for us that no one can who lives "untroubled by limitations."

COBURG, Germany, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Prince Gustaf Adolf, eldest son of the Swedish Crown Prince, and his bride, Princess Sibylle of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, stole away today for a honeymoon in Italy after the most colorful wedding Germany has witnessed in many years.
