CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Operators who covered the short sales of wheat on the Board of Trade here and went along late yesterday on a rumor that Henry Ford was to buy large quantities of cash wheat and sell it to China on long-term credits were active early today in liquidating their lines as a result of the denial of the report.

ATHENS, Oct. 20. -- Officially the note has no basis, And therefore no existence," was the comment of the Greek Foreign Office today on the nine-day-old note of United States Charge d'Affaires Morris asking the extradition of Samuel Instill under an unratiffed treaty.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 20. -- A crowd of about 15,000 greeted Governor Roosevelt at a short stop here tonight with the same enthusiasm that has been shown at the other cities on this trip.

Following the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday Controller Berry conferred with Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the National City Bank, and Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank, at the offices of the Chase Bank.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons tonight rebuked the Liberal Ministers who had resigned from the National Government for doing so at a time when Great Britain was confronted with so many grave questions that were still unsolved.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 20. -- Twelve Stockholm clergymen have protested Marc Connelly's play, "The Green Pastures," as profaning holiness and holding to ridicule the religious ideas of an oppressed people.

W.J.L. Banham, president of the New York Board of Trade, blamed political influence for the slow development of New York as a port in an informal talk yesterday to representatives of trade organizations, railroads and the press during the annual trin of inspection of the port aboard the city boat Macom.

Water-colors by eight artists make up the current show at the Morton Galleries. The pictures are widely varied as regards subject, method and vision. Eugene Fitsch has a quality of fantasy in his things, a somewhat devastating humor and, in the more material aspect, a surprisingly rich background.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Speaker Garner, resting here preparatory to a belated campaign tour, listed in a statement, issued today through the Democratic National Committee, a series of promises made by President Hoover in his 1928 campaign which, Mr. Garner declared, had not been kept.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20. -- The first Soviet comment on Britain's denunciation of her trade agreement with the Soviet Union, published in today's army organ, The Red Star, reflects the shock and irritation caused by the brusque suddenness of the British action no less than the old Soviet dislike of the British Conservatives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Thousands of American steel workers will be out of work this year because of the dumping of foreign products in this market by manufacturers in Belgium, Luxemburg, Germany and France, according to evidence presented in a Customs Bureau hearing today, at which the Treasury was asked to invoke immediately the anti-dumping act of 1921 for the protection of the domestic industry.

The New York appearances of three well-known solo entertainers, Dorothy Sands, Ruth Draper and Cornelia Otis Skinner, were, announced yesterday. Miss Sands, who made her debut as a diseuse last season, will impersonate a number of prominent actresses in a program called "Styles in Acting" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Secretary Stimson criticizes Governor Roosevelt for saying that the relief given by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is helping the banks, the railroads and the great corporations and is not reaching the people.

Supreme Court Justice Cohn heard argument and reserved decision yesterday in a suit by William B. O'Connell, a Washington lawyer and holder of $3,000 in bonds of the Wardman Real Estate Properties of that city, to remove the members of the organization committee for the properties on the ground that they were dominated by Halsey, Stuart Co., which sold the bonds.

BUTTE, Oct. 20. -- President Hoover assured Western producers today that "the whole silver question" would be "fully dealt with" at the world economic conference late this year and said that he was "anxious to secure the improvement of the silver situation."
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 20. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's address here today was as follows:

Ducks have landed on the Connecticut shore in the last two days, driven in by storing over Long Island Sound. Hunters In the vicinity of Saybrook had exceptionally fine shooting Wednesday, seven nimrods in one locality getting limit bags before the first gray streaks of dusk settled down.

Gold reserves advanced anew in the week ended on Wednesday, the grain amounting to $24,000,000, while Federal Reserve note circulation was reduced further by $20,000,000 and total deposits rose $35,000,000, according to the weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System.

Anders Jordahl, who was confidential representative of the late Ivar Kreuger in the United States, has settled in Montreal, Que., according to testimony presented here yesterday, and is disinclined to return from Canada for questioning concerning the affairs of Kreuger's bankrupt corporations.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations of candidates for the State Senate from this city. It is declared that, from the New York City viewpoint, the most important issue at Albany last Winter was the continuance of the work of the City Inquiry Committee and that the necessity for its completion was "apparent to any conscientious legislator."

Led by railroad issues, the bond market on the Stock Exchange was irregularly higher yesterday in quiet trading which aggregated $7,191,000, compared with $6,869,000 the previous day and with a total of about $10,000,000 for an average day. Gains in the rail list reflected the better car-loadings figures.

BERLIN, Oct. 20.--The presentation of the Goethe Centenary Medal to Premier Herriot in Paris yesterday by Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, the retiring German Ambassador, has produced a deal of astonishment here.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor, made an open bid for Democratic votes last night when, in a speech in the Bronx, he praised the budget reduction efforts of Joseph V. McKee, Acting Mayor, whose home is in that borough.

Wednesday's advances in prices on the Cotton Exchange were just about lost there yesterday under a moderate volume of offerings promoted by a slightly easier market in Liverpool and the action of stocks here. After selling off to 6.29 cents a pound in the early trading, the December rallied to 6.39.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (Canadian Press). -- The closing hours of today's debate on the Ottawa agreements saw a sharp attack on Sir Herbert Samuel, resigned free-trader Home Secretary, by Sir John Simon, National Liberal Foreign Secretary. Sir John challenged the validity of Sir Herbert's charges that the Anglo-Canadian agreement was unconstitutional in that it would be effective for five years without either party having the right to terminate it.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 20. -- A transfer tax appraisal filed here today on the property of Isaac Guggenheim, a member of the firm of Guggenbeim Brother's, who died in England Oct. 10, 1922, placed the gross total of his estate at the time of his death at 512,162,970.67.

A woman, 70 years old, smothered as she slept in a tenement room, yesterday became the fourth victim in a series of unsolved murders of elderly women on the west side of Manhattan during the last six months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The "campaign of fear" injected into the Presidential contest now complained of by Governor Roosevelt, results from statements made by Democratic leaders and by Governor Roosevelt himself in attacking the reconstruction policies of the administration, according to a statement issued today by the Republican National Committee.

Father is no longer lord and master of the home, but will not admit it; and therein lies the cause of much marital unhappiness and family discord, according to Rabbi Sidney E. Goldstein of the Free Synagogue. Dr. Goldstein's pronouncement came during a symposium yesterday on the sociology of the family at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

Denial that the Association of Railway Executives would vote to discontinue the Railroad Credit Corporation at a meeting here on Nov. 10 was made yesterday by E.G. Buckland, president of the credit corporation and chairman of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20. -- The Yale varsity football players today marked time for the Army game on Saturday by merely running through half an hour's supervised scrimmage, without any effort to score or to engage in hard tackling or running.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 20 (AP). -- The Cosmos Purse, a mile and seventy-yard affair for juvenile, resulted in a rather easy score for J.J. Flanigan's Arouse today at Latonia. Gilbert Elston took advantage of a ragged start, in which Captain Logan unseated his rider, and had the son of Hildur away winging.

Attorney General John J. Benaett Jr., after finding evidences of intimidation in the cleaning and dyeing industry, both in the wholesale and retail fields, has sought to remedy such conditions by having representatives of the various groups sign a joint agreement to refrain from such practices, or to report them to proper authorities and submit their disputes to arbitration, it was learned yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "The nations around us," said Secretary Stimson in his speech last night, "have had more bank failures, more acute panic, much more hoarding of savings by their citizens and worse than that, many of them, even the best and strongest of those nations, have been forced off the gold standard into monetary insolvency."

Mrs. Frederick Nathan was honored yesterday at a luncheon given by a committee of women in celebration of her seventieth birthday and as a tribute to her long service for civic betterment. The luncheon was held in the ballroom of the Colony Club.

NEWCHWANG, Manchuria, Oct. 20. -- Mrs. Kenneth Pawley and Charles Corkran, British subjects who were kidnapped forty-four days ago by Chinese bandits, arrived in Newchwang today under an escort of Manchukuo and Japanese soldiers.

The Board of Estimate formally approved yesterday the budget as proposed for adoption with a total of $558,406,601.73, which may not toe inceased but may be cut in further public hearings. Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee charged that a political "racket" was responsible for $1,000,000 of $1,785,301.33 put back into the budget during the session, which makes the decrease from this year's budget $72,959,696.24.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation loaned $655,376 today to the Governor of Minnesota for relief needs in twenty counties and one city from Oct. 16 to Dec. 31. The names of the counties and the city were not made public.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Solution of the farmers' troubles lies in the field of international relations. Senator Borah believes.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. ,20. -- An imposing monument in granite and bronze, sculptured by Sermon A. MacNeil, and built with a bequest of $100,000 left by the Late Andrew B. Murray, Charleston philanthropist, as a memorial to the Confederate defenders of Fort Sumter, was dedicated on the battery this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20. -- Thirty-one of the leading cancer specialists in the United States participated here this afternoon in a symposium on "The Curability of Cancer," in which they told of personal experiences in cancer cases of all types that they have cured and in which the patient remained free from a recurrence of the disease for periods of five to twenty-five years.

Two groups of customs men seized contraband liquor and a consignment of morphine on two liners lying at dock early yesterday morning. The liquor, fifty bottles of Spanish brandy, was found on the Spanish liner Habana at Coenties, Slip, East River, and the morphine was found concealed in the steering engine room of the North German Lloyd liner Stuttgart at Morton Street, North River.

After having declined for many months, the volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding in the country increased $1,723,339 in September, the American, Acceptance Council reported yesterday. The total outstanding at the end of that month was $683,189,146, or $313,175,932 less than at the end of September last year.

ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred upon Paul Claudel, French Ambassador to the United States, and R.B. Bennett, Prime Minister of Canada, at the opening of the convocation of the University of the State of New York.

Introduction of "baseless canards, vilification and scurrility" In an effort to picture President Hoover as an "arch, enemy of labor" in a pamphlet recently issued by the Democratic National Committee, was charged by Charles J. Dumas, senior past president of Typographical Union 6, in a statement made public yesterday by the Republican National Committee.
BUCHAREST, Oct. 20. -- Dr. Juliu Maniu formed a new Cabinet this morning, with Nicolas Titulescu, the stormy petrel or so many crises, as Foreign Minister.

Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, attacked last night the labor records of Herbert H. Lehman and Colonel William J. Ponovan, his opponents in the Gubernatorial race. Speaking at a dinner at Hollywood Inn, Far Rockaway, Mr. Waldman concentrated his attack particularly on Mr. Lehman because, he said, the Democrats were stressing the angle of "welfare and humanitarianism" in this campaign.

Governor Roosevelt is leading President Hoover by more than 3 to 2 in the fifth week's returns of the Literary Digest's Presidential poll, made public yesterday. Roosevelt is ahead in forty-one of the forty-eight States, with a clear majority in thirty-nine. Hoover being ahead only in New Jersey and the six New England States.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald and Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, tried today to convince a deputation of church leaders who visited them that the British Government really wanted disarmament and was doing its utmost to achieve it.

FORDHAM has had only one test so far this season and that was the Bucknell game. The big Maroon team came through with a high rating, but now another test is coming up with the visit of the Michigan State squad, coached by Sleepy Jimmy Crowley, the Barrymore of the football stage.

HAMBURG, Oct. 20. -- Stern opposition to autarchic experimentation was voiced by Dr. Hans Luther in an address to the Overseas Club today, during which he took pains to declare as president of the Reichsbank that he was firmily determined to maintain the service on Germany's foreign indebtedness as long as this was physicially possible.

Eight New York City scholastic football teams are scheduled to see action in some of the feature contests of today's schoolboy gridiron program that calls for twenty games in the metropolitan district, four of which will be played on fields within the city.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 20. -- The Michigan State football squad, thirty-one strong, left today for New York, where it will battle Fordham on Saturday.

KINGSTON, Oct. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Three grievances are listed by officials as possible qauses of the resentment at Portsmouth Penitentiary flaring into open rebellion. These are the refusal of prison officers to issue cigarette papers with the regular tobacco rations, the lack of daily newspapers for prisoners, and dissatisfaction with insufficient hours of recreation in the workshops.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Dedication of the new Colgate-Rochester Divinity School building began today at exercises attended by over 1,000 persons and which will continue through tomorrow.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Governor Roosevelt's campaign train got "lost" today in Ohio.
MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 2 -- Following is the text of the address of Ambassador Andrew W. Mellon before the Manchester branch of the English Speaking Union tonight:
TOKYO, Oct. 20. -- The War Office said today the Manchurian headquarters of the Japanese Army was continuing its efforts to effect a political solution of the Manchouli situation.

Jack Zaroff, 29 years old, Harlem gangster who pleaded guilty last week in General Sessions to shooting and killing Patrolman Maurice P. O'Brien at Lenox Avenue and 113th Street in a snowstorm on the night of Jan. 30, 1930, was sentenced to prison yesterday by Judge Corrigan for from fifteen to thirty years.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 20. -- Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander pave a dinner here this evening in honor of Mrs. De Forest M. Alexander. The guests included Mrs. Francis Rogers, Ernest A. Thompson, H. Rodney Sharp, H. Morris Paschall and Leon Gr. Moore.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 20. -- Norman Thomas declared tonight that Franklin D. Roosevelt, "who used the liberals and progressives to win his nomination," had gone over to the conservatives and was spending "most of his energy getting Wall Street approval."

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Lauding President Hoover's stand for a change in the prohibition law as "statesmanlike," Colonel William J. Donovan reiterated here tonight his call for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and return of liquor control to the States.

The first Fall luncheon meeting of the New York Trade Association Executives will be held on Tuesday in the Hotel Lexington. The program will include discussion of the proposed modification of anti-trust laws, the trade association as an educational agency for the business man, publicity, trade promotion, credit activities and financing.

Formation of the Joint railway-highway committee to seek a program of uniform legislation, both Federal and State, "looking to an amicable adjustment of prevailing elements of dissatisfaction in the transport situation on the railways and the highways, as well as to provide for fair and reasonable regulation of both means of transportation in the future," was announced yesterday.
REXBURG, Idaho, Oct. 20 (AP). -- Senator Borah told a campaign audience here tonight that the farmer would not get better prices for his products until "international problems" were adjusted.

The New York County Lawyers' Association, after a two-hour debate interrupted by prolonged cheering, heckling and hissing, disavowed last night the bipartisan Supreme Court candidacies of City Court Justice Aron Steuer and State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter.

An old-fashioned torchlight parade across Forty-second Street and through Times Square is planned to mark Governor Roosevelt's return from his Southern campaign trip, it was revealed at Democratic National Headquarters, where it was said that nothing of the sort had taken place in New York since the days of Grover Cleveland.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 20. -- The Naval Academy eleven had its last hard, practice for the Princeton game today. The first and second teams had signal and formation drills and light scrimmage and a very thorough workout in offense, both below and aloft.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- Despite a number of favorable developments, such as improvement in the world steel market and I.G. Farben's quarterly report showing unexpected betterment in its business, the Boerse continued lethargic today. The tendency was upward, but trading was slow and the price range narrow.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- After twelve years of suffering from eye trouble, James Joyce, the author of "Ulyases," whose vision has been despaired of on more than nine occasions and who is again threatened with blindness, has been, informed by his physicians that they believe his troubles are the result of abscessed teeth, it became known here today.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 20.--A reduction of $3 a ton in the price of steel rails, announced today in New York, the first in ten years, is expected to break a deadlock between...

The Macbeth Gallery is holding a "special sale exhibition," which will continue until Nov. 7. All the pictures on view have come from the gallery's own stock and they range over a rather extensive period, the list including A.H. Wyant, Dwight W. Tryon, Abbott H. Thayer, Francis J. Murphy, John LeFarge, William M. Chase, Ernest Lawson, Bruce Crane, Louis Paul Dessar and Childe Hassam.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 20. -- Appearing before the English Speaking Union of Manchester today, Ambassador Andrew W. Mellon made it plain to a British audience that in his opinion the American people should re-elect President Hoover. Most of his address was devoted to a statement of the reasons for his belief that this would be the wise course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- An attack on Franklin. D. Roosevelt, based on his soldier bonus stand, was being prepared today at the White House and will be voiced either in the President's speech at Detroit Saturday night or in an address by Secretary Mills at Cincinnati next Tuesday, or both.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Sun Archer, Willis Sharpe Kilraer's chief hope to win the Pimlico Futurity, coasted to an easy victory over six other 2-year-olds in the Tuscarora Purse of a mile and seventy yards today at Laurel.

Some of the fervor that a man might like in an Irish play is lacking in most of the acting by the Abbey Theatre troupe. But these wandering players came heavily freighted with the sort of plays that turn theatregoing into enchantment. Last evening at the Martin Beck they were doing "The Rising of the Moon" by Lady Gregory and "The Playboy of the "Western World" by J.M. Synge.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP). -- In a spectacular neck finish, Anna Adelia, ridden by Jockey C. King, captured the feature from Meloy at Sportsman's Park today. Doramelia, a long shot, finished third in the five-furlong event.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 16, in an article captioned "Again the Tariff Becomes a Dominant Issue," appeared the following statement:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- Ambassador Walter E. Edge called tonight for a Republican national victory as the one means of insuring a continuance of the progress already made by the country along the road to economic recovery.

KINGSTON, Ont., Oct. 20 (AP). -- Rioting prisoners turned Portsmouth Penitentiary into a bedlam for five hours today, seizing one corner of the prison yard and holding it even under the menace of machine guns manned by soldiers called to reinforce the regular guards.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 20. -- Before a crowd of 14,000 spectators the University of South Carolina defeated Clemson College at the State Fair today, 14 to 0. Despite the warm weather, the game was at a rapid pace, Clemson playing the victors to a standstill in the first half.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Despite material gains in collections of new taxes during September, receipts ran considerably behind Treasury estimates, according to figures made public by the Internal Revenue Bureau today.

BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- The German Andes Expedition, which recently discovered grandiose Inca remains in the theretofore unknown Quitarasca Valley, has performed new mountaineering feats netting scientific data of much value.

Post-operative pneumonia probably results from the use of ether that has deteriorated, it was indicated yesterday in a paper by Dr. Walter L. Mendenhall of the Boston University School of Medicine at the Congress of Anesthetists in session at the Hotel McAlpin.

Equity receivers for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company filed an assignment of errors and petitioned Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday for permission to appeal from orders of Federal Judge John M. Woolsey, including the order of Oct. 18 vacating the receivership and nullifying not only the appointments but all other acts of Martin T. Manton, senior judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
Contents Reveal the Date. The hospital patient who had been making a slow recovery was a last permitted to read the morning paper, but on condition that it did not excite him.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20.--Restriction of certain phases of free competition was recommended as the only means of insuring permanent economic recovery for the stricken steel industry in addresses at the convention of the American Institute of Steel Construction, which opened here today.

Yesterday's Federal Reserve statement again reflected strikingly the flow of gold to America, mostly through the paying-out of gold "earmarked" last Spring for the European banks. The increase of the system's holdings for the week ended Wednesday was $23,647,000 and $7,400,000 more was taken in yesterday; since June 15, they have risen $402,800,000.

In the hope of Inducing the railroads to place orders which have been long deferred the principal steel producers announced yesterday that the price for standard steel rails had been reduced to $40 a ton from the $43 figure, which had been in effect since October, 1922.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Two major railroad projects passed today into the realm of dreams as a result of adverse decisions from the Interstate Commerce Commission.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20. -- Following is the text of the speech prepared for delivery here tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for the Presidency:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 20. -- An ultimatum, demanding, among other things, the sale of Easter Island to the United States, was presented to the provisional government today by the "United Committee of the Armed Forces of Chile." It gave until mid-night for compliance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- A distinguished audience from official, diplomatic and social circles of this city, New York and Baltimore attended the concert given tonight in Constitution Hall by the National Symphony Orchestra, directed by Hans Kindler, opening its second season in Washington.

By a vote of 4,366 to 2,894, members of Typographical Union 6 voted yesterday to reject the proposal of the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association for a new wage agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding for the week ended Oct. 19, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,235,000,000, practically the same as the preceding week, and $43,000,000 below the corresponding week in 1931.

Ex-Governor SMITH'S speech in Tammany Hall was delivered in the midst of a national campaign. Under the circumstances, what he had to say about Federal and State issues will naturally command the most widespread immediate attention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- New mortgage loans amounting to $130,000,000 to 34,000 farmers have teen made by the twelve Federal land banks during the last three years, the Federal Farm Loan Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Donald R. Richberg, attorney for the standard railway labor unions, sent a telegram to Secretary Doak today, renewing the charge by Senator Norris that Secretary Doak offered to use his influence in obtaining a Federal judgeship for Richberg.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- In next year's French budget, which was presented in outline today by the government to the Chamber of Deputies Finance Commission, no provision is made for resumed payment of the French debt to the United States. That face was emphasized by several of the commission members when Finance Minister Louis Germain-Martin and Minister of the Budget Maurice Palmade attended the meeting to make their report.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20. -- After two indoor practice sessions Harvard's football team today went outside to drill in the rain and mud. It worked two hours to put on all finishing touches before Saturday's game with Dartmouth.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, the Democratic nominee for Mayor, declared last night that he expected to be elected by a majority of a million votes. He spoke at the dinner of the Italian-American Tammany Club, Inc., at the Hotel Moritz. He paid his respects to Lewis H. Pounds, his Republican rival, asserting that he had served his city faithfully in public office.
MANILA, Oct. 20. -- Opposition to the sweeping tariff increases urged in Governor General Theodore Roosevelt's message is gaining headway here.
The Sun asked all Republican and Democratic candidates for Congress in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for yes or no answers to three important questions. These were:

An analysis of the published annual reports for 1931 of 781 companies with stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange discloses that the financial statements of 651, or 83 per cent, were audited by independent public accountants, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.

The views on various pressing questions of the candidates for President, Governor, United States Senator and Mayor as disclosed in replies to questionnaires sent out by the New York League of Women Voters were made public yesterday. The candidates' news on the bonus and prohibition were not sought.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Cheapening the Dollar" quotes Senator Wheeler of Montana on the subject of free silver.

Formal announcement of a committee to investigate the prevention of wastes on the Eastern railroads was made following a meeting of the Eastern presidents' conference in the Bankers Club yesterday. The committee will seek to carry out for the Eastern lines the promise made by the Association of Railway Executives on July 20 which declared that the railroads "pledged themselves to avoid all preventable wastes in the competitive relationships between themselves."

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- The unofficial registration for Bergen County was announced today as 189,664, as against 181.338 for 1931. The total is almost 50,000 more than that in 1928. The registration in the largest towns was as follows:

Dancing Boy and Seymour gave W.L. Johnson a double at Empire City yesterday, where the weather was sunny for the first time since the meeting began, but the track was at its heaviest. Jockey L. Hardy piloted both winners, Dancing Boy scoring in the fourth race, which had the place of honor.

E.H. Sothern and his wife, the former Julia Marlowe, sailed on the French Liner He de France yesterday to spend the Winter in Luxor, Egypt, where they have had a home for six years. They said they spent half the time there and half in Lausanne, Switzerland.

Easier conditions on the Stock Exchange yesterday indicated, to Wall Street at least, that speculative activity was still sharply curtailed. Governor Roosevelt's disapproval of immediate cash payment of a bonus to ex-service men did not impress the market greatly.

PASADENA, Cal., Oct. 20. -- Photographs of blasted atoms are patiently being made by the thousand at the California Institute of Technology here in hope of getting another one such as was recently made by Dr. Carl D. Anderson, 28-year-old physicist of the institute's staff.

Significant advances in September business activity over August conditions, with gains extending into producers' goods industries, was reported yesterday by the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference, which regarded the improvement in the last two months as a probable "base for ultimate emergence from the current depression."

Court at St. George, S.I., yesterday at the second trial of Domenico Trombetta, Fascist newspaper editor charged with the murder of Salvatore Arena, a painter of 1,550 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Steel companies today announced a price of $40 a ton for standard steel rails and thereby took a step that may mean an immediate substantial increase in the rate of steel operations and the employment of many thousands of men.

PELHAM, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Thirty-six members of the Women's Westchestar and Fairfield County Golf Association turned out at the Pelham Country Club today for the next to the last one-day tournament of the season.

An examination under a microscope of a business card used by Harry Mills, an engraver, of Providence, B.I., and of one of more than 3,000 counterfeit $10 notes which have been offered in circulation since last January, convinced Alan G. Straight, head of the secret service offices here, that both had been engraved by the same man.

American political news usually reaches England in forms hard for the unskilled native to understand. This was reflected in the recent remark of Punch that, judging from the flood of dispatches from America and all the uproar over here, it looked as if either FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT or HERBERT HOOVER was in danger of being elected President.

HANOVER, N.H. Oct. 20. -- Bill Clark, Dartmouth's star halfback from Amesbury, Mass., was lost to the team today on the eve of the Harvard game when he pulled a tendon in practice. Clark's injury is not serious, but it is feared that he will not be available until next week.

Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, said yesterday the unemployment crisis would be worse this Winter and that $120,000,000 would be needed for relief during the forthcoming year. He spoke at the annual progress institute of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, 285 Schermerhorn Street.

Governor ROOSEVELT might have made a longer and more precise statement of his attitude toward the immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus, but what he said was sufficient to take it out of this campaign as an issue between parties. It also made it absolutely certain that no bill voting $2,000,000,000 out of the Treasury for the special benefit of the veterans could become a law except by being passed over the President's veto.
Small housing properties in various communities comprised the bulk of New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

Some of the difficulties which confront England in making the next payment on her war debt to this country were discussed in a news article in THE TIMES yesterday. The amount involved is far larger than that due from any other country, being five times that of the French payment and more than seventy times the sum to be received from Italy.
PARIS, Oct. 20. -- While activity remained reduced, the Bourse rallied today until just before the closing when prices again became irregular. Final quotations in most instances showed some recovery.

Howard Cann, New York University's football coach, has mentioned during conversations with friends a novel suggestion for the conduct of games. Discussing the practice instituted in baseball a year ago of turning over the direction of the couege team entirely to the undergraduate captain, the idea being to develop his initiative and responsibility, Cann expressed himself as believing a plan of the same type for coaching staffs might be worth while in football.

FRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Priziceton's varsity staged a forty-five-minute scrimmage with the reserves under the floodlights on University Field today. Two and a half hours were spent in final preparation for the Navy game Saturday.

The New York University football team completed its heavy work for the tattle with Colgate at Ohio Field yesterday. Only a light drill will be held today at the Tankee Stadium, the scene of the following day's clash.

John J. Raskob, who has taken no active part in politics since the Chicago convention which nominateted Governor Roosevelt for President and replaced him as National Chairman, contributed $25,000 yesterday to the Democratic campaign fund.

The adjusted index of carded cloth production has slipped back to 96.6 for the week ended Oct. 15 from 99.0 for the precedihg week and the top mark of 101.1 for the week ended Oct. 1. For the corresponding week last year it stood at 89.3. Actual production was again higher last week, reaching the largest volume since the Spring of 1930, but the increase was seasonally subnormal.

At a special meeting of stockholders of the Continental Can Company, Inc., on Nov. 22, action will be taken on a proposal of the directors to change the outstanding 1,733,345 no par capital shares to $20 par value. This would change the capital from a stated value of $63,249,903 to a par value of 534,666,900, creating a capital surplus of $28,583,003 as of Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Action to obtain income tax refunds amounting to $33,013 and relief from deficiency assessments of $197,739 was taken before the Board of Tax Appeals, today by Samuel Insull Sr., Chicago utilities man; Samuel Insull, Jr., his son, and Margaret A. Insull, wife of the senior Insull.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- Charging that Governor Roosevelt, in his references at Pittsburgh last night to Federal finances, was guilty of "extraordinary inaccuracies and distortions," Secretary Mills presented in a statement tonight the administration's reply.

Prepared for its first intersectional contest of the 1932 campaign, the Fordham University football eleven will clash with the Michigan State team at the Polo Grounds today. A crowd of 35,000 is expected to look on.

A Catholic University eleven, which possesses a ten-game winning streak, will provide Manhattan's football forces with their sternest opposition of the season at Ebbets Field today. A crowd of 25,000 onlookers is expected.
DETROIT, Oct. 21. -- The University of Detroit for the fourth successive year defeated the University of West Virginia when it turned back the Mountaineers by a score of 26 to 13 tonight.

The Brooklyn Prep football team Scored its first victory in three starts by downing St. Paul's School of Garden City, L.I., 13 to 7, in the fourth annual game between the teams before 800 spectators at the Boys High Athletic Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Travis Jackson's legs Were made "as good as new" today and the prediction was made by surgeons that he would be back at his post with, the New York Giants next season.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 21. -- Many luncheons were given at the Casino today, visitors afterward going to the golf courses and tennis courts. Mr. and Mrs. William S. Paley of New York entertained at a luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams, Countess Edith di Zoppola, Mrs. Shevlin Smith and William Rhinelander Stewart.

Bishop William T. Manning has announced that tomorrow at 11 A.M. he will visit All Souls Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, where there has been strife over Negro parishioners, to join the Rev. Rollin Dodd, the rector, in a service.

Nothing could be much simpler than "The New Gossoon," which the Irish players put on at the Martin Beck last evening. And by the same token nothing could be much more delightful. For this comedy of the countryside by George Shiels manages to catch the artless truth of so many simple things in life that you are inclined to grant it more virtue than its author intended.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- The railroads of the United States hold a huge reservoir of orders involving maintenance of way and structural equipment, which sooner or later must be opened, and when this is done employment in many lines of industrial and business equipment will be furnished for thousands of workers, according to Harry A. Wheeler, president of the Rail-way Business Association, who is also president, of the Railroad Equipment Finance Corporation.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21. -- After two days of meditation Moscow has reacted to Great Britain's denunciation of the trade agreement with Soviet Russia by an outburst of indignation even more vigorous than was indicated yesterday by the preliminary comment of the Red Army organ, Red Star.

Controller Charles W. Berry estimated yesterday that the city's basic tax rate for 1933 would be $2.43 per $100 of assessed valuation, a drop of 16 points from the present rate of 2.59. This, he said, would save $16 in taxes on a house with an assessed valuation of $10,000.

Apparently the lawyers of New York City are more aroused and indignant over the latest bipartisan, or bi-boss, selection of judges than had been supposed. The meeting of the County Lawyers on Thursday evening was illuminating. A partial and half-whitewashing report on the nominations of Justice STEUER and Senator HOFSTADTER had been agreed upon by the committee, but was overridden and thrown aside by the full association when the matter was put to vote.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The Frinceton board of athletic control announced tonight that Keene Fitzpatrick, for forty-two years an athletic coach and trainer at Yale, Michigan and Princeton, will retire at the end of the present football season.

The Stage Society announced yesterday that it had passed the halfway mark in its subscription drive for 3,000 members. The purpose of the group, patterned after the London organization of the same name, is to produce five plays during the season for a closed membership.

DELAWANNA, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Four payroll robbers, armed with two sub-machine guns and revolvers, obtained this afternoon a $3,000 payroll in the main office here of the plant of T.R. Goodlatte Son, oilcloth manufacturers. They escaped toward Passaic in an automobile.

Many changes in leasing contracts were detailed in papers recorded at the Register's Office yesterday. These provided most of the day's realty news and included modifications of the terms of leases, such as assignments, reductions of rental terms and surrenders.
The passenger list of the Italian motorship Augustus, which leaves today for Mediterranean ports, will include:

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Oct. 21. -- Tom Mix was badly hurt this afternoon in an accident during the filming of a scene for his cowboy picture "Oh Promise Me," on a ranch near Lone Pine, Cal. The extent of his injuries had not been determined tonight.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- In an address at the closing session of the convocation of the University of the State of New York today, Dr. David S. Muzzey, Graduate Professor of American History in Columbia University, declared that the people of this country had not outgrown the influence of George Washington.

The worst result of the protracted business slump which must now be corrected, according to Meyer Bloomfield, lawyer and adviser to business groups, is that business men have stopped making an effort.

A reduction of a quarter cent, making the domestic price of copper 6 cents a pound, was made yesterday by custom smelters. For several weeks sellers had been asking 6 1/4 cents, but owing to the accumulation of scrap and the small volume of sales, they found a price reduction advisable.

A precocious Brooklyn girl, who at the age of 9 is more interested in disarmament than dolls, breathed a sigh of relief last night when a newspaper man informed her that Secretary of State Stimson at Washington wrote her a letter yesterday to inform her that, although the appropriation for the American delegation to the Geneva disarmament conference had run low, "it really is not living in an attic."

ABERDEEN, S.D., Oct. 21. -- Republican orators, "in their desire to avoid ouster from office," are recreating the very dangers of panic which they ask the voters to believe the Washington Administration averted, Bainbridge Colby declared here tonight in a campaign address.

Despite a slight slowing up of the progressive improvement in business conditions, there is no sign of a cessation of the upward trend, according to the weekly reviews of the commercial agencies. In some lines expansion is continuing substantially beyond seasonal expectations.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Scoring all its points in the final period, the Horace Mann School for Boys football team of New York City defeated Irving School, 13 to 0, today. Ferdinand Marsik tallied the first touchdown when he took a Horace Mann forward pass thrown by Joe Vollmer that was deflected by an Irving player and ran five yards across the goal line.

A three-point program to establish better trade relations between the United States and Greece was set under way here last night at a meeting of more than 100 leading Greek industrialists, exporters, importers and bankers of the city at the St. Moritz Hotel.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- The dollar fell slightly again in the foreign exchange market today, closing at 25,41, while sterling improved. Virtually the whole Bourse list slumped. Both domestic and interna-national stocks weakened and in some instances the losses were large.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Although Harvard had the individual winner in both races, its varsity and freshman cross-country teams were defeated today by the University of New Hampshire.

Three combination freight-passenger ships were chartered under a long-term contract by the State Steamship Company from the United Fruit Company during a recent visit of Kenneth D. Dawson of Seattle, president of the State company, to New York, it was revealed yesterday.

A new international code of contract bridge laws has been agreed upon by the Whist Club of New York, the Portland Club of London and the Commission Francaise du Bridge, the recognized rule-making bodies in this country, Great Britain and France, Walter Beinecke, vice president of the Whist Club, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Samuel Insull Jr. arrived here from Paris tonight and kept newspaper men at bay. When the Golden Arrow pulled into Victoria Station he eluded a crowd of reporters and camera men by the simple device of removing his glasses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Declaring that his 1932 candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President consisted chiefly of his two weeks' trip to the Chicago convention, Alfred E. Smith reported today that he had spent $8,999.32 and received contributions of $9,000 in his unsuccessful campaign for the Presidential nomination.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Herbert K. Hyde, United States District Attorney, said today he would seek the forfeiture of the $25,000 appeal hond of S.K.J. Cox, convicted here several months ago for mail fraud in connection with activities of the Universal Oil and Gas Company.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Political vilification has shown a marked decline during the 1932 Presidential campaign, according to Dr. George P. Schmidt, Assistant Professor of History at New Jersey College for Women, who told students that his observations of the present political campaign lead him to believe that Americans are now more reserved than they were at earlier stages of our political life.

Henry L. Stevens Jr. of North Carolina, former national commander of the American Legion, in a statement issued yesterday through the Democratic National Committee, said that the veterans were satisfied with Governor Roosevelt's stand against immediate cash payment of the bonus because "he has not closed the door on them."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The Princeton football team will meet the Navy in Palmer Stadium tomorrow in the twenty-first game of a series which began in 1892. About 35,000 are expected to witness the contest.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Catfish produce "He-men that wear britches" while goldfish "produce silk-stocking experts," believes Governor Murray.

There appears to be something like competition between the various Presidential candidates in issuing promissory notes. They always flutter down like falling leaves at this stage of a national election. Reports are brought to headquarters that a certain element in the party is uncertain or dissatisfied and that a few kind words addressed to it, buttering the local parsnips, will solidify the organization.

The New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads appeared yesterday to be in a position in which they would be the first companies to buy rails at the new low price of $40 a ton. The quotation had been $43 for ten years, but the maintenance of this figure had recently been subjected to investigation by the Federal Trade Commission.

The problem, of homeless men will be serious this Winter, according to a study made by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which said yesterday that more than 500 men already had been forced to find shelter in temporary shacks.

The retention of President Hoover as a "President capable of doing great constructive work," was urged last evening by Mrs. Thomas A. Edison, widow of the inventor, in a radio address. She advised that the country not he turned over "to new forces who have not the same understanding and capabilities for action."

The temporary Martin act receivership ordered by Supreme Court Justice Norton of Brooklyn for the investment house of S.W. Straus Co., Inc., was lifted by the Appellate Division of Brooklyn yesterday pending trial of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.'s suit against the company.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 21. -- The will that Oliver William Bird, broker, polo player and sportsman, made forty-three years ago was filed today with Surrogate Howell together with, an application for letters of administration by his son, Oliver W. Bird Jr. Mr. Bird died at his home in Hempstead on Aug. 11, last.

The real estate losses of the United Cigar Stores Company of America during the first eight months of this year were $3,128,974, or nearly three times greater than the losses of $1,382,681 in store sales, according to testimony yesterday at a hearing before Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, at 15 Park Row.

A group show of oils and water-colors by nine American artists, all under 25 years of age, presents plenty of color at the American Contemporary Art Gallery, 1,269 Madison Avenue. Perhaps the best known of the group is William Steig, through his sketches for The New Yorker.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Oct. 22. -- Developments of the profoundest international significance are expected at the meeting here of the majority of the leaders of the Nanking Government, including those carrying veto powers from General Chiang Kai-shek.
BROWN vs. Tufts -- The straw vote last week was badly scorched. Tufts is the team that beat Bates. What this country needs is confidence. One vote for Brown.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21. -- "Alarmist newspapers along the border, hostile to the government and the revolution, have been propagating rumors that Mexican territory will be ceded to the United States through a possible agreement on boundary questions," said a statement by President Rodriguez tonight.

Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican nominee for Governor, was commended yesterday by General James G. Harbord for his activities in war and in peace. General Harbord said that the war experience of the Republican candidate for Governor had gone a long way to fit him for the Governorship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Further slight improvement in the economic situation of some American markets abroad, including Canada, France, Denmark, Japan and New Zealand, was reported today in the weekly survey of foreign business conditions made public by the Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- President Hoover left the capital tonight for Detroit on what party leaders regard as the critical tour of his campaign.

Two aged mountaineers from Beckley, W.Va., will tell another chapter next Wednesday in the history of the eccentric Wendel family. They will appear before Surrogate James A. Foley in an effort to prove that they are the rightful heirs to the millions left in the ill of Ella V. von E. Wendel, and their testimony will deal with the disappearance of John Hammond Dew, maternal uncle of Miss Wendel.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 21. -- Scores of arrivals at the Hot Springs today joined in a varied program of social and sports activities, which point to a brilliant week-end in the colony.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- In an effort to clear up the confused situation regarding what Premier Herriot did and did not say before the Chamber of Deputies Foreign Relations Commission regarding the payment of the French debt instalment to the United States on Dec. 15, the Foreign Office issued today a statement that reads:

Rejecting the proposal for a low tax on the sale of all manufactured articles, Congress chose at its last session to count largely on "nuisance" taxes for the additional revenue needed for a balanced budget. Receipts for the first quarter of the fiscal year (July-September) have now been made public by the Treasury.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Reports that negotiations were under way between the Chicago Board of Trade and the Department of Agriculture to have set aside or amended the restrictions on grain trading failed to create even a ripple in the wheat market here today.

Goethe Enters Politics. The German Nation alist press is angry with President HINDENBURG for giving one of the Goethe centenary medals to Premier HERRIOT. The spec tacle of the German Ambassador al Paris actually pinning a decoration on the chest of an arch-enemy of the Fatherland is more than ultra-patriotic hearts at Berlin can endure.

The New York Railroad Club, meeting last night in the Engineering Societies' Building at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, unanimously adopted a resolution stating that the present degree of regulation maintained in the case of the railroads, while competitive trucking remained unregulated, was one of the major causes of the depression.

Although crime has evolved into big business and "flaming youth" has jarred the foundations of matrimony, Supreme Court Justice Norman S. Dike still believes that matters will work out all right in the end.

ST. LOUIS. Oct. 21. -- Establishment of industrial medical clinics in existing reputable hospitals for the handling of industrial accident case was recommended here tonight by Dr. J. Bentley Squier, Professor o Urology at the College of Physician and Surgeons, Columbia University in his presidential address at the convocation ceremonies, which closed the twenty-second annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 21. -- Calling upon young ministers to make use of "one of the greatest opportunities in history" to lay tie groundwork for a truly Christian civilization, possibly centuries hence, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick of Riverside Church, New York, climaxed with a dedicatory sermon today the two-day exercises at the new Colgate-Rochester Divinity School here.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Donald Adams, editor of The New York Times Book Review, opened informal conferences at the "house party" of Southern writers here today by declaring that Southerners are leading at present in their work with drama, the novel, poetry and history.
The season in squash tennis will get under way Wednesday when play will begin in the Class A division of the Metropolitan League championships with seven teams entered.

James Paul Donahue, broker and son-in-law of the late F.W. Woolworth, left an estate of $3,708,7831 gross but only $1,784,497 net when he died on April 23, 1931, of poison taken four days before. The estate was reduced mainly by debts of $1,771,040 owed largely on brokerage accounts.

Sales brought $12,297.50 at the dispersal of paintings and drawings, the property of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Selmont, at the American Association-Anderson Galleries last night. The sales in the afternoon, at the first session, when furniture and objects of art were auctioned, amounted to $13,764.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- President Hoover has at the White House perhaps the biggest and most exclusive and inclusive collection of caricatures in the world.

No more fitting and enduring celebration of the tercentenary of the birth of Sir CHRISTOPHER WREN could have been prepared than the recent strengthening of the cathedral which is both his tomb and his monument. Barring some cataclysm of nature, those who seek his monument three hundred years hence need but look around.
WILDWOOD, N. J., Oct. 21. -- Fifty-five teachers, comprising the staff of the public schools here, received their September salaries in scrip today.

In 1928 Mr. JOHN J. RASKOB was taunted with his Republican antecedents. What Democrat has worked harder for the Democratic party and given, more to it? Undismayed, he steered it through a campaign that dropped millions. He revived it, reorganized it, set it on its feet, kept on paying its bills.

The reason for Tammany s sudden abandonment of the four-year bond financing of new subways-a matter of lively speculation in transit and political circles-became more obscure than ever yesterday when Controller Charles W. Berry announced that the city had no urgent need for funds when he applied to the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank on Oct. 13 for loans aggregating $35,000,000.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 21. -- Bolivia's Cabinet crisis was solved today when the Liberal party agreed to join in a coalition Ministry under President Daniel Salamanca to administer the nation's affairs during the emergency of the conflict with Paraguay.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 21. -- The final meeting of the welfare conference of the Junior League Association was held today with a program of lectures and group meetings on the subject of "Problems of Relief Administration."

The protective committee for holders of first mortgage 6 1/2 per cent Series A bonds of the Ohio Kentucky Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Appalachian Gas Corporation, has announced a reorganization plan calling for the acquisition of the assets of Ohio Kentucky Gas by a new company.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien and Lewis H. Pounds, rival mayoralty candidates, met yesterday on the same platform for the first time since their nominations and, although political discussion was prohibited, virtually made campaign speeches for each other.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- A prediction that unless the Socialist unemployment relief program was adopted "we will have starvation and riots next Winter," was made today by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21. -- Heavy imports of foreign steel last year deprived 240,000 American workmen of a week's work, J.W. Thomsen of Stupp Brothers Bridge and Iron Company, St. Louis, told the convention of the American Institute of Steel Construction today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the appeal in this morning's TIMES the public is urged to support those established agencies which are helping to determine "the quality of our communal life and of our future civilization." May I call attention through your columns to one such agency whose work is now imperiled?
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 21. -- Following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here tonight:

Twenty Bishops and almost 1,000 priests are expected to attend the consecration as Bishop of the Diocese of Salt Lake, Utah, of the Rev. Dr. James E. Kearney, for the last few years pastor of the Church of St. Francis Xavier, Lurting Avenue near Morris Park Avenue, the Bronx, which will take place in St. Patrick's Cathedral Friday morning at 9:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- With the exception of some stamp taxes, including those on capital stock issues and transfers, and the safety deposit box tax, the September revenue from the new levies ran considerably behind the estimates.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 21. -- Joseph P. Tumulty, secretary to Woodrow Wilson, in an address here tonight attacked the leadership of President Hoover, prohibition and the repudiation of Alfred E. Smith in 1928 because of his religious belief.

After a long dark spell the Cosmopolitan Theatre, on Columbus Circle, reopened for business last night with "Manhattan Varieties," a necessarily augmented and slightly Improved version of the little revue which under the title of "Belmont Varieties" recently had an ephemeral engagement in Forty-eighth Street.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 21. -- Penn State will meet Syracuse tomorrow in the eleventh annual football contest between the two colleges. The game will be a part of Penn State's thirteenth home-coming celebration.

New financing of bonds continued light this week, amounting to $10,735,000, compared with $12,860,000 last week. However, the individual issues marketed were uniformly high grade, so that most of them were placed quickly. In the corresponding week last year new financing consisted of a single issue of $20,000,000 New York City 4 1/4 per cent revenue bills and corporate stock notes.

Running in the fastest time in which the rearranged course has ever been covered, Joe McCluskey led the Fordham University cross - country team to triumph in its opening meet of the season with City College at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The final score was 20 to 35.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Fair Image, 2-year-old filly racing for Mrs. W.E. Schmidt, coasted to an easy victory in the featured six-furlong event today at Laurel.

My Purchase 3-year-old son of Purchase and Whim, which races for Mrs. Matt Colford, annexed the fourth race at Empire City yesterday to the surprise of many who watched the odds against his chances rise from an opening at 6 to 1 to a closing of 10 to 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The best fish story of the year is credited by Federal experts to Governor Alfalfa Bill Murray of Oklahoma.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- The text of Senator Robert F. Wagner's address before the Democratic mass meeting in the Hotel Syracuse here tonight was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company was authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to borrow $3,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to pay off interest on its bonds and taxes in New York and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Assertions that unfair competition from Great Britain had become a serious menace to the American Portland cement industry and cheap electric light bulbs of Japanese manufacture threatened the domestic industry with extinction were made today before F.X.A. Eble, Customs Commissioner.

OAKDALE. L.I., Oct. 21. -- With Elmer Taber, fullback, scoring four touchdowns, the La Salle Military Academy football team remained undefeated by crushing McBurney Prep, 54 to 0, on the victor's gridiron today.

TOKYO, Oct. 21. -- "Restoration of peace and order to China is humanity's greatest task in the twentieth century," said Yosuke Matsuoka in a final interview with your correspondent today before leaving for Geneva to make Japan's supreme effort to vindicate her Manchurian policy.

THE DALLES, Ore., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Mayor Fred F. Thompson today proclaimed a banking moratorium until Nov. 1 and the First National Bank, recently merged with the Citizens National, was closed in order to give officials time to work out plans to protect depositors.
The New York University cross-country team brought its dual meet season to a close by triumphing over Lafayette, 20 to 35, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Satisfaction of a $2,632,668 lien resulted in the sale at foreclosure yesterday of the Rockingham and Sonoma apartments and the Hotel Thorndyke, occupying the westerly half of the block bounded by Broadway and Seventh Avenue, Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor was asked today by William L. Hutcheson, director of the Labor Bureau of the Republican National Committee, to investigate the labor record of Governor Roosevelt, as well as certain unspecified, charges alleged to have been made by "Governor Roosevelt's campaign managers."
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Angelo Dente's two touchdowns in the final period today gave Mount Kisco High a 12-to-0 football victory over the previously undefeated Rye Neck High eleven.

In fanciful settings suggestive of Egypt members of the Seventh Regiment will give a Fall military ball tonight in the regiment armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. Virtually the entire interior of the famous old structure will be given over to the entertainment.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Temple University defeated the University of Denver at the Owls' stadium tonight, 14 to 0, and scored its fourth straight victory of the season.

There are "six deadly sins" daily Committed by the makers and distributors of books, Guy Holt, director of Whittlesey House, the McGraw-Hill book publishing unit, said in an interview yesterday. Expanding on ideas contained in his recent address before the New York Library Association, Mr. Holt called the "six sins" those of "being literary, being sentimental, being dull, being improving, being mercenary and humility."

In view of the importance of the financial and business problems that will come up for discussion at the twenty-first annual convention of the Investment Bankers' Association of America, which will be opened today in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., the meeting is expected to be one of the most important in the history of the association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Nov. 8 the voters of New York State will face one of the most momentous matters ever placed before them, voting on Amendment No. 1. This will appear on the ballots and the voting machines as follows:

BUENOS AIRKS, Oct. 21 (AP). -- The newspaper La Prensa, in an editorial headed "The Monroe Doctrine Does Not Interest Us," commented today on a speech this week by Dr. Leo S. Rowe, director of the Pan American Union, at Williamsburg, Va., in which he advocated a Pan-American system based upon the principle of non-aggression.

Representatives of a score of civic organizations voted yesterday to hold a series of open conferences on the general transit problem. Their action, taken at the suggestion of William J. Schieffelin, president of the Citizens Union, resulted from a general discussion at a luncheon given by the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Astor.

BERLIN. Oct. 21. -- The German steel industry is not surprised by reports from Washington that American steel men are demanding more effective anti-dumping protection, but the news increases apprehension here that the United States market is becoming still more narrowed, if not entirely closed to German products.

Lull Affected Accessories Least. The call for accessories in the wholesale market during the week stood out by contrast with the lull which developed in the major ready-to-wear lines. Handbags, novel jewelry, hosiery and rainy-weather specialties such as rubbers and umbrellas figured prominently in the business placed by the stores.
Portraits by Maria von Kammerer are on view at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries, 3 East Fifty-first Street. The exhibition will continue until Nov. 8.
MINNEAPOLIS, Qct. 21. -- Senator Norris in an address tonight proposed currency inflation as the solution of the nation's economic troubles.

Drexel Institute of Philadelphia, undefeated in three straight games since it was tied by Lehigh in its opening contest of the season, will oppose City College at the Lewisohn Stadium today at 2:30 P.M. in the Lavender's fourth contest of the year.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 21. -- San Bellini, with Wilcox handling the reins, won three straight heats to annex the 2:24 trot as a light-harness meeting opened at Sage Park today after three postponements.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The administration's attack upon Governor Roosevelt's Pittsburgh speech dealing with government finances was continued tonight by James H. Douglas, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

MANILA, Oct. 21. -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives discarded Governor General Roosevelt's budget today and prepared one of its own, balancing at 48,000,000 pesos [about $24,000,000], provided nothing is asked for government pensions or public works.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange lost further ground yesterday and closed around the bottom at declines of 4 to 9 points. Partly in sympathy with weakness in the stock market and partly because of the heaviest marketing movement so far this season prices failed to hold rallies when hedging pressure developed.

John W. Davis, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, yesterday replied to the defense by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, of his nomination of City Court Justice Aron Steuer by declaring that Mr. Macy was "probably the first and only individual who ever suggested in public that a judge should be selected on the basis of his father's merit."

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- Public abstention from the market continuing, the Boerse was left almost exclusively to professional speculators today. Trading was light, but the tone was firmer on reports of business improvement in several industries. The gains, however, hardly exceeded 1 point and most of the stock list closed virtually unchanged from yesterday.

Public interest in gardening has increased during the depression because many unemployed persons find more time to devote to this hobby, according to reports made yesterday at the seventh annual presidents' conference of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State at the Hotel Biltmore.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Guy Emerson, vice president of the Bankers' Trust Company of New York, today urged upon the third New England Bank Management Conference "a more sympathetic cooperation between bankers and business men on the one hand and our lawmakers on the other."

After a brief chase in which one was wounded, two alleged hold-up men who said they were deserters from the Eighteenth Infantry at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, and who were believed by the police to have held up at least eight cordial shops in the last two weeks, were caught about 1 o'clock this morning a few minutes after a second raid on a cordial shop at 266 West Twenty-second Street.

A regulation requiring all importers of steel to furnish additional bonds before shipments will be cleared from customs, was issued yesterday by the bureau of customs of the Treasury Department. The order followed a notice to the Customs Burean from F.J.H. Kracke, Appraiser, that he suspected dumping in the importation of steel into this port.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- The campaign document in which Adolf Hitler yesterday accused the von Papen Government of jeopardizing Germany's position in a peaceful world by bringing out a "re-arming program" that demands an army of 300,000 men and big battleships drew a caustic reply from the government today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 21. -- In a speech before 10,000 to 12,000 enthusiasticlly cheering men and women toight, Governor Roosevelt outlined his plan for protecting the savings and investments of the American peole by making secure, as far as posible, the bonds underlying every phase of American industry.

The eleventh, annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association will be held today over the estates of Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White, near Huntington, L.I. Six events will be contested, five over jumps. The first race, at a mile and a half on the flat, has attracted seventeen entrants.

Football throughout the nation stands on the rim of its climax games of the year with the set of contests listed for today. From now on each succeeding week-end will see more "big game" afternoons, with little or no easing off for any of the major colleges except in those cases where supposedly easy engagements have been scheduled as "breathers" before an important encounter.

New State and municipal loans scheduled for award next week amount to $15,968,969, against this week's revised total of $10,032,005. Few issues of any consequence, however, have been definitely announced for award on later dates. Next week's new financing will comprise forty-six issues.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- A lawsuit affecting the Federal and New York State estate tax laws will be argued in the Supreme Court as a result of a petition for a writ of certiorarl granted by the court a few days ago in the case of the Third National Bank of Springfield, Mass., and Frederic M. Jones, executors of the will of Frederick Harris.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Federal restrictions on trading in grain for future delivery may be removed and the responsibility for such trading shouldered by the Chicago Board of Trade, it was learned today after a conference here between Secretary Hyde and directors of the Board of Trade.

The body of Dominick Bifano, 35 years old, of 158 East 115th Street, an associate of the late Eddie Diamond, brother of the late Jack (Legs) Diamond, was found in a burlap bag on the rear seat of a sedan in front of 356 East Seventy-eighth Street at 9 o'clock yesterday morning.

The unbeaten, untied and unscored-upon records of the Colgate and New York University football teams will be in jeopardy as the elevens clash at the Yankee Stadium today. A crowd of 60,000 is expected to watch the battle, the sixth between the two institutions.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 21. -- Outlining a three-point program for the relief of agriculture, Governor Roosevelt, in a speech today in the home city of Abraham Lincoln, charged President Hoover with direct responsibility for foreclosures of farm mortgages by Joint Stock Land Banks through the failure to use the supervisory power of the Federal Government to prevent them.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- The appointment of eight bank examiners was announced today in the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department. They are: Nathaniel Orens, Long Beach; James J. O'Shaughnessy, White Plains; Robert B. Raymond, Mount Vernon; R.B. Caldwell, Glen Ridge, N.J.; W. Sargeant Nixon, the Bronx; Russell F. Prudden, Manhattan; George T. Terry, Richmond Hill, and L.P. Hosmer, Brooklyn. All the appointments were made from the civil service list.

PASADENA, Cal., Oct. 21. -- Aeronautical experts at the California Institute of Technology are studying the eventual feasibility of a "super-airplane" which, propelled by the burning of gasoline in long, open-ended tubes, would dart through the stratosphere at more than 1,000 miles an hour, 250 miles faster than sound, and encircle the globe in twenty-four hours.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that its operations in the third quarter resulted in a net loss of $4,464,229, which, after providing $2,344,207 for preferred dividends, showed a loss on the common stock of $6,808,436, equivalent to 16 cents a share.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 21. -- James A. Farley, national Democratic chairman, in an address under the aupices of the State committee here tonight, warned members of the party that, "though we have the battle won," it would not do to take chances.

An advance of 1 cent a gallon in the price of gasoline throughout New York and New England was announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of New York, Inc. This increase, which applies to all forms of delivery, was met by the other principal marketers.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, traced last night the origin of the move for social justice and humanitarian legislation in the country to the "men sent to Albany by the late Charles F. Murphy," and declared that if any man in his administration brought discredit to the administration or the party, "then he will no longer be a part of the administration."
Lacking subject matter nearer at hand, the stock market fastened yesterday upon gloomy utterances made from a distance as a possible explanation for the fall in prices here.

PUERTO CASADO, Gran Chaco Boreal, Oct. 21. -- Lieut, Col. Raimundo Cardenas, commander of the Thirty-fifth Bolivian Infantry, known as the "Padilla Regiment," arrived here today as a prisoner of war. He denied that his regiment had been wiped out, as was reported by the Paraguayan General Staff, saying it had successfully retreated to Fort Arce, which is now under siege by the Paraguayans.

Acute weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday was ascribed largely by Wall Street to pessimistic comments by Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, at a dinner in London. His remarks, delivered before a gathering of bankers, were quoted widely in this country yesterday and they were interpreted in the most mischievous manner, it was felt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent obituaries of Miss Elizabeth E. Farrell, inspector of ungraded classes in the city public school system, give her the credit she deserved for inaugurating the first class for ungraded children. She recognized the need for separating children who were not fitted for the classes in which they were placed and where they interfered with the progress of others of a more normal mentality.

Columbia's football team renews a series begun in 1900 when it opposes Williams College at Baker Field at 2:30 o'clock today. Following this contest major encounters await the Blue and White, as Cornell, Navy, Brown and Syracuse will be met in the closing stages of the campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- The Rev. Dr. John Stockton Littell, rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church at Lewes, Del., since 1929, died in Jefferson Hospital here today after a short illness in his sixty-third year.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 21 (AP). -- A dazzling 60-yard sprint for a touchdown in the first period by Nick Laney, fleet halfback, and a safety in the second gave Duke University's Blue Devils a 9 to 0 victory today over a battling eleven from Wake Forest.

The fifteen months of investigating by the Hofstadter committee came into the local Mayoralty campaign yesterday in the form of a passing reference, made by Lewis H. Pounds, Republican Mayoralty nominee.

There are plenty of ducks along the Northern Atlantic Coast, according to reports received yesterday. Most of them are native-hatch, but a few northern-flight flocks have landed, one flock at Gardlners Island and another in the sloughs off Stonington, Conn.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Penn took a light, fifteen-minute limbering-up practice today as the final preparation for its annual game with Lehigh on Franklan Field tomorrow.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Oct. 21 (AP). -- Senator Daniel O. Hastings, assistant Republican Eastern campaign manager, said in an address here tonight that Governor Roosevelt in 1928 was a director in a large "holding company, the Consolidated Automatic Merchandizing Corporation," and as such was connected "with a slot-machine trust."

LATONIA, Oct. 21 (AP). -- Form players were driven to cover today at Latonia, three of the first four choices failing to finish in the money and the rout was completed when Thistle Play, running in the colors of George Collins, accounted for the Red Bank purse, featured attraction.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Venus and Jupiter, having separated Oct. 19, not to meet again for a long time, the society lady of the sky, Luna, otherwise known as the moon, takes the centre of the early morning sky stage and calls upon Mars, Oct. 24, notwithstanding he will be beneath her and almost bumps into the telescopic Neptune on Oct. 25, slightly above her.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21. -- The National Democratic party, an amalgamation of the conservative elements which were largely responsible for the election of President Justo, published today a long manifesto on the republic's financial situation.

Mrs. Morgan Barney of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Harriet Stanton de Forest, to Marshall C. Allaben Jr., son of Mrs. Clarke Allaben of this city and of Marshall C. Allaben of Round Hill, Greenwich. Miss de Forest is the daughter of Dr. Lee de Forest, inventor.

KINGSTON, Ont., Oct. 21 (AP). -- The 900 inmates of Portsmouth penitentiary were sorted out, assigned to new cells and fed tonight after prison authorities had succeeded in stamping out the second riot within the week.
