LONDON, Oct. 21. -- A Treasury order issued tonight continues the existing 331-3 per cent duty on iron and steel for a further period of two years, beginning Oct. 25. This is the same duty that was imposed last April as an experiment for three months when Great Britain adopted a general tariff.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman carried his campaign for the Governorship into enemy territory today with a tour up the Mohawk Valley, ending tonight in the strongly Republican city of Syracuse, and received a series of welcomes which gratified him and the Democratic leaders.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 21. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's address in the Arsenal here today was as follows:

MADRID, Oct. 21. -- China is as eager to censor news as is Japan, it became evident today when China refused to go on record against consorship of the international telegraph and radio-telegraph at the joint conferences here, although it was evident that the Chinese proposal for the censorship of messages that might do economic harm was certain to be killed in committee.
One of the busiest Saturdays of the Fall season is scheduled for New York City's scholastic athletes today with football, cross-country, soccer, golf and swimming contests on the program.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Colonel William J. Donovan tonight charged Lieutenant Governor Lehman with personal responsibility for a "ruinous" financial policy which, he said, threatened the stability of the State government.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Rhode Island won the annual Harvard open intercollegiate cross-country race over a five-and-a-half-mile course on the banks of the Charles River today. The victors had a point score of 59, Bowdoin College was next with 61 and Northeastern trailed Bowdoin by one point.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (Canadian. Press). -- The National Government forged ahead today toward ratification of its Ottawa conference trade pacts, defeating by huge majorities a series of amendments aimed at financial resolutions connected with the agreements.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The stock markets were quiet today, with speculative profit-taking, particularly in British Government funds, and prices were lower. Home industrials were fairly steady, but following overnight Wall Street news, the internationals were lower.

John M. Morehead, United States Minister to Sweden, arrived here yesterday on the steamship New York from Stockholm to register in his home town, Rye, N.Y., and cast his vote in the Presidential election. He said that Mrs. Morehead was unable to accompany him because of her many social engagements in connection with the wedding yesterday in Coburg, Germany, of Prince Gustaf Adolf, eldest son of the Crown Prince, to Princess Sibylla of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.

The last days of cancer patients may be freed from pain by injecting a small amount of alcohol near the spine every few months, according to a method described here yesterday at the closing session of the annual Congress of Anesthetists by Dr. Henry S. Ruth of the Hahnemann Hospital and Medical School, Philadelphia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21. -- Clearing and colder weather was welcomed today by the Harvard and Dartmouth football forces which will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the start of their football relationship in the Harvard Stadium tomorrow. A crowd of 37,000 is expected.

Frederic M, Sackett, United States Ambassador to Germany, made a plea yesterday to voters of German extraction to support President Hoover for re-election. Addressing a luncheon of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce Inc., attended by 250 business men, he said ha hoped he was addressing "people who have their roots deep in German soil," so that he could "appeal to your love of the Father-land."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21. -- Lord William Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, in a statement issued tonight in connection with an address he made before the Philadelphia Forum, urged cancellation of foreign debts to this country in order that its own labor might benefit.

Jesse L. Lasky, pioneer motion picture producer and former vice president of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, has signed a contract to produce eight pictures a year for a period of years for the Fox Film Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Sidney R. Kent, president of Fox.

The Right Rev. Fan Stylian Noli, Bishop of the Albanian Orthodox Church, who was President-Premier of Albania in the latter half of 1924 and has been living in exile since his political overthrow, arrived here yesterday en route to Boston, to take over the bishopric of his creed in that city, but struck a snarl over his traveling papers and found himself detained with other immigrants on Ellis Island.

Another European speculative foray against the dollar broke out in the foreign exchange market yesterday, carrying French francs above the gold export point for the first time since early in June and forcing the other gold standard exchanges up one-half to 3 points.

Announcement by the important steel producers that steel rails are to be reduced to $40 from $43 per ton, the price unvaryingly maintained since October, 1922, is a matter of considerable importance. The step is generally assumed to have been taken in order to stimulate purchase of railway material.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover accepted the honorary chairmanship today of the National Women's Committee of the Welfare and Relief Mobilization. The committee was organized by Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady of New York to cooperate with Newton D. Baker in enlisting the aid of women throughout the country to assist in relieving this Winter's distress.
ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- A proclamation issued by Governor Roosevelt today designates Oct. 27 as Navy Day and urges the people of the State to mark its observance. The proclamation reads:

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21. -- The Court of First Instance ordered the release today of 134 members of the Zwi Migdal Society imprisoned since 1929 as a result of a campaign against white slavers at the instance of the Argentine branch of the International Society for the Protection of Jewish Women and Girls.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21. -- The Yale and Army teams, which for two seasons have battled to tie scores, will clash in the Bowl tomorrow before about 40,000 onlookers.
Friday, Oct. 21, 1932. Money market remained listless in go far as business was concerned. Virtually little was done in any section, while quotations for all classes continued unchanged.

Dr. William Linder, president of the Kings County Medical Society, declared yesterday that the physician in general practice was being driven to the wall as a result of the greatly increased use of clinics, hospitals and health centres by wage-earners hi moderate circumstances.

The formation of the International Cinema League for the development of motion pictures as a cultural medium was announced yesterday. The league plans to unite the foreign film interests in this country and to form advisory committees of educators to advance the film as an international art.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Rutherfurd of Allamuchy, N.J., have gone to Aiken for the Winter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- American acceptance of the proposal of the general disarmament conference at Geneva for a four months' extension to March 1, 1933, of the present armaments truce against increasing arms by new construction was forwarded today in instructions from Secretary Stimson to Hugh R. Wilson, Minister to Switzerland and United States representative on the bureau of the disarmament conference.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Sir John Simon found it necessary to repeat to his constituents in Yorkshire tonight what he told the church leaders yesterday -- that he never threw cold water on the Hoover plan for one-third reduction in arms and never was lukewarm in working for disarmament.

THERE are at least 1,000 orchestra players of the finest quality in New York today without work, without prospects and often without sufficient food. Their condition is dreadful. They do not want charity. They want a chance to practice the profession upon which they have spent the best years of their life in expensive education and exacting work.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Connecticut's political campaign this year has gone collegiate. Witness as proof the candidacies of five distinguished university professors, not to mention an all-American football star and coach of other years, for major political offices on three State tickets.

Remedies Ahead of Time. Columbia University Library has on its shelves more than one hundred Plans designed to cure the business depression and prevent its recurrence. Considering that there are 125,000,000 people in the United States and that nearly every other person one meets has a complete cure for our economic ills, a hundred published Plans is very little.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22.--Governor Roosevelt was welcomed by 10,000 persons tonight as he arrived here after a cheering journey through the highlands of Southeastern Kentucky and Eastern Tennessee following a speech at Louisville this noon.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 IN spite of old Mr. Brady's sagelike salute to Boston as the most flourishing seat, at present, of the American theatre, we natives have misgivings. With the reopening, last Monday, of the Wilbur, five downtown playhouses now minister regularly to us -- certainly enough in proportion to the waiting public, perhaps one too many.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 22 -- In the nine months ended on Sept. 30 Ontario's gold mines produced bullion to the value of $34,756,778 from 4,085,839 tons of ore, against an output valued at $31,375,616 from 3,692,207 tons treated in the corresponding nine months of 1931.

WITH only fifteen days remaining before election the broadcasters see the possibility of riches fading. Inspired by the many dollars paid to the microphone during the 1928 campaign, the broadcasting organizations looked ahead to 1932 as a year of wealth.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 -- A mighty stand on its 1-yard line in the closing minutes saved Ohio State from defeat today in its annual struggle with the Pittsburgh Panthers before 20,000 fans at the Pitt Stadium, the game ending in a scoreless tie.

The burden of the sixth instalment of the Appraisal Commission's report to the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry is that "a profound transformation of "the church in the mission field is "needed," and that it must look in the direction of unity and cooperation and away from sectarianism.

WHEN the average American considers the Philippines and their people he thinks in terms of 1898; of the insurrections which followed the first dramatic events of our war with Spain, of bush fighting against savage tribes, and of the old song which ran, "Damn, damn, damn the Filipinoa."

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- It is being recalled in Paris that just a year ago tomorrow Pierre Laval, then Premier of France, arrived in Washington for what was regarded as a momentous interview with President Hoover.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 17 -- It is now being recalled that a seer in Minas Geraes prophesied toward the end of 1931 that Brazil would pass through a severe upheaval during which one of the leading States of the Union would declare war against the Central Government.

Germany has been going through a lively national campaign of her own. The new Reichstag is to be elected two weeks from today. It is now some time since predictions began to drift in that HITLER'S strength would show a noticeable decline in the new Reichstag. Time has strengthened these forecasts.

Spurting on a small volume of transactions, the franc again moved yesterday against the dollar, reaching the highest price since June 9, at 3.94 1/2 cents, which was above the level at which gold can profitably be exported from this country to France.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- Penn's powerful eleven bowled over Lehigh, 33 to 6, today on Franklin Field. A crowd of 20,000 saw the Red and Blue register its fourth successive victory.

Following its example of a year ago, the Metropolitan Golf Association will hold another "I Will Share" tournament this year to aid the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, headed by Harvey D. Gibson.

LONDON. MOST people realize that poetry is worthless unless it ran be read aloud, but in this hustling age we tend to overlook the fact that a similar test must be applied in appraising the literary quality of prose writing also.

FOR a couple of generations Hector Berlioz's memoirs have been a source of edification, entertainment and knowledge concerning Berlioz's life times and character -- perhaps more of his character than accurately of his life and times.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Betterment of Canada's trade with Great Britain, showing an increase in both imports and exports, in addition to increased exports to foreign countries other than the United States, are reported in government statistics this week.
AN unknown fragment of music by Beethoven was performed late last month at one of the Promenade Concerts by the B.B.C. Orchestra in London. The London Times wrote about it as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Formation of a Roosevelt Business and Professional League of Philadelphia, with a membership of twenty-eight prominent men representing both major political parties, was announced today by its chairman, Professor Francis H. Bohlen, of the Law Department of the University of Pennsylvania.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 20 -- Arkansas politics is slowly but surely merging into the new season of Autumnal fox-hunting. Of course, if political prophecy be craved it may be said that Arkansas has supported every Democratic Presidential candidate since the close of reconstruction and assuredly will not turn tables in these days.

BERLIN. ON Nov. 13 our greatest author will celebrate his seventieth birthday. Not only Gerhart Hauptmann's native Silesia but the entire German people will give him many proofs of their admiration and love.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, pinned the label half wet, half dry on his Republican rival, Colonel William J. Donovan, in campaign speeches this afternoon and tonight. He charged that the Republican candidate, in taking a position beside that of President Hoover on prohibition, a "half-hearted, indefinite, vague kind of support on repeal," would not hasten repeal, but would only further confusion, uncertainty and delay.

WEST HILLS, L.I., Oct. 22 -- North Shore society and horse lovers from the Maryland and Virginia colonies, as well as many persons from New York and Westchester County, attended the eleventh annual race meet of the West Hills Racing Association today on the estates of Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State, and Thomas F. White.

ROME. A GREAT Fascist exhibition will open its doors in Rome on Oct. 28 to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the march on Rome. In halls decorated in the flamboyant but not particularly beautiful style affected by the ultramodern school of artists will be gathered a remarkable collection of mementos of the struggle which paved the way for the rise to power of the most dramatic dictatorship of modern times.

ATHENS, Oct. 22 -- M. Ladas, attorney for Samuel Insull, announced today that he had learned that President Zaimis had signed the extradition treaty with the United States, by the provisions of which American authorities hope to take the utilities magnate back to Chicago to face trial.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 22 -- The Rhode Island State football team scored its first victory of the season by defeating the Arnold College eleven, 6 to 0, today. A 44-yard march netted the Rams their score.

Morton Rosenberg, 11 years old, and his sister, Jeanne, 9, returned to their parents' home at 93 Hart Street, Brooklyn, about noon yesterday, and they both admitted a bit ruefully that they were glad they had not carried out their avowed intention of traveling "out West" to escape their violin and piano lessons.

NEW ORLEANS. Oct. 20 -- The unemployed of New Orleans grumbled mildly but effectively this week after their wages had been cut from $2.50 to $1.50 a day. Their grumblings led to a "compromise" which amounted to a restoration of the former rate.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 20 -- If Utah's electoral vote should appear in the Republican column on Nov. 8 it will be because the voters in the sugar-beet-growing counties are convinced that Governor Roosevelt wants to reduce the present tariff on sugar to a basis that would ruin their industry, or because of some similar campaign manoeuvre that the Republican organization may put over between now and the election.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22 -- The Harvard freshman eleven played a 6-6 te with Worcester Academy today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Although making a valiant battle, Rutgers lost to Holy Cross for the eighth consecutive year today, 6 to 0.

The week ended yesterday with markets practically stationary Prices on the Stock Exchange hardly moved put, as a matter of fact, their change during the week as a whole was entirely negligible. The "averages" ended the week about 2 points below the previous week's closing; about 17 points below September's highest, but 21 1/2 above the low point of July.
IN the exuberance of its readability this book makes the most of a story often told. Dr. Fisher presents "a master dramatist," whose flair for publicity is, as he explains, a fine art.

BLACK-SWATHED, pious matrons in Mexico's capital and provincial cities are telling their children that the end of the world is near, for is it not written that before the coining of the Antichrist the church will be "diminished, hunted and outlawed, and its faithful shall worship under the ground and in the depths of the forests," exactly as in the days of pagan and arrogant Rome?

CHERBOURG, Oct. 12 -- Cherbourg's new deep-water port, which will permit great ocean liners to come all the way in and tie up at the docks of the new $2,500,000 maritime station, will be ready for business early next Spring, it is now reported. Thereafter transatlantic passengers will not be obliged to use tenders, but may transfer from a Paris boat-train to their ship or vice versa right on the quays here.

THE one hundredth anniversary of Leopold Damrosch, who came to America from Breslau, Germany, in the pioneer days of American music, was celebrated yesterday by his two sons, Walter and Frank, and other members of the Damrosch family.

CHARITABLE organizations that minister to the ill and needy will be the beneficiaries of several bridge parties in the near future. In aid of the Mary Fisher Homo in Tenafly, N.J., a card party will be held on the afternoon of Nov. 1 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 22 -- Tulane's championship flag was lowered today by the fiery Auburn Plainsmen, 19 to 7, in a furious football game that marked the first defeat of the Green Wave in the South in four years.

PARIS, Oct. 8, 1932. THE chief interest of international festivals of music is to disclose the different aspects which, music assumes. The International Society of Contemporary Music at Vienna and the biennial festival of Venice reveal the fact, paradoxical as it may seem, that the music of differing peoples seems to be tending toward unity.
WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 22 -- The Colby football team blanked Bowdoin, 25 to 0, before a large crowd on Sevearns Field today.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Man's incapacity to keep money in its place is having one more illustration in France. He can harness water, oil and electricity, but money seems beyond him. It flows in, out and around like quicksilver and nobody is ever sure when he has it.

If the State has pursued a "ruinous" financial policy, as charged against Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in Plattsburg Friday night by Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, the responsibility for extravagance lies as much with the Republican Legislature as with the Democratio Governor, Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, declared last night.

THE possibilities of the transport of goods by air are just beginning to make themselves felt. Already the records for 1932 far surpass those for last year. Instead of 400,000 pounds more than 1,000,000 will be moved by airplane before the end of the year, and the field is not scratched.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- In a last-minute rally the Williams soccer team broke a tie to win by 3 to 2 from Hamilton today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- How deep a cache of political dynamite the depression has planted beneath the quiet Republicanism of Western New York will be determined only on election day. Occasional rumblings have given rise to suspicions that at least one blast, and maybe two, can be expected, but nothing violent enough to rip traditions asunder.

Predictions that Maine would go Democratic in November by an even greater plurality than it did in September and that Governor Roosevelt would carry Pennsylvania, "if he gets an honest count" in Philadelphia, were made public yesterday at Democratic campaign headquarters at the Biltmore.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22 -- The long-expected battle for Fort Arce has commenced, this being the third day of an intense artillery duel between the Bolivian defenders and Paraguayan attackers. About 8,000 men are engaged on each side. Bolivia and Paraguay having prepared carefully for a major engagement, expecting it to be decisive.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The Hamilton and Hobart elevens battled to a scoreless tie today before a large crowd.
IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Dr. Paul Kyle, founder of the Kyle School here, will celebrate his fiftieth anniversary as a teacher on Monday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20 -- With a committee of the State Senate investigating the relations between utilities and the Public Service Commission and with a reorganized commission settling into its stride with a large majority of its members appointed by Governor Pinchot, Pennsylvania consumers are now looking forward to having their inning.

BECAUSE Robert Hillyer has made himself known through eight volumes of exceptional poetry, our expectation runs high when we turn to his first novel. And we are not disappointed, for "Riverhead" is a subtle and delicate book, markedly the work of a poet

FRITZ KREISLER is planning to broadcast. When his violin will be heard on the air he does not know. He asserts that he is a member of the old school and must learn the technique of broadcasting before he attempts to entertain multitudes with his artistry.

WASHINGTON. HAS the government invaded to an unwarranted degree the fields of private enterprise? In other words, is the United States engaged in carrying on commercial and other activities in competition with the businesses of its private citizens?
CHAPEL, HILL, N.C., Oct. 22 -- Georgia Tech crushed the North Carolina Tar Heels under an avalanche of touchdowns, 43 to 14, today in Kenan Memorial Stadium.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Twenty-six freshmen at Cornell University have received scholarships valued at $27,800 as a result of examinations held in September.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The speech of Georges Pol Domine in the international oratorical contest tonight was as follows:
In face of an aerial attack, the C.C.N.Y. football team lost to Drexel Institute of Philadelphia, 20 to 0, yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. A crowd of 2,500 watched the contest.

St. Peter's Prep assumed first place in the race for the Hudson County Class A football championship by downing Emerson High of Union City at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, 12 to 6. McAleer skirted right end for the winning touchdown.
ORANGE, Va., Oct. 22 -- A crowd of 3,000 attended the annual joint meeting ou the Foxcatcher Hounds Hunt Club and the Montpelier Hunt Club held today at the estate of Mrs. Thomas H. Somerville.

STEPS are now being taken to straighten out the tangled affairs of Liberia. They are of deep interest to the United States, for this nation has concerned itself so often with Africa's Negro republic that Liberia is often referred to as the "American protectorate."

Two cowboys in high toots and "ten-gallon" hats, one of whom said he was connected with the rodeo now at Madison Square Garden, attempted an old-time wild West hold-up in an Eleventh Avenue restaurant last night. But a customer, who slipped out unnoticed, gave the alarm, and a police radio car arrived and prevented the robbery.

THE collection of antiques may perform the service not only of preserving furnishings of superlative workmanship but also of rescuing from oblivion everyday furniture and domestic arts that possess great historical and other educational values.

Regional committees, including bankers and others serving voluntarily, will be set up within a week by the Second District Federal Home Loan Bank, which has its headquarters in Newark, to facilitate the bank's work and to advise mortgage holders and home owners on the proper method of procedure to procure financial aid, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON. MANKIND may be divided into two groups -- those who appreciate fine architecture and those who do not. It must be regretted that the latter are by far the larger body. Yet for a hundred years after Sir Christopher Wren's death there was an observance of the broad principles he advocated.

THERE is a reminder of a real woman, not merely a nearer chance to see a famous picture, in the return to this country -- on a visit only -- of James McNeill Whistler's portrait of his mother, just half a century after an earlier visit to the native land of both artist and sitter.

"The immediate return of American prosperity depends more than anything else upon the rescue of the farmer from the economic disaster which has overwhelmed him," declares Dr. Bernhard Ostrolenk, economist and authority on agrarian problems, in opening an article captioned "Prosperity Waits Upon the Farmer" in November Current History.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 22 -- Eight persons were injured, two seriously, when two autos driven, by Yale students crashed and overturned at Howard and Davenport Avenues before daybreak.

PARIS. FEW critics or collectors seem to have considered James Ensor a great artist. Even the versatile tongue of Elie Faure who revaluates with so much gentlemanly independence speaks in unwonted brevity -- "Belgian art since Meunier offers little more than one isolated figure, James Ensor, who with frail forms and pale harmonies revives the marionette theatre spirit of Breughal and Jerome Bosch."
To the Editor of The New York Times: I want to offer a correction as to the origin of the Chinook jargon, referred to in a letter by William McDowell in THE TIMES issue of Oct. 14.

THE school bell of the American School of the Air will be chimed by electromagnetic waves tomorrow when the fourth season of broadcasting begins at 2:30 P.M., over WABC and eighty-four affiliated stations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- William Penn's efforts toward temperance stand high among his lagacies to the American people. Dr. William W. Comfort, president of Haverford College, told the Pennsylvania Federation of Historical Societies at a meeting held here today as part of the commemoration of the 250th anniversary of Penn's landing on American shores.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 22 -- On a front of about sixty-five miles the Bolivian and Paraguayan armies are engaged in the heaviest battle of the Chaco campaign, according to an announcement made tonight by General Jose Lanza, chief of the general staff.

PASADENA, Cal., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Dr. Edwin P. Hubble, noted for his study of nebulae, said today he has found new evidence that the earth's stellar system is similar to spinal nebulae, great spinning pinwheels of stars.

Election of Eugene P. Thomas, vice president in charge of sales of the United States Steel Corporation, as president of the National Foreign Trade Council was announced here yesterday by James A. Farrell, chairman, of the organization. Mr. Thomas's election, together with the appointment of Gardner L. Harding to succeed the late O.K. Davis as secretary of the association, took place at the annual meeting of the council last week.

GLUING his eye to a small lens of his own making, held in a silver and gold frame, and concentrating his gaze on a drop of water, Antony van Leeuwenhoek saw strange sights one day in the latter half of the seventeenth century.

A LONG with auction bridge and midget golf, the familiar permanent stock company, which in years gone by was a staple of entertainment in practically every corner of the land, appears to be suffering a rapid decline. Those indisputable criteria, statistics, attest the fact, and the statistics come from no less reliable a source than the Actors' Equity Association.

IN our own American scene -- easy-going, inchoate, indifferent, at loose ends -- indoctrination of the most vigorous kind is going on every minute of the day with a thousand-pound-to-the-square-inch pressure. Many of the best, most alert and ingenious minds of our country are devoting themselves, through the medium of marvelously shrewd advertising, to indoctrinating our children, young people and ourselves with the dogma that the more you possess the happier you are.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Roosevelt High School's football team of Yonkers came from behind to win its first W.I.A.A. game, 8 to 6, from Mamaroneck High today. It was Roosevelt's fourth triumph.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The University of Rochester football team defeated the University of Buffalo today by 12 to 7. Rochester scored in the first period on a blocked kick and in the second period when Drojarski got away for a 55-yard run. De Graff went across for Buffalo in the third period.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Senator Norris of Nebraska tonight told an audience here that President Hoover has failed to redeem "every pledge he made to the farmers" and as Secretary of Commerce "blocked genuine farm legislation."

MUKDEN, Sept. 29 -- The press in Manchuria is devoting much attention to an announcement that Russia has consented to the establishment of Manchukuo consulates at selected points in the Soviet Far East. Coming closely on the heels of Japan's formal recognition of Manchukuo, Russia's action is interpreted by newspapers here as an indication of her intention to accord early recognition to the young State.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Criticizing what she called "the national self-righteousness of the American people," Miss Jane Addams, president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, speaking at Swarthmore College today, attacked intolerance and narrow-mindedness and urged that labor and social welfare policies in this country be founded upon William Penn's breadth of vision.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Senator Johnson, Progressive Republican, announced today that he would speak here next Friday in support of Governor Roosevelt. Last week he issued a statement saying he could not support President Hoover.

TO the corps of correspondents aboard the special trains which carry Presidential candidates from one end of the country to the other, the campaign eventually falls into terms of barnstorming, and reporting takes on the aspect of theatrical reviewing in one-night stands.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- The home of William J. Bogan, Superintendent of the Chicago School System, and recognized as one of the foremost educators in the country, was the target for a black-powder bomb early today, but little damage was caused.

The application for a $2,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation made by the Lehigh Valley Railroad is precedent to the offering of a plan to meet the Lehigh Valley Coal Company's bonds of 1893, which, will mature on Jan. 1. These bonds are guaranteed by the railroad.

Bad dispositions in office workers, poor health and a reduction of efficiency that may amount to more than 10 per cent, result from standardization of office furniture that causes improper posture, Dr. Ralph H. Williams of Rochester said at the annual convention of the New York State Osteopathic Society, which opened at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Ship lines may move their vessels in and out of the port of New York as quickly as they desire when the city's pier-building program is further advanced, Dock Commissioner John McKenzie said yesterday. They may have such facilities as they want and the question of speed is one which the operators rather than the city must decide, he added.
COLONGE, Germany, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Senator William E. Borah, in a letter received by the Cologne Gazette today, defended Germany's demands for arms equality.

THE great virtue of Van Wyck Brooks, as it must be that of any critic worth his salt is that his work becomes in its final essence a sort of bursting seed-pod. The immediate uses and applications of his criticism have their value, of course; but it is in the seeds sown by the ideas he generates, and their slow but sure germination, that his superior and more lasting function lies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The impression that the principal actors on the American political stage have stopped polite arguing and retreated to their respective rock piles is inescapable. If old-fashioned oratory is lacking to dramatize the Presidential Contest, it is only because there is no breath to be wasted in platitudes.

TERRE HAUTE. Ind., Oct. 22 (AP) -- James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told a rally of Indiana Democrats here tonight that the Republicans "are trying to make everybody believe two absurd slogans:
OLYMPIA ARENA, Detroit, Oct. 22 -- The text of President Hoover's prepared address here follows:

Of 357,559 persons placed on probation in this State since 1908 more than 70 per cent have bettered their condition and abstained from criminal activities, it was declared yesterday by Irving W. Halpern, chief probation officer of General Sessions and director of the institutes in probation of that court.

BARCELONA, Oct. 5 -- On the very eve of the implantation of the regional autonomy granted to Catalonia by the Spanish Cortes the battle for federalism which envisions Spain as a union of sovereign States composed of the so-called historic regions is being renewed here.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- With one hand Illinois is accepting Federal loans, granted for the creation of jobs, and with the other is nullifying the Federal objective by creating additional numbers of jobless, recent legislation reveals. This legislation calls for the diversion of road funds for direct relief at the cost of thousands of jobs on roads.

Orders from the office of Major Gen. Benjamin B. Foulois, chief of the Army Air Corps, it was revealed here yesterday, have been sent to all corps areas in the United States authorizing extended cross-country flights by reserve pilots. The occasion of these flights will be the semi-annual convention of the Air Reserve Association of the United States to be held at Kansas City next Saturday.

IF Thucydides could invent speeches to put into the mouths of the personages of his history, why may not modern biographers do the same for their characters? Whether or not modern biographers ask this question, that is what some of them do.
NEW YORK. Emanuele Grazzi, former Italian Consul General at New York, who had been at the Ritz-Carlton, has left to take up his duties as Italian Minister to Guatemala.

Bishop William T. Manning will preach this morning at the All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, in the face of a threat made yesterday by vestrymen to prosecute him and the rector, the Rev. Rollin Dodd, for trespass if they enter the church.
Three long runs, each for more than 60 yards, brought victory to an alert Michigan State eleven over Fordham at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

WITH the honorary patronage of eminent figures in public and official life, and the active cooperation of many younger members of society, preparations are well advanced for three military fetes of early November -- the Victory Ball, the Armistice Day Ball of the British Great War Veterans of America, and the Armistice Ball of the Lieutenant Jeff Feigl Post of the American Legion.

PARIS. IN a manner of speaking, there are millinery openings in Paris every week; in fact, the two days' interim between one fitting and the next at great modistes, such as Reboux. Agnes and Talbot, generally suffices for the creation of a number of new models.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 22 -- William Rhinelander Stewart gave a luncheon at the Greenbrier Casino today for Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt; her daughter, Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis 3d; Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Bingham, Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams and Mrs. Shevlin Smith.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Oct. 22 -- The Trojans of Southern California, the nation's mythical football champions of 1931, met and mastered Stanford's Indians, 13 -- 0, to pass the first mighty test in defense of their title today in a Pacific Coast Conference game.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 -- Senator Hiram Bingham, Republican nominee for re-election in Connecticut, said in an address here tonight that Congress could take no action which would more immediately provide jobs for several hundred thousand people than the immediate modification of the Volstead act and that to legalize beer would greatly aid the taxpayers of this country.

BUFFALO, Oct. 22 -- Except for a temporary and partial paralysis of the leg muscles, a condition that will respond to therapeutic treatment, Governor Roosevelt is robust, according to an opinion expressed today by Dr. Francis E. Fronczak, Health Commissioner of Buffalo for a quarter of a century and internationally known physician.

A Fall military ball in a colorful Egyptian setting -- one of the first large dances of the season -- was given by members of the Seventh Regiment last night in the regiment armory, at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. In scenes suggestive of Cairo, nearly 2,000 guests, including many members of society, veterans of the regiment and men prominent in military circles, participated in the entertainment.

Competition from linoleum and feltbase floor coverings, rather than importations of foreign-made rag rugs, is responsible for the steady decline in domestic rag rug sales volume, Charles T. Riotte, executive secretary of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., said here yesterday.

PROMINENT women and debutantes of this and recent seasons will sell useful articles at a bazaar which has been arranged for Nov. 3 and 4 at the Plaza in aid of the Marie Reparatrlx Home for Business and Working Girls. Many articles suitable for Christmas gifts as well as household linens will be offered.

Responses to a letter sent out recently by Amos L. Beaty, president of the American Petroleum Institute, indicate a widespread acceptance among the larger oil companies of the suggestion that a forty-eight-hour week be adopted as a permanent policy and that a temporary forty-four-hour week program be put into effect as a mean of increasing employment.

A lively debate over the merits of the Republican, Democratic and Socialist parties and their Presidential nominees was staged yesterday at a luncheon of Saturday's Children, a group of women affiliated with the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, in the Town Hall Club.

With the issuance this week of a specially prepared brochure to several thousand retailers, manufacturers and newspapers, the first broad step in the National Quality Movement being sponsored by the National Retail Dry Goods Association will be taken.

WHETHER they do their playgoing amid the tawdry glitter and planless confusion of Broadway or in the quiet of their own libraries theatre lovers from Forty-second Street to California will be interested to know that Burns Mantle, a careful and conscientious chronicler of current American stags happenings, has again come to their aid.

With the Southern marketing movement the heaviest so far this season, hedging pressure continued yesterday to be the feature of trading on the Cotton Exchange and prices sagged to the lowest levels of the week and closed at the bottom, 2 to 4 points lower than on Friday.

The ideal method of State price control is to follow the commodity that is being controlled through all stages of its manufacture and distribution, and to regulate in detail the remuneration of all parties, according to Dr. William P. Sutch of Columbia University, who has just completed a study of the price-fixing efforts of the government of New Zealand in respect to wheat.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22 -- The government issued an order today for auditors of the Ministry of Agriculture to examine the books of seven packing houses, including Armour, Swift and Wilson.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- La Salle College chalked up its third straight victory today by defeating Brooklyn College, 39 to 0, at the Phillies' ball park.
Superior man-power that packed deception and speed paved the way to a 46 -- 0 Columbia triumph over Williams yesterday at Baker Field before 10,000 persons.

OTTAWA, Oct. 20 -- Parliament is debating the trade treaties and tariff schedules which were the tangible result of the recent Imperial Economic Conference held here, and although the outcome is a foregone conclusion -- they will be adopted within the next week or two -- there has been keen interest in the attitude of the Liberal opposition and perhaps some surprise at the uncompromising enmity displayed by Mackenzie King, the Liberal leader.

THE further we are remover from that epochal period during which the microphone be gan to replace the horn, and accoustical gave way to electrical recording, the more marked does that change seem to become and the wider appears the gulf between the old and the new.

IT is never the easiest thing in the world to assemble and fit together a one-man exhibition memorializing the career of an artist who has gone. Sometimes there will be unbridgable gaps in the oeuvre itself, particularly if it cover an extensive span.
Prices gravitated to lower levels in the wholesale markets yesterday, the softer tendency in values being recorded in the grains, cotton, rubber and hides and other staples.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The hand of the Communist International in Moscow can be discerned in the events which lately have occurred in the British labor movement. Last week at the party congress at Leicester the Left Wing group carried all before it, defeating the efforts of Arthur Henderson and his colleagues on the executive to keep the resolutions free from extremist slogans.

ADVERSE weather conditions here and in other sections of the country reduced trade volume during the week. Local stores received only a scattered demand most of the week, although there was a pick-up toward the close. Election uncertainties are now having a larger influence in cutting down purchases by the public, it is believed.

The microbe kept itself well hidden until about three centuries ago. Then it was that ANTONY VAN LEEUWENHOEK, draper and chamberlain of Delft, Holland, first saw it wriggling and devouring food. At last the fabled microcosm of the ancients was revealed. It is for this that LEEUWENHOEK is honored the world over on the three hundredth anniversary of his birth, rather than for his supposed invention of the microscope.

THE new giant of the seas, the Rex, sailed into New York with the very latest in radio equipment built in the Marconi works at Genoa, and with a radiophone outfit exactly the same as the inventor of wireless uses on his yacht, the Elettra.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Cornell defeated Yale by 22 to 36 in their annual cross-country run today. Individual honors went to Captain Joe Mangan of the visitors, intercollegiate mile champion. He finished first and broke the record for the course of about five miles, which lay from just outside the Yale Bowl through the Ray Tompkins woods.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Sterling again slumped in the foreign exchange market today, with the closing rate on New York $3.39 3/8.

MR. GATTI-CASAZZA began his twenty-fifth season with the Metropolitan in the approved fashion last week. He greeted the newspaper men and women with his annual pre-season announcement, beginning in the approved manner, with the name of the opening night opera -- this time Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra."

IT is a favorite device with Mr. Freeman to reveal in the beginning a part of the information that his detective. Dr. Thorndyke, later on is obliged to ferret out for himself, and it is a tribute to the author's skill to admit that this advance knowledge in no wise lessens the reader's interest in the tale.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 22 -- Michigan, on the trail of the Western Conference title, scaled another barrier today, smothering Illinois, 32 to 0, to win its third Big Ten game of the season and remain, with Chicago, the only undefeated and untied conference football eleven.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, announced tonight his opposition to the proposed amendment to the State Constitution to permit construction of "additional recreation facilities" in the forest preserve.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- The "young guard of the Bolshevist movement -- the Communist Youth organization of boys and girls between the ages of 15 and 21, although membership is often prolonged until 22 -- celebrated on Oct. 16 the tenth anniversary of its "chefstvo" or patronage-adoption of the Soviet fleet.

Action of the Board of Estimate on budget reductions promises little relief to the taxpayer so far, Walter Torresson, chairman of the city budget committee of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, said yesterday. Discussing "so-called savings" in the proposed budget as adopted Thursday by the Board of Estimate, he said that although these things were good in themselves, the Board of Estimate had not yet touched the "real waste in city government."
AFTER much discussion it has been decided that, during November, the Prince of Wales, representing King George, shall open the new Parliament House of Northern Ireland, which is now completed.

The financing and construction of the Midtown Hudson Tunnel between West Thirty-eighth Street, Manhattan, and New Jersey are going ahead and will not injure the prospects for the Greenville-Bay Ridge Tunnel as an all-rail freight link between Long Island and Jersey City, according to John F. Galvin, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

Bonds of foreign countries and domestic public utility corporations were the principal loans called last week for payment before their dates of maturity. They will be retired in future months. Only small lots of municipal bonds were added to this month's list.

The fourth Winter of unemployment will find thousands of families suffering from lowered morale, loss of work habits, mental and domestic maladjustments and general inability to attempt any solution of their economic problems, said Lawson Purdy, director of the Charity Organization Society, in a statement issued yesterday by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee on the functions of private welfare agencies as contrasted with those of public relief departments.
LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Weight, the old leveler of the turf, played a leading role in the running of the East Hills Handicap, feature attraction of an excellent card today at Latonia.

Interest in the share market had diminished to such an extent yesterday that the machinery of the Stocks Exchange barely moved. This apathy was reflected also in the lazy movement of prices. The market was almost at a standstill; the composite averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES showed a net decline of exactly 1 cent.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22 -- With the Presidential elections eight days ahead, the entire populace of this country is joining in public demonstrations for the various candidates.

THE Plymouth for next year will be a six-cylinder car, Walter P. Chrysler announced last week. The new car, he said, will embody the "floating power" engine mounting, will be characterized by improved performance and "radically new" fender and body lines and will have the lowest price ever placed on a Chrysler product.

Four Cabinet officers and scores of speakers of less prominence will participate in the heavy barrage of oratory which the Republican leaders are laying down this week, in preparation for the main attack on the Democratic lines in the East that will be led by President Hoover when he appears at Madison Square Garden a week from tomorrow.

ONCE again the Shuberts are to make a production of "The Land of Smiles," the melodious Franz Lehar operetta, whose rights they have controlled almost from the days of prosperity. It is listed to open in Boston on Dec. 26 before coming here.

Charges that Frederick Brown, realty operator, obtained $3,000,000 through various dummy corporations and left them unable to pay their own creditors were made in an injunction suit filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by George C. Franciscus, as receiver, to sequester the property of the Bare-Ray Corporation, one of the purported cloaks for Mr. Brown's loans.

DETROIT, Oct. 22.--Hailing ten sure signs of economic recovery, President Hoover tonight sounded a call for continuation under Republican command of the battle against depression and denounced the Democrats as a party of trouble makers, without constructive program or a candidate who had a comprehension of the fundamentals of Federal Government.

A BELGIAN scientific expedition in Central Africa reports discoveries in the Ruwenzori Mountains, the world's most mysterious mountain group. Various explorers have approached Ruwenzori from the British Protectorate of Uganda on the east, and one of them the Duke of the Abruzzi, climbed the two highest peaks in 1906, after a desperate struggle against jungle and storm.

NOW it is the little things that count; that give character to the costume. The season's gowns, so simple in effect, so intricate in architecture, have made accessories more important than ever before. From bonnets to boots, a variety of wearable items, "little things," so-called, are being created for the individual type and in relation to the ensemble.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Warden Lawes's recent article on education is something like the pot calling the kettle black, for Sing Sing's own school, which Mr. Lawes praises so highly, also fails to make law-abiding citizens of 100 per cent of those exposed to its charactermolding.

Charging that the indifference of bankers to the plight of the small but solvent business man has created an emergency requiring immediate action, Walter E. Soderstrom, secretary of the Gibbs Press, Inc., commercial printers, yesterday announced that he has petitioned the Senate Committee on Banking to hold a special hearing to consider the small industrialists' plight.

THE richest city on earth, claiming with some justice to have taken London's place, as the financial capital of the world, possessing taxable property which even, after three years of depression is assessed at not much less than $20,000,000,000, finds itself today in the position of a debtor who is hard put to it to get a few extra dollars of credit.

THE Macmillan Company points with pardonable pride to the fact that no less than nine Macmillan authors are among the twenty-three who have been chosen as members of the new Irish Academy of Letters founded by William Butler Yeats and George Bernard Shaw.

IN the past year New York City has invested $75,000,000 in the biggest business of all -- saving human beings from hunger, sickness and despair, and keeping alive their faith and hope for the future. This type of investment must be continued throughout the Winter on a similar or even larger scale.
BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- Shall the town of Chatham on Cape Cod change the name of Cedar Street to Skunk's Hill Road? Shall the name of another street be changed from Sea View Street to Wicked Hill Road?

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- The rigid Federal restrictions on open-market trading in grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade have been lifted, Arthur M. Hyde, Secretary of Agriculture, announced here tonight. The ruling, in effect, means that the Federal Government turns over to the Board of Trade the power to police futures trading by its own members.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 22 -- East Orange High scored a 12-to-0 victory over Montclair High today.

Butter. Receipts, 6,021 packages. Weakness developed at the opening, and without any buying support prices declined 1/2c on practically all grades of fresh creamery, with a little easier feeling on held goods. Many of the larger buyers held off expecting to secure some further advantage at the opening at next week.

The Community Workers' Auxiliary of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 172 East Ninety-sixth Street, will give a benefit dance, with supper and games, on the night of Dec. 4 at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. Bridge, backgammon, mah jong and other games will be played.

VENICE, Sept. 29, 1932. THE subject of chamber opera, as presented at Venice, brings us to one of the cardinal initiatives of the festival. Adriano Lualdi has long championed this idea, which coincides with the anti-melodramatic reaction already under way in Italy.
SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 22 -- St. Thomas College scored its third straight victory today, defeating East Stroudsburg State Teachers' College, 20 to 6.

LIFE being so full of a number of things, it is unwise to generalize too solemnly. It is unwise, for example, to say that a play cannot be drawn out of fiction. "Becky Sharp" was so skillfully drawn out of "Vanity Fair" that Mrs. Fiske could never quite draw herself out of the part even when she felt that she was too old to play it.

George Z Medalie, Republican candidate for United States Senator, accused Governor Roosevelt of inconsistency and warned against trusting "Democratic promises on the tariff" in an address last night before 300 independent Puerto Rican voters at a meeting and dance in the Hotel Clarendon.

LONDON, Oct. 5 THERE are people without judgment who seem to be unable to distinguish between a masterpiece and the 'prentice work of a dramatist of genuine promise. They are now doing Rodney Ackland disservice by proclaiming his "Strange Orchestra," which has appeared at the St. Martin's Theatre, to be much more than it is.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his article in THE TIMES Magazine James Truslow Adams says: "The Spanish revolution has gone on its way for a year and more without bringing forward any man whose name is known outside Spain except to those who make a business of following international affairs."

ROME, Oct. 22 -- The Congress of the International Institute of Agriculture here held its closing session today. Financial difficulties arising from unsatisfactory budget conditions of member governments compelled the assembly to devote most of its time to questions of international finance.

DALLAS, Oct. 20 -- An interesting chapter in the half-century-bid struggle for advantage between Texas Gulf port interests and those of the interior is now being written. It concerns the application of the Burlington System for a lower carlot rate on uncompressed cotton from interior points to the ports, heard last week at Dallas by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Texas Railroad Commission.

STILL the airline figures forge ahead. Traffic managers of fifteen major airlines, assembled in Chicago last week for the Air Traffic Conference, announced a gain in the first eight months of this year of 18 per cent in passengers carried, as compared with the same period in 1931, and a gain of 59 per cent in air express.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Steady improvement in the furniture industry in Grand Rapids is reported in the monthly bulletin issued by Seidman Seidman, accountants.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- After an inspection of the political situation in Philadelphia, following a survey at Pittsburgh, what appeared a great difficulty for the Democratic party has taken on the aspect of an impossibility to carry Pennsylvania this year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The NEW YORK TIMES for Oct. 9 contains an article by Major Gen. D. C. Shanks, headed "General March's War Story Attacked by General Shanks"; and with the subtitle: "Defending Pershing, he accuses the Chief of Staff of showing animosity toward the Commander-in-Chief of the A.E.F."

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- The elements of the political situation in Massachusetts are perfectly obvious, but the outcome of the voting on Nov. 8 is very much in doubt. There is discord in both parties. The Republicans are more harmonious, at least in public.

THERE has been an extensive sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "The Late Christopher Bean," a new play by Sidney Howard, which has been taken over for the night of Nov. 2 at the Henry Miller Theatre in aid of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Vic Fleming's Hoyle annexed the 2:20 class pace in three straight heats today at Windsor. Paul Bowser's Oh My took second honors, finishing third in the first brush and second in the next two.

WE are entering in the United States our third Winter of widespread unemployment and constantly increasing want. Each year savings accounts are becoming exhausted. The ability of friends and relatives to be helpful and of neighbors to be neighbors is growing less.

One of the reasons assigned by Senator JOHNSON of California for his refusal to support Mr. HOOVER is his own vehement desire to "give the government back to the people." This is a phrase, or formula, now quite common. It is found in the appeals of the Socialist party and turns up frequently among the vague aspirations of impatient radicals, young or old.

WHEN a character called "Tiger Man" made his appearance in Julian Duguid's "Green Hell" there must have been those among his readers who wondered if there hadn't really been five men instead of four who "walked with death at their elbows" through the "lovely, lonely, sinister green jungle" of South America, and if the fifth man hadn't been named A.A. Milne.

THE telephone, which has for long been an indispensable property in the theatre, was put to a somewhat surprising use one afternoon last week. Not as an unseen character in a stage melodrama was it cast, nor, indeed, was it snatched by an irate husband as an instrument with which to commit mayhem, upon his wife.

With a large amount of idle steel capacity on his hands, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, is making an experiment in aggresive salesmanship. Determined to break down an obstinate sales resistance, he is calling on the trade -- drumming up business.

BACK just before the middle of the past century nearly every one had read or was reading about that rascally schoolmaster in Yorkshire who made his half-starved pupils first spell "winder" and then go clean it. No one thought of his method as a symbol of the coming domination of the deed over the word.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The municipal elections on Nov. 1 in 300 cities and towns throughout England will serve as the first accurate indication of what the country thinks of the Coalition Government that took office a year ago. This polling by towns and boroughs serves about the same barometrical purpose in British politics as the United States Congress elections held in the middle of the Presidential term.

TO what extent, actually, is the United States divided into two nations? How inclusive or exclusive are the two States still described, despite constant mergers, constant shifting of the frontiers, as if they were natural and eternal antitheses -- agriculture and industry, city and country, or, for a handy generalization, "East" and "West"?
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I say a few words in defense of Governor Beverley of Puerto Rico because of his advocacy of birth control?

While scores of churches have reduced the salaries of their pastors and staffs by 10 per cent or more because of the depression, the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, has made no reduction in salaries, but has caused it to be easier for its members to keep up their church life.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 22 -- Andover triumphed over the Boston University freshman eleven today by 20 -- 0.

One effect of declining security values on trust funds was shown yesterday in a judgment against Reinald Werrenrath, singer, in the Supreme Court for $7,084 in favor of the Marine Midland Trust Company as trustee under an agreement between Mr. Werrenrath and Mrs. Ada Werrenrath, then his wife, made in 1927.

UP in Canada they are still telling about Nels Stewart, the belligerent hockey star, and his adventure on the turf this Summer. He was at the Blue Bonnets track when a friend strolled up to him and asked: "Have you got a dollar?"

Formation of a corporation under the Webb-Pomerene act to succeed the Copper Exporters, Inc., with a view to making certain that the foreign buyer may obtain as much of the metal as he wishes within a stipulated period at not more than 12 cents a pound, and thereby to stabilize the industry, is urged by Kenneth S. Guiterman, engineer in the nonferrous metal fields.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 22 -- S. Leslie Doremus of 610 Summit Avenue, former president of the Edgewater Trust Company, who resigned from his position last July under pressure, was arrested at his home here today on a charge of embezzling $6,870 from the funds of the bank.

WHEN Solomon said, long ago: "The thing that hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done; and there is no new thing under the sun," he may not have been thinking of politics, and yet he might well have been.

By the margin of one point Columbia University's varsity cross-country team triumphed over Princeton University's hill-and-dalers in a dual meet over the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The score was 27 -- 28.
CHARLESTON, W. Fa., Oct. 22 -- The text of President Hoover's address here today follows:

Announcement of the awarding of degrees to 161 City College students, who completed required courses of study during the recent Summer session, was made yesterday by Professor Morton Gottschall, registrar. Formal presentation of diplomas will be deferred until the annual commencement exercises in June.

Ten States and the District of Columbia have made effective increased rates of compensation insurance for workmen, according to schedules proposed for this year by the National Council on Compensation Insurance in a report filed last week by Clarence W. Hobbs with the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners at its annual meeting in Dallas, Texas.

AN appealing flavor of wistfulness runs all through this new book by Cornelius Weygandt. Now and then it deepens into a real nostalgia that is keen enough in the author's mind to enable him to put a touch of homesickness for the old America that is no more into the feeling of his reader.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- The nearer Nov. 6, with its balloting for the new Reichstag, approaches the more nebulous does that election become. There is growing tension and uneasiness throughout the electorate just because this very nebulousness is becoming more oppressive, especially among the major parties.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22.--Harvard remained among the undefeated football teams of the country by triumphing over Dartmouth, 10 to 7, today in a game where the tempo of the drama rose steadily to a smashing finale in the last minute, when the Crimson was almost overcome by the Green.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 22 -- Massachusetts State, led by Louis Bush, leading Eastern scorer, defeated Worcester Tech on Alumni Field today, 25 to 0. Bush tallied three times, once on a 97-yard runback of a punt.

A FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD boy wrote at "Jungle Peace" "A wonderful story of the jungle. A wonderful description of natural things in the jungle. You can just imagine yourself there." A much more experienced critic could not have put more accurately into words the charm of Mr. Beebe's writing.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Predicting a sweeping Democratic victory on Nov. 8, Governor Ritchie of Maryland attacked four of the major policies of the Republican Administration in an address tonight before a Democratic rally in the Elmwood Music Hall.

The board of trustees of the Foreign Language Information Service made public yesterday a resolution it has adopted, urging that President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt, as candidates for the Presidency, state their attitude on certain, issues of immigration policy of special interest to foreign-born voters.

With, the first sale tomorrow in six especially designated postoffices of the three-cent stamps in honor of William Penn in and Daniel Webster, the United States Government will have issued no fewer than eighteen commemorative adhesive postage stamps since the first of the present year.

POETRY for those who can see poetry in the esoteric and the macabre is contained between the covers of "The Fivefold Screen." by William Plomer. The edition of this book is limited, with but 100 copies for sale in this country. But those 100 copies should prove something out of the ordinary for those who obtain them.
Colgate's powerful Red Raiders put an end to New York University's dreams of an unbeaten season yesterday when they defeated the Violet eleven, 14 to 0, in one of the day's most important battles.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- The German Government, whose tradition it is ever to take time by the forelock and always be well prepared for any undertaking on which it intends to embark, has rested content since Chancellor von Papen's speech last Sunday on the position taken therein that a more definite consolidation of German private indebtedness, both long term and short term, will be necessary beyond that provided by the present stand-still agreement.
BETHANY, W.Va., Oct. 22 -- A 105-yard scoring dash marked Thiel College's 13-to-0 victory over Bethany today.
ROME, Oct. 21 -- The Fascist party is entering upon its eleventh year in control of public affairs in Italy in full efficiency and at the height of its strength.

Two youths were seriously wounded early this morning by two gunmen who sprang from a hallway at 544 East Sixth Street, fired a fusillade of shots and escaped. The victims, Joseph Ferro, 20 years old, of 540 East Sixth Street, and George Scica, 23, of 428 East Fourteenth Street, were returning to the former's home with his wife, Marie, when the unidentified assailants accosted them.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 22 -- Exeter, defeating Tufts freshmen, 73 to 0, today, ran up the largest score totaled here in twenty years. Rexford Kidd, Academy quarterback, was high scorer with four touchdowns.

On election night, as one watches the returns coming in, it is essential to understand that the early returns have very little value as indications of the final results unless they are accompanied by a statement of bow the same districts voted in a previous election. When so accompanied, however, a pretty small batch of returns, properly handled, suffices to justify a fairly confident conclusion.

THAT highly complex institution, the United States Post-office, whose many ramifications operate with such admirable efficiency, owes its existence largely to the efforts of William Goddard, a Colonial printer of Baltimore.

THESE peaceful Sunday nights of the otherwise hectic world of of Broadway's theatres are a long-established tradition. By stern rule even Equity holds them inviolate. Actors, free for a space from the exigencies of curtain time, curl up with a good book or philosophize in one of the sedater speakeasies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- The outcome of the efforts of the receivers of Middle West Utilities Company to obtain a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is being awaited with interest by security holders and others who have an interest in the company.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly last week, several staples showing stability in the face of reports of unusually large stocks. Coffee and wool tops closed higher, while net changes in rubber were mixed over the range.

At 8 o'clock on Tuesday morning the first brace will be ordered away in the opening stake of the ninth field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, at Fishers Island, N.Y.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 22.--Various forms of activity occupied the October colony of the Homestead today as scores of prominent persons arrived for the week-end.

JUST as the cameras were ready to turn on James Cagney's first peace-time picture, "The Inside," " Carole Lombard declined to play the part in which she was cast on the ground that she did not like the work the scenarists had cut out for her opposite the redoubtable Cagney.

BERLIN. IT was worth while making their acquaintance. Names yesterday unknown stick in one's memory -- thanks to Alfred Flechtheim, who opened his gallery to fourteen artists with reputations still to make.

UNA MERKEL, which, happens to be her right name, is contributing her amusing drawl to "They Call It Sin," which is at the Winter Garden. She was born in Covington, Ky., taught Sunday school, sang in the choir and when she grew up a little traveled extensively with her parents.

The reduction in the price of rails to $40 a ton announced last week by the United States Steel Corporation was hailed in railroad circles as a means for reducing their expenses. While the tendency of prices has been downward in recent years, the charge for rails had remained at $43 a ton since 1922.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- There was little in the news today to cause the trade to take an aggressive stand on either side of the wheat market on the Board of Trade here, and prices drifted within a range of 5/8 cent and averaged lower. Local traders sold on the relative weakness in stocks and cotton and the finish was within a fraction of the inside figures at net losses of 1/2 cent a bushel.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- To be born with feet like Charlie Chaplin does not sound like luck for a racehorse, or for that racehorse's owner. But Motrico, a horse with comedy feet, has just done at Longchamp what no other horse has ever done. On Oct. 9 he won for the second time the Prix de 1'Arc de Triomphe, one of the big international classics of the French turf.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Bank debits, outside New York, for the week ending Oct. 15 were lower than in the preceding week owing to the holiday, but on a daily average basis were about equal to the September average, according to the weekly review of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 22 -- Notebook, racing for the Wheatley Stable and brilliantly ridden by Hank Mills, drove to an impressive triumph over fourteen other 2-year-old fillies in the seventh running of the $10,000 added Selima Stakes today at Laurel.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 22 -- The Louisiana College football team beat the National University of Mexico, 12-0, today in the presence of a record crowd of more than 30,000.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Serious illness compelled the distinguished actor, Henry Ainley, to abandon the role of Jess Oakroyd in the film of Friestly's "Good Companions." The picture is being produced by the Gaumont Company.
WHITNEY Museum of American Art-Memorial exhibition of work by Glenn O. Coleman, Opened to the public last Tuesday and remains until Nov. 16. Reviewed Oct. 18 and on this page.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 22 (Canadian Press) -- In a market-page review in which it is declared stabilizing operations were necessary this week to hold both December and May wheat futures at current levels, The Winnipeg Free Press today says:

CRAWFORDVILLE, Ind. ON the last three days of this month Wabash College will celebrate its 100th anniversary. The "Wabash Country," in which it is the oldest-institution of learning, was first settled in 1821. Eleven years later a little band of Presbyterian ministers came together in Crawfordsville, in the 16-year-old State of Indiana, and founded the college -- it has never, however, been officially a Presbyterian institution.

STATESBORO, Ga., Oct. 19 -- Another "Jimmy Valentine" has appeared way down here in the turpentine section, of Georgia. Only the hero of this safe-cracking yarn had to get a hammer and a chisel with which to perform.

Attilio Piccirilli, sculptor, whose bust of Jefferson stands in a niche in the rotunda of the Virginia Capitol at Richmond, received the Thomas Jefferson Presidential Medal yesterday in recognition of his contributions to art, education and citizenship. The medal was presented at ceremonies in the hall of the Board of Education by Governor John Garland Pollard of Virginia.

THE really interesting basic thought in the narrative of "One Way Passage," a picture which has been held over for a second week at Warners' Strand, deserves more serious consideration it has received. The main and original idea is unfortunately some what vitiated by implausible streaks of comedy, which, although they drew laughter from audiences last week, drag the production down from a high level it could have attained as a straightforward drama.

NOW that the Summer has drawn to its close, it is gratifying to know that the vartous temples of learning in this metropolis which are known as dramatic schools have, in spite of the depression, sent back into the open spaces of the West and the South a considerable quota of disciples who know all about acting and are atwit and agog to pass on their acquired knowledge to the folks at home.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 10 -- Although there has recently been a perceptible coolness in Anglo-Argentine relations, neither Argentine officials nor British residents were quite prepared for the publication recently of word from London that the proposed visit to England of the Argentine Minister of Agriculture at the head of a special commercial mission would serve only to obstruct the negotiations for a new trade treaty now being conducted by the Argentine Ambassador.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Oct. 20 -- The ebbing enthusiasm of Kansas voters presents a problem that master strategists of both major parties are trying to solve. Measured by attendance at political rallies and a check on radio listeners, there has been more interest in this campaign for State and national candidates than in many years, and yet field men from Republican and Democratic headquarters report a growing interest in independent candidates.

MATAWAN, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Reorganization of the Matawan Bank, which was closed last December for the protection of depositors and stockholders, was completed at a meeting of stockholders here today. Christian Hausner, a commission merchant of New York City, former president of the bank, who will head the new organization, announced that a loan of $100,000 had been granted by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- Governor Rolph's assiduity in attending rodeos, during which, it may be presumed, he closely noted the technic of the bulldoggers and the buckaroos who "bust" the wild steers, has stood him in good stead during the past week or ten days.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A political parley took place here today on the eve of the departure for Europe of Wang Ching-wei.

An article by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, entitled "Fifth Avenue's Contribution to New York City" is contained in a shopping guide to the Fifth Avenue section, issued yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association in connection with the thoroughfare's silver jubilee celebration.

James Butler's Apprentice, winner of the Bedford Handicap on the opening day of the Empire City meeting, made it two in a row yesterday when he captured the featured Yorktown Stakes before the largest crowd of the meeting.

The premier event of the year in contract bridge, the annual competition for the team-of-four trophy donated by Harold S. Vanderbilt, will take place at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of this week, it was announced yesterday by Commander Winfield S. Liggett Jr., secretary of the committee in charge.

NEWTON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Arthur Barry, the notorious sneak thief, who got away with more than $2,000,000 in gems from exclusive homes in Nassau and Westchester Counties five years ago and who subsequently shot his way out of Auburn Prison during the riot there in July, 1929, was captured tonight near here on a lonely farm, where he had been living under an alias for the last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- In response to a request by President Hoover, the tariff commission will begin a study next week on the effect depreciated currencies of foreign nations have had upon the American tariff wall.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 22 -- An effective passing and rushing combination, composed of Fishel and Stark, enabled Syracuse University to defeat a persistent Penn State eleven, 12 to 6, today.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 22 -- A fighting band, of University of Oklahoma Sooners came from behind to upset Kansas State on a wind-swept field today by snatching passes for two touchdowns in the final period. The score was 20-13.

NEW YORK CITY, the world's most densely populated centre, with an estimated 1,000,000 automobiles on its streets every day, has yet to solve the problem of the parked motor vehicle. "With other cities throughout the country, it is seeking the avoidance of traffic congestion, the speeding up of vehicles through the streets, the expediting of deliveries and the saving of money, time and nerves.

Sentences of ten days each in the workhouse were imposed upon Mrs. Eleanor Curtis Henderson, wife of a Columbia University instructor and Communist candidate for Congress in the Twenty-first Congressional District, and seventeen other defendants yesterday by Magistrate William A. Farrell.

Competing against the pick of the schoolboy cross-country runners in the metropolitan district, Steven Szumachowski of Mont Pleasant High, Scheaectady, N.Y., scored an easy victory in the eighth annual Manhattan College interscholastic run yesterday morning at Van Cortlandt Park.

THE Midtown Galleries, in line with their policy of furthering the interest in American art throughout the country, will present a series at art talks by prominent critics, collectors and artists, through the courtesy of the National Broadcasting Company.
The Riverdale Country School football team conquered Hackley School of Tarrytown, 6 -- 0, yesterday in their Triangular League battle on the Riverdale field.

WATERBURY, Oct. 22 -- In his first major address of the present campaign, Governor Wilbur L. Cross, Democratic candidate for re-election, proposed "a non-partisan four-year program, participated in by State, county and town authorities, designed to make the State of Connecticut pre-eminent as a desirable place in which to manufacture, farm and live."

ROME, Oct. 7 -- The "Fasci Giovanili di Combattimento," or Young Fascists, are celebrating this month the second anniversary of their organization. They came into being just two years ago, to provide a kind of transition stage between the juvenile "Avanguardisti" and the full members of the Fascist party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Soviet dumping of manganese ore has paralyzed the American industry, J. Carson Atkerson of Woodstock, Va., president of the American Manganese Producers' Association, charged at the Customs Bureau hearing today.
