He declared that all mines in the country have been closed and that many people have been thrown out of work.

THE public this week will have opportunity to view the new lines of automobiles for the coming year brought out by two manufacturers. One is the Franklin company's "Olympic" series, the other the Marmon sixteen-cylinder models. In both cases the prices are said to be lower than any placed on previous corresponding models.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- No extraordinary session of the Legislature will be called by Governor Roosevelt to amend a statute in order to prevent the expiration of a list of more than 2,500 school teachers in New York City awaiting appointment, M. Maldwin Fertig, counsel to the Governor, today informed those who had urged Mr. Roosevelt to act.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 22 -- The fleet Cornhuskers of Nebraska, defending their Big Six football championship, defeated the revived University of Kansas Jayhawkers, 20 to 6, before a Kansas homecoming crowd of 9,069 today to remain in a tie with Oklahoma for the conference leadership.

First of a notable trio of equine exhibitions, the Boston Horse Show will open in the Boston Garden on Tuesday and continue through the week, with afternoon and evening sessions. It will be followed by the National Horse Show, to be held in Madison Square Garden, beginning on Wednesday, Nov. 9, and running through Tuesday, Nov. 15, with a special popular-priced show on Sunday, Nov. 13.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 22 -- Brown used only the simplest play this afternoon to turn back Tufts 11 to 0, apparently keeping under cover whatever deception it may have in store for Harvard next Saturday. Captain Bill Gilbane, Tom Gilbane and Joe Buonanno of the Brown regulars did not go onto the field at all, while the Brown brothers, Larry and Roland, had but a brief workout.

The first of the Sherry's Saturday supper dances took place last night in the main ballroom of Sherry's at 300 Park Avenue. The series of entertainments is under the direction of Charlie Journal. A program of divertissements included performances by Helen Knott and Chester Towne, dancers, and Murray Smith, pianist.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet Government received assurances today from General Su, commander of Chinese forces opposing the Manchukuo Government, that he would permit "peaceful" Japanese prisoners to evacuate to Soviet territory.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Led by the sensational playing of Halfback Eddie Myers. Bucknell downed Lafayette, 14 -- 6, before a homecoming-day crowd of 7,000 today. All the scoring was done in an exciting third period.

HOLLYWOOD. NEW microphones, new recording equipment and an ever increasing knowledge of what can be done with sound now permit sound recording to be made anywhere in the world with the pictures and then brought to Hollywood for assembling.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 20 -- Action of the Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals in holding unanimously that this State's Congressional redistricting act is unconstitutional because of gross discrepancies in the size of the districts, will have at least one outstanding result.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and Elihu Root yesterday accepted posts as honorary chairmen of the Independent Judges party, backing the candidacies of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch for the Supreme Court.

OTTAWA, Oct. 20 -- Stern and outspoken comment on Canadian railroading and its associated enterprises features the report to Parliament of the Royal Commission on Transportation, which was headed by Justice L.P. Duff of the Supreme Court of the Dominion, and whose six other members included Lord Ashfield of London and Leonor F. Loree of New York.

A warning against the spreading assumption that rapidly increasing and lasting prosperity is in sight, based on the current improvement in business in this country, was sounded by the Taylor Society in a report published yesterday, which saw in the reduced purchasing power of the majority of consumers a threat to any extended trade revival.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- The Library on the Common has closed for the season. The Parkman band stand which it occupied is a chilly place now, with only a roof above and a colonnade around, and the books and somewhat tattered magazines have been dumped into boxes and carted away.

In the slowest trading for a Saturday this month, prices of bonds sagged generally yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Foreign government and municipal obligations were irregular, while all other classifications, including United States Government securities, closed lower.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic nominee for Mayor, pledged last night in an address in Queens that he would make the city's officials and employes "toe the mark" if he is elected and indicated that he would be an exacting executive.

Scoring all its points in the third period to overcome the High School of Commerce's 13-to-0 lead, Stuyvesant's football team defeated the Commerce eleven, 14 to 13, yesterday at the George Washington High School Stadium in the annual renewal of their traditional series that started in 1908.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Advocating the elimination of Mrs. Miriam A. Ferguson from the race for the Governorship, Orville Bullington, "a Republican, but a Texan first," said today that, in return, he would withdraw as the opposing nominee and support the Roosevelt-Garner national ticket.

CAGNES-SUR-MER, France, Oct. 20 -- Caesar, the dog gigolo, is in jail! He was arrested for theft; caught with the goods as he was about to bury a diamond-studded collar he had stolen from a Pekinese, as if it were a mere bone.

Of paramount interest to hunters is an official announcement from the New York State Conservation Department issued yesterday in anticipation of the general hunting season, which begins in this State on Tuesday.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- An interesting wedding fashion was noted at the Breguet-Fenwick ceremony. The bride's gown, by Worth, had a tight plain-sleeved bodice and a long trained skirt, all made of white satin ribbons joined by fagoting. Fifteen small bridesmaids wore gray faille replicas of the bride's dress.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 23 -- The new civil war in Shantung, which appears at first to be only a quarrel between two provincial Generals for new territory, is really of national significance. It marks the end of submission to the orders of the Nanking Government by General Han Fu-chu, and his final rebellion against Nanking's edict that he may not have access to the sea.

A Catholic University eleven that had amassed ten straight victories aver a two-year stretch was extended to its utmost by a fighting Manhattan team in gaining a 12-7 triumph before 18,000 spectators at Ebbets Field yesterday.

WINTER PARK, Fla. COLLEGE youths and college professors have markedly different views on the best methods of improving the student's use of leisure time, it appears from prescriptions written for the problem by two committees at Rollins College, one of students and one of faculty members.

BERLIN. GERMAN politics, while absorbing, are heavy and somewhat exhausting. Let us take the evening oft and look into that lighter side of German life of which one has caught passing glimpses while flitting about this busy city.

Elliott Daingerfield, one of the important American artists of the older generation, who was a trustee of the National Academy of Design for many years and first showed his work at the academy exhibitions more than half a century ago, died suddenly last night in his apartment in the Gainsborough Studios, 222 West Fifty-ninth Street.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 22 -- The University of Missouri Tigers snapped out of their lethargy today, but failed to gain when gains meant touchdowns and wound up in a scoreless tie with the Iowa State College Cyclones.

Unless Canadian manufacturers of newsprint can compose their differences within a week, the protracted efforts to stabilize that industry in the Dominion through a consolidation of major companies will be in serious danger and a price war of world-wide importance is likely to begin, according to opinion in the financial district.

MR. DELL essays an ambitious and difficult task in this massive novel, in the portrayal and analysis of a young woman who rises successfully above conventions and inhibitions in the historical setting of the 1840s in Boston, Concord, the mill town of "Pickering" and, finally, in rural Pennsylvania.

BELGRADE, Oct. 21 -- The Congress of the Serbian Orthodos Church, which has just concluded thirty-four days of sessions at Karlovci -- where the Holy Synod of Bishops still is sitting -- emphasized a truth of both religion and politics Plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose (The more things change, the more they remain the same).
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Oct. 9 appeared an article written by General Shanks which purported to be a "Defense of General Pershing."

HELSINGFORS, Oct. 10 -- The election in the United States will be watched in Finland with unusual interest. It is believed here that in repealing her prohibition law at the beginning of this year Finland struck a blow also at the American dry law. The American wets, so it is argued, have taken courage from the example set here and the Finns are now eager to see what the result will be on Nov. 8.

PATSY KELLY has been a great disappointment to her father. Not that this youngest daughter hasn't been successful. In the course of a very few years Miss Kelly has participated in five musical shows and at present, at the age of 22, is co-starred with Clifton Webb, Charles Butterworth and Tamara Geva in "Flying Colors."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Visitors will be welcome on all ships of the navy and at navy yards, naval stations and air bases all over the world on the eleventh annual celebration of Navy Day, next Thursday, marking the anniversary of the date in 1775 when the Continental Congress established the naval force and also the birthday in 1885 of Theodore Roosevelt, a strong advocate of naval preparedness.

When Premier Herriot told a committee of the French Chamber of Deputies the other day that while France hoped for successful negotiations on the war debt she owes the United States, she would in any case pay her bill of $400,000,000 for war stocks purchased from us, he caused some little surprise in Washington.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 22 -- Following is the text of Governor Roosevelts address here today:

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 22 -- Headed by the rushing Jack Manders and Brad Robinson, Minnesota conquered Iowa by 21 to 6 today before 15,000 Hawkeye homecoming fans who sat through a dismal rain most of the contest.
OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- St. Bonaventure College won from Westminster at football, 13 to 7, today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Belief that an organized gang is operating here on a set quota of one flogging a week, administered to some person accused by the band of activities to which it objects, was expressed by police today following upon reports of additional whippings which brought to ten the number recently reported.

A lull in the purchasing of ready-to-wear lines featured buying activity in the wholesale markets here during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. The drop in orders was held due both to adverse weather conditions and to the fact that retailers are allowing their stocks to run low prior to the purchase of specially priced merchandise for November sales.

Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court has presented a collection of more than 1,000 law books, comprising most of his personal library, to the School of Law of St. John's College, Brooklyn, according to an announcement yesterday by the college.

Rare English sporting prints and a few sporting paintings, the collection of the late Frank Knight Sturgis, banker, were placed on exhibition yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. They will be sold the evening of Oct. 28 by order of James Madison Blackwell, William T. Eldridge and Henry T Sturgis, executors.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Amos Alonzo Stagg brought his Chicago Maroons, a band that looked like the Maroons of old, back to the Big Ten football wars today to earn, by two quick thrusts, a 13-to-7 victory over Indiana's husky Hoosiers.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 20 -- The memory of T. Coleman du Pont, former Senator from Delaware, who gave Cumberland Falls to Kentucky as a State park, was honored last week when a memorial was unveiled near the cataract. In the mountain gorge through which the Cumberland River continues to rush untrammeled by the hand of man, a life-size bas-relief bust of the late Senator bears the following inscription:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22 -- Tennessee's regulars sat on the sidelines for most of the game today and watched their second, third, fourth and fifth string team-mates run up a score of 60 to 0 against the Maryville College Highlanders.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22 (AP) -- With one complete team from the United States, flying the colors of the Meadow Brook Club, eight teams will compete in the Argentine open polo championship which will start Tuesday. The final match will be played Nov. 11.

The Winter's war in behalf of the unemployed is on. The plan of battle is to be found on a page in the Special Feature Section of today's TIMES. The first call is upon every voter to give support in the coming election to Proposition No. 1, authorizing the issuance of bonds by the State in the amount of $30,000,000 for relief, from which New York City should receive $15,000,000.

The shattering of the national interscholastic swimming record for 50 yards free style by Nathan Cannon of George Washington High School and the defeat of Erasmus Hall's interborough champion team were outstanding features of the weekly dual meets for the Public Schools Athletic League senior high school acquatic titles yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Yale's football hopes received a disastrous setback today with the most top-heavy score registered against the Bulldog in recent years.

There is endless talk every year in the United States about the reform of criminal justice; but, like MARK TWAIN'S weather, nobody does anything about it. In The Panel that long-honored and still active veteran jurist of Ontario, the Hon. WILLIAM RENWICK RIDDELL, Justice of Appeal, describes the administration of criminal law in Canada.

A SCENE of kaleidoscopic brilliance will be presented at the second annual Peacock Ball on Nov. 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The several smaller ballrooms of the entertaining suite will follow a decorative motif representing famous casinos in many sections of the United States and Europe.

SCHENECTADY, K.Y., Oct. 22 -- Colonel William J. Donovan hit tonight at Lieut. Gov. Lehman on the score of the public utility holdings of the banking firm with which his opponent was associated for many years.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. WE have just had a week of lightness in the German theatre--a week of whipped cream and gossamer. It ran the thistledown gamut from modern society comedy to Shakespeare, from topical revue to Offenbach.

DETROIT. THE bottom and the top of the automotive list vied for public attention during the last week and, so far as this particular city was concerned, both received their share of attention. Chrysler's announcement of his intention to abandon the four-cylinder engine for the Plymouth, in the face of the industry's recognition of his share in reestablishing it in popular favor, was a much-discussed subject.
Deputy Reynaud has been Minister of Finance, Minister of Colonies and Minister of Justice in various French Cabinets. He is in this country as a quest of the American Bar Association.

MISS BLANCHETTE HOOKER'S marriage to John D. Rockefeller 3d is the outstanding wedding of next month, and the first to take place in the Riverside Church, known as the Rockefeller Church, with a member of that family as a principal.

Boys High School gained its third victory in four smarts this season by routing James Madison High, 23 -- 6, before a crowd of more than 5,000 at Boys High Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The triumph marked the first time that the Red and Black had defeated its annual rival since 1928.

DUBOSE HEYWARD has turned from his Porgies and his Mamba's daughters to write a novel as romantic as the old South that made Walter Scott its favorite entertainer. He has turned backward in time to the first months of the Civil War and before, choosing for himself all the properties of the period; a duel, a race week in Charleston, an auction of Negroes, the St. Cecilia Ball.

"Les Visions Blanches," a group of painting by the French artist Louis Icart, were placed on exhibition yesterday at the Metropolitan Galleries, 530 Fifth Avenue, to remain until Nov. 5. A biographical note in the catalogue contains the following information:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Following the lead of the Federal Government, farmers have been refinancing their short-term, high interest rate debts with long-term cheaper money this year according to the Farm Loan Board.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 22 -- Four thousand Boy Scouts, led by Daniel Carter Beard, veteran scout leader, end other national scouting officers, filed past the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Young's Memorial Cemetery here this afternoon in their annual pilgrimage to the shrine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 15 totaled 650,578 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 24,942 cares more than in the preceding week. 111,018 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 280,527 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

THE keels of the fastest deepwater ships ever to be built in the United States will be laid down shortly in shipyards from coast to coast. Thirty-seven-knot destroyers -- whippets of the sea -- will be slowly shaped with riveting hammer and welding torch from the blueprint lines of the drafting room and the curves of the molding loft.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 22 -- End runs and line plunges in the opening minutes of play resulted in two touchdowns and gave Blair Academy a decisive victory over Lawrenceville school, a rival of seventeen years' standing, today on Blair Field before a crowd of 2,000.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 22 -- A favored and undefeated Wesleyan eleven was defeated today on Andrus Field, 6 to 0, in the opening game of the Little Three series by an Amherst team which unloosed a brilliant passing attack.

Two strikingly different pictures of Federal finance have been painted for the voter. In his address last week at Pittsburgh Governor ROOSEVELT estimated that "routine" expenditures in Washington were "approximately $1,000,000,000" larger in 1931 than in 1927, and described the rate of increase during these four years as "the most "reckless and extravagant pace I have "been able to discover in the statistical "record of any peace-time government "anywhere."
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 22 -- The Villanova College football team came through with its fourth victory of the season today, when it easily defeated Loyola of Baltimore, 31 to 7.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 22.--Three gunners tied for the high scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Each broke 48 out of a possible 50 targets. A.C. Webb scored in the shoot-off with a card of 24, R.H. Helsel had 23 and G. Mole 22. The high handicap cup went to F. Wise, with Mrs. G.J. Wheeler taking second prize.

EDUCATION that helps pay for itself as it goes has just been developed in a class in nature study in a high school in Weimar, Germany, according to an account that has coma to New York. That unusual consummation is reached by combining this study with the study of photography, which brings datable products.

Evander Childs High School's football team upset James Monroe High, 7 -- 0, yesterday before a large crowd it James Monroe Field. It was the first defeat in three games for Monroe and the initial triumph for Evander.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 20 -- Alberta Legislature this year decided that wastage of natural gas in Turner Valley oilfield, south of Calgary, must be curbed. Orders were issued to reduce the loss some 90,000,000,000 cubic feet per year. A three-man commission was appointed to do the job.

A wide variety of items, of which there were several sell-outs, featured local retail promotions during the week, according to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer-Both Retail Reporting Bureau. Less emphasis was placed on ready-to-wear, in consequence of the poor selling weather which prevailed.

Just now New York City is facing something of a fiscal crisis. It has not come without warning, or as the result of forces beyond its control. The depression was not the cause of the city's difficulties, as the politician likes to think, but only the occasion for them to become suddenly menacing.

Directors of the two largest industrial units in the country -- the United States Steel Corporation and the General Motors Corporation -- will hold meetings within ten days to conclude whether their companies, in the light of a widespread improvement in sentiment, are justified in continuing to draw upon their cash resources to maintain dividend payments.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 22 -- A flying start brought Marquette University two touchdowns early in the first quarter, and Boston College was never able to overcome the lead.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Isn't it hard enough to take care of one's own ideals without adopting or being bothered by those belonging to other people? Not that I would for a moment assume my own standards to be superior to those of my neighbors, but they are mine and I have chosen, though I do not pretend to have invented, them.

A CORRESPONDENT asks questions which have much to do with the attitude of audiences toward performers, composers and music. Some of these questions could be called naive. But they reflect the thinking of many concertgoers. The letter is as follows:

CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 22 -- The Washington State Cougars, mudspattered and water-soaked, trotted off the field today victors once more over Oregon State College. The score was 7 to 6. Oregon State's kick for the extra point was low.

BERLIN. IF we were to graph any German film season, we would always find its line taking a sharp upward trend at the name of Elisabeth Bergner. Her yearly film is awaited with an intense expectancy which has something almost religious about it.

IN the popular lecture on the expanding universe that he delivered a week ago in Berlin Professor Einstein remarked that the earth la 10,000,000,000 years old, thereby arousing the wonder of geologists and cosmogonists who had more or less accepted 3,000,000,000 years as a satisfactory estimate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A marked decline in requests from banks and other financial institutions for assistance from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is shown in its report to Congress giving the names of September borrowers which was made public today by South Trimble, Clerk of the House.

THE five essays comprising this little book -- "informal essays," the author calls them -- are all more or less concerned with the varying attitudes of sections of the American public toward theoretical questions of war and peace, their psychological implications and the conflict between them and practical conditions.

BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Oct. 22 -- Geneva trampled Boston University this afternoon, 39 to 6. The Covenanter attack of passes and runs had the Terriers baffled all afternoon, and Geneva had little trouble rolling up the score after the opening period had reached the half-way point.

MEMBERS of the social and musical worlds are taking an active interest in the forthcoming series of musical events that has been arranged in behalf of the endowment fund of Town Hall. The series will open with a recital by Feodor Chaliapin, Russian baritone, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera, on Dec. 7, at Town Hall, and other events in the series will be given there at frequent intervals throughout the season.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 22 -- Alabama's Crimson Tide defeated Mississippi today by 24-13 The Mississippians offered stern resistance and Alabama was forced to use its first team early all the way, leading by only 6 to 0 at the half.

DURING the last few months unusual diplomatic activity has been taking place in Europe. The present situation is in a state of flux; a new alignment of the powers may emerge. Recent negotiations have not been restricted to the leading governments of the Old World; they have involved the United States.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 22 -- Noire Dame's football army is still looking for opposition.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 22 -- Foreign military experts attached to the legations in peiping confidently expect an early official announcement from Tokyo that Japan has decided to limit the scope of her military operations in Manchuria to the area eastward and southward from the Kinghan Mountains, tacitly admitting her inability to conquer the vast Barga region and the wooded mountainous area northward from Harbin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- In a belated report on construction activity in New York in 1929 the Bureau of the Census showed today that the peak year witnessed building activity totaling $1,323,724,000 in New York State.
BLACKSBURG, Vt., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Virginia Poly's eleven today scored a smashing 7-to-0 triumph over Kentucky that halted the Wildcat's march through Southern Conference elevens.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor, took up the issue of charter revision yesterday, both in his daily interview with the press and in his one speech of the day, delivered before the Women's Republican Club of Riverdale, at the Riverdale Country School, Broadway and 242d Street.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- Parisians as well as Americans who own chateaux in the Paris region have done more entertaining this Autumn in the country than usual, for it is the first time in many years that we have had such a long stretch of good weather and a real Indian Summer.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 22 -- Voicing a spirit of optimism and confidence in marked contrast to that displayed at the meetings during the last two years, many of the 400 delegates and guests of the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America expressed the view that "the worst of the depression is past and gradual business recovery is in progress."
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 22 -- The Brooklyn Poly Prep eleven went down in defeat before the Hill School team on Dell Field today, 32 to 0.
NASHVILLE, Ienn., Oct. 22 -- After being outplayed in the first half, Vanderbilt rallied to score twice in the final periods today and defeat the University of Georgia, 12 to 6.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The other evening I went to a symphony concert, an open air affair, played by a small orchestra in a small town. It was a blind chance on my part for I knew neither how well my neighbors would listen, what the musicians would play, nor what the heavens would do.
SEATTLE, Oct. 22 -- The battered Bears of California trampled the Pacific Coast Conference championship hopes of the University of Washington football team today by scoring a sparkling 7-6 victory.

ONE of the strangest airlines in the world in now in full operation in New Guinea, second largest among islands. Since the termination of the World War Great Britain has held sway over about one-half of the island, the other half being Dutch.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22.--Georges Pol Domine, an 18-year-old French school boy, won the seventh international oratorical contest at Constitution Hall tonight.

WASHINGTON. THE sight of a bruised and bandaged hand on the wheel of the Ship of State a few mornings ago served to acquaint the country with the fact that the Presidency is possibly the greatest handshaking Job of modern times.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 -- As President Hoover made his campaign tour through the mining and manufacturing sections of Ohio and West Virginia today, he preached the doctrine of the protective tariff as the only insurance for open mills and a living wage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The text of the monthly report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to Congress showing loans authorized in September totaling $137,346,000 follows, as made public by South Trimble, Clerk of the House. Less repayments exceeding $100,000,000, outstanding loans on Sept. 30 totaled $995,406,403, with $289,580,373 authorized but uncalled for.

THE good parent apparently, like the good teacher, cannot be made merely by learning the preferred rules and reading the new books on child-rearing. First, he must be a person in his own right, with a coherent and developing philosophy of life.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 22 -- Outrun through the first two miles of the hard three-and-a-half-mile post and rail course, Brose Hover, the aged chestnut gelding owned by Benjamin Leslie Behr, scored a much-merited victory in the second running of the Long Island Hunt Cup at the eleventh annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association on the estates of Colonel Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State, and Thomas F. White near here today.
In a sudden melee between Irish and Italian inmates of Welfare Island Penitentiary yesterday one convict was stabbed to death and several others were injured.

Bridge parties in aid of various philanthropies will be held in the near future by women interested in several organizations that minister to the ill and needy. Small children whose mothers are employed during the day or have no means to provide for them receive care and training at the Silver Cross Day Nursery, which will be the beneficiary of a card party on the afternoon of Nov. 10 in the ballroom of the Plaza.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 23 -- The scoreless tie with Princeton yesterday left the Naval Academy coaches and players still confident that the team has elements of strength that should prove themselves by the winning of some major games before the season is over.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 23 -- The Green Bay Packers tightened their grip on first place in the National Football League today by defeating Benny Friedman's Brooklyn Dodgers, 13 to 0, on a rain-swept gridiron before a crowd of 5,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Preaching from the pulpits of three churches in and near Philadelphia today, Lord William Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, appealed to this country, and particularly its churches, to aid in "the freeing of the whole world from the curse of its greatest slavery, war."

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- Although German trade recovery has made further progress during the past week, nevertheless, business circles show increasing unwillingness to undertake commitments, and the prevailing uncertainty has caused moderate decline in the securities market.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Almost 20,000 persons heard Lily Pons sing "Lucia di Lammermoor" here today. It was the city's tribute to a singer unequaled here, observers said, since the days of Tetrazzini.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, is sounding out railway executives on the possibility of building up their depleted passenger revenues by reducing basic fares.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 23 -- John Joseph Smith, 4 years old, was killed by a truck while playing in West Avenue here, within Bight of his home, last night. James Stephani of Hagerman, L.I., was held on a charge of manslaughter. The police said a tractor truck driven by Stephani had killed the boy, although he had continued on his way without realizing there had been an accident.

PARIS, Monday, Oct. 24 -- France will be in a position to make the $19,000,000 war debt payment to the United States Dec. 15, but in view of the Hoover moratorium and the Lausanne agreement she will have the right to ask a new arrangement, according to Henry Berenger, who was France's representative in the Washington debt pact negotiations.

The habitual concert-goer faces an all-Russian program of songs with some diffidence; it is the habit of Slavic singers, apparently, to select only works steeped in melancholic mysticism or turgid with tragedy and to avoid the gay and homely melodies with which its folk literature abounds.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 23 -- Nineteen persons drowned tonight when a bus plunged off a ferry landing into the Mississippi River. Three others were rescued.

Outright repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, with unqualified remission of liquor control to the States except in taxation and interstate commerce, would produce liquor taxes that would balance the budget without any other new taxes, and might permit the reduction of real estate and income taxes, according to a statement just prepared by the executive committee of the Voluntary Committee of Lawyers, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 23 -- The fact that the University of Texas crushed Rice Institute, 18 -- 6, in a South-west Conference game and that Southern Methodist dropped an 18-7 non-Conference game to Centenary yesterday has not erased championship interest in the Texas and Southern Methodist game Saturday at Austin.

President DAY of Union College at the service yesterday in the college chapel in memory of Professor EDWARD EVERETT HALE, who died suddenly of a heart attack last August, ranked him among the few remembered great teachers in the 137 years of the life of that institution.

TOKYO, Oct. 23 -- A restoration that will reseat Henry Pu Yi on the Dragon throne is being predicted by Manchu courtiers and old Chinese royalists at Changchun. They assert a military campaign is unnecessary because the northern provincial leaders are sick of Chinese civil war and would voluntarily transfer their allegiance to an imperial regime, though they would retain their armies and their local autonomy.

The New York Giants and Boston Braves played a scoreless tie in their National Football League game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Despite the inclement weather, a crowd of 15,000 persons witnessed the contest.

SEATTLE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A woman who identified herself as the wife of Colonel William M. Inglis, 58, World War veteran prominent in Republican State politics, declared today he had shot her and then killed himself in his apartment last night because he was "dissatisfied" with life.

Registration up-State, as indicated by figures from forty-two cities the tabulation was completed by last night, showed a decline from the figures set in 1928. The total in those cities, including Republican and Democratic areas, was 1,022,282 voters, as compared with 1,035,860 in 1928.

ATLANTA, Oct. 23 -- Auburn's Plainsmen, essaying one of the greatest come-backs in Dixie football history, today rank with Tennessee as twin favorites for the Southern Conference gridiron championship.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- The following comments on President Hoover's speech at Detroit were issued here tonight at the headquarters of the Republican National Committee:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The national importance of the present Connecticut political campaign becomes more and more apparent. Chiefly it illustrates the extent to which the wet-dry "issue" may be used to hide notorious betrayals of popular confidence by such a slave of power trust domination as Hiram Bingham.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Featured by improvement in the position of member banks of the United States, reduction in all bank failures, decrease of hoarding and increase in monetary gold, the nation's financial situation in September was the most favorable in many months, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

Workers injured in industry in this State in 1931 received compensation totaling $36,012,788, according to the report for that year issued yesterday by the State Labor Department. The compensation was paid on grants by the department following hearings under the workmen's compensation law.

Although indicating few construction contracts during the first two weeks of this month in the metropolitan area, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reports show a gain for the entire month of September over August. This increase amounted to almost 27 per cent, the September awards of $19,714,100 comparing with $15,620,600 for August.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Landing here from the liner Cameronia with four children, including his 8-month-old son, James McEvaddy, retired Brooklyn street car conductor, was astonished to learn his leavetaking had caused some excitement in New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Business developments last week were favorable, although in a few instances they appeared to lack the spirit of recent weeks. Sentiment remained optimistic, nevertheless, and gains in sales and output were generally maintained.

Governor Roosevelt is quoted as saying that the present immigration laws need "humanizing," and that those charged with the carrying out of the immigration laws show a total lack of tact and discretion, in an interview with Joseph Brainin, editor of an English-Jewish newspaper feature service, made public yesterday by Mr. Brainin.
Alfred E. Smith will make his first campaign speech tonight in which national issues will be his principal theme, when he speaks at the armory in Newark.

Money on deposit in 1931 in banks of the New York retail trading area, recently defined by the Merchants' Association and the Publishers' Association to include the five boroughs of New York City and twenty-three suburban counties within a radius of approximately sixty miles, amounted to nearly $16,000,000,000, according to a survey by the industrial bureau of the Merchants' Association, made public yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 23 -- The polo game this afternoon at the Greenbrier Field between the Guyan polo team of Huntington, W. Va., and the Zane Grey team of Zanesville, Ohio, attracted a large gallery.

TURIN, Italy, Oct. 23 -- "The ship of debts and reparations is now safely in the harbor of Lausanne. Will the great American nation push this ship containing the hopes and fears of so many peoples into the open sea again?"

Four men were burned at noon yesterday when the engine of a converted submarine chaser, now a fishing boat, blew up in Long Island Sound. The accident took place not far from Hart's Island, which is near City Island, and there were fifty passengers aboard at the time.

PARIS, Oct. 23.--Albert Dalimier, French Minister of Labor, speaking in the name of the government today at Toulouse, said that for some weeks there had been signs that the bottom of the depression had been reached and that business was on the up grade.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 23 -- The South, the traditional stronghold of prohibition, has accepted the wet national platform of the Democratic party, and Southern Democratic Senators and Representatives, with few exceptions, are willing to vote for a resolution for submission of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and for a bill to modify the Volstead act, Governor Roosevelt was informed today on his arrival in Atlanta.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area dedicate yesterday afternoon the new edifice of the Metropolitan Methodist Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteent Street, successor to the structure on Seventh Avenue, south of Fourteenth Street, which was destroyed by fire a few years ago.

When George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber settle down to the writing of a play you can expect something not only skillful but solid. Their "Dinner at Eight," which appeared at the Music Box Saturday evening, is an extraordinarily engrossing piece of work, despite what seems to this column to be an incomplete conclusion.

Extensive use of the radio by Colonel Herbert H. Lehman and his colleagues on the Democratic State ticket was indicated yesterday when the Independent Citizens Committee backing Colonel Lehman's candidacy for the Governorship, made public the schedule of radio broadcasts for the rest of the campaign.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Julius Rosenwald Fund published today the results of a survey of newspaper medical advertising in the last ten years, conducted by Miss Mary Ross of New York and covering all efforts made in the way of public education in health problems by medical organizations, non-profiting institutes and private businesses.

Education, not evangelization, should be the primary aim of mission schools according to the eighth instalment of the appraisal commission of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry, published yesterday.
Out of the maelstrom of Saturday's football skirmishes three teams emerged to attain a stature a little bit beyond that of any others with claims to national recognition.

Arthur Barry, gem thief, who escaped from Auburn in the July, 1929 prison break and was recaptured Saturday at his farmhouse hideout near Sparta, N.J., was taken to Newark police headquarters for questioning yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- The Philadelphia Cricket Club field hockey team overwhelmed the British Overseas League eleven of New York, 21 to 0, in an intercity game at St. Martin's today.

Tommy Hitchcock, the only tengoal polo player in the world, named his choice for an all-time polo team during a sports radio program for welfare relief over the Columbia Broadcasting System and National Broadcasting Company networks last night.

John W. Davis, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and Democratic Presidential nominee in 1924, joined Nicholas Murray Butler and Elihu Root yesterday as an honorary chairman of the independent committee sponsoring the candidacies of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch for election to the Supreme Court bench.

A severe indictment of the colleges and universities of this country for failing to teach more spiritual values was made yesterday by the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, in a sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
PARIS, Oct. 14 (By Mail) -- The dedication of the new Alsace Canal and power plant at Kembs has opened to France the vision of a great waterway from the North Sea to the Mediterranean.

At a campaign rally in the Brownsville Labor Lyceum, 219 Sackman Street, Brooklyn, attended by more than 3,000 persons, Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, called upon his Democratic and Republican opponents yesterday to "stop talking trivialities and ambiguities" and "embark at last upon a discussion of vital policies and urgent problems now confronting this city."
NEW YORK. Charles Thompson Mathews will give a dinner dance Dec. 30 at the Ritz-Carlton to introduce his niece, Miss Patricia Mathews Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Drelincourt M. Martin.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 23 -- The capture this afternoon of Fort Arce, which has been the field headquarters of the Bolivian armies in the disputed Chaco region, was announced tonight by the Paraguayan Minister of War.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 -- James R. Wedell of Louisiana made a record flight today between Ottawa and Mexico City, with stops at Washington and Patterson, La. He flew the distance of about 2,500 miles in 11 hours 53 minutes, elapsed time, averaging more than 200 miles an hour.

Orders to show cause why the names of several hundred allegedly illegal voters should not be stricken from the registration lists in this city will be filed today in the Supreme Court, the Republican State Committee announced yesterday. This action, it was said, is the first step in a movement to strike several thousands of names from the roll of eligible voters.

Head Coach Howard G. Cann has ordered the entire New York University football squad to report at Ohio Field today, where the Violet team will begin preparations for its intersectional game with Purdue at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- France's armaments limitation and security plan, which is scheduled to be presented at Geneva Nov. 3, is encountering considerable resistance in military circles and in the Nationalist press of Paris.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23.--Two young men and a girl were killed and another young man and a girl were injured seriously when the light coupe in which they had been riding after a college dance crashed into a parked truck on the Brunswick Pike near here at 3:45 o'clock this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 -- Their goal line uncrossed and still championship defenders by right of might Southern California's Trojans were bounding down the back stretch of the Coast Conference football chase today while a home-town rival kept pace in what has developed into a two-team race in mid-season.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Mystified over the cause of their announced separation and impending divorce, Kathryn Carver, stage and screen actress and wife of Adolphe Menjou, film actor, was removed to her home today from a hospital, where she has been recovering from a nervous breakdown.

When Gangsters relax. When the body of a slain man is found wrapped in a burlap bag in a closed automobile there can apparently be no two opinions about it. It is another case of business competition in the underworld.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 -- In its widespread search for substitutes for rubber Soviet Russia has found that the dandelion contains a substance that preliminary investigation has established as equal in quality to natural rubber, virtually the only important raw material not produced in the Soviet Union.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- From the outset of the present armament dispute there has been difficulty in figuring exactly what Germany wants in the matter of a new army. The general principle, which she has stated plainly enough, is that she demands the right to equality of armament, but this is coupled with the intimation that, that right being granted, she is willing to accept in practice something less.

A runaway trolley car, spreading terror ahead, bolted down a few blocks of Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, late yesterday. The motorman, by use of his hand-brake brought the car to a halt within a few feet of busy Fourth Avenue where the police, by use of the radio, had already cleared traffic.

Men and women from all walks of life in the five boroughs of the city have formed a citizens' committee to cooperate with the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee in the $15,000,000 fund-raising campaign to be undertaken under the chairmanship of Harvey D. Gibson, it was announced yesterday by Bayard F. Pope, executive vice chairman of the relief committee.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 23 -- Princess Helen, the former wife of King Carol, who had been absent from Rumania for more than a year, arrived here this evening to be with her son, Crown Prince Michael, on his eleventh birthday Tuesday.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, said tonight that Governor Roosevelt "was more obedient to Tammany than any other Governor in recent years -- until he discovered that the country would not take him with the Tammany label."

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- In a drenching rain that poured down unceasingly today hundreds of ragged hunger marchers trudged wearily toward London intending to converge on the Houses of Parliament for a mass demonstration later in the week.

In a letter to President Hoover the Neptune Association charged yesterday that ship lines owned by the Federal Government and operated by private companies under a lumpsum agreement have violated the terms of working contracts which the United States Shipping Board made last June.

Behind the spectacular playing of George Oliver, No. 2, who tallied four goals, the Oraworth Polo Club rode to victory over the First Division four, 6 -- 4, at Port Hamilton yesterday before a crowd of 1,000. Although allotted a one-goal handicap, the winners, from Oradell, N.J., found no need for it.

To the Editor or The New York Times: An admirer of President Hoover, one who intends to vote for him, finds a pleasure in expressing his appreciation of THE TIMES editorial in the issue of Oct. 18, "Mr. Hoover in Cleveland."

Tammany candidates for office should be so many "forgotten men" to the intelligent New Yorkers voting next month, in the opinion of the Rev. Harold L. Gibba, curate of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street.

VIENNA, Oct. 23 (AP)--Princess Helen, divorced wife of King Carol, returning to Rumania from England, passed through this city last night. It was then understood she had requested that a royal private car meet her at the border, but the request had been refused.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 -- With the Brown game only a week away, the Harvard coaches will get back to serious work again tomorrow, probably scrimmaging all the players who did not participate in the Dartmouth game.

Head Keeper Robert Hurton scratched his head and Keeper James Hynes puffed long on a battered pipe. They stood yesterday in front of a tank in the antelope house of the Central Park Zoo and rued the day when they had accepted a rare Chinese turtle from the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler, in one of several campaign addresses today by party leaders, again asserted that he would take nothing less than full leadership of the German Government after the Retchstag elections Nov. 6.
The statement by the Executive Committee of the Voluntary Committee of Lawyers, Inc., urging unqualified repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and opposing substitute plans, follows.

The prohibition questionnaire addressed to the Congressional candidates of all parties throughout the country by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform has already been answered by 607, or more than half the candidates.

OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- In a stubborn football battle, Sing Sing's Black Sheep went down to defeat this afternoon before the assaults of the Kingston, Yellow Jackets. Sing Sing sorely missed the services of the bulky Jumbo Morano, who as defensive fullback last week sent several of the Port Jervis police team to the showers on stretchers and completely upset their running game.

LENS, France, Oct. 23 (AP) -- In the heart of the old war zone, Premier Harriot today appealed for world peace, referring to 75,000 German graves in the near-by Maison Blanche Cemetery which he asserted "France cares for with respect."

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23 -- Trading in contracts for future deliveries of cotton was light here last week, but there was a resistance to depressing tendencies that was gratifying to traders. Price fluctuations were frequent but not wide, and the trend toward lower levels was attributed more to lack of buying than to the action of stocks and wheat.

The United States would have gone to war against Great Britain in 1917 except for the influence upon Woodrow Wilson of Colonel Edward M. House, according to George Sylvester Viereck, whose book, "The Strangest Friendship in History, Woodrow Wilson and Colonel House," is published today by Liveright.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- With registration totals down in many up-State Republican communities, Colonel William J. Donovan will leave here in the morning to intensify his drive in Central New York as the Republican candidate for Governor.

Declaring that his early environment, education and political experience had given him great sympathy with and understanding for the foreign-born elements of New York, Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Demo- cratic nominee for Mayor, spoke briefly last night of the heterogeneous racial and religious mixture of the community and urged an audience of 250 in the Hotel Astor to support his candidacy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Marketing of cattle at the seven large Western markets last week was 193,000 head, or 4,000 in excess of the previous week. The totals for the same markets for the three preceding years, however, averaged 47,000 head more than last week.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 23 -- William Richter, 53 years old, of Union City, N.J., was rescued today from the bottom of a dry well, twenty-two feet deep, on his farm near Neshanic Mountain, about eight miles from, here, after the walls had caved in and had trapped him under a mass of rock for five hours.

Although only a few outstanding surprises were recorded, the weekend's scholastic football results reduced the number of undefeated New York City schoolboy elevens from thirteen to three, the smallest unbeaten group at a season's midway mark in many years.

The Rev. Dr. Isaac M. Haldeman, 87-year-old pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventyninth Street, returned to his pulpit yesterday after a five-month illness, during which his life had been de- spaired of several times.

TURIN, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini appealed to the United States to cancel or reduce the European war debts in an open-air address today, carried by loud-speakers to about a half million Italians jammed in three public squares of Turin.

No previous campaign address by the President was so polemic as the one he delivered on Saturday. He attacked Governor ROOSEVELT by name and challenged vigorously many of the positions taken by the Democratic candidate. One of the sharp differences between the two men has to do with Federal expenditures and the possibility of reducing them.

The successful treatment of arthritis and other chronic infections by means of a diathermal machine to raise a patient's temperature from 2 to 7 degrees above normal for a period of several hours was reported yesterday by Dr. W.J. Deason of Wichita, Kan., at the final session of the annual convention of the New York Osteopathic Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 23 -- Firemen, policemen and agents of the district attorney's office began a searchlight hunt tonight for the body of Joseph Konkel, 11 years old, who it is believed became entangled in the bumper of an automobile which struck a "pushmobile," in which he was riding with his twin brother, William along the Riverhead-Hampton Bay State highway.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 20 per cent of plant capacity, the same as in the two weeks preceding, after a rise of 6 points in as many weeks. The trade had concluded that the recent increase in demand was due chiefly to the improvement in business and financial conditions, and in only a small part to seasonal influences.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman expressed the view at the morning service in the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, corner of Sixtieth Street, that the pulpit was "no place for partisan politics."
A plan for arbitration designed to foster rehabilitation of real estate mortgage bonds now in default or in process of reorganization was announced yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.

MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 23 -- The city of Montreal has arranged with local banks a nine-months loan of $8,866,500 at 5.63 per cent. The proceeds of the loan are being used to pay off three loans in London, England, on Nov. 1, that transaction being the means of Montreal making a profit of $1,347,000 through the difference in the rate for pounds sterling.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 -- Fifty-one visiting committees have been named by the board of overseers of the Harvard College to observe and report on the activities of Harvard University this year.

The Metropolitan racing season for 1932, with the exception of the United Hunts on election day, will end at the Empire City track in Yonkers this week. Despite the great interest shown in the sport at Laurel, the stables at the Westchester course remain well filled for the final six days in New York.

Welfare Island Penitentiary was quiet yesterday and normal routine was observed as Warden Joseph A. McCann and the District Attorney's office prepared to resume today an investigation into the death of George Holshoe, the prisoner who was killed in Saturday's brief riot.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Gene Tunney, former world's heavyweight boxing champion, who has been in the forefront of Connecticut's political battle as an important Democratic campaign speaker, has apparently forfeited his vote on Nov. 8, it was learned today.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The decline of sterling has not shaken confidence here in dollar exchange. Declarations regarding currency inflation such as those of Senator Borah are not taken seriously in responsible circles here; it is not believed that a country such as the United States, the creditor nation of the world, would voluntarily depreciate its own currency.

If the dread disease of leprosy could be as readily cured as was the historic case of NAAMAN -- bathing seven times in the river Jordan -- such a movement as has been under way for five years to support research looking to its eradication would not be necessary.

The President's repeated glorification of the protective tariff is perhaps explicable on party grounds. Otherwise it is hard to understand how he can bring himself to say what he does. As leader and candidate of the Republican party he may feel it incumbent upon him to ring the changes on this old article of the Republican creed.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday its recommendations as to candidates for the Assembly, withholding its approval, without exception, from the Democratic nominees. Even Langdon W. Post, who is running as an independent in the Tenth Manhattan District, after having been turned down for renomination by the Democratic organization, does not receive endorsement.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 23 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 61.1, which compares with 61.3 a week ago, 61.8 two weeks ago, 62.2 three weeks ago and 62.4 four weeks ago. This season's highest was 63.2 on Sept. 10.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Uncovering a nineteen-point attack in the first period the Passaic Red Devils defeated the Newark team in an Eastern League game today, winning by a score of 25-0. By the victory Passaic took undisputed possession of first place.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Frederick Van Nuys, Democratic candidate for the Senate opposing Senator James E. Watson, Republican, in Indiana, was endorsed today by the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment. William Henry Harrison of Indianapolis, Republican candidate for Congress in the Twelfth Indiana District, also received the endorsement of the association because of his stand on the Eighteenth Amendment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Wheat traders who have made an analysis of the world's situation assert that under existing conditions there is likely to be little in the market until a determined effort is made by the leading governments to bring about a betterment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are observing this year in various ways the bicentennial of Washington's birth. What, it may be asked, are we as a city doing to commemorate for posterity this anniversary?

Seven hundred policemen attended the 10 o'clock mass in Holy Cross Church, Forty-second Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, yesterday as a testimonial to the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, chaplain of the Police Department, who was recently appointed pastor of the church to succeed the late Rev. Dr. Francis P. Duffy, Father McCaffrey stood on the front steps before and after the mass and welcomed the policemen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Content heretofore with casting their ballots and making a few scattered bids for public office, women this year are trying to pick political plums in record numbers.

The North German Lloyd liner General von Steuben arrived yesterday from the Channel ports with an extra passenger among the 368, because a son was born to Mrs. Kaethe Schernig last Friday off Cape Race, Newfoundland. She is the wife of Johannes Schernig, a radio engineer of San Francisco.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 23 -- Oklahoma and Nebraska, taking advantage of desperate but ill-starred aerial attacks launched by their opposition Saturday, remained in a tie for the Big Six football leadership with, two victories apiece, while Oklahoma's victim, the Wildcats of Kansas State, dropped to third place out of a three-way deadlock.

Activity in the wholesale markets here was curtailed rather sharply last week, as unfavorable weather in many sections of the country hampered retail turnover. In those districts where the weather was favorable, however, stores enjoyed a fairly good business.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Six acres of a large tract which was the site of William Penn's manor house on the Delaware River in Bucks County was presented today to the State in celebration of the 250th anniversary of Penn's landing in America.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- All financial markets were dominated this week by the excited break in sterling, which, at $3.35 on Wednesday, touched the lowest point since last December, when the collapse that followed England's departure from the gold standard culminated with a rate of $3.23.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A circular issued recently by the Republican National Committee, signed by a number of labor leaders who were declared to be opposed to the Democratic tariff plank, has been repudiated by fourteen of its alleged signers, according to a statement issued tonight by the National Progressive League.

Tremendous interest has been aroused among hunters by the recent announcement of landowners and farmers in this and adjoining States that they were willing to permit hunting on their posted land for a nominal fee. The More Game Birds in America Foundation has been flooded with inquiries since it let it be known that it would aid hunters in finding the locations of such places.

More than sixty-seven years after the Civil War the Confederate defense of Fort Sumter, which has been described as "five hundred and "sixty-seven days of continuous "military and naval operations," is recognized in an impressive monument of bronze and granite.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Governor Roosevelt was tonight criticized for his attitude on unemployment relief by the People's Lobby, of which Professor John Dewey is president, who in a statement issued here declared that this is the paramount issue of the campaign.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 23 -- Social and recreational functions marked the week-end of the Fall colony here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Election of Franklin D. Roosevelt by the largest electoral vote in recent history and full control of Congress by the Democrats was predicted today by Chairman Swanson of the Demo cratic Senatorial committee and Chairman Byrns of the Congressional committee.

IN the Eastern area Colgate, Columbia, Harvard, Holy Cross, Penn and Temple remained undefeated and untied. Harvard just managed to win from an aroused Dartmouth team on Saturday and Holy Cross had an unexpectedly hard tussle with Rutgers. But the big shocks to the football fraternity were the defeat of Fordham by Michigan State and the scoreless tie between Ohio State and the supposedly invincible Pitt Panthers.

Kansas is bleeding from every pore of her vocabularium. Sharp's rifles are discharging from the well-known Emporium of White Son, unlimited, and Bibles are closed until after election. Enormous statistic-spouts darken the air. White Son have "information which "would indicate that Doc BRINK"LEY'S bill with the Bell Telephone "Company for remote control is "around $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The coming "lame-duck" session of Congress, which begins in December, probably will be the last of its kind, for ratification of the proposed constitutional amendment killing such sessions is a distinct possibility even before that session closes.

With the aid of a locksmith, Bishop William T. Manning forced his way into All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church at 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 116th Street, yesterday morning, despite threats of the vestry to prosecute him for trespass, officially declared the church in charge of the rector, the Rev. Rollin Dodd, and preached a sermon strongly supporting the rector's decision to admit Negroes to the services on an equal basis with white parishioners.

Holders of second-mortgage securities on defaulted real estate in this city and vicinity are alarmed at what they call "threatened betrayal of trust and confidence" in the shaping of plans for reorganizing the management of properties in financial straits.

The exhibition of Chinese wood-block prints at the Chait Galleries, 600 Madison Avenue, is especially interesting, in view of the fact that so little is popularly known in this country about Chinese prints. The works now on view come from the large collection at the Pennsylvania Museum, and are being circulated, for an indefinite period, under the auspices of the College Art Association.

DENVER, Oct. 23 -- A week of upsets reduced the ranks of the undefeated and untied teams in the Rocky Mountain Conference to one, the University of Utah. The prospects that the Utes will be deprived of their fifth consecutive conference title are considered remote.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- The market for corn on the Board of Trade here is regarded as in a rut and as likely to remain there some time unless there are unexpected developments. While more or less export business is believed to be passing, there seldom has been a year when sales abroad have been a lasting influence in shaping the trend of the market for that grain.

The incident of real significance on last week's markets did not occur in the Stock Exchange or in prices of commodities. The two-day fall of nearly 10 cents in the pound sterling's value, however, bringing the price 48 cents below even this year's highest, was a striking sign of the times.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- In this week's financial markets, the relapse of sterling caused an eddy; some values were driven down and others went flying. The open-market price for gold bullion rose from 120 shillings per ounce to 122, and carried prices of gold mining shares along with it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, appealed by radio tonight for citizens in "all walks of life" to contribute generously toward the relief of the needy this Winter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Former Senator Robert L. Owen, of Oklahoma, one of the authors of the Federal Reserve System, who supported Herbert Hoover in 1928, has joined the National Progressive League, which is supporting Governor Roosevelt.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23.--The Yale football coaches tonight expressed faith in their eleven, which has gone through its first four games without a victory. They predicted that Dartmouth, Princeton and Harvard, the only opponents left on the schedule, will have a thorny path to pursue to outscore the Blue.

Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican nominee for Governor, arrived in the city early yesterday morning, after having completed the first part of his up-State tour. He started again last night on the second lap, to make a speech at Oswego.

Dudley Field Malone, who was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention which nominated Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for President, announced yesterday that he would vote for President Hoover. He said he would support also Colonel William J. Donovan and George Z. Medalie, Republican candidates respectively for Governor and United States Senator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Speeding back to the capital today from his trip to Detroit, President Hoover virtually decided upon a whirlwind finish for the remainder of the campaign, one that would take him to New York and Newark in the East, Indianapolis and Chicago in the Middle West, and possibly San Francisco and Palo Alto on the Pacific Coast.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Whatever occurs in regard to Great Britain's war debt payments to America, the City regards it as certain that the Treasury has left nothing to chance and is well prepared to carry out whatever obligations of that kind may lie ahead.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The theatrical business in Chicago has undergone a revival. The long-doused lights of Randolph Street's show houses have been turned on again, but there's neither light nor activity in the cubbyholes of the ticket scalpers, for the selling of show tickets has gone back fifteen years, becoming once more a mail-order business.

President Gluseppe Motta of Switzerland, in a radio broadcast from Berne yesterday, welcomed the collaboration of the United States in the League of Nations and told of the hope that America will lead the world to prosperity. He began speaking at 12:30 P.M. over networks of the Columbia and National systems.

Controller Charles W. Berry has nearly completed and will submit to the Board of Estimate early in 1933 a plan for rehabilitation of the city's credit and the revision of its financial structure, he declared last night at his home in Staten Island.
Jersey City housing sales figured largely in real estate deals announced over the week-end.
DES MOINES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Idle hands put to work on idle land have made the relief outlook brighter for Iowa's larger cities.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman will carry his campaign into the Mohawk Valley tomorrow, beginning a week's sweep through the western part of the State with the double aim of clinching the Governorship for himself and helping the Democratic party gain control of the State Legislature.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- They are getting ready at Michigan to nail the 1932 gridiron championship of the Western Conference to the old flagpole.

A plan under which importers here will cooperate with exporters in helping the latter collect for shipments made to countries where exchange restrictions make the transfer of money difficult has been worked out by the foreign trade committee of the Merchants Association, according to an announcement appearing today in Greater New York, official publication of the merchants' group.

At last there is good news for the cod-fishermen. While the weather hasn't turned cold enough to offer great encouragement and the wind has continued to be out of the wrong quarter to forecast the desired temperature some other signs have appeared that should give heart to the hardy souls who consider all fishing except cod-fishing mere child's play.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 24. -- Clarence Monroe Burton, city historiographer, and donor to the city of the Detroit historical library which bears his name, died Sunday night at his home here after a long illness. He was 79 years old. Death was caused by a cerebral hemorrhage.

Entering Queens last night to rally the workers in the Democratic organization, Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, pledged rigid economy and urged a "huge Democratic plurality" so that none of the possible fusion candidates for Mayor would run next year.

The combined traffic for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1932, on rapid transit lines, street railways, the Hudson tubes and bus lines reporting to the commission amounted to 2,960,800,000 passengers, the Transit Commission reported yesterday. The report noted that the traffic total had dropped for the first time below the 3,000,000,000 mark established in 1927.

"This society is organized to bring together artists of established reputation, with the object of giving, an annual series of concerts in a spirit of artistic fraternity. None of the members shall receive any remuneration for participation in these concerts, and the net proceeds therefrom shall be donated for a purpose of general musical interest, to be determined at the close of a season by vote of the members."

Six Manhattan properties and five parcels in the Bronx were sold in foreclosure actions yesterday. Included in the Manhattan offerings was the eight-story Explorers' Club Building at 544-46 Cathedral Parkway, which went to the Liberdar Holding Corporation for $213,500, representing a $1,000 bid above a $212,500 mortgage.

The charge made on Sunday by Assemblyman Abbott Low Moffat, Republican candidate for re-election in the Fifteenth district, that the NonPartisan Citizens League was a Tammany controlled organization, was backed yesterday by Walter S. Mack, Republican candidate for the State Senate from the Seventeenth district.

The adjusted index of automobile production has dropped to a new low record. In the Fall of 1931 it declined to 14.6 in one week when many factories were closed for model changes, but for the week ended Oct. 22, 1932, it declined to 14.4 from 16.6 for the preceding week and 24.4 for the corresponding week last year.

PARIS, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The American dollar rose two centimes on the Exchange today. It was attributed partly to steady purchase of American securities by financial interests in France, convinced that the United States is definitely on the road to economic recovery.

Opera, like the space of the modern physicist, has different frames or concepts, depending on the point of view, It may be a lyric drama, with music, acting and decor blended to a unity, or it may be the singing of soloists in costume, with a stage for background and an accompaniment of orchestral music and occasional chorus.

To the Editor of The New York Times: These few words are addressed to those mortals who have the distinction of being known far and wide as "forgotten men." It will probably be recorded in the annals of history that this species of man had his annual heyday and flourished gloriously in the month preceding election day.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., Oct. 24 (AP).-- A heavy home-made bomb shattered the interior of the Logan Bryan office building here at 5 A. M. today. No one was hurt.

Apparently the suggestion for "The Anatomist," which was played at the Bijou last evening, comes from Stevenson's grizzly tale about "The Body Snatcher." In James Bridie's inexpert play, an apprentice doctor, who deals with the grave robbers, finds one night that he has bought the cadaver of a girl he knows.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct 24. -- The Princeton coaching staff spent an hour and a half today instructing the Tiger varsity eleven in defense against Michigan plays in the first day of preparation for the Wolverines.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP).--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the Merchants Warehouse Company today petitioned Judge Dickinson in the United States District Court to dismiss suits for $6,000,000 damages filed by the Terminal Warehouse Company and Walter A. Bailey, who operates as Bailey Warehouses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Coincident with the hearing of testimony today that Japanese pottery and chinaware was being dumped into this country at prices that had curtailed the industry in this country by 25 per cent, F.X.A. Eble, Customs Commissioner, announced the entering of orders regulating imports of manganese ore and steel products.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Mrs. J. M. Keith-Miller, one of the principal witnesses in the recent murder trial at Miami, Fla., of Captain William N. Lancaster, Eluded, crowds of curious persons today when she returned to England from the United States.

QUEBEC, Oct. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Following an investigation carried out by school inspectors throughout the Province, fears are entertained that 197 schools may have to close on account of lack of money. Between 2,000 and 3,000 children would be affected.

The League of Mothers Clubs, a branch of the United Neighborhood Houses, took over the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night and served a dinner to 1,300 guests. A group of 130 of the mothers, in the picturesque costumes of many countries, acted as waitresses.

Voters on Long Island who happen to reside in Glen Cove or Oyster Bay will have an opportunity on election day to cast their bread once more on the waters that surround Jones Beach with confidence that it will be returned to them a hundredfold.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- While ragget groups of hunger marchers plodded toward London today, 1,000 police men guarded the County Hall, across the Thames River from the Houses of Parliament, during a visit of a deputation of unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.-State and Treasury Department officials today remained silent on the suggestion made by Premier Mussolini of Italy that the United States cancel or reduce wartime debts of the European nations, and all indications are that the administration does not intend to make any statement on the Premier's speech that would inject it into the Presidential campaign.

BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- The sluggishness was unabated on the Boerse today and the downward tendency that developed on Saturday continued. With the exception of a few stocks, however, including Chade which dropped five points, the declines were kept within 1 to 2 points.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor, asserted yesterday his independence of any political machine, declaring at the same time that both his rivals. Surrogate John P. O'Brien, the Democratic candidate, and Morris Hillquit, Socialist nominee, would be strongly bound by party ties if elected to the office they are seeking.

Probably the average heathen in his blindness imagines that lawyers manage to find fat pickings in times of economic and financial depression; obviously certain branches of their business must now be thriving. But multitudes of rich clients have gone under or are desperately treading water.

ATHENS, Greece, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Samuel Insull Sr., who is under Indictment in Chicago for larceny in connection with the receivership of bis companies, returned last night from a trip to Corinth. Two plainclothes policemen attended him. Mr. Insull previously had been advised by the police to tell them of any trips he planned after he had reported learning of a plot to kidnap him.

SPRINGFILED, Ill., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Governor La Follette of Wisconsin told a Democratic rally tonight that "Jeffersonian Democrats and Lincolnian Republicans should unite in whole-hearted opposition to Herbert C. Hoover."

The economic philosophy of the two major political parties was criticized yesterday by Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, at a political symposium held by the Foster Mothers Association of America in the Hotel Astor, where Theodore A. Peyser, Democratic candidate for Congress, and Walter S. Mack, Republican candidate for the State Senate, also spoke.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, Kentucky wrestler who is recognized here as the world's champion, conquered Bruno Gorrasini, Italian without much trouble last night in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory and retained his title.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- Anti-administration feeling aroused by the depression will have to be violent and deepseated indeed if the Democrats are to carry Massachusetts for Roosevelt and Garner this year. Nearly every other major political factor which aided them in 1928 is absent this year -- the candidacy of Alfred E. Smith, the Republican's dry position now abandoned; harmony among their Democratic leaders.

PATERSON. N.J., Oct. 24. -- Under the leadership of President Hoover the United States is leading the world in recovery from the economic depression, Walter E. Edge, Ambassador to France, said tonight at a mass meeting at the East Side High School here.

Business in money was at a standstill so far as quotations and turnover were concerned. There were no variations in rates, and the amount of funds taken was small. This was true in the Stock Exchange call loan market, maturity money and business paper.

Member lines of the North Atlantic Passenger Conference, which recently agreed to limit their Winter cruises to the West Indies, Central America and northern ports of South America with a view to limiting competition, have been summoned to explain the agreement to the United States Shipping Board at a series of hearings, to be started on Friday at 10:30 A. M. at 45 Broadway.
