Results of a questionnaire sent to Republican and Democratic candidates for the United States Senate, and for the office of Representative at Large, concerning their attitude on the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, were made public yesterday by Mrs. Marion Booth Kelley, chairman of the legislative committee of the Women's Organization for Prohibition Reform.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24. -- Yale's football regulars, with one exception, were excused today from active duty, because of their strenuous encounter with the Army Saturday. The usual blackboard talk was held at an evening meeting of the squad.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- Jack Sharkey will risk his heavyweight title only in a Boston ring and against an opponent acceptable to him, William F. Carey, president of the Madison Square Garden, was informed today by Johnny Buckley, the Boston titleholder's manager.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- United States iron and steel exports during September totaled 36,038 gross tons, an increase of 3,083 gross tons over August, due partly to larger shipments of sheet products, which accounted for three of the five largest gains during the month, the Department of Commerce announced today.

A request for the formation of a committee of alumni members of the Columbia University board of trustees to investigate and "clarify" rumors of alleged professionalism connected with intercollegiate athletics and athletes at Columbia will be made at the next meeting of the board of trustees on Nov. 7, it was announced yesterday by The Columbia Spectator, the student daily newspaper.
LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The Cabinet decided tonight to override the protests of police councils and impose the 5 per cent pay cut on Nov. 1 as originally intended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The question of financing through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation the sale of 15,000,000 bushels of privately owned wheat to China was the subject of a conference today between Wilson McCarthy, a member of the corporation's board of directors, and George S. Milnor, president of the Farmers' National Grain Corporation.

Abandonment of the short-term financing of new city subways has made rapid transit unification inevitable, but with, all the advantages as to price and terms on the side of the B.M.T. and Interborough, Acting Mayor McKee declared yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 24. -- Speaking before an audience of thousands here in wet New Jersey, former Governor Smith assailed the Republican party tonight for broken promises, bigotry, deception and hypocrisy and called President Hoover the leader of the dry forces in America.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24. -- Following the fall of Fort Arce yesterday, the Bolivian right wing today began falling hack onto Fort Munoz, fortysix miles behind the line of forts extending along the sixtieth meridian southward from Arce to the Pilcomayo River.

A demand for the "considerations behind the deal" that gave State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter a Democratic nomination for the Supreme Court was voiced yesterday by Bernard S. Deutseh, independent candidate put up by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, in a query directed at W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 24. -- The Rev. George S. Miller of Irvington, N.J., was elected president of the pastors' conference of the New Jersey Baptist convention which opened here today. Other officers elected were the Rev. C.W. Danehaur of Camden, vice president, and the Rev. J.E. Keith-MacLeod of Elizabeth, secretary-treasurer.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the slowest in more than three months. The turnover was 551,000 shares, compared with 1,244,500 shares on Friday, the last fivehour day of the previous week. The motionless market closed with a net loss of 2 cents in the average price of fifty assorted stocks.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- France's foreign policy under Edouard Herriot'a Government and, incidentally, France's debts will be the first things discussed when the French Parliament begins its new session tomorrow. M. Herriot will be called upon to defend the Lausanne settlement, his attitude toward the German demand for armaments equality and the policy followed by his government at Geneva, and it is expected he will easily obtain an important majority.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--A farreaching program toward the reduction of contagious disease, as a "constructive measure of public economy" and carried on with government encouragement, was urged tonight by President Hoover in an address before the sixty-first annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

There is a brave new world spinning out of the machine age to be enjoyed by those Americans now in early middle age, Walter B. Pitkin, professor of journalism at Columbia University, writes in "Life Begins at Forty," published today, by Whittlesey House.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24. -- Governor Roosevelt tonight added to the "forgotten man" as a campaign issue the "forgotten market" of the farmers of America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Re-investigations by the Tariff Commission into import duties on sixteen commodities produced in thirty States was ordered today by President Hoover. From the results of this study he purposes to determine whether to readjust the rates under the flexible provisions of the SmootHawley act to make up for the depreciation of currencies in foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Patrick McGovern, bead of Patrick McGovern, Inc., who contracted with New York City to build a $43,000,000 water tunnel from Yonkers to Brooklyn, must serve sixty days In the House of Detention for contempt of court, the Supreme Court ruled today.

It is commonly said that there is no "women's vote," since wives and husbands generally vote alike, or compensate for each other's defections from orthodoxy. Republican managers hope it will not prove to be true this year. In Belgian relief days, and later in food administration days, Mr. HOOVER entered thousands of homes through the kitchen door.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- A dark picture of the present economic situation in France and a plea for a cut in government expenses was presented to Premier Herriot tonight by a delegation from the Comite Saiut Economique, representing more than 500 industrial federations and syndical chambers all over France.
The national list of undefeated and untied football teams has dwindled to 26.

Slight early advances in the prices of cotton here yesterday on buying comoted by a relatively steady market in Liverpool and prospects for tins in the South were followed by declines under increased Southern selling. Offerings on the Cotton Exhange were absorbed by scale-down bying, but prices for all positions lade new low ground for the movement, December contracts selling off from 6.18 to 6.10 cents a pound, or 6 points below Saturday's closing quotation.

Astrology in the Exchequer. To what extent are we justified in expecting a Secretary of the Treasury to behave like Mother SHIPTON or Mme. de Thebes? At Detroit the President thought that Governor ROOSEVELT was unfair in blaming Secretary MILLS for not guessing right about the Federal deficit.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The Supreme Court settled a number of important controversies today without handing down a written opinion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- To keep the United States up to her treaty strength in cruisers, the navy plans to begin building next year another vessel of that type.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- If the Republicans, retain control of the State Senate at next month's election. Governor Moore's nomination of Wilfred H. Jayne of Ocean County as a judge of the Circuit Court will not be confirmed.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The kidnapping of 8-year-old Anna Kleinhandler of 26 Avon Place last night was solved this morning when the child appeared at a farmhouse near the Baltusrol golf course, at Springfield, N.J., and asked to be taken home.

Vestrymen constituting a majority of their board at All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, in St. Nicholas Avenue, took legal steps yesterday in opposing Bishop Manning's militant intervention into the racial controversy at the church Sunday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 24.--Legalization of beer at the coming short session of Congress might bring in $754,000,000 annually in taxes, the Investment Bankers Association's committee on Federal taxation reported at the convention here today.

Frigate Bird, by Man o' War-Pamfleta, which won at Bowie last year two days before the close of the Eastern racing season, gained his first victory since that time when he was first yesterday at Empire City in the Berkshire Purse, a mile and seventy yard test for three-year-olds and upward.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 24.-- A police search throughout Suffolk County for the body of Joseph Konkel, 11 years old, who was missing last night after an automobile accident near Flanders, L. I., in which his twin brother William was injured, ended today with the discovery of the boy's body in the underbrush along a dirt road about three miles from the scene of the accident.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Oct. 24.-- With figures for the fourth day of registration available for all but a few towns, Westchester stood today with the greatest voting strength in its history, even greater than the 213,812 record of 1928.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- President Hoover, the Governors of Pennsylvania and Delaware, and the Mayors of three American and one English city hailed William Penn as the embodiment of an undying spiritual force, in radio addresses and messages delivered to an audience of about 10,000 persons in Convention Hall this afternoon.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The text of former Governor Smith's speech here tonight follows:

active session of the Bourse today. Most French stocks benefited by a sharp recovery of French rentes, but all the international stocks were weak. To the pound sterling's drop and weakness in copper and the entire London metal market was attributed the downward tendency in international issues, such as Royal Dutch, Shell, Rio Tinto, Canadian Pacific and the Young loan.

A letter of retraction from Otto H. Kahn, former chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Company, was one of the considerations for the settlement of the suit by Rosalinda Morini, singer, against Mr. Kahn for $250,000 for libel as a result of a letter he wrote to The Musical Courier denying statements in her advertisement that he had praised her voice highly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Loans to nearly 5,000 banks, with 14,340,000 depositors, have been authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to a total of $853,496,289.
TURIN, Italy, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini made new proffers of peace today to the Torinese. who probably have been the most hostile people in all Italy toward fascism.
President Hoover's speech in Newark will be delivered Monday afternoon at Military Park.
ATLANTA, Oct. 24 (AP). -- The text of the speech delivered here tonight by Governor Roosevelt was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- A statement issued by the Republican National Committee today asserts that the recent attack on the tariff signed by 180 economists originated in the office of the National Progressive League in New York.

The Federal Reserve Board's current bulletin confirms the estimate made in his speech of Saturday by Mr. HOOVER (who doubtless obtained his figures from the Board) that $250,000,000 of the money lately hoarded in this country has returned since July 20 to general circulation. The Board explains that return of hoarded currency began in February, when the Reconstruction Corporation got to work.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Gould Shaw of Boston gave a supper party at Kate's Mountain Club last night for fifty guests in honor of the members of the Guyan polo team of Huntingdon, W. Va., who won their match with the Zane Gray team yesterday on the Greenbrier field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I ask you to repair a manifest error? So far in all the various straw ballots, no mention has been made of Snowville, N.H. The oversight, too, is serious, for as Massachusetts follows Hull New Hampshire marches after Snowville.

One of the best deals on Lexington Avenue in many months and which will be followed by the erection of a new bank building has been closed in the sale by Hiram C. Bloomingdale of Bloomingdale Brothers to the Dry Dock Savings Institution, of a large plot on the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

C.B. Comstock, 58 years old, an architect and engineer, listed as a director of three corporations, committed suicide about 6 o'clock last night by shooting himself in the head in his office in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street, after sending his bookkeeper out for a newspaper.

Three-fourths of last year's destitute families are still in that plight and 6 per cent of them have dropped out of sight because in many cases homes have been broken up, it was disclosed last night by Raymond W. Houston, assistant director of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 24. -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and her daughter, Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis 3d, were honored at a luncheon today at Malvern Hall by Colonel and Mrs. Arthur Kelly Evans. Prominent among the guests were Mrs. Richard Nott Dyer, Mrs. Francis Emory Warren, Mrs. Lawrence C. Phipps, Theodosius Stevens, Richard Stevens, the Rev. Ambrose H. Beavin and the Rev. Richard B. Washington.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- More than 200,000 New Jersey followers of Alfred E. Smith hailed the "Happy Warrior" tonight as he moved on to Newark to deliver his first campaign attack upon the acts and policies of the Hoover Administration.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP).--H.H. Temple's Brass Monkey, which has been performing rather indifferently in recent essays, suddenly came to life today to account for the La Vassar Place Handicap, feature of an evenly balanced card.

More than 400 women attended the Democratic reception in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt last night in the Panhellenic apartment building. First Avenue and Fortyninth Street, at which Miss Susan Brandeis, daughter of Justice Louis D. Brandeis of the United States Supreme Court, and Representative John J. O'Connor spoke.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 24. -- A serious agrarian revolt arose today at Yangchow in Kiangsu Province, less than fifty miles from Nanking, and seven persons were killed and six wounded. The rising of the peasants was in opposition to the latest tax measures.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Adams Delano gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for the American Minister to Haiti and Mrs. Norman Armour.

If one could be sure of the extent of individual and regional shifts of party voting since 1928, he would know beyond peradventure how the election on Nov. 8 will go. It is clear and conceded that one Republican asset of four years ago will have to be written off completely.

Fordham's football squad drilled for two hours at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for the only contest it will play away from home this season, the traditional battle with Boston College at Boston off Saturday.

The G.R.D. Studio opened yesterday its new gallery at 9 East Fiftyseventh Street with a large group exhibition called "Our First Four Years." This tells the Story -- though of course not in full detail -- of a most worthy enterprise. The exhibition represent a stock-taking, inasmuch as each of the artists has had, at some time within the last four years, his "first effective showing" at the G.R.D.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Andy Schuttinger's Pilate whirled a mile and seventy yards in 1:41 4-5 to clip two-fifths of a second off the track record in winning the Glenwood Purse today. The fleet son of Friar Rock dominated the running throughout and was four lengths ahead of the nearest opponent, Helianthus, at the end.
BERLIN, Oct. 24. -- Restoration of the monarchy is not an issue in Germany now but "mere campaign smoke," Chancellor von Papen declared today in another fighting speech.

An underworld conversation overheard by Detective Anthony Hanley on a crossed telephone wire early yesterday morning led to the arrest in Brooklyn of two men on charges of attempted robbery and three others as accomplices.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (Canadian Press). -- An Ottawa agreements bill, based on numerous financial resolutions that have engaged the House of Commons in the past week, received first reading tonight to the accompaniment of cheers from members of the government.

The new "safety" code of 1932 has had a tremendous effect in reducing deaths and injuries among college football players, but has failed to eliminate the hazards to prep school, high school and sandlot combatants, chief objectives of the new rules, a survey of gridiron fatalities so far this season indicated yesterday.

Republican leaders throughout the State professed yesterday to be undisturbed over the falling off of registration as compared with 1928 in many up-State cities and villages, while in New York City the registration of voters showed an increase of 304,513 above the 1928 high mark.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24 (AP). -- Governor Roosevelt told an applauding audience of 500 of the South's leading Democrats today that a calm appraisal of his receptions in various parts of the country had convinced him he would be elected and asserted "we as Americans, seeking the aid of Republicans as well, are going to do the best we can to restore prosperity to the American people."

Weaving through heavy traffic and at times galloping along the sidewalks of a congested neighborhood, three runaway horses created excitement along upper Park Avenue and near-by streets early last evening, until a mounted policeman rounded them up one after another after a chase of several blocks.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 24. -- The permanent solution of the crime problem does not lie in enforcement and punishment, said Charles H. Tuttle, former Federal attorney in New York City, in an address at Yale University today.

For the seventh consecutive month, the Reading company reported yesterday for September an increase in net operating income compared with the corresponding month last year. The Illinois Central, the New York, Ontario Western and the Soo Line also reported increased returns from operation.

While Acting Mayor Josaph V. McKee was announcing last night that he would press for additional economies at hearings on Thursday and Friday on the proposed budget, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, made a radio plea for the city to float bonds to complete the Eighth Avenue subway, the Triborough Bridge, new school construction and street improvements to provide work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much interested in the pictures in your Rotogravure Section of the so-called "homeless boys" now roaming the country. In the Summer of 1927, being interested in the Boy Scouts and for my own satisfaction, I made a journey of some 8,000 miles up and down this country to see for myself the condition of these "homeless boys."

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- Boston's fourth annual horse show opens tomorrow afternoon at the Boston Garden and will continue for five days, closing Saturday night, with the international military trophy competition among the army equestrian teams of United States.

The conflict of interests between the late Ivar Kreuger's foreign, companies and his American company in salvaging the promoter's tangled economic empire was formally declared here yesterday Before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal bankruptcy referee, to involve $747,000,000 of foreign claims.

The need of an emergency fund to meet the increased free nursing service anticipated during the coming Winter was stressed yesterday at a conference of the Visiting Nurses Service of the Henry Street Settlement, held at the residence of Mrs. Gerard Swope, 1,040 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Martha D. dropped dead when nearing the finish in the feature event at Sportsman's Park today. The animal rolled over on Jockey J. McLaren, who rode her, and the boy was picked up unconscious. He was rushed to the emergency hospital.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24. -- The Soviet Union's record cotton crop this year is being harvested at record speed. It is estimated that of the total of 1,500,000 tons, as compared with 1,100,000 last year, a third had already been harvested by Oct. 15, or more than double last year's figure.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Although she had five 6's on her card, three of them on pair 4 holes. Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol scored an 84 at the Green Brook Country Club today to lead a field of seventy starters in the first round of the two-day Autumn tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.

When Albert Einstein was asked if he believed in God he answered, "Yes -- in Spinoza's God," and Lewis Browne has tried to explain what sort of God that is in "Blessed Spinoza," a biography of Baruch de Spinoza, published today by Macmillan. The biographer pictures Spinoza as "a man who was indisputably good."

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Sterling again declined sharply in the foreign exchange market today. The New York rate, after opening at $3.37 3/4, fell to $3.32 1/2, recovering in later dealings to $3.33 3/4. At the bottom it was within five pence of the lowest level touched since Great Britain abandoned the gold standard.

James A. Farley, National Democratic chairman, returned to his headquarters at the Biltmore yesterday from a Western speaking trip in behalf of Governor Rooseevlt and reported that President Hoover's speeches had made little impression upon the voters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- President Hoover today studied various proposals for his last two weeks of campaigning. Announcement of his full itinerary of speeches is expected within a day or so.

A crisis has been precipitated in the commercial printing industry by instructions forwarded by the Employing Printers' Association to members instructing them to post notices in their plants tomorrow putting into effect on Thursday the wage scale rejected last week by Typographical Union 6.

QUEBEC, Que., Oct. 24. -- Asserting that price-cutting in the newsprint industry had never really ceased, Premier Taschereau of Quebec today criticized the men at the head of the business for failing to reach an understanding on prices and intimated that the Provincial Government might step into the field and bring the rival factions to an agreement.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Norman Davis, United States disarmament conference delegate, who visited Prime Minister MacDonald at Chequers Saturday, was with the Prime Minister again today at 10 Downing Street.

Edward F. Hutton, banker, industrialist and leader in relief work, in a speech broadcast last night over an N.B.C. network upheld the action of Henry Ford in informing his workers that he believed the welfare of the country called for the re-election of President Hoover.

IT had been a gray day and darkness settled early over the field above the Harlem River where the Columbia football squad was going through its daily drill. The four big floodlights were on. Two teams were lined up in scrimmage formation and Coach Lou Little's voice could be heard giving directions. Down on another part of the field there was some punting.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Tom Huskins and John O'Brien, representing the Old Belleclaire Club of Bayside, in winning the amateurprofessional tournament staged at the Nassau Country Club today were the only two in the field to equal par 70 for the well-known layout on which Jerry Travers got his start.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 25. -- Heavy fighting with a Chinese force which apparently is trying to recapture Tsitsihar, the principal city in Northwest Manchuria, is reported in dispatches received here this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Edward B. Dunford, general counsel of the Anti-Saloon League, took issue today with the statement of the Voluntary Committee of Lawyers, Inc., which urged repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment as one means of increasing taxation to balance the budget.

After the Brooklyn Daily Eagle had announced yesterday that it would refund to the city $1,404.31 in excess profit on a city printing contract Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee said he believed the city could save $1,000,000 a year on printing bills if it watched them carefully.

QUEBEC, Que., Oct. 24. -- Asserting that price-cutting in the newsprint industry had never really ceased, Premier Taschereau of Quebec today criticized the men at the head of the business for failing to reach an understanding on prices and intimated that the Provincial Government might step into the field and bring the rival factions to an agreement.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Norman Davis, United States disarmament conference delegate, who visited Prime Minister MacDonald at Chequers Saturday, was with the Prime Minister again today at 10 Downing Street.

Edward F. Hutton, banker, industrialist and leader in relief work, in a speech broadcast last night over an N.B.C. network upheld the action of Henry Ford in informing his workers that he believed the welfare of the country called for the re-election of President Hoover.

IT had been a gray day and darkness settled early over the field above the Harlem River where the Columbia football squad was going through its daily drill. The four big floodlights were on. Two teams were lined up in scrimmage formation and Coach Lou Little's voice could be heard giving directions. Down on another part of the field there was some punting.

Some Reordering of Gift Lines. Reorders on gift ware lines are beginning to come through in addition to a larger volume of initial orders for the holiday period, it was reported here yesterday. While, generally speaking, the trend is strongly toward utility merchandise, to sell at $5 or below, many luxury and semiluxury items are getting a good play.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although as an old New Yorker I cannot help watching New York politics, my interest in the re-election of Senator Wagner far transcends such a parochial attachment. In every epoch of our history there have been just a few men who were not merely Senators from a State but Senators for the United States.

The drastic changes in the basketball rules for the 1932-33 season were interpreted by L.W. St. John and Oswald Tower of the joint rules committee before a gathering of 800, the largest ever to attend the annual meeting, at the Hotel McAlpin last night.

The overshadowing incident on the financial markets yesterday was the fall of 7 5/3 cents in the pound sterling to $3.31 3/4, the lowest price witnessed since Dec. 7 of last year. As was the case in last week's abrupt fall from the level of $3.45 at which sterling had been "pegged" for some time, the "managers" of the Exchange stood aside and permitted the full force of the decline to make itself felt.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24. -- With the game with Brown this week in mind the Harvard coaches today ordered the longest scrimmage of the year.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 24.--In a moving appeal to fellow-Catholics at a closed meeting, Colonel William J. Donovan hit back tonight at what he called a scurrilous "whispering campaign" being conducted among his co-religionists.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Ending a day of vigorous campaigning before responsive crowds in the Mohawk Valley, Lieut. Gov. Lehman declared his policy on public utilities in an address here tonight in which he demanded genuine, aggressive regulation and a curb on holding companies in the interests of both consumers and legitimate investors.

The Women's Campaign Committee for Governor Roosevelt and Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, organized by the Democratic State Committee under the leadership of Mrs. Daniel O'Day, has nearly 100 members, it was announced yesterday.

Columbia set the stage yesterday at Baker Field for its most intensive week of practice this year. The Lions toiled for more than three hours preparing for their annual combat with Cornell on Saturday. However, according to Coach Lou Little the session will seem mild in comparison with the workouts scheduled for today and tomorrow.

Bishop Wilbur P. Thirkield, retired, of the Methodist Episcopal Church declared that some modern hymns were "hardly more than than religious jazz" at a meeting yesterday of the committee on worship of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.
Barring accidents during its preparatory activities this week, the New York University football team will face Purdue at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday at its full strength.

Speaking at the first of a series of "uptown" luncheon meetings of Illinois alumni at the Western Universities Club yesterday, Lou Little of Columbia scored the practice of criticizing quarterbacks for their selection of plays.

A report that a prison narcotic ring was operating behind the walls of Welfare Island Penitentiary was investigated yesterday as Federal and State officials joined the District Attorney's office and the Department of Correction in inquiries into Saturday's brief riot at the penitentiary, in which one convict was stabbed to death.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Fisheries of the United States in 1930 produced nearly 3,000,000,000 pounds of protein foods and gave employment to 204,000 workers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- All deliveries of wheat on the Board of Trade here sold today at new low marks for the season as the result of persistent selling of small lots by commission houses. The demand on the way down, which was not aggressive, came largely from commission houses on resting orders and from holders of bids.

On the coming week-end New York fans will have the opportunity of seeing in action what is undoubtedly one of the best Big Ten teams to visit the East in recent years when Purdue comes to the Yankee Stadium for the game with New York University.

The John Fritz Gold Medal, highest honor in the engineering profession in the United States, has been awarded for 1933 to Daniel Cowan Jackling of San Francisco for "notable industrial achievement in initiating mass production of copper from low-grade ores through application of engineering principles," it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Automobile production in September declined 6,183 cars under August to a total of 84,144, the Commerce Department announced today. The month's output was 56,425 units under the corresponding month test year and 136,508 less than in September, 1930.

In the year 1931, for which the figures are now made available by the United States Department of Agriculture, 1,679,000 persons "moved farmward," while only 1,472,000 left farms for towns and cities. In the previous year, 1930, the two movements almost balanced, the tide seemingly just beginning to turn.

Animal experimentation is absolutely essential for the ultimate solution of the cancer problem, and those who stand in the way of such experimentation "should be regarded as enemies of civilization," Dr. David J. Kaliski, president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, told 1,500 physicians attending the opening session of the second week's program of the fifth annual graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The Supreme Court allowed a review today to New York. State against Mark. M. MacLay and Charles E. McWilliams, receivers of Mc Williams Brothers, Inc., and the Federal Government.
Purchase of sites for immediate improvement with homes to be occupied by the buyers featured the suburban realty deals reported yesterday.

DENVER, Oct. 24 (AP). -- Colorado felt its first real Winter of the 1932 season today, with five inches of snow in Denver and varying depths from the eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountains to the Kansas line.
Johnny Reid's mother sent him down to the street at 9 o'clock yesterday morning with his face all clean and shiny. He took his toy auto with him.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Wheat consigned from Canada to the United Kingdom obtains the preference of 6 cents a bushel over foreign wheat, even if shipped from United States ports, so long as it is consigned on a through bill from Canada.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- Sitting silent in his place on the front bench this afternoon, Premier Herriot defeated the efforts of a considerable section of the Chamber of Deputies to have an immediate debate on foreign affairs, and, incidentally, war debts.

The liability of officers of a campaign committee for debts of the committed will be determined by City Court Justice Ryan as the result of a verdict before him yesterday for $1,516 in favor of the Empire City Job Print Company for printing done for the La Guardia committee in the 1929 Mayoralty election.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Colonel William J. Donovan lost no time in replying tonight to the charge of former Governor Smith that he was associated with arousing anti-Catholic sentiment in the national campaign of 1928.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 25 (AP). -- S.W. Labrot's Tred Avon, Maryland bred and owned, raced to a courageous nose victory in the Royal Oak Handicap for fillies and mares of all ages at six furlongs at Laurel today.

Members of the vestry of All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church on St. Nicholas Avenue near 116th Street were balked by lack of a quorum last night in their plans to hold a meeting to consider what legal steps, if any, they should take to establish their control of the church property.
George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, endorsed Lewis H. Pounds's candidacy for Mayor yesterday in the following letter to Mr. Pounds, made public at Republican headquarters:

BERLIN, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Prince August Wilhelm, son of the former Kaiser and a member of Adolf Hitler's National Socialist party, tonight declared himself opposed to attempts to alter Germany's present form of government.

The first twenty-one railroads to report for September showed net operating incomes of $17,476,000, against $19,221,000 in September, 1931, a decrease of 9 per cent, and against $33,045,000 in September, 1930, a fall of 47.1 per cent. This was a substantial improvement over August, when their net operating income was $10,148,000, or 41.4 per cent below the $17,337,000 for August, 1931.

It was evident from its first concert of the season that the youthful vivacity of the National Orchestra Association had not deserted it. Most of the members of this band of students, discreetly interspersed with more experienced players, were with the organization last year; a fact which, taken with Leon Barzin's able directing, probably accounts for the good ensemble yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

Stephen Vincent Benet, James G. Cozzens and Edwin Cranberry are the winners of the O. Henry Memorial Prize Awards for 1932. Their stories, with twelve others, are published today by Doubleday, Doran in the fourteenth annual volume of O. Henry Memorial Prize Stories, the plan of which was originated by the Society of Arts and Sciences and taken over by the publishers five years ago.

A great renaissance in the American theatre was envisioned yesterday by Eva Le Gallienne, actress and producer, who predicted that men and women "of the theatre" eventually would take control from the "real estate" men, who are its leaders at present.
LAFAYETTE, Ind. Oct. 25 (AP). -- Purdue's football regulars, facing an intersectional game with New York University, were drilled on pass defense in today's practice.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25. -- Whether Governor Roosevelt is elected or President Hoover is re-elected, America will continue the climb out of the abyss of depression, according to Dr. Irving Fisher of Yale University, who spoke tonight before the Pittsburgh area conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

The conclusion that Thomas J. Mooney and Warren K. Billings were tried unfairly when they were convicted of murder and that their prosecution included instances of "flagrant violations of the statutory law of California" is contained in what has come to be known as the "suppressed Mooney-Billings report of the Wickersham Commission."

In one part of his speech at Newark, ex-Governor SMITH showed that he still has in politics what has been called "the sure instinct for the jugular vein." New Jersey has for years been Wettest of the Wet States. On the prohibition issue she has elected one Democratic Governor after another, with an occasional United States Senator thrown in.

Opposition to salary reductions for teachers and "retrenchment" in the educational system was voiced last night by Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for United States Senator, in A radio address in which he declared that "there must toe no moratorium on education."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25. -- With the exception of Irad Hardy, left tackle; Jim Esterly, left guard; Danny Wells, quarterback, and Jack Crickard, left halfback, all of Harvard's regular eleven took part in today's seventy-five-minute scrimmage between the varsity and freshmen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- With an advance of six points in the production index, industrial activity and shipments of commodities by rail increased from August to September by considerably more than the usual seasonal amount, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

A New York football correspondent, taking a taxi from a South Bend hotel to the Notre Daine campus on the day before the Southern California game last Fall, sought a little inside information from the "downtown quarterback" at the wheel.

Sir Norman Angell, British author, economist, pacifist and former member of Parliament, arrived last night on the Cunarder Laconia to arraign in a series of lectures the present world system of education, which, he said, is largely responsible for the depression.

Shorter working hours and a shorter working week; security for the worker against forced unemployment, and a wage sufficient to provide opportunity for "individual expansion" were advocated last night by George Z. Medalie, Republican nominee for the United States Senate, in outlining his attitude toward labor legislation in campaign addresses.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The pound sterling dropped further today from $3.32 1/2, last night's closing New York rate. It opened around $3.30 1/4 and subsequently went down to $3.28, the year's lowest quotation and within 2d of the low record of $3.23 made since Britain abandoned the gold standard and also within only 5d of the lowest point touched in 1920.

Elimination of "uneconomic units" by suspensions, mergers and voluntary liquidations has made the country's banking structure generally stronger than any of the sweeping plans for legislative reforms could have done, the economic policy commission of the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, refused to make a statement today to House of Commons questioners who tried to learn the government's intentions regarding the American debt.

James A. Farley, Democratic State and national chairman, charged yesterday that campaign managers of Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, were making a "brazen bid" for votes of State employes with inferential promises of higher pay.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Liquidation swept the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today, and all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats and rye, except December oats, dropped to new low marks for the season, December wheat reaching within one-half cent a bushel of the lowest figure ever recorded for any future in the history of the Exchange.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- A commonwealth of nations based on an understanding among them is the world's great need, the American Chamber of Commerce of Berlin was told today by President George Norlin of the University of Colorado, who is occupying the Roosevelt chair at the University of Berlin, succeeding Professor F.J.E. Woodbridge of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Sixty-nine distinguished women leaders of feminine thought and action, including Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Sr., Mrs. William Howard Taft, Mrs. Calvin Coolidge and Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth, have signed an appeal to women of the United States to vote for President Hoover.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 25. -- Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch of New York entertained today with luncheon and bridge for eighteen. Colonel Arthur Kelly Evans motored from Hot Springs and gave a luncheon for Mrs. Richard Nott Dyer of East Orange, N.J., Dr. and Mrs. Guy Hinsdale and Miss Jessie Graham.

The San Carlo Grand Opera Company turned its attention last night to "La Traviata" at the New Amsterdam Theatre. And the result was a fair "Traviata," hardly an inspired one, but a competent journeyman "Traviata." For those who miss opera during the dull season, a performance like this fills the void satisfactorily.

While business in general is inclined to feel better, the reasons in actual support of this feeling are rather few and far between, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents states in its monthly report issued today. "The average feeling seems to be one of maintaining passiveness," the report points out, "until the political fury of the pre-election period has subsided."
Following is some of the editorial comment expressed yesterday throughout the nation on the campaign address of former Governor Smith in Newark on Monday night:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Characterizing President Hoover and Secretary Mills as the "leaders of the tearful chorus" defending the administration's record, Speaker Garner, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, quoted the figures from the Republican textbook of 1932 as "evidence of Republican extravagance."

BALTIMORE. Oct. 25. -- Traveling northward today on the home stretch of his second extensive campaign trip, Governor Roosevelt visited North Carolina, Virginia and Maryland, which President Hoover carried in 1928 but which, he was assured, were certain to be in the Democratic column this year.
MONTREAL, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Three men held up employes of a branch of the Banque Canadienne Nationale in the central part of the city today and escaped with about $13,000.

PARIS, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Premier Herriot told the Chamber of Deputies at the beginning of the new session today that he was ready to discuss foreign policy or anything else the house desired to present for debate. Thus he avoided a question of confidence at the outset, although it had been reported earlier he would insist that the debate on foreign policy receive priority.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, wag cheered by a crowd of more than 2,000 when he arrived at Pennsylvania Station at 9 A.M. yesterday. The welcomers applauded and sang, and surged toward him in shouting enthusiasm when he appeared on the main ramp of the station after alighting from a train from Pittsburgh.

Jack Maypole of River Forest, Ill., 15-year-old outboard motor boat driver, in winning the national outboard championship for 1932, scored 11,738 points, according to the official tabulation compiled by the American Power Boat Association and the National Outboard Association and announced yesterday.

Arnold Rothstein, murdered Broadway gambler, left only $50 in cash, it was disclosed yesterday when Jack Rothstone, his brother, and John J. Glynn, co-administrator, were permitted to delay filing an accounting of the assets until Nov. 30. I. Gainsburg. attorney for the administrators, asked Surrogate John P. O'Brien for more time on the ground that Rothstein had left a complicated estate.

The Fordham back field received most of the attention in the two-hour drill of the Maroon football squad at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for the encounter with Boston College at the new Boston Stadium on Saturday.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25. -- Rogers Hornsby, who was deposed last Summer as manager of the Chicago Cubs, will take the "come-back trail" with the St. Louis Cardinals next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP). -- A new angle to the Ohio-Western Pennsylvania coal rate fight developed today when fifteen Pennsylvania operators complained to the Interstate Commerce Commission that rates between the Pittsburgh, Connellsville and Preeport producing districts and Northeastern Ohio were unreasonably high.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 25 (AP). -- When the liner Neptunia arrived today a third-class passenger was Mme. Elisa Lupescu, a Rumanian, who said she was a widow come to visit a niece here. There were reports that she was Mme. Helene Lupescu, friend of King Carol of Rumania, but she denied that she had any connection with that Mme. Lupescu.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 25.--Following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here tonight:

A "square deal" for everybody, with the laws applied with common sense, is what the city will have from Surrogate John P. O'Brien after his election to the office of Mayor, he told more than a thousand garage men at a luncheon of the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 25. -- The stability of the American dollar "is the greatest factor in the world economy today" and our demonstrated ability to meet all demands for gold is "the cornerstone on which we have started to rebuild the structure of world business," according to a report made here today by the committee on trends of business to the convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America.
MADRID, Oct. 25 (AP). -- The International Labor Cuncil decided today by a vote sixteen to six to consider the question of the forty-hour week at the 1933 International Labor Conference.

A moderate volume of Southern hedging, combined with a little local selling or liquidation promoted by weakness in the grain markets, caused reactions from an opening advance in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchangee here, but quotations firmed again on continued buying and covering.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 25. -- Brown went through a hard forty-five minute scrimmage today in preparation for the "Harvard game Saturday. Frank Gammino replaced Captain Bill Gilfaane at fullback on the varsity team, but otherwise the line-up, which has worked through the first four scheduled games was intact.

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- Mrs. Helena McCann and Mrs. Jessie Donahue, daughters of Mrs. Jennie Woolworth, widow of the chain store founder, today asked the Court of Appeals to set aside an Appellate Division reversal of the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court which gave them commissions of $3,132,757, as administrators of the estate.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25. -- Amid clouds of locusts, which twenty-five peons, armed with rags, branches and noise-makers, sought vainly to dispel, Santa Paula, the defending champion, today won the first game of the Argentine open polo championship, 15 to 7, from the international La Pampa team.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edgerton Parsons will give an afternoon reception Nov. 19 at her home, 21 East Sixty-sixth Street, for her debutante daughter, Miss Leonora Hindsill Parsons.
Listeners to Governor Roosevelt's speech at Baltimore last night over WABC or other stations of the Columbia Broadcasting System failed to hear the complete speech.

At a mass meeting which ended with discussion of the advisability of organizing 50,000 persons for a protest march on City Hall, the Citizens Budget Commission carried its fight for municipal economy to the people last night in Carnegie Hall.

BUCHAREST, Oct., 25. -- It was officially announced today that Prince Nicolas, younger brother of King Carol, would return to Bucharest Thursday from Paris by airplane to resume his duties as chief of the Rumanian military air service after an absence of a year and a half.

The Carlaris gelding Character, piloted by Dominick Bellizzi and for the first time bearing the colors of the B.B. Stable, captured the Beechnut Claiming Handicap, feature at Empire City Yesterday. The time for the short six furlongs was 1:09 2-5, the fastest of the meeting and there was little surprise when it was announced, since there was a bristling duel all the way.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- A spectacular jumping performance by Tan Bark, veteran campaigner of the United States Army horse show team, gave the American riders a triumph in the opening event of the international military competition tonight before a crowd of 7,000, as the Boston Horse Show launched its fourth annual exhibition at Boston Garden.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Beaten to death with an empty bottle, Mrs. Mauree Bonzo, 44, wife of the record and parole clerk at Ohio penitentiary, was found dead in the basement of her home a few blocks from the prison late today.

With the unemployment relief this Winter imperiled by lack of money in the city treasury, Acting Mayor McKee called a conference yesterday of relief agencies, banks and members of the Board of Estimate for Monday to try to find a way to care for the city's needy.

United States Senator Felix Hebert of Rhode Island, Eastern campaign director for President Hoover, returned yesterday from a tour of New England with a prediction that all the States in that section of the country were safe for Mr. Hoover. He predicted also that New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and possibly Maryland would be in the Hoover column.

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- Colonel Frederick S. Greene, head of the Department of Public Works, told the Legislative Economy Committee today that he had anticipated one of the recommendations of the experts, who had reported that a saving of $21,000,000 could be effected in his department.

HARRISBURG. Pa., Oct. 25. -- Pennsylvania's total registration reported by all of the sixty-seven counties to the State Bureau of Elections, shows there are 59,205 fewer qualified voters today than in 1928, the year of the Hoover-Smith contest.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 25.--After a two-day rest period, Dartmouth's first-string football squad returned to action today in preparing for the Yale game at New Haven Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- President Hoover will make his next campaign speech at Indianapolis on Friday night. This was announced this afternoon by the Indiana State Republican Committee and confirmed by a White House secretary after he consulted the President, who was working on a campaign speech in the Lincoln study.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Going through another long workout, Cornell's football team showed improved form today, particularly in the rehearsal of its running attack. Coach Gilmour Dobie stressed blocking and interference for the ball carrier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25.--Authority to consolidate thirteen subsidiary lines of the Southern Pacific System under the leadership of the Texas New Orleans Railroad was sought in a joint application filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the lines to be unified.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "Mr. Borah's Orient," you question the Senator's view that governmental action to raise the price of silver will improve foreign markets for American goods. I believe that an examination of this question from all aspects will prove that Senator Borah's contention is correct.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25. -- Fat Sullivan today took over Dud Parker's place at Yale's quarterback and probably will occupy that position against Dartmouth Saturday.

Disregarding criticism of existing tariffs as too high, President HOOVER has ordered an investigation to determine whether they are not in fact too low. He calls the attention of the Tariff Commission to the fact that "currencies in thirty countries "have now depreciated irom 5 to 55 "per cent."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 25. -- Luis Davila, a brother of the recently ousted Provisional Bresident Carlos G. Davila, was seriously wounded today while resisting the destruction of the furnishings of his brother's home.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The first joint public appearance of the Republican, Democratic and Socialist candidates on the Westchester tickets took place this afternoon before the Westchester League of Women Voters at the Hotel Gramatan here.

Crockford's, Inc., a bridge club sponsored by Ely Culbertson, has rented for its own occupancy the house at 14 East Sixty-second Street, which thoroughfare already contains the homes of the Knickerbocker, Colony and Whist Clubs in the stretch between Fifth and Park Avenues.

Manhattan College opened preparations yesterday for the Oglethorpe game with a brisk two-hour workout at Manhattan Field. A dummy scrimmage between the varsity and freshman elevens featured the drill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Faced with three separate "threats" from various groups who are planning to "march on Washington" during the early Winter, E.W. Brown, Police Superintendent, today sent letters to police chiefs throughout the country requesting that every possible bit of information be supplied Washington authorities concerning the nature, temper and size of groups en route to the capital.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Oct. 22 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
CINCINNATI, Oct. 25. -- The text of the speech delivered here tonight by Ogden L. Mitts, Secretary of the Treasury, is as follows:

The Actors' Dinner Club, situated since last June in the basement of the Loew's State Theatre Building, where unemployed actors and performers have received meals free of charge, is faced with the necessity of finding new quarters, it was announced last night.

The Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding structure, reported yesterday a net loss of $39,710 after all deductions in the three months ended on Sept. 30, against a net profit of $566,723 in the same period last year. This brought to $210,692 the net profit for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, against $2,649,073 in the same period last year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- In this stronghold of Republicanism, Lieut. Gov. Lehman pledged tonight his utmost effort to the carrying out j of the Smith-Roosevelt program for the development and operation of the St. Lawrence water-power project by the State and declared the Republican party both in this State and at Washington have pursued a consistently obstructive course in the interests of private power companies.

Columbia's hope of victory over Cornell in their annual game Saturday received a serious setback yesterday when it was learned that Steve Dzamba, guard, and Otto Schwartz, fullback, would be unable to play.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The worst effects of the economic depression, in its relation to public health, are yet to come, according to Dr. Carl E. Buck of New York, field director of the American Public Health Association and chairman of its section on child hygiene.

President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt endorsed yesterday the work of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which will open its campaign to raise $15,000,000 for the alleviation of unemployment distress on Nov. 10.
Small residential properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Declaration yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation of its regular dividend on the preferred stock will everywhere be taken as one of the evidences of improving business conditions. There is nothing political about it, except as the directors plainly do not fear that the election of Governor ROOSEVELT would plunge us into industrial chaos.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Charges of "serious wastes" resulting from intense competition for freight traffic were made against the railroads today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, in a report on the conclusions growing out of its recent investigation into expenditures connected with duplication of produce terminals

Rita Orville, soprano, who sang last night in the Town Hall, performed for her audience that service described by a French colleague as "enlarging the public's circle of musical acquaintances," a service rare enough among singers to call forth prompt gratitude.

LONDON, Oct. 25.--While ragged detachments of 2,000 "hunger marchers" camped on the outskirts of London tonight the government rode roughshod over the Laborite motion of censure provoked by its handling of the unemployment problem.

After falling an additional 2 1/8 cents to $3.29 5/8, the lowest price since Dec. 9, last, the pound sterling yesterday met with sufficient support to induce short covering. The rally brought about by the closing out of bearish positions in the exchange lifted the currency to $3.31 1/4, but the final quotation, $3.30 1/4, was nevertheless 1 1/2 cents beneath Monday's last price.

Thirty-seven entries have been received for the Essex Fox Hounds Hunts Meet to be held this afternoon on the Schley estate at Far Hills, N.J., starting at 2 o'clock. Four events are on the program, with the Mount Defiance Cup and The Bernardsville attracting the largest number of entries.

If the sun has been coy about showing himself "in full meridian splendor" for some days, it was because he felt himself superfluous in a country dazzled by election predictions. Both sides are going to win. Ever since Mr. HOOVER became inspired with "fighting spirit" the Republicans have seen millions of voters changing their minds in a flash; and the task of the Republicans is easy.

Celebration of the tercentenary o CHRISTOPHER WHEN must have reminded Londoners that much of the historic architecture of their city is going down before wrecking crews Probably there is no better authority on the subject than E. BERESFORD CHANCELLOR, member of the London Topographical Society and author of several books about London squares streets and roads.

Motor classification by piston displacement, instead of by horsepower compilation as in former years, was included in the recommendations for inboard runabout racing by the Runabout Contest Board of the American Power Boat Association in session last night.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 25. -- A million-dollar "conspiracy" suit against Fox Films, Vitagraph and United Artists collapsed in the United States court this afternoon when a New Hampshire paper expert produced a watermarking stamp bearing the imprint "par value 100 per cent" and swore paper so watermarked was not marketed before April, 1930.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 25. -- An upset was scored in the renewal of the important Criterion Stakes for 2-year-olds today when Gerald Deane's The Blue Boy won by a length from the odds-on favorite, Lord Durham's Scarlet Tiger.

STREATOR, Ill., Oct. 25. -- Seven gunmen were captured here today two hours after they had taken $2,000 in a raid on the First National Bank of Ransom, twelve miles away. The men were arrested and the loot recovered in the home of Mike De Martino, owner of a Streator soft drink place, who, authorities believe, was the seventh member of the gang.

NAMPA, Idaho, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Senator William E. Borah, Idaho Republican, declared in an address here tonight that the Newark (N.J.) speech by Alfred E. Smith was "one of the most effective speeches yet made in this campaign for Mr. Hoqver."

MUSKOGEE, Okla., Oct. 25 (AP). -- The Rev. S.A. Berrie, 52-year-old unfrocked Cumberland Presbyterian minister, was convicted late today by a jury of the poison murder of his first wife, Mrs. Fannie Berrie.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 25 (AP). -- Gilbert Elston, called by some racing experts the year's best jockey on American tracks, suffered a fracture of the skull today in a tumble with his mount at the Latonia Jockey Club track. Hospital authorities said his condition was serious.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- In a day of wild gyrations, sterling tumbled at one time today to $3.28 -- a low record for the year -- then rallied and closed at $3.30, more than 2 cents below yesterday's final figure.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Mathew Geis has been appointed Princeton track coach to succeed Keene Fitzpatrick, it was announced today by Thurston J. Davies, supervisor of sports and acting chairman of the Princeton board of control.

Party leaders at the Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee in this city professed yesterday to find it a trifle difficult to conceal their extreme pleasure over the tone and temper of the address delivered by Alfred E. Smith at Newark, N.J., on Monday evening.

The appointment of an impartial committee, consisting of two alumni trustees, the president of the Columbia University Club, two members of the Columbia faculty and two undergraduates, to make an inquiry into charges of professionalism of intercollegiate athletics at Columbia University was announced last night by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- A three-year loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $6,170,000 to the Erie Railroad was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. It is proposed to apply the funds in part payment of overdue vouchers, taxes, intsrest, rents and capital charges up to Jan. 1, 1933.

The protective committee for holders of first-mortgage 6 1/2 per cent Union Gas Corporation bonds has announced the adoption of a reorganization plan providing for the purchase of the property at a foreclosure sale on Nov. 7 and the transfer of title to a new company.

An attack upon the Independent Citizens' Committee, which, is working for the election to the Supreme Court of Justices Richard P. Lydon, Aron Steuer and Timothy A. Leary and State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, as misleading and a "fraud" was made yesterday by George Trosk, associate counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press). -- George Lansbury, in a vehement speech in the House of Commons tonight, declared: "People are starving, and masses of young people are growing up without any hope." He said the Labor party, when it returned to office, would take over the country's industries and rationalize and reorganize them.

A precious-metal plant at 32 Flushing Avenue, opposite the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where adulterated gold, platinum and silver are put through a refining process, was robbed of gold, platinum and silver valued at $50,000 yesterday afternoon by five armed men, who took advantage of a brief period while the steel doors of the garage were opened to permit a truck to leave.

Business on the Stock Exchange was at low ebb yesterday, with speculative activity sharply curtailed in advance of the dividend meeting of the United States Steel Corporation. The total turnover was 604,000 shares, against 552,000 shares on the day before.

The American Water-Color Society will open its sixty-sixth annual exhibition this evening with a reception and private view in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Beginning tomorrow the work will be on public view, remaining through Nov. 13.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 25. -- A proposal to abolish the Senate as costly and unnecessary is understood to be under consideration by the government of President Getulio Vargas in making plans to rewrite the Constitution of 1891.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Fish packers and manufacturers of matches joined today the representatives of distressed industries which for a week have appeared before the Customs Commissioner seeking relief from what they consider to be unfair foreign competition.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct 25. -- S. Leslie Doremus, 57 years old, former president of the Edgewater Trust Company at Edgewater, was found dead this afternoon in a tool room adjoining his garage at the rear of his residence here by Bernardine O'Leary, a maid, who was sent to call him for lunch.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25. -- A writ alleging "gross negligence" was issued today against the members of the board of directors of the Kreuger Toll Company. Among those affected by the writ are the late Ivan Kreuger's 80-year-old father, Ernst Kreuger; Major Nils Ahlstroem, Oscar Rydbeck and Donald Durant of New York.
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- My Own High Time gained his second championship today when he led the greatest field of cocker spaniels ever gathered in a field trial in this country.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 25.--Lieut. Gov. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman narrowly escaped serious injury near Rochester this evening when a State Highway Department truck sidewiped the Lieutenant Governor's car and smashed head-on into the car following it.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Oct. 25. -- Daniel Frohman, internationally known theatrical producer, visited his birthplace, a little tumble-down story-and-a-half frame house in Sandusky's outskirts today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (AP). -- The diplomatic corps of virtually all the countries represented here bought up all the stock of a food store operated for their benefit today, the last day they were permitted to use Soviet currency in the shop. By mid-after-noon the shelves were emptied.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. John C. Maxwell were hosts at a large luncheon here today. Prominent among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Philip A.S. Franklin Jr., Mr. and Mrs. William W. Struthers, Mrs. Deforest M. Alexander and Dr. Stuart L. Craig.

A flock of broadbill ducks estimated to number 5,000 has landed in the marshes west of Saybrook, Conn., and in the last few days has furnished hunters with limit bags. Drift party of four reported yesterday that it had accounted for all the law allows, which is ten each, and that it could have bagged as many as thirty each without any great effort.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Perhaps it's the new rules, maybe it's a general trend toward open football, but the "rabbit" backs are stealing the show from their huskier team mates in the Big Six Conference this Fall.

TOKYO, Oct. 25 (AP). -- A new disarmament plan, distinctly Japanese and differing from the American and British suggestions for naval reduction, is to be advanced by the Japanese representative when the disarmament conference resumes next February at Geneva, The Associated Press learned today.

A reduced dividend scale has been prepared for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company for 1933 and will be submitted to the directors for their approval, according to a circular letter sent to the company's agents by John R. Hardin, president, yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 25. -- Suffolk County authorities were still searching tonight for the occupants of the automobile which killed Joseph Konkel, 11 years old, and Injured his twin brother, William, as they were riding in their pushmobile on the Riverhead-Hampton Bays Road near their home in Flanders last Sunday evening.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Additional National Guardsmen and squads of Rangers were rushed to the East Texas oil field tonight upon orders of Governor R.S. Sterling to keep the lid clamped on the vast producing area in the face of a Federal Court decision holding that existing proration regulations are invalid.

Former Governor Smith, whose speech at Newark, reviving the religious issue of 1928, was received yesterday at Democratic National Headquarters with mixed emotions, will leave tomorrow morning to fill a series of speaking engagements in New England and up-State cities for the Roosevelt-Garner ticket.

Severe criticism of America for "debunking" native artists, authors and thinkers and making heroes of prize-ring champions and baseball stars was made last night by Leon Dabo, veteran American painter, in an address at a dinner given under the auspices of the Friendship Bond Committee of Roerich Museum, 310 Riverside Drive.

A long scrimmage between teams A and C featured yesterday's two-hour workout of the New York University football team at Ohio Field, where the squad continued its preparations for the intersections battle with Purdue at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.
To the Editor of The New Times Times: In the editorial correspondence of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday the following passage occurs in the Boston letter:

ANCHORS aweight The Naval Academy belongs to the country at large and there, should be room for a little inside information about the midshipmen in football togs. Ready all? You may fire when you are ready, Gridley.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP). With three additional reports today of floggings, authorities pushed their search for members of a whipping gang reputed to have heaten at least nineteen persons here recently, including five white women.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday-1 3/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- Sir Walter Layton, economist, who came into world prominence when he drafted the reports of the Young Plan commission and the Wiggin bankers commission on conditions in Germany, resigned tonight, as British delegate to the preparatory commission for the World Economic Conference because of differences of opinion with the government.

New lows for short-term money featured an otherwise dull and uninteresting market. Sixty-day money was offered and traded at 1/2, a drop of 1/4, while ninety days were quoted at 1/2@3/4, also a decline of 1/4. Later maturities were maintained at previous levels.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "R.P.B.'s" letter on tariff responsibility, published in THE TIMES, is such an extraordinary contribution to a public understanding of the present tariff situation that I hope you can persuade him to elaborate.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 25. -- United States Senator Royal S. Copeland of New York, addressing a Democratic rally here tonight, declared it was no credit to big banking interests to boast they were "85 per cent liquid -- the boast being as cruel as the statement of a hospital showing 85 per cent of its beds empty, when 1,000 patients clamored for admission."

Abraham Lazoff, 47 years old, was found dead yesterday morning in his dry goods store at 1,474 St. Peter's Avenue, the Bronx. He had committed suicide, the police said, but had tried to make his death appear a murder, apparently so that, the police said, his family could collect double indemnity on six insurance policies said to total about $15,000.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25.--Replying to Governor Roosevelt's assertion that his opponents were attempting to carry on a campaign of fear against him. Secretary Mills declared in a speech here tonight that "his party and he himself are largely responsible for its existence."

A motionless stock market reflected Wall Street's uncertainty yesterday with respect to the United States Steel Corporation's preferred dividend action. The decision of the directors was not announced until after the close of business on the Stock Exchange.

The committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate, following the lead of Acting Mayor McKee and Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial, refused yesterday to award to the Fifth Avenue Coach Company a franchise to operate buses on two routes on the upper east side.

Abuses of the compensation laws in this State are making compensation insurance so costly that it presents an economic danger, according to Arthur Arnow, president of the General Insurance Brokers Association.

Unfamiliar Election Districts. Can it be calculated dereliction on the part of the newspaper polls or is it mere oversight? It is now some time since Ambassador MELLON delivered a pro-Hoover speech in Manchester, England, and neither The Literary Digest returns nor the Hearst papers have even a single straw to show the effect.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Prices of hogs broke 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds today and were easy at the finish. The top was off 15 cents to $3.55, coming within 25 cents of the lowest figure in thirty-six years, while the day's average was lowered 10 cents to $3.35, or only 20 cents above the inside price of the season.

Organizations of the Roman Catholic Church, two Bishops and a number of other clergy are listed as large creditors of Daniel O'Connell, indicted head of an investment banking house, which did a large business for trustees of religious funds, it was revealed yesterday when attorneys for Daniel O'Connell Company, Inc., filed schedules in bankruptcy.

Although criticism of contemporaries is said to be gossip, it is stimulating occasionally to talk in terms of a century. HENRY HAZLITT has attempted this in The Forum by Inquiring how great our greatest living American authors are. He is no jingo.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., Oct. 25. -- A steady round of 41, 40 -- 81, added to her first day's score of 84, enabled Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol to win by a margin of eleven strokes in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's Autumn tonrnament, which ended today at the Green Brook Country Club.

MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 25. -- Alter a protracted meeting of the bankers' committee here today in connection with the critical state in the newsprint industry, it was indicated that a further gathering will take place. Indications were that negotiations were approaching a head.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much has recently been said about the free classes for unemployed adults in city schools, but nobody has as yet attempted to analyze the question from an economic point of view. The facts are that the classes have cost the city about $80,000 in the past two years, and that about 20,000 persons have obtained positions as a result of that training.

The Board of Estimate, sitting in committee of the whole yesterday, voted to ask the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to defer approval of a loan asked by the Port Authority to finance the proposed Thirty-eighth Street Tunnel connecting Manhattan with New Jersey until the city had an opportunity to be heard on the matter.

Sales billed for the first nine months of 1932 by the General Electric Company amounted to $113,049,475, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday. This compares with $206,138,967 for the same period of 1931, a decline of 45 per cent. For the third quarter, sales billed were $32,838,986, against $64,958,876 a year before.
The charge that between 150,000 and 200,000 persons had fraudulently registered for the November election in the city was made yesterday at the office of the Republican State Committee.

MILAN, Oct. 25. -- Milan, for many years Premier Mussolini's adopted home city, in which he took the first steps on the road leading to the dictatorship of Italy, accorded him a great welcome today on his arrival to deliver a speech commemorating the tenth anniversary of the march on Rome.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Oct. 18 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 7,311,208 running bales, including 246,367 round bales counted as half bales and 2,526 bales of American-Egyptian.

There are indications that a well-organized system of narcotic distribution exists on Welfare Island, and that certain inmates of the penitentiary have regular runners and sources of supply, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, said yesterday in announcing that his assistants would present evidence today to a Federal grand jury.

MONTAUK, L.I., Oct. 25. -- A railroad engineer was scalded to death tonight and a fireman seriously burned when the Long Island Railroad Cannonball Express, traveling eastbound, jumped the track at 6:48 P.M. one mile west of the Montauk Station in Rodda Valley, crashed into an embankment and turned over.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- A sharp rise in quotations on the Bourse today affected both domestic and international stocks. Rentes led the activity with gains of between one and two francs from yesterday's closing prices.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- The Supreme Court at Leipzig today upheld President von Hindenburg and Chancellor von Papen in their removal of the Braun-Severing Government of Prussia last July. But the court also decreed that the Reich had no right to remove the Prussian Ministry permanently nor to prevent the Ministers from representing Prussia in the Reichstag, Prussian Diet or Federal Council.

The annual meeting of the National Association of Audubon Societies was thrown into an uproar yesterday in the Museum of Natural History when a clamorous minority shouted its protests against the officers of the assotion and charged the administration with favoring wood-pulp interests in opposing its efforts to have Admiralty Island, Alaska, set aside as a sanctuary for brown bears.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Speaking at a Republican rally of about 7,000 persons at the Convention Hall here tonight, United States Senator W. Warren. Barbour, Republican candidate for election to the office he now holds by appointment, declared that he believed, "absolutely and unqualifiedly in this country's Deed for an adequate protective tariff which safeguards our workers, our industries and our farmers from ruinous and unfair foreign competition."

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- The right of the State Parole Board to return to prison an alleged parole violator without red tape or court proceedings was upheld, in effect, by a decision today of the Court of Appeals in the case of Owen Madden, now in Sing Sing, who sought release through a habeas corpus proceeding.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Any proposal by Japan for reducing the burden of armaments will be studied sympathetically by the United States, but officials declined today to speculate on possibilities because of their complete lack of official information concerning the plan that Japan would offer at Geneva.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (AP). -- The newspaper Excelsior said today that a group of New York bankers and industrialists was in the city studying possible flotation of a $5,000,000 bond issue for reconstruction of the water supply, sewerage and drainage systems of the capital.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 25. -- Repeating his promises of a "new deal," Governor Roosevelt declared tonight that he was waging a war in this campaign against the "four horsemen" of the Hoover Administration.

The directors of the United States Steel Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on its preferred stock, maintaining the company's record of continuous payments on the issue for thirty-one years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Despite increased postage rates, which went into effect July 1, a report submitted to Chairman James M. Mead of the House Postoffice Committee, made public today, showed that receipts at 100 select and industrial offices druing the three months ended Sept. 30, had declined to $82,104,789,79, 1866,694.77 under the corresponding period of 1931.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 25. -- Nassau County established a new registration mark this year, according to figures released, today by the Board of Elections here. The figures show that with three election districts missing 176,857 persons are qualified to vote this year.

Supremely confident of election, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, returned yesterday from his second extended campaign trip, visited Democratic National Headquarters, went to his home in Hyde Park for dinner and then motored to Albany, where he will confer today with the Republican legislative leaders about issuing a call for a special session of the Legislature to provide funds for unemployment relief.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There will be submitted to the voters of this State on Nov. 8 one amendment and one proposition.

The belief that Europe has definitely begun to put her house in order was expressed last night by James D. Mooney, vice president of the General Motors Corporation in charge of overseas operations, on his return here aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- The text of the address delivered here tonight by Secretary Stimson was as follows:
