LANSING, Mich., Oct. 26 -- A new State law permitting depositors to have a voice in the handling of their funds is helping to reopen Michigan banks.

To an extent rarely paralleled in this city's history, economy has become the issue of the hour. This was amply attested by the speeches made at Carnegie Hall and elsewhere on Tuesday evening. Mr. POUNDS, Republican candidate for Mayor, put it in the forefront of his program, making a number of practical suggestions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Discovery of a method of distinguishing the differences between ostensibly identical bacteria by testing their electrical charges and thus making possible the quick and certain diagnosis of infantile paralysis was explained today by Dr. Edward E. Rosenow of the Mayo Foundation to the American Public Health Association.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is manifest that more bridges and tunnels would be more helpful to the growth of the City of New York than more controversies.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Alfred E. Smith returns to his favorite political territory here tomorrow night to plead for the re-election of his close friend, Governor Joseph B. Ely, and incidentally to put in a friendly word for Franklin D. Roosevelt and John N. Garner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- After losing a dozen forts to Paraguayan troops in the Chaco in the last month and the fall of two governments within a week. Bolivia agreed today, through a communication to the Commission of Neutrals here, to negotiate for peace.

An exhibition of work by Dorothy Varian is always a delight long to be remembered. Her paint imprisons -- releasing it lavishly for those who have eyes to see -- such a warm spirit of joyousness and spontaneous good humor. The new oils now shown at the Downtown Gallery do not, in this respect, dissappoint.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt's statement on the bonus, made in his Pittsburgh address, cannot fairly be called disappointing. All people of even moderately acute discernment expected from the Smiling Candidate only the continued evasion which is designed to keep both the bonus grabber and the taxpayer as strings on his political bow.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- The Princeton and Lafayette 150-pound football teams battled to a scoreless tie in Palmer Stadium today in the opening game of the season for the Tiger light-weights.

Land costs constitute the major problem in slum clearance and low-cost housing, William Stanley Parker, Fellow of the American Institute of Architects, concludes in a progress report of slum clearance in Boston released yesterday by the institute.

The "epidemic of incorporation" in Nassau County, which has resulted in the creation of seventeen new municipalities in the last year, bringing the county's total to sixty-eight, is "deplored" in a survey of the planning situation in seventeen counties of the New York region just finished by the Regional Plan Association.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Coach Gilmour Dobie today made two changes in the Cornell line-up as the team continued preparations for the Columbia game Saturday. Dick Beyer went to the second-string back field, being supplanted by Homer Geoffrion, while Tom Borland, a sophomore, was used for part of the drill in Harry Shaub's place at left guard.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Government circles tonight thought it probable that the superior Council of national defense, which will meet in the Elysee tomorrow, would approve the French plan for adapting disarmament to security so that it may be submitted to the disarmament commission at Geneva Nov. 3.

Praising President Hoover as "the outstanding figure of modern times," and assailing Governor Roosevelt as the advocate of "impossible" tariff proposals and the friend of a "detrimental" immigration policy, William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, replied for the Republican party last night to the Newark speech of former Governor Smith.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the approval of applications for listing new common shares of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation, the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation and the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which are to be exchanged share for share for the old no-par common stock of these companies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Cool weather and a light run induced buying of hogs today and prices generally were 5 to 10 cents a hundred pounds higher than yesterday, while some sales of sows were up 15 cents. Arrivals were the smallest for a Wednesday in recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Further improvement in general business conditions and a continuation of an upward trend for two successive months for the first time since the Spring of 1930 were reported today by Roy D. Chapin, Secretary of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A renewed drive for the bonus was launched today. The Veterans of Foreign Wars, the American Legion and the Disabled American Veterans took simultaneous action to forestall attempts to curtail govermental expenditures for ex-soldiers and to revive the fight for immediate payment of the bonus certificates due in 1945.

In revenge against his daughter-in-law, George La Maze, 60 years old, killed her 4-year-old son, George La Maze 3d, in his home at 91-18 Ninety-seventh Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens, yesterday while the parents were at their work in a Bronx enamelware factory, then hanged himself in the kitchen, according to the police.

Giuseppe Guarnerius made it clear by his signature that fie created his immortal fiddles through the grace of God. The same thing may be remarked of the playing of Fritz Kreisler. Especially when he plays in the mood that was on him last night before the audience that filled the house, sat on tHe stage, and stood and crushed in Carnegie Hall.

GIBBSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 26 -- An explosion which affected a twenty-five-mile area late this afternoon injured five workmen and caused damage estimated at $50,000 at the Repauno works of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., here and shattered dozens of windows in the town.

Four of fifteen witnesses who appeared at the Federal Building for examination in the government's investigation of the reported sale and distribution of narcotics on Welfare Island were questioned yesterday before a Federal grand jury.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 26 -- For the second time in about a week, the brokerage license of Halsey, Stuart Co. was suspended today by the Michigan Securities Commission. The commission first took action following the revelation that company officials had been indicted in Milwaukee, on charges of using the mails to defraud in connection with the flotation of Insull securities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The index number of wholesale prices for the week ended Oct. 22 was 64.4, the same as for the previous' week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index numbers are derived from price quotations of 784 commodities, weighted according to the importance of each commodity and based on average prices for the year 1926 as 100.

While an opening advance of quotations yesterday was followed by reaction on the Cotton Exchange here, prices firmed again on continued trade buying and by covering or rebuying by early sellers stimulated the firmer tone of the late stock market.

While representatives of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. were engaged in caustic argument with Republican spokesmen over Mr. Bennett's purported, failure to take proper and timely measures to prevent fraudulent registration, the rights of approximately 1,000 persons to vote in the coming election, challenged, from various sources, were under review yesterday by Justice Albert Cohn in the Supreme Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Mr. Hoover at Detroit" treats the President's vituperations of the Democratic party very leniently. If no plank of the Democratic platform can ever be carried out, such failure could not bring as much disaster upon the country as has the 1928 Republican promise of two cars in every garage, a chicken in every pot and poverty abolished forever.

At the suggestion of Newton D. Baker, a study of the relationships of the various religious groups in typical American communities, which the executive committee of the National Conference of Jews and Christians decided to undertake at its annual meeting at the Catholic Club last night, will include political and economic aspects of religious prejudice which cause trouble in community life.

The National Hockey League will start its season on Thursday, Nov. 10, when six of uhe teams in the circuit engage in opening games. The league will function with nine sextets this year, as against eight last season. The Ottawa Senators, who withdrew from major league competition at the end of the 1930-31 campaign, have re-entered the lists.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26 -- Joseph Hale Johnson of Hartford, Yale centre, will be out of football for the rest of the season, it was announced at the office of the Yale Athletic Association tonight.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, is the choice of Columbia "University students in the coming Presidential campaign, according to the final tabulation, made public yesterday, of a campus-wide poll straw conducted by The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Orders of "suspicion of dumping," requiring a 100 per cent bond from the importer, will be issued within a few days against imports of stearic acid from The Netherlands and waterproof rubber footwear from Czechoslovakia.

Alfred W. Jenkins, Brooklyn art patron and head of Parsons Petitt, importers of chemicals, left part of his art collection to the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, and more than $50,000 in specific bequests to other philanthropic and religious institutions, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of his will in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 26 -- General Hans Kundt, who gave Bolivia a modern army but left the country upon the overthrow of President Hernando Siles in 1930, will return soon from Germany, according to the morning newspapers and certain well-informed officials here.

Long Island fishermen again are having trouble. Flounders have provided good catches in recent days, but now the blue claw crabs have come in and the flounders refuse to take bait. Not until the crabs bury themselves in the mud will the flounders bite again.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is somewhat surprising that President Hoover and Mr. Coolidge should attempt to make "greenbacksm" an issue in this campaign, in view of the fact that the only greenbacks ever issued by our government since the adoption of the Constitution were by act of the Republican party.

Received and Contents Noted. "Dear Sir: As an alumnus, not irate but merely contemplative, of Ohio Wesleyan University, I rise to inquire why defeats of Syracuse University's football eleven by the team from Ohio Wesleyan are branded 'upsets' by sports writers of the East. (Vide your own comment upon occasion.)

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Wheat and other grains continued downward today and the break did not culminate until December wheat had dropped 1 3/8 cents to 44 1/8 cents a bushel, the lowest price recorded for any delivery on the Board of Trade here since trading in futures was started about seventy years ago.

ST. GEORGE, Bermuda, Oct. 26 -- John Teevan and I had our narrowest escape from death today when the bathysphere in which we were exploring the sea life off Nonsuch Island nearly struck a jagged ridge of the sea bed.

NAMPA, Idaho, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A call for "these able gentlemen who are so blue, so discouraged," to "come to grips with the real problems" of the depression was made here last night by Senator Borah of Idaho in an address in which he took issue with Montague Norman, governor of the Bank of England.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- An attack on Governor Roosevelt by Senator Charles J. Hewitt, Chairman of the Legislative Economy Committee, today enlivened the proceedings in the committee's questioning of Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, head of the Department of Public Works.

Up, bearing the colors of W.H. Karrick, scored in the Hartsdale Purse, the feature at Empire City yesterday, and chalked up his first victory in eleven starts this year. Last year, as a 3-year-old, the son of High Cloud and Idleness raced for James N. Crofton and was named for the Kentucky Derby, but was scratched the afternoon of the race.

Jeanette II hung her head in shame last night in the privacy of her stall in the Central Park Zoo. Her cheek burned with iodine and a maidenly blush. In her year and a half of existence she had maintained the tradition of her line; she had been a dry and a symbol of dryness.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- With the assertion that if Alfred E. Smith delivered two more speeches for Governor Roosevelt "then Hoover is sure to be re-elected," Norman Thomas, the Socialist candidate for President, began a forty-eight-hour invasion of Philadelphia and its vicinity today.

A voluntary plan of readjustment of the capital, debt and executive management has been submitted to stockholders of the Superior Oil Corporation by a committee formed at the request of holders of substantial amounts of the company's stock, it was announced yesterday.

Izzy Einstein, who helped to raid 3,000 speakeasies between 1920 and 1927 and made 4,932 arrests by the use of disarming brogue and quaint disguises, was introduced as a man of letters yesterday by Frederick A. Stokes Co. His maiden literary effort, "Prohibition Agent No. 1," is out today.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 26 -- Funeral services for Joseph Konkel, 10 years old, whose body wag found in the underbrush about three miles from the scene of an accident on the State highway where he and his twin brother, riding in a toy wagon, had been struck by an automobile, were held at the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Konkel, in Flanders, near here, today.

HONOLULU, Oct. 26 -- Army authorities at Fort Shafter announced this afternoon the arrest of two private soldiers from Fort Ruger, coast artillery post on the slopes of Diamond Head, on charges of the removal of confidential military documents from their files without the permission of the proper authorities.

Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Committee of One Thousand, aligned himself yesterday with those favoring the election of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch, candidates of the Independent Judges' party, running for Supreme Court justice against State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer.

The right to disaffirm three unprofitable leases was granted and further details of the losses to the United Cigar Stores Company of America through its real estate holding corporations were presented yesterday at hearings into the liquidated value of these holdings before Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Declaring that the election of a Democratic President was undetermined more than a year ago, Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, in a radio speech tonight predicted the election of Governor Roosevelt.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- The Irish Free State Army equestrian team triumphed tonight in the international jumping competition for pairs, the feature event of the second day of the Boston Horse Show in the Boston Garden. A crowd of about 10,000 attended.

State of Missouri. The State of Missouri received two bids yesterday for $2,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent highway bonds which it is attempting to sell, and rejected both. One was made by a group headed by the Guaranty Company, offering to pay 95.08 per cent for the bonds, with a thirty-day option on the re- mainder of the proposed issue of $5,000,000.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- The governmental schism in Prussia, made de jure yesterday when the Federal courts awarded the right to administer the State to the Reich and other executive prerogatives to the previously shelved Braun-Severing Cabinet, remained an unsolved problem today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The formation of the Gulf Associated Freight Conference, through which member lines are to cooperate in the joint administration of the separate conferences in which they participate, was approved by the Shipping Board today.

Alfred E. Smith's address in Boston tonight will be broadcast over a nation-wide radio hook-up although the Democratic national headquarters, it became known yesterday, has received many letters and telegrams from Democrats of the South and West protesting against Mr. Smith's revival of the religious issue in his Newark speech on Monday, and asking that he be kept off national radio hook-ups in the rest of the campaign.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Standing on the same platform from which Colonel Donovan assailed him last night as the "shadow" of Governor Roosevelt and denounced the Democratic administration as extravagant, Lieut. Gov. Lehman declared tonight that he would fight for genuine economy, but would not resort to a sham economy in order to make a showing.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- The Boerse opened somewhat more active and firmer today. The spurt soon died out, however, and most prices fluctuated on restricted trading. Bemberg and Rhenish Browncoal each closed 2 1/2 points above yesterday's final quotations and Allgemeine Lokalbahn, which had been subjected to a bear drive, rose 4 3/4 points, but most closing quotations were within one point above or below yesterday's finals.

An investigation into published charges that "high-pressure" salesmen had been used to sell tickets to a dinner dance of the T.R. Nulty Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars, which was begun last night by George Solomon, State Commander, was delayed when several of the men involved failed to appear at the post's headquarters, 541 Leonard Street, Brooklyn.

Despite the fact that Yale has been disappointed in the first half of its season, the annual encounter with Dartmouth at New Haven this Saturday remains the same midseason feature it has been for the past several years.

MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- Relations between Soviet Russia and Japan continue to improve and the prospects of a real agreement between them to replace the present indefinite, although cordial, understanding grow brighter.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 26 -- Twitting Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, for his "grief, over Democratic extravagance," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in a campaign speech here tonight in behalf of Lieut. Gov. Lehman recalled that her husband last year had vetoed $6,000,000 in extra requests of the Republican Legislative.

GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- A semi-official dispatch from Tokyo says that Yosuke Matsuoka, the special envoy Japan is sending to the League Council, intends to stop off at Moscow and discuss the possibility of Soviet representation at the meeting of the Council when the Lytton report on Manchuria is discussed.

On account or the eccentricity of his orbit, Mr. BORAH hag taken a little longer time than usual for his quadrennial revolution. Tuesday it wag thought that he had completed it. After he had risen to dizzy heights of indignation over Mr. SMITH'S Newark speech, the eremite seemed to have come forth from his cave for the season.

New York, Minnesota and Missouri, among the States which became involved over the reapportionment of the 435 seats in the House of Representatives, knew weeks ago what they must do Nov. 8 with respect to their Congressional elections.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- French discussions of the approaching war debt payment to the United States were further complicated today by a declaration that Stephane Lauzanne cabled to the newspaper Le Matin from New York to the effect that Americans were convinced that France had made $70,000,000 profit in disposing of the war stocks bought from the A.E.F.

MILAN, Oct. 26 (AP) -- His four-day tour of Northern Italy ended, Premier Mussolini left tonight for Rome, where the current Fascist decennial celebrations reach their peak tomorrow and Friday, the anniversary of the March on Rome.

LONDON. Oct. 26 -- Norman H. Davis, who is crowding many important talks into his last hours in London prior to his departure for Paris Friday, saw Dino Grandi, Italian Ambassador, today. Tomorrow he will see Aime de Fleuriau, French Ambassador.

With the favorites all coming through with flying colors, the elimination, round in the annual Vanderbilt Cup tournament for contract bridge teams of four came to a close at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel early this morning. Sixteen teams remained in the running out of the twenty-four that had started play yesterday afternoon.

Acting Mayor McKee expressed the belief last night that if the public contributed $15,000,000 to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee the city and the State would not shirk their full share of the responsibility.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. Ethelbert I. Low arrived here today from New York and will be in the colony for their usual Fall visit of several weeks. Prominent among other New Yorkers who joined the colony today were Mr. and Mrs. William R. Lott, Mr. and Mrs. D.W. Ketcham and Dr. and Mrs. W. C. Pendill.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Colonel William J. Donovan charged Colonel Lehman tonight with "faltering evasion" on the issue of economy in State government. He declared that the Democratic candidate was seeking to "alibi" himself.

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, predicted yesterday that Governor Roosevelt would carry New York State by at least 1,000,000 plurality. He has been assured by Democratic workers in this city that his candidate should carry the city by 800,000 and by up-State workers that Roosevelt should come down to the Bronx line with 225,000 plurality.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Coach Crisler excused the Princeton varsity football squad from scrimmage today and devoted the entire two-hour practice session on University Field to dummy scrimmage work on the defense and offense.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- Secretary Stimson declared in a speech here tonight that the action taken by the United States to preserve peace in the Manchurlan situation, backed by international cooperation, had strengthened the sanctity of treaties and set up a new milestone on the road to peace.

Trading was slightly more active on the Stock Exchange yesterday then on the day before and brokers ascribed this to the removal of uncertainty surrounding the United States Steel preferred dividend. The moderate recovery in prices was ascribed to the same influence.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Premier Braun of Prussia said today that yesterday's ruling by the Supreme Court meant that Germany was still a country where the Constitution and the law were supreme and that members of the Prussian Cabinet were particularly pleased that the court bad exonerated them of charges of being remiss in their duties.

Insistent demands upon President HOOVER are made by the Republican managers that he speak and travel night and day from now until Nov. 8 Mr. HOOVER Is apparently prepared to respond loyally to this party call to do what is thought to be his duty. Whether the course marked out for him is wise political strategy may be doubtful.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Harold W. Bennett, Camden attorney and City Commissioner, was reelected president of the New Jersey Baptist convention today at the closing session of the annual meeting.

Members of the Daughters of the American Revolution who went to France to place in Pershing Hall, Paris, a tablet bearing the names of 133 Frenchmen who died at the Battle of Yorktown will return today on the De Grasse of the French Line. In the delegation are Mrs. David D. Caldwell of Washington, vice president general of the national group; Mrs. Lamar Epperly of West Virginia, and Mrs. Maud Guttelius of Washington.

A better tone characterized the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with a slight increase in the volume of trading. The number of gains was in sharp contrast with the losses recorded at other sessions in the last two weeks. The turnover was $7,192,000 compared with $7,153,000 on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Deciding the first case of its kind ever presented for its consideration, the Interstate Commerce Commission held today that it was without any jurisdiction over the rates, regulations and practices of a radio broadcasting station.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The Irish Free State will lose the advantage of imperial tariff preferences in the United Kingdom on Nov. 15, J.H. Thomas, Dominions Secretary, told the House of Commons today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- The announcement recently by Claude R. Porter, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, that the Class I railroads of the country had been asked to state their views concerning reductions in passenger fares from 3.6 cents a mile, the rate established in 1920, brought favorable comment today from Harry A. Wholer, president of the Railroad Business Association.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- In order to remedy the already huge and steadily increasing deficit of the French railways, Edouard Daladier, Minister of Public Works, is preparing a plan for a gigantic railroad merger, despite the collective opposition of the lines, he told the Chamber of Deputies Public Works Commission today.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- With an early recovery in sterling exchange on New York from the overnight rate of $3.30 to $3.31, although the close today was at $3.29 1/4, British Government funds opened higher today. Conditions were quiet, however, and the early strength was not fully maintained.

Franklin D. Roosevelt is well qualified for the Presidency and for the task of leading the country out of the depression by his qualities of mind and character, his quick grasp of problems and his experience, Henry Morgenthau, former Ambassador to Turkey, said yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26 -- Los Indios polo team defeated the international Santa Ines four today in the Argentine open polo championship, 8 to 7, and qualified to meet Santa Paula, the defending champion, in their second match Sunday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The Republican and Democratic Gubernatorial campaign rubbed elbows today without any spectacular results, and Colonel William J. Donovan, the Republican, and Lieut. Gov. Lehman, the Democrat, traded cities for major addresses.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Terming "infantile paralysis" a misnomer, Dr. W. McKim Marriott, dean of the Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, declared here tonight that 80 per cent of normal adults in urban communities have had the ailment at some time or other and thus carry a high degree of immunity from further attacks.
The Shubert office announced yesterday that Charles Hackett, American tenor, had been signed to sing the leading role in Franz Lehar's operetta, "The Land of Smiles."

The sum of $3,192,534 was added yesterday to the assets of the closed Bank of United States as a result of a decision by the Internal Revenue Bureau in Washington making readjustments of income tax and certain deductions to the credit of the bank.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26 (AP) -- G.D. Widener's Jack High, holder of the recently established mile track record, displayed sterling stamina to win the Tilghman Handicap today at Laurel. Mate, one of the 3-year-old heroes of 1931, was a threatening second, with the Maryland-bred Rehoboth third in the field of seven.
TOKYO, Oct. 26 -- The government is taking remarkable pains with its observations on the Lytton report to the League of Nations.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The British Challenge Cup, presented by the English Springer Spaniel Club of England, was awarded tonight to Henry L. Ferguson of Fishers Island, secretary of of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, and owner of Tedwyn's Tailagan.

The movement to cut salaries of civil service employes as a means of economy was assailed last night by Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, in an address at a campaign meeting in the De Witt Clinton High School. He pledged himself to maintain salaries of city workers and demanded that economies be effected by eliminating waste and corruption and cutting the stipends of high officials whose value to the city he challenged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The case in which Bishop James Cannon Jr. is accused of violating the Federal corrupt practices act will be reopened Monday, when government attorneys will argue in the District of Columbia Court of Appeals against the dismissal of the indictment by Justice James W. Proctor of the District Supreme Court last February.

American universities today "look like bedlam" because they have attempted to combine a miscellaneous aggregation of teaching departments with research, investigation and the education of promising scholars in the technique of training and research.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- President Hoover will deliver his Newark speech Monday in the Mosque, a public hall, on South Broad Street, according to revised plans made by Republican leaders this afternoon. The hall seats 3,356.

Average dally electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, amounted to 211,700,000 kilowatt hours in the week ended Oct. 22, as against 212,800,000 kilowatt hours in the preceding week and 228,200,000 kilowatt hours in the corresponding week last year.

Harry J. Goldman, president of the Retail Glaziers and Setters Association, testified yesterday in the $500,000 damage suit brought against him and eight other members of the association by Jacob Okonowitz, 1,138 East Tremont Avenue, formerly head of the Federal Glass Company.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor, in two addresses last night stressed the need for the city to keep up its relief work this Winter and declared it could be done, despite the city's financial difficulties, if Tammany would permit economies to be effected.
Details of several leasing deals in Manhattan were announced yesterday. Two of the transactions involved structures in the downtown area.

Winners of the seventeen cash awards in a competition for unemployed architects conducted by the emergency committee of the American Institute of Architects were announced yesterday by Julian Clarence Levi, chairman of the committee.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Five thousand London policemen, mounted and on foot, will guard Hyde Park tomorrow when the ragged army of 2,000 hunger marchers arrives for the first of its mass demonstrations against the government's unemployment policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Many financial institutions have not made use of funds made available to them by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Up to Sept. 30, the latest date for which figures have been compiled, the corporation had made available $1,410,026,518 to these institutions, and of this amount $184,975,373 was awaiting the call of borrowers.

M.S. Szymczak, City Controller of Chicago, predicted yesterday that within two months that city would have its tax muddle straightened out and its financial affairs restored to a point at which its obligations would again have an A-1 rating in the municipal bond market.

Efforts to perfect the New York University football team's defense against Purdue plays were continued at Ohio Field yesterday. The Violet squad put in a busy two-hour workout preparing for the intersectional battle with the Boilermakers at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Army's varsity players rehearsed plays on the scrimmage machine today and also engaged in group work.

Sinclair Lewis's "Babbitt" must be considered by most Americans as more of romance than realism, according to facts and figures offered in "Housing-America," published today by Harcourt, Brace. The editors of Fortune Magazine wrote the book, in which they describe housing as the industry that the industrial revolution passed by.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 26 -- A program of golf events held during the week by the Investment Bankers' Association was concluded today and the winners announced.

Contrasts drawn, between huge unemployment in the leading capitalistic nations and total absence of it in Soviet Russia are not really unanswerable. One reservation often made is concerned with the totally different situations. Soviet Russia is out to fill up an economic void.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- A committee of twenty-four members was named today by Governor Moore to make the survey of the New Jersey school system requested by the State Teachers' Association. The association will defray the cost of the inquiry.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and Mrs. Henry G. Davis 3d will return Sunday from Hot Springs, Va.

A contract for the construction of a freight ship of 1,200 tons was awarded yesterday by the New Jersey Clay Products Company to the United Dry Docks, Inc., for delivery about Feb. 15, 1933. The vessel will carry hollow tile between the company's plant at South River, N.J., and ports on the Atlantic seaboard and will also engage in the coastal trade.

Page King Canute. The national interest is not the only thing apt to suffer in the heat of a campaign. The national language and the national sense of logic are among the casualties. Take this word "tide." How does one reverse or accelerate a tide?

Prominent Republicans joined yesterday in an attack on Governor Roosevelt for an interpolation in his Baltimore speech, in which he referred to the United States Supreme Court as controlled by the Republican party.

MANILA, Oct. 2 ((AP) by Mail) -- Sharp protests and warnings of possible retaliation by Japan and China were quickly aroused when a legislative program of higher tariffs, backed by the principal Filipino leaders and reported to have the approval of Governor General Theodore Roosevelt, was announced after a study of several weeks by a committee.

In response to the requests of Easterners, the Gold Cup Contest Board will recommend to the Detroit Yacht Club that the annual Gold Cup speedboat race in 1933 be held on either Aug. 5 and 6 or Aug. 12 and 13. This was decided at the annual dinner of the board at the Hotel New Yorker last night.

Eminent speakers from various sections of this country and Canada will participate in the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents, to be held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 8 and 9. Executives of companies having more than 90 per cent of the country's outstanding $113,000,000,000 of old line life insurance are expected to attend.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A campaign schedule which will take him to twenty-two cities between Friday morning and Monday night was completed by President Hoover today.

Three young men called at the home of Neil J. Merino, a furrier, at 1,257 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, just before noon yesterday and when his wife refused to admit them, they forced their way into the house, tied up Mrs. Merino, her son and a woman neighbor and stole jewelry valued at $1,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- Leopold Stokowski, music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, told a subcommittee of the orchestra women's committee today that he was working at present with engineers on electrically controlled instruments with perfect tones and overtones and true-tone colors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The newest road to the longer life and better health for man leads through his stomach, Dr. H.C. Sherman of Columbia University told the American Public Health Association today. The latest scientific study of the nourishment value of foods shows it is possible to extend the average length of life and better the health of the human race by improving diet, he said.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Staging a thrilling finish and withstanding a furious drive in the last hundred yards, Vander Gold, carrying the silks of J.W.Y. Martin and superbly ridden by William Alexander, captured the seventh running of the Whippany River Club Plate, the featured event of the seventeenth annual meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds, staged today at Froh-Heim, the estate of E.B. Schley.

OTTAWA, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Definite indications that the clouds of depression were beginning to break were cited to the Canadian Club here today by Alexander Dana Noyes, financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission received from the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation of New York today a formal statement that a so-called "write-up" of $36,000,000 in the stock of one of its predecessors in 1907 "had been justified by the value received."

In the closing weeks of the campaign both parties and both candidates have stressed the importance of reducing Federal costs and lightening the burden of taxation. By far the largest single item in them is the outlay for veterans' relief. This amounts to $983,000,000 in the present budget, or about one-third of the total expenditures of the Government aside from service on the public debt.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Hoover tonight served notice that failure of the disarmament negotiations now in progress among the principal powers would compel the United States to build her navy "to the full strength provided in the London agreement, equal to that of the most powerful in the world."

The "splendid cooperation" of Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader, at the recent convention at Madison Square Garden will result in an "unbelievable and record plurality" for the Democratic ticket at the coming election, it was declared last night by Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic nominee for Mayor, at his first campaign appearance in the Bronx.

Until new quarters are obtained free dinners will be served to the guests and workers of the Actors' Dinner Club, numbering between 200 and 300, by several restaurants in the Times Square sector, as a result of arrangements now being made by Col. Earle Boothe, business manager of the club.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Sterling see-sawed today through another series of violent fluctuations, swinging one time 5 points above yesterday's low level and then sinking to end the day at $3.29 1/4, the lowest closing mark since the present weakness in the pound began.
One of the most intensive practice sessions of the year was held yesterday by the Columbia football squad in preparation for its encounter with Cornell.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26 -- Harvard's varsity football squad received another setback today when it was announced that Leon Francisco, outstanding tackle replacement, would be unable to play against Brown on Saturday.

After four leaders of a demonstration staged last night at the College of the City of New York for the reinstatement of Dr. Oakley Johnson had been arrested and taken to night court, 1,000 students marched to the court and staged another demonstration outside.

Acting Mayor McKee issued a proclamation yesterday to the people of the City of New York designating the week beginning next Monday as "cancer week," during which the New York City Cancer Committee will conduct an intensive campaign to raise $50,000 to carry on for another year its program to "fight cancer with knowledge."

DENVER, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Senator Bronson M. Cutting, Progressive Republican of New Mexico and supporter of President Hoover four years ago, called tonight upon "all who believe in the benefits of our civilization to vote, as I am going to vote, for Franklin D. Roosevelt."

The 1932-33 squash tennis season opened yesterday when the Princeton Club, the Columbia Club and the Yale Club triumphed in the Class A inaugural matches in the Metropolitan League. The Princeton club men turned in the most decisive bit of play by turning back the Harvard Club in five straight encounters.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Caught in an avalanche of world-wide price cutting, grain values in the pits of the Chicago Board of Trade and other American exchanges today dropped to the lowest levels on record.

Controller Charles W. Berry, according to reports which persisted yesterday in political and financial circles, has again asked the banks for funds, despite his recent declaration that the city had enough money on hand to enable it to meet the Nov. 1 payrolls and other obligations maturing this month.

WARSAW, Oct. 26 -- Marshal Pilsudski, who was advised last year by his physicians that he must avoid the cold of Autumn and Winter here, is again planning to leave Poland for a time. He may go to Egypt, which he liked very much last year, or to Madiera.

Uncertainty as to the result of the Presidential election is cited by The Iron Age in its weekly review as the principal cause of the sluggish condition of the steel business. This publication reports that "except for larger orders from some of the automobile companies," the industry has made no further headway this week.

Declaring that the fight to repeal the prohibition, laws had virtually been won, former Governor Alfred E. Smith urged last night that the liberals of the nation should continue on to victory and then devote themselves to a new issue -- the banishing of the direct primary from American politics.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 26 -- The government financial position as reflected by the amount of the deficit for the current year appearing in the daily statement of the Treasury is by no means disturbing, Arthur A. Ballantine, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, told the Investment Bankers' Association of America at its final session today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 26 -- Declaring that the Democrats, if successful Nov. 8, would lead the country to inflation and ruin, Secretary Mills tonight called for the re-election of President Hoover as the only way to keep the nation on the path to recovery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Crude materials provided the largest single item in domestic exports valued at $129,526,000 in September and also in imports for the same month of $98,448,000.

HELSINGFORS, Oct. 26 -- Significant alterations in the present Finnish drinking regulations, including the withdrawal of all bar licenses, were foreshadowed in a statement that the monopoly company issued today in connection with the granting of alcohol licenses for 1933.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Reaching Watertown hours behind schedule tonight, because of his plane being forced down near Albany, F. Trubee Davison, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, replied to Governor Roosevelt's speech last night at Baltimore, characterizing the Democratic candidate's address as "insulting to the intelligence of the American voter."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- President Hoover led Franklin D. Roosevelt, 1,515 to 483, in a Presidential poll conducted among the students and faculty of Princeton University by The Daily Princetonian campus newspaper, today. Norman Thomas received 372 votes.

VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- After a renewal of anti-semitic rioting at the University of Vienna today in which three American students had been slightly injured a delegation of twenty members of the American student body called at the United States consulate and legation today.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday an increase of more than 50 per cent in net operating income in September, compared with September, 1931, which was the second time this kind of result has been shown this year. It increased its net operating income by 71.7 per cent in February, but for other months has shown decreases, which, in the case of May and July, resulted in operating deficits.

BUCHAREST, Oct. 26 -- A plot to oust King Carol and to restore Crown Prince Michael to the throne in Rumania under a regency is charged in official circles here as a result of the sudden return of Princess Helen and the announcement that Prince Nicolas will return tomorrow from his long exile in Paris.

After eleven years of the most enchanting memories "Liliom," with which Miss Le Gallienne reopened her theatre last evening, still retains its gusto. From the bizarre merriment of the prologue in the amusement park to the disarming fantasy of the scenes laid in Heaven it is still a play of humor and compassion, and it is still Molnar at the top of his form.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senator Davis of Pennsylvania expended in his primary campaign $9,374.54 and has $2,000 unpaid bills, according to his report filed with the Secretary of the Senate today.

The Sea Service keeps open house on Navy Day, Oct. 27, anniversary of the establishment in 1775 of the naval force by the Continental Congress. On that day every ship flying the flag in any port of the world receives American citizens as visitors.
SEVILLE, Spain, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Acting on information from the United States Consulate, the police today detained a man who gave his name as Jean Saul.

Navy Day, commemorating the establishment by the Continental Congress on Oct. 27, 1775, of the first naval force of the United States, will be celebrated today wherever the flag of the country flies. The day will be marked at sea, in the air, on aaval aircraft and at ground stations and navy yards all over the United States and in its possessions.

After the posting of notices by 300 employing printers, informing their employes that a new wage scale would go into effect beginning today, the officers of Typographical Union 6 yesterday arranged to hold a special mass meeting next Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Brooklyn Elks Club, Boerum Place and Livingston Street, to decide whether a strike will be called against the job plants that have put the wage reduction into effect.

OTTAWA, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press). -- The Canadian National-Canadian Pacific act, designed to bring about far-reaching changes in the operation and conduct of the Dominion's transportation systems, was introduced in the Senate tonight by Arthur Meighen, government leader. The act is divided into three parts.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- Asserting that no State administration could disown "the political corruption of any great city within its borders," Major Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, in an address at a Union League campaign luncheon today, attacked Governor Roosevelt's record of the last four years in connection with New York City rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has appealed to foreign interests for contributions to the Democratic campaign fund, the Republican National Committee declared today. The Republican committee said an appeal was made to a Montreal shipping man, and it quotes The Montreal Daily Star of Oct. 26 as follows:
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Rumors that Princess Ingrid of Sweden will become engaged to Prince George of Great Britain were revived today by the sudden arrival of the Princess by airplane from Brussels.
NEW YORK. The Danish Minister and Mme. Otto Wadsted are at tho Ritz-Carlton.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Miss Elizabeth Trivett was the youngest of the three daughters of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Trivett of this place. Her father is vice president of the Penn Building Company of Bloomfield. He and Louis J. Dundon of Glen Ridge, a son-in-law, went to Fort Lee tonight to claim the body.

The pound sterling steadied yesterday and closed with a net gain of 14 cent at $3.27 7/8. The exchange, however, was still apparently without official support and showed a weak tone during the later hours of trading, the final price being the lowest of the day.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Even the strenuousness of cross-country week-end campaigning has not disrupted the clock-like regularity of the sessions of President Hoover's week-day medicine ball Cabinet.

Under the leadership of a militant, alert, progressive Democracy, the country is headed for better days, after March 4, when the Democrats will take office after scoring a "splendid, smashing victory at the polls," Governor Roosevelt declared last night.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Rioting occurred today in Glebe, an industrial suburb of Sydney, when a mob of unemployed gathered to protest application of the "means test" for the dole. Policemen charged the crowd, cleared the streets and arrested several.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- President Hoover's Navy Day proclamation, serving notice that if the Geneva arms conference fails the United States will be compelled to build up to its fully authorized strength under the London treaty, was taken by high naval officers today as the first admission by the administration that our navy is below treaty strength.

The Roosevelt Memorial Association presented a gold medal last night to Dr. Robert Andrews Millikan, theorist of the cosmic rays, with a citation declaring him to be "a prophet of the new time, bearing to bewildered men, alike from atom and from star, news of the presence and the goodness of God."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 27. -- The operation of Cosach, the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, was assured until the end of this year, at least, by resolutions adopted this afternoon by the government after considering a report issued by the consulting committee recently designated by the Minister of Finance.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Sterling again fell sharply today. After opening at $3.27%, against $3.29 1/4, last night's closing, the New York rate touched $3.26. the lowest in the present slump, before recovering to $3.28 1/4. As a result of the lower exchange, sold, rose to 125s 8d an ounce, the highest price this year.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Norman H. Davis left here today after having reached an agreement in principle with Prime Minister MacDonald for harmonizing the Hoover disarmament proposals and the British counter-proposals.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- In his discussion here of State affairs Mr. Mills said:

First returns from a nation-wide poll of Congressional candidates on their attitude toward the immediate prepayment of the bonus show 194 candidates against immediate payment; 42 for, 17 against, with qualifications; 15 for, with qualifications; 9 indefinite and 547 who have not yet answered, it was announced yesterday.

New York celebrated yesterday the 157th anniversary of the establishment by the Continental Congress of the United States Navy. The city at the same time paid tribute to the memory of Theodore Roosevelt, who was born seventy-four years ago and who as President vigorously supported an adequate navy.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 27 (AP). -- The stable of Racing Commissioner Theodore Mueller broke into the winning column when the veteran sprinter Cayuga found the muddy track to his liking in the fourth event at Latonia today.
BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Rain fell in Southern New England today, but it did not dampen the enthusiasm of the crowds that turned out to see and cheer Alfred E. Smith.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 27. -- Walter Adams, the United States Consul General at Hankow, is investigating a report by C. G. Skinsnes, an American medical missionary at Sinyangchow, that Honan Communists murdered the Rev. Bert Nelson, an American missionary, on Aug. 23.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Balked by the weather, only a small number of women players turned out for the final one-day tournament of the season for members of the Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association today on the west course of the Westchester Country Club.

A world copper conference here before the end of the year was considered likely in local copper circles yesterday when it became known that representatives of the Union Miniere du Haut Katanga will arrive in New York soon after the elections. The present agreement for the curtailment of production wilt expire on Jan. 1, and it is expected the problems relative to renewing or revising that agreement will come before the conference.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 27 -- The Nobel Prize for medicine and physiology for 1932 was awarded tonight to Sir Charles Sherrington of Oxford and Professor Edgar Douglas Adrian of Cambridge on account of their joint discoveries regarding the functions of the neuron.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation increased its supply of ready cash today by $325,000,000 through a new issue of $1,000,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent notes to mature April 30, 1933. Of the total authorized by the corporation, $675,000,000 was immediately taken over by the Treasury in exchange for a like amount of notes previously issued and which matured today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Unceasing community effort to protect the health of the people, particularly of youth, from the dangers growing out of present economic conditions, was urged today at the concluding session of the American Public Health Association.

The text of the radio address delivered by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, Governor General of the Philippines, from Manila, P.I., yesterday at P.M., Eastern Standard Time, and broadcast over a nation-wide chain, is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- Complete reorganization of the Interstate Commerce Commission, because it is now so overburdened with duties that it cannot function efficently, was urged today at the opening of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association convention here by Frank S. Davis, manager of the Boston Maritime Association.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 27. -- Richard Stevens gave a dinner in the Homestead this evening in honor of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt. Among the guests were Mrs. Vanderbilt's daughter, Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis 3d and Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Reeves.

Coincident with the fiftieth anniversary of its initial performance in Paris, "Camille," by the younger Alexander Dumas, was played again at the Civic Repertory Theatre last night, where it had been previously given in January, 1931.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Cornell's football squad entrained for New York tonight to meet Columbia in their annual gridiron test on Baker Field Saturday. With two exceptions the players on the three elevens in the squad are in good condition.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 27 (AP). -- Secretary Mills in an address here tonight criticized Governor Roosevelt's administration at Albany and what he termed his "lack of definite issues" in the Presidential campaign.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Modeling itself along the lines of the New York Clearing House, the Westchester Clearing House Association, organized on May 2, accepted today the working plans for its Clearing House that had been approved by the board of governors.

HAVANA, Oct. 27. -- Dr. Jorge Alfredo Belt, attorney and counsel for the Hershey interests in Cuba, died this morning of a heart attack at his home in Vedado, a residential district of Havana. He was 63 years old.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Bud Barnum, Willis Bronkie and Dud Parker lost their positions today as first-string players on the Yale football eleven. Three lightweights, Allan Converse, Jim De Angelis and Dick Kimball, succeeded them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Eight Californians were permitted today by the District of Columbia Supreme Court to intervene in proceedings opposing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's plan to bid on $40,000,000 of bonds of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California.

A promise that he would reduce the city personnel "if, and where, it is possible," was made last night by Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, during one of four speeches given in various parts of the city.

Reflecting improvement in the prices of crude oil, several large oil companies are issuing reports for the first nine months of the year showing marked gains in income over the corresponding period last year. Among these are Phillips Petroleum, the Tide Water Associated group and Shell Union Oil.

A reminder that nostrums would not effect a cure of business conditions and a warning against the "vacillating policies" of Governor Roosevelt were voiced yesterday by George Z. Medalie, Republican candidate for Senator, in a luncheon address to the Women's Apparel Committee at the Garment Centre Capitol Club, 498 Seventh Avenue.
MONTREAL, Oct. 27. -- Francis Dominick Shallow, founder and editor of La Moniteur du Commerce, oldest French trade paper in Canada, died today in his seventy-ninth year at his home here.

The committee for holders of bonds of St. Petersburg, Fla., with which more than S3 per cent of the city's $21,500,000 outstanding securities has been deposited, announced yesterday that it would make its third distribution to all depositors recorded on Nov. 15.
PROVIDENCE, Oct. 27 -- The text of Alfred E. Smith's address at a Democratic rally in the Infantry Armory here today follows:

Brilliant performances were achieved by Miss Dorothea Dickinson of the Women's Swimming Association, John Wicklun of the Dragon Club and Charles Heyward of the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A. at the opening A.A.U. water carnival of the indoor season in the 75-foot pool of the Downtown A.C. last night.

Mrs. Mary Mooney, mother of Tom Mooney who is serving a life sentence in California for the bombing of the Preparedness Day parade in 1916, will sail for Europe tonight on the Europa as an honorary delegate of the International Labor Defense to the American section of the World Congress of the International Red Aid, to be held in Moscow Nov. 10 to 25, the organization announced yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP). -- The Duval County grand jury was brought into open court today and instructed by Circuit Judge George Couper Gibbs to protect residents from mob floggings.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Paul Robeson, now filling a music hall engagement at the Palladium here, intends to establish a permanent repertory company in London, with prominent British players, housed in its own theatre.

September sales of reporting department stores in this Federal Reserve district were 18 per cent below those in September of last year, while business of reporting chain store organizations averaged 11 1/2 per cent lower, the November review of credit and business conditions of the Federal Reserve bank of New York will say.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- A plan to hold a special session of the Legislature to appropriate funds for umemployment relief was abandoned today as unnecessary at a conference participated in by Governor Roosevelt and Senator George R. Fearon and Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies, the Republican legislative leaders.

While representatives of the Republican party continued yesterday their efforts to remove from the registration books names of voters said to have been falsely registered, the Attorney General's office set up a bureau to handle cases of false registration and prevent persons not entitled to vote from casting their ballots on election day.
PARIS, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Loans to brokers and dealers by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $81,000,000, or 18.7 per cent, this week. The total as reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York amounted to $352,000,000, compared with $433,000,000 last week.

The need for sharp curtailment of Federal and New York City governmental expenditures to permit tax relief was stressed by speakers at the third annual meeting of the Investing and Contracting Builders Association yesterday in the Fraternity Clubs Building.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- President Hoover's proposal for a one-third reduction of armaments will probably be the real foundation of whatever is built up at the Geneva conference, high British sources revealed today as Norman H. Davis left for Paris after his conversations here.
LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Oct. 27. -- Attorneys for Mrs. Marian Edwards Shouse announced today that a petition for divorce would be filed in her behalf tomorrow or Saturday in the Reno County District Court here against Jouett Shouse, former executive chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

With the major parties preparing for an intensive drive to close their national campaigns at the end of next week, leaders at Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee profess to be cheered by loosening of purse strings for campaign needs and reports of a swing to Hoover in some important States previously claimed for the Democratic Presidential nominee.

Sales brought $6,367 at the first session of the dispersal of the Rose Cumming collection of antique furniture and decorations at the former Anderson Gallery building, 489 Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

Of the first fifty-nine railroads to report for September, twenty-five increased their net operating incomes compared with September, 1931, the number in the group which reported increases also for August being seven. Roads which reported increases of this kind yesterday included the Chicago North Western, the Chicago Eastern Illinois, Wife Erie and the Pittsburgh West Virginia.

Charles H. Finkelstein, formerly an Assistant United States Attorney in the prohibition division, who went into private practice, specializing in enforcement cases, when United States Attorney Medalie took office, confessed to Supreme Court Justice Cohn, that he "made a mistake in trying to capitalize my connection with the United States Attorney's office and taking business coming to me under the national prohibition act."
VATICAN CITY, Oct. 27. -- Severe criticism of ultra-modern architecture and painting applied to churches was voiced by Pope Pius today when he inaugurated a new Vatican picture gallery.

"Colonel Lemuel Q. Stoopnagle" (F. Chase Taylor) and "Budd" (Willbur Budd Hulick), radio entertainers, will make their first revue appearance in "Forward March," the Lew Brown-Ray Henderson show, now trying out in Washington. They will join the cast late next week in Pittsburgh, in place of Ted Healy, who was previously announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Oct. 26, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,219,000,000, a decrease of $16,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $13,000,000 compared with the corresponding week of 1931.

MANILA, Friday, Oct. 28 -- In the first campaign address brought by radio across the Pacific in American history, Theodore Roosevelt Jr., Governor General of the Philippines, urged today the re-election of President Hoover, whom he characterized as a man "capable of facing the crisis."

LONDON, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Party leaders began consideration tonight of a proposal by George Lansbury, Laborite chief, to speed the Ottawa bill through the House of Commons by reducing the time allowed for its discussion in committee.

The rector, church wardens and vestrymen of St. Philip's Church, gave to the Greenwich Savings Bank a mortgage for $10,000 on 107-117 W. 135th St., on 127-129 W. 135th St.. and on 139-141 W. 135th St., subject to mortgages for $110.000.

For weeks past the Republican managers have been taking for their own a common phrase of sport. They could win if they only got the "breaks." That is what baseball captains and football coaches often say of an approaching contest. With a little luck on their side all will be well.

TOKYO. Oct. 27 (AP). -- Yosuke Matsuoka, who will represent Japan when the League of Nations takes up the Lytton report next month, is to stop off on the way to Geneva for conversations with Soviet Government officials in Moscow.

ROME, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Four Americans will ride for the first time with the personal staff of Premier Mussolini tomorrow when he reviews the parade of 15,000 Fascist disabled war veterans as the climax of several days' celebration of the Fascist decenaial.

A few days ago THE TIMES printed a letter from Professor FELIX FRANKFURTER of the Harvard Law School, expressing wonder that there could be reported a doubt about the re-election of Senator WAGNER. At one time, it is true, there were intimations that a part of the "deal" between the two political organizations in this city, involving also the Governorship of New York, was expected to work out to the disadvantage of Mr. WAGNER.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The upward trend of unemployment was checked to September when 560,000 persons were estimated to have been recalled to work, according to the monthly unemployment survey made public today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

James Joyce and Lord Dunsany both refused memberships in the new Irish Academy of Letters formed by George Bernard Shaw and William Butler Teats, Mr. Yeats, Irish poet and playwright, who has just arrived for a short visit in this country, said in an interview yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PRINCETON, Oct. 27 -- President Hoover led Governor Roosevelt, 29,289 to 18,212, in a Presidential poll conducted by forty-seven colleges in thirty-one States at the request of The Dally Princetonian, Princeton University newspaper, the final tabulation revealed today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP). -- Form players had a big day at Sportsman's Park today, favorites winning the first five races. Miss Sparkling from Ben Rosenheim's stable captured the featured race at six and a half furlongs by a half length over Upon, a long shot. Dr. Jillson finished third.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 27. -- Hickman Price, one of the world's largest individual wheat farmers, with vast agricultural holdings in the Texas Panhandle near Plainview, has fallen a victim of the times and his affairs now are in the hands of a receiver.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- The election of Governor Roosevelt to the Presidency would be "a direct and unequivocal turn to the left" and the beginning of a radicalization of the country, which might well threaten its stability, Representative James M. Beck of Pennsylvania told the City Club of Boston in an address tonight.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman, speaking here tonight in his campaign for the Governorship, cheerfully admitted that he was not a politician and based his appeal for election on the ground that he was a business man who knew the business of the State.

The terms of the proposed acquisition of the Federated Metals Corporation by the American Smelting and Refining Company, set forth in the announcement of a special meeting of stockholders of Federated Metals on Nov. 16, show that a new subsidiary is to be organized by the smelting company to acquire the Federated assets.
Apartment houses and dwellings in Manhattan came under new control as the result of transactions announced yesterday.

DANVERS, Mass., Oct. 27. -- St. John's, Prep of Danvers beat the Providence College junior varsity football team in a hard-fought game played on a muddy field during a steady downpour today, 2 to 0. A blocked punt forced a safety by Neun, Providence quarterback.

The visiting nurse service of the Henry Street Settlement is "fighting with its back to the wall" to uphold its forty-year motto of "never refusing a call," it was announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Downtown Association, when a "silent campaign" for $200,000 was launched.

Something called "The Surgeon" was presented with unwarranted enthusiasm at the Belmont Theatre last evening. Written by Anthony Young, the play was presented by Anthony Young, and the large cast caught in that dilemma tried valiently to make something of the occasion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- A worried old man, the lines of uncertainty written all over his brew, stepped into a doctor's office for a physical examination. An hour later, his eyes ablaze with determination, he strutted out to hand Father Time another licking.

A jury which for a week had listened to evidence in the mail-fraud trial of Frank C. Davis, accused of having swindled Miss Kathryn K. Beeson of New York and Uniontown, Pa., of $177,000 by use of the old "pocketbook trick," returned a verdict of guilty last night after deliberating more than four hours.

An intensive effort to rehabilitate the hosiery industry was started yesterday, when members of the National Association of Hosiery and Underwear Manufacturers approved a broad program to improve conditions through scrapping of obsolete machinery, adoption of statistical data, utilization of proper cost accounting, more stringent credits and uniform conditions of sale.

Harry Gottlieb, one of last year's Guggenheim scholarship artists, spent several months in Majorca, a few weeks in Paris, and now, at the Rehn Gallery, is showing the results of his recent study and labor. It is his first show since winning the scholarship and, filling all of the gallery's walls, contains oils, gouaches, drawings and prints.

Using perfect teamwork, the Tammany -controlled majority in the Board of Estimate annihilated Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee's economy program yesterday, spread a protecting resolution around their own salaries at present levels and finished the day with a budget reduced by $1,010,800.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Pennsylvania political bosses were denounced here tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, in an address in which he declared competitive capitalism to be ''choked fey the potential abundance of the machine age and strangled by its inherent contradictions" and said the "more far-seeing" of the industrialists knew that "their only chance for a little longer life is in Fascist regimentation."

The Evergreen Purse, feature at Empire City yesterday, fell to a granddaughter of Man o' War, Happen, which races for Mrs. George Fox. The filly is a 3-year-old and is by American Flag, one of Man o' War's best sons. Receding, after opening as favorite, Happen nevertheless ran one of her best races to win by a head from J.H. Louchheim's Al Neiman, which went to the post the choice at 13 to 5.
Taxes for Temperance. Beer may come back soon and stronger drinks may follow, but one thine that plainly will not return is the pre-war price of beer, wines and spirits.

Five paroled Sing Sing convicts and Jour women were held in Brooklyn Police Headquarters this morning for questioning in connection with the theft of $50,000 worth of bars of precious metals from a plant at 32 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, after a detective arrested three of the men late last night when they had dumped all but four bars of the $50,000 worth of loot from the Williamsburg Bridge into the East River.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Twenty bankers, business men and industrialists of Northern New Jersey attended a luncheon today at the Essex Club here, to start the share-the-work movement in the twelve northern counties of the State, forming the tenth regional unit of the Second Federal Reserve District.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Negotiations for peace between Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco were begun this afternoon under the auspices of the Commission of Neutrals, which has long been exercising its good offices in the situation, and resulted "in good progress."

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican nominee for Mayor, told members of the City Club at a luncheon yesterday that the city was "scraping bottom," and said "we do not know how we will pay our officeholders and clerks next month."

OTTAWA, Oct. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The government was asked in the House of Commons today to take some action to prevent the price of wheat from falling lower, with G.G. Coote, United Farmer member from Alberta, declaring that business generally was threatened throughout Canada if the fall in price continues.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "A Self-Increasing Tariff" hits squarely on the head a nail that has long needed to be smacked. Specific duties on commodities whose value has slid have not only increased automatically out of all proportion to the rate on an ad valorem basis, but in many instances have more than offset any disadvantage Senator Smoot et al. may profess to see in foreign currency declines.

The United States cannot get along without a protective tariff, Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, declared yesterday in issuing the company's earnings statement for the third quarter of the year, which showed a net loss of $5,425,724 from operations and after depreciation and interest charges, the largest sum for any three months in its history.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27 -- When Roger Hallowell, Harvard centre, who was not able to play in the Penn State game, worked full time against Dartmouth last week, the coaches thought that he was available for the remainder of the year.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There are two important phases of the present campaign to which, I fear, insufficient attention is being given.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here averaged higher today, due more to a let-up in liquidation and to scattered short covering than to any change in the general situation. Pressure from Eastern houses relaxed.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Thirty-five Princeton football players entrained tonight for Ann Arbor, where the Tigers will meet the University of Michigan eleven on Saturday.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for this year. In the subjoined comparative table all figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:

BOSTON, Oct. 27. -- The Canadian Army broke into the victory column in the international military rivalry at the fourth annual Boston horse show at the Garden tonight, when Lieutenant C.C. Mann, on the chestnut gelding Michael, outjumped twelve other officers to capture the coveted individual military trophy.

In a campaign, about as exhilarating as a spell of hay fever, Missouri seems an isle of bliss. At least her Democrats are making of their canvass a halcyon and vociferous occasion. Especially in the northeastern part of the State, where Republicans are rare and the unterrified Bourbons are still enthroned, a Democratic meeting is a holiday, a festival.
Conveyances of small flats and dwellings comprised the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of Oct. 1, shows the following principal changes during September. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

The estate of Edwin Prescott Grosvenor, lawyer, who died "Feb. 28, 1930, has lost $431,268 in the sale of securities and the decrease in the market value of certain stocks, according to an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company and Gilbert Grosvenor of Bethesda, Md., executors.

Columbia reached the peak of its drive yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Cornell tomorrow. The Blue and White squad is regarded as not only being at its apex in the technical Bide of football but also is in an excellent frame of mind, injuries to two of its regrulars notwithstanding.

The Literary Digest, in a statement issued yesterday by its editor, Dr. William Seaver Woods, announced that it had traced to the Republican National Committee headquarters in Chicago a rumor that 35,000 persons who originally voted for Franklin D. Roosevelt in The Digest poll had written to change their votes to Herbert Hoover.

In the ranks of the football teaching fraternity the country over there is scarcely a coach who is more exacting in his attention to detail or who has a more pronounced faculty for extracting the maximum capacity from a limited amount of material than Gilmour Dobie of Cornell and Lou Little of Columbia.

Without receiving any special inspiration from surface developments of the day, the stock market displayed yesterday an increasingly confident attitude, similar to that of the previous day. The net gains were narrow, but they extended to all groups of the list.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Hoover left the capital tonight for Indianapolis on a militant new offensive aiming to bring into the Republican camp doubtful areas of West Virginia, Ohio and Indiana.
OTTAWA, Oct. 27 (Canadian press) -- Race-track betting in Canada in 1932 again showed a marked decline from the figures of the previous year.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- With the completion today of the final stake events in the ninth field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, trophies were awarded at the Fishers Island Club, the presentations being made by Dr. Samuel Milbank, vice president of the association.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Strange as it may seem, the campaign will probably be decided upon the relatively least important of all issues -- beer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Iron and steel importers, protesting against the demand for the imposition of anti-dumping bonds on their imports, appeared before the Customs Bureau today to deny charges of unfair competition made recently by domestic producers.

A smaller decrease than usual from the figrures of a year ago is shown in the reports of bank clearances in the last week received from leading cities by R.G. Dun Co. It is noted, however, that the total for the week was somewhat smaller than in the preceding week, a shrinkage which normally occurs in the latter part of the month.

SPRING VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 27. -- Charles Solomon, Socialist candidate for United States Senator, in an address here tonight assailed as "inadequate and evasive" the stand of Governor Roosevelt on the questions of public utilities and unemployment relief.

The gravity of the unemployment situation, is apparent in the fact that the Municipal Lodging House has had to provide this year 1,130,000 free beds, an increase of 70 to 80 per cent over lost year, according to Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, who spoke, yesterday before the committee's Brooklyn, division at The Towers Hotel.

Denial of "rumors" of professionalism in Columbia athletics, particularly among members of the football squad, is made by Clarence E. Lovejoy, alumni secretary, in today's issue of The Columbia Alumni News.

PERTH, Australia, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Marylebone Cricket Club of England, here to play a test match series with Australia, today engaged in a tune-up contest with a combined Australian side and had scored 359 runs for three wickets at the end of the day's play.

BILLINGS, Mont., Oct. 27 -- Discovery of a dinosaur which gives the scientific world its most complete picture of the external appearance of these giant plated reptiles which roamed these regions millions of years ago was announced today by Dr. Barnum Brown, curator of the American Museum of Natural History.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Henry Somers Chatfield, manufacturer and industrial chemist, died of pneumonia today at his home, 426 Westminster Avenue, after an illness of six days. He was 68 years old on July 28. Mr. Chatfield was regarded as one of the country's leading authorities on paints and varnishes.
BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Former Governor Smith carried his campaign for the national Democratic ticket into the heart of New England today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I point out what appears to be a slight misunderstanding of the figures presented by the President last Saturday night and commented upon in THE TIMES today?

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Fluctuating within narrower limits, sterling exchange had another erratic day today, closing 1 cents lower than yesterday at 53.28%. At one time the rate dipped to $3.26, the lowest of the year and only 3 cents above the lowest since suspension of the gold standard.
