In the recent "Life" of ANDREW CARNEGIE is related an incident at the beginning of the World War which illustrates his own creed of wealth and which it is pertinent to recall in the present emergency. There had been commandeering in Scotland of everything that was useful in war, and the authorities announced that it would be necessary to levy even upon the trees for wood, one of the most pressing needs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP). -- While President Hoover was preparing today for his week-end addresses, two live elephants, emblems of the Republican party, were led into the White House yard, their sides placarded with such statements as "This is an elephant's job and no time for , donkey business," and "Young Republicans, tune in on Hoover's New York speech."

Irregularly higher prices marked dealings in bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange, despite the comparative dullness of trading. Railroad liens made the best gains, with industrials and utilities following. United States Government bonds were generally higher, finishing 4-32 point higher to 2.32 lower.

ROME, Oct. 27. -- Though the official tenth anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome arrives tomorrow, Premier Mussolini began today the formal opening of public works which are the distinguishing feature of the celebration. Among the most important works dedicated today was the new railroad line between Rome and Viterbo.

Elizabeth M. Trivett, 28 years old, of 279 Ridgewood Avenue, Glen Ridge, N.J., climbed the railing beside the footwalk of the George Washington Bridge yesterday afternoon, at about the centre of the span, and plunged 250 feet to her death in the Hudson River.

George H. Townsend of New York was re-elected president of the American Power Boat Association at the annual meeting of the organization yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker. Mr. Townsend, now in Paris, was notified by cablegram of his continuance in office.
PARIS, Oct. 27. -- Sterling again lost ground in the foreign exchange market today, but recovered slightly toward the close to stand at 83.78 francs. The dollar was steady.

Condemning the bi-partisan nominations for the Supreme Court of State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer as brought about solely for political expediency, the New York Young Republican Club endorsed last night the independent candidates sponsored by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York County Lawyers' Association, George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch.

After such full-blooded novels as "The Good Companions" and "Angel Pavement" most people will expect more from J.B. Priestley than his first original play discloses. "Dangerous Corner," which was acted at the Empire last evening, is a sort of boyish prank in the theatre.
In its final workout before departing for Boston today the Fordham football squad was sent through a two-hour drill at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for its encounter with Boston College.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (AP). -- It is impossible to say now what course the discussions here with Yosuke Matsuoka will take, but they will be watched with great interest here as a possible prelude to an even better understanding between Japan and Soviet Russia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The detention of Jean Saul at Seville, Spain, on suspicion of being connected with the Lindbergh kidnapping was reported to the State Department today by Richard Ford, American Consul at Seville.

So great was the charm of Edna Best and Herbert Marshall when they appeared last Winter in John van Druten's engaging comedy of manners, "There's Always Juliet," that you were willing to accept the definitely English Mr. Marshall as an upper-class American.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The trustees of Prineeton University at their Fall meeting here today granted leaves of absence to Dean Augustus Trowbridge of the Graduate School for the first term, to Professor Frank H. Constant of the Engineering School for the second term and to Professor Alien C. Johnson of the Glassics Department, who is serving this year on the faculty of the American School of Classical Studies at Rome.

Provisional support of the Federal dollar duck-stamp tax bill to license waterfowl hunters was announced yesterday by the More Game Birds in America Foundation. Thus there was brought into virtual agreement three of the largest organizations of their kind in the United States, the Izaak Walton League of America, the American Game Association and More Game Birds.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- Governor Roosevelt took steps today to have the Public Service Commission take the initiative in an investigation of the fairness of gas and electric rates charged in the city of Binghamton, in accordance with the principle he laid down in a speech at Portland, Ore., last month.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- Governor Roosevelt took steps today to have the Public Service Commission take the initiative in an investigation of the fairness of gas and electric rates charged in the city of Binghamton, in accordance with the principle he laid down in a speech at Portland, Ore., last month.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Will Rogers returned from a 16,000-mile flight over Central and South America today and reported that "the people down there are fed up on good-will."
BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Following is the text of Alfred E. Smith's talk here tonight:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Would you cut down a healthy tree which is hearing fine fruit?

Dr. Pedro Herrera Sotolongo, prominent Cuban, lawyer who has been imprisoned and threatened with death several times since June 11, when he was arrested and placed in a dungeon in Havana for revolutionary activities, arrived yesterday on the Spanish liner Magallanes.

Wide endorsement has been given to the arbitration plan advanced by the American Arbitration Association this week for the protection of realty bonds in default and for the ironing out of differences arising among bondholders and various protective committees working on reorganization plans, the association announced yesterday.

One of the themes stressed by Republican speakers is the risk of currency inflation after a Democratic victory. Secretary MILLS has emphasized this in many of his addresses, and to support his argument has cited the record of Democratic members of the House of Representatives at the last session of Congress.

William Butler Teats, Irish poet and dramatist, was elected an hotiorary member of the Authors Club of New York last night at a dinner in his honor in the club at 48 West Seventy-sixth Street. He is the thirty-sixth honorary member of the club in the last fifty years.

In an address this week Governor MOORE of New Jersey called upon the voters to support the referenda which will be on the ballot election day. There are two of them, one proposing to cancel the $20,000,000 bond issue already approved for highway construction, and the other directing that it be diverted to the care of the unemployed, of whom, it is estimated, 800,000 will need aid during the Winter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The picture presented in the letter of Eberhard Westarp of a Germany which he earnestly assures us is financially unable to arm, but which intends to arm nevertheless as the only way in which to fulfill the national duty of self-respect, is typical of the defiant new propaganda now being sent out from the Reich.

Cardinal Hayes, an Archbishop, sixteen Bishops, one Prefect-Apostolic, two Papal Chamberlains, thirteen Knights of St. Gregory the Great, together with seven hundred priests, will take part in the procession this morning from Madison Avenue, through Fiftieth Street and into St. Patrick's Cathedral to participate in the consecration of the Rev. Dr. James Edward Kearney as Bishop of the Diocese of Salt Lake, Utah.

Intensifying their attack upon employers who have sought, in the current Presidential campaign, to influence the Votes of workers, supporters of Governor Roosevelt began in investigation yesterday at Democratic State headquarters into the tax records of the outstanding industrial corporations of the country.

A.B. Cauty, general manager of the White Star Line, who arrived Wednesday night on the liner Europa to study conditions in the American shipping field, declared yesterday that the policy of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference with respect to revision of passenger fares would depend largely on the attitude of shipping men at the United States.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Gordon entertained with a luncheon at the Casino for twelve persons. Other luncheon hosts there were John D. Harrison, Mr. and Mrs. William Erdmann, Mr. and Mrs. Gould Shaw, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Meyer, Thomas J. Davis and Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Brown.

More than 500 delegates from ten States representing several hundred thousands members of German societies in the United States attended the opening sessions of the first German-American Congress at the Hotel Astor yesterday. The object of the congress is to promote nation-wide cooperation among German-Americans in this country on cultural, educational, economic and welfare problems and to acquaint Americans of non-German descent with the cultural and scientific contributions of Germany.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP). -- Mr. Sponge, a 5-year-old veteran ridden by the seasoned Mack Garner, defeated two other sprinters in the St. Leonard's Handicap of six furlongs, today at Laurel.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that in accordance with its recent decision to strike from the list bond issues that had matured or had been declared due and payable it would remove eleven issues from listing on next Tuesday.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 3/4 per cent for the best names.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 27 -- The Gillette Safety Razor Company reported today for the nine months to Sept. 30 a net profit of $4,655,062 after interest, depreciation and Federal taxes. This was equivalent to $15.02 a share on the 315,000 shares of $5 preference stock outstanding, or equivalent, after preference dividends, to $1.73 a share on the 1,968,769 common shares.

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., made public yesterday a telegram to Secretary of War Hurley urging on behalf of twenty-five civic organizations with a total membership of a half million that Mr. Hurley transfer to the city for a public park the fifty-six acres of Fort Schuyler at Throgs Neck in the Bronx.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 27. -- "The Mexican delegation to the world disarmament congress has governmental instructions to support any justified and honest motive tending toward peace either by means of disarmament or pacific anti-war propaganda," Manuel Tellez, Foreign Minister, said here this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP). -- For the first time in the history of the Philadelphia Orchestra season, tickets were placed on sale today at half the regular price for any place in the Academy of Music for half the concerts on alternate Saturday nights.
The fact that Public School 47, Station Plaza, Broad Channel, Queens, is housed in the shell of an old saloon and dancehall, was revealed yesterday by the Broad Channel Civic Association.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- William A. Patton, referee for the New York State Department of Labor and former newspaper editor and "publisher, died here yesterday at the age of 54. His fatal illness began when he was injured in an automobile accident last June.

Ten students of City College, who were convicted of disorderly conduct Wednesday night after they had created an uproar outside of Night Court during the arraignment of the alleged ringleaders of a demonstration on the campus a few hours before, were suspended by the college last night.

The receivers for the Interborough and the attorneys representing the financial interests behind the company moved yesterday to proceed with the handling of the company's affairs by the present receivers.

The New York City Cancer Committee has served 11,600 persons who came to its offices requesting advice and information on cancer since it was founded on Nov. 15, 1926, and the current year, in which 2,300 had applied up to Oct. 25, will ba the most active in its history, it was announced yesterday at the annual luncheon of its women's committee preceding cancer week.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 27. -- Declaring that "we are back on the high road," Nathan L. Miller, former Governor of New York, asserted in a campaign address here tonight that the change from panic condition of a few months ago was wrought by President Hoover's "radical and unprecedented" measures.

Sterling, having reached on Wednesday the low point of the year, after falling 17 cents in eight days, was watched with special interest yesterday. It recovered nearly 2 cents, then, lost virtually all the advance before the day was over. Discussion of the actual underlying influences behind the movement continued to show little hut confusion.

Continuation of the trade demand that has been a feature in the futures market on the Cotton Exchange for several days imparted a general steadiness to prices yesterday. Southern selling was in evidence at times and caused some irregularity.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Unitarians and Universalists of Central New York at a conference here decided to consolidate under the name of the Mohawk Valley Conference of the Free Churches of America.

Is Texas, which, voted for HERBERT HOOVER in 1928, going to add another chapter to political history this year by electing a Republican Governor? The Lone Star State seethes with this question. ORVILLE BULLINGTON, the Republican candidate, is the beneficiary of a protest among Democrats over the award of the nomination certificate to Mrs. MIRIAM A. FERGUSON and, by the same token, her husband, JIM.
LE ROT, N,Y-., Oct. 27.-- Colonel William J. Donovan charged in a speech here today that Governor Roosevelt was "inflaming discontent to win an election."

Work on the International Music Hall in Rockefeller Center, which will accommodate 6,000 persons, is rapidly Hearing completion. The network of tubular steel scaffolding and wooden platforms has been moved from the auditorium, and the large mural painting by Ezra Winter entitled "The Fountain of Youth" is being hung in the grand foyer.

If the citizens of this First Judicial District nave any power of political resentment left in them, the nomination of Senator HOFSTADTER and young Mr. STEUER as judges of the Supreme Court ought to stir it deeply. People do well to be angry at this kind of political trick attempted upon them.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 28. -- Greeting his 2,000 hearers as "pupils," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for president, took the role of teacher and presented a "history lesson" today at Reyburn Plaza.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court disbarred yesterday Jule Z. Janover and Sidney W. Salmon and suspended Edward A. Brown, Judson D. Campbell and Ezra Gottlieb for two years on charges of professional misconduct in connection with the use of money of clients.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28. -- The text of the address of Governor Ritchie here tonight was as follows:
ATHENS, Ohio, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The text of President Hoover's speech here follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- "White slavery" and social diseases are increasing, according to reports presented today at the Eastern regional conference of the American Social Hygiene Association, which issued an appeal for individual and collective action on all fronts against a rising tide of evils due to the economic depression.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- George Washington flashed its best form of the season tonight as 15,000 fans watched the Colonials turn back University of Iowa's Big Ten eleven by a convincing 21-6 score.

Only $4,340,022 of new municipal bonds will come up for award next week, compared with this week's revised total of $15,968,969, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $18,499,116. Subsequent to next week, few large issues have been announced for award thus far, a factor which will aid dealers in disposing of old blocks of bonds.

The New York Public Library is showing in its main exhibition room a collection of lithographs depicting varied aspects of life in this country between, roughly, 1830 and 1880. An exhibition well worth seeing, it is likely to appeal not only to those with antiquarian hobbies, but also to any one interested in reviewing the extent to which the externals of life have changed in this country since pre-Civil War days, with fundamentals the same.
Amherst vs. Mass. State -- No agricultural relief in sight. One vote for Amherst.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Reviewing work being done on waterway projects at a cost of 5400,000,000, Major Gen. Lytle Brown, chief of army engineers, told the convention of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association here today that realization of its vital aim, the development of trade among different parts of the country, would be one of the chief factors in accomplishing economic and business recovery.
Two exhibitions are current at the Montross Gallery, 785 Fifth Avenue: Oils by Frank London and water-colors by Elias Newman.

Electrical Appliance Sales Up. Reporting a sharp increase in activity in the closing days of this month, manufacturers of electrical household appliances yesterday estimated that this month's volume of trade will come within 5 per cent of the figures established in the corresponding month last year.
Football brings down the curtail on the first half of its season today rounding out the competition with the usual series of outstanding game throughout the country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Mellon's speech before the English-Speaking Union at Manchester, England, is a mature and intelligent summation of the present world situation and points out very clearly both the strength and weakness of the United States as a nation.

The Bayside Tennis Club, a new addition, upset the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 4 to 3, in a high light of the opening of the Class B Metropolitan League squash tennis season yesterday. The losers are the defending champions and went through the 1931-32 campaign of eight games undefeated.

LOS ANGELAS, Cal., Oct. 28 -- Outbid in its first tilt with the Sinclair interests for possession of the Richfield Oil Company of California, the Standard Oil Company of California came back today with an offer of approximately $22,500,000, or $5,500,000 more than its original bid and virtually the same as the Sinclair terms of three months ago.

Among the most loyal of his supporters -- the Democrats of New England ALFRED E. SMITH displayed, in two political speeches, those remarkable qualities which explain his place in the community and in the hearts of millions of Americans.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman declared in an address here tonight that the interests of industry -- of the employer as well as the employed -- were best served when labor prospered and laid down a twelve-point program for the betterment of labor in this State which he promised to follow if he is elected Governor.

TACOMA, Wash., Oct. 28 (AP). -- The forty-hour work week with no reduction in the minimum wage scale has been endorsed as a national policy for the lumber industry by delegates to the semi-annual fir district conference of the Loyal Legion of Loggers and Lumbermen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Declaring that the Veterans Administration was guilty of "half truths" as to allowances paid to World War veterans, and assailing the National Economy League's methods in advocating reductions, John Thomas Taylor, legislative representative for the American Legion, today told the Capital District Kiwania International that if the economies recommended were effected "thousands of veterans suffering from tuberculosis would receive announcement of their deaths."

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The disclosure was made in the House of Commons today by Sir John Gilmour, Home Secretary, that the police had seized 154 heavy ash sticks studded with nails in an automobile truck which followed the Lancashire "hunger marchers" to yesterday's demonstration in Hyde Park.

Will Rogers returned to New York last night after a three weeks' air tour of South America, during which he flew over twenty-one countries. He alighted at Newark Airport from a Condor plane of Eastern Air Transport, on which he flew from Jack-sonville, Fla., at 7:45 o'clock, immediately exhibiting a craving for news of the political campaign.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Army's eleven faces William and Mary tomorrow in what is expected to prove a hard battle for the cadets. The visitors are known to have a strong attack, as was evidenced by their victories over the Navy and other elevens, and the Army defense is expected to experience a stiff test.
Conveyances of small housing properties marked the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 28. -- The Princeton football team arrived in this city today and lost little time in taking a stiff workout at the stadium.

Controller Charles W. Berry has not paid any of the city's routine bills since Oct. 21, it was disclosed yesterday. An inspection of the files of The City Record, official publication of the municipality, showed that he has not prepared since that date a single warrant for payment of any member of the small army of contractors, tradesmen, merchants and supply and material men who do business with city and county departments and agencies.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 28 (AP). -- A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, in an article appearing today in the November issue of the Railroad Trainman, terms the national Sharethe Work plan of unemployment relief as "communism in its worst form',, and "a disguised form of wage cutting."

The action of the Tammany members of the Board of Estimate in the last few days in scrapping the economy program of Acting Mayor McKee was attacked last night by Lewis H. Pounds, Republican Mayoralty nominee, in two speeches in Brooklyn.

Feeling at Democratic National Committee-headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore was jubilant yesterday as a result of former Governor Alfred E. Smith's address at Boston on Thursday night. It was asserted that the speech had left no doubt that Mr. Smith's following would go to the polls and vote for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in large numbers.

City College's varsity football team will play its last home game of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium today, when it opposes the Brooklyn College eleven in the first contest ever played between the two institutions.

MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 28 -- Inability of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., a leading unit in the Canadian newsprint and lumber industry, to pay interest on $11,061,600 of 6 per cent first mortgage bonds was announced here today after a meeting of directors.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Temple University's eleven and Carnegia Tech battled to a 7-7 tie tonight under the floodlights at the Owls Stadium before a crowd of 22,000.

There will soon be much, ringing of doorbells in New England. The ringer's will not be persons in search of work but of Yankee dialect. Collectors for the New England part of the "Linguistic Atlas of the United States and Canada," undertaken by the American Council of Learned Societies and certain colleges and universities, will soon be on the road.

Poly Prep played a scoreless tie with Brooklyn Prep at Boys' High Field in Brooklyn yesterday in the eleventh edition of their football series, which started in 1909. It was the third tie in the series. Poly has won seven times and Brooklyn Prep once.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 28. -- The two most prominent candidates for the Presidency in the elections Sunday issued statements today concerning the future of Cosach, the Nitrate Corporation, of Chile, in which the Guggenheims of New York have important holdings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- Secretary Mills, speaking Here today before the Connecticut Manufacturers Association, challenged what he called Governor Roosevelt's "silence" on measures for inflating the currency passed by the House of Representatives under Democratic control.

Albert Goldman, Commissioner of the Department of Plant and Structures, and George Dobson, 55 years old, of 55 East Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx, a newspaper reporter, were painfully injured last night when a city-owned sedan in which they were riding uptown was in collision with two other cars at Broadway and 155th Street.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 28. -- Infuriated Bolivians compelled Congress to close its sessions today while the new Cabinet was trying to elucidate its policy in the conflict with Paraguay.

WILDER, Idaho, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Senator William E. Borah remarked in a political speech tonight that "with Smith prosecuting the drys and Reed defending them, my advice to the drys is to seek bail at once and apply for a change of venue."

If additional argument were needed for the separation of Federal, State and municipal elections it could tie found in the conduct of this campaign here in New York. It is not the fault of newspapers if daily they spread before their readers such a feast of politics as to dull appetite and daunt digestion.

PERTH, Australia, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The touring Marylebone Cricket Club of England today ran its first-innings total against a combined Australian side to 583 runs for seven wickets before declaring. Australia then scored 59 for no wickets before the close of play for the day.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Net profits of $3,722,576 were reported today by the Canadian Pacific Rail-way for September. This was an increase of $622,721 over September, 1931. Gross earnings were $13,344,078, an increase of $857,561. For the nine months ended on Sept. 30 net profits were $10,531,370, or $2,260,796 lower than the figures in 1931.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28. -- The steel industry roust become "distribution minded" by stressing creative merchandising and research during the next few years if it is to counteract the forces of depression, John H. Van Deventer, editor of The Iron Age, declared tonight at a meeting of the Metallurgical Advisory Board to the Carnegie Institute of Technology.

The New York Opera Comique will suspend performances during" the season of. 1932-1933,. Mrs. Paul D. Cravath, president of the board of directors, announced last night after the first Fall meeting of the board at her home, 784 Park Avenue.

An oil painting of Barbara Heck who assembled the first congregation in John Street Church, 44 John Street, known as "the cradle of American Methodism," will be un veiled in that historic house of worship tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock The service will be in charge of the Barbara Heck Bicentennial Commis sion, appointed at the last quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, held in May at Atlantic City.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- Tale practiced alone in the Bowl today in its final drill before its fifteenth gridiron clash with Dartmouth tomorrow. The game resumes a series dating from 1884 in which the Hanover team has not yet been victorious.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28. -- Condemning attempts by Republican orators to convince the country that there is economic danger in choosing a Democratic national administration at the November elections, Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland declared in a speech here tonight that there would be far greater danger in returning the present Republican administration.
LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- A number of men who were arrested in yesterday

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Convinced that the industrial centres of New Jersey are safely in line to cast their votes for the re-election if President Hoover, Walter B. Edge, American Ambassador to France, turned his attention tonight to the other side of the State, the seashore resorts, as he addressed a gathering of more than 5,000 persons who crowded the music hall of the Steel Pier.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 28. -- The subcommittee of the committee appointed by the Board of Supervisors to investigate Playland, the $6,000,000 Westchester County Park Commission amusement park at Rye, met this afternoon with J. Mayhew Wainwright and Arthur W. Lawrence, members of the park commission.

They have done everything with the old James Montgomery-Frederick Isbam farce, "Nothing But the Truth," in which William Collier once acted, except put it up in tablet form and sell it at the chain drug stores. In its latest reincarnation the play arrived, by way of London, last night at the Cort Theatre, where it was performed with sundry musical interruptions which turned out to be quite the brightest feature of the evening.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28. -- Senator Johnson lashed the Hoover administration tonight in his first campaign speech in behalf of the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Presidency.

Alexander F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, writing in the current issue of The Railroad Trainmen, official organ of the union, published today, opposes the "Share-the-Work" mover ment, not only as "a communistic form of wage cutting" but as "communism in its worst form because it seeks to make those least able to divide, divide their incomes with others."

Harcourt, Brace Co. soon will take over the Brewer, Warren Putnam publishing list, it was revealed yesterday. Details of the sale are not complete, but it is expected it will be made final early next week.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28. -- President Hoover made a scathing attack on Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight, accusing him of a "shuffle" on the tariff instead of a "new deal" and appealed to the nation for support of the Republican party as a body of sound policy and progress.

FOOCHOW, China, Oct. 28. -- Miss Leona Burr, a Congregationalist missionary from South Dakota, arrived here today in a motor boat with two other missionaries after a nervewracking trip of 200 miles to escape a horde of Chinese Communist bandits.

The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. will stage its twenty-fourth annual varsity and thirteenth annual freshman cross-country championships over the regular six-mile Van Cortlandt Park course on Nov. 14 with the entries the smallest in many years.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Former Governor James M. Cox of Ohio, Democratic Presidential nominee in 1920, asserted in an address here tonight that "Republican leaders have for more than a quarter of a century practiced bad faith with the American people on the subject of the tariff."

BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- Lieutenant C. W. Raguse of the United States Army horse show team, riding Ugly, scored a brilliant victory in the $1,000 international military stake, the feature event at tonight's session of the Boston Horse Show.

Reports received yesterday at-headquarters of the Republican National Committee here from national committeewomen in Eastern States give to President Hoover 151 electoral votes from eleven New England and Middle Atlantic States, including the 47 from New York.

There will be no "Winters in Palm Beach" or long vacation in the Summer if he is elected Mayor, Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, asserted at two of four meetings he addressed last night.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 28. -- Fordham is favored to win its fourth straight victory over Boston College when the teams meet before a capacity crowd of 16,000 in the new Boston College Stadium at Alumni Field tomorrow.
Following the recovery of more than 30 points from the low levels of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday under light business and ended 9 to 12 points down.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The Philadelphia Orchestra audience remained almost intact this afternoon during the first playing of a modernistic composition entitled "Three Units," but before it was repeated, which Leopold Stokowski, the conductor, explained would be done if the audience requested, a large part of the audience walked out, estimates as to the number remaining varying from less than one-third to one-half.

After rejecting a suggestion from George McAneny of the Citizens' Budget Commission that $17,000,000 in charges for subway financing be taken out of the budget, and shunting aside economy suggestions by Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee amounting to $1,395,817, the Board of Estimate reduced the proposed budget to $557,141,022 yesterday through reductions approved by the majority members which aggregated $254,779.

While representatives of the Republican party, charging wholesale fraudulent registration in the city, continued to fight yesterday in the courts for the removal from the voting lists of voters illegally registered, a special staff assigned by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. began examination of police complaints involving 350 cases of illegal registration in Manhattan.

The closing of many medical missions of the Far East whose services have deteriorated is recommended by the Appraisal Commission of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry in the eleventh Instalment of its report made public yesterday.

One of the important phases of the annual meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound held at the Yale Club yesterday wag the unanimous decision of the delegates to refer to the rules committee the question of the size and use of parachute spinnakers and Genoa jibs.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Purchase of The Chicago Evening Post by The Chicago Daily News was reported, tonight.

ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- All the way across Massachusetts former Governor Smith waved his brown derby at cheering crowds today and told them that he was working hard to bring about the election of Governor Roosevelt. He asked his loyal Bay State friends to do as much, and some 50,000 men and women who had gathered at stations through which he passed promised that they would.

SOFIA, Oct. 28. -- All Communist Deputies were forcibly ejected from Parliament by government members today after the Reds had made it impossible for King Boris to begin his speech from the throne by chorusing "Down with the Fascist Government!"

The motion of Lillian Boehm and Benjamin F. Johnson, stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company, for an order requiring the Interborough Rapid Transit Company to pay franchise and real estate taxes of $813,660 levied against the Manhattan and also interest of $864,000 due on the Manhattan's debenture bonds, was referred yesterday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson to Judge John M. Woolsey.

New York City's undefeated scholastic football teams, George Washington, De Witt Clinton and Erasmus Hall, are scheduled to see action today in three of the sixteen games carded for fields within New York City. Including encounters listed for Westchester, Long Island and near-by New Jersey gridirons, more than ninety contests are carded in the metropolitan district.

A rather impressive demonstration of strength in some sections of the railroad list featured dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Gains of 1 to 7 points by a number of rail issues contrasted with irregularly lower prices for Industrial bonds and in foreign loans.

With a stock of articles all bearing the word "repsal," and a group of young society women to act as sales-women, the repeal shop of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, New York State division, was formally opened yesterday morning at 501 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Charging that Republican sources were responsible for "whispers and rumors" that Speaker Garner was affiliated with the Ku Klux Klan, Harry L. Sexton, secretary to the Speaker, today wrote to Emerson L. Richards, a New Jersey State Senator, that recent statements credited to the Senator were false.

MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 28 (Canadian Press) -- The committee to protect holders of bonds of Price Brothers Co. is composed of Ross H. McMaster and James A. Eccles of Montreal, Thomas Bradshaw of Toronto, John Kelly of Quebec, W. Eugene McGregor of Boston and Murray W. Dodge of New York.

Declaring that "we had better abolish our judicial system" rather than permit "judgeships to be handed around by the bosses of the two parties as reward for personal relations," George W. Wickersham attacked last night the bi-partisan "judicial deal" and advocated the election of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch, candidates of the Independent Judges party, to the Supreme Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28. -- Football's main battle front in the Far West' shifts south tomorrow, where the undefeated, untied University of California at Los Angeles Bruins will make a home stand against Stanford's Indians.

While President HOOVER tours the Middle West, describing a high tariff as an indispensable bulwark against ruinous foreign competition, the Customs Bureau in Washington is holding hearings on charges of foreign "dumping." Manufacturers of iron and steel, manganese, cement, rugs and other products have appeared as witnesses and given testimony both in support and in rebuttal of these charges.

Prices continued to creep upward on the stock market yesterday, with trading falling 30,000 shares below Thursday's modest level to a total of 686,639 shares. There was a lack of incentive to speculators on either side, and, with the elections six full and two abbreviated market days away, political factors were at a surprisingly low ebb.

A strong Purdue football team, cochampion of the Big Ten last season, arrived yesterday confident that it would return to the mid-West with its record still free from defeat. The Boilermakers will oppose New York University at the Yankee Stadium today and a crowd of more than 30,000 is expected.

The foreign language press of this country was praised by Grover A. Whalen. president of the Advertising Club of New York, at the second day's sessions of the German-American Congress at the Hotel Astor yesterday. He hailed it as an aid to good American citizenship and a vehicle for important cultural contributions to our national life, urging those of foreign birth or extraction to support their language press.

The police notified Magistrate George De Luca in Morrisania court yesterday that Communists intended to demonstrate today at 2 P.M. in front of his home, 674 East 229th Street, the Bronx, in protest against his "vicious verdict" in the case of James Ford, a Negro.

A jury before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew in the Bronx returned a verdict of $50,000 in favor of Jacob Okonowitz of 198 Beach Twenty-ninth Street, Edgemere, L. I., in the $500,000 damage suit he brought against nine individuals and their firms in the glass business, charging a conspiracy, which resulted in his being shot and wounded because he refused to join the Retail Glaziers and Setters' Association.

Representatives of transatlantic steamship lines and lines operating throughout the year to the West Indies, Central America and the northern ports of South America agreed to confer next week in an attempt to settle their differences as to Winter cruises, after a hearing yesterday before H.C. Brown, examiner for the United States Shipping Board, at 45 Broadway.

LONDON, Oct. 28.-- Better tone was evident on the Stock Exchange today, due to a steadier tendency in sterling, which maintained last night's closing rate of $3.28 1/4 firmer American advices and brighter Continental news. British Government funds were easier and inactive.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Smiling and waving together or in turn to huge mid-West crowds, Mrs. Herbert Hoover and her guest, Alice Roosevelt Longworth, today campaigned in a common Republican cause.
PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The text of President Hoover's speech here follows:

The spirit of GALVANI must rejoice at the news that the Nobel Prize has been awarded to Sir CHARLES SHERRINGTON and Professor EDGAR D. ADRIAN for their illuminating discoveries about nerves. The famous experiment with the dead frog's legs, performed in 1780, brought little but ridicule to GALVANI.
ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Smith bured their political differences during in hour-and-a-half chat at the Executive Mansion here tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his article "Vare Moves to Sare State for Hoover," in THE TIMES of Oct. 23, Arthur Krock states that there are no starving or shelterless folk in this city. We have both in considerable and regrettable numbers.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 28. -- Mrs. George Quackenbush and her daughter, Mrs. Quackenbush Davis, entertained with a luncheon in The Homestead today for Richard Stevens and Clement W. Booth.

The maintenance or the united States Navy at treaty strength is absolutely essential as an insurance during war and a guarantee of peace. Rear Admiral Henry A. Wiley, United States Navy, retired, former commander-in-chief of the United States Fleet, asserted yesterday at a joint celebration of Navy Day and the anniversary of President Roosevelt's birth.

The open season for ducks, rabbits, quail, pheasants and squirrels will begin on Long Island Tuesday. From all reports there will be no shortage of any legal game. Prospects seem bright for a good quail season. The Conservation Department has released several thousand quail this year and Long Island has received more than any other section, it is said.

Suspension of one more student -- making a total of eleven-and milt mass meetings outside the college grounds provided the highlights yes terday in the City College row over the failure of the college to retail Dr. Oakley Johnson in the English Department.

Domenico Trombetta, editor of the Italian weekly newspaper II Grido Delia Stirpe was acquitted yesterday of a charge of murder in the shooting of Salvatore Arena, a painter, 35 years old, of 1,550 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, last July 4 after a clash between Fascists and anti-Fascists at memorial services at the Garibaldi Shrine on Staten.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Senatorial campaign committees reported to the clerk of the House today expenditures of $69,026.27 from Sept. 26 to Oct. 26. This was less than half of the usual expenditures. Few large contributors are listed in the reports.

Personal Touch Survives. It has been freely predicted that the radio in Presidential campaigns would make an end of the old barnstorming methods. Why should Presidential nominees go swinging around the circle, shouting themselves hoarse from the tall of railroad cars?

For the first time in five weeks all the new bond flotations this week consisted of municipal issues. There were five of them and they aggregated only $2,048,000, the smallest amount since the week ended on Feb. 5, when no issues were brought out.
Columbia and Cornell will clash this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock at Baker Field in their long-awaited combat. A capacity crowd of 40,000 is expected to witness the meeting of the undefeated rivals.

NEWARK, N. J.. Oct. 28. -- Centring their interest on one issue of the present political campaign and ignoring party affiliations, more than 10,000 persons inarched in a "beer parade" here tonight to Military Park, where addresses were made by various speakers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Westchester and White Plains patriotic and historical organizations joined today in celebrating the 156th anniversary of the Battle of White Plains and the 150th anniversary of the withdrawal of Washington's troops from Westchester County.

MADRID, Oct. 28. -- The efforts of United States delegates to the International Communications Congress to prevent stricter censorship regulations for private cable and wireless messages, as proposed by various nations, bore fruit today when the censorship committee approved by acclamation regulations submitted by the Americans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For more than ten years I have been an interested contributor to the Edge-water Creche. Never, in all that period, have I observed so many babies in such critical physical condition as have been brought to us for convalescent care this year.

Directors of the International League, gathered in special session at the Hotel New "Yorker yesterday, voted unanimously to reduce the salary and player limit of the eight clubs in the circuit in line with the recent action of the American Association.
TOKYO, Oct. 28. -- The Japanese Government's new instructions to Admiral Nagano, its naval delegate to Geneva, cover twelve pages of Japanese script with detailed figures.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Sales of wool have been comparatively few and far between this week, being mostly for the fine and fine medium French combing type of wools selling at 40 cents, clean basis, more or less.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- France will propose at the next meeting of the disarmament conference the abolition of the German Reichswehr and the substitution of national defensive militias by all European countries for regular armies.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 28 -- Attacking the Democratic tariff program as "vague" and "mystic," George Z. Medalie, Republican candidate for Senator, told an audience here tonight that the protective tariff is vital to the welfare of the laborer, the employer and the farmer.

GENEVA, Oct. 28. -- A trend toward stronger measures to supervise the execution of the proposed disarmament treaty, including a favorable attitude toward several Soviet suggestions to this end, marks a report on the question of supervision by M. Bourquin, Belgian, published today.

Strong buying, originating in the Far East and executed chiefly by one house, came into the market for silver futures on the National Metals Exchange yesterday lifting prices 50 to 75 points in one of the biggest days in the history of the market. December silver the most active contract, closed at 27.68 cents an ounce, up 3/4 cent.

Louis Waldman, Socialist candidate for Governor, addressed a telegram to Governor Roosevelt yesterday asking the Governor to order the Public Service Commission, "as an agent of the public," to take steps to reduce gas, electric and telephone rates in New York City, in line with the Governor's action on rates in Binghamton.

In two raids on supposedly private homes in Coney Island and Manhattan Beach last night, Federal agents arrested seven men and seized a wireless set which they said had guided ships to this port with $7,000,000 worth of illicit liquor in the last year and which was the most powerful set of its kind located in the metropolitan area in several years.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

Railroads reporting yesterday brought to more than thirty the number of those that have showed an increase in net operating income for September, compared with September, 1931. Among those announcing such results yesterday were the Monon, Gulf, Mobile Northern, Louisville Nashville.

A novel radio - phonograph - piano combination, manufactured in Germany under the patents of John Hays Hammond Jr. for Radio City, was demonstrated privately last night before an audience of 250 guests, who marveled at the remarkable piano tones that swelled through a theatre auditorium with the intensity of a massive organ.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- The Bourse session today, the last until Wednesday, was dull, with tee tendency downward. So little trading took place that the losses in most instances were unimportant. Some of the internationals were supported, following yesterday's improvement in Wall Street and remained firm.

Receipt of a donation of $1,000 to aid the American Arbitration Association in financing arbitration work for the rehabilitation of defaulted real estate bonds was announced yesterday by Lucius R. Eastman, president.

CHICAGO (AP) Oct. 28. -- Wheat bulls contended today that present prices reflected virtually complete deflation of all grain values. Dips in wheat quotations to below 45 cents a bushel for December contracts have brought the market to within 2 cents of what wheat sold for 344 years ago in England, although the all-time bottom, records show, was in 1287 and 1288, when wheat in England changed hands at 9 cents a bushel.

BLACKWOOD, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Two youthful hold-up men were shot and killed tonight in a gun battle when they and two other armed men attempted to hold up two State troopers, one of them dressed as a woman, who were parked as a decoy in a police sedan on the lonely Davis-town road between here and Erial, ten miles from Camden.

Dr. Austin S. Johnson has bought for improvement with a residence an acre plot in Narragansett Avenue, Lawrence, from Samuel P. Hinckly. The site adjoins the estates of Thomas R. Williams and Todd D. Sloan. F.R. Mackey arranged the deal.

P. Hal Sims and his team-mates, Willard S. Karn, Harold S. Vanderbilt and Waldemar von Zedtwitz were pushed to the limit in the quarter-final round of the Vanderbilt Cup contract bridge tournament at the Ritz-Carlton last-night and won their way into today's semi-finals only by a rally on the last hand of the match.

Details of recent transactions involving business properties in Manhattan were shown in papers recorded at the Register's office yesterday. Two of the properties were taken by firms catering to the automobile trade.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 28 (Canadian Press). -- A more optimistic feeling pervaded the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today as yesterday's gains in wheat, following a two-day precipitous drop, were consolidated and even emended fractionally in the October and November deliveries.
Colonel William J. Donovan injected a startling note into the campaign yesterday when he proposed the election of the President for a single term of seven years.

Opposition to any reduction in State aid for public education or to the droppirig of new curricula adopted to equip students better for modern times was expressed yesterday in meetings here attended by 9,000 teachers of the southeastern district of the New York State Teachers' Association.

Increases in the annual fees for season permits to use the golfing and tennis facilities of the city's parks were voted a week ago by the Park Board at a meeting at the Arsenal, it was disclosed yesterday by Thomas J. Dolen, Park Commissioner of the Bronx.

The Manhattan eleven will experience its first taste of intersectional competition today when it clashes with Oglethorpe University of Atlanta, Ga., at the Polo Grounds. A crowd of 20,000 is expected.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 28-Four quarters of nip and tuck football found Loyola of New Orleans and Xavier University of Cincinnati in a 6-to-6 deadlock at Corcoran Field tonight in a game packed with close play throughout.

Answers to the series of questions on domestic and international policy which is being put to candidates in a questionnaire by the New York League of Women Voters were made public yesterday in the league's weekly news report. There were replies by Robert F. Wagner, Democratic candidate for Senator; Elmer E. Studley, Democratic candidate for Representative at Large, and the two Republican candidates for the same position, Nicholas H. Pinto and Sherman J. Lowell.

More than 20 per cent of New York City's school children are suffering from malnutrition, according to Health Department statistics given to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, and which served yesterday as a basis for an appeal by medical authorities for serious consideration of the child health problem a one of the gravest facing the community this Winter.

Many debutantes of this season and older members of society are now in Tuxedo Park for the festivitives arranged in connection with the Autumn ball tonight at the Tuxedo Club. This event is regarded as the first entertainment of importance to the young women "coming out" this season, and on this occasion many of them are introduced to older friends of their families.

Five members of the Brooklyn band accused by the police of participation in four robberies that netted them a total of $190,000 in loot, of which $150,000 was in precious metals, were held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Ellperin in Adams Street Court for hearing next Thursday in Gates Avenue Court.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28 -- President Hoover carried his campaign into three States today in a strenuous series of back-platform appearances at ten stops of his special train en route here.

Shere Khan, a 50-to-1 shot, the longest price of the meeting, scored by two lengths yesterday at Empire City in the third race. A 2-year-old son of Dunbar II and Waif, Shere Khan was purchased for a polo pony by his present owner, J.D. Moran, and was maintained in training only because of the confidence of Trainer Rufus Felder that he would prove a winner.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Soft track performers had another inning today at Latonia. R.L. Silver's Parnell Bound, ever partial to soft footing, proved a repeater in the featured offering, a six-furlong dash for older sprinters.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28. -- Coach Heartly (Hunk) Anderson and his squad of thirty-five Notre Dame football players arrived this morning. This afternoon the Ramblers were sent through a final light signal drill. Tomorrow the Notre Dame band, accompanied by a trainload of loyal rooters, will arrive to lend encouragement to the Ramblers in their battle with Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Improved conditions in a number of countries were reported by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly survey of the business situation abroad.

President Hoover's reference last night to Governor Roosevelt's connection with the Federal International Banking Company was the third reference by a Republican campaign spokesman to business activities of the Democratic nominee while a private citizen.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Hal Price Headley's 3-year-old Village Vamp nosed out the Belair Stud's juvenile, Dominus, after a bitter stretch duel in the Tangier Purse today at Laurel. The Audley Farm's Bright Shadow, two lengths away, was third in the field of seven.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28. - President Justo is planning to send a special embassy to London with Vice President Julio A. Roca as Ambassador Extraordinary.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28. -- Following is the prepared text of President Hooper's address here tonight:

Being a poet, even when he is writing prose, Mr. Yeats could not for a moment write a dull word about Swift, Stella and Vanessa in the one-act play, "The Words Upon the Window Pane," which had its American premiere at the Martin Beck last evening.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 28 -- In his address here today President Hoover said:

The fifteenth running of the New Jersey Hunt Cup, a four-mile test over the stern rail course of the Froh-Heim Estate at Far Hills, N.J., will feature the second and final day's racing of the Essex Fox Hounds today. Eleven have been named over night for the race, won last year by W. Cosgreve Jackson's aged bay gelding Sennacherib, which.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (AP). -- Most persons take high blood pressure too seriously, Dr. Harlow Brooks of New York University told the assembly of the Interstate Post-Graduate Medical Association here today. He said persons could have this ailment and yet live to old age if other conditions of their health were good.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Bringing to a close a two weeks' series of Customs Bureau hearings in which the dumping of a wide range of commodities in the American market has been charged, Benjamin Schwartz, director general of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel of New York City, joined in the application of the American Iron and Steel Institute today for an order against foreign, iron and steel products.

With colorful ceremony, which lasted three hours, the Rev. Dr. James Edward Kearney, founder and for the last four years pastor of the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 1658 Lurting Avenue, the Bronx, was consecrated yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral as Bishop of the Diocese of Salt Lake, Utah.
Columbia brought its Autumn rowing season to a close yesterday on the Harlem River, where varsity and freshman crews competed in the annual Fall regatta.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- The New Haven Lawn Club was the scene this evening of the second debutante dance of the season given by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Owsley of Hillhouse Avenue to introduce their daughter, Miss Julia Owsley, a sophomore at Smith College.

The Board of Taxes and Assessments was out last night -- on the end of a limb. Its members and officials had placed a $15,000 assessment on the personal property of one Eustace Tilley. It developed, alas, that the gentleman is non-existent, that he is nothing more than a picture in a high hat, a name in the telephone book.
BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- Democratic arid Republican leaders disagreed today as to the effect on the electorate of Alfred E. Smith's speech here last night.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Whether Pennsylvania units have been weakened by the collapse of the Samuel Insull utilities network held the attention today of the State Senate committee investigating the Public Service Commission.

ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- The Stats Banking Department announced today the appointment of the following as bank examiners; Fred W. Leimbach, Danville, N.J.; John W. Johnson, Hollis; Robert L. Lott, Lynbrook; James J. Sherry, Rutherford, N.J.; Chester R. Hartzell, Brooklyn, and John F. Timmons, the Bronx.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 28 (AP). -- The trial of Torsten Kreuger, brother of the late Ivar Kreuger, on a charge of fraud in connection, with the affairs of the Hogbrofors Wood Pulp Company started today.

While differing as to the rate of activity in the last week, the principal reviews of trade and industry expressed yesterday the belief that fundamentally the economic wounds of the country were healing.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Lack of buying interest rather than any pressure to sell wheat on the Board of Trade here today was given as the main reason for an early break of about 3/4 cent a bushel. The December was lowered to 44 3/4 cents, or within 5/8 cent of the record low figure here for a future, which was established on Wednesday.

Financial markets continued yesterday to drift in the pre-election doldrums that have held them for several weeks. Trading on the Stock Exchange was again small, but there were renewed efforts to improve the tone of the market under the stimulus of better railroad earnings.

Mrs. Courtland Nicoll, national vice chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, has announced that, although she is a Republican, she will support Lieut. Gov. Lehman, the Democratic candidate for Governor, because of his stand for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Declaring that "Mr. Hoover and the Republicans believe in doles to banks and business," and that the beliefs of the Democrats, except that they wanted to hold office, were "still far from clear," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, carried his campaign into New Jersey with speeches here and in Elizabeth tonight.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP). -- Secretary Mills, speaking here tonight, warned against the casting of "a vote of despair and forlorn hope -- the forlorn hope in the magic of a mere change."

The claims of nineteen residents of the Middle West to shares in the $40,000,00 estate of Ella V. von E. Wendel were termed a hoax by counsel for the estate at a hearing yesterday before Surrogate James A. Foley.

BLOOMFIELD. N.J., Oct. 28. -- In the last regularly scheduled one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, played today over the Forest Hill Field Club course, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol, the association champion, won low gross prize with a card of 40, 41 -- 81.

Secretary of Labor William N. Doak was heckled last night by radicals at a Republican rally in the Bay Ridge High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, where the hecklers created such a hubbub that a dozen extra policemen were rushed to the building from the Fourth Avenue station to prevent uglier demonstrations.

A resolution opposing the "recreational amendment" on the Nov. 8 ballot was unanimously adopted yesterday by more than 800 women, representing 368 clubs, attending the eighty-ninth convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.
ROME, Oct. 28. -- The tenth anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome was fittingly celebrated today when Premier Mussolini opened the broad new avenue linking the Piazza Venezia with the Colosseum.

The New York Central Railroad has pledged for bank loans all its $13,145,000 of common stock of the Reading Railroad, $3,515,000 of its $6,840,000 Reading first preferred and $8,990,000 of its $15,015,000 Reading second preferred, it is disclosed in the trunk line's application to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a $2,500,000 work loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today for a further relief loan of $6,000,000 to carry the State through November.
NEW YORK. The American Consul General in London and Mrs. Albert Halstead arrived on the Manhattan and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- The French and Chilean governments signed an agreement last night whereby France agrees to make about half its nitrate purchases in the coming year from Chile. Although the terms of the agreement have not been made public, pending formal ratification at Santiago, enough is known to assure Americans here that they probably will not lose their hard-won share of France's great nitrate market.

With election eleven days off. Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, continued to lead President Hoover by a 3-to-2 vote in semi-final returns from The Literary Digest nation-wide Presidential poll which will be published in this week's issue of the magazine.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The doors of Butler University field house were opened an hour and a half before the President was scheduled to speak, and half an hour later its 22,000 seats were filled.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28 -- Notwithstanding the loss of a hard afternoon's drill on Thursday because of rain, Harvard will start against Brown tomorrow in a confident frame of mind.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28. -- The Montreal Star publishes a story this evening which says that the sending of a Democratic appeal for funds to a resident of Montreal was only a clerical oversight and might have been avoided if a closer inspection of the list of people to whom the letter was sent had been made.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press). -- The conference of Associated Chambers of Commerce adopted a resolution today urging the government to introduce discriminatory and lower tariffs, on both empire and foreign goods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Investigation of charges that a wide range of foreign products were being dumped in the United States at prices threatening American industries were in progress today in several parts of the world, and the Customs Bureau was anticipating further complaints.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The undefeated Princeton freshman football team defeated the Penn yearlings, 27 -- 0, in Palmer Stadium today. It was the first defeat of the season for the Penn Cubs, McMillan, Pauk, LeVan and Roper scored touchdowns.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sunday, Oct. 30 (AP). -- Harold MacGrath, the novelist, died early this morning at his home here. He had been ill several months. He was 61 years old.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the absence of Redmond F. Kernan Jr., the president of the National Catholic Alumni Federation, may I, as one of the trustees and an officer of the federation, reply to Dr. Knopf's recent letter wherein he criticizes Mr. Kernan's action on behalf of the federation in protesting to President Hoover the public advocacy of birth control by Governor Beverley of Puerto Rico?

PANAMA, R.P., Oct. 24. -- Dr. Raymond Ditmars, curator of the Bronx Park Zoo, who came here from New York and spent four busy days vainly hunting the bushmaster, the deadliest snake in tropical America, will be sorry he was not driving with two American women, Mrs. William Cates and Mrs. Everett Seaburg, from this city to Madden Dam recently.
With the exception of rubber and hides, which moved higher, commodities on local exchanges continued last week to decline in price in sym- pathy with securities.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 29. -- Although he praised Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt as "a man of upstanding character," Representative Robert Low Bacon, Republican candidate for re-election, declared in a speech here today that he felt that the election of the Democratic candidate for President would result in a "slowing up" of business.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 29. -- Auburn's aerial thrust with two minutes to play broke a 7-7 deadlock to defeat Mississippi today, 14 -- 7.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 29. -- Carnival stunts with martial music of eighteen bands furnished a colorful background for Dixie Roberts's onslaught today that gave Vanderbilt a 12-to-0 victory over Georgia Tech before Nashville's greatest football crowd, estimated at 25,000.

WHEN E.F. Dakin published his biography of the founder of the Christian Science Church two years ago he admitted that there were gaps in his information and added that "the eventual publication of Mr. Dittemore's documents must be eagerly awaited, providing as it will the final and conclusive evidence concerning the many disputed points in Mrs. Eddy's career."

THIS month has taken from the American art world two distinguished figures, Roland Knoedler and Edward G. Kennedy. Their personal quality has been widely and appropriately commented upon; but it is interesting to look back for a moment upon the period of their greatest activity in guiding, inspiring and also reflecting and responding to this country's taste at that time.

IN these last days before election the Tammany machine for vote getting bums into fortissimo. It has been turning over slowly all year, generating the power which makes it the most effective political organization in the world, but just before election day the captains sit on the safety valve, open the throttle wide, and bring the whole mechanism up to top speed.

PANAMA, R.P., Oct. 25. -- Colombians are so aroused over the controversy that has arisen with Peru concerning their almost forgotten border town, Leticia, hidden in the deep Jungles of the upper Amazon, that there is agitation for changing the name of the village of several hundred palm-thatched houses.

Predictions of an overwhelming victory for the Democratic ticket, with record pluralities in the city, were made last night at a rally for Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic Mayoralty nominee, at Carnegie Hall. The rally, held under the auspicies of the Business and Professional Men's League for O'Brien, was the major meeting for purely local candidates so far in the campaign.

POETRY is still a headliner. While gloomy philosophers moan that the world has gone to the materialists, poetry holds its own in the news of the day as a thing of live interest. Clippings, a tall stack of them, are testimony in the matter.

NEWS comes from Moscow that a variety of dandelion has been discovered in the Crimea which contains a milk from which rubber can be made. Thus another chapter is added to the Soviet quest of rubber. Early in the year Moscow announced that chemists had discovered, in what was called "towsagis" in the news dispatches, a plant which yielded a rubber-milk.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Two Kentucky mountain families shot out their differences in front of the courthouse here today and sent several hundred persons scurrying for shelter in a fight in which six persons, three of them, bystanders, were wounded.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Before a capacity crowd of 15,000, White Plains High School's football team, Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association champion for the past two years, defeated Mount Vernon High, 14 to 7, today at Howard Field in their W.I.A.A. meeting, that was also the thirty-second annual gridiron game between the two schools.

A SCOUT, surveying the horizon with powerful binoculars for any and all evidences of theatrical activity, declares that from present indications only one new show is in prospect for the week beyond this. That is Miss Fears's production of the Kern-Hammerstein operetta, "Music in the Air," which is due at the Alvin on Tuesday evening, Nov. 8 -- and don't forget to vote before you go to see it!

THE recent order of the British Admiralty for "direct" steering commands in the navy has evoked widespread comment in nautical circles and adverse criticism from some naval officers, to say nothing of forebodings among old salts steeped in the traditions of service afloat.
A series of splendid performances by schoolboy harriers marked the P.S.A.L. borough championship runs over the two-and-a-half-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
NEW YORK. The former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Sherman Allen, who passed the Summer traveling in Europe, returned on the Europa and are at Mayfair House.

BUFFALO, Oct. 29. -- Alfred E. Smith told the fellow-citizens of Colonel Donovan tonight that the campaign statements of the Republican Gubernatorial nominee proved him incompetent for the high office he is seeking, and declared that the nation's future welfare "lies absolutely" in the election of Governor Roosevelt to the Presidency."

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 29. -- Lehigh conquered its traditional foe, Muhlenberg, 25 to 6, today before 7,000 spectators, turning a closely contested battle into a rout in the last period by scoring two touchdowns.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- Scoring in the second and fourth periods, the University of Pennsylvania eleven hung up its fifth successive victory of the season today by turning back Navy, 14-0, before more than 57,000 spectators, including the Annapolis regiment of 2,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The Republican National Committee collected $1,478,791.96 between Sept. 1 and Oct. 26, and spent $1,356,548.29, according to the reports submitted today by J.R. Nutt, treasurer, to the Clerk of the House.

THE wisest policy for a foreigner should be to pay compliments or keep silent. The most cautious policy for an author should be to pay compliments and by no means keep silent. But there is something in my feeling for Americans which prevents me from regarding myself as a foreigner in this country, and, furthermore, I have never considered myself an author's shop runner.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 29. -- A 40-yard pass from Captain Graham to Tardiff paved the way for the touchdown that enabled Andover to beat the Brown freshman football team today at Brown Field by 7 -- 0.

As might have been expected from the character of the week, yesterday's financial markets mostly lost ground fractionally. They had been creeping slowly upward in the few preceding days and, although the advance was trifling, it was enough to induce the usual "week-end professional profit-taking."

With the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment a savings of $2,000,000,000 would accrue to the government, including $1,163,432,000 in annual revenue from the liquor traffic and the cost of prohibition enforcement, according to A. Mitchell Palmer, Attorney General in Wilson's administration, who gave that estimate in an interview here yesterday.

SINCE Hope Farm, in Verbank, Dutchess County, was established many years ago as a community school for needy boys and girls there have been varied ways of raising funds for its support, but the forthcoming benefit promises to be one of the most unusual as well as instructive, and one that will attract art lovers from far and near.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society's concerts for children and young people will begin Nov. 12 with the first concert of the more elementary series. The other group of concerts, for more advanced work, will begin Nov. 19, and devote four mornings to the study of concerto form and one to the works of Brahms, apropos the Brahms centenary.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 29. -- The Lafayette College soccer team was defeated in a hard game today by Swarthmore. 2 -- 0.
DUBLIN, Oct. 29. -- It is reported an appeal will be made to the Prince of Wales, when he visits Northern Ireland soon, to mediate the Anglo-Irish dispute.

Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, makes on Friday night in Madison Square Garden his first defense of the title here since he fought Kid Chocolate a year ago. The popular Brooklyn Italian is to battle the rugged, stout-hearted veteran of Fargo, N.D., Billy Petrolle, in a fifteen-round battle that promises to be one of the greatest lightweight encounters since Benny Leonard defended the crown against Richie Mitchell in the old Garden.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The Harvard varsity cross-country team defeated both Princeton and Yale, and the Yale harriers conquered Princeton in three dual races which were run simultaneously over the Princeton course today.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 29. -- Wesleyan triumphed over Trinity in the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the football rivals today by 7 -- 0 before a crowd of 5,000.

"TOLEDO the rich, Salamanca the strong, Leon the beautiful, Oviedo the holy and Sevilla the great" -- that is the way an old saying tells the tale of the major cathedrals of Spain, those cathedrals that now, along with a thousand lesser parish churches, it is proposed to make the property of the State.

ONLY once is anything strange or original in Hollywood. Immediately the strangeness is certified by publicity, the motion picture industry, avid for oddity, makes carbons of the circumstance until what was strange, by its reiteration, becomes commonplace and routine.

To judge from the comments of some of the more optimistic opponents of prohibition, the Eighteenth Amendment is as good as repealed and modification of the Volstead act almost a matter of record. Governor SMITH, in fact, is looking ahead to a new goal to be won when the victorious army of repealists has swept past its first objective.

THE airlines of the country are getting ready for the Winter. Formerly such preparation implied retrenchment, the laying tap of so many planes and engines, the suspension of pilots and, in some cases, the actual elimination of schedules.

So great has been the demand for tickets to the Madison Square Garden meeting tomorrow night at which President Hoover will make his principal appeal to voters in the East, that the seating capacity of that auditorium has been exhausted and the Republican campaign managers have been compelled to make arrangements for a large overflow meeting at Carnegie Hall.

FOR six generations Young America has received its visual impression of the great events of the Revolution principally through the eyes of Colonel John Trumbull -- reproductions in their history books of his paintings of the Battle of Bunker Hill, of the death of General Montgomery at Quebec, the surrender of Burgoyne, the surrender of Cornwallis, the signing of the Declaration of Independence and the rest.

PEACE AND THE NAVY. By PRESIDENT HOOVER, In 1/2. Public Statement Issued on the Eve of Navy Day. OUR people have ever been lovers of peace, and they have consistently pursued a policy designed to preserve national lights by peaceful negotiations wherever possible, rather than by resort to arms. * * * Our patience in these negotiations has never for a moment jeopardized the safety of the United States.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 29. -- Washington and Jefferson's sustained drive of 33 yards for a touchdown turned back Lafayette today, 7-0.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29. -- The Soviet Government is dismayed and angered over a new anti-Bolshevist campaign in London, where it is being stated that Russian matches are peddled in the streets with anti-religious cartoons and captions on the boxes, which are reported "smuggled into England in coffins."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Army, using reserve players throughout, defeated the William and Mary eleven today by 33 to 0. Twenty thousand spectators watched the contest played in Michie Stadium under ideal weather conditions.

Notes and Oddments. Both sides heartily agree that party lines should be sacrificed to the national welfare. The only difference is that the Democrats think the Republican lines should be sacrificed and the Republicans think the Democrats would look perfect with all their lines gone.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- The fighting Illini of Illinois today fought themselves out of the depths of Western Conference football to score a startling 13 to 7 triumph over Chicago, and wreck the Maroons' hope for a Big Ten title. A crowd of 22,000 saw the game.

RETAIL trade was quieter during the week due to unfavorable weather and the increased attention paid to politics. Reports came from various sections of the country where there was snow or a cold wave that demand for warm clothing and other Winter needs had spurted.

The strong Erasmus Hall High School eleven continued in its unbeaten stride by vanquishing Alexander Hamilton, 18-0, yesterday at Commercial Field for its fourth victory in five starts, one of which was a deadlock with James Madison.

A.T. TORAN, artist and decorator, will hold an exhibition of the work of young artists between the ages of 15 and 21 years at his studio, 160 East Fifty-seventh Street, beginning Oct. 31. Mr. Toran has a large studio which is not in use at the present time, so decided to place it at the disposal of young artists who are as yet unknown.

HOLLYWOOD, CAL. THE film version of "Little Women" has suddenly become the centre of controversy on the RKO-Radio lot, its direction a coveted plum and its Jo a most desirable role. Most surprising is that Constance Bennett is eager to play the lead, a characterization quite different from anything she has thus far essayed.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Germany's demand for equal status with the other powers gets its weight from a deep popular feeling that the nation must be solemnly exonerated from the charge of moral responsibility for the World War.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 -- Going into the final week of the campaign California sustains its role as the national question mark. Straw votes and betting odds continue to favor Governor Roosevelt, but the Republicans have regained a lot of lost courage during the last two weeks.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith's New Jersey speech, and the possible appearance of President Hoover for a major effort in Illinois, may be decisive factors in settling the outcome of the Presidential and subordinate campaigns in this State.

ATLANTA, Oct. 27. -- The visit of Governor Roosevelt to Atlanta and Warm Springs this week was made a gala occasion. Not only were the Democratic Presidential candidate's ears almost deafened by shouts of enthusiastic welcome, but he grew hoarse from repeatedly replying: "Hello folks," in response to neighborly greetings of "Hello, Franklin."

A considerable increase in dispossess actions and in actual evictions in September, as compared with September, 1931, was reported yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, Public Welfare Commissioner, who said the Home Relief Bureau was attempting to bring down the number of evictions by arranging compromise settlements, in many cases, with landlords.
