NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Keyed to a fighting pitch which befitted the traditional nature of the game, the Boston College football team upset Fordham's eleven, 3 to 0, at Alumni Field today. Eddie Kelly of Boston booted the ball from the ten-yard line in the third period for the only score.

THERE is always pronounced pleasure for this reviewer, a pleasure which he hopes is widely shared, in coming across a book on the American mountain people when the writer thereof knows what he is talking about and has sufficiently won the confidence of the folk, never an easy thing to do, so that he can faithfully depict their lives.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Howard Bruce, noted Baltimore sportsman, today won permanent possesion of the famous New Jersey Hunt Cup, when his aged bay gelding Hubar, ridden by Ray Woolfe, scored a six-lengths victory over Coolagh Boy in the fifteenth running of the four-mile post-and-rail race which marked the finale of the two-day meeting of the Essex Fox founds on the estate of E.B. Schley.

A merger of three savings banks, the East River, the Maiden Lane and the Italian, was put into effect at noon yesterday, according to an announcement made later from the main office of the first named institution at 291 Broadway.

September showed an advance over August all along the line in employment, weekly hours of work and average weekly earnings, with a slight decline in the cost of living, according to a statement issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Winter sports apparel faces a good outlook during the coming season, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Tobe, fashion and merchandising councilor to retail stores. The buying public, she said, is now "Winter sports conscious," having been influenced by the Olympic games at Lake Placid early this year and other important factors, such as inducements offered by railroads to visit leading Winter sports centres.

THIS is a book about John Brown of Osawatomie and Harpers Ferry. It is not to be classed with those modern familiar hybrids that run the gamut from the biographical story to the story biography. It rather reverts to an older spirit form -- that of the poetic historical drama.
BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- Alfred Dwight Foster, chairman of the board of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company since 1924, died after a long illness today at his home in Milton.

MOST of the higher learning in America is carried on in tax-supported State universities. The situation of all these public institutions is now so critical that unless there is some change in the attitude or condition of our people there is indeed very little hope for the continuation of that higher learning which is my theme.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 29. -- The annual hunter trials of the Albemarle County Hunt, held today over a course on the Wavertree Hall and Portaferry estates of Colonel H. D. Newcomb and George L. Maxwell of New York and Greenwood, attracted entries from Kentucky, West Virginia and Hot Springs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Greatly encouraged by the reception given him in Indianapolis and by enthusiastic crowds en route, President Hoover returned to the capital today with his mind made up to make another trip next week into the Middle West.

GOGAMA, Ont., Oct. 27 -- The gold fever is running high in this northern village, and many go so far as to predict that a miniature Klondyke gold rush is in the making. From Shining Tree, twenty-five miles to the eastward, through Hotstone and Raney Lakes, sixty-five miles northwest of here, the wild bush country is being ranged by prospectors with picks and dynamite in search of the yellow metal.

AN all-Wagner program will be presented by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Toscanini, as a special concert Wednesday evening. The regular Thursday night concert will feature on its program Beethoven's "Pastoral" symphony and will also include Casteinuovo-Tedesco's overture to "The Taming of the Shrew," Sibelius's "En Saga" and Enesco's Rumanian Rhapsody No. 1.

Young Alistair Ross is the personal acolyte of His Eminence Gian da Garda, Cardinal of Panama. Hidden in the vestry, Alistair watches the Cardinal take off his scarlet robe and emerge dressed for the sea, in leather coat and breeches and sea boots, with a sword at his side.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Anxious Moments, a chestnut gelding owned by Lieutenant John W. Morris of Staten Island, carried off two blues in jumping events at the third annual Fall horse show conducted by the Bronxville Riding Club on its grounds on California Road today.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Colgate continued its drive toward the Eastern championship today before a large home-coming day crowd by downing Penn State, 31 to 0, in a game which was one-sided from the opening kick-off until the final whistle blew.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Republican headquarters made public today a statement that G.A. Eddy, head of a Chicago printing press concern, had forwarded to Governor Roosevelt a charge that the Democratic national organization, in an appeal to him for a campaign contribution, made "flagrant attempts at political blackmail."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Rutgers shattered Johns Hopkins's undefeated record on Neilson Field today, the Scarlet winning 33 to 0.

John R. Keim, diamond expert and jewelry buyer, of 270 Park Avenue, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself through the temple while seated in his private office in his company's headquarters at 10 East Thirty-ninth Street. He was 69 years old and, according to an assistant, had worried frequently over business conditions.

A large number of pastors will preach today on the political situation. The feast of Christ the King will be observed in Roman Catholic churches. It will be "Reformation Sunday" in Protestant, especially in Lutheran, churches, this being the 415th anniversary of the act of Martin Luther on Oct. 31, 1517, in nailing to the door of the College Church at Wittenberg, Germany, his ninety-five theses.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- Commencing on Wednesday, the Paris stock market will have a new department called a "Bourse du Soir," or Evening Stock Exchange, which will open at 2:45 P.M., when the regular trading ends, and close at 3:30 P.M. The late trading has been instituted to permit French arbitrage firms doing business with Wall Street to operate after the opening of the New York Stock Exchange.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 29. -- A spirited rally in the second half of the game with Princeton today enabled the University of Michigan football team to remain among the undefeated elevens of the country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29 AP). -- Henry E. Bedford, New York artist, died in his berth aboard the State of Maine Express early today as the train approached this city. The body was removed from the train here.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Mrs. Mabel Willebrandt told a Republican rally tonight that "in spite of the insinuations of my self-appointed biographer, Mr. Alfred E. Smith, I have not turned wet, or even damp."

ROME. UNLlKE any other capital, Rome has not been surrounded by gardens and suburbs. Climb Monte Mario or to the dome of St. Peter's and you would see beyond the city walls the Campagna -- a wilderness, a green desolation, soggy, low-lying, malarial, fatal to health.

The rise of the motor bus and the increasing use of this form of transportation by companies formerly exclusively devoted to the operation of street railways, has brought about a reorganization of the American Electric Railway Association, a revision of its constitution, and the change in name of the group to the American Transit Association.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- With the result in doubt until the last horse had finished the course in a jump-off, the Irish Free State Army's stout-hearted riders tonight scored their first international military trophy victory in four appearances at the Boston Horse Show.

PRAGUE, Oct. 29. -- After a week's delay caused by the reluctance of the Socialist sections of the government coalition to agree to a reduction of civil service salaries, Jan Malypetr today succeeded in forming a Cabinet to succeed that of Frantisek Udrzal, who resigned chiefly on account of ill health.

Appropriations totaling $18,737,967.90 were made for philanthropic work in 1931 by the Rockefeller Foundation, whose latest report, describing the foundation's world-wide activities devoted exclusively to phil- anthropies, was made public yester- day.

JED HARRIS has tentatively booked time on the subway circuit -- the week of Nov. 21, in Jackson Heights -- for a new production. When pressed for some definite information the other day, he said that it was for one of three plays on which he was now working.

STILL gently purveying her faith in pixies. Temple Bailey spins another of her Cinderella tales in modern dress, introducing Araminta, a merry sprite, as heroine, and safely guiding the lass through the sunshine and shadow of a quest for true love and happiness.

ENGLAND is not altogether well served by laying stress on the indomitable spirit with which the English face their tremendous problems. The indomitable spirit is beyond question there, but undue insistence upon it cannot help giving rise to exaggerated notions of the desperate nature of England's case.

Josef Lhevinne, planist, played in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon what was announced as his first allChopin program to be given in New York. The printed list included the barcarolle in F sharp major, the impromptu in G flat major, three mazurkas, the F minor ballade, the sonata in B minor and finally the twelve etudes of Op. 25.

The Winter trapshooting season of the New York Athletic Club opened at Travers Island yesterday, with thirty-three gunners taking part. The wind was high, but J.H. Wantling took the High Scratch Cup with 97 out of a possible 100 targets.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Mrs. Theo Alice Ruggles Kitson, prominent sculptor and wife of Henry Hudson Kitson of New York, also a sculptor of note, died this morning at the Massachusetts Memorial Hospital following an operation. Mrs. Kitson had been making her home in Framingham for several years, and formerly lived in Quincy.
MADRID, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Spanish officials were preparing today for the visit of Premier Edouard Herriot of France, who will reach the Spanish border tomorrow morning.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 29. -- Declaring for an outright repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, a wet Republican, and Jouett Shouse, former Democratic Executive Chairman, speaking tonight before 3,000 persons in the Naval Armory, urged Michigan voters to repeal the State Constitution's drastic prohibition provision.

To the Music Editor: The controversy between several of our leading musicians over what is good musical diet for our rising generation seems to be based entirely upon orchestral presentation. Of course no musician will gainsay the importance of the orchestra as a means of education; still, one cannot help thinking that too much stress is laid upon it.
Curtis High School's football touch down Flushing High, 6 -- 0 yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island, before 6,000 persons.

THOUGH the depression has now achieved a literature which begins to rival that of the World War, few of the books about it have been widely read. The reasons for this are perhaps not difficult to understand. The course of events in the last three years has changed so rapidly that it has been difficult for contemporary interpretations to keep pace with new developments.

It was powerful Purdue against the valiant Violet of New York University yesterday at the Yankee Stadium as the Hoosier eleven, co-champion of the Big Ten in 1931, triumphed 34-9. A crowd of 25,000 was present.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 14. WITH its production at the Royal Dramatic in Stockholm, Marc Connelly's "The Green Pastures" has had its European premiere, and the Swedish critics are almost unanimous in calling it a daring experiment that has triumphed.

Autumn. IT STRIKES many New Yorkers is a perennial wonder that there is so much of nature so near the city. And nature is particularly striking in Autumn. Already the season's polychromists have swooped across the landscape, leaving such flamboyant murals that the most maniacal speed-worshiper willy-nilly stops to contemplate.

THE particular interest of this diary is in its background and its time. For its writer was in and about Paris during the Revolution, numbered among his patrons most of the important members of the court circle, in which he seems to have been always persona grata, and saw with his own eyes and wrote down with his own pen many stirring scenes.

IT may seem difficult to evoke anything beyond a dim, scholarly interest in the remote almost forgotten elegiac poetry of the Augustan Age; yet Elizabeth Hazelton Haight, while never setting foot outside the stern precincts of scholarship, has contrived to treat her subject with a living enthusiasm that makes it instantly kindle with life and reality.

Arthur S. Vernay, explorer of the Kalahari Desert and leader of eight expeditions into unfrequented areas in the East Indies and Malaya, sailed early yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for London, where he said he would apply to the colonial authorities for permit to shoot the last known specimen of the sondaicus rhinoceros in the jungle of Selangor in the Malay Federated States.

LONDON, Oct. 15, 1932. THE new season has been inaugurated with the first concert of the London Symphony Orchestra -- partly reconstituted -- conducted by Hans Weisbach, who introduced to us Bach's "Die Kunst der Fuge" in the orchestral version prepared by Wolfgang Graeser.

Quite a furor developed in chain-store circles during the week when it became known that a small-town chain-store organization through its house organ had addressed an insistent appeal to all its employes to support the Presidential candidate preferred by the heads of the company.

WHEN George Arliss passed, through this city the other day on his way back to Hollywood, he informed the inquisitive press of an ambition to play Voltaire. Now he has arrived in the cinema city and almost at once Warner Brothers make the unusually interesting announcement that Paul Green has been assigned to write a script on the life of Voltaire for Mr. Arliss.

FOR a month I have been traveling in America. In more than a score of cities and States, stretching from one coast to the other, I have made a political inquiry. By train, motor car, airplane and on foot I have wandered 10,000 miles. I have talked with, observed and listened to many hundreds of people on trains, in restaurants, on the streets, in speakeasies, in hotel lobbies, in clubs and in their own houses.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Encouraged in the belief that he will carry New England because of his reconciliation with former Governor Smith and Mr. Smith's speech in Boston, Governor Roosevelt sped into Massachusetts today for a trip combining political campaigning and a visit to his son John at Groton School.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Williston Academy's eleven defeated Wilbraham today, 21-0. McGonnigle scored Williston's first goal early in the first quarter. Dave Todd scored the other two by intercepting forward passes in the third quarter.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Following is the text of the speech made by former Governor Smith here tonight:

John McCambridge's War Plane, talked of last Fall as a worthy competitor for the Kentucky Derby of 1932, captured the closing-day feature at Empire City yesterday, where the regular jockey club season came to an end.

VERA CRUZ, Mexico, Oct. 29. -- Dr. Salvador Mendoza, one of the drafters of the new civil code, announced today that State authorities had decided to draw up a law to establish a system of birth control in Vera Cruz.
SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 29. -- An aggressive Villanova football team today downed Bucknell, 13-0, in a game played for the educational fund of the Scranton Kiwanis Club.

The world financial situation "may make it expedient for us to cancel the war debts owed us," but such action would be "foolish" unless it is accompanied by European agreements to cut down armaments, Dr. Harry Elmer Barnes, historian, said at the closing sessions of the German-American Congress at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 29. -- Exeter defeated Worcester Academy 25 -- 12 today in a game replete with action. Worcester tallied all of its points in the last five minutes of play, Bernard Alexs taking two Exeter kickoffs 80 and 75 yards respectively for touchdowns.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16. -- President Hoover's selection of Dr. Epitacio Pessoa, former President or Brazil, to fill the vacancy left by the death of Jules Jusserand, late French Ambassador, as non-national commissioner in the Permanent Commission of Arbitration between the United States and Great Britain is regarded here as a happy choice.

GENEVA, Oct. 28. -- American representation in the economic and monetary preparatory committees, whose sessions will open here on Monday, promises now to be about three times greater than that of any other country. Other nations have named only one expert each to the two committees.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Andy Howe, bay gelding trotter, driven by Cliff Woodruff, won the 2:10 class which featured the matinee at Weequahic Park today.

BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- Under livelier trading, with renewed public participation, the Boerse was definitely bullish today. The majority of the stock list made advances of 1 to 2 points, a few gaining up to 4 or 5 points. The closing generally was at the day's highest prices.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- France's new disarmament and security plan was explained to Norman H. Davis and J. Theodore Marriner this afternoon by Premier Herriot and Joseph PaulBoncour, War Minister, in conversations at the Ministries of Foreign Affairs and War.

TO the lay reader, the average collector and most bookmen, the subject of incunabula means something dull, flat and unprofitable. Its name is intimately associated with ponderous works of theological doctrine, heavy with rhetoric, logic or the exact sciences.

John F. Grimm, chairman of the Cheney Brothers reorganization committee, announced yesterday that more than 89 per cent of the bonds of the corporation had been deposited under its plan of reorganization. All creditor banks and holders of more than the necessary amounts of stock had concurred in the plan, he said.

GERMANY'S demand for equality in armaments has again focused the attention of the world on Part V of the Versailles Treaty, containing the military clauses which reduced the German Army to a virtual police component of 100,000 professional troops.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 29. -- Ralph A. Powers, L.S. Haskins, Beekman Pool and G.D. Debevoise entered the semi-finals today in the annual invitation squash racquets tournament being played at the Nassau Country Club.

The Coast Guard and the police of New York City were accused yesterday by agents of the Department of Justice of having known of the operations of a $7,000,000-a-year rumring, said to have been broken up with the arrest Friday night of seven of its alleged members and the seizure of a 600-pound safe believed to contain records of its transactions.

Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr., radio director for the Women's Division of the National Democratic campaign committee, announced yesterday a list of radio addresses by prominent women on behalf of the Roosevelt-Garner candidacy in the coming week.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 29. -- A fast-running veteran halfback, Stanley Saluski of Chicago, slashed his way through a slowly yielding Mississippi State football team today to help Indiana University gain a 19-to-0 intersectional victory.
CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 29 (AP). -- The text of President Hoover's speech here follows:

THE office of President of the United States has been held, in the course of 143 years, by thirty men. No two of these men have been alike, for standardization has yet to invade the White House. The nation produces one Jefferson, one Hayes, and then, every time, it breaks the mold.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Hill turned defeat aside in the last period of its traditional game with Lawrenceville today and gained a 7to-7 tie with only three minutes left to play.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27. -- Despite a last-minute definite trend to President Hoover, political observers believe that Missouri will give Governor Roosevelt a majority of at least 100,000 in the election on Nov. 8 Many estimates place the figure at 200,000.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28. -- One thing about the "subcrisis" of the food and goods shortage here that differentiates it from the troubles in the rest of the world is that the causes can readily be ascertained and are linked in a logical and chronological chain.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Published reports that the home of President Hoover on the Stanford University campus was being wired for a final campaign speech to be delivered there by the Chief Executive brought explanations from

VIENNA, Oct. 16. -- Two interesting old Viennese customs, the Vintage Festival and Reserl Day, were combined yesterday in a single celebration of the anticipated excellent vintage of 1932. In olden times the first girl born in any Viennese winegrower's family was always christened Theresa (Reserl), for it is always on or about Oct. 15 -- St.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, announced today that The News had bought The Chicago Evening Post. Final issues of The Post were published today, and Monday the former publisher, Knowlton L. Ames, will join The News as assistant to Mr. Knox and The Post will be consolidated with The News.

ALBANY, Oct. 29. -- Governor Roosevelt today commuted to life imprisonment the death sentence of Benjamin Gordon, known as "cockeyed Benny," in view of the assistance he gave New York City police in convicting Jack Zaroff, the slayer of Policeman Maurice O'Brien in January, 1930.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 (AP). -- President von Hindenburg, Chancellor von Papen and Otto Braun, Premier of Prussia, talked for an hour today trying to straighten out the controversy between the State and federal governments over the administration of Prussia.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 29. -- Sparkling line play and a deadly passing game brought West Virginia a 34-to-7 victory over Marquette before a homecoming crowd of 12,000 today.
COLUMBUS, Oct. 29. -- The deadlock jinx again haunted the Ohio State University football team today as it played a 7-to-7 tie with Wisconsin before 17,000 spectators.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Massachusetts State for the second year in a row upset its old local rival, Amherst, by vanquishing the Purple and White today before a crowd of 7,000, on Alumni Field, 21 -- 6.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29. -- Notre Dame was rudely jolted out of its national championship aspirations before 65,000 spectators in the Pitt Stadium today, bowing to the Pittsburgh eleven, 12 to 0. The Ramblers flung forward passes wildly for loss after loss in the closing stages in an attempt to overtake the Panthers, who scored twice in the final period.

ROME, Oct. 29 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini inauguarted the Fascist Decennial Exposition this morning and relived the first stirring three years of fascism before he came into power. The exhibition illustrates the story of the tumultuous days from 1919 to Oct. 18, 1922, when the blackshirts were fighting Communists and Socialists in the streets.

DURING the past fortnight the Abbey Theatre troupe from Dublin has been acting a series of Irish plays at the Martin Beck Theatre. According to present plans, it will continue there another fortnight preliminary to a swing around the great American circle.

GENEVA, Oct. 28. -- Monday begins a period probably the most momentous in the history of the League of Nations. Every grave issue in the world comes up in Geneva in that period and every power in the world will be represented here. The depression, disarmament and the undeclared war in Manchuria and all their offspring will crowd on the League stage in what is left of 1932.

Plans for an intensive promotion of modernistic furniture styles for Spring, 1933, are receiving hearty endorsement from manufacturers throughout the country, it was learned here yesterday. The producers feel that intelligent promotion of modernistic styles will force retailers to purchase substantial stocks on initial orders and end, for the Spring season at least, the tendency toward limiting early purchases to small quantities and supplementing stocks later by heavy reorders.

IN a setting portraying the famous restaurants and dancing casinos of the world, the second annual Peacock Ball will be held on Friday night at the Waldorf-Astoria. The entire ballroom suite will be in use, with the various smaller ballrooms done into reproductions of other places, in keeping with the theme, "Casinos du Monde," chosen for the event.

FANTASTIC as is the theme of "Six Hours to Live," the picture which was at the Roxy, William Dieterle's gifted direction and the capable performances of the principals cause it to be an unusually compelling piece of work. It may disappoint those who look for a final flash of the hero and heroine in each other's arms, but it will please others who want imagination and subtlety in screen entertainment.

The executive committee of the board of higher education served notice upon the student body of City College yesterday that wholesale expulsions would follow attempts to "strike" in protest against the suspension of eleven undergraduates as an aftermath of a demonstration in front of night court Wednesday night.

OMAHA, Oct. 27 -- The clamor of the campaign now reaching a crescendo can do no better hereabouts than share public attention with the government's local liquor syndicate trial, which has been going on for the past fortnight.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Entering the home territory of Governor Roosevelt today, Colonel William J. Donovan received a tumultuous welcome from Republicans of the Hudson Valley. Enthusiastic audiences throughout Dutchess County hailed him as he assailed the pretensions of Governor Roosevelt as a farm expert and struck once more at Lieut. Gov. Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- An emergency relief loan of $274,300 was made available today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for alleviating distress in fourteen counties of Tennessee during November and December.

Affiliated Products, Inc., and Subsidiaries -- Nine months ended Sept. 30: Net profit after taxes and other charges, $533,690, equal to $1.39 a share on 382,800 no par capital shares. Quarter ended Sept. 30: Net profit, $225,364, equal to 58 cents a share, against $152,764, or 40 cents a share, in preceding quarter.

STRONG confirmation of the feasibility of the northern North Atlantic route for airline use is contained in the report of one of the two commissions into which the International Congress of Transoceanic Aviators, which met in Rome last May, resolved itself.

THE dance is definitely to have a place in the Century of Progress exposition, at Chicago. Though the idea has been discussed for something more than four years, conditions both within and without the precincts of the exposition have undergone so many fluctuations that it has not been safe to count on anything specific for dancing until now.

GENEVA, Oct. 29. -- Experts consulted by the disarmament conference's committee on effectives made a report today substantially supporting the French view that the German police must be taken into account in calculating the Reich's army as a measuring stick for reducing other armies.

MANY requests for easy history stories come to parents, teachers and librarians. Often the needs of small readers are apparently well satisfied by such volumes as Eggieston's "Stories of Great Americans for Little Americans," or Blaisdell's "American History for Little Folks."

The fall of the pound sterling in the last two weeks has been explained in two ways: as a deliberate act of British monetary policy and as the simple outcome of normal foreign-exchange dealing operating on a currency cut loose from gold. Neither of these explanations is completely satisfactory by itself, according to bankers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A unique patent law passed a little more than two years ago has resulted to date in the granting of thirty-nine patents on flowers, fruits and other plant life.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29. -- Minneseta unpacked a driving power-house attack, centring around big Jack Manders today and swept to a 7-0 victory over Northwestern before 35,000 chilled fans.

THE Blessed Damozel, as all persons who are acquainted with the story of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood know was Elizabeth Eleanor Siddall, long the model of Dante Gabriel Rossetti and for a briefly tragic period his wife.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- The powerful Michigan State eleven defeated Syracuse today, 27 to 13.

ROME, Oct. 28. -- Hard times are nothing new in the Italian Kingdom's brief history, for lean years have been more numerous than years of prosperity in the half century since it achieved unity and independence. This explains why Italy has the least grumbling about the depression and perhaps why the pinch is felt less severely in Italy than elsewhere.

An exhibition of nineteenth century wedding gowns, all worn at weddings in this city, has been arranged by the Museum of the City of New York and will be opened to the public on Tuesday. Tomorrow a private view will be held for members of the museum and their friends.

SOME of Germany's inventive minds, thinking of the future development of aviation, have left the common roads of aircraft construction in search of entirely new methods in plane design, says a Berlin dispatch to The Associated Press, describing some sensational innovations in construction at the all-German Aircraft Exposition there.

Negotiations between companies in the radio manufacturing group are reaching the stage where a new plan for reconstructing their relationships to meet the principal objections set forth in the government's suit against them is likely to be formulated within a few days.

THREE years ago this month a lean-faced New Englander was driving along a Massachusetts roadway lined with trees "in russet mantle clad." Famous and successful in a field foreign and even utterly alien to his traditions -- the field of Broadway theatrical production -- he was planning a permanent retreat to the quiet and solitude of his country place at North Easton, just beyond the hills which were silhouetted against the blue horizon.

THE CHERRY TREE" continues the chronicle of life on an East Anglian farm, begun by Adrian Bell in "The Silver Ley." In the earlier book the writer tells how, wearied of life in London, he went to the country and worked for a farmer in Sussex, eventually settling on his own farm.

Managers of investment trusts have been cheered recently because their persistent efforts in the last three years to improve the practices of their companies and to maintain liquidity in the face of almost incessantly declining prices are beginning to be recognized.

ROME. THE quarrels of Guelphs and Ghibellines is an eternal jack-in-the-box. How often have we not heard that it has been settled once and for all! When Victoria-Louise of Prussia married the Duke of Brunswick, shortly before the World War; and again, recently, in February, 1929, when the "Conciliation" took place between Church and State in Italy.

THE crisis in the affairs of the Opera-Comique has finally passed. People are saying that its maladies are to be healed thanks to the mysterious intervention of a silent partner who will supplement the government backing with an annual contribution of 4,000,000 francs.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 29. -- "I am one of those who think the price of silver will not stay where some would have it stay -- at these low prices -- but once more come into its own," said Charles McCrea, Minister of Mines in Ontario, at an advertising men's convention held this week in the Royal York Hotel here.

The total deficit of ten important producers of steel, including the seven largest in the country, in the third quarter of this year was $37,367,705, according to the magazine Steel. These ten companies have an ingot capacity of 55,447,000 tons, or 82 per cent of the nation's total.

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- Recently compiled figures show that French agricultural exports are probably harder hit than any other branch of the foreign trade. There has, in fact, been a hardly disguised economic war between the various European countries, each one trying to protect its own at the expense of the outsider.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Just as apparently, everything that could be said in the political campaign had been said, a new voice was raised by Alfred E. Smith, this week.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The wedding of Miss Marie Louise Vondermuhll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Vondermuhll of 59 Warren Place, Montclair, to James French Baldwin, son of Mrs. Margaret French Baldwin of Boston, Mass., took place this afternoon at 4 o'clock, at the Vondermuhll home.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I feel, as do many leaders of American industry, that the low point of the business depression is definitely past.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 29 (Canadian Press). -- A heavy movement of wheat from country points today precapitated a last-hour flood of hedging sales on the Grain Exchange here and prices at the close were 1 7/8 to cents a bushel lower than yesterday's final quotations.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 28 -- A move ment for substantial reductions it rates charged by power companies serving North Carolina now seems almost certain of success, either before or after the General Assembly meets in January.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 27 -- A proposal for an exchange of news between this city and Toledo, Spain, for which it was named, has been received here by Dr. Henry J. Doermann, president of the University of the City of Toledo, from Adoracion Gomez Camareo, editor of El Castellano.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Oct. 22 increased, following the holiday week, and were larger than the weekly average in recent months, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.
BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- William Ellery Channing Eustis, for more than half a century a prominent mining and metallurgical engineer of this city, died today at his home in Milton at the age of 83.

Admitting they face the most crucial period in their history at the present time, importers sought vainly throughout last week for a means of stemming the drive against forign goods now being carried on by domestic manufacturers with the coperation of government officials.

Rival port cities are trying to win away the freight ship lines of the port of New York and are using inducements to the large passenger lines as a "smoke screen," according to Albert B. Hager, vice president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and chairman of its committee on port and terminals.

LONDON, WHEN Bertrand Russell produces a treatise on the philosophy of mathematics, there are few persons anywhere who are competent to review it. But when he discusses such a subject as "Education and the Social Order" (Allen) he exposes his work to the comments of a large number of critics who are quite capable of following and appraising his arguments.

FOR three months Republicans and Democrats have carried their battle for the Presidency into every section of the country, seeking votes on the merits of the candidates they have nominated and the position they have taken on the issues of the day.

Scoring in every period, the George Washington High School football team trounced Stuyvesant High, 41 to 0, yesterday at George Washington High School Stadium for its fourth victory in as many games, and with its goal line still uncrossed.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 29. -- Susquehanna University defeated Swarthmore, 13 to 10, today, when Carmichael recovered Sipler's blocked kick for a touchdown in the last three minutes of play.

Mrs. Alton B. Parker, widow of the Democratic Presidential nominee who was defeated in 1904 by Roosevelt, urged voters in a statement made public yesterday by the Republican National Committee to support President Hoover for re-election.

STOCKHOLM. ICELANDIC paintings, in exhibitions in two galleries in Stockholm that opened in connection with an "Icelandic Week" devoted to the arts and allied cultural activities, reveal a new national art in the making, already so far advanced that it must be included in any cosmopolitan panorama of whatever is significant in the modern expression.

COLOR, like any other phase of fashion, often comes unberalded and slips quietly into the mode, to become later the most important thing in the sartorial picture. Watch it spread, like a panic, until, having become too popular, it passes beyond the standard of taste and chic.

ANTIQUE furniture, once introduced into the home mainly because of the collector's enthusiasm for the old, is now carefully selected for its special adaptation to everyday needs. Cabinet work incorporating inlay, painted panels and delicate and profuse carving, created for reception rooms of great mansions, is, of course, still prized, but the pieces most in demand today are of the smaller, more intimate types.

PARIS. IN this year of economy, the greatest task of the Paris couturiers has been to prevent charm from being submerged in the rising wave of utilitarian fashions, and they have risen to the occasion.

Flemish, French and Italian tapestries, old English furniture and silver, Persian rugs and art objects, the property of the late Katherine Clemnons Gould, Mrs. John Gellatly, Mr. and Mrs. John Borden of Chicago and other owners, will be sold at auction on Friday and Saturday afternoons at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., where they will be on exhibition until the time of sale.

MEMBERS of the Manhattanville Alumnae Association have arranged a luncheon, to be followed by bridge, for next Thursday in the Seaglade at the St. Regis in behalf of their charitable enterprises. The funds realized will be devoted to the care of the ill and needy during the coming Winter.

THIS curious tale of the Idaho frontier is founded largely upon fact -- or so, at any rate, the author has given us to understand. It is a story intimately associated with the history of Fort Hall and the Bottoms district near Pocatello, Idaho, and some of its principals were personally known to the author.

Merchandising policies adopted by voluntary and corporate grocery chains in the coming six months will determine the outcome of the current battle between producers of private and nationally advertised brands of food products, marketing authorities agreed here yesterday.

EDDIE CANTOR, the funny man with those banjo eyes, arrived from Hollywood Tuesday morning. At 2 P.M. he had finished his breakfast, delivered a final ultimatum to the effect that he would not sing that ditty about the old lady's home, cut many pages of gags out of a radio routine the boys had worked up for him, tried out two new songs and was ready to talk about his film, "The Kid From Spain."

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The days on which history is made often are recognized to be such only later, when events have taken their course and when people find time for retrospective inquiry. Friday, Oct. 14 of this year, will sometime be admitted to be a milestone on the road of politics in Europe.

SOME of the statements and prophecies which President Hoover made in 1928 during his Presidential campaign are now being recalled by his opponents, and contrasts are being drawn between the promises of his administration and the fulfillment.

ST. NAZAIRE, France, Oct. 29. -- Amid scenes of national rejoicing, France's new 75,000-ton transatlantic liner Normandie, the largest ship in the world, was launched with great success today in the presence of President and Mme. Lebrun and throngs which came from all parts of France.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP). -- Twenty years at hard labor -- the limit of the law for manslaughter -- was the court's answer today as George W. Courson, former prison gruard, pleaded for mercy in the death of Arthur Maillefert, strangled to death in a sweat-box last June.

Domestic corporation bonds and foreign loans were irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the dullest trading in more than a year. Declines of 1 to 5 points were noted in the railroad group, erasing the gains of the previous day in some instances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Twelve State functions, including the judicial reception, which is already a part of the season's social history, make up the official entertainment program announced today at the White House.

ECONOMIC depression has had disastrous effect upon the practical affairs of many musicians, great and small. Very prominent artists have suffered in certain instances to an extent of which the public does not dream. Men and women whose lifelong profession has been music, in which they have reaped richly deserved honors and given the most distinguished public service, are in many cases in dire financial straits.

St. Peter's Prep of Jersey City overpowered Seton Hall Prep of South Orange at the Jersey City baseball park yesterday, 20 to 0, for its third straight victory. The feature of the game was a 35-yard pass from McAleer to Laders, who ran 20 yards for a touchdown in the third period.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- France's new disarmament proposals and General Maxime Weygand's reported opposition to some of its most important suggestions have provided much material this week for speculation and for argument.

THE up-to-date campaign spellbinder in the 1932 political campaign carries a loud-speaker in a suitcase. If a heckler tries to shout him down he is easily able to roar forth all the louder. His voice can be magnified a hundred times and he has the power to literally blow the audience out of their seats, but, of course, he does not go to that extreme, because he is after their votes.
Cessation of the city school-building program was assailed last night by Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, at a rally at Franklin Manor, 836 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- Lebanon Valley turned back the St. Joseph College eleven today by 19 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- President Hoover gave warning today as he renewed his campaign on his way back from Indianapolis that the people's very welfare would be "jeopardized by transferring the government to the Democrats."

A HOHENZOLLERN NAZI. GERMANY appears to have had some success with a favored policy of America's pioneer West. In days when pistols belonged to the haberdashery of every well-dressed man, certain obstreperous characters were quelled by giving them the silver star of a sheriff.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 27. -- As the closing days of the national Presidential campaign approach the increasing strength of the revolt against President Hoover in Oregon is becoming more apparent than ever before, so much so that many cautious forecasters of results are now making unqualified predictions that Governor Roosevelt will carry the State, which is normally three-to-one Republican, and which has gone Democratic only once since 1859.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican Mayoralty nominee, addressing a mass meeting of Staten Island Republicans last night, attacked Surrogate John P. O'Brien, his Democratic opponent, for having failed to lay before the voters any sort of an economy program.

Every fisherman dreams of a place where he can catch all the fish he wants, a place where there is a never-ending source of hard fighters of his favorite species, a spot where he can hide away and forget the cares of the world while enjoying what to him is the greatest sport on earth.

This Presidential campaign approaches its end amid a general conviction that a great political change is impending. It was said of WILLIAM PITT, when Prime Minister of England, that he had received "secret warnings which, fore"bode the cyclones in which Govern"ments go down."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Secretary Stimson declared in a speech here tonight that the Republican liquor plank made adequate provision for Federal protection of dry States in the event of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, but that the Democrats relied merely on "pious requests" to the States to control the liquor traffic.

Miscellaneous bonds and warrants of several small municipalities called for redemption but with definite dates for the redemptions not stated, and parts of two issues, one foreign and the other an industrial issue, for repayment in future months, were the principal additions made last week to the list of bonds called for payment prior to their maturity dates.

NEWARK, Del., Oct. 29. -- Wake Forest College of North Carolina defeated the University of Delaware, 7 to 0, today Myers, substitute fullback, called the hall over and then lan through the Delaware line for the extra point.

THE recent induction of Hermann Oelrichs and several other men into the Society of Tammany recalls the social aspect of that old organization. Originally formed in protest against aristocratic influences in the young Republic, Tammany soon became an instrument of politics.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much interested in reading in THE TIMES Magazine about Sir Christopher Wren and in the statement made that his influence is felt in America.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 29. -- Yale defeated Lafayette today, 21 to 0, in a 150-pound football game which was stubbornly contested until late in the final period when two Yale touchdowns decided the outcome.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- Norman Thomas, in an address at Tremont Temple tonight, took up the charge that "socialism is impracticable" and retorted that the worst graft and incompetence in the United States was in business, in privately owned and operated industries, and not in government.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Two long marches, brilliant in their execution and irresistible in their power, gave Brown a 14-0 victory over Harvard today as the Crimson was tumbled from the ranks of the undefeated and the Brunonian unbeaten record remained intact.

For the first time an arbitration clause in deposit agreements will be used by a protective committee for bonds, it was announced yesterday. The committee acting in behalf of holders of first mortgage-bonds of the Hotel Drake, 440 Park Avenue, has been authorized to use the facilities of the American Arbitration Association.

WACO, TEXAS. THE whole conduct and attitude of the 2,000 pupils who attend the Waco High School each year have been transformed, in the opinion of their principal, through the organization of an unusually complete school municipality.

Ely Culbertson and his teammates, Oswald Jacoby, Theodore A. Lightner, and Michael Gottlieb, were eliminated from the annual Vanderbilt Cup contract bridge tournament at the Ritz Carlton Hotel when they were beaten in the semi-final round last night by David Burnstine, Howard Schenken, Charles S. Lochridge, and Richard L. Frey by a margin of 1,500 points.

Manhattan's rapidly improving football team battled to a 20-7 victory over Oglethorpe University of Atlanta in a thrill-packed intersectional game at the Polo Grounds yesterday. A crowd of 10,000 watched the Jaspers regain winning form after two straight defeats.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If beer is ever legalized again with a 4 per cent or 3 per cent alcoholic content, or any other stipulated percentage, there is going to be trouble. The un-American espionage system brought in by prohibition will be continued and the army of snoopers will be haling before the courts offenders selling 4 1/2 per cent or 5 per cent beer.

AMONG the workers in the modern theatre the scene designers are the ablest. Although the best playwrights, actors and directors frequently go astray, the best scene designers rarely fail. As Mr. Simonson candidly declares in the foreword to this splendid volume, the scene designer's task is the simplest:
SHATTERED last year by the economic crisis, the British Labor party has sustained a further shock. The veteran Arthur Henderson, now approaching the age of 70, has resigned the leadership.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16. -- When the final shot was fired in the civil war that shook Brazil from the Amazon Valley to the pampas of Rio Grande do Sul, 3,000 miles apart, it was found that Sao Paulo had organized practically overnight large bodies of extraordinarily efficient war workers.

Scoring in every period except the last, the C.C.N.Y. eleven defeated Brooklyn College, 18 -- 7, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday in the first gridiron meeting in the history of the two municipal institutes. The victory ended a two-frame losing streak for City College.

THE interest of younger members of society in the annual Victory Ball is shown by the large number of debutantes of this season and former years who have formed several committees to aid in preparations for the event, which is to be given the night of Nov. 10 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Norse Sagas. The Norse Sagas seem to be a favorite subject for a number of writers in THE TIMES editions. They have much to say about Lief. Long before Lief was born the Sagas refer to a great land far in the western ocean, and they call it "Irland it Mikla."

DR. PHILIP GOSSE, whose "History of Piracy" has just been published by Longmans, Green Co., became interested in the freebooters of the sea when he was a very small boy. That in itself is nothing unusual, for most small boys are pirates at heart, but young Gosse had the inestimable privilege of hearing pirate stories from the lips of Robert Louis Stevenson himself.

THE SHADOW FLIES" is startlingly unlike any of Miss Macaulay's previous work. From the author of "Orphan Island" and "Told by an Idiot" one felt a right to expect pleasant satire, mild in appearance but caustic in fact, on the problems and customs of modern life; nor did the later "Staying With Relations," though a departure from her former style prepare us for this careful presentation of life in seventeenth-century England.

MUCH interest is being shown by many prominent men and women in the performance of "Music in the Air," the forthcoming musical production at the Alvin Theatre, which has been taken over for the night of Nov. 16 as a benefit. The proceeds will be devoted to the philanthropic enterprises of the Babies' Wards Committee of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital and Medical School.

I am a Republican because I believe that the Republican party is by tradition and practice a better team-playing party than the Democratic party. It has a fringe of irreconcilable individualists, but they are the products of locality rather than doctrine and seldom represent any real cleavage in the views or action of the body of the party.

SO different is this world of today from that of the '60s and '70s it seems almost incredible that the two should be separated only by the length of a fairly long lifetime. Those who were children then are the grandparents of today, men and women who have seen changes more rapid and sweeping than were ever before known.
GENESEO, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Lucier, a bay gelding, owned by Ward A. Wickwire of Buffalo, today won the annual three-and-a-half mile steeplechase for the Genesee Valley Cup.

The Dominican Republic, which occupies the eastern part of the island of Santo Domingo or Haiti, is not having the difficulty in balancing its budget which nations throughout the old and the new world are experiencing. It was announced yesterday at the consulate of the republic, 17 Battery Place, that for the first six months of the current year the national budget showed a surplus of more than $117,000.

Politics has its value, after all Governor ROOSEVELT'S use, in his own sense, of WILLIAM GRAHAM SUMNER'S "The Forgotten Man" has led to the publication of an admirable article in The American Mercury by Dr. KELLER, Sumner Professor of the Science of Society at Yale.

BUFFALO, Oct. 27. -- The opinion may be heard among experienced political observers that Buffalo probably has as large a proportion of Hoover supporters as may be found in any city in the State and perhaps in the United States. By tests which ordinarily have guided election forecasts in the past, this is one corner of the country which should show a substantial Hoover plurality.

Warns on Truck Speed. TRUCKING companies, by requiring trips to be made in insufficient time, cause drivers to travel at excessive speeds, Commissioner Charles A. Harnett of the New York State Bureau of Motor Vehicles, declared recently.
CRANFORD, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Scoring seven points in each of the last three periods, Cranford High School's football team conquered the previously unbeaten Westfield High eleven, 21 -- 16, today.

Completing the field-trial season in the East, the American Spaniel Club has scheduled its annual trials for Saturday, Nov. 19, on the Ivor Estate in the Dix Hills at South Huntington, L.I., through the courtesy of Charles Gould.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Little Vermont leads the way. A State with only 360,000 people is doing the best job of the Whole family of States in the financial education, of its citizens. More exactly, the State Chamber of Commerce at Springfield is doing the work in behalf of the general welfare.

Speaking last night from Station WRNY on behalf of the candidacies of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch of the Independent Judges Party, Charles C. Burlingham, former president of the Bar Association, attributed the bipartisan nominations of Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer to two principal causes.

Several hundred men and women Communists, shouting denunciations of Fascism and Mussolini and cheering for communism and Italian political prisoners, attempted to march to the Italian Consulate General at 134 East Seventieth Street yesterday to hold a protest demonstration and to present a resolution.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29. -- Yale's band marched under the goal posts of the Bowl tonight at the head of a wildly roaring Eli snake dance, for the Blue had come back from the shadows of defeat into the blaze of a brilliant victory over Dartmouth. The Green's ambition to beat a team of Yale is still unfulfilled.
Commodity prices worked lower yesterday, and in the grains the December position in wheat declined to a record low price. Cotton, rubber, silk, hides and others declined.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Oct. 29. -- Emmet Corrigan, well known stage and screen actor, dropped dead of a heart attack while watching a card game in the Maskers Club this afternoon. A rescue squad from the Los Angeles Fire Department attempted to revive him but failed.

A TWELVE-CYLINDER horizontally opposed engine of 225brake horsepower is the outstanding feature of a new type of motor coach for city service announced by the White Company. Departing radically from conventional design, the cylinders in the new engine, instead of operating in an upright position as in the present bus, truck or automobile, operate from a horizontal position.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 29. -- The North Carolina eleven shook off its jinx today and unset North Caro- lina State College, 13 -- 0.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- A hard-charging Union College eleven triumphed in its traditional game with Williams today, 6 to 0, scoring its first victory over the Purple since 1926 before the largest crowd of the season here.

HAVANA, Oct. 25, -- Declaring that it is a "cruel jest" to say that prosperity can be brought back to Cuba by restriction of the sugar crop, Dr. Viriato Gutierrez, president of the Sugar Institute, the official body controlling the industry, issued a statement to the press yesterday analyzing the present situation and intimating that the government realizes that the Chadbourne plan is a temporary measure at best.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Suffering a heart attack while apparently recovering from an operation for gallstones, performed on Monday, Frederick Gilkyson of West Trenton, Adjutant General of New Jersey since 1918, died suddenly at Mercer Hospital here today.

Supper dances were given last night by various organizations. A Bolero Ball opened the season of the Romany Club at the Waldorf-Astoria. The club rooms were decorated in Argentine fashion, and a special entertainment enlisted the Cansinos, Argentine dancers; Reva Reyes and her Gaucho Guitarists, and other dancers and singers.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 29. -- Cy Grant, sophomore halfback from Cornelia, Ga., spun and punched his path through Florida's line today for three touchdowns to lead Georgia to its first gridiron victory of the season, 33 to 12.

THIS year, particularly, motorists would do well to consider Winter preparation of their cars from the angle of whether they can afford not to spend the money for it. The average car in use today is older and more worn than was the case in other seasons.

The most ambitious American exhibition thus far prepared by the Museum of Modern Art will open to the public next Wednesday, remaining for three months. It covers seventy years, from 1862 to 1932, and the roster contains names of the utmost significance in the annals of art in this country.

BUFFALO, Oct. 29. -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman, in the final address of his up-State campaign for the Governorship here tonight, struck at Colonel Donovan's record and utterances on prohibition, declared that prohibition was a State issue no less than a national one and asserted that the Republican position offered no solution of the problem, "but rather a substitute as dangerous and unsatisfactory as the noble experiment itself."

THE season of rumors having passed, it is possible to form an idea of what is in the offing. Certainly the tales of dearth ahead were grossly exaggerated, and at least it can be definitely stated that we are in for no shortage of piano concertos.

HAVING established his reputation as a novelist who can delve deep into human motives and portray emotion, Frank Swinnerton has elected to assume a more playful role in the writing of "Georgian House." And who in these parlous days will deny that a little playfulness is not an agreeable variation from novels overburdened with psychology and the cast of pale (too often, exceedingly pale) thought?
NORMAN THOMAS, Socialist candidate for President, has stated the outstanding issues of the campaign, as he sees them, in the following words:

IN her latest novel Miss V. Sackville-West has abandoned the mood of mellow reminiscence which colored her previous books, "The Edwardians" and "All Passion Spent." She still writes with a full consciousness of the importance of the past and she views contemporary men and events in their relation to it; but she is vitally concerned in "Family History" with England's present.

NASSAU, Oct. 25. -- The Bahama Islands, at one time the richest country in the world and one of the last to feel the economic depression, are beginning to take account of their finances. On Nov. 1 the English Governor of this British possession will summon a special session of the Legislature to consider measures calculated to put the colony on an "even keel" until world conditions improve.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 29. -- Alabama's power proved too much for Kentucky today, and the Crimson Tide, after trailing, 7 to 6, until near the end of the game, swept over the Wildcats for another touchdown and a 12-to-7 victory. It was Alabama's tenth straight victory over Kentucky.

De Witt Clinton High School's football team remained unbeaten and unscored upon by defeating Evander Childs High, 19 to 0, yesterday at Ohio Field before a crowd of 5,000. The triumph was the fourth straight.

MADRID, Oct. 28. -- South of the Atlas Mountains the French Foreign Legion, which has been converted from a road-making into a fighting force once more, has dug in for the Winter. France is quietly but effectively "penetrating" the territory south of the mountains in her vast scheme of uniting Morocco and Algeria.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the advent of his Imperial Majesty Pahlavi, our beloved country has begun to advance in an astonishing manner. During this short lapse of time much has been accomplished, and many reforms have been realized.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic nominee for Mayor; Magistrate David Hirshfield and Edward Cadley, Democratic leader of the Seventeenth Assembly District, Brooklyn, had a narrow escape from serious injury last night when the car in which they were speeding from one Democratic rally to another was in a collision with another car at Sumner Avenue and Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn.

ONE of the most remarkable developments of American finance since the turn of the century has been the growth of trusteeship. A two-year study by Wood, Struthers Co. entitled "Trusteeship of American Endowments," soon to be published by Macmillan, brings out the increasing importance of this feature of our financial system.

While the Rev. Rollin Dodd, rector of All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, storm centre of a controversy with members of the vestry, was preparing yesterday to hold services in the church today despite the fact that the outer gate remains under lock and key, Manuel J. Roure of 148 West 117th Street, clerk of the vestry, issued a statement denouncing the rector and also criticizing Bishop William T. Manning.

TO answer the question, whether the financial tide is turning is to indulge in prophecy, and prophecy has shattered a good many promising reputations in last few years. One need only recall the economic doctors who assured us in August of 1929 that nothing but uninterrupted prosperity was ahead; the chief of state who in March, 1930, grave trade reaction only sixty days more to last.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 29. -- Choate School's sturdy football team today accounted for its fourth consecutive triumph by turning back Loomis, 27-0. The victors remain unbeaten and unscored upon.

UP-TO-THE-MINUTE comments on such timely subjects as war debts, unemployment relief, taxation, administrative economy, the gold standard, overproduction and the tariff will be covered by broadcasts under the auspices of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education beginning Nov. 12.
AMERICAN FINE ARTS BUILDING -- Sixty-sixth annual exhibition of the American Water-Color Society. Opened to the public Oct. 27, closes Nov. 14. Reviewed Oct. 26 and on this page.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29. -- This city will complete tomorrow its arrangements to meet President Hoover when he stops here Monday for a campaign address. Workmen will decorate the streets along the line of the automobile parade.

ROME, Oct. 15. -- One of the most typical manifestations of presentday Italy is the increasing enthusiasm with which the youth of the country is dedicating itself to sport. Italians, as a whole, are endowed by nature with excellent physiques, but in past years they did little to exercise their bodies.

The State Banking Department is seeking a way to surmount legal obstacles which prevent it from borrowing from the Reconstruction Fi- nance Corporation to make possible a payment to depositors of closed banks, it was disclosed yesterday when members of a depositors committee of the Bank of United States came to the department to demand that a loan be asked.

HAS the city university in modern industrial America a responsibility for inspiring the leisure life of all the people, for giving their existence a significance and a beauty it would otherwise lack? Chancellor John G. Bowman, in a striking report to his board of trustees last week, has proposed re-stating the policy of the University of Pittsburgh with such a responsibility as a main tenet.

PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Hotchkiss School of Lakeville, Conn., downed Pawling School's football team, 6 to 0, today. The victors tallied their touchdown midway in the final period. Bosworth intercepted a Pawling pass and ran 20 yards to Pawling's 9-yard mark.
Under active Saturday hedging operations usual at this stage of the marketing season, prices on the Cot- ton Exchange declined again yester- day and closed 13 to 15 points lower than on Friday.

LILLIAN GISH had her first dramatic try-out, made her first triumphant entrance upon any stage, at the age of 3 in Baltimore on the shoulder of Nat Goodwin. He was serving as Santa Claus for a big Christmas tree on the stage of Ford's Theatre, and, needing a particularly angelic-looking child to perch on his shoulder and distribute the gifts, little Lillian Gish was chosen.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The British Government is not adopting the French attitude indicated by various resolutions and declarations in Paris this week to the effect that abandonment of German reparations automatically relieves France of her obligations to pay her war debts to the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- With sterling exchange on New York steady at $3.281/2, the stock markets were extremely quiet today, the tone remaining firm. British Government funds showed some improvement in sympathy with the steadiness in sterling.

A close victory by the New York A.C. in a 200-yard relay swim and a striking performance by Miss Elsie Ferril of Far Rockaway, a 14-year-old new comer, marked a water carnival in the 75-foot pool of the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A. last night.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- Although discussion of the inter-allied debts was definitely ruled out of the Chamber of Deputies debate by Premier Herriot yesterday, some mention of them was inevitable, and they were spoken of by Henry Franklin-Bouillon and others in an effort to show that everything the Herriot government has done, is doing and intends to do is so much less well done than they would have done it themselves.

Investment bankers hold that, although the record of defaults is the greatest in the history of investment banking in this country, the comparative safety of bonds as investments is still marked when consideration is taken of the great amount of new financing undertaken to meet the post-war investment demand and of the revaluation of prices and stagnation of trade throughout the world.

VIENNA, Oct. 28. -- The Yugoslav dinar and the Rumanian leu recently followed the schilling, pengo, leva and drachma on the downward course from that parity whereon, with the assistance of French loans, they so long desperately struggled to remain. The loss in the leu is not yet substantial, but the dinar has dropped 28 per cent.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- There seems always to be room for one more cafe in Paris. Where was once a large American tourist office on the Avenue de l'Opera is today a flourishing up-to-date cafe. Another, smaller, tourist office, which has gone out of business since the trips to the battlefields, the chateau districts and so on dropped to nothing is now a popular "bistro."

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Scotland Yard is making a special investigation of the methods whereby criminals are able to obtain firearms. The authorities are convinced that there is a considerable illicit traffic in these weapons and are determined to get at its source.

ALBANY, Oct. 29. -- The greatest city registration in the history of the State was reported today by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State. The total was 5,349,213, as against 4,885,276 before the Presidential election in 1928, an increase of 463,937 this year.

COMFORT for passengers who must spend long days in the air in zones of high temperature has been emphasized in the interior arrangements of the new airplanes which are to be used on both the African route of Imperial Airways and the East Indies route of the K.L.M., the Royal Dutch airline.
PARIS, Oct. 21. -- The Paris Opera, largely attended by Americans on the Monday and Friday subscription nights, is preparing its first novelty of the season and will stage it early in November.

A PRIZE of $1,000 will be awarded to the winner of the Hollywood Bowl's fifth annual composition contest, which is open to composers of any nation and any nationality. The prize is for a symphonic work, not restricted as to form, but which must be written for full symphony orchestra.

MR. WOODWARD has attempted to write for the man in the street an account of our present economic troubles, why we have them and how we are apt to overcome them. As might be expected of an ex parte work, the bulk of the reading matter is composed of bitter attacks upon the men and the ideas which, in the author's opinion, have brought us to grief.

The frontal attack on the gold standard, conducted by CASSEL and KEYNES, has been based mostly on a preconceived theory of what ought to happen, or is morally bound to happen. If episodes such as the "scramble for gold" by European central banks are cited to prove the main contention, care is taken to ignore other circumstances which would explain them.

ANNOUNCEMENT has just been made of the plains for the annual Beaux Arts Ball to be held in January at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Society of Beaux Arts Architects. These details call for a complete departure from the precedent established by the ball committee two decades ago and followed, in the main, of depicting through the medium of fanciful pageantry the trials and glories of France in her long history.

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 29. -- The East, which in recent years has developed the habit of winning the more important Kentucky fixtures, again triumphed decisively over the West when C.V. Whitney's The Darb accounted for the thirteenth running of the $15,000 added Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Republican headquarters held today that President Hoover's fighting speech at Indianapolis last night would swing the 100 electoral votes of Indiana, Illinois, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin into the Republican column.

BROADCASTING celebrates its twelfth anniversary on Wednesday. It was on Nov. 2, 1920, that the pioneer Station KDKA went on the air at Pittsburgh to send out Harding-Cox election bulletins. The audience consisted of wireless amateurs with homemade receivers designed to pick up code messages.
READING, Pa., Oct. 29. -- Albright overcame stubborn opposition provided by the Mount St. Mary's eleven to triumph by 13 to 0 today. Brilliant runs by Hino and Orr featured the victors' drive.

THERE is a curious stir in the air. On Wednesday the citizens of New York will enjoy the privilege of making, or of renewing, the acquaintance of Whistler's famous "Mother." She is pretty sure to prove, at least so far as popular interest is concerned, the clou of the American group show at the Museum of Modern Art.

To the Music Editor: Not long ago Mr. Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and a decidedly forward-looking musician, announced that he had plans afoot which would provide protagonists for operatic performances satisfying to both the eyes and the ears of the audience.

PEIPING, Oct. 1. -- A controversy has been precipitated in the Chinese press and popular magazines here as a result of proposals to modernize the Chinese drama, which, although much of everything else in China has been swayed by Western influences during the last thirty years, has remained unchanged since it was introduced by the Mongols in the Yuan dynasty, 1260 to 1368 A.D.

THREE notorious gangsters, hard-eyed, well-dressed, manicured and murderous, walked into the headquarters of the Milk Wagon Drivers' Union in Chicago one afternoon last Summer and asked to see one of the officials.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 29. -- Punching over a touchdown in the first three minutes of play on the flying feet of Don Zimmerman, Tulane scored a 6-to-0 victory over a hard-fighting South Carolina eleven today before a crowd of about 18,000.

NOVEMBER will be a busy month on the radio. A glimpse of the broadcasters' plans indicates four weeks of diversity in events seldom presents on the air. The high spots are political rallies, election, bulletins, return of the Metropolitan Opera to the microphone, special Thanksgiving programs and major football games.

As a result of a substantial reduction in operating expenses and increased passenger revenue, American Airways, Inc., the airline operating subsidiary of the Aviation Corporation of Delaware, lowered its operating loss in the third quarter of the year to $30,367 from $563,888 in the second quarter of 1932 and $444,933 for the first quarter, it was announced yesterday by LaMotte T. Cohu, president of the parent company and the subsidiary.

RESOLVED, that books about Frank Harris have increased, are increasing and ought to be diminished. Mr. Kingsmill's work is to be excepted. It shows a thorough appreciation of the old chap's essential gifts. His literary ideas were mainly derivative, filched and spoiled in the filching.

FARMINGDALE, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- The New York Aggies won their first game of the season by beating Cooper Union, 13 -- 0, today. Eisenhauer, the Aggies' fast quarterback, scored both touchdowns. Proft made the extra point on a line buck.

The Law Preservation party, through Mrs. E.D. Prendergast of 419 West 118th Street, one of its supporters, announces in a newspaper advertisement published today that it needs help because, Mrs. Prendergast explained last night, it has suddenly found itself a participant in the Congressional and State Senatorial contests in the Nineteenth District where it had net previously known that it had candidates.

Failure of the manufacturers' excise taxes to produce the estimated revenue combined with widespread dissatisfaction with the levy in those industries affected by them, will lead to a general demand on the part of industry for a general sales impost at the December session of Congress, according to a canvass during the week of the various trades subject to the tax.

After opening yesterday at fraction- ally higher prices, the market on the Stock Exchange turned and drifted downward in dull trading. The day's turnover amounted to only 359,820 shares, comparing with 447,820 shares on the preceding Saturday. There was a tendency to attribute the reaction more to the break of wheat to new low levels than to any other one thing.

The encircling gloom of dusk fell upon the banks of the Harlem yesterday with hundreds of overjoyed undergraduates snake dancing in the dark of Baker Field in celebration of another step upward and onward for Columbia football.

It has been established again that politics interferes, temporarily at least, with the business of Wall Street. Whatever other excuses may have been offered, the brokers say that the extreme apathy of the last month on the security markets has been due to the approach of the national election.

The number of children placed in institutions throughout the country as a result of the breaking up of the family has increased 48 per cent since July, 1930, according to Dr. C. C. Carstens, executive director of the Child Welfare League of America, who addressed the semi-annual meeting of the league directors yesterday in the Hotel Gramercy Park.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Many dinner dances were held in Westchester County tonight in celebration of Hallowe'en.

JUST about two months ago a tall, heavy-set man took his hat from the rack in the office which he occupies as president of the largest oil-producing company in the world and, gathering four or five of his assistants about him, declared: "We are through here for the time being.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 29. -- The University of Tennessee proved conclusively today that it has a great football team when the Volunteers staged a rally in the final minutes to defeat the Duke Blue Devils, 16 -- 13.

THE Maternal Health Centres will benefit from the performance of "Dinner at Eight" at the Music Box Theatre on the night of Nov. 10. Already there have been many reservations made through the New York committee of that organization, which has taken over the performance to grain funds with which to carry on its work.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. THE playgoers of this city have begun to suspect that happy days are here again or are, at any rate, just around the corner. For this has been a week of two first nights -- an amazing state of affairs on Chicago's spectral Rialto.

TOKYO, Oct. 29. -- Members of the Patriotic Youth League, who had waited all night to forestall any demonstration by Communist sympathizers, crowded into court today when the trials of the last of 185 Communists arrested in various raids since 1928 were concluded.

It has been established again that politics interferes, temporarily at least, with the business of Wall Street. Whatever other excuses may have been offered, the brokers say that the extreme apathy of the last month on the security markets has been due to the approach of the national election.

Carstens, executive director of the Child Welfare League of America, who addressed the semi-annual meeting of the league directors yesterday in the Hotel Gramercy Park.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Many dinner dances were held in Westchester County tonight in celebration of Hallowe'en.

DEEPLY tanned, Katharine Cornell returned to New York last Wednesday evening on the Europa from a three months' holiday in Europe, her first vacation in three years, except for the enforced rest she had to take last Winter during her engagement here in Besier's "The Barretts of Wimpole Street."

BEN AMES WILLIAMS in at his beat to describing middle-aged or elderly characters. He prefers, it seems, to write about men and women who have seen life and whose experience has taught them to appraise the actions and motives of their fellow-men without being unduly censorious.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, asserted yesterday that, despite "the bag of tricks" the Republicans had emptied recently, the campaign was entering upon its last week with the Roosevelt-Garner tide at its peak and without the last-minute change of sentiment to Hoover that the Republicans had predicted.

Ebullient youth on two of New York City's campuses has lately raised anew the issue of whether college faculties should undertake to maintain student discipline. Two heads of colleges sum up the opposing points of view in the Statements below.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- The brilliant annual Autumn ball was held tonight in the Tuxedo Club. Many dinners wer given before the ball in various residences here and at the club.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 29. -- A black cocker spaniel, Champion My Own Today won best in show among nearly 200 sporting dogs which were benched in the new armory at the sixth annual exhibition of the Mid-Jersey Field Dog Club this afternoon and tonight.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Holy Cross scored its sixth consecutive victory and toppled Catholic University from the list of unbeaten teams by winning, 8 to 0, today. Catholic University had won eleven straight.

TOKYO, Oct. 29. -- Members of the Patriotic Youth League, who had waited all night to forestall any demonstration by Communist sympathizers, crowded into court today when the trials of the last of 185 Communists arrested in various raids since 1928 were concluded.
