Missions should maintain as far as possible friendly relation with labor union leaders and Socialist or Communist leaders as well, the churches are advised in the thirteenth instalment of the report of the appraisal commission of the Laymen's Foreign Mission Inquiry, made public yesterday.
CHICAGO. Oct. 30 -- Football winds from Minnesota were sending cold shivers down Michigan's spine tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--Efforts of business and industrial leaders in every Federal Reserve District to stimulate employment and business recovery under the program adopted at their conference here in August were set forth today in the first progress report of the Central Banking and Industrial Committee, which was set up to coordinate the work of local committees.

George Bernard Shaw is described as a "professional celebrity" in Archibald Henderson's authorized biography, "Bernard Shaw: Playboy and Prophet." The book, of more than 800 pages, which Shaw delayed in proof for many months while he searched it for errors of fact, is published today by Appleton.

The following summary of the new international code of contract bridge, adopted jointly by the Whist Club of New York, the Portland Club of London and the Commission du Bridge of France, was made public yesterday by John Godfrey Saxe, chairman of the Whist Club's committee on laws, ft outlines the more important changes made in the new rules as follows:

The elimination of overstaffing, waste and inefficiency in the Department of Hospitals would result in savings of about $1,000,000 in 1933, the Citizens' Budget Commission announced yesterday. Its conclusion was based upon a report made by Dr. Carmen Haider of Columbia University, who investigated conditions in the department.

The Most Rev. James Edward Kearney, who was consecrated Bishop of Salt Lake. Utah, by Cardinal Hayea on Friday, celebrated his first solemn pontifical mass at noon yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, 1,658 Lurting Avenue, the Bronx, where he has heen pastor for four years.

Governor Roosevelt's connection with the Federal International Banking Company, to which President Hoover referred in his Indianapolis speech Friday night, was explained yesterday by Frederick A. Delano of Newbureh, N.Y., uncle of Governor Roosevelt, and at one time one of the company's directors.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Chancellor von Papen will attempt tomorrow to clinch the Reich's temporary jurisdiction over Prussia with the appointment by President von Hindenburg of Dr. Franz Bracht and Dr. Popitz as members of the Reich Cabinet without portfolios.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Official assurances received from Paris during the week-end have largely dispelled the worst British fears regarding the French disarmament proposals. Consequently the plan is beginning to receive a cautious but unmistakable welcome from the British press.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Oct. 30 (AP)--Premier Herriot arrived tonight in this Spanish city, eleven miles from the French frontier, and was received by a great crowd which cheered France and Spain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- The greatest championship race of the Coast Conference in many seasons was still a two-team rivalry today with the University of California at Los Angeles Bruins' claim to coleadership asserted again through their great victory over Stanford's Indians.

DENVER, Oct. 30 -- The champion Utah Utes, having retained the western division football laurels without much of a struggle, begin a Colorado invasion this week with, the eastern sector of the Rocky Mountain Conference devoid of a formidable contender.

Wellmar Bostrom, Minister from Sweden to the United States, is returning today from Stockholm on the motorship Gripsholm accompanied by Mrs. Bostrom and Baron Johan Beck-Friis, counselor to the Swedish Legation in Washington, with Baroness Beck-Friis.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Lard has declined to the lowest of the season, with local and Western packers hedging the make of their houses by selling distant futures, and at the same time buying nearby deliveries from speculators and Western packers. There is a good export demand and clearances of late have increased materially, and cash prices have declined, with futures, regular lard finishing the week at $4.10, with loose and leaf at $4.12 1/2.

Mount Sinai Hospital closed 1931 with a deficit of $168,519, caused chiefly by the increased demand for free service and a falling off of receipts from paying patients and of gifts, according to the seventy-ninth annual report of that institution, made public yesterday by George Blumenthal, the president.

Voting by an overwhelming majority in favor of strike action should it become necessary, members of Typographical Union 6 (Big Six), at a meeting at the Elks Club, Livingston Street and Boerum Place, Brooklyn, adopted a resolution yesterday requesting authorization from the International Typographical Union, the parent organization, "to strike such offices as actually put into operation the terms of the proposed scale of prices rejected by referendum on Oct. 19."

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- The total number of unemployed in Germany as of Oct. 15 is stated at 5,150,000. It increased in the first half of October, but only 48,000, as against increase of 129,000 in the same period last year, and the increase was confined to occupations governed by seasonal influences.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, made public yesterday a telegram sent on Oct. 19 by Governor Roosevelt to G.A. Eddy, president of the Goss Printing Company, Chicago, disavowing letters written to Mr. Eddy by A.P. Homer, director of the marine committee of the finance division of the Democratic National Committee, soliciting campaign contributions in a way characterized by Mr. Eddy as "a flagrant attempt at political blackmail."

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Senator Henry D. Hatfield, Republican, of West Virginia, in a statement tonight said that a "battle to the death" over the leadership of former Governor Alfred E. Smith was imminent in the Democratic party.
POITIERS, France, Oct. 30. -- Premier Herriot, in an address here today on his way to Spain, warned that the disarmament conference "had once more reached a critical point."

Overcoming a three-goal handicap allotted to its opponent, the First Division polo team subdued the Freebooters, 10-9, in a hard-fought match played yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Reservation before a crowd of about 4,000.

When artists give their services to charitable enterprises, criticism is wont to walk softly and speak with tongues of praise or not at all, Fortunately, Albert Spalding's concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, given for the benefit of the Lighthouse Music School for the Blind, calls for no polite omissions.

The first two weeks of the annual campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies to raise $3,923,000 for the support of its ninety-one affiliated institutions, which opened on Oct. 16, has netted donations amounting to $359,000, it was announced yesterday by Paul Felix Warburg and Ira M. Younker, chairmen of the appeal.

The New York Board of Motion Picture Censors was asked to eliminate those parts of motion pictures depicting Italians in gangster and other criminal roles, in a resolution passed unanimously last night at a dinner at the Hotel New Yorker of the Grand Lodge of the State of New York of the Order of Sons of Italy in America, attended by more than 800 persons.

Contract bridge gets a new set of rules tomorrow. Throughout the Western world the game will be governed by a new international code making the rules and scoring uniform for all countries, and the code will serve as the official basis for bridge play in the home the club and the tournament hall.

Several card parties will be held this week in aid of the funds of philanthropical organizations that are devoted to the care of the ill and needy and other causes. A group of women interested in the management of the Mary Fisher Home will give their annual card party in behalf of that organization tomorrow afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican Mayoralty candidate, made only one campaign speech yesterday, an informal one last night at the Brooklyn Hebrew Home for the Aged, 813 Howard Avenue, Brooklyn, and prepared for the wind-up of his campaign this week.

The decline in cotton prices which began in September was halted last week. The market displayed no recuperative power but it showed steadiness. Active deliveries on the Cotton Exchange here registered declines of 1 to 5 points net for the week.

Featuring what the management prefers to bill as "the stars of tomorrow" in a revue entitled "Look Who's Here," the Palace Theatre this week presents a vaudeville bill in which the winners of the various RKO "Opportunity Revues," held throughout the nation, make their public bow before starting a nationwide tour.

Completely outplaying its opponent in the first half, during which it scored three goals, the Fairchester Field Hockey Association eleven retained its early advantage to turn back the New York Field Hockey Association team, 4 to 1, in an exhibition match at the Prospect Park hockey grounds before 1,000 spectators yesterday.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, made public a letter yesterday to Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, inquiring whether a body known as the Hotel Reconstruction Corporation has any connection, with the Federal corporation.
The victories of Choate and Taft and Hill School's late rally to gain a 7-to-7 tie with Lawrenceville were among the outstanding features of the week-end's play in the scholastic football world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Representative Celler, Democrat, of New York, suggested today that appropriations for prohibition enforcement in the next fiscal year be "cut to the bone" so that there would be "only mere skeletons of enforcement."

With one major and two minor appearances, President Hoover will invade New York and the metropolitan area today and make what is regarded as the climactic speech of his campaign at Madison Square Garden tonight.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to comment on your editorial "Stalin's Opponents."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 30 -- One of the most popular and at the came time one of the most decisive victories in local hunt club circles was scored today when Miss Becks Lanier, riding her own bay gelding Buster, won the championship trophy at the Ox Ridge Hounds hunter trials held at Oenoke Ridge, near here.

Heartened by enthusiastic receptions during the last few days, Colonel William J. Donovan will start his final week of campaigning today with a tour of Sullivan County before returning to Madison Square Garden tonight to speak on the same platform with President Hoover.
The Portsmouth Spartans triumphed over the New York Giants by 6 -- 0 before more than 20,000 at the Polo Grounds yesterday in one of the most exciting National Football League games ever played here.

If any reminder were needed at this time of the patronage at stake in this as in other post-war Presidential elections, Mr. KAPLAN of the National Civil Service Reform League has furnished it in his estimate that 135,000 Federal positions of one kind or another, with salaries totaling $125,000,000, are "at the disposal of the victorious party."

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Gold reserves at the Bank of France rose 25,000,000 francs by Thursday's statement. Since, however, no gold was received from abroad, the increase is commonly ascribed to the release of gold formerly earmarked at the Bank of France on foreign account.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Extortion notes demanding $10,000 from Dr. Walter G. McGuire, prominent Chicago physician, and threatening the life of his son, John, 15 years old, if the sum was not paid, were made public today by the police.

Samuel H. Hofstadter, whose nomination with that of Aron Steuer for the Supreme Court by both the Democrats and Republicans stirred a storm of protest and cries of a "deal," denied yesterday that his endorsement by Tammany had been solicited by him, or that any "deal, bargain or agreement" figured in the nomination in any way.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Lack of speculative buying in all grain markets of the world, particularly here and in Winnipeg, has resulted in liquidation of speculative holdings and a decline in prices to bottom levels never known before by traders of the present day.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 30 -- The Big Six football title race turned into a dual affair between the defending champion Nebraska Cornhuskers and the Oklahoma Sooners when the Huskers Saturday put their old jinx on Kansas State, eliminating the Wildcats from the scramble with another late rally, 6 to 0.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- St. Mary's Galloping Gaels, driving toward national football recognition as an unbeaten team, kept their record unblemished today with a brilliant 14-to-18 victory over Santa Clara's Broncos that thrilled a crowd of 50,000 fans.

It was natural that the scattered premonitory signs of business reawakening, two or three months ago, should be followed by something tangible. It is slow; but what the wise man watches for on such occasions is the trend of things. Last week, the September railway earnings contributed their part.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Republican National Committee made public tonight letters purporting to be signed by A.P. Homer and addressed to Charles M. Schwab and Eugene Grace, appealing for contributions to the Roosevelt campaign fund.

ATLANTA, Oct. 30 -- October's last gridiron charge swept two teams from the Southern Conference race, severely threatened another pair and left only Virginia Poly, Auburn, Tennessee and Louisiana State unbeaten.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 30 -- The only all-United States team in the Argentine open polo championships, Meadow Brook, overwhelmed the Venado Tuerto four, which included one member of the invading North American squad, 19 to 6, today, to enter the simi-final round.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- American corn is virtually on an export basis and within the last few weeks it is estimated that about 5,000,000 bushels have been sold to England and the Continent. France was among the buyers. Foreigners were asking yesterday for offers of corn for export, but no sales were reported.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The American oil industry, fifth biggest business in the United States, has maintained 90 per cent of the sales and production peak it attained in 1929, and prices which fell as low as 10 and 12 cents a barrel for crude last year have been reinstated around 98 cents.

Of interest among Manhattan realty items reported over the week-end was the leasing by Mrs. I. Townsend Burden of her six-story English basement residence at 115 East Seventieth Street to Herbert Pulitzer, president of the Press Publishing Company.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 30 -- A Halloween dinner dance was held at the Greenbrier last night. The terrace dining room was decorated with Autumn boughs, jack o'lanterns, sheaves of grain, and the fruits of the season and dinner tables were strewn with Halloween favors.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. S. Hinman Bird and Mr. and Mrs. John T. Harrison will give jointly a dinner dance at the St. Regis Dec. 29 for their respective debutante daughters. Miss Olivia S. Bird and Miss Virginia Haxall Harrison.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There have been few periods in American history when the average citizen thought more about government in relation to his own private business, his own job and his own daily living. There was a time when his conception of the Federal Government was a body which made treaties and fixed tariff-rates.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 30 -- Lafayette's basketball schedule, listing twelve contests, the smallest number in years, and the baseball schedule of fourteen games have been announced by D.L. Reeves, graduate manager of athletics.

Mr. SMITH in his Buffalo speech about the State campaign made great play with Colonel DONOVAN. The former Governor is a very dangerous antagonist when it comes to debating New York affairs. He knows them from top to bottom and from one side to the other.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- More than 260,000 men are employed on highway and bridge construction in thirty-three States, the United States Employment Service said today in the September issue of its bulletin, which added that there has been a further expansion in jobs throughout the country.

The padlock on the iron gate at All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, was broken yesterday for the second successive Sunday, and the rector, the Rev. Rollin Dodd, again, defied the board of vestrymen "by holding ser vices for a mixed congregation, of white and Negro parishioners.

Although reiterating his pledge of an economical administration if elected Mayor, Surrogate John P. O'Brien warned a group of West Side voters last night not to be misled concerning the size of the economies.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The weakness in sterling had an unsettling effect on this week's security markets in general and particularly in the market for gilt-edged stocks. In comparison with the preceding advance, the fall which has just occurred in British Government securities is trifling.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 30 -- A warning of "grave danger" that the ship- building industry of Southern NewJersey might be forced to remove to "other and more congenial grounds" because of high, taxes, was given today by Clinton L. Bardo, president of the New York Shipbuilding Company of Camden and of the New Jersey Taxpayers Association, in replying to recent charges of State Senator Emerson L. Richards concerning' the "shipbuilding racket."

A reduction in taxes was urged by F.E. Wllliamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, in a statement issued for publication today. Mr. Williamson said that the annual national tax burden was $14,500,000,000, or $125 for every person in the country.
ROME, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Twelve American students were ordained as priests today in the chapel of the German College here by Cardinal Marchetti-Salvaggiani, Vicar-General of the Pope.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Hoover has decided to end his appeal for re-election with the most intensive wind-up campaign ever conducted by a President of the United States in recent years. Spurred on by reports or increasing Republican strength in the Middle West and in the industrial centres of the East, the President will continue his campaign almost without interruption until election day.

An urgent appeal for immediate aid for 2,765 needy families in the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New York was made yesterday afternoon during a special service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by Bishop William T. Manning, Homer Folks, secretary of the State Charities Aid Association, and Suffragan Bishop Charles K. Gilbert.

Following is the text of the letter sent to Controller Berry by Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the National City Bank, and, Winthrop W. Aldrich, vice chairman of the governing board and president of the Ohase National Bank:

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Victories in three out of four races in a series of frostbite dinghy races held under the auspices of the Larchmont Yacht Club gave William W. Swan the high score of 31 points today. Sailing in a strong northwest breeze of about thirty miles an hour, the New Rochelle entrant, with his Sea Swan, was an easy winner.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 -- There is little disposition in steel circles here to estimate steel-ingot production last week below the rate of 20 per cent of capacity, which was figured for each of the preceding three weeks. October would therefore be estimated at 20 per cent, against 17.34 per cent officially reported for September, and 14.26 per cent for August, representing a rise in tonnage of 40 per cent in two months.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- Hope of a new reduction in the Reichsbank rate counteracted this week the other unfavorable influences such as the collapse in sterling, the Reicnsgericht's unsatisfactory decision in the conflict between the Federal Government and Prussia and the increasing boycott of German goods by Northern European countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States has appointed a special committee, headed by David F. Edwards of Boston, to make an impartial study of all forms of competing transportation with a view to developing greater coordination and assuring fairness of opportunity among the different types of carriers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The hysteria exhibited by a number of Republican lawyers because Governor Roosevelt mentioned the fact that a majority of the members of the Supreme Court are Republicans would be amusing if it was not calculated to deceive the public.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Mounted and foot police saved the King's palace and the official residences in Downing Street from attack by thousands of unemployed and "hunger marchers" after a hard battle today at Trafalgar Square.

After several days of mystifying the public about the city's cash on hand, Controller BERRY has had to resort to borrowing in order to meet his November obligations. The bankers to whom he has again applied for a loan agree with him that the state of his accounts shows that he will require for the coming month "a minimum of $18,500,000 over and above available receipts."

A plea to the voters of New York State to rally to the support of the relief bond issue at the election was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. C. Everett Wagner, the pastor, in a sermon at the Union Methodist Church, Forty-eighth Street, near Broadway.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Lower prices were recorded last week for the general run of live stock, although averages were up 20 cents on beef steers and off 10 cents on hogs, while fat lambs and sheep sold at the same average as in the previous week. All live-stock prices are materially under those of a year ago.

In discussing what the Democrats should do with their expected Presidential victory, Alfred E. Smith, writing as editor-in-chief of the New Outlook in the November number, out today, says that "the most important issue with which the new Democratic administration must deal is that of unemployment."
Completion of plans for the annual budget campaign to raise $230,000 for the Y.W.C.A. in this city was announced yesterday by Mrs. Frank C. Munson, chairman of the campaign committee.

With the prospect of forty of the State Legislatures in session this Winter, municipal bankers are preparing to follow closely all proceedings affecting municipal securities with a view of safeguarding the contractual rights of the bondholders.

Football is a humbling game for the connoisseurs of form, and one should be prepared by now for any eventuality on the gridiron. But even the most philosophic assayer of values, inured to the weekly invalidating of his computations, must have been shaken out of his complacency in the face of Saturday's returns.

A final effort to obtain enactment into law of the proposed new building code was started over the weekend by the Merchants' Association, whose representatives cooperated in drafting the building rules, now in completed form and awaiting action only by the city authorities to make them law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Senator Costigan of Colorado, vice chairman of the National Progressive League, asserted in a statement made tonight that President Hoover had lent his name and the authority of his high office to the "deception of the American people" in referring to the percentages of imports under the Hawley Smoot tariff law in his Cleveland and Indianapolis speeches.

Preliminary surveys have convinced the leaders of the Democratic organizations in the city that Colonel Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic nominee for Governor, will roll up a plurality in the city that may reach 800,000; that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt will carry the city for the Presidency by only slightly less than that, and that John P. O'Brien, the party's Mayoralty nominee, will receive a plurality of some 600,000 votes.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Official announcement of the details of the new Dominion Government $80,000,000 loan to be formally offered tomorrow through bond houses and banks throughout the country was made by the Minister of Finance, Edgar N. Rhodes, in a statement issued here.

The Public Housing Conference, organized to provide modern housing for every worker "since it does not pay private business to provide it," adopted resolutions calling for the creation of a municipal housing board at a meeting yesterday afternoon at 99 Park Avenue, at which speakers criticized Rockefeller Center as representing a surplus of lofts, theatres and music halls.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Two "flying grandmothers," traveling toward Iowa City in an open biplane on a stumping tour for President Hoover, crashed into a field here this afternoon, but were only slightly bruised.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- Governor Roosevelt urged the voters of the State to approve a $30,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief in a statement issued today. He also joined Senator George R. Fearon, President pro tem of the Senate, and Joseph A. McGinnies, Speaker of the Assembly, in urging approval of the bond issue.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 30.--Beekman Pool, national squash racquets champion, won the final today in the annual Nassau Country Club invitation squash racquets tournament which started on Friday with thirtytwo players.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 30 -- St. Thomas College registered its fourth straight victory of the season today by defeating the University of Baltimore, 41 to 13, in their annual game at the Crystal Garden Stadium.

Scoring two touchdowns against Amherst on Saturday to give him a total of 96 points, Louis Bush of Massachusetts State again increased his lead over his nearest competitor, Clifford Montgomery, Columbia quarterback, in the Eastern individual scoring race.

Champion Ace of Aces Aviator, owned by the Ace of Aces Kennels of Providence, R.I., won the title of best in show at the eighth annual specialty exhibition of the Boston Terrier Club of New Jersey, held yesterday in Jersey City. M.J. Lally of Brooklyn judged the exhibition and made his award at the close of a long day of interesting competition.

The next fifty years were pictured as an era of super-industrial development, with gigantic machinery throwing men out of work, by Rev. Harold L. Gibbs, assistant rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Unification of banking in this country should be sought through enlarging the sphere and membership of the Federal Reserve System rather than through abolition of State-chartered institutions in favor of a completely Federal supervised system of banking, according to the Economic Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association.
This is the nicht o' Halloween, When a' the witchie micht be seen; Some o' them black, some o' them green, Some o' them like a turkey bean.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Thomas E. Mills resigned today as head football coach at Georgetown University and was succeeded by John L. Hagerty, quarterback of the New York Giants professional team.

Has the salt water fisherman, who seeks bluefish and tuna, turned to some of the devices of the fresh water angler? This is a question that is agitating many who devote a little time to both fresh and salt water fishing. In fact, one dyed-in-the-wool salt water devotee rises to claim that the fraternity has taken not just a leaf from the fresh water fisherman's book, but the entire book.

The congregation of the famous old John Street Church, 44 John Street which celebrated yesterday the 166th anniversary of its founding, was told at its morning service by William Phillips Hall that Methodism could not exist on its glorious record of past achievements, but must start a new Methodistic movement, which would shake the world from sin.
The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open its 1932-33 season this week with an exhibition of American painting and sculpture covering the period from 1862 to the present time.
Miss Margaret Halstead, American dramatic soprano, has been engaged to appear with the Metropolitan Opera during the coming season, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza.
Down the Home-stretch. As we enter on the final week of the campaign the situation would size up approximately as follows:
WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Oct. 30 -- The reappearance of the lost "Comet of 1866 One" is expected in the first two weeks of November.

The budget of the Columbia University Corporation for the year ended June 30, 1932, as adopted in April, 1931, and subsequently amended, showed an estimated deficit of $478,890, according to the report of the treasurer, made public yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, the president.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 30 -- The Green Bay Packers scored their sixth victory today defeating Ken Strong's Stapleton club, 26 to 0, before a fair-sized crowd.

Developments of the last month have strengthened the generally accepted belief that the most acute phase of the depression is past, but that progress toward recovery will be slow and hesitant, says the Guaranty Survey, published today by the Guaranty Trust Company.

What has become of the short and ugly word? Has the Ananias Club died of inanition? These troubled questions must occur to every one who compares the campaign speeches of THEODORE ROOSEVELT with the painfully polite examples now current.
BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Next Sunday, two days before the far more important election in the United States, Germany will go to the polls -- and most regretfully.

The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday that its net profit for the third quarter was $2,450,047, or 47 cents a share on 5,251,493 shares of common stock, against $4,240,345, or 81 cents a share for the corresponding period of 1931.

The annual Fall meeting of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association, held at the New York A.C. yesterday, was devoted largely to the revision of the water polo and fancy diving rules. Delegates of eleven Universities were present. President Herbert H. Vollmer, Columbia '17, presided.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 30 -- John Kochansky, 25 years old, a former prizefighter, of 96 West Seventeenth Street here, was held on charges of murder and assault with intent to kill by the police today in connection with the fatal shooting last night of Mrs. Dorothy Gavrun, 66, and the wounding of her daughter Barbara, 30, in their home at 171 Prospect Avenue here.

Twenty-two toy singers, members of the Wiener Sangerknaben, whose ages range from 9 to 11 1/2 years, arrived here yesterday from Vienna on the Statendam. They marched down the gangway to the pier at Fifth Street, Hoboken, wearing the dark blue serge uniform with cap and overcoat of the same color of the famous choir which was founded in 1498 by the imperial decree of the Emperor Maximilian, head of the Holy Roman Empire.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Speaking tonight over the radio in aid of relief measures for the unemployed and others suffering from the effects of the economic depression, Governor Roosevelt asserted the time had come for heroic measure "to save, not only for the immediate future but for generations to come the human values of our citizen ship."

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The continued fall in sterling will have no influence on official stabilization plans. It has again been officially stated that the government has no intention yet of arranging for stabilization, and that this must depend upon world conditions which we are still far from witnessing.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., Oct. 30 -- Mary Ellen McGovern, 7 years old, was shot in the right side of the chest and seriously wounded today while walking here with her older sister, Catherine, in Falcon Street, a short distance from her home.
MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Peace in the cotton industry appears doomed to end tomorrow, when 170,000 operatives in the spinning section are expected to go on strike.

Going to church and giving money to church causes should be "a glorious privilege" rather than acts performed grudgingly with the idea that only thus can one win Heaven, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Paul's Lutheran Church, 796 East 156th Street, in celebration of its golden jubilee.

It must be four or fiva years since a comprehensive showing of Alexander Archipenko's work was held in New York. His enormous exhibition on that occasion, which included the much heralded machine "Archipentura," startled the local public and set tongues wagging, not altogether coherently, about the new "dynamism" in art.

An analysis of the financial status of the interstate bridge and tunnel facilities of the Port of New York Authority, based on the record for the first nine months of the year, and forecasts for the next three months indicate their ability to withstand five more years of depression with no harmful effect, according to a statement issued yesterday by Chairman John F. Galvin.

In a message to THE NEW YORK TIMES Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland yesterday endorsed the views expressed by former United States Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer, who estimated that it would be possible for the government to save $2,000,000,000 annually with the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and that the saving could be effected in the next fiscal year.

IN the recent firing a downtrodden Yale team rose up to snatch its first victory of the year and a fast-traveling Notre Dame team was thrown for a total loss. One tradition was upheld. Apparently Dart-mouth is unable to win a game in the Yale Bowl. Another tradition wag bent and battered. The Pitt Panthers sprang a late rally and defeated Notre Dame.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30 -- An American college tradition was broken today when the Harvard Business School announced that, in view of unemployment and the number of young executives who, through no fault of their own, have lost their jobs, a special emergency session will start Jan. 30 and continue to Aug. 16.

Despite their belief that the city has made no real cuts in the budget, the National City Bank and the Chase National Bank have notified Controller Charles W. Berry that they are ready to act favorably on his application for a minimum loan of $18,500,000 to meet "immediate" requirements for November.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman arrived here last night at the end of ten days of heavy campaigning through up-State New York convinced that he, Governor Roosevelt and the rest of the Democratic ticket had made formidable inroads in the normally Republican areas of the State and apparently convinced also that the State would be in the Democratic column on the night of Nov. 8.

Senator DAVID REED has recovered from his short attack of Mussolinism. Now he is all for suasion and reason. He told an assemblage of earnest Pittsburgh Grundyites to go out and spread the gospel of fear among their employes. Tell them, he said, that ROOSEVELT'S election will mean, in all reasonable probability, two years of business stagnation and alarm.

United States Senator David I. Walsh of Massachusetts replied in a statement issued at Democratic national headquarters yesterday to a charge by President Hoover in his Indianapolis speech that the Democrats had falsely credited the United States Public Health Service with a statement that 6,000,000 public school children, in the United States did not have enough to eat.

The charge that New York City was "being ruled by a dictatorship of bankers more insidious and despotic than the Communist dictatorship ruling in Moscow" was made by Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, in an address last night at the Rand School of Social Science, 7 East Fifteenth Street, in which he urged municipal operation of public utilities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Confidence in all lines of merchandising and manufacturing made steady gains in the West in the last week, and indications of continued activity for the remainder of the year and in many lines for an enlargement after the new year are seen.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 30 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 60.6, which compares with 61.1 a week ago, 61.3 two weeks ago, 61.8 three weeks ago and 62.2 four weeks ago. This season's highest was 63.2, on Sept. 10.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Work on the Pennsylvania Railroad is to be distributed further among employes to give jobs to the maximum number of workers, General W.W. Atterbury, president, announced today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The Brooklyn Dodgers, playing without the services of Benny Friedman, lost to the Chicago Cardinals today at Wrigley Field, 27 to 7.

The United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries, excluding the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, report for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $35,925,626 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal after preferred dividends to $1.38 a share on the common stock outstanding at the end of the period.

Although "Juno and the Paycock," "The Plough and the Stars" and "The Silver Tassie" have been acted in New York, Sean O'Casey's first play, "The Shadow of a Gunman" had somewhat eluded "the crossroads of the world" until the Abbey Theatre troupe mounted it at the Martin Beck Theatre Saturday evening.

Unseasonable and rainy weather in mar sections of the country, together with political uncertainties, served to reduce activity in the wholesale markets here last week. Retailers are holding apparel stocks down, but gains were noted in orders for merchandise of a pre-holiday character.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Countering the plan of the unemployed to parade through the Loop at noon tomorrow in protest against the relief they have been receiving, orders were issued tonight to mobilize a large part of the city's 6,000 policemen for duty in that district to prevent disorders.

One of the plainest signs that the Republicans realize the odds are against them this year is the open shifting of campaign strategy. That the President is conscious of the perils implicit in the change can be detected in this passage from his Indianapolis speech: "I presume the Governor of New York will announce that I am acting upon the defensive."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- How the Tariff Commission will proceed in an effort to carry out President Hoover's request for a sweeping investigation of the effect of depreciated foreign currencies on production costs abroad of a large group of commodities is receiving the study of economists in Washington who represent industries interested in many of the items which the President listed.
Small housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Here for a brief visit at Groton School, from which he was graduated in 1900, Franklin D. Roosevelt made today a further gesture toward identifying himself with the progressives of the nation with a declaration that a time had come to adopt new policies to meet new needs.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Even those who in this country and elsewhere systematically mistrust any and every arms-limitation proposal, while themselves urging disarmament, acknowledge there is not only a new idea but good faith behind the French Government's suggestion to substitute in Continental Europe a system of defensive militias for the standing and conscript armies which have so often been more of a menace than a safeguard.

Great South Bay is the mecca today for hundreds of duck hunters. The season for ducks, as well as for upland birds, squirrels and rabbits, opens on Long Island at noon. The opening has long been awaited by nimrods who reserve their activities for the bays and woods of this section of the State.

Felix M. Warburg, financier and philanthropist, urged the re-election of President Hoover last night in an address at the Brooklyn Jewish Centre, 667 Eastern Parkway. He listed sixteen reasons for voting for Mr. Hoover.

Justice Louis Goldstein of Brooklyn, who prosecuted many swindlers during his career in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, became a detective Saturday and after a fifteen-hour chase through this city and Northern New Jersey caught a man wanted by the Los Angeles police in connection with a $65,000 theft.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Democratic National Committee reported to the Clerk of the House today expenditures of $926,208 and receipts of $1,065,654 in the period from June 1 to Oct. 22.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press) -- For the third time in two years Florence A. Deeks, Toronto author, personally pleaded today before a justice for $500,000 damages from H.G. Wells for an alleged plagiarism.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- President W. Howard Pillsbury of the New York State Teachers Association in a statement issued today to all teachers of the State directed their attention to declarations of Lieut. Gov. Lehman and Colonel Donovan upon the "vital and important question of the maintenance of State aid appropriations for the support of public schools."
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The Labor party expects to make substantial and possibly sweeping gains in the municipal elections tomorrow in 300 cities and towns of England and Wales.

"The Traveling Salesman," a Yiddish play by Louis Freiman, was presented at the Second Avenue Theatre last night. In a work every detail of which is as subtle as a Minsky double meaning, the title alone is ironic, for it is the alleged occupation, for family consumption, of a notorious bootlegger and bad man.

Captain A.M. Moore, master of the United States liner President Harding, was nominated yesterday as president of the Neptune Association to succeed Captain E.F. Mitchell of the liner American Importer. No opposition to the ticket headed by Captain Mitchell was offered in New York and none is expected in other port cities in which the association has branches.

The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $5,346,146 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, in contrast with a net profit of $1,186,052, or 27 cents a share on 4,384,392 shares, in the preceding quarter and a net profit of $1,518,966, or 34 cents a share on 4,414,922 shares, in the third quarter of 1931.
Following is the text of President Hoover's address last night at Madison Square Garden:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- After five years of research into the question of making adequate medical service equally available throughout the country, the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care will make its report on Nov. 29.

Samuel Seabury endorsed last night the candidacy of Langdon W. Post, who is running as an independent for re-election in the Tenth Assembly District, Manhattan, after having been refused renomination by Tammany. Mr. Seabury made known his support of Mr. Post in a letter to the Assemblyman.

Lieut. Gov. Lehman opened yesterday the last phase of his campaign for the Governorship in the New York City area with a series of speeches in Rockland and Westchester Counties, in which for the first time he leveled his guns at the campaign Colonel William J. Donovan has been making against him.
The New York University football team yesterday began preparations at Ohio Field for the game with Georgia at the Yankee Stadium Saturday. Virtually the entire Violet squad reported.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- It was announced tonight that the outstanding L114,600,000 of 5 per cent Treasury bonds of 1933-35 will tie repaid at par on Feb. 1 with the six months' interest due on that date. The news, which was fully expected in financial circles, foreshadows an early issue of moderately long-term securities on terms that will mean a substantial saving to the Exchequer.

More than 100 prominent engineers and city officials attended a testimonial dinner at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street, last night in honor of Robert Ridgway on his seventieth birthday and retirement from active service as chief engineer of the Board of Transportation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- While most of the Syracuse University varsity football players were excused today, the reserve squad and the Blues staged a regulation game. After 45 minutes of play the second team, led by Captain Tom Lombardi, managed to put across the only touchdown of the game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission told the Fredericksburg Northern Railway Company today in effect that it must sell out to the Gulf West Texas Railway Company, a Southern Pacific subsidiary, for $200,000 or be forced out of business by a new road paralleling its own which the commission would authorize to be built.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my youth I was all for putting theorists into office. I rejoiced when ever a "radical" was made a legislator no matter what his equipment for the job of lawmaker might be My faith is not so unfaltering now.

Achilie Mirner, 39 years old, a partner in the jewelry firm of L. Berenson A. Mirner of Paris, London, Antwerp and New York, died yesterday in the Park West Hospital, 170 West Seventy-sixth Street, of internal hemorrhages. When he was admitted to the hospital in a semiconscious condition, Mr. Merner, according to the police, said he had been kicked and beaten in a west side speakeasy on Saturday night.
A rise in the price of automobile tires will follow any increase in the price of crude rubber, William O'Neill, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, said yesterday.

The number of City College students suspended as an aftermath of a demonstration in front of Night Court "Wednesday night was reduced to ten yesterday with the reinstatement by Dean Daniel W. Redmond of Norman Schrank, a senior, who had been barred from classes Friday for posting notice of a protest meeting in violation of a Student Council regulation.

The government of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia will not pay the interest and sinking fund instalments due today on its 8 per cent secured external bonds and its Series B 7 per cent secured external bonds, both due in 1962 and outstanding in an aggregate amount of approximately $45,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Republican National Committee today attacked the Democratic campaign managers for their alleged appeal to business interests for funds. In two statements the committee cited a letter said to have been received by the concern of Lamb Lerch, 25 Broadway, in which a particular appeal was made to importers, exporters and customs brokers on the basis of proposed tariff revision and echoed Ambassador Edge's criticisms of appeals to hotel proprietors.

In their letter to the Controller the bankers set forth the various reforms they deem essential to the restoration of the city's credit, putting the responsibility for adopting the requisite economy measures squarely upon the Board of Estimate.

A plan for reorganization of the Public Utilities Consolidated Corporation has been undertaken by a committee headed by Edward L. Love, vice president of the Chase National Bank, and formed at the request of holders of substantial amounts of the various securities and claimants against the corporation.
The Musicians' Symphony Orchestra, an ensemble of 200 unemployed players, will begin the first of two series of ten concerts each at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight for the benefit of the idle.

SEATTLE, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Charging that President Hoover has used his appointive powers "to serve the interests of the power trust," Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska, in an address here tonight, urged the election of Governor Roosevelt.

Dividends declared in October, although smaller in the aggregate of payments, showed definite indications of a change in the downward trend of disbursements, which had continued steadily since Jan. 1. The payments voted by directors were less than half the amount ordered disbursed to shareholders a year ago and the curtailments embraced most groups of stocks.

Newspaper advertising will be the backbone of Brazil's $1,000,000 campaign for increased consumption of Brazilian coffee in this country, it was announced jointly yesterday by Frank C. Russell, chairman of the Brazilian-American Coffee Promotion Committee, and Sebastiao Sampaio, Consul General of Brazil and United States representative of the National Coffee Council of Brazil.

A board of arbitration convened in The Times Annex yesterday to determine the wages and hours of printers employed by the New York newspaper publishers, in order to complete a new contract in place of the one that expired three years ago.

The new International code for Contract bridge, which goes into effect today, "was generally praised by bridge experts yesterday, but many of its features, including the large bonus for a grand slam, received some criticism.

A plea of guilty to criminally receiving $300,000 in jewelry taken by three gunmen in the hold-up of the hoine of Harry C. Glemby, hair-net manufactured, at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street, last Jan. 21, was entered in General Sessions yesterday by Miss Helen Smith, 44 years old, whose right name was said to be Buda Godman.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Ralph D. Blumenfeld, once an American newspaper man and now the best-known and best-loved editor in Fleet Street, has retired from the editorship of The Daily Express, it became known tonight.

The United States is rapidly "coining of age musically" and the old illusions with regard to European "superiority" and American, "inferiority" in music have been dispelled, Henry Hadley, composer and formerly associate director of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Society, declared last night in an address at the Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University Extension, held in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street.

In a formal report to the Governor Mid Legislature of New York on the administration of the Emergency Unemployment Relief law, compiled and submitted jointly by the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration and the Attorney General's office, members of the relief administration express the belief that they have been able to "have a part in what seems to us to be one of the greatest social experiments ever undertaken."

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- As the Stock Exchange will be closed for tomorrow's holiday, the attendance today was very small and business restricted. Virtually the only activity was in British Government funds, where steadiness in the sterling rate on New York at $3.28 1/2 helped the rises.

Convinced that his continued advocacy of high protective tariffs had a telling effect in his campaign in the Middle West, President Hoover brought the same strategy to the East yesterday and came up through the industrial sections of Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania and New Jersey preaching the doctrine of protection.

The unemployed who have been rioting in London cannot properly be called "hunger marchers," the Marquess of Reading, the British statesman, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the British Empire Chamber of Commerce in the United States of America at the Downtown Athletic Club.

Last night in Town Hall Mme. Olga Averino gave a song recital with the assistance of her distinguished countryman, the pianist Alexander Siloti, who did not think it less than an honor to accompany an uncommonly sincere and sensitive artist. Mme. Averino began her program with a Bach group of transcriptions or editings of Bach by Mr. Siloti.

The Museum of Modern Art officially opened its season yesterday afternoon with an exhibition of American painting and sculpture covering the period from 1862 to our own day. The showing was for members of the museum and artists represented. Today there will be another private view for an invited list, and tomorrow the exhibition will open to the public.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- The Boerse opened quiet today, with virtually no orders for stocks. Prices consequently were extremely irregular. In the course of the day I.G. Farben and United Steel Works improved somewhat, providing a stimulus for other stocks which led to a general rally.

Walter Scheiber, young professional at the Hillcrest Golf Club in Jamaica, scored a 64, one of the most remarkable rounds of the season, as he and his partner, John J. Loftus, home club champion, carried off the honors in a pro-amateur one-day tournament on the Hillcrest course yesterday.

From the notebooks of Major Laban J. Miles, an uncle of President Hoover, John Joseph Mathews has reconstructed some of the story of how the Osage Indians lived before they became a rich community. He tells this story in "Wah' KonTah: The Osage and the White Man's Road," a Book-of-the-Month Club choice for November which will be published today by the University of Oklahoma Press.

Greeted by throngs estimated to total 75,000, President Herbert Hoover brought his campaign into the metropolitan area yesterday afternoon by delivering the first of his three major speeches of the day in the Mosque Theatre at Newark.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 31 -- Miss Gertrude Low arrived at The Homestead from New York and joined her parents. Mr. and Mrs. Ethelbert I. Low, who entertained at dinner this evening in her honor.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Leaders of the ragged army of "hunger marchers" today threw the pretense of peacefulness to the winds and announced they would try to force Parliament to surrender by a mass demonstration tomorrow.

In 1913 The Scientific American held a contest open to the world to determine what were "the ten greatest inventions of our time." Commercial importance was to be the criterion of greatness, and by "our time" the preceding twenty-five years was meant.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Princess Ingrid of Sweden with her aunt, Princess Alice, the Countess of Athlone, and the Earl of Athlone dined with the Prince of Wales and Prince George at York House tonight. The quiet, informal dinner in the intimacy of the Princes' private apartments, their London residence, strengthened rumors of an impending announcement of Princess Ingrid's engagement to Prince George.

Nearly 30,000 men and women surged in waves against lines of perspiring and harried policemen last night in a desperate attempt to enter Madison Square Garden after the auditorium had been packed to capacity.

The treasurer's report of the Rockefeller Foundation, now public, listing the investments in which a fund of $191,000,000 is being carried through, the depression, reveals that the foundation held through the last year every security that it had at the end of 1930.

Important casting engagements for productions now in preparation were learned yesterday. Besides Patricia Collinge and Francis Lederer, the players in "Autumn Crocus," by C. L. Anthony, which the Shuberts are offering, will include Eda Heinemann, Patricia Calvert and Florence Edney.

Senator HOFSTADTER'S belated explanation itself needs explaining. He implies that he simply had to have a nomination of some kind for office. Being refused that for Attorney General on the Republican ticket, what was there left for him but to demand a judgeship here in the First District?

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 -- The Quincy Stable's Repaid scored by a neck over Lee Rosenberg's Futurity winner, Kerry Patch, in the mile and seventy yards of the Pikesville Purse as the twelve-day meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club opened at Pimlico today with a charity card.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 31 -- The Naval Academy football team began today the task of preparing for the Columbia game Saturday. The feeling here is that Columbia will be about as strong as Pennsylvania, which defeated the Navy decisively Saturday.

Holiday Goods Lead in Orders. Orders for holiday merchandise again were noteworthy in the mail received from out-of-town stores, it was reported here yesterday. Numerous apparel accessories, home items, toys and cosmetics were sought.

Application for authority to issue $1,568,000 of short-term promissory notes has been made by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad to the Interstate Commerce Commission. In its plea the company estimated that this year it would show a net loss of $2,548,625 after all deductions, in contrast with a net income of $1,090,691 in 1931.

Politely but firmly the bankers upon whom the city of New York depends for its financing yesterday refused to advance the city $25,000,000 to cover the Winter's unemployment relief program because they felt they could not consider the relief problem apart from the general financial problem of the city.
The 1932 football campaign enters the crucial November engagements with only twenty teams unbeaten and untied.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Most of the Princeton football players who saw action in the Michigan game on Saturday received a rest today and two reserve elevens held a two-hour drill on University Field. A sixty-minute scrimmage between the second and third teams concluded the session.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31 -- Harvard's unique collection of glass flowers is nearing completion, with the recent receipt of twenty-one models from Dresden.

President Hoover was "re-elected" yesterday at a meeting of the Greater New York Federation of Churches held in the assembly hall of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. The "election" was the result of a straw vote taken at luncheon. The result was announced at the close of the afternoon session.

With the continued success of Brown the impression is growing that the Bears, through the medium of Tuss McLaughry, the coach, are contributing something brand new to football, one of the few original additions to the plan of the game that have been made in recent years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Revival of a rumor that Secretary Adams would resign soon caused a flurry today in the Navy Department.

By discovering one of the great world artists in the resentful twilight of a New England village, Sidney Howard has written a broad, undisciplined comedy, "The Late Christopher Bean," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening. According to the program, it is based on a Parisian satire, "Prenez Garde a la Peinture," by Rene Fauchois.

President HOOVER'S defense of the Hawley-Smoot tariff includes a denial that it has seriously disturbed world trade. "The Democratic party "seldom mentions that 66 per cent "of our imports are free of duty, "but that is the fact," he says. "I remind you that we levy tar"iffs upon only one-third of our "imports."
TORONTO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Directors of the National Hockey League took a big stride forward today in their attempt to bring hold-outs into line.

There was a continued flow of funds into the banks last month, according to the monthly review of credit and "business conditions published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. As in the two previous months, the review says, some of the funds were used for further repayment of member bank indebtedness at the Reserve Banks or as the basis for expansion of bank credit, and the remainder was added to unemployed reserves.

Sharp reductions in rates featured the money markets here during October. Call loans were offered at 1 per cent, a rate equaled only twice -- on two days in 1931 -- since 1908. Time loans were placed at even lower rates, dropping to one-half of 1 per cent for sixty-day accommodations, threefourths of 1 per cent for ninety-day loans and three-fourths of 1 per cent to 1 per cent for six-month borrowings.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 31 -- The Dartmouth soccer team won its first major victory of the season today by defeating a strong Princeton combination, 4 to 1.

Charges that the State Attorney General's office was "apparently being used to obstruct the forces working toward an honest election" met yesterday with a denial from First Assistant Attorney General Mahon, in charge of the New York office.

Low records for the month on the Cotton Exchange were made yesterday when December contracts touched 6.06 cents a pound, the lowest quotations since the early part of August and nearly 1 cent below the figures of a month ago. Lancashire labor troubles involving 100,000 to 200,000 operators, active hedge selling by dealers and a break in wheat unsettled sentiment.

MADRID, Oct. 31 -- While all of Spain's high dignitaries were giving Premier Herriot the nearest approach to a royal welcome that the republic could achieve and the Spanish press was pronouncing eulogies of him, Madrid's collegians, who bow neither to Kings nor to Presidents, greeted the French Pemier's car with shouts of "Death to Herriot" and "Down with war."

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 31 -- Because of violence and disorders that have been rampant since it was formed a week ago, Bolivia's new Cabinet will resign to make way for another, the fourth in two weeks.

State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter's reply to attacks upon him for his acceptance of a Democratic nomination for the Supreme Court was characterized yesterday as "untrue and only another evidence of his unfitness" by W. Kingsland Macy, State chairman of the Republican party, of which Mr. Hofstadter is a member.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The government asked the District of Columbia Appellate Court today to reinstate the indictment against Bishop James Cannon Jr. and Miss Ada L. Burroughs, charging conspiracy to violate the corrupt practices act.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 Traveling more than 250 miles by automobile, Governor Roosevelt appealed today for the electoral votes of Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts and, in a speech, at Portland, quoted from a speech by Calvin Coolidge, made as his opponent for Vice President in 1920, to sustain his contention that there should be a change in government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Enough has been learned here of the French disarmament plan for the State Department to announce informally today that it welcomed it as a contribution to the cause of disarmament and as a proposal which should fit well into President Hoover's program for a one-third cut in armaments generally.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 -- There have been several indications recently that any trade advantages Argentina may obtain from Great Britain will only be in exchange for a friendlier attitude toward British capital invested in Argentina, which exceeds the amount invested in any of the dominions.

Many persons have subscribed to boxes for the second annual Peacock Ball, to be given on Friday in the ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

Columbia pointed its undefeated football team yesterday toward its contest with the Naval Academy at Annapolis on Saturday. Most of the first team went through a light workout while the reserves indulged in a lengthy scrimmage at Baker Field.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- At midnight tonight, when the armament holiday year, based on the agreement of 1931 of the powers participating in the Disarmament Conference elapses, the Secretariat of the League of Nations has not received the agreement of the German Government to a prolongation of the holiday for another four months, for which a request had been sent to all the governments involved.

President Hoover received an ovation of nearly five minutes when he made a flying trip to Carnegie Hall last evening to address the overflow audience of 2,500 that had listened to his Madison Square Garden address broadcast in the hall by means of amplifiers suspended above the stage.

Plans for a dramatic appeal to independent Republicans, and particularly to those who broke away in 1912 from their party to follow another Roosevelt, were under discussion last night by independent supporters of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated yesterday at a special service commemorating the centenary of the consecration of four Bishops of the Episcopal Church, which was held at noon in St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish, Fulton Street and Broadway. The event commemorated was held in the same edifice on Oct. 31, 1832.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 31 -- Coach Anderson ordered a drastio shake-up at Notre Dame today. Captain Paul Host was demoted from first-string end to the second team in favor of Hugh Devore, Nick Lukats was ousted from left halfback on the regulars for Mike Koken and Ben Alexander was replaced at centre by Gorman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hardly ever in my life have written to a newspaper, but I feel impelled to write to you today because of the prominence you have given a man named Arthur Barry, a gem thief who escaped from Auburn, and I am wondering whether you can understand my point of view against giving any prominence, or indeed any notice, of such people in the newspapers.

Following the defeat administered to it by Boston College, the Fordham football squad began a week of intensive practice at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for its East-West battle with St. Mary's of California at the Polo Ground on Saturday.
The money market developed no variations in quotations or business on the resumption of business in the new week. Turnover was light and rates for all classes Unchanged from those of last week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- This city had its "hunger march" today, when 10,000 men, women and children chanting "We want bread" marched without disorder through the Loop and congregated in Grant Park, where speakers exhorted them to unite under the Communist flag and fight the "bosses of the capitalist class."

Joseph M. Madden of Lexington, Ky., son of one of the country's most famous turfmen, the late John E. Madden, shot and fatally wounded himself yesterday in the firearms department of Abercrombie Fitch, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Louise Holder, a 19-year-old college student, was released on $1,000 bail today while State police investigated the fatal shooting of her father, Andrew J. Holder, 42, at their home at Burning Springs today.
A stenographic report of President Hoover's address at Newark, N.J., as broadcast over Station WOR, follows:

LATONIA, Ky., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Mad Frump, which will carry the hopes of Cornelius V. Whitney in Saturday's renewal of the Latonia Championship, failed to enhance his prestige with regard to that rich stake, when he finished among the also rans in the Halloween Purse, today's feature.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 31 -- An 86 that included a 7 and three 6s gave Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol the distinction of being the low scorer in the final tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's season over the east course of the Essex County Country Club today.

HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- After a fatal political riot today at Matanzas, in which one person was killed and one seriously wounded, the government took every possible precaution tonight to prevent bloodshed in tomorrow's elections. The military forces will have complete control of public order.

TOO many football followers are donning smoked glasses and peering at the dark side of things. The attitude is not confined to any one sector. It is spread over a wide area. It must be the effect of the general depression.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Yale's varsity football squad did not visit the gridiron today. The vacation for the regulars will continue until Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A farm population of 32,000,000 for the United States by the end of 1932 was predicted by the Department of Agriculture today on the basis of compilations of the farmward trend during the first three months of this year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Those who have followed the series of speeches that Governor Roosevelt has delivered cannot have failed to be impressed by the consistency of the argument. The speeches have been uniformly urbane, good-tempered and tolerant of opposing opinion; and they have maintained the discussion on a high plane.

A scarecrow dressed gaudily for a Halloween prank threw the New Haven Railroad into turmoil for a time last evening. Some one -- very likely a small boy -- threw it from a bridge to the tracks in Mount Vernon, and it landed just in front of the Yankee Clipper.

The inadequacy of vocational guidance facilities in the Southern Appalachian mission schools was discussed yesterday at a luncheon given by the New York branch of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance to the executive board during the eighteenth annual meeting at the Hotel St. Regis.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the slowest in more than eight years for a full five-hour day. The turnover was 384,800 shares, against 360,000 on Saturday and 687,000 shares on Friday, the last five-hour day of the previous week.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31 -- Police fired rifles and machine guns on part of a crowd of 30,000 persons demonstrating today for Colonel Marmaduque Grove, who was defeated in yesterday's Presidential election by former President Arturo Alessandri.

The Delos Chappell-Robert Edmond Jones presentation of "Camille" will open at the Morosco Theatre tonight with Lillian Gish in the title role. At the Avon Theatre "Incubator," a play by John Lyman and Roman Bohnen, will have its first performance.

NEW YORK. Lady Johnstone, the former Miss Antoinette Pinchot, widow of Sir Alan Johnstone and sister of Governor Gifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania, will arrive on the Aquitania and will be at the Ambassador.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- December wheat on the Board of Trade here dropped again early today 1 cent a bushel to 43 1/8 cents, the lowest mark on record for a future. Commission houses and stop-loss selling were effective in making the decline. A somewhat oversold condition developed later and prices rallied to around Saturday's finish and closed unchanged to 1/4 cent net lower.

Bonds called for redemption last month before their dates of maturity made, with the exception of those in June, the smallest total for a month this year. They amounted to only about one-tenth of those called a year ago and were the smallest in volume for any October in the last six years.

In these lean and Spartan days the political expenses of the two major national committees are reduced to something like reasonable proportions. Between June 1 and Oct. 22 the Democratic concern received a little over $1,000,000 and spent $926,000.

Crowds jammed the Pennsylvania Station, the Waldorf-Astoria and the streets surrounding Madison Square Garden last night when President and Mrs. Hoover arrived here from Newark, but so closely were the visitors guarded by Secret Service men and city detectives that only a handful of the spectators caught more than a passing glimpse of them.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Pigeon Hole won the Au Revoir Purse, feature of the final card at Sportsman's Park today, for his eleventh victory this season.

Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and chairman of the national "share-the-work" movement, denied yesterday the charge of Alexander F. Whitney, head of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, that the drive represented "communism in its worst form."
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech here tonight was as follows:

A committee of Hoboken clergymen, representing, the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths, sent telegrams to Governor A. Harry Moore and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City yesterday declaring that unless a decision to open the Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, which was closed last Summer, were made this week they would denonnce political conditions in Hudson County, N.J., from their pulpits next Sunday.

Babylon Election Forecasts. In his Buffalo speech Mr. SMITH told the story of a king in the Bible who was sitting at a great feast when a "roar was heard outside" and a mysterious hand wrote something on the wall, and next morning it was "decoded."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- F. Lamont Belin of Scranton, Pa., a veteran foreign service officer who resigned from the service last year, will be appointed shortly by President Hoover as Ambassador to Poland, according to reports today. He will fill, the vacancy caused by the recent resignation of John N. Willys.

The Board of Estimate adopted a final budget for next year yesterday amounting to $557,141,022.73, with looting Mayor Joseph V. McKee and the bankers, to whom the city must look for $200,000,000 on Dec. 15, describing it as an unsatisfactory reduction from the current budget.

Terminating his bout with flying tackles after being thrown from the ring himself, Gus Sonnenberg, formerly recognized as a world's wrestling champion, pinned his rival, Marin Plestina of Chicago, in one of the feature bouts to a finish at the 71st Regiment Armory last night.
TORONTO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Statistics showing a rise in employment in Canada since Aug. 1 were made public today by Professor Gilbert Jackson, University of Toronto economist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Effective tomorrow, three daily transcontinental air mail flights out of New York over the New York-Kansas City-Los Angeles route, instead of two, will be started, the Postoffice Department announced today. The new schedule will include an additional round-trip passenger service on tri-motored planes between New York, Philadelphia, Harrisburg, Pittsburgh, Columbus, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Kansas City.

The "break-down of capitalism," not the administration of President Hoover, is responsible for the depression, and because both the Republican and Democratic parties "stand for the present anarchist economic and social order," the people cannot look to either of them for relief.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Senator Harrison denounced the Republicans today for making what he termed a campaign of deception and stirring up fear among the voters. His statement, telegraphed here and released by the Democratic National Committee, read:

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31 -- Handicapped by injuries to some of his regulars, Captain John J. McEwan started today to drive the Holy Cross team into shape for Brown on Saturday with a light drill. Don Kelly, Bart Hanus, Charlie Jarvis, Marty Murray and Fred Drescher are suffering from injuries.

William J. Donovan and George Z. Medalie, Republican nominees for Governor and the United States Senate, in their addresses at the Hoover meeting at Madison Square Garden last night, concentrated their fire on Governor Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Jack Hagerty, a determined looking young Irishman, fresh from the professional game, today took harge of Georgetown football and in his first five minutes on the job clossed the Notre Dame system out of the window.

Of all the New York Democrats who are candidates for office this Fall, the two whom the machine particularly wants to defeat are Assemblyman POST, in the Tenth (Manhattan) and State Senator LOVE in Brooklyn. Both of them voted their convictions against the orders of party bosses, and both were denied renomination for that reason alone.

Lou Henry Hoover kept pace with her husband, the President, as he carried his campaign north yesterday into New York. Wearying though the campaign tour may have been, Mrs. Hoover found time to smile, to accept floral offerings from welcoming committees and to remember those who were wearier and weaker than she was.

President Hoover's declared last night that the "inchoate new deal," proposed by Governor Roosevelt and his supporters would "destroy the very foundations of our government and crack the timbers of the Constitution." He made this charge when he addressed the nation by radio from a rostrum in Madison Square Garden.

NORTH BAY, Ontario, Oct. 31 -- (Canadian Press) -- The Ontario government received a check for $400,000 today, representing the approximate net earnings of the Temiskaming Northern Ontario Railway for the fiscal year ending today. The final statement will not be available until Dec. 6.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, beginning a two-day swing up-State, declared in a speech before an audience of 3,000 in Elmwood Music Hall here tonight that "both conservative parties" and their candidates were pledged to pass the sales tax, "putting the burden of a staggering deficit upon the shoulders of the workers, employed and unemployed."

New financing here last month, all of which was in bonds, was larger than in September and almost three times as large as a year ago. The total was $107,240,000, compared with $98,328,000 in September and with $37,000,000 in October, 1931.

GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- The preparatory committee meeting for the World Monetary and Economic Conference was opened here this morning by Joseph Avenol, secretary-general-elect of the League of Nations, with the warning that the situation is now "so grave as to make success absolutely indispensable."

Scarsdale, N.Y. With ten banking groups competing by means of sealed bids for an issue of $749,000 town of Scarsdale (N.Y.) Union Free School District bonds, due serially on Nov. 1, 1937 to 1963, award was made to a syndicate comprising the Bankers Trust Company and the Chase, Harris, Forbes Corporation, which bid 100.157 for the bonds as 4.40s through the Caleb Heathcote Trust Company of Scarsdale.

"Carson the Advocate," an authorized biography written by the late Edward Marjoribanks, in close cooperation with Lord Carson, is published today by Macmillan. The book is both a biography and the story, of a dozen famous trials, that of Oscar "Wilde, the Colonel Lynch treason trial, the Russell divorce case, the Archer-Shee case and the Alaska boundary case, among others.

Curtailment in the use of railroad passes, for which the managements of Eastern lines have been working more than a year, will take effect on Jan.1 when these courtesies will not be extended to officials of short or terminal lines and their issuance will be otherwise restricted.

The turnover of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in October was the smallest for any month since July and for any October since 1924, the month prior to the election of President Coolidge. The last day's business was the smallest for any full day since June, 1924, being only 384,760 shares.

DeLancey Nicoll, lawyer, who died March 31, 1931, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,855,674 gross and $1,403,603 net, which included securities valued at, $1,559,790. After making gifts of $25,000 to St. Mary's Free Hospital for Children, in memory of his daughter, Josephine, an annuity of $1,200 to his sister-in-law, Edith T. Nicoll of Montclair, N.J., and $1,000 to three servants, Mr. Nicoll gave the residue to his son, DeLancery Nicoll Jr.

MONTREAL, Que., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Appointment of R.L. Burnap, widely known among American railroad executives, as executive assistant of the Canadian National Railway lines in the United States was announced today. His office will be in Chicago.

In sharp contrast with the movement of gold a year ago, when record shipments were being sent to Europe, imports here in October, together with steady decreases of earmarked metal, caused a large increase in stocks of gold in the United States, making it the fourth consecutive month to record a gain.

The number of applications for reductions of property assessments throughout the city is expected to run far ahead of the record of 70,000 set in 1931, it was disclosed yesterday at the office of the Department of Taxes and Assessments as it prepared for the greatest rush of applications in the city's history.
