MONTREAL, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government's three-year loan, totaling $25,000,000, was oversubscribed four times today, and unofficial estimates were made that the twenty-year loan of $55,000,000 was well on the way to subscription.

LONDON Oct. 31 -- The ruins of the historic Richmond Palace were heavily guarded today following an attempt by thieves to loot the traditional treasure of Henry VII, consisting of bullion and jewelry valued at L2,000,000, which, according to legend, was secreted in a hidden tunnel beneath the palace.

Even less interest was displayed in the share market yesterday than in the closing days of last week. The speculative apathy was such that the machinery of the Stock Exchange barely moved. The brokers, after splitting the day's business, were able to meet only a fraction of their overhead expenses.

Open remuneration to football players "to an extent commensurate with their services to the university" was urged yesterday by The Columbia Spectator in its leading editorial, which suggested that, instead of operating under the present system, football be recognized as a "paid advertising medium."

The most notable aspect of the current political campaign is the endorsement by both candidates and party platforms of principles of economy and sound money, the National City Bank declares in its monthly bulletin.

There are eighty-one singers, eleven of whom are newcomers, on the roster of the Metropolitan Opera this year, according to the 1932-33 prospectus made public yesterday. Last year there were ninety-seven singers on the list, with eight newcomers.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- It was agreed at the legislative economy hearing this afternoon that in the future a board of engineers should pass upon all plans for new and reconstructed highways and their location, and that the findings of the board should be presented to the Legislature before the plans are finally submitted to contractors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The Hoboken Manufacturers Railroad Company received permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission today to issue promissory notes not exceeding $320,000 to provide funds for improving its terminal facilities and for payment of rents and taxes.

The Printers League Section of the New York Employing Printers Association yesterday rejected the proposal of New York Typographical Union 6 for arbitration of certain matters on the ground that the league had twice suggested arbitration and the union had rejected the offer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- In making a loan of $1,476,000 to the Maverick County Water Control District of Eagle Pass, Texas, the corporation estimated that work would be provided for 2,700 men for eighteen months. Of the money, to be provided through purchase by the corporation of the applicant's bonds, by far the larger part will be spent for labor, only $230,500 going for materials, such as cement, steel and lumber, according to the corporation.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Ignoring a threat by a committee of clergymen from Hoboken, representing 22,000 depositors of the closed Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, that they would expose political conditions in Hudson County from their pulpits next Sunday unless a decision to open the bank were made, Colonel William H. Kelly, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, announced after a conference here today that he had rejected a plan for reopening the bank.

TOKYO, Nov. 1. -- Plans for strengthening Japan's naval and air forces are an important feature of the supplementary building program which the navy is now discussing with the treasury in the preparation of the budget.

There is no more blessed word now than "economy." Municipal and State expenses must be cut to the bone; but there is moderation in all things. The bone would not be healthy without one good big piece of fat left to cuddle. We know what became of Mr. McKEE's plan for reducing the salaries given to our official lords and masters.

Officials of railroads and of companies or organizations interested in motor vehicle transport met in the Pennsylvania Railroad Station yesterday and discussed means by which they might reach an agreement as to what should be desirable legislation for the regulation of highway traffic.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Mrs. William Gibbs McAdoo, youngest daughter of the late President Woodrow Wilson, in a radio speech tonight, called upon American women to vote a Democratic ticket Tuesday as a protest against "the present administration's theory that the one cure for an evil condition is to ignore it."

A New York economic council to reshape the economic and financial policy of the State and to deal with agriculture, taxation, unemployment and other "new problems" confronting the State would be set up by Colonel William J. Donovan immediately upon taking office, if elected Governor, the Republican candidate declared last night in mapping a program of reconstruction.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Leopold Stokowski will conduct an orchestra of 225 men in a world-wide concert from Radio City, in New York, on New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Only 10 per cent of the building and loan associations in the United States have subscribed to stock in the Home Loan Bank System and of these, only 75 per cent are eligible to membership, officials of the Home Loan Bank Board revealed today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Those of us here who signed the recent petition of 180 economists and others to the President of the United States received on Oct. 28 the following telegram:

The Railroad Credit Corporation announced that up to yesterday it had made or authorized loans of $35,500,719 to enable railroads to meet fixed interest obligations. It derives its revenues from the freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 4. These amounted to $40,847,000 in the first eight months of the year, the total for August being $5,082,395.

Advances in the prices of gasoline were reported yesterday to be in contemplation, but the situation was confused by an announcement that the Atlantic Refining Company was putting into effect discounts ranging from 1 to 3 1/2 cents a gallon for retail and tank-wagon sales, depending upon quantity.

Lewis H. Pounds, the Republican candidate for Mayor, changed yesterday that the Tammany administration at City Hall had "discarded and ignored" the reports of the Committee on Plan and Survey which Mayor Walker had appointed in 1926 because it was "discovered that putting some of the recommendations into effect would eliminate millions in annual municipal expenditure."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The text of the speech broadcast by Senator Carter Glass of Virginia over a nation-wide hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight is as follows:

HARBIN, Wednesday, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Two of,the sharpest battles in the recent Manchurian campaign were fought Sunday and Monday along the Tsitsihar-Koshan Railway, Japanese military leaders in Harbin were informed today.

Donations to philanthropies should become a duty on a par with the payment of taxes, Mrs. Felix Warburg said yesterday at a rally and tea of the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies in the home of Adolph Lewisohn, 881 Fifth Avenue.

"Singapore" a melodrama by Harold Woolf, stage manager at "Of Thee I Sing," will be presented at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre on Monday evening, Nov. 14. Betty Linley and Suzanne Caubaye will head the cast, which will include Elizabeth Mears, Edward Broadley and Ann Caruth.

Formation of five new Stock Exchange firms, Bach, White Co., Brumley Anderson, Raven, Brown Price, George D.B. Bonbright Co. of Rochester, N.Y., and Mortimer W. Loewi Co. was announced yesterday by the Exchange. The firm of Mortimer W. Loewi Co. succeeds a firm with the same name which has been dissolved.

Reports of the national committees of the two major parties, filed for the period up to the last week of October, reveal once more that the great mass of the American people are willing to leave the financing of campaigns to the rich -- or, as currently called, "the new poor."

The Harvard Club's Class A squash racquets team, which swept through without a defeat last year in the Metropolitan League, started with a victory last night in the first squash racquets team play of the season.

Through the cooperation, of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board a Brooklyn division of the Home Mortgage Advisory Board has just been formed. D.E. McAvoy, secretary of the home board, announces that with this addition there are now four sectipnal divisions of the advisory board actively functioning in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Rear Admiral Edward Radcliffe, Evans, whose career in the Royal Navy since 1897 has been marked by a rapid succession of promotions and distinguished services, was promoted today to Vice Admiral. Vice Admiral Sir William Doyle, president of the Royal Naval College and former commander of the reserve fleet, has been promoted to Admiral.

The Rev. Rollin Dodd and one of his supporters left a meeting last night of the vestry of All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, in an attempt to block the passage of a resolution that he considered would ruin the church financially.

LATTINGTOWN, L.I., Nov. 1. -- Two electricians who had been called to repair a water pump above an underground tank on the estate here of Harvey Dow Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee of New York City, were injured critically today when the tank exploded.

Puccini's "Tosca," given last night by the San Carlo Grand Opera Company at the New Amsterdam Theatre, presented Bianca Saroya in the title role, Mario Valle as Scarpia and Edward Molitore as Mario. Few operas are as skillfully written to blend the dramatic and musical elements which in older works are often woefully at war or frankly divorced.
LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The government announced tonight a new medium-term conversion loan of u300,000,000 ($986,250,000 at the current rate) to meet heavy obligations falling due between now and Feb. 1.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. While the new International contract bridge laws speak for themselves, I propose in the following article, written in reply to a number of requests, to give a few supplementary pointers in the hope that they may help players to understand the new laws and simplify scoring calculations.
Santa Claus Seasonal Q. -- Now as to this nomination for the Supreme Court, how did you happen to come into possession of it?

Bond prices drifted lower yesterday on the Stock Exchange, with the turnover $6,066,000, compared with Monday's $5,768,500, which was the Slowest trading since Dec. 24, 1928. United States Government issues showed about the best average strength, finishing unchanged to 3-32 point higher, except the Treasury 4 1/4s, which lost 1-32 point.

The text of Newton D. Baker's speech in Brooklyn is on Page 10. Warning the nation that the greatest danger which confronts it at this time "is Mr. Hoover's sudden and violent conversion to the Hawley-Smoot tariff," Newton D. Baker declared last night in a campaign address at Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn, that the economic collapse of the last three years was directly attributable to the "extraordinarily contradictory" program of Republican administrations since the war.

The Citizens Budget Commission considered the 1933 municipal budget yesterday, and in a statement issued by the chairman of its trustees, Peter Grimm, pronounced the passage of the budget through the Board of Estimate "the occasion for a curious mixture of gratification and disappointment, in which disappointment predominates."

The factors contributing to the economic success of women, placement trends in college appointment bureaus and the occupational outlook for women in a dozen major professions were summarized yesterday by a group of vocational experts at the final session of the annual convention of the Southern Woman's Educational Alliance at the Hotel St. Regis.

President HOOVER expressed his fears, under various heads, that the American System is in grave danger. He needn't be afraid. Like the world, it is a tough old institution which goes on much the same, generation after generation. Especially as understood and exemplified by our politicians, the American System always runs true to form.

Before many audiences President HOOVER has predicted that disaster would follow any substantial reduction of our present tariff. "The very "basis of safety to American agriculture is the protective tariff on "farm products," he said in his Des Moines address.

To say that the new "Camille," which came to the Morosco last evening, is a museum-piece is to tell something of the truth but not enough. For museum-pieces may be dingy and faded. But the 'Camille" which Robert Edmond Jones has designed and in which Lillian Gish is acting has a strange, quaint sort of magic.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Prices of wheat were on the downgrade again today and for the third straight session the December on the Board of Trade here dropped into new record low ground, selling 1/4 cent a bushel below yesterday's inside figure and 1 cent under the low mark made on Saturday.

GENEVA, Nov. 1. -- Measures in the United States aimed to put more money into circulation, far from raising commodity prices, merely sent more currency down into the cellars of banks while prices failed to respond. Professor John H. Williams of Harvard told the committee of experts, discussing today the monetary phase of the coming world economic conference.

President Hoover's Madison Square Garden address was hailed yesterday by Republican leaders and sympathizers as "magnificent" and "courageous." Democrats, on the other hand, were unanimous in their opinions that it was a speech of "desperation."

The exhibition of pastels by Mary Cassatt at the Durand-Ruel Galleries brings together exceptionally fine examples of this American artist's work in a medium also used with such striking effect by Degas, whose art was so important an influence in Miss Cassatt's life.

With the football season turning into the home-stretch and the situation made crystal clear on all fronts, the moment is timely for a cut-back to get a proper perspective of the whirlwind that has thrown the prophets into confusion.

To the Editor of The New York Times. In view of the fact that the Democratic party nominated Franklin D. Roosevelt and John T. Garner, your editorial "Looking for a Change" carries slight conviction. That one demonstration of lack of even ordinary intelligence is sufficient to condemn the party, and destroys any confidence which the public might otherwise have as to the Democratic ability to guide the nation.

Several violations by the managerial group of the Minimum Basic Agreement between the Actors' Equity Association and the Managers' Protective Association will soon be brought up before an arbitration board.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The financial readjustment plan for the Frisco Railroad, now being advanced through a receivership, was put forward when the Reconstruction Finance Corporation made such a plan the condition of any further loan after granting its first loan to the road.

Working indoors because of the heavy rain, the Fordham football squad was sent through an intensive drill in the college gymnasium yesterday. The Maroon eleven polished its offense in preparation for the encounter with St. Mary's of California at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Always intelligent and nearly always good humored in its comments on the protective tariff and all its works, THE TIMES is occasionally a little inaccurate in its implications of facts. For example, in the editorial "Charges of Dumping."
LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 2. -- A drift of voters back to the Labor party is indicated by the first results of the municipal elections held in 300 cities and towns of England and Wales yesterday.

The present coalition government of Japan does not represent a militaristic tendency but, rather, a popular disgust with the opportunism of the nation's two political parties, Jiuji G. Kasai, a member of the Superior Council of the Tokyo Municipal Assembly and president of the International Publishing Company of Japan, said in an interview yesterday.

A dummy scrimmage in which the New York University varsity football team opposed team C was a highlight of yesterday's two-hour drill at Ohio Field. The Violet squad continued its preparations for its intersectional meeting with the University of Georgia on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

THE proposal to give the thrower of a forward pass on a touchdown play equal credit with the receiver a suggestion advanced by Gus Dorais of Detroit, is running into further difficulties. One inquirer wants to know many points should be credited to a passer whose spiral toss, through interception, leads to a touchdown for the opposing side.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Princeton stressed its passing attack during a two-hour practice session on University Field today in preparation for the Lehigh game Saturday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1. -- The steamship Pedro I, Brazil's floating prison, which has been anchored in Rio de Janeiro Bay, sailed away without previous, announcement this morning with seventy-five military and civilian leaders of the unsuccessful Paulistan revolt.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, running for re-election on the Democratic ticket, last night denounced President Hoover's campaign as "fear propaganda" and declared the fact that Republican leadership was resorting to it showed that it was "so panic-stricken with the prospect of defeat that it has abandoned every consideration of caution and restraint."

Beginning the month without any flurry, the stock market displayed again yesterday the familiar preelection apathy. The transactions on the Stock Exchange made up a total of 522,000 shares, compared with 385,000 shares on the day before. The slow reaction was associated, in the Wall Street mind, with the further decline in wheat.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, will arrive today with Lady Lindsay on the Aquitania. Others due on the ship include Sir Arthur Salter, Lady Mendl, Lady Johnstone, sister of Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania; Count and Countess Pecciblent and Miss Harriet Cohen and Egon Petri, pianists.

Representatives of all of the American-owned steamship lines operating between the Atlantic seaboard and the West Indies, Central America and the northern ports of South America have agreed to meet this morning with spokesmen of the transatlantic steamship lines to discuss the Winter cruise trade to the Caribbean.

Mrs. Daniel O'Day, vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee, drew a murmur of indignation from a group of fifty prominent women yesterday by recounting some of the tactics which she said were being employed by up-State Republicans to swing votes into the Hoover column.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Six months, of racing in Illinois came to an end with the closing of the nineteen-day meeting at Sportsman's Park yesterday. The thoroughbreds will not pound over the turf again in the Chicago district until May 1 of next year.
ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- Governor Roosevelt completed tonight one of the most strenuous days of campaigning ever undertaken by a Presidential candidate.

Almost 7,000,000 hunting licenses were issued in the United states last year. This number, according to a survey of various States, will be equaled if not surpassed this season. Economic conditions, however, have changed, judging from the number of inquiries received for information on private hunting preserves where the public is welcome.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The possibility of the announcement of Prince George's engagement to Princess Ingrid of Sweden seemed more likely than ever today with a report that Prince George would receive a dukedom on his thirtieth birthday, Dec. 20.

An upward trend of building in 1933 and "a future greater and more prosperous than, the industry has ever before known" were predicted here last night at the Architectural League by Rolland J. Hamilton, president of the American Radiator Company, addressing the ninth semi-annual dinner of the Producers Council, a national association of manufacturers of building material, affiliated with the American Institute of Architects.

An Englishman -- a botanist, to judge by his technical knowledge of ferns and palms -- recently made the mistake of visiting Juan Fernandez, Robinson Crusoe's island. His shattered illusions make doleful reading in The London Times. A mass of land that towered several thousand feet some 400 miles off Valparaiso looked promising enough from the deck of a steamer.

A big audience, and a brilliant one, assisted, as the French say, at the first of the concerts to be given this season by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra of otherwise unemployed players last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. The occasion opened with an unconventional reading by Sandor Harmati of the noble symphony of Cesar Franck.

To the Editor of The New Y.prk Times: There should be a moratorium called on candidates' speeches. They have both called each other everything in the world they can think of. From now on they are just talking themselves out of votes.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 1. -- A business and bank holiday extending until Nov. 12 was declared throughout the State of Nevada today by Leut. Gov. Morley Griswold, acting in the absence of Governor Fred B. Balzar, who is in Washington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his speech at Madison Square Garden last night, President Hoover, made, what purported to be an exact quotation from his speech of acceptance at Palo Alto four years ago, as follows:

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Tammany candidate for Mayor, promised yesterday that after he was elected he would institute a vigorous campaign of police warfare against radical agitators and "preserve the metropolis against the army that gathers in Union Square."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1. -- Joe Crowley, veteran Yale back, who wrenched his shoulder in the Dartmouth game last Saturday and went to the hospital, was able to appear at recitations today with his arm in a sling.

Dean Archibald L. Bouton of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science announced yesterday that places on the honor roll had been awarded to 101 students of that institution. Last year 114 students were named on the roll.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity is again slightly lower at 24.8 for tthe week ended Oct. 29, as compared with 25.0 for the preceding week and 41.3 for the corresponding week last year. This is based on estimates indicating that actual operations ware little changed from those of the preceding week.

Following is the official transcript of Newton D. Baker's address last night in Brooklyn. Naturally I appreciate the very gracious and complimentary phrases which Mr. Swope has used in introducing me to you. This campaign, I regret to say, has seemed to grow in bitterness in its latter stages. I myself shall not enter upon that kind of debate.

Crude oil production in the United States averaged 2,096,600 barrels daily last week, compared with 2,159,150 barrels in the previous week, showing a decrease of 62,550 barrels, according to the estimate of the American Petroleum Institute yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Prices of the best hogs dropped today to $3.35 a hundredweight, a new low mark since 1896, barring Saturday, and then came within 5 cents of the bottom figure recorded in December, 1878. The day's average fell 10 cents to $3.15, equaling the low of June 4.

A gale from the southeast which rushed across the metropolitan area about noon yesterday at a seventy-mile-an-hour clip toppled three frame houses at the Summer colony of Broad Channel, Queens, into Jamaica Bay; whipped roofs and timbered walls about like paper scraps and caused damage estimated at $175,000 to fifty homes and business structures in Broad Channel and Rockaway Beach.
NEW YORK. Mrs. John W. Garrett, Wife of the American Ambassador to Rome, is visiting her sister, Mrs. Ralph Ellis, at River House.

Edwin Markham's new poem, "The Forgotten Man," which he has "dedicated to Franklin D. Roosevelt, after hearing his lofty and noble appeal for the forgotten man," was made public yesterday by the Democratic National Committee. Among the famous poet's works are "The Man With the Hoe" and "Lincoln, the Man of the People."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 1. -- Bill Clark, stocky back who has been alternating with Gordon Chung-Hoon at left half on the Naval Academy team, was used at quarterback in practice today and may start at that position against Columbia here Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced, approval today of a $3,957,000 loan to the Hillside Housing Corporation of New York City for the construction of low-cost model apartments in the Bronx, and a tentative agreement to lend $3,400,000 to the New York State Bridge Authority for building a bridge across the Hudson at Catskill.
Play continued yesterday in the Eastern sectional three-cushion tournament, a preliminary to the national championship play, at both the Strand Academy and Doyle's Academy.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Heavy rain forced the Army to abandon plans for a full speed defensive scrimmage today in preparation for the game witth Harvard.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 1. -- Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt, showing in all sections, won nine blue ribbons, six reds and two yellows in the first day's judging of the twenty-seventh annual chrysanthemum exhibition of the Nassau County Horticultural Society which opened this afternoon in the main building in the oval on the Pratt estate.

The attack by Senator GLASS on the Hoover Administration's policies is marked by his well-known incisiveness. He is always a powerful controversialist, invariably forces the fighting and seldom spares the foe. If he is not always fair in every respect to the other side, we have grown accustomed to that of late.
The rain could not dampen Columbia's football ardor yesterday at Baker Field as the Lions commenced intensive preparations for their contest with the Naval Academy at Annapolis on Saturday.

Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, assailed yesterday the refusal of bankers to market more than $3,000,000 of city securities for home and work relief for the unemployed and demanded that the city go directly to the people in a campaign to sell $30,000,000 worth of "hunger bonds" to feed the destitute.

What was put down on the police records yesterday as a frustrated hold-up was considered by Miss Eve Corry, 24-year-old assistant to Dr. Leo L. Rubin, a dentist of 311 Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, as retributive justice which evened her score with robbers.

Statements of earnings of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York and its principal subsidiaries, issued yesterday, show a combined net income of $61,626,639 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, equal, after preferred dividends and minority interest in subsidiaries, to $50,070,081, or $4.36 a share on the 11,476,527 shares of common stock outstanding.

Ross Norton McDiarmid, 14-year-old Winnipeg (Canada) boy who disappeared from his home city on Oct. 22 and has been traced as far as Cleveland, where he was believed to have been seen on Monday, was sought here yesterday by his father, John S. McDiarmid, a lumber dealer.

An easier tone in commercial paper, with the best names selling in greater volume at 11/2 per cent than previously, was the only exception to an otherwise quiet and uneventful money market. Other names were also shaded a fraction. On the Stock Exchange the day loan rate remained at 1 per cent and outside trades at 1/2.

George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch, candidates of the Independent Judges party for the Supreme Court in opposition to State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer, bipartisan nominees, were endorsed yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise.

Schenectady, N.Y. The Guaranty Company obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $400,000 Schenectady (N.Y.) road bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1933 to 1944, at its bid of 100.1599 for the bonds, to bear interest at the rate of 3.70 per cent.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 1. -- Changing Cyrus S. Eaton, founder and former president of Continental Shares, Inc., a Cleveland investment trust, with wrecking the company for private gain and causing the loss of $112,000,000 in stock values to investors in it, counsel for George L. Gugle, a stockholder, sought in court here today to throw the concern into receivership.

Harold W. Bonwit, a debenture bondholder of Philadelphia, filed suit yesterday in Federal court here asking for the appointment of an equity receiver for the Garment Centre Capitol, Inc., the real estate venture of Saul Singer, who was executive vice president of the defunct Bank of United States.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- The great event today on the Boerse was the introduction of the government's tax-redemption certificates, which were quoted officially for the first time since they were created in Chancellor von Papen's economic reconstruction plan last August.
LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Somerset Maugham's, new play, ''For Services Rendered," proved tonight to be a bitter and depressing drama, utterly unlike Maugham's usual sophisticated work.

The annual report of the Jewish Agency for Palestine to the Permanent Mandates Commission of the League of Nations will be submitted to the Secretary General at Geneva today, the fifteenth anniversary of the Balfour declaration.

Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, addressing 300 associates on the citizens committee of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, declared yesterday that the general industrial situation was more promising than it had been for two years.

When the prosecution had ended its case yesterday in General Sessions at the extortion trial of Mrs. Antoinette Barbo, 48 years old, East Harlem settlement worker, Judge Donnellan, on the motion of defense counsel, ordered the defendant's acquittal.

A legal fight for the possession of two paintings commemorating Admiral Peary's visit to the Arctic region was foreshadowed yesterday when Gaspare M. Cusumano, an attorney of 44 Whitehall Street, filed in Surrogate's Court the will of Albert Jasper Ludwig Roccobigliera Operti, artist and explorer, who died of pneumonia, in his seventy-fifth year on Oct. 29, 1927, at the Explorers' Club.

OSHAWA, Ont., Nov. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Bullet Joe Simpson predicts that his New York Americans will give the Toronto Maple Leafs a great battle for the Stanley Cup this season. Following the best workout of the year so far, Simpson was the speaker at today's luncheon of the Oshawa Kiwanis Club, and alluded to the season's prospects.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover planted an oak in the yard of the Gordon Junior High School this afternoon, at the conclusion of a ceremony in which she received a desk tray of beaten copper, a rag doll for Peggy Ann and a model airplane for Peter, her grandchildren, the handiwork of the school children.

Shoe retailers and manufacturers were urged to develop new styles, emphasize quality more, dramatize their promotions and rehabilitate their plants and stores to aid the capital goods industries at the semi-annual style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association, held yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1. -- J.W.Y. Martin's 5-year-old mare, Con Amore, scored her first victory since the meeting at Arlington last July when she staged a game finish in the Country Club Purse, feature today at Pimlico, to beat Kincsen, also a 5-year-old mare, by a head. Cabezo was third, half a length back of Kincsen.

The Appellate Division heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on the appeal by Mrs. Katherine Rogers, Queens taxpayer, from the decision of Supreme Court Justice Cohn refusing to strike the names of John P. O'Brien and Lewis H. Pounds from the Mayoralty ballot.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1 (AP). -- Santa Paula, the team which probably will be taken intact as Argentina's representative in the coming international polo matches against the United States, entered the find of the Argentine open polo championship today with an impressive 16-to-4 victory over Los Indios.

GENEVA, Nov. 1. -- The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations will open a long session here Thursday with Palestine, Syria and the Pacifip Islands under Japanese administration among the leading questions before it.

Two exhibitions that revive styles of former years were opened yesterday. A display of nineteenth century wedding gowns, all worn at weddings in this city, opened to the public at the Museum of the City of New York after a private showing on Monday.
Upper west side housing properties figured prominently in Manhattan realty trading yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The text of Secretary Mills's radio address replying to that of Senator Glass tonight was as follows:

For a hundred years the port of Baltimore has dreamed of a way across the head of the Maryland-Delaware peninsula, and through the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, for its deep-water ships bound for Europe. From Baltimore to Cape Charles, Virginia, at the other end of Chesapeake Bay, steamships have now about 140 miles to go before reaching open water.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP). -- In the fighting between the unemployed and the police tonight in Victoria Embankment, the mobs pulled destination signs from tramcars and used them as clubs. Numerous attempts to set automobiles afire were made, the favorite method being to throw lighted matches toward gasoline tanks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- President Hoover approved plans today for three more major speeches on a fifth "back-platform" swing through the battleground of the Middle West. At the same time he was holding open the proposal to go to his home in Palo Alto, Cal., to vote.

Fourteen conferences on current financial and business problems, to be held on Thursdays at 5 P.M. in the governors' room of the New York Stock Exchange, were announced yesterday by the New York group of the Investment Bankers Association of America and New York University.

The outstanding points of interest, yesterday, in markets which for the most part moved apathetically, were the continued recovery of sterling and the continued fall of wheat. The pound sterling, which rose 5/8 cent on Monday, scored a more emphatic advance of 2 1/4 cents yesterday, bringing the price for sight bills, at $3.31, to a figure 3 1/2 cents above last week's lowest, although still 25 1/8 cents below October's highest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Senator Glass in a radio speech at 10:15 o'clock tonight denounced President Hoover, and one hour later Secretary Mills, after he had obtained an advance copy of the Glass speech, followed him on the same broadcasting chain with a vigorous defense of the administration.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 1. -- With his gaze focused on a distant horizon that fakes in the Pasadena Rose Bowl, the undefeated Brown Bear is girding himself for the dangerous journey he must make before he can gain an invitation to enter those famous football portals.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 1 (AP). -- Stanford University has not lost confidence in the Warner brand of football despite two straight setbacks and on the campus and in alumni circles the sentiment is for "Old Pop" -- Coach Glenn Scobey Warner.

OTTAWA, Nov. 1 (Canadian Press) -- As from today, Canada's maritime jurisdiction, so far as it affects Canadian-owned, vessels, extends to twelve miles offshore, from low tide. This is the effect of a proclamation issued here today in an extra of the Canada Gazette.

OTTAWA, Nov. 1 (Canadian Press) -- As from today, Canada's maritime jurisdiction, so far as it affects Canadian-owned, vessels, extends to twelve miles offshore, from low tide. This is the effect of a proclamation issued here today in an extra of the Canada Gazette.

MADRID, Nov. 1. -- Premier Herriot of France with apparently go back to Paris with assurances that the French disarmament plan will have the support of the newest "little entente" -- Spain, Belgium, Holland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Czechoslovakia and Switzerland, which have pooled their interests on the disarmament question at Geneva.

Declaring that "this is the psychological moment" for the automobile industry to lead the way back to better times, Walter P. Chrysler yesterday addressed his corporation's 20,000 dealers and salesmen over the Columbia broadcasting network. The occasion was the introduction of the new Plymouth six, and it was said to be the first time that radio had been used to present a new car to a dealer organization.

Rallying last night after a disastrous start in the afternoon, the contract bridge team of David Burnstine, Howard Schenken, Charles S. Lochridge and Richard L. Frey had a lead of 225 points over P. Hal Sims, Willard S. Karn, Waldemar von Zedwitz and Harold S. Vanderbilt as the halfway mark was reached in the final of the annual Vanderbilt Cup tournament at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 1. -- Count Raoul d'Adhemar and Countess d'Adhemar, who were married here last Saturday, returned to the colony today after a short wedding trip. Countess d'Adhemar is the former Mrs. Emeline Darler Barnhill of New York and Washington.

In a secondary phase of the current market reaction, stocks relinquished in October a greater part of the gains made in the advance, which eliminated on Sept. 8, than in September. Trading, however, was considerably smaller than in the previous month.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The hunger marchers' attempt to force their was into the House of Commons failed utterly tonight, but they and their sympathizers plunged the very heart of the British Empire into turmoil for three hours and led fierce clashes between the police and the unemployed.

Production of gold in the United States has increased faster this year than in any other country, according to an estimate made yesterday by the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The output in August was 241,000 fine ounces, equivalent to $4,981,470, compared with 174,000 ounces, worth $3,596,580, in January, an increase of 38.4 per cent.

A suit to foreclose on two leasehold mortgages aggregating $4,500,000 on the property known as the Squibb Building, at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the Continental Bank and Trust Company as trustee under a trust deed made in 1929 by the Abenad Realty Corporation to the S.W. Straus Investing Corporation.

W. Bostrom, Swedish Minister to the United States, arrived yesterday on the Swedish-American liner Gripsholm after spending two months at his Summer home near Gothenburg. He was accompanied by Mrs. Bostrom and by Baron Johan BeckFries, counselor of the Swedish Legation in Washington.

Dun's index number of average commodity prices as of Nov. 1 indicates average reduction, in the entire list of scheduled commodities, of 1 3/8 per cent during October. This follows an advance in the average of 1 7/8 per cent in September, of 4 7/8 in August and of 2 3/4 per cent in July.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- Demands in the House of Commons for further elucidation of the position of Canadian wheat in reference to preferential tariff treatment in the United Kingdom brought a statement today from Leslie Hore-Belisha, Financial Secretary of the Treasury, that "mere transit of Canadian goods across the United States will not prevent them securing British preferences, provided the goods were definitely consigned from Canada to the United Kingdom."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 1. -- In an effort to put into effect a financial reorganization required for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, known as the Frisco, in Federal court here today joined in the suit of a creditor asking for appointment of a receiver.

A further slight decline occurred in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday after the market had displayed resistance for several hours. The action of securities and new low records for wheat unsettled sentiment in the absence of an active demand for mill sources.

Appeals for contributions to Governor Roosevelt's campaign fund were issued yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, and former Governor Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, chairman of the executive finance committee, as the speakers' bureau planned an intensive drive for votes in the metropolitan area between now and election day.

WASHINaTON, Nov. 1. -- The newest authorized, addition to the first line of the French Navy, the Dunkerque is neither a light cruiser nor a "pocket battleship." She is to be the last word in modern battlecruiser construction and is France's, answer to Germany's famous Ersatz Preussen and her announced sister ship.

Thorvald Solberg, who spent fiftyfour years of his life in the Library of Congress fighting what he terms "barbaric and stupid copyright laws," arrived yesterday on the Swedish-American liner Gripsholm from his first visit to Norway, the land of his forefathers.

LATONIA, Nov. 1 (AP). -- The fifth dash, a three-quarter affair for 2-year-old fillies, proved the best attraction today, at Latonia, and the winner turned up in the Greentree Stable's Soeur Blanche, outsider, which overhauled Milton Reiser's odds-on-favorite, Muslet, at the stretch turn and was never headed.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The Canadian author, Miss Florence Deeks, who is seeking u100,000 damages from H.G. Wells and the Macmillan Publishing Company, collapsed today while addressing the judicial committee of the Privy Council, to which she had carried an appeal after losing in the courts.

The cooperation of the French and British Armies in the decisive Battle of the Marne was decided at a tea table where Marshal Joffre, ordinarily as little given to impassioned speeches as Calvin Coolidge, made an emotional appeal to Field Marshal Sir John French, commanding the British forces, and won his promise to cooperate.

Many boys from New York City and vicinity will see action in one of the football classics of the New England prep school ranks, the forty-fourth annual Groton School-St. Mark's School gridiron game, scheduled for Wednesday, Nov. 9, at Groton, Mass. Both squads contain a number of players who hail from the metropolitan area.

HAVANA, Nov. 1. -- Three persons were slain and twenty wounded in gun battles between opposing political groups today as Cuba went to the polls to elect municipal and provincial officials, Representatives and three Senators.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 1. -- Miss Mary Schwab, 23, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Schwab, Normandy Park, Morristown, N.J., and niece of Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, is in Easton Hospital seriously injured and three other young women are also receiving hospital treatment as the result of an automobile accident on the road between Bloomsbury and Phillipsburg, N.J., early today.

A recommendation to unite the New York and New Jersey Cricket Association and the Metropolitan District Cricket League was made at a joint meeting of delegates representing clubs in those organizations held yesterday at the Crescent A.C.-Hamilton Club in Brooklyn.

Acting Mayor McKee, disregarding Controller Berry's warning that he would be held responsible if the city found itself in contempt of the United States Supreme Court for failure to provide new incinerators by next June, forced the Board of Estimate yesterday to throw out bids submitted on the $2,000,000 contract and readvertise the work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Shipping Board authorized today the acceptance of a bid by the Boston Iron and Metal Company of Baltimore to dismantle and scrap 124 government-owned surplus ships. The contract price is $1.51 per gross ton of recoverable material, the work to be performed within three years.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1. -- Rain drove the Harvard football squad indoors today, but the big baseball cage provided plenty of room for all the work the coaches had planned.

The United States Freight Company, a forwarding company which operates largely over the lines of the New York Central Railroad, announced yesterday that, because of an improvement in business, reductions of 16 2-3 made in salaries and wages last Spring had been restored as of Sept. 1.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Hiram Johnson, Senator from California, called upon Progressives of the State last night to support the Democratic ticket next Tuesday as they supported the Progressive movement in California in 1910 when "we had a Republican party dominated by a corrupt machine."

Dr. Alexander Alekhine, chess champion of the world, arrived here yesterday on board the steamship Oriente of the Ward Line, a day behing his schedule. Because of this his performance at the Engineers Club in Baltimore had to be postponed until tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press). -- The government tonight held to its stand that Canadian wheat consigned direct from Canada to the United Kingdom would enjoy a tariff preference of 6 cents a bushel, but that wheat from the Dominion shipped to the United States and reconsigned from there would get no preference.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The hunger marchers who converged on London in a dozen shabby processions last week started home-ward today, disillusioned after the failure of last night's "march on Parliament."

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Answering statements made by Senator Carter Glass of Virginia last night in a radio speech about the policy of the State Department in respect to foreign loans. Secretary of State Stimson today said:

MUKDEN, Manchuria (Thursday), Nov. 3. -- Sixty insurgent soldiers were killed today when they rushed into electrically charged wire used as part of the defenses of the Fenghuangcheng station on the Mukden-Antung Railway, the Rengo (Japanese) News Agency reported from Antung.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Excepting Philadelphia, which felt the decline in the total Pennsylvania registration, all of the big cities show increased registrations this year. Some of them, follow, with comparisons for 1928:

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has selected the Bronx for its first experiment in housing. The loan, is in the comparatively moderate sum of $3,957,000, representing two-thirds of the proposed investment. The promoters of the project, including ex-Senator NATHAN STRAUS Jr., who owns the land, will furnish the equity money, thus avoiding difficulties on that score which some other housing projects have encountered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Government expenditures in the first four months of the current fiscal year were reduced considerably below the decline in revenue, with the result that the deficit was $44,686,867 less than, for the corresponding period of last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- While wheat prices failed to break into new low grounds today on the Board of Trade here, the distant future equaled the lowest figures recorded so far, and the rally of around 1/4 cent a bushel from the bottom was not regarded as impressive by pit brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Protests from several New York business organizations and realty interests against the loan of $3,957,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Hillside Housing Corporation of New York for construction of model low-cost apartments in the Bronx were received by the corporation today.
Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, returned yesterday on the Cunarder Aquitania from a three-month vacation, accompanied by his niece, Lady Elizabeth Lindsay.

The Joint Committee of Railroads and Highway Users concluded a meeting in the Pennsylvania Station yesterday without arriving at an agreement on a policy for highway traffic regulation, but it issued a statement saying that it was expected such an agreement would be reached.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Fourteen-year-old Ross McDiarmid, son of J.S. McDiarmid, Minister of Mines and Natural Resources of Manitoba, slumbered comfortably today on a cot in the Village Hall jail at Willoughby, a Cleveland suburb.
LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The government refused to commit itself today on either the disarmament or Manchurian problems despite insistent prodding in both Houses of Parliament.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 2. -- Mrs. Ewing R. Philbin gave a luncheon here today for Miss Mabel Choate. Mrs. Mathilda W. Williams also entertained with luncheon, in honor of Mrs. Lanier Pole.
Pointing for the Intersectional battle with St. Mary's of California at the Polo Grounds on Saturday, the Fordham football squad continued its program of intensive work at Fordham Field yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- Governor Roosevelt was preparing today for the finish of his campaign after his whirlwind automobile trip through New England yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The Princeton freshman eleven gave Coach Crisler's varsity stern opposition in a forty-five-minute scrimmage today.

The Jewish celebration of the fifteenth anniversary yesterday of the Balfour Declaration was begun by Morris Rothenberg, president of the Zionist Organization of America, with the announcement that President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt had sent messages of greeting.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the recent action of the committee on stock list in striking from the list twelve matured bond issues apparently was being used to persuade certain holders to dispose of the bonds for the purpose of acquiring other securities, some of which were of doubtful value.

A thorough rehearsal of passing formations marked the first practice session of the Manhattan eleven in preparation for its election day game with its traditional rival, City College. A two-hour session on Manhattan Field awaited the Jaspers yesterday after the three-day layoff following their 20-7 triumph over Oglethorpe.

Picturing Governor Roosevelt as "a routine Governor and a very expensive one" and as a candidate without a program, Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, in an address at a Republican rally in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night challenged again the Governor's qualifications for the Presidency and accused him of "downright meanness" in his criticism of President Hoover.
Lady Astor, member of Parliament, is to arrive this afternoon from London on the Leviathan of the United States Lines to visit a relative Who is seriously ill.

Political circles have been wondering in the last few days how many voters in the city would attempt to register anti-Tammany protest votes in the Mayoralty election by writing in the name of Acting Mayor McKee on the voting machines.

GENEVA, Nov. 2. -- Restoration of the gold exchange standard as the best way to get back to gold was urged today by Leon Fraser, the American who is vice president of the Bank for International Settlements.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 2. -- Victor Downs, 44 years old, former Norfolk policeman, who went on trial in the Supreme Court here yesterday charged with the murder of Frank Tuthill, chiropodist of Quogue, was released in bail on a robbery charge tonight following the dismissal of the murder indictment against him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the pending, continuation, of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and the immediate necessity of understandings between the nations principally involved as to the broad outlines on which a reduction in arms may be based, the report in today's newspapers of the French plan as stated yesterday by M. Herriot, and which has the support of the Chamber of Deputies, is of great significance.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- G.H. (Pete) Bostwick's Masked Knight, with the owner riding, 1 to 2 favorite in the featured race at Pimlico today, was beaten by Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Magyar in what was the major upset on the card.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Every day brings fresh proofs of Mr. Hoover's prescience. Mr. Hamlin Garland tells us in today's TIMES that "more than two years ago" Mr. Hoover warned him that "the depression had only just begun. He was even then marshaling his forces to meet the coming storm."
GENEVA, Nov. 2. -- From the early deliberations of the committees that are preparing the way for the world monetary and economic conference, two prospects already seem definitely to stand out.

State of Idaho. Award of a new issue of $225,000 State of Idaho general fund treasury notes, dated Nov. 1, 1932, and maturing on Aug. 1, 1933, has been made to Hallgarten Co. and R.W. Pressprich Co. at their joint bid of par plus a premium, of $30 for the notes to bear interest at the rate of 3 1/2 per cent.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 2. -- Prizes offered by Mrs. Junius S. Morgan for the most original and the most natural table decorations were awarded today to Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt Jr., exhibiting for the first time in this show, and Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field of Huntington, in the final day's judging of the annual chrysanthemum exhibition of the Nassau County Horticultural Society which closed tonight on the Pratt estate here.

New York University has received gifts and bequests amounting to $1,182,605.35, the larger part of the total coming from the estate of the late Dr. William H. Nichols, a graduate of the class of 1870, It was announced yesterday by William. M. Kingsley, treasurer of the university.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The New York Central Railroad Company was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to borrow $2,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to finance repairs to its rolling stock.

MADRID, Nov. 2. -- Premier Herriot left here tonight for France on the Sud express after having learned what another great Frenchman, Napoleon, found out more than a hundred years ago -- namely, that the Spanish people, whatever policies their governments may adopt, will not be willing allies of the French.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 2. -- Rabbi Jacob R. Marcus of the Hebrew Union College, chairman of the committee on contemporaneous history, submitted a report to the Central Conference of American Rabbis today in which he advocated that the "mass hysteria of the anti-Semitic movement be met with united national and international organization of Jews and by uncompromising resistance.''

A woman and two men were held yesterday on murder charges growing from the death on Monday of Achille Mirner, Parisian jeweler, who died after being beaten in a west side speakeasy Saturday night. The three -- who were arrested Tuesday night -- were said by the police to be the owners of the speakeasy -- a fly-by-night affair on Seventy-fourth Street.
Liberty Versus Monotony In the matter of liberty versus dictatorship one might take the case of Madison Square Garden.

Aviation enthusiasts, in particular, should enjoy the exhibition of prints by John MacGilchrist, which will continue at the Harlow-McDonald Galleries through November. This artist, who served in the Royal Air Corps, is interested almost exclusively in aviation as subject-matter for his etchings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- At the end of a busy day of preparation for his trip to the West, President Hoover delayed his dinner long enough tonight to make known beyond question that his attitude on prohibition had not altered since he made his speech accepting renomination for the Presidency.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Army's final haad practice for the Harvard game was held today, with Major Sasse dividing the period equally between defensive and offensive work. The session included the first full-speed scrimmage for the first team this week.

The New York University football team engaged yesterday in its first competitive scrimmage of the season and tallied four touchdowns against Team C at Ohio Field. The contact session lasted for nearly half of the two-hour workout.

HAMBURG, Nov. 2. -- A large and well-organized group of Communists armed with revolvers assaulted a detachment of National Socialists engaged in election compaign work here today, shooting down ten of them and two other persons.

The churches in America should send abroad a better type of missionary and they must know better the needs of the people to whom they go, Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, a missionary in China, who won the Pulitzer Prize for 1932 with her novel, "The Good Earth,"' declared' yesterday in the Hotel Astor before about 2,000 persons at a luncheon given in her honor.

St. Louis, which normally votes heavily Republican, is so disaffected this year over what is and what is not in the Republican prohibition plank that the prevailing opinion is Missouri will go for Governor ROOSEVELT. The President will speak in St. Louis tomorrow night in the hope of saving it, and, with it, a great State.
Seven canvases by Walt Kuhn, all but one painted this year, have been placed on view at the Marie Harriman Gallery, where work by the same American artist has been seen upon several occasions.
Colonel William J. Donovan set forth last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music the items in a program which he said would insure real economy in State government.

Rain almost spoiled the opening of the Long Island duck hunting season, yet despite the downpour and the gale that sent the rain in sheets across Great South Bay the majority of the nimrods had good luck.

The prosecution rested yesterday at the end of the second session of the trial in Washington Heights court of Donald Henderson, instructor in economics at Columbia University, and two others, on disorderly conduct charges growing out of their alleged participation in an unauthorized meeting at City College last week.

A condition similar to the present one in London, due to unemployment and poverty, might exist today in New York City were it not for the "splendid" manner in which city government handled its problems in the past two years, Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A prediction that the next Congress will be decisively Democratic, with a Senate majority of six to ten and an increased House majority, was made today by Senator Swanson, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial campaign committee.
OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 2. -- The La Salle Military Academy cross-country team inaugurated its 1932 campaign by losing, 19-36, to Manhattan Prep in their two-and-three-quarter mile race today.

On and after March 1, 1933, all bills sent by utility companies in this State to their customers must bear the names of the corporations actually providing the service, instead of that names of holding or affiliated companies, according to an order issued yesterday by the Public service Commission.

When Army meets Harvard on Saturday at Cambridge the Cadets' team will rule the favorite so far as the average football follower is concerned. But the West Point players and coaches will not be overconfident. Harvard, for the past three years, either has beaten Army or has come close to it.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 2. -- Senator George H. Moses, after a personal canvass of the State, predicted here that the Republicans would carry New Hampshire, "not by the swollen majorities of former years, but comfortably."

Joseph E. Ridder has issued a statement through the Democratic National Committee declaring that Governor Roosevelt should be thanked rather than criticized by GermanAmericans for his activities in behalf of holders of German marks after the war.

(Ballad of Football.) Not of the halfback who gallops to glory; Not of the fullback who plunges to fame. That as a thesis is moldy and hoary; I'll take the Grenadier Guards, of the game, Making a breach or defending the same Battered and battling where no one can see. You take the halfback of scintillant name; The gridiron guards are the heroes for me.

Charges that the United Cigar Stores Company of America had attempted to minimize its assets in the published schedules of the stock and bond holdings of its subsidiary companies were made yesterday by counsel for a group of creditors at a hearing before Irwin Kurtz, referee, at 15 Park Row.

PASADENA, Cal., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Mother earth's deep-seated quakes in the Pacific may result from the twitching of the old wound which some scientists believe was left when the moon was torn from what now is that water-filled hole called the Pacific Ocean.

It is reassuring to learn from Professor JULIAN HUXLEY that insectsabove all, the social insects -- are not destined to rule the earth, whatever so learned an authority as Professor AUGUSTE FOREL may teach. The ants, for example, are too small, they cannot hand down facts from generation to generation and they stopped evolving long before man appeared.

Governor SMITH'S words at the close of his brief address before the Chamber of Commerce in behalf of the campaign for the unemployed should have been heard by the entire community. The downtown audience, made up largely of men of business, was stirred by the utterance of his faith as no preacher or priest or rabbi could have moved it.

The November financing for the Federal Intermediate Credit BanK system, reaching approximately $5,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent collateral trust debentures, dated Nov. 15 and due in one year, has been more than five times oversubscribed, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent.

To the Editor of The New York Times : I believe with Mr. Ostrolenk that prosperity waits upon the farmer. I do not believe that any man-made law can do the farmer much permanent good. I do believe that any law that decreases the exchange value of his product and confiscates a large part of his income will and has put the farmer on the ragged edge.

The playing of Blanche Gailard, pianist, who gave a recital last night in Steinway Hall, was refreshingly free from most of the blemishes which young pianists often interpose between the audience and the music they project. It possessed the firmness of line Which arises from an understanding of the inner content of a composition rather than from technical facility alone, and the suppleness supplied by a natural feeling for phrase.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Following is the text of the speech of former Governor Alfred E. Smith here tonight:

CINCINNATI, Nov. 2. -- Assailing the Republican party as an organization which has caused Americans to lose faith in their form of government, James M. Cox, former Covernor of Ohio and Democratic Presidential nominee in 1920, asserted in a speech here tonight that the administration of President Hoover should be voted from office in the interests of social justice.

Replying to the employers' version of their dispute with Typographical Union No. 6 in the commercial shops, the executive committee of the union issued a statement last night to buyers of printing, accusing the employers of misstating the situation.

Pressure exerted against domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday sent a sizable list of railroad bonds off 1 to 6 points for the day. Industrial and utility bonds were also easier in the order named. Total dealings ran somewhat heavier than in the previous few days, with a total turnover of $7,390,000.
Sales and leases announced yesterday indicated a continued demand for housing properties on the west side above Seventy-second Street.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 2. -- In one of the longest practice sessions of the season. Navy today sought to improve its running attack and perfect a defense against Columbia's pass plays.

Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday denied an application by Mrs. Florence J. Foreman, widow of Winfleld A. Foreman, clothing manufacturer, for the appointment of temporary administrators of her husband's $5,000,000 estate. The court held that there is apparently no emergency in the affairs of the estate at present requiring additional protection of the assets of the estate.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Flying men have never planned a more picturesque endeavor than the assault on Mount Everest which will be made by British pilots in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee issued a statement tonight which said that "racketeering methods of the Democratic National Committee in its drive for political funds seem to have been adopted by the State organizations."

Sputterers and spouters at street corners, on trucks, over radios innumerable. An unprecedented speech-storm in all American areas. Everywhere whirlwinds, tornadoes, roaring oceans of yawp. Well, there was one haven of peace. We would go call on our old friend, Professor Sordoff of Columbia.

Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt will preside at a meeting this afternoon of the dance, junior dance, debutante and floor committees for the annual Victory Ball, of which he is chairman. The meeting will take place in one of the committee rooms of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The Democratic State Committee, meeting here today, was told by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, the party's State leader, that "the outlook indicates to me a landslide."
MELBOURNE, Nov. 2. -- October was the happiest month for the Commonwealth since the onset of the economic depression.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Alfred E. Smith told a State-wide radio audience here tonight that President Hoover, instead of "defending his administration," was "talking to scare the American people."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- A communication was submitted to the governing board of the Pan American Union today from the Secretary of State of Cuba, Dr. Creates Ferrara, former Ambassador at Washington,' recommending the inclusion in the program of the Seventh International Conference of American States, which is scheduled to meet at Montevideo in December, 1933, of a topic on "The Creation of an Inter-American Conciliation Commission."

The marriage of Miss Louise Cable Dennis, daughter of Mrs. Alfred L. P. Dennis of Berneval-le-Grand, France, and Boston, Mass., to Dr. Paul A. Younge of Peoria, Ill., and Brookline, Mass., will take place Saturday in Newton Centre, Mass., in the presence of members of the two families.

A second presentation of "Whistling in the Dark" will open tonight at the '"Waldorf Theatre with Bernard Granville in the role acted here last Winter by Ernest Truex. Tonight's bill of the Abbey Theatre Irish Players at the Martin Beck Theatre will be composed of three short plays -- "The Shadow of the Glen" by J.M. Synge, "Birthright" by T.C. Murray and "Crabbed Youth and Age" by Lennox Robinson.

The destitution of 30,000 young girls and unattached women in New York City, with no regular agency to which they may turn for food, shelter, clothing or medical care, was pictured yesterday by Miss Margaret Webster, general secretary of the city Y.W.C.A., at a luncheon of branch team leaders opening the annual budget fund campaign, at the Central Branch, 610 Lexington Avenue.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- A pledge that no more higher-priced cars, would be bought for officials in the State Department of Public Works was given to the legislative economy hearing today by Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, commissioner of the department.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The State Parole Board, meeting at Sing Sing Prison here today, ordered that Owen Madden, convict and alleged racketeer, serve one year of imprisonment for violation of his parole.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Enforcement today by Pennsylvania of its new law requiring licensing of all trucks owned by non-residents and operated in that State for hire or on regular schedules brought drastic reprisals by New Jersey.

Bruce Barton, author, lecturer and advertising executive, was arrested yesterday on a civil order signed by Supreme Court Justice Norton, of Brooklyn in a suit by Mrs. Frances King, a writer, lor $250,000 damages for alleged slander.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2. -- Warren Heller, Pitt's triple-threat halfback at the start of the season but now the blocking back, will make his second appearance on the Atlantic seaboard Saturday, when he leads the Pitt Panthers onto the field against Harvey Harman's Penn eleven.

With the opening program of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden only six days off, all of the military teams now have started their final preparations and for the next few days may be seen giving their mounts conditioning work in Central Park.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- A director of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., testified in Federal court today that the $250,000,000 investment trust had authorized payment of a preferred dividend months before it went into receivership when liabilities exceeded assets.

After developing resistance and recovering about 10 points at one time yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased in the last hour in sympathy with weakness in the stock market and closed a point lower 2 points higher than on Tuesday.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 2. -- Lafayette's 1933 football schedule was ratified today, but only after the faculty committee had emphatically protested that it was too hard.

Suit to recover $8,108 from S.W. Straus Co., Inc., and the Majestic Hotel Corporation for alleged misrepresentation of bonds of the hotel company was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn by Mrs. Hattie Posner, executrix of the estate of her husband, Jacob D. Posner of Brooklyn, a shoe manufacturer.
DAYTON Ohio, Nov. 2. -- The text of the address of Secretary Stimson, delivered here tonight, was as follows:

The names of John P. O'Brien, Democrat, and Lewis H. Pounds, Republican, will remain on the Mayoralty ballot for the coming election as a result of a decision yesterday by the Appellate Division upholding Supreme Court Justice Cohn's refusal to strike them off.

A bazaar in aid of the Marie Reparatrix Home for Business and Wording Girls will be opened today in the Plaza and be continued tomorrow. A variety of articles suitable for Christmas gifts will be on sale. This afternoon Grover A. Whalen will speak on the needs and charitable activities of the home, which is at 14 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Mme. Maria Jeritza, Fritz Reiner and Nelson Eddy will join the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra in a performance of a condensed version for orchestra and soloists of Richard Strauss's "Salome" next Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday.

To Wall Street the significance of yesterday's late reaction on the Stock Exchange was that it preceded such a favorable development as the declaration of the regular quarterly dividend by the General Motors Corporation. There was enough doubt, among speculative interests, as to the intention of General Motors' directors to make their decision a pleasant incident in what had promised to be another extremely dull day.

Voters will have two proposals to pass on in this State on election day. Some confusion, has been caused by the fact that one of these is designated "Proposed Amendment Number One" and the other "Proposition Number One." They relate to very different subjects, as any one who takes the trouble to scan the questions submitted as they appear on the face of the machines can discover for himself.

Alcohol is a poison, but in proper amounts and conditions it may do more good than harm, and the normal adult may drink it in moderation habitually without any permanent bad organic effect, some of the leading representatives of the medical sciences say in "Alcohol and Man: The Effects of Alcohol on Man in Health and Disease," published today by Macmillan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A Republican normally, I have for years subscribed to and read THE NEW YORK TIMES, and now a growing impatience with your open avoidance of comment and criticism or many glaring and inexcusable misstatements and representations of Democratic candidates and speakers has culminated in resentment.

Senator Robert F. Wagner fired another broadside at President Hoover's campaign utterances while Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman characterised the "economy" campaign of Colonel William J. Donovan, running against him for the Governorship, as specious and misleading, at Democratic rallies in Queens County last night.

Twenty Grand and Equipoise have been assigned 126 pounds each, top weight, for the Whitney Gold Cup, to be run on election day at the United Hunts meeting at Belmont Park, according to an announcement yesterday from Walter S. Vosburgh Jockey Club handicapper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Payments to World War veterans, under that section of the veterans' act passed in 1930 which allows compensation and hospitalization for injuries not connected with war service, increased at the rate of $154,448 a month in July, August and September and is continuing at about the same ratio, it was stated at the Veterans' Administration Building today.

Reinforced by Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt will open the final stage of his Presidential campaign tonight with an address at a rally in the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Republicans-for-Roosevelt League.

Making its first appearance to league competition this season, the Class A squash tennis team of the New York Athletic Club turned back the Yale Club aggregation by 4 to 1 at the Winged Foot clubhouse courts yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Fuller returns from yesterday's municipal elections confirm first impressions that the pendulum has begun to swing Left ward in Britain again.

The young intellectuals in Europe and in Asia who can find no work are turning to communism in such proportions as to "menace the existence of the present social order," according to the thirteenth annual report of the Institute of International Education by Dr. Stephen P. Duggan, its director.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- What was believed to be an attempt to do violence to Prime Minister MacDonald or to rob his house was revealed in a case in Hampstead police court today. Ivan Seruva, described as a British subject, was arraigned on a charge of loitering at the Prime Minister's home.

DAYTON, Nov. 2. -- Secretary Stimson declared here tonight, in his only Ohio address of the campaign, that President Hoover had displayed his ability and courage for national leadership through the very daring and aggressiveness of his campaign.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, is urging all employes and stockholders of that company who ask him for advice to vote as they think best, according to an announcement yesterday from Democratic National Headquarters. Mr. Young characterized Governor Roosevelt, in a letter to a taxpayers' group made public yesterday, as a "man of sound intelligence, fine intuition, deep sympathy, adequate understanding and real independence."

An "absolute restriction" of new building until the gap between supply and demand lessens was advocated yesterday by Robert L. Hoguet, first vice president of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, at a luncheon meeting of the Jamaica Real Estate Board in the Chamber of Commerce Building at Jamaica.

Beyond the offering of Street money at 1/2, which duplicated the low for day loans of the last several days, there was little else of interest in the money market. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, while time money ranged from 1/2 to 1 per cent for the near and distant dates.

In a brilliantly decorated seating, the second annual Peacock Ball will be given tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. The first Peacock Ball was held last year to mark the formal opening of the entertaining quarters in the hotel.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 2 (AP). -- Warden Joseph Brophy of Auburn prison began preparation of legal papers today to extradite Arthur Barry, jewel thief, from Newark, N.J., where he has been held since his capture two weeks ago. Warden Brophy said Barry would be returned under heavy guard and kept in solitary confinement.

Ray Steele of California threw Pat McKay of Memphis in 30 minutes 37 seconds of the feature exhibition of a wrestling card that attracted about 2,500 fans to the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Two Body slams proved the undoing of McKay as a climax to an exhibition in which Steele repeatedly was subjected to painful headlocks by his opponent.

The process of bringing home the foreign bank accounts of the International Match Company, which the late Ivar Kreuger organized in America, will involve the Federal Court here, through Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, in determining an exchange rate today for the Austrian schilling.

Wet as New Jersey is known to be, the Hobart State enforcement act is still on the statute book. At the election on Nov. 8 the question of its repeal will be referred to the voters. In ten years of controversy, with the Republican party temporizing and yielding but gradually to the inevitable, the people have not had an opportunity to declare themselves.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The first annual report of the New Jersey State Emergency Relief Administration, containing 159 printed pages in book form and submitted by Chester I. Barnard, State director of emergency relief, to Governor Moore and the Legislature, was made public by Mr. Barnard here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Both major Presidential candidates having declared themselves as against the immediate payment of the bonus, people are turning their attention to the question of veteran legislation in general. The following is a brief digest of the principal laws relating to veterans which, have been enacted during the last ten years:

Forty players are on the Brooklyn club roster, according to the list filed yesterday with Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis by Business Manager Dave Driscoll. This is the greatest number claimed by any major league club. Forty is the limit allowed under the rules.

George H. Taylor, 85-year-old veteran of the Civil War and secretary of the G.A.R. memorial committee, and Miss Gertrude Manchester, 76, a former nurse, obtained a marriage license yesterday in the Municipal Building. They both live in a boarding house at 2,032 Fifth Avenue.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Christian Swartz, former Mayor of South Norwalk and manufacturer of hats and cigars, died here today at his home, 68 West Avenue, after a year's illness. His age was 86.

A plea for the "socialization of medicine" to provide adequate medical and dental care for the workers and poor of the city was voiced by Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, in a radio address last night from Station WEVD. This was part of the health, housing and education program which he has been outlining in the course of his campaign.

Columbia's football team undertook to acquire a working knowledge of Navy's offense yesterday at Baker Field as the Blue and White continued its heavy work in preparation for its encounter with the midshipmen at Annapolis on Saturday.

Turning what had been a close struggle into a complete rout, the contract bridge team of P. Hal Sims, Willard S. Karn, Harold S. Vanderbilt and Waldemar von Zedtwitz defeated the team of David Burnstine, Howard Schenken, Charles S. Lochrudge and Richard L. Frey by 5,845 points last night in the final round of the annual Vanderbilt Cup tournament at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
