An increase of one point in the national average of steel-ingot production is reported in the weekly review of The Iron Age. The rate is put at 20 per cent of capacity, and the increase is attributed to an expansion of buying from the automobile industry.
COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Stung by what he called the disrespectful attitude of S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, Acting Mayor McKee rebuked Mr. Cohen and his department for inefficiency at a Sinking Fund Commission meeting yesterday when the question of a lease for the board's quarters in Queens came up.

Women will be brought strongly into the foreground in the closing stage of the campaign to re-elect President Hoover, it was decided yesterday at a conference at the Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- The new French converted rentes were introduced officially on the Bourse today at a slightly lower rating than had been expected. They opened at 96.50, rose to 96.75, then dropped back at the close to the opening price, for term transactions and 97 cash.

Yesterday's markets may be summarized by saying that stocks, declined on a considerably increased business, that bonds continued to swing irregularly, that grain and cotton prices hardly moved and that sterling, after an early advance at London, lost practically all of It later at New York Business done on the Stock Exchange was exactly double Tuesday's and something less than three times Monday's.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- An important step in the Federal regulation of water-power resources was taken by the Power Commission today in a decision directing the Pennsylvania Electric Company to "revest" in the Clarion River Power Company property and rights acquired by the former through a foreclosure sale of the Clarion River development.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP). -- A new wheat tariff was in effect in Germany today, imposing a duty of 7.50 marks [about $1.77] a ton on wheat imported on import certificates.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- The entire Harvard squad, including Hallowell, Casale, Grady and Crickard, was on the field in uniform today.

Sir George Lenthal Cheatle of London, England, internationally known authority on cancer, delivered an illustrated lecture last night before a distinguished gathering of New York physicians at the Lenox Hill Hospital, in which he gave a general outline of the disease and discussed theories of its origin and methods of treatment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- The Farmers National Grain Corporation, the sales agency created by the Federal Farm Board with a capitalization of $20,000,000, announced today the issuance of 5,011 additional shares of stock to its twenty-eight member grain associations as a patronage dividend.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The Stock Exchange was enlivened today by the conversion loan. Other British Government funds were active and prices rose sharply in early dealings, but reacted somewhat before the close. The assented war loan scored the biggest gain, touching u102 before finishing at u101 1/2.

One of the largest audience in nine days at the New Amsterdam Theatre applauded the versatile singers at the San Carlo Grand Opera Company last night in the favorite double bill of "Gavalloria Rusticana" and "I Pagliaool," following their only repeated opera, "Madama Butterfly" earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Reorganization of the field forces of the Radio Commission, at a saving of $75,000 a year, was ordered by the commission today. The country will be divided into twenty districts, each in charge of an inspector with a total reduction of thirty-three in the personnel.

Inquiry whether it will be possible to vote accurately for the four Supreme Court candidates in New York this year, because of the arrangement of the judicial slate on the face of the voting machines, was answered by the Board of Elections yesterday with a statement that the balloting will be accurate and the same as in other years.

Fifty members of the women's division of the Independent Citizens Committee for the Election of Lehman and Bray called upon Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, at his headquarters in the Chanin Building yesterday and reported on their stork in obtaining votes among women.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- Republican, leadership in the Federal government since 1920 was assailed tonight by Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, as having plunged the United States into depression through failure to carry out the far-sighted projects of Woodrow Wilson.

The steamship Boyaca, formerly the American freighter Bridgetown, which recently was purchased by the Colombian Government and converted into an army transport for service in the Amazon River, sailed for South America from the Tietjen Lang Shipyards in Hoboken, N.J., shortly before last midnight.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Warren G. Harding was a tolerant, but sadly abused President, Harry M. Daugherty, Attorney General in the late President's Cabinet, declared in a speech here today at a Kiwanis Club ceremony commemorating the sixty-seventh birthday anniversary of Mr. Harding.
BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 2. -- The Southern Baptist handbook for 1932 declares Southern Baptists are "still wasting money in riotous living" and reports a "miserable and tragic falloff in contributions" but the largest annual membership gain since 1923.

Jesse Isidor Straus, president of the Roosevelt Business and Professional League, and president of R.H. Macy Co., predicted yesterday that the election next Tuesday would be a Roosevelt landslide, with President Hoover defeated even more decisively than was William Howard Taft in 1912.
LEWES, Del., Nov. 2. -- Two sweep launches have arrived here to continue the search for the sunken sloop-of-war De Braak, which, with its $10,000,000 treasure, was sunk in 1798 off Cape Henlopen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The text of President Hoover's broadcast tonight to the citizens of California, Washington and Oregon follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Speaking by radio tonight to citizens of his home State of California, President Hoover announced to them and to the nation that he would go to his own precinct, in Palo Alto, to vote on election day.

Police reserves, gun squads, emergency crews, mounted men and patrolmen numbering more than 100 took command of the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn yesterday when two dozen men and women led by the Rev. Eliot White, formerly rector of Grace Church, Manhattan, marched to the Brooklyn Edison Company building, 280 Pearl Street, where they intended to stage a protest meeting directed against the company's action in "laying off 2,800 workers."

WASHINGTON. Nov. 2. -- Reopening of its investigation into freight rates on newsprint in the Eastern States to hear evidence of changed conditions since the closing of the record in 1930 was ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission today at the request of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the Publishers Association of New York.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- A consultative anti-war pact with the United States is suggested in the new arms plan France will present at Geneva or Friday, says a report on foreign affairs to be submitted tomorrow to a convention of Premier Harriot's Radical-Socialist party.

Declaration of a friendly receivership for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway came after an application for receivership made in a Missouri State court by outside interests on Saturday, E.N. Brown, chairman of the road, said yesterday. He added that granting of a receivership by the State court would have acted to dismember the road.

The Manhattan Railway Company Stockholders' Protective Committee began yesterday a campaign to elect at the annual meeting on Nov. 9 four directors pledged to fight against cancellation of the 999-year lease of the company's elevated lines to the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Under the pressure, of his campaign for re-election, President Hoover has developed a method of preparing speeches which his aides describe as "something like working out a cross-word puzzle."

SYRACUSE, Nov. 2 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, asserted in a speech here tonight that "only socialism offers a program for political progress, world peace and economic justice."

Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, and Billy Petrolle, veteran Fargo, N.D., challenger, yesterday concluded hard training for their fifteen-round title battle tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden, and each was reported in excellent condition.

Complete returns from the Presidential election may be delayed as long as twenty-four hours, even under the best circumstances, owing to a law which recently has gone into effect in Kentucky, according to The Associated Press in a country-wide survey of the closing time of balloting in the several States.

Eighteen per cent of the women applying to the Central Registration for the Homeless are suffering from mental or nervous disorders, according to a study made for the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which announced yesterday that a definite increase in mental disturbances among the 30,000 unemployed women in the city was one of the most serious results of protracted unemployment.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Several hundred American flags were set up twice in sockets along Bloom-field Avenue, the main thoroughfare here, today and taken down twice in a controversy among members of the Town Commission over the use of the flags for political purposes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- The Yale varsity football squad today ended the vacation that followed the Dartmouth game and resumed light practice on Anthony Thompson Field. No scrimmaging was ordered.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on its common stock, amounting to $10,875,000 on the 43,500,000 shares. The announcement of the dividend action was made after the close of the stock market.

Samuel Untermyer, sponsor of the so-called Untermyer plan for a liquidation corporation to take over the remaining assets of the Bank of United States, issued a statement yesterday admitting that the "decided change for the worse" in business and financial conditions since the announcement of the plan had made it virtually impossible to raise the full amount required as a start.

A proposed Communist demonstration in front of the Henry Miller Theatre in West Forty-third Street, between Broad-way and Sixth Avenue, was thwarted last night when fifty patrolmen and detectives guarded the playhouse before and during the performance.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- Operations of steel mills in the Mahoning Valley have been better this week than was expected. Additional orders enabled the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company to continue its open-hearth furnaces at Campbell after it had been planned to suspend them.

Ship lines and grain brokers were concerned yesterday over the newly declared policy of Great Britain, which denies to grain moving between Canada and other parts of the United Kingdom when reconsigned at American ports, the tariff preferences which are granted to grain shipments which move directly between those points.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Half-dollar wheat disappeared from the American continent today and virtually from all world markets as prices on most of the major grain exchanges dived to record low depths.

Back in New York City for his final campaign drive in the metropolitan area, Governor Roosevelt made last night another automobile dash through Newark and Jersey City. He was received with a display of enthusiasm which indicated, according to New Jersey party leaders, that he would receive large pluralities in the two cities and carry the State on election day.

ATLANTA, Nov. 3 -- The plight of the nation's railroads today is due chiefly to lack of vision and uncurbed competition, Clark Howell Sr., editor of The Atlanta Constitution and member of the recently formed national transportation committee, declared today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3. -- Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth, Speaking here tonight over a radio hook-up of the National Broadcasting System, accused the Democratic party of an effort "to saddle President Hoover with complete responsibility for everything that has happened since 1929."

A seasonal rise of $32,000,000 in She amount of money in circulation, reflecting the increased demands for cash over the first of the month. was reported yesterday for the week ended on "Wednesday by the Federal Reserve System. This increased currency demand, combined with the fact that the week's gain in gold.

Led by Al Acerno, the Manhattan freshman harriers scored their second consecutive victory of the season, defeating the Columbia cubs, 16-39, in a dual meet over the threemile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 3 (AP) -- F.X.A. Eble, United States Commissioner of Customs, announced here today he had issued notice to Collectors of Customs to suspend appraisement on all shipments of tuna fish, salmon and electric light bulbs from Japan, pending completion of an investigation of such shipments.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The biggest scheme for cooperative production and marketing of primary produce ever attempted has been launched by the establishment of the "Empire Farmers' Co-op., Ltd." Many prominent agriculturalists are to be members of the control board, of which Lord Strathsoey, member of the House of Lords, is chairman.

The growing trend toward individualism in education and the improvement in school and college relations to bring about this end were noted in discussions by prominent educators yesterday at a joint conference on college admissions and guidance problems which have been emphasized largely through changes in social conditions.

Protests against the grant of a $4,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for an apartment development in the Bronx were voiced yesterday by the New York Real Estate Board, the Realty Associates of Brooklyn and the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.

Final returns from the Literary Digest's nation-wide Presidential poll give Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, a lead over his Republican opponent, President Hoover, in fortyone. States and, approximately, a 3-to-2 lead in the popular vote.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- Pressure from 'the Trade Union Congress representing nearly 4,000,000 British working men failed today to move Prime Ministre MacDonald or Sir John Simon to a definite declaration of their disarmament policy. A deputation from the congress, and several affiliated unions visited the two Ministers today to 'express their "disquiet" over the slow progress at Geneva and to urge bolder action by the British Government.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday continued to run substantially below those of the corresponding period last year, according to the reports received by R.G. Dun Co. The total for twenty-two cities was $4,121,356,000, or 34.5 per cent less than in the same week in 1931, which included election day and was therefore a short week.
Many retail stores, most of them in midtown Manhattan, were leased by brokers yesterday. Some of the transactions were for retail selling locations in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

A larger quantity of contracts changed hands within a range of 5 points on the Cotton Exchange yesterday than within similar narrow limits at any other time this season. Most of the trading in the active deliveries was at a point above or a point below one figure, while the list closed 1 to 3 points lower than on Wednesday.

It would be a mistake to waste time on a criminal of the type of "OWNEY" MADDEN if his case had no more than personal significance. But from the moment when he challenged the authority of the Parole Board he became the leading figure in a controversy the outcome of which was certain to mean much to the State, and to have a place in penological history.

Anti-vivisectionists, anti-vaccinationists and irregular practitioners medicine were characterized as enemies of society last night by Dr. Walter B. Cannon, professor of physiology at the Harvard Medical School, in the eighty-sixth anniversary discourse of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Raising the slogan, "Vote your hopes, not your fears," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, brought the Socialist campaign to a dramatic climax last night when he told more than 20,000 persons assembled in Madison Square Garden to rally behind the Socialist ticket and cast their ballots for socialism as the only solution of what he described as the breakdown of the capitalist system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The United States has notified Great Britain that she thinks this country is entitled to be heard with respect to the conditions under which Iraq is to be administered when the mandate over that country is ended.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, has repudiated a circular issued by the Republican National Committee, over Mr. Green's signature, on the benefits of tariff protection to labor, according to a letter from Mr. Green made public yesterday at Democratic national headquarters here.

A suit of $324,828, covering a fee nd expenses, has been brought gainst the B.M.T., Gerhard M. Dahl. Albert H. Wiggin, Charles Hayden, Percy A. Rockefeller and George Walker by William D. Pratt, capitalist, of Fredonia, Kan., who allges that his work was done in promotion of the company's higher fare campaign in 1927 and succeeding years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today announced its approval of a $2,500,000 work loan to the New York Central Railroad, the loan to provide employment for about 1,500 men for seven or eight months.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 3 (AP). -- After calling on President-elect Arturo Alessandri to renew an old friendship, Colonel Marmaduque Grove, the defeated Socialist candidate, issued a manifesto to workmen today declaring he would "fight for a definitive triumph, of the socialistic ideal."

The American Engineering Council, which is organizing the engineering profession to cooperate with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in speeding construction projects contemplated by Congress, announced yesterday that application for loans under the self-liquidating previsions of the emergency relief and construction act aggregate more than a billion dollars.

A dramatic story of the efforts to prevent the failure of the Bank of United States on Dec. 11, 1930, was told last night by Lieut. Gov. Lehman, candidate for Governor, at a Democratic rally in the Hunts Point Palace in the Bronx.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3 -- The abuses revealed by Judge Samuel Seabury's investigation of the magistrates' courts of New York City are still to be remedied, according to Professor Raymond Moley of Columbia University. Among the problems involved are the methods of appointing magistrates, the bail system, immediate arraignment of offenders, and their prosecution and defense.

New public financing done in the United States in the first ten months of 1932, excluding domestic and Canadian municipal bonds, amounted to only $574,529,000, compared with $2,156,090,000 in the same period in 1931 and with $4,754,680,000 in 1930, according to a compilation announced yesterday by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of National Statistical Service, Inc.

Moses Newborg of the banking firm of Newborg Co., has leased his five-story American basement residence at 50 East Fifty-second Street, through Warren L. Marks Co., brokers. The house contains sixteen rooms and an electric elevator. The lease contains a purchase option.

WARSAW, Nov. 3. -- Parliament, at the opening session today, faced the unpleasant task of voting a budget with a $40,000,000 deficit. Income for the fiscal year beginning April 1, 1933, is estimated at $232,000,000 and expenditures are estimated at $272,000,000.

Lady Astor, member of the British Parliament, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Leviathan to spend a few weeks with friends and relatives in her former home. She was accompanied by her sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Brand, and will visit Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, another sister, for a few days before going to Mirador, Va., where she was born.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3. -- Commenting on Washington dispatches revealing a hitherto secret Argentine note to the Commission of Neutrals in Washington, insisting that the neutrals have no right to use any measures of force or compulsion against either Bolivia or Paraguay, foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas admitted it had been sent in September.

Miss Puth Nichols, whose plane was badly damaged when it groundlooped at the take-off of what was to have been a non-stop flight to Los Angeles in behalf of President Hoover's re-election, denied yesterday that the machine had been tampered with as was charged by A. B. Cornell, an employe of the speakers bureau of the Republican National Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Amateur Athletic Union will consider more than 100 amendments to its constitution, by-laws and general athletic rules at its national convention at the Hotel Paramount on Nov. 20, 21 and 22. The report of the legislation committee, containing all the changes, was mailed yesterday to the 450 delegates from the thirty A.A.U. districts.

New York City obtained yesterday the $21,500,000 from the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank which the bankers in their joint letter last Sunday indicated they would lend. Of the amount $18,500,000 is required by the city to meet contract obligations and $3,000,000 will go for emergency relief.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: Somebody should really explain to President Hoover about his bread-and-butter equivalents. The chorus of criticism which greeted their use in 1928 might well have prevented their resurrection for the purposes of this campaign.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A sharp earthquake, which frightened school children, caused Stanford University students to rush from their class rooms and shook a wide area around San Francisco Bay, was felt at 10:55 o'clock (Pacific Standard Time) this morning.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 3 -- The Greenwich Country Club scored two victories in the opening round-robin team matches today for women squash racquets players representing the Greenwich Country Club, the Field Club of Greenwich, the Sleepy Hollow Country Club and the Ardsley Club.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The expected success attended today's issue of the 3 per cent u300,000,000 conversion loan at 97 1/2, the lists closing three and one-quarter hours after they were opened. British Government funds opened weaker on profit taking following yesterday's rise, but rallied on the conversion loan's success.

LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP). -- The hunger marchers who moved into London a week ago to serve a set of demands on the government had ceased today to be a threat, but remained as a problem. A few of them already have gone back where they came from, but apparently the weary march in has deterred the rest from beginning the march back.

The continued decrease of cargoes moving by water has brought the volume of laid-up tonnage in the ports of the world to 15,000,000 tons, or 20 per cent of the total tonnage, according to Lioyd's Register of Shipping. In the annual report, issued yesterday, Lioyd's professed to find no indication of immediate improvement in the freight market upon which, it pointed out, the prosperity of shipping mainly depends.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Under the heading, "Football Tickets Too High," The Yale Alumni Weekly tomorrow will urge the Yale Athletic Association to consider lower ticket prices for another year. The Weekly will predict that a loss of public interest which will have a serious effect on college football will follow refusal by the university to drop the price of admission to the gridiron contests.
A one-man show of paintings and sculpture by Warren Wheelock has opened in the galleries of An American Group at the Barbizon-Plaza, to remain until Nov. 19.

Borough President Levy of Manhattan announced yesterday that he would oppose the granting of any further permits for the use of vacant lots in either business or residential sections for automobile parking spaces.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, making his final pre-election analysis of the situation at his headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday, asserted that the supposed pro-Hoover drift of the last days of the campaign is a myth, and that on the contrary a Roosevelt landslide is sweeping the country, and will roll up a clear majority of close to 11,000,000 votes for the Democratic Presidential candidate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Alcoholic beer Will be approved by Congress before March 4, according to a prediction of Labor's National Committee for Modification of the Volstead Act. Beer of 2.75 per cent alcoholic, content is a strong probability by that time, and possibly early in the Winter, it was stated.

Disputing Democratic claims of a sweeping victory in this State for Governor Roosevelt, as his party's nominee for President, former State Senator William H. Hill, assistant manager of the Hoover campaign in the East, said last night that President Hoover would carry New York by a plurality of from 200,000 to 250,000.

The Seventeenth Senatorial District in Greater New York City is more populous and industrially more important than some States in the Union. Geographically and otherwise it is the "heart of Manhattan." Its representative in the Legislature at Albany has stewardship over matters affecting the welfare of more people than many Governors have under their jurisdiction.
Important labor support was indicated yesterday for Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, in statements and assurances of prominent labor leaders in this city.

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- A trend toward giving the World Bank more and more work to do and generally making its role more important marked today's secret discussions here in the committee preparing the financial side of the coming World Economic and Monetary Conference.

The choicest of the fruits of a nation-wide autograph-hunting contest that began last April were placed on view yesterday in the Canadian Club at the Waldorf-Astoria, where the judges selected the prize-winning collections.

ROCKVILLE, Md., Nov. 3 (AP) -- In the first division running of the All-Age Stake of the National Foxhunters' Association meet today, Bess Stride, owned by J.A. Niesler, Kings Mountain, N.C., was well ahead of the pack of nearly 100 hounds with her score of 260, based on hunting, training, endurance and speed.

Floods or oratory instead of arias floated from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House last night at the meeting of the Republicans-for-Roosevelt League. On the stage were a number of erstwhile Republicans, including Mrs. Courtlandt Nicoll, prominent in New York society; Miss Josephine Striker, who was secretary to the late President Theodore Roosevelt for six years, and Mrs. Howard Chandler Christy.
Sir George Lenthal Cheatle of London, distinguished British, surgeon and cancer expert, and Lady Cheatle sail for England tonight on the Cunard liner Aquitania. Others booked include:

Operations in the listed bond market yesterday were largely a repetition of those on Wednesday. Issues of domestic corporations continued irregularly down, railrord bonds, especially, losing ground in relatively quiet trading.

Governor Roosevelt delivered his answer to President Hoover's warning that Democratic victory might spell disaster for the nation at a campaign rally last night in the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of Republicans who are supporting him for the Presidency.

Completing its long journey across the continent from California, the St. Mary's College football team arrived in New York early yesterday for its intersectional battle with Fordham at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

For the first four months of the new fiscal year expenditures and receipts of the Federal Government make the following comparison with those of the same period a year ago. Figures represent millions of dollars:

About a hundred young women, members of the dance, junior dance and debutante committees for the annual Victory Ball, were urged by Mrs. Arthur W. Little, chairman of the dance committee, to start at once an intensive effort to sell tickets for the ball, at a meeting held at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon.
Collateral loans to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange showed a decrease of $55,099,384 in October, or from $379,801,583 at the end of September to $324,702,199 on Oct. 31.

Several flights of woodcocks have been sighted in the swamps and along the hillsides in Connecticut in the past two days. These are the first flight woodcocks that have been noted in this section since the opening of the season, and better hunting now is in store.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Wheat was again on the down grade today, the December on the Board of Trade here dropping 1 1/2 cents to 41 7/8 cents the lowest mark recorded since trading in futures started here. The market displayed no rallying power at any time, and the finish was within a fraction of the bottom at net losses of 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents.
PARIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Magistrate Guy Van Amringe paid tribute yesterday to the "excellent traditions" of City College at the third session of the trial in Washington Heights Court of Donald Henderson, instructor in economics at Columbia University, and two others on charges of disorderly conduct.

About 150 members of the Junior League beard several things about themselves-mostly uncomplimentary last night from Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, who had come to the meeting at the league's clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, to take part in a three-sided' discussion of the leading Presidential candidates.

The New house Galleries are trying their own experiment in contrasting styles, now that the College Art Association's traveling exhibition, "Comparisons and Contrasts," has departed. The earlier show was devoted only to American works. Mr. Newhouse has broadened the scope of his exhibition by including both old and modern paintings by artists of various nations.

The theft of a painting, "The Temptations of a Saint," by Charles de La Fosse, seventeenth century French painter, from the Summer home of Mrs. Margaret Albans at 21 Auburn Avenue, Bay Shore, L. I., was discovered yesterday, the Bay Shore police announced last night in an alarm sent over the intra-State teletype system.

The twenty-one member banks of the New York Clearing House Association, including the most important banks in the city, pledged their support yesterday to the "share-the-work" movement directed by Walter C. Teagle.

Probably the decline in wheat, which yesterday went below its previous low price of the season, had most to do with the uncertain aspect of the markets. No special cause seems to be visible for the recent heavy pressure of wheat on the international market.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- The National Women's Christian Temperance Union announced today that it endorsed no Presidential candidate and favored neither major party because "one is as wet as the other."

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 3 -- Admitting the mailing of a threat letter to Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, widow of the Senator and mother of Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, Charles C. Jodrey, 55 years old, an unemployed carpenter and father of nine children, of Everett, was held in $5,000 bail today by United States Commissioner Edwin C. Jenney for a hearing next Monday.
One of the longest and most strenuous practice sessions of the year marked Columbia's workout yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the meeting with Navy at Annapolis tomorrow.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation announced here last night that it had made a new bid for the assets and properties of the Richfield Oil Company of California and the Pan-American Petroleum Company, agreeing to give $25,000,000 par value of its 6 per cent twenty-year debentures and 400,000 shares of its common stock.

The textile industry is at last emerging from the "trade secret" period, although textile science has not yet reached maturity, the third annual meeting of the United States Institute for Textile Research, held yesterday at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel, was told by Professor H.B. Millard of Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP). -- Intertwined in varying degrees in the windup of the Presidential campaigning by President Hoover in the West and Governor Roosevelt in the East are the contests for Governor in thirty-four States.

Residential properties continued to lead in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday, an outstanding deal being the purchase of an old chateau in Ridgewood, Bergen County, by Ira C. Nichols, a Manhattan resident.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Extradition proceedings against Martin J. Insull, who faces embezzlement and larceny charges in Chicago with his brother, Samuel, in connection with the collapse of their utilities interests, will be postponed tomorrow for at least a week.

As the battlefront of the trucklicensing war between Pennsylvania and New Jersey was shifting to the Federal courts for adjudication of the controversy and spreading to involve five other States, Pennsylvania opened a counter-offensive last light, extending its registration requirements from common carriers to all New Jersey trucks after 8 o'clock tonight if an amicable settlement does not result from a "peace" conference set for three hours earlier.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 -- A.C. Bostwick's Mate, winner of $214,775 in fifteen 1931 races, when he was the greatest rival of Twenty Grand, scored his first victory in what was his fifteenth 1932 start when he was an easy winner over St. Brideaux, Pilate and five others today at Pimlico.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 3 -- Upsets featured the racing at the Latonia track today, climaxed by a dead heat in the last race when E.L. Snyder's Star Play and M.M. Riddle's Stop Gap finished so closely locked that the judges were unable to decide which was winner.

The crisis in the book and Job industry deepened yesterday when two of the three printing establishments against which Typographical Union No. 6 called a strike late Wednesday night capitulated to the union demands and the third employed nonunion men to till the places of the strikers.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 -- A report urging a curb on the "greed which the present profit system makes inevitable" was adopted by the Central Conference of American Rabbis today after a heated debate in which portions of it were attacked and after elimination of a paragraph interpreted as criticism of President Hoover.

Twenty-five football games involving scholastic teams are scheduled for today in the metropolitan district. Seven contests are listed for fields within New York City, while the others are booked for New Jersey, Westchester and Long Island gridirons.

GENEVA, Nov. 3. -- The disarmament conference's bureau resumed its work today and decided to reserve tomorrow morning's session for hearing a speech by Joseph Paul-Boncour, French War Minister, on the French "constructive" disarmament plan.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, condemned yesterday a public official who, "with the spotlight on him," asserts the city's credit is in danger. This statement, interpreted at the time as an attack upon Acting Mayor McKee, was made at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor tendered him by the Real Estate Committee of New York, an informal organization of prominent real estate operators.
Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee formally disavowed yesterday all efforts to make him a candidate for Mayor through a movement to write his name on the voting machines.

Anglo-American cooperation, the theme of Lord Reading's first remarks to ship-news men when he arrived on the Aquitania on Oct. 7, was the keynote of his final speech before his scheduled departure on the same ship tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Protests from New York realty interests against approval by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of its $3,957,000 loan to the Hillside Housing Corporation of that city will have no effect on its action in the matter and the loan will be made unless it fails of final approval by the State Housing Board or is prevented by a writ of mandamus from a New York court.

Billy Petrolle, the veteran lightweight known throughout boxing circles as the Fargo Express, will make his bid for the championship of his division tonight when he opposes Tony Canzoneri, the titleholder, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

TOKYO, Nov. 3. -- The newspaper Asahi's correspondent at Tsitsihar reported today that attempts which Chinese volunteer forces, numbering 20,000, had been making since Oct. 7 to capture Tsitsihar had been defeated in a month of difficult fighting.

A plan for reorganization of the Appalachian Gas Corporation was announced yesterday by John C. Adams, chairman of the debenture holders' committee, which undertook the readjustment program some weeks ago. It provides for a reduction of fixed interest charges from about $800,000 a year to approximately $43,000.
TOULOUSE, France, Nov. 3. -- "President Hoover's disarmament plan as presented at Geneva was absolutely impracticable for us because it would leave France exposed to her enemies."

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The question of whether the Federal court had jurisdiction to appoint a receiver for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway in a creditor's suit filed after a State receivership suit was brought before Federal Judge C.B. Faris today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3 -- The Harvard eleven today concluded its preparations for the Army game with the hardest work of the week. There was no regulation scrimmage but the varsity players ran full speed against the big blocking dummies. The three teams lined up against the scrubs who demonstrated the Army plays.

Dry Goods Convention Jan. 16. The twenty-second annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will be held during the week of Jan. 16 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced here yesterday by P.A. O'Connell, president of the organization, following a meeting of its executive council.
The substitute members of Manhattan's football squad received Head Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan's main attention in the two-hour workout on Manhattan Field yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 3. -- The text of Colonel Donovan's speech here tonight was as follows:

The range of Toscanini's imagination, if also its limitation in a certain field, was strikingly manifested at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. On the previous evening Mr. Toscanini had struck fire with a program of Wagner.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor, continued his attack on the Tammany administration m four speeches yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens. He warned his listeners that the election of another Tammany Mayor would throw the city into bankruptcy.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein told clergy of all denominations attending the Institute of Family Relations, 130 East Twenty-second Street, yesterday afternoon that the family court over which he is now presiding should be consolidated with the children's court and that it should be conducted as a family court, with one department for adults and another for children.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- A lost will written by D.H. Lawrence, the novelist, was accepted in probate court here today and his widow thereby became sole heir to the u2,438 estate. Letters of administration which had been granted jointly to her and George A. Lawrence of Nottingham, England, brother of the novelist, were revoked..

To the Editor of The New York Times: As chairman of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration disbursing the State unemployment relief funds, I am glad to answer the request for information about the relief bond issue which appeared in William B. Kahn's letter published in THE TIMES.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3. -- Scrimmage practice for the Yale varsity eleven today was ordered for the first time since last Saturday, when, the first team faced the scrubs for a twenty-five-minute session.

Mrs. Carrington Gindrat Arnold gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for her debutante daughter, Miss Cassandra Lee Arnold. The debutante was assisted in receiving by her sister, Mrs. Andrew Duncan McIntosh Jr.

Stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company, who have been pressing for payment by the Interborough receivers of $860,000 in back franchise and real estate taxes and $813,000 of mortgage bond interest which fell due on Oct. 1, became fearful yesterday that the pending jurisdictional conflict between the Federal District Court and the Circuit Court of Appeals might jeopardize their interests.

An unidentified man got past a guard stationed on the staircase leading from the 102d-floor observatory of the Empire State Building to the top floor yesterday, hurdled a fourfoot circular wall and leaped to his death. His body hurtled past the eighty-eighth-floor observatory in view of twenty visitors and landed on the roof of a promenade on the eighty-sixth floor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 2, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,228,000,000, an increase of $9,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $54,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is not enough news of crime in our newspapers. The protest of Gordon Knox Bell, whose long experience with criminals in the House of Refuge, Randall's Island, has made his point of view prejudiced, is. I believe, an echo of a dying complaint.

Nea Lap, full sister to Phar Lap, the famous Australian thoroughbred which died shortly after winning the 1932 Agua Caliente Handicap in March, arrived in the United States last night and was shipped promptly to Kentucky, where she will be used as a broodmare. Nea Lap was purchased by John Hay Whitney.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- An inventory of the estate of Mrs. Edith Rocke-feller McCormick, listing such assorted items as treasures lent to the Art Institute and floor mops poked in closet corners, was filed today with Probate Judge Horner and approved by an assistant.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- It has again become advisable for Prime Minister MacDonald to conserve all his energy for strictly official work and for that reason his engagement to speak at the Lord Mayor's banquet next Wednesday has been canceled, it was announced at 10 Downing Street today.

Plans for a campaign which has for its objective a more liberal treatment of the small and mediumsize manufacturer and retailer in the matter of banking credits were announced yesterday by the Business Men's Bank Credit Committee, an organization formed by representatives of several local industries.

George Z. Medalie, Republican nominee for United States Senator, speaking at the Jamaica Training School last night, accused Governor Roosevelt of having abandoned the traditional Democratic doctrine of States' rights and States' sovereignty in an attempt to shift responsibility for evils he failed to cure as Governor of this State to the shoulders of President Hoover.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Continued expansion of national bank currency during October was reflected in the announcement of the Treasury Department today that $23,146,350 additional 3, 3 1/8 and 3 3/8 per cent government bonds had been pledged with the Treasurer of the United States to secure crculation.

Frank M. Gordon, vice president of the First Union Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago and newly elected president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, announced yesterday the chairmen of the standing committees of the association who will serve for the ensuing year.

Cabled accounts of Mr. MONTAGU NORMAN'S remarks at the Lord Mayor's "bankers' dinner," two weeks ago, caused varied conjecture. On the face of the words cited, and of the headlines, it might have been imagined that the Governor of the Bank of England despaired of the economic future.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 3 -- Decisive moves leading to the extradition of Samuel Insull from Greece were revealed by the United States Government today. Following an announcement that an extradition treaty with Greece had been ratified last Tuesday, the State Department said it had instructed Leland B. Morris, Charge d'Affaires at Athens, to ask the Greek Government to arrest Mr. Insull provisionally and hold him until extradition proceedings could be instituted.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3. -- Will Levington Comfort, novelist, dropped dead yesterday. Mr. Comfort, who was 54 years old, had just been removed to Monte Sano Sanitarium when his seizure occurred. He was author of "Routledge Rides Alone" and about fourteen other novels.

Permission to abandon four leases was granted yesterday to the bankrupt United Cigar Stores Company of America by Irwin Kurtz, referee, on petition of the Irving Trust Company, as trustee of the bankrupt. Several hundred leases have been disaffirmed in the last two months.
Opinions Clash Sharply. The Herald Tribune's Opinions editorial page yesterday carried an admirable lesson against jumping to hasty conclusions. The text was demagogues who foment class hatred.

Investigation of cases of alleged illegal registration in the city continued yesterday, and Monroe Percy Bloch, directing counsel of the election frauds bureau of the Hoover Engineers' Committee and the Republican State Committee, announced that about 200 applications for warrants for service on electibn day had been prepared.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Proclamations by President Hoover urging observance of Thanksgiving Day and Armistice Day were issued at the White House today after the President had left for the West.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Stable assignments for the midwinter racing season of Jan. 19 to March 11 were given 1,093 horses, including the best of the country's thorough-bred crop, at Hialeah Park today.
The text of the address delivered by Morris Hillquit, Socialist candidate for Mayor, at Madison Square Garden last night follows:

The 105 employes in the office of the Internal Revenue Agent of the Second District, 17 'Battery Place, announced yesterday that they had voted to make donations to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, whose $15,OO0,000 campaign will begin on Nov. 10.

HAVANA, Nov. 3 -- The elections in Cuba Tuesday, which replaced half the House of Representatives, two Senators and all the municipal and provincial officials, have not in any way affected the political or economic situation here, since the opposition to the present administration not only failed to make a bid for nominations but even went so far as to refrain from voting.

Football has been classified as the nearest approximation to war within the experience of the civilian. It is interesting in this connection to find that the four college teams being coached today by West Point met are all among the leaders in their sections.

The Kings County Democratic organization will formally close its campaign tonight with a rally at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, during which Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Smith will share the speaking honors in a nation-wide broadcast.

Owen D. Young, banker and industrialist, in his first and only speech of the Presidential campaign, called last night for the election of Governor Roosevelt as the best means of pulling the nation from the economic morass.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, candidate for re-election, characterized the campaign defenses of the Hoover administration as "unadulterated fiction, composed to serve as an alibi for a most shameful failure to deal with a national catastrophe," in an address last night at Hunts Point Palace, 163d Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The tendency was distinctly downward at today's session of the Boerse. With another slump in sterling, an unexpected transit strike in Berlin, showing the Nazis and Communists in cooperation, uncertainty about what the Cabinet's ultimate decision will be regarding the introduction of import quotas, few wanted to buy.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The Ottawa tariff agreements passed their third and final reading in the House of Commons today by the overwhelming majority of 416 to 68.

ATHENS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The United States Legation formally applied to the Court of Appeal today, for the extradition of Samuel Insult, who is wanted in Chicago to answer an indictment for larceny and embezzlement based on the collapse of his utilities interests.

Although the fare was not especially fattening at the Martin Beck last evening, it was a good deal juicier than a Broadway crust. When a theatregoer departed he had at least the satisfaction of having been in good company. The Dubliners were playing two one-act plays, Lennox Robinson's "Crabbed Youth and Age" and J.M. Synge's "The Shadow of the Glen," and one two-act tragedy, T.C. Murray's "Birthright."

James Speyer and Charles H. Sabin, as chairman and associate chairman, respectively, of the Bankers and Brokers' Committee of the United Hospital Fund of New York, announced yesterday that contributions totaling $53,955 have been received since the appeal for funds was made on Oct. 18.

The custom of-making second presentations of recent Broadway plays was continued by O.E. Lee and J.J. Leventhal last night at the Waldorf Theatre, where "Whistling in the Dark" was the bill. As recently as last January at Miss Barrymore's playhouse this prankish melodrama by Laurence Gross and Edward Childs Carpenter was making crime a cheerful after-dinner diversion.

While business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was of about the same proportions as on Wednesday, the action of the market indicated that confidence was being restored. At any rate, Wall Street appeared less concerned over the tremors which accompanied the reaction of the late afternoon before.

MEDINA, N.Y., Nov. 3. --Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an informal address here today, declared that teachers could not do their best who were not receiving the proper pay. She favored economy, she said, but not at the expense of youth.

While business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was of about the same proportions as on Wednesday, the action of the market indicated that confidence was being restored. At any rate, Wall Street appeared less concerned over the tremors which accompanied the reaction of the late afternoon before.
BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- There were no buses, no trolley cars and no subway trains running in Berlin today because of an unauthorized strike of employes of the Municipal Transit Company.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN BOUND FOR CALIFORNIA, Nov. 3 -- President Hoover hurried westward tonight on a crucial trip across the nation in which he will try to win a vast stretch of doubtful territory to the Republican cause by next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Photostatic copies of a letter written on June 3 by General Pelham D. Glassford, then Superintendent of Police, which until today bad been locked up at the District Building, were given out tonight by Commissioner Luther H. Reichelderfer, to contradict repeated assertions by the General that he never recommended that troops be called to evict the Bonus Expeditionary Force from the capital.

Large numbers of forged certificates, each for 100 shares of common stock of the Radio Corporation of America, were discovered this week in the Middle West, and it was announced yesterday that several public and private agencies have started on the trail of the counterfeiters.
J.M. Barris's "Peter Pan" will be presented for the first time this season at the Civic Repertory Theatre tomorrow afternoon, with Eva Le Gallienne again in the role of Peter.
LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
The text of Owen D. Young's address at the Republicans-for-Roosevelt League mass meeting at the metropolitan Opera House last night follows:
NEW YORK. Mrs. Louis de Bebian Moore will give a tea dance at the Colony Club Dec. 19 to introduce her daughter, Miss Nina Moore.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3 -- Five women were killed when a stalled automobile in which they were seated was struck by a Richmond, Fredericksburg Potomac passenger train this morning at the Glendale crossing in the suburbs of Richmond.

Professor JOHN DEWEY makes the point that people who are not Socialists should be glad to vote for certain candidates of that party, on the ground that they are highly intelligent and could, in office, do useful public service, irrespective of their special political program.

Professor JOHN DEWEY makes the point that people who are not Socialists should be glad to vote for certain candidates of that party, on the ground that they are highly intelligent and could, in office, do useful public service, irrespective of their special political program.

The New York University football team completed its heavy work prior to its intersectional battle with the University of Georgia tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium by participating in a two-hour drill at Ohio Field yesterday.

THE scouts have turned in their reports to the coaches, but a few extra words of warning may not come amiss. For instance, Army is invading Cambridge. The stout Mr. Arthur Sampson, with his hat tilted down and his cigar tilted up, scouted Army for fair Harvard on several occasions this Autumn and can call off troop movements with his eyes closed and never miss a single corporal or even an acting-private.

The expected scramble for the last word of the political campaign on the radio Monday night is upsetting the plans of radio organizations for election eve, according to the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The Princeton football team will meet the Lehigh eleven in Palmer Stadium tomorrow in the thirty-fifth game of a series which began in 1887.

Donations to the Emergency unemployment Relief Committee represent "distress insurance," which will protect unemployed families from hardship and misery this Winter, Walter E. Barton, president of the Life Insurance Underwriters. Association, told a group of insurance executives yesterday at a meeting at 255 Broadway, where the insurance men organized to take part in the committee's $15,000,000 campaign beginning Nov. 10.

A.B. Cauty, director and general manager of the White Star Line, sailed yesterday for England on the Georgic, having changed his original plan to leave on the Majestic on Nov. 11, because of business matters requiring his presence in London.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 4. -- "The time is come for us to behold the truth that we are not to suffer ourselves to be consumed and devoured, overborne and assimiliated," declared Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York, before the conference of American rabbis here today.

RFVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 4. -- Mrs. Mitzie Downs, 24 years old, who upset the trial of her husband on a murder charge by refusing to testify and then was accused of the murder in turn, will be taken before Supreme Court Justice John. R. Vunk at Patchogue tomorrow for the argument of a writ of habeas corpus, obtained tonight by her attorney, Lorenzo Carlino.

ST. VINCENT DB PAUL, Que., Nov. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Fire, started by a Negro convict, and flashes of knives as guards ran to investigate, today touched off a short hut fierce riot in St. Vincent de Paul Penitentiary here. One hundred and thirty convicts, armed with cobblers' knives and shoemakers' hammers, turned on the guards after setting fire to the prison workshops.
Colonel William J. Donovan renewed last night his charge that Lieut. Gov. Lehman failed as a State official to take action to prevent the crash of the Bank of United States.

ROME, Nov. 4. -- The armistice between Italy and Austria in the World War was celebrated throughout Italy today with parades of war veterans and speeches in which Italy's sacrifices in the war were recalled.

How far will the unbridled audacity of Chairman FARLEY and Mr. RASKOB let itself go? Yesterday, while Mr. HOOVER was still actively engaged in winning the West, the odds on the election of Governor ROOSEVELT were 4 to 1. We leave it to any good sound Republican if that isn't a "plot."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today made available $5,462,265 more to Pennsylvania for relief work during November, and at the same time notified Governor Pinchot that it would "hesitate" to provide further funds until the various political sub-divisions had done more to help themselves.

WINNIPEG, Man., Nov. 4 (Canadian Press). -- The obstacle to Canadian wheat obtaining 6 cents a bushel preference in the United Kingdom when shipped through United States channels will be overcome, in the opinion of grain exporters here, if the one point that remains to be settled is cleared by the British Government.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 4. -- A parade with red lights and several bands preceded the Republican rally in Stamford High School tonight, which was addressed by Charles Evans Hughes Jr., son of the chief justice.

A brilliant gathering of more than 2,000 persons representative of society, the artistic, theatrical and literary worlds thronged the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the second annual Peacock Ball. In a setting of kaleidoscopic decorative effect, and with a lavish program of entertainment seldom equalled in charity dances of the past, the ball proved to be one of the most notable entertainments given in recent years.

In a telegram to representatives of five farm organizations, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, reiterated yesterday that he consistently had favored tariff protection for American farmers sufficient to insure for them the domestic market.

The First National Bank held $1,970,000 of St. Louis-San Francisco Railway consolidated mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1978, on Oct. 10, it was shown yesterday in papers filed with the report of the Irving Trust Company as receiver for the former New York Stock Exchange firm of Kountze Brothers, now bankrupt.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley today vacated the injunction issued by him last week against the sale by New York banks of collateral held by them against defaulted loans to Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Owing to the postponement of the League Council's discussion of the Lytton report, the Japanese delegation will stay in Moscow over the celebrations of the fifteenth anniversary of the revolution, it became known today at a reception in honor of the delegation at the Japanese Embassy.

Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, denied yesterday in a letter to James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, made public at Democratic national headquarters here, that the R.F.C. had ever promised any loans to finance any hotel or hotels.

A group of men and women more than 60 years old participated yesterday in an organization meeting of the Threescore Club of Greater New York under the leadership of the Rev. Edward Eells, author and lecturer, known as "the cheer-up man," at Riverside Church, West 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Earl Sande, famous jockey, who is now trainer for Colonel Maxwell Howard, was operated on yesterday morning at Roosevelt Hospital for appendicitis. Sande entered the hospital Thursday evening, Colonel Howard said yesterday. Dr. Russell, who also attended Sande after his most serious accident in 1924, said his patient was doing well.
WOODMERE, L.I., Nov. 4. -- After winning four consecutive games, the Woodmere Academy eleven was held to a 7-7 tie by the Barnard School for Boys team today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov., 4. -- Pennsylvania, still undefeated and untied, meets its hardest test tomorrow in the game with the unbeaten but tied Pittsburgh team, which surprised the football world with its 12-0 victory over Notre Dame last Saturday.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- The Bourse was dull today, with the trend of prices steadily downward. The volume of transactions was considerably reduced, with trading limited almost entirely professionals. At the night session Canadian Pacific and Royal Dutch were fairly strong.

Jose Chamaco clinched the right to advance to the Eastern sectional three-cushion billiard final at Jack Doyle's Academy next week by triumphing yesterday at the Strand Academy in the sectional semi-final. At Doyle's Academy Kinrey Matsuyama and Joe Stone remained in the race for the qualifying place there by emerging victorious in their matches.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Nov., 4. -- Your page with Owen D. Young's clear and forceful expression of wisdom from his wide experience is of great value. I hope all your readers may preserve that page; it deserves to be read again and again.

Speeches of Gov. Roosevelt and ex-Gov. Smith, Pages 10 and 11. Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic candidate for President, and former Governor Alfred. E. Smith, his rival for the nomination, gava public evidence last night of their reconciliation by appearing together at the main campaign rally of the Kings County Democratic organization at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

After the tumult and the shouting are over next week it should be the duty of citizens generally and of parents in especial to see the schools in which the nation is preparing pupils for future citizenship. In that hope, the week has been set apart as "Education Week."

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP). -- In a letter to Ford Motor Company dealers throughout the country, W.A. Cowling, Ford salesmanager, said today that Henry Ford, in his recent message to employes advocating President Hoover's election, was frankly answering intelligent employes who usually are interested in knowing what informed employers think."

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Villanova -- All that is certain about this game is that Coach Joe McKenney of the Eagles will be taller than Coach Harry Stuhldreher of Villanova all afternoon. One thin vote for Villanova.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- The Boerse today made up yesterday's losses with a general advance in stocks. The rally was confined, however, for the most part, to gains of one to two points. The turnover continued extremely small and toward the end trading stagnated. Bonds were irregular, with municipal loans advanced slightly.

William L. Carns, Republican candidate for Representative from the Nineteenth Congressional District declared in a statement yesterday that the independent voters of the district should substitute him for Representative Sol Bloom, for the reason that Mr. Carns is for "real economy."

The New York University football team will oppose the University of Georgia at the Yankee Stadium at 2 P.M. today. The contest will be the second consecutive and final intersectional game of the season for the Violet. A crowd of more than 25,000 is expected.

Stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company are advised in a letter sent out last night by authority of all directors except Nathan L. Amster that reports of Interborough domination of the company are "unjustified and without foundation."

Establishment of a system of public hospital clinics to end certain abuses such as in the Walker fee-splitting cases and the extension of the State insurance fund to cover all compensation cases, thus eliminating the private profit motive-from the field, were urged by Louis Waldman, Socialist nominee for Governor, in an address last night in Forward Hall, 175 East Broadway.

BUFFALO. Nov. 4. -- Ogden Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, and F. Trubee Davison, Republican nominee for Lieutenent Governor, tonight delivered the closing addresses of the 1932 Republican campaign in western New York, speaking before an audience of 3,000 in Elmwood Music Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Estimating the decline in workers' income in 1932 at $25,020,000,000, as compared with 1929, and the decrease in retail sales for the same period at $20,000,000,000, the American Federation of Labor, in its monthly survey, today called upon business men to create jobs and raise wages as the only sure way to bring about a continuing economic revival.

John H. McCooey, the Kings County Democratic leader, entertained 150 men and women prominent in political, social and business life at a private dinner last night in the Hotel Granada, opposite the Academy of Music, in Brooklyn, before the Democratic rally there.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- George Bernard Shaw, whose good-humored scoffing at America has been a source of financial profit to him for many years, today confirmed reports that next year he may visit the United States, a land where he has Said many times that he never would risk his neck.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4. -- Huge crowds numbering up to 50,000 at a single stop greeted President Hoover today as he carried his appeal for re-election into the agricultural and industrial sections of Indiana and Illinois with back-platform appearances at fourteen cities and towns.

A campaign would not be a campaign to me without coming over here to the Academy of Music. I have returned to the State of New York to spend the last four days before election among my neighbors and it is to me a happy homecoming.

Holiday Accessory Volume Gains. Orders for accessories showed a marked increase during the latter part of the week. Lingerie in the medium and better price ranges figured prominently, with buying offices here urging the placing of as much of this business as possible before Dec. 1.

The tramp, tramp of files on parade on Boston Common and Soldiers Field mingles with the march of the unbeaten Eastern brigade into action on three important fronts today as the football season heads into the homestretch.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 4. -- The text of the speech as prepared by President Hoover for delivery here this afternoon was as follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 4. -- Beneath the towering stands of Harvard Stadium, which tomorrow afternoon will hold the largest crowd to see Harvard or Army play this season, the rival squads today finished preparations for their fifth clash since they renewed relations on the gridiron in 1928.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Importation by Germany of up to 20,000,000 bushels of American corn for stock feeding was cited as a probable development in the near future in a report to the Commerce Department today from John H. Bruins, American Consul at Hamburg.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- George Washington conquered another intersectional rival tonight before a crowd of 12,000 when the Colonials put to rout a previously unbeaten North Dakota State eleven, 20 to 0.

ST. LOUIS COLISEUM, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Arriving in St. Louis long behind schedule. President Hoover hurried from his train to the Coliseum through a hard rain that he might deliver his speech within the time allotted to him on a nation-wide radio chain.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4 (AP). -- The discovery of a marble-stepped ancient tomb whose doors may hide vast Indian treasures comparable to those exposed in January of this year, was officially disclosed at Oaxaca today by Dr. Caso.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Dr. Lewis P. Shanks, Professor of French at Johns Hopkins University, and Miss Louise Johnson, a graduate student, were married yesterday by the Rev. Francis R. Sturtevant of the First Unitarian Church here.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Wheat today reversed its action of the previous day on the Board of Trade and prices were on the upgrade from the start. At the top December was 2 1/3 cents above the low mark of Thursday, with the close only a fraction under the best figures and at net gains of 1 3/8 to 1 5/8 cents.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- In a campaign speech, here tonight in defense of the Hawley-Smoot tariff. Ambassador Walter E. Edge turned to the subject of prohibition.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Twenty-three 2-year-old colts and fillies have been named for the $40,000 added Pimlico Futurity, richest race of the Maryland Fall season and notable this year in that its entry includes practically every top-flight juvenile with the exception of Ladysman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The Democratic National Committee reported to the Clerk of the House receipts of $504,188.11 from Oct. 24 to Nov. 2, in a pre-election account filed today. The total receipts from June 1 to Nov. 2 were $1,427,118, and expenditures, $1,261,412, leaving a balance of $165,706.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4. -- John A. Roebling's Sons Company of Newark, N.J., today received the contract for the fabrication and erection of cables and accessories for the Golden Gate Bridge and highway district. The figure was $5,855,000. It is the second largest contract in units representing an expected total of $35,000,000.
Tony Canzoneri weighed 132 pounds and Billy Petrolle 134 1/2 as they entered the ring at Madison Square Garden last night.
TOKYO, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Resumption of diplomatic relations between China and Russia was recently proposed again by the Chinese, the Japanese Foreign Office said today.

The claim of a landlord put forward by Mortimer T. Hays as representative of claims amounting to several million dollars against the bankrupt United Cigar Stores Company of America was argued yesterday before Irwin Kurtzr referee, 15 Park Row, as a preliminary to consideration of a demand by Mr. Hays for access to the bankrupt's books to verify his allegations that assets of the company are being undervalued.

Lewis H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor, replied last night to the Democratic charge that statements by officials had injured the city's credit by retorting that the shortcomings of successive Tammany administrations have brought the city government to the point where its shortcomings must be pointed out publicly.

By refusing to halt at the commands of several patrolmen, Frank Mattox McGinn, 33 years old, an automobile salesman of 1,127 Dean Street, Brooklyn, drew upon himself a pursuit during which he was shot and killed early yesterday morning, at Grand Avenue and Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, although he was guilty of nothing more serious than eccentric driving.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Joseph E. Widener's White Lies, beaten a nose by Tred Avon in the Royal Oak purse at Laurel, scored at Pimlico today in the featured Annapolis Handicap, finishing a neck before Projectile with Poppyman three lengths further back.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 4. -- Various protective committees of the Richfield Oil Company were in conference here today endeavoring to figure which had submitted the highest offer for Richfield's properties, the Standard Oil Company of California or the Consolidated Oil Corporation, which made a new bid last night.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 4. -- Policies of the Hoover administration were defended tonight by George W. Wickersham of New York at a Republican rally at which State and local candidates appeared.
A stenographic report of former Governor Smith's address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night follows:

Whatever the actual cause may have been for yesterday's lively advance on the Stock Exchange, Wall Street chose to ascribe it largely to the reassuring political comments of Owen D. Young and others. No doubt, the market was influenced to some extent by other considerations, but Mr. Young was the hero of the day in market circles.

Paul Whiteman and his orchestra, assisted by composers, orchestraters, arrangers and soloists, held their "Fourth Experiment in Modern American music" at Carnegie Hall last night. The result, if one can be reduced into a few words from the various matters presented, was to prove that the experiment has not yet brought to light distinctive or individual beauty, and that its chief virtue is that it serves as a public forum for composers.

John J. Raskob, former Democratic National Chairman, in a radio speech last night over Station WEAF and a national hook-up proposed a five-point program for the restoration of prosperity after the election it Governor Roosevelt and Democratic Congress, which he predicted is a certainty.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Reviewing President Hoover's career from his mining and stock activities of earlier manhood down through his "three years of governmental vacillation, false prophecies and broken promises" in the White House, Senator Johnson of California pleaded before a crowd of 20,000 tonight for the election of Roosevelt.

More than 1,750,000 telephone calls are exchanged between New York City and the suburban districts of the New York retail trading area in "a fairly typical week," the industrial bureau of the Merchants' Association of New York announced yesterday.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange rallied substantially yesterday and several corporation issues, notably rails, recovered some of the losses of the previous few days. In most instances the issues to show the best gains were those that sustained the greatest losses earlier in the week.

George Washington High School's football team, undefeated, untied and unscored upon in four games, will tackle Theodore Roosevelt High at the George Washington Stadium in one of the dozen schoolboy gridiron clashes slated today for fields within New Tork City.

GENEVA, Nov. 4. -- Taking as a cornerstone Secretary Stimson's recent declarations that no nation longer could be disinterested when the Briand-Kellogg pact was violated or could recognize territory acquired by war, Joseph Paul-Boncour, War Minister of France, outlined a plan here today for progressive disarmament.

The two leading reviews of business conditions differ in their opinions of developments in the last week. Dun's Review finds the general trend continuing upward. while Bradstreet's Weekly reports that ejection uncertainty and the recently renewed declines in commodity prices have increased apprehension.
ATHENS, Nov. 4. -- Samuel Insull was arrested today by the Greek Security Police at the request of the United States Department of State.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Dr. Joseph C. Bloodgood, cancer research worker of Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, told the Ottawa Medical Society tonight that mothers might become the guardians of their families against the ravages of cancer.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4. -- Upham Pope, the American authority on Persian art, who played an important part in the organization of the successful exhibition held some time ago in London, recently passed through Moscow en route to Persia with Victor Warburg, son of Felix Warburg.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The Princeton University Senior Promenade was held in the gymnasium here this evening. About three hundred undergraduates and their guests attended the dance, which marked the high point of the university Fall social season.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Representative James M. Beck, addressing a political rally tonight sponsored by the Woman's Republican Club of Pennsylvania, declared that the election of Governor Roosevelt Tuesday would endow him with a one-man dictatorship over American tariffs for eight months, carrying: the threat of virtual extinction of Pennsylvania industries.

The "spiritual bouquet" which will be presented to Cardinal Hayes on Thanksgiving Day by Bishop John J. Dunn in the name of the priests, laymen, women and children of the Archdiocese of New York will contain a record of 29,728,428 "prayers, aspirations and good works."

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Two takes were completed and one, the most important of the card, was carried over until tomorrow at the eighth annual field trials of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America, which began this morning on the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.

Distribution of pheasants by State fish and game commissions, especially in Eastern States, has been providing hunters with such certainty of a bag of game that this class of hunting has now become one of the most popular In almost every locality. Pheasants alone, however, are not the only game distributed in New Jersey, as the report of the commission in that State indicates.
ATLANTIC, CITY, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Davis and Elkins invaded the indoor gridiron of the Municipal Auditorium tonight and defeated Seton Hall, 33 to 6.
ROCKVILLE, Md., Nov. 4 (AP). -- A little dog from the Kings Mountain country today swept far into the van in the second division of the all-age stake of the National Fox-hunters' Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Crude petroleum production of the United States during September totaled 65,036,000 barrels, representing an average daily output of 32,000 barrels more than in August. It was the first time since last April that production increased from one month to another, according to the monthly report of the Commerce Department, issued today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- The Tale Athletic Association today announced the approval of awards of seventy-eight insignia on the recommendation of the Undergraduate Athletic Association.
After having lost 10 to 20 points in the last ten days under constant pressure, quotations on the Cotton Exchange rose $1 a bale yesterday and ended with gains of 13 to 17 points.

Traffic from Santos, Brazil, has been at a record rate since the opening of the port for exports of coffee on Oct. 12. Fourteen steamships have cleared from pantos for this port and two of them have arrived with 105,300 bags, or 13,899,600 pounds, of coffee beans, while the others are bringing 245,000 bags, or 32,340,000 pounds.

The crisis in the Job printing industry was passed yesterday, in the opinion of committees representing employers and compositors, when an all-night, conference ended at 5 o'clock in the morning with an agreement that was satisfactory to both sides.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- A prehistoric pair of "snow goggles" dug from a frozen grave at the northern-most point under the American flag added a whole new chapter today to the history of the human race in the Arctic.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 5. -- Further revolts in Northwest Manchuria were reported this morning By the newspaper Nichi Nichi's correspondent in Tsitsihar, who says the Manchukuo Peace Preservation forces at Kushan and Anta have joined the rebels: Japanese detachments have telegraphed for assistance.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, made public yesterday the report of the company for the third quarter of this year, showing a net deficit of $812,128 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, contrasting with a net income of $1,318,785 in the corresponding, period last year.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4. -- New football formations which Yale will use against Princeton and Harvard were tried today in a drill in which actual scrimmage was avoided.
