WARSAW, Nov. 4. -- A neatly engraved card, inscribed "Generale Ting Shin-yuan, Representant du Chef Executif de Manchoukuo en Mission en Europe," introduced an elderly Chinese gentleman who was lunching today in a Warsaw restaurant with three Japanese Legation members and his private secretary, a German girl, Herta Olschewski.

ABOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL EN ROUTE WEST, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Cheers of "Illinois for Hoover" greeted the President at Gresham Junction, Ill., when he declared to the crowd that their welcome was "evidence of how you will vote on Nov. 8." Some one from the crowd called the "fighting Quaker" and the president smiled.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 4. -- Declaring that the "political nearsightedness" of the Republican party had made it incapable of making a change or "turning our face in the right direction," Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the administration of President Wilson, told an audience at the Montclair Theatre here tonight that he was "happy the country is returning to a time when idealism is coming into its own.

The odds quoted by Wall Street betting commissioners continued to rise in favor of Governor Roosevelt yesterday. Wagers ranging from 4 to 1 to 5 to 1 were made that the Democratic Presidential candidate would win, and late in the afternoon one concern announced that it had $50,000 to bet on Roosevelt at 5 to 1.

An easier tone in time money, with four months' traded at 3/4, a fractional concession from the previous quotation, featured. While other dates remained unchanged there was, nevertheless, a slight increase in business in these maturities. Stock Exchange call money continued at 1 per cent, with Street money, "Federals" and "governments" developing no change.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- No real improvement in the general business situation abroad was shown in the weekly summary of the situation issued today by the Department of Commerce.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the approach of the election, two hoary political beliefs are being revived: First, that a Presidential pear is characterized by uncertainty and is therefore "bad" for business; second, that a Democratic administration means disaster to general business.

PASADENA, Gal., Nov. 4 (AP). -- The question in the minds of most astronomers and students of the skies is whether the Leonid meteors, due to appear between Nov. 12 and 17, will actually be seen. A similar display in the sky was scheduled thirty-three years ago, but watchers were disappointed.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- A letter from Moscow was read in court here today which was intended to prove the recent hunger marchers' demonstrations in London were planned by the Red International of Labor Unions, the Profintern of Moscow.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4. -- following is the text of President Hoover's address in the Coliseum here tonight:

TOULOUSE, France, Nov., 4. -- After listening to a discussion of the budgetary situation and the economic crisis, 2,000 delegates attending the Radical Socialist convention here today voted entire approval of the Herriot government's efforts to cope with these problems.

Dressed as workers, four men entered the sub-basement of the seventy-story R.C.A. Building being constructed in West Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets as part of Rockefeller Center yesteday, held up a subcontractor's paymaster who was paying off thirty workmen and escaped with $2,500.

The undefeated and untied Taft School and Choate School football teams will defend their records today against Kent School and Lawrenceville School, respectively, In two of the feature attractions on the Eastern prep school football schedule that presages a number of interesting contests.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Nov. 4. -- An hour before the Pennsylvania State police were preparing to stop at the State line every New Jersey motor truck without Pennsylvania license plates, in accordance with the last order issued from Harrisburg in the truck war involving half a dozen States, a truce was reached here tonight at a conference between officials of Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

Michel Sarwicki is a barber in Chicago most of the time, but there are periods of rebellion when he is a wanderer. In these times he dons whatever costume best suits his state of mind for the moment and sets his feet on unfrequented paths, or turns his eyes seaward.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 4 (AP). -- Bids for deepening the channel of New London's harbor to 25 feet from its present depth of 20, the work extending from Long Cove to Allyn's Point and involving the removal of 558,000 cubic yards of earth, were opened today by Major Charles J. Taylor of the United States engineers, in charge of the Providence district.

Samuel Untermyer, who is trying to conserve the remaining assets of the Bank of United States by private liquidation, warmly praised Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman's services to the public in the Bank of United States case and denounced Colonel William J. Donovan's attack on Mr. Lehman's connection with the case.

The hearing before a subcommittee of the medical grievance committee of the State Board of Regents on charges that five physicians, including Dr. William H. Walker, the former Mayor's brother, conspired to split compensation fees, was brought to a dramatic close yesterday when Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, resented remarks of the chairman and called the hearing "a most injudicial proceeding."

With both teams at the top of their form for the encounter, Fordham and the strong St. Mary's eleven of California await the opening whistle at the Polo Grounds at 2 o'clock today. The intersectional battle is expected to attract a crowd of 50,000.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The stock market was fairly cheerful today, but business was restricted. British funds were subjected to profit-taking in early trading, but renewed support appeared later and quotations improved.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Little Bobby Holmes, 135-pound halfback, furnished two spectacular touchdown runs to give the Haskell Indians a 14-14 tie with Temple University in the Owls' Stadium tonight.

It is more than a cruel coincidence that wheat has been selling at the lowest price ever recorded in the history of the Chicago market as Mr. HOOVER sets out once more to convince the farmer that a protective tariff is "the very basis" of his prosperity.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 4 (AP). -- A disqualification marked the running of the Bellevue Purse, feature at Latonia today, when the winner, Plunkett Chinn's 3-year-old colt, I Pass, was set back for fouling.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4. -- The discovery of two more tombs of ancient Mixtecan or Zapotecan chieftains at Monte Alban, where the first excavations electrified the archaeological world, has been confirmed by Dr. Alfonso Caso, who is directing the excavations.

Although no financing for corptorations was done this week, new bond and note issues aggregating $30,837,000 were placed on the market. Of this amount $25,837,000 was in State and municipal obligations and $5,000,000 in Federal Intermediate Credit Bank system debentures. Last week the new financing amounted to only $2,048,000. A year ago new bonds in the amount of $7,950,000 were marketed.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 4. -- The Columbia football team reached Annapolis today and a little later went to Thompson Stadium, where it will meet the naval academy tomorrow. The Lions returned to Baltimore in the early evening.
Three teams share the lead in the Class B squash tennis competition of the Metropolitan League as a result of second straight triumphs scored last night.

The Columbia University athletic investigating committee adopted a resolution yesterday to withhold all findings concerning alleged professionalism in intercollegiate athletics it Columbia, unless ordered otherwise by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.
Bivalves or Ballots? A new method of opening oysters by the use of narcotics has been mentioned. It is discussed at length in a recent number of The United States Daily.

Mrs. Whitney Endt, 28 years old, wife of an insurance broker living at the Hotel Montclair, Forty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue, was held in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning as a fugitive from justice. She had been arrested quietly on Thursday in the disappearance of jewelry from the home of Mrs. Paul M. Browne of Delafield Island Road, Darien, Conn.

Outstanding bank loans and letters of credit of McKesson Robbins, Inc., manufacturers and distributers of drugs, were reduced from $4,820,000 on Dec. 31 last to $2,900,000 on Aug. 31, it was announced yesterday by F. Donald Coster, president. Since Aug. 31 the amount has been reduced to approximately $2,750,000, or by $2,070,000.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, candidate for re-election, denounced last night President Hoover's radio appeal to the Pacific Coast States on Wednesday night, in which he recounted the millions that had been advanced to California and Pacific Coast banks and enterprises by the Federal Government, as a resort to the "pork-barrel" and the most sordid appeal which he had ever seen in an election.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, said yesterday at his headquarters here that President Hoover's Springfield speech showed that the President at last had recognized that his re-election was improbable, inasmuch as he had quoted from President Lincoln's pessimistic address just before his re-election in 1864.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in October totaled $20,022,433,089. This was a loss of 2.9 per cent from the September turnover and of 38.7 per cent from the total in October last year. It was the first drop in clearing since July, there having been an increase in each of the succeeding months until October.

Colonel William Boyce Thompson, mining engineer and banker, whose estate was estimated at $85,000,000 when he died at his home in Yonkers on June 27, 1930, left $18,284,423 gross and $16,24,717 net, the appraisal showed yesterday. The bulk of the estate consisted of securities worth $16,680,550 at the time of his death.

Prizes for table decorations featuring Autumn shades were awarded yesterday, in addition to those in the remaining classes for plants and cut flowers, at the annual exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, which opened on Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Maurice Frank, impresario of the Chicago Stadium Grand Opera Company, denied tonight published reports that the opera company had disbanded.

A program for the socialization of the railroads to solve the problem of the nation's carriers was outlined last night in a campaign address at James Madison High School in Brooklyn by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President.

David Ross, announcer of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has been selected as the third recipient of the gold medal for good diction on the radio, presented annually by the American Academy of Arts and Letters, it was announced yesterday. The award will be presented on Nov. 10 by Dr. John H. Finley, member of the Academy's Committee on Awards, during the literary exercises to be held at the Academy Auditorium, 632 West 156th Street.

In an address at the eighty-sixth anniversary of the New York Academy of Medicine Dr. WALTER B. CANNON of Harvard renewed the plea of physicians and surgeons for unhampered animal experimentation "as a means of solving the riddles of such diseases as infantile paralysis, cancer and the degenerative diseases."

A second-period forward pass from Larry Spellman to Thacker Kaye gained 30 yards to score the only touchdown of a hard-fought game between the Manhattan freshman football team and St. John's Prep of Danvers, Mass. The Jasper cubs won, 7 -- 0, before 1,200 at Manhattan Field yesterday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Noranda Mines. Ltd., report net earnings of $2,819,853 for the first nine months of this year, equivalent to 35 cents a share. This compared with 42 cents in the second quarter and 48 cents in the first quarter, bringing the net earnings for the nine months to an equivalent of $1.26 a share.

Now that this city has obtained the loan of a sufficient sum to tide it over election day and the brief interval that remains before the next instalment of taxes must be paid, the politicians may rest in peace. Payrolls will not be disturbed at this awkward moment, and contractors will have their first-of-the-month bills paid.

The authorship of "Singapore," coming to the Forty-eighth Street Theatre on Nov. 14, is now being credited to Robert Keith, instead of Harold Woolf, who was listed as the author during the play's recent tryout on the subway circuit. Louise Prussing, Edward Raquello and Lionel Ince are late additions to the cast, which is headed by Suzanne Caubaye.

A procedure that will make Christian, literature societies in foreign countries "completely indigenous as rapidly, as properly qualified national leaders can be enlisted, and can gain experience in the conduct of the enterprise," is suggested in an instalment of the report of the appraisal commission appointed by the Laymen's Foreign.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 4 (AP). -- Pierre S. du Pont, chairman of the board of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., announced today his support of Governor Roosevelt for President, "chiefly because of Mr. Hoover's attitude on prohibition."
That grim-visaged, battle-scarred warrior of the ring, Billy Petrolle, made his championship bid too late and against odds that were too great for his weary old frame.

Alarmed by the fact that the candidacy of Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon has been generally overlooked, in the controversy over the Hofstadter - Steuer judiciary "deal," a committee working for his re-election yesterday issued an appeal in his behalf.

Difficulties that threatened the West Indies trade, particularly the services between New York, Nassau and Havana, were said to have been eliminated yesterday when a three-day conference of the representatives of transatlantic ship lines and lines serving the West Indies throughout the year was closed at the offices of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference, 8-10 Bridge Street.

The Grasselli Medal for 1932, an annual award for distinction in applied chemistry, was presented to Professor George L. Clark of the University of Illinois at a meeting last night of the American section of the Society of Chemical Industry at Grand Central Palace.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- Three persons were killed today as frequent clashes between the police and rioters in all parts of the city marked the second day of the strike of municipal transit company employes, sponsored by National Socialists and Communists. A woman was so seriously injured that she was expected to die during the night.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Hotchkiss Ely will give a dinner tonight at the St. Regis for her debutante daughter, Miss Gertrude Ely.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4. -- The governmental intention to insure as national reserves numerous mineral resources of Mexico took the practical form this evening of a Presidential order that said substantially:

Pointing out that certain of its older producing properties were developed under "boom" conditions, the Simms Petroleum Company in a statement to stockholders accompanying the income report for the three months ended on Sept. 30, says that it has revalued some of its assets at reduced book figures.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The British Actors' Equity Association's proposal for a closed shop in the London theatres, along the lines of the Actors' Equity in the United States, was approved at a mass meeting of the profession today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Hoover will be re-elected if only his Republican friends can refrain from calling him names this week. The fashion began, as I remember it, with "Herbert Hoover, Humanitarian." That was quite credible, although at the time we were being taught to be chary of capital letters.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The list of the British delegates to the next Round Table Conference on Indian Affairs, issued tonight, fails to include any one from the Labor party.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4. -- For the first time in public speech since he began his campaign for re-election, President Hoover tonight in this wet city and before an audience which included many German-Americans took up, although briefly, the question of prohibition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Comment on the French disarmament plan, broadly outlined by Joseph Paul-Boncour at Geneva, was refused by State Department officials today in the absence of formal advices.

Recovery was the rule on all of the markets yesterday. The spirited advance in stocks and the slower but no less impressive rally in bonds and commodities seemed to indicate, to Wall Street at least, that fears arising from the possibility, or the likelihood, of a change in the Federal administration had been largely dissipated.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee was supported by the full Board of Estimate yesterday in rebuking the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for its proposed loan to the Port Authority to build the Thirty-eighth Street tunnel under the North River without consulting the city officials on the project.

We think it was KIPLING who Somewhere spoke of "the magic of the necessary word." If anybody in the United States has command of it better than OWEN D. YOUNG, his name is not known to the public. What Mr. YOUNG said at the great meeting in the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday evening, heard as his address was over the radio by millions, had, first of all, the magic of perfect phrasing.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The "Princeton varsity and freshman harriers defeated their Lafayette oppopents both by 15 -- 40 scores, in races over the Princeton course today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Representative John J. O'Connor, Democrat, of New York, charged in a statement today that the Republican party was obtaining large campaign contributions from the beneficiaries of tax refunds.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 (AP). -- Chancellor Franz von Papen declared in a nation-wide radio broadcast tonight that Adolf Hitler's criticism of the government's foreign policy amounted to a "stab in the back."

Women will eventually be given a more important part in court affairs and will probably hold judgeships on every bench in the nation, Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, told 500 women members of the Theatre Assembly yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, pledged himself to "a continuation of the enlightened social legislation relating to labor" for which he gave credit to Governors Smith and Roosevelt, and laid down a series of specific promises of the things he intended to accomplish if elected, in an address last night at the Democratic rally in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith is slated for the post of chief budgetary officer for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt on his election to the Presidency next Tuesday, a gathering of Democrats were told last night at the Barbizon-Plaza by Frank Carstarphen, former Assistant United States Attorney.

The re-election of President Hoover with at least 270 votes in the electoral college, four in excess of a majority, is predicted in a statistical study of vote percentages in the several States, based on a poll taken by the Hearst publications, which was made public yesterday by Frank A. Vanderlip Jr., on behalf of the Fact-Finding Committee for Hoover.

To the Editor of The New York Times: CLAREMORE, Okla., Nov. 4. -- This is a hot campaign. Tempers have been lost, gentlemanly conduct is a lost art, but let's just stop and study a minute and give the rascals the benefit of the doubt.

The Montclair Academy and Horace Mann School for Boys football teams played a 13-to-13 tie at Horace Mann Field yesterday. Vollmer's touchdown on a line plunge late in the final period tied the score for Horace Mann.

Judge John M. Woolsey of the Federal District Court declined yesterday to hear the petition of Manhattan Railway Company stockholders for an order directing the Interborough receivers to pay $860,000 due for franchise and real estate taxes and $813,660 interest due Oct. 1, last, on the Manhattan's first consolidated mortgage bonds.

Disclosure in the bankruptcy proceedings against Kountze Brothers that the First National Bank held $1,970,000 of St. Louis-San Francisco Railway consolidated mortgage bonds was said in financial circles yesterday to throw the proposed recapitalization of the railway into a new aspect.
TOKYO, Nov. 5--The Soviet icebreaker Siberiakov III arrived at Yokohama today after successfully negotiating the first Arctic passage between Europe and Asia in a single season.

The Unexpected Visitor. After a long absence, the Man From Down Under turned up again. He strolled in casually and began talking about some Australian horses that were coming to Agua Caliente -- Ammon-Ra, Pillow Flight, and so on. He was half-way through their pedigrees and past performances when he was rudely interrupted. What did he mean by rambling along about Australian horses that were going to race in Mexico?

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- A tale of clouds and watermelons and two days' wandering is told by Pilot Zabelin, a Soviet aviator who made a record parachute jump and then spent two days getting back to his starting point.
During the month of October there were registered with the American Kennel Club a total of 4,465 dogs of all breeds. For the same period in 1931 the total was 3,200, representing a gain of 1,265.

All markets rounded out the week with a show of firmness yesterday. This steadiness naturally attracted most attention in sterling and in wheat, prices for both having moved with a good deal of activity last week. On the Stock Exchange the week-end steadiness, with small net advances predominating, had little significance, for prices had heen falling in the first half of the week and have merely retraced their steps in the two past days.

THE city of Genoa has just published and reproduced with color photography all the documentary evidence in her archives and libraries on the origin Columbus. Each record, notarial deed, conveyance, family will, letter and writing by contemporaries is submitted and translated into English and German.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Political developments in Westchester County this Fall indicate, according to observers, that the results of the election on Tuesday will bring some shocks to the Republican party, which has controlled Westchester for the last three decades.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 5 -- In a hard-fought intersectional game today the Notre Dame Ramblers triumphed over the Kansas Jayhawkers, 24 to 6.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5 -- Duquesne University sprang an upset today by defeating the Washington and Jefferson eleven, 19 to 0, at Forbes Field before a crowd of 12,000.

The composite opinion of nearly 200 usually well-informed political observers in the several States is that Franklin D. Roosevelt will be elected President next Tuesday with from 400 to 450 electoral votes. Their preponderant view is that he will carry at least 39 States with a total of 438 electors.

THE layman and legislator and not a few students of social problems have a tendency toward oversimplification of the problem of crime causation. If, for example, they are particularly interested in the improvement of housing conditions, they will point to the fact that in some localities crowded tenements and "slum areas" are found together.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: I have just read a letter from Lucy V. King relative to to the Ku Klux Klan. There is no doubt as to its origin and personnel. I listened to General John B. Gordon tell how imperative it seemed that some protective agency should exist, and he called to his aid men identified with him in the war; he especially mentioned Generals Wade Hampton and N.B. Forrest.

ROME, Nov. 5 (AP)--The names of the prisoners affected by Premier Mussolini's amnesty will be announced when the King signs the decree. It was considered unlikely that the amnesty would be extended to anti-Fascists living abroad, such as former Premier Francesco Nitti, who lives in Paris, and Count Sforza.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 5 -- With a registration of about 300,000, the greatest in its history, Nassau County is expected to establish a record vote next Tuesday, exceeding by several thousand the number of ballots cast in 1928, when almost 125,000 persons voted for the Presidential candidates.

One of the musicians so great that they can do no wrong, at least in the eyes of the public, is Sergei Rachmaninoff, the distinguished Russian pianist who gave his first-recital of the season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. And Mr. Rachmaninoff is indeed a prodigious planist in all that the word implies -- not merely as regards his phenomenal planistic equipment hut in his profound sincerity, his musicionship, his heritage of the grand style.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- More than 12,000,000 men, women and children received disaster and unemployment relief from the American Red Cross in the fiscal year ending June 30, according to the annual report of that organization, made public today.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 5 -- The Hill School eleven defeated Williamson Trade School today in a close game, 13 -- 7. Hill scored in the first quarter on Smale's end run, and in the next period on a pass, Hebard to Lowndes.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Mrs. George G. Milne of Rye opened her home yesterday for a bridge tea to aid the United Hospital of Rye and Port Chester. Mrs. Carl H. Randebrock, chairman of the benefit, was assisted by Mrs. Stuyvesant Wainwright, Mrs. William J. Wilson, Mrs. Bryan L. Kennelly, Mrs. George L. Peters and Mrs. Oscar W. Anderson.
The text of the address of Governor Roosevelt at Madison Square Garden last night follows:

MOTOR vehicle accidents have increased continuously each year since the wide use of the automobile, until in 1931 nearly 35,000 persons were killed in this form of accident. However figures available for the first nine months of 1932 have shown a substantial decrease in the number of persons killed in such accidents for this year as compared with the same period for 1931.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Napoleon's library, hurried out of France in 1814 by the Empress Marie Louise, has been brought back and is now on exhibi- tion in the chateau at Malmaison. It has only been loaned, however, by a Berlin bookseller, who intends to offer it for sale later.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 5--Mrs. Stella Clara Behr, a descendant of several noted persons and widow of Joseph Leighton, Montana cattleman and banker, and of Robert Behr, Brooklyn manufacturer, died on her estate at 211 South Broadway here yesterday after a long illness.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Nov. 5 (AP) -- President Hoover greeted a crowd estimated at 15,000 when he stopped here ten minutes at 8:40 A.M. today.

Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee and director of the Hoover campaign, in a pre-election statement made public yesterday simultaneously in this city and in Chicago, declared that President Hoover would emerge a winner from Tuesday's election with a "bedrock margin" of 281 electoral votes and at least twenty-one States in his column.

HAVING tired a little of purely contemporary poetry, we turn now to study the early American poets and the development of our poetic literature as a whole. Mark Van Doren presents in his anthology fifty-seven names "in the belief that even so few may speak after all most perfectly for the better part of American poetry over three centuries."

STOCKHOLM IT is no "great shakes" to be a statue in Stockholm. No sooner had the fifteenth century liberator, Engelbrekt Engelbrektsson, been put upon his lofty pedestal in the formal gardens of the Stockholm Town Hall than the architect of the building, Ragnar Ostberg, pointed out that the pedestal was crooked.

JAMES ABBOTT McNEILL WHISTLER, while he is by no means the "whole show" at the Museum of Modern Art, serves fascinatingly to revive interest in a chapter in the history of American art that had grown a little dim with the dust of passing time.

No immediate change in the policy of the Federal Reserve System is contemplated, according to informed bankers. Two factors, one seasonal and the other psychological, militate against a reduction in the system's portfolio of $1,851,000,000 of United States Government securities before the end of the year.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 5 -- New Hampshire Cats put up a game fight today, but Dartmouth scored a touchdown a period and beat the down-State visitors, 25 to 0.

In accordance with a call sent out by their leaders, the drys of the country will observe today as a day of humiliation, fasting and prayer "that the great evil of legalizing intoxicating drink may not again overwhelm our nation."
MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 5 -- Led by dodging Dougal Russell, who carried the pigskin only seven times, for an average of 18 yards, Kansas State today took the measure of Iowa State, 31 -- 0.
CONCORD, Nov. 5 -- For the first time in sixteen years New Hampshire, normally Republican by about 30,000, faces a national election with the result in doubt.

With an entry comprising the stars of the leading show stables of the country, the National Horse Show Association of America will inaugurate its forty-seventh annual exhibition in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, with the finale on Tuesday evening, Nov. 15.

WHILE looking for new tax sources, France recently became aware that she had a surprisingly large number of licensed saloons -- 480,000, as compared with only 395,000 before the war. Is the number of saloons in other countries also increasing?

LONDON WHEN Montagu C. Norman, governor of the Bank of England, suddenly appeared on the coast of Maine recently, his unaccountable presence there under an assumed name was quickly noted and discussed throughout Europe.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Damocratic candidate for Governor, declared last night in an address at the rally in Madison Square Garden that Democracy taught its disciples that the State and nation were human agencies, and predicted an overwhelming victory in the coming election in nation, State and city.

To the Music Editor: The Damrosch reply to the Stokowski proposal to broadcast "modernistic" music to school children was what the boys over in the publicity pastures call a "honey." The dean's rebuttal delivered below the belt was as gratuitous as this letter to the press.

FOR years Samuel Levene, the young actor who scores a substantial success as Maxy Kane, the theatrical agent, in "Din ner at Eight" -- must you be told the it's playing at the Music Box? -- cherished two great ambitions. One was to get a part in a Broadway "hit" and the other was to persuade his oldfashioned Jewish mother to make a pilgrimage from the Bronx to see him act.

BLIND flight is something more than setting up delicate instruments somewhere near the pilot's normal line of vision. Some time ago oculists in Johns Hopkins University's famous medical school carried out a series of studies, in which Colonel Lindbergh collaborated, seeking to establish the correct color and size for an instrument board.

Emphatic denial that his election would mean bankruptcy and ruin for New York city was voiced last night at the Madison Square Garden, rally by Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Tammany candidate for Mayor. Judge O'Brien declared he spoke in denial of this charge of another candidate for Mayor because it would be heard over a national broadcast throughout the country.

SUMTER, N.C., Nov. 3 -- Although the auction season is just over, a widespread movement has already started in South Carolina to persuade tobacco farmers not to let this year's relatively high prices lead them into another year of overproduction and rock-bottom prices such as prevailed in 1931.

ART lovers will have an opportunity to view for the first time a notable collection of Matisse paintings when, on Nov. 16 and 17, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Clark open their home, 46 East Seventieth Street, in aid of Hope Farm, a community school in Verbank, Dutchess County, N.Y.
BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- The transit strike continued today and most of Berlin had a third day of walking to and from work.

BURLINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Observers believe that Vermont will remain true to its rock-ribbed Republicanism on Nov. 8 in spite of the fact that the Democrats have put up the stiffest campaign in twenty-five years with a complete State ticket in the field.

ANNUAL balls in commemoration of the Armistice will be features of the current week, with the occurrence on Thursday and Friday of three entertainments that each year are among the chief functions of the early season in New York.

Color Variations. IT sounds incredible that color variations used in automobile finishes actually run up to ever 11,500, and, at the present rate, would go on increasing by about 800 every year. But the point is -- and there is a point -- that something is being done to arrest this gigantism.

GUAYAQUIL, Nov. 2 -- Political circles in Quito are involved in an argument over the question whether the government troops who revolted Aug. 27 and caused the loss of between 500 and 1,000 lives shall be punished.

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 5 -- Franklin and Marshall improved its chances in the Eastern Pennsylvania intercollegiate conference by defeating Muhlenberg today, 21 to 7. The Blue and White scored in three of the four periods. Brubaker was the star, his 44-yard run for a touchdown in the closing minutes being the longest of the game.

The United States Shipping Board reports that American ships have won an important share of the cargoes moving between the Pacific Coast and the Orient since the war through the establishment of government-owned lines and the encouragement of operations by private interests which have acquired the government lines.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 5 -- The text of President Hoover's speech here this afternoon follows:

ELKINS, W. Va., Nov. 3 -- West Virginia, which has a normal Republican plurality of 40,000, is regarded as a doubtful State by the Republican side and is counted for Roosevelt by optimistic observers, who estimate that the Democratic plurality this time will be at least 50,000.

Carbon monoxide fumes from a small still condensing liquor into a one-gallon jug killed a man, his son and a young nephew early yesterday in their apartment on the fifth floor of the tenement at 328 East Fifty-ninth Street. All the windows in the five-room apartment had been closed, apparently in an effort to prevent the odor of alcohol from spreading to neighbors' apartments.

WHEN Nero shed the blood of Christian martyrs nearly nineteen centuries ago in the great circus which bore his name, he could hardly have dreamed, in his most extravagant moments, of the changes which years would bring to the section of imperial Rome where the walls of the arena towered.

IT is doubtful if a subject for an American biography which offers a fuller range for the exercise of the most versatile traits of literary portraiture can be found in the whole rich range of the nineteenth century than John Quincy Adams.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 5 -- Twenty-one gunners took part in the opening shoot of the second trap-shooting season of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club over the traps of the organization today. The program was made up of two events, each at fifty targets, and the winner of the High Scratch Cup in each event was G. Schwalb, who each time returned a card of forty-six.

ONE of First National's most important pictures of the year, "20,000 Years in Sing Sing," is finished and was previewed in Hollywood last week. This is the picturization of the book by Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing prison and features Spencer Tracy, Bette Davis, Lyle Talbot and Edward J. McNamara.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 5 -- Exeter routed Hebron Academy, 44 -- 0, today, rolling up the largest score ever made against the Maine school. The second eleven started and at halftime had a 14-0 lead, the touchdowns coming on forward passes, Batten to April.
This New Old World. More impressive than the fact that we live in an unrecognizable world is the speed with which the world has been rendered unrecognizable. It has happened almost overnight.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 5 -- Wesleyan triumphed over Williams by 13 -- 6 today, breaking the string of Purple victories in the Little Three series which has extended over a period of three years. The Middletown team was forced to come from behind to win, Williams leading at the half, 6 -- 0.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Amherst displayed consistent superiority over Trinity this afternoon and was a 31-to-0 victor in Trinity's last game of the season.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- The Russians have rather strange ideas about the American elections. If the average reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES could imagine what he would think if he read only The Daily Worker [New York Communist newspaper] and the bitterest opinion of radical reviews he would get in line with the Soviet viewpoint.

A GROUP of young matrons under the direction of Mrs. C. Shelby Carter will sell gardenias at the benefit performance of "Dinner at Eight" on Thursday night at the Music Box Theatre, when the net proceeds from the performance as well as from the sale of flowers will be devoted to the work of the Maternal Health Centres.

KENT, Conn., Nov. 5 -- A heavily-favored Taft School football team triumphed over Kent School, 14 -- 9, today, but it had to come from behind and fight to the very last whistle to accomplish it. However, the Watertown Warriors proved equal to the task, and as a result remain unbeaten and untied.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 3 -- Unless unexpected weather conditions upset things on Nov. 8, Vermont will poll the heaviest vote in its history, and will uphold its rock-ribbed Republican reputation by giving its three electoral votes to Hoover and Curtis.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- President George Norlin of the University of Colorado, who holds the Theodore Roosevelt Professorship of American History at the University of Berlin for this academic year, delivered his inaugural lecture today in the university hall that is set aside for occasions of ceremony.

In the fight between George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch, independents, and State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer, bipartisan nominees, for two of the four places on the Supreme Court bench the voters of the two major parties in New York will have their chief opportunity on Tuesday to express their opinion on the issue of Tammany dominance in New York City.

MODERN music should be heard. That fact has been emphasized in these columns. There are special places and special conditions under which modern music is properly stressed, and the organization which has put itself in the foreground in this field of performance is the League of Composers.

Recent uncertainty as to whether prices would continue to advance is now being dispelled, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. A number of the more staple lines that were raised, the report says, have been lowered, while prices on others still remain stationary, but with a tendency to ease.

Led by Miss Nina Volknar, Swarthmore College player, who tallied four goals, the Germantown Cricket Club of Philadelphia triumphed over the Carroll Club first team, 8 to 1, in an inter-city field hockey match at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 3 -- If, by chance, the outcome of the Presidential election should hinge upon the eleven electoral votes of Kentucky, it may be Nov. 12 before the result is known. This is due to the operation of a State law, passed in 1930, which postpones the count of the ballots.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my book entitled "The Law of Territorial Waters and Maritime Jurisdiction," published in 1927, there is a discussion of various legal problems which arose out of the operations of rum-runners along the coasts of the United States.

The importance of promoting mental hygiene in the public schools to counteract increasing mental disorders and crime in the country was stressed yesterday by school authorities at the annual luncheon of the United Parents' Associations in the Hotel New Yorker to mark the beginning tomorrow of "Open School Week."

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 -- A Bolivian regiment of Indian, rubber workers from the upper Amazon has just added to South American military history a chapter typical of the difficulties the Bolivians are forced to overcome in getting troops to the Chaco.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Bank debits outside New York City declined during the week ended Oct. 29, and on a daily average basis were the lowest for the month, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 5 -- Alabama's Crimson tide won a hard-fought game from V.P.I. today by 9 to 6 before a homecoming crowd of 15,000 persons. Alabama was forced to rally for its victory after trailing at the end of the first half by 6 to 0.

THIS new biographical series starts off at a good, brisk pace and promises to make an admirable addition to current literature. In the first place, the conception of it is gratifyingly fitted to the needs and desires of many modern readers who have neither time nor willingness to read full-sized, detailed biographies of all the world's great, concerning whom they want to know enough to be able to think intelligently about them.

THE world-wide aviation of the future, with a network of airlines extending all over the globe, demands the evolution of long-range flying machines which shall be fitted to operate safely and regularly over the great oceans and along the main sea routes according to the Society of British Aircraft Constructors.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 5 -- Playing with a reserve line-up for all but the final period and one minute of the first, the C.C.N.Y. football team lost to Providence College, 46 -- 0, on Hendricken Field today.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 5 -- A brilliant final-period rally, netting two touchdowns, enabled Massachusetts State to overcome a strong Rensselaer Polytechnic eleven on Alumni Field today, 18 -- 13.

MOUNT HAMILTON, Cal., Nov. 5 (AP) -- An alert observer watching the sky for an hour on any clear moonless night will see one or more of the objects popularly called falling stars or shooting stars, and known to astronomers as meteors. Then, more rarely, there comes an extremely brilliant one that lights the whole heavens and that may explode as it disappears.

The Mayoralty contest between Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democrat; Lewis H. Pounds, Republican, former Borough President of Brooklyn, and Morris Hillquit, Socialist, is the chief local contest to be decided in Tuesday's election. The successful candidate will fill that part of the unexpired term of James J. Walker, who resigned under fire, extending from Jan. 1, to Dec. 31, 1933.

THE Pennsylvania Museum has been living up to its reputation for putting on stimulating shows, a reputation, of which some of us localists are ignorant, by staging an unusually fine exhibition, retrospective and representative, of WorK by Jean-Louis Forain, artist, caricaturist and Academician in just that order of importance.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 BERNARD SHAW is getting old. He lets himself be photographed in a Ghandi-like nudity among the waves of the Mediterranean, be worshipped among the elms of Malvern -- and now along comes a disciple and writes a better play than the master.

FULTON, Mo. A MISSOURI college, daring the athletic, fates, has deliberately abolished intercollegiate football. And as part of the step, it has made a careful check-up to see what the effects would be on its abil- ity to, hold students, on the kind of students attracted, and on public favor.

BECAUSE the whole world was heartily weary of fighting in 1919, one of the most important and decisive military actions of the last decade has been allowed to pass virtually unnoticed and unchronicled. The newly-formed nation of Poland, already crippled by war and torn by internal political strife, united itself desperately against the power of the Bolsheviki.

WHEN the Leonids make their annual visit, between Nov. 15 and 17, astronomers will look for Tempel's comet, last seen in 1866. Its orbit and that of the Leonid meteors coincide closely. Hence it is assumed that a comet which exploded thousands of years ago may be responsible both for the Leonids and the body known by Tempel's name.

After one of the most intensively fought campaigns in the history of the State, all surface indications support the Democrats' claim that Franklin D. Roosevelt, their Presidential nominee; Herbert H. Lehman, their candidate for Governor; Robert F. Wagner, who is seeking a second term, in the United States Senate, and other candidates on their State ticket will win by towering pluralities on Tuesday.
NEWARK, Del., Nov. 5 -- The University of Delaware eleven defeated the St. Joseph team of Philadelphia on Frazer Field today, 7 to 0.

This was the summing sentence of Mrs. BUCK'S recent review of missions out of her own experience in China. By "sympathy and feeling" as well as by the years of her life she spoke as a Chinese, though by birth and ancestry American and by "choice and belief a Christian."

Corporation bonds, on the average, extended slightly yesterday their gains of the previous day, while advances and declines in the foreign group on the Stock Exchange were about evenly balanced. Trading in the two-hour period aggregated only $3,455,000, making the slowest day since Aug. 15, 1931, when the turnover was $3,425,000.

THERE is one great difference between the work of a politician like myself and the work of the physician. The medical profession has a body of science at its back as its final court of appeal, with a pharmacopoeia regularly revised and brought up to date and recognized internationally; and I envy the physician, because I am dealing with such things as economics, the monetary standards and international exchange.

MADRID, Oct. 22 -- With the new Italian liner Rex now cutting the time from Gibraltar to New York to little more than that from New York to Cherbourg and Havre, Spain sees itself gaining importance as a point of entry for Europe.

HENDRIK WILLEM VAN LOON is planning a broadcast course in history, which he will introduce to the audience of WEVD on Nov. 11 from 8:15 to 8:45 P.M., and every Friday thereafter. This broadcast is the forerunner of a wider curriculum in which authorities in philosophy, psychology, music, poetry, literature and politics will be invited to participate.

BERLIN, Nov. 5. -- Tomorrow's election whereby it is intended to remove the Damocletian sword that was suspended over the von Papen Cabinet while the last Reichstag existed will in all probability achieve that purpose.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index is 55.5 for the week ended Oct. 29, as against 55.4 for the preceding week and 65.4 for the corresponding week last year. None of the five component indices showed any marked change, and none showed any significant movement, with the possible exception of the adjusted index of automobile production, which turned upward after a long and severe decline.

Elmer Taber scored all the points as the undefeated and untied La Salle Military Academy football team of Oakdale, L.I., blanked Poly Prep, 18 to 0, yesterday at Poly Prep field in Brooklyn for its sixth straight triumph. Taber substituted for McGratty at right halfback early in the game.

TOPEKA, Nov. 5 -- With the Kansas farmers staging one of their periodical political revolts, most anything can happen Tuesday. Although the Republican State Committee hopes that the women votes will offset the Democratic trend, they are not optimistic that the Hoover-Curtis ticket will carry the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- President Hoover's half-hour visit to Philadelphia last Monday probably did not win or lose votes for him. It did, however, serve one outstanding purpose. It showed the skeptics that William S. Vare, the sick but still powerful leader of the Philadel-_ phia Republican organization, really had determined to overlook his grievances, real or imagined, and send his machine all the way down the line for the President.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- Germany is again voting as this is being read, but independent political minds -- and there are such even in this party-ridden country -- are less interested in their home balloting than in the election in the United States two days later.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 -- Ohio voters will give twenty-six electoral votes to Roosevelt unless all signs are wrong.

A crowd of about 5,000 watched the John Adams High School eleven conquer Jamaica High, 25 -- 13, yesterday at Jamaica Stadium in the first game played between the two teams. The winners, after being held scoreless during the first half, tallied 12 and 13 points in the third and fourth quarters, respectively, to emerge triumphant.
MONTROSE, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Hendrick Hudson High School's eleven vanquished Dobbs Ferry High, 12 to 0, today. Chester scored both touchdowns.

MEN and women interested in the community project of the Berkshire Industrial Farm for needy and promising boys are subscribing to the performance of "When Ladies Meet," the comedy by Rachel Crothers, at the Royale Theatre, on the night of Nov. 16.

Stung to the quick by the defeats of the past two weeks, a rejuvenated Fordham eleven made a brand new start yesterday when it vented its feelings on the vaunted St. Mary's College eleven from the valley of Moraga in far-off California.

The New York Stock Exchange has received from the receivers for the Booth Fisheries Company a notice that they are unwilling to incur the expense of continuing to employ a transfer agent for the company's stocks, which have been listed on the Exchange for many years.

WHEN Dorsha opened the nintn season of her Theatre of the last week, she extended its record for longevity to a poimt where it becomes almost a curiosity in the "littte theatre" field. The records reveal no other dance organization in that category that can begin to rival it, and few dramatic organizations.

A program of economic planning as part of a larger Socialist program for collectivization of industry was urged by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, in addresses yesterday at Erasmus High School, Brooklyn, and at Teachers College auditorium in Jamaica.

Voters of Brooklyn and Queens were told that they, as home-owners and rent-payers, held the balance of power in the city election and could "swing the election against Tammany" if they cast their ballots in full force, by Lewis H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor, who made three addresses in those boroughs last night.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- New Jersey, which gave President Hoover a plurality of 309,000 in 1928 and then turned a political somersault last year to elect a Democratic Governor, who carried seventeen of the State's twenty-one counties, was in the doubtful column tonight as the voters awaited Tuesday's balloting.

The election of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Presidency as a "true humanitarian" was urged yesterday by representatives of fourteen railroad workers' organizations in New Jersey in a statement made public by the Democratic State Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Voters qualified to participate in next Tuesday's election are 47,757,102 as against 43,388,492 in the 1928 Presidential campaign, according to figures collected by Simon Michelet, president of the Get-Out-the-Vote Club.

The attacks by Colonel William J. Donovan on Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman based on the failures of the City Trust Company and the Bank of United States have been denounced as unfair by Michael F. Longro, a Brooklyn attorney and chairman of the committee of depositors and stockholders of the City Trust Company, in a letter to Colonel Lehman, which was made public yesterday by Mr. Longo.

DURING the three years that Carl Laemmle Jr. has been general manager of Universal's studio he has on several occasions attracted the attention of his colleagues, and comparatively recently he astonished them by announcing that he had bought the rights to "Once in a Lifetime," the play poking fun at Hollywood.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Scientists representing thirteen foreign countries have indicated that they will join with the American Association for the Advancement of Science in a meeting here next June in connection with the Century of Progress Exposition.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- While a month ago it appeared most probable that President Hoover would carry Massachusetts and that Governor Joseph B. Ely, the Democratic incumbent, would be re-elected, the prospects have changed so rapidly within the last month that non-partisan observers regard the outcome as a toss-up.

LAKELAND, Fla., Nov. 3 -- Besides taking every possible step to care for its own unemployed, Florida is preparing to meet complications which are certain to ensue when many of the jobless from other States begin to arrive in large numbers to spend the Winter in the mild climate.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 5 -- New Ashford, a Berkshire town fourteen miles north of Pittsfield, with thirty-four voters, expects to lead the nation in making known its election result on Tuesday morning. The poll is to open at 5:45 A.M. Alarm clocks will be set at 4:30 A.M.

Because Tuesday is election day many pastors will today devote their sermons to the political issues and others will refer to the political situation. Some churches will observe the call sent out by "dry" leaders to make the day one of fasting and prayer "that the great evils of legalizing intoxicating drink may not again overwhelm our nation."

The New York Giants will oppose Red Grange's Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds and the Brooklyn Dodgers will encounter the Portsmouth Spartans at Ebbets Field this afternoon in National Football League contests. The Giant game will start at 2:15 and the Dodger engagement at 2:30.

OTTAWA, Nov. 3 -- A civil court action which has rested dormant in the records of Montreal judicial offices for twenty-three years has been revived, and the yellowing records throw an interesting light on the adventures of motoring in 1909.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Mount Vernon High School defeated Mamaroneck High, 21 to 2, today before 4,000 in their W.I.A.A. football game.

Those who attend the nineteenth American Game Conference, which will be held in this city on Nov. 28, 29 and 30, will hear some lively and important discussions of all the topics which are considered paramount among those who are striving to conserve our natural wild life.

CARD parties in aid of various charitable organizations have been arranged for the near future, some of them for the coming week. Needy crippled and delicate children who are cared for by the Walter Scott Free Industrial School and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home in Claverack, N.Y., will benefit by a bridge party to be held on Wednesday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WHAT appears to be the first lock of hair of the advancing auction season will be offered for competitive bidding at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries on the evening of Nov. 10. This priceless memento, from the head of no less a person than Charles Dickens, is now on display, along with other examples of the author's more conscious growth.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 5 -- Norman W. Church's Gallant Sir, fresh, from a successful invasion of Maryland, wound up his 1932 campaign in a proverbial blaze of glory today when he accounted for the richly endowed Latonia Championship.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I returned from Europe yesterday. The most frequent query made there of persons from the United States is "What are the chances for America to come out" of this depression soon?"

THE Exposition, of Indian Tribal Arts, which, has attracted crowds in every city where it has been shown, will have an innovation when it opens the 1933 schedule in Washington, D.C., on Feb. 2, according to an announcement just received. The American Indian artists, whose water-color paintings have received world-wide recognition through the exposition have added mural decoration to their accomplishments and some of these murals "will be shown at the Corcoran in Washington.

PEIPING, Oct. 8 -- Peiping is to be the first city in China to have policewomen. The Bureau of Public Safety is now enlisting 1,000 young women, who will receive three months of intensive training in police work by Chinese who have studied the work of policewomen in New York and other American cities.

FOUNDED six years after Columbus discovered America, the Wiener Sangerknaben -- singing boys of the one-time Austrian court choir -- have just made their bow to the Western World in a concert at Washington last Tuesday, to be followed by a first appearance in New York at the Cohan Theatre on Wednesday evening of this week.

Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, widow of the twenty-third President of the United States, broadcast an appeal over Station WRNY last night at 8 o'clock on behalf of the Republican national and State tickets. Although she was allotted fifteen minutes, she required only nine minutes to deliver her spirited appeal.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 5 -- Mrs. Daniel H. Holmes entertained with a hunt breakfast at Fassifern Farm today for about a hundred persons, including the riders who followed the hounds in today's drag hunt over the Fassifern course. Mrs. Fay Ingalls, M.F.H. of the Bath County Hounds, led the chase.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 5 -- Bucknell scored a 14-to-13 victory over Western Maryland today, the latter's defeat coming from a missed place-kick for an extra point by Shepherd, the visitors' powerful fullback. Shepherd, however, made the most spectacular play of the day, cracking through Bucknell's line and dashing 76 yards.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Bobby Walthour Jr. of New York, and Mickey Rodak of Chicago were tied for first place with Alfred Letourner of France and Gerard Debaets of Belgium at the end of the seventy-second hour of Chicago's twenty-eighth international six-day bicycle race tonight.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- The Union College team defeated Rochester today, 28 to 0, outclassing the home team from start to finish. Union made fourteen first downs to Rochester's six. Mitchell, Dain, Dill, Semerad and Chrysler starred for the invaders in a varied attack.

GENEVA. THE League of Nations, people everywhere say, is at the crossroads. There is Japan, taking the law into her own hands, and threatening to withdraw from the League if it dares try apply the covenant, or even back up its own Lytton commission's declaration that in the interests of peace the new State of Manchukuo must be neither maintained nor recognized.

PEIPING, Oct. 8 -- Szechuan Province, the largest in China, in addition to having a war with Tibet on its western frontier, is now the scene of civil strife after a year of internal peace forced by China's need for presenting a united front in the face of Japanese aggression.

MUNICH. MUNICH'S annual October Festival, the greatest beer-drinking carnival ever devised by man, has just closed as this is written. It lasts three week's and although officially styled an "Oktober Fest," it begins and mostly continues in September.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5 -- Army's football forces carried another of their major objectives today. With the relentless drive of a division going over the top, the Cadet squad thrust seven touchdowns across the Harvard goal line and added four of the extra points to leave Harvard on the short end of a 46-to-0 score.

ILLUSIONS of American inferiority in music are being dispelled. We are rapidly coming of age in this art. It is, therefore the province of a conductor to present not only the classics and his "sure-fire" reper- toire but it is also his privilege to help create and contribute to the future of musical art in the country where he is obtaining a livelihood.

Details of the financial dealings of the General Gas and Electric Corporation since its acquisition by the Associated Gas and Electric System early in 1929 have been mailed to stockholders in a long letter, sent at the suggestion of some stockholders a the New York Stock Exchange.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 5--President Hoover in his final major speech of the campaign here tonight declared that the great issue before the people was the problem of overcoming the industrial and commercial crisis. He contended that he had presented a comprehensive program to overcome the depression, and declared that a Democratic victory would mean a year's delay in bringing about decisive action.

Steven Szumachowski of Mont Pleasant High, Schenectady, recorded his third major cross-country victory in as many starts this season when he led home the field in the twentieth annual Columbia University interscholastic run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

Wall Street remained temperately optimistic yesterday and the share market sought to demonstrate that the recovery which got under way on Friday was no mere flash in the pan. However, the volume of trading was small, even for a Saturday, and there were no wide advances.

To the Dramatic Editor: I read with great interest Mr. Atkinson's article, "Project for a Repertory Theatre," in last Sunday's TIMES. As one who has more than a passing interest in the establishment of such a theatre and who is, as a matter of fact, actually considering ways and means for making its realization possible, I ask the courtesy jot your columns for several comments which I hope will contribute helpfully to the discussion.

SEVERAL entertainments have been arranged supplementary to the forty-sixth annual National Horse Show, to be held from Nov. 9 to 15. The climax will be the annual Horse Show ball on Nov. 14 in the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria, the official headquarters of the show.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 5 (AP) -- In a thrilling encounter marked by sensational runs and many intercepted passes, Washington's Purple and Gold gridiron warriors smashed to an 18-to-13 victory today over Stanford's Indians.

IN literature as in monarchy, there are dynasties. Lord Macaulay lived and died a bachelor, but unto this day his clan still flourishes. His nephew and biographer. Sir George Otto Trevelyan, wrote a classic history of the American Revolution and was awarded the Order of Merit.

A CURIOUS incident in American history and the origin of one of our political idioms were recalled the other day in connection with the Presidential campaign. Some one set the rumor rolling that 35,000 people who had voted for Roosevelt in The Literary Digest poll had written in asking that their ballots be changed in favor of Hoover.
THE successful adjustment of American educational relations demands a sharp deflation of the swollen and unwholesome concern with mere admission to college.

Moscow ANNIVESARIES, for some reason, are dear to the Bolshevist heart. Perhaps it is that the regime is still young, so that each repetition of the day it began existence is a cause for rejoicing, as children rejoice over their birthday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Penn's dream of an unbeaten season was rudely shattered by a hard-driving Pitt eleven at Franklin Field today as the undefeated Panthers turned back the Quakers, 19 to 12, before a crowd of 70,000, the largest gathering to witness a football game in the East this year.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 5 -- Wisconsin loosed a superior passing attack and a smoother running game to win its homecoming game with Illinois, 20 to 12, today.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 5 -- Winding up his campaign with a rapid tour of Suffolk and Nassau Counties, Colonel William J. Donovan retorted tonight to former Governor Smith's criticism of his charges of State extravagance.

CONSIDERED as the very frank reminiscences of an ex-officer of the A.E.F., or as a fictionalized commentary on social and economic developments since the Civil War or as one of those treatises influenced by Spengler.

BERNARD WAGENAAR'S Second symphony will have its premiere at the Thursday evening concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony under Toscanini at Carnegie Hall. The work will also appear on the program Friday afternoon and next Sunday afternoon.
COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Nov. 5 -- Rushing and passing its way over the goal line four times to a 28-to-6 victory, Ursinus College today shattered Drexel's hopes of finishing the season undefeated.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 5 -- At a brilliant reception in the Presidential Palace in the presence of the diplomatic corps and prominent Nicaraguans and foreigners, President Moncada yesterday presented the Presidential Gold Medal of Merit to Brig. Gen. Randolph C. Berkeley of the United States Marine Corps, and other medals to twenty-two members of the United States Navy and Marine Corps.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The recent refurbishing of the exterior of the famous Opera House here has again called attention to the fact that the building contains a splendid, though little-known library. That is to say, it is little known to the outside world, but students of the theatre and the opera have always valued it.

HOLLYWOOD TWO films that have been previewed in Hollywood this week are Ronald Colman's "Cynara," which has reverted to its original title after various experiments, and "The Kid From Spain," the new Eddie Cantor picture.

An American delegation appointed by the Government is now in Geneva, helping to shape plans for the forthcoming World Economic Conference. It is still uncertain exactly when the conference will meet. But the project is one upon which both political parties in the United States are able to agree.

BERLIN ONE may make the observation that even in objective presentations of history, general or literary, the temperament of the historian plays a not unimportant role. Historic currents or figures that are in tune with his character or philosophy will inevitably be treated in greater detail, with more warmth and more colorful imagery.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Few delegates to international conferences have left Japan so well prepared or amid greater manifestations of public interest than Yosuke Matsuoka, who left last night for Geneva, where he will make the Japanese Government's supreme effort to avert a break with the League.

ODD manipulations of numbers hold interest for those in pioneer regions as well as in urban centres. This is evidenced by the following story, published in The Northern Tribune of Kapuskasing, Ontario:

GENEVA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Monetary experts preparing for the world economic conference reached a unanimous agreement today upon the desirability of a return to the gold standard by the nations which have left it.

Growing recognition of the importance of reciprocity in the buying and selling of products by industrial plants has led in recent months to the establishment of special departments by large companies to handle such matters, according to comment yesterday in purchasing agent circles.

A MOVEMENT to place a uniform identification tag on all used cars as a means of building up public confidence in used cars has been launched under the sponsorship of the Ross Roy Service, Inc., of Detroit, used car appraisal authorities, it is announced.

VERBANK, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Craigden Consolation, a black bitch owned and handled by Ralph C. Craig of Albany, today won the open all-age take for cocker spaniels. The open all-age stake for English springer spaniels was captured by the black and white dog Top, owned and handled by Francis J. Squires of Norvood, Mass.

A CERTAIN young man named Alexander, whom historians have preferred to call "the Great," is known in days gone by to have sighed for more worlds to conquer. One afternoon last week another young man, whose name is not Alexander, sat in a room on Madison Avenue and did practically the same thing.

A.W. Robertson of Pittsburgh, chairman of the National Committee on Industrial Rehabilitation, made public yesterday a list of manufacturing companies and other business organizations that had responded to the committee's program for industrial modernization begun late in August.

This week will see the first of the games which have come to be regarded as traditional big encounters. The Yale team will enter the Palmer Stadium for the resumption of the ancient series with Princeton in the Tigers' home town. Then will follow, on successive week-ends, the Tale-Harvard, Army-Notre Dame and Army-Navy contests.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Whatever else may have been accomplished this week while politics has risen to a crescendo, the statements of the most outstanding partisans have left no doubt as to the proposals put forward by the Republicans and Democrats.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- The Princeton football team crushed the Brown and White eleven from Lehigh today. The Tiger warriors, apparently heartened and inspired by their fine showing against the University of Michigan last Saturday, waged an intense and vigilant battle and toppled their game rivals by the score of 53 to 0.
CLINTON, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Displaying a clever passing attack and a hard line drive, Hamilton College defeated Haverlord, 13 to 0, today.

BUYING a new house by the pound -- 25 cents a pound or something like that -- ordering it by mail with a line or two looking like a chemical formula, then dismissing it from the mind and a few days later moving into a new habitation -- complete to the last detail -- that is the possibility which the editors of the magazine Fortune envisage in this book.
MUSEUM OF MODERN ART -- Exhibition of American painting and sculpture (1862-1932). Opened with a private view Monday, to the public Wednesday. Remains until Jan. 31. Reviewed Nov. 1 and on this page.

J.H. Wantling won the opening regular shoot of the Winter season over the traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, winning the High Scratch Cup in a field of thirty-two gunners by breaking 98 out of a possible 100 targets.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- By the thin margin of Captain Steve Grenda's placekick for the extra point, following Tony Matal's touchdown on a blocked punt, Columbia held its place among the leaders of Eastern football today and at the same time gave its coach, Lou Little, his first victory over Navy.

There is a Rue de la Paix where couturiers decide whether sleeves shall be fuller this year, and whether evening gowns shall be trimmed with fur or not. From the rapidity with which the universe changes its cut we might well infer that somewhere there must be a corresponding Rue de la Cosmogonie.

BACK in 1913 Louis D. Brandeis, not yet a member of the Supreme Court, took the information gleaned from the Pujo investigation of the so-called "money trust" and wrote a startling little book, "Other People's Money and How the Bankers Use It."

THIS is the third of a series of seasonal nature rambles, in which Mr. Medsger tells of the things to be seen in the woods, in fields and uplands, by streams and marshes and by the roadside in this part of the Atlantic seaboard.

IN his recent address to the American Public Health Association President Hoover called for a new national offensive upon infectious diseases. If we could reduce them even by one-third, he said, the reduction would repay the country more than a thousandfold its cost.

PANAMA, R.P., Nov. 2--The National Bank of Panama, the stock of which, is owned by the government, was founded in 1904 and has never been examined, a fact to which attention was called by George E. Roberts, former vice president of the National City Bank, in the report of his investigation of the financial affairs of Panama several years ago.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Yale blanked Princeton, 20 -- 0, in their third annual 150-pound varsity football game played in the Bowl today before about 1,500 persons. Acting Captain Jack Curtiss, Weymouth, Max Glick and Red Brown of Yale starred.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 5 -- The Trenton State Teachers College team decisively outplayed the rival Montclair State Teachers College in their annual battle today, to triumph by the score of 25 to 0. It was the third victory in four years for the winners.

Social workers find that when destitute parents say "the kids are too young to understand" they are minimizing the extent to which unemployment forces an enormous mental and emotional burden on their offspring, according to a report to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee made yesterday by its investigators.
NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 5 -- With a thrilling comeback led by Whitey Randour, the Villanova eleven overcame a 9-0 deficit and scored a 20-9 victory over Boston College at Alumni Field today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Federal Judge John Boyd Avis dismissed today an application for an injunction restraining Harold G. Hoffman, Motor Vehicle Commissioner of New Jersey, from barring Pennsylvania trucks which did not have New Jersey licenses.

The inaugural supper dance and entertainment of La Boheme, the recently organized "club of the artists," took place last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Pierre, which had been decorated to represent a scene in the Latin Quarter of Paris. The event served as a benefit for unemployed musicians of Local 802 and for the Actors' Relief Fund.

HIGHLAND MILLS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Barricaded in the basement of the Convent of Jesus and Mary here, an armed maniac killed the janitor. He sought to slay the mother superior and nuns by firing through the floor at them. Finally he was killed after a five-hour gun fight, by State Trooper Harold Quinn, who volunteered, to go into after him.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Between four and five million bottles of champagne used to be shipped from France each year to the United States in the days before the Volstead act, and all that and more stand ready to be packed to be shipped the moment -- perhaps before the moment -- the United States goes wet again.

IN the ever-expanding, ever-improving network of air transportation another notch of speed has been attained. Service to Los Angeles by way of Kansas City has been cut to twenty-four hours. Eleven hours have been lopped from its westbound schedule and fourteen from its eastbound schedule by the "Lindbergh Line," started in July, 1929, as Transcontinental Air Transport and now, through consolidation with Western Air Express, known as Transcontinental and Western Air.

ANY one attending [American] student gatherings today and familiar with student thinking is aware of the greatly increased seriousness of the attitude toward life that they show. They have little faith in the political and economic leadership of the period since the World War, even of today.
Following is a stenographic report of Alfred E. Smith's address at Madison Square Garden last night:

GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- The divergences over the details of the French disarmament plan do not cloud one notable development accompanying it. It is that the atmosphere, as reflected in the very sensitive Geneva barometer, is considerably less stormy than it was a month ago.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 5 -- Georgia Tech's football team dropped a hard-fought game to Tulane today, 20 to 14.
TODAY. 11:30 A.M. -- WJZ -- Sigismund Stojowski, who studied under Ignace Jan Paderewski, will be heard in a piano recital when the Polish pianist's seventy-second birthday is celebrated today.

EMMITSBURG, Md., Nov. 5 -- Washington College held the Mount St. Mary's eleven in a closely contested game today until the last five minutes, when the Mountaineers unleashed an aerial attack combined with powerful thrusts at the line that resulted in two touchdowns and a 19-6 victory.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Choate's football team added one more triumph to the string of victories it has been compiling since the start of the 1931 season by winning in the inaugural of a new rivalry today. It was Choate's eleventh straight triumph and its fifth this year.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 5 -- Coach Jack Hagerty's revamped Georgetown eleven was no match for West Virginia today and the Mountaineers celebrated "West Virginia Day" by scoring a 19-0 victory.
PROVIDENCE, Nov. 5 -- Brown, already victorious over Yale and Harvard this season, remained in the unbeaten ranks today by conquering the Crusaders of Holy Cross, 10 to 7.

Back from the depths of defeat. New York University's football team rejoined the ranks of the triumphant yesterday by defeating Georgia, 13 -- 7, at the Yankee Stadium. It was a superb victory for the Violet brigade, which had to overcome the Southerners' lead.

DESPITE interest in the election, clear, cool weather toward the close of the week shook buying apathy and brought a brisk upturn in retail trade. There was a spurt in apparel sales and cold weather goods generally.

THE evolution of the country's most famous street has been in the weird last quarter century -- the change from Broadway to Midway. Once the parade of fashion tripped by its lighted doors, in the silver-slipper era that is celebrated now only in contemplative history.

To the Dramatic Editor: It was, indeed, quite a shock for the writer to read in last Sunday's edition of THE TIMES of the death of an old friend, Emmett Corrigan, in Hollywood, Cal. Way back in 1887 both Corrigan and I trod the boards with a little "barn-stormer outfit," doing the hinterlands.

In a rapid tour from his home to the Grand Concourse Hotel and thence to the fair grounds at Mineola, where more than 10,000 persons acclaimed him, Mr. Roosevelt voiced complete optimism yesterday that Tuesday's vote would show an overwhelming Democratic sweep.
NEWARK, Nov. 5 -- Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, declared here tonight that the Republican stand on prohibition is the "only practicable program that promises a change."

Today and tomorrow the newspaper observers who have been visiting the various States, taking the political pulse of the voters, will have space for their predictions. These have already begun to appear. The forecasts are written with great care and seriousness, for the task of the journalistic prognosticator is based on an idea exactly opposite to that of the political chairman.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 THE triple event on which Boston prides itself as a pulsing capital of musical comedy and revue draws near. Before these words are printed, Messrs. Shubert will have obligingly transformed Rostand's Cyrano into a singing actor of operetta, with most of the fashionable "fixin's," men's chorus included.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The stock markets were cheerful today. The international issues rose on over-night reports from Wall Street, British funds were much steadier and home industrials continued firm, bright features being Dunlop Rubber, chemicals, Unilever and Cables Wireless.

WHAT must be faced is the alternative whether we can find a system which gives to the peoples of the world -- our own people first of all, because it is our duty to defend them -- the right to work in peace or, if we must, resume that armament rivalry the consequences of which are not only ruin but worse.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Nov. 3 -- Not in years has Oklahoma felt of so little consequence in national affairs as it does this November, when neither political party has paid much more attention to the Sooner State than if the State did not have any votes in the Electoral College.
