TOPEKA, Nov. 3 -- Kansas is going into the final days of one of the most bitter campaigns it ever has known, with Republican leaders exerting every influence they can command to bring prohibition into the foreground as the dominant issue. The extent of their success will determine whether the Kansas vote will go to Governor Roosevelt or to President Hoover.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Sharp improvement marked the first Saturday session opening the Winter schedule on the Paris Bourse. News of Wall Street's activity on Friday fostered firmness, both international and domestic stocks advancing to close at the day's highest levels.

MUNICH -- One of the great German mysteries is the Nazi army. Not the existence of the army itself; that is only too obvious. The uniformed Nazi is everywhere, an all-pervasive and to many Germans not altogether an agreeable sight. But how many of them actually are there?

The future of the cotton goods industry hinges to a great extent on the action taken by mill executives at the meeting in Spartanburg next week, when the policy of discontinuing night work for women and minors is taken up, leading factors agreed yesterday.

MARION, Mass., Nov. 5 -- Loomis School and Tabor Academy played a 6-to-6 tie in football here today. Kennedy made a touchdown for Loomis on a 24-yard run, and Morrison scored for Tabor on a pass from S. Perry.

BERLIN, Oct. 16, 1932. IN a manner of speaking, Berlin has put something over in Baireuth More or less, it has set before the eye and the ear a lifesize picture of what might have been. For if you will he able to hear "Die Meistersinger" conducted by Furtwangler at the Festspielhaus next Summer you can do so at the Staatsoper today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Final pre-election statements of their campaign contributions and expenditures filed by the Republicans today and the Democrats yesterday, show sharp reductions from the huge collections and expenditures reported in the campaign four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- As Tuesday approaches, leaders of both the Democratic and Republican Congressional campaigns officially express the utmost confidence in the outcome of the election, the Democrats prophesying extensive gains, the Republicans asserting that they will hold their own.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 5 -- It appeared this afternoon that the only accomplishment of the tri-partite meat trade conference among Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay would be an agreement designed to break up the packers' conference thereby they fix the proportion of exports each packer may ship to Great Britain.

THE death of William Morris, which, occurred shortly after midnight last Wednesday morning in the card room of the Friars Club, amid surroundings dear to his, heart, removed from the Times Square scene one of the most respected and honored citizens whose pleasure it was to do business in that field called Entertainment.

THE fanfare has sounded. The curtain is up. The social pageant is beginning to swing across the Winter's stage. Balls, dinners, theatre parties are scheduled on the calendars. Behind the, scenes all is in readiness for the social display. Fashion, mistress of the wardrobe, has seen to it that her stock of costumes is worthy of the performance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What is the university student's reaction, if any, to Dr. Flexner's Institute for Advanced Study? I am quite sure the rank and file of students have given it little thought, provided they even know about It. It has, however, received serious discussion in little groups here and there, groups of students who refuse to be complacently indifferent to the problems of higher education in this country.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 5 -- Entertaining the father and son day crowd, Gettysburg drew nearer the Conference championship today by defeating Dickinson by 25 to 7.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Purdue's machinelike offensive overcame Chicago today as predicted, but went further than expected, to smother the Maroons, 37 to 0, in their Western Conference football engagement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Frequent reference has been made in this political campaign to loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to insurance companies and the alleged "protection thus given to million's of policyholders."
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- A kind of Indian Summer, for which the French equivalent is L'Ete de la St. Martin, has produced a series of enchanting days that have helped to give the Autumn racing much, eclat.

VIENNA, Oct. 22 -- At least 30,000 beggars, mostly street singers, it is reckoned here, are trying to live on the charity of the city's population of 1,800,000. Such a nuisance have they become that even the Socialist newspapers, which usually complain when the police take any measures to protect the public from these swarms of mendicants, are now beginning to demand that something be done to rid the streets of them.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General in New York, has followed the recent remarks by Albert Halstead, the retiring American Consul General here, with a letter published in the London Times on the question of visa fees.

AFTER its unhappy dispersion last year, the Yiddish Art Theatre has gathered itself together and made, in this most inhospitable of seasons, an admirable comeback. Embodying the best that the Yiddish stage has to offer by way of drama, it has had a career representable by one of those zigzag curves that chart the course of commodity prices, with peaks of prosperity and troughs of depression.
ROME, Nov. 4 -- Now that the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the march on Rome is a thing of the past, every one's thoughts turn naturally to the next decade.

AMONG the shows opening during the traditionally prosperous Christmas-to-New Year's week are "Lucrece," "Twentieth Century" and "Pardon My English." Miss Cornell's presentation of "Lucrece" has just gone into rehearsal, and the present intention is to give the first out-of-town performance in Buffalo, the star's home town, on Dec. 5.

AMONG the more important tasks faced last Summer by the combined booking office presided over jointly by the Messrs. Jules Murry and Augustus Pitou was the plotting of a route for "Counsellor-at-Law," Elmer Rice's saga of a poor east side boy who becomes a famous lawyer.

THE chief news which this diligent column has turned up for your delectation, on this presumably crisp Sabbath is that David Wark Griffith, known to every one who has seen a motion picture, is coming back to the theatre.

It is understandable that Europe is taking a very real interest in our Presidential election Tuesday. It would, of course, be unbecoming for a foreign power to demonstrate a preference as between the candidates of the two major parties, but, however, the wide publication abroad of forecasts that the Democrats would be successful has caused no little speculation on what difference such a result would make in the foreign policy of the United States.

CERTAINLY this must be a trying literary season for ailurophobes, those unfortunate humans who regard cats as the untouchables of the animal kingdom, for these three books are devoted exclusively to Felis domestica.

THE People's Chorus, under the direction of L. Camilieri, will hold its meetings this season on Monday evenings in the Auditorium of the High School of Commerce, Tuesdays at the auditorium of the Central Y.W.C.A., and Thursdays in the High School of Commerce.

CHICAGO THIS year's annual exhibition of American paintings and sculpture, the Art Institute's forty-fifth, has greater unity than any that has hung in the galleries since the bold, brightly colored surfaces and forms of so-called Modernism supplanted the once everpresent, shimmery surfaces of the Impressionists.

PARIS, Oct. 17, 1932. THE programs of this season's symphonic concerts do not offer much hope for novelties. At least one can be sure of fine performances at the Orchestra Symphonique de Paris under Monteux, some distinguished guest conductors and some interesting new auditions.

The movement among large corporations to write down the values at which they are carrying plants and other fixed assets to current replacement value has gained momentum in the last month as a result of the write-downs announced by the United Fruit Company, the Simms Petroleum Company and several others.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Once more after some five years of comparative tranquillity France's financial situation and budgetary difficulties are beginning to loom large not only on the political but on the national horizon. There are not wanting prophets who foretell that soon there will be a repetition of the disasters of 1926 and naturally enough these wiseacres shake their heads and add: "You see the same men are in power."

EVERY nook and corner of the country will be within range of election bulletins on Tuesday night. Every powerful broadcasting station in the country and many of the less powerful will electrify the heavens with reports that come from the polls from coast to coast.

In The Quarterly Review Miss ELIZABETH HALDANE writes of "Scottish Family Life in the 'Seventies." The HALDANES were brought up in an ultra-religious atmosphere. Yet on Sunday there was one concession to the carnal man. Eggs were substituted for the ritual porridge at breakfast.

LONDON, Oct. 18 A last we have been given a play of genuine passion and significance, and it has come to us from Germany, heralded by the success of Leontine Sagan'a film, "Madchen in Uniform," and produced by her on the stage.

IT is common knowledge that there is little in Russian literature that antedates 1830. It is not generally known, however, that there is a huge mass of oral literature in Russia, some of it eight and nine hundred years old. The byliny, the narrative and heroic poems of North Russia, passed now from generation to generation, are now made available in small part for English-speaking people by the British philological scholar, Mrs. Chadwick.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose more than a quarter cent yesterday under the heaviest general buying since the government raised the crop estimate a month ago. Houses with foreign connections had been active buyers for two days, and with reports that the strike in Lancashire had been settled demand for contracts expanded materially.

Rises in the prices for sugar and coffee futures broke the general decline in commodity prices in local markets last week. All other staples, including cocoa, rubber, hides, silk, silver and wool tops, closed with losses on the week.

THE statisticians at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have put their heads together and brought out an interesting computation of the company's plans for the immediate future. There are seventeen properties just completed or in various stages of production, of which there are six scripts written directly for the screen besides adaptations of five novels and one non-fiction work.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 5 -- The University of Maine won the football championship of the State today by defeating Bowdoin, 7 -- 6, before 8,000 persons on Whittier Field. Maine gained repeatedly on brilliant forward passes and trick plays, while the losers' best weapons were end runs and line plunges.

IT is likely that Fridtjof Nansen figures in many people's memories as an Arctic explorer who did not succeed in getting to the Pole and who many years later, during and after the World War, organized relief work in Russia or Armenia or somewhere.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 5 -- Michigan still rode the top of the Western Conference wave tonight after a hard-fought 7-to-0 victory over Indiana today.

HARTFORD, Nov. 3 -- An amazing degree of interest in the Socialist party, which may indicate a support of the candidates on that ticket unheard of in Connecticut, is providing an additional worry this year for those intimately concerned with the outcome of the election Tuesday.

MEADVILLE, Pa., Nov. 5 -- A pass snared by Captain Waite in the end zone in the third period today gave Allegheny its first touchdown of the season, but it wasn't enough to defeat Oberlin, which triumphed by the margin of a point after touchdown, 7 -- 6.

Expressing confidence that business in general will resume its forward drive, regardless of the outcome of Tuesday's elections, leading business men and trade association executives yesterday suggested that some form of cooperation to consolidate the gains already made be undertaken by the two major parties in the event of Governor Roosevelt's success at the polls.

WHEN Mussolini enjoined the organizing committee of the "Maggio Musicale Flortino" to make this newly constituted triennial event an attraction of world-wide resonance, an ambitious undertaking becomes a matter of course.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A Vanderbilt team, which gave only flashes of its power and speed, defeated a stubborn Maryland team today by a 13-to-0 score.

PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., Nov. 5 -- In a thrilling neck-and-neck finish, Thomas W. Berger's Misque won the Hampton Challenge Cup point-to-point race in the Fall meeting of the Pickering Hunt Club today before a crowd of 5,000 persons.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- Southern California defeated California, 27 to 7, today, but the Bears from Berkeley did something no other football team has been able to do this season.

Dr. Wendell C. Bennett, curator of South American archaeology of the American Museum of Natural History, has received from Venezuela ten cases of prehistoric objects which he recovered from the site of an early culture during his recent visit to that country.

THE film version of Joel "Sayre's" "Rackety Rax," now at the Roxy, presents Greta Nissen in the principal feminine role. Miss Nissen is almost a stranger to the talking screen, but she is back new and seems likely to stay. She was born in Oslo, Norway; went to school in Copenhagen, and afterward studied music, dancing and dramatic art at the Royal Opera House in that city.

A new anti-dumping law, modeled on statutes in operation in Canada and other countries, will be sought by domestic manufacturers at the December session of Congress, it was learned here yesterday. The present law, adopted in 1921 to prevent foreign countries from dumping products into this country at prices below those obtained in the home market, is held by manufacturers to be subject to too many delays to afford the protection which American industry requires.

BALBO HEIGHTS, C.Z., Nov. 2 -- Lieut. Col. Julian L. Schley, who has succeeded Brig. Gen. Harry V. Burgess, as Governor of the Panama Canal, was born in Savannah, Ga., Feb. 23, 1880. He began his education at Lawrenceville School, and later matriculated at Princeton University.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Syracuse defeated Oglethorpe's eleven today, 27 -- 6. Dick Fishel and Joe Moran, veteran Orange backs, set the pace in the attack, while Frank Tindall, guard, gave a brilliant display of defensive football.
PINE BLUFF, Ark., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A new "Young plan" has sprung up here to aid business recovery and depositors of defunct banks.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: In THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of Oct. 16, 1932. Lucy V. King, in a letter, comments upon Charles Willis Thompson's review of a history of the Reconstruction period, written by Dr. Simkins and { Dr. Woody of Chapel Hill.

MEMBERS of the alumnae of St. Catharine's Academy are giving their annual Autumn dance on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of their scholarship fund. One of the features of the evening will be the making of informal crayon sketches of the guests by Robert Eppee, artist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Joint allocation of the Lehigh New England Railroad to the New York Central, the Baltimore Ohio, the Pennsylvania and the Chesapeake Ohio Railroads, as provided in the four-party plan of Eastern consolidation recently approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, was opposed by the New England road in a petition filed with that body today.
MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 5 -- Tufts College defeated Lowell Textile, 18 to 7, today in a home-coming game.

FOR some months, Britain has been disturbed by increasing dissatisfaction among the unemployed. There have been riots in a number of cities and this disorder has culminated in a demonstration similar to the bonus march on Washington.

THERE passed within the week an anniversary marking one of the significant advances in transport achievement by American planes plus American initiative and technical skill. This particular anniversary was, perhaps, of less importance to aeronautics in itself than to the business and industrial world of North America.

BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 3 -- With a special session of its Legislature still on hand and Franklin Roosevelt's victory at the State polls next Tuesday assured beyond concern, Alabama's interest in its own political situation has grown acute, while that in the national scene has become almost academic.

Bear operations on the New York Stock Exchange last month were shown yesterday in official figures of the short interest to have increased 39,053 shares from Oct. 3 to Oct. 31. It was the smallest change for any month since the Exchange began to issue these statistics in May, 1931.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which will launch an intensive campaign on Thursday for $15,000,000 to provide work and direct relief this Winter for thousands of unemployed breadwinners and their needy families, expects to recruit 30,000 men and women who will endeavor to reach 2,000,000 New Yorkers who are employed or have steady incomes.

WITH the eyes at the intellectual world turned upon Spain as a result of the recognition accorded "The Revolt of the Masses," by the great dialectician Jose Ortega y Gasset, fresh interest is being manifested in Spanish literature.

WASHINGTON. THE United States Tariff Commission, which is to investigate, at President Hoover's request, production costs of many articles on the theory that depreciated currencies of foreign countries have made the rates of the tariff act of 1930 ineffective, was created in 1916 as a first step toward the much-sought goal of taking the tariff out of politics.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- The formation of a campus bank, described as a "pedagogical expedient" for students of the economics class in money and banking at Rutgers University, was announced here today. The bank, which will be operated as a lesson in the theory and reality of banking, also will function as an agency for the granting of loans to students.

SILENT tribute to the heroic dead, the re-enactment of stirring scenes in the World War and a memorial service to the War President will carry listeners back to Nov. 11, 1918, when hostilities ceased.
The two great leaders of the Democratic party stood with arms about each other's shoulders in Madison Square Garden last night and delivered the valedictory addresses of the 1932 campaign.

INSTEAD of this being the machine age, or the age of steel, considerable could be said in support of the contention that this is the age of formulas. Babies are brought up on them. Physicians prescribe them. Druggists obey them (we trust).
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- John G. Lonsdale, president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Com-

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Another recent complication in the almost historic Woog estate case will further delay its settlement by the Paris courts. Altogether 105 children and grandchildren of the brothers and sisters of Samuel Woog, who died in Paris twenty-six years ago but whose fortune of several million dollars is held in trust in New York, have been hopefully waiting for a decision regarding their inheritance claims for more than a year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- After seven successive years of defeats, Rutgers won from Lafayette, 7 to 6, in a hard-fought game before 8,000 persons today. Len Tarcher, substitute quarterback, drop-kicked the extra point which meant victory for the Scarlet.

JOSEPH JACQUES CESAIRE JOFFRE, Marshal of France, Papa Joffre to the poilus of the French Army and to the citizens of that country, was, to us, the best known of the allied military leaders when the United States entered the war.
The Mayoralty contest virtually came to an end last night without, in the opinion of political observers, ever having actually started.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Thanks to masterly batting by Don Bradman, Australia's wonder cricketer, New South Wales made a strong reply to Victoria's first innings total when play continued today in the match for the Sheffield Shield.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 5 -- A touchdown by Bill Orr in the third period enabled a rejuvenated Swarthmore team to win its first game of the season today, defeating Johns Hopkins by 6 -- 0.

The attitude of the Republican party toward merchant shipping and seamen is attacked as short-sighted and unfair in an editorial in The Neptune Log, issued yesterday by the Neptune Association, an organization of licensed deck officers and engineers.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- A meeting to impress new voters with the responsibilities of the suffrage has been arranged for tomorrow night in the Bedford Road school here by the political parties and churches of this village. The Rev. Edward I. Campbell suggested last Sunday to members of the Pleasantville Presbyterian Church that "we could at least do as the old Romans did with their initiating ceremony into citizenship."
DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Marquette held the University of Detroit eleven to one touchdown today, but it proved sufficient to win the battle for Detroit, 7 to 0.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some little time back Major Gen. Hugh L. Scott, formerly Chief of Staff of the United States Army and now chairman of the New Jersey State Highway Commission, made a joking remark to the effect that some people might not believe that he had seen a lock of hair from the head of Long Hair that was over twenty-five feet long.

Extensions of international radio telephone networks how definitely planned will embrace all of the continents on the globe and make possible the connection of virtually any two telephones in the world, according to Baneroft Gherardi and Frank B. Jewett, vice presidents of the American.

TEN years ago the Self Govern ment Committee (organized in 1904), national in scope and seeking information in every State of the Union, had upon its lists only about 200 schools where student cooperation and responsibility were practiced.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The first among the distinguished foreign scholars and scientists who, at impressive ceremonies in the grand amphitheatre of the Sorbonne, received honorary doctors' degrees today from the University of Paris was William D. Guthrie, professor emeritus of Columbia and Yale Universities and former president of the New York State Bar Association.

MR. GOODMAN has performed an excellent service in gathering together here some of the most interesting of Franklin's writings, hitherto not available in convenient form. His collected works are bulky, for he was a prodigious writer, and like so many men of his time, this was true of his correspondence.

THE hero of this yarn of adventure, romance and mystery is Wilfred Haven, an attache of the American Embassy at Petrograd. When the revolution breaks in 1917. Haven undertakes to smuggle the Ostrekoff Jewels, worth about $15,000,000, out of Russia and deliver them to Ellsaveta, daughter of the Prince and Princess Ostrekoff.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 5--Nebraska defeated the Iowa eleven today by 14 to 13.
AMSTERDAM At the end of Hendrik van Loon's "Rembrandt and His Time," a book that warms the cockles of your heart with its sustained mellowness, the author quotes an early eighteenth century critic.

Having displayed a "surprising" ability to maintain unit or tonnage volume, the chain store systems will be the first to come back in sales and dollar volume with business recovery, according to views expressed yesterday by Alvin E. Dodd, well-known, merchandising authority.
BROADCASTERS on the eve of election are discussing the voice personalities and radio technique of the orators who have fought the campaign of 1932 on the air.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 5 -- Scoring a touchdown in each of the four periods, Middlesex Academy defeated St. George's School here this afternoon, 24 to 7.

ALL the voting in New York City in the election next Tuesday will be done on voting machines. The uncommonly heavy registration, 311,112 more voters than in 1928, led the Board of Elections, S. Howard Cohen, president, to consider whether the 3,825 machines owned by the city were enough to go around.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- Minnesota's two big offensive cogs, Pug Lund and Jack Manders, kept up a touchdown-per-period pace today to beat down the Southern challenge of Mississippi University, 26 to 0, before 15,000 spectators.

ATHENS, Nov. 5 -- The Court of Appeals here decided today that the extradition treaty recently concluded with the United States was retroactive and that the arrest of Samuel Insull, former chairman of the Middle West Utilities Company in Chicago, was justified.

A group of drawings by E. Barnard Lintott is being shown at the Marie Sterner Gallery. This work is as fine as anything Mr. Lintott has thus far exhibited in America. Landscape is chiefly his subject. The sensitiveness with which trees and the infinite moods of earth are felt and expressed irradiates each of these beautiful evocations.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 -- The soundness of the old adage, "Look out for fillies in the Fall," was demonstrated at Pimlico today when Swivel, daughter of Swift and Sure-Toddle, scored a brilliant victory in the thirteenth running of the $40,000 added Pimlico Futurity, the mile and a sixteenth special for 2-year-old colts and fillies which topped the program of the Maryland Jockey Club.

CHILDREN'S BOOK WEEK will be observed from Nov. 13 to Nov. 19, and that will be a good time to select books for Christmas gifts.... There will be enough books displayed in the leading shops so that it should be easy to find something suitable for every child....
ST. PAUL, Nov. 5 -- The text of President Hoover's address tonight follows:

SHANGHAI, Oct. 8 -- Only five of the thirteen provincial governments which have submitted their annual budgets to Nanking have any prospects of income sufficient to meet the necessary minimum expenditure for the next year. This is shown by a lengthy official table given out at Nanking, which lists the estimated revenue of the thirteen provinces as more than $220,000,000 and the estimated expenditures run above $265,000,000.

BERLIN, Oct., 27 -- The National Socialist party may be hard pressed financially, as seems to be indicated by its having resorted for the first time to posting collectors at street corners with rattling coin boxes. Nevertheless, that has not deterred it from acquiring new and expensive headquarters in the German capital, in addition to its famous "Brown House" in Munich.

The United Hunts meeting, which will end thoroughbred racing in the metropolitan district this year, will be held on Tuesday at Belmont Park. One of the most successful meetings in the history of the association is expected. Secretary Harry A. Buck announces six races, three on the flat and three steeplechases.
Dickinson High School's eleven captured its fifth straight game at Jersey City yesterday, defeating Newark East Side, 13 to 0, before a crowd of 3,000. O'Reilly and Conlan registered the touchdowns.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 5 -- Carrying his campaign into this centre of La Folletteism this noon on his way to St. Paul, President Hoover attacked his rival for the Presidency on a new front.

Rare old velvets, damasks, brocades and embroideries, together with Italian majolica of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries collected by V. L. Benguiat will be auctioned at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on next Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

EUREKA, Nev., Nov. 3 -- Nevada could safely have been placed in the Democratic column for the general election even before the official registration closed on Oct. 18. That formality gives the Democrats a majority of more than 3,000 and removes any uncertainties regarding earlier predictions.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 5 -- Ohio State's football famine ended with a rousing feast today.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 5 -- While Mayor Hague, State Democratic leader, predicted today that Governor Roosevelt would carry New Jersey by a plurality of 200,000, former Governor Stokes, Republican State campaign chairman, in a statement from Trenton said that "New Jersey should be counted in the Republican column election day by a reasonably substantial majority."

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 -- President Justo and about 10,000 other polo fans saw the all-United States Meadow Brook four defeat Hurlingham, 11 to 5, and advance to the final round of the Argentine open championship today.

OTTAWA, Nov. 3 -- Following very closely recommendations of the Royal Commission which completed recently an inquiry into Canada's railroad problems, a bill now before Parliament provides for many important changes in the administration of the State-owned Canadian National system and compels a high degree of cooperation between it and the privately owned Canadian Pacific.

CLUB interiors today suggest up-to-date comfort and smart elegance rather than the heavy ornateness and cloistered luxury of the immediate past. This change is partly due to the appearance of clubs for women, where in lounges and dining rooms new vogues and a more homelike air have been introduced.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- It has been a trying week for the British Government and next week promises no let-up in the attacks leveled against the coalition cabinet from many directions on all the major questions. But the immediate effect of the simultaneous hostilities is not very great, measured against the stability of the government with its huge Tory majority in the House of Commons.

Election of a new Reichstag today is the fifth major contest in Germany in less than eight months. A single and outstanding feature characterizes all of them. It is HITLER. On March 13 occurred the election of a successor to President HINDENBURG. It was forced by HITLER, who would not consent to the prolongation of the President's term of office by a vote in the Reichstag.

Under that title HOMER FOLKS of the State Charities Aid Association discusses the need of an affirmative vote throughout New York State next Tuesday on Proposition Number One, the $30,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief. The phrase recalls the twin remedies for poverty and threatened disorder in the days of the Roman Empire, familiar to all readers of history.
Brilliant performances marked the fifth series of dual meets for the senior high school swimming team championships of the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday.

BERLIN. WITH the election of a new Reichstag upon us, the old question is discussed again whether the Nazis will emerge stronger, or whether, for the first time in many years, they will experience a decline in their vote.
To the Music Editor: I read with great interest Olin Downes's article about the opening concert of the Philharmonic Orchestra, Mr. Toscanini conducting.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 5 -- Penn State closed its home season by defeating Sewanee, 18 to 6, in an intersectional game today.

MISS BROSTER not only knows history: she has the happy faculty of living imaginatively in the time of which she writes and through the bits of detail she introduces, the touches of human nature, the consistency with which her characters are developed, she makes it quite possible for the reader to return with her to that earlier day.

NO one will denounce our play wrigrhts as optimists. Where ever there is sin they valiantly expose it. Wherever there is a handful of New York characters they discover corruption in its more celebrated forms. Rose Franker in "Another Language" has managed to isolate two virtuous and enlightened characters from the inverted oppression of the Hallam clan.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 5 -- Loyola's Wolves, flashing their best form behind a powerful line, put together two marches of 49 and 92 yards to score by 14 -- 0 over the Moccasins of Chattanooga University today.

A Persian medallion carpet of the sixteenth century brought $16,500 yesterday at the last session in the dispersal of English furniture, silver, rugs and tapestries, the property of Mr. and Mrs. John Bordon of Chicago, Seth Ely, James W. Lane, Mrs. John Gellatly and the late Katherine Clemmons Gould, at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Blair Academy was defeated here today by Mercersburg, 14 to 13, in the first meeting of the two schools in football. Powers made the winning point after White, fleet Mercersburg halfback, dashed sixty-five yards for a touchdown that tied the score in the third period.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "My position has always been that we have made a serious mistake as a people in embodying the Eighteenth Amendment in our Constitution and I am for its repeal." So spoke Colonel Donovan on Oct. 20 at Ogdensburg.

Harold Lillja's touchdown in the second period gave George Washington High School's undefeated, untied and unscored-upon football team a 6 to 0 victory over Theodore Roosevelt High, its fifth triumph of the season, before 5,000 yesterday at the George Washington High School Stadium.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Cornell defeated Albright's eleven, 40 -- 14, today. Four intercepted passes paved the way for Cornell scores.

MUDKEN, Manchuria, Oct. 8 -- Accepting the viewpoint that the work of bandit suppression in Manchuria is not so much a military problem as an employment problem, the high command of the Japanese forces there has modified its military policy in favor of an increased emphasis on "negotiation."

LONDON ALTHOUGH this is the tail end of a depressing year instead of the Springtime in a more hopeful one, there is a new spirit abroad in film land. Future prospects have brightened so considerably that already the dark days of the past are almost forgotten.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 24 -- Renato de Almeida, staff editor of the Diario de Noticias and an Under-Secretary of State, believes that the fascination the United States holds for Brazilians does not necessarily originite in poor moving pictures, detective romances or bad alcohol.
GENEVA, Nov. 5 -- Norman H. Davis is going to Rome tomorrow to discuss disarmament generally and naval questions in particular with Premier Mussolini.

TOULOUSE, France, Nov. 5 -- France's desire to work in the closest harmony with the United States for peace and disarmament without asking more than the United States has already indicated she is willing to give was affirmed half a dozen tunes today in the third day of the meeting of the Radical-Socialist party congress and was a triumph for Premier Edouard Herriot.

JUDGING by the sale of boxes and seats that have been purchased for the recital on the night of Nov. 28 at Carnegie Hall in aid of the Women's Trade Union League of New York, the funds of that organization will be augmented greatly.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- Business on the Boerse the last day before the Reichstag elections was extremely quiet. Stocks, however, held their own, without any marked improvements anywhere. Bonds were irregular, with a small turnover. There was some demand for tax redemption certificates, especially those of 1934 and 1938.

When tournament golf is over it is usually time for committee chairmen to get busy and plan for the following year. Within a short time most of the associations that sponsor golf in and around the metropolitan district will be holding their annual business meetings.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Michigan State College's football machine turned back another intersectional threat today, defeating South Dakota, 20 to 6, with seeming ease.

More than 1,000 teachers of commercial subjects attended the annual convention of the Commercial Education Association yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania to hear reports on latest methods in business education. About 95 per cent were residents of the metropolitan district.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, in an interview at his headquarters here yesterday, denied President Hoover's statement at St. Louis that a Democratic victory would mean the blocking by Southern Democrats in Congress of outright prohibition repeal and modification of the Volstead act.

Confident that the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt and John N. Garner would mean beer by January, Norman S. Goldberger, president of the Fidelio Brewery, Inc., 501 First Avenue, announced last night that he had just let to five companies manufacturing brewing and bottling supplies contracts aggregating $100,000.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 5 -- Production from gold mining in Ontario, including a small value of silver but exclusive of gold recovered from nickel-copper mining and other miscellaneous sources, in the first nine months of 1932 was $34,788,569, against $31,415,336 in the same period of the previous year.

Paul Mundy of the Nativity Catholic Club in Philadelphia led a field of nineteen to win the national A.A. U. championship ten-mile run staged at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. His victory was registered in the time of 54:09 1-5, which is approximately three minutes slower than the American record established in 1913.

Cardinal Hayes has sent a letter to the pastors of the Roman Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of New York calling upon them to urge all parents to have their children immunized against diphtheria. The Cardinal is cooperating with Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne in the latter's new drive against diphtheria.

The construction of new ships since the World War has increased in tonnage more than four times faster than the value of world trade and shipping has been seriously affected, according to Robertson F. Gibb, chairman of the Union Castle Steamship Company.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Houses with Eastern connections were on the buying side of wheat again today on the Board of Trade here, but were unable to make much headway in advancing prices because of bearish foreign demand and the presence of many of the pit element on the selling side.

Whatever the result next Tuesday, the campaigning methods of Governor ROOSEVELT will long furnish an interesting study in American politics. Let it be said at once that he has shown himself to be a skillful politician. He has made no bad blunders whether in speech or in personal attitude.

Foreign and domestic municipal bonds continued last week to show the principal redemptions of loans called before maturity dates, both for November and for future months. The total for this month is now $29,053,000, compared with $8,760,000 in October and $21,817,000 in November, 1931, in corresponding weeks.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Quentin Durward, owned and ridden by Gerard Smith of New Canaan, Conn., won the championship honors at the seventh annual running of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds hunter trials, conducted on the John V. Sterling estate, Quaker Ridge Road, Greenwich, this afternoon.

When the voters go to the polls on Tuesday their approval will he Bought for a proposed constitutional amendment which would open up the State's forest preserve for the establishment of "additional recreational facilities" and a proposal for a bond issue of $30,000,000, the proceeds to be used for the relief of unemployment.
ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 5 -- The New Hampshire University freshmen defeated the Phillips Andover Academy eleven, 27 to 13, on Brothers Field today.

Karel Treu left his home at 6,734 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, happy in the assurance that he and his grandparents would celebrate his tenth birthday today with a party, and that his father, a widower, who for the last two weeks has been ill of pneumonia in the French Hospital, would return in time to take part in the festivities.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 -- It is unofficially reported from Asuncion, Paraguay, that the Bolivians have evacuated Fort Murguia and also that Paraguay recently mobilized the Sixth Division of 6,000 reserves to proceed to Chaco and participate in the Paraguayan push against the Bolivians in the Pilcomayo sector.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Further protest of New York realty groups against the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's approval on Tuesday of a $3,957,000 loan to the Hillside Housing Corporation of that city was made here today in charges by the Harlem and Bronx Property Owners Association that by such action "the corporation is demoralizing real estate conditions in New York City and fostering unfair and unwarranted competition by the use of government funds."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., at the New York State Republican Convention, said: "The American people do not understand why they should now be called on to carry the entire financial burden of the World War.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Colgate's Maroon machine bowlel over Mississippi College today in an in- tersectional clash, 32 to 0. Using power plays, the Red Raiders marched on sustained drives to score their five touchdowns.

A "DISTINCT division between automobile offenders who are criminals and those who are not," with separate forms of trial for the willful lawbreaker and the inadvertent offender against motor vehicle statutes, is suggested by Robbins B. Stoeckel, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles of Connecticut.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 5 -- With third and fourth stringers playing at least three-quarters of the game, Tennessee won easily from Mississippi State College today, 31 -- 0.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- Which party will carry New England in the battle of ballots next Tuesday? The best estimate now justified is that of the five New England States here considered, Connecticut being omitted, Vermont and Maine Will occupy places in the Republican column, Rhode Island will go Democratic with a whoop, and the results in Massachusetts and New Hampshire are very doubtful.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., Nov. 5 -- Middlebury's football team defeated Norwich, 24 to 0, on Sabine Field today. Two Middlebury touchdowns followed blocked kicks and the other two came as result of Norwich forward passes being intercepted.

THE second concert in the series of twenty to be presented this Winter by the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra under Sandor Harmati at the Metropolitan Opera House will be given Tuesday evening with Fritz Reiner as guest conductor and with Maria Jeritza and Nelson Eddy as guest soloists.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- A new spirit in dealing with so-called patriotic societies, which are the curse of Japanese public life, was displayed today when, for the first time in his life, Mitsuru Toyama, patriarchal leader of the superpatriots, found his home raided, his son arrested and many documents seized.
NEW YORK. The Baroness de Villiers Terrage, who arrived recently from her home in Paris, has joined her sister, Mrs. Charles de Rham Jr., at 975 Park Avenue.

IN his accustomed ingratiating manner Padraic Colum here presents his ever-widening circle of readers with something over a score of as delightful essays as he has yet turned out with his facile pen. Yet the word "essay" is far too formal to characterize the product of this Irishman's companionable mind and lilting imagination.

PROFESSOR MEANS dedicates his book to "the imperishable memories of William Hickling Prescott and Clements Robert Markham," the one the greatest authority on the conquest of Peru, and the other author of "The Incas of Peru" and a president of the Royal Geographical Society.

Expressing confidence that electirc day would bring a sweeping Democratic victory. Senator Robert H. Wagner, candidate for re-election declared at the Democratic rally in Madison Square Garden last night that the American people had assured themselves of new deals of prohibition and unemployment.

IT is occasionally our good luck in reading books to stumble upon something rare and personal, something which we instantly realize is alone of its kind and different from everything else in literature. That infrequent experience is to be met with in Rilke's "Stories of God."

NEXT Saturday thousands of motorists from the metropolitan district will converge upon Princeton on the occasion of the annual gridiron battle between the Princeton Tiger and the Yale Bulldog. There is little doubt that Palmer Stadium will be filled to capacity.

AFTER a century and a half of existence the peculiarly American institution of the "camp meeting" is going the way of many another feature of a simpler and more rural civilization. Such decisions as the recent one of the trustees of the old Methodist camp grounds at Ossining to transfer their property to the State Organization of their church for other uses tell part of the story.

To the Music Editor: Mr. Francis Rogers's letter in today's TIMES is a good summary of the attitude which refuses to consider Leopold Stokowski's plan for purging opera of its traditional irrelevanices as anything but the devitalization of opera through fallaciously mechanistic division of labor.

The railroad managements are willing to extend the present 10 per cent deduction in the wages of unionized railway employes for six months, it is disclosed in correspondence between the managements and the union heads which led to the calling of the joint meeting to be held in Chicago on Dec. 10.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Dr. A.A. Mitten's The Country Gentleman, a handsome and typical English setter, won best-in-show before one of the most enthusiastic galleries of the season in the Thirteenth Regiment Armory tonight. The Country Gentleman was best among 415 dogs benched in the eleventh annual exhibition of the Paterson Kennel Club.

Demand from domestic and foreign spinners absorbed new crop offerings of cotton at well maintained prices last week on the New York Cotton Exchange here, with the result that the cotton market showed much greater strength than did grains and other commodities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- In a pre-election statement summarizing the prohibition situation, F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, said today that the repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment rested entirely with members of Congress and that the next President of the United States can take "no official action with respect to repeal or modification."

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 6.--In the same Hudson Valley towns where he began his political career twenty-two years ago, Governor Roosevelt will make a final appeal tomorrow to the voters of his home district and of the nation.

ROME, Nov. 6. -- Prison sentences up to five years for all civil crimes, including political offenses, were wiped out by Premier Mussolini's amnesty decree, published today. The amnesty also provides considerable reductions in heavier penalties.

Theodore Roosevelt Jr. and Grantland Rice have compiled "Taps: Famous Poems of the World War," which Doubleday, Doran will publish next Wednesday. The collection includes not only the great popular favorites such as "In Flanders Fields," "I Have a Rendezvous With Death" and "Christ in Flanders," but some less known pieces that had been lost in newspaper and magazine files.

A proposal to have war declared illegal by an enactment of international law has been presented to President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Colcord, New York publicist, one of the signers. The plan is endorsed by churchmen, attorneys, statesmen and citizens representative of all professions.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 6.-- Colonel and Mrs. Arthur Kelly Evans were hosts at a luncheon at Malvern Hall today for Baron and Baroness Rosenkrantz, Mrs. Alexander Willams Biddle, Miss Mabel Choate, Joseph Brown Whitehead, C.P. (Conkey) Whitehead and Richard Stevens.
DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 6. -- There will be no peace and quiet on the Southwest Conference football front on Armistice Day.

As the campaign ends, the question of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is merely a dispute as to method between the major parties which will have the votes in Congress to submit the proposal to the States. This is one of the most remarkable aspects of the political situation.
To the Editor of The New York Times: SANTA MONICA, Cal., Nov. 6. -- Well, I am like Mr. Coolidge. You ain't going to get me taking sides in this election. I am going to write about aviation.

Voters in various States will be asked to pass tomorrow upon proposals to issue State and municipal bonds in the amount of $158,013,301, compared with $634,766,415 at the 1928 Presidential election. Of the total $56,600,000 is for relief. Six States will ask the electorate to approve issues aggregating $126,700,000, of which $50,000,000 is for emergency relief sand $40,000,000 for funding of existing indebtedness, so that only $56,700,000 will represent financing for public improvements.

Twenty thousand booing cheering, singing Communists filled Madison Square Garden last night at the final election rally of the party, and an additional 3,000, unmindful of the rain, assembled around amplifiers on the Forty-ninth Street side of the auditorium, echoing the boos, the cheers and the songs.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The cornerstone for the "Cathedral of the Air," which is being erected at the entrance to the Naval Air Station here as a memorial to the pioneers of aviation, was dedicated today by Charles Francis Adams, Secretary of the Navy, in ceremonies attended by representatives of the American Legion from five States.

A goal by Lieutenant Benjamin Jacobs late in the overtime period enabled the First Division polo team to conquer the Freebooters, 8-7, before 1,000 spectators at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, yesterday. The game was closely contested throughout, with the count being deadlocked at four different times after the Freebooters took the lead in the opening period.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP). -- The Rev. Dr. Chester B. Emerson, one of Detroit's most prominent ministers, read a letter of resignation to his congregation today in the North Woodward Congregational Church and announced he would leave before the end of the year to take charge of Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Cleveland.

Red Grange gave flashes of the brillance of his college football days by leading his Chicago Bears to a 28-8 victory over the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. While a crowd of 12,000 looked on, the erstwhile Gafloping Ghost, playing for almost an entire half, crossed the New York eleven's goal line three times and in addition contributed several exciting dashes.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 6. -- Playing an aerial game that completely baffled its opponent, the St. Thomas College football team defeated Notre Dame's B eleven by 24 to 6 before a crowd of 8,000 today at Dickson City.

WASHINGEON, Nov. 6. -- Commercial bankruptcies are due chiefly to inefficient management and unwise use and extension of credit according to report on the subject made public today by the Commerce Department after a detailed analysis of 570 cases of bankruptcy.

Donations totaling $484,000 were received during the first three weeks of the campaign to complete a $3,928,000 budget for the upkeep of the ninety-one institutions affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, it was announced yesterday by Paul Felix Warburg and Ira M. Younker, joint chairmen of the appeal.
A new high record for American Socialism in the balloting tomorrow was predicted yesterday by Morris Hillquit as national chairman of the Socialist party.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 6. -- It has been many years since South America has shown an interest in a United States Presidential election comparable to that with which it has been watching the Hoover-Roosevelt campaign.

GENEVA, Nov. 6. -- Informed circles here attach considerable importance to the talks with Premier Mussolini for which Norman H. Davis left Geneva today in company with Italy's, new Ambassador to Washington, Augusto Rosso.

C.J. Winninger broke 94 out of a possible 100 targets to capture the high scratch trophy at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He also annexed the doubles scratch cup, returning a card of 44 out of a possible 50 targets. The high handicap cup went to B.L. Duke after a shoot-off.

The Fifth Avenue Association announced yesterday its complete support of the pending bus franchise applications through which the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, New York Railways Corporation and New York City Omnibus Corporation hope to establish a unified bus system in Manhattan.
Against a background of silver-gray sky, the eleventh annual Massing of the Colors parade moved up Fifth Avenue yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- The enthusiastic welcome accorded to the government's latest and final conversion loan, followed by its immediate and big success, provided this week a tonic for financial markets generally. The resultant placing of British Government credit on a basis of virtually 3 per cent necessitates further adjustment of investment values.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Nov. 8.--Paul D. Cravath was host this afternoon at a musicale at Still House, his country residence here, for the benefit of the unemployment relief fund of Locust Valley. Mrs. Skeffington Norton of Jericho was in charge of the invitation list, which included about 150 music lovers of the North Shore community.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Bolivia's woman spokesman argued her adopted country's cause in the Chaco jungle war with Paraguay to the women of her native land today over the tea tables of the National Woman's Party.

Charges that Governor Roosevelt would be Tammany-controlled if elected President, were vigorously denied last night by Assemblyman Langdon W. Post of the Tenth Manhattan district, speaking at a meeting of the Square Table Club, non-partisan current affairs group, at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- New understanding of how ultra-violet light from the sun affects radio transmission has been gained from long study of the observations made during the eclipse of Aug. 31.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Another Red October dawns tomorrow for Soviet Russia. Tonight the legions of the proletariat were in readiness to march again to commemorate a further milestone in the history of the world's only workers' and peasants' State -- the fifteenth anniversary of the October revolution, which placed all Russia in the hands of the Bolsheviki.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Conditions are not all favorable for higher prices in the immediate future for live stock and meats, according to observers here. Supplies of dressed beef, fresh pork, lambs and mutton are liberal and above consumptive requirements, especially of dressed beef.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6. -- Nearly 11,000 persons thronged the Civic auditorium here today to hear Theodore Dreiser and Lincoln Steffens in addresses urging the release of Thomas J. Mooney from San Quentin prison. The crowd, good-natured and orderly on the whole, booed the mention of the name of Governor James Rolph Jr., and his adviser in the last Mooney pardon hearing, former Judge Matt I. Sullivan.

If the economic situation should result in the conscription of our intelligence for social uses so that the same kind of scientific and business brain that solved the problem of production could solve also the problem of distribution, there would be no economic problem in the next hundred years, according to the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Harvey Stephens, instead of Jackson Halliday, will replace Humphrey Bogart in "I Loved You Wednesday" at the Sam H. Harris Theatre tonight. Henry Lase also will join the cast at this time. Mr. Stephens was seen earlier this season in "Best Years." Last Winter and Spring he appeared in "The Animal Kingdom."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- A post-election, stock-taking conference, sponsored jointly by the American Academy of Political and Social Science and the Taylor Society, will bring together business and industrial leaders, ministers and educational authorities at Witherspoon Hall here Friday and Saturday.

The annual sale of articles made by patients in the occupational therapy departments of several hospitals in this city, to be held under the auspices of the Junior League of New York, will open next Monday at the league's clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, and continue until Nov. 17.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6. -- Production of steel ingots last week was estimated at about 19 per cent of plant capacity, after four weeks estimated at about 20 per cent. No marked decrease in demand for any one product was reported, but for two or three weeks sellers have observed a widespread disposition among buyers to defer action until after the election.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Henry Morgenthau, former Ambassador to Turkey, declared tonight in an address delivered here before the Central Democratic Clubs of Essex County, in Krueger Auditorium, that the Democrats desire through the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt as President "to stop business from being the football of speculation and politics."
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- A speedy St. Bonaventure eleven gained a 7-6 verdict over Canisius College today in a bitterly contested game.

A final appeal for support by the voters tomorrow of the $30,000,000 bond issue authorized by the Legislature for the financing by the State of unemployment relief this Winter was made yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

While there were reports from some sections of the country of improved business on women's coats, due to colder weather, the wholesale ready-to-wear markets last week disclosed the usual between-season appearance. Requests were received on reorder numbers and on specially priced lines, and there was some activity on formal dresses, but otherwise, business was quiet with the manufacturers.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Nov. 6. -- In an exhibition match for charity at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today, two of the country's leading amateur golfers eclipsed a pair of outstanding professionals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent statements in the newspapers are givirg many people the impression that foreign missions are sectarian and that the mission boards need to be advised to seek a "unified Christianity."

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Chaos was the word used today to describe the Chicago tax situation by J.L. Jacobs, Cook County special assessor. He warned that unless drastic tax reductions were effected not only here but elsewhere the same situation likely would spread over the nation, with complete disruption of government resulting.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The Princeton football squad will begin preparation tomorrow for its final encounter with Yale on Saturday.

RANDOLPH, Mass., Nov. 6.--Frederick Lothrop Ames Jr., wealthy sportsman, and two passengers were killed here today when Mr. Ames's cabin monoplane fell into a tail spin after performing a series of acrobatics and crashed from a height of 2,500 feet into a field.

Realization of a better social order will come through recognition of the example of Christ rather than through adoption of any political philosophy or platform, the Rev. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson, president of the Princeton Theological Seminary, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the North Presbyterian Church, 155th Street and Broadway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6.--Prices of wheat and all other grains except corn declined last week to the lowest levels known. Corn was not far from the bottom mark of 1926, when it sold at 19 1/2 cents a bushel. It would not surprise the trade to see that price reached unless the grain situation is materially changed.

The annual session of the New York State Conference on Social Work will be held in Syracuse Nov. 15 to 18, it was announced yesterday by Dudley D. Sicher, its president. Social workers in public and private agencies, concerned alike with the health and the relief needs of citizens throughout the State, will attend.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Spurred by the launching of the French superliner Normandie, London bankers have now offered to lend enough money to the Cunard Line for rushing the completion of two monster ships designed to regain the Blue Ribbon of the Atlantic for Great Britain.

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 6. -- After spending a restful night in a private room of a hospital, whither he was transferred last night after the Court of Appeal had dismissed his plea for release, Samuel Insull today entertained many visitors, to whom he vivaciously told anecdotes.

Much Restraint Exhibited. It has been a campaign in which some regrettable things have been said, but not really very many or very serious. On the other hand, there have been many things to be grateful for:

Louis Bush of Massachusetts State increased his lead in the race for Eastern individual football scoring honors by making two touchdowns against R.P.I. on Saturday. He passed the century mark, his total now being 108 points. Bush shook loose from his closest pursuer of the season, Cliff Montgomery of Columbia, who was held scoreless for the second successive week.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 6. -- Paraguayan troops in the Chaco region achieved their greatest victory since the fall of Forts Boqueron and Arce at noon today when they captured the Bolivian Fort Platanillos after a sharp three-hour battle.

Eva Le Gallienne last night presented the young German dancer, Tina Flada, in her American debut recital at the Civic Repertory Theatre, and a large number of professional people in the various branches of the theatre turned out for the occasion, helping to make the audience a decidedly friendly one.

Before an audience of 8,000 in the Bronx Coliseum yesterday afternoon and again in the evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where another 3,000 filled the auditorium, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, Louis Waldman, Gubernatorial nominee, Morris Hillquit, who is running for Mayor, and Charles Solomon, candidate for United States Senator, made final pleas for the Socialist cause.
A plurality of 981,303 in New York City for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, is indicated by the Tammany estimate, it was learned yesterday.

November's first week-end further reduced the ranks of the unbeaten in football and provided surprises even in cases where favorites emerged on top, for in some instances the margins of victory were either so great or so small that the results took on the aspect of upsets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt, in his speech in Baltimore, in speaking of the Republican party's control of the government, casually remarked that it also had control of the Supreme Court. This remark was no reflection whatever on the Supreme Court, but referred merely to the historical fact that the Republican party has always sought to hold control of the Supreme Court.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL, SPECIAL EN ROUTE TO PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 6. -- Carrying his campaign across the Continental Divide tonight, President Hoover left behind him at Denver as the climax of a day of non-political speaking a "guarantee" by the Federal Government that during the coming Winter "no one shall be hungry or cold."

The Class C squash tennis tournament in the New Jersey group of the Metropolitan League opened yesterday with victories by the Montclair Athletic Club and the Essex Club. Montclair defeated the Short Hills Club combination, 6 to 1, while Essex was vanquishing the Elizabeth Town and Country Club, 4 to 3.

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace is cooperating with the League of Nations Association and other organizations in arranging for fifty disarmament meetings, to be held in as many different cities on Friday, Armistice Day, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment, announced yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Publication today of Italy's long-awaited amnesty, which Premier Mussolini described as "the most liberal of all Italian amnesties," revealed that it applies to thousands of prisoners other than political offenders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have been hearing in many quarters on Long Island reports and innuendoes regarding Congressman Robert L. Bacon's stand on the question of prohibition. Naturally, it is easy for us to understand that reports to the effect that Mr. Bacon is "dry" are merely "political" stories invented to hurt his candidacy, unfairly disseminated.

On the ground that he must be left free to continue his fight for rapid-transit unity on terms fair to the city, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission, has declined to act as counsel for groups of Manhattan Railway and Interborough stockholders seeking to upset the pending receiverships of the two companies in the Federal courts.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, ridiculed yesterday the assertion by Everett Sanders, Republican national chairman, that President Hoover would be re-elected by a safe electoral majority on the basis of recent polls. Reiterating his contention that Governor Roosevelt would carry all forty-eight States.
More than usual activity is in prospect in local billiard circles this week, with stars of the cue world scheduled to play at three academies.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 6. -- A combination of conditions kept the cotton market here comparatively dull last week. Most important of these was pre-election uncertainty, which discouraged operations on either side of the account. A second deterrent to speculative activity was the approach of the government's next crop report.

Although they had closed their campaigns formally on Saturday night, both Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, and United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, running for re-election, spoke over the radio and addressed a meeting of the Young Men's Hebrew Association at Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue last evening.

Confident of an 800,000 plurality, 200,000 higher than the generally conceded margin, Surrogate John P. O'Brien toured two boroughs yesterday to meet voters in what he described as "joyful ratification meetings" rather than to appeal for their support on election day.

Somewhere in Chesapeake Bay the fifty-six-foot schooner Aileen Booth was en route to Baltimore last night, her only crew a New York couple who plan to make her their home. The couple are Mr. and Mrs. Ellery Tuck, who left City Island a week ago yesterday.
With Republican leaders claiming victory by a narrow margin for President Hoover, the final appeal to the voters to make that possible will be made throughout the nation tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Prices of corn here are on an export level, with sales by Chicago cash handlers last week estimated at 1,000,000 bushels. Cable messages from Germany say that country would like to buy 20,000,000 bushels of American corn this season for shipment to Hamburg.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith and President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University appealed last night for funds to carry on local relief work this Winter in a radio program sponsored by the Welfare and Relief Mobilization of 1932 of which Newton D. Baker is chairman.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 6. -- All grains weakened last week from the previous week's low levels. Prices rallied slightly on Saturday, but closed lower than on the previous Saturday. Wheat was hardest hit and declined from 6.25 pesos a quintal to 5.85 pesos, equivalent to from 43 to 41 cents a bushel.

ATLANTA, Nov. 6. -- Tennessee and Vanderbilt, a pair of strong, resourceful and unbeaten elevens, resume their traditional rivalry at Nashville Saturday in a game that may decide the Southern Conference football championship.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- While foreign credits held by the Bank of France, as shown by Thursday's statement, remained virtually unchanged, the bank's gold reserve increased for the week 233,000,000 francs, reaching a new high figure. This increase was chiefly due to reappearance, in reserves, of gold previously earmarked for fareign account at the bank.

The first bridge party of a series for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be held on the afternoon of Nov. 22 at the home of Mrs. John D. Ryan, 3 East Seventy-eighth Street. Subsequent parties will be held at the homes of Mrs. Erasmus C. Lindley, Mrs. Ogden H. Hammond and Mrs. Arthur M. Anderson.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 6 (AP). -- Senator Bronson Cutting, Progressive-Republican, of New Mexico, tonight renewed an appeal to "public-minded citizens to vote for Franklin Roosevelt Nov. 8."

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Uncertainty created by increased political activity in preparing for the Presidential election, as well as the outcome, brought last week a nervous feeling among business and manufacturing interests which tended to reduce purchases of raw materials and finished products in many lines.

Steel production increased last week from 19 1/2 per cent to 21 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. This is the first time since June that the rate has exceeded 20 per cent. A rise to 22 per cent this week is indicated if schedules are maintained, Steel says.

DENVER, Nov. 6. -- The Rocky Mountain Conference season has three weeks to run and Utah University has two more games to play, but Ike Armstrong's eleven appears assured of its fifth championship in as many years.

Pennsylvania has been so true to the tariff that fell from heaven, and so replete with Republicans, that it is hard even for Democrats to believe that The Literary Digest poll, giving the State to Governor ROOSEVELT, isn't an hallucination. One wouldn't scan with more incredulity a report that the Home Market Club had flopped for free trade.

ATHENS, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Samuel Insull said today he was pleased with his new lodgings in the Aretaieon Hospital. He said he slept well last night, had a bath and breakfast and sat reading in his room until his chief counsel, Cristos Ladas, arrived.

Cornell University might fitly date from the birthday of EZRA CORNELL 125 years ago, but such a university as Cornell has come to be might not have come into existence but for ANDREW D. WHITE, born a hundred years ago today. He was one of America's foremost citizens.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 6. -- William Reynolds Edrington, former Fort Worth banker, who had made his home in New York since 1919 while associated with several banking and brokerage firms, died of pneumonia at a hospital here this morning after an illness of several months. He had been in Fort Worth since February, when his health failed, and entered a hospital on Wednesday. His age was 60.

Final details for the campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee to raise $15,000,000 to aid the city's jobless were being worked out yesterday. H.B. Lamy Jr., executive chairman of the committee's commerce and industry division, announced the formation of ninety major trade groups through which employers and employes of the city's business enterprises will participate in the drive.

Dr. OTTO SCHMIDT, director of the Leningrad Arctic Institute, must be credited with a polar record. With the ice-breaker Siberiskov, carrying a crew of sixty-five, including a staff of scientists, he has pushed his way through ice fields and uncharted seas from Archangel to Bering Strait in one Summer.

Although the number of hunting licenses issued in this State this year has not yet been announced, all reports nimrods in the field than in many years. Gains protectors report that fields are filled with hunters.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP). -- Warren Van Dyke, Democratic State chairman, today issued a statement announcing that Congressional investigators have been sent into the State's anthracite mining regions "to investigate election, irregularities."

In the midst of all the general talk about an unusual "protest vote" this year it is desirable to fix on something definite and concrete. Here in Manhattan and the Bronx the voters for judges of the Supreme Court in the First District have it fairly thrust upon them.

Funeral services for William Morris, theatrical booking agent and president and founder of the Jewish Theatrical Guild, were held yesterday afternoon in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street. Two thousand persons were present. Burial took place in Mount Hope Cemetery, Westchester County.
Details of recent leasing deals were shown in contracts recorded over the week-end.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, 120th Street and Broadway, told the congregation at the James Memorial Chapel yesterday morning that the "mood of a great many people today is similar to that of the Prodigal Son who, returning to his father, said: Make me as one of thy hired servants.'"

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- A brilliant rally late in the second half which netted two goals enabled an aggressive New York Field Hockey Association eleven to gain a 3-all tie with the Stuyvesant Field Hockey Association team in an inter-association match at Bowman Park today.

"They may say that O'BRIEN is vague on the budget, but the answer is going to come later when "I am in office and put into effect "a real scheme to reduce the budget "and help property owners." -- Address at a meeting of the Queens County Democratic Speakers' Bureau, Oct. 24.

Police Sergeant Joseph Volk, with a pistol in one hand, attempted a short-cut yesterday by vaulting over a railing including an advertising sign, shoulder high, in pursuit of a hold-up man who had passed through the turnstile and disappeared down the stairs to the express platform of the Lexington Avenue subway station at 125th Street.

The text of Justice Kernochan's address is on Page 2. The story of how a $50 campaign contribution was returned to him by Tammany Hall as "too cheap," with the statement that other judges were giving from $500 to $1,000, was told last night by Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions in a radio address.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- Yale football coaches tonight expressed the belief that the Elis face two most exacting football engagements the next two Saturdays with Princeton and Harvard in the last two games on the schedule.
PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 6 (AP). -- Peaceful Palo Alto stirred today with the knowledge it was to become a key nerve centre of the nation with the arrival of the President of the United States Tuesday.

Declaring that "anything can happen in politics" and warning the voters not to be "surprised at a political miracle," Lewis H. Pounds, Republican candidate for Mayor, issued a pre-election statement yesterday in which he indicted the present city administration for its "official neglect and misrule."

When Parliaments break down in the world today it is Napoleon's dream that is at work against them, Hilaire Belloc, English historian, poet and publicist, writes in his new history, "Napoleon," just published by Lippincott. The true aim of Napoleon, he says, was not war and glory but the political and cultural reuniting of Europe, and in some degree he succeeded, although out-wardly and ostensibly he failed.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- The Economist index number of wholesale prices in sterling values, based on 1927 as 100, is placed as of Nov. 2 at 62, comparing with 62.3 a fortnight before, 65.5 a year ago and 60.4 on the 18th of last September, just before Great Britain's suspension of gold payments.

Foreign-language publications in the United States are about evenly split in their support of President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt, a survey of the 1,078 such publications in the country completed by the Foreign Language Information Service shows.

Monroe Percy Bloch, counsel of the election frauds prevention bureau of the Hoover engineers' committee of the Republican State Committee, charged yesterday that it had evidence of 7,500 cases of illegal election registrations in Manhattan, in a statement accusing the State Attorney General of deliberate and unwarranted delay in prosecuting such cases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Once again tomorrow an extra delegation of police will be stationed at the Capitol to forestall demonstrations in connection with the Scottsboro case before the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- United States foreign trade with the Far East was valued at $43,204,000 during September, or 37 per cent below that of the same month last year when the combined value of imports and exports reached $76,230,000, according to a review by Janet H. Nunn, made public today by the Commerce Department.

CORK, Irish Free State, Nov. 6--A mob armed with sticks and stones was beaten off by two police charges today, while former President William T. Cosgrave was a speech denouncing the de Valera government. The crowd rushed the doors of a cinema theatre where Mr. Cosgrave was speaking, but the police quickly formed a cordon around the building and broke up the attack with clubs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. --The result of the election probably will have en important bearing on government financing operations between Dec. 15 and March 4.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Genevieve Paddleford, out on parole from prison, is again sought by authorities, who say she is wanted in connection with swindling a hotel and an automobile firm.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Leo Treadwell Kissam is giving a luncheon today at the Barclay.

The Portsmouth Spartans paid their annual visit to Ebbets Field yesterday and after a shaky first period which saw them trailing the Dodgers, put over a touchdown to even the count in the second quarter and then pressed ahead in the last fifteen minutes to add a field goal and another touchdown and so gain a 17-7 victory.

LYONS, France, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Deputy Giarratana of Italy was the object of an anti-Fascist demonstration here today. About a hundred of his compatriots hooted at him, and when the police restored order they made five arrests.

As the campaign of 1932 reaches its end, it is possible to say that the time-honored tradition of trade set back by a Presidential contest has not been observed. Neither industrial nor financial markets present a brilliant picture, compared with years before 1929; the effect of electoral uncertainty, however, must be measured by different comparison.

Low-cost housing developments such as that in the Bronx on which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation granted a $4,000,000 loan last week will attract private investment funds because of the encouragement given to such projects by the Federal grant, writes Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

More than thirty States will ship Thanksgiving turkeys to New York City, with four of the New England States contributing to the supply for the first time in many years, it was said yesterday by P.Q. Foy, market expert and food economist.

Appeals to the voter to do his duty conscientiously at the polls tomorrow were made from many pulpits throughout New York City yesterday. In a few instances ministers advised against injecting religion into politics. One group concentrated an attack on local corruption.
DENVER, Nov. 6. -- The text of President Hoover's speech here tonight was as follows:

After having won two major games on consecutive Saturdays, the Columbia football team will turn its attention today toward another opponent of high calibre, Brown, which comes to Baker Field on Saturday.
