BERLIN, Monday, Nov. 7 (AP). -- A preliminary computation of the complete vote in yesterday's Reichstag election showed the following party standing compared with the standing after the election of last July 31:

Preliminary reports on the results of a nation-wide survey of the stand of Congressoional candidates on the question of increasing the participation of the United States in world affairs show that more than three-quarters of the candidates whose replies have so far been compiled are in favor of an international agreement to call the nations of the world into immediate conference should the Kellogg pact be threatened.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- As Representative Loring M. Black of New York, acting as a special subcommittee for the House Committee on Election Expenditures, prepared to open a hearing here tomorrow, plans were announced by Roosevelt leaders tonight for insuring an "honest count" in this stronghold of Republicanism on Tuesday.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL, Nov. 6 (AP). -- Last night in St. Paul, after he had concluded his prepared address, President Hoover continued speaking for several minutes. His voice was low, and at the press tables, almost directly under him, where the amplifying system did not reach, few could follow his words.

The Rev. Dr. George Maychin Stockdale, whose recent symposium on pacifism at the St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 126th Street, was conducted despite an order from the board of trustees forbidding the meeting, continued his activities on behalf of the War Resistance League yesterday.

Alexandra Carlisle, who returned to the Broadway stage this season after an absence of almost ten years, has received the award of the Gold Medal for Good Diction on the Stage given by the American Academy of Arts and Letters, of which Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University is president.
The United Hunts Autumn meeting, which will be held tomorrow, at Belmont Park, has attracted a large list of entries and all of the six races that compose the program will be well filled.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6. -- While the race for 1932 Pacific Coast Conference honors is still a two-team affair, the standing of the circuit presents a pair of outstanding teams of football history in the second division.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT HOOVER'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Nov. 6. -- President Hoover is speeding to his California home for election day convinced that there has been a big turn in the tide in the West, and a shift throughout the country, because of his presentation of campaign issues in recent weeks.

Graham M. Brush, president of Seatrain Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that the Interstate Commerce Commission had granted his application for a hearing to determine the status of the Seatrain service, and that testimony Will be taken, starting Thursday in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP). -- A revised compilation of labor laws for women, issued today by the Woman's Bureau, shows there ate still some jobs a woman can't tackle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Rotogravure Section of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 30 appeared a picture with the caption, "The President meets a crowd of farmers and miners in West Virginia; Mr. Hoover speaking from a platform at the railway station at Huntington."
The text of Justice Kernochan's radio speech endorsing the independent Supreme Court candidates and attacking Tammany Hall for its attitude toward members of the bench follows:

Political statements from President Hoover, Governor Roosevelt, Colonel Donovan and Lieut. Gov. Lehman are to be heard at the Embassy Newsreel Theatre this week. Owen D. Young, in his first appearance as a spokesman for the Democratic national ticket, is another feature.

A group of 115,000 men and women, hitherto "forgotten" by every Presidential candidate, will constitute the main reliance of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, for getting the full Democratic vote to the polls at tomorrow's election and the effectiveness of their work is expected to be a big factor in determining the result.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have observed several letters recently in your newspaper from college professors who apparently are annoyed with me for having been unwilling to pay for telegrams they sent to me in reply to a request to specify what rates in the tariff act of 1930 were too high.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Cash interests were good buyers of oats futures last week on breaks and took advantage of bulges to do a little hedging. Speculative interest is light, although there are 25,106,000 bushels of open contracts for future delivery, compared with 25,199,000 bushels a week ago.

Reports received yesterday from Republican campaign workers throughout the State indicate victory for Colonel William J. Donovan, candidate for Governor, by a "safe majority," according to Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Win With Donovan and Davison Committee.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- The Western Conference football championship is within the grasp of Michigan.

BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 6 (AP). -- His absentee ballot in Tuesday's election cast for a candidate whose identity he did not disclose, Senator Borah was en route tonight to Washington, where he has called a hearing for Nov. 10 on the St. Lawrence treaty with Canada.

Because of precautions taken beforehand to meet conceivable emergencies, the balloting which, residents of New York will do tomorrow by means of the 4,143 voting machines installed in the city is expected by the Board of Elections, despite indications of an unusually heavy vote, to proceed more smoothly this year than ever before.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 6 (AP). -- The American steamer Caracas radioed the Coast Guard station here tonight she had in tow the steamer Tachira, whose engines broke down earlier today.

Two hunters were killed in their homes in the city yesterday, one in Howard Beach, Queens, when a 3-year-old boy pulled the trigger of a loaded shotgun as its owner was stowing it away in a closet, and the other in West Brighton, S.I., when he was accidentally shot by a friend demonstrating a pistol.

The key to the prohibition question rests with the State of New Jersey, Representative Percy H. Stewart, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from New Jersey, declared yesterday in a speech in which he said that upon his election depends modification of the Volstead act during the coming session of Congress.

As the football season for most of the big prep school elevens enters the final week, those of Choate, Taft and Hill are among the teams which have only one more obstacle each to clear in their drives for undefeated records.

PENN and Holy Cross went down in the recent firing, leaving Brown, Colgate and Columbia of the Eastern teams up there with clean slates at this point in the Fall campaign. Pitt, Temple and little Wagner College have been tied but not defeated. Wagner doesn't claim to be on a par with the big fellows and Temple's record shows two ties, one with the Haskell Indians, who were all but massacred by Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Revision of veterans' relief legislation during the next session of Congress to provide a new basis of compensation is demanded in a report of a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, sent out to its membership today.

Modern life, with its tendencies to "browbeat us, shrink our souls and bury us with bewilderment, cynicism and unbelief," was the subject of a scathing denunciation yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Paul Sherer in his sermon at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

KINGS PARK, L.I., Nov. 6. -- The beaches for several miles along Long Island Sound in this vicinity were searched by the State police today for the bodies of four men who had been reported as having drowned when a rowboat with an outboard motor sprung a leak and another rowboat turned over while five men were hunting ducks about four miles from shore.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 6. -- Frank Carideo's Missouri Tigers scored their first football victory of the season yesterday, a 14-6 triumph over the Oklahoma Sooners which knocked the latter out of a tie with Nebraska for the Big Six Conference leadership.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- Displaying a much-improved offense, the Boston Braves conquered Stapleton in a National Professional League game at Braves Field today, 19 -- 6. The Staten Island team played without its star back, Ken Strong. It was the second victory of the season for the Braves.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee issued a proclamation yesterday calling upon all residents of the city to suspend their normal affairs for two minutes at 11 A.M. on Friday, Armistice Day. The proclamation follows:

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 60.2, which compares with 60.6 a week ago, 61.1 two weeks ago, 61.3 three weeks ago and 61.8 four weeks ago. This season's highest was 63.2, on Sept. 10.

FORT FRANCES, Ont., Nov. 6 (Canadian Press) . -- The pathetic story of a terrified woman tossed on the rocky shores of a lonely island in Lake-of-the-Woods, wet, cold and mourning the loss of her husband and two little daughters was related today by Mrs. Eyner Petersen of Chicago when she was brought to camp in an Indian canoe.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Buffeted by a heavy rain and wind storm, the Yale football team opened the week before the Princeton game by running through half an hour's modified dummy scrimmage and a long signal drill on the Phipps polo field.

BEFORE the Army-Harvard game at Cambridge Captain John J. McEwan, coach of Holy Cross, called on his former Army confreres and displayed diagrams of a "paleozoic defense" Holy Cross was going to use against Brown. But the Brown Bears went through the "paleozoic defense" in the last few minutes of play with a Jurassic attack.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Fullback Carl Perina, Penn's 205-pound kicker, came out of the Pitt game in poor shape and it is questionable whether he will be able to start against Ohio State at Columbus Saturday.

When President WASHINGTON in 1789 issued the first national Thanksgiving Proclamation (which has been incorporated in President HOOVER'S Proclamation of 1932) the action was criticized "as infringing "upon the prerogatives of the Gov"ernors of the States."

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- The volume of trading on the Boerse increased substantially as a result of the elections, which bore out predictions made on the Stock Exchange in the past few weeks. Stocks advanced an average of 1 per cent, although Aschersleben Potash rose 3 per cent and Harpener 2 per cent.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 7. -- There follow the texts of the two speeches Governor Roosevelt delivered here tonight, the first on State issues and the second, which was broadcast on a national radio hook-up, on Federal issues.
UVALDE Texas. Nov. 7 (AP). -- After casting his ballot John N. Garner, Vice Presidential nominee, will go fishing tomorrow instead of sitting at home here to await the election result.

A taxicab, skidding on the rainsoaked paving of the Williamsburg Bridge yesterday morning, crashed into a wagon, hurling the driver from his seat out over the bridge parapet to his death in the East River 125 feet below. The crew of a police launch grappled for the body throughout most of the afternoon, but found no trace of it.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- London is expecting an international boomlet in stocks, in trade and in general cheerfulness as soon as the American Presidential election has been decided tomorrow. This expectation has nothing to do with Franklin D. Roosevelt, whose triumph is seen here as a foregone conclusion, nor with the prospect of debt revision after the election.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP).-- The heat of a Presidential campaign at its very climax was tempered with local pride here tonight as citizens of varying political faiths arranged a welcome for Herbert Hoover, Stanford graduate, foster son of California and President of the United States.
NEW YORK. Countess de Faramond de Lafojole has arrived from Paris and has joined Mrs. Adolf Pavenstedt at 10 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Germany's election has not resolved the deadlock of parties or opened the way to an immediate termination of the conflict between parliamentarism and government by decree. But it is no paradox to say that an ultimate solution of the crisis has been hastened by the indecisive outcome on Sunday.

A largo and thoroughly delightful exhibition that opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries is devoted entirely to flowers. The canvases are by French painters of the eighteenth and ninetieth centuries, ranging from Corot and Delacroix, who were born in 1796 and 1799 respectively, to such living artists as Matisse, Picasso, Leger, Lurcat and Raoul Dufy.

The election today will make political history, Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Democratic candidate for Mayor, said last night in a short radio speech, in which he predicted that welfare work and economy in city government would be the paramount issues facing the Mayor on Jan. 1.

The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $3,294,166,840 in October, the Exchange announced yestyday. The total value on Nov. 1 was $23,440,661,828, against $26,734,828,668 on Oct. 1.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 7.-- Winding up his campaign for the Presidency here tonight before crowd of about 11,000 Milwaukee Socialists, Norman Thomas pronounced the Progressive movement "dead, to all intents and purposes." and pre dieted that Franklin D. Roosevelt would fail, as President, to lift the nation's burden of depression.

The adjusted index of automobile production is 19.2 for the week ended Nov. 5, as against 16.9 for the previous week and 14.6 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, amounted to 10,207 cars and trucks, as compared with 9,546 cars and trucks in the preceding week and 8,592 cars and trucks in the corresponding week last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP). -- A whirl of issues, State and national, will face the 5,000,000 voters of seven Western States tomorrow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- The New Haven Journal Courier says it has received a report from a reliable source that Dean Clarence W. Mendell of Yale College has been offered the presidency of Princeton University.

VINITA, Okla., Nov. 7. -- From behind the bleak walls and barred windows of the Eastern State Hospital here has come news of a treatment for the twisting condition that is the sequel to encephalitis, or American sleeping sickness.

Markets Await Buying Revival. Aside from a fair volume of requests for merchandise in the gift category for first-floor selling, orders received in the wholesale markets here yesterday reflected the lull which has continued during the last fortnight.

Paper ballots, to be used in the event that voting machines do not function properly will be printed and distributed at Tammany Hall, instead of by the city, in the interests of economy, it was announced yesterday by Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly.
Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. ABOARD PRESIDENT HOOVER'S CAMPAIGN TRAIN, ELKO, Nev., Nov. 7. -- It was in a most interesting setting that President Hoover closed him campaign.

BUFFALO, Nov. 7. -- Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican candidate for Governor, ended his camaign in his home city tonight with a radio speech broadcast throughout the State in which he emphasized again, as he has daily since the campaign started, the need for greater economy in government.

Two men walked behind Mrs. Mary Mareno as she trudged through the rain up Second Avenue just before 9 A.M. yesterday holding the hand of her nephew, Paul Marciante, 10 years old. One of the men seized the aunt.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL, SPECIAL, EN ROUTE TO PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 7 (AP). --President Hoover made known today that a telegram had been received saying that leading Argentine newspapers were advocating the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt with the hope that tariffs would be lowered, thus enabling their nation to export its agricultural and animal products to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- With all plans laid for double duty, the Secret Service today awaited the result of the election to ascertain if it is to guard both the President and a President-elect until March 4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a $35,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to construct a new allelectric line between St. Louis and Kansas City was asked today by the St. Louis-Kansas City Short Line Railroad Company, a new corporation.

With Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, making his final appeal to the country over a nation-wide radio hook-up from Milwaukee, where the Socialists expect to elect some members of Congress, local Socialist leaders wound up their campaign yesterday with last-minute calls to the voters to rally behind the Socialist ticket.

The importance of food values in maintaining health was emphasized yesterday at the opening session of the fifteenth annual meeting of the American Dietetic Association, held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Two winners of the Grand National Steeplechase and eight other crack jumpers are scheduled to meet today at Belmont Park in the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase, feature of the Fall meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association.

Some time ago a little band of economists, including the inevitable and infallible JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES, in a joint letter to The London Times put forth the theory that it was the duty of both private individuals and public authorities to spend freely.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- Long shots scored in most of the races at Pimlico today, the climax coming in the third when F.A. Griffith's Rock Coventry won by a head from Idle Stefan at 109 to 1. The mutuel payoff on the son of Coventry, which never had won before, was $219.90 for $2.

Members of the army teams which will compete at the National Horse Show, which opens tomorrow in Madison Square Garden, paid their respects yesterday to Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, at Governors Island.
ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL AT ELKO, Nev., Nov. 7. -- following is the text of President Hoover's election eve radio address from the parlor car of his train here:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Led by a youth who carried a rifle and spoke his commands in a falsetto voice, five unmasked bandits entered the Lehigh National Bank today, covered fifteen employes and patrons with guns and escaped in an automobile with $7,000 to $8,000.
There was no rest for Columbia's football team yesterday as the Lions began preparations for their important contest with the undefeated Brown eleven.

The rain yesterday served only to stimulate the action of the New York University football squad as it began preparing for Saturday's battle with Fordham. The Violet athletes drilled for nearly two hours, half of which time was spent outdoors at Ohio Field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Even a cursory examination of some of the books listed in any large library catalogue under "Capital Levy" would have saved you from some of the errors in your editorial of Oct. 22, "Open Season for Promises."

PRAGUE, Nov. 7. -- "The year 1933 will determine whether Europe proceeds toward peace or the possibility of war," Foreign Minister Benes told the foreign, committee of Parliament today. If the armed States did not disarm or if the disarmed ones armed themselves it would only be in preparation for a new conflict, he added.

The trustees of the Jewish Centre, 131 West Eighty-sixth Street, have presented to Governor Roosevelt copies of resolutions gratefully acknowledging his special message to the Assembly in 1921 which led to the passing of a bill incorporating the Centre according to the principles of orthodox Judaism.

While openly professing no interest, Tammany politicians privately expressed, on the eve of election, concern over the movement to write in the name of Joseph V. McKee, the Acting Mayor, on the voting machines today.
GENOA, Italy, Nov. 7. -- The new liner Conte de Savoia arrived here today, ending a successful trial trip from Trieste.

The directors of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company have voted the payment of six months' interest to Oct. 1 on the new ten-year 6 per cent notes. The interest will be paid as soon as the notes are issued, to holders of the company's old 6 per cent preferred stock under the capital readjustment plan, according to a letter from W.H. Lalley, president, to the stockholders.

The Police Department prepared itself yesterday for a hard day today. The registration has indicated the biggest vote in the History of the city, and the entire force has been ordered to be on duty, or in reserve, from one minute after midnight last night until 8 A. M. tomorrow, a thirty-twohour stretch.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Seventeen men and women, arrested in Bergenfield May 22 for distributing religious literature on Sunday and convicted under an ancient "blue law" on the charge of "wandering abroad in the open air and failing to give a good account of themselves," were absolved by the Supreme Court today in a decision ordering the charges dropped.
Six Manhattan properties and seven parcels in the Bronx offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday were bid in by the plaintiffs. The results were as follows:
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 7 (AP). -- The text of former President Coolidge's radio address tonight, as released through the Republican National Committee, follows:

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENTIAL, SPECIAL AT ELKO, Nev., Nov. 1 (AP). -- With the parlor car of his train as a brilliantly illuminated stage In this dim-lit Nevada valley, President Hoover tonight broadcast nation-wide his final campaign appeal while miners, sheep-herders, cattle ranchers and part of the 3,000 population of this little town clustered about his car.

GENEVA, Nov. 7. -- Monetary and economic experts, meeting together today as a preparatory committee for the world conference, agreed on the broad lines of their report and named a drafting committee to put the text into shape and issue a statement tomorrow.

Appealing for generous response from individuals on behalf of the unemployed, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the New York Edison, Consolidated Gas and Niagara-Hudson Power Companies, declared yesterday that unless the response this Winter was greater than ever before it would come close to meaning that the capitalistic system had broken down.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 7. -- Among neighbors of his home county, Governor Roosevelt issued his final appeal tonight to the voters of the nation to send him to the White House as "the humble emblem" of "the new deal."

ROME, Nov. 7. -- Norman H. Davis, immediately on his arrival this morning, was received by Fulvio Sulvich, Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs, with whom he had a talk lasting almost two hours. In the afternoon he was received by Premier Mussolini, who remained in conversation with him an hour and a half.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Unemployment and the problem of insuring workers against it were the two questions monopolizing the attention of Parliament today when Prime Minister MacDonald discussed them in the House of Commons after receiving the final report of the Royal Inquiry Commission.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic candidate for Governor, made his last speech of the campaign last night from the Paulist Fathers' radio station WLWL, and ended a review of the political issues with, a non-political appeal for the support of character-building organizations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The text of the Supreme Court decision in the Scottsboro case, read by Justice Sutherland, follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The action of the Interstate Commerce Commission in approving the lease of the "Big Four" and Michigan Central Railroads to the New York Central for ninety-nine years was upheld by the Supreme Court today in an opinion handed down by Chief Justice Hughes.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- President von Hindenburg and Chancellor von Papen will spare no effort to enable those sections of the new Reichstag that really desire to cooperate in the reconstruction of the fatherland to translate that desire into action, the Chancellor said in an interview today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 7. -- Coach Crisler canceled the usual Monday day of rest for the Princeton varsity football squad today, and three elevens held a two-and-a-half-hour drill in the rain as preparations for the Yale contest on Saturday got under way.

MONMOUTH, JUNCTION, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Eight men were injured this afternoon, one seriously, when a Pennsylvania Railroad work train was overturned in a collision with a freight train here. The work train, in charge of Engineer William Frank of 28 Dewey Street, Newark, was proceeding toward Philadelphia, and on the adjoining track a freight train was traveling toward New York.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 7. -- Attorney General Thomas E. Knight, who defended the death sentences imposed on seven young Negroes in the Scottsboro cases, said tonight he would not discuss the State's procedure until he had read the decision of the United States Supreme Court reversing the sentences.

GENEVA, Nov. 7. -- The bureau of the disarmament conference reached a provisional agreement today on all the most troublesome points in the chapter of the convention dealing with supervision of its enforcement.

ABOARD PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 7. -- Making 'a farflung last-minute radio appeal from the remote town of Elko, Nev., President Hoover tonight called upon the nation to return him and his administration to power for another four years.

It was raining in Bridgeport at 7:23 yesterday morning. At 7:38 it had been raining for some time at Westport, causing the devil-maycare literary men who live there and park their cars outdoors to say " Oh, dear me!" when their motors refused to start.

The Bulgarian Government has sent here sufficient funds to pay one-half of the interest due on next Tuesday on the issue of Kingdom of Bulgaria 7 1/2 per cent stabilization loan of 1928, according to an announcement made yesterday by Speyer fe Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, through whom payment will be made here.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The majority report of the Royal Commission on Unemployment Insurance, made public today, upholds the "dole" system as the "first line of defense over a large part of the field of employment for a great majority of the unemployed."
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Commuters to Manhattan took an extra forty winks this morning without fear of missing their toast and coffee.

Major Thomas F. Lynch, who years ago conquered John L. Sullivan in feats of strength died yesterday at his home at 555 Ovington Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 80 years old, and when he retired at the age of 77 he was referred to as the "army's strong man."

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published a letter from Clarence H. Low under the caption. "Mr. Hoover and Rubber." Mr. Low seems to criticize Mr. Hoover for not doing something for the British Government.

An appeal for contributions to defray expenses of the Citizens Budget Commission was broadcast last night through Station WEAF to all the voters of Greater New York, by Thomas J. Watson, a trustee of the commission, president of the Merchants Association and president of the International Business Machines Corporation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7. -- The Toledo Edison Company applied today to the Ohio Public Utilities Commission for permission, to issue $27,500,000 of bonds to be sold at once. The bonds are to bear 5 per cent interest, to run thirty years and to be sold at 95% per cent.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Tito Schipa, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, appeared at the R.K.O. Pickwick Theatre here tonight, before an audience of about 2,000 persons, in the second of a series of concerts sponsored by the Wednesday Singing Club.

With eighty-two players competing, two elimination sessions were held yesterday in the first annual individual contract bridge championship of New York State, being hedl at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel under the auspices of the Metropolitan Contract Bridge League.

PARIS, Nov. 7. -- There is good reason to believe, the French disarmament plan will be largely rewritten within the next few days with a view to its simplification, although Premier Herriot reported to the Cabinet today the scheme had been well received as presented by Joseph Paul-Boncour at Geneva.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- On the site of the old Harlem race track, one of America's famous race courses of thirty years ago, a new $1,500,000 racing plant will be constructed that will take its place in the first rank of the nation's race courses.
ROME, Nov. 7. -- The comprehensive vastness of the amnesty, promulgated by Premier Mussolini was emphasized today when full figures were published of the numbers benefiting from it.

The action of the United States Supreme Court in ordering a new trial for the seven Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case was praised here yesterday by persons who had taken an active interest in the case as in accord with the best type of American justice.

PASADENA, Cal., Nov. 7. -- Directing his words especially to the independent voter "always ready to scratch any ticket to set a better man," Dr. Robert A. Millikan, head of the California Institute of Technology, made a final appeal tonight for support of President Hoover.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Two hours before Governor Roosevelt's arrival at Columbus Hall tonight all the 1,500 seats were taken and crowds were jamming about loud-speakers in the streets. Inside, one speaker after another was urging the election of the Democratic State ticket in New York and bringing resounding "boos" for the Republican, candidates for State offices.

All the markets of consequence, as well as banks and financial institutions generally, will be closed today because of the national election. Business will be curtailed sharply everywhere. Activity will be resumed tomorrow. The foreign markets will be open today.

GREENSBORO, Ga., Nov. 7 (AP). -- Two men who proposed to bet Henry Ford a 201-acre farm against a model V-8 Ford automobile that Franklin D. Roosevelt would be elected president have increased the odds by offering a milk cow and a calf.
Pre-election, dullness accounted for the limited trading in the realty market yesterday. In New Jersey there was a continuance of the turnover in small housing parcels.

On the eve of election, with the result of the Presidential contest pretty plainly fore shadowed to every one and even the last-hour "election odds" running into high figures, virtually all of yesterday's markets advanced. Stock Exchange business was double last week's full-day, average volume.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Lewis C. Ruch, whose team-strengthening policies lifted the Phillies from the National League baseball cellar to the first division in two years, resigned today as president of the club.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Harvard's defeat by the Army was discussed editorially today by The Tale Daily News, which criticized the West Pointers for starting their prac tlce season too early and adhering to eligibility rules not allowed in Prince ton-Yale-Harvard football.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 7. -- John H. Bligh, a retired newspaper man, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Francis H. Reynolds of Oakley Place, east of this village, after a long illness due to hardening of the arteries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Herbert Hoover, possessing probably as pronounced a distate for electioneering as any Chief Executive the nation ever had, concluded tonight the most strenuous campaign for re-election undertaken by a President in recent decades.

Kid Chocolate, Cuban fighter, will make his first defense of the world's featherweight championship in Madison Square Garden on Dec. 16, in a. fifteen-round battle with. Fidel La Barba, Coast challenger.

Yesterday's decision by the Supreme Court ordering a new trial for the seven Negroes under sentence of death in Alabama turned wholly upon "due process of law." The right to it in all matters affecting life and property is guaranteed by the Constitution to the humblest citizen of the United States.

Reports of sales made so far by chains of stores for October show a preponderance of gains in the relative position of the month, contrasted with a year ago, over the month of September, although most of the companies are still doing business on a smaller scale than last year.

Miss Edwina L. Crowen, 20-yearold Adelphi College student living at 114-65 114th Street, Ozone Park, Queens, will cast her first vote today in the Ninety-fourth Election District of the Fifth Assembly District as a result of a decision handed down by an Attorney General of New York State in 1898.

Surrogate James A. Foley dismissed yesterday a motion by Saul J. Baron, temporary administrator of the estate of Abraham L. Erlanger, theatrical producer, to compel former Supreme Court Justice Mitchell L. Erlanger to surrender records of confessions of judgment and a bond and mortgage after Mr. Erlanger had agreed to relinquish the documents.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 7 (AP). -- In a final declaration for the Republican ticket, Calvin Coolidge tonight said:
Shaking off its pre-election lethargy, the stock market celebrated yesterday the termination of the national political campaign by a broad and vigorous advance.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7. -- Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and rational chairman of the share-the work movement, told more than 300 business leaders of Baltimore today that already 4,000 employers were cooperating in the movement and that 3.500,000 persons now employed hold their jobs because of this cooperation.

Miss Mildred Harbeck, 35 years old, a member of the Junior League, was found dead yesterday morning in a gas-filled bedroom by her older sister, Miss Helen Harbeck, with whom she lived in the old-fashioned four-story brownstone house at 306 Lexington Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No one seems to halve given attention to the declaration of Norman Thomas in favor of the recognition of the Soviets. This, it strikes me, is either a piece of political strategy to catch radical votes or an example of ignorance of the declared purposes of the Russian leaders to subvert representative government everywhere.

Apparently driven by the storm to seek a haven along the south shore of Long Island, two large flocks of flight ducks, declared by observers to consist mainly of broadbills, were sighted winging across Long Island Sound late yesterday.

While there was irregularity In some commodities yesterday, cotton and silk particularly, there were notable gains elsewhere. Wheat rose 1@1 1/2 cents, corn also showing an improvement of 1 cent, with rubber, sugar and cocoa developing higher levels. Eggs reached a new high price for the year. Elsewhere values were maintained without change.

After bearing protests yesterday from members of the Board of Trade against the proposed loan of $3,957,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Hillside Housing Corporation for new model housing in the Bronx, Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee sent telegrams of protest to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the State Housing Board.

Lindley M. Garrison, Secretary of War in President Wilson's Cabinet, who died at Seabright, N.J., on Oct. 19, left most of his estate, formally valued at "more than $10,000," to seven young relatives and friends, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

September figures of the Department of Commerce show that the United States sold goods valued at $244,000,000 in Asiatic markets during the first nine months of 1932. This is substantially below last year's total of $305,000,000 for the same period.

Despite, the probability of rainy weather today political leaders in the suburban area were confident of a record vote, based on the heavy registration figures. Good roads and the automobile have lessened the possibility of bad weather reducing the vote, particularly in the areas surrounding New Tork City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The Supreme Court today refused to order Federal District Judge George O. Taylor of Eastern Tennessee, to call a three-judge Federal court to act on a suit challenging the validity of the Tennessee Congressional redistricting act.

The Canadian dollar, which had given evidence of weakness at the close of last week, broke two cents yesterday to a discount of 13 1/2 cents in terms of United States money, the widest discount since July 19. The Canadian monetary unit closed on Saturday at 88 1/2 cents.

Two hundred broadcasting stations will devote their time and radio facilities to election bulletins tonight, beginning at 6 o'clock. Most of them plan to stay on the air all night, if necessary, to cover completely the reports sent to the studios by press associations aria newspapers from all parts of the country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- Fluctuations in Canadian exchange were a factor in wheat today, and on a bulge of 3 5/8 cents in the Winnipeg market, coincident with a break in the exchange rate to the lowest level since August, prices here advanced rather sharply, and the close was higher for the third straight day, the first time this has occurred since Sept. 5.

Amelia Earhart, first woman to fly the Atlantic alone, presented a Persian kitten to the Explorers Club last night as a mascot, at the first "ladies' night" given by the club in its new home at 10 West Seventy-second Street.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, issued a statement yesterday retorting to what he called an "implied threat" in President Hoover's address at St. Paul last Sat urday. The President was quoted as having said, "Thank God we have a government in Washington that knows how to deal with a mob."

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- A further move in the economic war between Great Britain and the Irish Free State was made tonight by the British when a new treasury order was Issued, doubling the import duties on Irish live cattle shipped to England and increasing by 50 per cent the duties on Irish pork, poultry and dairy products.

City College brings its 1932 football schedule to a close today with the game against Manhattan College at the Polo Grounds. It will mark the eighth annual clash between the local rivals. The opening kick-off is set for 2 P.M.

With more than 9,000 names on the registry books listed for challenge, with 200 Special Deputy State Attorneys General, more than 100 Deputy United States Marshals and 2,000 trained watchers of the Hoover engineers' committee ready for duty at the polls, extraordinary precautions will be taken today both by officials and voluntary groups to prevent illegal voting and intimidation at the polls.

Those concerned over city affairs will turn quickly tomorrow to the table showing the election returns in the Mayoralty contest between Mr. O'BRIEN, Mr. POUNDS and Mr. HILLQUIT. On the result may hang the city's fate in the five years that lie ahead.

A new wage agreement for the 4,000 men employed by tugboat line operating in the Harbor was signed yesterday by representatives of the men and the owners, meeting at the New York Towboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place. Peace was thus assured for six months after a series of conferences held in the last four weeks at which threats of a strike to tie up harbor traffic were conveyed to the employers.
Enrolments in the various units of Columbia University show a drop this year as compared with 1931-32, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university announced yesterday.

The mind is gradually divorcing itself from matter, and the present generation's far-away descendants may see the rise of a submaterial type, like the fable ghosts, immaterial and scarcely human save in mind and thought. Dr. C.C. Hurst, pioneer geneticist of Cambridge University, England, writes in "The Mechanism of Creative Evolution," a publication of Macmillan and the Cambridge University Press.

A last-minute avalanche of protests descended upon State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer yesterday because of their bi-partisan nominations for Supreme Court. George W. Alger, who with Bernard S. Deutsch comprises the independent ticket opposing them, delivered a final radio speech, in which he said that his election would be a protest against the picking of judges by "political bosses."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Yale's varsity and freshman basketball schedules for the coining season were announced tonight by the athletic association.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden, parents of Princess Ingrid, arrived tonight and were met at the station by the Dowager Marchioness of Milford Haven, mother of the Crown Princess, with whom they are staying at Kensington Palace and by the Swedish Minister and Baroness Palmstierna.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The stock markets were cheerful today, although British funds were adversely affected by profit-taking. Dealings in the new 3 per cent conversion loan started at 3/8 discount, but following good support improved to 1/4 discount.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Werner Janssen, American composer, received an enthusiastic ovation when he appeared here tonight as the first American to lead the Budapest philharmonic orchestra. The program included the composer's "Obsequies of a Saxophone" and "Idyll," by Baron Frederick Koranyi, twice Hungarian Minister of Finance.

The famous scoring trio of the New York Rangers will start Its seventh consecutive season against the Maroons in Montreal Thursday night. This was assured yesterday by the signing of Frank Boucher star centre. The other members of the first line are the Cook brothers Bill and Bun.

The managers for the various nominees, having worked for months to win public support, which will be recorded at the polls today, turned yesterday to arranging for the customary election night celebrations.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov.7. -- The text of President Hoover's address "here was as follows:

With President Herbert Hoover making his final plea to the voters of the United States in a speech, broadcast from Elko, Nev., and with Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, speaking at Poughkeensie, the 1932 Presidential campaign came to an end last night.

The appeal of the Interborough receivers from the recent ruling of the Federal District Court that Circuit Judge Martin T. Manton acted illegally in establishing the receivership and appointing them will be heard by the Circuit Court of Appeals next Monday morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- New trials were ordered by the Supreme Court today for seven Negroes condemned to death at Scottsboro, Ala., on charges of attacking two white girls.

BOSTON, Nov. 7. --Russell Jellison of Bates College today won the twentieth annual New England intercollegiate cross-country run at Franklin Park, having a margin of almost seventy-five yards over Henry Raduazo of New Hampshire at the finish.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- Prices of hogs here were on the upgrade again today, graining 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds. Receipts were the smallest for a Monday in more than eight years. The top was lifted 20 cents to $3.60, the highest price in eleven days, while the day's average was moved up 15 cents to $3.45, the best figure in twelve days.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Two years of suspense for August Gobel ended early this morning when a fusillade of shots poured out of the blackness of an empty boiler room in the ice plant of the Christian Feigenspan Corporation in the "ironbound" section of Newark and killed him instantly.

The Luckenbach Steamship Lines, operators of two freight services, announced plans yesterday to remodel their twenty-one freighters to provide accommodations for passengers. A precedent of sixty-seven years, during which Luckenbach ships have engaged exclusively in transportation of freight, will be broken.

"Music in the Air," the new Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical play, will open tonight at the Alvin Theatre. A revival of "The Silent House," a melodrama which, had a New York run four years ago, will be presented at the Ambassador Theatre this afternoon.

BELFAST, Nov. 7. -- The Nationalist members of the Parliament of Northern Ireland have decided to boycott the opening of the new Parliament House by the Prince of Wales as a protest against the partition of Ireland. There are eleven Nationalists among the fifty-two members of the House of Commons and two among the twenty-four in the Senate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are times when an electorate should rise above party considerations and vote for a candidate whose ability and experience already tried and whose constructive thinking and vision transcend party labels. No one will deny that these are such times, and that Senator Robert F. Wagner, by virtue of his record in the United States Senate, is such a candidate.

Mrs. Susan Brandeis Gilbert, attorney and daughter of United States Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis, acted as an arbiter in three cases in the Sixth District Municipal Court, 25 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Dietaries and Farmers. Nutrition experts now assembled in this city have no doubt done much the health and vigor of the American people, but they are also accused of having played hob with the nation's economics.

United States Senator Felix Hebert of Rhode Island, Eastern campaign manager for President Hoover, claimed last night the election of Mr. Hoover, with 289 electoral votes, conceding only 149 to Governor Roosevelt, his Democratic opponent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Increased exports in September to twenty-three of this country's thirty-nine principal foreign markets and larger imports from twenty-seven were shown in the monthly analysis of American foreign trade, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The advance in bond prices was extended yesterday on the Stock Exchange under the leadership of domestic railroad issues, many of which gained a point or more. Leading utility issues averaged higher and industrials slightly lower for the day.

As a result of its study of the General Gas and Electric Corporation in its relationship with the Associated Gas and Electric Company, which controls it, the New York Stock Exchange has concluded that the company belongs in the investment-trust classification and has persuaded the company to follow the practices required of that group, with certain exceptions.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Arriving here unexpectedly today in an automobile which showed the effects of an all-night drive over rain-soaked roads, John Hughes Curtis, boatbuilder of Norfolk, Va., who was convicted of obstructing justice in the search for the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby, appeared at brief proceedings in court, at which he paid the $1,000 fine imposed after his conviction and was released from a one-year jail term included in his sentence.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The Mexico City representative of General Agusto Sandino, Nicaraguan insurgent, announced today that the General would not recognize the winner in yesterday's election. General Sandino plans to seize Managua and call a new election, the representative said.

New York has its annual election day football game today in the meeting of Manhattan and City College at the Polo Grounds. Each year this contest invariably produces hard, close football, regardless of previous records.

Franchised buses will be operating throughout the city by Feb. 1, 1933, Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly declared yesterday, urging the Appellate Division in Brooklyn to extend to that date the stay which protects "emergency" buses in Manhattan and Queens from the taxpayer's injunction obtained by Stanley Bogart two years ago.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Lots of excitement here today. Art Kelly, George Dennis and Ed Graney killed Charlie Brenlin's bear, the one he used to keep in a cage alongside his road stand on the main road outside of Pearl River. The local police, troopers from New City barracks and about fifty citizens were in on the hunt.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (AP). -- Climaxing a two-day celebration of the fifteenth anniversary of the founding of the Soviet regime, K.E. Voroshiloff, Commissar for War, told 50,000 troops of the Moscow garrison assembled in Red Square today that the world depression signalized the end of capitalism.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7.-- This was no "easy Monday" for many of the Harvard football players who took part In the Army game on Saturday. Head Coach Casey, after talking to his squad about the game with the Cadets, sent two varsity teams against each other in dummy scrimmage.

Baroness Keichi Ishimoto, leader of the feminist movement in her country and "the Margaret Sanger of Japan," sat back in her chair in her apartment at the Hotel St. Moritz yesterday and told of things about her country that seldom found their way into the dispatches from the Far East filled with news and rumors of wars.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 7. -- The Warm Springs Valley Garden Club will hold its monthly meeting tomorrow at Boxwood Farm, the home of Mrs. Susan Park. The program for next year will be discussed. Baroness Rosenkrantz, the president, will preside.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 7. -- The authorities here are taking unprecedented precautions against disorder tomorrow, when 25,000 Social Democrats and trade unionists from all parts of Holland will hold an antigovernment demonstration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP). -- The steamship Sixaola, believed to be somewhere in the Caribbean, sent out a message yesterday which was intercepted by the navy saying it had picked up an S O S from a vessel of unknown identity. The Sixaola reported it was unable to establish contact with the distressed ship, the call letters of which were given as G-B-W-Y.

Lewis H. Pounds, the Brooklyn civic worker chosen by the Republican party as its Mayoralty candidate this year, closed his campaign yesterday confident that whatever the result at today's election the foundation has been laid for an anti-Tammany uprising next year.
For the fourth consecutive month the output of steel ingots in the United States increased in October, according to statistics issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 7.-The election eve address by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, tonight was as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7. -- One railroad bridge guard, stationed on the route taken by President Hoover's special train through Nevada, was shot to death tonight and another was seriously stabbed, according to information received by Southern Pacific officials here.

TOKYO, Nov. 7. -- The Japan Times tonight assails the United States Customs Bureau for suspension of appraisement of Japanese imported canned fish and electric lamps as "making Japan's treaty rights a football of politics."

Commenting yesterday on the statements of Herbert Straus and Paul Block, in which they announced that they would support Representative Ruth Pratt, candidate for reelection in the Seventh Congressional District, George Gordon Battle, who is a member of the campaign committee of Theodore A. Peyser, Mrs. Pratt's Democratic opponent, said:

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- Revised election figures tonight merely confirm the political outlook indicated last night. The new Reichstag will consist of 582 members against 607 last time, and no party combination strong enough to control it is conceivable in the light of the aims and histories of the various factions.

Thirteen track and field meets will be staged in the East during the coming indoor season, it was revealed yesterday in the November issue of The Amateur Athlete, monthly publication of the A. A. U. The Meadowbrook Club and Knights of Columbus fixtures are missing but two new events have been planned.

PARIS, Nov. 7. -- The favorable tendencies shown on the Bourse Saturday were accentuated today. From the beginning to the end, the tone was firm, with the closing prices generally the highest of the day.

Renewals of three traditional rival ries, which date back more than two decades, top today's scholastic foot ball program, which calls for seven games on fields within New York City to be played before an antici pated total attendance of approxi mately 60,000 fans.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 7.-- Officials of mid-Western Iron and steel companies believe the industry will maintain operations at 20 per cent of capacity In this area until the end of the month, and perhaps longer. Schedules for this week show steady production in the Mahoning Valley but some falling off in the Shenahgo Valley, where the output reached a peak last week.

Compelled to work indoors because of the inclement weather, Fordham's football squad drilled for two hours in the college gymnasium yesterday. A program of intensive work was begun in preparation for the traditional encounter with New York University at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8. -- An intensive passing drill featured the Princeton eleven's two-hour practice session on university field today.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa. (Wednesday), Nov. 9. -- Pennsylvania lived up to tradition by remaining Republican in yesterday's Presidential election, but incomplete returns early this morning indicated that President Hoover's plurality might be considerably less than half of the 500,000 figures claimed by leaders in the last weeks of the campaign and that Philadelphia, for many years the stronghold of Vareism, stayed loyal by a mere 75,000 votes.

DES MOINES, Nov. 9. -- The Des Moines Register, an independent Republican newspaper, soon after 11 P.M. conceded that Governor Roosevelt would carry Iowa. Gardner Cowles, a member of the board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, is the publisher of The Register.

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- The German Andes Expedition has reported, as its last feat after the exploration of the Peruvian Cordillera, the ascension of Aconcagua in Western Argentina, the highest peak In the Western Hemisphere.

Patience was the order of the day yesterday not only for the average voter but for candidates for office and for persons prominent in political and civic life. Long, slowly moving queues waited in front of many of the city's polling places, and candidates who refused to take precedence of voters ahead of them stood patiently in line waiting their turns to pull down the levers of the voting machines.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 8. -- Fire early this evening destroyed Preston Hall, the home of Dr. Preston, Pope Satterwhite, with most of its contents, including many fine paintings, rare books, valuable rugs and tapestries and famous echo pipe organ.

Franklin D. Roosevelt has referred to Herbert H. Lehman as "that splendid right hand of mine." Mr. Lehman, whether in his capacity of Lieutenant Governor of New York or as a private citizen, has enjoyed in an unusual degree the confidence, respect and cordial liking of all with whom he has come in touch.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 8 (AP). -- One man was killed and five wounded in three clashes today as Kentucky voters thronged to the polls in such numbers as to promise to beat the 1928 record or 940,514 ballots in a Presidential year.
Governor Roosevelt may be the next President to millions of voters in this country, but to Mrs. S.S. Forbes, his aunt, he is just a "nice young fellow who deserves the election."

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 8. -- Returns from more than a third of the precincts indicated that Governor Roosevelt had won Indiana over President Hoover by a margin of more than 200,000. Chairman Earl Peters of the Democratic State Committee claimed the election of Governor Roosevelt by at least 250,000.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The stock markets today lost some of their early firmness in the afternoon. British funds did not maintain early improvement, and the internationals, which began lively, became quiet, with Wall Street closed on account of the elections.

The Isabel C. Wilde collection of early American folk paintings will be placed on view today at the John Becker Gallery, 520 Madison Avenue, to remain until Dec. 5. It is the first time this fascinating collection has been shown as a group, although selected examples have appeared in exhibitions at the old Whitney Studio Club, at the Harvard Society for Contemporary Art and at the Newark Museum.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- Sweeping through rock-ribbed Republican rural territory and piling up a sizable plurality in the cities, Governor Roosevelt yesterday wrested Ohio and its 26 electoral votes from President Hoover.
Tyranny of Numbers. Percentages are very important, and seeing things in the right proportion is much to be commended, but there is no denying the impact and the prestige of mere brute numbers.

Supremely happy as bulletin after bulletin promised fulfillment of his anticipated victory, Franklin D. Roosevelt received election returns last night in a small room just off the entrance to the Democratic National Headquarters on the first floor of the Biltmore Hotel.

As a final tune-up for its big bid in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships on Monday, the wellbalanced Manhattan College crosscountry team snapped the four-year string of New York University to win the metropolitan intercollegiate harrier title at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
The vagaries of football, so painfully evident in the flouting of expert opinion all season, are strikingly illustrated in the outlook obtaining for the Yale-Princeton game.

Of the fifty fire houses erected in New York City under a five-year building program of Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman, twenty-nine have been built in the Boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens, according to a survey made public yesterday. The $3,300,000 program calls for two more buildings, one a fire house now under construction at Ninety-first Avenue and 197th Street, Queens, and the other a boat house at the root of Broomfield Street, Manhattan.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Since the very beginning of journalism no newspaper has given its readers so accurate and comprehensive a record of the human activities of the world as is presented in the pages of THE NEW YORK TIMES each morning.

In the Presidential election in Nicaragua, under the supervision of Admiral WOODWARD of the United States Navy, the Conservatives conceded the success of the Liberal candidate, Dr. JUAN B. SACASA, even before the returns from three departments were received.

The practice of the bride and bridegroom kissing at the altar after the wedding ceremony is condemned by St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, Chicago, according to the current issue of The American Lutheran. The same church prohibits the throwing of rice and confetti at weddings and it rules out the singing of "O Promise Me;" "At Dawning," "I Love You Truly," and other songs "which have no religious or churchly character."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The Bureau of Industrial Alcohol, which has jurisdiction over the manufacture, distribution and sale of all legitimate alcoholic products, already has an organization that could be employed for the regulation of beer production should Congress enact legislation legalizing that beverage.

In view of the recent arrest of a man charged with sending narcotics through the mail and destined for ultimate use of inmates of the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta, Ga., United States Attorney Ameli, in Brooklyn, yesterday warned all narcotic sellers they will be prosecuted vigorously by his office.

After being held scoreless during the first quarter, the Ridgewood Football Club tallied once in each of the next two periods to conquer the East Side Tigers, 12 -- 0, at Farmers Oval, Ridgewood, yesterday.
MONTE CARLO, Nov. 8. -- Financial difficulties may force the principality of Monaco to surrender its independence and accept French control, it was learned here on good authority today.

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, returned unannounced yesterday from Italy, arriving on the new Italian liner Rex in time to cast his vote. The Rex's list did not carry Mr. Schwab's name.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Governor Roosevelt has carried Illinois by 420,000 votes. The Democratic nominee for Governor, Judge Henry Horner, has defeated former Governor Len Small, his Republican rival, by 515,000. Representative William H. Dieterich Democrat, has been elected United States Senator over Senator Otis F. Glenn, by about 320,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Democrats from the South and West under the seniority rule will obtain the chairmanships of many important committees if that party wins control of the Senate in the election. Whether this change will come about in the "lame-duck" session, which begins in December and terminates by March 4, will be determined by the results in two States, New Jersey and Colorado, where there are contests for the short terms.
Brooklyn College's eleven defeated St. Francis, 26 to 0, in the second annual encounter between the two institutions at Commercial Field yesterday.

GROTON, Mass., Nov. 8. -- Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., son of Governnor Roosevelt, has been named as the starting right tackle on the Groton School football team for its forty-fourth renewal with St. Mark's School, to be played on the Groton field tomorrow.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 8. -- The Democratic victory in Texas was complete. On the basis of about 288,000 votes counted out of a probable total of 850,000 cast in the State, Governor Roosevelt will receive a majority of more than 500,000. He obtained 253,950 in 134 counties to 34,455 for Hoover.

Holding that dangers are likely to arise from efforts which are being made in certain States to limit taxation by the adoption of measures arbitrarily fixing tax rates, municipal bankers are awaiting news of the action taken yesterday at the polls in several communities, which, in some instances, may not become known for several days.

What is the use of being a city? Pittsfield, the New York of Berkshire County in Massachusetts, has a population of nearly 50,000. New Ashford, in the same county, has or had in 1930 a population of 75. Yet Pittsfield is obscure and New Ashford's name on fame's proud temple shines afar.

At last the musical drama has been emancipated. In "Music in the Air," which was sung at the Alvin last evening, Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d have succeeded in telling a romantic story without recourse to the superannuated formula. What "The Cat and the Fiddle" gallantly began last season Mr. Kern and Mr. Hammerstein have now completed by composing a fable that flows naturally out of a full-brimming score.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 8. -- Complete returns of the vote for President, Governor and Lieutenant Governor showed that Nassau County, one of the Republican strongholds in the State, remained loyal to President Hoover and gave him a majority of 17,335, the second largest accorded any of the candidates on the Republican ticket.
Tammany Hall received the news of the sweeping Democratic victory with jubilance last night, but without surprise. Every one, apparently, from John F. Curry, the leader, down, had expected it.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Two hundred dinghy sailors gathered at the Larchmont Yacht Club today for their second regatta of the chilly season. They demonstrated that no other class of sailing craft on Long Island Sound or elsewhere can boast of such expert skippers as the dinghy division.

Miss Katherine Mayo, American author who wrote "Mother India." arrived yesterday on the Cunarder Scythia after spending several months in England, Germany, France and Italy collecting material for her next work, which will be about social relief work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The Vicksburg Bridge and Terminal Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval of a $4,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. It was proposed to apply the proceeds of the loan to liquidation of the company's bonded indebtedness and replace a temporary timber trestle with a permanent steel structure on concrete footings, under requirements of the War Department.

ELKO, Nev., Nov. 8 (AP). -- Railroad officials were in disagreement tonight as to whether two men frightened away from the Southern Pacific right-of-way near Palisade, Nev., last night had planned an attempt to wreck the special train speeding President Hoover across the great American desert to California.
LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The House of Commons tonight approved by 250 to 38 votes the new government order increasing tariffs on live stock, poultry and other products from the Irish Free State.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8. -- Reports that oil companies operating in Mexico would lend the government $10,000,000 as an advance on taxes are declared in reliable circles to be likely to materialize in a few days.

First of a number of social events to be held in connection with the National Horse Show, which opens in Madison Square Garden this afternoon, was the annual horse show dinner given last evening by the officers and directors of the association in honor of the foreign officers and other guests in the Jade Room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

John P. O'Brien, New York's new Chief Magistrate, has been known as the "battering ram" and the "machine gun" of the Hylan administration. He has so often brought his "fighting Irish" temperament into civic politics, whether in the open or behind the scenes, that he has come to be regarded as a man of high spirits and one of the stanchest supporters of Tammany Hall.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 8. -- Political leaders tried vainly all day to solve the Cabinet crisis precipitated by Bolivia's reverses in the field against Paraguay.

An amendment to the zoning resolution which would permit owners of private garages in residence districts to rent space in these garages will have the support of the Brooklyn Civic Council when it comes before the Board of Estimate at a public hearing Friday.

No better illustration of the ideal woman as described in the Book of Proverbs has been furnished in our day than the life of Mrs. E.H. HARRIMAN. As was recalled in yesterday's TIMES, Mr. HARRIMAN in his will, written nearly thirty years ago, gave all his property to her " absolutely and forever" -- the best evidence that "the heart of her husband trusted in her."
MELBOURNE, Nov. 8. -- Two hundred sailors from Australian warships, chiefly the cruiser Australia, came shore tonight and held a meeting to protest against pay cuts under the financial emergency act.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One amazing piece of stupidity is the present ruling of the Treasury Department in reference to manganese ore. The order will compel manganese ore importers to give a redelivery bond, assuring return of the shipments to the custody of the collectors in event a finding of dumping is entered later according to oral explanations at the Bureau of Customs.

Predicting that Franklin D. Roosevelt will make a great President, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, expressed his happiness at the overwhelming victory of his party, in an address broadcast over an NBC network early this morning.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 8. -- The Baldwin High School football team recorded an unexpected victory by defeating the Freeport High warriors, 6 -- 0, in the annual game between the schools at the Freeport Municipal Stadium today. The setback was the first suffered by the losers in three South Shore League Class A encounters.

The fully expected Democratic sweep in the Presidential election is, primarily, an emphatic vote of want of confidence in the Republican party and in the Hoover Administration. This is partly the result of Governor ROOSEVELT'S sagacity and skill as a leader of the campaign.

For the President personally in his defeat there will be a feeling of kindness touched by the pathos of the political misfortunes against which he has struggled in vain. The strong god circumstance was too powerful for him. He was held responsible for the sins of others.
NEW YORK. Mrs. J. McKeon Hecker and Mrs. Frank X. Sadlier will give a luncheon today at the Colony Club for Miss Jeannette Hecker, debutante daughter of Mrs. Hecker, and niece of Mrs. Sadlier.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8. -- Missouri voters in today's election gave a plurality of more than 300,000 to the electors for Governor Roosevelt and swept into office by unprecedented pluralities the entire Democratic State, judicial and Congressional ticket.

Embarrassment of riches confronted music reviewers on election night, but this situation afforded brilliant and engrossing performances of music in two of the largest auditoriums of this city, packed these auditoriums to capacity, and provided at the Metropolitan Opera House at least one major sensation.
UVALDE, Texas, Nov. 8 (AP). -- John N. Garner, Democratic candidate for the vice presidency, listened to election returns tonight in the home of his son, Tully Garner, Uvalde banker.
The Ferretti family all three of them, voted the straight Democratic ticket yesterday in their own third election district of the Fourh Assembly District, Richmond Hill.

The social service commission of the Brooklyn Federation of Churches received applications for aid from 5,322 persons between June and October, inclusive, and placed 112 in permanent positions, 105 in temporary employment and referred 704 to other sources for work, it was made known yesterday in a report by Myles Porter Law, director of the commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have been assured, on the highest authority, that America has in no way contributed to the economic degression in Europe; but during the entire post-war period a protective tariff has been levied upon imports from Europe and elsewhere, and at the same time America has demanded that the nations of Europe shall nreet their obligatinns and pay their indebtedness to us.

With Governor Roosevelt leading President Hoover by a plurality of 50,819 in 611 of New Jersey's 3,415 election districts, Democratic leaders estimated Roosevelt's eventual plurality at 125,000 to 150,000. The 611 districts grave Roosevelt 136,734 and Hoover 85,915.

Although there were delays in many polling places arising from technical difficulties experienced by many voters in writing in the name of Joseph V. McKee and from minor troubles with voting machines, the great army of New York's voters went to the polls yesterday in good order.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 9. -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt has carried Massachusetts over President Hoover by a margin probably well in excess of 100,000 votes, and Governor Joseph B. Ely has been reelected over his Republican opponent, Lieut. Gov. William S. Youngman, by about 150,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Winnipeg and other foreign grain markets reflected today the advance made here by wheat yesterday. With the Board of Trade here closed today, there was a realizing movement in the way of profit taking in foreign markets, and the highest prices did not hold.

Challenged by the problem or extremely heavy local and through traffic, mounting in density almost daily, and by peculiar topography requiring that much of this traffic load be transported across numberless bays, rivers and inlets, private and public agencies in Rhode Island have spent within the last few years, or are considering spending in the near future, a total of nearly $14,000,000 on great bridges, reports The North American Newspaper Alliance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Wednesday, Nov. 9. -- President Hoover carried Connecticut with a plurality of 4,481 votes over Governor Roosevelt, but Governor Cross was re-elected over John H. Trumbull, his Republican opponent, with a margin of over 11,000, and Senator Hiram Bingham was defeated by Augustine Lonergan, Democrat.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic nominee for Governor, defeated Colonel William J. Donovan, Republican, yesterday, in the Democratic whirlwind that swept New York State, by a plurality of about 887,000, a record for a Democratic candidate in this State.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 8. -- The Patchogue and Westhampton High School junior varsity football teams battled to a scoreless tie today.

Thousands of ballots intended for Mayor Joseph V. McKee were wasted yesterday by voters. Some could not find the slide in which to write his name, many were not tall enough to reach the slide, others locked it by inadvertently throwing the lever over the name of one of the duly nominated Mayoralty candidates and hundreds forgot to bring pencils.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Two Philadelphians were arrested today on charges of robbery growing out of the hold-up of the First National Bank of Florence, N.J., seven weeks ago.

The Forgotten Man went last night to Times Square to see what it was that he had done. To the number high in the tens of thousands, he wandered slowly up and down Broadway, complacently tooting a small tin horn in honor of the newest national hero.

Samuel Insull Jr., son of the Chicago utilities promoter who is now in a hospital in Athens awaiting extradition to the United States, returned yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic to resume his duties as vice president of the Mid-West Utilities Company, in which he has been retained by the receiver.

Pointing for its traditional encounter with New York University at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday, the Fordham football squad was sent through one of the most intensive practice sessions of the season at Fordham Field yesterday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Taking Premier R.B. Bennett at his word that his government stands or falls by the four trade treaties negotiated at the imperial conference, Mackenzie King threw out a direct challenge tonight for an election.

Reports of the Presidential election were broadcast from virtually every radio station, large and small, last night as rapidly as they became available from the compilations of newspapers and news services. Listeners throughout the world were able to follow the returns almost from minute to minute.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Nov. 8. -- Bishop McConnell of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal Church and president of the Federal Council of Churches of America, will be principal speaker at a dinner Armistice Day evening at St. James Church here for officials of Methodist churches in eighteen South Shore communities.

LOUISVTLLE, Nov. 8. -- About a million Kentuckians voted today and went home to listen to the results of the election in the other forty-seven States, mindful that the national result might be known even before any Kentucky votes are counted.
Striking with unexpected swiftness in the opening two minutes of play, De Witt Clinton's eleven smashed through for a touchdown and turned back Stuyvesant, 6 to 0, at the Yankee Stadium, yesterday.

Complaints of intimidation and interference with voters, fraudulent voting, repeating, use of force against voters and even bribery poured in all day yesterday to officials and voluntary groups undertaking to insure an honest vote, but the complaints resulted in only a small number of arrests despite the large number of official and voluntary watchers at the polls.
The Democratic national, State and city tickets swept New York City in yesterday's elections with the greatest pluralities in the city's history.
BERLIN, Nov. 8 (AP). -- George Sylvester Viereck, American author and editor who has been in a hospital receiving treatment for heart trouble, left the institution today, fully recovered.

Returns from 282 out of 3,794 election districts in New York City, and from 160 out of 5,043 election districts outside New York, indicated early this morning that Proposition No. 1, asking approval for a bond issue of $30,000,000 for the relief of the unemployed, was overwhelmingly approved by a majority in the State estimated at 1,643,465, with a probable majority in New York City alone of 565,306.

Earle B. Babcock, assistant director of the European Centre of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, arrived from Europe yesterday on the French liner Paris to make his annual report to the endowment organization here.
PASADENA, Cal., Nov. 8 (AP). -- Eruption of volcanoes and the building of the earth's mountain ranges may be the work of radium, Benjamin Holzman, geologist, suggested here today.

CONCORD, N.H., Wednesday, Nov. 9. -- Although President Hoover was apparently carrying New Hampshire by a margin of less than 5,000 votes over Governor Roosevelt and although Governor John G. Winant was elected to a third term over his Democratic opponent, Henri T. Ledoux, Senator George Higgins Moses, Republican stalwart of the Granite State, went down to defeat at the hands of former Governor Fred H. Brown, Democrat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest in THE TIMES that twenty-one banks have subscribed to Walter Teagle's worksharing plan. In my opinion this is the most constructive piece of relief work that has been put into action during this economic crisis.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8. -- Head Coach Mal Stevens today launched the only scheduled scrimmage of the week for the Yale eleven, the coaches sending the varsity through a long and strenuous session against the scrubs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- With nearly one-half of California's total vote tabulated, Governor Roosevelt led President Hoover by nearly 3 to 2. It seemed certain tonight the State's electoral vote of 22 was in the Democratic column. Figures indicated a Roosevelt plurality of more than 300,000 in a total vote of about 2,100,000.

A 19-year-old youth was killed and a repairer of voting machines who had spent the day rushing with a police escort to various polling places was injured together with his chauffeur last night in two automobile accidents within the city.

More than 150 persons attended the 124th Assembly of the Colonial Daughters of the seventeenth century at Plymouth Institute, Orange and Hicks Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. Dr. Wallace Nutting, author, lecturer and authority on early American furniture, was the guest speaker.

Putting aside for the moment candidates and personalities, the overwhelming defeat of the Republican party yesterday is one of those events which come at rare intervals to satisfy one's sense of poetic justice. If ever such an emphatic rebuke to a political organization was warranted, it was in this instance.

Forty players competed yesterday afternoon in the opening round of the mixed pair contract bridge championship of New York State at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The tournament is being held under the auspices of the Metropolitan Contract Bridge League.

OTTAWA, Nov. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The easing of money and credit in Canada has become necessary, Premier Bennett told the House of Commons today, explaining the borrowing of $35,000,000 from the chartered banks.

Among transactions announced in Manhattan yesterday by real estate brokers were leases of space in buildings for business occupancy. Although most of the trading was done in the midtown section, other areas were fairly well represented.

The Junior League of Brooklyn, of which Miss Dorothy Remsen Johnson is president, held an election night party last evening in the ballroom of the Towers, Brooklyn.
