Red, white and blue streamers, flags and posters of the candidates decorated the room. Up-to-the-minute election returns were flashed on a screen during the evening, while a Meyer Davis orchestra, with Joe Moss, played for dancing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Half of President Hoover's Cabinet was absent from Washington while the elections proceeded throughout the nation today. Secretary Stimson, remaining here, was the nominal head of the government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- In a seven-to-four decision today the Interstate Commerce Commission refused to excuse the New York Central Railroad from the obligation to take over the Chicago, Attica Southern, one of the short lines required to be acquired by the Central under the commission's conditional approval of the Central's acquisition of the Big Four.

Trading was suspended on all the important exchanges and business generally was curtailed in the financial centres yesterday because of the national election. The only markets that functioned were those in foreign countries. Business in the United States will be resumed today as usual.

Everything is set for the opening of the New Jersey hunting season tomorrow. Members of the Fish and Game Commission expect that close to 250,000 licenses will be issued, in which event last year's mark will be surpassed by several thousand.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (Science Service by Mail). -- The addition of minute quantities of certain ferments will preserve caviar from decomposing in the absence of chemical antiseptics, Mme, Jermoljewa, a woman scientist at the Bach Institute for Biochemistry at Moscow, has found.

The decision of the United States Supreme Court ordering new trials for seven Negroes condemned to death at Scottsboro, Ala., on charges of attacking two white girls, was hailed yesterday by the National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners as a vindication of the defense policy of the International Labor Defense.

Thousands of World War heroes and veterans of the Spanish American War, Philippine Insurrection and numerous other campaigns will be permitted, under a recent ruling of the War Department, to wear "a new and impressively beautiful medal," according to the United States Army Recruiting News, which publishes an article describing the new decoration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Operators of lotteries in foreign countries levy a heavy toll on American seekers of "easy money" if the amount intercepted by the Postoffice Department is indicative of that which escapes this net.
City Court Justice Aron Steuer and State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter were elected yesterday over their independent opponents, Bernard S. Deutsch and George W. Alger, by a vote of about 2 to 1.
The Democratic wave of victory yesterday gave that party complete control of Congress and in its onrush carried down to defeat the four Republican leaders of the Senate.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 8. -- Great Neck downed Manhasset, 7 -- 0, today in the ninth annual football game between the schools. Great Neck now holds six victories in the series to two for its rival. The other battle ended in a tie.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Judge Kernochan's arraignment of Tammany brings forcibly to public attention from official authority the practical workings of appointments to exempt positions without the requirement of competitive tests as to fitness and qualifications.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 8 (AP). -- CIosing through the stretch with a fine burst of speed, C.V. Whitney's Skirl a 5-year-old son of Broomstick and Pigeon Wing, took first money in the Dixie Terminal Purse, feature today at Latonia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of comments on the subject of the recent loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for housing in the Bronx, I call attention to a view of the situation which is generally lost sight of.

The dietitians of America are considering a new attack on unhealthful eating habits, tempting people to eat correctly by means of flavor, Edith Barber, home economics consultant, said yesterday at a "flavor luncheon" at the fifteenth annual meeting of the American Dietetic Association.
Complete control of the next Congress by forces opposed to Federal prohibition was one of the results which came with the political upheaval that took place with yesterday's election.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Mr. Dunbar left for Chicago this morning immediately after receiving word that his wife had ended her life there.

The German cruiser Karlsruhe will arrive in New York Saturday morning, the first German warship to visit New York since the World War. She is scheduled to reach Quarantine about 6:30 A.M., and until her departure on Thursday, Nov. 17, her officers and crew will be feted by German organizations in New York and New Jersey.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Westchester County continued its adherence to the Republican party in the election, today by giving President Hoover a plurality of about 10,000 votes over Governor Roosevelt, but a strong trend toward Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, a resident of the county, gave a victory to the Democratic candidate for Governor by a margin of 458 votes, according to tabulations made at party headquarters.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 8 (AP). -- Warm Springs, which nestles in the hills of Meriwether County in Southwest Georgia, watched and waited with great interest today for balloting on Franklin D. Roosevelt, the man who made it famous.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Discussion of probable Cabinet places occupied the attention of Democrats in the national committee headquarters tonight as the early returns forecast the election of Governor Roosevelt.

PARIS, Nov. 8. -- The Paris Bourse was irregular today but showed underlying firmness. Opening strong, the market gave way in selling attacks which brought general declines, but toward the closing a rally occurred and prices finished at about yesterday's final levels or slightly above.
In a citation that went with the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters which she received from Russell Sage College in 1929 Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was described as follows:

The French-bred 6-year-old, Golden Meadow, bearing the gold and purple of the Sanford Stud Farms, scored such a decisive and impressive victory in the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase, feature of the United Hunts program yesterday at Belmont Park, that many horsemen already are comparing him to his great stablemate, Tourist II.

The slender working majority of two votes by which the Republicans control the present State Senate was swept away in yesterday's Democratic landslide. The next Senate will be made up of 25 Republicans and 26 Democrats, giving the Democrats a majority of one.

Dr. Alexander Alekhine, world's chess champion, engaged 200 opponents on fifty boards at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night. A crowd of 1,000 persons witnessed the matches, in which the titleholder pitted his skill against the consultation play of teams representing several colleges, high schools and chess clubs.'
WEST ORANGE, Nov. 8. -- West Orange High easily defeated Glen Ridge High, 25-0, today for the home eleven's tenth consecutive triumph over its election day rival.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Tammany's candidate, was elected Mayor of New York yesterday, but over-shadowing his victory, which was a foregone conclusion, was the tremendous "write-in" vote cast for Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee.

While flames raged all around them in their home on the top floor of a three-story apartment and store building at 21-09 Astoria Avenue, Astoria, Queens, a mother and her three children, one of them suffering from pneumonia, were rescued early this morning by firemen after the mother had been made unconscious by smoke inhalation and two of the children had been burned about the hands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- News that Governor Roosevelt had apparently been elected President started keen rivalry between the Army and Navy Air Services, for it is generally believed here that Mr. Roosevelt will take full advantage of his position as Commander-In-Chief of the armed forces and make frequent use of the service airplanes.

Five hundred unemployed "white collar" workers from the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau will open the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee's $15,000,000 fund-raising effort for the relief of the unemployed needy tomorrow by beginning the distribution of 750,000 pamphlets carrying the committee's appeal to the business offices and homes of the city.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8. -- Perfectly suited to the heavy going, the Wheatley Stable's Dark Secret romped home to win the $5,000 added Bowie Handicap at Pimlico today. The Shandon Farms' Evergold, another good mudder, finished second, while W.W. Vaughan's Canron was a distant third.
Columbia's football team had one of its longest and most grueling practices of the year yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Brown's undefeated eleven here on Saturday.

If it be true that the Presidential campaign has been making both spirits and business hesitant, that obstacle to a better feeling and brighter hope is now removed. Unbought and uncoerced millions of American citizens have given, expression to the national will.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, gratified with the unusually large Socialist vote indicated in early returns, tonight fired the following parting shot as he left for his New York home:

Although railroad equipment trust certificates to the amount of nearly $4,000,000,000 have been sold to American investors in the last fifty years, there has been no loss of any consequence despite many railway receiverships, acording to Salomon Bros. Hutzler, who issued yesterday a report of a survey which they had made.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 (AP). -- In his first speech since the Reichstag election Sunday Chancellor Franz von Papen declared today that the new French disarmament plan apparently afforded a basis for discussion.

Robert Ferdinand Wagner's career epitomizes the American success story. He came to this country with his parents from Germany When he was 8 years old. Born at Nastatten in the Province of Hessen June 8, 1877, he was unable to speak the English language when he entered Public School 83 in East 110th Street.

One time Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars sat in a Rio de Janeiro hotel room staring at a hungry, crimson and gold-ringed serpent and wondering how to feed it. The snake wanted some small, fresh-water fish or, if those could not be obtained, some frogs.
Brooklyn's traditional rivals, Boys High and Alexander Hamilton, resumed their football series yesterday in their twenty-sixth annual meeting, Boys High trouncing its opponent, 51-0.

Thirteen points scored by Sid Luckman, versatile sophomore quarter-back, in the second half enabled the undefeated Erasmus Hall High School eleven to conquer its traditional election day football rival, Manual Training High, 13 to 7, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
SACRAMENTO., Cal., Nov. 8 (AP). -- The text of President Hoover's address here today follows:

PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 8 (AP). -- When the announcement of President Hoover's conceding came tonight a throng of Stanford University students filled his driveway. They waited opportunity to stage a rally for him.

An intercepted forward pass gave Manhattan College's green-jerseyed eleven a hard-earned victory over City College at the Polo Grounds yesterday in the eighth game of the series between the intracity rivals.

M. William Bray, New York State's Lieutenant Governor-elect, at 43 is an experienced leader in State Democratic affairs. He was State Democratic chairman for two years and has long been a strong supporter and friend of former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

Resolutions and petitions for fourteen public improvements will be considered tomorrow at a meeting of the Newtown Local Board in the County Court House, Long Island City. There also will be a joint meeting of the Newtown and Jamaica local boards to consider regulating, grading and crosswalks in Nassau Boulevard from Queens Boulevard to the Nassau County line.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (AP). -- At the climax of an echoing reception here, before he sped on to Palo Alto, President Hoover told a throng that there has been a "turn in the economic tide so great that I felt justified in coming home to vote with you, my neighbors."

The people of New York State have declared in an unmistakable manner that the high tradition of integrity, ability and social conscience which has ruled in the Executive Chamber at Albany for a decade and a half shall be preserved. HERBERT H. LEHMAN exemplifies to a conspicuous degree that combination of heart and mind which the office of Governor of New York demands.

Newtown captured the Division 2 P.S.A.L. golf crown with an undefeated record in eight starts by blanking Richmond Hill, 3 -- 0, as both teams closed their regular league schedules over the Forest Park Golf Club course yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 8. -- The Republicans retained their control of Suffolk County, according to the complete returns tonight, although the margin of their superiority was decreased in comparison with previous years. President Hoover carried the county by 9,431 votes.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 8. -- Wisconsin broke loose from its traditional Republican moorings today and gave Franklin D. Roosevelt a majority over Herbert Hoover that may exceed 300,000. It was the first time since 1912 that it has failed to back the Republican nominee.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 8. -- Dartmouth's football team again was at full strength today with the return of Bill Clark, sophomore halfback. The Cornell game, the season's wind-up, will find every varsity man ready for duty.

John Gilbert, moving picture actor, arrived yesterday in the White Star liner Majestic with his bride, Virginia Bruce, a film actress. They have been abroad for four weeks, mostly in England, and returned with the parents of the bride, Mr. and Mrs. Earl F. Briggs.

LONDON, Oct. 31. (Science Service by Mail). -- Fading of radio signals so annoying to most broadcast listeners and especially to fans specializing on long-distance receptions, promises to help meteorologists to make weather forecasts. This is pointed out by Professor R.C. Colwell, of the Department of Physics of West Virginia University, in a communication to Nature, the British scientific journal.

FOOTBALL coaches, scouts, officials and fans were gathered in a group discussing their favorite topic. Good players were mentioned and there was agreement among the younger men that Ernie Nevers was just about the best all-around player they had ever seen. Some of the older debaters were still cheering for Jim Thorpe, the big Indian of other years.

In Madison Square Garden today the National Horse Show Association will open its forty-seventh annual exhibition. For seven days admirers of the show horse in competition will have opportunities to witness some of the most noted specimens of numerous types put through their paces in the ring.

Observance of the Armistice anniversary Friday in Kings County again will be marked by the traditional two-minute cessation of all activity by citizens at 11 A.M., according to a special proclamation by Borough President Hesterberg of Brooklyn.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 8. -- President Hoover conceded his defeat in a telegram of congratulations to Governor Roosevelt tonight just as students of Stanford University had gathered before the Hoover home to serenade him and Mrs. Hoover as they did four years ago when the election went Republican.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8. -- President-elect Alessandri today cabled to Gustavo Rosso, Chilean financier in Paris, that the government here will not allow closing of the plants of Borax Consolidated, operating in Northern Chile.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Sixty-one Federal buildings, each representing an outlay of more than $1,000,000, were under contract at the end of October, according to a progress report issued by the Treasury Department today.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York announced yesterday that it had filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application for the extension through 1935 of the commodity rates between points in the Eastern Official Classification territory which were granted by the commission last year.

The study of place-names is something more than a harmless hobby, in the opinion of Lewis H. Chrisman, Professor of English Literature at West Virginia Wesleyan College, Buckhannon. In fact, it has in it possibilities of "humanizing and vitalizing" classroom work in history, geography and language.
Roosevelt Statement. President-elect Roosevelt gave the following statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES early this morning:

The Socialist party appeared to have increased materially its vote in the nation yesterday, with a total of perhaps as much as 1,500,000 votes for Norman Thomas, its candidate for President, and James H. Maurer, his running mate.

Green Cheese, Barometer and Rideaway, three of the best known steeplechasers in training, have been entered for the Llangollen National Steeplechase Handicap, $3,500 added feature of the hunts meet to be held Saturday on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Whitney, Upperville, Va., it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, the wife of the Governor-elect of New York, is a native of California. While she lived at and near San Francisco she swam, rode, played tennis and cultivated all outdoor sports. Before her marriage she was Miss Edith Altschul.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Senator Claude A. Swanson, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Committee, in charge of Democratic headquarters, tonight issued the fallowing statement:

BERLIN, Nov. 8. -- Trading was unusually heavy on the Boerse today and prices displayed marked strength throughout. Stocks as well as bonds rose substantially above yesterday's levels, Rheinishe Braunkohlen leading the list with an advance of 8 per cent.

Several card parties will be held this afternoon and evening in behalf of charitable organizations. Many tables have been reserved for the bridge in aid of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation Fund, to be held in the afternoon in the roof garden of the St. Regis.

NEW ASHFORD, Mass., Nov. 8 (AP). -- The little town of New Ashford, nestled deep in the Berkshire hills of Western Massachusetts, again today claimed the honor of being the first community in the country to report its Presidential vote.

Buyers of iron and steel who have displayed "pre-election hesitancy" since the middle of October did little in the last few days, with the result that business suffered noticeably, according to a summary of market conditions announced yesterday by Iron Age.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt left the Biltmore Hotel late last night, declining to make any statement concerning her husband's election until he himself had done so, according to The Associated Press.
Leases predominated in what little activity there was in the real estate market yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 8. -- Miss Mary D. Brooks gave a luncheon in the Homestead today in honor of Mrs. C.A. Hamilton and Miss Josephine A. Kelly. Her other guests were Mrs. William Talbott and Mrs. William Welch Collin. Mrs. Collin, with her daughters, the Misses Katherine F. and Georgia Anne Collin, gave a dinner in the Homestead this evening.

Interpretative comment on the outcome of the election by a group of political analysts, edtors and journalists of New York was carried last night over WEAF-WJZ nation-wide networks from the studios of the National Broadcasting Company during the height of the incoming bulletins.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Financial resolutions submitted to Parliament by the government today are designed to modify the troublesome means test. The resolutions are based on the findings of the Royal Commission on Unemployment Insurance that presented its report yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The national capital was perhaps the quietest city in the country during the day. Voteless Washington was awaiting the returns of the election, with thousands on the anxious seat lest their jobs disappear with a change of administration.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 8. -- Plans for a $7,200,000 housing project, involving a $4,800,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of which the corporation is declared to have given "informal approval," were announced today by Nathan Harris, architect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Money circulation in October declined $26,000,000, as compared with an increase of $293,000,000 in the same month last year, the Treasury announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Not even the cloud - obscured skies of the Republican party today could dampen the buoyancy of Mrs. Dolly Gann, champion, woman campaigner of the year.

A conference of the world's copper producers probably will be held here in the latter part of this month, James Y. Murdoch, president of the Noranda Mines, Ltd., of Canada, said yesterday. He arrived here on Tuesday from Europe on the Majestic. Representatives of the Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., and the Rhokana Corporation of Africa probably would attend the conference, he added.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The government revealed tonight its plans for removing some irritations in connection with the administration of the highly contentious "Means test," which originally was designed to prevent payment of a full dole to unemployed persons of substance.

The fact that George Tuttle Brokaw, lawyer and son of the late Isaac Vail Brokaw, and his wife, Mrs. Clare Boothe Brokaw, made an agreement when they were living apart in 1929 that each should have the custody of their daughter, Ann Clare Brokaw, then 5 years old, for six months periods was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday when Mrs. Brokaw applied to have the court rule on the question of the child's custody.
Another national election, a vote for a national tree, was announced yesterday by the National Life Conservation Society, a woman's organization with headquarters here.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- Yale football coaches today continued their policy of tapering off the practice until the squad departs Friday for the game in Princeton.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Millard Draudt, veteran Princeton half-back, who has been out of action since the Cornell game three weeks ago, will not see service against Yale on Saturday, it became known today. The aggravation of a neck injury resulted in his loss to the Tigers for the final contest with the Elis in Palmer Stadium.

ROME, Italy, Nov. 9 -- Dean Clarence W. Mendell of Yale College, who is here on Sabbatical leave, denied today that he had been offered the presidency of Princeton University as the successor to Dr. John Grier Hibben, who resigned as president of the university last June.

With a brilliant performance, perfect save for half a fault, the Canadian Army team carried off the two silver trophies in the class for international officers' pairs of junipers, which was the notable event on the evening program of the forty-seventh annual National Horse Show which opened yesterday in Madison Square Garden.
BERLIN, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A government spokesman said today that "the American people have chosen a first-class man for the nation's highest honor."

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 9 -- Snapping back into the Democratic column, from which it strayed in 1928, Tennessee gave a sweeping victory to Governor Roosevelt, and elected a Democratic Governor, Railroad Commissioner and seven of the nine members of Congress by decisive figures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President-elect Roosevelt and the still unannounced members of his Cabinet can expect sincere, non-partisan cooperation from President Hoover and his official family in becoming acquainted with the complexities of their jobs between now and March 4, according to all indications here today.

Declaring that definite evidence has been brought to light this year of fraudulent election practices previously suspected but never proved, executives of the election frauds bureau of the Hoover engineers' committee urged yesterday the setting up of a permanent non-partisan body to deal with the problem between elections and thus be able to handle it more effectively at election time.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Bowing right and left inside his gilded coach, Sir Percy Greenaway rode through densa throngs today as successor to Dick Whittington and new Lord Mayor of London.

Nine persons were injured shortly after 10 o'clock last night when a bomb exploded in a chimney in the double wall between a four-story tenement house at 545 Grand Street and a three-story private house at 547-549 Grand Street. Both buildings were badly damaged by the blast, which routed several families from the tenement.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The United States' tremendous renunciation of Republican doctrines and many outstanding leaders was greeted today in France as marking the end of an epoch, which collapsed, it is said here, because it was founded, on selfish interest, suspicion and materialism.

Re-election of Senator WAGNER was based on personal merit and solid achievement. Step by step he has advanced from the lowest to the highest office that one of foreign birth can hold, filling every position with quiet fidelity and industry, making himself master of the tasks which came to his hand.

Fewer failures of retailers and manufacturers were mainly responsible for a sharp decline in the total number of business defaults for the week ended Nov. 3, according to Bradstreet's. The retail failures numbered 296, against 303 in the preceding week, while those of manufacturers dropped 10 to 40.

HAMILTON, Ont., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Walter Masters and Rolf Carlsten, two former Pennsylvania backfield stars who have become famous in Canadian amateur rugby, were banished today from the Interprovincial Rugby Union on the grounds that they were both professionals.
James A. Farley, Democratic National chairman, announced yesterday that he would start a campaign soon to clear up the committee's deficit, reported to be about $200,000, before Jan. 1.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic nominee for Governor, continued yesterday, as on election night, to lead his party associates, as more complete returns were received, and the few districts missing in the returns on President and Governor made it certain that he would continue to lead in the official canvass.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 -- The Soviet Union, receives the Democratic victory in the United States with calm slightly tinged with gratification and hope. Ever since the days of President Wilson the Bolsheviki have "heard" that a new administration would be likely to take a different attitude toward them, but each time they have been disappointed.

ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- After broadcasting a message to the nation, avowing that his election was a victory for liberal thought in the country. Governor Roosevelt came home tonight o settle down to his tasks as Chief Executive of the State.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Kay Hammond, actress, the daughter of Sir Guy Standing, was married today to Ronald Leon. partner in Leon Brothers, stockbrokers.

Sales of General Motors cars by dealers to consumers in the United States in October totaled 26,941 units, against 34,694 in September and 49,042 in October, 1931, it was announced yesterday. At the same time the inventories of dealers were sharply curtailed, the corporation selling only 5,810 cars to dealers last month, against 23,545 in September and 21,305 in October, 1931.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 9 -- President Hoover began today the consideration of his course of action up to and after March, 4, when he will retire from the White House as a result of yesterday's decision by the electorate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- The wheat trade was thrown into confusion for a brief time this afternoon by reports that an order in bankruptcy had been signed against the Manitoba wheat pool. However, trade leaders believed the markets neither here nor in Canada would be affected, feeling that the action was only of minor importance as a market factor.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Stock Exchange opened strong today. Under the influence of the American election interest centred in the international group. Dealings started as soon as the session opened, with rises general and in most cases well maintained, although there were a few reactions on profit-taking in the afternoon.

Senator MOSES got his political sunset six years earlier than he had expected. If he will write his memoirs with his accustomed frankness and publish them for the entertainment of his contemporaries, and not defer them for the imperfect appreciation of posterity, the loss of his seat may be a gain for the rest of us.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Republican leaders in Nassau County were receiving congratulations today on their feat in carrying the county for all of their candidates, notwithstanding the Democratic landslide which swept over most parts of the country.

Addtional plans have been filed with the State Board of Housing for model apartments proposed for erection in the New York area with the aid of loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and the work involved in the projects now listed in the applications would represent an expenditure of about $170,000,000, it was made known yesterday.

Seventy-eight variations of the name of Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee were written in on the voting machines Tuesday, a recapitulation showed yesterday. Many of them were obviously the result of inability by voters with large or awkrward handwriting to complete the name in the small spaces provided.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Holding that the present Congress has no mandate from the electorate on prohibition, Republican Senate leaders are planning to prevent action in the coming session on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and modification of the Volstead act.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- During the celebration welcoming President-elect Roosevelt to this city this evening a sedan in which Mrs. J. Roosevelt Roosevelt of Hyde Park, aunt of the President-elect, crashed into a telegraph pole when it was struck by a hit-and-run driver.

The annual Victory Ball, which in recent years has won an international reputation, by its distinguished patronage and brilliant military ceremonial, will take place tonight in the grand, ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Always regarded as one of the most spectacular of the celebrations in New York in commemoration of the Armistice, the ball again will aid the relief work of the New York County Welfare Committee among dependents of disabled ex-service men.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 9 -- The Ohio Public Utilities Commission today authorized the Toledo Edison Company to refinance its first-mortgage bonds and to issue and sell $27,500,000 of first-mortgage 5 per cent onds. It held a brief hearing in which John M. MacMillen and Dale B. Carson, representatives of Henry L. Doherty Co. of New York, were the principal witnesses.

Although the share market did not act yesterday as if Wall Street was surprised by the election result, the decline after the early upswing indicated that the uncertainty which prevailed during the campaign had not been entirely dispelled. By canceling its early gains and ending the day with substantial net losses, the market gave indications also of its sensitiveness to post-election realizing.

Six teams wall ring up the curtain tonight for the 1932-33 season of the National Hockey League. With every sextet strengthened by new players, and with the addition of the Ottawa Senators to the circuit, officials of the league look forward to a successful season.

One of the largest sales of a Westchester housing property was announced yesterday, when the Sagamore Apartments in Bronxville were acquired by the Cleveland Holding Corporation, William A. Daly, president. The deal, which was the outstanding feature of a quiet market in the metropolitan area, was negotiated by Brooks, Harvey Co., brokers, for the Manhattan Savings Institution.

Confidence that the decisive verdict registered by the people of the United States on Tuesday would have a beneficial effect on business and relief that the long period of election uncertainty is over were voiced yesterday by prominent figures in many lines of industry.

Although it had erred in five States by giving Massachusetts, New Jersey and Rhode Island to President Hoover and Pennsylvania and Delaware to Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, the quadrennial straw ballot of The Literary Digest proved yesterday to be within two votes of having accurately forecast the electoral vote for President.

The arbitration board which has been considering testimony to determine the wages and hours of printers employed by the New York newspapers completed the hearings on the case yesterday at a meeting in The Times Annex.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Despite the favorable reception in France of news of Governor Roosevelt's election the Bourse today failed to produce the rally that was expected. Instead, the session was inactive, with the tendency steadily downward and closing prices on the day's lows.

"Autumn Crocus," the C.L. Anthony play which has been successfully produced in London, is the latest addition to next week's list of theatrical openings. It will be presented at the Morosco Theatre on Saturday evening, Nov. 19. In all, eleven premieres are scheduled, making it the most active week of the season to date.
One of the better-known assistant coaches of the East, a man who has done a great deal of scouting in football, was speaking not long ago of the forward pass.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- With Illinois more solidly Democratic than at any time since the Civil War, Governor Roosevelt appeared to have carried the State by more than 426,000. For Governor of Illinois, Henry Horner, Democrat, apparently will lead Len Small, Republican, by 543,000.

GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- Although Secretary Stimson will lose officers a result of the American elections, this defeat is not deemed here in any sense a defeat for the Stimson doctrines of non-recognition of the fruits of aggression, consultation when war threatens and abandonment of the neutral rights dogma.

Persevering until 4:05 o'clock, in the morning in a nerve-trying ordeal that endured for more than twelve hours. Dr. Alexander Alekhine, world's chess champion, held the satisfaction yesterday of having beaten the record set by Jose R. Capablanca, famous Cuban master and former titleholder, for what is generally conceded to be the most difficult form of all simultaneous chess exhibitions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Jules Audy, 18-year-old rider from Montreal, and William (Torchy) Peden of Vancouver last night won Chicago's twenty-eighth international six-day bicycle race, defeating the Italian-American pair of Alfredo Binda and Norman Hill, in a sensational finish at the Chicago Stadium.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 -- Governor Roosevelt's victory in Michigan yesterday broke an eighty-year record. It was the first time the State, often called the birthplace of the Republican party has given its electoral vote to a Democrat since it went for Franklin Pierce in 1852.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 9 -- The Brown starting line-up for the Columbia game continued to remain in doubt as Coach Tuss McLaughry put the unbeaten Bears through a, hard three-hour workout today.

For the first part of his term, at any rate, President ROOSEVELT will not be hampered by lack of a working majority in Congress. So greatly increased is Democratic representation in both House and Senate that the majority may almost be said to be "over-working."

White Plains, N.Y. Details of the issue of $2,534,000 of bonds which the city of White Plains, N.Y., plans to award through competitive bidding on Nov. 21 were disclosed yesterday. The issue will comprise $1,099,000 of public improvement bonds, due from 1934 to 1943, and $1,435,000 of school bonds, due serially from 1939 to 1966.

Mayor-elect John P. O'Brien will continue his duties as Surrogate of New York County until he is sworn into office as Mayor Jan. 1, he announced yesterday. His spare time, however, he declared, would he devoted to study of the city's problems so that when he assumes the office to which he has been elected he will be fully conversant with them.

There will be an abundance of pheasant shooting when the season opens in New Jersey today, according to advices from many parts of the State. The State Game and Fish Commission has distributed thousands of birds.

Vincent Walsh, 19 years old, on trial with three other youths in General Sessions on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Patrolman Joseph E. Burke in a Harlem speakeasy hold-up last June, testifying in his own defense yesterday, admitted the killing, but said it was accidental.

ALFRED, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Dr. Paul Emerson Titsworth, president of Washington College in Chestertown, Md., has accepted the presidency of Alfred University and will take office on July 31, 1933, when President Davis resigns at the age of 70.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Signs of approaching economic recovery already are appearing, Premier Herriot declared today in addressing the National Economic Council, which he asked to assist in preparing a program to combat the depression.

Dr. William Bartlet Brebner, Assistant Professor of Bacteriology at the New York University and Bellevue Medical School, died yesterday in Belleuvue Hospital of infection resuiting from a monkey bite received in the city Health Department laboratories on Oct. 24. He was 29 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Following today's signal drill on rainsoaked Franklin Field, Coach Harvey Harman selected the Pennsylania players who will make the trip to Columbus for the intersectional battle with Ohio State on Saturday.

Eighty years of sensational discoveries in medicine have added twenty years to the life expectancy of babies, but only thirty-six days to the life expectancy of men and women who are now 35 years old, Paul de Kruif, popularizer of medical knowledge, who wrote "Microbe Hunters" and helped Sinclair Lewis gather material for "Arrowsmith," writes in "Men Against Death," published today by Harcourt, Brace.

Overcoming an early lead of about 100,000 by Representative Percy H. Stewart, his Democratic opponent, in the contest for the unexpired term of the late Senator Dwight W. Morrow of New Jersey, Senator W. Warren Barbour, Republican incumbent, was practically assured of election yesterday afternoon when he established a plurality of 8,430 with only 29 election districts missing out of 3,415.

No one but a churlish partisan could have failed to feel a glow of satisfaction on reading President HOOVER'S telegram to Governor ROOSEVELT. It was manly, handsome and patriotic. Still reeling under the heavy blows of the election, the President sent sincere good wishes to the President-elect, and made in effect an offer of cooperation.

Speaking yesterday over an N.B. C. radio network, Jules Sauerwein, foreign editor of Paris-Soir of Paris, gave his impressions of the American elections and expressed the hope that the new administration, by a high-spirited and broad-minded policy, would help to promote international understanding and cooperation.
Details of leasing deals were shown in contracts recorded at the Register's Office yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 -- The new Naumberg wing of the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University was dedicated this afternoon, with President Lowell and James N. Rosenberg of New York as the principal speakers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 A cooperative plan whereby the staff and employes of Massachusetts Institute of Technology have undertaken to lay up a reserve against a possible deficit was announced today by President Karl T. Compton following a meeting of the faculty.

Reporting an increase of more than $4,690,000 since June 1 in the deposits of the midtown office of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, Walter H. Bennett, president, said yesterday that no business depression seemed to be great enough to destroy the ability of those still at work to set aside a regular profit between earnings and Jiving expenses.

WARSAW, Nov. 9 -- Commenting on the election of Governor Roosevelt to be the next President of the United States, the Foreign Office told your correspondent today that Poles were glad the party that had counted among its members President Woodrow Wilson and Edward M. House was returning to power.

The Abbey Theatre Irish Players this afternoon will repeat their performances of "Riders to the Sea" and "The Playboy of the Western World," both by J.M. Synge. Tonight they will play "The Things That Are Caesar's," by Paul V. Carroll.

Election Reduced Buyers' Total. Due to the election, the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended Tuesday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The Wiener Sangerknaben immediately captivated a large audience last night at the Cohan Theatre by beginning their program, not with the first number, but with a performance of the "Star-Spangled Banner" in English beguilingly quaint. As the capacity audience got to its feet, and the twenty-one youngsters, grouped each side the piano, informed one that "ze flak, vass stillzere," it was easy to see that the house was theirs before the concert began.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- There is already in preparation for Cabinet approval a note to be sent by the British Government to the Washington government in the near future concerning the war debt instalment due from this country to the United States Dec. 15.

Funds for the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee are helping to rehabilitate those in distress and preparing them for a return to normal employment when present conditions have eased, Mrs. Vincent Astor, a leader of the women's divition, declared last night over station WOR.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 9 -- The Dodge six-cylinder automobile for 1933 was displayed today to more than 300 representatives of newspapers and trade journals in the factory of the Dodge Brothers Corporation.

Robert Goldsand, youthful Viennese pianist, gave at the Town Hall last night the first of three concerts planned to present most of the masters who wrote for the piano in the last two and a half centuries. The program last night, termed "classic," was exhaustingly generous.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The large preponderance of Democrats in the new House of Representatives will necessitate a general reorganization in committee chairmanships, and at the same time cause a warm contest for the Speakership.
One-family homes and small flats comprised the bulk of yesterday's reported realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area.

Alton. The first railroad to report for October, the Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, showed yesterday an increase of nearly 900 per cent in net income on an annual basis for the month. Gross-revenue was down only slightly.

New York racing in 1933 may bear a sharply different complexion from that in recent years if plans of leading racing men, prominent in, the Jockey Club, which is the governing body of the turf in this State, are completed, it was learned yesterday from a high official.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Satisfied with the continuance of his party in control of Westchester, William L. Ward, Westchester Republican leader for the last thirty-six years, conferred this afternoon with his successful candidates at county headquarters and discussed plans for carrying on the county's business until another election threatens Westchester's Republican rule.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 -- Sylvester W. Labrot's mare Tred Avon, which defeated Equipoise in her previous start, made it four victories in a row today when she galloped easily over a heavy track, to win by four lengths at Pimlico.

PALO ALTO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Hoover, constant companion of the President on his many strenuous campaign trips, today snared with him the quiet of their home, smilingly directing household activities and apparently enjoying the first day in several years hack in home surroundings.

VIENNA, Nov. 9 -- Since a Democratic victory in the United States was inevitable, the general view here is that it is just as well that it was overwhelming, since the size of the victory "Will give the new President an unequivocal mandate and a free hand to take the drastic action necessitated by the world's economic stalemate.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Nadya Alliluieva Stalin, the wife of Joseph Stalin, most powerful figure in all Soviet Russia, died last night.

At a meeting which lasted from noon until after 7 P.M. yesterday, control of the Manhattan Railway Company passed out of the hands of its former board of directors into that of Nathan L. Amster, chairman of the stockholders' protective committee, and his affiliates.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Confident that the election result means the early return of beer, brewers in Milwaukee and St. Paul announced plans today to prepare for its manufacture when legalized.

DUBLIN, Nov. 9 -- The Free State government announced tonight that it would pay bounties on all articles locally manufactured to the equivalent of the duty that will be imposed on them after next Tuesday, When imperial preferences end between Britain and Southern Ireland.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- Favorable news of German industry and the rise in copper prices produced general optimism on the Berlin Boerse today. Bonds continued their upward movement, carrying stocks along. The result of the American elections gave further stimulus to the market.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- In the two concluding events of the Yale Fall regatta today the freshman heavyweight crew defeated the winning varsity 150-pound boat and the winning class oarsmen in New Haven Harbor, and the crew captained by Charley Tenney won the race in which the four varsity eights competed at Derby.
HAVANA, Nov. 9 -- The hurricane that has been ravaging shipping on the Caribbean Sea for several days struck Cuba this morning and is known to have taken at least twelve lives.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 -- Harvard's first and second elevens each engaged in a thirty-minute offensive and defensive scrimmage against the scrubs in a driving rain today.

J. Seward Johnson, who sailed his 6-meter sloop Jill in English waters last Summer as a member of the victorious British-American Cup team from this country, and who afterward recaptured the Seawanhaka Cup with the Jill on the Clyde, has chartered the 12-meter Cantitoe for next season and will race her on Long Island Sound.

Ignoring a recommendation of John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, Acting Mayor MoKee yesterday moved to make his own appointment to a vacancy in the magistrates court in Brooklyn, although he said when he assumed the duties of Mayor in September that he would accept the recommendations of the Democratic county leaders when making appointments.

A large retrospective exhibition of paintings by Gari Melchers will open privately today and to the public tomorrow at the American Academy of Arts and Letters, on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets. This work, impressively hung in the large exhibition gallery, and telling the story of an artist's long career from virtually its beginnings to the present day, will remain on view until May 1.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Prices for hogs were higher today, making the sixth successive day of advancing markets which have lifted prices about 60 cents a hundred-weight from, the low of last week. Today's upturn of 10 to 25 cents was regarded as the sharpest of the year. Cold weather, small receipts and better wholesale demand for fresh pork were the main influence.

Prince Basilo Mleischkine and Princess Mleischkine will arrive today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Also on board are Feodor Chaliapin, Russian basso, Princess Eugenia Ruspoli, Baron von Scholl, First Secretary of the Hungarian Legation in Washington, and Philipp Heincken, president of the North German Lloyd.

Richard Washburn Child, former United States Ambassador to Italy and founder of the Council on Foreign Relations, announced yesterday the formation of a committee of holders of external dollar bonds of the various departments, or States and municipalities of the republic of Colombia now in default.
BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- Germany today received the expected news of the forthcoming change in administration in the United States with mingled feelings.

GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- The preparatory commission for the world monetary and economic conference concluded today its first session with the declaration that this "preliminary exchange of views has done much to effect an understanding and agreement with regard to defining the problems with which the conference should deal and analyzing the best means of solving them internationally.

A gale, raging more than fifty-five miles an hour at times, battered the New fork and New Jersey coast all day yesterday and last night, endangering the safety of a family of ten on a leaking houseboat in the New Rochelle harbor, causing widespread property damage, delaying coastal shipping and forcing the complete abandoment of a New Jersey Coast Guard station.

Predicting that Governor Roosevelt will have one of the most successful administrations in history as President, James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, said last night that the President-elect would surround himself with the best men available in the official life of his administration.

Lawyers who backed the independent candidacies of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch for places on the Supreme Court against State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and City Court Justice Aron Steuer, the bi-partisan nominees who were elected, considered yesterday the practicality of establishing a permanent organization.

On the surface Tammany might seem to have cause for satisfaction in the election of Mr. O'BRiEN as Mayor by the largest plurality ever accorded any candidate for that office. For the first time more than a million men and women cast their votes for the organization candidate, whose plurality over Mr. POUNDS, 616,736, exceeded anything either Mr. HYLAN or Mr. WALKER in their heyday, were able to achieved.

If the credit for the nomination for and election of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Presidency belongs to any man besides the Governor himself, that man is Louis McHenry Howe, one-time newspaper man.

The New York Stock Exchange has approved an application by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company for the listing of 55,000 additional shares of common stock, which are to be issued in connection with the acquisition of the assets of the Root Glass Company.
NEW YORK. Mrs. William H. Harkness will give a dinner dance Dec. 3 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for her debutante sister, Miss Eleanor Grant.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 9 -- Captain John J. McEwan, head coach of football at Holy Cross since 1930, today was suspended as coach by the Rev. T.J. Phelan, moderator of athletics.

Millions of American citizens, numbering probably one-third of the total population, went about their normal tasks as usual yesterday after the voting out of the Republican party on Tuesday with a majority at least as great as it received four years ago.

Society was well represented In the boxes at the first night performance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night. There was a brilliant display of gowns and fur coats, and the promenade was animated and colorful with a fashionable crowd of horse enthusiasts.

Basil O'Connor, former law partner of Governor Roosevelt, was named yesterday special master in the Interborough receivership case by Senior Judge Martin T. Manton of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting as a District Court Judge. Mr. O'Connor was directed to pass upon the advisability of having the Interborough receivers pay rental charges, including taxes, bond interest and stock dividends due under the 999-year lease of the elevated lines of the Manhattan Railway Company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- Final Connecticut election returns today showed that Republican electors were chosen at yesterday's vote, that President Hoover had a plurality over Roosevelt of more than 6,000 votes, that Governor Wilbur L. Cross led the entire State and national ticket with a plurality of more than 11,000 and that he was the only member of the Democratic State ticket elected.

Dry leaders refused yesterday to concede that the Democratic landslide which swept many wet candidates into office on Tuesday bad materially changed the prohibition, picture, although representatives of wet organizations jubilantly predicted modification of the Volstead act within a few months.

Hon. Louis Zeltner, former east side Alderman and founder of the New York League of Locality Mayors, looked out at the swirling rain late yesterday afternoon in his office high up in 25 West Forty-fourth Street and outlined the league's coining election plans.
BEVERLY HILLS, Gal., Nov. 9 -- Mr. Hoover, the consolation you have from the whole American people is no doubt greater than that ever shared by a losing President.

Following are the latest returns from the States of polling for Roosevelt and Hoover as compared with the totals at the close of voting in 1928. Many of the States are still incomplete and so exact comparisons are impossible:

The National Transportation Committee is awaiting the receipts of reports from groups interested in adjusting conditions on the railways and highways, Calvin Coolidge, chairman of the committee, said yesterday. Mr. Coolidge issued his statement following a meeting of the committee in its office in the Empire State Building, the first it has held since its organization last month.
Fordham's football team continued its intensive practice at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for its traditional encounter with New York University at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

Tammany pointed yesterday with pride to the vote cast for Surrogate John P. O'Brien for Mayor, holding it indicative of the strength of the organization in the city, but at the same time admitted, by implication, that Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee had been placed in the forefront as a fusion candidate for Mayor next year.

Mournfully viewing the wreckage left by Tuesdays election, Republican leaders yesterday reached the conclusion that their party had been shaken to its very foundations and required rebuilding rather than reorganization. How 'this was to be accomplished and how soon the work was to begin, none of the party leaders here, State or national, were in a position to say.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Kentucky appeared headed tonight toward 100 per cent Democratic representation in Congress for the first time at least since the war between the States.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Republican leaders taking stock today of the heavy damage wrought by the Democratic cyclone that came near to sweeping Pennsylvania from its traditional party foundations yesterday, found that Franklin D. Roosevelt had won twenty-six of the sixty-seven counties, that the number of Democrats in the Congressional delegation, had apparently increased from three to eleven and that the Democrats had nearly tripled their strength in the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Declaring that the mandate, of the electorate yesterday was overwhelmingly in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, with eleven States voting to repeal State prohibition laws, Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, in a statement today reviewed the sweep of the wet movement.

Scrimmaging was the order of the day yesterday at Baker Field as Columbia's football squad went through another intensive practice session in preparation for its meeting on Saturday with the undefeated Brown eleven.

Despite the fact that Harry F. Wolf, national titleholder, was an individual winner in his first appearance in tournament play this season, the New York Athletic Club Class A squash tennis team was beaten last night by the Fraternity Club, 3 to 2.

LONDON. Nov. 9 -- Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, who in the absence of Prime Minister MacDonald spoke for the government at the Lord Mayor's dinner tonight, made a significant allusion to the Hoover disarmament plan and clearly implied that ending of reparations at Lausanne should now be followed by a new deal on war debts.

The issue of $30,000,000 State of New york unemployment relief bonds, largest of the issues to be approved on Tuesday by the voters of various States, is awaited eagerly in investment banking circles in view of the recent paucity of offerings of new high-grade issues.

With little more than a third of the country's election districts heard from, the vote cast for Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, and his running mate, James H. Maurer, were moving close to the record established by the late Eugene V, Debs in 1920, when he polled 920,000.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 9 -- The annexation of six estates in Cold Spring Harbor to the incorporated village of Lloyd Harbor was sought here today in a petition presented to the Huntington town board in behalf of Walter Jennings, vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the owners of adjoining estates.

The Progressive Education Association will hold a regional conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania Nov. 18 and 19, it was announced yesterday, the first of a series of similar meetings to be held in various sections of the country. Educational problems created by present American social and economic conditions will be discussed by educators, administrators, civic leaders and laymen.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9 -- The foreign, relations committee of the Senate recommended today that Congress approve the award made by the King of Italy in February, 1931, declaring Clipperton Island in the Pacific Ocean the property of France.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's first adventure into politics, which began when he accepted the Democratic nomination for Representative in Congress from this district, ended today with a telegram of congratulations to Robert L. Bacon, his Republican opponent.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw hit out emphatically in the House of Lords today at the agreements of the Ottawa Imperial Economic Conference.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 9 -- The afternoon newspapers here devoted their whole front pages to news of and comment on Governor Roosevelt's election to the Presidency.

A sharp break in the value of the Canadian dollar is a reminder that Canadian exchange has been selling at a discount since November, 1930. During these two years average monthly rates have varied from a "high" of 99.9 cents in the Spring of 1931 to a "low" of 82.7 in December of the same year.

In accounting for Governor ROOSEVELT'S plurality of more than 40,000 in New Jersey it would be a mistake not to give special emphasis to unemployment. In many of the factories of that Commonwealth the men and women retained have been working on part time, while a host of others have been idle for from one to two years.

Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman spent his first day as Governor-elect quietly but busily yesterday at his borne at 820 Park Avenpe trying to catch up with his correspondence, responding to congratulations pouring in over the telephone or brought in person by his friends, and watching a huge stack of telegrams of felicitation rise higher hour by hour.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 9 -- One hundred teachers invaded the offices of the Jewish Agency Executive this morning, ocpupied them, stationed guards at the exits, and announced that they would permit no member of the Executive to leave the building until arrears in salary from May to August were paid.

"I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang," produced by Warner Brothers from the autobiography of Robert E. Burns, will be presented at the Strand at 8:30 o'clock this evening. Paul Muni heads thn cast, which includes Glenda Farrell, Noel Francis, Helen Vinson, Preston Foster and Sally Blane.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The Short Hills Club defeated the Montclair A.C., 5 -- 0, in the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League tournament, which opened today.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Eight men were killed by machinegun fire turned on a crowd outside a political meeting at Community Hall, near the University, tonight.

The complete report of the Columbia University committee investigating intercollegiate athletics at Columbia will be made public immediately after it is presented to the president of the university, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler announced yesterday in a statement for The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper.

A destitute youth, arrested after he had hurled a piece of iron through the window of a. cigar store at 572 West 125th Street, was released yesterday in West Side Court when he said he had done it only to attract attention to his condition and offered to pay the damage as soon as he could get a job.
A school teacher returned to her desk yesterday and led her pupils in a discussion of current events. She was Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President-elect.
Anna M. Becker gave to the Bank for Savings a mortgage for 530,000, due Nov. 7, 1937, at 6 per cent on 347-49 E. 53d St.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Combined credit advances by the banks under the jurisdiction of the Federal Farm Loan Board outstanding Sept. 30 amounted to $1,906,639,048 and the assets of these institutions totaled $2,064,526,100, according to a statement by the board today.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- The Italian public followed every phase of the American Presidential election with the closest attention, as any political change in America is of absorbing interest in the present, delicate period of the world situation.

The death of bloc control of Congress and the re-establishment of a strictly party government was assured yesterday as final election returns confirmed early indications that the Democrats had won sweeping victories in both houses.

GROTON, Mass., Nov. 9 -- A clever lateral at the end of a forward pass gave St. Mark's a touchdown and a 7-O triumph oven Groton School in the forty-fourth annual game between the two rivals, played on rain-swept gridiron today.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9 -- La Nacion and other important Argentine newspapers point to the elections in the United States as an example of revolution by ballot instead of bullets, calling attention to the advantages of the North American method of overthrowing an unpopular regime as compared with the South American method of military revolutions.
Voting In the Trenches. It will be much harder to speak of the lazy and indifferent American voter after the example of fortitude and patience given by the people of New York City.

The reputedly suppressed ego of the average bank clerk was encouraged to come into the daylight yesterday by Dr. John Erskine, novelist and educator, in a talk to a number of young men of the financial district sponsored by the Older Boys' Council of the Wall Street Y.M. C.A. The talk was given in the auditorium, of the State Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street.

The minimum amount of nutritive ingredients essential to the maintenance of health from the standpoint of families with strictly limited budgets was outlined yesterday by Miss Lucy Gillett, director of the nutrition bureau of the Association for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor, at the annual convention of the American Dietetic Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The meeting of the board of governors of the League of New York Theatres scheduled for yesterday was postponed until next week, according to Dr. Henry Moskowitz, executive adviser to the league. Among the matters to be discussed will be plans for the renewal of the fight for the removal of the 10 per cent entertainment tax of the Federal government on the legitimate theatres.

Sufficient wet strength in the new Congress to put through a resolution for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, as well as modification of the Volstead act, was indicated more and more last night as the political avalanche of Tuesday continued to gain proportions.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Heavy overnight rains converted the Latonia strip into a virtual sea of mud and today's racing card was riddled with scratches. So many were withdrawn from two of the races, the fifth and eighth, that it was necessary to declare off both and substitute claiming events.

Conjecture and curiosity, which have been fairly active as to what the stock market would do on the actual news of Tuesday's voting, were disposed of yesterday by a moderate decline. At the start, respectable advances were scored over Monday's closing; some of them ranged up to 2 points.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Six insurance companies were named as defendants today in a suit to recover more than $1,000,000 brought in the Federal District Court by a group of Eastern investors headed by Gilbert Mather, head of the Philadelphia firm bearing his name.

Dissension among the directors of the Aviation Corporation of Delaware and North American Aviation, Inc., concerning the proposed acquisition of certain assets of the latter company by the Aviation Corporation developed yesterday into an open conflict when Herbert Bayard Swope, director of North American, announced his resignation as a protest against the alleged secrecy surrounding the deal.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- Belated additional returns from all parts of California tonight raised President-elect Roosevelt's plurality in Mr. Hoover's home State toward the 400,000 mark.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A cotton crop for 1932 of 11,947,000 bales was predicted by the Department of Agriculture today on the basis of conditions as of Nov. 1. This is an increase of 522,000 bales or 4.6 per cent over the crop indicated by conditions a month earlier, but leaves the prospective yield at 5,149,000 bales under that of 1931.

With felicitations In absence from two of its more prominent members, Governor Franklin D. Rosevelt and Nobel Prize Winner John Galsworthy, the Authors' Club celebrated its fiftieth anniversary last night with a dinner at the Hotel Brevoort. Organized at a meeting in the home of Richard Watson Gilder in 1882, the club has a roll of members containing the names of some of the best known writers in the world.

The Musicians Emergency Aid is granting free ticket privileges to its Members for the five festival concerts being held under its auspices this Winter at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel St. Regis in honor of Dr. Walter Damrosch, chairman, who has arranged the concerts, the first of which will be given Nov. 26.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in a letter yesterday to Mayor-elect John P. O'Brien, pledged its cooperation to him, at the same time calling on him to make a survey of the operation of city departments so that waste might be eliminated, and efficiency increased.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10. -- Alberto Hueyo, Minister of Finance, issued today a detailed statement on the finances of the Argentine Republic. It shows that the floating debt on Oct. 31 was 885,600,000 pesos ($227,599,200), compared with 1,267,800,000 pesos ($325,824,600) on Dec. 31, a decrease of $97,225,400.

ROME, Nov. 10. -- The Foglio d'Ordini, official organ of the Fascist party, will announce tomorrow that a decision has finally been reached to have the Italian air force undertake a formation flight to the United States and back next year. The attempt is scheduled for the end of March.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Miss Caroline E. Green, a public school teacher here for many years, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital after an operation. A native of this city, she was the daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth A. Green and the late William H. Green.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Republican leaders are considering the creation of a committee to devise a reorganization program for the party. Recognition of new men, establishment of a liberal legislative program and rehabilitation of the national committee are among the things which are held necessary to revive the faith of electors and make the party virile for the 1936 election.
TORONTO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, champions of the hockey world, and the Boston Bruins played a 1-1 tie tonight in their first game of the new National Hockey League season.

After a final and unsuccessful effort yesterday to conciliate the differences between them, the representatives of the Publishers' Association of New York and Typographical Union 6 notified John T. Saulter, chairman of the arbitration board, that they referred all questions to him for determination.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Loans of $1,125,000 to the Twin Lakes Reservoir and Canal Company of Olney Springs, Col., for construction of a water diversion tunnel and of $45,OOO to Sanford, N.C., for a modern filtration plant were approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The crux of the British proposals which Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, will present to the Disarmament Conference at Geneva next week is that there must be a pact of European States pledging themselves against the use of "force" as a corollary to granting Germany's claim of an equality status.

The last species of flight ducks due to land in this general sector, the Canadian red legs, now can be found along the Connecticut shore and a few of them have drifted over into North Shore Long Island waters.

In spite of the optimism and cheer already manifest among those who brew for profit because of last Tuesday's verdict at the polls, it became evident yesterday that the spirit of dissension was just around the corner. A gap is appearing in the ranks of those opposed to prohibition.

A contest between E.L. Cord, automobile manufacturer, and the present management to gain control of the Aviation Corporation of Delaware loomed yesterday when Mr. Cord's representatives presented a letter to the company's directors asking that a stockholders' meeting be called for Dec. 21 to increase the directors from thirty-five to sixtyeight.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The Jewish teachers of the Palestine educational system gave up their siege of the offics of the Jewish Agency Executive today after they had been assured of a settlement of their demands tomorrow.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Nov. 10. -- Miss Lucille Heizmann Mudgett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Chase Mudgett of Southern Pines, was married tonight to Henry McKenney Dingley Jr. of Auburn, Me. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis Morrissey at the home of the bride's parents.

Results of the various State referenda on Tuesday are of utmost significance for the future of prohibition. The issue was presented on its own merits, without reference to economic discontent, to party preference or to choice of candidates.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- A two-hour offensive drill today featured Princeton's last hard practice session in preparation for the Yale game Saturday. The Tiger attack reached the peak of its form as Bales, James and Kadlic exhibited fine running form and the passing game was consistently effective.

Robert Foresman, who for fifty years was devoted to the musical education of public school children, died in New York Hospital on Wednesday, his 76th birthday, after an operation. He compiled and edited several song books for public school use, his outstanding work being a series of fourteen books known as "The Foresman Books of Songs."

Ivar Kreuger's confidential agent in America, Anders Jordahl, began to unload Kreuger Toll stock through his own brokerage account as soon as Kreuger sailed for Paris last March, according to evidence received yesterday by Henry K. Davis, sitting as Federal referee in the American inquiry into the affairs of Kreuger's bankrupt holding corporation.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- Governor Roosevelt prepared today to invite Democratic leaders of Congress to confer with him at Warm Springs, Ga., on a legislative program designed to be of aid in the nation's economic recovery.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest figure of the year to date. No other important item reached a new high or low figure. In the subjoined comparative table all figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:

To the Editor of The New York Times: One can draw some very interesting conclusions from a study of the financial statement of the City of New York furnished by the Controller's office in connection with the recent bond issue.
Galsworthy's Nobel Prize. The Nobel Prize comes to JOHN GALSWORTHY in deserved recognition of a fine talent united to prodigious industry and a sincere dedication to the profession of letters.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- Andrew Schuttinger's Pilate won his fifth race of the Maryland season when he galloped strongly over a heavy track to victory in the Calvert Purse, feature at Pimlico today.

Two one-man shows of prints and drawings and a group exhibition of water-colors, lithographs pastels and drawings are on view at the New School for Social Research. In the group show, which was selected by Michael E. Landgren, appears work by Thomas Benton, Simeon Braguin, George Constant, Orozco and Mark Tobey, each represented by three or four examples.

Favorable action on dividends concerning which there had been some uncertainty was cited in Wall Street as one of the causes of yesterday's sharp rally on the Stock Exchange. The market had the benefit also of other encouraging developments, including an increase in the unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation.
Here are the latest figures on the Presidential contest, as gathered by The Associated Press, showing that Roosevelt's plurality has crossed the 6,000,000 mark.

HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 10 AP). -- Captain Frledrich Alers and fifteen members of the crew of the Hamburg-South American liner General Osorio received mementoes today from President Hoover for their rescue of eighty-seven passengers from the American steamer Western World Which foundered at Ponta do Boi, Brazil, in August, 1931.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 10 (AP). -- Impish, the consistent son of Peter Pan and Stigma which races for L. Unger, picked up top weight to lead home a select field In today's main attraction at Latonia, the Whistling in the Dark Purse.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- An attorney for the Chicago Board of Trade argued before the Circuit Court of Appeals today that the board had no alternative but to bar the Farmers National Grain Corporation front clearing-house privileges.
GENEVA, Nov. 10. -- Japan's campaign for banning gas reprisals against violators of a ban on gas warfare grained strength in the Disarmament Conference Bureau today.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- From the tribune of the Chamber of Deputies this evening a Socialist, Fabien Albertin, read the names of three Senators, a Bishop, a high army officer, three manufacturers and a director of a newspaper, who, he declared, were implicated in an operation through an intermediary Swiss bank to defraud on revenue.

Voting on the two proposals submitted to the electorate of this State last Tuesday was satisfactory. The relief bond issue was approved, the forest preserve amendment defeated. The $30,000,000 made available to the welfare agencies in this way, supplementing local efforts, will be a "present help in time of trouble."

At no time in the last thirty-six years has there been justifiable ground for doubt as to the ability of this country to maintain the gold standard, Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, declared yesterday in an address before the forum on investment banking of the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- In an effort to compete more effectively with inland water carriers, all railroads touching points served by the Mississippi Barge Lines, the Inland Waterways Corporation and independent barge lines asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to reduce freight rates to 25 per cent above the allwater rates.

The directors of the American Securities Investing Corporation, the so-called bond pool organized by banks here last June under the leadership of J.P. Morgan Co., met yesterday and declared an initial distribution for the first half year of operations of 1 1/2 per cent on the corporation's outstanding income debentures, payable on Dec. 1.

Fragrant cigar smoke, blue and wraith-like, partly obscured the goldframed paintings in the brownpanelled and red-draped dining hall on the tenth floor of the National Republican Club at 54 West Fortieth Street last night, when the School Boys of Old Harlem had finished their annual dinner and started reminiscing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Senator Borah, regarded as one of the leaders of the Senate dry forces, expressed the opinion today that the Senate would not act finally in this session on a beer bin or the resolution amending the Eighteenth Amendment.

The start of another tournament season for squash tennis, one of the court games that has been flourishing within the city in recent years, took place yesterday at the New York Athletic Club when the Fall scratch tourney was Inaugurated.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Dr. Howard Arthur Lanpher, formerly a director of the Connecticut Bureau of Child Hygiene, died recently at his home in Des Moines, Iowa, according to word received here today.
ORMOND, Fla., Nov. 10 (AP). -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. got some firsthand information about football when he arrived in Florida today for his annual Winter sojourn.

The Association of Railway Executives, which represents about 95 per cent of the Class I railroad mileage, decided yesterday to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to extend the freight rate surcharges which are scheduled to expire on March 31 and to permit individual railroads to retain the proceeds, instead, as they now do, of transfering them to a pool for loans to needy railroads.

From whatever standpoint it is viewed, the meeting at Baker Field tomorrow between the unbeaten teams of Columbia and Brown offers as inviting a prospect as has any game staged in this city in recent years.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Dispatches from the chief British centres tonight indicate that Armistice Day ceremonies will be held tomorrow on a scale equaling that of former years.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, announced this evening that Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, had been instructed today to present immediately to Secretary Stimson the British Government's note concerning the $95,550,000 due Dec. 15 as an Instalment on account of principal and interest of the war debt.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The effect of the reduction of the Rutgers University appropriation by $200,000, on the university's service to the people of the State, has been both injurious and immediate, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers, told more than 150 members of the alumni and faculty of the university at a charter day dinner here tonight.

One hundred and seventy-eight sailing dinghies are registered in the North American Dinghy Association, it was reported last night at the meeting of the association at 145 West Forty-fourth Street. Several score more of the craft have been sold, but not as yet registered.
