WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Little change in crop prospects during the past month was indicated today by the Department of Agriculture.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Yale's eleven which has been picked to face Princeton Saturday today held its final hard practice of the week. The coaches sprang a surprise in calling from the line Clare Curtin, right tackle, for routine punting.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, President-elect, has received an offer of cooperation from Hamilton Fish Jr., Representative from his home Congressional district, the Twentysixth. A telegram from Mr. Fish to the Governor, made public yesterday, read:

Although Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, President-elect, carried only eleven out of sixty-two counties, with only six of these up-State, he won the forty-seven electoral votes of New York State by a plurality of 593,938, an unofficial tabulation of the complete returns disclosed yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- Buffeted about in gales of almost hurricane force for five days, the schooner yacht Aileen Booth, which sailed from New York Oct. 27, arrived at Baltimore early today with Captain Ellery Tuck and his wife, Mrs. Aileen Booth Tuck, aboard.

A man of "many tasks of different kinds," done all with high distinction and supreme grace, a preacher turned teacher, poet, diplomat, fisherman -- yet preacher always -- to whose sermons, like those of good St. BRENDAN and St. ANTHONY of Padua even the fishes were attracted, Dr. VAN DYKE dwells at fourscore in his island valley "Avalon."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Department store sales increased from September to October by about the usual seasonal amount, according to preliminary figures based on 569 stores in 238 cities made public by the Federal Reserve Board today.

Criticizing the continued grants of funds from American sources to the support of mission churches in foreign countries, particularly in Asia, the Laymen's Foreign Mission Inquiry, which has been investigating mission problems for seven of the leading Protestant denominations, recommended yesterday that these subsidies be curtailed.

The pound sterling had another sinking spell yesterday, falling at one time to $3.28, nearly 2 cents cheaper than the previous day's closing price, and finishing at $3.28 3/8, off 1 1/2 cents on the day. Apart from the further discussions of the question of payment on Dec. 15 of the $95,500,000 due on Great Britain's war debt to the United States, there were no visible factors to account for the renewed decline.

If in these days of congratulation Vice President CURTIS is not known to have sent kind words to his destined successor, the omission shouldn't be attributed to Mr. GARNER'S observations about him. The other day the Speaker, with an air of humorous regret, referred to the correct, solemn and almost hieratic attitude that differentiated Senator CURTIS from Vice President CURTIS.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The almost superhuman effort that must be made to take care of the unfortunate this Winter should enlist common sense as well as dollars.

Topped by the Hlll-Hotchkiss, Peddie-Blair, Boxbury-Columbia Freshmen and Poly Prep-St. Paul's contests, three of them renewals of traditional rivairies, today's scholastic football program calls for more than twenty-five games, most of them listed for fields within the metropolitan district.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Virtually the entire negotiable estate of Miss Harriett Draper of 255 South Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, daughter of Daniel Draper, for many years Meteorologist in charge of the Central Park Observatory, was left to the persons who care for her "family of pets," consisting of cats and dogs, according to her will filed here today.

A total of $46,268,000 in heavy engineering construction contracts reported by The Engineering NewsRecord for the week ending Nov. 7 is said to be the largest weekly volume announced so far this year State and municipal contracts at $31,378,000 account for this increase, although both Federal Government awards of $8,021,000 and private awards of $6,869,000 are above the average rate.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- The Rev. John W. Daily, assistant pastor of St. Cecilia's Catholic Church here and former army chaplain, died today at the age of 52.

Outstanding in the election returns from many States and cities is the proof that more voters than ever are discriminating. They break away from party nominations which they cannot approve. On Tuesday there was an immense amount of what used to be called "scratching the ballot."

As if the United States had not already a post-election headache, our European debtors are preparing gently to remind us that they cannot pay the full sum they owe us. This disagreeable news they considerately kept back until after the Presidential election.

TOKYO, Nov. 10. -- Though a Japanese mission is about to leave for Machefskaya, Siberia, to negotiate with the rebel, General Hsu Pingwen, who holds the Barga area, the situation in Northwest Manchuria continues to be obscure and dangerous.

Florence Nestule, 14 years old, found there was so little joy in her life so much to worry about and so much sorrow to bear that she gave way yesterday to the impulse of many an older person in similar circumstances and tried to commit suicide by jumping in front of a B.M.T. train not far from her home at 2,078 East Seventh Street, in the Gravesend district of Brooklyn.

Former Mayor James J. Walker made his definite exit from New York City politics yesterday. He sailed at 5 P.M. on the Italian liner Conte Grande, and, according to information here, his destination is India, where he will be the guest for a time of Maharajah of Mysore whom he entertained in New York in his capacity as the city's Chief Magistrate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Assuming that the incoming Democratic members of Congress carry out the party platform of drastic economy, World War veterans who are urging immediate payment of the bonus will meet disappointment, a veteran official privately predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Eleven States held prohibition referenda Tuesday. They were Louisiana, Michigan, New Jersey, California, Washington Oregon, Colorado, Arizona, North Dakota, Connecticut and Wyoming.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Detroit's revamped and renamed hookey team downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 1, tonight in the opening game of the local National Hockey League season before 8,000 spectators.

Purity of tone and delicate coloration are the special gifts of the lyric soprano voice to mezzo-voce singing, as Mabel Zoeckler reminded us last night during her projection of Brahms's "Sandmannschen" and Mozart's "Das Traumbild" and "Das Veilchen," during her concert debut in Town Hall.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- During the past few weeks, several hints have been given that as soon as the Presidential election was over in the United States the question of a debt settlement or revision in accord with the new situation created by cessation of German reparation payments would be raised by France.

There were during the campaign many Republican claims that the election of Governor ROOSEVELT would swell the number of "wild men" and "freaks" in public life Forgetting the fine representation in their own party of persons thus unkindly described, the Republican gave to the Democrats complete possession of the political zoo.

The address of Newton D. Baker last night at the dinner at the Hotel Astor opening the $15,000,000 fundraising campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee to aid the needy unemployed follows:
CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- All grain markets in North America as well a that in Buenos Aires will be closed tomorrow, Armistice Day. Only the market in Liverpool will be open.

Without any obvious cause in the day's developments, and perhaps without any need for it, yesterday's stock and bond markets reversed their trend from Wednesday and considerably more than recovered that day's losses. Advances ranged in numerous active shares from 3 to 5 points, and practically all closed around the highest.
New York will celebrate Armistice Day today, the fourteenth, anniversary of the cessation of hostilities in the World War.

Reporting the third consecutive increase for a month, the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that unfilled orders at the end of October amounted to 1,997,040 tons, compared with 1,985,090 tons on Sept. 30, a gain of 11,950 tons.

ATLANTA, Nov. 10. -- An order issued in Federal district court today, freeing a convicted slayer from a life sentence in the Federal Penitentiary here, declared that Franklin D. Roosevelt erroneously assumed Presidential authority while he was serving as Acting Secretary of the Navy in 1919.
PARIS, Nov. 10 (AP). -- A vote of confidence was accorded the Herriot Government today by a show of hands in the Chamber of Deputies on measures taken to suppress tax dodging and fiscal frauds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Police will not interfere with the entrance, of delegates into Washington for the farmers' national relief conference Dec. 7, farm, representatives were told today by Police Superintendent Brown. He gave this assurance on being told that the farm delegates were coming for a peaceable conference and would stage no public demonstration other than a parade.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- A large volume of realization sales depressed the stock market today, causing declines of 2 to 3 points. Failure of Wall Street to react strongly yesterday to the elections was the chief reason given for the downward tendency. Bonds were irregular.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Rear Admiral Frank T. Chambers of Louisville, Ky., director of naval petroleum reserves, died at his home here today after a long illness at the age of 62.
Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, President-elect, does not intend to make any decision on members of his Cabinet until some time in February.

Young matrons and society women as well as debutantes are interested in the entertainment which will be given tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association.

An intensive search by ten picked detectives for Paul Marciante, 10 years old, who was kidnapped Monday morning while on the way from his home at 315 East Sixtieth Street to school on Sixty-third Street between Second and Third Avenues, failed again yesterday to produce any clues as to the boy's fate.

Speeding up the tempo of the drill, the Fordham football squad went through a lengthy workout at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for the traditional contest with New York University at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow.

A brilliant scene enhanced by military ceremonies and the attendance of many members of Society, the Belgian Ambassador and other distinguished persons in diplomatic, civic and military circles was presented last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria when the annual Victory Ball took place in celebration of Armistice Day.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The stock markets generally were dull today. A feature was further selling of British funds. The new 3 per cent conversion loan fell to a 2 1/2 per cent discount, but a slightly better tendency developed in the afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I, a former member of the Italian Parliament and an exile, perfectly conversant with the Italian situation, state, in service to truth, that this so-called amnesty granted by the Fascist government is the greatest practical joke ever played on foreign public opinion by Il Duce?

Encouraged by eloquent appeals which portrayed graphically the social dangers involved in a possible breakdown of the relief program in New York City and the nation, 2,000 volunteer workers for the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee pledged their utmost efforts last night in the committee's campaign for $15,000,000 which citizens of this city will be asked to give as their share toward relieving this Winter's distress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I reply to Wendell Farrington's letter on "Expensive Public Schools"? There is a widely held view that the objective of education is good citizenship. Accordingly, having mastered the three R's, the student should be subjected to a vigorous training in "history, government, economics, sociology and ethics."

Agents of the White Star Line in the principal Canadian cities and in Chicago and Detroit are opposed to a drastic revision upward of transatlantic passenger rates, according to Major Frank Bustard, passenger traffic manager of the line. Major Bustard returned to New York yesterday after a hurried trip of inspection in Montreal, Toronto and the mid-West and will return to England today on the liner Majestic.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Armed with daggers improvised from a screwdriver and from an iron spring, two convicts in the New Jersey State Prison here fought a duel in a cell today that brought death to one of them and serious injury to the other. John Sparola, 30 years old, of Essex County, serving ten years for robbery, died of a stab wound in the left lung soon after the fight.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Contending it had better do some trade on a primitive barter basis than do no trade at all, the London Chamber of Commerce today published a scheme for the reversion to a temporary form of barter with thirty-five foreign countries which have imposed severe restrictions on currency exchanges with Great Britain.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 10. -- Governor George White, reputedly the "weak link" in the chain with which the Democratic leaders were confident of jerking the State of Ohio out of the Republican ranks, surprised political observers by leading the State and national tickets in last Tuesday's election.

With a continuation of the decline here, bank clearings throughout the country in the week ended on Wednesday again ran substantially below those of a year ago, according to reports received from leading cities by R.G. Dun Co. The total was $3,395,769,000, or 37.3 per cent less than in the same week of 1931.

In anticipation of the funds to be made available after Nov. 15 by the $30,000,000 relief bond issue, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, which will disburse the money, is making plans to resurvey the work relief system of the State, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman. The study will be made from the point of view of technical efficiency and the number of jobs provided.

The money market was quiet. In all sections quotations were maintained without change on a minimum of business. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, but in the Street trading 1/2 ruled. Maturity money and business funds were unchanged.

DETROIT, Nov. 10. -- William Munn, a bootlegger, was the first beneficiary in a Detroit court by the action of voters Tuesday in declaring by 3 to 1 for repeal of the prohibition amendment to the State Constitution.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Mrs. Carrie T. Miller, widow of Edwin M. Miller and a former resident of Mount Vernon, died last night at Ballston Spa, N.Y. Mrs. Miller was born in San Francisco, a daughter of Frederick B. Taylor, one of the pioneers of that State. On her mother's side she was descended from the Remingtons, Meachams and other Connecticut families of Revolutionary days.

John Galsworthy, this year's winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, writes of love and the depression in "Flowering Wilderness," published today by Charles Scribner's Sons. Through the love story of Dinny Cherrell in contact with many of the characters first encountered in "Maid in Waiting," he describes the effects of the world's present welter upon the surviving English aristocracy.

Rochester, N.Y. Award of a new Issue of $2,500,000 city of Rochester (N.Y.) eightmonth notes, dated Nov. 14, 1932, and due on July 14, 1833, was made yesterday to the M. T. Trust Company of Buffalo and Sage, Wolcott Steele of Rochester at their joint bid of par.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10. -- An inheritance tax of $444,408.68 must be paid "by the estate of Mrs. Anna Sinton Taft, widow of Charles P. Taft according to an order made in Probate Court today. The tax will be paid by Mrs. Jane Taft Ingalls and Mrs. Louise Taft Semple, her daughters.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10. -- The job of hauling the lowly Cincinnati Reds out of last place in the National League was pinned today on the shoulders of diminutive Donie Bush, whose teams have finished out of the first division only twice.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 10. -- The terms of $22,500,000 offered by the Standard Oil Company of California for the properties of the Richfield Oil Company of California and certain assets of the Pan-American Petroleum Company have been accepted, it was announced here tonight by committees of bank creditors, bondholders and unsecured trade creditors.

At the seventeenth annual International Good-will Congress, which opened here last night at the Biltmore Hotel, Professor Andre Philip of the University of Lyons, presenting the French viewpoint, declared that a failure of the forthcoming disarmament conference would mean war in five years.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Keene Fitzpatrick, who will retire on Saturday from his position as Princeton track coach and athletic trainer has selected all-time track and football teams composed of his most proficient pupils at Yale, Michigan and Princeton.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 10. -- The discovery of a rich goldfield has just been reported from the Guiana section of the State of Bolivar. More than $500,000 worth of gold has been taken from the site in less than three weeks.

A new speed record on the Atlantic between Cherbourg Breakwater and Ambrose Light was established when the North German Lloyd liner Bremen steamed into port early yesterday, 4 days 16 hours 43 minutes out of Cherbourg.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 10. -- The tempo of the Roosevelt victory in the United States presents a beautiful example of revolt of the American people against an autocratic regime, says the press here today.

Running Through Signals. There Is also the little matter of the Tiger and the Bulldog and that's always a good story about this time of the year. Eli Yale has been pushing the Princetonians around on the gridiron in recent years, but down in Jungletown the undergraduates have, an idea that there may be a change this season.

Benjamin Feigenbaum, for several decades one of the cultural leaders of the Jewish Socialist movement and well known as Journalist and lecturer, died yesterday of paralysis agitans at the Home for Incurables in the Bronx, after an illness of about ten years. He lived at 150 Ninety-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

Preservation of mental health makes support of public and private agencies for relief of the unemployed doubly important at this time, since those agencies are combating the specter of insecurity, Dr. C.M Hincks, general director of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization at its headquarters, 450 Seventh Avenue.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters held its annual meeting yesterday at its home on West 155th Street. It elected three new members, gave its usual "diction" awards -- to those of the stage and the radio -- and then settled down to the business of helping Dr. Henry van Dyke celebrate his eightieth birthday.

With complete returns from all 3,415 election districts in New Jersey reported yesterday, an unofficial count gave W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for the United States Senate seat of the late Dwight W. Morrow, a vote of 735,475 to 721,157 for Representatice Percy H. Stewart, his Democratic opponent, a plurality of 14,318.

Feodor Chaliapin, who arrived yesterday, on the Bremen for his first concert tour here in four seasons, told Interviewers at the Plaza in the late afternoon that If he had a vote, he would have cast it for Roosevelt. He was particularly delighted over the prospect that prohibition was soon to end.

Hitherto one has first of all associated with Edward Bruce the infinitely various landscape of Italy, as translated into the simplified language of his pallidly sunlit style. From now on, however, Bruce must be accepted as one of the innumerable band of artists who have looked out upon New York City and found it teeming with motifs that await the painter's revaluing and metamorphosing touch.

Mr. Toscanini produced a new score by an American composer last night at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. The composer was Bernard Wagenaar, and the symphony was his Second, heard for the first time anywhere on this occasion.
November puffed a northwest gale across the Eastern seaboard yesterday, and pounding seas, pelting rain and an exceptionally high tide caused damage to hundreds of communities along the coast.

WASHINGTON NOV. 10.-- A modification of shipping agreements, covering the protection of direct-line freight rates from North Atlantic to Adriatic, Black Sea and Levant ports, was approved by the Shipping Board today. The purpose was to record the substitution of the member lines of the Atlantic-United Kingdom, North Atlantic-Continent and North Atlantic-French freight conferences as participating carriers in a single agreement.

A rise of 0.4 point from the previous Tuesday lifted the Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices to 88.9 on Monday, interrupting the decline of the eight previous weeks. Last Tuesday's prices were largely unavailable, as the day was a holiday.

More than a score of Manhattan and Bronx properties were put up for bidding at auction sales conducted yesterday as the result of foreclosure proceedings. All the parcels were struck down either to the bondholders or the mortgagees.

Life insurance has met the abnormal strain of the depression in a manner such as to leave no doubt of its safety and reliability not only as a means to provide for dependents in the event of the death of the Insured but as a safe reservoir of credit to be used in times of emergency, George S. Van Schaiek, State Superintendent of Insurance, asserted last night.

With the Hofstadter committee about to resume hearings in connection with the constructive phase of its inquiry, Tammany control of the State Senate, as Republicans view the situation, in all probability will spell defeat to any remedial legislation brought before the Legislature.

A new name will be engraved on the Killearn Farm Challenge Trophy, presented by Alfred B. Maclay, which was one of the leading cup competitions on the program of the second evening session of the Forty-seventh Annual National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Following Wednesday's decline to the lowest ground of the last three months, prices on the Cotton Exchange turned abruptly yesterday and, after recovering about $2 a bale, ended with gains of 30 to 35 points on the day.
MONTREAL, Nov. 10. -- The New York Rangers opened the 1932-33 campaign in the National Hockey League by defeating the Montreal Maroons in the Forum tonight.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 10. -- The Winter meeting at Hialeah Park, Jan. 19 to March 11, will offer horsemen stakes and purges totaling more than $300,000.

NEW YORK. Franklin Brooke Voss and Edward Somerville Voss, who have been hunting in Ireland, are guests of the Duke and Duchess of Beaufort at Badminton, their estate in Gloucestershire, hunting with the Duke's pack.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 10 (AP). -- The Farmer-Labor party of Minnesota, a struggling infant since its birth fourteen years ago, has won its largest grant of power. Rural returns today completed the political turnover of the State which swept it into the Democratic Presidential column for the first time.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- Declines in staple commodities yesterday, together with French budget discussions, weighed heavily on the Bourse today and stocks fell sharply. There was a slight recovery toward the closing, but losses on the day were generally large.

TORONTO, Out., Nov. 10 (Canadian Press). -- "With the disappearance of panic, I believe the worst of the present financial crisis has passed," J.A. McLeod, presidentelect of the Canadian Bankers Association, said today in addressing the annual meeting of that body.

GENEVA, Nov. 10. -- Barely had a peaceful aspect returned to Geneva today after last night's outbreak, with the death roll increasing from eight to eleven, when 2,500 citizens of Geneva and 2,500 of Lausanne, forming the militia of the two lake cities, were under orders to keep military equipment ready for instant mobilization and orders were issued for a further mobilization of 2,500 tomorrow.

How a fearless woman detective, whose identity has never been revealed, mingled with a gang of alleged jewel robbers and gunmen with whom she "plotted" robberies was brought out yesterday in General Sessions Court when Miss Buda Goddman, 44 years old, a divorcee known also as Helen Smith, who was described as an associate of narcotic addicts and gunmen, was sentenced to a term of from four to eight years in the Auburn State prison.

Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, wrote yesterday to Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald, asking a public hearing and disciplinary action on the alleged "misconduct" of Magistrate Samuel Katz in refusing on election day to issue a warrant for an election official and two policemen.

John M. Morehead, United States Minister to Sweden, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Other prominent passengers booked for Cherbourg, Southampton and Bremen include H.R. Jolles, vice president of the National City Bank; Jeddu Krishnamurti, Indian theosophist; H.S. Karara, Egyptian Vice Consul at San Francisco; Harry Yates, director of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, and M. R. Meadows, secretary to Frederic M. Sackett, Ambassador to Germany.

Little testimony was taken yester day in the trial of the breach, of contract action brought by Mme. Lydia Lindgren, the singer, against Otto H. Kahn, the banker and music patron, because the plaintiff repeatedly drew the rebukes of Justice Frank F. Adel.

Dry Goods Jobbers Ready to Buy. Dry goods wholesalers reported yesterday that with the election out of the way they were prepared to go ahead on additional purchases but that they would move cautiously in view of the price weakness. The recent slower rate of retail turnover has curtailed demand from stores, jobbers said, and until store volume starts to improve again, not much in the way of business could be expected from Jobbers' accounts.

Columbia reached the high point of its training yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter tomorrow with the Brown eleven. Coach Lou Little had the Morningside squad going through its football paces for three hours, during which every phase of the sport was rehearsed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Franklin D. Roosevelt will enter the White House with the greatest party strength in Congress any President ever had since the early days of the republic.

"Sherlock Holmes," a Fox production featuring Clive Brook, Miriam Jordan and Ernest Torrence, opens at the Roxy this morning. Mme. Schumann-Heink is the star of the stage program, which is called "Rhapsody in Color."

Reflecting Increased demands for pocket money on election day, money in circulation rose another $35,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve reports published yesterday, revealed. This expansion of currency in use followed a seasonal advance of $32,000,000 last week and lifted the total of money outstanding to $5,651,000,000 which was $134,000,000 above the amount outstanding on the corresponding day last year.

Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly held a conference yesterday with Chairman W. Kingsland Macy of the Republican State Committee at which organization by the Republicans of the Assembly was discussed. Speaker McGinnies will be a candidate for re-election to the post of power and responsibility he has occupied in the lower house at Albany since 1925.

Disposal of the stock of one of the subsidiaries of the United Cigar Stores Company of America and granting of authority to disaffirm ninety leaseholds of the bankrupt company marked the hearing yesterday before Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, at his offices in 15 Park Row.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 10. -- An order restraining North American Aviation, Inc., from selling certain of its assets to the Aviation Corporation of Delaware for 1,977,000 shares of the latter company's common stock was issued here today by J.O. Wolcott, Chancellor of the Court of Chancery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am so happy this morning that I cannot resist expressing my joy in the result. I can now approach the radio when an occasion arrives for the President of the United States to go on the air. For seven years, during Coolidge's incumbency, I tuned in with fear and trembling to hear what he had to say -- no thrill from voice or speech or personality.

WASHINGTON, Nov. l0. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 9, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banka, was $2,223,000,000, a decrease of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $128,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Drastic proposals for reform of the House of Lords are contained in a report issued tonight by a joint committee, headed by the Marquess of Salisbury, of Conservative peers and parliamentarians.

The development of twenty acres of the Fort Schuyler site, in the Bronx, as a ground base for the New York State Merchant Marine Academy, was supported and opposed by Captain J.H. Tomb, superintendent of the academy, and Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, yesterday at a luncheon of the Propeller Club of New York at the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street.

Bond prices moved forward briskly on the Stock Exchange yesterday with all groups except United States Government bonds closing the day substantially higher tin the average. Domestic corporation obligations led the advance, with utilities showing the best average improvement.

HARTFOKD, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Suicides due to financial losses have upset all actuarial tables on which life insurance is based, and increased mortality, combined with decreased earnings, has brought the life insurance companies to the threshold of higher rates and curtailed privileges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, and Paul Glaudel, French Ambassador, called on Secretary of State Stimson today, and their visits confirmed reports from abroad that Great Britain and France would seek an extension of the Hoover moratorium so that they would not be compelled to make payments on was debts due to the United States on Dec. 15.

A red oak sapling was planted yesterday in memory of Dr. George F. Kunz, civic leader and internationally known gem expert, on the Central Park West lawn of the American Museum of Natural History. The ceremony took place under the auspices of the New York Bird and Tree Club, of which he was honorary president, and was marked by eulogies delivered before a group of his former scientific colleagues.

All of the markets rose sharply yesterday in response to news of enlarged industrial and trade activity. On the Stock Exchange, where the most enthusiastic demonstration of strength in a month was witnessed, the net gains ran from 2 to more than 5 points.
MONTREAL, Que., Nov. 10 (AP). -- The British tramp steamer Ingola, drifting in the hurricane in the West Indies, has a complement of thirty men, it was learned here today.
CAMAGUEY, Cuba, Nov. 10. -- More than 1,000 persons were known to have been killed, the police said tonight, by the hurricane which swept over Southern Cuba yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Barley, a foundation stock of beer, was recalled today from a nine-year exile by traders on the Chicago Board of Trade.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- The French Government revealed today the first details of the great public works scheme which is intended to cut unemployment and at the same time relieve the budget of some expenses that ordinarily would have to be met.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 10. -- Coincident with the coming of unofficial reports that the foreign debt problem would soon arise again through notes from the British and French Governments asking for new negotiations, President Hoover decided today to cut short his Vacation by one day and leave tomorrow night for Washington.

Edwin Nash Sanderson, one of the leading developers and operators of public utilities in the United States, who had been president of the Federal Light and Traction Company of New York for more than twenty years, died Wednesday evening in the New York Hospital at the age of 69.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- When John Galsworthy received the news today, at his Sussex home near Arundel, that he had won the Nobel prize in Literature, he said:
Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee said yesterday that he would fill two important posts within a few days and indicated that his selections would not be dictated by political considerations.

A prediction that the great demand for governmental economy will aid the railroads in solving their business problems and help to promote a better economic position for the principal American lines was made last night by Professor G.W. Dyer of the economics department of Vanderbilt University in a speech at the Hotel Comomodore.

The five-story American basement dwelling at 14 East Ninety-fourth Street has been leased to George S. Kaufman, playwright. The property includes a garden, and the house was entirely rebuilt four years ago, according to Warren L. Marks Co., brokers in the deal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If one were to make a survey of the political officeholders in each municipality, it would be interesting to learn how few government officials are familiar with government finance, budgetary control, economics, city planning and other related subjects the knowledge of which is so vital to the efficient administration of government.
MOSCOW, Nov. 10 (AP). -- Soviet Russia today mourned the death of "the most faithful Bolshevist woman," Nadejda Sergeivna Alliluieva, the wife of the powerful Joseph Stalin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- In lieu of official notices of postponement, it was pointed out today, the Treasury expects to collect the following obligations, due Dec. 15:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Speakers for the domestic organic oils and fats industry urged at a Customs Bureau hearing today the enactment of an emergency tariff on such products to protect the farmer from serious competition from countries whose currency has depreciated.

HAVANA, Nov. 11. -- Mayor Kumberto Rodrlguez of Camaguey announced tonight that 300 survivors of the Santa Cruz del Sur disaster had arrived there by train. Ten others died en route and the physical condition of eighty was such that they had to be rushed to a hospital for immediate medical attention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Invading the national capital in the drive for reduced government expenditures, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, chairman of the National Economy League, tonight told the Washington Board of Trade that unless "the yoke of high government cost is thrown off, chaos and bankruptcy will eventually prevail."
Headed by the latest chapter in the oldest story of intercollegiate football, the Yale-Princeton game, football is poised today at the top of the season's homestretch.

Senator BORAH would doubtless resent being called a Bourbon, but he returns to Washington in the spirit of one who has learned nothing and forgotten nothing since he left the capital months ago. With an almost sublime disregard of what has happened, he jauntily assumes again his old power of veto over legislation.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 11 -- Dr. Stanley King, delivering the inaugural address today at his induction as eleventh president of Amherst College, declared his opposition to vocational studies and asserted that "we must get away from the all too prevalent coddlings and immaturities in our attitude to young men."

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Stanley Baldwin's appeal to the youth of the world to think hard about the perils of air bombing, delivered in a tense House of Commons last night, has raised the question whether all countries can unite to make the prohibition against air bombing absolute.

BOSTON, Nov. 11. -- Champion My Own Today, famous cocker spaniel, owned by Miss Alice A. Dodsworth, Sharon, Conn., today took first honors in the eleventh annual show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders' Club of New England, staged at Horticultural Hall.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The laconic statement that "the government in engaged in diplomatic conversations regarding which courtesy demands complete and absolute discretion" was the only admission and confirmation given by the French Foreign Ministry today of a report from Washington that Paul Claudel, French Ambassador, had presented on behalf of his government a request for reopening the discussion of the interallied debt settlements.
CLEMSON COLLEGE, S.C., Nov. 11.-- Scoring in every period, the Georgia Bulldogs outplayed the Clomson Tigers today to win a thrilling Armistice Day football game 32 to 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- A plea that the "best dole system in the world" be given to this country was made here today by Dr. Sumner H. Slichter, Professor of Business Economics at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, in addressing a post-election stocktaking conference of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, with the Taylor Society cooperating.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- The statement by Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons yesterday has been received in Germany as an important step in the direction where escape from the present impasse in the disarmament negotiations may be found.

The reversal in the trend of cotton prices on Thursday became more pronounced yesterday, when a rise of 1/4 cent carried quotations on the Cotton Exchange 70 points above the low levels of the week. Short covering by a prominent stock and commodity operator was estimated at 30,000 bales and, with a holiday at many Southern points, the market had difficulty in supplying the demand.

The American Hebrew Medal for the Promotion of Better Understanding Between Christian and Jew in America for 1932 has been awarded to Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The award is announced in the current issue of The American Hebrew and Jewish Tribune, national Anglo-Jewish weekly edited by Rabbi Isaac Landman.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- One point proved to be the margin of victory by which the University of Delaware defeated the eleven of the Pennsylvania Military College on the indoor gridiron of the municipal auditorium tonight.

A list of part of the realty holdings of the bankrupt United Cigar Stores of America was submitted yesterday at a hearing to determine the value of these assets, held before Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, at his offices in 15 Park Row.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- While the King was laying a wreath today on the cenotaph in Whitehall, the central point .of the British Empire commemoration of the fourteenth anniversary of the armistice, Communists in other places broke the two-minute silence by singing "The Internationale."

The art collection of Colonel Michael Friedsam will be on public exhibition, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art beginning next Tuesday and continuing through April 9, 1933. On Monday thera will be a private showing for members of the museum.

New issues of State and municipal bonds listed for award next week and on later dates show a sharp increase over the last few weeks. A total of $12,881,937 is scheduled, compared with $2,168,936 up for award this week. The weekly average for this year to date is $17,830,996.

The West Indian hurricane that cut a path of devastation across Cuba after playing about for more than a week in the Caribbean swung back in an easterly direction last night, according to reports received here from ships at sea. Dr. James H. Kimball, meteoroligist, said that he had received reports of a third violent disturbance.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- Persistent rumors that Japan is developing submarine and other naval bases in the former German Pacific islands now under her mandate were aired today in the mandates commission of the League of Nations, Sitting secretly here.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The French, Italian and Belgian Ambassadors to London were informed today by Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, of the tenor of the note concerning the British war debt to the United States. The note was presented to Secretary of State Stimson yesterday by Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador.

The Rutgers freshman football team, undefeated and, champion of the Middle Three, had to come from behind to tie the New York University cubs, 6-to-6, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the Violet yearlings fourth and final game of the season and gave them a record of two victories, one defeat and one tie.

While Harry F. Wolf, the national titleholder, advanced by virtue of a default, other favorites gained victories in the seven second-round matches played in the Fall scratch squash tennis tourney at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

Michigan, under whose laws occurred that edifying case of life imprisonment for an habitual offender whose last offense was possession, or sale of a pint of whisky, has had a complete change of heart. She has voted to rip the prohibition laws out of her statute-book.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Nov. 5 issue of The Saturday Evening Post Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank, propounds the question "What about the banks?"
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11. -- With a team comprising only five of the eleven veterans with which it started the season, and six newcomers, the Harvard eleven tomorrow will engage Holy Cross.

A bus bearing sixty commuters from the Long island Railroad station in Hollis, Queens, to their homes crashed into an electric light pole at Hollis Avenue and 194th Street last night, injuring twenty-five persons, two being seriously hurt.

Daniel M. Enright, wholesale coffee merchant of 98 Front Street, left $50,000 to employes by his will, which was filed in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn yesterday. His estate was estimated at more than $300,000.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 11 (AP). -- The Viscountess Astor of Cliveden, first woman member of the British House of Commons and long an advocate of prohibition in Great Britain, says "American women never will vote for liquor."
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator Joseph T. Robinson declared in an Armistice Day address here today in favor of this government announcing a fixed policy for collection of the war debts.

PALO ALTO, Cal., Nov. 11 -- Refreshed after a vacation of three days in his old home on the Stanford University campus, President Hoover, with Mrs. Hoover left here tonight at 8:55 o'clock (Pacific Time) by special train on the way back to Washington.

The continuation of the Independent Judges party in the form of a permanent organization to divorce the judiciary from party politics was decided upon yesterday at a meeting of a group of the attorneys who actively supported the candidacies of George W. Alger and Bernard S. Deutsch in the last election.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- A replica of the famous Houdon statue of Washington, which stands in the Capitol at Richmond, Va., was unveiled this afternoon in front of the new State Office Building by Miss Alice Miriam Tobin, daughter of Charles J. Tobin, chairman of the George Washington Bicentennial Commission.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 11 -- Fourteen years ago today Newton D. Baker issued the order that dissolved the greatest war machine the world had ever known. Before departing for Washington to speak today at the tomb of Woodrow Wilson, his Commander-in-Chief in that conflict, the former Secretary of War sat in the quiet of his law office here and recalled incidents leading up to the Armistice of Nov. 11, 1918.

A plea for "simple and inexpensive" Thanksgiving dinners throughout the nation this year as penance for an economic system which is "in its distribution of the good things of life a travesty on brotherhood" was made public yesterday by the Brooklyn Federation of Churches.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Great Britain is selling more "goods abroad, while at the same time there has been a check in the flood of imports according to Board of Trade, returns for October.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The overwhelming landslide of the election, which has exceeded all Democratic hopes and Republican fears, can be interpreted only as a vote of confidence in the character and ability of Franklin Roosevelt.

For the fifth consecutive year the New York City Cancer Committee is raising funds to maintain and increase the service it is rendering in teaching the public about cancer. Thanks to the generosity of the Chemical Foundation, it is distributing a book on cancer to which some of the most eminent physicians and surgeons of the city have contributed brief, illustrated articles that any intelligent person can understand.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, invited Mrs. F. Stephen McCarthy, chairman of the Municipal Affairs Committee of the New York City League of Women Voters, and her committee to attend the next meeting of the board at 11 o'clock Monday morning, for answers to her questions about the instructions given to election inspectors at last Tuesday's election.

The annual Bed Cross Roll-Call in the churches will be held tomorrow by the church division of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross, of which Mrs. William C. Dickey, a parishioner of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary tha Virgin, is the chairman.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 11. -- A patriotic program in which city officials and officials of the Elizabeth Washington Bicentennial Committee participated, was held at the World War monument in Scott Park here today in observance of Armistice Day.

To Wall Street, and particularly the commission house brokers, the most interesting feature of yesterday's share market was the sharp expansion in trading activity. The total turnover was 2,631,000 shares, compared with 1,557,410 on the day before.

There was little feature to the trading in money, as quotations remained unchanged upon a volume of business that was small in all sections. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 1 per cent and Street trades at 1/2.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The erratic action of prices of hogs is keeping packers busy trying to make the product and the quotations correspond. Light receipts and large shipping demands have left comparatively small supplies for local packers, who have been largely responsible for the recent advances.

UNION CITY, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Officials of the Union City Brewing Company, the largest brewery in Hudson County, said today that their plant could manufacture 300,000 barreis of beer annually and could begin operation at that rate within twenty-four hours after legal permission had been given.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Appalachian Coals, Inc., and 137 producers of bituminous coal in eight coal districts in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky filed in the Supreme Court today an appeal from a three-judge Federal Court ruling that the organization and proposed operation of the corporation was prohibited by Sherman anti-trust laws.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Nov. 11. -- Stephen Szumachowski of Mont Pleasant High School, Schenectady, N. Y., won the third annual Villanova College interscholastic 2 1/4-mile cross-country run today.

Many younger members of society went to Rumson, N.J., last night to attend two dances given for debutantes. Mr. and Mrs. James Ford Johnson of Half Way House gave a supper dance at the Rumson Country Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Fisk Johnson.

An attractive program which featured international military events and the rough riding of members of the State mounted police, entertained a notable assembly of society at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Spirited bidding for domestic corporation bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday lifted prices of a long list of Issues 1 to more than 8 points. Comparatively few issues were set back and their declines were generally of a minor character. Foreign loans were irregularly higher, as was the case with United States Government bonds.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lee Haggin of Mount Brilliant Farm, Lexington, Ky., are at the St. Regis.
Columbia and Brown, members of the small and rapidly dwindling group of undefeated football teams, will meet today starting at 2 o'clock at Baker Field before 35,000 onlookers.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Overnight improvement in Wall Street helped sentiment considerably on the Stock Exchange here today. All sections were cheerful, even British funds recovering sharply.

A 5,000-year-old Egyptian secret was recently brought to light in the laboratories of Columbia University through the study of ancient Egyptian vases belonging to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This was revealed last night by Dr. Colin G. Fink, head of the division of electrochemistry at Columbia, in a lecture before the New York chapter of the American Institute of Chemists, at the Chemists' Club.

To Push Early Christmas Trade. With the opening in the next ten days of expanded toy and gift ware departments by a number of retailers both here and out of town, a pronounced drive to develop early shopping for the holidays will develop. Some scattered buying of gift and semi-gift items was reported here during the week by executives, but the total volume was not great.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney announced yesterday the retirement of Captain Joseph L. Betz, who had been transferred only the day before from the Meserole Street Station in Brooklyn to the station in St. George, S.I. Captain Betz, who lives at 970 Seventy-ninth Street, Brooklyn, applied for retirement yesterday afternoon.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Nov. 11 -- A well-balanced attack built around the versatile Dick Hebard brought victory to The Hill School football team today in its annual battle against Hotchkiss. Crossing the goal line twice, Hebard, former national junior tennis champion, led his team to a 12-0 triumph.
CAMAGUEY, Nov. 11 (AP).-- More than 1,000 dazed and suffering refugees from Santa Cruz del Sur were brought to Camaguey today in crowded box-car trains.

The 3-year-old son of a Brooklyn rabbi was burned and smothered to death yesterday afternoon when a nurse in the New York Children's Hospital on Randall Island left her ward for a few minutes. The death was described as "accidental" by both the police and the medical superintendent of the hospital after an investigation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Although without any official information as to the extent of the damage resulting from the hurricane that swept across Cuba yesterday, some government officials with past experience on the island expressed apprehension today as to its effects on American interests there.

KEMPVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 11 (AP). -- Losing their way in the darkness and rain on a flight from Chicago to Florida, where they planned to spend the Winter, five persons in a private plane piloted by Joseph F. Hirt, industrial engineer, fell to their deaths in a hillside woods on the fringe of Kempville.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 11 -- A courageous Poly Prep football team subdued the St. Paul's School representatives, 7 -- 0, today in the seventeenth renewal of the traditional series.

DUBLIN, Nov. 11 -- For four hours tonight the entire police force battled mobs of young hooligans bent on attacking any wearer of a red armistice poppy, emblem of respect for the nation's, war dead, and demonstrating against the British Union Jack.

The trapeze on whiten Bess of the Central Park Zoo has played capers for the amusement of thousands of children during the last eight years dangled at rest last night. Bess, the only chimpanzee in the zoo, will clown it no longer. She died of heart disease late yesterday afternoon.

Business and industrial activity in the last week was marked by interruptions by the national elections and armistice day, in spite of which the essential stability has been maintained remarkably, according to the weekly reviews of trade and industry.
Many leases of dwellings on both the east and west sides were announced by brokers yesterday.

Elizabeth, N.J. The city of Elizabeth, N.J., announced yesterday through John A. Mitchell, Controller, that it would be in the market with a new issue of 51,500,000 of tax-revenue bonds on Nov.25. It is planned that the issue shall mature 5300,000 on Dec.10, 1933; a like amount on Dec. 10, 1934; S400.000 on Dec.10,1935, and $500,000 on Dec. 10,1936.

Cuba, like Puerto Rico, has been stricken by a hurricane. Puerto Rico experienced calamity on Sept. 28, just about four years after the great San Felipe storm of Sept. 13, 1928. In the case of the Cuban seacoast town of Santa Cruz del Sur, what is improperly called a tidal wave caused the devastation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was sorry to see your editorial "New Ventures in Housing." It seems most unfortunate that THE TIMES should appear to approve of an enterprise so unsound, not to say vicious in principle. This, like all other attempts to interfere with the natural law of supply and demand, is bound to end in failure, but in the meantime it will cause great injustice and do irreparable mischief.

The Citizens' Budget Committee has tendered its formal congratulations to the Mayor-elect, accompanied by an offer of assistance to the new administration in effecting the economy to which Mr. O'BRIEN is pledged. The committee concedes that he will meet "great difficulties" in that endeavor.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11. -- The Quantico Marines defeated the American Legion All-Stars, 7 to 0, on Franklin Field today before a crowd of 12,000.
AMHERST vs. Williams-Alumnus Calvin Coolidge of Amherst may he a trifle glum in the wake of recent balloting on a wide-scale. He needs cheering up. If this will help, one vote for Amherst.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11. -- Jim McDonald, substitute back for Duquesne University, ran wild today and Duquesne defeated South Dakota State College, 34 to 12, in the first meeting between the two schools. McDonald could not be stopped and romped away for four touchdowns.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Only sporadic signs of improvement were shown in the weekly summary of the business situation abroad issued today by the Department of Commerce.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Unleashing a diversified and powerful attack in the final period, to score two touchdowns, Blair Academy today conquered its ancient rival, Peddie School, 20 to 7, on the latter's field in their thirtieth annual gridiron meeting.

The Radio Corporation of America, its subsidiaries and the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, which jointly control the corporation, have drawn up a comprehensive plan for reorganization to be submitted to the Department of Justice in Washington in an eleventhhour effort to forestall the government's suit against them under the anti-trust laws, which is scheduled to come up for trial on Tuesday in Wilmington, Del.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11. -- St. Mary's football team returned to the Western wars today, and before an armistice day crowd of 65,000 flashed to a 14-to-7 victory over University of California at Los Angeles.

Discontinuance of Mme. Lydia Lindgren's suit against Otto H. Kahn, financier and patron, of music, was announced yesterday by Justice Frank F. Adel to the jury in Supreme Court, Long Island City. Details of the settlement out of court, arranged between counsel, were withheld.

Five of the Metropolitan Opera's eleven new singers will make their debuts with the company during the first week of the season, which will begin on Monday evening, Nov. 21, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza. They are Tito Schipa, Italian tenor; Gustaaf de Loor, Dutch tenor; Ludwig Hofmann, German bass-baritone, and Helen Gleason and Margaret Halstead, American sopranos.
BOSTON, Nov. 11. -- The Boston College Eagles were unable to hold a third period 20-6 edge over Western Maryland today, the Southerners smashing and passing their way to two scores for a 20-20 tie.

By writing books that children like to read, an author can best make certain of being remembered, Frederic Melcher, editor of The Publishers' Weekly, said in an interview yesterday. He was talking in connection with Book Week, which starts tomorrow and which he organized fourteen years ago.
It was a statesman, who spoke these words at the opening meeting of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- While Congressional wets pressed plans today for a fight to put through a modification measure at the short session beginning next month, Amos W.W. Woodcock, prohibition administrator, made it known that despite the outcome of Tuesday's election his department would "carry on as usual."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The qualities of character making an Irishman will be brought out in a unique anthropological survey of Ireland, from prehistoric times down to the modern Irish Free State, was announced tonight at Harvard University by Professor 'E.A. Hooton.
One-family dwellings figured largely in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The Columbia freshman football team defeated Roxbury School of Cheshire, Conn., 24 -- 6, yesterday at Baker Field. It was the final game of the season for both teams and marked the Lions' first victory in five games. The Roxbury record is two victories and three defeats.

A golf player whose ball hits his own caddy is not necessarily responsible for injury to the caddy, but if he hits the caddy of another player then he is responsible, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

Captain Leon Saunders, hajbor master at Clinton, Conn., is one fisherman who refuses to be silenced by the barrage of shot fired by duck hunters along the Connecticut shore. Not that Captain Saunders doesn't do his share of duck hunting, especially with plenty of the birds almost at his front door, but he thinks that so long as there is a chance of getting fish a real fisherman should devote his time to that objective.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Stimulated by yesterday's improvement in the New York market and the opening of debt negotiations, the Boerse started stronger today, with gains of 1 to 3 points in early trading. No public demand developing, however, stocks receded again under realizing sales and the general closing level was not materially changed from that of yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11 -- On the spot where Appleton Chapel once stood, hundreds of graduates and resident members of the university gathered today for dedication of the new Harvard Memorial Church.

The $1,000 international military sweepstake, most notable event on the program of the third day of the forty-seventh annual national horse show in Madison Square Garden was won last night by a member of the Irish Free State Army's team.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Central High School's hitherto undefeated team was eliminated from city, sectional and State titular consideration, today when it lost to South Side High, 12 to 6, before more than 8,000 at the Newark School Stadium in a City League game.

TOKYO, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Jiro Satoh, Japanese Davis Cup star and former national champion, today was defeated in the final of the national tourney by Ryosuke Nunoi, a college student, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

A touchdown in the second quarter by Aesop, substitute right halfback and an extra point by Devine, right tackle, enabled the St. John's High School football team of Brooklyn to tie Horace Mann School for Boys 7-7, before 1,000 on the Horace Mann gridiron yesterday.

Homeless but Not Children. Our rotogravure section for Sunday, Oct. 23, had a, page of pictures showing some of the young men who have taken to the road in large numbers under the pressure of economic conditions.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Havens Titcomb of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Burgess Titcomb of Los Angeles, Cal., and Guadalajara, Mexico, to William Murdock Rains of Los Angeles took place yesterday arternoon at the Biltmore. The Rev. Herbert R. Stevenson of St. Bartholomew's Church performed the ceremony.
Hope for greater international understanding was voiced by consuiar representatives of Great Britain, France and Italy in Armistice Day addresses broadcast yesterday afternoon over WINS.

Victories were gained by George Fissler of the New York A.C. and Miss Dorothea Dickinson of the Women's Swimming Association, members of the recent American Olympic team, in scratch free style events that featured a water carnival for the benefit of the New York American Christmas Fund last night at the London Terrace pool.

With oratory and ceremony and a display of flags and with a din of Whistles, sirens and bells, followed by two minutes of silence at 11 A. M., New York City joined yesterday in the world-wide celebration, of Armistice Day, marking the fourteenth anniversary of the end of the World War.

BOSTON, Nov. 11. -- Fortune Gallo announced here today that he had engaged Mme. Maria Jeritza to sing the role of Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana" next Wednesday evening and the part of Elsa in "Lohengrin" next Friday evening at the Boston Opera House.

After a series of meetings at Geneva, the preparatory commission for the forthcoming World Economic Conference has adjourned. An American delegation was present at each session. The commission reports that a preliminary exchange of views has helped to " define the problems with which "the conference should deal and to "analyze the best means of solving them internationally."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- George Washington University's football team rolled up a two-touchdown lead and then held off a militant William and Mary eleven to score a 12-to-6 victory tonight before 15,000 fans.

Factory employment in New York State in October showed an increase over September of 2.8 per cent, an increase several times greater than the seasonal rise of less than 1 per cent, according to the October figures given out yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Frances Perkins.

A transfer of the interest of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in the manufacture of higher alcohols to a new company, ending patent litigation between Standard of New Jersey and the Petroleum Chemical Corporation, was announced yesterday.

For the thirteenth time since 1904 the football teams of New York University and Fordham will clash today. The battle between the Violet and Maroon will get under way at the Tankee Stadium at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

The first batch of food and shelter tickets to be distributed as a means of ending professional begging on the streets was furnished yesterday to contributors to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee's $15,000,000 fund-raising effort.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- As political discussion here centred upon the chances for legalizing beer at the short session of Congress, Representative McDuffie of Alabama, Democratic Whip of the House, declared that he saw no reason why this should not be done without waiting for a new Congress.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Princeton and Yale will clash on the gridiron of Palmer Stadium here tomorrow in one of tire outstanding football games of the East. A crowd of 50,000 is expected to witness the contest, which will mark the fifty-sixth meeting in a series inaugurated in 1873.

All the markets advanced yesterday and there were further signs of returning financial confidence. The stock market, which added substantially to Thursday's gains, entered what Wall Street referred to as the "profitable phase" -- meaning that the volume was of sufficient size to make the business remunerative from the viewpoint of the brokers.

LLANGOLLEN, Va., Nov. 11. -- Unless the weather takes a turn in this valley in the Virginia hills, one of the most interesting and successful hunt meetings of the season is expected to be run off here tomorrow on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney.

Two games are outstanding on today's prep school football program, the Exeter-Andover contest, a fixture for more than half a century, and the Kent-Choate encounter, which will be the twenty-third gridiron meeting between the two schools.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The tariff issue as emphasized by the two major parties is not primarily the cause of our present economic disturbance, and so long as we adhere to this belief, so long will we have our hands tied.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The nation paid homage today to the heroes of the World War in the dedication of the completed Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington Cemetery. The ceremonies were the chief event of the Armistice Day observance here, and the big amphitheatre at the tomb was filled with guests, while outside, over the Virginia hills, thousands of veterans were packed with massed colors.

Plans were being made yesterday to operate the elevated lines of the Manhattan Railway Company at a five-cent fare, in case the 999-year lease to the Interborough should be abrogated because of that company's equity receivership.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 11. -- Vanderbilt's eleven is in top form to meet the Conference pace-setters, the University of Tennessee Volunteers, tomorrow. A ball-carrying duel between Roberts, Vanderbilt halfback, and Feathers, Volunteer halfback, is expected.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Although the total of demand and savings deposits in State banks on Sept. 30 was approximately $13,000,000 less than three months previously, the State Department of Banking reported today that money was not withdrawn in the last quarter in the same proportion as in the preceding six months.

Cardinal Hayes has appointed the Rev. John J. Casey, who has been an assistant at St. Ann's Church, 112 East Twelfth Street, to be his private secretary. Father Casey succeeds Mgr. Stephen J. Donahue, whom the Cardinal recently appointed pastor of the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street.

No unified wish for real disarmament has yet been professed by the nations of the world, Dr. Julius Curtius, former German Minister for Foreign Affairs, declared at an Armistice Day meeting held last night in Carnegie Hall by the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Joe D'Alessio of the local Irish-American A.C., a former runner at Newark Central High School, won the second annual five-mile road race today held by the 312th Infantry Association. He finished first in a field of 104 in 29 minutes 17 seconds.

The Abbey Theatre Irish Players will end a four weeks' engagement at the Martin Beck Theatre tonight. Their bill this afternoon will be "The New Gossoon," and they will repeat this evening "The Playboy of the Western World," which "Will be preceded by "Spreading the News."

BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP). -- Some of the uses science has found for derivatives of natural gas and petroleum were described tonight for the northeastern section of the American Chemical Society by Dr. J.G. Davidson of New York City, and they ranged all the way from artificial ripening of oranges to automobile anti-freeze.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- The Glen Riddle Farm's War Glory, a chestnut son of Man o' War, captured the featured $5,000 added Walden Handicap before an Armistice Day crowd of 10,000 at Pimlico today. Leading practically from start to finish, the colt was the winner by two lengths at the end of the mile and a sixteenth over a muddy track.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Colgate's Red Raiders, unbeaten and unscored on, were overwhelmingly favored tonight to defeat Syracuse in their thirty-fifth meeting in Archbold Stadium tomorrow. The only betting was on points, with Colgate supporters freely offering 20 points.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- The United States, through Hugh R. Wilson, put its weight today behind the proposal Naotake Sato of Japan made Wednesday that gas reprisals against violators of the ban on gas warfare be forbidden.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., Nov. 11 (AP). -- A Georgetown woman with a New England fortune and a Virginia estate was described in court proceedings here today as the cause of the marital rift between Mrs. Jouett Shouse and her husband, former chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee.

TOKYO, Nov. 11 -- The draft budget for 1933-1934, as adopted by the Cabinet yesterday, amounts to the unprecedented total of 2,235,000,000 yen [$469,350,000 at the current rate, about two-fifths of parity].

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Ninety-eight House drys and seven dry Senators who have given strength to the prohibition cause in the present Congress will not be present when the Seventy-third Congress is called together. Among them are some outstanding leaders in the dry cause.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Although today, the Crown Prince of Sweden's fiftieth birthday, which he celebrated quietly in London, passed without an announcement of the engagement of his daughter, Princess Ingrid, to Prince George, which it had been rumored would be made on this occasion, nevertheless the belief continued strong here and in Sweden that early developments might be expected.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee introduced yesterday an amendment to the emergency housing law in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly with the object of giving the city power to grant or deny tax exemption to such housing developments as that planned by the Hillside Housing Corporation in the East Bronx, for which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is favorably disposed to lend money.

Members of the American Railway Association, the organization through which the railroads act in concert to improve equipment and operating methods, took steps yesterday at their Fall meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to widen the scope of the association's research and experimentation.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 -- The newsprint situation in Canada, recently acutely disturbed by price-cutting and fears of further reductions, assumed a more encouraging aspect today, when it was stated that progress had been made at conferences between representatives of the principal producers and a bankers' committee.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Because of a slight cold Governor Roosevelt stayed in bed today and canceled plans for a week-end at Hyde Park. He arranged for a period of complete isolation and rest at the Executive Mansion until Tuesday.

HAVANA, Nov. 11 -- Estimates of the death toll in the hurricanewrecked town of Santa Cruz del Sur ranged from 300 to 1,500 today, with the wounded put at 700. In addition there were untold casualties in outlying districts along the cost of Camaguey Province.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the one-year franchise applications of nine existing bus operators in Queens and one in Manhattan. At the same time it fixed Dec. 9 as the date of the statutory public hearing on the franchise contract in each case.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 11 (AP). -- C.E. Hamilton's Slash, a lukewarm favorite, scored in the Armistice Purse, feature today at Latonia. After a rather tardy beginning, the mudrunning son of Atwell closed with a rush that was not to be denied. The winner ran the mile and seventy yards in 1:52 2-5.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The fourteenth anniversary of the armistice was observed here today by French and foreigners alike with less of the martial spirit than has marked the occasion in Paris in the past.

In the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night the British Great War Veterans of American gave "their annual Armistice Daj ball, an event attended by several hundred persons, including prominent officials and members of the British colony here. The net pro ceeds will be devoted to the relief fund of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today postponed until Dec. 12 the general investigation of its jurisdiction over Seatrian, Lines, Inc., but continued taking testimony as to the legality of stock holdings in the line by the Texas Pacific Railroad Company and the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company.

The annual armistice ball and reunion of the First Division Lieutenant Jeff Feigl post, American Legion, took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Astor, drawing a throng of more than 2,000 persons representative of society, military and civic circles.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11. -- The Baron and Baroness von Popper (the Baroness is Maria Jeritza) are not contemplating a divorce, nor are they separated, they declared today in answer to rumors of such action.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 11 (AP). -- Frank Lloyd Wright, the Wisconsin architect, speaking at the Institute of Art at Brown University, today ridiculed Yale University for its "foolish" perpetuation of modern architecture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Notes from Great Britain and France dealing with the war debt problem had been received by the State Department, Secretary Stimson said today. The British note, which was delivered yesterday by Ambassador Lindsay, was telegraphed to President Hoover at Palo Alto, Cal.

A stampede to cover short positions in sterling exchange, started by the action of Great Britain in requesting a postponement of the payment of $95,500,000 on her war debt to this country in December, whirled the pound up 4 3/4 cents yesterday before it was checked by official selling.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (AP). -- The case of Earl Seibert, holdout New York Ranger defense man, has been referred to President Frank Calder of the National Hockey League for official action under the new league ruling covering "persistent holdouts."

Commodity values were higher yesterday and, with the consolidated gains of the last several days, the best improvement in staples recorded in some time. Cotton rose 17 to 22 points, while rubber, silk and hides also moved upward. Eggs reached a new high for the year. Grain markets were closed for the Armistice Day holiday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 11. -- More extensive and more accurate handling of scientific news by the nation's press was advocated by Waldemar Kaempffert, science editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an address here tonight before a convention of Michigan editors.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- W.S. Knudsen, president and general manager of tha Chevrolet Motor Company, announced today that orders for material based on the manufacture of $20,000,000 worth of automobiles within the next few weeks are being released.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Chaco neutral commission today replied to the Argentine note asking about the neutral commission's conduct of the negotiations of peace between Paraguay and Bolivia. Text of the communication, which was given Ambassador Espil, was not made public.

Jane Addams of Hull House, Chicago, and six other well-known national leaders in character-building work for youth, have stressed the urgency of this division of social welfare in statements to Paul F. Warburg and Ira M. Younker, co-chairmen of the 1932 campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies to complete a budget of $3,923,000.
Editor, The New York Times Book Review: In his review of "Tudor Sunset" in your issue of Oct. 16, Herbert Gorman writes:

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES, in giving an account of present conditions in Siam, repeats the assertion, previously suggested in your issue of Aug. 14, that the Siamese revolution of last June was secretly promoted by his Majesty, King Prajadhipok, himself.

MONTREAL, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Bits of skin cut from his hands by Stanislaus Hausner, American transatlantic flier who was forced down at sea and given up for lost last June, proved indifferent lure for fish.

100 Tears a Democrat. James F. Webb of East Marion, Suffolk County, N.Y., cast his first vote in 1854. His first Presidential vote was for Buchanan, in 1856. On Nov. 8 he cast his twentieth Presidential vote, for Franklin D. Roosevelt.

TWO Democratic Presidents have occupied the White House since the Civil War, each coming to power at a time of change and crisis in the nation's affairs, each a strong personality guided by a definite conception of the functions of government and of his own high office.

A TWENTY-YEAR cycle, showing the remarkable reversal in ascendency of the Democratic and Republican parties, is covered by the maps on this page. The Republicans, after a series of victories beginning with McKinley, sank to a nadir in the vote by States in 1912, carrying only Vermont and Utah for their Presidential candidate, "William Howard Taft.

MORE in sorrow than in anger, or so he maintains, a correspondent wishes enlightenment as to why two comparatively recent Victor Masterpiece sets (Nos. 123 and 141, numbers, be it noted, having no reference to sequence of issue) have been allowed to slip by without any mention here.
LONDON, Nov. 12.--Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, will start for Geneva tomorrow, ready to make disarmament proposals that will synchronize with the revival of the war debt issue in Washington.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -- Meadow Brook, the invading team from the United States, turned the tables on Argentina today by defeating Santa Paula, 8 to 7, to win the Argentine open polo championship. Santa Paula, defending champion, won the United States open title two years ago.

HAVANA, Nov. 12 -- Overwhelmed by the number of refugees pouring into the city since yesterday from the hurricane area, the authorities of Camaguey frantically beseeched the government today to rush urgently needed medical supplies, physicians, food and wearing apparel in order to combat an imminent epidemic.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 12 -- Notre Dame's football machine, heated to the boiling point by one of the most intense rivalries in athletic competition, flattened Northwestern today in a wintry setting.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Scoring in every quarter, Seton Hall College easily defeated Brooklyn College at Setonia Field today, 32 -- 6. Three of the Seton Hall touchdowns were made by Marty Shrinkwitch, who crossed the goal Iine twice in the second quarter and once in the final period, all on runs from beyond the 25-yard line.

To the Music Editor: When Walter Anderson, in his letter in yesterday's TIMES, gets so wroth, and begins to razz Dr. Damrosch, I wonder if he really means what he said, and if he knows what he is talking about, and, if so, has he children of his own?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- West Virginia Wesleyan defeated Georgetown, 14-0, today before a crowd of 3,000.

By a vote of 3,780 to 3,256, Typographical Union 6 has rejected the wage scale for book and job plants offered by the Printers League Section of the New York Employing Printers Association, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 24. MOST of the new plays of this week are exactly what one would expect from the theatres and the authors who have produced them.
