Denys Amiel's "L'Age duFer," at the Comedie Francaise, and Jean Suberville's "Don Juan," at the Odeon, are both eminently admirable' works, the one full, of serious thought on the social problem of contemporary life end the other displaying a creditable degree or poetic imagination, being written in verse.
A 27-yard forward pass which Tony Sarausky, 190-pound fullback, caught on N.Y.U.'s 4-yard line gave Fordham its eighth victory over its intracity rival yesterday at the Yankee Stadium.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Coach Fritz Crisler was a disappointed but proud man as he walked from Palmer Stadium to the Osborne Field House, where the Princeton team was dressing after today's game.

THESE days one hears a good many people talking about the great American game -- football -- as though it were a Frankenstein monster, built up by the colleges and now running away with them. Football, these people say, is being ruined by professionalism, or by roughness of the game, by the high cost of coaching staffs, or by the big money interest involved.

THAT the classroom movie is able to add facts to a pupil's repertoire at a spectacular rate has been indicated in test after test lately. An attempt to see whether through its power of concentrating attention it can also arouse curiosity or stimulate ideas has now been made in the Junior High School at Great Neck, L. I., by Miss Josephine Matthews, an instructor.

The universities of the world, while making progress in the sphere of learning, have failed to provide public leadership and gave little assistance in meeting paramount political and economic problems during the depression, Howard Lee McBain, Dean of the faculties of political science, philosophy and pure science at Columbia University, declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday.

ONE must be a clock watcher to be a successful broadcaster, according to David Ross, staff announcer of the Columbia Broadcasting System, who was singled out from the ranks of his fellow microphone colleagues as the recipient of the fourth award for good diction on the radio, presented annually by the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

ONE HUNDRED years ago last night the Bowery Theatre roared with such applause as greets few actors in any generation. The orchestra pit and the four circling balconies rocked and cheered, forgot the tragedy that had opened the program, forgot that another play was to come, forgot even to munch peanuts and throw the shells about in the accepted manner of those times.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 12 -- A long pass from Carnie Smith to Quarterback Elmer Schaake in the waning moments of the game gave the University of Kansas Jayhawkers their third consecutive victory over the Missouri Tigers, 7 to 0, in the forty-first renewal of their football rivalry today.

When a hurricane turns the ordinary perturbations of weather into disaster and breathes death across the landscape, the nature-lover finds it necessary to revise his conceptions. Although nature is man's deepest refuge, she is also his greatest peril. Those who live where tornadoes and hurricanes are a constant danger to life and security have ample reason to know how feeble human powers are in the face of natural frenzies.

PHILANTHROPY is to have a large place in the many dances being planned for the diversion of both older and younger members of society. While parties for debutantes can be arranged more or less tentatively, those in behalf of various charities must be set for definite dates well ahead in order to allow the organizing committees ample time to sell tickets and prepare supplementary features of entertainment.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 12 Choate School's powerful scoring machine stamped itself as one of the strongest teams in scholastic football circles today as it brought to a close its season with a 40-to-7 triumph over Kent. Choate's victory was the twelfth in a row over a period of two years.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: In your issue of Oct. 9 the closing paragraph of Mr. Hutchison's review of "John Clare: A Life," while it pays adequate tribute to the quality of the man, does little honor to the poet whose influence, spiritual and technical, on postwar verse can hardly he overestimated.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Reduction of Federal expenditures and discovery of why the capitalistic system "is not working" were two jobs delegated to the Roosevelt administration by speakers at concluding sessions today of a post-election stock-taking conference, sponsored by the American Academy of Political and Social Science and the Taylor Society.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- A hard fighting Yale freshman eleven defeated the Harvard yearlings, 32-19, in the Bowl today. The Crimson cubs in the final period scored two of their three touchdowns and narrowly missed other tallies.

THERE is a controversy on saving as opposed to spending -- whether in these days it is wise or right to save. We had better disregard theory and come hack again to our own common sense to decide what is right. It must be clear that there is a distinction between the duty of public bodies and private individuals.

THIS, the third volume of Hamlin Garland's literary recollections pieced together from his diaries, is pre-eminently a Book of the Dead. To begin with, it carries Mr. Garland through the melancholy war years, from 1914 to the aftermath of the "Red hunts" and the post-war depression.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial, "The Universe Changes," gives considerable quiet satisfaction to some of us interested in styles of universes. Step by step, for nearly four years, theory after theory has fallen of its own weight. We are reminded of the medieval architects who, ignorant of mechanical laws, threw up pile upon pile of masonry.

MADRID, Oct. 29 -- The Socialist party, most powerful factor in Spanish politics, voted in its National Congress in favor of the dissolution of the Guardia Civil, Spain's national constabulary, which has been used as a model for similar forces all over the Spanish-speaking world.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Indications of better conditions were observed in Several lines here this week.

To the Music Editor: May I beg a little of your patience and your space to endorse the courageous statements of Walter Andersen in your issue of Sunday, Nov. 6, with regard to the claims of Dr. Walter Damrosch?

Gains in prices of bonds of domestic corporations were extended yesterday on the Stock Exchange in trading that ran about $1,000,000 heavier than on the previous Saturday. A fairly representative list of issues moved up 1 to more than 4 points.

OF the eighty-six paintings constituting the memorable loan exhibition of Flemish primitives held at the Kleinberger Galleries in 1929, twelve were borsowed from the Friedsam collection. The eighty-six Flemish primitives came, in all, from some thirty-six American sources, including the collection just mentioned.

IT was a formidable, but doubtless intriguing, task to which Clifford Smyth set his hand when he essayed the telling of the story of this country through the biographies of the men most responsible for its birth and growth, its form and feature and spirit.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- Premier Herriot's speech at Toulouse, wherein he appeared to make a bid for Italian friendship, reviving the hope that the Italo-French difficulties may be smoothed out, has not impressed Italy as deeply as perhaps was intended.
HOOVER DAM, Nev., Nov. 12 (AP) The full text of President Hoover's address here tonight follows:

NOW that the political bombardment of 1932 is silenced the broadcasters are surveying the ethereal battlefield. The mail received from listeners is giving the broadcasters a clue as to what a cross-section of the many millions who own radio sets think of politics on the air.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 12 -- Only ideals of generosity, gratitude and geniality will tide a man over the storms of economic adversity and economic prosperity, James E. Finnegran, 02, of Brooklyn, told the faculty and undergraduates of Union College today, speaking for the alumni at the college's Fall homecoming.

American exports to Canada have suffered a drop of less than 10 per cent in volume as a result of the imposition of new duties by the Canadian Government a month ago today, according to unofficial checks completed Friday by export organizations here.

Great interest was aroused in the insurance world late last week by the critical recommendations that other forms of insurance might well model their investment practices after those of the life companies, made by George S. Van Schaick. New York State Superintendent of Insurance, before the Life Underwriters Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Bank debits outside New York City increased during the week ended Nov. 5, according to the Department of Commerce weekly survey of domestic business made public today. The rise continued the irregular movement of recent weeks, marked by an absence of trend in either direction.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Albie Booth Vas the first of the Yale force to move into Palmer Stadium today. He went in to discover how the wind was blowing and reported back to Coach Mal Stevens at the Field House that it was blowing in all directions.

BUDAPEST, OCT. 20. A DEGREE of optimism which is particularly surprising in face of the apparently everlasting economic crisis has marked the opening of the Fall theatrical season in this capital. Ten theatres and ten vaudeville houses have opened their doors and the playwrights of standing who, in other years, have reserved their products until later "in the season have come forward this year before the snows have begun to fly.

IT seems very strange after so long an interval to come across another story from the pen of Sir James Barrie. "Farewell Miss Julie Logan" is the first story he has written for nearly thirty years, and though of course many of his best-known plays are comparatively recent, the stories by which he first made his name have retreated so far into the past as to make him almost a legendary figure.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt's victory was announced to Paris by radio and by bulletins throughout election night at every restaurant and bar where Americans habitually congregate.

SUVA, Fiji Islands, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press).--All the members of the crew and all the passengers of the Church of England's mission ship Southern Cross VI were safe today, some on the island of Aneityum in the New Hebrides and others bound for the Solomon lslands.

To the Music Editor: Permit me to answer Mr. Walter Andersen's strictures as printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday, on my objections to feeding children with experimental ultra-modern music before they have been well grounded in the classics.

THE defeat of President Hoover directs attention to the careers of ex-Presidents following their retirement from office. Several have continued to wield political power; others have quit politics entirely.

AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ARTS AND LETTERS -- Retrospective exhibition of paintings by Gari Melchers. The large and well-arranged showing presents this artist's oeuvre so comprehensively as to give a wholly satisfactory resume of his career.

T.H. Lawrence won the first registered shoot of the season over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The scores counted on the year's averages of the American Trapshooting Association, and as a result thirty-six went to the firing line.

WHEN Giulio Gatti-Casazza opens the Metropolitan Opera season a week from tomorrow right he will fill his first round of the subscription with a varied interest of daily debuts and diverse operas that range from last year's chief triumph, of two American-born baritones to a centenary of Italian classic comedy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Weather that was made for most anything but golf stung and blew some of the nation's foremost professionals clear off their game today and a pair of comparative unknowns led the field in the opening round of the national capital open.

A rise in three days of nearly three-quarters of a cent a pound in the price of cotton brought out large supplies of that staple in producing sections yesterday and quotations on the Cotton Exchange here were set back 15 to 18 points net.

VICTORIA, B.C., Nov. 12 -- Canada is preparing to defend herself. The government has appointed a radio commission which will go to work at once to devise ways to protect Canadians from having their peace of mind disturbed in 1936 as it has been in this Presidential year of 1932.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- Southern California is as pleased as a baby with a toy balloon over the result of the election -- that is, all but the wise-acres who guessed that the State was in the doubtful column; that Los Angeles county was for the Rev. Bob Shuler and that this end of the Commonwealth was dry.
NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 12 -- The Boston University football team finished its home season by holding the highly favored Tufts eleven to a 9-9 tie today.

Notice has been given to the delegates to the American Kennel Club for the regular meeting to be held at the offices of the club on Tuesday, Dec. 6. This will be the last meeting of the year and also one of the most important, since the delegates will have before them for final action the revised rules as drafted by the special delegates' committee.

ATHENS ACIENT GREECE emerges. From under the ruin that centuries have piled upon her, she comes up smiling. To visit Athens is to find something always new. You find the stones of her temples being once more set in place.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Discussion of possible solutions to economic problems of the United Hates and the world occupied the attention of some of the nation's foremost industrial and business leaders here today.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 17 -- With the recent formal opening of the new 133-mile automobile highway, joining Shanghai and Hangchow, the people of Shanghai are at last able to drive more than twenty-five miles from the city, which has hitherto been the extreme limit for an automobile trip.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A news item in THE TIMES about the finding of articles made of ivory in the northern part of Alaska by a Smithsonian Institution expedition, and the theory of an "ivory civilization" based upon the discoveries has a strong appeal to the imagination.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 12 -- Wisconsin gambled on passes in the last minute of play today and won, defeating Minnesota, its traditional rival, by a score of 20 to 13, in one of the most thrilling games ever played in their forty-two years of competition.

The proposed absorption by the Aviation Corporation of Delaware of the transport lines of North American Aviation, Inc., and the Transamerican Airlines Corporation, which is being opposed by E.L. Cord, a director of the Aviation Corporation , and the largest single stockholder, represents the most important integration of air transport lines that has been projected since 1930.

TODAY. 1:00 P.M. -- WEAF, WJZ -- The initial broadcast from Radio City brings to the microphone its "Mayor," S.L. Rothafel (Roxy), and his group of entertainers. Roxy will act as master of ceremonies.

If there was but little discussion of the war debts during the campaign, it was tacitly understood that an effort would be made by European nations to reopen the question as soon as the campaign ended. The agreement on German reparations in July was made to depend for its ratification on "a satisfactory settlement" of debts due to the United States.

Giacomo de Martino, retiring Italian Ambassador to the United States, sailed yesterday afternoon for Genoa on the new Italian liner Rex for a rest, he said, before taking up a new post to be offered to him toy Premier Mussolini.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- What is equality? Anatole France once defined it as "the majesty of the law punishing in the same way the rich and the poor when stealing a piece of bread." This rather paradoxical definition is quite true. The principle of equality does not mean a substantial equality but nothing else than "non-discrimination."

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- Moderately encouraged by the results of his talk with Premier Mussolini, Norman H. Davis returned to Geneva today to confer tomorrow with Sir John Simon, whom he expected to arrive then by air with details of the British disarmament plan.

WALTER B. PITKIN, of the faculty of Columbia University's School at Journalism, is known to readers as a man who holds his convictions sturdily and expresses them without fear or favor. In this new book he assails with profound conviction and picturesque vigor the idea that this world is for the young, and that after 40 life pales and rapidly becomes less useful, interesting and pleasurable.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 12 -- Paced by little Chris Mathis, 147-pound halfback, and galloping George Sauer, the Scarlet's great fullback, Nebraska's ball carriers stole the show from Warren Heller and Mike Sebastian, Pitt aces, to gain the Huskers a scoreless tie with the Panthers today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1 -- The political panorama of the entire world presents at this moment everchanging scenery. In Europe Sovietism, fascism and Hitlerism have come into being. In South America Argentina tried mild socialism with some success and Chile essayed bolshevism with disastrous results.

Although President Hoover did not achieve the impossible, history "may very well decide that under a lesser man America during his term of office might have suffered far more grievous misfortunes than she has in fact been called upon to face," according to John Drinkwater, the English poet and playwright, in a statement he prepared for today's issue of The London Sunday Dispatch giving his impressions of the American Presidential election.

SHALL the individual States be permitted to erect barriers at their individual boundaries to prevent free and unrestricted interflow of commerce? The possibility of such a situation being realized is suggested by recent activities involving Pennsylvania and its neighboring States.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The recorded annual circulation of the Princeton University Library has more than doubled since 1923, James Thayer Gerould, librarian, revealed in his annual report to the university trustees, made public recently.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. S. Hoxie dark will give a supper dance Nov. 25 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary H. Clark.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee of New York City, finished a fox hunt over several estates with a group of hunters today despite injuries which required medical attention.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The running attack of Jack James of Princeton and the punting of Dud Parker of Yale were high lights of the gridiron battle of the rival elevens today. Both sides exhibited a strong defense until passes brought touchdowns in the final period.

THERE is no denying Francis Brett Young's superb endowment as a novelist. He commands a prose style which is supple and rich in color; he possesses a vivid and fertile imagination, and the range of his material, both realistic and romantic, is uncommonly wide.

THE economic stress of the last three years has revealed in a disquieting manner the insecure foundations on which the Entire structure of our private hospitals rests. In view of the reliance which our communities have placed on the private hospital, the situation calls for measures that will do more than bridge over a temporary difficulty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A most-favored-nation commercial treaty has been concluded between Germany and Switzerland and becomes provisionally effective next Thursday, pending mutual ratification, according to a report today to the Commerce Department.

THE plans for the Winter season of opera in Prague have been determined somewhat by the response to works given last year, according to an article in the Central European Observer. The 1931-32 season concluded with a financial success superior to that of previous years, and well-nigh unique in operatic annals these days.
Columbia's dream of a season of conquest surpassing any other in its history came to an end yesterday in the last ten minutes of one of the most thrilling football games ever seen in this city.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Eighty-five honor students at Smith College, winners of scholarships valued at $202,000, are announced as follows:

To the Dramatic Editor: Since Shakespeare's time, the play has been uppermost in every one's mind. But -what about the play-wright? How do authors "get that way" and where do they learn their extremely difficult and many-sided art of writing for the stage?

The Cosmopolitan Club women's field hockey team scored its fifth victory in as many starts by turning back the undefeated Carter-Circle eleven, 4 to 3, in a New York Field Hockey Association match at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. It was the closing game of the season for both teams and left the winners as the only unbeaten eleven in the association.

CLINTON, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Asserting that rosy visions of those foreseeing beer in sixty days were only "idle dreams," Senator David I. Walsh, a militant wet, said here today that it would probably be two years before legalized beer could be sold and five years before the Eighteenth Amendment could be repealed.
PERFORMANCES of a number of theatrical and musical productions have been taken over in behalf of various philanthropic organizations, several of them taking place this week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The first experience that our country had in connection with being off the gold standard was with respect to the depreciation and redemption "of Continental currency. On the commencement of the Revolution, Congress had no money.

Bonds called last week for redemption this month in advance of their maturity dates were few in number and small in amount. They were chiefly lots of municipal loans. The total of calls for November is $29,053,000, compared with $9,827,000 in October and $26,827,000 in November, 1931, at corresponding dates.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- Massachusetts might well be recognized as the most unpredictable State in the Union, with Rhode Island next in line. The Literary Digest poll went wrong on both in 1928 and again this year. Both times the poll put the two States in the Republican column, and both times both States went Democratic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Without waiting for the arrival of President Hoover, the State Department will make public tomorrow afternoon the British and French appeals for revision of their war debt settlements with the United States. The notes will be published in newspapers Monday morning.

AFTERMATH. LAST Tuesday's tornado has passed by, and prgstrate orphans of the storm are picking themselves up. Something has happened also to Charles Darwin's theory of evolution. The election has given it a backward twist.

Last week the following statement of direct concern to more than one-half our total population and of indirect concern to the remaining millions was made by Mr. GEORGE S. VAN SCHAICK, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York:

Four of the largest motors ever built for any purpose will be used to propel the new French liner Normandie, which was launched on Oct. 29 at the Penhoet shipyard at St. Nazaire. Engineers of the General Electric Company yesterday said that the ship would have an official horsepower rating of 160,000, each of the motors being listed at 40,000 horsepower.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The existence of a secret French dossier, containing evidence of Germany's alleged evasions of the disarmament clauses in the peace treaty, was revealed by Premier Harriot at Geneva some weeks ago. I am now able to disclose part of the testimony bearing on German naval preparations which the French Government collected for the purpose of this dossier.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 12 -- Effective bombardment by ten airplanes of a Paraguayan troop concentration on the southern front in the Chaco district was unofficially reported here today.

WHETHER you want to take it that they're putting new wine in old bottles or puting old wine in new bottles or just putting wine in bottles -- or not bothering with the bottles at all -- there have come along several producers during the current season who have pumped new life in old plays and presented what they call revivals.

LAST Tuesday the American people made a choice for what is regarded as the world's most difficult job. Upon the man who occupies the White House for the next four years, more than upon any other man on earth who can now be named, depends the solution of problems which affect not only a nation but a planet.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) -- An attempt of Colonel Roscoe Turner to establish a new round-trip transcontinental air record ended at Port Columbus here at 2:22 P.M. today when, the right tire blew out as he brought his 375-horsepower monoplane to the ground.

Moscow's big newspapers, Pravda and Izvestia, made a radical departure from the strictly impersonal tone which characterizes news in Soviet Russia by publishing a portrait of JOSEPH STALIN'S dead wife. But only once does the name of the Communist dictator appear. Among tributes to "Comrade NADEZHDA SERGEIEVNA ALLILUIEVA" as faithful worker for socialism, as "splendid" Bolshevist woman, as devoted party member, mention does occur of "the wife, "close friend and true helpmeet of Comrade STALIN."

Early United States coins, Colonial paper money used during the Revolutionary period, old banknotes, foreign gold coins from many countries and some scarce specimens of ancient Greek and Roman mintage will be sold at auction next Saturday afternoon by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

MILAN, Nov. 1, 1932. THE new "Inno del Decennale" or Decadal Hymn in commemoration of the tenth anniversary of the Fascist revolution, upon the text of Gavino Gabriel, which Umberto Giordano was commissioned by Mussolini to compose for the occasion, was heard for the first time recently at La Scala as part of a special benefit concert in the presence of II Duce.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- New Rochelle High School's undefeated, untied and unscored upon football team continued its brilliant record and forged ahead in the WestChester Interscholastlc Athletic Association championship race by blanking White Plains High, 12 to 0, before 15,000 today at the New Rochelle High School field.

The will of Darwin P. Kingsley chairman of the board of the New York Life Insurance Company, filed for probate yesterday, leaves the entire estate to his wife and five children with the exception of six gifts aggregating $14,000 to relatives and employes.

EVEN better will be the times that are coming. Destiny is in our hands, and it will be the masterpiece of our invincible will. In all countries one notices signs of uncertainty and uneasiness. Even people of old civilizations seem to be proceeding without guidance.

Incensed over the sudden change of attitude on the part of the Customs Bureau toward its inquiries into alleged violations of the anti-dumping regulations, importers here yesterday moved to initiate a Senatorial investigation of the recent activities of the bureau and of its head, F.X. A. Eble, Commissioner of Customs.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Providence College football team lost to Catholic University by 6 to 0 today in its final game of the season.

That Tuesday's crushing defeat of the Hoover Administration will go into political history as convincing evidence of the effect of hard times on electoral results, no one is inclined to dispute. Whatever may be said of the reasonableness or unreasonableness of voting against the "ins" and for the "outs" because of business disaster which had affected the world as a whole, the habit is as old as popular elections, perhaps as old as human nature.

TREGUIER, Brittany, Nov. 2 -- Abbe Jean Laine, who served as interpreter with the Seventh United States Infantry and was wounded near Montfaucon in October, 1918, has started a movement to place a memorial window in Treguier Cathedral in honor of St. Yves, the patron saint of all lawyers.

WHEN Edgar Selwyn was in town last season and planning to produce plays (he did, as a matter of record, produce one, but it didn't last very long) among the titles he sent out to the press was "The Lady Is Tired," a comedy by Frances Marion, who has some reputation as a scenario writer.

BARRY WOOD, former Harvard football captain and quarterback, and Reed Harris, former editor of The Columbia Spectator, whose attacks on football caused something of a campus furor last year, have written of college football from opposing standpoints, if Reed Harris can be said to have any standpoint.

OTTAWA, Nov. 10 -- Canada had a very deep interest in the United States Presidential election, not merely because everybody is concerned with the outcome of a hardfought battle but because in a number of ways the result touches this country's business and politics.

Mme. Guiomar Novaes, returning to her New York public after an interval of six years, gave a piano recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. She played a program of compositions of attested virtue, by Bach and Bach-Siloti, and Chopin, and finally a group of more recent compositions by the Brazilian VillaLobos, by Mompou, and Albeniz.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Army's powerful eleven overwhelmed North Dakota State College of Fargo, N.D., by 52 to 0 today. Ten thousand spectators, assembled in Michie Stadium, watched the Cadets crush the Westerners with a hard-driving attack which netted them eight touchdowns.

Sixteen hundred girls from a score of Y.W.C.A. branches in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut participated last night in "a celebration of the past and a dedication of the future" of the Young Women's Christian Associations at the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the organization's founding as a national unit, at Carnegie Hall.

The revision of reparations and tariffs to be followed by the disarmament of nations were factors recently urged as necessary to economic restoration and world peace by Premier Mussolini in an interview with Professor William Lyon Phelps of Yale University.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Effective at once, bonds equal to the value of all importations of Portland cement from Great Britain will be required by the Treasury Department, it was announced today. On a report of suspicion of dumping, filed with the Customs Bureau by the customs appraiser of New York, the bureau issued the order for the bond.

THIS is Her season: the debutante's. Everything in her orbit revolves around her. From now on until after the Christmas holidays she passes through her first important stage of social grooming. Each step of the way is fraught with excitement.
The Curtis and Textile High School football teams played a 12-to-12 tie yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, S.I., before a crowd of 5,000.

The downward trend in prices on the local commodity exchanges was partly broken last week. There were rallies in sugar, rubber, hides, silk and silver. Cocoa was fairly steady, while coffee and wool tops continued to move lower. Recoveries on Thursday and Friday counteracted earlier losses in some cases.

WEYHE Gallery -- Photographs or art forms in nature by Professor Karl Blossfeldt, which have aroused wide interest in reproduction in book form, make an interesting exhibition. The photographs excite admiration none the less because some of them have become familar.
A transcript of a default judgment for $485.90 against former Mayor James J. Walker was filed yesterday in the office of the County Clerk, in the Supreme Court Building.

Bids probably will be sought in December for the construction of a combination passenger and freight vessel for the Gulf Pacific Mail Line, to operate between Pacific Coast ports and Tampico, Puerto Colombia and Kingston. Two reconditioned ships Will be operated with the new ship.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- The University of Buffalo closed its season today with a 6-to-0 victory over Hobart, its old rival, on a snowcovered field. The victory was Buffalo's fourth straight over the Orange and Blue.

To the Dramatic Editor: There are some things in connection with the production of "The Paasionate Pilgrim" at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre recently that have not been said, and deserve some attention in your columns; for it ia not the first time in the history of Broadway criticism that a play of imaginative and poetic beauty has been dealt its death-blow by the critics.

IN "Flowering Wilderness, the latest novel by John Galsworthy, the commentator who is desirous of recording a fair judgment, a Judgment in which the demands of the reader are balanced with the purposes -- the apparent purposes -- of the author, finds himself confronting no easy task.
"NEVER before in the history of science has there been a subject about which so many able investigators have disagreed."

CHARITABLE enterprises will benefit from a number of forthcoming musical events that will enlist the aid of many persons prominent in the social and musical worlds. Chief among them will be the special performance of "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera House on the afternoon of Dec. 8, the net proceeds from which will be used to further the work of Sir Wilfred Grenfell among the fisher folk in Labrador and North Newfoundland.

THE election of Governor Roosevelt at a crucial time in the nation's history has directed attention once more to the four months' gap between the day When the voters name a new President and the day when he takes the oath of office.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- An occasion to watch the intimate connection which exists between affairs of Europe and in the United States is supplied by the Presidential election. Really, one is tempted to use the word "dependence," for it is the American influence upon the affairs of the old Continent, which is so great nowadays.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12.--Wet and dry leaders expressed radically different opinions today on the meaning of Tuesday's general election with reference to prohibition.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 12 -- Lake Shore Mines, Ltd., the largest Individual producer of gold in Canada, is reported to have treated 204,645 tons of dry ore in the three months ended on Sept. 30, from which was recovered a total builion of $3,032,000.

With the arraignment of two men in the Tombs Court yesterday on a charge of posing as city firemen, it was revealed that for some time the Welfare Department had been investigating reports that fake firemen had been imposing on business establishments and residents of the city by inducing them to buy tickets for balls under pretense the receipts were to aid charity funds for city employes.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Bronxville High School tallied a 20-to-0 football victory over Hackley School on the latter's field today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with deep interest THE TIMES editorial, "From Sectarianism to Unity." Doubtless the released extracts from the appraisal commission's report to the Laymen's Foreign Missions inquiry are being widely read.

LLANGOLLEN, Va., Nov. 12 -- Mrs. Marshall Field's Outlaw, a gelded son of Sir Gallahad III, won the Llangollen National Steeplechase Handicap, contested over the 3-mile brush course on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney today after the disqualification of Mrs. Allen Potts's Berrilldon Flash.
SANTIAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The tariff war between Chile and Argentina apparently came to end today when a modus vivendi was signed between the two countries.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 12 -- One steady, aggressive drive, which resulted in a touchdown, enabled the Harvard football team to defeat Holy Cross today. The Crimson warriors, outplayed considerably in the first half, managed, nevertheless, to keep their goal line safe and returned in the second half to fight their way through to a score and a 7-0 triumph.

Although the regular season of the National Hockey League opened last Thursday, New Tork has yet to see a home team in action. The Rangers began their activities on Thursday night against the Maroons in Montreal, and the New York Americans will inaugurate their campaign tonight in Chicago against the Black Hawks.

Faced with tin prospect of farreaching changes in the banking laws of the country at the forthcoming session of Congress, the banking community began last week to consider what steps it should take to meet the situation.

Due to the habit of keeping its Representatives and Senators long in office, the South gets most of the Congressional honors when the Democrats carry the country. This has often been used as a Republican bugaboo. The rule of seniority, which is responsible for Southern ascendency, has its foundation in the "you-tickle-me-I'll-tickle-you" philosophy.

A John Marin exhibition is always an event. This artist's latest work, in both water-color and oil, has been placed on view at Mr. Stieglitz's gallery, An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue. When speaking of Marin, one irresistibly mentions the mediums in that order, since until recently he has been identified in the public's mind almost exclusively with water-color.

Those who are thirsting for legal "real beer" may never be able to get it for 5 cents a glass. This was the opinion yesterday of an official of one of the large brewing companies which would supply the demand for beer if the Volstead act should be modified by Congress to legalize the brewing of beer of more than one-half of 1 per cent alcoholic content.

AMHERST, Nov. 12 -- The Amherst freshmen captured the Little Three title today by defeating the Williams yearlings, 20-0. Bob Donovan and Bob Dunn starred for the winners, while Mosely showed up well for the losers. On the first play in which Amherst had the ball, Donovan got loose around right end and ran 60 yards for a score.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 12 -- Charlie Galloway, Georgia Tech halfback, zigzagged his way for seventy-five yards and a touchdown to upset the University of Alabama team today, 6 to 0.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- It is no mere obvious remark to say that the most significant thing about the balloting in Pennsylvania last Tuesday was the way the people voted the Democratic ticket. That Democratic Presidential electors running on the Democratic ticket alone could even threaten the "ancient Republican fortress of Pennsylvania" was unthinkable.

MARGARET BREUNING, art critic of The Evening Post, contributes the leading article to the November number of The London Studio, her subject being American art at the Whitney Museum. "In this collection," writes "Miss Breuning, "it is quite possible to appreciate the undefinable quality we call 'American.'"

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Colgate's great football machine defeated Syracuse, 16-0, today in one of the finest football games ever played in Archbold Stadium. Twenty-five thousand fans saw the engagement. Held scoreless in the first period, Colgate delivered in the second.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Charles P. Howland of the Yale faculty was fatally injured when struck by an automobile on Whitney Avenue tonight. He died at the New Haven Hospital two hours later.

ANTIQUE interiors set up in museums serve as a source of knowledge concerning correct period decoration. They graphically demonstrate the proper harmony of walls, windows, floor and furniture, and show an appropriate color scheme for an interior of a given period.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- An armistice dance was given last night at the Scarsdale Golf Club by the Scarsdale Post of the American Legion.

Approximately 10 per cent of the homeless population of New York is made up of boys between the ages of 16 and 21, according to a survey of the effects of employment on community welfare made public yesterday by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- One of the most gratifying aspects of the election, of Judge Henry S. Horner as Governor of Illinois, in the opinion of many voters who, irrespective of party affiliation, gave him their support, is the fact that, although a Chicagoan, down-State Illinois endorsed him by a splendid majority.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- Soviet Russia began a campaign to purge the government of excessive employes today with orders to discharge between 25,000 and 30,000 "white collar workers" in government departments and trusts.

Children of society, subdebutantes and boys home from school for the week-end followed with keenest interest the program of events at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

OMAHA, Nov. 10 -- While it was in general the expected which happened in the corn belt on election day, it happened in a measure wholly unanticipated. It is doubtful if the chagrin of Republican party leadars over the result can equal the delighted surprise of their Democratic antagonists.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Henry Phipps, who was a member of the executive board of the United States Steel Corporation and who died at Great Neck on Sept. 22, 1930, left a net estate valued at $3,121,810.32, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed here with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The Yale players were rather subdued in their dressing room after the game today. They took off their togs and repaired to the showers in the matter-of-fact manner in which they would dress after a practice.

The annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science on Friday at the Hotel Astor will bring together distinguished economists, bankers and industrialists to discuss "Steps Toward Recovery" in an effort to point the way to a revival of world commerce.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Serge Koussevitzky, comes to New York for its first concert of the season here and offers on Thursday evening an all-Sibelius program, including the "Swanwhite" suite; the tone poem, "Tapiola," and Symphony No. 1.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Earl M. Reed Jr. of Mount Vernon, N.Y., who was believed to have perpetrated a practical joke when he forced a friend to ride with him to New Haven and left him there penniless, was held here today on charges of driving while intoxicated.

RICHMOND, Nov. 10 -- Something new in scenic driveways, at least in the Western Hemisphere, was made available to the public when the gorgeous new Skyline Drive on the crest of the Blue Ridge was thrown open recently in the Shenandoah National Park area.

BEFORE the Irish players have strolled too far away it might be interesting to inquire into the nature of their consistent success. Although their plays ranged from the mastery of "The Playboy of the Western World" and "Juno and the Paycock" to the mediocrity of "Birthright," they were never dull.

LONDON, Oct. 25. THE lady whose pen-name is C. L. Anthony and whose first piece, "Autumn Crocus," had good-humored romanticism that won for it considerable popular success has now written the story of a department store's fight for existence during the depression of trade.

RICHMOND, Nov. 12 -- Virginia, light-hearted with an all-time record Democratic majority and three sons mentioned as Cabinet possibilities, appears ready to take the advice of Viscountess Nancy Astor, back at her girlhood home, who told 5,400 persons at the opening of a community fund campaign:

Washington Square, which blossomed last Spring with the city's first outdoor art exhibition, reassumed a trace of Summer coloring yesterday when artists returned to open their second show and decked the streets about the square with their paintings.

HERBERT MARSHALL, whose cinematic image may be seen at the Rivoli in "Trouble in Paradise" and at the Paramount in "Evenings For Sale," was one individual who was born with no mission to become an actor. He wanted, in fact, to become a business man.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Department of Justice is studying the proposal for reorganization of the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiaries, a proposal which may, If agreed to, result in the abandonment of the anti-trust suit against the Radio Corporation group, scheduled for trial in the United States District Court at Wilmington next week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Before a chilled home-coming crowd of 15,000 Temple University defeated Penn State in the Temple Stadium today, 13 to 12. In seven starts the Owls have won five games and tied two.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 12 -- Auburn's unbeaten football team pushed aside Florida, 21-6, this afternoon in one of the finest games ever seen in Montgomery.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 25 -- Traces of the realistic art of prehistoric times in Palestine, the first ever to be Pound in this country, have been revealed in a cave called Umm Qatafa, in the Wadi Khareitun, near the site of ancient Herodium, about five miles east of Bethlehem.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 12 -- Don Zimmerman, Tulane back, who last week led the Green Wave to victory in the last two minutes of play, repeated today against Kentucky. With his team trailing, 3 to 0, Zimmerman ran a kick-off back 60 yards, threw a successful forward pass and then plunged-over for a touchdown.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Expter's student body marched through this Massachusetts town tonight back of a jubilant band to celebrate a 6-0 football triumph scored over its ancient rival, Andover, today.

There has been the usual praise or "American good nature" in accepting the result of a national election. In the present instance no other course was possible. The Democratic victory was so like a flood submerging the whole country that to rebel against it, or set up demurrers, or speculate upon what a difference would have been made by the transfer of a few votes in this State or that, would have been ridiculous.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Displaying a crushing offense that swept aside ends and opened wide holes in the line, the Amherst football team defeated Williams by 31 -- 7 today. The capacity crowd included two noted graduates -- former President Coolidge, of Amherst, and Governor Ely, of Williams.

THAT strange and mysterious man, George Berkeley, 1685-1753, philosopher, Bishop and Irish patriot, was born in Kilkenny. Of his parents little is known beyond some kinship with the English house of Berkeley. George matriculated at Trinity College, Dublin, destined for a fellowship and the church.
THE troubles of Ireland have again been attracting world attention. Not only have differences with England shaken the country bat factional disagreements within its own borders have continued.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 12 -- Continuing along the path to a Big Ten football championship, Purdue's high-powered Boilermakers rolled over Iowa, 18 to 0, today in the final game for the Hawkeyes.

TORONTO, Nov. 12 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs maintained their supremacy over the New York Rangers by scoring a 4-2 victory tonight in a rough contest. In the Stanley Cup play last Spring the champion Leafs took three straight games from the New Yorkers.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- Germany has another grievance, and this time the object of it is Wickham Steed, who is accused here of swallowing, hook, line and sinker, the charges in a propaganda volume entitled "Germany and Peace," by a Franco-Swiss named Roger de Wyss, who has recently published it in Franch in Geneva.

A change in the law protecting hen pheasants may be made in Connecticut before the advent of another shooting season, according to men well posted on the subject. The reason for the change is that, under a strict protective law, hen pheasants have become almost a nuisance.

The cruiser Karlsruhe, the first ship of the German Navy to visit the Port of New York since 1912, steamed into the harbor yesterday, glinting in the November sunlight. On a mission of good-will, she and those aboard her exchanged greetings, formal and informal, with everything from the harbor defenses to workbound commuters from New Jersey.

FROM Nov. 14 to 18 astronomers, professional and amateur, will turn their eyes and instruments to the constellation of Leo. For from a point in the sickle of Leo the Leonids will burst. Each year they are seen about the middle of November, and every thirty-three years they shoot across the sky in unusual abundance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The documents brought to light by Dr. Otto H.F. Vollbehr, German collector of incunabula, and chiefly the ordinance relating to the introduction of convict labor in the early stages of development of the Spanish colonies in America, constitute a valuable discovery.

LONDON LET us be thankful there are lots of books we haven't read. If they are any good, we have a pleasure before us; if not we have escaped a pain." That is Hamilton Fyfe's philosophical reflection in replying to an invitation from The Bookman (London) to supply a list of important books that have not hitherto been included within the range of his reading.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The wedding today at Holy Trinity Church, Marylebone, of Lord Hailsham's elder son, Quintin Hogg, and Natalie Sullivan, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Sullivan of Pluckley, Kent, was attended by many notables of several circles.

Butter. Receipts, 9.059 cases. The market wound up in extremely firm position on all grades. Prices were very firmly supported at the opening and additional strength was lent the position before the close by advances at Chicago, both spot and future, to a point wet above a parity with our present level.

Much has teen accomplished toward removing bigotry by the religious organizations of public school teachers in this city, Rufus M. Hartill, president of the Protestant Teachers' Association of New York City, declared yesterday at the Hotel Astor at the seventh annual luncheon of that organization.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Haverford won its first football game of the season by defeating Washington College here today, 7 to 6.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The mid-season fashion shows closed confirming the trends and silhouette already signaled. An unusual unanimity relating to skirt lengths, with daytime hems stabilized at about ten inches off the floor, was evident.

Nearly $500,000,000 of Christmas club savings will be distributed by savings banks and other thrift institutions throughout the country between now and the end of the year, it was estimated yesterday. The official estimates, compiled by the incorporated Christmas Club, will be published on Tuesday, showing by States the amounts saved by club members during the year to defray holiday expenses.

With orders for machine tools having shown a slight gain in October, the first in many months, builders and selling agents yesterday looked forward to a better demand in a few weeks, after plant managements have had time to digest the outcome of the election and to determine future policy.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Massachusetts State was the victor over the Coast Guard Academy eleven in a hard-fought battle on Alumni Field today. The score was 20-13.

FOR the House of Windsor, as for the rest of the world, time passes quickly. It is ten years since Princess Mary was married to Viscount Lascelles, now Earl of Harewood. Nine years have elapsed since the chimes of Westminster Abbey were rung for the Duke of York and his bride, Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Evidence that Japan is resolved to maintain the open door in Manchukuo is found in the fact that United States trade there had not decreased since Japanese occupation of Manchuria, it was said here today by Yosuke Matsuoka, who will represent Japan at the session of the League of Nations Assembly called to discuss the Lytton report.

WITH Ernst Lubitsch it is a case of the picture, not the story, being the thing. Judging by what he has Bone with a germ of an idea in his latest achievement, "Trouble in Paradise," one is constrained to think that ha could make a good picture out of the poorest of tales.

HOW business can become a profitable pleasure for youth will be revealed on Thursday evening when the members of the twenty clubs which have adopted what is called the junior Achievement scheme of teaching economic principles and business administration through actual experience gather at the Town Hall Club here for their first annual Metropolitan Junior Achievement convention.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- Before the smallest homecoming crowd in more than ten years, Ohio State defeated Pennsylvania today, 19 to 0, in the first game in history between the two elevens. In the face of near-freezing weather and a chilling breeze the crowd numbered only 19,301.

The United States Presidential election out of the way, the European nations which owe this country war debts have lost no time in seeking a revision of the accords under which they stand obligated to pay this country some ten billion dollars in the next half century or so.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Captain Alexander (Sandy) Schmidt. playing his last game for Taft, led his eleven to its sixth victory of the year today, when Westminster School's team was vanquished 13-2 on Rockefeller Field before a large crowd.

THESE latest instalments of the Sellgman-Johnson encyclopaedia contain rather more than the usual number of extended articles, and in addition, the wealth of shorter ones, including condensed biographies, which users of the work will naturally look for.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Nearly 20,000,000 persons have received government flour through the American Red Cross; and 15,000,000 individuals will receive clothing made from government cotton, John Barton Payne, chairman of the Red Cross, announced today.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE EAST, Nov. 12 -- Suddenly shifting his route for a side trip that will delay his arrival in Washington by a day, President Hoover tonight paid an inspection visit to Hoover Dam in Nevada.

Seasoned army veterans may find themselves learning new formations if the War Department formally approves plans under consideration to remodel the army's close-order formation of columns of fours to ranks of three. A prediction that the plans would be approved was made last night by Colonel Walter A. De Lamater, commander of the Seventy-First Infantry Regiment of the New York Rational Guard, at a dinner in the Hotel Astor.

MEXICO CITY. THE flood of books on Pancho Villa increases. Last Winter Rafael Munoz's "Vamonos con Pancho Villa" (Espasa-Calpe) completed a portrait of the famous bandit General which the author had commenced in two previous volumes, "El Feroz Cabecilla" and "El Hombre Malo."

SHANGHAI, Oct. 17 -- Nothing short of the word dismay can describe the feelings of the leaders of the Nanking government when Marshal Feng Yu-hsiang, erstwhile "Christian Genera!," finally emerged from his long retirement upon a sacred mountain in Shantung and traveled in state to Kalgan, a railway city northwest of Peiping.

With a municipal election coming next year, at which the Republican organizations must furnish the nucleus for any effective anti-Tammany movement, rumblings of conflict within the Republican party are already being heard.

Regarded as a significant step toward lower distribution costs, the cash-and-carry plan of merchandising is credited with making appreciable headway in the department store field. This plan will be put into effect tomorrow throughout its basement store by Gimbel Brothers in this city.

DALLAS, Nov. 10 -- All Texas is wondering now what the Fergusons are going to do. Texas, of course, to use Jim Ferguson's own phrase, now has "two Governors for the price of one." Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson during her second term will again have Farmer Jim, husband and counsel, "hewing wood and hauling water" around the Executive offices.

The appointment of the eighty-two undergraduates to the various editorial boards of The New York University Daily News, student publication, was announced yesterday by Sidney S. Freidberg, editor-in-chief. The appointees were:

SUPPOSE it's only natural for those who know me only through archie and his column-cousins or through "The Old Soak" to wonder why I ever wrote a play like "The Dark Hours." It's very simple. I had always been interested in the subject.

Finishing in a dead heat, Paul Dee and Joseph Moclair led the Manhatton Prep cross-country team to the City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship in the annual run staged over a two and a quarter-mile course in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday morning.

Scoring two touchdowns in the final period, the Hampton Institute football team of Hampton, Va., colored intercollegiate A.A. champions, triupmhed over Howard University of Washington, D.C., by 19 -- 6, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 12 -- A stubborn Maroon line wavered twice under relentless pounding today, and the powerful, undefeated Michigan eleven, by a score of 12 to 0, added Chicago to its list of seven gridiron victims since Oct. 1.

The "National Prosperity Luncheons," scheduled to be held on Tuesday in 100 cities as a feature of the National Quality Movement under the auspices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, have been postponed, probably to Jan. 16, 1933, when the association will hold its annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Apparently the draft of the new Franco-American trade treaty which Ambassador Edge recently took to Washington has been quietly relegated to the limbo of the unfinished business of all retiring Republican administrations. Officials of the French Ministry of Commerce have just announced that negotiations with the United States Embassy for conclusion of the new pact would be suspended until the Roosevelt Administration had assumed power.

After several days of increasing activity and rising prices, the share market, it appeared to Wall Street, deserved the rest which yesterday's pause afforded. That, at least, was the tenor of the day's comment. The early irregularity reflected, in the opinion of brokers, a mixture of profit-taking and renewed operations for the advance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Hope for the recovery of 37 cents on the dollar by holders of a $40,000,000 issue of serial gold notes in Middle West Utilities Company is contained in a report on the condition of the Insull holding concern issued today by the noteholders' committee headed by Charles S. Dewey.

THE Madison Square Garden Horse Show, which used to be and perhaps still is, next to the opera, New York society's most brilliant contribution to the metropolitan spectacle, is concerned primarily with the polite uses of the animal which furnishes the excuse for the show's existence.

With little remaining of the $523,201,524 of public utility maturities of 1932 to be cared for, bankers are already looking ahead to the $304,454,256 maturities of 1933, of which nearly one-fourth, or $69,123,405, will be due in January. While some casualties attended refunding operations this year, little difficulty is expected next year unless there should be a radical downturn in business from current levels.

DETROIT FORMAL announcement by Chevrolet that next month it will introduce its 1933 line with no change in the number of cylinders definitely disposes of recent rumors to the effect that this company was planning a so-called "economy" model for the new year.

A touchdown by Carl Balasky from the 1-yard line on a plunge following a 75-yard march down the field enabled the Richmond Hill High School football team to turn back far Rockaway, 6 to 0, in a battle between two Queens County elevens at Dexter Park yesterday.

A decision of the United States Supreme Court last week released to the Great Northern Railway $2,096,000 of Liberty bonds which it had deposited in a suit for $1,329,000 brought against it by the government. The court's decision was communicated to F.G. Dorety, vice president and general counsel of the Great Northern, who conducted the case for the company, as he stood in line in a cafeteria.

Caught in the turmoil as a Joyous group of Brown University partisans tore down the goal posts at Baker Field yesterday afternoon, Miss June Joseph, 24 years old, of 158 Bradford Street, Brooklyn, was struck on the head by one of the falling uprights. She was attended by Dr. Lechner, an ambulance surgeon from the Jewish Memorial Hospital, who diagnosed her injury as concussion of the brain.

A call for the mobilization of 10,000 men and women volunteers who are needed at once in Manhattan to complete the work of the general canvass committee of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee was sent out last night by Thomas L. Robinson, chairman of the committee, who announced that Manhattan has been divided into ten districts, in every part of which the volunteers are needed to make a home-to-home and store-to-store canvass.

H.B. Anderson, secretary of the Citizens Medical Reference Bureau, Inc., announced yesterday that Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, had acceded to its request that a hearing be granted concerning a bill the bureau plans to have reintroduced into the State Legislature amending a provision of the public health law making smallpox vaccination compulsory for public school children in cities of 50,000 population or more.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- The first experiment in what the Japanese press calls "a new policy of bandit suppression by persuasion," in which financial arguments will play a part, begins at Manchouli, Manchuria, as soon as the Japanese mission under Colonel Komatsubara establishes contact with General Hsu Ping-wen.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- In its first official shape the French disarmament plan, which is called "A Plan for the Organization of Peace," will be approved by the French Cabinet Monday and will be issued for publication here and at Geneva Monday afternoon.

A DEVICE which simulates radio beacon, direction finding and blind landing signals, making it possible to train pilots without the actual use of ground equipment and at airdromes where such equipment is not available, is being installed in a training plane at Randolph Field for instruction of army pilots.

MUNICH. TWO days before the signing of the armistice in Marshal Foch's private railway car in the forest of Compiegne ended the World War, that is on Nov. 9, 1918, the republic was proclaimed throughout Germany and nineteen minor crowns and coronets, in addition to the German imperial crown, rolled together down hill.

THE world of the opium addict -- judging by all accounts of those who have made excursions beyond its fantastic borders -- must be as far from the comprehension and experience of ordinary humanity as the world of the dwellers in the great nebula of Orion.

Acting upon the report of a committee headed by George W. Wickersham, former Solicitor General, the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches committed itself yesterday to a campaign for modification of the Kellogg-Briand pact, through a system of anti-war embargoes.

THE famous Adams family and the equally celebrated Harrison family, each of which has given two Presidents to the nation, must now make room on the bench of honor for the Roosevelts, for the Presidency runs in the Roosevelt family, too.

Before Franklin D. Roosevelt, the President-elect, plunged into his labors on the budget of New York State (of which he will remain Governor until Jan. 1) he issued a statement warning the public not to heed "unfounded and unauthorized rumors with reference to prospective appointments under the Federal Government."

UNFAVORABLE weather again held down retail trade in the week. Election day brought a spurt, however, though the result fell quite a bit below the former mark. Men's wear stores and departments appeared to find the most activity, which was pronounced in some cases the best of the year.

I DO want to buy 'Undine' and 'Sintram' for myself, I've wanted it so long," said Jo on the first page of "Little Women." Sixty-four years ago the author whose centenary we are soon to celebrate wrote these words, thinking as she did so of her own reading at 15, since the March family were the Alcotts and Jo March, in particular, a very exact portrait of Louisa May herself.
MADRID, Nov. 11 -- Premier Azana has become virtual dictator of Spain, but his view of the way to operate a dictatorship is different from that of either Mussolini or Stalin.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The stock markets finished the week on a firm and cheerful note, with a fair amount of business done. A good demand for British funds brought further recovery and prices generally closed higher.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that more than 55,500,000 motor vehicles had used the Holland Tunnel during the five years ending today in which it has been in operation. The tunnel was opened on Nov. 13, 1927, at one minute after midnight.

THE American debut of Tina Flada, which occurred last week under the sponsorship of Eva Le Gallienne, arouses a conflicting set of reactions, consisting mainly of delight on the one hand and of misgivings on the other. The first category includes such indisputable items as her charming appearance, her ingratiating youthfulness, her suggestion of roguish good humor, and above all her exceptional technical gifts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the farmer does not profit during the next four years there is nothing in a name or names. Even a Republican should be enough of a philologist to see that "Roosevelt" is a Dutch word, derived from roos, meaning "rose," and veld, meaning "field."

BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 10 -- On the same day that the United States Supreme Court ordered a new trial for the seven Negroes sentenced to death at Scottsboro for criminal assault on two white girls a crowd of 2,000 unemployed men and women assembled in front of the City Hall in Birmingham to hear radical speeches and to demand food and money from the City Commission.

JUST as geniuses among composers must study music in order to fit themselves for creative work, and the most talented artists are required to go through years of strenuous work before they can give adequate performances of music, so the radio listeners must have adequate ear-training before they can function completely as listeners, according to Olga Samaroff Stokowski, concert pianist.

St. Cloud, upstanding chestnut gelding owned by Hugh Bancroft Jr. of Cohasset, Mass., was rideien to a perfect performance in Madison Square Garden last night to capture the Brooks-Bright Foundation challenge cup, the leading number on the program of the fourth evening session, of the forty-seventh annual National Horse Show.

IT is in his own way that Mr Belloc writes a book. This Life of Napoleon consists of a succession of what the author, in his ironic vein, calls "Incidents" -- entertaining little trivialities like the whiff of grapeshot or the Battle of Jena -- each of which glimpses it complete in itself.

So quickly are the asperities of a political campaign forgotten that Wall Street is already warming to Governor Roosevelt. He is no longer a radical or a visionary, but a "statesman from whom business has nothing to fear." Much is being said, approvingly, of the possibility that he will include some of the notable Democrats of finance and industry in his cabinet.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Nov. 12 -- There was talk of whaling on the village green here today and the eight ships that returned here regulary with whales in the years from 1837 until Cold Spring Harbor became a modern residential community.

To the Dramatic Editor: A prolonged, tedious convalescence has made theatre attendance out of the question, but I get much pleasure in dramatic news. Recently Brooks Atkinson wrote interestingly of the Abbey Theatre troupe and of Eva Le Gallienne's Fourteenth Street Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Unconfirmed reports that a toll of 1,500 lives was taken in the hurricane that devastated Eastern Cuba were verified officially today in the first message received by the State Department after three days of effort to establish communication.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The New York Aggies and Montclair Teachers battled to a 7-7 deadlock today.
BUDAPEST, Oct. 28 -- For defending the honor of William Shakespeare with ancient eggs and onions, three gallant Hungarian youths were fined twenty pengoes each in the Budapest County Court.

PRESCRIBING the death penalty to all thieves and my use of the word "sacred" are objected to. The question is asked why, after fifteen years of the Soviet regime, it has become necessary to issue such a "sharp and cruel" law for such a trifling offence as stealing grain or an agricultural implement or a cart wheel.

SAMUEL BUTLER ought to have been named Habakkuk. He was not only capable of everything and anything, but he did it if he found the time. At least the faithful Butlerites tell us so; and in this age faith is beautiful, even if it find strange gods and goddesses to worship.

From the London Chamber of Commerce comes a curious testimonial to the tariffs and quota systems that have tied up trade and to the net of restraints on currency exchanges. The chamber proposes the revival, in elaborate form, of the primitive method of exchanging one article for another.

More than 600 internationally prominent educators, public leaders and economists will gather at the Waldorf-Astoria Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday of this week to discuss the obligation of universities to the social order, under the sponsorship of New York University.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Paris is beginning to show some of its mid-Autumn animation. While the hunting crowd will stay at their country places until after the St. Hubert meets in the first weeks of November, the lovers of good racing gathered last Sunday at Longchamps for the Prix Gladiateur, which is the longest of fiat races anywhere and closes the season at Longchamps until next April.

FOLLOWING the announcement of a conference of universities to be held this month, sponsored by New York University, I have been deluged with inquiries regarding so unusual an enterprise. What is it all about?

ALBANY, Nov. 12.--Although practically fully recovered from his cold, Governor Roosevelt remained in bed at the Executive Mansion today and received no visitors. No comment was forthcoming from him on the foreign debt situation, although reports from Washington were that Secretary Stimson had forwarded to the President-elect a copy of the note of the British Government supposed to request a suspension of war debt payments and revision of the agreements concerning them.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Leopold Stokowski, conductor and musical director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, has incorporated himself under the laws of Delaware, it became known today, although the charter was obtained at Dover last year. It says he is "engaged in managing, operating and conducting a general agency for music and musicians to include dancers, actors, pantomimists, designers of stage costumes, scenery and lighting and artists of all and every description."

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter to THE TIMES complained recently that our schools are neglecting the most important part of education; that educators must not use the alibis of home and church while they themselves condone dishonest practices in the schoolroom, citing "identical answers" in examinations.

To the Dramatic Editor: It seems to me that most of the critics adopted a silly attitude in their judgments of J.B. Priestley's "Dangerous Corner." Because Priestley is an essayist, novelist and critic of note, our reviewers presupposed that he was trying to write something highly serious and extravagantly profound, whereas the play is a simply devised and highly entertaining romp.

Charging that defamatory statements, circulated by the Committee for the Protection of Holders of First Mortgage Bonds sold through the American Bond and Mortgage Company, affected its credit and the value of its property, the Roerich Museum at 103d Street and Riverside Drive, through its attorneys Greenbaum, Wolff and Ernst of 285 Madison Avenue, filed suit against the committee in the Supreme Court yesterday asking $500,000 damages.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- Under martial law, with 3,000 of its crack militia troops reinforced by a battalion of 600 men brought in from Vallais Canton and with a general protest strike of twenty-four hours on in the building, typographical and metallurgical trades, Geneva passed a quiet day, burying in separate funerals the eleven persons killed when recruits fired into a crowd Wednesday.

Thousands of employes of the General Electric Company who have been temporarily laid off have continued to carry the life insurance policies that they obtained at attractive premium rates by virtue of their original status as employes, the company announced yesterday.

THE performance of excerpts from Richard Strauss's "Salome" last Tuesday night at the concert of the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra in the Metropolitan Opera House, and the reception of the music, raise again the question of how long it will be before this opera can be mounted on the stage in this city.

A K'ang-hsi "green hawthorn" vase from the collection of former King Alfonso XIII, originally a gift from the Emperor K'ang-hsi to the royal family of Spain, and a pair of Imperial Ch'ien-lung famille rose temple vases from the same collection, taken out of Spain when Alfonso left for France, appear, with other examples, in a collection of Chinese art to be auctioned at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., next Thursday and Friday afternoons.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Two teams that refused to accept defeat fought each other on the turf of Palmer Stadium today as 45,000 watched from the towering cement stands. At the end of another chapter in the oldest series in football, the scoreboard read: Yale 7, Princeton 7.

This is the membership of the Young Women's Christian Association in the United States, which yesterday celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of its organization under the leadership of Miss GRACE DODGE. Two or three tunes this number share in its activities without being members, which means that its fellowship includes in its 1,103 local associations more than two million young women and girls.

We Are Good Losers. THE NEW YORK TIMES financial reporter said the other day: "Commission houses and other commentators continued to express satisfaction with the results of Tuesday's election and to emphasize that, contrary to previous contentions made in financial circles, business has nothing to fear from the impending change in the Federal administration."

AMES, Iowa, Nov. 12 -- A plunging, passing Oklahoma University eleven today wrested a hard-earned 19 -- 12 victory from Iowa State College and automatically sunk their opponents to the bottom of the Big Six cellar.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Unable to cope with the ground and aerial attack of Rutgers in the twenty-eighth game of their long series played before 5,000 spectators in Taylor Stadium today. Lehigh went down to a crushing 37-to-6 defeat.

AFTER twenty-four crowded and eventful years, another Roosevelt -- this time a Democratic one -- will move into the White House after March 4 and become Chief Executive of the United States. During those twenty-four years national problems have multiplied and become more perplexing, public thought has undergone an almost revolutionary transformation.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 12 -- Mrs. Henry P. Joy gave a dinner in the Homestead this evening for Mrs. John W. Dyar, Mrs. Russell A. Alger and James J. O'Brien.

HANKOW, Oct. 16 -- The Nanking Government is going to try a form of collective ownership of farm lands in portions of the areas which General Chiang Kai-shek's armies have recovered from the Communists this year. Since under the Communist administration all farm lands were confiscated and all records and boundary markings were destroyed, it is announced that lands will be restored to former owners only upon the presentation of "irrefutable documentary evidence."

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Having received requests from nineteen nations to begin reciprocal tariff negotiations, the British Government now hopes it will receive another after March 4 from the new administration of the United States.

TWO works unperformed in this country will be played by Marcel Grandjany, harpist, and Rene Le Roy, flutist, in their joint recital in Town Hall next January. The first is a sonata in G minor by Bach, which is said to have come to light in Germany last year among the possessions of the Rust family; the second is Arnold Bax's sonata for flute and harp.

THE EMPEROR JONES," the two-act opera by Louis Gruenberg based on Eugene O'Neill's play, which the Metropolitan Opera Company plans to put on this season with Lawrence Tibbett in the title role, is essentially a drama of inward conflict.

Fourteen boys and girls from the Dickinson High School in Jersey City, who were lost in the snake-infested thickets of the Ramapo Mountains all Friday night, were brought back to their homes yesterday afternoon -- tired, hungry and cold, but cheerful.

THE positive assurance of Mr. Maugham's style is now that we are familiar with his talent, his greatest attraction. Whatever he does is admirably done. Whatever his introspection -- softened by pity in "Of Human Bondage" or sharpened by malice in "Cakes and Ale" -- we shall find his outlook clarified by suavity and good-humored tolerance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Searching among some documents recently, I came across two letters written long ago which might well be applied to modern discussions. One was written by Henry Clay to Edward C. Delavau from Ashland, Aug. 20, 1838, and contains the following passage:

THE hum of activity in the auction bouses continues unaffected by elections and other events of world-wide significance. The sales for the month of November, which must have been planned some time in advance, give no indication that they were prepared with a weather eye upon impending political changes.
HUNTINGDON, Pa., Nov. 32 -- Scoring almost at will, the Juniata College team had little difficulty in defeating Gallaudet College, 45 to 0, here today.

Through a general underrating of their intellectual capacities, children are being invited in many churches to sing hymns that are "unreal and foreign to their own religious experiences,'' according to a report read yesterday by Dr. Walter M. Howlett of the New York Federation of Churches at the opening session of the tenth anniversary meeting of the Hymn Society, held in the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway at 120th Street.

TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- The conviction that before long Henry Pu-yi will again sit on the dragon throne of his ancestors at Peiping and restore imperial peace to China is prevalent among the Manchus and the Chinese officials of Manchukuo, according to travelers recently returned from Changchun (now Hsinking).

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 10 -- With interest in politics dormant, Arizona is turning its attention to irrigation projects and new highways. Both are of vital interest to this extensive, expanding but youthful State. Each has complications, Big irrigation projects require loans of millions, something none too easy to obtain in these times.
