BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- The Naval Academy's powerful running attack piled up a decisive lead on the University of Maryland today to triumph, 28 -- 7, in spite of a real offensive flash by Maryland late in the final quarter.

ALONELY farmhouse in Canada, close to the American border, is the scene of this story of sudden and violent death. Lieutenant Valcour of the New York police is cooperating with the Canadian authorities on a case the nature of which is not revealed until near the end of the book.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- The silks of William du Pont Jr.'s Foxcatcher Farms were carried to a mildly surprising victory in the $10,000 added Riggs Handicap at Pimlico today as his 6-year-old gelding White Clover II won by half a length over A.C. Bostwick's Mate, with the Greentree Stable's St. Bvideaux in third place.

NO one can complete a reading of "A Count in the Fo'c'sle" without experiencing an exasperating and ambivalent attitude of belief and disbelief. Tall tales at adventure lend themselves to a variety of interpretations, and in these pages are crowded an inextricable tangle of fact and phantasy.

BARCELONA, Oct. 31 -- Whether the "revolutionary hour" of anarchy shall have passed forever in Spain is the silently overshadowing issue in the campaign now being waged for the election of the Catalan constitutional Parliament which President Francesc Macia of the Generalitat has convoked to meet on Dec. 6

CHARLES LAUTRUF, the Danish conductor who will lead the Musician's Symphony at the Metropolitan Opera House next Tuesday, has had a unique career among contemporary conductors. After five years' experience as guest conductor with European orchestras in Germany, Austria and Denmark, he was summoned to Tokyo, Japan, to take charge of the Imperial Orchestra and the chorus of the Imperial Academy of Music there.

The rags and tags of cases that excite public interest usually draw the headlines. But even lay comment upon the Scottsboro decision was alive to a significance that went beyond a respite from death for seven illiterate Negro boys. In truth, the Supreme Court last Monday wrote a notable chapter in the history of liberty, emphasized perhaps in importance because it was conveyed through the sober language of a judicial opinion.

The George Washington High School football team remained undefeated, untied and unscored upon in blanking Evander Childs High, 52 to 0, yesterday at the George Washington High School Stadium, for its sixth victory. A crowd at 4,000 saw the winners roll up one of the largest scores made in a schoolboy game in the metropolitan district this Fall.

A sparkling 200-yard relay swim by boys of Manual Training and capture of the Manhattan-Bronx junior high school title by the lads of Henry P. O'Neil were the outstanding features of the sixth series of aquatic dual meets for the team championships of the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Detroit's powerful, tricky football team came out of the West to mar Villanova's "homecoming" game today, triumphing by 28 to 12. The crowd numbered 8,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 AFTER three days and three nights the floods have receded, the wondering natives have returned to their homes and the busy beachcombers are searching the shore for whatever worthwhile the waters have cast up.

NEARLY a quarter of a century has elapsed since Professor Soddy brought out the first edition of "The Interpretation of the Atom." In that period there has been a succession of upheavals in physical science which has overthrown nearly everything that was considered fundamental by such eminent Victorians as Faraday, Maxwell and Kelvin.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Norman E. Mack, veteran of a dozen national political campaigns, believes "if the Democratic party will do for the nation what it has done for New York State it will be in power nationally as long as or longer than, it has been in control in Albany."

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: May I correct a statement made by E. Francis Brown in his review of Dr. James Ernst's book on Roger Williams appearing in your issue for Oct. 16? Mr. Brown states that Dr. Ernst has proved conclusively that Williams sprang from a family of the upper middle class."

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12 -- Mexico will use the $7,000,000 advanced by three foreign oil companies on petroleum taxes to strengthen the peso and aid agriculture and large and small industries, Alberto Pani, the Finance Minister, announced today.

VIENNA, Nov. 12 -- Southeast Europe, according to the opinions expressed in the newspapers, sees little hope in the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt for the lowering of the American tariff or the abolition of prohibition, both measures of great importance to factories and vineyards in this part of the world.

ISTANBUL, Oct. 25 -- In common with other Southeastern European States, Turkey is passing through a severe economic crisis. But the difficulties confronting the young republic are different from those of other countries. Turkey has practically no unemployment problem.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 12 -- Taking to the air with startling effectiveness, West Virginia easily humbled Washington and Lee today, 19 to 0, in their annual football game.

LATONIA, Ky., Nov. 12.--The Western racing season ended today with the twenty-seventh running of the Latonia Cup race at two and a quarter miles as the feature of the closing day of the twenty-eight-day Latonia meeting.

Hyman Berger, who according to Federal investigators is "the big shot" of a narcotics ring engaged in a mail-order business, with addicts in Hollywood, San Francisco and Baltimore, was held in bail of $15,000 yesterday when he was arraigned before Francis A. O'Neill, United States Commissioner.

Need for the formation of an independent foreign bondholders' protective organization strong enough to command the support of the Department of State, which was discussed informally at the convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America last month, is emphasized in a report on the situation made by Wood, Struthers Co., investment bankers.
From Editor and Publisher, Nov. 12. Adolph S. Ochs, NEW YORK TIMES publisher, in a statement to Editor and Publisher, in connection with THE TIMES' election issue, said:

The transfer of three ships of the Cunard Line and one Anchor Donaldson liner from New York to terminals at Halifax and St. John in the Winter service to the Channel ports and Glasgow, as announced last week, is considered in shipping circles to be the start of a general movement to divert Canadian wheat away from New York on its way to other parts Of the British Empire.

THE exhibition of Matisse paintings and sale on Wednesday and Thursday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street, promises to be a success, according to its sponsors. The proceeds from it will go to further the work of Hope Farm, a community school in Verbank, Dutchess County, N.Y.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Seven Princeton players concluded their collegiate football careers in the game with Yale today. Three others finished theirs on the bench.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Lafayette's football team entered the winning column for the first time in six games when it defeated St. John's of Annapolis today, 51 to 0. Showing the first real offensive of the season, the Maroon pushed across eight touchdowns, six of them in the first two periods.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- That present-day Germany and in particular her political perplexities are largely the result of her geographic position and historical development was the theme that formed the chief portion of Chancellor Franz von Papen's confession of faith as it was unfolded by him to 100 members of the Foreign Press Association a few days ago.

Red Cross week starts today and many pastors in their sermons will urge support for the organization's drive for funds. Representatives of the Red Cross will be in the vestibules of churches to receive subscriptions after the services. Some pastors will preach armistice sermons, as Friday was the fourteenth anniversary of the signing of the armistice.

Despite the improved statistical position of the petroleum industry as shown by heavy withdrawals from stocks in September, the functioning of natural economic laws in the industry was precluded by the heavy potential production of crude oil which is being held off the market through proration, William J. Kemnitzer reported yesterday.

The fate of Paul Marciante, 10 years old, who was kidnapped last Monday near his home at 315 East Sixtieth Street, remained unknown yesterday as ten detectives assigned to the case attempted in vain to find some clue that would lead them to the boy's abductors.

WASHINGTON THE transfer of Lieut. Col. Barton K. Yount from the West Coast to the command of Boiling Field brings one of the Air Corps' most diplomatics officers to "the toughest spot in the Army Air Service." Colonel Yount assumes command on the eve of one of the largest changes in years in the House and Senate.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Eighteen months of prison to obtain public recognition of an official injustice is the ordeal that has just been ended by Jean Armand Baptiste Pascal Tourencq, and he is satisfied. But he ran a much more serious risk than the sufferings involved in a long imprisonment, for Tie stole from the government in order to bring his case to notice.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc. and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 27, a net loss of $11,224,550 after interest, amortization and depreciation and after allowing for a profit of 52,870,503 arising from the retirement of debentures and subsidiaries' funded indebtedness.

KANDINSKY is shown in New York for the first time. Twenty-seven canvases from 1923 to 1932. News! To be sure, it was just twenty years age that this reviewer wrote her first notice of Kandinsky, and even then neither he nor she was a young adventurer in the world of art.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 12 -- Brown University bestowed honorary degrees today on Walter J. Damrosch, conductor and composer; Henry W. Kent, secretary of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Oliver La Farge 2d, author and Pulitzer prize winner.

LAFAYETTE, Ind. THAT large classes are at best as good for the student as small, and possibly better for him, is deduced from the results of three experiments conducted at Purdue University over a two-year period. The report, written by the three members of the faculty who conducted the tests, the director of the division of educational reference and a professor and instructor in mathematics, has just been published.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The Soviet Union begins its sixteenth year in relatively better shape than most of the world, but is not exempt from the effects of the depression. Compared with other countries, the Soviet Union, has the advantage at complete internal peace.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Cornell struck early and with devastating force today to defeat Dartmouth, 21 to 6, at Schoeilkopf Field before a crowd of 10,000.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Although the French request to Washington for postponement of the Dec. 15 debt payment followed the British request by only twenty-four hours and was expressed in similar terms, it is officially stated here that the two requests should not be regarded as in any way joined.

LONDON. LIKE every other city, London slumbers during August and early September. The galleries close their one-man exhibitions and put on Summer shows, which are left hanging until the season comes to life again.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 12 -- Washington bound after his re-election Tuesday, Senator Nye of North Dakota suffered a rib fracture and was cut and bruised today when his car skidded and overturned on a slippery highway.

Dr. Julius Curtius, former German Minister of Foreign Affairs, at a luncheon in his honor yesterday a the Hotel Astor, asserted that the theory of national economic self-sufficiency was "a grave delusion," from which all countries are suffering, that single nations can not make any headway against the world depression by individual action, and that international economic cooperation is necessary.

PARIS. JUST now when every night is apt to be a big one -- what with almost every well -- known restaurant and night club in gay Paris phoenix-like rising in its glory and blossoming forth with new bars, dance floors, paint and galas -- the evening wrap is much in the sartorial eye.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Asbury Park High maintained its unbeaten and untied record for the season toy turning back Long Branch, 7-6, in a hard-fought game today. The victory clinched the Central New Jersey championship for Asbury Park.

All markets were strong at the week-end yesterday, but in most of them the advance of the two preceding days was checked. Stocks began the day with further rise of a point or thereabouts, but it was mostly lost before the closing. Domestic bonds went as a rule a fraction higher; in a dozen or more of such securities, gains of 2 to 4 points were made.

THRUSTING southward along the North Carolina coast is a narrow spit of land -- sandy waste for the most part, but here and there a tangle of swamp or woodland. This land separates historic Albemarle and Currituck Sound from the pounding Atlantic.

MANY ears will be open to catch the full import of the announcement which Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary for Great Britain, is to make at Geneva. Forecasts indicate that it is to contain sweeping proposals not merely for the limitation of bombing and fighting aircraft but even the suggestion of limitation of commercial aircraft under a system of quotas applied to each country.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- In the days when the ex-Kaiser was nicknamed "William the Sudden" he had a weakness for, figuratively speaking, breaking china. Now, as the Exile of Doorn and absentee landlord, he is thriftily making china -- more specifically, majolica ware, at a factory owned by him, at Cadinen, East Prussia.

Two years of effort to bring about changes in the laws affecting railroads foreshadow the success of proposed railroad legislation at the next session of Congress and open the possibility that the interstate commerce act may be amended further as radically as it was by the transportation act of 1920.

OFFICERS and members of the Junior League are now busy with plans for the various activities of the organization during the new season. Civic, cultural and artistic events are included in the program for the Winter months as well as of choosing possible provisional members from the list of this season's debutantes who may become officially enrolled as members of the League after a period of intensive training.

THOUGH called the story of a man this is really a prose poem, a delicate and lovely nature-idyl. It is set in that seaward part of the Providence plantations which lies close over against Massachusetts, and is chiefly distinguished from it by its darker fertility of soil.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 12 (AP) -- It was revealed here tonight that Greta Garbo had slipped quietly out of Stockholm several days ago accompanied by the Countess of Wachtmeister.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- A 77-yard march late in the second period gave Union College a 6-to-0 victory over Hamilton in the fortieth game between these old rivals today. It was the fifth consecutive triumph of the season for the Garnet which outplayed Hamilton in all save the third period.

A NEW prose translation of the "Odyssey" of Homer is announced for publication on Nov. 25 by the Oxford University Press. The translator is T.E. Shaw, better known as Lawrence of Arabia and author of "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" and "Revolt in the Desert."

John Flynn, Curtis High School harrier, climaxed a successful campaign by capturing the annual city P.S.A.L. individual cross-country championship run at Van Cortland Park yesterday morning. He led field of almost 200 starters hone over the approximately two-and-a-quarter-mile course in 12:03.

THE new Dodge six, demonstrated at a pre-view to newspaper men in Detroit last Wednesday, comprises five body types with a "floating power" engine of eighty-one horsepower. Prices probably will not be announced before the Automobile Show in January, but it is asserted that they will be "low."

FLORENCE. HAVE you ever witnessed a Fascist funeral? Every one gathers around the bier and the name of the deceased is called out as in a roll-call. Presente! answers the crowd with a loud voice, while saluting with the hand. This is very impressive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The desire of the United States for what President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt has termed a "new deal" was amply demonstrated on Tuesday through balloting that not only gave him a sweeping victory but insured for the Democratic party a strong majority in Congress.

Scoring in every period, a smoothly clicking Manhattan eleven overwhelmed Clarkson Tech of Potsdam, N.Y., by 28 to 0 before 10,000 persons at Ebbets Field yesterday. The triumph marked the fifth victory of the season for the Jaspers and brought to an end the six-game winning streak of the up-State team.

HEWLETT, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Gavin D. Robertson, 19-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Robertson of Woodside Drive, Hewlett, and a freshman at Tale University, was instantly killed here this afternoon when a motorcycle he was riding and an automobile collided at Mill Road and Waverly Place.

GOING back only to the second half Of the nineteenth century, A.S. Rutta writes in The Strad concerning the music of Egypt, recalling the munificent Khedive lsmail, who asked Verdi to compose an opera with Egyptian setting. Thus "Aida" was born, Mr. Rutta says, and he adds that the scenery then prepared is still used in Cairo at the Theatre de I'Opera.

Activity in the wholesale markets quieted down during the week, according to the market report especially prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. It is the general opinion, however, the report says, that real Winter weather and active consumer buying would quickly deplete stocks and retailers would be in the market for the special price merchandise that is being offered to stimulate business at this time.

Soviet Russia's battle against Arctic hardships in its efforts to advance the five-year plan is revealed by the grounding of the Russian steamer Tovarish Stalin off Spitsbergen, says an Associated Press discatch from Washington. This steamer was carrying Russian workers to the coal mines which Soviet Russia has acquired in Spitsbergen, the Norwegian archipelago half way between the European coast and the North Pole.

AMONG the foremost stylists of the present day, Virginia Woolf is also among those whose words are more than ordinarily worth one's while to listen to. A keenly discerning critic of books and men, as proved by her first "Common Reader," her deserved reputation is enhanced by the second of these collections.

WASHINGTON THE vast untapped reservoir of Federal revenue that would be released with modification or repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is graphically illustrated by the fact that in the last year before prohibition became nation-wide the government collected $482,000,000 in taxes from the liquor traffic.

The elementary series of the concerts for children given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Ernest Schelling began yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall with a program intended to illustrate the string choirs of the orchestra.

PROGRESSIVE education, its critics and even its supporters sometimes claim, can never become general because of its free methods and its high per capita cost. Faster, however, than is usually realized, it seems already to be permeating public schools.

THE Holland Tunnel was opened to the public on Nov. 13, 1927. In the five years that have elapsed this great artery of motor transportation between the States of New York and New Jersey has assumed an indispensable position in the life of the metropolitan district.

Three squads of emergency police had to be called to Bryant Hall, in Sixth Avenue, near Forty-second Street, shortly after 8 o'clock last night to suppress what approached a riot of 5,000 men and women investors in the local branch of the Trustees System Service Corporation, who tried to crowd into the hall.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 12 -- Illinois's battered football warriors gave another demonstration of why they are called the Fighting Illini today, rallying to defeat Indiana, 18 to 6, for their first major victory at home since 1929.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Advancing prices and a marked change in general sentiment featured the grain markets today, the belief being that conditions were to improve gradually so far as agricultural products were concerned. Barley led the upturn on the Board of Trade here, reflecting nationwide interest as the result of the probable modification of the prohibition laws.

WHEN the famous Leonid meteors last made their spectacular appearance before the eyes of a startled world there was no such thing as radio broadcasting. At intervals of thirty-three years this remarkable meteoric swarm swings past the earth, and while astronomers, cannot say with certainty, it should fill the sky with "falling stars" on the 15th and 16th of this month.

In answer to a letter from Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of Governor Roosevelt's Agricultural Advisory Committee, charging that the reduced price of milk as a result of the price war in various parts of the city had resulted in lowering its quality, Health Commissioner Wynne declared yesterday that the milk being sold here had even a higher butter fat content than that required by the sanitary code.
BEATRICE, Neb., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Chester Mason, Federal prohibition agent, was killed and Byron Kennedy, an undercover agent, was wounded seriously in a shooting scrape near here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Relief loans of $256,200 to Arizona and $5,000 to Georgia, and an agreement to finance a $45,000 addition to the municipal water-works at West Monroe, La., were approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12 Vanderbilt and Tennessee played to a scoreless tie in a furiously fought gridiron battle here today before 27,000 unruly spectators and left Auburn the only major untied and unbeaten eleven in the South.

WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Both the Wolff and Telegraphen Union news agencies reported anti-Semitic rioting today in LWOW, Poland, and said police with clubs dispersed 1,000 Nationalist students who marched on the city and smashed hundreds of windows in Jewish stores.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Cornelis Vande Stadt, passenger traffic manager of the Holland-America Steamship Company, died of pneumonia early this morning at his home here, 25 Erwin Park Road, after a brief illness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Horton Smith, pro at Oak Park, Ill., celebrated his return to top form today with a par-cracking last round of 69 to win the $2,500 national capital open tournament at the Kenwood Club by a two-stroke margin.

Weather conditions slowed up buying in the wholesale markets here last week, and it is felt that a spurt in purchasing by retailers now depends largely upon consumer response to offerings of holiday merchandise. Signs of further industrial activity are awaited by merchants, with the passing of election uncertainties.

TURIN, Italy, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The King's attorney has announced a pardon of part of the offenses of the man officially known as Mario Bruneri, whose real identity has been for years one of Italy's most publicized mysteries.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- A pronounced change in sentiment favoring the constructive side of grains and live stock came over the trade last week, due in a measure to the elimination of politics. There is a feeling that commodity prices have been too low and that an upturn is due.

Chicago, Nov. 13 -- Prospects for a return of the manufacture of real beer as the result of the recent Presidential election are being used as a bullish factor in corn, inducing increased buying by speculators on the Board of Trade here because prices are exceptionally low.

The appointment of Dr. W. Francklyn Paris, architectural director and author, as honorary director of the Hall of American Artists of New York University was announced yesterday by Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown.

To unemployed musicians must be given an opportunity to practice their art in order to prevent their fingers from growing stiff and their minds from going stale, Hendrik Willem Van Loon declared yesterday afternoon in a talk over Station WOR.

The tenor of the British note to our Government on the war debts had been so clearly divined in advance that its publication causes no surprise. Much the same may be said of the note of the French Government, made public at the same time.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, in a formal statement issued yesterday called for the taking over of the reins of the Republican party by the young, liberal elements in it. Unless that is done, he said, the Republican party will go the way of the Whig party "and will soon pass out of existence because of its incapacity to face the future with understanding and courage."

Five years of research, a report of which is published in the current issue of the quarterly journal of the American Braille Fress, has disclosed that there are 887 persons in the United States, and fifty-seven in Canada, who are both blind and deaf. The report summarizes the conclusions of a survey conducted by Mrs. Corinne Rocheleau Rouleau, of Washington, D.C., and Miss Rebecca Mack of Cincinnati.

DENVER, Nov. 13 -- The undefeated Utah Utes, seeking their fifth consecutive Rocky Mountain Conference football title, will close their gridiron campaign in Fort Collins, Col., against the Colorado Aggies Saturday.

The world is nearer to war today than it has been at any time during the last fourteen years, and only through an abandonment of the selfish nationalistic principle of "I will do whatever I wish" can peace be preserved permanently, Professor Andre Philip of the University of Lyons, France, declared at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 13 -- Professor Irving Fisher's Index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 60.3, which compares with 60.2 a week ago, 60.6 two weeks ago, 61.1 three weeks ago and 61.3 four weeks ago. This is the first weekly rise in eight weeks.

HAVANA, Nov. 13 -- President Macbado in an interview tonight expressed Cuba's gratitude for the many manifestations of sympathy in connection with the hurricane that ravaged the provinces of Camaguey and Santa Clara last Wednesday, and outlined tentative official plans for the work of rehabilitation.

Hunters look upon Maryland as one of the best shooting spots in this country. There ia a variety of game in that State, and in its long stretches of waters, along its famous Chesapeake Bay and in the rivers and creeks which feed that famous body of water, some of the finest wild waterfowl shooting in this country is to be enjoyed.
Columbia enters the final chapter of its football campaign today when it commences preparation for its annual encounter with Syracuse here on Saturday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 13 -- "Art releases the hidden beauty of man and by its touch lifts humanity above mere animal existence," Dr. Charles A. Dinsmore of the Yale Divinity School told the Institute of Art in its closing session at services held today in the First Baptist Meeting House.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- The Bureau of Motor Vehicles today explained the marked reduction in the number of revocations for driving an automobile while intoxicated. The peak of revocations for this offense was in 1931, when 2,816 licenses were revoked. Up to that year the number had steadily increased.

The Grace liner Santa Elena, last of four ships built in 1932 to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of the birth of the late William R. Grace, founder of the line, will be launched Nov. 30 at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--Pages of history were thumbed in vain today for a precedent for President Hoover's action in inviting his successor to help share in framing policies of State before he takes office.

Konstanty Kisiel, a building contractor living at 7,208 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, was found dying last night on the lower level of Shore Road near the foot of Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, by Patrolman William Kennedy of the Fort Hamilton station.
BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- One week after the Reichstag election finds the "presidial" government more firmly in the saddle and the chances of any Parliamentary Cabinet supplanting it remoter than ever.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- All reports from the Southwest indicate that Kansas and Oklahoma next season will have the smallest grain crops in years, even though rains should come in the near future, as the season for seeding is past the average time and grain put into the ground from now on is not likely to germinate rapidly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- William S. Brock, who in 1927 attempted a flight around the world, died at the Presbyterian Hospital tonight after a long illness. He entered the hospital on Sept. 23 for treatment for cancer. He was 36 years old.

Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr., recently appointed chairman of the World Service Council of the National Young Women's Christian Association, will give a luncheon today at her home, 10 West Fifty-fourth Street, for the members of the council who are in New York for the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the National Board of the organization.

Several bazaars and sales of useful articles suitable for Christmas gifts have been arranged for this week. A bazaar in behalf of the charitable activities of the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor will be held on Thursday and Friday at the convent of the order at 140 West Sixty-first Street.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 13 -- The Big Six football race will enter its final stage next Saturday for all conference squads except Missouri and the defending champion, Nebraska.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 13 -- David Sinton Ingalls, unsuccessful candidate for the Governorship of Ohio, and Mrs. Ingalls arrived at the Homestead today and entertained at dinner this evening for Mr. and Mrs. Earle Johnson, who accompanied them from Cleveland.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- All parties in France will approve the text of the French note to Washington, which was published here this evening, for it exactly presents the attitude and argument which has developed here since the Hoover moratorium threw the mechanism of the Young plan out of operation and established real link between German and other intergovernmental payments.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the question of government has been decided, let us turn to the job of unraveling the tangled conditions confronting us. The sooner we start tackling this entanglement, individually and collectively, the better.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 13. -- A system of State unemployment insurance financed by employers and employes is recommended in a report submitted to Governor White today by a committee of citizens named by him to study the question. Provision for the investigation was made by the Ohio General Assembly eighteen months ago.

So poor that they even had to borrow from their neighbors the 21 cents necessary to claim the telegram the city sent them--collect--to notify them their 12-day-old daughter, Josephine, had died in Bellevue Hospital from the effects of a rat bite, Sylvio Giacinto, 25 years old, and his wife, Vincenza, 28, sat silently mourning yesterday in their two-room flat at 407 East Twelfth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 -- Production of steel ingots in October, as reported by the American Iron and Steel Institute, was at 19 per cent of plant capacity, or slightly less than estimated during the month. 'An increase of exactly one-third was recorded in two months, the August rate, low for the depression, having been reported at 14.26 per cent.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The newspaper Izvestia, organ of the central executive committee of the Soviet Union, today published accusations that the British Intelligence Service plans to fake "proof" that Joseph Stalin directed the London "hunger march" and that he is organizing a civil war in India.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., Nov. 13 -- Man turned the muddy waters of the mighty Colorado River through a hole in one of its mile high canyon walls today -- a man-made hole burrowed in one year to remove the river from the bed it has been carving deeper, year by year, for more ages than man has known it.

The International Military Trophy event, which will be held at the National Horse Show tonight with teams of army officers representing Canada, France, the Irish Free State and the United States, presents the most spectacular, colorful and exciting competition of the annual exhibition.
Scholastic football's biggest week of traditional encounters furnished many keenly contested games, as most of the major school elevens concluded their campaigns.

OAKLAND, Cal., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Bob Carey of Anderson, Ind., won the national driving championship at the Oakland Speedway today, although he came in second to Wild Bill Cummings of Indianapolis in the 150-mile classic of the automobile racing season here.

Bishop William T. Manning has written a letter to all members of the Protestant Episcopal clergy in New York City at the request of the Gibson unemployment relief committee, it was revealed last night, urging Episcopalians to contribute to the Gibson committee as well as to their own relief campaign for unemployed members of the Episcopal Church.

Albert E. Powers, an employe of the Department of Plant and Structures, who served in the Spanish-American War with the First United States Volunteer Cavalry, better known as Roosevelt's Rough Riders, died on Saturdav of a heart attack at his home, 1,192 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn.
Normalcy and rationalism returned on Saturday to the gridirons of the country, whereupon week after week only chaos had prevailed, to the mortification of the prophets.

Armed with a new theme song and apparently undaunted by last Summer's reverses, a committee of "rank and file veterans" went into executive session last night at the Irving Plaza, Irving Place and Fifteenth Street, to consolidate their resources for a new bonus march on Washington, scheduled to converge upon the national capital Dec. 5.

The Women's Division of the Architects' Emergency Committee will begin today-which is the second anniversary of the committee's organization -- a campaign to raise a $100,000 relief fund to finance created jobs and meet urgent needs among the metropolitan area's unemployed architects and draughtsmen.

John Stewart Bryan, Richmond publisher, Mortimer Fleishhacker, San Francisco banker, Miss Amelia Earhart, the filer, and Owen D. Young of New York, joined last night in an appeal for support of the Welfare and Relief Mobilization of 1932 which was broadcast over combined networks of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

PARIS, Nov. 11.--After showing great firmness on Monday, Bourse prices have subsequently relapsed. Transactions at the same time grew very small. Anxiety is still shown concerning the situation of the national finances and in regard to the debates in Parliament for which the budget discussion will give occasion.

For the first time in the twenty-four-year history of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country championships a New York college awaits this annual classic as a potential winner. Well equipped in the two requisites of speed and balance, Manhattah's seven-man team will be the favorite when more than 100 athletes from sixteen colleges compete this afternoon over the six-mile Van Cortlandt Park layout.

Economists report on war debt readjustment is on Page 10. Reconsideration and revision by the United States of the war debts in a manner "as would best advance the interests of American trade and promote the prosperity of the American people" is recommended in a report made public yesterday by the Committee for the Consideration of Intergovernmental Debts, headed by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation.

After piloting the United States Golf Association safely through two of its most critical years, H.H. Ramsay is about to step out of the presidency of the governing body in deference to the custom of changing leaders every two years.

More than 600 persons, many of them connected with the theatrical profession, attended the annual memorial services of the Episcopal Actors' Guild, held yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Rev. Dr. Milo H. Gates, dean of the cathedral, officiated during the ceremony, in which a full choir participated.

PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 13 -- A citywide storm of protest, which, has been gathering momentum since Thursday, when the finance committee of the City Council approved a municipal income tax of one-half of one per cent on the salaries of wage-earners, brought an announcement today from Edwin R. Cox, council president, that body was not committed to the tax, but that some method of obtaining additional revenue was essential.

ATLANTA, Nov. 13 -- Dixie had to turn its pages of gridiron history back to the World War years to find a parallel to today's championship situation which found Auburn out in front and the customary leaders in its wake.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 13 -- Lured by a sensational discovery of gold, hundreds of Australians are gambling with death in an effort to wrest riches from the great central Australian desert.

Whatever danger the country faced from the withdrawal of gold by foreign countries was "deliberately" caused by President Hoover "in the granting of the moratorium and standstill agreement," it was charged yesterday by Francis P. Garvan, a former Alien Property Custodian.

The proposed Bronx housing project for which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has advanced a $4,000,000 loan is under attack because the plans for the development are said to dispense with the services of carpenters, according to Alien E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

The bench has its share of "stuffed shirts" and a great many enter the legal profession, who should have followed the plumbing and paper-hanging trade, Municipal Court Justice Frank E. Johnson asserted yesterday in a communion breakfast address to law students of the St. Thomas Aquinas Society of St. John's College at the Hotel Bossert in Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- Despite the mathematical aspects of the election returns in the United States, conservative German editors refuse to interpret them as presaging a radical departure from Washington's traditional foreign trade and financial policies.

Captain H. Jeffries Davis, commodore of the Furness-Bermuda Line, has been appointed master of the new flagship Queen of Bermuda, which is nearing completion at Barrow, England, and which will enter the service between New York and Bermuda in February, it was announced yesterday.

Thirty-five candidates for the women's field hockey teams that will represent New York in the Northeast tournament at Wellesley College Friday went through intensive four-hour practice at the Prospect Park hockey grounds yesterday. At the end of the afternoon drill Miss Virginia Bourquardez, chairman of the selection committee, announced the line-ups of the first two teams.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Clarence J. Housman, special partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of E.A. Pierce Co. and former Mayor of this city, died at his home in the West End section of Long Branch at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

Card parties and bridge and backgammon tournaments will be held in the near future in behalf of various philanthropic projects. The Good Shepherd Auxiliary will have its annual card party, supper and blind auction of useful articles on Thursday afternoon and night in the small ballroom of the Plaza.
The French memorandum, delivered to the State Department by Ambassador Claudel, follows:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 13 -- A.P. Haggard, 71 years old, a banker, philanthropist and for many years a leading citizen of Dayton, the scene of the Scopes trial, ended his life this afternoon by slashing his throat with a razor.

ALFRED, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Fire destroyed Alfred University's women's dormitory this afternoon. The loss, estimated at $120,000 by Loomis C. Alien, chairman of the university's finance committee, is covered by insurance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Yearlings had the call in the cattle market last week and well-finished steers weighing around 1,000 pounds and less advanced 25 to 50 cents, while middle steers had a top of $8.75 a hundred weight, or the same as heavies. The general steer market, however, weak-ened toward the last and closed 25 to 50 cents net lower, while yearlings finished 25 to 50 cents higher.

The campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies to complete a $3,923,000 budget to provide for its ninety-one affiliated institutions has thus far netted a total of $652,000, it was announced yesterday by Paul F. Warburg and Ira M. Younker, joint chairmen of the drive.

Many changes in the "Golden Horseshoe" of the Metropolitan Opera House will be observed next Monday night when Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" opens the first full season under the administration of Paul D. Cravath as chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Association and the twenty-fifth season with Giulio Gatti-Casazza as director.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Southern California was the only undefeated, untied major team along the entire Far Western football front today, within striking distance of its second straight Coast Conference title and the right to represent the West in the annual New Year's Day game for mythical national honors.

Feodor Chaliapin, returned to New York after an absence of four seasons, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. The enormous man, with gray hair but the face of a boy, strode on the stage, remarked that he was "happy to be more times with you," and then something about "depression -- I am sorry" -- and commenced his part of the program.

GENEVA, Nov. 13 -- League quarters are seriously considering the creation of a new organization to deal with the political situation that will arise when the Council at its approaching meeting on the Lytton report exhausts the League's conciliatory procedure in the Chino-Japanese conflict.

St. Francis Prep was ousted from the unbeaten ranks in the second annual Brooklyn Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association team championship swimming tournament when it bowed to the undefeated Bishop Loughlin team, 30 -- 29, in the third of a series of weekly dual meets in the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus pool yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 13 -- Cold-weather sailing in dinghies was returned today to the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, where it started on Jan. 2 last as a jest and grew into a coast-wise proposition.
The text of the report of the Committee for the Consideration of Intergovernmental Debts, prepared by a group of eminent economists, follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The comments of Freda T. Baumann on my letter of Nov. 5 miss the points which I tried to make. She criticizes the loan made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for housing in the Bronx on the ground that new construction at $11 a room is in competition with existing facilities and that it is not a slum-clearance project.

With the squad intact after its 28-0 victory over Clarkson Tech Saturday, the Manhattan eleven will open preparations today for its game with Holy Cross at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday. The decisive triumph over Clarkson has inspired hopes of gaining the most important victory since the readoption of football at Manhattan College in 1923.

Following the trend of the last eight years, saving-bank transactions in October in the State of New York showed a gain in new accounts of 14,144 and a net decline in deposits of $12,302,311, according to the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.

Fire swept through six two-story frame buildings at the southwest corner of Surf and Stillwell Avenues in the heart of Coney Island's amusement centre early this morning despite the efforts of firemen summoned on three alarms to check it, but the flames finally were halted by the brick wall of the Stillwell Baths Building.

Can't progress be carried too far? The Greeks got along without family names. The Turks are not known to suffer from their absence. But since it is the fashion in so many other countries to wear them, Turkey must follow suit. The Minister of the Interior is drafting a law making the adoption of family names compulsory, but allowing a free choice so long as it is 100 per cent Turkish.

The New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., had a "Guest Day" program for its November meeting yesterday, a business meeting and demonstration of dances being held at the Hotel Astor and a luncheon at The Fraternity Club. The guest artists were Winona and Gomez, exponents of exhibition ballroom dancing.

The elevated lines are breaking into the news again. One of the supposed objects of the Interborough receivership, now being contested in the courts, is to rid the parent company of the Manhattan lease, which has been a heavy burden for years. The group of stockholders which has now come into control of the Manhattan is naturally anxious to preserve the existing relationship.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Champion Ace of Aces Aviator, Boston terrier that has done considerable winning for Charles O'Connor of New York City, today won the Fred Davis Challenge trophy for best of breed at the forty-first annual specialty show of the Boston Terrier Club of America at the Hotel Somerset.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Nov. 13 -- Owing to heavy withdrawals of deposits and shrinkage of securities, the Diamond National Bank will not reopen for business tomorrow morning, E. E. Rieck, chairman of the board of directors, announced late today. The board voted to suspend and place the bank's assets in the hands of the Controller of the Currency.

Led by the speedy Red Cagle, the New York Giants registered their second victory of the National Football League season by defeating the Stapleton eleven from Staten Island at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants, after trailing for a short time in the second period, recovered splendidly and fought their way through to a 27-7 triumph.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 -- The two goal-line stands against the Holy Cross Crusaders and the long march to a touchdown which brought the only victory in Crimson's last three starts are expected to prove a great tonic for the Harvard eleven this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Chiding be wet leaders for their announced plans to dispose of Federal prohibition as a reault of anti-dry sentiment in Tuesday's election, the Anti-Saloon League of America issued a statement today avowing its faith in the Eighteenth Amendment as the only solution to the liquor problem.

Joseph Martin, 50 years old, a salesman of 1,076 Brooks Avenue, the Bronx, was killed instantly last night when the automobile in which he was riding, driven by Miss Margaret Shubert, 30, of 207 Lament Avenue, Annadale, S.I., was in collision with another machine driven by Edward Jackson, 23, of 2,366 Richmond Road, New Dorp, at Hyland Boulevard and Craig Avenue, Tottenville, S.I.
YUMA, Ariz., Nov. 13. -- Following is the text of the message of President Hoover to Governor Roosevelt, inviting the President-elect to confer with him in Washington this week:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The text of the British war debts note, presented to Secretary of State Stimson by Sir Ronald Lindsay British Ambassador, follows:

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired and just placed on exhibition in its room of recent acceasions a wood-block from the famous Figdor collection in Vienna which is, so far as is known, one of the two extant wood-blocks of the sixteenth century bearing an original drawing by a great master.

VIENNA, Nov. 12 -- The shrinkage in the foreign trade of Central Europe continues at a frightful pace. Even the small increase in export of Austrian finished goods during September and October was chiefly due to the release of goods consigned for export, on payment in Austrian schillings instead of foreign currencies as has hitherto been prescribed.

The accurate toe of Benny Friedman sent the Dodgers back into the winning column yesterday, the Brooklyn captain booting a 15-yard placement goal in the first period to give his team a 3-0 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in a National Football League game before a crowd of 17,000 fans at Ebbets Field.

Thirteen post-season high school football games are to be played in various parts of the city on Saturday, Dec. 3, for the benefit of the Board of Education's School Relief Fund, the P.S.A.L. and The New York American Christmas Fund, according to an announcement by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education.

CHICAGO, Nov 12 -- Business in all lines of trade and industry is maintaining recent growth and making further headway, although there is no rush, but sentiment is more strongly in favor of better conditions after the first of the year. Trade leaders in a few instances are urging persistent buying and in some sections this advice is being followed, but in others, where trade revival has been slow, conservatism continues.

BUFFALO, Nov. 13 -- La Salle College of Philadelphia was held to a scoreless tie by Canisius today. The game, played on a muddy field, marked the second scoreless deadlock of the year for the visitors.

The Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., now open to receive its first involuntary guests, embodies the latest principles of prison architecture. Over one of the portals are graved BACON'S words: "That " which is past and gone is irrev" ocable; wise men have enough to do " with things present and to come."

Provision for work relief employment for 5,000 men on public improvements under the jurisdiction of the State Conservation Department was made yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration when it allotted $541,500 for this purpose from the funds to be made available by the $30,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief approved by the voters on election day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Capitol Hill will buzz with committee hearings this week in preparation for the December session of Congress.

There has been a "startling decrease" in the number of men and women offering themselves for missionary service during the last few years, according to the report of an appraisal commission appointed by the Laymen's Foreign Missions inquiry and financed by John D. Rockefeller Jr. and other members of seven Protestant denominations.

URBANA, Ill., Nov. 13 -- The Pact of Paris, which was signed and ratified by sixty-two nations, has reversed the practice of centuries whereby war was considered the legitimate prerogative of any sovereign State, according to Frank B. Kellog, co-author of the Kellogg-Briand pact and former Secretary of State.

Z.J. Simmons Jr. was the principal winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He annexed the High Scratch Cup with a card of 98 out of a possible 100 targets, won a leg on the Scratch Doubles Cup by breaking 41 out of 50 and gained a leg on the distance cup, returning a card of 23 out of 25 from the 25-yard mark.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The New York Americans tonight battled the Chicago Black Hawks to a 1-to-l overtime tie in a National Hockey League match. A crowd of 7,200 saw the game, played in the Hawks' old home, the Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Although valued at less than at any other time since pre-war years, there is no indication that Anierican foreign trade will not return to its former level, and "there is ample reason for optimism, reassurance and determination," Frederick M. Feiker, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said today in his annual report.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Texas erected a new legal dam today across its vast oil pools, declaring officials may consider "market demand" in fixing the flow of petroleum allowed the 8,000 producing oil wells in the rich East Texas field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Oct. 31 a correspondent asks why the college professors petitioning for reduced duties do not "offer concrete and wellstudied suggestions with which one may agree or disagree." May I as one of them take up the challenge?
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Francisco Lagos Chazaro, former Provisional President of Mexico, died today at the age of 70.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13 -- The grain markets here were calm throughout last week, with the downward price trend apparently stopped, and although there was no notable price reaction, there was less pessimism than in the previous two weeks.

PASSAIC, N.J., Nov. 13 -- The national election was seen as a challenge to Christian churches throughout the land by Dr. John McDowell, secretary of the board of national missions of the Presbyterian Church, who delivered a sermon here tonight at the First Presbyterian Church.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- London's security markets are undergoing a change which, as the City sees it, may or may not be lasting. Present conditions, it is thought, may again give place, temporarily at all events, to the conditions which had prevailed a little while ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial on the Scottsboro decision states, with much truth, that "it is not often that we see the issue of justice to the lowliest * * * so clearly appearing in an important judicial decision." The reason for this is not far to seek.
Spurred by Captain Rogers Dumestre, the French Sporting Club surprised a large gathering at Gas Companies Athletic Field in Astoria by trouncing the veteran New York Rugby Club, 11 to 0 yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Chicago's socio-judicial experiment, intended by its sponsors to protect women offenders from "racketeers operating under the cloistering cloak of the law," was acclaimed a success today by Mrs. Ethel R. McDowell, director of social service of the municipal courts.

ANN ARBOR, Mlch.,Nov. 13 -- The National Academy of Sciences is to hold its Autumn meeting at the University of Michigan tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday under the presidency of Dr. William Wallace Campbell, director emeritus of Lick Observatory.
Auld Lang Syne. All right-feeling men and women must be hoping as one that JOSEPHUS DANIELS'S extraordinary proposal is sharply turned down, and that it will not be a case of the Forgotten Donkey.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (AP) -- With an official explanation still lacking, Moscow today had accepted generally the story that Nadya Alleuieva, 30-year-old wife of Joseph Stalin, died last Wednesday from acute appendicites.
WATERLOO, Neb., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Gus Sumnicks, thirteen strong and "just folks," plan to visit the Franklin D. Roosevelts in Washington next Summer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Foreign debt settlements, reduction of the budget, provision of new revenues to meet the increasing Federal deficit and prohibition will be the chief subjects of consideration of the "lame duck" session of Congress which meets three weeks from tomorrow.

Before leaving for Hot Springs, Va., Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, yesterday gave out a statement in which she said that, although she doubted the possibility of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment by the present Congress during the lame-duck session, a survey of its members indicated sufficient wet gains since the adjournment of the last session to make immediate modification of the Volstead act possible.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- It is taken for granted by the British Government that the negotiations that may grow out of its note made, public tonight in London and Washington asking a moratorium on the debt payment due Dec. 15 will take place in Washington.
Several Jersey City and Bayonne residences and flats were included in the New Jersey realty sales reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Pleas by Great Britain and France for reconsideration of the war debt settlements and temporary postponement of instalments due Dec. 15 were revealed today through publication by the State Department of notes from these governments.

I.W. Ross, a large holder of all classes of securities of the Southern Utilities Service Company, has written to other security holders asking them, to deposit first-mortgage 6 1/2 per cent bonds and three-year 6 per cent notes of the company with the First National Bank of Birmingham, Ala., or the First Union Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago in assent to a reorganization plan which he has prepared.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The grand finale for the 1932 gridiron championship of the Western Conference will be presented next Saturday, with all ten teams in action and with two possibilities involved.

OYSTER BAY, L.T., Nov. 13 -- The birthday Mrs. Annie Ide Cockran received by contract forty-one years ago from Robert Louis Stevenson, author of "Treasure Island," was not celebrated today for the first time since the contract was signed in Samoa in 1891.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Awards of twenty-four prize scholarships were announced today at Yale University.

Hope that anti-Jewish feeling in Germany would continue to recede as Hitlerism waned was expressed yesterday in the executive committee report adopted by the American Jewish Committee at its annual meeting at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

The Montclair A.C. defeated the Essex Club of Newark, 3-2, yesterday at Montclair and the Elizabeth Town and Country Club tied with the Short Hills Club, 2-2, at Elizabeth, as competition in Class B of the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League got under way.

Early in the second volume of "The Journal of Arnold Bennett: 1911-1920," published today by Viking, the author announces his achievement of "worldly success." For half of 1912, from April 1 to Oct. 1, illness had kept him inactive. He had turned out "comparatively few words," about 200,000, yet his writings had earned for him approximately $80,000.

Twenty-five mechanics chosen for outstanding craftsmanship in the construction of the Radio City Music Hall in Rockefeller Center will receive certificates and gold buttons in exercises to be held in the building tomorrow morning under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- In the seclusion of the Executive Mansion, Governor Roosevelt remained silent tonight on the invitation of President Hoover for a conference on international debts and other problems.

THE season in the East may wind up with, just one team holding a clean slate. Tbjere were three until the recent firing started: Colgate, Brown and Columbia. In a see-saw battle Lou Little's Lions were nipped by the big Brown Bear, 7 -- 6. The difference was not as wide as a church door nor as deep as a well, but it served. Columbia sadly departed from the undefeated class.
NEW YORK. Lord William Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, and Lady Cecil are arriving today at the Biltmore, where they will be until they sail for England Saturday.

High hats and berets mingled agreeably in Washington Square yesterday as the outdoor art exhibition went into its second day. Fully 1,000 persons passed any given display every hour, but the 360 artists exhibiting their works along the southern margin of the square complained that there was too much "passing" and not enough buying.

The Board of Taxicab Control made public yesterday the governing code for the industry in the city, effective Dec. 15. The board in one short paragraph eliminated the high rate cabs and substituted as the maximum charge the prevailing "fifteen-and-five" rate.

Formation of a protective committee to represent holders of approximately $23,000,000 of bonds outstanding of various storm sewer districts in the State of Michigan was announced yesterday. "Grave doubt as to the validity of the outstanding bonds," due to a decision of the Supreme Court of Michigan, is expressed by the committee, which consists of Kenneth M. Keefe, chairman; P.C. Wilmerding, vice chairman, and E.E. Quantrell.

Miss Evangeline Booth, commander-in-chief of the Salvation Army in the United States, declared in a sermon preached last night before 2,000 persons in Centennial Memorial Temple of the Salvation Army, 120 West Fourteenth Street, that the handwriting on the wall Belteshazzar saw in Babylon was his guilty conscience and that men today were seeing the same kind of handwriting.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, en route to Washington, Nov. 13. --Taking a forthright step for which there is no exact parallel in the nation's history, President Hoover has invited Franklin D. Roosevelt as President-elect to sit down with him soon in Washington to talk over the war debt problem.

The spirit of a world "determined to pursue a military policy" like a "suicidal maniac determined upon self-destruction" was condemned yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George Maychin Stockdale, pastor of the St. James Methodist Church, Madison Avenue and 126th Street.

In his speech of farewell to his California friends President HOOVER spoke two words for the country, one for the Republican party and none for himself. He made a plea and pledged his best efforts for "unity and constructive action" in order to promote recovery.

The Broadway premiere of "Gay Divorce," starring Fred Astaire, has been set back from Thanksgiving Week to Tuesday evening, Nov. 29, at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. With this postponement the number of next week's openings has been reduced from eight to seven.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 13 -- Trading in cotton contracts here last week was interrupted by election day, although it was not a legal holiday, and by Armistice Day, which was a legal holiday. Despite these interruptions, however, and an unexpectedly large government crop estimate, coupled with large ginnings for the last period, the week closed with prices fully $1 a bale higher locally than on the preceding Friday.

The new $1,250,000 edifice of the All Souls' Unitarian Church at Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue was dedicated last night with special services. More than 800 parishioners filled the interior of the church and its reception room in the basement, to which the program was carried by amplifiers.

After withstanding three years of depression, the country's life insurance companies are preparing to take further steps to make their financial stability doubly certain regardless of what the economic future may hold. Indications are that some actuarial adjustments and a general downward revision of dividend payments will result.

Before last Tuesday, Wall Street seemed to be much more in doubt on the question how the stock market would act when election results were known, than on the question what those results would be. The actual response fulfilled even opposite predictions.

With an attendance of 8,000, larger than that at any regular session, the "Thrill Night" staged by the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night proved a decided novelty. It was a radical departure from a tradition of nearly half a century, for never before in the forty-seven years of the show has there been a session held on Sunday.

The Right Rev. Lord William Gas coyne Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, hailed the United States as a leader of the Anglo-Saxon people, whose greatest power lay in the desire of other nations to copy her. He spoke from the pulpit of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Tenth Street, yesterday morning on the "Mission of the Anglo-Saxon Race."
No temporal power will ever prevail against the church, the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

It is perhaps too much to hope that future political campaigns will differ from past ones. There will always be the extravagant and foolish claims of the party managers, not issued to be believed by any but innocents. And, in the last few days, there will always be talk of the "back-swing" to whichever candidate is considered by the forecasters to be trailing.
DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 13 -- Texas Christian University football warriors have taken, the lead in the South-west Conference championship race and are favored to keep it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Senator Walsh of Montana said tonight that "if the debts question is urgent enough and it becomes necessary to dispose of the matter at once a special session of Congress should be called."

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Although the American cotton market seemed this week to have been influenced at first by the increased estimate of the American crop, the London view is that such estimates will not affect the future course of prices. In comparison with the world stock of American cotton, which at the end of September stood at 22,300,000 bales, the 500,000 increase in the estimate is considered insignificant.

With the resumptions of hearings by the Hofstadter legislative commitee scheduled for late this month, the decks were cleared yesterday for action on a broader scale and with a change of personnel urged as the aftermath of the elections.

The use of talking motion pictures in education received a new and important impetus yesterday with the exhibition of two scientific films for classroom work, the first of a series of twenty in the physical sciences announced by the University of Chicago last Spring.

COLOGNE, Germany, Nov. 14 (AP) -- In an exhaustive discussion of French military organization and equipment, to be presented in a special issue tomorrow, the Koelnische Illustrierte Zeitung, a weekly circulated throughout Germany and also read abroad, reaches the conclusion that "before the gates of Germany there stands the best-equipped army in the world, ready to march."
NEW YORK. Mrs. S. Morgan Barber of this city and Green Farms, Conn., will give a dinner dance Dec. 22 at the Pierre to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Barbara Barber.

Controller Charles W. Berry and the Tammany-controlled bloc in the Board of Estimate, who threw overboard the four-year bond plan of subway finance rather than effect budget economies by means of salary cuts or the elimination of patronage jobs, are scheduled to be "put on the spot" by Acting Mayor McKee today at a meeting of the committee of the whole.

The final whistle of the Yale-Prmceton football game Saturday did more than bring to a close a game in which the excitement had heen steadily mounting since the start of the second half. It marked also the finish of one of the most remarkable careers that college sport has yet produced in this country -- the retirement of Keene Fitzpatrick as trainer and coach at Princeton.

A civilian employe at Miller Field, S.I., headquarters of the Twenty-seventh Air Division, New York State National Guard, was killed instantly and four privates were injured, one severely, yesterday afternoon in the explosion of a huge underground gasoline tank in which they were tracing a leak.

A Federal grand jury investigating violations of the election fraud laws will have an opportunity today to examine a record of returns and all of the registration books in the twenty-five election districts of the Fourth Assembly District and the thirty-six election districts of the Second Assembly District.

Santa Claus will come to about 10,500,000 members of the Christmas Clubs within the next two weeks, when $441,000,000 will be distributed by more than 7,000 banking institutions and organizations, according to an estimate yesterday by Herbert F. Rawll, president of the incorporated organization.

Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink, veteran operatic star, was presented with a gold plaque from the stage of the Roxy Theatre last night as a belated testimonial to her fiftieth anniversary before the footlights, and as an appreciation of her influence in bringing the peoples of this country and Germany closer through her singing.
After dropping about 15 points on Saturday, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost 12 to 15 points more yesterday. Spot salee at Southern markets aggregated 60,000 bales, compared with 51,000 a year ago.
The possible influence of diet upon mentality is discussed by Dr. Louis Berman in "Food and Character," his latest book, published by Houghton Mifflin.

Three American diplomats are to sail tonight on the Leviathan of the United States Lines to their posts in Europe. They are F. Lamont Belin, newly appointed Ambassador to Poland; Lauritz S. Swenson, Minister to Holland, and Herman Bernstein, Minister to Albania.

Mrs. Harvey M. Ridabock of the Woodway Country Club was unanimously elected president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association at a meeting at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday morning. A board of officers for the coming year also was named.

Officers and crew of the German cruiser Karlsruhe saw New York from the dance floor and the tea table yesterday as the extensive entertainment program which had started on Saturday, soon after the cruiser's arrival, was continued.
Another fencing season will get under way tonight, when a long schedule of events which will continue through April is officially inaugurated at the New York Athletic Club.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, speaking yesterday at a meeting of the trustees of the United Hospital Fund, deplored the growing tendency of the public to expect government and public agencies to assume the entire burden of individual needs.

LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The city council has advertised for bids for the balance of a school bond issue amounting to $239,000 to be received tomorrow night at City Hall. This is being done in order that, if no bids are received tomorrow, the city will have thirty days more in which to try to sell the remaining bonds privately.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Many financial, business and legislative problems were discussed today by governors of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks and Federal Reserve agents, meeting here for the regular quarterly session.

Those who strayed down to the Civic Repertory Theatre yesterday evening were gently wafted back to the days of manners and periwigs, of Dr. Samuel Johnson and Lord Nelson and Trafalgar, and, most important of all, Jane Austen. For Miss Le Gallienne's company was engaged in re-establishing that period through the medium of the comedy "Dear Jane," by Eleanor Holmes Hinkley, with the vivacious Jose phine Hutchinson in the title role.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Roscoe Turner shot his monoplane into Albuquerque for a fast refueling 9 hours and 11 minutes out of New York and streaked away.

Play in Class C of the metropolitan squash tennis league got under way yesterday with three of the five matches being decided by one point, one resulting in a shut-out and one in a default. The City A.C. accounted for the clean sweep, when it conquered the Columbia University Club, 7-- 0, at the City A.C.

President HOOVER was under a sort of double obligation to seek Democratic cooperation between the election of Nov. 8 and the coming of a new Administration on March 4. Repeatedly during the campaign he dwelt upon the misfortune of having a sterile and uncertain interval in case Governor ROOSEVELT were elected President.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- With the exception of Charlie Nevin, right halfback, Coach Eddie Casey of Harvard today was able to start his entire first string eleven in the drive for the Tale game in New Haven on Saturday.

GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- According to trustworthy information here, China is already following the Lytton reports hint to the League of Nations that peace requires normal relations between Moscow and Nanking.

For the second year in succession the United States Army team captured the international military trophy by triumphing last night in the feature event of the forty-seventh annual National Horse Show. A gathering of 12,000 spectators cheered the winners in Madison Square Garden as Major John Tupper Cole, last of the American riders, completed perfect round, giving his team a total of four faults.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight accepted President Hoover's invitation to a conference at the White House on war debts, making his reply in a telegram conferred upon by the Governor and his advisers for many hours.

Joseph Baumann, 21 years old, who is under sentence to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing next Thursday for the killing of a man in a West Forty-ninth Street ciderstube hold-up in August, 1931, testifying yesterday in General Sessions at the first-degree murder trial of Francis Howard Reddy, 23, in the shooting, identified the defendant as his confederate.

BASLE, Nov. 14 -- It was learned from authoritative sources tonight that an unofficial session of directors of the Bank for International Settlements Sunday was devoted to discussion of the present world monetary situation and that their general view was optimistic.

Neighbors reached out helping hands yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. Sylvio Giacinto of 407 East Twelfth Street, who were unable on Sunday to claim the body of their daughter Josephine, 12 days old, as it lay in Bellevue Hospital Morgue, dead from a rat bite.

An ancient "talent," in gold or silver, was variously estimated by weight. According to ATHENAEUS, whose hooks are a storehouse of miscellaneous information, ALEXANDER the Great gave to ARISTOTLE for his researches 800 talents, which in the reckoning of a modern authority amounted to more than the endowment of many a college.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Opposition to the British and French proposals for suspension of the Dec. 15 payment on foreign debts, on the ground that such action would lead to ultimate cancellation, appeared today to be the dominant reaction among the few Congressional leaders here.
PARIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The text of the official English translation of the French disarmament plan, given out by the Foreign Office tonight, follows:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- Head Coach Mal Stevens today reversed his plans for drilling the Yale varsity squad for Saturday's game with Harvard.

If the Volstead act were modified at once to legalize beer, New York City brewers could start producing real beer at the rate of 4,000,000 barrels a year, or more than 10,000 barrels a day, while production in Northern New Jersey would be a little under 1,000,000 barrels a year brewers estimated yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The close resemblance of the British and French debt notes to the United States, both in substance and form, recalls the incident of last July when the British and French Governments disagreed as to the scope of their gentlemen's consultative agreement made after the Lausanne settlement.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 14 -- Indications that the tide of defeat in the conflict with Paraguay may have turned back and that internal dissension here may have come to an end delighted Bolivia today.

Old-timers say that rabbit hunting is one of the most thrilling of sports because to get Mr. Rabbit one must always be ready to shoot from the nip in good old Western fashion. This is especially true when there is no snow on the ground and the rabbit has plenty of cover.
Supreme Court Justice James A. Dunne in Brooklyn denied yesterday an application for an order holding State Senator John A. Hastings in contempt.

Henry Warner Ells, retired man- ager of the New York office of Procter Gamble, soap manufacturers, who died Nov. 21, 1931, left an estate appraised yesterday at $569,640 gross and $540,516 net, of which $560,202 was in securities, including 12,000 shares of Procter Gamble common stock worth $529,560.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 14 -- A continuance was decided on today in the anti-trust suit against the Radio Corporation of America, General Electric, Westinghouse Electric, American Telephone and Telegraph and others. The suit had been scheduled to open in the Federal District Court here tomorrow.

A general inquiry into the terminal services performed in various industrial plants in this area was begun yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission at a hearing before representatives of the commission in the Hotel New Yorker.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Many hundreds were reported killed in twelve hours of heavy fighting between rebels and Federal troops today at the city of San Pedro.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting yesterday to hear argument on the appeal of the Inter-borough Rapid Transit Company, the receivers for that company, the Manhattan Railway Company and others, heard attorneys for the appellants uphold what they termed the validity of the acts of the senior judge of that court in connection with the two receiverships.

Upon the decision taken by Congress on the request of Great Britain and France for a reconsideration of the war debts may depend the safety of billions of dollars of private American investments abroad, according to views expressed by bankers yesterday in discussing the British and French notes transmitted to our government.

Joseph M. Price, chairman of the board of trustees of the City Club of New York, made public yesterday a letter sent to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in Washington urging the board to feel no alarm at the outcry from Bronx landlords against the $8,957,000 loan being sought by the Hillside Housing Corporation and declaring that the unemployed and the building trades were eagerly awaiting favorable action on the project.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The House of Lords was ex- pected tonight to give third reading to the governments' bill implementing the United Kingdom's Ottawa conference trade pacts with the Dominions. The measure passed through committee stage today.

The three-day advance in the stock market with which last week ended did not continue yesterday; in fact, the market opened with initial declines ranging from fractions to several points. While it went still lower afterward, the subsequent losses were not large, and were mostly recovered before the close.

NICE, Nov. 14 -- George Anthell, the American composer, claims to have discovered in an old mattress at Cagnes sur Mer, near here, a gold coin wrapped in a piece of paper on which was written the following note, signed "George Washington".

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two features of the Nov. 8 American revolution are worth especial emphasis at this time, it seems to me. The first is the effect of the election on public spirit. Even Senator Moses, now reported to be unearthing "plots" in the recesses of the White Mountains, may eventually realize what that means.

A suit to compel Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the B.M.T. board of directors, and William S. Menden, president, to restore to the B.M.T. treasury an aggregate of $330,000 paid as "additional compensation" in 1928, 1929, 1930 and 1931 was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Quarterback Eddie Masavage of the Pennsylvania football team is not likely to start against Cornell in the final game.
