SACRAMENTO, Cal., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Freedom came in sight today for about 1,000 persons held in California prisons and jails on charges of violating the State prohibition law when Governor James Rolph Jr. announced that he intended to pardon all these as a result of the overwhelming vote last Tuesday for repeal of the statute.

GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- The detailed negotiations on the Franco-Italian naval problem that were broken off in April, 1931, were resumed here today. They are the centre of unusual activity behind the scenes, while public attention is being drawn elsewhere by the French publishing the text of their general disarmament plan, which was given out in the League of Nations tonight as well as in Paris.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Coach Charles Caldwell of the Williams football team today made his annual selection of an all-Little Three eleven for the last season. Six Amherst, three Williams and two Wesleyan men were chosen. His team follows:

Kid Chocolate, world's featherweight champion, won the decision from Pete Nebo, Key West, Fla., lightweight, last night at the St. Nicholas Arena in one of the greatest ten-round battles seen here in recent years. A crowd of 2,500 was present.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 14 -- A new attempt to solve the controversy be- tween Colombia and Peru over the town of Leticia, near the international border, which was seized recently by citizens of Peru, was made today by Pedro Irigoyen, Peruvian Ambassador to Chile.

Franco-German friendship growing out of contacts between young people of the two nations was characterized as a "new hope for our troubled world" in a radio broadcast over station WEAF yesterday by Dr. Paul Schwarz, German Consul in New York City, who spoke on the youth movement in his country.

Reporting in fine physical condition after its 28 -- 0 triumph over Clarkson, the Manhattan football squad opened preparations for the final and most important contest of its official season, with Holy Cross at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday, by engaging in a ninety-minute drill on Manhattan Field yesterday.

It is fascinating to listen to a great artist, when he has reached his maturity, discoursing at his instrument great music. Because there are two things in a performance by a virtuoso and interpreter. One is the composition itself and the other is the interpretation.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, vicar of the Chapel of the Intercession, who in 1924 declined two opportunities to become a Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, we selected yesterday to be the twelft rector of Trinity Parish and successor to the late Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson, who died June 15.

The adjusted index of automobile production is 20.5 for the week ended Nov. 12, as against 19.2 for the preceding week and 16.5 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, amounted to 11,047 cars and trucks, as compared with 10,207 cars and trucks in the preceding week and 9,156 cars and trucks in the corresponding week last year.

Laws to compel re-classification of the civil service lists and a reduction in exempt positions, to extend the inquiry powers of the Governor an to pave the way for proportions representation and consolidation of city and county governments were recommended yesterday by the Committee of One Thousand in a report on charter revision.

A transaction which, it is predicted, will go far toward re-establishing Fourth Avenue as the sales centre of the wholesale dry-goods and affiliated industries wag closed yesterday when William Iselin Co., factors and sales representatives of independent manufacturing concerns, signed contracts for a 20,000-square-foot increase in their floor space and the extension of their lease at their present location, 357 Fourth Avenue, the block front from Twenty-fifth to Twenty-sixth Streets.

The Yiddish Art Theatre last night presented as its second offering of the season a dramatization of Sholom Asch's novel "Chayim Lederer," which Is to be played the first Kalb" of the week, while "Yoshe Kalb" will continue as the week-end attraction.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The Duke of Leinster, Premier Duke of the Irish peerage, has joined Mrs. Raffaele Van Neck of New York in issuing a denial of the widely-published report of their engagement. Mrs. Van Neck, formerly Miss Raffaele Kennedy, is tall and graceful and an accomplished pianist.

Seymour Alexander, national champion, advanced to the second round in the New York State one-wall singles handball title tourney at the Union Temple, Brooklyn, last night, when he defeated George Sgouras, 21-- 2, 21 -- 14, in a first-round encounter.
ALBANY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Democratic platform carried only a one-sentence reference to war debts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- An appeal from President Hoover for all Americans to "respond in generous measure" to the Red Cross rollcall was made public tonight by officials of the relief organization, along with their own plea.

Among the commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday were several contracts for office space in the midtown Fifth Avenue district. Several stores also were leased. Rentals were listed as follows:

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A charge that The Youngstown Telegram, a Scripps-Howard newspaper, "padded" circulation figures, was made and denied today as three officials and one ex-official of the paper went on trial charged with fraudulent advertising through publishing a false circulation statement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The newest of American 8-inch gun cruisers, the Indianapolis will be placed in commission at the Philadelphia navy yard tomorrow. She is the first 10,000-ton cruiser to be laid down and completed since the ratification of the London Naval Limitation Treaty, and the first to reach the maximum tonnage under the treaty.

Re-examination of intergovernmental war debts with the view to such action as the facts, "and nothing but the facts," will warrant was urged yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor. He was in New York on his way from Washington to Cincinnati to preside at the convention of the federation, which opens Nov. 21.

As a result of petty thefts from turnstile coin-boxes, some entrances to the new Independent subway system have been ordered closed during the hours when no agent is on duty in the change booth, it was revealed yesterday. No station has been closed entirely, however, the order being applicable only to what were termed "secondary" entrances.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The British debt note was the dominating influence today on the exchange market, where sterling was purchased in speculative anticipation of acceptance by the United States of the British suggestion, and the dollar value of the pound rose from $3.32 1/2 to $3.34 1/2, the highest figure in three weeks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Buying of wheat by houses with Eastern connections and bullish summaries of conditions abroad, especially regarding the Russian food situation, advanced prices of that grain 1 1/2 cents a bushel in early trading today on the Board of Trade here.
GENOA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Owners of the new liner Conte di Savoia disclosed today that the vessel had averaged 29.5 knots in her speed tests.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 -- The first time I crossed the country in an airplane it took me a week.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, en route to Washington, Nov. 14 -- President Hoover received this evening Franklin D. Roosevelt's acceptance of an invitation to confer on war debts and other national problems that will continue over into his administration.

Monday, Nov. 14, 1932 The money market opened the new week in the same position it had closed the previous week -- there were no changes either in quotations or business. Stock Exchange demand loans held at 1 per cent, while the usual concessions from this figure obtained on Street trades and government money.

To most of us Don Marquis is known and reverenced as the creator of Archy the cockroach, the Old Soak, Captain Fitzurse and other discursive savants. To many of us he is also known and properly respected as the author of a modern play of the passion, "The Dark Hours," which was published as a book about eight years ago and which was acted at the New Amsterdam last evening.

The thirty-eighth annual convention of the New York State federation of Women's Clubs opened at the Hotel Astor yesterday, with the achievements of women as its keynote. More than 400 delegates from all over the State had registered last night.

William Carter, unattached, was a double victor in the 118-pound class at the monthly amateur boxing tournament at the Downtown A.C. last night. He defeated Paul Guglielmo, unattached. In the semi-final and then gained the decision over John Cabello of the Ascension Parish House in the final.

The Rev. Dr. Maitland Bartlett, for the last few years Vice Moderator of the Presbytery of New York, was unanimously elected Stated Clerk of that body at a meeting yesterday in Christ Presbyterian Church, Thirty-Sixth Street, near Ninth Avenue. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Harlan G. Mendenhall, who resigned at the last meeting of the Presbytery and was unanimously elected Stated Clerk emeritus.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Trading was slow, but the trend of prices was steady on the Bourse today, with some buying by professionals in advance of tomorrow's mid-month liquidation. Closing prices were at about the same levels as Saturday's.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 14 -- The Mexican Senate postponed action indefinitely today on a resolution of the Foreign Relations Committee providing for acceptance of the award of Clipperton Island to France by the King of Italy as arbiter.

With many distinguished naval officers, headed by Rear Admiral F.R. Lackey, commanding the New York Naval Militia, in the reviewing stand, the First Battalion of the New York Naval Militia and the United States Naval Reserve held its annual review and parade last night aboard its training ship, the U.S.S. Illinois, at the foot of West Ninety-eighth Street at the Hudson River.

A total of 1,606 thoroughbreds raced in 1932 over the five New York State courses which are under Jockey Club jurisdiction, according to the annual report filed by Albert Burlen, clerk of the scales at the five courses. This number represents a slight decrease from 1931, but there were only 170 days of racing this year as against 171 last year.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- The Boerse seemed to be upset today by the situation in domestic politics, especially about the question of what the government will do with regard to the new Reichstag, which does not seem inclined to support it. Business accordingly was extremely quiet and stocks declined early in the session.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- A story which the police said today would bear deeper investigation was related here by an alleged swindler who declared that Colonel Raymond Robins, missing prohibition advocate and friend of President Hoover, was thrown to his death in the Atlantic Ocean forty miles off Montauk Point, L.I., after being kidnapped by rum runners.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Transformation of branch-line railway mileage in New England into heavy-duty highways as a partial solution of the New England railroad problem was proposed today by the Rhode Island Commission on Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Cash-Carry Brings New Record. New records for sales and attendance were established yesterday in the basement department of Gimbel Brothers when that department went entirely on a cash-and-carry basis. The number of transactions exceeded the 75,000 mark, with attendance running more than double that figure, according to estimates made by Barney Marks, general merchandise manager for the basement.

The Congress that meets next month may be the last "lame duck" session of that body. Dictionaries refer to "lame duck" as a "disabled person or thing; specifically, one who cannot meet his financial engagements." Even NOAH WEBSTER'S successors meekly accept this connotation.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Subscriptions totaling $393,281 to the Newark community chest were reported at the first meeting of campaign, workers held today in the Mosque ballroom. The amount is about 28 per cent of the quota of $1,395,859.

Who is to clean up the wreckage and start to rebuild the Republican party in this State? "The hope of the Republican, party," says Dr. BUTLER, "lies in its youth." No doubt, unfortunately, Republican youth was not strongly inclined to vote the Republican ticket last Tuesday.

The Book-of-the-Month Club choice for December is "Sherman: Fighting Prophet" by Lloyd Lewis, dramatic critic on The Chicago Daily News. The club's fourth "book-dividend" of this year is a one-volume "Nine Plays of Eugene O'Neill," which includes "Mourning Becomes Electra" and "Strange Interlude," and contains an introduction by Joseph Wood Krutch.

Thirteen, the black cat that was adopted Sunday afternoon by Dr. Joseph Tamerin of Bellevue Hospital when it strolled out of a burlap bag supposed to contain a human body, became a problem at the hospital yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The large amounts at stake in the negotiations concerning revision of the wartime debts owed by European nations to the United States are shown by the latest figures compiled by the Treasury Department. The funded debt of the fifteen nations is $11,229,968,706, to which later will be added $184,000,000 in interest which was postponed because of the Hoover moratorium for the fiscal year 1932.
JUAREZ, Mexico, Nov. 14 (AP) -- "Marquis" Emllio del Sera Fiaschi received a divorce here today from Leta Constance Wright del Sera of New York.

HAVANA, Nov. 14 -- One hundred and fifty Americans engaged in the citrus fruit industry in the vicinity of the town of La Gloria, just outside the city of Camaguey, have appealed for assistance as a result of last weeks' hurricane, Ambassador Harry F. Guggenneim said today.

ON BOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL, en route to Washington, Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Hoover tonight worked at an improvised desk in his private car upon plans to be discussed with Franklin D. Roosevelt for dealing with the moratorium requests of foreign debtors.

A Brighton line subway train, entering the Stillwell Avenue station of the B.M.T. at Coney Island yesterday with more than fifty passengers aboard crashed into a six-car train coming from, the yard tracks and injured thirty-one persons. All were treated by ambulance surgeons in emergency quarters set up in the dispatcher's office, but none was taken to the hospital.

Many new varieties of roses made their debut yesterday. In red, pink, yellow and in various shades they were shipped from greenhouses in New Jersey, Indiana and Maine to compete in the flower exhibit of the New York Florists' Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Senator Ashurst of Arizona, a recent wet convert and probable chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the next Senate, issued a call for Democrats today to stand by their campaign pledge on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

A supper dance and fashion show will be held on Dec. 10 in the Cascades of the Biltmore for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre, which carries on an extensive health program for mothers and children in a crowded district of the city.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 15 -- The French plan for a League of Nations army to insure peace is not considered here likely to gain any great number of adherents. Nor is the retention of heavy weapons in national hands, though nominally under the special care and supervision of the League, expected to be seen by the present generation.

Four seeded players, including Edward G. McLaughlin, Columbia University Club star, emerged victorious in their second-round matches of the Fall scratch squash tennis tourney at the New York A.C. yesterday. McLaughlin defeated F.A. Sieverman Jr., New York A.C., in straight games, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 9.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 14 -- Dispatches from Manchuria today report that a carefully planned Japanese campaign is successfully advancing against Chinese irregulars, the Japanese forces sweeping the entire territory bounded on the west by the Mukden-Changchun Railway, about 175 miles long, on the north by the fifty-mile Changchun-Kirin line and on the east by that from Kirin back to Mukden direct.

Five of the city's leading trade organizations announced that they had yesterday agreed to support the Port of New York Authority in its proposal to build the midtown tunnel under the Hudson River and had forwarded virtually identical letters to the Board of Estimate urging that it reconsider "calmly and promptly" opposition to the application of the Port Authority for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to finance the work.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Governor Roosevelt made public today an interim report of the Saratoga Springs Commission, declaring that important results in cardiac therapy were already being obtained from the State-owned springs on the reservation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Nov. 9 shows an increase for the week of $44,000,000 in net demand deposits, and decreases of $50,000,000 in government deposits, $22,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Bank and $6,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

Ralph Gonzale, 9 years old, son of an unemployed laborer, was seized with convulsions and died in his home at 70 East 114th Street, yesterday afternoon after he "was supposed to have eaten some poisonous food in Public School 57, 160 East 115th Street," according to a police report.

The restoration of Lincoln Cathedral, recently completed, is of interest to people in the United States because more than half of its cost, L130,000, was provided by them. It has been said that the cathedral "has perhaps no rival among the churches in Great Britain in the combination of size, delicacy of detail, effectiveness of both exterior and interior, and grandeur of situation."

A new issue of $1,000,000 Milwaukee County (Wis.) relief bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1932, and due on April 1, 1933 to 1942, was awarded yesterday to a group headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, and including Kidder, Peabody Co., Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; R.H. Moulton Co., Inc., and Stern Brothers Co., Kansas City, Mo.

The best was pretty much like the worst and the Ten Commandments took a frightful kicking around the stage at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last night when John Henry Mears presented "Singapore," a play all about people living in -- yes, Singapore -- and love and bate and things.

The body of Benjamin Levy, 59-year-old insurance man, who had been missing since 9 o'clock Sunday morning, was found last evening in the rear of an abandoned garage in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. He had been killed by two blows over the head, evidently after he had put up a fight against his assailants.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 15 -- The severest typhoon ever recorded in Japan struck the Loochoo Islands late Sunday, swept up the east coast of Japan to Numazu and then gave Tokyo a night of anxiety and danger, finally passing out into the Pacific this morning.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 14 -- The Autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences, held at the University of Michigan this year, was selected by Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago to present his conclusions from a survey of the cosmic rays which covered 50,000 square miles, which took him from the equator to the icy North and which made it necessary for him to climb mountains 15,000 feet high.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- The cross-country team of the Hartford High School today won the first annual Connecticut interscholastic athletic conference run.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 14 -- Mad Frump, bearing the silks of C.V. Whitney, scored by a neck in the Glen Echo Purse, feature on the opening-day program of the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association at Bowie today. The fourteen-day session will be the last of the Eastern racing season.
Columbia entered the final stages of its football campaign yesterday when it started preparation for its annual encounter with Syracuse on Saturday.
More false clues hampered the police again yesterday in their search for Paul Marciante, 10 years old, of 315 East Sixtieth Street, who was kidnapped a week ago yesterday while on his way to school.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The engagement has been announced of Miss Leonora Wodehouse, daughter of P. G. Wodehouse, the British novelist, and Mrs. Wodehouse, to Peter Cazalet, son of William Marshall Cazalet who died in October.

Appealing for the cooperation of all church women in raising funds for the unemployed within the Episcopal Church, the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop, yesterday deplored any seeming lack of cooperation between his church an the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, but explained that aid for needy Episcopalians would be sought by Bishop Manning's committee on behalf of applicants on the rolls of the City Mission Society.

The Pictorial Review Company's annual award of $5,000 was presented yesterday to Helen Keller at a luncheon in the Hotel Ambassador, and was turned over by her to the American Foundation for the Blind to be held in trust and distributed at her direction.

Racing over the famous six-mile stretch of hill and plain at Van Cortlandt Park faster than the distance had ever been traversed before, George Barker of New York University climaxed a harrier career of rare consistency by winning the twenty-fourth annual running of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country championship yesterday.

Although several groups of operators and owners of taxicabs voiced yesterday their approval of the new code promulgated by the Board of Taxicab Control, at least one group protested that the new regulations were detrimental to the "independent."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Liberal party in Nicaragua won most of the principal offices in the election held on Nov. 9 under the supervision of the United States Marines, Rear Admiral Clark Howell Woodward reported to the Department of State today.

A Modern Master Builder. ABRAHAM E. LEFCOURT started out as a bootblack and newsboy on Delancey Street and died, at the early age of 55, one of the greatest builders in history since Louis XIV and Sir CHRISTOPHER WREN.

Julio Perez, 29 years old, a laborer arrested Sunday night in the murder of Manuel Gonzales in Yonkers on Jan. 8, 1931, insisted yesterday when questioned by Inspector Vincent Sweeney in the line-up that he had no knowledge of the murder, although he had known Gonzales.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was unsatisfactory in volume, from the viewpoint of the brokers, and the price movement was disappointing to the rank and file of speculators who happen, at the moment, to be committed to the advance.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's rallying cry to young and liberal Republicans to rejuvenate their party was received yesterday with interest but without enthusiasm in local Republican circles.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Adventurous soldiers of fortune still go dashing into battle -- and one of the latest of these is Guy Maloney of New Orleans, a federal General in the present Honduran rebellion.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- In Paris and Geneva simultaneously the French Government today issued in the form of a memorandum to the disarmament conference its plan for reducing European national armaments and armies to a defensive scale, setting up the nucleus of an international force and giving equality rights to all countries.

The Baron Lionel Walter Roth schild collection of birds -- with a original value of more than $1,000,000 and constituting the largest single gift in the history of the American Museum of Natural History -- was acquired through funds supplied by the widow and children of the late Harry Payne Whitney, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Ratification of the St. Lawrence waterways treaty negotiated last Summer between the United States and Canada was opposed today by New York waterways officials and the Association of Railway Executives, when a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee opened hearings at the Capitol.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -- A new trophy donated especially by President Justo of Argentina will be at stake in the international pole series, starting Saturday, between picked teams representing the United States and the Argentine, but it has not yet been determined whether it will be called the "Cup of the Americas" or involve championship significance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Supreme Court refused today to pass upon the validity of an internal revenue search warrant against which Rocco Catagrone of Kansas City protested after prohibition agents used it as authority to raid his home.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- After a firm opening today the stock markets slumped, due to lack of buying. Sterling exchange on New York was higher at $3.33 1/4, which helped British funds, but early improvements were not held, prices reacting on profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The District of Columbia authorities are quietly preparing for a possible second invasion of destitute marchers, this time, according to advance notices, in the form of a "hunger march" the columns of which will start from several cities.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The world economic conference is not likely to be held before April, it is admitted in official circies here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Early Wednesday morning Harvard College Observatory will begin the most extensive meteor study in astronomic history, from points scattered over the United States and Canada, in an effort to find out more about the Leonid shower.

DOVER, Del., Nov. 14 -- Arguments were heard here this afternoon for more than three hours by Chancellor J.O. Wolcott on an application of the Aviation Corporation that the courts dissolve a restraining order obtained last week by the Cord Corporation enjoining the directors of the Aviation Corporation and others from holding a meeting at which they would consider the question of buying certain assets of North American Aviation, Inc.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Libby Holman Reynolds may be freed tomorrow of the murder charge that has hung over her since shortly after her husband, Smith Reynolds, heir to a tobacco fortune, was fatally shot here last July.

Comment of newspapers of the country on the proposed war debts conference of President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt is generally favorable. Here are extracts from editorials gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Supreme Court refused today to pass upon the validity of an internal revenue search warrant against which Rocco Catagrone of Kansas City protested after prohibition agents used it as authority to raid his home.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- After a firm opening today the stock markets slumped, due to lack of buying. Sterling exchange on New York was higher at $3.33 1/4, which helped British funds, but early improvements were not held, prices reacting on profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The District of Columbia authorities are quietly preparing for a possible second invasion of destitute marchers, this time, according to advance notices, in the form of a "hunger march" the columns of which will start from several cities.

Evidence that the hotel industry is preparing for the expected modification of the Eighteenth Amendment was found yesterday at the National Hotel Exposition, opening at the Grand Central Palace under the joint auspices of the New York State Hotel Association and the Hotel Association of New York City.

The handsome new galleries of Wildenstein Co., Inc., at 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, will be opened today with a reception, for which invitations have been issued, but the public will be admitted also. Yesterday there was a preview exclusively for members of the press.

Before representatives of about forty women's organizations in the metropolitan district and a number of unemployed actors, Chamberlain Brown, Broadway casting agent and occasional theatrical producer, yesterday afternoon at the Shubert Theatre outlined a plan whereby he hopes to revive interest in the legitimate stage.

DOVER, Del., Nov. 14 -- Arguments were heard here this afternoon for more than three hours by Chancellor J.O. Wolcott on an application of the Aviation Corporation that the courts dissolve a restraining order obtained last week by the Cord Corporation enjoining the directors of the Aviation Corporation and others from holding a meeting at which they would consider the question of buying certain assets of North American Aviation, Inc.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Libby Holman Reynolds may be freed tomorrow of the murder charge that has hung over her since shortly after her husband, Smith Reynolds, heir to a tobacco fortune, was fatally shot here last July.

Comment of newspapers of the country on the proposed war debts conference of President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt is generally favorable. Here are extracts from editorials gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Thomas Patrick Morris, Brooklyn house painter who contends he is a son of John Gottlieb Wendel and rightful heir to the Wendel fortune of $30,000,000 or more, admitted yesterday under examination by John M. Harlan, trial counsel for the estate, that most of the dates he cited in his testimony last Summer were at least a year in error.

Early accounts of the havoc done by a typhoon in the Tokyo and Kanagawa Prefectures on Monday made the loss of life and destruction of property much greater than was reported after the passing of the storm. It is little more than nine years since earthquake, tidal wave and conflagration almost destroyed both Tokyo and Yokohama, which is in Kanagawa Prefecture, and 58,000 persons were killed in Tokyo, and 29,600 in Kanagawa Prefecture.

Property owners by the thousands descended yesterday upon the borough offices of the Department of Taxes and Assessments to file objections to the tentative assessed valuation of their holdings before the statutory time limit expired last night.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument by counsel representing shareholders of the Manhattan Railway Company on the appeal taken by receivers for that company and the Interborough Rapid Transit Company from the decision of Federal Judge John M. Woolsey holding the receiverships to be invalid.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15. -- During October production of Canadian newsprint mills amounted to 157,506 tons, as compared with 150,691 tons in September, and 184,252 tons in October, 1931, according to the current report of the Newsprint Service Bureau.

Charging that the American Sugar Refilling Company, in publicly announcing the closing of its refinery in Baltimore, was making a transparent attempt to capitalize a routine procedure to seek an advantage in the tariff on sugar. H.H. Pike Jr., president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, stated yesterday his belief that the proposed "super-tariff" on refined sugar for which many leading refiners have been working was still unjustified.

Montgomery should advertise its corn pone, Fort Wayne its good milk gravy, and there should be food maps as well as road maps for distribution at filling stations, Sheila Hibben writes in the introduction to her "The National Cookbook: A Kitchen Americana," published today by Harpers.

On Monday Colonel ROSCOE TURNER landed in Burbank, Cal., 12 hours and 33 minutes out of New York, breaking the East-West record. The schedule of passenger, mail and express service between the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts has just been cut to twenty-four hours by one of the airlines.
The driver of a motorcycle and a friend astride the seat behind him were killed last night in a collision with a taxicab at Park Avenue and Sixty-third Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- With nothing more at stake than the settlement of an annual rivalry, Stanford and California will meet at Berkeley Saturday in a football game that will draw the largest crowd and the most money and will cost the highest price for tickets of any contest played thus far this season.

Mrs. Mary G. Ford of 33 Riverside Drive, who taught in the city's schools for more than, thirty-five years, was found guilty last night of first-degree grand larceny on a charge of obtaining $1,800 under false pretenses by a jury in the Kings County Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Showing a gain of $198,284,000 in three months, national bank resources Sept. 30 were $22,565,995,000, F.G. Await, Acting Controller of the Currency, announced today. This marked a reduction of $3,180,069,000 since Sept. 29, 1931.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- While most foreign countries treated the French plan for the organization of peace with at least a certain courtesy today, almost the whole Paris press subjected it to a heavy fire of criticism which goes to the point of supposing, "What if the League of Nations army were beaten?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The importance of cotton in the American economic structure was demonstrated in a report by the Commerce Department today, showing that exports of this commodity in the three months ended Oct. 31 totaled 2,194,000 bales, with a value of $89,613,000.

With the noteworthy exception of Tennessee and Southern California, the ranks of the major contenders for national football honors have undergone a remarkable turnover within a year, comparison of today's pace-setters with those of the battle of 1931 reveals.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 15 -- The 5-year-old mare Kincsen, which races for Mrs. F.A. Carreaud, came from last place to first in the featured race today to win in a hard drive. Espinetta, 2-year-old, was second, half a length back of the daughter of Cudgel and Buckwheat, and six lengths before Seven Veils which landed the show.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 -- Measures to control the labor supply for factories, which perhaps will be similar to the recent action regarding clerks and other office employes, was foreshadowed in today's leading editorial in the Pravda, revealing the present unsatisfactory situation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Recommendations for a reduction of 12.6 per cent in the production of refinery gasoline during the next five months, to offset an anticipated decline of 10.1 per cent in potential demand and excessive stocks in some localities, are contained in the semiannual report issued today by the Volunteer Committee on Petroleum Economics of the Federal Oil Conservation Board.

The creation of the National Economy League to combat the "legalized racket" of World War veterans' compensation was described yesterday by Archibald B. Roosevelt, national secretary of the league, son of President Theodore Roosevelt and a wounded veteran himself.

Considerable mystery surrounds the ultimate disposition of the Federal Hall reproduction in Bryant Park, which was opened to the public last April by the George Washington Bicentennial Commission. Until yesterday it had been expected that the building would be torn down when the celebration ended on Nov. 28 and that the park would be restored to its former state.

Three of five men who were playing pinochle in a West Forty-fourth Street cider stube in August, 1931, when the porter was shot and killed by one of two gunmen, failed yesterday to identify Francis Howard Reddy, 23 years old, as one of the thugs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Nov. 12.

At a private exhibition of still-life paintings by Hovsep Pushman yesterday at the Grand Central Art Galleries, the entire group of sixteen canvases was sold to New York and Chicago collectors, according to announcement yesterday at the galleries.

Former Governor Smith, "pinch-hitting-," as he termed it, for President-elect Roosevelt, appealed last night for support of the 1932 rollcall of the American Red Cross in an address broadcast over a nation-wide network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15 -- The entire country seems to be undergoing a feverish political reorganization in anticipation of the new Constitution and elections next May.
Harry F. Wolf, national champion, was among those to gain the quarter-final round yesterday in the Fall scratch squash tennis tourney being held at the New York Athletic Club.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied at one time yesterday, but hedge selling increased in the last hour and the list closed unchanged to 2 points lower than on Monday.

With many plans and discussions on the day's news budget, the share market displayed yesterday more hesitancy than in a week or so. The obscurity of the questions surrounding the war debts must have contributed to the uncertainty, but brokers also emphasized various unsettled features touching domestic matters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Senator Borah, Republican, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, declined today to define his attitude toward the proposals of the British and the French for a postponement of their interest payments on their debts to the United States.

Ship lines operating in the coastwise service have no fear of losing business to the railroads because of the new methods of delivering rail freight in the New York port district, it was indicated yesterday at a "town meeting" of shipping men at the Merchants' Association rooms under the auspices of the Shippers' Conference of New York.

State Senator Leon F. Wheatley whose name had been signed to the telegram in which three Republican members of the Hofstadter legislative committee asked Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter to resign as chairman, sent a message to Mr. Hofstadter yesterday asking him to remain.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Governor Moore having been shorn of the effect of his veto power in the 1933 session of the Legislature by the failure of the Democrats to retain control of the Assembly in last Tuesday's election, Republican leaders began consideration today of a majority program for economy.

FRANK FRISCH, otherwise known as the Fordham Flash, has been spending most of the Autumn planting and transplanting shrubs and trees on his extensive suburban lawn. That was probably what started him on the subject of sore backs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Yale will send against Harvard next Saturday the same lineup that started in the Princeton game, according to tentative plans of the coaches, who sent that combination against the scrubs today for nearly an hour of supervised scrimmaging.

An affidavit charging that the bankrupt United Cigar Stores Company in its schedule of assets on file in the Federal court assigned values that are "without foundation" was filed yesterday with Irwin Kurtz, referee, at 15-Park Row.

In an effort to collect something on the $485 judgment obtained by an interior decorating firm against former Mayor James J. Walker, Deputy Sheriff Lanman went to the Hotel Ambassador yesterday afternoon to levy on the former Mayor's property in his four-room suite there.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The Prince of Wales departed tonight for Belfast, Northern Ireland. He is to dedicate the new houses of Parliament at Stormont tomorrow, after a strenuous day with the Crown Prince of Sweden.

Every one concerned with "Chrysalis," which was played at the Martin Beck last evening, has gone to a great deal of pains. Rose Albert Porter has told this parallel story of love among the rich and the poor in ten meticulously detailed scenes. Theresa Helburn, taking a holiday from the Theatre Guild, has carefully directed a cinematographic production that whisks from Park Avenue to the slums and back again with sufficient celerity.

It is plain that the first effects at Washington of the plea for a revision of the war debts are unfavorable. Senators and others start up in the name of common honesty and of sound commercial policy to protest against the idea of letting off our creditors more easily.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- As this government received today from Belgium a request similar to those of Great Britain and France for a further study of the international war debts and an extension of the Hoover moratorium, Congressional leaders predicted that any proposal for postponement of payment Dec. 15 would be decisively rejected by Congress.

DUBLIN, Nov. 15 -- William T. Cosgrave's attempt to overthrow the de Valera government on the ground of its failure to make peace with Britain was defeated in the Dail tonight by five votes supplied by the Laborites.

An outstanding sale yesterday was that of the four-story modern residence at 114 East Seventy-eighth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, in Yorkville. The house has a brick front and American basement and was sold by the William B. May Company, as broker, for Marion Alexander Meding after an ownership of eight years.

The young well-dressed man, who left the Brooklyn Elks Club, 110 Livingston Street, early Sunday morning with Benjamin Levy, 59-year-old insurance man, a few hours before Levy was murdered in his own abandoned commercial garage, at 346 Maujer Street, in the Williamsburg section, was the object of a city-wide police search yesterday as all other available clues failed.

Two stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against Charles M. Schwab, chairman; Eugene G. Grace, president, and other officers and directors of the corporation, in 1929 and 1930, for an accounting of $15,000,000 alleged to have been lost to the corporation because of the purchase of 221,200 shares of the company's common stock for $20,383,614 to carry out a plan to sell stock to the officers and employes.

A new issue of $27,500,000 Toledo Edison Company first mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds due in 1962, will be offered today at 95 1/2, to yield 5.30 per cent, by a syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and including the Guaranty Company, N.W. Harris Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co.

The Westchester County Golf Association, always the first organization of its kind to convene, held its annual meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt last night, reviewing the past season and planning for the next.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Ernest R. Adee has left Almost Brook, her place in Tuxedo Park, and is at 161 East Seventieth Street for the Winter.

Within, a month, or two the largest lawsuit, in point of number of defendants, in the history of the United States will be filed in the Supreme Court here. The suit is that of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, against those of the 23,000 stockholders of the defunct Bank of United States who have failed to pay the $25-per-share assessment levied upon them.

Stocks offered yesterday what Wall Street called "effective resistance" to slow selling pressure. The tone was steady and firm, both of which appellations denote to the speculative mind a favorable condition. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,048,000 shares, against 1,307,000 on the day before.

Seventeen Manhattan and Bronx properties were offered at forced sales conducted by auctioneers yesterday. One of the parcels was withdrawn, the others being bought in by interested parties, two of them by committees representing the bondholders.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 15 -- More than 10,000 persons have been rendered homeless by General Liu Hsiang aerial bombing of the city of Luchow in Szechwan Province and more than 2,500 civilians and soldier defenders were killed or wounded in Sunday's battle, according to belated reports from China's Far West.

GENEVA, Nov. 15 -- Technical explorations to bring France and Italy into the London naval treaty continued throughout today along yesterday's lines with hope somewhat stimulated by the opposition developing in Germany to the French general disarmament plan.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- Detroit subdued the New York Americans in a rough and tumble National Hockey League game tonight, the Red Wings outclassing the Americans to win their second home contest, 6 to 2. Johnny Sorrell led the attack with three goals.

"To achieve substantial progress in the work of increasing game birds the cooperation of State and Federal game officials, legislative committees, game organizations, farm organizations, farmers and sportsmen is required," declared Colonel Arthur J. Foran, vice president of More Game Birds in America, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--Samuel Insull Jr., once under-chief of a $2,000,000,000 utilities system, withstood five hours of grueling examination today at a bankruptcy hearing called by Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley to discover assets of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., top unit in the pyramid of Insull companies now in ruins.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Efforts of commission houses with Eastern connections to advance wheat prices today on the Board of Trade here met with little success. The buying was aggressive several times and the December was run up about 1/2 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Delegates to the American Petroleum Institute convention today heard Amos L. Beaty, president, declare that oil companies had made financial progress in the past year, and then listened to a committee report predicting lessened motor-fuel demand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Opponents of the St. Lawrence waterways treaty pictured to a Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee today a scene of disrupted commerce and unemployment which they said would follow ratification and the construction of the waterway.

Jascha Heifetz grave his second recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. He played Cesar Franck's sonata, Bruch's concerto in G minor, Sain-Saens's "Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso," and a group of shorter pieces; "La plus que lent" of Debussy, Castelnuovo-Tedesco's "Tango" and "Sea-Murmurs" in arrangements by Mr. Heifetz; Drigo's "Valse Bluette" and Bazzini's "La Ronde des Lutins."

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The vast wastes of the Sahara Desert tonight held secret the whereabouts of Amy Johnson, Britain's leading woman flier, who is the wife of Captain J.A. Mollison, the only man to make a westward solo flight over the Atlantic.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 15 -- The first group of applications by mortgage-lending institutions for affiliation with the Federal Home Loan Bank of the Second district probably will be approved by the board of directors and forwarded to Washington for final approval by the Federal board within ten days, George L. Bliss, executive vice president, announced today in reviewing the bank's work since it opened a month ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Prices of hogs continued today to decline, losing 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. The movement was again heavy, in excess of the demand, and the forecast for arrivals tomorrow added to the bearish sentiment. However, demand became active toward the last.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Samuel Insull Jr. denied today that any of the Insull family received a $40,000 "dividend" from Insull companies at a time when the companies were "technically insolvent."

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,134,350 barrels, compared with 2,103,700 barrels in the preceding week, an increase of 30,650 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Virtually all important producing areas contributed to the increase, but the gain of 10,400 barrels in the daily output of California was the largest.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- The Indianapolis, first 10,000-ton cruiser to be completed since the ratification of the London naval limitation treaty, was commissioned at the Philadelphia Navy Yard today.

GENEVA, Nov. 15 -- The tentative program of the League of Nations for dealing with the Lytton report on Manchuria is to have the council, when it receives Japan's long answering statement, refer it immediately for a reply to the Lytton commission itself.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL, TRAIN, Nov. 15 -- President Hoover will return to Washington early tomorrow morning and go directly from the train to the Executive offices at the White House to prepare for his coming conference with Governor Roosevelt on the international war debts.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- An adventurous World War voyage by Franklin D. Rdosevelt in the Irish Sea was recounted today in a new book, "Number Thirteen," by Rear Admiral Gordon Campbell, famous Qboat commander.

Buyers' Arrivals Increased. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the number listed in the previous week, but remained well below the total reached in the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15 -- Led by Rodney W. Brown Jr., a former Andover star, Yale's 150-pound football team ended an undefeated season today, scoring its fourth straight shutout victory by vanquishing Harvard's 150-pound team, 25 to 0.

Following is a transcript of the debate in the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate over the request submitted by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, for another $52,000,000 issue of four-year bonds to finance new subway construction:

The feature of the concert given by the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was Josef Lhevinne's magnificent playing of the Tchaikovsky B flat minor concerto. The concerto was played as it ought to be played, but seldom is, in spite of the familiarity of the work.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Seven Japanese Ambassadors and Ministers gathered here today under the direction of Yosuke Matsuoka, chief of the delegation that is to represent Japan at the Geneva discussions of the Lytton report on Manchuria, starting next week.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- War veterans' pensions and allowances are reduced by $22,000,000 and civil servants' salaries by $30,000,000 in the budget project for next year that the French Government today presented to the Chamber of Deputies.

Norwegian yachtsmen are planning what they have decided to call a Jubilee Regatta for next Summer in their waters. A communication was received here yesterday urging that American yachtsmen build 12-meter yachts in this country this Winter, ship them to Norway next Summer and race them there for the new 12-meter trophy offered by the North American Yacht Racing Union.

The stern disapproval with which General Sherman has been regarding the Lady of the Fountain for these many, years is expected to soften somewhat soon, for the Lady is to be restored to her full glory with a $35,000 beauty treatment approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 -- Members of a United States Chamber of Commerce committee on competing forms of transportation, meeting here today, agreed that all government subsidies to common carriers should be eliminated, putting all forms on a fair basis of competition.

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- Official returns show that the casualties resulting from the storm in Greater Tokyo and the five neighboring prefectures totaled twenty-six killed, twenty-five injured and twenty-six missing.

More than ten years of litigation between Mrs. Bula Croker, widow of Richard Croker, Tammany leader, and his children, Richard Croker and Mrs. Ethel White, over his property in Ireland, was settled yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Walsh when the son agreed to pay $20,000 as the cost of the unsuccessful suit he and his sister brought in Ireland.

The campus of Columbia University was thrown into an uproar yesterday afternoon when more than 400 members of the sophomore and freshman classes engaged in a "free-for-all" fight at the annual songfest. Fists flew, water was thrown from the surrounding school buildings, and the students at Barnard College were serenaded by the freshmen before the battle was ended.

Seaton Pippin, 11-year-old bay mare owned by the Seaton Hackney Farm of Morristown, N.J., won the title of best in show last night in the crowning event of the forty-seventh annual National Horse Show, which came to a close in Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- On the eve of the third round-table conference on Indian affairs, which meets here Thursday, official London was dismayed and completely bewildered today at the news that Burma had voted against separation from India. Yesterday it had been reported the Separationists had a plurality of two seats.

A list of 136 applicants for admission to the bar, including ten women, who have been instructed to appear before the committees on character and fitness of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, was made public yesterday by the committee. Examination of the applicants is to start next Tuesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with great interest THE TIMES survey of "favorite sons" who might conceivably be asked to fill Cabinet positions by President-elect Roosevelt. The article stimulated me to ponder over many aspects of our political history and to suggest that the two living ex-Presidents be invited to sit in the Cabinet, with or without portfolio.

The closing performance of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, attracted a large assembly of society last night. The program was replete with feature events which stirred the fashionable gathering to enthusiasm.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 15 -- Scoring six birdies and an eagle on the last round, Tommy Armour and Al Watrous. Detroit professionals, today won the thirteenth annual mid-South open best-ball golf championship by three strokes. Their thirty-six-hole total was 131.

A thrilling rescue at the height of last week's storm was described yesterday when two men who had been carried to sea on the Ward liner Oriente after their pilot boat had capsized returned from Havana on the same ship.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- Holding his first press conference since last Thursday when he went into seclusion because of illness, President-elect Roosevelt today indicated that he would confer with President Hoover on war debts at the White House next Tuesday.

Persistent reports that the city's fiscal affairs arc rapidly approaching another serious crisis received impetus yesterday at a turbulent session of the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate.

While President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt has said that no decisions with regard to Cabinet positions will be reached until he has finished his term as Governor on Jan. 1, the belief is general in Democratic circles that James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will be the Postmaster General.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--Angered at the massacre of 150 Kenya tribesmen by slave raiders from Abyssinia, the British Government today sent a stern warning to Emperor Haile Selassie that if he was unable to keep order in his own territories Britain would have to take "appropriate action."

Navy journeys to the Middle West this week to meet Notre Dame in the huge Municipal Stadium at Cleveland. Bringing together the two teams that remain as the major objectives of Army's juggernaut, the game is also particularly interesting because of the fact that it is one of the few instances the season has furnished of a conflict between exponents of unadulterated Rockne football.

LA PAZ, Nov. 15 -- The unsuccessful Paraguayan attack on Fort Saavedra Friday cost the enemy 1,300 casualties, including dead, wounded and prisoners, it was revealed in additional details of the battle received here today.

Representative Joseph W. Byrns of Tennessee, in years of service one of the oldest members of the House and an aspirant with strong backing for the Speakership. said yesterday that he was strongly opposed to cancellation or reduction of foreign debts or to a further moratorium.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 15 -- The State today dropped the murder charge against Libby Holman Reynolds and Albert (Ab) Walker, which was filed after young Smith Reynolds, tobacco heir and husband of the former Broadway blues singer, was fatally shot last July.

Business in the money market was featureless. Quotations for all classifications carried over without change. Turnover was light and chiefly of a routine character. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, Street trades 1/2.

A certain malign interpretation has been put by some of our perfervid patriots upon the simultaneous publication of the British and French notes on the war debts. This looks to their sensitive eyes like a concerted move against the United States.

Forecasting an improvement in hotel business as a result of better trends in business generally, Philip E. Rice, president of the New York State Hotel Association, predicted yesterday at the association's annual convention at the Hotel Commodore a gain from the ending of waste and the improved operating methods forced by tha depression.

The National Transportation Committee is not likely to disclose much information concerning the railroads which has not already been published and it should confine itself to general principles, the Chesapeake Ohio lines contend in the current issue of their magazine.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 -- More than 200 of the nation's leaders in the advertising field -- men who are reputed to spend more than $300,000,000 annually on all forms of advertising -- will assemble in Atlantic City tomorrow for a three-day convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A formal meeting of the governors of the various Federal Reserve Banks as the open market committee was held today. There was no statement, but in view of the various economic influences now at work, it was generally believed there would be no change in the open market policy.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--George Lambert, Liberal, asked in the question hour in the House of Commons this afternoon whether the government would make a declaration to the United States that it could no longer continue to make war-debt payments in gold.

Five of Belmont Park s lesser known stakes will be run as overnight events next season, it became known yesterday from Racing Secretary Victor Schaumburgr, who also developed the point that the conditions of the Belmont and other of the big classics had been altered slightly to insure better racing and keener competition.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15 -- Harvard's two-hour football workout today was conducted along the same lines as that of yesterday, with continuance of fundamental tackling and blocking drills.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15 -- A fine broken-field run for a touchdown by Pinky Pinkham midway in the third period gave the Yale junior class team a 7-0 victory over Winthrop House of Harvard today.

Arguing that the Board of Aldermen could not act intelligently upon the 1933 budget placed before it yesterday, without complete information on the city's financial status, Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin, in a resolution referred to the Aldermanic finance committee, called for a full statement of the city finances from Controller Charles W. Berry.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The Ottawa agreements bill received royal assent tonight, and with its enforcement tomorrow night Britain enters a period of five years of protective tariffs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt polled the highest percentage of the popular vote of any Democrat during the last half-century, today declared Simon Michelet, president of the National Get-Outthe-Vote Club, in a statement analyzing the Presidential elections.
Election of officers concluded the two-day semi-annual meeting of the Women's Swimming Association of New York last night and all but one of the incumbents retained their posts.

Mrs. Peter Farnum gave a large luncheon yesterday at the Junior League Club for her niece, Miss Evelyn Byrd Kobbe, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kobbe. The luncheon was served in the Persian dining room at a T-shaped table decorated with varied colored chrysanthemums.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- Regarding reports that the Democrats in Congress would attempt to scrap the entire treaty with Canada for St. Lawrence development and seek a new agreement, the intimation was given at the Executive Mansion today that so long as the interests of New York State were protected in allocation of water power project costs, the backers of the Roosevelt plan for development of the river would be satisfied.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told 800 members of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night, that no leader could go far unless he had intelligent and enthusiastic backing. "I think and feel that the women of this country are going to give that backing," she said.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Miss Anne Valliant Burnett is a granddaughter of the late Captain S. Burk Burnett, cattleman, of this city.

Trotsky Tours Europe. When TROTSKY emerges from three years of exile in Turkey and sets foot on West European soil he will probably be met by almost as many, reporters as if he were BERNARD SHAW himself.

In an effort to throw sand into the machinery of prohibition reform some Dry leaders have cited the technicality that the Seventy-second Congress has no instruction from the people on this issue except as expressed by Congressional districts in the 1930 elections and the by-elections held up to November, 1932.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries report for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $18,012,084 after taxes, charges, depreciation, depletion and subsidiary preferred dividends and minority interest, equal, after preferred and preference dividends, to $1.04 a share earned on 11,608,150 no par common shares, excluding shares in the treasury.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Franklin D. Roosevelt correctly appraised the result of the election as a great liberal victory, for entrenched privilege hiding under the purple robe of ultra-conservatism was fast uniting the malcontents under the red jacket of ultra-radicalism.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad will announce this week the availability of funds from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to begin immediate payments in the refinancing plan for its $63,250,000 of convertible 4 1/2 per cent bonds due on March 1.

WILMINGTON, Del., -- Nov. 15 (AP) -- Because negotions are under way to bring about a settlement, the trial of the government anti-trust suit against the Radio Corporation of America and others was postponed today until next Monday by the United States District Court for Delaware.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee addressed more than 700 members of the New York Stock Exchange in their board room yesterday afternoon on behalf of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee's campaign to raise $15,000,000. He was applauded enthusiastically when he arose to speak.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The stock markets were dull today on failure of sterling to maintain its recent firmness, coupled with weakness in Wall Street yesterday. With interest in British funds small, the undertone was easier and prices weakened.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15 -- The University of Pennsylvania soccer team continues to lead the Middle Atlantic Intercollegiate Soccer League as a result of games played Saturday, it was revealed today with the announcement of the official standing by Burnham N. Dell, president of the league.

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 15 -- Harvard men of today of old American stock are taller and heavier than their fathers and grandfathers, are still gaining in height and are now one of the tallest groups in the world, according to Gordon Townsend Bowles, research student of anthropology at Harvard University.

Directors of the Aviation Corporation who are seeking to thwart E.L. Cord's attempt to obtain control of the company sent a letter to stockholders yesterday formally asking for proxies for the meeting scheduled for Dec. 21, at which Mr. Cord will attempt to elect a majority of the board.

Robert Walsh, 52 years old, who save his address as 35-30 103d Street, Corona, appeared yesterday before Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal court in Brooklyn chained with sale and possession of whisky. The address given by Walsh is also the address of the North Side Democratic Club of Queens.

The American Red Cross is, as Chief Justice HUGHES said in his address, "the highest expression of "the humanitarian sentiment of the "nation." It is, moreover, an expression of instant promptness in its practical applications. A blizzard strikes a blow at defenseless farmers and their live stock out in Nebraska.

The formation of a complete and permanent opera company, organized for the most part among graduates of the Juilliard School, is expected to be the result of the performances of opera given each year by the opera school of the foundation, Ernest Hutcheson, dean of the graduate school, said yesterday at a luncheon at his home.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with keen interest Mr. Krock's article on possible Cabinet choices of Governor Roosevelt. It was a highly illuminating discussion, linking news and interpretation in an effective manner. I append a list of additional names which, I believe, might be considered:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 15 -- Blood and lymph are not the only liquids that circulate through the body, Dr. G.H. Parker of Harvard University informed the National Academy of Sciences today at a meeting given over largely to the biologists, physiologists, geologists and botanists.

Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, defended modern American universities against recent criticism of their educational innovations and declared that the university must meet the demands of the social order, in an address last night at the first general session of the Conference of Universities on the Obligation of Universities to the Social Order, held under the auspices of New York University at the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Confidence has returned, the United States no longer suffers from the paralyzing influence of fear and a rally in business merely to the level of the Summer of 1931 would solve many of the worst of the country's problems, said Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank of New York, in a talk this evening before the Illinois Manufacturers Cost Association in the Hotel La Salle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The great tidal wave that has just overwhelmed the Republican party was not stirred up in a few months. It was not due to the personalities of Herbert Hoover and Franklin Roosevelt, except as the one seemed blind to its gathering and the other was able to ride it skillfully.

A sale of articles made in Kentucky will be held this afternoon in the Perroquet suite of the WaldorfAstoria at a bridge party of the Society of Kentucky Women. During the afternoon Mrs. Oliver Harriman will speak on the philanthropic activities of the organization.
Fordham's football squad began an intensive drive at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for its final contest of the 1932 campaign with Oregon State at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

OMAHA, Nov. 15 -- A fight will be made at the coining session of Congress for refinancing farm mortgage loans at radically reduced rates of interest, delegates to the annual convention of the National Farmers' Union were told here today by Senator Lynn J. Frazier, Republican, of North Dakota.

The great auditorium of Radio City Music Hall in Rockefeller Center was used for the first time yesterday to provide the setting for craftsmanship exercises in which twenty-five mechanics deemed to have done outstanding work on the edifice received craftsmanship certificates and gold buttons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- From his private room where he is confined with a slight cold, President-elect Roosevelt today sent a message to Judge John Barton Payne, chairman of the American. Reel Cross, commending the organization to "everyp loyal American" in this period of need.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Upon completion today of twenty-five years of service at the Trenton State Hospital for the Insane, Dr. Henry A. Cotton, Medical Director Emeritus and Director of Research, reported to the board of managers it was his conclusion no abdominal operation for the purpose of correcting functional mental disorders or for any purpose should be performed while a patient had infected teeth.

Thomas D. Thatcher, Solicitor General in Washington, who was strongly urged by the United States Attorney's office in this district to aid prohibition enforcement by authorizing officials here to appeal from an "embarrassing decision" of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals last July, has decided against this action.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Old Cuban records indicate that Camaguey Province, prior to last week, had not been visited by a severe hurricane for nearly 100 years. For three generations its people had seen cyclonic disturbances uniformly deflected southward by the mountains of Eastern Cuba, and had felt safe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Recontruction Finance Corporation today announced the appointment of Mark Feet of New York as executive vice president and general manager in charge of the Regional Agricultural Credit Corporation for the First Federal Land Bank District, comprising New York, New Jersey and the New England States.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 16. -- A petition, brought in behalf of the principal railroads operating in New Jersey for a reduction of tax levies for 1932, was denied here today by the State Board of Tax Appeals, which also upheld the method of determining the average tax rate on which the amount to be paid by the carriers on certain classes of property was computed.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 16. -- With the opening of the duck-hunting season today and the approach of Thanksgiving, tourists from the North are beginning to arrive here and Winter residents are preparing to reopen town and country places. The villa Margherita, has opened for the season, and the Yeamans Hall Club will open after Thanksgiving.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- If Congress, as is reported here probable, refuses to grant the French request for a postponement of the Dec. 15 debt payment, there is every likelihood that the Chamber of Deputies will in turn refuse to vote the necessary credits to enable the government to pay.

Three discoveries concerning the "fundamental nature of the cancer process," made recently at the National Institute of Health of the United States Public Health Service in Washington, were described last night before the Science Forum of New York Electrical Society, held at the Engineering Societies Building, by Professor Carl Voegtlin of the chemistry staff of the institute.

Average dally electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, was 211,600,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Nov. 12, as against 210,700,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 223,800,000 kilowatt-hours in the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--President Hoover indicated to visitors today that he would not recommend to Congress a suspension of the war debt payments due Dec. 15 as requested by Great Britain, France, Belgium and other countries The decision was reached, it was said at the Capitol, after Mr. Hoover had been informed of the almost unanimous opposition to a further moratorium reported among members of Congress.

The complete program for the four appearances by the Metropolitan Opera at the Westchester County Centre in White Plains was announced yesterday. The five operas will be "Lakme," with Lily Pons and Martinelli, on Dec, 9; "Hansel and Gretel," with Queena Mario, and "Pagliacci," with Lucrezia Borl, on Dec. 30, "Il Trovatore," with Rosa Ponselle on Jan. 20, and "Lohengrin," with Gota Ljungberg; on Feb. 10.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 46 (AP). -- The United States District Court restrained seven major motion picture producing and distributing concerns today from operating a "prize zoning and clearance" system, which the government asserted would be a monopoly in restraint of the trade of independent "first-run" picture theatres.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 16. -- A nation-wide increase in the volume of merchandise sales during the last three months was reported here today by executives of large business interests of the country at the twenty-third annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers, which opened at the Hotel Ambassador.

The sale of an entire triangular block in the Bronx was the feature of realty trading in the metropolitan area yesterday. The block is bounded by Westchester Avenue, Forrest Avenue and West 156th Street and is improved with a theatre and eleven stores.

Representatives of 3,000 basic industries of the country, comprising the membership of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared at the thirty-seventh annual meeting of the association here yesterday that they favored the adoption by Congress of a tax on beer.

Five leading trade organizations which are seeking to reconcile the differences among the Port of New York Authority, the Board of Estimate and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to bring about immediate construction of the midtown tunnel under the Hudson at Thirty-eighth Street, advanced their program yesterday.

Dividend uncertainties were blamed in Wall Street for the moderate decline on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The losses in stocks were widely distributed, with the sharpest declines occurring in American Telephone and Telegraph, R.H. Macy, American Can, Columbian Carbon, International Business Machines, Union Pacific, United Aircraft, United States Steel and a few others.

And still they come, these "revivals" of recent plays. Last night "Cradle Snatchers" turned up at the Liberty Theatre; tonight a second presentation of "The Good Fairy," which was done here only a year ago, will take over the Forrest. At least they reduce the hazards of producing for the lesser entrepreneurs and they serve to light up theatres which otherwise would be dark.

Mrs. Lillian Bauer, 48 years old, who two years ago won a $25,000 verdict in a breach of promise suit against Dr. Fred E. Smith, a dentist, committed suicide yesterday by inhaling gas in her apartment at 455 West Thirty-fourth Street. The body was found after a milkman had smelled the gas and an elevator boy, with a pass key, had entered the apartment.

Duff Gilfond has gathered more than 100 anecdotes concerning Calvin Coolidge in "The Rise of Saint Calvin," published today by Vanguard. Ha sees Mr. Coolidge as already a legendary figure about whom there are many good stories, which, he says, are also true and which deserve rescue in the lapse of time between the work of reporters and the advent of historical biographers.
The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee expects to obtain contributions from 1,000,000 persons to its $15,000,000 relief fund for the jobless and needy of the city.

TOKYO, Nov. 16. -- Official reports from Moscow confirm rumors that General Hsu Ping-wen, commander of the revolters in the big Barga area of Manchuria, refuses to meet the Japanese mission now assembled at Dauria [in Siberia, near the border] to negotiate a "political solution."

Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, announced yesterday at the first report luncheon in the drive for funds that $721,500 had been raised so far by the women. The luncheon was held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. George Harrison Frazier Jr., socially prominent residents of Chestnut Hill, were robbed of jewelry valued at $9,000 and of $26 in cash by two masked bandits early today. During a two-hour search of the Frazier home the robbers interspersed a discussion of the election, the latest literature and the depression with threats of kidnapping and torture.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- Plans for a merger of the Continental Chicago Corporation and Chicago Investors, Inc., into a $28,000,000 investment trust to be known as the Chicago Corporation were announced today.

Tomorrow evening at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries will be held the unrestricted public sale of paintings collected by F. Kleinberger, mainly from his own private collection. These have been on exhibition since Saturday.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- Governor Roosevelt said today that he had no recollection of having made a statement to the International Diplomatic Academy before the recent election declaring that "we Democrats do not believe it possible and do not desire an isolated national existence" for this country and saying the United States should cooperate with the League of Nations.

The ranks of great men, said SWINBURNE, are divided not into thinkers and workers but into Titans and Olympians. To classify individually the men who are now gathered for high academic discussion under the auspices of New York University would be invidious, but it may be said that a real Titanomachy is on.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Declaring that the welfare of the urban population is "inextricably tied up with the welfare of agriculture," and that thousands of farmers are receiving insufficient income to cover taxes and interest on mortgages, Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, named a committee today to determine what practical measures, legislative or otherwise, could be taken to rehabilitate the agricultural industry.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 16. -- Public opinion is tending toward the belief that the State, rather than the individual, is to be held responsible for employment conditions, the thirty-third New York State Conference on Social Work was told today by George L. Warren of New York City, director of the International Migration Service.

ROME, Nov. 16. -- The general amnesty promulgated soon after the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the march on Rome was supplemented today by a further act of sovereign grace in favor of seventeen prominent anti-Fascists for whom decrees depriving them of their Italian citizenship and confiscating all their goods have been revoked.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- To remove the penalty of a double tax from sellers of stocks living at too great a distance from New York to make delivery within twenty-four hours, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that the New York broker or agent having available sufficient shares in his office to make delivery may use this stock without incurring a transfer tax.

In a market whose prices seemed rather to drift than to move with definite purpose, stocks went irregularly lower yesterday. Declines in the more active shares, both industrial and railway, ranged from 1 to 4 points, a fraction of the loss being recovered before the closing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- The House Campaign Committee, headed by Representative Ragon of Arkan- sas, Democrat, decided today to in- vestigate last week's elections in Pennsylvania and Delaware.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee reported yesterday these contributions to the $15,000,000 fund which the committee is raising for the relief of the unemployed. Subscriptions to the fund may be sent to Thomas Cochran, treasurer, 70 Pine Street.

Dr. Walter Damrosch, chairman of the Musicians' Emergency Aid, urged yesterday, in addressing the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor, that parents help qualified unemployed musicians and at the same time benefit their children by letting them have lessons in music.
Two resales of properties recently acquired were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
