Plans are well under way for the filing of a taxpayer's suit to transfer from the 1933 budget to the account of the city's independent Subway system the Item of more than $17,000,000, representing interest and amortization on rapid transit securities issued and to be issued on account of construction of the new network, it was ascertained yesterday.

Prizes for exhibits in culinary art, including the gold medal of the French Government, were awarded yesterday at the sixty-fourth salon of culinary art, held in connection with the seventeenth National Hotel Exposition at the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Fortysixth Street.

Fordham's football squad participated in its final practice scrimmage of the regular season at Fordham Field yesterday in preparation for the encounter with its Western foe, Oregon State, at the Polo Grounds on Saturday, which will mark the conclusion of the 1932 campaign for the Rams.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP). -- E.L. Cord decided to take a vacation at 20. That was almost twenty years ago. He and a friend started on a fishing trip, but it never was finished, as Mr. Cord was diverted by a business opportunity. It and succeeding ones have fully occupied his time since.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- High British financial circles showed little enthusiasm today over reports of a French-German-British financial and industrial consortium for stimulating trade on the Continent.

BERLIN, Nov. 16. -- Chancellor Franz von Papen's hopes of winning the new Reichstag's toleration, for his Cabinet of "national concentration" and its program of economic and constitutional reforms collapsed today when an-official delegation from the Centrist and Bavarian People's parties bluntly notified him of their refusal to cooperate with a government under his leadership.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Townsend Ashmore will give a reception at 7 East Fifty-third Street, the afternoon of Dec. 9, to introduce her daughter, Miss Eulalie Ashmore.

Tammany leaders have in the last few days indicated their intention of letting Federal patronage distribution wait for a while, and devote their time to a consolidation of the position of the organization in the City Hall.

Coach Lou Little told the Columbia football squad yesterday to forget about its defeat at the hands of Brown last week and concentrate on its annual encounter with Syracuse. Little is fearful that the eleven will enter Saturday's contest against the Orange still upset over its defeat and that such a state of mind might lead to another setback.

ROME, Nov. 16. -- Commenting on the report of the Committee for the Consolidation of Intergovernmental Debts, published in the United States Monday, the Osservatore Romano, official Vatican newspaper, says the report fully faces the problem of debts but does not solve it.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- German criticism of the French disarmament plan has been in such sharp contrast to the comment from other countries that it has immediately provoked just that atmosphere of polemics and dispute that is the worst kind of beginning to an international agreement.

Close Enough Forecasting. The Literary Digest's marksmanship in the recent poll shows up very well to the layman, whatever the percentage experts may think. The Digest's boast that it came within two votes of foretelling Mr. HOOVER'S 59 electoral votes is far from justified, seeing that 37 of the 59 votes came from the wrong States.
CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 16. -- The Commonwealth Parliament finally passed the Ottawa agreement bill without amendment today, although labor opposition led to some disorder.

Unify Plans for Design Law. Plans were formulated and unified yesterday for speeding the enactment by the next session of Congress of the measure providing for copyright of textile designs at a meeting of a general committee representing all branches of the textile industry and held in the rooms of the Silk Association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Active campaigning for the Speakership of the next House began today when Representative Rainey of Illinois an- nounced that he was a candidate.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16. -- The food scarcity in Soviet Russia has meant new and tighter ration regulations for staple commodities already classed as luxuries by most of the people. There appears to be at present, in the large centres at least, plenty of bread, both the black bread and the slate-colored, which passes here for white.

Rex Brasher, who has spent forty years painting the birds of North America, came to New York for the first time in seventeen years yesterday to see an exhibition of his work. He lives no further away than Kent, Conn., but he is not a lover of cities, and could not be induced to venture into New York even by scientific societies which have often sought him as a lecturer.
LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Compton Mackenzie, the novelist, appeared in Guild Hall police court today charged with disclosing official secrets in his book "Greek Memories."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Secretary Chapin expressed confidence today in the prospects for business recovery this Winter, which he said he believed would be enhanced by the coming conference between Mr. Hoover and Mr. Roosevelt.

A narrow price movement was found in commodity market trading yesterday, changes for the most part being unimportant in size. Grains were moderately lower, as were sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides and silk. Lard and coffee were higher. Eggs were steady.

E.H. Patterson Jr. of Albany, president of the Hudson-Mohawk Mutual Casualty Company, asked yesterday that George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, begin an investigation of workmen's compensation insurance rates.
A transcript of Acting Mayor McKee's address last night, at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, follows:

The increasingly acute problem of unemployment among railroad workers will be discussed by representatives of twenty-one railroad brotherhoods and a committee representing the railroads, headed by Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, at a meeting this morning in the Grand Central Terminal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The account of an interview with Henry M. Bronner, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 19, ends with an axiom against which the whole of Champagne protests. Mr. Bronner considers it inevitable that the duties on champagne should be exorbitant.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, declined last Tuesday to produce the board's books and records for the examination of Federal officials investigating election frauds, because those books are State property and are not subject to removal except on order of "a court of competent jurisdiction, a legislative committee or a Congressional committee," Mr. Cohen explained yesterday.
Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee broke with Tammany Hall last night on the issue of "decent government."

A third group yesterday entered the struggle between E.L. Cord and the management of the Aviation Corporation, for control of the company, when John H. Trumbull, former Governor of Connecticut, announced the formation of a "non-partisan" committee to represent stockholders and solicit proxies for the meeting to be held on Dec. 21.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the committee on stock list had completed its investigation of seven matured bond issues and had decided to strike them from the list tomorrow. The Exchange recently announced that it would take this action with regard to matured bonds on the ground that such securities had lost the legal attribute of negotiability.

The New York Americans, with two games already played, will open their home campaign on the Madison Square Garden ice tonight when they oppose the sturdy Bruins of Boston. The game will be the first of the National Hockey League season in this city, and promises to attract a large crowd.

Outside the automobile industry, which has done some buying, the steel industry is finding little demand for its products, The Iron Age reports. The publication says the cautiousness of buyers which was noticed before election has not yet disappeared, and continues:

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- Provisions for State aid to counties to carry on reforestation projects will be omitted from the State budget, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Conservation Commissioner, and Senator Charles J. Hewitt today notified chairmen of the various county Boards of Supervisors.

A farmers' march on Washington is a possible by-product of the short session of Congress. Plans are said to have been made for a caravan to leave Seattle this week or next. It would be joined by six columns of farmers traversing different routes through the West and planning to converge on Washington in time for the reassembling of Congress.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced yesterday a plan to meet the maturity of $63,250,000 of bonds on March 1, one-half with a $31,625,000 loan which has been approved by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and one-half with a new issue of bonds.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 16 (AP). -- A "double-header" program for the relief of agriculture, to be presented the short session of Congress, was outlined today by Louis J. Taber, master of the National Grange, in an address at the opening of that organization's annual convention.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 16. -- The elevens of Groton School and St. Paul's School battled to a 6-5 deadlock in their annual football contest today. Each team registered a touchdown in the second period and both failed to convert the try for the extra point.

A bronze bust of John Gottlieb Wendel, with a derby, spectacles and even a mustache that can be removed, was produced, in Surogates' Court yesterday in support of the claim of Thomas Patrick Morris, Brooklyn housepainter, that he is the son of the last male Wendel and is legally entitled to the fortune of the late Ella Virginia von E. Wendel.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The members of the International Chamber of Commerce meeting here issued today a vigorous protest against the decision of the International Telegraph Conference at Madrid to abolish ten-letter code words now currently in use for business communications the world over.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- Prices of wheat held within a range of about 3/4 cent today, with a good part of the trade in changing between the December and distant months. Plenty of wheat was for sale on the rallies, while the breaks met fair support.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- Hope of supplanting the old German system of Mitteleuropa in its economic aspects by international cooperation, was raised here today by announcement that a Franco-German accord for a European consortium for the construction of public works throughout Europe had been reached at a meeting of experts in Berlin.

Grete Stueckgold, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, gave a song recital in New York yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, with Hurt Ruhrseitz at the piano. In view of the extraordinary beauty of their performance, the program is worth quoting in full.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Keith Gledhill, a member of the United States lawn tennis team now touring Australia, was elimi- nated today in the second round of the New South Wales title play by Jack Crawford, famous Australian player, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the death of Robert Brookings yesterday in Washington the country has lost one of its most distinguished as well as successful business men.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A special session of the Seventy-third Congress, probably in April, seems unavoidable, in the opinion of Democratic Senators.
Among many hostesses and hosts at dinners and luncheons at hotels here yesterday was Miss Elanor Sherburne Wendell. She gave a dinner last night in the St. Regis.

Fifteen young women and fifteen young men, presumably the best amateur singers of the northeastern part of the country, will compete today over WEAF's network in the semifinal singing contest of the sixth National Radio Audition, conducted by the Atwater Kent Foundation.

Amelia Earhart, first woman to fly the Atlantic alone, received the American Women's Association medal for "eminent attainment" at the sixth annual friendship dinner last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The Women's Press Club was host to representatives of about nineteen other professional women's organizations in the city.
Municipal operation of the Eighth Avenue subway is failing, by a substantial margin, to meet bare operating expenses, according to figures obtained yesterday from the office of Controller Berry.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 16.--Twenty thousand years ago, when late Neanderthal men were hunting in Assyria, and Egypt was a wilderness inhabited by equally primitive savages, a 17-year-old girl, who had something of the Mongol and something of the ape about her, was killed and perhaps thrown into a glacial lake in what is now Ottertail County, Minn.

Joseph F. Addonizio has been appointed managing director of the Central Park West Columbus Av. Association to succeed E. W. Estes, who resigned recently. The appointment was announced by Albert Mayer, the president. The Association went on record as opposing the licensing of newsstands at subway entrances of the new Eighth Av. line along Central Park West.
When Yale and Harvard battle again in the Bowl on Saturday two outstanding stars of recent Eli-Crimson games will be missing.

One of the grounds for the vote of censure on the Government, moved but defeated in the Parlia- ment of the Irish Free State on Tuesday, was that the President had blocked the negotiations with Great Britain about the Irish land annui- ties.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 16. -- Mme. Maria Jeritza, singing one of her famous roles, Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana," as guest artist for the first of two title-role performances with the San Carlo Opera Company, drew an almost capacity audience to the Boston Opera House tonight.

BELFAST, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Railroad tracks were ripped up today in an effort to prevent sightseers from coming to Belfast to see the Prince of Wales, who, guarded by 12,000 men, took part in a five-mile parade to Stormont, where he dedicated the new Northern Ireland Parliament Buildings.

LONDON, Nov. 16.--A strenuous fight by Theodore Roosevelt against big battleships is among the disclosures in the eighth volume of British official documents on the origin of the World War, to be published tomorrow. Although he later became an advocate of a big navy, Mr. Roosevelt opposed the building of heavy battleships When he was President and tried to persuade the British Government to negotiate an agreement limiting them.

Irregular fluctuations again characterized trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and the list ended with gains of 3 to 6 points on the day. Weakness in the stock market influenced professional sentiment in the last hour and the December sold below 6 1/4 cents a pound at one time, only to recover 10 points in the final dealings.

The Board of Estimate, sitting in committee of the whole yesterday, named a committee of three as a fact-finding commission to determine what rate of pay would be equitable for mechanics and artisans employed by the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- Again the Leonid meteors disappointed astronomers who watched for them, expecting possibly a return of the brilliant shower of shooting stars of November, 1866. A careful watch, in a beautifully clear sky, at two observatories near Philadelphia, revealed a very sparse display, far inferior to that of last year.

Paul Kochanski, violinist, and Felix Salmond, 'cellist, will be the soloists at the fourth of the series of twenty concerts by the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House next Tuesday evening. Sandor Harmati, permanent conductor of the orchestra of 200 unemployed players, will direct the concert.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16. -- A rigid federal licensing law with stringent publicity features, binding on all organizations engaged in interstate commerce, was advocated today at the annual convention of the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor.

The plan of adjustment of the Birmingham Gas Company was declared operative yesterday as a result of the receipt of deposits of more than 95 per cent of the 4 1/2 per cent $1,250,000 notes and approval by the Alabama Public Service Commission. Holders who have not deposited their notes may do so until Dec. 31.

ALBANY, Nov. 16, -- Having promised in the Presidential campaign to readjust Federal fiscal affairs, Governor Roosevelt today pledged himself to present an "absolutely balanced budget" for the State of New York to Governor-elect Herbert H. Lehman.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 16. -- The speed Which sent Jack High on to a mile record in 1930 still is his, for he dashed to a decisive victory today in the featured W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap in spite of an impost of 126 pounds.

Bequests of about $250,000 to various Catholic organizations, institutions and individuals are made in the will of Mrs. Annie F. Brady, formerly of 40 Avenue B, Bayonne. N.J., which was admitted to probate in Jersey City yesterday.

ATLANTA, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Al Capone emerged from the Federal peniten- tiary long enough today to hear Judge E. Marvin Underwood take under advisement a government motion to dismiss the habeas corpus petition brought by his attorneys.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- President Hoover's home-coming this morning was marked by an unscheduled reception participated in by more than 3,000 persons who "crashed the gates" at Union Station to see him disembark from his special train.

Demanding to know why Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, felt that the best interests of the committee would be served by the continuance of State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter as chairman, Assemblymen Abbot Low Moffat and Hamilton F, Potter in a telegram to Mr. Seabury renewed yesterday their request of last Sunday for the resignation of Senator Hofstadter.

The financial outlook of the nation, barring unexpected adverse credit developments abroad, is "exceptionally promising," Francis H. Sisson, president of the American Bankers Association, declared last night at a dinner meeting of the Bankers Forum of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the Hotel Commodore.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- The government's budget proposals were the centre of interest on the Bourse today, while the market was irregular, with the tendency toward weakness. Financial circles generally consider measures for the repression of tax evasions too severe, even impossible of enforcement.

Forward passing was stressed by the Manhattan eleven yesterday as it speeded its preparations for Saturday's contest with Holy Cross at the Yankee Stadium. The squad held a two-hour workout on Manhattan Field.

Grants totaling $5,256,000 were made by the Carnegie Corporation of New York to colleges, universities and other educational institutions in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, last, according to the report of Frederick P. Keppel, president, to be made public today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16. -- More than an hour of defensive dummy scrimmaging featured Yale's football drill on Anthony Thompson Field today.
Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association of New York and Leo Sexton of the New York A.C., respectively, lead the women and men in the list of 234 record applications for the year 1932.

In the opening scene of a successful musical show a season or so ago the principals were seen coming into a theatre, being seated noisily and tardily, turning supercilious glasses in the direction of the supposed curtain and chanting skeptically: "It better be good, it better be good and funny."

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding increased $15,431,223 in October to $698,620,369 on Oct. 31, the American Acceptance Council reported yesterday. The rise, which was the second consecutive monthly gain in bill volume, was interpreted by Robert H. Bean, executive secretary of the council, as a sign of a return to the normal seasonal use of acceptance credits.

Following a long discussion last Tuesday by the directors of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce on the merits of the Hillside housing project which is to be financed by a loan of nearly $4,000,000 from the Reconstruction Financial Corporation, it was voted to refer final action to a regular meeting of the members to be held next Tuesday evening, Nov. 22, in the Concourse Plaza Hotel.

GENEVA, Nov. 16. -- The local Journal des Nations publishes today the text of a secret "note" that the monetary subcommittee of the world economic conference's preparatory commission drew up, giving the results of the recent session here. The paper also publishes a substantial summary of a longer similar note by the economic subcommittee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The role played by Owen D. Young, New York industrialist, in staving off a threatened bankruptcy of the Insull Holding and Investment Companies last December, was described today in Federal Court, at a hearing held for the purpose of discovering assets of the two concerns, now in bankruptcy.
LATROBE, Pa., Nov. 16. -- Shot accidentally by a companion on a hunting expedition, De Lancey Kountze, 55, at New York, was in a serious condition at a hospital here tonight.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -- The Harvard eleven today continued its hard drive for the Yale game, although no contact work was on the program. Dummy scrimmage was ordered again.

Near Mount Airy, N.J., there is a tract of land of about 1,500 acres, composed or ten or more old farms. Until a year ago no one ever thought of it as holding possibilities as a pheasant hunting ground, yet today, as a private preserve, posted and stocked by a trio of sportsmen, it is as natural a pheasant breeding ground as can be found in New Jersey.
IN the lull before the final football storms there is a chance to take note of the opening of the local hockey season at the Garden this evening and other incidents of the early campaign on ice.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- Stroked by Al Comstock of Minneapolis, the combination 150-pound crew won the St. Paul's Cup in the annual University of Pennsylvania Fall regatta on the Schuylkill River tonight. The regatta was rowed in darkness.
The Columbia University Club's Class A squash tennis team continued its winning pace in the metropolitan league race last night by defeating the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 4 to 1.

In what was regarded as a hint of the policy of retrenchment likely to be pursued by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt after he assumes the Presidency, Mark Graves, Director of the State Budget, declared last night that a substantial reduction of governmental activities must precede any great lowering of taxes.

The Federal budget must be balanced and the return of prosperity must be hastened by taking the hand of government off the taxpayers' throat and by greatly reducing expenditures for purposes that have been forced into the budget by the self-seeking efforts of organized groups, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said last night in an address before the National Economy League at the Hotel Commodore.

The second of Robert Goldsand's three recitals of piano music of the last 250 years was given last night in the Town Hall. His program included Schubert's sonata, op. 120; works of Hummel, Czerny, John Field; Schumann's "Novelette in F Major" and "Traumeswirren"; Chopin's sonata in B flat minor, and Liszt's "Eclogue," "Feux follets", and "Soiree de Vienne."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The first comprehensive picture of the results of the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa in July and August was presented today in finding's of separate investigations by the Commerce Department and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States that more than $150,000,000 of this country's exports to Canada and the United Kingdom are affected by the tariff preferences they accord each other under the Ottawa pacts.

Why is Vermont, which used to be content under local option, somewhat kinder to prohibition than might be expected? With the old stock, descended from thirsty Puritans and dogged individualists, are blended other strains that have no objection to looking on the wine when it is red or even when it is white.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Condemnation of "indecent literature" was voted unanimously today by the members of the Catholic hierarchy in their meeting at Catholic University.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The penultimate stage in the process of fashioning a democratic federal constitution for India will begin tomorrow when Prime Minister MacDonald opens the third round table conference in the committee room of the House of Lords.

The second of Robert Goldsand's three recitals of piano music of the last 250 years was given last night in the Town Hall. His program included Schubert's sonata, op. 120; works of Hummel, Czerny, John Field; Schumann's "Novelette in F Major" and "Traumeswirren"; Chopin's sonata in B flat minor, and Liszt's "Eclogue," "Feux follets", and "Soiree de Vienne."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The first comprehensive picture of the results of the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa in July and August was presented today in finding's of separate investigations by the Commerce Department and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States that more than $150,000,000 of this country's exports to Canada and the United Kingdom are affected by the tariff preferences they accord each other under the Ottawa pacts.

Abraham Lincoln's career was probably as much helped as hindered by the "terrible interludes" of his married life that were the result of the "brain disease" suffered by his wife, Carl Sandburg suggests in his "Mary Lincoln: Wife and Widow," published today by Harcourt, Brace.

Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co. characterized the war debts as "perfectly just but impossible" yesterday in an address before the Conference of Universities, held at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of New York University and attended by men and women representing colleges, universities and other institutions of learning in thirty-two countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP). -- Bolivia replied today to the Paraguayan proposal for a prisoners' convention by accepting articles I, II, IV, VIII, IX and X. As to the article which would have provided for weekly payment by each country to the other of the cost of upkeep of its prisonerse, the Bolivian Government supported the oral refusal of its representative, Dr. Enrique Finot, last week.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 16. -- The theft of all the ballots cast in the Third Ward and others from several districts in the First and Fifth Wards of this city was discovered this morning as officials prepared to investigate charges of election frauds here.

Contending that most tax-exempt model housing developments had done nothing to relieve slum congestion, Controller Berry recommended to the Sinking Fund Commission yesterday that it deny the application of Otto B. Shulhoff and his associates to build elevator apartments on the seven-block tract in the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported for the first nine months of this year a net income of $6,273,815 after taxes and charges, equal to 47 cents a share on its $50 par stock, against $15,265,828, or $1.16 a share, in the corresponding period last year.

A return to the plays of former days, when realism was not stressed as much as it is at present, is advocated in the new issue of Equity, the official publication of the Actors' Equity Association. It is the contention of Equity that audiences are not interested in having the mirror too closely held up to nature, at least not for entertainment purposes.

Strength in United States Government bonds again featured dealings on the Stock Exchange yesterday. All Federal issues closed higher, gaining 1-32 to 15-32 point, the Treasury 4 1/4s making the maximum advance. The rise brought many issues to within small fractions of the best prices made this year.

Apparently the North American Yacht Racing Union's new trophy for international large yacht racing on a wide scale is to be sent to Norway for competition next Summer, instead of being raced for here the first time, as was intended.

Is the richest city in the world about to default? Will New York go into the month of December unable to meet its contract payments or to supply funds for the payroll? Shall we soon have Chicago and Philadel- phia calling out to the metropolis: "O daughter of the morning, art thou become as one of us ?"

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 16. -- The thirteenth annual Mid-South Open golf tournament ended today in a three-way tie when Al Watrous of Detroit, Henry Picard of Charleston, S.C., and Al Houghton of Washington returned 143 for the thirty-six holes.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- An extra detail of policemen was stationed today at the hotel where Greta Garbo, who has been seeking obscurity by wearing a dark wig and otherwise disguising herself, is staying while visiting Paris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--The movement for beer at the approaching short session of Congress had reached such proportions today that Representative Rainey of Illinois, majority leader in the House, revised his opinion regarding the prospects and virtually predicted that modification was close at hand.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 16. -- The Short Hills Club increased its lead today in the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League when it scored its second clean sweep in as many weeks, defeating Plainfield, 5 -- 0.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The stock markets were dull today, with business still at a low ebb, mainly influenced by anxiety concerning America's reply on war debts. Sterling exchange slumped again, the New York rate dropping to $3.31 3/4, British funds weakening in consequence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The wreckage of the Insull utilities companies will be combed by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee as a part of the stock market inquiry, to be resumed as soon as Congress reconvenes, it was learned today when Senator Norbeck, chairman of the committee, returned to Washington.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 17. -- Six matches each in swimming and water polo make up the schedules announced at the Naval Academy today. Four contests in each sport will take place in the Navy pool.

Although showing some improvement from the preceding week, bank clearances continued this week to compare unfavorably with those of last year, according to records compiled by R.G. Dun Co. The decline of 31.1 per cent in the first half of November from the amount in the 1931 period was, however, smaller than in any other half month so far this year.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP). -- Pressing through involved testimony, the State Senate Utilities Investigative Committee. Inquiring into the affairs of the Public Service Commission, will turn tomorrow to the Clarion River Power Company property sale.

As a result of a recent decision by Supreme Court Justice Bliss in Albany, the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that it had placed on the competitive list twenty-two assistant clerkships of the Municipal Court of New York City.

Slightly more than seasonal improvement was registered in business conditions during October, with a tendency to increased activity in the heavy industries apparent, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

After days of charge and counter charge, the two factions, one led by E.L. Cord and the other by La Motte T. Cohu, president, seeking control of the Aviation Corporation of Delaware, Inc., and its operating subsidiary, American Airways reached an agreement late last night.

Mrs. Douglas Robinson gave a small tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 147 East Sixty-first Street, for her granddaughter, Miss Alida Robinson, debutante daughter of former Assistant Secretary of the Navy and Mrs. Theodore Douglas Robinson. The guests were limited to friends of the debutante's parents.

Weighed down by prospects of a postponement of the payment of war debts due on Dec.15 from Great Britain to the United States the pound sterling fell yesterday 2 3/8 cents to $3.27 3/4, within 1/8 cent of its low mark for the year. Pressure against the exchange was not large in volume but was persistent and met with no compensating demand.

Commendation upon what they regarded as his break with Tammany Hall poured in yesterday upon Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee from civic leaders and groups including Peter Grimm, the Young Men's Board of Trade and from some Republican political figures.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt shortly after noon today telephoned to President Hoover in Washington that he would call at the White House at 4 P.M. Tuesday for their conference on war debts and other problems.

A radio mass meeting to protest the attitude of Mexico to the Roman Catholic faith was held last evening over WLWL. At the conclusion a resolution of protest was propounded, the audience to signify "by writing an 'aye' on a post-card and sending it in." The resolution was dispatched to the United States Department of State and to the President of the Mexican Republic.

Three fourth-round matches and one postponed third-round contest were played in the Fall scratch squash tennis tourney at the New York A.C. yesterday, with Harry F. Wolf, national champion and Winged Foot representative, scoring a comparatively easy triumph over F.B. Ryan Jr., Yale Club, 15 -- 6 and 15 -- 1.

Concluding its journey across the continent, the Oregon State football squad arrived in New York yesterday for one of the major games on its 1932 schedule, that with Fordham at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Strict supervision over projected flights by American airmen to foreign countries will be exercised in the future by the Commerce Department through an amendment to the air commerce regulations, it was announced today by Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics.

No conductor in America has done as much for the music of Sibelius as Mr. Koussevitzky, who gave an entire program of that composer's works at the first New York concert of the season by the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

Ivar Kreuger's confidential agent in America. Anders Jordahl, who had remained in Canada during the Kreuger bankruptcy inquiries here, appeared for questioning yesterday before Henry K. Davis Federal bankruptcy referee, with the books that he withdrew from this jurisdiction after they were subpoenaed on Sept. 16.

President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt became a grandfather for the fourth time yesterday when an eight-pound son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Roosevelt at the Harbor Sanitarium, 667 Madison Avenue. Mr. Roosevelt is the Governor's second son.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP). -- For the first time a President-elect is going to take part in New York's ancient biennial custom of formally inaugurating a Governor.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Ralph Errole Smith, Metropolitan Opera tenor, known professionally as Ralph Errole, was divorced today by his fourth wife, Mrs. Mabel Woody Smith, whose elopement with the singer when she was 17 years old resulted in her being named corespondent in the divorce suit of his third wife.
J.P. Morgan, banker, returned unexpectedly from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after spending four months abroad in England, France and Scotland.

Members of the faculty and administrative staff of Teachers College, Columbia University, will receive a cut in salaries, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William P. Russell, dean of the college, after a meeting of the board of trustees. The reduction, which will go into effect on Dec. 1, calls for an 8 per cent cut for the year ending next June, and a 10 per cent reduction for the succeeding twelve months.

In the Dumas Manner. Frankly admitting that an office armchair is a perfectly safe place for taking heroic risks, one may yet wonder whether the opportunity for a splendid gesture was not missed when the Prince of WALES consented to an armed guard of 12,000 soldiers' and policemen on his visit to Belfast.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- Major Stuart R. Carswell of the historical section of the Army War College will conduct a hearing Tuesday in the State Office Building on the plan of the Federal Government to acquire the Saratoga battlefield. This is the first of a series of hearings by which it is purposed to ascertain from historical societies and others what sort of memorial the Federal Government should erect on the site.

Samuel Seabury answered yesterday the renewed demand for the resignation of State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter from the legislative committee investigating the city in a telegram to Assemblymen Abbot Low Moffat and Hamilton F. Potter, two of Senator Hofstadter's Republican colleagues in the Republican majority on the committee.

Elimination of obsolete merchant tonnage and upbuilding of the naval and merchant fleets of the nation to meet treaty standards and the challenge of foreign competition were urged by J. Howland Gardner, president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, at the opening yesterday of the fortieth annual series of professional sessions of the society at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn will give a dance on the night of Nov. 23 at their home in Westbury, L.I., to introduce their daughter, Miss Nancy Milburn.

Speculative apathy was such yesterday that the business on the Stock Exchange made up a total of only 700,000 shares. This was about 250,000 less than the turnover of the previous day. Price movements were narrow and the market was colorless. Taking the day as a whole, stocks lost some ground.

The bitter factional struggle in Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, which has rent that organization of 8,000 members for more than a year, was settled yesterday when James McNaughton and fifteen other members of the union reached an agreement with Frank Wilson and thirty-three other officers and members of the organization by which the suit brought by Mr. McNaughton and his associates was withdrawn.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Following an announcement today by State Controller John McCutcheon that estimated revenues accruing to the general State fund for 1933-34 would total only $15,933,870, resulting in an estimated deficit of $4,350,672, Governor Moore served notice that budget requests must be reduced by $5,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- A struggle with a new tax bill at the "lame duck" session of Congress appeared today to some of the Democratic leaders already on the scene to be inevitable, regardless of the extensive revenue that might be made available if beer is legalized.

Whenever there is an unusual number of ducks at a given spot there will be found a veteran guide who can tell why this condition exists. This year there has been a greater number of ducks in Long Island Sound off Connecticut than in twenty years, and guides who have hunted for many seasons have concluded that it is the squaw clams that have attracted the birds.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 17. -- With 55,000 seats already sold, a crowd of from 60,000 to 75,000 is expected to witness the Navy and Notre Dame play their annual football game here Saturday.

Sir Arthur Salter, British economist; Silas H. Strawn, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce; Jesse I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., Lord William Gascoyne-Cecil, Bishop of Exeter; Charles G. Norris, author, and Allan Dwan, motion picture director, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 17 (AP). -- Governor O. Max Gardner of North Carolina told the National Grange convention here tonight that "we must find and apply new remedies" if "we are to save the democratic civilization of our people."

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The first session, of the present Parliament ended today with the reading of the King's speech of prorogation and Tuesday the King and Queen will drive in state to the House of Lords to open the new session.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press). -- Huge crowds which saw Captain Mollison shatter the record for airplane flight between England and the Cape of Good Hope last March began to gather at the airport early today to see his wife lower the record still further.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League will open its season on Jan. 7, it was announced yesterday by Ellwood W. Kemp Jr., secretary-treasurer of the league. A schedule of thirty games has been arranged, with each of the six member colleges playing the others on a home-and-home basis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Theodore Brent of New Orleans, as spokesman for inland waterways, suggested to the Shannon Congressional committee today that domestic and foreign water traffic be taxed, a thing he said had not been done for 150 years. The committee is investigating government competition with private business.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17. -- Preston Burch's Tambour, a 4-year-old daughter of General Thatcher and Castanet, kept her 1932 record clean when she scored her third consecutive victory of the season in the Rose Hill Purse today. Tambour made her first start this year at Laurel and won.
THERE is nothing small about the week-end program in sports. A few of the items on the card are offered in evidence, to wit:

Three documents offered in support of the claim of Thomas Patrick Morris that he is the son of John Gottlieb Wendel and therefore legally entitled to the millions left by the late Ella V. von E. Wendel, sister of Mr. Wendel, were declared spurious yesterday by Elbridge W. Stein, handwriting expert, who was called to the stand in Surrogates' Court by John M. Harlan, trial counsel for the estate.

The Paramount Publix Corporation formed yesterday four subsidiaries to carry on certain of its corporations in pursuit of its program to reorganize departmental activities in the interest of greater efficiency and economy. The new subsidiaries will be qualified in certain States and the parent company withdrawn, and in addition certain companies formed in some States for local purposes will be eliminated.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Federal Judge William Clark directed today that agents of bonding companies giving bail in Federal cases be fingerprinted and photographed. He also instructed the United States Commissioners here to refuse the bonds of all the companies now writing such bonds in the Federal courts here, with the exception of the Union Indemnity Company.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read THE TIMES editorial "A New Federal Prison." In the last paragraph, referring to the Lewisburg prison in Pennsylvania, you state:

In Professor SELIGMAN'S long report on the revenue system of Cuba it is recommended that the Government lottery be abolished. The cost of collection is high, it is an unstable source of State income, the distribution of its burden among the social classes is "utterly unknown" and "it dulls all sense of civic responsibility."

Manhattan's chief hope of recovering Its dwindling business and residential population lies in the creation of more open spaces in the form of wider streets, parking and bus terminals and attractive surroundings for dwellings, in the opinion of Thomas S. Holden, vice president of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, who was a speaker yesterday at the monthly luncheon of the Penn Zone Association, at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Postal savings deposits throughout the country established a new high record of $868,047,747 on Oct. 31, the Postoffice Department announced today. This was an increase of $13,280,485 over the September 30 total.

Pronounced weakness in wheat and in sterling exchange afforded the only variation yesterday from what otherwise was a monotonously routine day in the various markets. Stocks gave a languid performance, with no change in the trend, although the "resistance" was more effective than it has been on other days in the recent past.
With fluctuations continuing limited and volume of business light, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday declined 2 to 4 points.

Americans have an "unhealthy modesty" as to the success of their nation, and are inclined to attribute to purely extraneous causes results which are due to their own energy and intelligence, Lord William Gascoyne-Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, declared yesterday afternoon at a farewell reception and tea given in his honor by the English-Speaking Union at their headquarters, 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Representative Rankin of Mississippi today called upon the "untrammeled, unbossed members of the next House from all parts of the country" to support him in his candidacy for the Speakership.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The address of Norman H. Davis, representative of the Department of State, at the meeting of the Bureau of the General Disarmament Conference today, as given out by the department, was as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The Princeton football team will play an eight-game schedule next year, according to an announcement made today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics. Seven games are listed for 1934.

PARIS, Nov. 17. -- A suggestion credited here to President Hoover for recalling into being, in agreement with President-elect Roosevelt, the Debt Funding Commission to re-examine the debt settlements has removed from that controversy here some of its acuteness.

MONTREAL, Nov. 17. -- Conferences between representatives of Canadian newsprint manufacturers and the bankers' committee were resumed here today, with good progress reported as made in efforts to arrive at some stabilization of the industry and the prevention at further price-cutting.

Faced with actions in Cuba to foreclose mortgages and to place the company in bankruptcy, a group of bondholders of the Eastern Cuba Sugar Corporation have formed a protective committee for its fifteen-year 7 1/2 per cent mortgage sinking fund gold bonds.
GENEVA, Nov 17. -- The text of the British proposal for armament reduction as announced by Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, was as follows:

Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney, in an address yesterday before the Women's National Republican Club denounced the local leaders of his party for placing the Republican rank and file in a position where they have come to be regarded as "merchandise on the counter of a political five-and-ten-cent store."

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., Conservation Commissioner, declared tonight that he would urge the 1933 Legislature to put his department's fish and game division on an entirely self-sustaining basis, with all its revenues used for game protection, propagation and research and other purposes of fish and game management, including the provision of game refuges and public hunting grounds.

Two of the largest boxers among the modern heavyweights will clash at Madison Square Garden tonight when Primo Camera of Italy opposes Jose Santa, Portuguese giant, in a ten-round bout which will feature the card.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17. -- An aggressive campaign for the five-day week and the six-hour day, "not as a cureall but as stop-gap in which to start to take up the slack caused by technological unemployment," was recommended to the American Federation of Labor today by three trade union groups, said to represent 1,500,000 workers affiliated with the federation.

In her debut recital at the Barbizon-Plaza last night as a dancer of authentic dances of the Orient, Rosamund Birchby attempted the impossible and got away with it very neatly. It is incredible, of course, that any Westerner could go into the East for a year or two and absorb traditional material not of her own culture when the native dancers spend lifetimes in the acquisition of its perfection of detail.

Charles A. Levine, first transatlantic air passenger, testified yesterday before Official Referee Jacob Marks that, although his companies made $10,000,000 salvaging metal from war munitions, he had nothing left with which to pay the $52,000 a year alimony asked by his wife, Mrs. Grace B. Levine.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored their first National Hockey League victory tonight, defeating the world champion Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 1, before a crowd of 3,000.

If "A Midsummer Night's Dream" is to be performed at all it is not unreasonable, to hope that it may be performed with grace. Under the direction of Percival Vivian it was mounted last evening at the former Jolson Theatre by a company that is inaugurating Shakespearean repertory at bargain prices.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- The von Papenvon Schleicher Cabinet, installed by President von Hindenburg on June 1 to bring about a "national concentration," resigned today after Chancellor von Papen's overtures for support in the new Reichstag had met with a flat rejection.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- "Appalling" conditions exist in ten Southern States, where per capita incomes are so low that the people are unable to purchase adequate medical care," according to a report made public here today by the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care.

A thirteen-point summary, embodying tentatively the conclusions expressed by eminent educators in their discussions at the Conference of Universities, was made public last night as the proceedings ended at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The Prince of Wales, who dedicates the new Parliament buildings at Stormont yesterday, spent this day playing golf on a course several miles from the city, but here in town the people talked of little but a gesture he made last night.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 17. -- Field day at Smith College today ended the Fall athletic season, with all four classes competing in field hockey, soccer, rowing and archery.

Last night's second engagement was that of "The Good Fairy," Molnar's cheerful and diverting comedy, acted, trick epilogue and all, at the Forrest Theatre before the original Joseph Urban settings which last Fall and Winter served as back-grounds for the performances of Helen Hayes and Walter Connolly.

Mayor MCKEE'S unpremeditated delivering of his soul at the Chamber of Commerce dinner had a multiple appeal. It was, in the first place an outburst from an able and honest public servant who for two months had been wrestling with the powers of evil in our city government.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- C.H. Clendining, chairman of the Transatlantic Corporation, Ltd., announced tonight that preliminary investigations had been completed for a combined sea and airport scheme that would bring New York thirty-six hours nearer to London.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- Press comment here on Sir Jobn Simon's speech before the disarmament conference bureau in Geneva today Is on the whole favorable, although there la some criticism of the Foreign Secretary's proposals as lacking in boldness.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- The charges in the $300,000 "mystery suit" which James G. Clark of Mount Kisco, N.Y., filed last Summer against Norman W. Harris, vice president of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago, were brought to light by attorneys for the two litigants in arguments on preliminary motions today before Circuit Court Judge John R. Caverly.

DANZIG, Nov. 17. -- A high Official of the Polish Ministry of Transportation arrived in Danzig today to prepare for the introduction of Polish currency for payments in the railroad system of the Free City on Dec. 1. All parties in the Diet have pledged their assistance to the government in its protest against this move.
Commercial Paper, Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 17. -- John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, when Samuel Seabury's telegram to Acting Mayor McKee was shown to him upon his arrival here tonight, remarked with an ironic smile, "I guess he's read where the Kings County organization piled up pluralities of more than 300,000 for the national and State tickets.

Although public economy is necessary, the welfare of children should have first claim on available resources, George A. Hastings, extension director of the White House Conference on Child Health and Protection, told the delegates of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at the closing sessions of its four-day annual convention at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The downward trend of wholesale prices continued uninterrupted during October and averaged 11-3 per cent lower than during the preceding month, the Labor Department reported today.

At the meeting in Edinburgh when the Carnegie Trust for Scottish Universities was set up, with the Earl of ROSEBERY, Mr. BALFOUR, JAMES BRYCE, JOHN MORLEY, Lord KELVIN among its trustees, the Earl of ELGIN objected to the provision that by a two-thirds vote the trustees could, under new conditions, modify even the specific ends determined upon at the establishment of the trust.

Representatives of twenty-one railway brotherhoods and a group of railway executives headed by Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, met in the board room of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in the Grand Central Terminal yesterday and discussed complaints presented by the railway employes bearing on employment conditions on the roads.

W.A.W. Stewart, chairman of the committee of the North American Yacht Racing Union vested with drawing up the conditions for the international 12-meter cup, expressed himself yesterday as not altogether favorable to the idea of sending it to Norway for the initial competition next Summer, instead of having the first races here, as was the original intention.

Builders are preparing to apply to home construction on a large scale many of the improvements which have proved feasible for the erection of skyscrapers, including use of steel in walls and floors, Charles F. Abbott, executive director of the American Institute of Steel Construction, bott, the members of the Gray Iron Institute, the trade association of the cast iron industry, at their meeting yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The committee for the $5,000,000 first lien bonds of the Utilities Service Company has announced the adoption of a reorganization plan involving twenty-one telephone companies and four ice companies operating in Ohio whose stocks are pledged as collateral for the bonds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 16, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,205,000,000, a decrease of $18,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $169,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Following President Hoover's telephone talk with Governor Roosevelt today at which they arranged for their conference here Tuesday, the White House announced that while their meeting would be informal, as Governor Roosevelt had originally requested.

Marie Kryl, concert pianist and daughter of Bohumir Kryl, a noted bandmaster, was married yesterday afternoon in the Municipal Building to Michel Gusikoff, violinist and a conductor at the National Broadcasting Company studios. The bride was attended by Mrs. Arthur Glass and Miss Josephine Goffin.

Three changes in the list of thirteen post-season scholastic charity football games announced on Monday by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, were made yesterday at a meeting of high school coaches and authorities held at P.S. 27, Manhattan.

In virtually every one of seventeen occupational groups studied the proportion of persons over 46 years old had increased considerably by 1930 since 1890, Ralph G. Hurlin of the Russell Sage Foundation said yesterday at the annual conference of the Personnel Research Federation at the Hotel Astor.

An ambitious experiment in "Empire preference" began yesterday, when the British trade treaties negotiated at Ottawa became effective. In return for concessions granted by the various Dominions on her textiles, chemicals, machinery and other manufactured articles, Great Britain has granted similar concessions on Dominion farm products and raw materials.
PARIS, Nov. 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee for a $15,000,000 fund to help the unemployed in this city passed the $2,000,000 mark yesterday when additional contributions of $537,014 were announced at a meeting of the committee's commerce and industry division at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Testimony that there was a difference of $39,951,988 between the fixed capital of subsidiary companies of the New England Gas and Electric Association as recorded on their books and as it appeared on the association's balance sheet at the end of 1929, was given to the Trade Commission today by Ossian Cole Van Zandt, an examiner.

P. Hal Sims, captain of the contract bridge team of four which won the Vanderbilt Cup, who recently organized the various phases of his bidding technique into a "Sims system," renewed his attack upon Ely Culbertson yesterday, charging that Mr. Culbertson was evading the proposed match between the two experts.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Distressed economic conditions have stimulated in advertisers a desire for quality rather than quantity in newspaper and magizine circulation, according to Ralph Starr Butler of New York, vice president of the General Foods Corporation.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17. -- Senator Harriaon of Mississippi today called for a balanced budget through elimination of unnecessary functions and expressed hope that the next Congress would legalize beer as a new source of taxation.

Despite the failure of the price of bread to come down in proportion to that of wheat, for which the farmer is getting around 25 cents a bushel, bakers contended yesterday that reduced wheat prices had been adequately reflected in lower prices for bread.

With 186 entries from more than a dozen States, the annual cat show opened yesterday at the Hotel Taft. This year's exhibition is known as the "Big Four in One," making the first time that four clubs have benched their shows together.
PARIS, Nov. 17. -- The Japanese delegation, which, aided by seven Japanese Ambassadors and Ministers in Europe, has been preparing an answer to the Lytton report on China, completed its work today.

Showing an aggressive spirit which never subsided, the New York Americans opened their home season in the National Hockey League by defeating the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night. Taking the lead in the opening session and holding it tenaciously, the Americans managed to register a 4-2 triumph over the rugged sextet from Boston.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- Grade-crossing elimination projects numbering 102 are listed in the 1933 program of the Public Service Commission, it was announced today. The commission added seven new ones and took over ninety-five from the 1932 program, which, because of conditions, were not undertaken.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- President-elect Roosevelt was working in his study on the first floor of the Executive Mansion when he called Mr. Hoover. He was seated on a well-worn, plush, plum-colored divan, a card table covered with correspondence in front of him.

University professors who are repudiating all idea of God, immortality, free will and personal responsibility "degrade the human mind far more than the unlettered, superstitious savage," Cardinal Hayes declares in a letter issued yesterday to the pastors of the Archdiocese of New York.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Attorney General William A. Stevens held today that the State prohibition enforcement law, known as the Hobart act, would remain on the statute books until the State Board of Canvassers meets on Dec. 6 to certify that the voters of New Jersey had repealed it at the referendum held in connection with the general election.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The Federal, county and municipal authorities investigating Newark election frauds were informed today by Frank Klumb, assistant superintendent of elections, that several pages had been torn from two poll books in the Hall of Records.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP). -- A robust college professor with thinning gray hair, familiar with economics, government and social problems, is Professor Raymond Moley, who will be Governor Roosevelt's counselor at his conference with President Hoover next Tuesday.

Wages and material costs appear to be settled enough to encourage new building projects, according to Bradstreet's Weekly, which sees the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as the most promising aid to quickening the industry.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Europe cannot recover without the help of the United States, Dr. John Grier Hibben, former president of Princeton University, declared here today. Dr. Hibben, who has just returned from a four months' vacation with Mrs. Hibben in Europe, found relations between nations far from amicable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Generous contributions by the American Red Cross to aid the sufferers in Cuba from the recent hurricane were urged by Harry F. Guggenheim, the United States Ambassador to Havana, in a report to the State Department today.

In the week ended on Wednesday, $22,000,000 of the $67,000,000 of additional money drawn into circulation in the two preceding weeks to meet first-of-the-month and election day demands flowed back to the banks, the report of the Federal Reserve System published yesterday shows.

Coordination of American Protestant missionary work under a single administrative unit was proposed in a report of the Appraisal Commission of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry issued yesterday by Albert L. Scott, the chairman.

The melodramatic matter of some stolen love letters, supposed by some German historians to have had a critical influence on the course of German diplomacy while Prince von Buelow was in power, goes unnoticed in the fourth volume of the von Buelow memoirs.

The Railroad Credit Corporation approved yesterday loans of $2,725,400 to seven railroads, bringing to $39,291,369 the total of loans authorized since the corporation was organized early this year and to fifty the number of lines aided. The corporation pools revenues received from the freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 2 and lends them to needy railroads for paying interest charges.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 17. -- The Brevities Publishing Company, publishers of the "Baltimore Brevities," "New York Hush" and other papers, was indicted today by the Federal grand jury, charged with sending obscene matter through the malls and shipping obscene matter in interstate commerce.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17. -- Official opening of the United States' new $500,000 legation building here is scheduled for tomorrow, and in connection with that function a reception has been arranged by Fierre Boal, United States Charge d'Affaires.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17. -- Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas made public today the text of a proposed South American anti-war covenant which Argentina submitted to other South American Foreign Offices in June. Accompanying the text was a long statement explaining its objects and saying the compact already had been accepted by several republics.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17. -- After staging the usual dummy-burning ceremony, the Harvard football squad ended its season's home preliminaries today. Tomorrow the team will run through signals in the Bowl at New Haven and then go to Wallingford, Conn., for the night.

Viewed from the perspective of Sept. 15, the Harvard-Yale game indicated that Nov. 19 would find the two strongest Crimson and Bulldog slevens in years pitted against each other in the Bowl. At that time-two months ago-it was regarded as not it all improbable that the game would find them both unbeaten and meeting for the mythical championship of the East.

The basketball triple-header at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the unemployed will again be played this season, it was announced yesterday by Daniel M. Daniel, chairman of the Mayor's Sports Committee, following a conference at the New York A.C. at which representatives of colleges in the metropolitan district were present.

The impetus given to the fusion movement by Acting Mayor McKee's attack on Tammany caused organization leaders yesterday to begin hastily revising their plans on the city budget, in an effort to satisfy the growing demand for economy, and to insure the meeting of payrolls and running expenses for the current fiscal year.

The annual meeting and dinner of the Indoor Polo Association of America was held last night at the Riding Club. Plans for the new season were discussed, three new member clubs admitted and the handicap committee took under advisement the handicaps for the new season.
To the Editor it The New York Times: J.M.R. has asked why the streets of New York are flooded with water at the exact time when people go to work, blaming the Department of Sanitation.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- Banks which are 75 per cent or more liquid and refuse to lend money on proper security were characterized as "parasites" by Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in an address before the conference of the New England Council today.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- After opening slightly better today, the stock markets developed renewed weakness under the lead of British funds, which slumped sharply, following a firm start. A further decline in sterling exchange on New York to $3.29 also was an adverse factor.

The board of examiners reports that there have been placed, as of the dates indicated, upon the eligible list of holders of licenses as teachers of Grades 1A-6B, License No. 1, in day elementary schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

A general reversion to fundamentals featured the final strenuous drill of the Manhattan eleven in preparation for its game with Holy Cross at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow. Coach Meehan closely watched the Jasper squad in a complete over-hauling of offensive and defensive manoeuvres in a two-hour session on Manhattan Field yesterday.
In a keenly contested Metropolitan League match last night the Montclair A.C. representatives turned back the Princeton Club Class A squash racquets players, 3 to 2, at the Princeton Club courts.

Lion Feuchtwanger, German author, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to lecture here and try out the American filang which he has practiced so assiduously. One of his first observations was an expression of surprise at American speech.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Captain Mollison received a message tonight saying that Miss Johnson had taken off from Mossamedes, continuing her England-to-Cape Town flight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- An intensive hunt for a youthful slayer who shot down a salesman, then kidnapped a niece of John Alcock, Deputy Police Commissioner, and attacked her, was made by Chicago police today, prepared to shoot the youth on sight.
The offering at the Shakespeare Theatre tonight will be "Twelfth Night," which will be repeated at tomorrow's matinee.

Elisha Walker, former head of Transamerica Corporation and one of the central figures in the battle for control of that organization which finally was won by its founder, A.P. Giannini, will become a partner in Kuhn, Loeb Co. on Jan. 1, and on the same date Jerome J. Hanauer will retire.

LEONIA, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The keen observation of a butcher's boy resulted today in the discovery of what Police Chief Henry B. Lockwood of Leonia declared to be a widespread racket in which pedigreed dogs were stolen and sold for the manufacture of antitoxin.
Leasehold deals formed the bulk of mild real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The third India round-table conference opened without ceremony today in a bare and draughty committee room of the House of Lords.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- Judd Gray, calmly going to his death believing his crime of murder expiated, is still not explainable in the light of science, Dr. Gregory Zilboorg, psychiatrist, of New York City, declared today at the New York State conference on social work.

In his letter to THE TIMES ex-Governor STOKES catalogues modestly the exceptional resistance of New Jersey to the Democratic tornado. Ten out of fourteen Representatives in Congress, a United States Senator and both branches of the Legislature make up a remarkable record for Republicans of any State on Nov. 8.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (AP). -- Testimony that Republican organization workers bought votes, intimidated Roosevelt voters, gave illegal assistance to citizens and ran the recent election in a high-handed manner was given today before the House committee on campaign expenditures.

The International Nickel Company Of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday that its net loss for the third quarter was substantially smaller than in the second quarter of the year. Net loss for the three months ended on Sept. 30 was $199,097, after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion and other charges.

State Controller Morris S. Tremaine announced yesterday that New York State would market a new issue of $30,400,000 of bonds on Dec. 14, of which $15,400,000 would represent the first instalment of the issue of $30,000,000 of emergency-relief bonds which the voters of the State authorized on Nov. 8.

The claim is now being made in France, according to Harper Bros., that had Marshal Joffre been permitted to remain in command of the French armies instead of being removed late in 1916 and replaced by Nivelle, the war might have ended more than a year earlier than it did.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 13 published a prodigious and formidable list of names that the nation is discussing as likely choices for Mr. Roosevelt's Cabinet. The list is noteworthy in the fact that it contains a remarkable forest of dead wood.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 17. -- In an effort to re-establish football relations between Princeton and Dartmouth, The Daily Dartmouth and The Daily Princetonian, undergraduate publications, joined today in urging editorially that every effort be made by athletic authorities of the two institutions to effect a resumption of an old rivalry which terminated in 1916.
"The Most Dangerous Game," with Joel McCrea, Leslie Banks, Fay Wray and Robert Armstrong, opens at the Paramount today. Maurice Chevalier and last week's stage show are being held over.

BULAWAYO, Africa, Nov. 17. -- Arthur Loew, American film producer, narrowly escaped death today when his round-the-world monoplane, Spirit of Fun, crashed while taking off from Victoria Falls, famous gorge on the Zambesi River in Rhodesia. The pilot, Captain James B. Dickson, was killed.

To the Editor of the New York Times: I have read in THE TIMES that at a meeting of the Guild of Catholic Law-yers, Archibald R. Watson, a former Corporation Counsel, stated that Judge John P. O'Brien, as Mayor of the City of New York, "would be called upon to resist the demands that business methods be applied to city affairs."

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Hoover moratorium for the suspension of payment of all reparations and war debts for a year expired last June, and resumption of the debt payments must be made next month unless an extension of the moratorium is granted by the United States.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17. -- Yale divided an hour's workout today equally on offensive and defensive football in the final dummy scrimmage scheduled before the Harvard game. Head Coach Stevens directed the team which he expects to start in Saturday's contest.
Columbia's football team reached the high point of its training yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its annual encounter with Syracuse here tomorrow.

After deliberating more than four hours yesterday a jury in General Sessions convicted Francis H. Reddy, 23 years old, of murder in the first degree as the man who planned the hold-up in which a porter in a West Forty-fourth Street cider stube was shot on Aug. 6, 1931.

Joseph V. McKee became the leader yesterday of a formidable but as yet unorganized anti-Tammany fusion movement, the aim of which is to overthrow the organization's hold on the city government through victory in the 1933 Mayoralty election.

The joint legislative committee on banking, of which Senator Newson W. Cheney of Erie County is chairman, and the recently established State Banking Board conferred yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt relative to legislation designed to improve the banking laws of the State.

Just at the moment when the economic subcommittee of the World Economic Conference's preparatory commission is saying that excessive protection must be reduced, and pointing an accusing finger at the trade policies of creditor countries, it is consoling to hear the familiar voice, with not a quaver of weakness in it, of an orthodox high protectionist congregation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- On the desk of the American Secretary of State was unfolded today a little diplomatic drama which might be entitled, "Six Cases of Liquor, or Who Gets the Goods?"

In the American mural exhibition last season at the Museum of Modern Art, one of the best of the panels was George Biddle's. Again, in his one-man show that has just opened at the Rehn Gallery, Mr. Biddle demonstrates-though such was not formally his aim -- a marked appreciation of mural requirements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Industrial employment increased 1.1 per cent during October and payroll totals were 3.8 per cent higher than in the preceding month, the Department of Labor announced today on the basis of returns from 67,988 establishments in seventeen major industrial groups which had 4,505,857 workers for the month with combined earnings of $89,125,870.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP). -- Final returns from the recent Congressional elections show the Democrats to have won out with majorities of twenty-two in the new Senate and 191 in the House.

Interest in new awards in the municipal bond market next week will centre on the competitive bidding on Monday for the issue of $2,534,000 city of White Plains (N.Y.) school and public improvement bonds. The aggregate of new municipal issues up for award next week is $9,215,523, representing the requirements of thirty-one communities in various parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Department of Justice expects that the government's anti-trust action against the Radio Corporation of America, the General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and other corporations will be settled soon through a consent decree to be entered by the United States District Court at Wilmington, Del.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 18. -- The resignation of Henry Root Stern, counsel for the Chase National Bank, as chairman of the Nassau County Emergency Work Bureau was announced today by Theodore Bedell Jr., clerk of the board of supervisors here.

With $34,160,000 of new bond issues placed on the market this week, the new financing was the heaviest since the first week in October. Last week's total amounted to only $1,585,500. In virtually every instance the two public utility issues and the six municipal loans, which went to make up the total, were sold quickly.

Darwin R. James, chairman of the State Board of Housing and spokesman for several tenants', business, civic and welfare organizations, appeared before the Board of Estimate yesterday morning in opposition to the proposed amendment to the emergency housing law that would give the city supervision over exemption from local taxation in connection, with new housing developments.

A small group of men and women who can remember back to days when the "horseless" carriage was non-existent, when Gilbert and Sullivan were more than revivals, and even to the days of the Civil War, gathefed yesterday afternoon to complete the organization of their Threescore, or Best to Be, Club of Greater New York.

Two of New York City's three undefeated scholastic football teanss, Erasmus Hall High and George Washington High, are to bring their regular schedules to a close in the feature attractions on today's program of eleven schoolboy gridiron contests on fields within New York City.

NEW YORK. Mrs. C. Frederick Fayen will give a luncheon today at the Junior League for her debutante sister, Miss Leonora Parsons. This afternoon Mrs. Edgerton Parsons will give a reception for Miss Parsons at 21 East Sixty-sixth Street.

The committee headed by W.R.C. Corson which is opposing a recapitalization plan for the New Orleans Great Northern Railroad on behalf of holders of its 5 per cent first-mortgage bonds announced yesterday that it would seek to intervene in the receivership recently declared for the railroad.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18. -- An important "cleansing" of agricultural organizations of the Communist party has begun in North Caucasus under the direction of high party chiefs from the "Centre" to cope with many cases of "compromise with kulak elements" and other forms of slackness which have slowed grain collections and Fall sowing to a "disgraceful level," the newspaper Economic Life announces today.
Columbia and Syracuse will meet for the twelfth time since 1901 this afternoon at 2 o'clock at Baker Field before a probable crowd of 20,000 spectators.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18. -- HollyWood's awards for achievement were made tonight when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences voted the performances of Helen Haves, in "The Sin of Madelon Claudet," and Fredric March, in "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde," as the noteworthy acting of the year and named Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Grand Hotel" as the finest motion picture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Governor Roosevelt and General John J. Pershing today joined the army of community chest campaigners engaged in raising $2,419,787 with which to combat poverty and distress in the capital this Winter.

Three armed men entered a tailor shop at 1,069 First Avenue yesterday for the second time in two months, held up six men, including Patrolman Samuel Terrantova of Traffic N, who was in civilian clothes, and escaped with the policeman's pistol and $500 after slightly wounding Patrolman James Rogers of Traffic F who was called to the scene by a victim of the first hold-up.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- Harvard and Yale singers united tonight in their biennial glee club concert which was given in the Woolsey Hall auditorium as the event of the day in the Yale-Harvard football week-end social program. A total of 253 members of the two clubs were on the stage for the two final general numbers.

Antonio Lopez, 28 years old, and Miquel Rugana, 28, were identified yesterday as the slayers of Patrolman Joseph J. Goodwin of the Wadsworth Avenue station last Feb. 15 at their trial for first degree murder before Judge Corrigan in General Sessions.

The committee of Eastern railroad presidents formed to reduce competitive wastes appointed subcommittees yesterday to investigate lighterage charges in New York and free unloading of less-than-car lot merchandise at New York and Philadelphia.
