The officials took this action at a meeting in the Pennsylvania Station.

RANGOON, Nov. 18. -- Burma appears to be faced with something like a Ministerial deadlock, as U Ba Pe, leader of the People's party, followed the example of Dr. B.A. Maw's party and refused to accept office.

With Joe Vollmer scoring three of his team's touchdowns, the football team of the Horace Mann School for Boys concluded its 1932 campaign by routing the McBurney School eleven, 45 to 0, on the victor's gridiron yesterday. Roger Harrison, substitute right halfback, also starred on the attack, tallying two touchdowns.

Louis Stancarl of White Plains High School was an easy winner in the fourteenth annual cross-country championship run of the Westchester Interscholastic A.A. yesterday over the two-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park.

Katherine Brush, novelist and short-story writer, Lewis Browne, essayist and biographer, and Edward Johnson, tenor, will be guests of honor at the first of this season's series of six teas for the benefit of the Authors' League Fund. It will be held tomorrow at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Hull Brewster, 350 East Fifty-seventh Street.

There are two ways of looking at the question of the war debts owed to the Treasury of the United States. One is the easy short cut which avoids thinking matters through. The money is our just due; our debtors can pay it; they should be told flatly that they will not, either now or in the future, be let off a further penny.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Federal airways maintained by the Aeronautics Branch of the Department of Commerce, the governing unit for all civil aviation, were expanded during the fiscal year 1932 to 19,500 miles of lighted and radio-equipped routes, the annual report of Colonel Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aviation, revealed today.

The fusion movement looking toward Tammany's overthrow in the 1933 Mayoralty election continued to grow yesterday, but the situation was complicated by the possibility that the real fight for control of the city government might be waged in the Democratic primary next September.

Tradition plays a large part in today's football throughout the country, with Harvard's visit to the Yale Bowl attracting chief interest in the East and the same type of contest, California-Stanford, providing the high light on the Pacific Coast.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18. -- Argentine correspondents with the Paraguayan general staff at Fort Arce report the Paraguayans believe the Chaco war has entered the final stage and that it will terminate with the fall of Fort Saavedra, which the Paraguayans expect soon.

A new schedule of film amortization, providing for more rapid writing off of film inventories, is being drawn up for Loew's, Inc., by the company's auditors and an indepenent accounting firm, officers of the company announced yesterday. The change, it was said, was deemed advisable because of the depressed conditions in the theatre business.

Unemployment Sabbath will be observed today and tomorrow in churches and synagoges of the city in support of the campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee for a fund of $15,000,000 for the relief of needy unemployed and their families.

Overriding the single opposing vote of Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, the Board of Estimate awarded contracts for two garbage incinerating plants amounting to $1,409,535 yesterday to the second lowest bidder, after the low bid of the Brader Construction Corporation had been rejected on the ground that it did not meet the Sanitation Department's specifications.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial of The Yale Daily News reported in your issue of Nov. 8 is obviously based on a misapprehension of the wide difference between the difficult practice conditions which face Army players as compared to the almost unlimited opportunities for practice of football players in other educational institutions.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 18. -- Federal indictments charging violations of banking laws in connection with the closed American National Bank of Dayton, Tenn., were returned here today against Andrew P. Haggard, president of the bank, who committed suicide last Sunday; Wallace C. Haggard, his son, a bank employe: F. Earl Robinson, a druggist and son-in-law of the elder Haggard, and A. Beirns Andrews, former official of the Dayton Hosiery Mills.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 18. -- Seventy-five thousand persons, constituting the greatest football crowd in the history of this city, are expected to see Navy and Notre Dame meet tomorrow on the turf of the new Municipal Stadium.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- Harvard today defeated Yale, 14 -- 6, in their annual junior varsity football game. Although Yale gained the most ground by rushing, two brilliant plays turned the tide of victory toward the Crimson.

The Norwegian-America liner Bergensfjord will be laid up for three months for engine remodeling, according to Captain Ole Bull, master, who brought the ship in from Oslo and Bergen yesterday. Captain Bull said the ship would sail for her home port on Wednesday and then go to Bremen for installation of a new Bauer Wach turbine as an auxiliary to the present engines.
BERLIN, Nov. 18 (Ap). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 15 shows the following changes in reichs-marks:

The compromise announced on Thursday night by E.L. Cord and the management of the Aviation Corporation, who had been struggling for control of the company for more than a week, was followed yesterday by an almost complete ending of hostilities.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP). -- America has missed the opportunity for "reflation," Virgil Jordan, New York economist, said in an address before the New England Conference today, and now faces the necessity for a radical write-down of capital values and debts to cope with the decline in prices.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt surprised three "hunger march" leaders today by receiving them readily in the quiet of the Executive Mansion study and reasoning with them calmly about their demands.

Three kidnappers who kept Paul Marciante, 10 years old, of 315 East Sixtieth Street, a prisoner after making off with him Nov. 7 when he was on the way to school, released him about 9:40 o'clock last night, letting him out of an automobile at First Avenue and East Thirty-first Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP). -- A plan of reorganization for the Republic Gas Corporation, natural gas and oil producer, was announced today by James R. Buck of Chicago. He is chairman of a protective committee for the first-lien collateral 6 per cent convertible bondholders.

The unpleasant subject of additional taxation is being discussed in Washington by members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House. They have been compelled to admit that the Federal budget is still far from balanced. On Tuesday the Government ended the first four and a half months of the new fiscal year with a deficit of $708,000,000.

WHITTIER, N.C., Nov. 18 (AP). -- In this little village nestled deep in the Appalachian Mountains where Colonel Raymond Robins was lost to the outside world for two months, natives recalled tonight that he spent much of his time "prospecting."

HELSINGFORS, Nov. 18. -- The Cabinet's decision to ask Parliament to grant a year's moratorium for the Finland Residential Mortgage Bank came as a surprise to the public. The bank's losses in exchange on its American and British loans have been so heavy, it is stated, that it is unable to meet maturing annuities.

With business only slightly more active than in the uncommonly dull market of the day before, stocks continued yesterday to give a perfunctory performance. The only impulses that moved the market were of professional origin, brokers said, complainingly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- While President Hoover and his Cabinet struggled today with the problem of reducing expenditures so that heavy additional tax levies would be unnecessary, members of Congress, discussing the situation, expressed hope that such a solution could be found.

Text of Thomas W. Lamont's speech last night is on Page 8. Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co. told the Academy of Political Science at its annual dinner in the Hotel Astor last night that two vital changes were needed as primary steps for banking reform in the United States -- to bring all commercial banks, large or small, under the Federal Reserve System and to establish "sensible" provisions for regional branch banking.

WINDSOR, Conn., Nov. 18. -- A late drive for a touchdown enabled the Deerfield Academy football team to defeat Loomis School today, 16 to 13. Quarterback Ray tallied all of the winning team's points on two touchdowns, a conversion and a field goal.

A new highway between Northern New York and Canada will be opened next Summer with the conversion of the New York Central Railroad bridge across the St. Lawrence River between Nyando, N.Y., and Cornwall, Ont., into a private vehicular and pedestrian toll bridge.
The text of Thomas W. Lamont's address on banking reform, delivered lost night at the annual dinner of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor, follows:

Although it was only their second night at the theatre named for the celebrated mammy singer, the newly organized Shakespearean players last evening made it "Twelfth Night" up at Fifty-ninth Street. While, as doubtless was to be expected, it was not an ideal presentation of the Bard's joyous comedy, it must have represented considerable improvement over the opening performance, "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- The appointment of George A. Porter of Bellaire, as a Special deputy superintendent of banks was announced today by the State Banking Department, together with the selection of ten senior bank examiners.

GENEVA, Nov. 18. -- Hopes for a convention restricting munition makers took a new lease on life today in the disarmament conference's bureau when the United States formally dropped its long-standing opposition to the supervision of private manufacturers of arms as incompatible with the Constitution.

The Indoor Art Market, sponsored and subsidized by Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Tyng of 620 Park Avenue, will open today at 134 East Seventy-fourth Street. It will start as an exhibition, but is destined quickly to turn into an auction. As a matter of fact, bids may be made on any of the work shown, beginning today.

The record of the last week contains further evidences of greater stability in general business, according to Dun's Review, which notes expansion in retail trade, steadier commodity price's and signs of improvement in industry generally. The review says in part:

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Boston University -- The ticket is getting shorter. That helps some. It cuts down on the mistakes. Under certain treatment, litmus paper turns from blue to red and back to blue again. So do football prophets. One vote for Boston College.

As a result of complaints received at the office of George Z. Medalie. United States Attorney, who is investigating alleged violation of the Federal election law in the Second and Fourth Assembly Districts, it was considered likely yesterday at the Federal Building that investigators would issue subpoenas for voting machines used in these districts.
Edward G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club, third in the national ranking, gained the semifinal round of the Fall scratch squash tennis tourney at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- Miss Barbara Stearns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Stearns, was introduced to society tonight at a dance at the Wee Burn Club in Darien.

Except for the fair activity in the "outside" market, where day loans were arranged at 1/2, compared with 1 per cent on the Stock Exchange, there was little else that was interesting in the day's trading. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were all dull and unchanged in quotation.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 18. -- The Northeast Field Hockey Association's sectional tournament opened at Wellesley College today with five associations of women hockey enthusiasts represented.
After holding within a range of a few points most of yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange worked off to the lowest levels of the week and closed 5 to 7 points lower than on Thursday.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- Making ready for a week-end stay at Hyde Park, Governor Roosevelt was busy today with a final clean-up at Albany and with the assembling of data to equip him for a broad-range view of war debts at his conference with President Hoover.

Both the Butwell and Willie Price Challenge Cups may be retired this afternoon as a result of the competition for both in the point-to-point races which will be held at Jericho, L.I., under the auspices of the Meadow Brook hounds. The races each at three and one-half mlies, will be run over the Burrill and Underhill properties.

Miss Elsa Maxwell gave a dinner last night in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Lady Juliette Duff, niece of the Earl of Lonsdale; Mr. and Mrs. Cole Porter, and Sir Charles and Lady Mendl, all of "whom arrived recently from Europe.

Only absolute necessity and the dread of consequences can force political bodies, whether at Washington or in the State Legislature or at the New York City Hall, into a policy of economy. Tammany had been slow to admit that necessity; unaccountably and unpardonably slow in realizing that its financial jig was about up, the patience of the bankers exhausted.

MUNICH, Nov. 18. -- Whether there will soon open a market for German beer in United States concerns the Bavarian brewery owners less than the danger of an exodus of experienced brewmasters to that country
Bringing to a close its 1932 campaign, Fordham's football team will line up against its third intersectional foe of the season at the Polo Grounds today when it clashes with the Oregon State eleven.

Because Controller Charles W. Berry had not given assurance that funds could be provided, the Board of Estimate again deferred action yesterday on the request of the Board of Transportation for money needed to complete and place in operation the first section of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens links of ths Independent Subway system.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 18 (AP). -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, head of the National Economy League, told the National Grange convention here tonight that "the government controlled by selfish groups, is taking charge of the people, and, unless we are to see disorder prevail and liberty gone, the people must take charge of their government."
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 18 (AP). -- Colonel Raymond Robins was located tonight in the boarding house at Whittier, where he has made his home for the past two months.

That portion of Wall Street which depends upon the share market for its entertainment was disappointed yesterday. The movement of stocks was slow and irregular, with no emphatic fluctuations in either direction. The net results were unimportant.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 18. -- Samuel Seabury of New York denounced "the privilege against self-incrimination" as "enabling criminals to violate the rights of others" in an address here tonight before the West Virginia Bar Association.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- Dwight B. Ladu, secretary of the State Bridge Commission, said today that the leasing of the bridge between Cornwall and Nyando would in no way affect the State's plan to extend bridges across the St. Lawrence River. The commission intends to build a span at Ogdensburg and others later, he said.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Liquidation was on again today in December wheat on the Board of Trade here, and the finish was at the bottom at net losses of 5/8 cent a bushel, the near-by future reaching within 1/4 cent of the lowest mark established by any future since trading started in the local market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The opposition of Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas of Argentina to some of the efforts of the commission of neutrals to achieve peace between Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco was fully revealed today when the commission made public without comment an exchange of notes concerning the degree of pressure that should be applied by the Pan-American governments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ended Nov. 12 stands at 64.0, as compared with 63.9 for the week ended Nov. 5, showing an increase of two-tenths of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- President Hoover gave intensive consideration today to the war debt suggestions which he will submit to Governor Roosevelt at their conference next Tuesday, but how far he will go in proposing a new approach to the problem remained undisclosed.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- An animated cartoon was included in the program at the premiere performance of the Film Guild of America, which was attended by 650 adults and children this afternoon and tonight in the auditorium of the Mamaroneck Junior High School.

Official support was sent to the rescue of the pound sterling yesterday after selling, based on disappointment over the outlook for a postponement of the December war debt payment, had driven the exchange down to $3.26 1/2 in London. By the time the foreign exchange market in New York had opened the recovery was well under way and the first transactions here were done at $3.29, up 1 1/4 cents from Thursday's final price.
The list of the Anchor liner Cameronia, leaving today for Glasgow via Moville, includes:

The old Seventh Regiment broke a tradition of a half century last evening in asking the public to attend a full-dress review. In the past these infrequent events have been by invitation only, but yesterday it was at $1.50 a person. The proceeds went to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, and its chairman.

The triple tie for first place that had existed among the City A.C., the Bayside Tennis Club and the Yale Club for leadership in the Metropolitan Class B Squash Tennis League was broken yesterday when Bayside conquered the Eli clubmen, 5 to 2, to send them into a quadruple tie for third place.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18. -- Philadelphia's first and second teams scored easy victories in the first day's play of the Southeastern field hockey tournament today on the Bryn Mawr school grounds.

To assist the Travelers Aid Society of New York, the play "Autumn Crocus" will be taken over for the night of Dec. 6 at the Morosco Theatre. Those interested in the charitable work of the society include Governor and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Lieutenant Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont, Mr. and Mrs. William C. Potter and Miss Mary Lincoln Aldrich.

Beginning tomorrow morning a service in the Dutch language will be held the third Sunday of every month at 9 A.M. in St. Boniface's Chapel of the cathedral of St. John the Divine. This is one of the seven "Chapels of the Tongue" built around the ambulatory of the cathedral.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The recent weakness in sterling was accentuated at the opening of the foreign exchange market today, the New York rate touching the lowest of the year at $3.27 1/4. In later dealings the quotation recovered to $3.30 3/4, closing higher on the day at $3.30 1/2.

The Wisconsin unemployment compensation act, providing compulsory Compensation, for employes in that State unless a voluntary plan is agreed upon by a representative group of employers, was discussed yesterday in a paper by W.H. Burhop, secretary of the Employers' Mutual Liability Insurance Company of Wausau, Wis., which was read at the nineteenth annual meeting of the Casualty Actuarial Society in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The claim of Thomas Patrick Morris, Brooklyn house painter, to filial kinship with John G. Wendel and through that to rightful ownership of the $30,000,000 Wendel estate was thrown out as "false and a forgery" by Surrogate Foley yesterday. Surrogate Foley announced he would send the record to District Attorney Crain, with the hope that it would "receive prompt attention."

There will be no further discharges of employes at the Brooklyn Navy Yard on account of shortage of work, according to orders forwarded by Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, to the commandant and posted yesterday in the yard by Captain Paul B. Dungan, yard manager.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Together with the majority of our citizens, I have the very highest respect for Mayor McKee. I have known him since he was in the Legislature. He is an honest, straightforward, high-minded man, thoroughly capable and intelligent.

Scoring six points in each of the final two periods, Evander Childs High School's football team defeated Morris High, 19 to 6, yesterday before 2,000 at Evander's field. The game was the final regularly scheduled contest for Evander.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 18 (AP). -- The two American doubles teams competing in the New South Wales tennis championships advanced today to the final with straight-set victories over Australian opponents, Ellsworth Vines Jr. and Wilmer Allison previously had gained the final of the singles.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- A false news bulletin from Geneva stating that Adolf Hitler had been named Chancellor of Germany caused a flurry on the Bourse today. Otherwise the session was dull. As soon as the report was denied a rally occurred and the closing came without important changes for the day.

Doubt and confusion over the city's present and future financial condition continued to grow yesterday as new rumors and "inside" tips arose at City Hall and in Wall Street. The only certainty in the entire situation was the fact that Acting Mayor McKee was still without news from the office of Controller Charles W. Berry and evidently without hope of getting any information from that source.

Federal agents, working at the instance of President Hoover, and the police of New York, Chicago, Boston and many other cities have been pursuing an intensive search for Colonel Raymond Robins, since his mysterious disappearance Sept. 3 while en route to Washington for an audience with Mr. Hoover.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- A charge that the Vare organization brought out the spectre of the Ku Klux Klan to frighten voters into casting their ballots for the Republican ticket last week was injected into the Congressional investigation of election frauds here today.

The shaft to be unveiled today at Kill Devil Hills, Kitty Hawk, as a memorial to ORVILLE and WILBUR WRIGHT, who at that spot flew the first airplane driven by a motor, will carry a flashlight to guide pilots in the hours between sunset and dawn.

Harriet Cohen, the English pianist, brought with her an interesting program for her first appearance of the season here at the Town Hall last night. She began with eight transcriptions from a dozen made by twelve British composers from the works of Bach.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Nov. 18 (AP). -- The Texas University Longhorns presented a dazzling running and passing attack to trample Arkansas University under a 34-to-0 score today.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 18 (AP). -- Federal forces under General Reina were reported today to have recaptured the town of Nacaome, sixty miles south of here, with little resistance from the Liberal rebels, who precipitated a revolt last week.

More than 180 cats of pedigreed aristocracy paraded yesterday before the judges in two specialty shows competition for national and international honors at the annual championship two-day cat show at the Hotel Taft. The last day was marked by keen rivalry among the champions, and several that were judged among the best at the opening received only second and third prizes.

Theodore T. Sugar, plaintiff in a disclosure action involving the sixbuilding at 675 Fifth Avenue, adjioning the northeast corner of Fifty-third Street, bought in the property at an auction sale yesterday. The realty was put up for bidding in an action against the Hicks-Downs Realty Company and was acquired by the plaintiff on a bid totaling $386,000.

Weakness in the grain markets yesterday overshadowed trading in all other sections. December wheat sold down to 42 1/8 cents, which was 1/4 cent above the record low established two weeks ago. Corn, rye and oats also declined. Cotton was off 5 to 7 points, while coffee, sugar, cocoa and rubber went lower. Hides and silk were firm. Eggs reached a new high for the year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 18 (AP). -- Officials at a sanatorium here where Dr. Vernon Robins, brother of Colonel Robins, is confined, said tonight he was too ill to be notified of the finding of the prohibition leader.

Hope that the seven Protestant denominations which participated in the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry could accept the constructive recommendations of the report despite their credal and theological differences was expressed last night by Professor William Ernest Hocking, chairman of the inquiry's appraisal commission, at the opening session at the Hotel Roosevelt of discussion of the report by representatives of the various Missions boards.

Anders Jordahl, the late Ivar Kreuger's confidential American representative, spent yesterday on the witness stand, his second day, while Jacob K. Javits, counsel for American creditors of the Swedish Kreuger Toll Corporation, questioned him in an attempt to retrace the involved transactions whereby companies were bought and sold, assets were shifted and stock owned by holding companies was pledged to secure loans.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18. -- Jockey Johnny Gilbert scored a triple today and now is only four behind Hank Mills for the honor of having ridden the most winners this season. Mills is retired for the year and if Gilbert can get five more winners between now and the end of the Bowie meeting, which has nine days to run, he will have attained the distinction sought by all riders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The desirability of strengthening economic ties between the United States and Cuba was stressed today by Senor Don Oscar B. Cintas in presenting to President Hoover his credentials as Ambassador from Cuba.

The older job-seeker is definitely barred from 59 per cent of the available jobs and is discriminated against in 89 per cent of them, according to studies of the manufacturing industries of New York State by the State Commission on Old Age Security, now being completed, Solomon Barkin, a member of the commission, told the conference of the Personnel Research Federation at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

ATLANTA, Nov. 18. -- Police, county Commissioners and citizens joined forces in Atlanta today for warfare on bandits and bombers in the wake of a prolonged series of murders, robberies and explosions that wrecked transmission lines of the Georgia Power Company.

BELFAST, Nov. 18 (AP). -- "Every one who knows Irishmen likes them," the Prince of Wales said in a farewell speech to Ireland tonight just before he boarded a special train to catch a Channel boat back to England.

Words of Power. One German author on his way to the United States took care to have himself coached in American slang by no less a person than JOSEPH HERGESHEIMER. That the Philadelphia writer did his full duty by his German confrere was made apparent when Herr FEUCHTWANGER unleashed his new vocabulary upon the ship news reporters.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- The North American Light and Power Company announced tonight plans for changes in its financial structure, including a substantial write-down in its common stock capitalization and the setting up of reserves to take care of the depreciation in values in recent years.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18. -- A.M. Dankman, director of the Soviet Music Hall and Circus Trust, tomorrow will send a cable offering Harpo Marx a month's contract for next Spring. Recent films of the four Marx brothers, which have won great success in Europe, have not been presented in Soviet Russia.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP). -- A financial report showing income of $2,844,201 from the holdings of the mentally incompetent Stanley McCormick, brother of Harold F. McCormick, head of the International Harvester Company, and disbursements of $2,837,472 during the last year was approved in Probate Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The cost of all building construction for which permits were issued in 351 cities in October increased 2.3 per cent to a total of $32,498,455 from $31,756,088 in September, according to the monthly report issued today by the Department of Labor.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The question of whether Germany will return to her seat in the disarmament conference will remain open until France has unequivocally recognized the German claim to equality rights or, as it has always been formulated by the German Government, has agreed that the future status of German armaments shall be an integral part of the general disarmament convention to be concluded at Geneva.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noted in THE TIMES this morning, with surprise and some dismay, the Misinterpretation, by a correspondent signing himself "Onlooker," of my informal remarks recently made before the Guild of Catholic Lawyers.

ATLANTA, Nov. 18 (AP). -- Because of the prospective increase in competition from foreign cottons any material further increase in consumption of American cotton will require an improvement in world demand canditions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 18. -- A cross-seetion of present conditions and efforts of the nation to ride above the economic depression was provided by speakers today at the twenty-third annual Convention of the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Ambassador.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- President von Hindenburg issued an emergency decree under Article XLVIII of the Federal Constitution today defining the jurisdiction of the titular Prussian Cabinet and of the Reich's commissioner and his subcommissioners.

Immediate attention to a broad program of adult education was advocated as one of the vital steps in planning a "new education for a new America" at the opening session yeserday of a regional conference of he Progressive Education Associaion at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press). -- France won the international army officers' event at the Royal Horse Show tonight. The Irish Free State carried off second and third places with the United States Aarmy team fourth. The Canadian team was last.

American bankers who participated in the original marketing of various European loans which were issued under the auspices of the League of Nations and are in default, have been invited by the League Loans Committee of London to collaborate with it, according to the Institute of International Finance, which is conducted by the Investment Bankers Association in cooperation with New York University.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 18. -- A "spread the work" movement for Nassau County was organized here tonight at a meeting of about fifteen representatives of various industries of Long Island. The meeting had been called by Richard T. Childs, county representative of the Long Island Chamber of Commerce.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment would bring about a nation-wide decrease in crime, Dr. Walter N. Thayer Jr., State Commissioner of Correction and president of the American Prison Association, declared here today in an address before the New York State Conference on Social Work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Bowing to the mandate of his State, Senator Vandenberg of Michigan today joined those demanding immediate resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment and immediate modification of the Volstead act.

Primo Carnera. Italian giant, knocked out Jose Santa, Portuguese heavyweight, last night at Madison Square Garden without causing much excitement. A crowd of not more than 5,000, one of the smallest at a professional ring show in the Eighth Avenue arena in years, saw the huge Venetian conquer his foe in the sixth round of what was to have been a ten-round encounter.

"Autumn Crocus" will be presented tonight at the Morosco Theatre by Lee Shubert, in association with Basil Dean. Francis Lederer, a Czech actor who is making his debut here, and Patricia Collinge will be the leading players.

A conference of the leading copper producers of the world has been called for Nov. 28 in this city to discuss the extension of the present curtailment agreement for another year and the apportionment of the foreign field, excepting Great Britain, among the various interests.

GENEVA, Nov. 18. -- Yosuki Matsuoka arrived here today to take charge of Japan's case when the Council takes up the Lytton report next week. He began by calling in the world press and handing out a statement concluding:

Charges of fraud and "racketeering" were made yesterday against the financial interests behind the bankrupt United Cigar Stores Company of America at a hearing before Irwin Kurtz, referee, at 15 Park Row, by James A. Delahanty, former General Sessions judge., Mr. Delahanty appeared as attorney for the William F. Kenny Company, owner of the building at 58-60 East Twenty-third Street.

A painting by Rembrandt, "Woman Plucking a Fowl," brought $26,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of paintings collected by Francis Kleinberger, New York art dealer. The buyer was an agent, acting, it was said, for a private collector of this city who did not wish his name revealed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- United States export trade with the United Kingdom in commodities on which that country has granted new or increased tariff preferences to Canada and other dominions under the Ottawa agreements was placed at $28,000,000 in a formal announcement today by the Commerce Department.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 18. -- Montclair Academy outplayed the hitherto undefeated and unscored upon Pingry School of Elizabeth to gain a 7 to 0 victory in the final football game of the season for both teams today. A crowd of 1,500 witnessed a thrilling battle.

Cargo ships will play a minor part, if any, in the future construction of American vessels, it was indicated yesterday by experts in the field of marine engineering who addressed the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers at the closing session of its fortieth annual meeting.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- The State Tax Commission issued a statement today to clarify an apparent misunderstanding relating to the imposition of the stock transfer tax law as applied to fixed trusts. The statement follows:

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The former Alice Silverthorne, niece of Mrs. J. Ogden Armour of Chicago, is seeking a divorce in France, it was learned today, from Raymond de Trafford, young Englishman, whom she married in Paris last year and who at present is in Australia.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt in his Thanksgiving Day proclamation as Governor today called for special consideration for those in distress, including in it a prayer from the Episcopal Book of Common Prayer which mentioned the "forgotten man."

All the ingredients of the traditional Thanksgiving dinner are less expensive this year and families of moderate incomes should be able to afford the best on the market, it became apparent yesterday. Experts in the Bureau of Home Economics of the Department of Public Markets figured that a New York housewife would be able to serve an old-fashioned turkey dinner, with all the fixings, at a total cost of not more than $5.42.

Manhattan, with three straight victories to its credit, and Holy Cross, beaten by Brown and Harvard in its last two starts, will clash at the Yankee Stadium this afternoon at 2:00 o'clock. Indications point to a crowd of 25,000, which would be the largest ever to see the Jaspers in action.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa, Nov. 18. -- Her eyes reddened by lack of sleep and her ears almost deafened by the continuous roar of her plane's engine, Amy Johnson landed at the municipal airfield here this afternoon after one of the greatest feats of endurance any woman hag ever accomplished.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18. -- Strikes lockouts and largre losses to investors in building construction throughout the United States were threatened today by spokesmen for 500,000 building trades workers involved in a Jurisdictional dispute with the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and the International Association of Machinists.
TOKYO, Nov. 18. -- The draft budget for 1933-34, after undergoing adjustment in the Finance Ministry, was again presented today to the Cabinet, which adjourned discussion until Tuesday.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 18. -- Colonel Raymond Robins, dry crusader and social worker, who disappeared Sept. 3 while on his way to confer with his close personal friend, President Hoover, has been found, Deputy Prohibition Administrator J. Ed Kanipe revealed tonight.

New construction contracts during the first half of this month totaled $50,990,300, against $54,339,300 in the coresponding period last month, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reports for the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains. Highway contracts furnished one of the bright spots in the heavy engineering report for the country during the past week, this compilation, made by The Engineering News-Record, showing a total of $8,396,000, against $1,034,000 in the preceding week.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- Much more importance is attached in Paris to the question of who will succeed Chancellor von Papen and Defense Minister von Schleicher in the government of Germany than to Sir John Simon's disarmament proposals at Geneva.

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The presence of the large Japanese delegation to the League of Nations session in Paris for five days before going on to Geneva for the Lytton report discussions has again revived reports that Japan is going to get financial aid to carry out her expensive program in Manchuria.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- Yale and Harvard will meet tomorrow i the fifty-first game of their traditional football series. Members of the rival elevens slept tonight in adjoining suburban towns, the Crimson in Wallingford and the Blue in Cheshire.

Few are the families not in anxiety over the possible need of medical care and its cost. The brief extracts from the report of the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care, published in yesterday's TIMES, suggest the shadow that must hover over millions of homes.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- President von Hindenburg discussed the parliamentary implications issuing from the precipitate resignation of the von Papen-von Schleicher government with Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, the Nationalist leader, today. Later, he received Dr. Ludwig Kaas, the Centrist leader, and Dr. Eduard Dingeldey of the People's party.
MADRID, Nov. 18. -- Extremist Left Deputies in the Cortes today violently attacked the contract of the Compania Telefonica Nacional, subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Emil Kissel, 20 years old, of 7,208 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, whose father Konstanty Kissel, 46, was found shot to death last Sunday night beside the sea wall at the foot of Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was held without bail in Homicide Court yesterday as the slayer.

OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Steven Szumachowski of Mount Pleasant High, Schenectady, today trotted down the cinder path of La Salle Military Academy's track eighty yards in the van of a strong field to capture the fifth annual invitation run conducted by the school.

Starting Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock and closing on Thursday night, the annual Old Glory sale of trotters and pacers at the Squadron A Armory promises to be one of the test ever held. During the three days of the auction several noted performers will be brought into the ring and the leading farms again will have big representations.

DURHAM, N.H., Nov. 19 -- New Hampshire closed its season today with a 43-0 victory over Connecticut State before a Dad's Day crowd of 5,000. An 84-yard run by McGowan for a touchdown in the third period was the feature of the game.

LONDON, Nov. 2 WHEN a theatre unaccustomed to failure meets with two or three successive reverses a paralysis of judgment seems to fall upon the unhappy manager. He stands bewildered before his patrons' whom he no longer understands, trying to guess what kind of thing it is that they really want.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 -- W.W. Vaughan's Canron, the only filly in a field of ten 3-year-olds, plowed gamely through the sloppy going at Bowie today to win by a neck in the mile-and-a-sixteenth of the $5,000 added Prince Georges Autumn Handicap. The favorite, G.H. Bostwick's Pom-, peius, finished second, three lengths before the Anall Stable's Larranaga.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 19 -- Purchase of votes, at the rate of $5 each from white electors and $2.50 from Negroes, at the Republican election of delegates to the State convention on Sept. 10, was admitted by a witness here today at the House campaign funds inquiry.

BERLIN, Nov. 19.--In place of the arrogant Adolf Hitler of last August a much chastened National Socialist chieftain was received by President von Hindenburg today, and because of this changed demeanor a softening of some of the asperities left over from their historic clash three months ago seems to have been the outstanding result of their meeting.

INSANITY is increasing throughout the United States at an alarming rate. Its yearly advance is four times as great as the total population increases. Within the past two decades cases of mental diseases reported by hospitals and asylums show a numerical growth of 66 per cent in comparison with an upward population trend of only 16 per cent.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- Is Europe losing the preeminent position it has held almost since the beginning of its history as the supreme influence controlling the material and later the intellectual development of the peoples of the world? What causes underly this decline?

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A dissenting faction of the American Federation of Labor, describing itself as consisting of "rank-and-file" delegates, arrived here today in advance of the federation's national convention, opening Monday, to demand approval of a system of unemployment insurance which would be created by the government and industrial employers.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 19 -- Twenty seconds before the game ended, Baby Rounsaville, end, caught a 15-yard pass from Chester Curtis and ran 22 yards for a touchdown to give the University of Mississippi a 7 to 0 victory over Southwestern of Memphis today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Practical Pan-Americanism has received a decided boost from the recent Presidential election. That is the only conclusion that can be logically drawn from the "complete returns," so to speak, reported from Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--The movement for beer at the short session of Congress received a blow today with the intelligence that a modification measure prior to a change in the Eighteenth Amendment probably would encounter a veto at the hands of President Hoover.

Contending that Inefficiency in management will be responsible in the next decade for the major part of losses in industry, Eugene Szepesi, consulting engineer, declared yesterday that the outstanding requirements of business to combat such inefficiency are facts on economic changes as soon as they occur.

After rallying in the preceding week, and in some cases for the preceding two weeks, most prices on the local commodity exchanges turned downward last week, slipping steadily until the close of trading yesterday. One exception was coffee, which moved higher.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- Towering above the surface of election aftermath which lies in the wake of the avalanche that swept over Cali-, fornia and carried the President's home State into the Democratic column, is a dominant peak overshadowing every other phase of the result.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Following the seasonal trend of the past five years, United States merchandise exports increased nearly $21,000,000 during October over the preceding month to a total of $153,000,000, according to foreign trade figures made public today by the Commerce Department.

Steadily decreasing average rates for electric current since the war have become available to the northeastern section of the United States as a result of the interconnection of large power sources, manifold technical improvements in production and distribution of current, increased and broader uses of current, and consolidation of small local companies into larger systems, in the opinion of the Public Service Commissions of the several States.

LAST Summer, at Williamstown, Mass., when economists, political scientists, students of history, men of public affairs gathered for the annual meetings and discussions of the Institute of Politics, pre-eminent among the matters considered was the exposition and critical examination of the three great economic systems now in use in the world.

Directors and sponsors of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry and representatives of foreign missions boards, in conference in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday, were told by the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, that the report of the appraisal commission criticizing various aspects of foreign missionary work was not "aiming at and hitting at" missionaries so much as the church boards and church people, in the United States.

MANY charitable enterprises will benefit from theatrical performances in the near future. The proceeds from two next month will go toward the work of the board of trustees of the Public Education Association, which for more than thirty-five years has been closely linked with the development of the public schools of New York City.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 19 -- Nebraska's Cornhuskers, who tied the Pittsburgh eleven in a scoreless game last week, won the Bix Six football championship today by defeating Oklahoma's Sooners, 5 to 0. The Cornhuskers finished unbeaten in the Conference.
HARBIN, Oct. 15 -- Poets who sing of pastoral peace are likely to get a rude shock in Manchuria, where the pursuit of agriculture sometimes takes on all the aspects of a military campaign.

HELSINGFORS, Nov. 19 -- With a substantial decline in legal liquor sales and increased smuggling, Parliament is now discussing a bill providing for drastic amendments to the drinking law with a view to stamping out rum-running. Sales of hard liquor have recently declined nearly 40 per cent, which authorities hold is largely the result of a revival of large-scale smuggling, since cheap liquor is plentiful.
MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 19 -- In the thirty-first meeting between Tufts College and Massachusetts State College on a muddy gridiron today, Tufts emerged the victor, 6 to 2.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- A $300,000 damage suit under the Clayton act, charging eight of the largest motion picture corporations with combination find conspiracy in restraint of trade, was filed in Federal Court today on behalf of the Clinton Amusement Corporation, operators of the Mayfair Theatre at 1,011 South Orange Avenue.

WHEELING, W. Va., Nov. 19 -- Led by Halfback Joe Korshalla, who individually accounted for 71 points on eleven touchdowns and 5 points after touchdowns, West Liberty Teachers today overwhelmed Cedarville College of Ohio by 137 to 0.

The turbo-electric ship Colombia, first of two new ships built for the Colombian Steamship Company to operate to Haiti, Jamaica, Colombia and Panama, is due to reach New York this afternoon, carrying officials and guests who boarded her yesterday at Newport News, Va.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Ottawa's players who served with Detroit last season performed the major roles tonight as the Senators turned back the Red Wings, 2 to 0, for their first victory since returning to the National Hockey League.

CHARLES LAUGHTON will add a new portrait to his somewhat frightening gallery of screen characterizations when the Cecil B De Mille film, "The Sign of the Cross,"comes to the Rialto on Nov. 30. Mr. Laughton will be seen as Nero in this drama of early Christianity.

CLOSED models of all the 1933 General Motors cars will incorporate a new ventilation system developed by the Fisher Body Corporation, it is announced. This feature, which will be built directly into the car's body, is designed to eliminate drafts as well as to insure constant air circulation.

American systems of transportation would lose an important volume of trade to foreign ships if the proposed St. Lawrence seaway were built under the terms of a treaty between the United States and Great Britain which is now the subject of a Senate hearing, says the Foreign Commerce Club of New York in a statement issued yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, Nov. 19 -- Under the heading "An Interview with the War Minister Who Destroyed the Navy," Dagons Nyheder publishes today the views of the Danish Minister of Defense, Laurkz Rasmussen, who will resign next week on account of his age after having introduced a disarmament bill in the Rigsdag seven times.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The approach of the consideration of the Lytton report by the League of Nations directs attention here to the status of the "Hoover Doctrine" in international relations, under which recognition would be denied any situation resulting from violation of international commitments.

The Commerce Department's classified statement on origin and destination of gold imported or exported during October shows that the month's trifling exports went entirely to Switzerland and Canada. Imports came from eighteen separate countries.

THIS study is probably a Ph. D. thesis enlarged upon. It presents a complete survey of the use of mythology in English non-dramatic poetry from the Renaissance through Milton. The book is scholarly and interesting, but, as is the case with so many such studies, the subject treated in such detail and with so much analysis is never once summarized.

THERE MILE HOUSE, an isolated homestead on a Pennsylvanla mountainside, is the scene of most of the strange events with which this story deals. The story opens with the death of Mary Alice Greer, the elderly owner of this house. Within a few days of her death the house is rented, completely furnished, to Miss Fenwick, who makes it plain that she likes solitude and hopes to find it there.

PARIS, Nov. 19.--Paul Reynaud, formerly Finance and Colonial Minister in the French cabinet, who has just returned from the United States, in a lecture today before a large French audience gravely warned his countrymen against an ultranationalist attitude on the question of debts to the United States.

IT is hazardous to venture predictions as to what attitude or action the League may take toward the Lytton report. Problems of world politics, especially of European politics -- questions of security, disarmament and attempts to develop the international structure of peace machinery -- are inseparable from the Manchurian dispute.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Tale's astonishing accuracy with its forward passes, under the prevailing conditions, provided the high light of the Elis' victory over Harvard today. Four passes were hurled and three were successful for a total gain of 75 yards. Lassiter was the tosser of three, getting the oval safely away despite the rain.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Thirty-three members of the Yale and Harvard football squads concluded their gridiron careers with the final gun of today's game. They included fourteen wearers of the Crimson and nineteen wearers of the Blue.

An exhibition of paintings by Emile Branchard is on view at the Bourgeois Galleries. As those who have seen his previous one-man shows will recall, Mr. Branchard does not paint for the delectation of those who must see every leaf on every tree, but persons less exacting will find much of interest in his work.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Germany is a country famous for the rumors spread therein. Sometimes they have a slender basis of fact and sometimes they are wholly imaginative. In both cases a large part of the time of American correspondents is consumed in running them down.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- A Broadcast hook-up today provided listeners with speeches by Amy Johnson the British flier who has just Broken the England-to-Cape Town record, and her husband, Captain J. A. Mollison, who held the former record.

THE first of five concerts for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid will take place next Saturday in Madison Square Garden. Walter Damrosch will conduct, with Jascha Heifetz, violinist, as soloist. According to the announcement, this will be Mr. Heifetz's only appearance with orchestra in New York this Winter.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Stocks continued to advance slightly at today's session of the Boerse, although the turnover, with few exceptions, was small. I.G. Farben had a large market, as did several mining issues. The tone was firm throughout the day, owing to what was regarded in financial circles as a brighter outlook in the political situation.

TWO vital and arresting screen dramas are now on exhibition at theatres in the Broadway area. One is "I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang," which is an adaptation of a book written by Robert E. Burns on his own experiences, and the other is a German production known as "Kameradschaft," which depicts incidents in a coal mine tragedy supposed to occur on the Franco-German border.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 18 -- Bolivia forgot the conflict with Paraguay this week long enougrh to commemorate the Spanish conquest four centuries ago of the ancient Inca empire. Under the sponsorship of cultural and patriotic societies there were lectures, entertainments, and excursions to such treasure centres as Lake Titicaca, Tiahuacanu and the Islands of the Sun and Moon.

BERLIN THERE are men in Germany, plenty of them, who still wear iron watch chains And there are many women who wear iron wedding rings. Each chain and each ring bear the inscription: "Gold give I for iron."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Three members of the flying squadron, prohibition campaigners, who were closely associated with Colonel Robins, expressed gratification today that their leader had been found.

BERLIN. THERE is a curious fascination about seeing one's own country, its outstanding personalities, its conditions and difficulties, as viewed and described by a foreigner. Of course, the general attitude of the author most be sympathetic and friendly: in such a case one willingly accepts criticism, and at times, indeed, lets one's own opinions be modified by those of the stranger, based as they are on fresh impressions.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 19 -- Michigan State College closed its 1932 football campaign today by defeating Detroit University for the first time since 1923. The final score was 7 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Almost simultaneously with the reappearance of Colonel Raymond Robins the State Department today made public documents which throw new light on the effort he made fourteen years ago to align Soviet Russia with the allied powers.

GENEVA, Nov. 19 -- The Manchurian issue, which was adjourned by the League of Nations pending the inquiry by its Lytton Commission, will come to the fore again tomorrow when Japanese and Chinese diplomats will open attacks on each other in advance of the meeting of the League Council on Monday.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- What's in a name? Would not a street by any other name be as useful?

By the thin margin of a safety, the Fordham football team repulsed the New York invasion of the Oregon State eleven at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Playing on a gridiron which was ankle deep in mud, the Maroon succeeded in turning back the visitors from the West by the score of 8 to 6.

NEW YORK women have made their choice; out of the season's fashion offerings, they have nicked the winners in color, contour and fabric. To see a group of smartly dressed women in a restaurant or whirling around on a ballroom floor represents an enlightening spectacle.

The rezoning for residential use of a six-block area near St. Gabriel's Park in the midtown east side district, as approved by the Board of Estimate on Friday, will foster the development of a new apartment community there, in the opinion of many civic leaders and realty interests.

POLITICAL campaigns, as Philip Guedalla said of historians, repeat themselves. The same smiling candidates, the same red-fire parades of crowds, the same pledges, the same pomp and circumstance of official appearance.

Another step toward ending the hostilities in which E.L. Cord and the management of the Aviation Corporation have been engaged was taken yesterday, when LaMotte T. Cohu, president of the corporation, announced that the $1,000,000 libel suit which he had brought against the Stock Exchange firm of E.F. Hutton Co. had been withdrawn.

DETROIT PLANT activity in the Detroit area is reminiscent of old times. Automobile manufacturers here, no longer fearful of slowing down sales of current models by announcements of 1933 intentions, are frankly telling the public that their plants are now busy on new lines.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17 -- Canada is getting a taste of lower taxes, and finds the experience much to her liking. Reductions in the excise tax have brought about a five-cent cut in the retail price of practically all Canadian-made cigarettes, which now sell at 20 cents for a package of twenty.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Temple's dream of an undefeated football season was smothered in the mud by Villanova today as the Wildcats won, 7 -- 0, at the Owls' Stadium before a crowd of 8,000.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 19 -- Although total production of gold in Ontario showed a moderate drop in October, output for the ten months was up to $38,701,435, exclusive of premium, against $35,167,304 in the same, period in 1931, and if the rate holds for the balance of the year, production in 1932 will be somewhere around $46,447,000.

HAS art, as considered in relation to the distressing economic situation, turned the corner? Is it entering a zone of greater security and is it about see better days again? There are current indications that seem to point that way.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Even those in France who most firmly believe in government of the people, by the people, for the people are beginning to wonder it it is not because the machine of democratic government is so slow and cumbersome that the world's affairs are just now in such a tangle.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 -- A fighting Carnegie Tech football team rose to its greatest stand of the season today to hold the powerful Pitt Panthers to a 6-0 victory in the nineteenth annual city championship struggle at the Pitt Stadium.

GENEVA, Nov. 18 -- Much stress has been laid on the force which the unanimity of the members of the Lytton Commission has given to their report on the Chino-Japanese conflict, which comes before the League of Nations Council Monday.

The issue of war debts transcend in interest all other problems no before the statesmen, of the world in particular world attention turn to the conference to take place next Tuesday between President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt at the White House.

From certain Republican authorities have come complaints about the sordid and materialistic nature of the Presidential election. What a pity that the voters disregarded large principles and thought only of bread and butter! Important issues of governmental policy were at stake.

With the prospect of $1,000,000,000 or more of new financing to be done by the United States Treasury before the end of the present fiscal year, to refund maturing obligations, aid in the balancing of the Federal budget, and to provide for the requirements of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the banking community is surveying closely the probable policies which may be adopted by the Treasury.

CHICAGO. WHEN the Century of Progress, Chicago's second world's fair, opens its gates next year, the visitors in their lighter moments will come upon a Midway Plaisance named after the amusement section which delighted, astonished and shocked some 27,500,000 people in 1893, but which will impress the elderly ones among them more by its differences from the original Midway than by its resemblances to it.

An event not yet materialized -- the meeting of the President and the President-elect at the White House next Tuesday afternoon at 4 o'clock -- entirely overshadowed all of last week's important developments. It is unprecedented, of fundamental gravity and importance, and it was arranged as simply as any other business conference.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 19 -- Like scores of other American cities, Rochester awoke the day after election to find the unbelievable had happened. True, the city had been expected to give Messrs. Roosevelt and Lehman the pluralities it did, but nobody looked for the Democratic, sweep to unseat Monroe County Republican Chairman Harry J. Bareham, something reform groups within and without party ranks tried to do for years and failed.

An armed robber held up the night superintendent of the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-seventh Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues, early yesterday morning and escaped with $1,000 in jewelry and $40 cash, which he took from a safe.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Bert Arnold, 16-year-old high school student, described as a "model boy," was sought by police today in the hope that he might be able to help in the solution of the brutal murder of his grandmother.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 19 -- Using its second stringers during most of the encounter, Tulane's Green Wave scored an easy 26-to-0 victory over the Sewanee Mountain Tigers today before 11,500 fans.

Oscar Davisson, young American sculptor, is having his first New York one-man show at the Ferargil Galleries. Although a graduate of Yale and an Oxford student, Mr. Davisson decided when he set out to become a sculptor to work without formal training at an art school, supplementing his experience by contacts with well-known sculptors.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Aldrich Rodger today will give the first of a series of Sunday afternoon receptions for their debutante daughter, Miss Mathilde Bruce Rodger, at 36 Gramercy Park.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some time ago THE TIMES printed a notice to the effect that Professor Jaime Sadis of the University of Salamanca had stated that Columbus received only $60 from the Crown of Spain for his first trip which led to the discovery of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Fresh light on the American attitude toward the Russian revolution is given in the third and final volume of diplomatic papers relating to Russia during the revolution in 1917-18, which was issued by the State Department today as part of the War Supplement Series of "Foreign Relations of the United States."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Nov. 12 were slightly under those of the preceding week but exceeded those of the week ended Oct. 29, according to the weekly survey of domestic conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

TRAVELERS along Fifth Avenue in the November sunshine cannot help having their eyes caught up to the sky by the towering mass of a great unfinished building which is set back in an open space so big that looking up at it is sensibly less a neck-breaking operation than looking up at most of our skyscrapers rising steeply from the sidewalk.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 -- Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, a proposal which has been sidetracked every year since the prohibition law was enacted, will be approved by an overwhelming vote by the delegates to the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor next week, according to forecasts made today by leaders who have canvassed the sentiment of the federation.

MANLIUS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- The Manlius School football team closed its season on Kallet Field today, routing the Raymond Riordon School eleven of Highland, 50 -- 0. The game was played in a downpour with the field a sea of mud, but despite frequent fumbles, Manlius pushed over eight touchdowns.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Rutgers displayed a powerful offensive to turn back Springfield by 18 -- 0 in a driving rain today.

THE new Metropolitan Opera season will open tomorrow evening with a performance of "Simon Boccanegra," with Lawrence Tibbett in the title role. Of the singers new to the Metropolitan this season five will make their debuts.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Loyal troops operating under General Manuel Trejo have recaptured the city of Santa Barbara from the rebels, it was officially reported today. The city was taken yesterday afternoon without any fighting, the government reported, and the rebels, consisting of Liberals defeated in the recent Presidential elections, retreated toward Gracuas.

MOTORISTS who have struggled through the traffic jams and delays common along the Lincoln Highway between Jersey City and Newark will welcome the opening, on Thanksgiving Day, of the magnificent new viaduct across the Newark Meadows.
PARIS WHEN our delegates to the Disarmament Conference unpacked their bags in Geneva last January, more than a few European officials wanted to know who Norman H. Davia was.

MARK SULLIVAN, in the fourth volume of "Our Times," arrives at last at what Elmer Davis has called "the peak year of human felicity" -- "good old 1913." It is, for Mr. Sullivan as for so many others who stood at Armageddon and battled for the Lord Roosevelt, the year that divided youth from age, sanguine hopes from dismayed perplexity, buoyancy from caution.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 DECIDEDLY the theatre scene in Boston is altered. No longer does the "theatrical business" speak of "another success in the city of successes." Instead, it counts the house anxiously and scrutinizes the box office narrowly.

TOKYO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- It was officially learned today that Japan will remind the Council of the League of Nations next week that Manchukuo is not the first State to be separated from its parent State and to win independence through the actions of another power.

"In spite of our large American stocks and the disorganized foreign market, copper is undoubtedly at the beginning of an era of recovery," according to Sam A. Lewisohn, active head of the Miami Copper Company and the Tennessee Corporation. "The extent and duration of the recovery will coincide with the recovery of our whole international economic situation, and because of its unique qualities copper may outstrip many other commodities in the revival," Mr. Lewisohn added.

MANILA, Oct. 17 -- Representative Butler B. Hare, author of a bill granting Philippine independence, has evoked considerable discussion in the Philippines through his flat refusal to show any interest in a Moro outbreak near Jolo which resulted in the death of more than fifty persons, among them a popular young Filipino liutenant of constabulary.

Capitalism had few friends among a group of ministers and Protestant Episcopal lay leaders at a luncheon forum yesterday at 99 Park Avenue under the auspices of the Church League for Industrial Democracy.

The transfer of the supervision of foreign students and teachers from the Department of Labor to the Office of Education in the Department of the Interior was urged yesterday by Dr. Stephen P. Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, at a meeting of the Conference on Immigration Policy at Town Hall.

Police of the Missing Persons Bureau said yesterday that no trace had been found of Verson W. Gooch of Wakefield, Mass., 54-year-old executive of the United Fruit Company in Boston, since he checked out of the Hotel Pennsylvania about 8 P.M. on Nov. 8, carrying a suitcase nearly four feet in length.

ATLANTA, Nov. 17 -- After a series of hold-ups which, strangely enough, followed the publication of an amazing list of physical and mental defects among Atlanta's policemen, more than 100 members of the police force volunteered for extra night service, and not a hold-up or shooting occurred Wednesday night.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- Striking as are the differences between the United States and Germany, the parallels are not less so. The agricultural situation in both countries shows identical features: inadequate money returns, mortgaged farms, the outcry against interest rates and the middlemen and the clamor for special protection.

A stockholder's suit alleging mismanagement of the funds of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, with headquarters at 61 Broadway, and asking for a receivership pending the action for an accounting from the officers, was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The death of Senator Jones at Seattle vacated the chairmanship of the Senate Appropriations Committee on the eve of a more than usually important session of Congress in which that committee's work will be outstanding in view of the necessity of economy in government operation.

Reviewers, young and old, who attended the first American recital given by Miss Poldi Mildner of Vienna yesterday afternoon in Town Hall left the occasion in some confusion, perturbation and a not unnatural wonder. For Miss Mildner, who is a Miss, according to the publicity agent's statements, of 17and who looks her years -- developed a quite incredible virtuoso technique and a virtuoso temperament which on several occasions swept her audience from its feet.

IN a conference for which there is no precise precedent in American history, the President and the President-elect will meet this week to discuss informally one of the great questions of foreign policy now before the country.

William Intermann of Evander Childs High School equaled the Public School Athletic League record for 100-yard free style swimming and narrowly missed the national interscholastio standard at the weekly series of dual meets for the league's Manhattan-Bronx senior high school championship in the 75-foot pool of George Washington High School yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17 -- The detective on a puzzling case today can command science to serve his purposes just about as far as can his imaginary counterpart between the covers of a book. That was demonstrated at the meeting of the International Association for Identification here this week.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The stock markets ended the week depressed and dull, under the influence of renewed weakness in sterling xchange on New York which fell to $3.28, against last night's closing at $3.30 1/2. British funds also declined.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- Two broadly defined alternative courses, each of them unpalatable and even injurious to the League of Nations, will confront the Assembly when it discusses the Lytton commission's report.

In a quick poll of Congress on the war debt issue, telegrams were sent each Senator and Representative asking whether they favored or opposed extension of the Hoover moratorium, with postponement of the interest payment due Dec. 15, and whether they favored or opposed revision or cancellation.

Columbia and Syracuse battled through the mud of Baker Field to a 0-0 deadlock yesterday before 10,000 spectators. Rain in varying intensity handicapped both teams and Field General Nick Dinunzio and Clifford Montgomery punted frequently and waited for breaks.

Whatever may be the outcome of the Cabinet crisis at Berlin, the events of the last six months permit one thing to be said. The collapse of German democracy, so often predicted, has not yet come to pass. The outlook for German democracy is by no means so gloomy as would appear on the surface of things.

Eight hundred patrons in the Horn Hardart automat in the basement of 1,441 Broadway, at the southwest corner of Forty-first Street, were thrown into an uproar late yesterday when a tall young man with an automatic pistol reached through the cashier's cage and seized a bag containing $2,800.

PIETRO MASCAGNI is working on a new opera, "Nero," according to an announcement in the foreign press. From his youth he has always had a fancy for this subject, having been attracted by the tragedy of the same name by Pietro Cossa, an Italian poet of the early nineteenth century, we are told.

DESPITE spectacular flights to break records, such as those of Hinkler, Amy Johnson and Scott, and occasional journeys for special purposes such as that of Kingsford-Smith last year carrying the Christmas mails, the fifth continent, Australia, with airlines of its own, has not as yet been knit into the picture of world air routes.

Several large retirements to be effected in future months featured the announcements of bonds called last week for redemption before their dates of maturity. Additions to the November list were few and consisted entirely of small lots of municipal bonds.
MADRID, Nov. 18 -- Catalonia will hold on Sunday the first election of a Catalan Parliament since 1705.

Veteran riders will predominate in the fifty-third international six-day bicycle race which is to start in Madison Square Garden a week from tonight. In the field of thirty cyclists, including outstanding stars of this country and from abroad, are twenty-two veterans of previous grinds here.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 -- In a cold, wintry and almost primitive setting, Notre Dame's green-shirted football squad, two complete teams, ground out a 12-to-0 victory over Navy today as 55,000 persons sat high in the Cleveland Municipal Stadium, braving the icy wind that blew in from the east and Lake Erie.

THE new Plymouth six, whose coming was announced recently by Walter P. Chrysler, is now on display by De Soto, Dodge and Chrysler dealers throughout the country. The four body models of the line are equipped with a 70-horsepower "floating power" engine and are built on wheelbase of 107 inches.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 12 -- The sum of about $1,677,034,000 has been paid as interest on loans contracted abroad by Brazil in the last ninety-two years.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- A new chapter in the story of the former close association between President Hoover and President-elec Roosevelt was brought to light today as they prepared to meet at the White House for a conference on war debts.

MANILA, Oct. 15 -- Dr. Emilio Sanson, supervising veterinarian of the Philippine Bureau of Animal Husbandry for the district of Zamboanga, has submitted the first formal report on the extraordinary saltwater cattle of the Sulu Islands.

The American merchant marine included 25,156 vessels of 15,838,655 gross tons at the close of the fiscal year on June 30, according to the annual report of A.J. Tyrer, Commissioner of Navigation, published yesterday. All types of documented vessels are included in this total.

Sedgewick Harvey, national junior 126-pound amateur champion, survived the semi-final round of the amateur boxing tournament at Madison Square Garden last night by scoring a knockout victory over Ed Robinson.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 19 -- Student anti-Japanese demonstrations in Shanghai, which were temporarily put down, are being formally revived tomorrow, when a large student demonstration is planned to voice a formal protest against the Lytton report to the League of Nations before discussion starts at Geneva Monday.

LONDON. OLD GOTHIC, old oak, old leather and old peers -- what more complete epitome of old Toryism could be imagined? In the House of Lords it finds a richly harmonious setting: in the crimson of the long benches, the dull gold of the walls and the subdued colors of the stained glass in the windows.

The refusal of Controller Charles W. Berry to honor legally issued vouchers for payments to subway contractors has completely upset a program under which operation of the Eighth Avenue subway would have been extended to the Borough Hall-Jay Street station in Brooklyn by Dec. 15, the Board of Transportation charged publicly yesterday.
A strain of super-trout is being developed in New Jersey, according to a report of Superintendent Charles O. Hayford, in charge of the State's hatchery at Hackettstown.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Clinton Scollard, the poet, whose verses have been enjoyed by American readers since they first made their appearance nearly half a century ago, died at his home here at 9 o'clock tonight of heart disease after a month's illness.

The New York Rangers will make their bow on the Madison Square Garden ice tonight when they play their first home game of the season in the National Hockey league. The blue-jerseyed skaters, who already have taken part in two games on the road, will make their New York start against the Toronto Maple Leafs, holders of the world's championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- High officials of the Federal Reserve System have agreed on a branch banking program and endorsed the plan of Eugene Meyer, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, for a unified backing system, according to the underptanding today.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 6 -- Two commissions appointed by the government to effect new commercial treaties with England and Germany are objects of much interest. Swedish export trade has suffered owing to the swift increase of tariff barriers in various countries and the general depression; problems of unemployment are growing.

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Boston College continued its string of victories against its home town rival, Boston University, today, registering a 21-to-6 triumph at Alumni Field. More than 10,000 attended, the largest assemblage ever at a B.C.-B.U. contest.

Revolt of the Goose. THE motorist goose that lays the golden eggs of gasoline taxes is cackling and clacking ominously, and may yet decide to quit, aware that in the end it will probably have its head chopped off anyhow.

JERICHO, L.I., Nov. 19.--Hunters owned by Townsend B. Martin won both the Willie Price Challenge Cup and the Butwell Challenge Cup in the point-to-point races held today over a flagged course on the properties of Middleton S. Burrill and Daniel Underbill, under the auspices of the Meadow Brook Hounds.

A MEETING ON DEBTS. From HERBERT HOOVER to Franklin D. Roosevelt. I AM prepared to deal with the subject [war debts] as far as it lies in the power of the Executive, but it must be our common wish to deal with this question in a constructive fashion for the common good of the country.

It is no figure of speech to say that the eyes of the world will be fixed upon Washington next Tuesday afternoon when the President and the President-elect sit down together to talk over the foreign-debt situation. If only on account of the unprecedented nature of the proceeding, the interest which it is arousing would be explained.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Disquieting crop reports on wheat are coming from Argentina and houses that received the cable messages were on the buying side today in the Board of Trade here. The news and the prevailing low level of prices caused a change in sentiment in some quarters.

GEORGE COULOURIS, who supplies his share of the artful duplicity in Gilbert Miller's production of "The Late Christopher Bean" as the mysterious Mr. Tallant, is, despite his Greek name and indeterminate countenance, an Englishman.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Sweetheart on Parade, dapple gray mare owned by Mrs. W.P. Roth of Redwood City, Cal., won the five-gaited saddle horse grand championship, most coveted title of the American Royal Livestock and Horse Show, for the second straight year tonight.

A one of our two or three leading popularizers of biology Paul de Kruif has evolved a formula whose success one studies with interest in each new book. He makes of his scientists men whose perils are sometimes equal to those of the old Western front, and whose excitements are comparable with those of explorers entering unknown seas.
