Wall Street was interested in the statistical record of yesterday's stock market because of the small group of stocks to which trading was confined. Only 313 of the listed issues were dealt in, which made the market the narrowest in this respect since August 9, 1924.

Plans for the formation of a central bank for savings banks in this State, proposed at the convention of the savings bankers last September and approved last week by the joint Legislative Committee on Banking, took definite shape yesterday with the announcement of an outline of organization of the institution.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Former Governor Edward C. Stokes, who served as Republican State campaign chairman, declared today that the theft of ballots in Newark would indicate that President Hoover had the right to feel that an honest count might show that he had carried New Jersey.

Criticizing the President. The President of the United States, whoever he may be, is entitled to the respect and support of every citizen, regardless of party. Captious criticism and ruthless abuse, such as all of our Presidents have suffered, disgrace us in the eyes of the world.
NEW planes are being produced this year by two of the well-known and veteran builders of aircraft.
Food for Beasts. Of civilization in Philadelphia, Pa., as it flourishes today, it is quite conceivable that a historian of the year 2132 may write briefly as follows:

THE Bermuda Biological Station, which has served William Beebe and his staff as a base during their recent dives into the ocean deeps, is an active centre for biologists and oceanographers. Established by an international body of scientists, with the cooperation of the Bermuda Government and the Rockefeller Foundation, it has attracted students and research workers from many scattered places.

TO the manifold inconveniences which beset a poor but honest citizen who tries to worm his way through the phalanx of gleaming shirt-fronts and female backs which regularly appear at opening nights in the theatre you may add one more menace -- a menace which has made its appearance within the past two years, at best.

Calvin Coolidge will be invited to speak for the Protestant faith, Governor-elect Herbert H. Lehman for the Jewish faith and former Governor Alfred E. Smith for the Catholic faith at a proposed dinner of the Interfaith Committee, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, announced yesterday.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 19 -- Duke University won its first game from the University of North Carolina since 1893 today. The Blue Devils took the breaks and slightly out-drove the Tar Heels to win, 7 to 0.

Because today has been designated Unemployment Relief Sunday by the Clergymen's Division of the Gibson committee, virtually every pastor in the city will devote at least a part of a sermon to a plea to help the work of this committee. As Thanksgiving is next Thursday many ministers, priests and rabbis will deliver Thanksgiving sermons and point out special ways to assist the needy.

BERLIN THE jubilee exhibition of portraits painted by the 85-year-old Max Liebermann proves one of the finest collective showings of the century. Here we get a complete impression of this complete painter, who although not yet definitely classified in the history of art (there is a dispute regarding the number of stars to be affixed to his name) still must be counted among the best representatives of German Impressionism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Glancing over the list of obituaries in The Journal of the American Medical Association for the week of Nov. 5, I was appalled to learn that five phjysicians had committed suicide. In a total of seventy-six, slightly more than 6 per cent.

A SEARCHLIGHT drill was held recently in honor of Brig. Gen. W.E. Cole, commanding the Hawaiian Separate Coast Artillery Brigade. All lights on the main post were darkened, and simultaneously twenty-seven anti-aircraft searchlights, each having the high power of 800,000,000 candles, illuminated the sky.
MONTREAL, Nov. 19 -- The Montreal Maroons defeated Joe Simpson's New York American, six, 4 -- 1, tonight with a fine three-goal rally in the overtime period which broke a 1-1 tie.

A TRAVELER journeying to these shores from foreign lands remote most frequently approaches New York through that waterway known as the Narrows and has the experience of beholding a veritable city of dreams arise before his sea-weary eyes like a vision come out of the sky.

Slightly lower prices, on the average, were recorded in the listed bond market yesterday for domestic issues of all classifications. Foreign loans, led by the German issues, pointed higher in the two-hour trading period. Total transactions in bonds on the Stock Exchange amounted to only $3,687,000, compared with $4,464,000 on the previous Saturday.

ATLANTA, Nov. 19 -- "A lynchless South in 1933" was the goal set by the central council of the Association of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching, which closed its annual meeting here today.

ITALY'S recent amnesty, providing for diminished sentences or complete freedom for more than 2,000 political prisoners, draws attention to the host of men in various parts of the world who are serving prison terms of some kind for their political activities.
LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Football games played in the British Isles today resulted as follows:

TO write adequately about a book by Osbert Sitwell demands a review in the Sitwellian manner. The best conceivable review about "Winters of Content" would be written by its author. How otherwise than in words of like coinage is this book to be praised and its peculiar charms reproduced?

THE whole literate world does honor this year to a man born 300 years ago and to a mind that has never died, that is increasingly giving life to other minds. To say that this tribute is paid to Baruch, or Benedict, Spinoza, born in Amsterdam on Nov. 24, 1632, and dead at The Hague forty-four years later after a life not marked by many striking external events, is not to say enough.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 17 -- Three candidates for the Presidency of the United States visited Salt Lake City during the recent campaign. Governor Roosevelt made this city the point of delivery of one of the few major speeches of his tour to the Far West.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is advisable that the next Congress re-examine the facts relating to the Hoover Dam, and particularly the economic and financial features of this huge risk. Aside from the temporary local benefits resulting from the expenditures, it seems increasingly doubtful if this enterprise will be self-liquidating, and it may prove to be but another Elephant Butte and of scant benefit north of the Mexican border.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 19 -- Trailing by one touchdown as late as the middle of the third quarter, the West Virginia University eleven finally broke loose to defeat Davis and Elkins, 25 -- 12, today. The contest was played before a small crowd and on a muddy field.

BELGRADE, Nov. 18 -- Despite the fog of censorship, there are many indications that the view of the banned Serbian and Croatian parties is correct -- that the dictatorial hand, although still gripping Yugoslavia, is gradually withering.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 -- After twelve lean and hungry years, the Democrats of Missouri once again have caught aromatic whiffs from the pie counter and so clamorous has become the chorus of job seekers that Judge Guy B. Park, Governor-elect, went on a hunting trip a few days after election and left no forwarding address.
THE broadcasters are warned by Federal Radio Commissioner Harold A. Lafount that they are "selling their birthright for a mess of pottage."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- The tradition of Tale's predilection for covering itself with glory in the ruck of a rain-soaked field asserted itself again at the expense of Harvard today as the Elis gained their most decisive victory over the Crimson in thirty years.

WHEN the biographee emerges from the clouds of wordy sentiment which hover around this story of his life he is revealed as a wiry little Sealyham, with, seemingly, every wire charged with electricity. Bunch of Black-adder is his name, with a prideful pedigree behind it, despite some rather unsatisfactory bench points, such as a pigeon breast and an un- dershot jaw.

Efforts on the part of chain stores and other retail organizations to scale down rental charges, particularly the instances recently in which resort has been had to bankruptcy, have centred attention on the status and treatment accorded merchandise creditors in failures of this type.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Traversing the long road which leads from hope to disappointment in one short week, leading British newspapers tomorrow will carry Washington and New York dispatches in which their correspondents indicate Congress is unlikely to extend the moratorium on war debts and that public sentiment in the United States demands their collection on the due date, Dec. 15.

ONE of the outstanding musical events of next month will be the festival concert to be given at Carnegie Hall on the night of Dec. 7 in aid of the Edward MacDowell Association, Inc. It is in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., and is being sponsored by distinguished men and women, many of whom are noted as patrons of art.

WHEN the President and the President-elect of the United States confer on intergovernmental debts at the White House this week, they will meet as old acquaintances who have been in harness together before. Their meeting sets a precedent in American statesmanship, and as such it will doubtless be historic.

HOLLYWOOD REALISM was found in new form during recent days when Fox, in shooting the Armistice Day sequences of "Cavalcade," staged the action on the day and hour of the anniversary with marked effect upon the players.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Professor Albert Einstein said tonight that the idea of cosmic space expanding, like a rubber balloon, the surface of which is pushed outward uniformly in all directions, might have been put forward sooner but that nobody had had the courage to do so until astronomy provided evidence for the belief.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 17 -- Election landslides are no respecters of persons. The one which engulfed Indiana the other day not only propelled Senator James Eli Watson out of public life but deprived him of the satisfaction of leading his ticket. Even President Hoover, whose political acumen has caused many a hearty Watsonian laugh, and a novice at the game, Raymond S. Springer, the G.O.P. nominee for Governor, polled more votes than did the veteran.

Too late, unfortunately, for the campaign but full of promise for the future is the discovery of the secret of oratory. The method is far from as simple as the kissing of the Blarney Stone, but once mastered must be very filling. In The Quarterly Journal of Speech Mr. RAYMOND H. BARNARD presents the significant results of "An Objective Study of the Speeches of Wendell Phillips."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 19 -- It was fourth down, 4 yards to go for goal, with 39 seconds remaining in the first half today, when Harry Newman, Michigan quarterback, decided to stake his team's chances for an undisputed Big Ten title on his right foot.

AN effulgent beam of hope for the aging is shed by Dr. Walter Miles of Yale University, who reported his investigations of the abilities of older men before the annual conference of the Personnel Research Federation here last week.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- Twelve thousand stock corporations which have not filed an annual franchise tax return during the last five years are about to be dissolved.

The Golden Rule Association made public yesterday its list of twenty-one economy menus which would provide for a family of five average Americans, including two adults and three children, wholesome meals for a week at a cost of $8.88. The menus were prepared by Miss Clara Mae Taylor of the nutrition department of Teachers College, Columbia University, in collaboration with an advisory committee of home economics experts.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 19 -- Auburn's rejuvenated Tigers virtually clinched their first Southern Conference title today when they rallied to defeat Georgia, 14 to 7. A crowd of 12,000 saw the game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- General economic conditions improved little in the last week in foreign countries covered by the weekly survey made public today by the Commerce Department.

OF the two monographs which form this volume, the first, by Professor S. Kohn, is a study of the cost of the war to Russia in human lives, and the second, by Baron A. F. Meyendorff, formerly Vice President of the Russian Duma, is an account of the effects of the war upon the peasants, industrial workers and foreign investors.

OF course, in an ordinary autobiography it is natural for the author and convenient for the reader to have things set down in chronological order. In no sense are these memoirs ordinary. Volumes I, II and III were written in accordance with the preconceived hypothesis that Germany could have prevented the World War if von Bulow had been Chancellor in the Autumn of 1914.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Commonwealth of Massachusetts has a law which permits the submission of "public questions" to the voters on the official ballot on the application of 200 voters in any representative district. Under this law, at the election on Nov. 8, the ballots in eleven representative districts in Massachusetts contained the following:

Award of 298 scholarships to students in the three tipper classes of Harvard College was announced last night by the committee of scholarships of Harvard College. The awards which total $99,284, or an average of about $330 for each student, have been based primarily on high scholarship, and each of the students is on the "Dean's List" of honor rank.

Jamaica High captured the seventh annual New York Stock Exchange interscholastic rifle meet at the range of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, Brooklyn, yesterday, compiling a total of 1,021 points. Abraham Lincoln finished second with 973. Brooklyn Tech, with 969, placed third, and Richmond Hill, with 965, fourth.

OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 19 -- The powerful La Salle Military Academy football machine concluded its regular campaign with an unbeaten and untied record in eight games by routing the Mount St. Michael's High School of the Bronx, 35 -- 0, today. A driving rain did not hamper the playing of the winners, who got off to an early start by recording fifteen points in the first Quarter and thirteen more in the following session.

Acting Mayor McKee denied yesterday that he was encouraging any movement aimed at making him a candidate for the Mayor's office next year, contradicting a report that had become current in political circles.

Industry as a whole has as much reason to rejoice in the award of the Nobel Prize to JDR. IRVING LANGMUIR as the General Electric Company, in whose lab- oratories the conducted investigations that won him world-wide fame. When Dr. WILLIS R. WHITNEY established the laboratories about a quarter of a century ago and recruited the best physicists and chemists that he could find in universities, scientists freely uttered their misgivings.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Material purchases amounting to more than $42,000,000 will De made by the Chrysler Corporation to be used in the manufacture of the new low-priced Plymouth six, according to a statement authorized here today by Walter P. Chrysler.

ONE of the trends manifested in this radio season is the invasion of the motion-picture realm by broadcasting artists. When a year ago a rush from the microphone to the vaudeville circuits began, the aerial performers proved to be box-office attractions at the variety houses.

New York City recently escaped financial dangers in a breath-taking manner, but the hazards are by no means over, and the next six months will be critical ones. For the city is still in the hardly enviable position of having the world's largest municipal budget and the world's largest municipal debt.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 17 -- Kentucky politicians are gasping over the unprecedented magnitude of the vote for Governor Roosevelt, who swept the State by approximately 190,000 plurality. Four years ago Herbert Hoover won here by 177,000.

A NEW common language for all the nations of the earth comes up for attention. Unlike Volapuk, Esperanto, Ido and the many other unnatural systems of talk which the invention of man has put forward in the past, it is a ready made and living language that has been in use a long time.

Democratic leaders throughout the State are eagerly awaiting the return of Governor-elect Lehman from his holiday in the South. With his return they expect to gain some light on his policy regarding the filling of places at the head of the State administrative departments, and, incidentally, what they may expect in the way of patronage.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Washington and Jefferson's schedules for three varsity Winter sports have been announced by Wilbur Henry, director of athletics. The Winter program is one of the most ambitious and extensive ever undertaken by the Presidents.

Asserting that British and American policies diverge seriously on several major international issues, Lieut. Commander J.M. Kenworthy, British authority on naval affairs and former member of Parliament, in an article in December Current History entitled "Where Britain and America Disagree," warns that feeling between the countries is not good, and that "a disservice is done by not recognizing the fact frankly."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Three Burn Pansy, a white and black bitch owned by Mr. and Mrs. George E. Watson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and handled by Mr. Watson, today won the open all-age stake for English springer spaniels at the annual field trials of the American Spaniel Club.

Information yesterday from sources close to Governor Roosevelt was to the effect that if a struggle comes next year between Tammany and Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, Mr. Roosevelt would side with Mr. McKee.

ROYAL EDITORIAL "WE." A PROPERLY starched British Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary stood before a dark, bearded Emperor last week and informed him orally that if the absolute-constitutional monarch could not maintain order in his own territory Britain would be compelled to take what was euphemistically described as "appro- priate action."

Twenty gunners took part in the turkey shoot of the New York A.C. at Travers Island yesterday. T.H. Lewis won the High Scratch Cup with a card of 91 out of a possible 100 targets. The second scratch cup went to S.B. Masten, who had 86. D.L. Taylor was next with 85.

IN order to arouse an intelligent public interest in cancer, which must now be regarded as humanity's worst scourge, the New York City Cancer Committee prepared last year a pictorial exhibit comprising a series of charts that showed the development of medicine and surgery in their relation to cancer from the earliest times to the present.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- For many weeks the health of Premier MacDonald has been discussed privately as a factor in British politics. Periodical warnings by his physicians that he must spare his eyes and conserve his strength and energy have been seized upon by political enemies as a signal that he might soon be eliminated.

TECHNICIANS who worked on the screen production of "Rasputin," which may follow "Strange Interlude" at the Astor Theatre, were faced with the problem of reproducing buildings from pre-war Moscow, as well as the details to do with court coronation, state reception and the private life of Russia's regal family.

APROPRIATELY timed for Thanksgiving week is the official reopening of Philipse Manor Hall at Yonkers tomorrow evening by the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society, custodian of the famous Colonial house.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- Anglo-Soviet relations, marked by growing tension in the past six weeks, have now reached a stage of quite acrid controversy in the press of both countries, and there is a corresponding state of ill feeling.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Tale defeated Harvard in two soccer games today and played a scoreless tie in a third. In the varsity contest Yale won, 2 to 0, scoring both goals in the second half. Following a close first half, Yale rallied to its most brilliant form in the third period.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index shows a further small decline to 55.1 for the week ended Nov. 12 from 55.2 for the preceding week. Although, with one slight interruption, the index has now been declining for four weeks, the net result has been the loss of less than one point.

THE recent cut in the price of standard steel rails from $43 to $40 a ton follows an almost constant decline in the amount of rails bought each year since 1926. In that year American railroads used about 3,085,000 gross tons, or more than had been consumed in any previous year since 1910.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- Bolivia is ready to submit the Chaco frontier dispute to free and ample arbitration whenever Paraguay is ready to agree upon the zone to be arbitrated, provided Paraguay cede a port on the Paraguay River to her before arbitration is begun, according to well-informed unofficial Bolivian sources here in constant communication with members of the government at La Paz.
METROPOLITAN MUSEUM -- The Friedsam collection, placed on public view Tuesday, remaining until May 1. Reviewed on this page last Sunday.

Samuel Greenberg, who with Harry Stein was acquitted more than a year ago of the murder in February, 1931, of Vivian Gordon, on the eve of her scheduled appearance as a witness before the Appellate Division inquiry into the police vice squad, was a prisoner again last night at Police Headquarters.

The first concert of the second series of children's concerts given by Ernest Schelling, as lecturer and conductor of these occasions, took place yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall. The concert was devoted to the early history of the concerto, with the Fugue from Beethoven's String Quartet, opus 59, No. 3, as a conclusion.

As an outgrowth, of what police said was the fourth attempt in two years by various swindlers to obtain money from secretaries to executives of the advertising firm of N.W. Ayer Co., 500 Fifth Avenue, through collections from faked purchases of "valuable rugs," Francesco Gonzales, 28 years old, a taxicab driver, of 1,351 Fifth Avenue was held in $25,000 bail yesterday for a hearing tomorrow on suspicion of attempted grand larceny.

Four women passengers were injured yesterday morning when a northbound Willis Avenue trolley car, operated by Raymond Petty, and a truck driven by Eugene Bushel of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., collided on Third Avenue just south of 179th Street, the Bronx.

The urgent plea of Mr. THOMAS W. LAMONT, that banks throughout the country hitherto separated from the sustaining influence of the Federal Reserve should join, the system, was not only timely but has been powerfully reinforced by the experience of the last two years.

To the Music Editor: In your issue of Nov. 13 a "Briton" begs "a little of your patience and your space to endorse the courageous statements of Walter Anderson with regard to the claims of Dr. Walter Damrosch."
The Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn will be sponsor of the Brooklyn Junior Horse Show Saturday afternoon and evening, Dec. 17. It will be an open show for riders not more than 18 years old.

Formation of a corporation to finance the purchase of new equipment for manufacturers, permitting the latter to repay the costs of the improvements out of savings made possible, was announced here yesterday by R.G. Macy, president of the Improved Industries Corporation, of 521 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A plan for a $700,000,000 reduction in government expenditures designed to obviate the necessity for new taxes in balancing the budget in 1934 was determined upon by President Hoover and his Cabinet at an extraordinary session at the White House, today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 12 amounted to 537,093 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 51,290 cars fewer than in the preceding week, 152,867 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 291,930 cars fewer, than in the corresponding week two years ago.

The week ended yesterday with the markets in a somewhat more cheerful spirit. Stocks began by declining slightly, but the movement was rather sharply reversed before the closing, leaving numerous respectable net advances for the day. Along with Stock Exchange prices, wheat and corn went higher.

BY his fine flight from Floyd Bennett Field, New York, to the United Airport at Burbank, Cal., in 12 hours 33 minutes elapsed time, Colonel Roscoe Turner last week dramatized once more the tremendous increase in air speeds of which the last two years have been witness.
MADRID, Nov. 19.--A fishing vessel's radio apparatus saved it from Moorish pirates today by bringing two Spanish warships, a mail ship and a fishing boat to its rescue.

The total cost of government in the United States is estimated at nearly $15,000,000,000 annually, or almost one-third of the "depression period" national income of upward of $50,000,000,000 in a series of cost-of-government charts made public yesterday by the National Committee for Economy in Government and the National Association of Manufacturers of the United States.

IT was Novalis, himself not wholly negligible as a philosopher, who first called Spinoza "a God-intoxicated man": words which have stuck ever since, and, now that the three hundredth anniversary of Spinoza's birth is being celebrated, words which are being examined afresh.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Amos Alonzo Stagg ended his record-breaking football run today but there was no story book finish.

WHEN Ann Harding finishes her work with Leslie Howard in "The Animal Kingdom" she will be featured in "Christopher Strong," a novel by Gilbert Frankau, which RKO-Radio has purchased for talking film production.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y,. Nov. 19 -- A barn dance and entertainment was held tonight at the Manor Club by the civic section of the club. Mrs. Charles Mills Russell was in charge, assisted by:
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Business is getting down to brass tacks.

Momosaku Hata, representative from the Gunma District of Japan in the House of Representatives of the Imperial Japanese Diet, sailed early yesterday for Europe on the Europa. Mr. Hata, whose constituency is one of the largest silk raising districts in Japan, will attend the sessions of the League of Nations as a private observer.

ATLANTA, Nov. 17 -- If, when President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt comes to Georgia next week, there is lacking something of the fire of enthusiasm which greeted his pre-election visit here, he will understand that we all looked on him as already elected, but when it was certain that Governor Roosevelt was the winner, the Atlanta Constitution's famous little brass cannon was brought out to signal another Democratic victory.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Stuyvesant, Fairchester, Boston Reserves and the Wheaton College Varsity were the winners in the second day's play of the annual Northeast sectional field hockey tournament at Wellesley College today.

DR. MORRIS FISHBEIN, versatile and energetic editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association and militant foe of medical quackery, in this, his latest book, has again attacked his ancient enemies with customary vigor. He has let loose a flood of satire, ridicule and indignant denunciation in his stanch battle to mitigate the harassments to which the medical profession has been subjected since early days.

The government's Panama Mall Railroad Company, which operates a ship line between the Panama Canal Zone and the United States, is termed "a most uncompromising enemy to privately owned American shipping" in a statement filed by the American Steamship Owners' Association with the Shannon Congressional committee.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 19 -- Here for a week-end rest before his conference with President Hoover, Franklin D. Roosevelt decided today that he would prolong his stay in Washington next week to allow for conferences with Democratic Congressional leaders.

TINY waves, which astonished radio experts on March 31, 1931, when words were carried across the English Channel between Calais and Dover, will now be used by the British Air Ministry in connection with cross-Channel flying services, according to the International Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Rain caused the postponement of numerous collegiate and scholastic contests scheduled yesterday in four sports -- football, cross-country, soccer and field hockey. The metropolitan schoolboy ranks were the hardest hit, more than twenty gridiron games being among those deferred because of the unfavorable weather conditions.

IT is not surprising that several of the German writers who have praised this book should speak of its fairy-tale atmosphere. For the world it presents has life for us, not because we recognize it but because we gradually succumb to its charm and voluntarily cease to question its oddities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Georgetown and Bucknell elevens played to a 6 -- 6 tie today on a field of mud and water.

Charges of "cruel and inhuman punishments" alleged to have teen inflicted within the last four years in Georgia prisons and prison camps on white and Negro convicts are contained in a letter sent yesterday to the Georgia prison commissioners by the American Civil Liberties Union and signed on its behalf by twelve prominent persons, which, speaks of "the possibility of some action in the Federal courts based upon the Federal constitutional guarantee."
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 19 -- Marquette outplayed the lighter Washington and Jefferson team here today to win a 6-to-0 victory before a small crowd that braved a temperature of 20 degrees.

WITH the election out of the way, theatrical business has begun to improve. Over at the Leblang ticket office they bring forth statistics to show that attendance in the playhouses during the past week was better than for the corresponding period last year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Hun School's unbeaten and untied eleven vanquished Penn Military College freshmen of Chester, Pa., 35 to 0, today for its fifth straight victory. The game was played on a muddy field.
WHITTIER, N.C., Nov. 19 -- Leaving this tiny mountain village buzzing with rivalry for the credit of having first recognized him, Colonel Robins departed from here at 6:30 o'clock this morning.

IT is not so much as an authority puppets and puppet shows, which he is, but as a merry adventurer along quiet ways that Walter Wilkinson comes before us. Many are already acquainted with his genial "Puppets in Yorkshire" and "Vagabonds and Puppets," to which is now to be added "Peep Show."

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Stockholders of the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company met tonight and approved by a large majority the arrangements which the bank entered into by which most of its business was transferred to the new City National Bank and Trust Company.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 19 -- After the Yale-Harvard game at New Haven this afternoon, club members entertained at a dinner dance for their guests at Round Hill Club. The ballroom was decorated in the colors and pennants of both colleges.

A number of changes have been made in the personnel of the trial boards of the American Kennel Club. These are the bodies which function in various sections of the country, acting in most of the local cases and presenting their findings to the board of directors for further procedure.

THE sound film is now gaining a recognized place in colleges, as was indicated last week by the showing here and in Chicago of two films, specially made for the purpose, "The Molecular Theory of Matter" and "Oxidation and Reduction," sponsored by the University of Chicago.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Army wound up its home season today by winning a close game from West Virginia Wesleyan by 7 to 0. Only a few hundred spectators sat in a torrential downpour which prevailed through the greater part of the contest.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 11 -- Peru and Chile have just signed a commercial agreement to cover trading through the frontier between Tacna and Arica. The agreement provides for the appointment of joint commissions to study the basis for a definite treaty.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- H.G. Wells told millions of British radio listeners tonight of the horrors in store for them "if we go on without taking hold of the war problem much more courageously than we have done hitherto."

BERKELEY, Cal., Nov. 19 -- Clicking for the first time this season in a major game, Stanford University held the California eleven to a scoreless tie today before a crowd of 75,000. California was the 10-8 favorite before the contest.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Upsala College closed its season with a victory over Wagner today, 8 -- 6, the game starting on a water-soaked field and ending in darkness.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- An inferential but sharp criticism of a policy of considering war debts a separate and individual factor in world economics was made today in a statement by Senator Hull.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 19 -- The Colombian Minister here, Ricardo Sanchez Ramirez, declares that the Peruvian capture in September of the Colombian frontier town of Leticia and the subsequent international complications resulted from a thwarted attempt of a land owner to sell a farm called La Victoria to Colombia at an excessive price.

SEVERAL dances to be given in the near future for various philanthropic causes are now occupying the attention of younger members of society. In the current week, with its Thanksgiving holidays given over largely to the first of the season's debutante dances in town, there are a few parties arranged for charity.

THERE was a fairly sharp upturn in retail trade last week, particularly toward the close. Business was well distributed through the apparel and home furnishing departments. Men's wear volume advanced. Special sales, after a dormant period, regained some of their former popularity.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Their faces caked with mud, the Harvard players plunged under the showers with more than the usual zest after today's game. No one was injured and except for a natural feeling of disappointment, the Crimson squad seemed more than happy that the Tale fray had passed into history.

MANY men and women prominent in the social and professional life of New York are cooperating to make the International Toy Carnival, that opens on Nov. 28 at Essex House, one of the most joyous events of the pre-holiday season. The Association of Music School Settlements and the Music Division of the National Federation of Settlements benefit from the carnival, which will continue for a week in the ballroom of Essex House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES not long ago Ephraim Cheever, in his reply to Charles B. Reynolds, says: "But in so far as my knowledge extends, there is no surviving record of such births" -- referring to children born in St. Augustine between 1565-97.

WHEN Radio City went on the air for the first time last Sunday listeners heard a novel electrical piano played by Vladamar Padwa, who came from Germany to teach pianists associated with WEAF-WJZ to master the unique instrument.

ROME, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Senator Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of the wireless, told the National Research Council today that arrangements had been made with the Aeronautical and Navy Departments for simultaneous studies of penetrating rays, the stratosphere and the depths of the sea.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 19.--Purdue's Boilermakers ran and passed their way to a 25-to-7 victory over Indiana University here today, completing an undefeated football season in which a tie game prevented their sharing the Western Conference title.

SOME of the notables who have inadvertently contributed to this Symposium of Sappy Remarks are dumb and some, like Mahatma Gandhi, who announces "I was never made to be ornamental," are dumb as foxes. But most of them are plain dumb or have a transcendent sense of humor.

BEAVER FALLS, Fa., Nov. 19 -- Geneva's flashy eleven failed to let a muddy field stop its brilliant play today, and with two long runs and a 62-yard sustained drive put over a 19-0 victory on Westminster.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Allocation of 105,000,000 francs of the 7,000,000,000-franc national-equipment measure to the Ministry of Beaux Arts has permitted Under-Secretary Jean Mistler to draw up an elaborate plan for the restoration of France's historic buildings and monuments, which at the same time will favor the reduction of unemployment.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Wesleyan defeated the University of Rochester eleven by 13-0 today, Captain Larry Schlums playing the star role.

Bringing to an official close the first season under Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan's regime, Manhattan's football warriors fought a stubborn defensive battle yesterday over the rain-soaked turf of the Yankee Stadium and checked Holy Cross in a scoreless tie.

GENEVA AT the end of the World War the victorious governments, led by the United States, wrote into the covenant of the League of Nations this indictment of a branch of their national industry and this pledge:

PARIS ONE expects to find wearable rather than sensational clothes in the midseason collections, and this season has not fallen short of the promise. In the couture showings are many clothes that every woman would like to own, though they often appear to be so simple that they defy description.

Salary cuts of 10 per cent for the bulk of the city's 148,000 employes and the consolidation of various city departments and bureaus will be discussed at City Hall by the finance committee of the Board of Aldermen tomorrow just before it holds a public hearing on the 1933 budget of $557,141,022.73.

MR. PEARSON, whose activities at the Design Workshop of the New School for Social Research hare been followed with interest for several years, has written a book that is clearly thought and clearly written; an exceedingly helpful book, which should be read by every student of art, and in fact, by all who wish really to "experience" works of art rather than to pass them by with vague understanding or with no understanding at all.

RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 7 -- A recent law establishing the eight-hour day, put in force in Brazil on Nov. 1, compels all business establishments to close their doors between 11:30 and 1:30 P.M. During those hours the city of Rio de Janeiro presents the unique aspect of a city of vacant buildings, with most of the population living in the streets.

YUNGAY, Peru MOUNT HUASCARAN appears to be the highest mountain of Peru and the third highest on the American continent. Nothing more positive can be said in the present state of the orographic survey of the Andes.
CHESTERTOWN, Md., Nov. 19 -- St. Joseph College came from Philadelphia to win its first football game of the season today when Washington College was defeated, 12 to 7, in a sea of mud.

PLANS are going forward rapidly for Ye Olde English Faire, which will be held under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York Nov. 30 and Dec. 1 and 2 at the Biltmore, for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women in Ossining, N.Y.

THE publication of Volume VI of the "Dictionary of Anonymous and Pseudonymous English Literature" brings to a conclusion a project of the highest importance for bookmen. The "Dictionary" appeared originally in four volumes between the years 1882 and 1888, and for long years it was sought after by students, who knew it by the name of its compilers, Samuel Haikett and John Laing.

IN those long-ago pre-war days before unbridled enthusiasm had decided to find a royal road to sobriety by means of the law, there was much and fruitful effort to reach the same result by education. And then all that endeavor was forgotten in the midst of the uproar for and against the prohibition movement.

The decided trend to repeal of prohibition in the last ten days led executives in several industries which are large users of industrial alcohol to hope that their troubles with this commodity will soon be over. For fourteen years now, one executive said yesterday, the chemical, drug, paint and varnish industries and other trades have been subjected to unceasing annoyance and worry, not to mention extra costs, by the control of alcohol.

BUFFALO, Nov. 17 -- With the clearing away of the smoke of battle, perhaps the most interesting fact disclosed by detailed examination of the election returns in this corner of the country is that the citizens registered a greater degree of approval for President Hoover than for any other Republican.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- Winston Guest's Meadow Brook four tallied five goals in the fifth and sixth chukkers today to defeat Santa Paula, 9 to 6, in the first game of the polo series between the United States and Argentina for the Cup of the Americas.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Without any apparent reason in view of the unsettled conditions in finance concerning the budget and the war debts, together with the German Cabinet crisis, the Paris Bourse today ended the week with a good session. For a Saturday, trading was active, and both international and domestic stocks advanced.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 4 -- Opposition to the transfer of the Alaska Road Commission from the War Department to the Interior Department, manifested by a large element of Alaska's citizenry when legislation was first introduced in Congress last Winter, has slackened little if any in the months since the transfer actually took place.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 19 -- In biting cold weather Northwestern closed its season today by beating Iowa, 44 to 6, handing the Hawkeyes, who have not won a game in Western Conference competition since 1929, their worst rout of the season.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Walter Crotty of the North Medford Club won the twenty-seventh annual New England A.A.U. six-mile cross-country race, held over a rain-swept course at Franklin Park today. The victor's time was 34:05.

Princess Henry XXXIII of Reuss gave a dinner followed by dancing last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for, her debutante step-daughter, Princes Marie Louise of Reuss, and her goddaughter, Miss Lucile Brokaw, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Brokaw.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES prints a letter from W. F. McSparran, Pennsylvania farmer, relative to the tariff and its relation to the present condition of American agriculture.

PARIS, Nov. 2 A FEATURE of this Autumn's theatrical season in Paris is the flood of adaptations of foreign plays. They hold the stage at no less than eight leading theatres, to say nothing of the old Bouffes-du-Nord, where Yvette Guilbert, who has this week received the ribbon of the Legion of Honor, began her career forty-seven years ago in melodrama, before she took to singing songs.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 19 -- Its last desperate drive for a touchdown stalled by an Illinois defense that was just as desperate, Ohio State called Mickey Vuchinich back into action today to place-kick the Buckeyes to a 3-to-0 triumph in a thrilling Western Conference football final.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 19 -- The Texas Christian University eleven continued its steady campaign toward the Southwest Conference football championship today, defeating Rice Institute, 16 to 6.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The Goncourt Academy will be established soon in a permanent headquarters in the former Paris residence of the brothers Goncourt, founders of the most important literary society in France after the French Academy.

MAJOR GEN. BENJAMIN D. FOULOIS, Chief of the Air Corps, in his annual report for the fiscal year ended June 30, reveals that the Army Air Corps is 396 flying officers under its strength and that the only method of bringing the Air Corps to its rated strength, now provided in the regulations, is by transfer from some other branch of service.

MR. TARKINGTON harks back a little to the Tarkington of "Monsieur Beaucaire" in this, which the jacket ineptly calls a "gay romance of England in the days of Charles the Merry," but it is a quite mature Tarkington; this is a novel rather than a romance, and it is not at all "gay."

DEPARTING from precedent in his Thanksgiving proclamation this year, President Hoover called attention to the first Presidential Thanksgiving proclamation that of Washington in 1789, which came at a dark hour in the history of the infant Republic.

THAT there is no formula for motion-picture fame was the conclusion arrived at on the Paramount lot after a look at the sixteen stars who make up the cast of "If I Had a Million." Charles Laughton came to Broadway from England and attracted film producers with his acting in the play, "Payment Deferred."

With Palmer Ekeland scoring all three touchdowns, the Manual Training eleven conquered Brooklyn Technical High School, 19 -- 0, in the eleventh annual meeting between the teams at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn. A crowd of 1,000 braved the rain which fell throughout the encounter.

The Rev. Albert J. Beyer, who was pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church, Maujer Street and Graham Avenue, Brooklyn, for twenty-two years, from 1905 to 1927, died yesterday of heart disease in the Lutheran Hospital, Brooklyn, where he had been a patient for the last fortnight.

LONDON. IN our new tariff schedules no duty has as yet been imposed on imports of poetry, but how long will they remain on the free list? If the dicta of our leading critics influence public consumption, the domestic verse-making industry will soon be faced with foreign competition to such an extent as to stimulate a demand for its protection.
HOW can the university best help bind up the wounds of our economic order? At the conference of university heads and advisers sponsored by New York University here last week the doctors disagreed.

EACH inhabitant of New York City pays 8 cents a year to help litigants get justice in the Municipal Court, the "poor man's court," whereas he pays 50 cents annually so that the man of larger affairs may have his disputes settled in the Supreme Court.

HOW many people," asks Francis Toye in The London Morning Post, "realize what it meant to launch Sadler's Wells in a time of depression and economic crisis like that in which we have been living during the last two years?"

WHAT appears to be proof that the pictures of Chinese life presented in the novels of Pearl S. Buck, and more particularly in the latest of these. "Sons" (John Day Company), are drawn from life without exaggeration, is found in the "Chronicles of Wang Lung, the White Tiger," now appearing in the Chinese vernacular press and translated in part in the foreign-language papers of Peiping and Shanghai.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- "Yale's dressing room resounded with shouts and songs of joyous celebration shortly after Referee Eddie O'Brien blew his whistle to halt the game. Players and coaches were showered with congratulations after having been drenched by the downpour on the gridiron in the Bowl.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- A comprehensive solution of the international debt and credit problem and the removal of international trade barriers are twin tasks for the world economic conference if the depression is to be ended and the debtor countries are to meet their obligations, Professor Hermann Warmbold, Minister of Economy, said today.
RATHER extensive revisions are planned for this year's activities of the New York Music Week Association, according to its announcement.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Heavy rains that transformed the show ring of the Old Radnor Hunt Club, Bryn Mawr, into a sea of mud today, marring performance of many of the entries in the Hunt View Farms Horse Show, apparently did not bother Miss Charlotte Ives Montgomery of Villanova.
Michael Mansfield, a grocery clerk who wears a temperance society emblem and lives at 425 West 124th Street, returned yesterday from Ireland on the liner President Harding.

Heralded by appeals in synagogues, Catholic and Protestant churches, the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee's drive to reach the small giver will begin tomorrow with 10,000 men and women solicitors starting on a three weeks' job of canvassing every block in Manhattan.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19.--The investigation of the theft of poll books and ballots from the Hall of Records and the City Sail early Wednesday morning, while an inquiry into alleged election frauds in the city's Third Ward was going on, resulted today in the arrest of thirty-one members of local election boards and in repercussions throughout the city government.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- A comprehensive solution of the international debt and credit problem and the removal of international trade barriers are twin tasks for the world economic conference if the depression is to be ended and the debtor countries are to meet their obligations, Professor Hermann Warmbold, Minister of Economy, said today.
RATHER extensive revisions are planned for this year's activities of the New York Music Week Association, according to its announcement.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Heavy rains that transformed the show ring of the Old Radnor Hunt Club, Bryn Mawr, into a sea of mud today, marring performance of many of the entries in the Hunt View Farms Horse Show, apparently did not bother Miss Charlotte Ives Montgomery of Villanova.

A militant campaign is afoot in the insurance world to counteract the effects of what is said to be a whispering campaign against the fundamental soundness of insurance generally and of some of the individual companies in particular. A "call to arms" has been sounded by Thomas J.V. Cullen, insurance commentator and editor of The Spectator, in his leading editorial in the current issue of the magazine.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Ignatius Varecha, 17-year-old alleged desperado, who was the object for three days of manhunt as a suspected killer, was captured latter today as he watched a performance in a cheap burlesque theatre.

With delegates in attendance from all sections of the United States and far off Hawaii, the forty-fourth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union will open today for a three-day session at the Hotel Paramount. The various standing and sports governing committees will start their deliberations this afternoon with the convention proper assembling tomorrow morning.

WHILE the musical season of 1932-33 in Soviet Russia is likely to witness a marked continuance of the "return to the classics" noted some time ago, it will also see the premiere of two operas "of revolutionary tendencies" by Vassilenko and Davidenko-Shekhter respectively, and one of an opera by Shostakovitch, built on a novel by Turgenief, according to prognostications by Eugene Braudo printed in a recent issue of the Moskauer Rundschau.

WITHIN the past fortnight two exhibitions have opened steeped in the romance, the patriotism, the canny promotion of "Big Business" -- business bigger than any our century has known, and in the craftsman skill of the far past; steeped, in a word, in the glory of eighteenth century France.

KITTY HAWK, N.C., Nov. 19 -- Breasting triumphantly into the north winds and etched sharp against a rain-heavy gray sky, the Wright memorial, its granite top 150 feet above the sands of Kitty Hawk, where Wilbur and Orville Wright gave wings to man in December, 1903, was unveiled today.

FOR the first time in many years the purse strings of American taxpayers are tightening on the schools. Educators, heretofore given almost a lavish hand in many cities and States of the nation, and to a marked and increasing degree aided by the Federal Government, are being stayed or even forced to retreat.

While members of Congress continued last week to express hasty and intemperate views on the proposed revision of the war debts, a more thoughtful statement on this subject was made by LOUIS J. TABER, master of the farmers' National Grange. He pointed out that his organization believes "that these are honest debts and should be paid."

DURING the past two years a good deal of scholarly comment has been printed about the rejuvenation of the musical stage. It is still a current topic. Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, who once made "Show Boat" out of Edna Ferber's novel, have now made "Music in the Air" out of their own heads, and they have made this studious department return promptly to the Alvin Theatre for a second visit.

Without referring to him by name, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, a Democrat, characterized last night as "shameful" and "due to devious machine politics" the recent defeat of Representative Fiorello H. La Guardia in his campaign for reelection.

MINEOLA. L.I., Nov. 19 -- R.H. Helsel won the turkey shoot over the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today, breaking 49 out of a possible 50 targets. The second turkey was taken by W.J. Burns with 48. There was a tie in the handicap shoot between H. Frankling and F.C. Chapman.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Playing on the rain-soaked turf of Lafayette Stadium, Lafayette and Lehigh, traditional rivals, met in their sixty-sixth football game since 1884 today and the final whistle found Lafayette on the long end of a 25-6 count. A continual drizzle kept the attendance down to 10,000.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will open its season tomorrow night with a house sold out for days past in all the more expensive quarters. Orchestra chairs and grand-tier boxes for the gala premiere were exhausted when the box office closed last night, while a few spaces in upper balconies were expected to fill with a final rush before the curtain rises Monday evening on the returning stars.

Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission, has been retained by the new management of the Manhattan Railway Company to represent it in the Interborough equity receivership now pending in the Federal courts. With Mr. Untermyer will be associated Charles D. Williams, his associate in the long litigation in the State and Federal courts over the futile efforts of the Interborough to obtain a seven-cent fare on its subway and elevated lines.

Hovsep Pushman's exhibition of paintings was formally opened with a reception at the Grand Central Galleries last Friday evening. But the work had been informally on view since Tuesday, and what certainly constitutes a record-breaking event, at any rate for these times, is the fact that in the course of the first day all of the sixteen canvases found buyers.

American schools had their faults listed in wide variety yesterday at the sessions of the Progressive Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania, where the two-day regional conference closed. They were critized for failing to tell children the realities about unemployment, disarmament and Tammany Hall, for not going far enough in rewriting national history from an international view, and for producing a "top-heavy white-collar class" with no sound sense of values.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 FROM Heidelberg to New York is a long distance even in these days of Lindbergh and Eckener, but the world success of Meyer-Forster's "Alt Heidelberg" once made it seem no more than round the corner.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 19 -- Still protesting that he was Reynolds Rogers, a mining engineer, Colonel Raymond Robins, dry leader and friend of President Hoover, was brought here this morning by Federal dry agents, who found him yesterday at Whittier, sixty miles west of here in the mountains.

Measured by what they could buy with the money in their own countries, the real cost of the war-debt payments has increased 87 per cent in the case of the British taxpayer and decreased 30 per cent in the case of the French taxpayer since the debt funding agreements with this country were made.

IT is curious that a German author writing on the customs of his native land should view the people of whom he writes with great scorn. If they were his contemporaries and he and they held opposite political or religious faiths, his unkind words could be attributed to a desire to convert them.

Analyzing the European situation at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association at "the Hotel Astor yesterday, James G. McDonald, chairman of the association, declared himself, "at the moment, an unqualified pessimist."

Charging that many department stores are insisting that toy manufacturers ship from 60 to 100 per cent of their orders to them on a consignment basis, Harold Everts, sales representative of the Aluminum Specialty Company of Manitowoc, Wis., yesterday called upon toy producers to stand firm against the consignment sale plan.

Forthcoming distribution by banks throughout the country of approximately $441,000,000 in Christmas Club savings, of which it is estimated about 38 per cent, or $167,500,000, will be spent over retail counters, has developed interest in how the Christmas sayings idea could be applied in the retail field.

THE life of a newly created film favorite was revealed at the St. Moritz on a rainy afternoon recently. Gloria Stuart had enjoyed her first look at the celebrated New York night life and was ready to call it a day, or a couple of days. But there were photographers.

THE Magic Walking Stick" is a sort of small boy's day dream. What could be more delightful than to imagine one's self possessed of power to travel into the strange places of the earth at will and to find one's self the hero of every adventure and master of every situation?

IN that remarkable galaxy of talent and genius formed by writers of the contemporary South, no star is more brilliantly ascendant than that of Elizabeth Madox Roberts. She is an artist in whom there is an extraordinary blending at delicacy and power that is nowhere more clearly exhibited than in this collection of her short stories.

SEVERAL hundred million years ago the nautiloids dominated life. Compared with them the dinosaurs, titanotheres and other giant reptiles now extinct belong, as it were, to last week. The nautiloids were huge, weird octopus-like creatures that rode the seas like submarines, each with two enormous, eyes, powerful tentacles and a horny beak.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A new machine that will search across 93,000,000 miles of space for secrets of the earth's weather believed hidden on the sun went into action today at the Smithsonian Institution.

OF a spritely humor is Paul James, whose "Shoes and Ships and Sealing Wax" appears to be his second book of jocund ventures in verse. Mr. James apparently likes everything, at least he does not seem to dislike anything, even the depression.

The Eleemosynary Outfit. The Green Bay Packers have been called a number of things, including the Green-Eyed Monsters of the gridiron, but truth is stranger than fiction, and the truth about the Packers is that they are an eleemosynary (Hold that line!) outfit, no more, no less.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 -- For the first time in eighty-four years the State of Michigan has gone Democratic. The electoral upheaval was greater proportionately in Detroit than in any other place in the United States. At an election held two and half years ago 10,000 Democratic votes were cast here; at the recent election there were 300,000.

After a sanguinary conflict of two weeks, which furnished Wall Street with more sensations than it has enjoyed in a year or more, the differences between E.L. Cord and the management of the Aviation Corporation have been settled. The fighit will rank as one of the most savagely contested struggles for control of a company in financial history.

HARBIN, Oct. 16 -- Although the newest bandit outrage against Harbin's foreign colony -- the murder of an English matron -- seems finally to have awakened the Manchukuo police to the need for drastic action, conditions indicate that the Winter months will see an increase of lawlessness here.

Registration of passenger automobiles for 1933 will begin on Monday, Nov. 28, when renewal applications will be available at police stations and at the offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, Commissioner Charles A. Harnett announced yesterday.

The pre-election judgments of newspapermen of at least 30 years' experience were revealed last night at the semi-annual dinner of the Silurians at the Hotel Lafayette. The estimates were chosen from 210 answers to a questionnaire sent to the 400 members of the group.

A rainstorm riding a sixty-mile wind, the third within two weeks, swept across Eastern New Jersey and over New York City yesterday. As it passed on up across New England it left in its wake lower temperature, scores of uprooted trees and many flooded cellars.

FOUR magazines dealing altogether or in large part with architecture are at hand. Innen Dekoration (for October), published at Darmstadt, is, like most of the German art periodicals, beautifully prepared. In a winning manner it sets forth newest developments in the field of interior decoration.

ONE of the great functions of society is the gathering at the Metropolitan Opera, which has its initial performance tomorrow night. The opening this year comes at a time that is coincident with the beginning of the fashionable season.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- Fall River, threatened with financial collapse a few years ago, now is moving slowly toward financial stability. The city is not out of the woods yet. But that important textile centre is headed in the right direction. The difficulties were so great, the problems apparently so insoluble, that cities and towns all over Massachusetts and some in other States are sending delegations to see what is being done.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- New and interesting light on the Soviet attitude toward foreign labor unrest, which may well become a dominating factor in European affairs this Winter, is thrown by two editorials in Pravda, one published last Monday and the other shortly before the anniversary of the revolution, Nov. 7.

THE offerings of the Metropolitan Opera season, which opens tomorrow night, includes eleven singers new to the company, five of whom are Americans; three new productions and three revivals. The new singers are Helen Gleason, Margaret Halstead, Eide Norena, Frida Leider, sopranos; Rose Bampton, Marie Olszewska, contraltos; Richard Crooks, Gustaaf de Loor, Tito Schipa, tenos; Richard Bonelli, baritone; Ludwig Hofmann, bass.

Registration of passenger automobiles for 1933 will begin on Monday, Nov. 28, when renewal applications will be available at police stations and at the offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, Commissioner Charles A. Harnett announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question of ratification of the St. Lawrence seaway treaty will soon be considered by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. Protagonists of the project attribute much of the opposition to a selfish fear on the part of the Atlantic seaports that they will lose much of the waterborne commerce that they now enjoy.

A rainstorm riding a sixty-mile wind, the third within two weeks, swept across Eastern New Jersey and over New York City yesterday. As it passed on up across New England it left in its wake lower temperature, scores of uprooted trees and many flooded cellars.

FOUR magazines dealing altogether or in large part with architecture are at hand. Innen Dekoration (for October), published at Darmstadt, is, like most of the German art periodicals, beautifully prepared. In a winning manner it sets forth newest developments in the field of interior decoration.

ONE of the great functions of society is the gathering at the Metropolitan Opera, which has its initial performance tomorrow night. The opening this year comes at a time that is coincident with the beginning of the fashionable season.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- Fall River, threatened with financial collapse a few years ago, now is moving slowly toward financial stability. The city is not out of the woods yet. But that important textile centre is headed in the right direction. The difficulties were so great, the problems apparently so insoluble, that cities and towns all over Massachusetts and some in other States are sending delegations to see what is being done.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- New and interesting light on the Soviet attitude toward foreign labor unrest, which may well become a dominating factor in European affairs this Winter, is thrown by two editorials in Pravda, one published last Monday and the other shortly before the anniversary of the revolution, Nov. 7.

THE offerings of the Metropolitan Opera season, which opens tomorrow night, includes eleven singers new to the company, five of whom are Americans; three new productions and three revivals. The new singers are Helen Gleason, Margaret Halstead, Eide Norena, Frida Leider, sopranos; Rose Bampton, Marie Olszewska, contraltos; Richard Crooks, Gustaaf de Loor, Tito Schipa, tenos; Richard Bonelli, baritone; Ludwig Hofmann, bass.

It would be a blunder for the fusion movement in the city to lend itself to a fight between Edward J. Flynn and John F. Curry for control of the Democratic organization, James Marshall, chairman of the New York County Republican Advisory Committee, declared yesterday in a letter to Joseph M. Price of the City Club.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 20. -- Ted Clark, sailing Eskimo, won four of the five dinghy races held off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. He finished second in the final race, which was won by his brother. Allen Clark, sailing Feather.

Four of the metropolitan district's unbeaten private school football teams risked their records in Saturday's downpour, and all came through their contests victors by substantial margins. They were Iona School of New Rochelle, La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L.I.; Kingsley School of Essex Fells, N.J., and the Hun School of Princeton.

A special Thanksgiving service for the patriotic societies of the city was held yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Representatives of some thirty organizations, with banners and medals, took part in the procession. More than 1,000 members were present.

One man was burned to death and twelve other persons were injured early this morning when fire swept a three-story frame dwelling at 884 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 155th Street, filling three adjacent frame buildings with heavy smoke and driving more than two score occupants of the houses to the streets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- A mass meeting for members of all the Episcopal Churches of Westchester County was held this afternoon at the County Centre with more than 2,000 persons attending. It was the first Episcopal meeting of its kind at the County Centre.

Miss Bertha Galland, the actress, who in the first decade of the century was famous for her portrayals of romantic roles, and her mother were killed yesterday afternoon when the automobile in which they were passengers crashed with another car in North Street, White Plains.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will open its golden jubilee year this evening, when Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" ushers in the forty-eighth active season in fifty years since the beginning of the Faustspielhaus in 1883. There is assured tonight a $15,000 audience.

The cotton, market worked lower last week, influenced by depressing factors both within the trade and in the general business situation. On the Exchange here offerings were moderate, but demand from trade and investment sources was insufficient to absorb them except on a gradual downward scale.

Contributions totaling $808,000 have thus far been made in the campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies to raise a budget of $3,923,000 for the support of the ninety-one institutions affiliated with it, it was announced yesterday by Paul F. Warburg and Ira M. Younker, joint chairmen of the drive.

The American-Scandinavian Foundation has purchased for its head-quarters the four-story dwelling at 118 East Sixty-fourth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues. The property was sold for Mrs. Margaret W. Bacon through Culver, Holliday Co. as brokers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- More concrete factors are being presented to wheat markets of the world at present than at any time this year. Many factors are enumerated, but overtopping them all is the supply-and-demand situation. A great deal of stress is laid on the action that may result from the world conference soon to be held which, it is believed, will develop many constructive influences.

The text of the address made by the Earl of Lytton at Geneva yesterday, broadcast in the United States over station WABC and sixty stations in the Columbia chain and over stations in Canada from coast to coast, was recorded by stenographers of the broadcasting company here. It reads as follows:

Whether the city will be able to obtain from the banks the new funds required to meet not only its ordinary December requirements but also its program for unemployment relief for the Winter will be largely determined by this week's developments, it was indicated yesterday.

ATLANTA, Nov. 20. -- With Auburn's triumphant Plainsmen marking time until their early December championship battle with South Carolina, traditional Thanksgiving Day duels draw attention in the Southern Conference this week.

The alleviation of world-wide suffering will "come neither through communism as in Russia nor through advanced socialism as in New York," but only through men and women becoming disciples of Christ, and through the application of Christian principles to government, declared the Rev. Dr. Walter H. Hewlett in his sermon yesterday morning at the Presbyterian Church of the Good Shepherd, 152-West Sixty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Merchandising and manufacturing are moving along at a fair to good rate in this territory, with small gains reported by different interests. With the holiday selling season on, wholesale and retail distribution of goods especially suited for that period is virtually the same as last year, but trade leaders look for enlarged buying within a few weeks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Michigan alone ruled the Big Ten on the gridiron tonight for the first time since 1926. The Wolverines yesterday achieved undisputed possession of the championship, an honor they were forced to share with Northwestern, in 1930, and with the Wildcats and Purdue a year ago.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- Pending the settlement of the question of Cabinet personnel for the Reich, business has shown reserve in Germany. The security market is inert, credit operations have shrunk and many orders which were to have been placed with industry have been temporarily withheld.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 20.--Trading in cotton contracts for future delivery reached last week about the lowest ebb of the season. Aside from some occasional trade buying and a moderate volume of hedge selling, business has been restricted to the scalping operations of ring traders.

The importance of a national meeting of lovers of wild life and conservators of game, both furred and feathered, has been manifest for many years, but it is doubtful that any one of the previous sessions of the American Game Conference was confronted with the need of such a united front to work out really serious problems as the nineteenth conference will face at its opening next Monday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Sir Edward Elgar, 75-years-old dean of British composers, conducted his own violin concerto at Albert Hall today while Yehudi Menuhin, 15, played the soloist's part alongside him.

ATHENS, Nov. 20. -- Armed with copies of depositions made before the Cook County (Ill.) grand jury, which will be translated pending the expected arrival of the originals and a warrant for Samuel Insull's extradition about Nov. 28 from Washington, Andrew J. Vlachos and Charles A. Bellows, Assistant State's Attorneys from Chicago, arrived here this morning.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Eliot Wadsworth, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, will represent United States investors on the League Loans Committee of London, which, with the sanction of the League of Nations, will endeavor to formulate a policy regarding loans sponsored by the League which are now in default.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Great Britain is as much interested in the outcome of Tuesday's conference between President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt at the White House on the proposed debt moratorium extension as she was a fortnight ago in the electoral battle to determine which of those two men was going to occupy that mansion for the next four years.

Declaring there was danger that the economic system of the United States might become "more heartless than the feudal system of Europe," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday in his sermon at the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, at Sixtieth Street, that this condition indicated a need for a more effective training of American's in cooperation.

Senator NORBECK of South Dakota describes himself in the Congressional Directory as "Roosevelt Republican." In the desire to avoid ambiguity he announces that he is going to change the description to "Theodore Roosevelt Republican." Thus he will discriminate himself from the Progressive Republicans who might be temporarily classified as "Franklin D. Roosevelt Republicans."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The belief was expressed among some Republican Senators tonight that President Hoover again may recommend to Congress a revival of the War Debt Commission, but not until he had informed the debtor governments that they would be expected to pay the instalments due Dec. 15, and that any action which the administration may take will be dependent upon payment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The pressing need of the Allies for shipping during the World War, in the face of the German submarine campaign and the necessity of obtaining loans from the United States, are related in diplomatic correspondence published by the State Department today in two war supplement volumes of "Foreign Relations of the United States."

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- James Varecha, 17 years old, broke down at the detective bureau today after his alibi had been destroyed by his own sister, and confessed the murder last Wednesday night of Frank F. Jordan, a salesman, and the subsequent kidnapping and attacking of Miss Lillian Henry, niece of Deputy Police Commissioner John H. Alcock.

With a stricter adherence to amateur ideals as its keynote, the forty-fourth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union got under way at the Hotel Paramount yesterday. This point was stressed in President Avery Brundage's report, released in advance, and in the actions of the various committees.

A crusade for social justice in industry, based on the tenets advanced in the papal encyclical of Leo XIII in 1891 and of Pius XI last year, was set in motion yesterday at a regional conference, one of three held in the nation, at Fordham University under the leadership of the National Catholic Alumni Federation.

Transatlantic ship lines that plan to divert part of their tonnage to the cruise field during the Winter will conduct only thirty cruises to Nassau, Havana or any single port in the Bahamas, Cuba or Bermuda this season, under the terms of an agreement with the lines operating to the West Indies throughout the year.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Stung by attacks on the British disarmament policy, Prime Minister MacDonald's National Labor friends will issue a statement this week implying that the Hoover plan and French plan were merely "propaganda" proposals and that only the British method at Geneva has been helpful.

The December choice of the Literary Guild, a selection that was made ten months before publication, is Chaucer's "Troilus and Cressida," made into modern verse by George Philip Krapp. The volume contains fifty engravings toy Eric Gill, an artist hitherto identified with English books. The book will be published by Random House.

Fritz Kreisler did yesterday afternoon what few artists in these difficult times can do. He gave his second Carnegie Hall recital of the season before a packed house that was sold out in advance and that filled the added seats on the platform as well as available standing room.

Martha Graham opened her New York season yesterday afternoon at the Guild Theatre with another of those stirring performances which her audiences have come to expect from her as a matter of course. Theoretically, it was the presence of three new compositions on her program that served to fill every seat in the house and to bring forth more than once whole-hearted cheering.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Bertram Arnold, 16 years old, Riverside High School boy, sought for thirty-six hours as the slayer of his step-mother's mother, Mrs. Ellen Saxe, a retired educator of 60 years, was caught tonight in Stockton, Ill., 130 miles west of here, and confessed the killing.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 20. -- Undaunted by a disillusionment earlier this month when the stage supposedly was all set for the event, newspapers here have decided a royal gathering this coming Saturday is the appropriate time for an announcement of the engagement of Prince George of England and Princess Ingrid of Sweden.

Although held scoreless by Tufts on Saturday, Louis Bush of Massachusetts State still retains his position as leader in the Eastern individual football scoring race, with 114 points. Bill Pendergast of Manhattan, who was likewise held scoreless by Holy Cross, remains the runner-up, with 74 points.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Nov. 20 (AP). -- While the League of Nations was preparing today to resume debate on the Manchurlan question, the Japanese position in this territory was becoming increasingly difficult. The most serious situation today was in the northwest, where insurgents have established their own government in opposition to the Japanese-sponsored Manchukuo regime.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A new and ingenious panhandling technique has just been tried out on me, an account of which may serve as a warning to others who, like myself, profess an interest in art.
Sales and leases of various vacant and improved properties in New Jersey were announced over the weekend. Some business properties were included in the transactions.

Rolling up a lead of four goals in the opening period, and adding to it in each of the succeeding sessions, the New York Rangers made a highly successful stand in their first game of the season in this city by defeating the world's champions, the Toronto Maple Leafs, at Madison Square Garden last night.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 20 (AP). -- Mrs. Charles J. Cox has turned her lessons as a mother into such a business success that her husband has dropped his own interests to become her sales manager.

The final figures on the make-up of the Seventy-third Congress should prove as reassuring to business as a rise in the price of commodities. They reveal that the new President will have a party majority of 213 -- of which the House will contribute 191 and the Senate 22.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Aldrich Rodger gave the first in a series of Sunday afternoon receptions yesterday at their home, 36 Gramercy Park, to introduce their second daughter, Miss Mathilde Bruce Rodger, to the older friends of the family.

Five Archbishops spoke last night over the radio in behalf of the Catholic University at Washington.
