A message from Pope Pius XI, read during the broadcast, expressed his appreciation for the work of the university. The program went out over a national network of the Columbia system, locally over WABC, and replaced the usual Sunday afternoon "Church of the Air" service.

BARCELONA, Monday, Nov. 21. -- Premier Manual Azana, the virtual dictator of all Spain, found his policy approved by Catalonia in yesterday's elections, which swept Colonel Francisco Macia's Esquerra party to victory over the reactionary Regional League of the financier, Francisco Cambo.

The case of AMY JOHNSON, the Yorkshire girl who made a record flight from Kent to Cape Town, does not call for special comment as an adventure or as a feat in aviation. Nothing seems impossible to little Miss JOHNSON. No woman at the controls compares with her, unless it be AMELIA EARHART, who made light of the perils of the Atlantic passage and alone nonchalantly crossed over to Ireland.

Inasmuch as Wall Street talk was mostly directed, last week to the "war debt notes," it might have been supposed that impressions regarding that incident, expectation concerning the probable result of it, would have governed the course of markets.

Pastors of many churches throughout the city joined yesterday in urging their parishioners to contribute to the full extent of their ability to the organized welfare agencies, including the Gibson Committee, which are seeking to alleviate distress among the city's unemployed and destitute.

GENEVA, Nov. 20. -- Dr. W.W. Yen, China's representative here, said in a statement to the press today that his country would not challenge the findings of the Lytton commission on Manchuria, and added that the report more than upheld all China's charges against Japan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Relief machinery set up at the last session of Congress will get a thorough inspection and probably there will be some overhauling, in the session beginning Dec. 6.

John Lowry, chairman of the Building Code Committee of the Merchants' Association, announced yesterday that he had sanguine hopes of quick action on the new building code by the Board of Aldermen. This is the code upon which many months of work have been expended by the Merchants' Association Code Revision Committee at the request of former Mayor Walker.
LYNN, Mass, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Harry E. Whitten was captured by the Lynn police this morning before they had been informed of the jail delivery in Portsmouth.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Oats are moving in a limited way from farms to country elevators and terminal markets. Primary receipts were 688,000 bushels last week, compared with 1,104,000 bushels a year ago, while shipments for the week were 795,000 bushels, against 977,000 bushels a year ago.

Two large group events outstanding in importance are on the week's art calendar. Tomorrow the Whitney Museum of American Art will open the first of its biennial exhibitions, presenting a generous cross-section of contemporary painting in this country.

A tribute to the achievements of Baruch Spinoza, the philosopher, the 300th anniversary of whose birth occurs next Thursday, was paid yesterday by John Haynes Holmes in his sermon to the congregation of the Community Church, meeting in Town Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One gets a little weary of the constant reiteration, by certain of our Senators, of the statement that the United States has already made great reductions in the amount of these debts.

J. Errol Vaughn of the New York A.C. captured the annual metropolitan A.A.U. junior cross-country run over a six-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday in 29:56.6. Sixty runners in the field of sixty-nine finished.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 20. -- With only a single exception Philadelphia girls were given berths today on the hockey squad that will represent the southeastern district in the national tournament.

If the story of "Autumn Crocus" were as buoyant as the drama is amiable it would be easier to understand why this schoolma'am's romance has been imported from England. It is the work of Dodie Smith, who signs herself grimly as C.L. Anthony; and in addition to our own Patricia Collinge it brings us Francis Lederer, who played in the original production in the Spring of last year.

The sun obviously pleased about something, shone yesterday on all but a very small part of the city. It lighted the gas tanks and the Hell Gate Bridge of the east and the Palisades of Jersey. It lured elderly men and horses into the paths of Central Park, and baby carriages onto the Drive.

Southerners in New York will hold the first in a series of tea dances under the auspices of the women's committee of the New York Southern Society next Saturday in the jade room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. N. Baxter Jackson heads the organization.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 (AP). -- General Araki, Minister of War, asserted today that Japan did not intend to refute the Lytton Commission, report on Manchuria, which the Council of the League of Nations will discuss tomorrow.

The Manhattan Symphony Orchestra, which was under the direction of Henry Hadley during the last three years, gave the first concert of its current season at the Waldorf-Astoria last night with David Mannes as the new conductor. The orchestra has curtailed its season from ten to six concerts, and promises to continue its policy of presenting prominent soloists and American compositions at its concerts.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 20. -- The text of the unemployment insurance proposal to be reported by the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor tomorrow, is as follows:

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Corn traders realize that they made a mistake recently in advancing prices on the prospect of the return of real beer, because barley was bought by speculators and the prices advanced 6 cents or more. The upturn carried American corn prices out of line with Argentina in foreign markets, virtually killing business in that line.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- The vigilance of a railroad employe thwarted an attempt to wreck Premier Herriot's train by blasting out sections of the rails near Nantes this morning. The Premier arrived only a half hour late for the ceremonies commemorating the union of Brittany with France.

The recent discovery by Dr. T.D. Lyssenko, who is known as the Russian Luther Burbank, of a process that permits the growing of subtropical plants in northern climes, and also makes possible the crossing of plants requiring entirely different periods of vegetation, has been placed in operation on a half-million acres of land in Soviet Russia, it was revealed here yesterday by Dr. Dmitry N. Borodin, Russian agronomist and plant physiologist.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- It was a bear week last week in the live-stock market. The supplies of cattle had been exceeded only three times since last January, and the run of hogs was the largest since February. The run of lambs, however, was the smallest since the week of July 30, but despite this fat lambs sold 50 to 75 cents a hundredweight lower, and yearlings 50 cents lower than in the previous week.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 20. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 60.4, which compares with 60.3 a week ago, 60.2 two weeks ago, 60.6 three weeks ago and 61.1 four weeks ago. This season's highest average was 63.2, on Sept. 10.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- The Niagara University football team ended the season today with its fifth straight victory, defeating its old rival, St. Bonaventure, 6-2, for the Bishop Turner Trophy.

BOGOTA, Nov. 20. -- The press today prints the authorized final text, heretofore secret, of the private debts moratorium bill awaiting the practically certain signature of the President, to be immediately effective thereafter.

Harold Bauer's first piano recital of the season took place yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall before an enthusiastic audience that packed the auditorium to the doors and overflowed hopefully in the direction of the ticket office; a fact complimentary to music and pianist in view of the solidity of his program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the tragic phases of this depression is the despair and utter hopelessness of many middle aged a daily evidenced by the experience at the City Free Employment Agency of the Department of Public Welfare, located at 59 Leonard Street, Manhattan.

DUBLIN, Nov. 20. -- President de Valera has decided to test the strength of republican sentiment in the Free State by forcing two by-elections in Cork and Waterford, where seats have been vacant for months because of the deaths of Deputies supporting former President Cosgrave.
T.H. Lawrence broke 98 targets to carry off the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The second scratch trophy went to E.H. Locatelli, who finished with 97.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- Three hundred and twenty-six undergraduates of Princeton University have been awarded scholarships for the current year, it was announced today by V. Lansing Collins, secretary of the university.

There is a growing conviction that humanity has no greater stake than to keep Christianity in its purest form alive and vigorous, the Rev. Dr. Vincent Norman Peale asserted yesterday in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

France is spending the annual labor of 3,600,000 Frenchmen to protect herself from invasion, the cost in money of this attempt at security amounting to twelve times the annual cost of the French debt to the United States, Edwin D. Schoonmaker, writer and lecturer on international problems, writes in "Our Genial Enemy France," published by Ray Long Richard R. Smith.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--The business situation in October was marked by a continuation of the higher levels of activity which were reached in September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its monthly review of conditions. Final reports for September, the board said, showed a 10 per cent increase over August in the physical volume of industrial production, including both manufactures and minerals, and preliminary reports for October indicate that this higher level was sustained.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- In a crisp northwest breeze sixteen sailing dinghies competed today in the third regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Winter series. Honors in the Class A international contests were divided among Dick Laubly, Jim Brown Jr., Bill Swan, Arthur Knapp, Porter Buck and Bob Garland.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 20. -- Nebraska is the Big Six football champion for the third time in the four years Dana X. Bible has coached at Lincoln and the Cornhuskers missed national recognition only by losing to Minnesota, 7 to 6, early in the season.
Stitch (Samuel Rothberg) McCarthy was re-elected chief of the New York League of Locality Mayors, Inc., yesterday afternoon in Mayor Lou G. Siegel's restaurant at 209 West Thirty-eighth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20. -- Cross currents in steel demand have resulted in a net loss, ingot production last week being barely more than 17 per cent of plant capacity, against about 18 per cent for two weeks and an average of 19 per cent in October as officially reported.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 20 (AP). -- The government announced today that more than 6,000 Bolivian soldiers had been, killed and more than 1,500 captured since the beginning of the undeclared war between Bolivia and Paraguay for possession of the Gran Chaco in July.

Detectives of the East Twenty-second Street squad investigating the hold-up of a philatelist's office on Oct. 20 in which John R. Miller, 72 years old, was so brutally attacked that he died on Nov. 2 in Bellevue, arrested last night a man who, they said, bad disposed of part of the $2,000 worth of rare stamps taken.

Declaring that a growing atheism is typified by the anti-religious activities of Russia, Mexico, Spain and other countries, the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, S.J., urged yesterday that Protestants and Jews, as well as members of his own faith, should present a united front in opposition to this type of action against the churches by various States.

HONOLULU, Nov. 20. -- With a prepared statement setting forth Hawaii's position toward bills pending in Congress which curtail the Territory's self-government, Governor Lawrence M. Judd has appointed the long-awaited legislative commission authorized by the last special session of the Hawaiian Legislature for the purpose of presenting authentic information assisting Hawaii's delegate at Washington in opposing such legislation.

The following summary of the observations of the Japanese Government on the report of the Commission of Inquiry appointed by the Resolution of Dec. 10, 1931, of the Council of the League of Nations, was issued yesterday through the Japanese Consulate General in this city:

The new 7,500-ton turbo-electric liner Colombia of the Colombian Line, which operates to Jamaica, Haiti, Cartagena and Colon, arrived yesterday afternoon from the builders at Newport News, Va., and docked at Pier 9, North River, where she landed the ninety guests of the company who had made the trip.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 20. -- The elderly, gray-bearded man in blue overalls and khaki shirt, who still insists that he is Reynolds Rogers, a Kentucky mining engineer, but whom wife and relatives positively identify as Colonel Raymond Robins, friend of President Hoover, and prominent prohibitionist and reformer, was transferred today from the Norburn General Hospital to Appalachian Hall, a private hospital on the outskirts of this city for nervous and mental cases.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20. -- Grains continued sluggish last week, with a pronounced downward price trend which a slight rally at the end of the week was unable to wipe out. Wheat, corn and flaxseed closed slightly lower than on the previous Saturday.

GENEVA, Nov. 20. -- China, Japan and the Earl of Lytton, president of the League of Nations commission of inquiry into the undeclared Manchurian war, successively stated their viewpoints here today on the eve of the League Council's session for consideration of the commission's report.
NEW YORK. Mrs. E. Singer Proctor will give a small dinner dance at her home, 630 Park Avenue, Dec. 27, for Miss Alva Root, debutante daughter of Mrs. Henry Breckinridge.

Copyright, 1932, The Associated Press. GENEVA, Nov. 20. -- The Japanese people are convinced that the report of the Lytton commission on conditions in Manchuria and China, which the coming session of the League Assembly is convoked primarily to consider, fails to present these conditions in their true light because it does not make clear the comparative conditions of the two neighboring nations of East Asia most vitally concerned, Japan and China.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, passed his sixty-fifth birthday today in his Summer home on the grounds of St. Joseph's Sanitarium and Mountain School, Sullivan County, four miles from here. He wished to escape the excitement that his birthday always has meant at home.

The first contingent of 2,500 volunteer workers of the 10,000 being recruited for the campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee to raise $15,000,000 will begin solicitation today of more that 33,000 retail business places in Manhattan in an effort to swell the fund for the relief of the city's needy jobless.

Orders for ready-to-wear came into the local wholesale markets in larger volume last week, as store turnover was spurred by intensive post-election promotions and by the cooler weather. Toy and gift departments were opened earlier this year in an attempt by stores to start the holiday buying season.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Although the Stock Exchange resolutely clings to the belief that Great Britain will not be called upon to pay its December war debt instalment to America, that attitude is rather the case of wish being father to the thought. The City fully realizes that its hopes may not be fulfilled and a mild depression has therefore settled upon the security markets, investors and speculators alike temporarily withdrawing their support.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 20. -- The Northeast team defeated the Northeast Reserves by 2 to 0 today in the final game of the sectional field hockey tournament at Wellesley College.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- The second annual county-wide arts and crafts exhibit will open at the Westchester County Centre here tomorrow night and will continue for two weeks. The Westchester County Recreation Commission, which has arranged the exhibit, has invited the public to attend the opening, when many of the 200 exhibiting artists, sculptors and craftsmen, both amateur and professional, will be present.

DENVER, Nov. 20. -- The University of Utah won the championship of the Rocky Mountain Conference for the fifth consecutive year by defeating a fighting Colorado Aggie team, 16 to 0, yesterday, in Fort Collins. Brigham Young assured itself of second place by downing Utah Aggies, 18 to 6.

Various charitable organizations that carry on relief work among the ill and needy will be aided by card parties in the near future. Members of the Little Mothers' Aid Association, of which Mrs. FranK Oliver Hall is president, will hold a card party on the afternoon of Dec. 5 at the Plaza to augment the association's funds.

Persons in the confidence of President HOOVER said on Saturday that if Congress passes a bill to modify the Volstead act so as to permit the manufacture and sale of beer he will veto it. The main reason given is that he would consider it a nullification of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Mr. ALFRED NOYES has relieved himself of temporary depressive influence by some humorous and whimsical observations to a reporter. He spoke of the elder writers as "old fellows" who have spent all their intellectual capital and by their cynicism exert "a poisonous influence" on the young.

Recommendations for bettering the crowded conditions in the State Supreme Court are contained in a report of a study by a court calendar committee made up of lawyers from the three bar associations of Manhattan and the Bronx, which, it was announced yesterday, has been placed fore Presiding Justice Edward R. Finch of the Appellate Division and its committeeon administration and procedure.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler will be received tomorrow morning, instead of Tuesday, as originally planned, by President von Hindenburg, whose selection of the nation's next Chancellor is awaited.

On the eve of the taking up of the Manchurian report by the League of Nations at Geneva today, Lord LYTTON, Chairman of the Commission, issued a special broadcast for the United States. In it he gave an admirably clear summary of the origin and course of the troubles in Manchuria.
A deficiency judgment in favor of Alan L. Wolf of New York City against the Amusement Corporation of America for $118,248,34 was entered yesterday in the County Clerk's office at Jersey City.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20.--Compulsory unemployment insurance under State auspices, with the entire cost borne by industry, is made imperative because of the continuing rapid mechanization of industry and the failure of industrial management to stabilize employment, according to the annual report of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, which will be presented tomorrow to the delegates at the annual convention of the federation.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 20. -- St. Thomas College of Scranton defeated La Salie College of Philadelphia today, 24 to 0. The Purple and White began scoring early to register two touchdowns in the first period. La Salle never threatened the St. Thomas goal line.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP). -- A cable received here last Friday from Pandit Malaviya, Hindu champion of the Untouchables, said a settlement of their differences had been reached at a joint conference held in Allahabad among Moslem, Hindu and Sikh political factions.

A forty-yard forward pass by Jack McBride, former Syracuse football star, gave the New York Giants a 6-0 victory over the famous Green Bay Packers yesterday in a game that drew 30,000 spectators, the largest crowd of the professional season here, to the Polo Grounds.

Like his two younger brothers, Francis Anthony Fabrizio, 40 years old, who was writing a book designed to be an expose of the underworld he knew, was killed last night at the behest of gangland enemies by three men who invaded the home of his parents at 6,207 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, where Fabrizio had taken refuge a week ago.

Thrillers in the News. When the front page contains side by side the Fraudulent Claimant and the Amnesia Victim we are far away from the tedium of war debts and Cabinet crises and in the simpler and warmer world of the mystery novel.

Two touchdowns in the opening period and one more in the last gave the Stapleton eleven a hard-fought victory over the Chicago Cardinals, 21 to 7, yesterday at Thompson Stadium, Staten Island, before a crowd of 5,000.

"Firebird," with Judith Anderson heading the cast, will open tonight at the Empire Theatre as Gilbert Miller's second production of the season. Other premieres this evening will be "The Barrister" at the Masque Theatre and "Moral Fabric" at the Provincetown Playhouse.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Chinese Legation tonight made public the following statement from the government at Nanking on the Japanese "observation" on the Lytton report:

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The Paris Bourse has been generally dull, with French rentes particularly weak. The budget bill submitted to the Deputies made an unfavorable impression in financial circles, where it is considered that too large a proportion of the deficit is covered by proposed economies.
TOKYO, Nov. 20. -- The text of the official summary of the Japanese reply to the Lytton report was issued to the press tonight.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- Enjoying a quiet, peaceful Sunday in the role of a Hudson River Valley squire, Franklin D. Roosevelt worshipped in the vine-clad St. James's Episcopal Church this morning and later relaxed at home in preparation for strenuous days ahead.

Sectional championships were won by Michigan, Nebraska and Utah on Saturday; two more teams, Temple and Waynesburg, were eliminated from the East's unbeaten group of six and the day provided its allotment of surprising and meritorious performances as Yale scored its most decisive victory over Harvard in thirty years and Manhattan and Syracuse held Holy Cross and Columbia, respectively, to scoreless draws.

GENEVA, Nov. 20. -- The Earl of Lytton, chairman of the League commission that investigated the situation in China and Manchuria, said in a radio address here tonight that the "Far Eastern horizon since September, 1931, has grown into a very threatening storm which overshadows the whole of international politics."

Among the passengers who arrived from Havre yesterday on the French liner Rochambeau was A. Bottiau, noted French sculptor, who has several commissions for work in the United States. Mme. Bottiau accompanied him. He was decorated for his statues for the big war memorial erected at Billecour, France, in memory of the American dead, which he said was 325 feet long at the base.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20. -- It was all quiet along this Far Western football front today, but for some 78,000 fans memories will live long of yesterday's scoreless battle between California's Bears and Stanford's Indians in the thirty-eighth annual game of the Coast's oldest collegiate rivalry.

The deadlock between Typographical Union 6 and the Printers' League Section of Employing Printers on the negotiation of a new contract for the book and job printers gave little hope of solution yesterday. Officials of the union reported to the membership at a meeting in Stuyvesant High School on the efforts to reach a settlement following the rejection by a union referendum of the compromise agreement reached recently between the scale committee and the employers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- The Chicago Bears, after a scoreless first quarter, which was the only period in which Benny Friedman played, crashed through the Brooklyn Dodgers' defense today at Wrigley Field to win their third game of the year, 20 to 0. The Bears were leading, 7 to 0, at the half.

Such is the forecast of one who has a wide and intimate acquaintance with missions throughout the world. The prediction was evoked by the most thoroughgoing and searching study of Protestant missions that has been made in modern times.

Governor ROOSEVELT's reception of a committee of "hunger marchers" at Albany was an eye-opener for them and a fine demonstration of the public value of such an attitude on the part of the authorities. He listened to their complaints and demands.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Yale would rather Bee its football teams champions of the Big Three by beatig Princeton and Harvard than conquerors of every undefeated and untied eleven in the country, according to The Yale Daily News today. The editorial said in part:
BALTIMORE, Nov. 21. -- A Baltimore girl, member of a family long prominent in politics here, is making her last stage appearance before her marriage.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21. -- The Soviet Union confronts the Winter, which it fears will bring disaster to Europe, with little less anxiety than some of the capitalist countries that are trying desperately to cope with the effects of the economic crisis.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 21. -- The regular Brown back field, composed of Bob Chase, quarterback; Eddie Gilmartin and Dave Alien, halfbacks, and Captain Bill Gilbane, fullback, will start for the Bruins against Colgate on Thanksgiving Day.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 21. -- The burial of Kalman Goldberger at Mount Zion Cemetery in Brooklyn was stopped by the New York police this morning on the request of the authorities here, and the body was returned to this city for an autopsy.

The nucleus of a permanent organization to fight corruption at the polls and protect the rights of voters was started yesterday at a meeting at the home of Mrs. Efrem Zimbalist, the former Alma Gluck, 227 East Forty-ninth Street, with the formation of a steering committee to get the organization under way and obtain support from independent voters who had difficulties at the polls on election day.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Prices of hogs were generally steady today, except that choice lightweights were quoted at 5 to 10 cents a hundred pounds higher than on Saturday. Receipts fell below expectations, but packers had little difficulty in obtaining their wants.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21. -- Johnny Gilbert, who is making a sensational spurt in his endeavor to wrest from Hank Mills the distinction of having ridden the most 1932 winners, scored a double today and now is only two behind his rival. Mills had ridden 182 winners before his recent suspension, and he has hung up his tack for the rest of the season.

Dissolution of the "Radio Group" and the settlement of the government's suit against participants in the great radio patent combine was effected yesterday when a consent decree, providing for drastic changes in the relations of the companies involved, was signed in the United States District Court at Wilmington, Del., by Judge John P. Nields.

With the slowest trading pace for a full five-hour period since Aug. 13, 1928, bond prices on the Stock Exchange moved irregularly lower yesterday, although few issues sustained losses of any consequence. Total dealings aggregated $5,477,000, against $7,482,000 on Friday, the last previous full trading day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- An alleged German spy message, written in invisible lemon juice across the pages of a 1917 magazine, was produced today at the opening of the final three-day hearing before the Mixed Claims Commission on $40,000,000 of American claims against the German government.

Governor-elect Herbert H. Lehman will be the unseen host Thursday at a Thanksgiving dinner for 347 old people in the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, at 105th Street and Columbus Avenue, in memory of his mother, Mrs. Babette Lehman. Included among the guests will be Michael Levy, who will celebrate his 100th birthday on Saturday.

Marking the premier lyric theatre's golden jubilee year, the Metropolitan Opera House opened its doors last night on a new season, achieved in large part through the courageous and gallant leadership of Giulio Gatti-Casazza, the generous and voluntary cooperation of nearly 900 persons making up New York's great opera company and the loyal rallying on this occasion of a public long devoted to opera by taste or heritage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The State Department intends to maintain complete silence during the consideration of the Lytton report on Manchuria by the League of Nations and to do or say nothing that could be construed as exerting pressure for adoption of the conclusions of the report and for a finding that Japan has violated the Briand-Kellogg pact and the Nine-Power treaty.

The admission that the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, contrary to the terms of its 999-year lease of the elevated lines of the Manhattan Railway Company, has failed since 1917 to keep separate accounts for its own lines and the Manhattan properties was made yesterday before Basil D. O'Connor, the special master recently named by Federal Judge Martin T. Manton.

Three dogs, two cats and a retired policeman, who were the chief beneficiaries of the will of a Brooklyn school teacher, were precluded, by a decision of Surrogate Wingate in Brooklyn yesterday, from sharing in her estate.

The Beethoven Association presented the second concert of its fourteenth season at the Town Hall last night, with the Perole String Quartet, Ernest Schelling, Dan Gridley and Carl Deis as the participating artists. The audience was of good size and warmly received the various offerings.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Harpo, the silent Marx brother, today formally accepted a theatrical engagement in Russia, but he hasn't any idea of what he'll do when he gets there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- When Representative Britten was informed today of a statement by Theodore Joslin, saying the President had declined to discuss beer legislation with the Illinois legislator, Mr. Britten replied:

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 21. -- Raymond Robins, who disappeared from the City Club in New York City on Sept. 3 and was found fast Thursday at Whittier, a mountain hamlet sixty miles from here, apparently suffering from amnesia, regained his memory this afternoon and recognized his wife and his nephew, John Dreier of Brooklyn.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 21. -- Holding that the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin did not have sufficient grounds for suspending the broker's license of Halsey, Stuart Co., Judge A.C. Hoppmann of the Dane County Circuit Court today issued an injunction giving the investment house full right to resume business in Wisconsin.

Surveying the details of the vote of Nov. 8 in the agricultural districts of the country, an Omaha news agency connected with the grain exchanges has concluded that the old game of getting elected to Congress on a platform whose only plank is vituperative abuse of the private grain dealer and the local independent farm elevator has about played out."

Since Mr. Justice DARLING went up to the House of Lords, Mr. Justice McCARDIE has been chief humorist of the High Court of Justice. He loves to strike those sparks of the law in which the author of "Scintillae Juris" abounded.

Attacking the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for its failure to act upon loans for slum clearance in New York and asserting that the city must spend $100,000,000 this year for relief purposes, former Governor Alfred E. Smith pleaded last night for popular support of the $15,000,000 fund-raising campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

THE group discussing recent and coming football encounters included Lou Little, Herb Kopf, Chick Meehan, Bunny Corcoran, Arthur Sampson, Judge John P. Egan, Jim Keegan and a dozen more coaches, assistant coaches, scouts and officials.
A flock of little auks, birds that breed in Iceland and Greenland, fell exhausted yesterday in streets in the metropolitan area.

Professor McGOLDRICK of Columbia is a thoughtful student of municipal affairs who is, nevertheless, accustomed to view our local problems in their practical aspects. He is chary of easy solutions and prefers to leave to others the construction of Utopias.

The management of North American Aviation, Inc., most of whose assets were to have been acquired by the Aviation Corporation of Delaware under the deal that precipitated the fight for control of the latter company, sent yesterday a letter to stockholders announcing that negotiations looking to consummation of the plan had been halted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The "dissolution of the $7,000,000,000 radio trust" was described today by Oswald F. Schuette, executive secretary of the Radio Protective Association "as the greatest victory ever won in the court of public opinion."

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 21. -- A fugitive from the New York prison in Auburn who, after escaping from a road camp near Aurelius, married and lived the life of a good citizen for seven years, surrendered today to the police here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The announced purpose of President Hoover and his Cabinet to press for a radical reorganization of the whole Federal Government structure, with the idea of saving around $700,000,000 in the next fiscal year, met with general favor today with Democratic leaders returning here for the short session of Congress.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Ernest Flagg in his letter to THE TIMES says of tax exemption for model tenements under the State housing law: "Is that a fair or honest procedure?"

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The legal machinery of Cook County moved swiftly today against two boys held as murderers. A coroner's jury returned a verdict of murder against 16-yearold Bert Arnold, Riverside High School boy, who has confessed killing his stepmother's parent, Mrs. Ellen Saxe, 60-year-old educator, the woman whom he had been taught to regard as his grandmother.

Opening tonight at the George M. Cohan Theatre will be "The Dubarry," a modern version of the 50-year-old operetta, with Grace Moore singing the title role. George White will bring his "Music Hall Varieties" to the Casino Theatre and Cornella Otis Skinner will start her repertory of character sketches at the Lyceum Theatre with her new dramatic sequence, "The Empress Eugenie."

For the benefit of the Service Club of St. Thomas Church, a fashion show and supper dance will be given tonight in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The proceeds will be used by the organization for charitable work in cooperation with Chaplain Sidney Ussher on Welfare Island and the Church Mission of Help.

The Merchants Association has started a movement among the business organizations of the United States to have business men of high calibre appointed to represent this country at the World Economic Conference in Europe next year rather than a delegation composed primarily of government officials.

The Erie Railroad announced yesterday that it proposed to Increase commutation fares by 15 per cent on Jan. 1, but at the same time to reduce the rates for tickets sold on a twenty-five-trip basis. About 37,000 commuters are affected.

After the enormous deficits of the last three years, President HOOVER has announced that "the Administration is determined to present a balanced budget." With this in view, he intends next month to submit estimates to Congress calling for a reduction of Federal expenditures by "about 5700,000,000."

GENEVA, Nov. 21. -- Important conversations aimed at solving the German equality issue and at least bringing her back into the disarmament conference began today while statesmen were keeping an uneasy eye on the Chino-Japanese conflict in the League of Nations Council and Adolf Hitler's attempt to take power in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The campaign tour by Dr. Leonidas Pacheco, Foreign Minister of Costa Rica, is undertaking by airplane to other Central American countries to encourage denunciation, abrogation or modification of the treaty of 1923 among the five Central American republics against recognizing revolutionary governments among their number is being watched closely by the State Department, but without any move having been made to counteract It.

Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, made public yesterday a letter to Register Peter J. McGarry of Queens, who will take office as Sheriff of that county Jan. 1, calling upon him to withdraw from his real estate and insurance brokerage business "which may possibly lead to profit by virtue of your public office."
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The AngloAmerican war-debt problem will overshadow every domestic issue when the ninth Parliament in the reign of King George V assembles at Westminster tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- An effort by Representative Britten of Illinois, one of the House wet leaders, to interpret the attitude of President Hoover as favorable to 2.75 per cent been met a rebuke at the White House today.

The Whitney Museum of American Art opened with a private showing yesterday its first triennial exhibition of contemporary American painting. The work will be on public view, beginning today, until Jan. 5.

Efforts of the Seatrain Lines, Inc., to win recognition as a regular ship service operating between the Atlantic seaboard and Havana, failed yesterday when the Havana Steamship Conference, which includes the leading ship lines in that field, declined to admit the Seatrain ships to membership on an equal footing.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Liberalization of the ancient blue laws was suggested today to permit big-league baseball and movies on Sunday as one means of extricating the city from its financial trouble.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21. -- The Thomas Spacing Machine Company of Glenshaw is being kept busy on a $1,000,000 contract from the Soviet Government. The factory, said to be the only one of its kind in the world, keeps eighty men at work turning out machines known as multiple presses and automatic spacing tables, for punching steel plates.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 21. -- C.W. Culkin, Vincent and William McGuire and H. Freeman motored from Hot Springs for a round of golf and a luncheon. Others on the links were R. Gorges, C.J. Ryan, Mrs. Eunice Rand, Mrs. E.C. Logeling, Mr. and Mrs. S.R. Kent, E.A. Pierce, J.A. Peck and Mr. and Mrs. S.H. Moore.

If Chick Devlin of California had any championship aspirations they were ended last night at the St. Nicholas Arena, where, before a crowd of about 2,500 fans, Ben Jeby, east side middleweight, did everything but knock out the fighting man from the Coast.

BUFFALO, Nov. 21. -- The Special Joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment, of which Assemblyman William L. Marcy Jr., Buffalo Republican, is chairman, will resume its public hearings in New York City on Dec. 1 and 2, when consideration will be given to the committee's proposed bill setting up a system of compulsory unemployment insurance in New York State.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The text of the consent decree of Judge John P. Nields of the Federal District Court at Wilmington, Del., today, in the R.C.A. case, follows:

Inez Lauritano, violinist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation, which awarded her one of its prizes this year. The distinction fell upon worthy shoulders, for Miss Lauritano's playing showed the indisputable talent of temperament embodied in commensurate technique.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company, which was sued on Saturday in an application for a receivership by Philip Newbold, a stockholder, on the ground that its assets had been wasted and that it had been mismanaged, obtained yesterday an order from Supreme Court Justice Cohn directing Mr. Newbold to show cause tomorrow why the suit here should not be restrained.

Somewhere down near the end of "Moral Fabric" a wistful soul remarked, "Cheer up, Grace; things aren't as bad as they seem." Oh, yes, they were, every bit. For a broken man sat facing either certain ruin or marriage and a willowy lady held both his career and those railroad stocks in the hollow of her hand.

MARSEILLES, France, Nov. 21. -- Leon Trotsky, exiled Soviet leader, accompanied by his wife and three "young friends," was taken off the steamship Praga when she arrived several miles outside the Marseilles harbor today on her way here from Greece.

A further marked expansion in Plymouth output and an absence of further curtailment by other producers, coupled with the fact that motor-car output is usually approaching its seasonal nadir at this time, were the main factors in a rise of nearly 10 points in the adjusted index of automobile production last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs, said today that he was seeking to formulate a plan which would permit payment of the present value of the soldiers' bonus to World War veterans.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21. -- Herbert Ulrickson, a 17-year-old high school student, was shot and killed late last night by a man who saw three boys prowling around a neighbor's house, thus paying the price for theft of radio parts that fascinated him, according to police.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- In the face of arguments from some of the score of Bishops and fifty ministers and laymen present that an additional fund should be established for emergency use, the Methodist Episcopal Church Board of Home Missions and Church Extension at its annual meeting today adopted a budget of $1,804,065 for next year, representing a decrease of about $500,000 compared with 1932.
Thanksgiving Day is no longer the high spot it once was in any season of football, but the coming Thursday will present a program of unusual interest, aside from the traditional angle.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan yesterday entered the lists once more against "boss-controlled" city government. He declared that it was time the "overburdened taxpayers" were represented in the Board of Estimate, instead of the political leaders of the city.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 21. -- Most of the first-team players were out for signals and blocking practice on Cartier Field today, an unusual thing at Notre Dame, for the custom is to let the first team have a holiday on Monday following a hard game Saturday.

Williams College will receive $454,603 from the estate of William Ellis Carnochan, lawyer, after the death of his half-sister, Mrs. Sarah B. Willett of Troy, Pa., who has a life interest in the property. This was disclosed yesterday in the appraisal of the estate of Mr. Carnochan, who died April 23, 1931, in a fall from his penthouse apartment at 40 Fifth Avenue.

All opera seasons cannot open with "Aida." There must be a substitute now and then, if only for the sake of appearances. And the substitute opera must have something spacious and splendid about it; something rhetorical and magistral; something which combines in suitable quantities sin, sobbing and singing, and these along melodic lines that are well known and calculated not to disturb but to convey a sense of the festivity of the occasion.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- President Hoover's reply to France's request for an extension of his moratorium on intergovernmental payments, about the necessity of which in the interest of business prosperity he was so insistent sixteen months ago, is awaited here with interest.

Realty trading in Manhattan opened for the week yesterday with a few scattering transactions. There was no outstanding deal and the little activity that was reported was confined to housing properties many of which went to mortgagees at forced sales.
Frank Rotante, Ascension Parish House boxer, carried off the 138-pound class honors in the semi-monthly amateur boxing show at the New York A.C. last night. A crowd of 1,000 looked on.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES "Germans Fear Loss of Brewmasters to Us and of Waitresses Who Can Carry 24 Steins." Let me allay the fears of the American workers, shatter the dreams of the German hopefuls and rescue the German brewery owners from a raid upon their experts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- An appeal has been taken by the Customs Bureau of the Treasury from a decision of Judge J.B. Sullivan of the United States Customs Court, holding that a copy of Raphael's "Disputa," set in mosaic and imported to this country, is a work of art.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 21. -- Establishment of the five-day work week and the six-hour day on a nation-wide scale "as a step in the right direction," was advocated today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in his keynote speech opening that organization's convention.

The Board of Estimate has set Dec. 9 as the date for the final public hearing on the resolution for widening the easterly side of Rutgers Street from Henry to Cherry Street and assessing the local area 25 per cent of the entire cost for acquiring title to the property required and 75 per cent on the Borough of Manhattan.
EDGEWATER, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Dr. Benoni F. Underwood, one of the oldest publishers in the United States, died yesterday at his home, 26 Colonial Terrace. He was 89 years old.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Play in the national field hockey championship will get under way Thursday morning at 11 o'clock at Rosemary Hall Field, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear four cases involving economic issues on their merits and adjourned until Dec. 5. During the recess the court will prepare opinions in thirty-two cases which have been heard.

Net income of the National Power and Light Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $9,111,210 after expenses, interest, taxes, subsidiary preferred dividends, depreciation and depletion. This was equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $1.36 a share on 5,452,101 common shares, and compares with a net of $11,030,535, or $1.71 a share on 5,449,301 shares, in the preceding twelve months.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The Essex County grand jury returned to Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan tonight indictments charging two policemen, arrested yesterday in the investigation of the theft of ballots from the City Hall last Wednesday, with misfeasance in public office.

The New York University football team yesterday resumed preparations for the Thanksgiving Day battle with Carnegie Tech at the Yankee Stadium by engaging in a two-hour workout at Ohio Field. The squad reported in perfect condition and apparently benefited by its Saturday holiday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Litigants need not intend to become permanent residents of the State in order to obtain a divorce under the 90-day residence law, the State Supreme Court held today.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 21 (AP). -- Paul C. Hunt of Boston asked the Probate Court this afternoon to remove H. Nelson Slater of New York as one of the trustees of $3,000,000 trust funds left for the benefit of his mother, Mabel Hunt Slater.

On the eve of his conference with President Hoover on intergovernmental debts, Governor Roosevelt arrived in the city last night ready to act as a "listener" in the conversations at the White House tomorrow.

There was a brilliant gathering of society last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the occasion marking the initial performance of the Metropolitan Opera Company for this season, the forty-ninth season in that house, famed throughout the world for its productions.

No reply as yet has been made to the cabled suggestion from Clifford D. Mallory, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union, who is in Scotland, that the new twelvemeter international cup be sent to Norway for competition, there next July.

Bankers here who headed syndicates which marketed the American portions of various European government loans issued under the auspices of the League of Nations indicated yesterday that Eliot Wadsworth, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who has been selected to represent American bondholders with the League loans committee of London, will have their fullest cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Nov. 14 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 10,532,745 running bales, including 474,442 round bales, counted as half bales, and 5,073 bales of American-Egyptian.

Eight actors and actresses gathered upon the stage of the Theatre Masque last night and grimly went about the business of constantly ringing doorbells, speaking hollow lines and getting themselves all confused in the dull and uninteresting meanderings of a so-called play, "The Barrister," which was written, directed and presented by Sydney Stone.
Resales of New Jersey properties, some of which were acquired recently at foreclosures, were announced yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Amid military pomp and profusion of color, their Excellencies the Governor General of Canada and Lady Bessborough visited the Royal Horse Show tonight, as bands blared forth and a throng of more than 10,000 cheered the arrival of the viceregal entourage.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Arthur S. Lane of Arlington, Masa., Princeton junior, was elected captain of the Tiger 1933 football team tonight. He succeeds F. Tremaine Billings Jr., '33, of Pittsburgh.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- The trend was higher during an active session of the Bourse today. The improvement come as a general surprise in view of America's attitude toward the Dec. 15 debt payment, the possibility of the Hitlerites taking power in Germany and concern over the forthcoming budget debate in the Chamber of Deputies.

HELSINGFORS, Nov. 21. -- The Mantsala rebellion trial, the biggest court case in recent Finnish history, ended today in a dramatic climax as fifty-two men who took part in the revolt were found guilty of active rebellion or as accessories. All were sentenced by the High Court to penal servitude or to imprisonment for terms ranging from two to thirty months.

Payment of an additional 10 per cent dividend to the 408,000 depositors of the Bank of United States will he made before Christmas, it was learned yesterday. This will bring the dividend total since the bank was closed Dec. 11, 1930, to 55 per cent.
Pressure continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here and prices lost 5 to 8 points.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Police today revealed a threat by extortionists to kill Frank L. Weyenberg, 49, wealthy shoe manufacturer, and to bomb his palatial home.

Spurred to action by a joint appeal by former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Thomas L. Robinson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee's general canvass committee for Manhattan, thousands of volunteer workers began their general canvass yesterday in the campaign to raise $15,000,000 for relief of the unemployed.
Ed (Strangler) Lewis, recognized here as world's wrestling champion, defeated George Calza in one of the shortest title contests ever staged in this city in Madison Square Garden last night.

GENEVA, Nov. 21. -- The League of Nations Council quietly began consideration of the Lytton report on Manchuria today before a distinguished audience that crowded the Crystal Chamber and remained respectfully attentive through two of the longest statements ever read there.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The Round Table Conference on Indian Affairs got down to business today by showing its unmistakable approval of the report issued in June by the Marquess of Lothian's franchise committee.
Next Tuesday afternoon in Town Hall an orchestra will blandly play "The Sidewalks of New York," and leading the audience in the singing thereof will be Alfred E. Smith, the Oliver Street Nightingale.

Manhattan College and Rutgers University have agreed to match their football teams in a post-season charity game at Ebbets Field on Dec. 3, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm and George E. Little, respective athletic directors of the institutions.

Braving a ring of blazing gasoline, Patrolman John Woods of the Ozone Park police station rescued an unconscious woman from the back seat of a wrecked automobile at Jerome Avenue and 118th Street, Richmond Hill, yesterday afternoon. The flames destroyed the car.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The gross income from farm production in the United States for 1932 is estimated at $5,240,000,000 by the Department of Agriculture, a reduction of $1,715,000,000 under that for last year, $4,153,000,000 under 1930 and $6,710,000,000 less than for 1929.

The deer-hunting season in New York State has come to an end, and reports indicate that deer were plentiful and that hunters were, in a general sense, successful. The forest land of this State is well stocked with deer, and the enforcement of the hunting laws regarding this species of game has been so rigid that there has been no wanton killing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Nearly 80 per cent of the total tonnage launched at Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coast shipyards from the beginning of 1930 through October of this year has been financed through loans from the Shipping Board. In that period the board has granted construction loans of $122,744,000, the amount covering about 75 per cent of the contract cost of the ocean-going craft on which the loans were made.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 21. -- While Japan's observations on the Lytton report on Manchuria are arousing a storm of indignation among Chinese leaders and the press, general despondency prevails as it is feared that neither the League of Nations nor the major powers are disposed to adopt an attitude drastic enough to force Japan to relinquish her hold upon Manchuria.

TOKYO, Nov. 21. -- Published comment here of the situation in Geneva reveals a deep gulf between Japanese public opinion and the sentiments reflected in the press dispatches from Geneva and Washington.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The text of the memorandum, handed to Secretary Stimson today by Ferdinand Veverka, the Minister of Czechoslovakia, follows:

HAVANA, Nov. 21. -- Dr. Ricardo Dolz, rector of Havana University, who had been under the protection of the Mexican Embassy since last September, left Havana this afternoon as a political exiie aboard the steamship Rio Bravo of the North German Lloyd Line for France.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 21. -- A desire to be square with the law by serving a sentence imposed on him thirtyfour years ago was rewarded today by an unconditional pardon from President Hoover to William Kirby Robinson, now 65 years old.

Jackie Ryan ran his last cross-country race for Manhattan College yesterday and terminated his career with a brilliant individual triumph in the fifteenth championship meet of the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate A.A.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Yale has booked Georgia and Washington and Lee as rival universities on its football schedule for next season, it was announced tonight by the Yale Athletic Association.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont, who had been at the Ritz-Carlton, have gone to Washington.

While the program is not completed, the first show at the Radio City Music Hall, opening Dec. 27, will definitely include Martha Graham and Harald Kreutzberg, leaders in the modern dance movement; Vera Schwartz, contralto, who has sung in Berlin and Vienna, and the Tuskegee Negro Choir.
ASCUNCION, Nov. 21. -- Dispatches from Paraguayan headquarters at Fort Arce say the Chaco war was suspended today on account of bad weather.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- King George and Queen Mary, wearing their crowns and royal robes, will go to the House of Lords tomorrow noon, where the King will open the new session of Parliament with all the magnificent ritualism of the centuries-old manner and tradition.

Detectives raided a lavishly furnished apartment on the fourteenth floor of the residential Elysee Hotel, 60 East Fifty-fourth Street, last night on the strength of a tip from an unnamed broker who lost $70,000 there last week, arrested three men as common gamblers and seized a roulette wheel, a dice table and a number of chips marked in denominations ranging from $5 to $2,500.

A world in which the book "Capitalism," by Karl Marx replaces the Bible, was pictured in an interview yesterday by Dr. Lewis Browne, a former rabbi who has become a popular writer and lecturer on religion. He said that if bad times continued "the world is fairly sure to turn to a new religion, and it is entirely conceivable that that religion will be communism."

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The assertion that circulation figures of The Youngstown Telegram for 1927 and 1928 were "padded" more than 4,000 copies daily was made from the witness stand today by Edward T. Reilly, a former Telegram office manager.

John Galetti, owner of a restaurant at 108 West Forty-fifth Street, who was alleged to have telephoned to his lawyer last Friday that he intended to kill himself rather than face trial on larceny charges, walked into Judge Collins's part of General Sessions yesterday, announced he was ready for trial and offered no excuse as to why he had stayed away.

The week opened yesterday with no movement of consequence on any financial or commercial market, except for a further weakening of sterling. That exchange rate declined 1 3/4 cents, touching the lowest figure of the present year, during which it has swung from $3.35 for sight bills in January to $3.83 in March, and back again to yesterday's $3.26 7/8.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Except for West African gold mining stocks, in which almost boomlike conditions prevailed, the stock markets continued weak today under the influence of war debt uncertainty and a fur- ther slump in sterling exchange on New York to $3.27 1/2.

Dr. Harry M. Warren, founder and president of the National Safe-a-Life League, reported yesterday at the organization's annual luncheon in the Hotel Commodore that the league received gifts totaling $28,000 in the current year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today overruled a motion to dismiss a petition asking for a receiver for the Illinois Life Insurance Company, one of the oldest and largest of Illinois insurance corporations in the State.

TORONTO, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Champions of the dog world, including almost every known breed, vied for the highest laurels within the gift of the Royal Winter Fair today. Entries from the British Isles and the United States afforded keen competition for the homebreds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The Treasury Department selected today Cross Cross of 385 Madison Avenue and Pennington, Lewis Mills of 250 Park Avenue, New York City, as architects for the Federal Building in New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president of Harvard University for twenty-three years, resigned today after distinguished service to the cause of education. He will be 76 years of age on Dec. 13.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 21. -- Mrs. Hester Smith Larner filed suit for divorce here today against Robert Johnson Larner of New York City, to whom she was married on July 3, 1928, at Cedar Rapids, Iowa. The charge was cruelty. An agreement over the custody of their child is said to have been made.
The text of Owen D. Young's speech at the Waldorf-Astoria last night follows:

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The court precedent requiring that the jury in a murder trial be guarded, fed and sheltered at county expense during murder trials was broken here today, when Judge Joseph A. Delaney of the Court of Oyer and Terminer informed the members of a jury that they could go to their homes for the night and save the county the cost of feeding them and keeping them in a hotel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Ohio State, although engulfed in an erratic season, tied Michigan in placing players on the Big Ten all-star team selected for The Associated Press by coaches, landing two berths in the line and one in back field.

In a recently published extract from the private diary of METTERNICH, that statesman confided to himself: "How right I am, and how wrong all the others are!" As it happened, METTERNICH'S whole "system" not long afterward fell, and he fled into exile.

Swimmers of Henry P. O'Nell Junior High School, winners of the Manhattan-Bronx junior championship of the Public Schools Athletic League, successfully defended their Greater New York title by trouncing the boys of Lew Wallace, Brooklyn-Queens champions, in the second of three dual meets for interborough laurels yesterday.

Grand Circuit racing in 1933 will begin on June 26 and continue until Sept. 25, according to an announcement by the stewards of the organization, who met yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel to set dates, elect officers and transact other business.
Candidates for office in the last election conducted their campaigns economically, according to the election expense accounts filed up to yesterday with the Board of Elections, as required by law.

WARSAW, Nov. 21. -- The Polish Government rejected today the finding of the League of Nations high commissioner in the matter of the duty-free importation by the Free City of Danzig of half finished goods for finishing and their re-exportation and also in the matter of quotas on foreign products for use by the Free City's population.

A typewritten letter which, according to the police, was to have been used in negotiating the sale of a series of articles "exposing" the underworld was made public yesterday by detectives investigating the slaying Sunday night of Francis Anthony Fabrizio, 40 years old, of 6,207 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn.

The city of White Plains, N.Y., awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., a new issue of $2,534,000 of bonds, consisting of $1,099,000 improvement bonds due on Dec. 1, 1934 to 1943, and $1,435,000 of school bonds due on Dec. 1, 1939 to 1967.
PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Witnin the next few days it is expected France will sign with Soviet Russia and Poland the treaty of non-aggression which has been under discussion for more than two years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -- Robert Lassiter Jr. of Charlotte, N.C., tonight was elected captain of the Yale football eleven for next season. His selection was made at the annual dinner of members of the football squad.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- Philipse Manor Hall, one of the oldest Colo- nial homes in the country, which was the seat of the lords of the manor of Philipsborough for nearly a century before the Revolutionary War, was reopened tonight after it had been closed for four months, during which the old bricks and stones of the manor were strengthened and restored.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Greeted with thunderous applause as "the outstanding representative of the best in the official and private life" of New York, Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee of that city during a flying visit here today addressed 1,500 workers in Philadelphia's $6,000,000 welfare campaign.

Seven hundred industrialists, business men, financiers and civic leaders assembled at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, joined last night in support of the "share-the-work" movement originated by President Hoover to reduce unemployment.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP). -- A new code of bridge rules governing dupli- cate contract tournament bridge and pivot and progressive contract was agreed upon today by the American Bridge League, the United States Bridge Association and the American Whist League.

Four hundred and twenty-nine head will come under the hammer during the annual Old Glory Sale of light harness horses, which will open today in the Squadron A Armory and continue through Thursday. This is about two-score fewer than were sold a year ago.

By dint of his powerful smashing attack, Harry F. Wolf, national champion, swept through to gain the final round of the Fall scratch tourney, the first of the season's major squash tennis events, at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

At a hearing yesterday on an application by three Board of Education employes, who sued to compel Controller Berry to pay them for services last August at playgrounds, Deputy Controller Prial submitted to Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel an affidavit criticizing public employes who seek to draw pay for two jobs.

Controller Charles W. Berry assembled a number of proposals aimed at reducing the city budget yesterday, sent them to the printer and announced that he had found the solution to the city's financial difficulties. At the same time the Finance Committee of the Board of Aldermen held a public hearing on the $557,141,022.73 budget for next year.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter "Readjustment Needed,'' which appeared in THE TIMES several days ago, touches on a matter of real importance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Two of its agents told the special House elections committee today that they had observed voters in Wilmington Del., receiving money at polling places.

At a hearing yesterday before the law committee of the Board of Education members of the Citizens' Medical Reference Bureau sought the support of the board for a legislative bill that would make vaccination of public school children optional instead of compulsory.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 21. -- Notwithstanding that the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company this year is expected to fall short of earning its fixed charges by more than $4,000,000, Daniel Willard, president, told the stockholders at their annual meeting today that through the medium of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Railroad Credit Corporation a situation which otherwise might have caused serious concern had become less disturbing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During recent months and particularly within the past fortnight we have witnessed many meetings throughout this country and in Europe, sponsored by the most distinguished citizens of their respective countries, for the avowed purpose of decrying the colossal sin of war and of encouraging all proposals looking toward its eventual abolition.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Two officers were beaten and eighteen arrests made during a clash in front of the City Hall today between officers and a group of demonstrators. Police said the demonstration was led by several members of what they termed "the national hunger marchers" here, en route to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- On the eve of President Hoover's conference with Governor Roosevelt on the war debts payments. It was agreed in high administration quarters that the program which this country will adopt in dealing with the controversial problem will depend upon what takes place at the meeting of the President and President-elect.

Trading practices on the Stock Exchange yesterday were no different from those of the recent past, so Wall Street took only a scant interest in the market proceedings. There was a turnover of 611,000 shares, against 729,300 on last Friday, the concluding five-hour market of the previous week.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Nov. 21. -- Undergraduates at Bryn Mawr College have been aroused by a critical editorial in the current issue of The College News, comparing their general appearance with that of inmates of a house of correction, to the credit of the latter group.

Two of the seven denominations affected by the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry at meeting's yesterday acted on the report submitted to the seven Boards of Foreign Missions and their staffs last week in the Hotel Roosevelt. The report was presented in the presence of John D. Rockefeller Jr., who largely financed the movement, and other leaders in the missionary cause.

Although Ralph Metcalfe of Marquette and Mrs. Evelyn Hall of Chicago finished second in the Olympic 100-meter sprint and 80-meter hurdles, respectively, the national Amateur Athletic Union voted yesterday to accord them record recognition along with the winners.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- The trade is waiting for liquidation in December wheat to run its course on the Board of Trade here. Today, with outside interest limited, moderate scattered selling of the near-by month caused a decline of about 3/4 cent from Saturday's finish.

The North American Company, which holds utility and other corporations, and its subsidiaries report for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $18,892,215 after operating expenses, interest, depreciation and other reserves. This is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.42 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding in that period, and compares with $25,210,221, or $3.64 a share, for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, 1931.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 21 (AP). -- After a 1,000-mile hike from Liberty, Texas, with her 4-year-old daughter, Ollia Nora, Mrs. Lucinda Dunaway obtained an audience with Governor Ruby Laffoon today and pleaded with him to release from the State reformatory her husband, Oscar Dunaway.

After a Busy Life. Ex-Mayor WALKER announces that an American magazine has offered $50,000 for his autobiography. It will probably turn out to be a very good investment, and yet we venture the guess that the offer does not come from the magazine of which ALFRED E. SMITH is editor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of Friday, containing the views of England's ex-Chancellor Snowden on Britain's war debt to us, together with your editorial in Saturday's issue, is a real and necessary contribution to an understanding of the problem of foreign debt.

Orders Show Gain Over Week Ago. Orders received here yesterday were of somewhat larger size than those of a week ago, reflecting better consumer demand for seasonal apparel and also the start of gift and toy shopping. Resident buyers also reported that an increasing number of out-of-town stores have put on sales that sent volume totals ahead of the corresponding period a year ago.

The New York Athletic Club team scored its second straight triumph in the Class C division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by turning back the Yale Club players in a close struggle on the Winged Foot courts yesterday, 4 to 3. An early lead enabled the New York A.C. to register the victory.

A sharp and sudden rise in the prices of spirits, champagnes and cordials, traced to a concerted movement started three weeks ago by syndicates in control of the supply, was reported here yesterday in speakeasies, cordial shops and restau- rants.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- Adolf Hitler, leader of the National Socialist party, tonight refused to accept the Chancellorship under conditions listed earlier in the day by President von Hindenburg. Further conferences are expected tomorrow in their effort to bring about a return to Parliamentary government.

The decline of the pound sterling, furthered last week by the growing belief that Congress would refuse to grant Great Britain, a postponement of the Dec. 15 war-debt payment of $95,550,000, continued unchecked yesterday, bringing the exchange to $3.27, the lowest price since Dec. 9 of last year and down 1 3/4 cents oh the day.

A sharp and sudden rise in the prices of spirits, champagnes and cordials, traced to a concerted movement started three weeks ago by syndicates in control of the supply, was reported here yesterday in speakeasies, cordial shops and restau- rants.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- Adolf Hitler, leader of the National Socialist party, tonight refused to accept the Chancellorship under conditions listed earlier in the day by President von Hindenburg. Further conferences are expected tomorrow in their effort to bring about a return to Parliamentary government.

The decline of the pound sterling, furthered last week by the growing belief that Congress would refuse to grant Great Britain, a postponement of the Dec. 15 war-debt payment of $95,550,000, continued unchecked yesterday, bringing the exchange to $3.27, the lowest price since Dec. 9 of last year and down 1 3/4 cents oh the day.

Lord Rosebery, in presenting a copy of his respected biography of Napoleon I to the late Empress Eugenic of France, paid to the aged lady what was perhaps the finest compliment of all those which she proudly received in her lifetime. Said he: "To the surviving sovereign of Napoleon's dynasty -- the Empress who has lived on the summits of splendor, sorrow and catastrophe with supreme dignity and courage."

The debuts of two American singers, Rose Bampton and Richard Bonelli, and the first performance of "Elektra" will mark the second week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week. Miss Bampton, youthful contralto, will make her first appearance with the company here on Monday night in Ponchielli's "Gioconda," which will have Rosa Ponselle, Lauri-Volpi, Borgioli and Pasero in other leading roles and Serafin conducting.
The text of Controller Berry's report to the Board of Estimate on the city's financial condition and policy with recommendations for economic follows:

The RKO Roxy Theatre, the new motion picture theatre in Radio City, will give its first performance on Dec. 29, S.L. Rothafel announced at a luncheon in the St. Moritz Hotel yesterday. The film for the premiere, it was learned unofficially, will probably be the RKO version of Philip Barry's play, "The Animal Kingdom," with Leslie Howard and Ann Harding in the leading roles.
PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 22. -- For the first time in its history the Professional Golfers' Association of America will be led by a home-bred professional.

A "serious increase" in thefts of freight during the first six months from nearly all railroads in the United States was reported yesterday at a meeting of the Eastern sectional committee of the protective section of the American Railway Association.

The model of Federal Hall erected in Bryant Park by the George Washington Bicentennial Commission is to be removed and the park restored to its former condition by Nov. 26, according to the terms of the contract by which permission was granted for use of the park property.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- President Hoover will not recommend suspension of the December payments on the European, debts to this country, but will urge Congress to recreate the war debts funding commission with a view to possible revision, THE NEW YORK TIMES learned on good authority tonight.

Tributes from President Hoover, President-elect Roosevelt and others were read last night at the presentation to Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, of the American Hebrew Medal, awarded to the American who has done most of the promotion of better understanding between Christian and Jew in the United States in 1932.

That part of Controller Charles W. Berry's report on fiscal reform which deals with rapid transit financing was interpreted yesterday by Tammany Hall, its political allies and its transit advisers as a direct assault upon the five-cent fare on the city's independent subway system.

Fate seems to have destined that certain football teams should serve in the role of a nemesis to a particular rival. Just as Yale has persistently had the "Indian sign" on Dartmouth, and Pennsylvania, until the coming of Gilmour Dobie, baffled Cornell year after year, so has Colgate been the fly in the ointment to Brown.

Buyers' Total Showed Gain. Buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a slight increase over the figures for the preceding week, but still remained under the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 22. -- In a closely contested women's field hockey game at the Rosemary Hall School field today, the first team of the Ethel Walker School of Simsbury, Conn., won from Rosemary Hall, 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- A modification of the Atlantic Conference agreement of April 16, 1930, which permitted member lines to grant a reduction in passenger fares to officers and their families of American railroads granting reciprocal privileges, was approved by the Shipping Board today.

Of all "the men in Washington" entangled with the red tape of which ALFRED E. SMITH complained in his speech to the Unemployment Emergency Relief Committee, there is not one who knows how to get rid of it. Regardless of the length of the service of any Federal official, and despite ability, forthrightness, energy or willingness, the one who can eliminate the bureaucratic delays has not yet been born.

Norman Thomas, defeated Socialist candidate for President, in a speech last night over WRNT, attacked, among other things, the McKee fusionist movement. Mr. Thomas declared in substance that the movement had no constructive program, but had simply raised a cry of "Down with Tammany."

MADRAS, Nov. 22. -- The reign of the notorious adventurer who described himself as the future King of the Vizagapatam Agency in Northern Madras and whose later activities appear to have been directed toward organizing an armed revolt against the government, have been terminated by his capture and sentence to eight years' imprisonment.

A plan for recapitalization of I. Miller Sons, manufacturers of and dealers in shoes, has been forwarded to stockholders by George H. Burr Co., an investment house, which is acting as reorganization manager. The plan involves the organization of a new corporation or recapitalization of the existing one with an authorized capital stock of 25,000 shares of preferred stock of $50 par and 115,374 shares of common stock of $5 par value.

The directors of the Aviation Corporation met yesterday to select a new board of fifteen directors for the corporation as previously agreed between E.L. Cord and the management. They adjourned without taking definite action to permit the completion of some details, according to a joint statement issued by Frank A. Vanderlip and W.A. Harriman, the former representing the Cord interest and the latter, the management.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Recommendations by the executive committee of the board of supervising inspectors of the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection, including changes in pilot rules in New York waters, have been approved by the Secretary of Commerce and now have the force of law, Dickerson N. Hoover, assistant director of the bureau, said today.

There probably never was a more far-reaching attempt to integrate and monopolize half a dozen industries than that which ostensibly came to an end when the Radio Corporation of America and its nine associates consented to a decree of dissolution.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 22. -- Colonel Raymond Robins, who regained his memory in a hospital for mental and nervous cases here yesterday after more than two months of apparent amnesia, suffered a relapse today and had to be kept in bed.

Playing in his characteristically brilliant fashion, Harry F. Wolf, the national tltleholder, annexed the laurels in the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The tourney, the first on the season's program, was staged on the club's courts.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 22. -- Storekeepers in and near Boston visioned today a better season of Christmas business than they had expected, when it was announced that the receivers of seven closed banks would pay out $2,000,000 in dividends to depositors before the holidays.
