MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22.--Kinta Arai, who was for thirty years a Japanese diplomat and up to a year ago was counselor of the embassy at Madrid, has published here and circulated widely in Latin-American countries a fifty-page pamphlet in defense of Japan's actions in Manchuria.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Army's football squad, preparing for its contest with Notre Dame Saturday, went through a prolonged practice on the plains gridiron today. The workout was held in secret, the Cadets drilling behind drawn curtains, with a detail of military police patrolling all approaches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Visiting Washington for the first time since his election as President, Governor Roosevelt today received a welcome much warmer than that usually accorded a high official by Washingtonians, to whom a new President is no novelty.

TORONTO, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press). -- For the first time in seven years a United States horse won the International Challenge Cup for hunters over a difficult course at the Royal Horse Show tonight. Mrs. Rigan McKinney rode the beautiful gelding, Grey Knight, owned by Mrs. J.H. Whitney of New York, to a perfect performance.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- County Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire announced today that he would hold an inquest as soon as possible into the causes of the accident Sunday night at the intersection of Bryant Avenue and North Street in White Plains in which Miss Bertha Galland, 50 years old, an actress, and her mother, Mrs. A.M. Galland, 86 both of 2211 Broadway, New York, lost their lives.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,111,100 barrels, compared with 2,134,350 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 23,250 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 12,100 barrels and 9,900 barrels, respectively, in the daily outputs of Coastal Texas and Oklahoma and an increase of 10,350 barrels daily in West Texas were the most important changes.

For every passenger who was the victim of a fatal accident last year on the street railways and buses of the United States and Canada, 257,000,000 rode in safety. This record was revealed yesterday at a luncheon of members of the American Transit Association, formerly the American Electric Railway Association, at the Union League Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The opinion at the Capitol that Congress will pass a beer bill at the "lame duck" session, despite predictions of a veto, was strengthened today when Speaker Garner indicated his intention of giving such legislation a clear track in the House.

New York University's football team completed intensive preparation for tomorrow's tattle with Carnegie Tech at the Yankee Stadium by drilling for more than two hours at Ohio Field yesterday. A light practice is slated for today at the Stadium.
LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The text of King George's speech from the throne opening Parliament today was as follows:

MONTE ALBAN, State of Oaxaca, Mexico, Nov. 22. -- The only Zapotecan painting yet known has been discovered in the first of the ancient tombs opened here this season by Professor Alfonso Caso, working under the auspices of the Mexican Ministry of Education.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Congestion developed suddenly today in Decem- ber wheat on the Board of Trade here, surprising the trade, as heavy liquidation had been axpected. Rumors that a movement had been begun to bring about lower storage rates for carrying cash grain in local elevators started buying in the near-by future, which disclosed a lack of pressure.

Little new business was transacted yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and aside from a steady reduction in the December interest prior to notices on Friday, trading continued unusually quiet. Most contracts changed hands at slight advances, but the influence of outside markets resulted in the list closing unchanged to 2 points lower than on Monday.

Several housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx changed hands yesterday as the result of foreclosure actions, leases and a sale, the latter being the purchase of an east side dwelling by a religious organization.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22. -- The value of newsprint exports from Canada in October was $6,754,504, as compared to $5,424,021 in September and to $8,711,521 in October, 1931, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- While it is generally regarded as certain that Democratic House leaders will not again attempt to reduce the army personnel, as they unsuccessfully tried at the last session, it is certain that another attempt will be made to consolidate the War and Navy Departments into a Department of National Defense.
Staff members of the Child Study Association of America took part yesterday in a symposium on problems of child honesty at the association's headquarters, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The Roman Catholic Church was placed on record today as favoring no retrenchment other than that absolutely necessary in its expansion program for 1933.

Denying that the unemployed are losing the habit of working because of relief funds, Mary L. Gibbons, director of the New York City Home Relief Bureaus, cited an instance of their eagerness for work of any sort, in an address last night before the board of directors of the Welfare Council of New York City, at the home of its president, Charles C. Burlingham, at 860 Park Avenue.

The executives of the United States Lines Company of Nevada, organized a year ago by the International Mercantile Marine Company, Dollar Steamship Company and State Steamship Company of Portland, Ore., met yesterday at the offices of the I.M.M. at 1 Broadway, to consider the affairs of their several enterprises.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- After a conference with about fifty spokesmen for New Jersey shore towns, Governor Moore announced today that he would consult with the State Board of Commerce and Navigation to determine what might be done to aid the municipalities in protecting their beach fronts from storm damage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP). -- After his short trip to Baltimore to return here with Governor Roosevelt, Speaker Garner left the Governor's party at the train and returned to his office at the Capitol.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22.--Yale varsity swimmers will take part in sixteen meets this season, eleven in the pool in the new $4,000,000 Payne Whitney Gymnasium and five at other universities. Fourteen dual contests, including the opening match on Dec. 10 with an alumni team, have been listed.
Further reports on the campaign expenses of candidates in the last election filed with the Board of Elections yesterday showed the same trend toward economy noted in earlier reports.
Controller Charles W. Berry filed a twelve-point economy program with the Board of Estimate yesterday designed to effect comprehensive savings in the cost of city governmemt next year.

This year's award of the Yale Bowl, presented by the Yale Club of Montclair and vicinity, will go to Wilbur Lucius Cross, Governor of Connecticut. The award goes to Governor Cross as the Yale graduate who has "won his Y in life."

A revision of the agreements between the United States and its European debtors would be of greatest importance in restoring the operations of the world economic system, declared Dr. Julius Curtius, former Foreign Minister of Germany, last night, in a lecture at Columbia University on "Germany's Post-War Policies."

Horsemen from all over the United States and Canada and representatives from Belgium, Denmark, Italy and Germany gathered in the Squadron A Armory yesterday as the thirty-eighth annual Old Glory Horse Sale of light-harness horses got under way.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 22. -- If the nations indebted to the United States were to reduce their armament "they could in a short time pay their debts without any discomfort to them," Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania told the American Federation of Labor convention today.

A quick upturn in the renting of space for business purposes in Manhattan buildings was noticed in reports of new contracts announced by brokers and managing agents yesterday. The bulk of this activity centred in the midtown area, with an unusually large number of entire floor rentals.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I think the letter of Edward P. Doyle was very good, and I agree with him in everything he wrote about except that he did not go far enough.

ALBANY, Nov. 22. -- Colonel Lehman assumed the office of Acting Governor this morning at 9:30, breaking recent records for early arrival at the Capitol. No Governor ever entered the Executive Chamber earlier except David B. Hill, who was there usually at 8:30, according to veteran employes.

Since it has become necessary to produce Millocker's "The Dubarry" operetta in an English version, Morris Green has been good enough to produce it well at the George M. Cohan Theatre, where it was done last evening. Seldom in these astringent times has a show been accoutered so extravagantly.

THE mall box gets all cluttered up in the football season. The football followers demand justice for their favorite teams, players and plays. The rooters for other sports weigh in with bitter protests about football crowding everything else off the stage. Glancing at some of the missives:

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Increasing consumption of poultry has curtailed the demand for hog products, prices of hogs dropped 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight here today. The extreme top was off 10 cents at $3.50, while the day's average dropped 5 cents to $3.30, which was only 15 cents above the lowest figure of the season.

Determined mothers pushing baby carriages, gleeful school children obviously enjoying a lark, and unemployed men and women teachers earnestly promoting a cause, paraded through two miles of wind-swept streets in Brighton Beach yesterday afternoon protesting inadequate school facilities and demanding a new school for their part of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt was the guest of honor tonight of hundreds of the newspaper correspondents with whom he will have constant relationship after he enters the White House on March 4.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22. -- The Naval Academy football squad today put in an active session in preparation for the game with Army, the varied drill including a short scrimmage in which nearly all of the regulars participated.

Irving Bitz, who, with Salvatore Spitale, was appointed by Colonel Lndbergh to negotiate for the return of his kidnapped son, was arrested yesterday with a friend, Herman Bennick, as they sat in a room in a Negro boarding house at 134 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, eating breakfast from a paper bag.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Brushing aside the suggestions made by former United States Senator David Baird Jr. for organization of the 1833 Legislature and creation of a committee of twelve to dictate party policies during the session, the Republican majority in each house today made its own arrangements, in accordance with prearranged plans.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 22. -- The twenty-four-day battle for Fort Saavedra in the disputed Chaco region has cost Paraguay thousands of wounded, including many officers, according to a Bolivian officer who arrived from the front today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Relief expenditures made public today by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor amounted in September to $22,581,469, representing an increase of 1.1 per cent since August. It represented also an increase of 90.6 from the total expended by the same 978 agencies in 124 cities in September, 1931.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 22. -- In the only upset of the first round of match play in the seventeenth annual Carolina golf tourney, over the No. 2 course, today, R.T. White of Bayonne, N.J., defeated D.N. Tallman of Minneapolis, member of the United States senior golf team and winner of this tourney two years ago, 1 up, on the twentieth hole.

In his address at the meeting on Monday evening in support of the "Work-Sharing Movement," Mr. YOUNG dwelt upon the old clash between human sympathy and political economy. It seems to be especially violent in times like these. It may be contended, as Mr. YOUNG himself suggested, that on the basis of "pure economics," it is better to let our financial disease run its course as speedily and thoroughly as possible.

The accounting methods under which the Interborough has claimed substantial losses due to operation of the elevated lines under a 999-year lease from the Manhattan Railway Company, were assailed again yesterday at an adjourned hearing before Basil D. O'Connor, Federal special master.

BERLIN, Nov. 22. -- Another link will be added to the system of commercial airlines of the Deutsche Lufthansa that stretch to all parts of Europe and several overseas countries when regular mail service between Berlin and Shanghai is begun next Spring.

A dry, departmentally phrased announcement that Police Headquarters was seeking 200 pages of manuscript, about 10 by 12 inches, in the handwriting of Sir Walter Scott and forming part of his novel "Guy Mannering" made known yesterday the theft of one of the literary treasures of the late J.P. Morgan.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Every Presidential election is a check on industry." A statesman said that, many years ago; and he was right.

Reports from every section of the country where duck-hunting seasons have been under way indicate an abundance of this wild water fowl. But their presence in such large numbers is not due to any seasonal condition or whim of nature. The fact that hunters never have had a better year for the sport is due, mainly, to the policy of shortening the season as adopted by the Federal Biological Survey last year.

The Musical Art Quartet presented three interestingly contrasted works in their concert last night at The Town Hall; Dohnanyl's Quartet in A minor, Op. 33; the fugue from Reger's Quartet in E flat major, Op. 109, and Beethoven's Quartet in F major, Op. 59.

The Brooklyn College field hockey team turned back the Hunter College girls, 3 -- 1, yesterday at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The winners held a 2 -- 0 advantage at half-time, the result of a pair of goals by Miss Ruth Malberg, right wing.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 22 (AP). -- John S. Keefe, whose retirement as president of the American Steel and Wire Company was announced today in New York, and his successor, Charles Frank Blackmer, literally grew up with the steel industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Wasteful practices, resulting in unnecessary expense to the railroads and the public and in losses to private enterprise, were charged against railroad management in two documents made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, MASS., Nov. 22. -- Harvard's profit from athletics for the year ended June 30, 1932, was $36,729.36, according to the financial report of the Harvard Athletic Association, revealed today by Henry L. Shattuck, treasurer of the university.
SEATTLE, Nov. 22. -- Major E.S. Grammer, lumberman and Republican, wag appointed today by Governor Hartley to fill out the unexpired term of Senator Wesley L. Jones, who died Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the enthusiasm aroused by Mayor McKee's speech, I am hoping that one thing may take root in our minds and grow to an effective conviction. It is futile to back a man, no matter how good he is, for any movement for better city government unless that backing gets organized into a party.

SYRACUSE. N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Culminating three years of effort, the New York Pastors' Conference voted today for the merger of the State Council of Churches and the State Council of Religious Education. The conference authorized the appointment of seven members to the joint committee which will undertake to bring the two groups together.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt conferred tonight in his suite at the Mayflower Hotel with Democratic Congressional leaders, who were almost unanimous in their determination that there should be no revision or suspension of war debt payments.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22. -- The Soviet expects little that is sensational to come of the discussions on Manchuria at Geneva, whether the subject is handled by the League of Nations Council or the Assembly.

Although trading was slightly more active in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday, prices continued to drift lower. Leading foreign loans showed a greater degree of weakness than did domestic corporation issues. With the exception of Liberty 3 1/2s, United States Government bonds closed unchanged or down 8-32 point.
The Board of Aldermen received yesterday the new city building code prepared by the Merchants Association after four years' work and referred it to its building committee for public hearings.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Dr. Augustus F. Paulsen, wealthy surgeon-dentist of New York City, who had been living in an apartment here since his home at Port Chester was destroyed by fire six weeks ago, was found dead tonight beneath his limousine on Colonial Place.

MADRID, Nov. 22 (AP). -- The Music Palace, one of the most elaborate motion picture theatres in Spain, was swept by fire tonight. Prompt action by attendants in leading out a large crowd resulted in only minor injuries being reported.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Max L. Stegman, suspended executive clerk in the Department of Public Property and Democratic leader in the Third Ward, where alleges election frauds resulted in the arrest of election officials, was arrested tonight, according to an announcement by Prosecutor Joseph L. Smith, following the adjournment of a sitting of the grand jury.

Under the auspices of the Holy Child Alumnae of New York a supper dance will tie held tonight in the roof garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Rosemont College, conducted by the Sisters of the Holy Child in Rosemont, Pa.

Lou Little, football coach at Columbia for the past three seasons, will continue his affiliation with the Morningside Heights institution, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics. The length of Little's new contract was not made known.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- With a cold wind sweeping over Franklin Field, the University of Pennsylvania varsity squad completed its hard work today for the annual meeting with Cornell on Thanksgiving Day.

The campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee for a fund of $15,000,000 passed the $3,000,000 mark yesterday. Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the committee, announced that contributions to date totaled $3,027,863.

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- The dollar today reached the highest point is several months when it closed at 25.55 3/4. The rise was simultaneous with a drop in sterling, which fell during the Bourse session as low as 83.15, but rallied slightly, closing at 83.45.

In a letter sent yesterday to stockholders of the Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Corporation, G.W. Kennedy, its president, said that as the financial position of the company had become increasing precarious since Dec. 31 last, a readjustment of its indebtedness and capital structure must be effected at once.

Before discussing the trouble with New York City finances Controller BERRY is at pains to point out what is not the trouble with them. While the gross funded debt of the city has reached the impressive total of $2,333,706,091, at least a quarter of that sum, $635,291,328, is self-supporting; the revenue from docks, subways and water supply is sufficient to meet all the annual interest and amortization charges.
BERLIN, Nov. 22.--Developments in the German political tangle wait on Adolf Hitler's next move.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of Nov. 1 shows the following principal changes during October; gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

Except for a recovery in sterling, no change occurred in the principal markets yesterday from the apathy of the day before. Sterling, after sinking another fraction to $3.26 1/4 for sight bills (which was still nearly 2 cents above the low point of last December, and 8 1/4 cents above the low-record price of 1920), regained some of the lost ground.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22. -- Mrs. John D. Hertz's 5-year-old gray mare Valenciennes displayed a fine brand of speed to win the Bouquet Purse, feature race at Bowie today. She scored by a length and a half over J.W.Y. Martin's Con Amore, the favorite, while A.C. Bostwick's Scuttle was third.

That the members of the Jockey Club and the officers of the various associations which conduct race meetings in New York are making strong efforts to insure the success of 1933 racing again was demonstrated yesterday following a meeting of the directors of the Saratoga Association.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The Marquess of Reading and Viscount Lee of Fareham both begged their countrymen tonight not to say or write anything which would embitter Anglo-American relations during the present critical stage of the war-debt situation.
Play in the annual P.S.A.L. championship hockey tournament is scheduled to open tonight at the Brooklyn Ice Palace with two games slated, the first to begin at 7:30 o'clock.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday involved a total of 535,000 shares, compared with 611,816 on the day before. The market was the slowest and narrowest since Oct. 31. Price movements, which were uncommonly small, reflected Wall Street's prevalent attitude of hesitancy.

The New York Americans made their second successful home stand of the National Hockey League season by defeating the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 6,000 persons looked on the star-spangled sexlet conquered their Canadian rivals, 5 to 2.

Ending a picturesque and highly eccentric career, Clarence Wiener, former Harvard student, British soldier in the Boer War and member of a once wealthy and socially prominent Philadelphia family, committed suicide by hanging last night in his room at the Hotel Taft, Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

The Freeport Texas Company announced yesterday that it had concluded arrangements for the development of sulphur properties in the southwestern part of Plaquemines Parish, La., and that the construction of a plant for this purpose would be started in the near future.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Brewster will give a dance Dec. 30 at the Ritz-Carlton to introduce their daughter, Miss Phyllis Brewster.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Besieged by two groups of conflicting advisers, Adolf Hitler decided today to put off until tomorrow his reply to President von Hindenburg's reiterated conditional proffer of the Chancellorship.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22. -- The only chance for America's economic salvation is for business to establish a balance between production and consumption, Harry Arthur Hopf of New York, president of the National Office Management Association, tonight told a meeting of Maryland business men.
PARIS, Nov. 22. -- Once again French opinion as manifested in the press is showing itself very friendly to Japan in regard to Manchukuo.

WAYNE, Pa., Nov. 22. -- Hun School of Princeton, N.J., scored a 38-0 football victory over Valley Forge Military Academy today. Ken Sandbach tallied two touchdowns and threw passes that accounted for two more.

Led across the finish line by Joseph Moclair, the Manhattan Prep harriers yesterday won the cross-country championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools, which was run off over the frosty, wind-swept hills and meadows of the Van Cortlandt Park course.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- An Indication that Governor Roosevelt as President intends to work on the most friendly terms with John N. Garner as Vice President was evident today.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The war debt uncertainty continued as the domi- nating factor in the foreign exchange market today, although the stock market generally was steadier. Sterling on New York established the year's lowest record, falling to $3.25 1/2 before rallying to $3.26 1/2.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- A "Financial Society of Nations" with an international currency based on gold is advocated by Sir Basil Blackett, a director in the Bank of England, formerly Chancellor of the Exchequer for India and well known in the United States because of various British Government financial missions to that country, in a book called "Planned Money," published today by Constable, He says:

Berlin Lion-Taming. ADOLF HITLER, if he does get to be German Chancellor, will be like the man who married for money: he will have earned it. He is being subjected by President HINDENBURG to an ordeal which must be more than painful.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP). -- A stockholders' committee of the Middle West Utilities Company, to which participation in the receivership litigation was once denied, was admitted as an intervening party to the court proceedings against the $1,000,000,000 Insull holding company today.

The metric system for track and field events was adopted unanimously by the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday as its forty-fourth annual convention came to a close at the Paramount Hotel. This move came as a distinct surprise, since it had not been on the agenda, but sentiment in favor of the metric basis has been increasing with every year.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, was adjudged in contempt of court yesterday and sentenced by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe to serve thirty days in the Federal House of Detention for his refusal to comply with the court's order requiring him to produce records of the board for the inspection of a Federal grand jury, which is investigating election frauds.

Justification of the sale of The World and The Evening World by the trustees of the Joseph Pulitzer estate was asserted before the Appellate Division yesterday on the argument of an appeal from the decision of Surrogate Foley authorizing the sale to Roy W. Howard, head of the Scripps-Howard newspapers.

Blair Thaw Scott, 59 years old, banker, religious writer and former industrialist of Baltimore and Washington, D.C., jumped to his death yesterday from his seventeenth-floor room at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He left three notes, one of which said, "I am extinguishing this sense of consciousness as an evidence of my desire to interest our people in the forgotten man's birthright."

The number of school children in New York City suffering from malnutrition has increased more than 33 per cent since 1930, according to a survey by the Department of Health made public yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne. Health Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Declaring that competent business observers believe that the international debt situation "is one of the chief obstacles to our recovery at present," the American Federation of Labor in its monthly survey made public today, argued that "business improvement abroad and increase of world trade would unquestionably stimulate revival in this country."

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I reassure the public in regard to the care of "homeless" boys in New York City? Recent sensational reports have so distorted the facts as to leave in the public mind the impression, not only that a vast army of boys are roaming our city streets foodless and shelterless but that no organized, constructive efforts are being made on their behalf.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Harry J. Graham of Chicago, Western traffic manager for the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, died suddenly in Milwaukee today. He was srticken with a heart attack while walking with his wife. He was 67 years old.
TOKYO, Nov. 22. -- The Japanese people are now beginning to feel the pressure of rising prices resulting from the fall of the yen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP). -- With some exceptions, more than 100 nominations to be submitted to the short session of Congress by President Hoover probably will be pigeonholed by the Senate until Presidentelect Roosevelt takes office and makes his own appointments.

Mrs. Frank N. Doubleday gave a luncheon followed by bridge yesterday at the Barclay. Among her guests were Mrs. Daniel Bacon, Mrs. Samuel R. Outerbridge, Mrs. William C. Bowers, Mrs. Ary J. Lamme, Mrs. Willis H. Booth, Mrs. John N. Stearns, Mrs. Frederick S. Fish and Miss Frances A. Stiger.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 22. -- A petition of F. Frazier Jelke of New York and Newport for a divorce from Mrs. Eugenia Woodward Jelke on the ground of misbehavior has been docketed for the December term of the Newport County Superior Court.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Parliament was opened today by the King of England, who, wearing his crown and adhering to ceremonial customs centuries old, read from the throne his message on such modern topics as unemployment insurance and regulation of motor traffic in London.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- No loans have yet been made by the Federal Home Loan Banks, although they were expected to open for business Oct. 15. The delay is due to the failure of eligible institutions to subscribe to stock as rapidly as had been counted on.

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- Leon Trotsky, Nicolai Lenin's partner in the Russian revolution, en route to Copenhagen to deliver lectures, boarded the Danish steamer Bensdorff at Dunkirk this afternoon after a rapid tour of France personally conducted by the French Secret Service.

The Indoor Art Market held its first public auction yesterday afternoon at 134 East Seventy-fourth Street. Liveried butlers placed the various works on the block and a committee of debutantes scurried about getting the names of the purchasers.

The Merchants' Association of New York was authorized yesterday by the Treasury Department at Washington to announce that notices have been issued by the government calling upon the tenants in the block bounded by Barclay Street, West Broadway, Vesey Street and Church Street, the site of the new downtown postoffice, to vacate by Dec. 31, 1932, and that the work of demolishing the buildings on the property will be begun shortly thereafter.

As the pound sterling and the franc weakened further yesterday in anticipation of the adverse effects of payment of the December war-debt instalments, $16,415,300 of gold was released from earmark at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the account of an unspecified foreign central bank.

Members of New York society turned out in large numbers yesterday at a tea and reception given at the Goddard Neighborhood Centre, First Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, by Mrs. John Sloane, president, and the board of directors of Maternity Centre Association.

Food and clothing will be provided for the destitute and unfortunate on an exceptionally wide scale by public and private agencies tomorrow when New York City joins with the rest of the country in observing Thanksgiving Day. Services will be held in many houses of worship and public meeting places.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Refuging a sumptuous State suite of ten rooms front, Governor Roosevelt moved today into a modest four-room rear hotel apartment for his first night's stay in the capital since the people elected him President.

In anticipation of early legalization of the manufacture of beer, Kings Brewery, Inc., has commissioned Shampan Shampan, architects, to prepare plans and to supervise reconstruction and equipping of the old Excelsior Brewery at 227-81 Pulaski Street, Brooklyn.
Antonio Grossardi, the new Italian Consul General in New York, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Augustus. He was accompanied by Mrs. Grossardi and their daughter, Adriana.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22. -- The State of Vera Cruz is reported in dispatches from the city of Vera Cruz to have placed an embargo on the Huasteca Petroleum Company's properties at Tuxpan, where the 100,000-barrel well "Cerro Azul" is located, as security for payment of 109,000,000 pesos ($35,566,700), which the company is declared to owe the State for taxes and inheritance levies against the original owners, whose rights long ago passed to the State.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 22 (AP). -- Dr. William Engelbach of New York and St. Louis, regarded as one of the leading authorities on endocrinology, or the study of ductless glands, their internal secretions and influence, died at St. John's Hospital today of heart disease.

When President ELIOT'S long and illustrious term had ended it was thought that no name could soon be put beside his. But that of A. LAWRENCE LOWELL is already written there. Without the educational statesmanship of LOWELL the work of ELIOT could not have teen made perfect.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The resumption of normal relationship between debtors and creditors is advanced as one of the principal objectives of the informal committee studying the German standstill question here.

The International Hydro-Electric System, the public utility division ofthe International Paper and Power Company, reports for the year ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $3,452,918 after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interest, equal, after preferred dividends, to $3.44 a share earned on the average number of Class A common shares outstanding.

Toward the close of a lean year official Thanksgiving proclamations sounded in true martial style. There are still things for which we may be officially thankful. But if it be not treason to say so, may we regret that we are no longer young? To responsible citizens fully acquainted with the realities of life, holidays are pleasant interludes in the sober progress of daily affairs.

A mosquito fish, less than one-quarter of an inch long, habitat the waters of South Carolina, is the smallest exhibit, and a white Burmese elephant, the largest, at the fourth national pet show, which opened at noon yesterday for a five days' run in Madison Square Garden.

Paul Crosbie of 39-22 Forty-ninth Street, Long Island City, resigned yesterday as a Democratic district captain in the Anoroc Democratic Club of Queens, of which Register Peter J. McGarry, Sheriff-elect, is executive member. He declared his action was a protest against the refusal of Mr. McGarry to withdraw from a private real estate and insurance business before taking office on Jan. 1.

David Herman, manager of the N. Y.U. varsity fencing team, captured the honors in the prep individual foils competition at the New York Athletic Club last night when he defeated Fred Biel, another N.Y.U. entry, and Hans Foy of the New York Turn Verein, in a fence-off.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- From the top of a mountain at Lake Desolation tonight John Bellamy Taylor, inventor of the system of transmitting sound over light waves, and his assistants talked with Heywood Broun of New York, sitting in the comparative luxury of an improvised studio of the General Electric Company here, by the medium of a giant searchlight beam.

Opinion among professors of the existing intercollegiate football system was made public at Columbia University yesterday by The Spectator, which published the results of a questionnaire sent to 108 members of the faculty of the university. Views were expressed that ranged from warm approval of the football system to bitter condemnation.

OSAKA, Nov. 22 (AP). -- United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew reminded a gathering of Japanese business leaders today of the close connection between peace and prosperity on the one hand and warlike activities and economic disaster on the other.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Light housekeeping and visiting among the prisoners and entertainment in cells in the Monmouth County jail must cease, Sheriff Howard Height, who assumed office a week ago, ruled today.

Thirty-three veterans were decorated with the Order of the Purple Heart "for meritorious service" last night at a full-dress review of the Seventy-first Regiment, New York National Guard, in the Armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. --Terming race prejudice a fundamental problem of the city church, the Rev. Dr. C.A. Richardson, superintendent of city work for the Methodist Episcopal Church, in a report to the Board of Home Missions and Church Extension here today, declared that, with the cessation of immigration, churches now named for national and racial groups must relinquish those designations and become identified as "churches serving new generations."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 22 (AP). -- Nine-year-old Mary Mulliken has received "for her very own" a rare first edition of Mark Twain's "Adventures of Tom Sawyer" in settlement of a quarrel with her brother over the right to look at its pictures.

The Musicians' Symphony Orchestra continued, in its fourth concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, its commendable practice of combining its charitable offices with the presentation of substantial symphonic programs. Particularly attractive last night were the Brahms Double Concerto with Paul Kochanski and Felix Salmond and the opportunity to hear 200 players perform Strauss's "Don Juan."

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Thirtythree Cornell football players, accompanied by the coaches and managers, left tonight for Philadelphia and the final test of the season, with Pennsylvania Thanksgiving Day on Franklin Field. The players were selected at the close of the final home practice today.

The estate of Mme. Johanna Gadski, opera singer, who died Feb. 22 following an auto accident in Berlin, included property worth $45,887 gross and $13,359 in this State, the appraisal showed yesterday. She left no will and under the law a third of the estate would have gone to her husband, Captain Hans Tauscher, and two-thirds to her daughter Charlotte Busch, but the daughter assigned her interest to her father last June.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- The first distribution of part of the $30,000,000 which voters of the State authorized on Nov. 8 has been sent to New York City for unemployment relief, State Controller Morris S. Tremaine announced today. He sent a check for $1,075,000 to Controller Charles W. Berry.

The stockholders of the Manhattan Company approved yesterday the plan, submitted to them by the directors on Oct. 19, for converting the company from a holding corporation to its old status of a bank and absorbing or distributing to shareholders the various allied institutions under its control.

A large Franco-German syndicate of companies engaged in manufac- turing electrical equipment and supplies is in prospect, it was stated by Raymond Patenotre, French Under-Secretary of State for National Economy, last night in an address in Paris which was re-broadcast here by the National Broadcasting Company.

ALBANY, Nov. 22. -- Following a hearing held today on the proposal for the Federal Government to take over the Saratoga battlefield, a committee was formed to keep the subject alive and present it to Congress.
LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The Prince of Wales will leave London tomorrow for Lancashire, where he intends to see for himself the grim realities of unemployment and what is being done to relieve them.

State of New Jersey. The State of New Jersey will not enter the market this year with any portion of the $20,000,000 of relief bonds voted on Nov. 8, according to advices received yesterday by bankers here. It is understood that the State still has sufficient relief funds to carry it until January.

GENEVA, Nov. 22. -- The Manchurian question, the world economic conference and world disarmament became intermingled in confusing fashion at meetings of statesmen here today, with Norman H. Davis, representative of the Washington State Department, involved in the discussion of all three.

Vera Webster, pianist, introduced as a Brooklyn society girl and sister of a well-known polo player of that borough, made a professional debut last night in the series of Tuesday evening musicales now in their second season at the Barbizon-Plaza. Her musical training was with the late Arthur Friedheim and her program, beginning with Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 27, No. 2, included short works of Chopin, Brahms, Balakirev and Liszt.
ALBANY, Nov. 22 (AP). -- Death sentences for seven convicted murderers were affirmed today by decisions of the Court of Appeals.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 23. -- Light practice was held by Brown and Colgate today in ending preparations for their annual Thanksgiving Day football game in the Brown Stadium, where the two undefeated and untied teams will battle for a sectional championship and a probable invitation to play in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Unshaken faith in prohibition, active support of world disarmament, criticism of an economic situation that "produces poverty in the midst of plenty" and a decision to attempt the exercise of greater spiritual leadership over the home, were among the outstanding items in the "profession of faith," adopted by delegates to the annual Pastor's Conference of the State Council of Churches at the concluding session in Plymouth Congregational Church today.

The Durand-Ruel Galleries have opened an exhibition of paintings by Renoir, which will remain for three weeks. The exhibition is restricted to canvases painted by this modern French master since 1900. He died in 1918.

A scrutiny of the proclamations of Thanksgiving issued during periods of depression by Presidents of the United States, since Abraham Lincoln made them a part of the annual Presidential program in 1863, shows that Woodrow Wilson was the only President who mentioned current economic difficulties of the nation.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- The question of what is to replace the standstill agreement expiring at the end of next February will remain open until Dec. 6, when the conversations of the study commission, interrupted on Nov. 11, will be resumed at London, but there is no hope for broad conversion of the credits concerned into long-term obligations.

Six witnesses, including three lawyers, were questioned yesterday by Harold W. Hastings and Edwin B. McGuire, Assistant District Attorneys, in their preliminary inquiry for the grand jury into charges of Surrogate James A. Foley that Thomas Patrick Morris, house painter, made a fraudulent claim to a share of the $35,000,000 Wendel estate by posing as a son of the late John G. Wendel.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 23 (AP). -- M. Moucheron, it is said, reported to Congress that the Ecuadorean Min- ister of War had bought rifles in France at $40 each when they were in bad condition, despite a report by the technical military commission recommending the purchase of Belgian rifles at $19.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 23. -- The Northeast and Southeast first and second teams have arrived for the women's national field hockey tournament to be held at Rosemary Hall School hockey field tomorrow afternoon, Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Ossian Ray, 53 years old, Yale graduate and former Boston lawyer, who was alleged to have stolen more than $39,000 from the local branch of an old Swedish newsprint manufacturing corporation to meet medical expenses for members of his family, was sentenced by Judge Levine in General Sessions yesterday to from one to five years in prison for the specific theft of $1,263 from the concern on June 12.

Moving with quotations on other speculative markets as a result of developments in Washington in regard to foreign payments on war debts next month, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke nearly $1 a bale yesterday. Final liquidation of December contracts prior to notices tomorrow brought heavy selling pressure from the start and closed the list, at the bottom, 14 to 17 points lower than on Tuesday.

With hopes of a last-minute postponement of the December war debt payments blasted by President Hoover's statement on the subject, the pound sterling melted away under small offerings yesterday to close at $3.25 1/8, the cheapest price since Dec. 8 last, and 1 7/8 cents below Tuesday's final quotation.

Shakespeare wrote it; therefore let the piece which was presented last night upon the stage of the lately rechristened Shakespeare Theatre pass for "The Merchant of Venice." A rather large audience, composed in the main of obvious high school students who must be pretty close to that sort of thing, seemed to recognize it as such.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 23. -- A tentative budget of about $8,000,000 for Nassau County was announced tonight by Supervisor J. Russell Sprague, head of the finance committee of the County Board of Supervisors, following the last of a series of conferences with a committee of five bankers, headed by W. W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank, who acted as advisers in drawing up the budget.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- For the thirty-ninth time in the football series that started in 1893, Pennsylvania and Cornell will meet on Franklin Field tomorrow.
LONDON, Nov. 23. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in his speech to the Company of Newspaper Makers today on the War debt question, said:

TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press). -- President Frank A. Rolph told the annual meeting of shareholders of the Imperial Bank of Canada here today that there is a greater feeling of optimism throughout the country than there has been for two years, that opportunities are offered for developing business due to the Imperial Conference, and that further stabilization may be expected from the coming World Economic Conference.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee pledged his cooperation last night to the plan of Controller Charles W. Berry for budget economies next year. The Controller said earlier in the day that the city would show a surplus of about $90,000,000 on Dec. 2 after paying its bills up to that date.

The price movement in commodities was lower. Wheat sagged 7/8 to 1 cent, while corn, rye and oats were proportionately lower. Cotton declined nearly $1 a bale, with rubber, silk, hides and provisions reactionary. Eggs dropped more than 2 cents, the first setback in value in weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Speculation on the selection of three members of President-elect Roosevelt's "Little Cabinet" reveals one of the most unusual situations in recent political history. It is that three assistant secretaries in the new Cabinet will be charged solely with the business of directing aviation activities in the United States and the announcement of the men for these places is being awaited as eagerly as the names of the higher ups.

A letter sent to stockholders of the National Cash Register Company, giving details of the recapitalization plan announced on Monday, shows that the corporation bought 50,000 shares of its Class A stock this year, and gave Edward A. Deeds, chairman of the board, a five-year option on the block at cost, $489,869, plus 4 per cent interest, less whatever dividends may be declared.
The game today between New York University and Carnegie Tech will provide the final action of their collegiate careers for some of the best football athletes who have played here in recent years.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23. -- Argentina evened the polo series with the United States for the Cup of the Americas today, winning a fast and stormy game, 8 to 7, in an extra chukker.

Ernest Schelling will conduct and Guila Bostabo, 14-year-old girl violinist, will be the soloist at the fifth concert by the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House next Tuesday evening, it was announced yesterday. The orchestra is made up of 200 otherwise unemployed musicians and is giving a series of twenty concerts at the Metropolitan this season.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Nov. 23. -- H. Edward Dreir, brother-in-law of Colonel Raymond Robins, stated at his home at Fort Salonga this evening that the report that ransom letters had been received by Mrs. Robins demanding $50,000 for the release of Colonel Robins was true, and that the Federal officials are continuing their investigation in an effort to locate the writers.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 23. -- Miss Nancy Gordon Milburn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn, made her debut here tonight at a supper dance given by her parents in their country home, which they will keep open until after the Christmas holidays.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- President Hoover today refused the appeal of war debtor nations for suspension of their payments to this country Dec. 15, and declared the situation should be met by the appointment of an agency with broad powers of negotiation under circumstances definitely linking debts, disarmament and the subjects to be discussed at the world economic conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The William A. Clark first prize of $2,000 and the Corcoran Gold Medal have been awarded to George Luks, New York artist, it was announced today by officials of the Corcoran Art Gallery. The award was for his painting, "Woman With Black Cat," which he is to show in the thirteenth biennial exhibition of contemporary American oil paintings at the Corcoran Gallery on Dec. 4.

A collection of Communist posters purchased in Russia by Corliss Lament, son of Thomas W. Lament, and held by the customs authorities here as seditious since last September, have finally been released as "not objectionable," it was announced yesterday by the National Council on Freedom From Censorship.

New York City's millions will observe today the traditional Thanksgiving festival begun by the Pilgrim Fathers three centuries ago. Some of today's celebrants will mark it with prayers and church services; some with feasting and family reunions; some with the manifold sporting and amusement activities which in recent years have become associated with the holiday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Tom Mooney's mother, now 84, here as an American delegate to the Congress of the International Red Aid, may get a chance to present her son's greetings in person to Joseph Stalin, it appeared today.

Jamaica High School, winner of the P.S.A.L. hockey championship six times in the last seven seasons, including 1931-32, opened the league campaign last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace with a 2-0 victory over Thomas Jefferson. In another game Samuel J. Tilden, playing for the first time, bowed to Boys High, 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Big brewers, believing their rainbow of anti-prohibition sentiment has a barrel of beer at the end, already have begun to lay their prospective troubles at the government's doorstep. The worst of their fears, as expressed to Dr. James M. Doran, director of industrial alcohol, is the gangster.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23. -- The Pitt football squad went into seclusion in the country late today, following its workout for the final game of the season against Stanford at the Pitt Stadium Saturday.

Only 40 per cent of the girl students at the New York University Washington Square centre attended the university to "get an education," a confidential survey conducted by The New York University Daily News, undergraduate publication, revealed yesterday.
Governor Roosevelt: This is the statement on the war debts question issued last night by Governor Roosevelt:

Cleveland, Ohio. The city of Cleveland, Ohio, plans to enter the market on Dec. 14 at noon with a new issue of $5,332,000 of various improvement bonds. The issue will mature variously from 1934 to 1973. The largest item in the new improvements to be financing is that of $3,200,000 for water works.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Port Chester High School rallied in the second half to defeat Mamaroneck High, 20 to 6, today in the final Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association football game of the season for both. The contest was postponed from last Saturday.

GENEVA, Nov. 23. -- French spokesmen predicted tonight that informal "Big Five" talks would be necessary here on the German arms equality issue. A little later, however, German spokesmen affirmed that the Reich was unwilling to join even in such informal conversations unless the equality question were viewed in broad lines.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23. -- Undaunted by a cold wind, nearly a thousand horse lovers gathered today on a hillside of the Harvey S. Ladew estate at My Lady's Manor to watch the first running of the Harford Hunt Club's races.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 23. -- Development of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Yellowstone's Eastern rival, is threatened with delay because of a dispute among members of the Tennessee Park Commission.

In a Thanksgiving statement issued yesterday, Newton D. Baker, chairman of the Welfare and Relief Mobilization, called for a united effort of all the people of the nation in support of the needy and unemployed.

Yearlings from a number of the great harness horse nurseries of the country were put on the block by the Fasig-Tipton Company yesterday at Squadron A Armory during the Second day of the thirty-eighth annual Old Glory sale. The sale will end today.

The annual Thanksgiving appeal by the United Hospital Fund for the support of free hospital service for the sick poor has brought in $159,235 to date, it was announced yesterday, The drive began on Monday. The amount thus far reported by Albert Wiggin, treasurer of the fund, ineludes $53,000 previously announced by the bankers' committee under the chairmanship of James Speyer, in anticipation of the public appeal.

Several improvements in earnings were reported by railroads yesterday. The Erie reported an increase in net operating income for October compared with October, 1931, while the Lehigh Valley, which had shown net losses for the five previous months, showed a net income of $287,747 in October.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 23. -- Any attempt by the railroads to further reduce wages of unionized employes will find the rail unions prepared to fight to the end, was the declaration here today by Alexander F. Whitney, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives' Association at the convention of the American Federation of Labor.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 24. -- Commenting on President Hoover's statement that Britain and other debtors must pay the December instalments to the United States, The London Times this morning says editorially:
BALTIMORE, Nov. 23. -- The Rev. Dr. John. Falconer Fraser, pastor of Central Baptist Church in New York, has been asked to fill the pulpit at University Baptist Church here after Jan. 1.

A transfer tax report on file in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn yesterday showed the net estate of Thomas E. Murray, inventor and public utilities executive, to be $10,044,070. The report, however, disclosed that this amount was far in the excess of the valuation, placed on the estate by the family and attorneys for the estate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Two of the three alienists named by the State to pass on the mentality of Bertrand Arnold, 16-year-old hammer slayer of his grandmother, agreed today that he is legally sane. On the basis of their report, it was announced, the State will seek a murder indictment against the boy Friday.

Average daily electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, amounted to 209,500,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Nov. 19, as against 211,600,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 226,200,000 kilowatt-hours in the corresponding week last year.
The bulk of real estate conveyances in New Jersey yesterday consisted of frame flats, small dwellings and business parcels.

To the Editor of The New York Times: How many times have you walked out of the house without a nickel in your pocket? But how many times have you walked out of the house with only a small dividend check in your wallet? Anyway, once is enough.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The White House conference today between President Hoover and the leaders of both parties in Congress emphasized almost unanimous Congressional opposition to postponement of the debt payments due Dec. 15, as well as to cancellation or to revision of the debt structure.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 23. -- At the suggestion of the Coffee Council the Brazilian Government issued a decree today forbidding the planting of new coffee trees anywhere in the entire federation during the next three years. The replanting of trees will be allowed only with the government's consent.
Mr. and Mrs. Ethelbert Ide Low gave a dinner dance last night in the roof garden of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Gertrude Low.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- The Federal court suit to prevent the Louis K. Liggett Company, chain drug-store owners, from going into bankruptcy, thus voiding all leases on its stores, was continued by Judge George A. Welsh today until Jan. 3, while a national committee of the landlords of the 483 Liggett stores considers a proposal for an adjustment of the leases as a solution of the company's financial problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Early enactment of a farm relief bill which its sponsors estimate will enrich producers by at least $250,000,000 annually is to be sought by Democratic leaders in the December session.

Charges of negligence, misconduct and bribe-taking against four inspectors in the bureau of construction and maintenance of the Board of Education were dismissed yesterday by action of the board in adopting reports on the cases over the objections of two of the board members.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 23. -- The strong forces with which Paraguay expected to overwhelm Forts Saavedra and Agua Rica are thoroughly demoralized by failure to advance in nearly four weeks on these stoutly defended Bolivian positions in the disputed Chaco region, according to a reliable military informant.

The second "Dutch treat" report meeting of the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee was held in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, when Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the division, announced that the division had accepted $3,000,000 as its quota of the $15,000,000 being sought by the committee.

Leon S. Senior, general manager of the Compensation Insurance Rating Board, replied yesterday to recent assertions of E.H. Patterson Jr., president of the Hudson-Mohawk Mutual Casualty Company, that the proposed increase of 9.2 per cent in this State in compensation insurance rates was dictated by an "insurance combine."

As a preliminary to the world-wide observance today of the 300th anniversary of the birth of Benedict Spinoza, educational and religious leaders joined last night in paying tribute to the Dutch philosopher, who died in neglect and poverty after having been excommunicated from the Jewish faith for his teachings.

The mulligan stew, mittens, canvas belts and thirty-odd sleeping bags that were taken to the cobbled streets of the City of Hardluck-on-the-River by Urbain Ledoux, better known as Mr. Zero, as part of his annual donation to the poor and needy, were rejected last night.

The eyes of the Eastern football world will be turned toward Providence, R.I., today as Brown and Colgate, the only teams remaining in this section with perfect records to their credit, meet on Aldrich Field, starting at 11 A.M.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- President Hoover's reply to the British and French requests for postponement of the Dec. 15 debt payments and the proposals he declares he is ready to make to Congress have placed France in a somewhat embarrassing position.

Those who realize the perils which can spring from a blind insistence on payment to the United States of "the last red cent" of the war debts will welcome and support the words and the spirit of President HOOVER'S statement on the subject yesterday. He does not abandon the position, strongly held by his predecessors and by Congress, that the debts were contracted as actual loans which would faithfully be repaid.

Except for United States Government bonds, which closed substantially higher, the listed bond market was weak yesterday and all classifications of domestic corporation and foreign loans recorded about the same average loss. The Washington government issues were lifted 1-32 to 6-32 point, and the Liberty 3 1/2s and the Treasury 3 1/2s due in 1943 callable in 1940 touched their previously established highs for the year to date.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 23 (AP). -- The Rev. Henry S. Whitehead, author, traveler and lecturer, died today at Dunedin, near here, where he had resided for three years. He was 50 years old.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- President Hoover's statement today that debtor States had not presented facts that would justify America's postponement of debt payments due in December is not regarded by the British Government as absolutely the last word in the matter or as irrevocably closing the door against further Anglo-American discussion of the advisability of postponement.

GROVE CITY, Pa., Nov. 23. -- The Grove City College eleven defeated Thiel, 14 to 6, in the annual meeting of the rivals today. The game, postponed from last Saturday, marked the close of the season for both teams.

Traditional Thanksgiving Day games, intersectional contests and a number of encounters postponed from last Saturday are among the sixty scholastic gridiron battles slated today in the metropolitan district. With the exception of Westchester, where two big intersectional meetings are predominant on the card, renewals of old-time rivalries head the schedule in virtually every section of the metropolitan area.

Because of Thanksgiving all the financial and commodity markets as well as the banks will be closed today. This means that business generally will be suspended in the financial centres. The foreign markets will, however, be open. Business in the United States will be resumed as usual tomorrow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23. -- Undergraduate approval of the Yale football schedule for next season, containing a total of eight games, an increase of one, today was expressed editorially by The Yale Daily News. The editorial said in part:

State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, will confer tomorrow, after which, it is expected, the date for the resumption of public hearings in the city inquiry will be announced as next Tuesday or Wednesday.

Joseph L. Buttenwieser, operator, returned to the realty market yesterday by purchasing at a court sale tight buildings in the Chelsea section. The property, which was acquired by the operator through the Arcy Realty Corporation, consists of three four-story dwellings at 219-223 West Twenty-fourth Street, two five-story flats at 226-228 West Twenty-fifth Street and three four-story houses converted for business at 230-234 West Twenty-fifth Street, near Seventh Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- The dollar advanced today still further beyond par of exchange, closing at 25.56 1/2 francs. Sterling also recovered somewhat, reaching 83.74 franca in consequence of the belief in financial circles here that the United States will ask Great Britain to make only the interest payment on the debt on Dec. 15, thus reducing the payment from $95,000,000 to $65,000,000.

BOLEY, Okla., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Two white gunmen and a Negro accomplice fell today before the blazing weapons of residents of this all-Negro village, who frustrated the attempted robbery of the Farmers and Merchants State Bank.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ellis Brown will give a tea-dance Dec. 23 in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Helen E.L. Brown.
TORONTO, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Nancolleth Markable of Happy Valley, owned by the Happy Valley Kennels of Philadelphia, led a parade of winners from the United States in the international dog show today.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- Andre Bouilloux-Lafont, director of the Aeropostale Company, the French air-mail service to South America, was arrested today on orders from the examining magistrate and charged with fraud and the use of false documents in his complaint against Paul-Louis Weiller and Emanuel Chaumie, Air Ministry officials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Henry Ford was charged in a suit filed against him in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today with attempting through others since 1930 to obtain control of the Muscle Shoals nitrate and power plants in Alabama.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 23. -- A Thanksgiving pageant was not held at Earlington Heights elementary school today because one of the "Indians," aged 15, shot one of the "Pilgrims," a girl of 14.

The Laurent Club, a lavishly furnished supper club on the ground floor of a twenty-two story apartment house at 324 East Fifty-seventh Street, in the Button Place neighborhood, was raided shortly after last midnight by police plain clothesmen acting on a Federal warrant.
GENEVA, Nov. 23. -- Japan vainly fought lone-handed this evening to prevent the Council of the League of Nations from consulting the Lytton commission further on the Manchurian dispute.

There are signs that important elements in the coming Fusion campaign are not going to be stampeded into enlisting at this time under the banner of any particular candidate. Mr. MACY, chairman of the Republican State Committee, who has not hesitated on occasion to take a hand in local affairs, agrees with "most of the nice things " that have been said about Acting Mayor McKEE and his administration of city affairs during the interregnum.

General John J. Perching, chairman of the Battle Monuments Commission, is due today from France on the United States liner Manhattan. Others on the same ship are Mary Garden, the singer; Count H.T. Lakopolamski, Baron de Reuter and S.R. Romero, consul for Spain at Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Minister from Hungary and Countess Szechenyi, the former Gladys Vanderbilt of New York, entertained with, tea at the legation this after-noon to present to society in Washington their daughter Gladys. Countess Szechenyi received with the debutante, who wore a model gown of blue chiffon.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from Herbert L. Noll raises within me mingled emotions. Although I am happy to know that we have competent brewmasters in this country, I cannot allow to pass, without a peremptory challenge, his animadversions against the product of the Continental breweries.

The railroads of the United States have appointed a national committee to investigate a suggestion that they reduce basic passenger rates. The proposal was made recently in a letter to railroad managements sent by the Interstate Commerce Commission, an action that brought to a head conflicting opinions expressed among railroad officials for years.

Representatives of Typographical Union No. 6 and the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association, meeting yesterday in the league's office at 461 Eighth Avenue, failed again to resolve the deadlock that has marked the negotiations for a new contract for the book and job trade to replace the one that expired last September.

The James Monroe High School soccer team blanked Stuyvesant High of Manhattan, 2 to 0, yesterday before 2,000 at Crotona Park in one of the interborough semi-finals in the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship tournament. The Bronx team's goals both were scored in the second half, the first being tallied by Al Abajian and the second by William Hotonian.

The voters of eleven Massachusetts cities and towns where the question of the United States' entrance into the League of Nations was placed on the official ballot on election day all turned in substantial majorities in favor of it, returns showed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Operators who were frightened yesterday into covering short lines of December wheat on the Board of Trade here recovered confidence today and resumed fairly general liquidation in the near-by future. Some selling of the May was attributed by pit brokers to scattered longs.

Walter P. Chrysler Jr., who says he has made money this year as a publisher of limited editions despite a loss of $38,000 on one book, enters the trade publishing field tomorrow with the publication of a mystery thriller written by a friend. He intends to bring out eight more general trade books during the next year under the imprint of his Cheshire House, Inc., originally incorporated two years ago to publish limited editions exclusively.

A man-hour electrical estimate manual, the first of its kind, which, experts say, makes electrical estimating an exact science, enabling contractors, builders, engineers, architects and others to tell from the beginning just how many man-hours each given job will take, has been published this week by the Rurick Press, Inc., of 303 West Forty-second Street.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- The new antidumping bill which the Minister of Commerce has been authorized to introduce in Parliament was published today. It is intended to make the present law more flexible by permitting swifter action against countries believed to be discriminating or profiting by any sort of export premiums.

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The new bridge that links Jersey City and Newark -- and so completes the express highway between the Holland Tunnel and Elizabeth -- was dedicated today in ceremonies at the Kearny ramp. The bridge itself is about three and a half miles long, crossing the Hackansack and Passaic Rivers, and it was erected at a cost of about $19,000,000.
An active demand for retail shopping space, particularly in the mid-town district, was reflected in the large number of commercial leases reported by brokers yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- After three days of hesitation, Adolf Hitler, in an informal communication delivered to Dr. Otto Meissner, President von Hindenburg's secretary, this evening, was compelled to own that the task of forming a parliamentary government under his leadership was beyond him.

Jobbers Fight Change in Terms. Dry goods wholesalers who have been asked by retail stores to grant longer discounts on wash goods are uniting with converters in the latters' efforts to resist a change in terms. Some of the large Western wholesalers are also converters, and their problem is the same as that of the direct-selling converters.

Admiration was expressed in the banking community here yesterday for President Hoover's suggestion that, in cases of necessity, this country might consider a plan whereby debtor nations could temporarily give this country credit in their own currencies, until such time as an improvement in foreign exchange occurs, when the actual transfer of funds would be made.

When the United States Marshal's auctioneer brought down the hammer yesterday on the seized effects of Peggy Hopkins Joyce at the largest government auction ever held at the Brooklyn Army Base, Fifty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue, the selling price of the lot which included a jeweled plaque and a rather complete wardrobe was $1,103, or about one-sixth of the duty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The House Ways and Means Committee will be called into session Dec. 7, two days after Congress is convened, to consider a tax on legalized beer, Chairman Collier announced this afternoon.

Evidently disappointed over the reported results of the conference between President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt on the war-debt problem, the share market reacted rather sharply yesterday. Some of the selling, no doubt, was induced by the ordinary speculative impulses to liquidate in advance of a holiday, but it was apparent that special pressure originated in quarters that were dissatisfied, for some perverse reason, with the negative consequences of the unique debt discussion in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The White House statement on President Hoover's attitude toward the requests of the debtor nations was as follows:
Our Election Abroad. It would do no harm if occasionally other people had the gift to see us as we see ourselves.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave a luncheon at Fassifern Farm today in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Deming. Others in the party were Mrs. Herbert Coppell and Mrs. George Winkler.

After a long conference with three representatives of the Unemployed Council of Greater New York yesterday. Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee said he had refused to accede to their demands that food and shelter be provided for 600 hunger marchers bound for Washington, who are planning to pass through the city next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- In his visit of less than twenty-four hours at the capital, ending this afternoon, President-eject Roosevelt assumed control of the Democratic forces, solidified their ranks and left them with a broad program for the short session.

A protest by Deputy Controller Prial that city employes should not hold two jobs, and that to permit them to do so would not aid the efforts of the city to relieve distress, was ineffective yesterday in opposing an application by three Board of Education clerks for an order directing the Controller to pay them for work done at public playgrounds last Summer during their vacations.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 23 (AP). -- The management of Consolidated Copper Mines, Inc., of New York was sustained in a report filed in Chancery Court today by Clarence A. Southerland, Wilmington attorney, who was appointed special master last June in the suit of Paul A. Gow against the corporation.

The campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee for a fund of $15,000,000 to finance jobs and relief for the unemployed passed the $5,000,000 mark yesterday as the campaign gathered momentum in a mass effort to attain the final goal.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee bought the first Christmas seals sold in the annual Christmas seal drive at City Hall yesterday, from Carol and Georgia Volkman, 7 and 3 years old respectively, and issued a proclamation asking the people of the city to support the movement to stamp out tuberculosis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Capital net gains realized upon the sale of securities held for more than two years may not be reduced by losses sustained upon the sale of securities held for two years or less, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- H. O. (Fritz) Crisler, head football coach at Princeton University, today reviewed his first year at Old Nassau and called it the "most enjoyable season I have ever experienced."

TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Canada won the internaional officers' team challenge trophy, donated by G. Howard Ferguson, Canadian High Commissioner in London, at the Royal Horse Show tonight. Canada took the cup from the Irish Free State team, winners in 1931.
LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The tone was much better on the Stock Exchange today, but business showed little improvement. British funds maintained yesterday's firmness and industrials generally recovered.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Alleging breach of contract, Captain John J. McEwan, recently suspended as head football coach at Holy Cross, today asked the Superior Court to restrain the college trustees from Interfering with the carrying out of his duties outlined in his contract with Holy Cross.

The Metropolitan Square Corporation will receive 100,000 new common shares of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation as consideration for the modification of the twenty-year leases under which the latter company is to occupy space in Radio City, it is revealed in an application to the New York Stock Exchange to list the additional shares, approved yesterday by the governing committee of the Exchange.

Sixteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were offered at liquidation sales conducted by auctioneers yesterday. Most of the offerings consisted of multi-family buildings which were put up for sale as the result of foreclosure actions.

The principals of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference will meet in London today to consider the upward revision of passenger fares and the reclassification of some types of ships as a means of reducing heavy losses incurred in the last year by operators on the Atlantic.

Feodor Chaliapin, Russian bass, gave his second recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, assisted by John Corigliano, violinist. The singer's program included Leporello's aria from Mozart's "Don Juan," Moussorgsky's "Song of the Flea" and "Trepak," and semi-popular Russian songs ranging from the tragic to the ludicrous.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 23. -- Heartly (Hunk) Anderson, Notre Dame football coach, was pessimistic tonight as a mild Influenza attack swept five of his players from the playing field to the university infirmary.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Opposition to a Federal sales tax, to any reduction in Federal income taxes and to the issuance of bonds to cover current governmental expenses was expressed in resolutions adopted today by the National Grange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Five loans in as many States amounting to $1,094,372 were approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Of the total authorized $965,000 is for financing construction of self-sustaining projects. The other $129,372 was a relief loan to Michigan to enable it to carry on relief work in five political subdivisions for the rest of the year.

Because of the failure of the Friars Club to pay a butter and egg bill for which a judgment for $1,130 was obtained in the City Court a year ago, Supreme Court Justice Callahan appointed yesterday Hyman Bushel, a lawyer, receiver under a bond of $25,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Debutantes' hopes of attending an inaugural ball March 4 seemed brighter today, following the President-elect's hasty conference with Admiral Cary T. Grayson, who will serve as chairman of the inaugural committee.

BOSTON, Nov. 23. -- Gilman Moncure Parker, staff writer of The Daily Record and former Chicago and New York newspaper man, died early yesterday from accidental carbon monoxide poisoning suffered when a heater in his Beacon Hill apartment burned up the oxygen in his room as he lay sleeping.

New York University's eight-game football schedule will be brought to a close today when the Violet team meets Carnegie Tech at the Yankee Stadium at 2 P.M. The contest will be the seventh in a series which began in 1926. N.Y.U. has captured five of the six games thus far.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 23. -- Foreign Minister Titulescu announced in Parliament today that the negotiations with Soviet Russia for the conclusion of a pact of non-aggression had finally been broken off because it had been impossible to reach an agreement on the vexed question of Bessarabia.

Sedgewick Harvey, Salem-Crescent A.C. boxer who holds the national junior featherweight championship, scored an impressive victory last night at Madison Square Garden in the Metropolitan A.A.U. boxing tournament for the New York American's Christmas and Relief Fund.

Another stage has been reached in the patriotic movement to conserve the Saratoga battlefield, reconstruct the features of the conflict that was "the turning point" of the American Revolution, raise Appropriate memorials, build approaches to it, provide it with good roads and transform the countryside, one of the most beautiful in the States, into a military park.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Charles Hammer of Garden City, L. I., charged that he had been deprived fraudulently of $286,177 by Christian H. Werner of New Rochelle and Sterling B. Smith of New York, former president and treasurer, respectively, of the American Metal Cap Company, in a suit filed in the Supreme Court here today.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Eight men under arrest in connection with the theft of ballots from the City Hall, including five policemen and three employes of the city Department of Parks and Public Property, were named in an indictment charging conspiracy to steal, returned to Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan this afternoon.
