Aristocratic cats with pedigrees as long as their tails, timid little rabbits with tremulous pink noses and poultry -- from Plymouth Rocks to old English game bantams -- competed for blue ribbons and silver trophies yesterday at the fourth annual pet show in Madison Square Garden.

A lively and charming performance last night in the Metropolitan Opera House of Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'amore," was also signalized by the debut with the Metropolitan Association of Tito Schipa. This was not Mr. Schipa's first appearance in New York by any means, for he has appeared both in recital and in opera.

The first general report regarding the quail which the New York State Conservation Department distributed on Long Island late last Summer discloses an odd situation. These quail, about 2,000 in number, were raised in captivity on the State quail farm at Middle Island, L.I.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23. -- The first fast track of the week at Bowie prevailed today, but neverthless the Espino filly Espinetta, which scored at long odds recently through sloppy going at Pimlico, annexed the victory. Espinetta, bearing L. Perry's silks, won in the easiest sort of fashion by four lengths and returned $10.50 in the mutuels.

The proposal for an extraordinary session of the present Legislature to repeal the mandatory salary laws and give the New York City administration power to reopen the budget is not favored by the Republicans. They prefer to have any such action wait until the 1933 Legislature meets.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 23. -- Representatives of Schenectady's com- mercial, Industrial and professional life honored at a public luncheon to- day three of their most distinguished scientists. Dr. Willis Rodney Whit- ney, retiring director of the General Electric Research Laboratory; Dr. William David Coolidge, who succeeds him, and Dr. Irving Langmuir, their associate, to whom the 1932 Noble Prize in chemistry has just been awarded.
PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 23. -- Halbert J. Blue of Aberdeen, N.C., and Eric D. Thomson of St. Andrews, N.B., gained the final round of the seventeenth annual Carolina golf tourney today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Official announcement was made today that Foreign Commissar Litvinoff and Stanislas Patek, the Polish Ambassador, had formally signed a conciliation treaty for the peaceful settlement of any disputes arising between the two countries.

Dr. William Beebe returned from Bermuda yesterday after another season spent in prying into the private life of deep-sea tropical fish. He brought back his famous bathysphere in which he and his assistant descended nearly one-half mile off Nonsuch Island.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 23. -- The first of the Winter racing meetings will open tomorrow at Jefferson Park, where the Thanksgiving Day Handicap will be the feature. Eight have been named for the main event, with Lullaby II top weight with 116 pounds.

Another drop of 0.7 point from the previous week carried The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices down to 88.1 on Tuesday. It is still 0.8 above the postwar low of 87.3 on June 14, but well below a year ago, when it stood at 101.2.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Turkey will be conspicuously absent from the menu when inmates of the State's big prisons file into their huge mess halls for Thanksgiving dinner tomorrow.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire of Westchester County said today he was "still open to conviction" as to the nature of the mysterious death here last night of Dr. Augustus F. Paulsen, surgeon dentist, of the Bronx.

It was not without opposition that Congress authorized the issuance of the first national Thanksgiving Proclamation under the Constitution of the United States. A member from South Carolina observed inthe debate that

MADRID, Nov. 23. -- The accused turned on their accusers today. While the Parliamentary Court of Responsibilities was trying eighteen members of the late Premier Primo de Rivera's directorate, another reactionary, Martin de Velasco, in another building of the Cortes accused Premier Manuel Azana of being "a second Primo de Rivera."
Press comment generally throughout the country was favorable to President Hoover's views on the wardebt questions. Following are the expressions of some of the leading newspapers:

Paul P. Crosbie of Long Island City, who resigned Tuesday as a Democratic district captain and as a member of the Anarock Democratic Club, denied yesterday that he had ever requested Register Peter J. McGarry of Queens, who becomes sheriff Jan. 1, to take him in as a partner in his private real estate and insurance business.

Unless there are wise planning and prompt decisive action, tax sales and mortgage foreclosures in the Western farming districts will reach calamitous proportions this Winter, Henry A. Wallace of Des Moines, Iowa, editor of Wallace's Farmer, said yesterday at a luncheon given for him in the Bankers Club by Edward L. Bernays.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- Winston Churchill, author and statesman, unleashed the die-hards' attack on the present India round-table conference in the House of Commons today while the delegates were hard at work in a committee room of the House of Lords only a hundred yards away.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Colonel Raymond Robins, who dropped out of sight in September and caused a nation-wide sensation, sped out of Asheville in a large automobile late today and headed southward, presumably for his Brooksville (Fla.) home.

Mrs. Catherine Carl, 74 years old, a cripple for four years, was burned to death yesterday afternoon as she sat in her apartment at 40 Columbia Place, Brooklyn, awaiting the return of her 75-year-old husband, William, who had gone to make Thanksgiving purchases.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Two years of Cornell supremacy over Pennsylvania came to an end on Franklin Field today as the Red and Blue staged a 58-yard march to a winning touchdown in one of the most thrilling closing periods in the thirty-nine years' history of this Thanksgiving Day fixture.

Alarm clocks jingled early in Greenwich Village yesterday, despite the fact that it was a holiday. In 125 homes at least the bells informed their owners that the annual Thanksgiving celebration of the Original Hound Guards of the Village was due to start at 9 A.M.

C.M. Mitchell and E.H. Locatelli tied for the high scratch cup in the holiday shoot held over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished the regular event with a card of 96 out of a possible 100 targets. In the 25-target shoot-off, Mitchell scored by 23 to 22.

The finance committee of the Board of Aldermen begins its study of the 1933 city budget in executive session at City Hall today, with the probability that, for the first time in years, items will be stricken from it and other items reduced, as the first steps in a Tammany program of economy.

CALGARY, Alta., Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- A conference of the four leading wheat exporting countries of the world with a view to curtailing acreage was suggested at the Alberta Wheat Pool's annual meeting today by C.W. Peterson, farm paper publisher.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Undeeated this year, Steven Szumachowski of Mont Pleasant High School of Schenectady brought his second season of cross-country running to a brilliant conclusion by winning the seventh annual national interscholastic run in record time over the two and a half mile Branch Brook Park course this morning.

The man is to be congratulated and envied who, coming into possession of what Lord MACAULAY called "not a reflex of heaven but heaven itself," has had the rare privilege and joy of giving it to the country in which it lies. As announced in yesterday's TIMES, Mr. WILLIAM BOWERS BOURN of California has purchased and presented to the Irish Free State the Lakes of Killarney and the islands to which they give setting.

A nation with a knowledge of poverty observed yesterday its traditional day of thanks with prayers as fervent and hopes as buoyant as were those of the Pilgrim settlers who began the custom 309 years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Victor Smith, 19-year-old South African flier, completed a flight of 11 days and 15 hours from Cape Town today, making the last few miles as a passenger after cracking up near Ashford, in Kent.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- George Lambert, a Liberal member of Parliament, placed on the paper for future business today the following resolution:

Opera broadcasting was ushered in yesterday for the season over WJZ's coast-to-coast network, directly from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House. Delibes's "Lakme" was the production. Using a new and improved type of microphone, the music was transmitted with unusual fidelity.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Two goals down at the end of the first period, the Ottawa Senators sprang a surprise tonight, running up six goals in the second and third periods to win from the Montreal Maroons in their National Hockey League game, 6 -- 3.

The American business of ragamuffing turned the corner yesterday, thus beating the occupations of steel and copper working and car loading. But, alas! it was the wrong corner. A cop was down there, instead of coppers, the difference being more than just the apparent plural.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 24 -- In observance of the seventh anniversary of the consecration of the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires as Bishop of Long Island, the Council of the Diocese has sent him a letter of appreciation signed by every member of the body.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24 -- Total savings of $431,692 in Yale's 1932-3 budget and additions to the university's endowment funds during the past year making the total on June 30 $95,320,171 were revealed today in the annual treasurer's report.

GENEVA, Nov. 24. -- Hopes of informal talks this week among the Big Five on the German demand for equal rights in armaments seemed definitely abandoned today, largely because of the reaction to the debt situation.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Electing to have his case dealt with summarily by the magistrate, Joseph Volodarsky, departmental manager of Russian Oil Products, Ltd., was fined L50 [$162.50] for attempting to bribe Marcus Weinstein, employe of the Shell-Mex and British Petroluem Company, Ltd.

The New York retail trading area ranks above the rest of the country in the number of automobiles and radio sets owned within its borders, according to a statement made public by the Merchants' Association yesterday.
Mary Garden, opera singer, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan to get away from a Europe that is too peaceful and calm for one of her temperament.

BUFFALO, Nov. 24 -- A call to orthodox Jewry to unite to finish rebuilding Palestine as a Jewish homeland was sounded today by Rabbi Wolf Gold of Brooklyn, president of the Mizrachi Organization of America, at the opening session of the annual convention of that body.

Some doubt was cast last night on the validity of the latest honor bestowed upon Surrogate John P. O'Brien, Mayor-elect of New York City. It was intimated that the future Chief Magistrate of the city was taken in when, decked in a ceremonial war bonnet, he smoked the pipe of peace last Sunday night which made him Chief Big Thunder of the Blackfoot Indian tribe.

MALVERN, Pa., Nov. 24 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney of New York rode her horse Murphy to a victory in the President's Cup for ladies' hunters, one of the feature events of the annual Radnor Hunt Horse Show, held near here today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 -- A California lad who wandered to northern fields to gain his gridiron laurels, John Eubank, kicked a field goal from the 40-yard line in the last second of play to give Washington Stats a 3-to-0 victory over the University of California at Los Angeles today.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 24 -- Professor Auguste Piccard spoke publicly in English for the first time at a reception given for representatives of American newspapers at the home of one of his friends today.

Every visitor to a transatlantic ship docking at a pier in the port of New York will be assessed 10 cents as a contribution to the support of unemployed seamen, it was announced yesterday by the joint emergency committee of seamen's welfare agencies.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 24 -- Thanksgiving Day charity dinners were more numerous than ever before in Nassau and Suffolk Counties today, while special collections for the poor were taken at every Thanksgiving church service.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- Senator Arthur Meighen, government leader, told a delegation of railway brotherhood officials this morning that the present railway policy toward labor had reached its limit and could not be extended.

WINNIPEG, Man., Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Apathy of overseas buyers and absence of inter-spreading operations because of the holiday on grain exchanges in the United States set the wheat market here back into dull routine trading today. Prices at the ciose were 1/8 to 1/4 cent a bushel lower than yesterday's final quotations.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Iowa corn is in the market for Arkansas lumber on a car-lot basis. And E.D. White, assistant marketing economist of the State Agricultural Extension Service, sees no reason why these surpluses should not be put to work devouring each other.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 -- A Thanksgiving Day gift of the Methodist Episcopal Church to the American Federation of Labor today was an agreement to unionize the printing plant of the Methodist Book Concern in this city which publishes all the Sunday-school literature of the church in the North and West and part of the literature of the colored Methodist Episcopal Church in the South.
CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 24 -- Pennsylvania Military College closed its football season today by beating St. John's of Annapolis, 22 to 0, before a big holiday crowd.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- President Hoover's reply to the French request for an extension of time pending a new discussion of the international debts reached the Foreign Office this afternoon and after translation was handed to Premier Herriot for study. It will be discussed at a Cabinet meeting Saturday and a reply will be drafted which, it is expected, will be closely similar to that which the British Government is preparing.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 24 -- The University of Alabama football team defeated Vanderbilt University, 20 to 0, before 17,000 onlookers today. The result was an upset, Vanderbilt being a 6-1 pre-game favorite.

Ivan R. Gates, founder of the Gates Flying Circus and perhaps the most famous barnstorming aviator in the country, jumped yesterday morning from a window of his apartment on the sixth floor at 220 West Twenty-fourth Street and was killed. Mrs. Gates was in the room and tried to keep him from jumping.

Utility and symmetry -- one may well add beauty -- are combined in the Diagonal Overpass or viaduct highway between Jersey City and Newark which Governor MOORE symbolically opened to traffic by cutting a blue ribbon. Yesterday motor traffic began to flow east and west with thanksgiving for valuable time saved by eliminating congestion at drawbridges on the Hackensack and Passaic Rivers.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Eddie Guerin, who escaped from Devil's Island in 1904, was sentenced to one year's imprisonment here today for stealing a woman's handbag on Armistice Day. The presiding Judge, Sir Percival Clarke, said that but for Guerin's age his sentence would have been longer.

Chairman COLLIER of the House Ways and Means Committee has called its members to meet on Dec. 7 to begin a discussion of a tax on beer. In the present disequilibrium of the budget it is as a revenue measure that the modification of the Volstead act is most important.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 -- St. Bndeaux, bearing the Greentree Stable colors of Mrs. Payne Whitney and one of the largest money winners in 1931, scored his most important victory of the year today when he won the Thanksgiving Handicap by a nose before a throng estimated at 20,000.
PARIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 24 -- There is no longer the slightest doubt about the right of Colgate to call its football team a great one. This morning, before a crowd of 26,000 that filled Brown's stadium, Colgate broke at last the string of Brown victories, rushing and passing its way to a brilliant 21-0 victory.
A Good Bookkeeper Needed. In the early hours of the morning the Caliph found a Citizen in a dinner jacket seated on the sidewalk and beating his head against the walls of the Paramount Theatre.

The one distinctively American festival which is annually celebrated whether the year be one of plenty or of want has at its heart a recognition of an overruling Providence and a charity that makes the whole world kin. It is primarily a family day, but the centripetal force of the human affection that dwells in the home makes those in need its nearer neighbors.

BARNEGAT, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Unemployed families in Ocean County and other parts of Southern Jersey, through the "bounty of nature" and the enterprise of hunters, enjoyed Thanksgiving feasts of wild duck, pheasant and other game such as their ancestors had in Colonial days when turkey could not always be had but wild fowl and other game were there for the taking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- All ranks of official life and leaders of resident society were represented at the annual Thanksgiving Navy Relief Ball given tonight at the Willard Hotel. It was a gay and brilliant spectacle.

All financial and commercial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving Day. The banks also being closed, there were no Wall Street quotations for money or foreign exchange. On European markets, sterling declined somewhat further; its early price of $3.24 1/4, against Wednesday's New York low rate of $3.25, being nearly down to last December's low figure of $3.23 3/4.

The Austrian Government having failed to remit the funds necessary to cover the service on its League of Nations loan since July 1, the trustees announced yesterday that in order to provide the paying agents with funds to meet the semi-annual coupons due on Dec. 1 it had been necessary to draw on the reserve fund which is guaranteed by Great Britain, France, Czechoslovakia, Italy, Belgium, Sweden, Denmark and Holland.

The emotional wave of progressivlsm which farmers, small business men, politicians and writers pushed high in the time of La Follette and Roosevelt left little of material benefit behind it, John Chamberlain writes in "Farewell to Reform: Being a History of the Rise, Life and Decay of the Progressive Mind in America," published today by Live-right.

Civic pride was much in evidence yesterday in Hardluck-on-the-River, the city of the jobless, as Thanksgiving found its 250 residents stirring feast-day dinner pails containing edibles that they said had been gained honestly, independently and without recourse to the thousands of charitable agencies in the metropolis.

Two old Manhattan retail establishments yesterday announced the leasing of new store quarters on Fifth Avenue. A number of commercial rentals also were reported by brokers for the midtown office district. General realty trading was restricted owing to the Thanksgiving holiday.

SEATTLE, Nov. 24 -- Squeezing out a slim but sparkling 9-to-6 victory over a stubborn band of Washington Huskies on a mud-covered gridiron today, the Southern California Tro- jans finished their 1932 Pacific Coast Conference season undefeated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Germany's defense against the charge of responsibility for the Black Tom and Kingsland disasters was ended today by Dr. Wilhelm Tannenberg before the Mixed Claims Commission. Robert W. Bonynge of New York, the American agent, will he heard in rebuttal tomorrow.

New York University completed only two forward passes out of fifteen attempts in its final game of the season against Carnegie Tech yesterday at the Yankee Stadium, but the two successful thrusts produced touchdowns and enabled the Violet to defeat the Tartans, 13 to 6.

The $19,000,000 elevated highway between Newark and Jersey City, which was dedicated Wednesday, was opened to traffic along its three-and-a-half miles at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. When employes of the New Jersey State Highway Commission removed barriers from the approaches, there were about two dozen automobiles waiting at each end.

Arrested yesterday morning as the result of a "tip" to the police that an unnamed gangster was to be kidnapped for ransom in front of a West Forty-ninth Street hotel, James Cahill, 27 years old, a former policeman, of 121 West Forty-sixth Street, was held in Brooklyn police headquarters early this morning on a charge of homicide in connection with a killing in a Brooklyn speakeasy on Sept. 3.

Two appeals to the generosity of New Yorkers, issued as usual this Thanksgiving week, must not go unheeded. The money collected by the United Hospital Fund is spent on free hospital treatment for the sick poor. Whether there are more sick than in other years may be a matter of dispute, but beyond the shadow of a doubt there are more poor.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- "Complete harmony" prevailed at today's meeting of the Atlantic Conference, according to a brief official statement issued tonight when the members, including representatives of the French and Canadian Pacific lines, adjourned until tomorrow.
READING, Pa., Nov. 24 -- Albright defeated Ursinus, its traditional rival, 26 to 0, today with the Hatton Brothers and De Franco featuring for the victors. The line-up:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The volume of industrial output was maintained in October, following a considerable increase during August and September, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly summary of business and financial conditions.

The upland game-shooting season in Connecticut closed on Wednesday and that in New York State, with the exception of Long Island, on Nov. 15. New Jersey's upland game still can be taken until Dec. 15. Ducks may be shot in up-State New York until Dec. 15 and on Long Jsland until Dec. 31.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -- Led by a charging fullback whose second-half appearance in the line-up transformed a battered squad into a fighting, yard-gaining eleven, St. Mary's Gaels galloped to a 7-0 victory today over the University of Oregon while 20,000 fans cheered.

Louis Shebansky, 17 years old, of 389 Chester Street, Brooklyn, was slightly wounded in the left arm and left ankle yesterday afternoon by Patrolman William Harrigan of the Canarsie Precinct after he was interrupted with two other young men attempting to start a car that previously had been reported as stolen.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 24 -- The fast-stepping backs of Tennessee gave another brilliant exhibition today as the Volunteers raced to a 26 -- 0 victory over Kentucky on Shields Watkins Field. The decisive triumph avenged the three tie games of recent years in which the Wildcats dashed the title hopes of the teams coached by Major Bob Neyland.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- Oregon State's football eleven, en route home on a 9,000 mile trip that carried it into the East, fell today before the University of Detroit, 14 to 6, in a Thanksgiving Day game witnessed by 10,000 persons.

With the work of the battle monuments commission, which has kept him occupied in Europe for several years, virtually completed, General John J. Pershing returned to the United States on the United States liner Manhattan yesterday in time to have his Thanksgiving dinner with friends and relatives.

Mgr. John P. Chidwick, who was chaplain of the hatlleship Maine when she was blown up in Havana Harbor, in a sermon yesterday at the Capuchin Church of St. John the Baptist, Thirtieth Street, near Seventh Avenue, declared the world was in a "mess" because the name of God was not invoked at the drawing up of the Treaty of Versailles.

Frank Butter of the German-American A.C. finished first in the twenty-second annual walk from City Hall to Coney Island yesterday, leading a field of seventy-five in the ten-and-a-half-mile Thanksgiving Day fixture. His actual time was 1:34:46.6, while his handicap was 24 minutes.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 24 -- Scoring two touchdowns in the fourth period, the University of Nebraska, 1932 big six champions, closed its conference and home season today with a 21 to 6 victory over Missouri University. The Huskers led 7 to 6 at the half.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- By the narrow margin of one point the Iona School football eleven retained its unbeaten and untied record for the seasons of 1931 and 1932 by vanquishing Georgetown Prep of Maryland, 14 to 13, at the Iona field today.

"The Mad Hopes," Romney Brent's comedy which Bela Blau is now presenting in Boston under the title of "No Money to Guide Her," has been added to next week's Broadway theatrical openings. It will arrive on Thursday evening at the Broadhurst Theatre.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 24 -- Both Bolivia and Paraguay apparently are expecting the Chaco war to acquire a new impetus with the arrival of General Hans Kundt in Bolivia, whose army he trained before a revolution forced him to return to Germany two years ago.

Frederick Van Wyck, a native New Yorker, who has lived for eighty years and can remember when Fifth Avenue was lined only with trees and homes, has written an anecdotal record of his time called "Recollections of an Old New Yorker." The book will be published on Nov. 30 by Live-right.

TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- News of the rift that occurred today in the heretofore friendly cooperation between Russia and Japan in Northwest Manchuria came from Eiji Amo, Japanese Charge d'Affaires in Moscow, who sent the Russian Government's request to the Foreign Office.

Bank clearings continued to decline in the week ended Wednesday, the total for twenty-two leading cities in the United States in that period falling 25.5 per cent below the amount for the same period a year previously, according to Dun's Review.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the late campaign is over, the Forgotten Man is perforce still just the Forgotten Man: I mean the individual home owner. It would seem that the depression had been created expressly for him; no one else has suffered so severely.

The sweep, the splendor and inspiration of Gotterdammerung, if they are not matchless, are incomparable. The performance last night at the Metropolitan was the kind of presentation only possible to a great opera company with its resources, and the presentation had several features of exceptional interest.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- As a vice chairman of the Committee for the Consideration of Intergovernmental Debts, Edward A. O'Neal today declared that this country's internal debt situation should be considered if there were to be any review of the war debts.

Trailing until there were less than two minutes of regular time to play, the New York Rangers tallied a goal which put them on even terms with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden, last night, and despite their furious efforts in the ten-minute overtime session, the New York skaters were unable to register another score.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Communist "hunger march" agitators, ostensibly seeking to petition President Hoover in behalf of the "child misery conference," sponsored by the Unemployed Councils of America, were frustrated at the White House gates this afternoon by metropolitan and White House police, while thousands of curious citizens crowded available vantage points to witness the much-heralded demonstration.

A tea dance was given yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Jay Tompkins in the Japanese room of the St. Regis to introduce their daughter, Miss Harriet Schurz Tompkins. Tropical tree ferns decorated the room and Miss Tompkins received in a bower of these plants interspersed with chrysanthemums.

Forced to come from behind for the first time this season, George Washington High School's undefeated and untied football team scored 13 points in the second period to defeat James Monroe High, 13 to 6, yesterday before a crowd of 7,000 at the George Washington High School Stadium.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Thomas S. Baker, president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology, has accepted an invitation of the Oberlaender Trust of the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation to spend January and February in Germany visiting and lecturing at some of the leading German universities.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24 -- With the coveted prize of a place on the all-America team at stake, six teams, representing the Northeast, mid-West and Southeast sectors, were in action today in the inaugural play of the national field hockey tournament.

ROME, Nov. 24 -- President Hoover's attitude on European war debts has not created great surprise here because it was fully expected after the declared policies of the Democratic and Republican candidates in the Presidential election. It is believed here, nevertheless, that the Democratic victory apparently stiffened the position of the Republicans.
ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 24 -- Virginia Polytechnic Institute defeated Virginia Military Institute today, 26 -- 0. It was the thirtieth game between the rivals and a crowd of 16,000 was on hand.

"It is felt that progress has been made" were the words of the White House communique issued after the meeting of the President and the President-elect on the question of the war debts. Within twenty-four hours there was heartening proof that this is so.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 -- Men, women and children lined the sidewalks of Central Avenue and West Market Street ten deep this morning to watch the annual Thanksgiving Day parade of the L. Bamberger Co. department store. The police estimated that between 200,000 and 300,000 spectators stood along the five-mile walk.
PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 24 -- Halbert J. Blue of Aberdeen, N.C., defeated Eric Thomson of St. Andrews, N.B., 2 up, in the eighteen-hole final of the seventeenth annual Carolina golf tourney today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A report issued today by the committee on the costs of medical care cited a rapid decline in the incomes of physicians during the depression and declared that even in the boom year 1929 half the American physicians received a net income of only $3,800 or less.

The Committee of Fourteen, which was formed in 1905 to fight commercialized vice, has stopped its work and its affairs are being liquidated as rapidly as possible, Dr. James Pedersen, its chairman, announced yesterday in a letter to the thirty-seven members of the organization's general committee.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Thanksgiving Day at the National Pet Show in Madison Square Garden was marked by the largest attendance recorded since the inception of the show four years ago. Hundreds of children, accompanied by adults, swarmed around the birds, wild and tame animals on exhibition.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Three New York trios moved into the semi-finals of the annual Atlantic City indoor polo tournament by triumphing in the Municipal Auditorium tonight. Red Bank is the fourth team that continues in the play.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- A "demonstrative" mass trial will be held tomorrow in a village of Sverdlovsk Province, in the Ural region, where a gang of peasant boys recently lynched two youths who had denounced their father for conniving at the activities of kulaks [peasants with a small property].

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 24 -- Representatives of virtually every branch of industry and commerce met tonight under the auspices of the Commerce Defense League to draw up plans for a nation-wide tax strike in opposition to government proposals for increased taxation pending before the extra session of Congress, designed to balance the increased budget.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Lady Constance Stewart-Richardson, famous sports-woman, whose first stage appearance in New York as a scantily clad Greek classical dancer evoked a storm of criticism in 1909, died here today at the age of fifty years.

Activity will be resumed today on all of the financial and commodity Exchanges. The banks and other business institutions will also be reopened after having been closed in observance of the Thanksgiving holiday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In all the objections to forgiving the war debts and reparations I have yet to see offered what seems to me the supreme objection -- an objection not on materialistic grounds, but in the great interests of mankind.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 24 -- The Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Ogden L. Mills were hosts at a family Thanksgiving dinner in the Homestead today. Their guests included Mrs. Mills's son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Fell Jr.; Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Fish, Miss T.S. Burke, Walter Hopkins and Philip Fell.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A crazed Filipino armed with knives went on a murderous rampage in the streets here today, killing six persons and wounding fifteen before police answering riot calls ran down and captured him.

It appears now that Coach Heartly Anderson will have eleven men on the field in Notre Dame uniforms after all. A few days ago there were disheartening reports from South Bend. The team was holding secret practice and a band of enthusiastic students broke open the gate and marched in to cheer the squad. Taking a good look around, the invading students burst into tears.
A half-dozen grinning monster writhed and twisted down the sunlit canyon of Broadway from 110th Street to Herald Square yesterday afternoon in Macy's annual Thanksgiving Day parade.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Nov. 25 -- A Chinese Foreign Office communique issued here today charged that 2,700 Chinese peasants were massacred by machine guns recently in Northern Manchuria by Japanese troops.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I point out, in reference to your resume of the Japanese reply to the Lytton report, that there is a constant repetition of allusions to the "Chang" dynasty or administration?

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Five thousand racing: fans pretended not to notice the weather today as they turned out in a raw November rain to celebrate the Thanksgiving Day opening of Jefferson Park's fifty-one-day Winter meeting at Shrewsbury.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Throughout London tonight, on posters on the streets and in huge type across the front page of Lord Beaverbrook's evening newspaper, it is proclaimed: "Britain Will Not Pay."

BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 24 -- Closing with a dazzling burst of speed, Wilf McCluskey, sturdy Canadian, representing the Monarch A.C. of Toronto, today won the twenty-third running of the Berwick modified marathon.

CAP D'ANTIBES, France, Nov. 24 -- Former Mayor Walker of New York told his entourage today that he was in fear of a nervous breakdown, in explaining a rule he has adopted of retiring at 10 P.M. at the hotel where he is staying with friends.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The government ordered mobilization of troops at Ambato today to reinforce the garrison at the capital, following upon disclosure of an anti-administration plot attributed to the Conservative party.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Ferguson will give a dinner Dec. 23 in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Ruth W. Ferguson.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 24 -- With the Louisiana prohibition law already repealed so far as the police are concerned, New Orleans hotels, restaurants and barrooms which were famous before enactment of the Volstead law are completing arrangements to reopen their bars as soon as the law is modified or the Eighteenth Amendment is repealed.
UNIVERSITY, Va., Nov. 24 -- Virginia's eleven registered a 14 to 7 victory over North Carolina today for its first triumph over the Tarheels in six years. A crowd of 15,000 saw the game.

Four wealthy young college students, one a nephew of Mgr. John L. Belford, pastor of the Church of the Nativity in Brooklyn, were arrested early yesterday morning on charges of disorderly conduct after they had tried to "crash" an exclusive Thanksgiving Eve debutante dance at the Heights Casino, 75 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

Held in firm check for the greater part of the game by a persevering Commerce eleven, De Witt Clinton slammed over a touchdown in the final period to turn back its traditional foe, 6 to 0, in the feature contest of a schoolboy double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Twice coming from behind, the Staten Island Stapletons played a 13 -- 13 tie with the New York Football Giants in their annual Thanksgiving Day game before a crowd of 8,000 yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, S.I.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 24 -- Under Federal indictment the Brevities Publishing Company, publishers of The Baltimore Brevities and similar weeklies in other cities, informed United States Attorney Simon E. Sobeloff today that they had abandoned publication of all papers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Of the $274,350,405 in loans authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from July 21 through Sept. 30, which were definitely allocated in individual States, California, with $49,971,922 in authorized loans, has received more than twice as much as any other State, according to a review of monthly reports to Congress by the corporation.

The three principal committees that have undertaken in different fields to protect the holders of defaulted real estate bonds since the first of this year have combined into a unified organization which will take over their separate responsibilities today under the name of the Real Estate Bondholders' Protective Committee, 31 Nassau Street, with George Emlen Roosevelt as chairman.
TOKYO, Nov. 24 -- A request to leave Russia was sent by the Soviet Government today to the Japanese military mission at Dauria, Siberia, where it has been making futile ef-
LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 24 -- Frank lin and Marshall rallied to tie Gettysburg today, 6 -- 6, in their annual football battle before a crowd of 15,000.

Miss Lydia Summers of New York and Thomas L. Thomas of Scranton, Pa., were announced yesterday by the Atwater Kent Foundation as winners of the Northeastern district semi-final singing contest held in this city Nov. 16 as part of the sixth National Radio Audition for young amateurs of the country.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 24 -- West Orange conquered Columbia High of South Orange and Maplewood today, 13 to 0, before 8,000.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 -- North Dakota's Sioux showed a distinct liking for muddy going in a steady downpour of rain today to overwhelm Loyola University's Wolves, 18 to 6.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 24 -- Two Americans, Terris Moore and Richard Burdsall, members of a party of five American explorers, scaled Mount Minya Konka, in Sikong on the border of Szechwan and Tibet, Oct. 28, according to telegraphic advices received tonight from Jack Young, a member of the party.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- War-debt developments depressed the stock markets today and prices dropped. British funds weakened as a result of a further decline in sterling exchange on New York to $3.24 1/4.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 24 -- University of Maryland scored a decisive 23-to-0 triumph over its rival, Johns Hopkins University, before 12,000 persons today.

A crowd of 10,000 persons including Governor Moore of New Jersey and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City saw Dickinson High School's powerful eleven stop St. Peter's Prep, 13 to 0, in the twenty-fourth renewal of their traditional rivalry at Jersey City yesterday.

The Green Bay Packers retained their lead for the championship of the National Professional Football League yesterday by defeating the Brooklyn Dodgers, 7 -- 0, at Ebbets Field. A crowd of 30,000 persons, one of the largest gatherings ever to witness a professional football game in Brooklyn, saw the battle.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- George Bernard Shaw tonight delivered his verdict on the United States election which, he declared, accomplished exactly nothing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Before the largest gathering here of the season, George Washington and Oklahoma played to a 7-7 tie while a crowd of 30,000 looked on today at Griffith Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- While administration leaders appeared confident today that progress had been made in handling the foreign debt situation, some concern was manifested over the nature of a second British note, expected within a few days, which, according to reports, will detail the difficulties confronted by that nation in making the payment due Dec. 15.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 24 -- Temporarily laying aside consideration of public questions, Franklin D. Roosevelt, President-elect, arrived this morning at Warm Springs and received a warm welcome from the entire population of the village and the surrounding countryside.
LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 24 -- Frank lin and Marshall rallied to tie Gettysburg today, 6 -- 6, in their annual football battle before a crowd of 15,000.

Miss Lydia Summers of New York and Thomas L. Thomas of Scranton, Pa., were announced yesterday by the Atwater Kent Foundation as winners of the Northeastern district semi-final singing contest held in this city Nov. 16 as part of the sixth National Radio Audition for young amateurs of the country.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 24 -- West Orange conquered Columbia High of South Orange and Maplewood today, 13 to 0, before 8,000.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- Adolf Hitler's second formal bid for dictatorial power foundered today on President von Hindenburg's summary refusal to consider him for the Chancellorship on any except a Parliamentary basis. The President declared he could not reconcile such an appointment with his oath of office.

The depression has "solved the eternal domestic service problem in America" for housewives and "demoralized" it as to wages and hours, the magazine Fortune declares in its December issue, out today. The magazine says that "for the first time in a generation the supply of trained domestic workers is greater than the demand" and that "hundreds of thousands of maids" may be hired for as low as $4 a month.

There is little indeed in his now exhibition at the Kraushaar Gallery that need be thought of as not sustaining Guy Pene duBois's reputation as one of our most accomplished contemporary American painters. Now and then a canvas such as "Nude in Woods" may strike the visitor as not up to standard, and there are rather questionable points in "Studio Nude."

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Pans paid belated homage today to Georges Clemenceau, the wartime Premier, by dedicating his statue in front of the Petit Palais in the Champs Elysees, the ceremonies having been postponed from last May, when the nation was in mourning following the assassination of President Doumer.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Ambassador Andrew W. Mellon said tonight that there was great cause for thanksgiving in the fact that the people of the United States had "weathered the storm remarkably well and not only maintained the integrity of our financial structure, but preserved intact our social organization and inherited institutions of government."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The National Guard is described by Major Gen. George E. Leach as standing higher today in public esteem than at any period in its history.
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- Lady Astor told interviewers here that "this country must watch out in its treatment of the workers."

Listening to sermons which in some instances depicted the business depression as a partial blessing in that it has called the attention of the world to fundamental economic facts, New Yorkers of all creeds celebrated Thanksgiving yesterday in the city's churches.

TORONTO, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Flowing Gold, famous old chestnut gelding, made his last appearance in a horse show ring tonight and won the $1,000 three-galted saddle stake given by John Irwin, Montreal, for competition at the Royal Winter Fair.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Fire caused by a short circuit in the wardrobe room of the Broad Street Theatre, 568 Broad Street, at noon today destroyed nearly 100 costumes, or one-third of the wardrobe of the cast of the musical comedy "Take a Chance" three hours before the opening of a matinee performance of the show.

After staring in seventh-floor and eighth-floor windows of apartment houses, hotels and office buildings all the way down Broadway from 110th Street to Herald Square, the nightmarish helium beasts that took part in Macy's annual Thanksgiving parade yesterday, were cut loose in front of the department store in Thirty-fourth Street.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Sterling moved lower today. At one time during the Bourse session it was quoted at 82.75 francs, but it rallied and closed at 82.90. The dollar fell to 25.35 francs.

The Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, Mr. RAINEY, suggests that his party's campaign pledges to the farmer will be redeemed at the short session in terms of the "domestic allotment" plan. Several variations of this were proposed at the last session in bills introduced by Mr. RAINEY himself and by Senator NORBECK.

Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Fleetwood Shallcross of this city and Dublin, N.H., gave a dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Shallcross. The hostess wore a gown of dark blue net, and the debutante a gown of white velvet embellished with kolinsky fur and carried a bouquet of pink orchids and lilies of the valley.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini last night gave Bruckner's Fourth or "Romantic" symphony, Viotti's A minor concerto for violin with Mishel Piastro as soloist, and Beethoven's overture to "Leonore" No. 3, truly a Thanksgiving Day program in point of amplitude and solidly nourishing fare.

Redoubled effort will mark the activity over the week-end of the volunteer army of workers in the campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee for a fund of $15,000,000 for the alleviation of distress among the needy unemployed of the city.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- A blocked kick enabled the invading Central High eleven from South Bend, Ind., to come through to a 7-to-7 tie today in the final quarter of its intersectional game with White Plains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- In answer to an inquiry on beer distribution, August A. Busch of Anheuser-Busch, Inc., St. Louis, has replied that "Congress should not attempt to regulate the distribution of beer in the event the Volstead act is amended, inasmuch as any act passed by Congress on this subject can relate only to non-intoxicating beer under the Constitution."

Hunger marchers representing various veterans' organizations, who had promised a large demonstration at City Hall yesterday, left the building in indignation without registering all their protests because Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee refused to hear the grievances of Hortense Danaher, a dismissed city employe who was one of a committee of thirty marchers.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 25 (AP). -- Resolutions opposing immediate cash payment of the soldiers' bonus, advocating support of the Volstead act and calling for uniform laws for regulation of motor vehicles were adopted today at the final session of the National Grange.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES this morning there appeared an article in regard to the meeting in Washington between Governor Roosevelt and Miss Pauline Munell, a former patient at Warm Springs, Ga. I desire to add a few facts which may interest some of your readers and be an inspiration to other victims of infantile paralysis.

Miss Annette Gibson, student flier, and her instructor, Hugh Copeland of Roosevelt Field, who charged one of the Macy baloons over Jamaica Thursday afternoon, will face an inquiry today by Inspector Sanford A. Willetts of the Department of Commerce, Aeronautics Branch, as to why they flew as they did over a thickly populated area.

The New York Athletic Club hockey team defeated the St. Nicholas sextet, 7 -- 0, in the opening game of the Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League season at the New York Coliseum last night. The contest was interesting despite the one-sided score.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP). -- A belief that Philippine independence would be approved by Congress before or soon after Christmas was expressed today by Senator Smoot, as opponents of the legislation began preparations for a finish fight.

PARIS, Nov. 25. -- Acting upon a Soviet request, the French Government today joined Soviet officials in a new study of the possibilities of reaching a commercial accord. The conversations took place at the Ministry of Commerce between representatives of the Ministries of Commerce, Agriculture, Foreign Affairs and Finance and two commercial attaches of the Soviet Embassy.

Contrary to a popular notion, ministers' sons have a rather better chance to attain distinction (according to the standards of Who's Who) than those of any other one professional group -- 2,400 times as good a chance as the sons of unskilled workmen.

WILD WOOD, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Ivan Crooks of Roxborough and Frank Irete of Paxon Hollow tied for the lead in the qualifying test of the Wildwood Golf Club's Eastern States Thanksgiving tournament today. Each shot a 75.
HARRISBURG, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Clayton G. Miller, aged 57, a bank official and a prominent Church of God layman, died suddenly at his home today.

MADRID, Nov. 25. -- Spain's revolutionary government today ordered the Compania Nacional Telefonica, an affiliate of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, to draft a formal reply before Dec. 3 to a bill placed before the radical Cortes eleven months ago, which holds the company's contract, obtained under Primo de Rivera's dictatorship, is illegal and should therefore be annulled.

An appraisal filed yesterday of the estate of William Wilson Cook, corporation lawyer, shows that the University of Michigan, his chief beneficiary, will receive about $9,000,000 instead of $12,000,000, the estimate when his will was filed in June, 1930. Deputy Tax Commissioner Stephenson appraised the estate at $10,730,453 gross and $10,123,967 net, nearly all of which goes to public institutions.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Ball totaling $135,000 was set by Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan today for six men who pleaded not guilty to an indictment charging them with conspiracy to steal ballots from sealed boxes in the City Hall base- ment here.

TRUNO, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP). -- Liquor valued by officials at about $75,000 in 1,500 cases was seized along with four automobiles on the beach here today by Coast Guardsmen. Nine hundred cases were found on the beach and about 600 more on property near by.

Several hundred members of the New York County Lawyers' Association have signed a petition calling for a special meeting on Dec. 5 of the association members to make formal protest against the practice of Federal judges in granting the Irving Trust Company "a monopoly of administering estates in bankruptcy and equity suits."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Following is the text of the note on war debts handed to the British Ambassador in Washington by Secretary Stimson Wednesday:

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Atlantic travel is going to cost more than it does now. Although the heavy cuts in rates, amounting to about 20 per cent, made early last Summer will not be fully restored, first class, cabin and second class fares will on Monday, Dec. 5, be raised 6 per cent, while $5.50 will be added to tourist class and $5 to third class westbound and $7.50 to third class eastbound tickets.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- Colgate, sitting on top of the Eastern gridiron world and expecting a call to the Rose Bowl contest, today found, in looking over its season's record, that against six major opponents on its nine-game schedule it had made 99 first downs to the opponents' 21.

The casual way in which Ivar Kreu- ger disposed of millions through An- ders Jordahl, his confidential Amer- ican agent, without requiring an ac- counting, or put $330,000 in $10,000 banknotes in his pocket when he needed "some money" was revealed yesterday in Mr. Jordahl's testimony before Henry K. Davis, Federal bank- ruptcy referee, at the inquiry into the affairs of the Kreuger Toll Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a plain, average man in trouble. The financiers, economists and politicians of the country have inflicted upon me, quite unintentionally of course, a state of extreme mental confusion. They tell me we have an abundance of raw materials, machinery, foodstuffs and more gold than any nation in the world.

BUFFALO, Nov. 25. -- Immigration restrictions imposed on Palestine by Great Britain were attacked today by Rabbi Meyer Berlin, world president of the Mizrachi Organization, at the convention of the organization here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES'S complete report of Mr. Lamont's remarks on banking, and also the editorial on the same subject, proved to be very interesting and dealt with a matter of paramount importance.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Sefiora Dona Leonor Calles left Boston last July flushed with the hope that sound health soon would be hers.

Stores Push Gift Lines Strongly. Retailers yesterday launched concentrated promotional efforts on holiday gift lines that will continue unabated until Christmas. Unless weather conditions intervene, the expectation in retail circles is that today will see a notably heavy spurt in consumer buying of gift and semi-gift merchandise.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Interscholastic sport practices were assailed here today by Carl A. Jessen of Washington, D.C., specialist in secondary education of the Department of the Interior, in an address at the opening session of the convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.

The season's first performance of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was the occasion for the return to the company of Rosa Ponselle and Giacomo Lauri-Volpi and the debut of Miss Helen Gleason, the first of five American newcomers to make her bow to the opera's audiences.

The Republicans of New Jersey are at loggerheads again and more divided than ever, in spite of their success on Nov. 8 in overturning a Democratic majority in the Assembly and adding to their majority in the Senate, a body that has the power of rejecting appointments made by the Democratic Governor.

GENEVA, Nov. 25. -- Norman Davis, United States delegate to the disarmament conference, left tonight for a three or four days' "holiday" in Paris, taking the same train with Sir John Simon, British Foreign Minister. Mr. Davis expects to see Premier Herriot and Geneva will be surprised if Sir John does not also see him.

The first debutante ball of this season was given last night at the RitzCarlton by Mr. and Mrs. S. Hoxie Clark of this city and St. Louis to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary H. Clark. The entire ballroom suite was used and was profusely decorated with chrysanthemums and palms.

Shipping interests will again press their fight for government regulation of domestic shipping when Congress reconvenes, it was indicated yesterday. In a statement issued by Lewis Luckenbach, vice president of the Luckenbach Steamship Lines, conditions of rate structure and shipping practice were described as "chaotic" and progress in domestic shipping declared impossible unless a government body assumes control.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (Science Service by Mail). -- Dr. George E. Hale, director emeritus of the Mount Wilson Observatory at Pasadena, Cal., will receive the Copley medal of the Royal Society for his work on the magnetic field of the sun.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 25. -- Unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor announced plans today to fight moves said to have been begun by Chicago gangsters to control the sale and dispensing of beer if the beverage is legalized.
Leaseholds furnished the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday. Included in the leasing items were details of several transactions contained in contracts recorded at the Register's office.

Realization of the interdependence of the world is wanted in Congress today. Theirs are the only official voices which offer no hope to stricken Europe as it pleads for a new consideration of the debt question. Both President HOOVER and President-elect ROOSEVELT have spoken with sympathy and understanding.
Count Carlo Soardi of the Italian Embassy in Washington is to sail today for Naples on the motor ship Augustus of the Italian Line. Others sailing on the ship for Mediterranean ports include:

Far removed from the trails of the frozen North and amid the turmoil and noise of New York, Old Fritz, last surviving husky of Leonard Seppala's sledge dog team that raced 245 miles to Nome with diphtheria serum in 1925, died yesterday from the infirmities of age.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 25. -- Mirabeau Lamar Towns, whose versifying facility in the court room won him the title of poet-lawyer during his forty years of practice at the New York bar, died suddenly and peacefully here yesterday afternoon at the home of his daughter and sonin-law, Mr. and Mrs. George C. Reynard, in Henhawk Lane.

A total of 9,117 unemployed men and women have already received jobs financed by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee from funds now being collected in the committee's campaign for $15,000,000 to alleviate unemployment distress in this city, Raymond W. Houston, assistant director of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, announced yesterday.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company in the fiscal year ended on June 30 credited the Manhattan Railway with at least $724,000 less than the elevated lines yielded in net operating income, according to testimony given yesterday before Basil D. O'Connor, Federal special master, by George W. Burpee, consulting engineer for the Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- A sizable attack by Chinese troops against Japanese forces of occupation in Manchuria is predicted by the Chinese Legation here, on the basis of cable advises from Nanking.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Lawless youth, often swaggering and sometimes furtive, continue to be the bane of law enforcement authorities.

Mrs. Pearl Basker, 42 years old, of 390 Wadsworth Avenue, mother of five children, was saved from punishment for failure to answer a summons yesterday in Washington Heights Court because her son, Solomon, 14, decided he could act as her lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Colonel Courtland Nixon, United States Army, retired, and Mrs. Nixon, gave a tea dance this afternoon at the Army and Navy Country Club to present their daughter, Miss Margaret Nixon, to society. The debutante wore a gown of blue velvet and carried a bouquet of pink roses.

WINNIPEG, Man., Nov. 25 (Canadian Press). -- R.H. Channing, president of the Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company, who will go to New York for the copper conference on Tuesday, remarked today that he would attend the meeting with an open mind.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 23, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was 2,209,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $248,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.
DANVILLE, Ill., Nov. 25. -- A new effort of American railroads to escape paying the government's bill for profits in excess of 6 per cent was started today in Federal court.

A serious food situation in Soviet Russia which seems certain to grow more serious with the coming of Winter is reported by Mr. DURANTY. The existence of dearth in the U.S. S.R. is not news. We have been prepared for it by Government statements on harvesting troubles, by reports brought out of Russia by visitors, and with increasing frequency by dispatches dealing openly with food shortage.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 26 (AP). -- A Foreign Office spokesman told The Associated Press today that Japan would reject any proposal at Geneva to transfer the Manchurian question from the League of Nations to a conference of signatories of the NinePower treaty, on the ground that the treaty did not apply to Manchukuo.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 25 (AP). -- Steve Szumachowski of the fleet-footed Szumachowskis, who won the national interscholastic championship run in Newark, N.J., in record time yesterday, is waiting for the first snow to get out into the hills on skiis.

Ellery Sedgwick James of 1,021 Park Avenue, a member of the banking firm of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., who was a captain in the 324th Field Artillery in France in the World War, died yesterday morning in the Doctors Hospital.

American universities were praised yesterday for their disinterested work in government and economics by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the New York Edison, Consolidated Gas and Niagara-Hudson Power Companies, in an address before the twenty-fourth annual session of the National Interfraternity Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Great Britain was encouraged to make a presentation of her position as a special case looking to debt revision, but little hope for relief was held out to France and Belgium in the notes delivered to the Ambassadors of the three nations by Secretary Stimson upon the conclusion of the debt conferences between President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The annual Christmas seal sale of the National Tuberculosis Association was opened from the White House by President Hoover this afternoon. Speaking over a nation-wide hook-up of the National Broadcasting and Columbia Systems, the President commended the sale as deserving the support of all American citizens.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much publicity has been given to the hearings before the finance committee of the Board of Aldermen with reference to the budget to be allowed for the Board of Taxicab Control.

Representative Henry T. Rainey of Illinois, Democratic floor leader, appeared yesterday in Federal court to tell Judge Alfred C. Coxe and a jury how stock salesmen for the Southern City Supply Corporation induced him to buy 500 shares of that corporation's stock for $7,500.

A tea dance was given yesterday in the Perroquet Room of the Waldorf-Astoria by Irving T. Myers to introduce his daughter, Miss Betty Myers. Mr. Myers and his daughter were assisted in receiving by Mrs. Samuel Irving Myers, grandmother of the debutante.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 25. -- Governor Roosevelt, who in his campaign for the Presidency declared repeatedly that the return of prosperity for the farmers must be an important factor in a general restoration of good times, will discuss agriculture relief tomorrow with a delegation of the National Grange.

TEGUCIGALPA, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The garrison at Comayagua abandoned its barracks last night, taking all arms with it, and the government immediately issued a decree cammandeering all government funds to be used for war purposes exclusively.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to introduce your readers in the linen racket -- not that old-fashioned, small-time swindle whereby some ignorant, bargainhunting person is tripped into buying a bit of machine-made "real Scottish" lace at a price a hundred-fold its real insignificant value.

Weapons for a new war, powerfill enough to pulverize beyond hope of repair what is left of civilization, are being made ready in the laboratories of the world's great nations, Winston S. Churchill, British statesman, writes in "Amid These Storms: Thoughts and Adventures," published yesterday by Scribner's.

New Utrecht High School moved into a tie for first place with Jamaica and Boys High in the annual city P.S.A.L. championship hockey tournament by defeating Erasmus Hall, 4 to 3, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Samuel H. Hastings, president of the Illinois Manufacturers' Association, largest industrial organization of its kind in the country, charged Congress today with responsibility for restoring public confidence as a means of reviving business.

Mrs. Sidonia Anderson, 91-year-old widow, a native of Switzerland, was a witness yesterday in Judge Allen's part of General Sessions at the second degree grand larceny trial of Mrs. Angelique Tozzini, 63, for the alleged theft of $8,000 in bonds from her.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Argument in the Black Tom and Kingsland sabotage cases closed today before the Mixed Claims Commission, when Robert W. Bonynge of New York, spoke in rebuttal of the German defense for two days by Dr. Wilhelm Tannenberg.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- A further loan of $1,500,000 to the Wabash Railway Company receivers by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, bringing to $14,825,000 the amount of loans authorized to that road.

Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist, got back from the Orient yesterday. He bad been away since July, and gave more than thirty concerts in various parts of the Far East. He did not, however, go to Manchuria. The two trains that preceeded his were blown up, and he decided finally that the residents perhaps could get along without his musical contributions to happiness.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- France exported 6,892,000 francs' [about $275,680] worth of "arms, powder and munitions" in October, according to detailed trade statistics issued today. This brings the ten months' total to about 132,000,000 francs [about $5,280,000], which is more than twice the amount of such exports in the first ten months of 1931.

Fourteen properties, ten in Man- hattan and four in the Bronx, were offered at foreclosure sales yester- day. The parcels were put up for bidding at auctioneers' stands as the result of defaults on mortgages. Except for a withdrawal and two ad- journments, all the holdings were bought in by interested parties.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- Dr. Thomas Edward Finegan, originator of classroom visual education through motion pictures, president of Eastman Teaching Films and creator of legislative programs in New York and Pennsylvania looking to greater professionalization of teaching and elimination of politics from public schools, died at Strong Memorial Hospital today at the age of 66.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Jim Londos made a successful if not brilliant defense of his claim to the heavyweight wrestling title tonight by throwing Joe Stecher of Nebraska, scissors specialist, in 47 minutes and 14 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Breaking his silence on the war debt situation, Senator Borah, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, declared informally today that the ne- gotiations were a closed incident so far as revival of the debt commission is concerned.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The text of that part of Neville Chamberlain's speech at Birmingham tonight relating to the American debt follows:

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 25. -- Charles S. Mitchell's 3-year-old son of Man o' War, Happy Warrior, led a field of ten home in the feature race at Jefferson Park today. Anne L. was second and Newgro third. First Mission was fourth, and all four leaders finished noses apart.

Awards were made for the best birds in the pigeon department, in classes already judged, and prize winners were announced in the first red specialty championship cat exhibition at the Pet Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

One of the wonders of game con- servation is the number of persons actively engaged in the work. Not many years ago conservation of wild- life was a subject in which few either took an interest or had more than a passing knowledge. Today there are thousands upon thousands of men and women and boys and girls engaged in some form of wild-life conservation or propagation.

A harvest festival of folksongs, dances and tableaux vivants, enlisting groups of young people representing ten different nationalities, will be presented by the International Institute of the Young Women's Christian Association tonight at 341 East Seventeenth Street.
Stocks, bonds and most of the important commodities drifted lower yesterday, while sterling exchange broke sharply, as the animated discussion of the war-debt problem continued.

Wholesale markets were reactionary yesterday. Particular weakness was found in wheat, where new lows were recorded, December selling down to 41 1/2 cents, displacing the previous low of 41 7/8 cents, made three weeks ago. Corn, oats and rye also slumped. Cotton, lard, sugar, rubber, silk and hides declined. Eggs continued weak.

The City-Wide Non-Partisan Committee, formed to further the election of Joseph V. McKee as Mayor in 1933 and pledged not to fuse with any political group, held what had been advertised as its organization meeting last night in the Level Club in West Seventy-third Street.

Occupying a de luxe suite on A deck of the Berengaria and accompanied by his wife, Harry Geen, 33-year-old Englishman who was arrested in Philadelphia last year after a world-wide search by Scotland Yard, departed early this morning for his native land, where he faces charges of having been a ringleader in a $7,000,000 stock swindling scheme.

The Negroes in the United States have made big strides forward, both educationally and economically, ac- cording to Dr. J.E. Holloway, director of Census and Statistics in the Union of South Africa, who has come to this city after a tour of several Negro institutions in the East and South.

On the 300th anniversary of his birth Jew and Gentile alike do honor to SPINOZA -- the man who once drew fierce excommunication upon himself. He has an especial claim upon Americans. JEFFERSON wrote the Declaration of Independence with his principles in mind.

An enormous demand for tickets to the Army-Notre Dame football game was evidenced in this city last night. Notwithstanding the depression, and the fact that each team has sustained a defeat this year, officials in charge of Army and Notre Dame headquarters were flooded by an unprecedented surge of ticket buying for a football game in this city.

Held without bail yesterday in Brooklyn Homicide Court on a murder charge in connection with the shooting Sept. 3 of Frederick Gillies, 35 years old, in an alleged speakeasy in Brooklyn, James F. Cahill, dismissed policeman, was said to have been identified as the killer by three witnesses, whose names were not divulged.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke nearly $1 a bale yesterday, but a reaction toward the close left the list 11 to 14 points lower than on Wednesday.

PARIS, Nov. 25. -- Premier Herriot read over President Hoover's note of Nov. 23 to his colleagues in the Cabinet at a special meeting this afternoon and then went on to discuss the proposed pact of non-aggression with Russia. The Cabinet will meet again tomorrow, however, and tonight the French experts are digging deep into documents and figures getting ready material for a new note to Washington if it should be decided to send one.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 25. -- Paul A. Hesse Jr., 12 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Hesse, was killed today when his shotgun went off accidentally while he was hunting near his home in the Silvermine section.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- A renewed fight by Republican leaders for the enactment of a general manufacturers' sales tax in the coming short session was indicated today when Senator Smoot, chairman of the Finance Committee, joined House Republicans in supporting such legislation.

In Battle Array. The troops are massed for the big attack. No Army football brigades have humbled Notre Dame two years in a row, but from the battlements that peer over the placid Hudson to the outposts in Alaska and the Canal Zone there is a feeling in military circles that this Army team is going to break through.

Will Is No Die-Hard. In the last twenty-four hours the outlook for a rational war debts settlement has grown brighter. WILL ROGERS begins to see the light. His example is sure to be followed by others who write better grammar than he does but who have gone along with him on the subject of foreign payments.

A collection of original paintings, including marines and landscapes, by Mrs. A.M. Galland, who, with her daughter, Miss Bertha Galland, lost her life in an automobile accident last Sunday on North Street, White Plains, N.Y., may be converted into a permanent memorial to Mrs. Galland if wishes of a group of relatives are carried out, it was revealed yesterday.

New municipal financing next week will be enlivened by three State issues. The total scheduled is $13,957,654, representing the requirements of forty-two communities. This amount compares with $9,215,523 this week and with the weekly average for the year to date of $18,143,453.

Except for the Army-Navy game at Philadelphia a week hence, the curtain falls today upon the gridirons of the East for 1932, with the stage set for the grand finale of the local season and three other interesting games in this section.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, made speeches tonight in different parts of the country evidently to prepare the British people for the long tussle ahead of their government in the war-debt negotiations with the United States, especially with respect to the payment due on Dec. 15.

Bond prices weakened considerably on the Stock Exchange yesterday with only the United States Government issues holding their ground to any extent. The further break in sterling caused heavy trading in United Kingdom 5 1/2s due in 1937, the heaviest in any issue, foreign or domestic, and sent the market for the loan down 1 1/8 points to a price of 103.
MOSCOW, Nov. 25. -- What are the reasons for the food shortage that is menacing the Soviet program at the end of the first period of its planned economy, which otherwise is outwardly successful?

A decision as to the liability of New York life insurance companies on policies taken out in Russia before the assets of the United States companies doing business there had been confiscated by the Soviet Government was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, who ruled that the Equitable Life Assurance Society must pay on a twenty-year endowment policy which matured in 1925, five years before suit was brought on the policy here.

Renewed pressure for the resignation of State Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter as chairman of the Hofstadter legislative committee when the investigating body meets next Tuesday was foreshadowed yes- terday.

Yesterday's, statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure. In the subjoined comparative table all figures except ratio of reserve are in thousands of dollars:

VIENNA, Nov. 25. -- The directorates of two big Austrian banks, the Niederoesterreichische Escompte-Gesellschaft and the Wiener Bankverein, are meeting to consider the problem of their future existence. The immediate impulse was given by the conclusion of the Creditanstalt agreement and by pressure from Kienboeck, president of the National Bank, who is concerned about the contents of his currency portfolio.

Returns to date for October indicate that for the first time since the Winter of 1929 the downward trend of railroad net operating income has seen brought to or near to a halt. Of the first eighteen railroads to report for October, eleven reported increases in net operating income, compared with October, 1931, and the net for the entire eighteen was only 2.1 per cent below that for October, 1931.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The war debts continued to dominate the stock market today, with a further slump in sterling exchange on New York to $3.20, the lowest figure since 1920, when the rate was unpegged after the wartime and post-war-restrictions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Virtual agreement for a vote on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment on the first day of the short session of Congress was reached tonight by Speaker Garner and Representative Snell, Republican House leader.

The Associated Gas and Electric Corporation has disposed of its in- vestment in the Eastern Utilities In- vesting Corporation and the Binghamton Light, Heat and Power Company to the Associated Gas and Electric Company, parent holding com- pany of the system.

Retail trade in the pre-Thanksgiv- ing period was good, while reports from the wholesale trades are encouraging, according to Dun's Review. Slight improvements in the heavier industries as well as maintenance of activity in textile and shoe lines were also noted.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25. -- For the second day in succession, the feature event at Bowie fell to a Greentree Stable color-bearer, as Curacao came home first today in the Mount Vista Purse. St. Brideaux, stablemate to Curacao, captured the Thanksgiving Handicap yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Lavender Whirlwind, a bluish male Persian cat which was rated as the best cat in the recent show in New York City, won first place in the open class of the two-day show of the Boardwalk Persian Cat Club of this city and the Columbian Cat Fanciers of Washington, D.C., here today.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 25 -- For the benefit of holders of first liens on the various properties of the United Railways and Electric Company, a bondholders' protective committee has been formed. The company owns all the street railways and the principal bus lines in Baltimore.

The George Washington Bicentennial Commission in its official report, made public last night, revealed a deficit of $76,254.74, exclusive of the construction costs of Federal Hall in Bryant Park and Mount Vernon in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, which are covered by special contract between the commission and Sears, Roebuck Co.

GENEVA, Nov. 25. -- The League of Nations Council dealt energetically today with the undeclared ChinoJapanese War and Japan made important concessions on points of procedure while continuing to keep strings attached and to protest, apparently to save "face" at home.

Charging that officials of the United Cigar Stores of America falsified the assets of that bankrupt corporation and its subsidiaries, Mortimer Hays, counsel for a creditor in the action, yesterday asked Irwin Kurtz, referee, to turn over the conflicting statements to the proper authorities for investigation, at a hearing held in the referee's offices at 15 Park Row.

NEW YORK. The first Knickerbocker Assembly for this season will be held tonight at the Ritz-Carlton. The series of dances is under the direction of Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow, who is being assisted by Mrs. Adrian V.S. Lambert, Mrs. I.N. Phelps Stokes, Mrs. James Gore King, Mrs. Thatcher Magoun Brown, Mrs. Lyman Delano and Mrs. F. Kingsbury Curtis.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 25. -- Officials of the Western Cartridge Company, formerly the Winchester Arms Company, of this city, confirmed tonight reports that an order for cartridges had just been received from a South American country which will keep the factory employed until Christmas.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The Rev. Dr. Rembert G. Smith, suspended a year ago on charges of "gross imprudence and high unministerial conduct," was reinstated by the North Georgia conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, here today, after he had made an apology.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov 25. -- Bringing to a close the national field hockey tests for the selection of an All-America team, the Southeast and Northeast aggregations will clash to- morrow afternoon at Rosemary Hall Field in what is expected to be the most significant game of the tournament.
