WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Messages from Premier Mussolini of Italy, President Machado of Cuba and Acting Foreign Minister Schaetzel of Poland, on the closing of the George Washington Bicentennial Celebration, were made public by the State Department today.

One of the outstanding members of the new order of Americans who rendered an international service following the World War was Colonel ROBERT E. OLDS. He represented his country officially in several posts of honor and responsibility, but he will be remembered especially for his unique service as commissioner of the American Red Cross for all operations abroad, beginning in 1918 and carrying on for three years.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The text of that part of Prime Minister MacDonald's speech at Retford tonight concerning the war debts follows:

The National Academy of Design opened its Winter exhibition last evening with a varnishing day reception. The paintings, sculpture and graphic art, which go on public view tomorrow, will remain at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, until Dec. 21.

Former State Senator Conrad Hasenflug, who was a former Democratic leader of the Nineteenth Assembly District in Brooklyn and a powerful political figure during the regime of the late State Senator Patrick H. McCarren, John H. McCooey's predecessor as Brooklyn leader, died Thursday of pneumonia at his home, 84-37 169th Street, Jamaica, Queens, after a week's illness.

Young Jake Schaefer of Chicago, world's champion at 18.2 balkline billiards, defeated Albert G. Cutler of New York last night in an exhibition at the opening of the Capitol Recreation, Broadway and Fiftieth Street. The new academy is operated by Harry Wakefield, ex-Pacific Coast titleholder, who formerly was in charge of the billiard room at the New York Elks Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lispenard Suydam gave a tea dance yesterday in the ballroom of the Colony Club to present their daughter, Miss Elizabeth S. Suydam. The debutante, who is of old Dutch ancestry, is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lispenard Suydam, the latter having been Jane Mesier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- While wets press their drive for legalization of beer and repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, House members interested in economy are giving serious consideration to a drastic reduction in Coast Guard appropriations.
HUNTINGTON, L.I, NOV. 25. -- Mrs. Luella Nichols Peckham, wife of Hal Merritt Peckham, died today at her home on the HuntingtonNorthport Road near here.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 25. -- George Connors, for nine years Yale's head track coach and football squad trainer, today closed his active career with an appointment by the Yale Athletic Association as trainer in an advisory capacity for all Yale athletic teams for the remainder of the college year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Minya Konka in Tibet, one of the world's highest peaks outside the Himalayas, which was reported in a Shanghai dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES to have been scaled by two American explorers, Terris Moore and Richard Burdsall, has been seen by only a few white men, the National Geographic Society said today.

TOKYO, Nov. 25. -- Members of the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry, at their annual dinner last night, heard an unpremeditated exchange of views between their president, Baron Seinosuke Go, and Lieut. Gen. Sadao Araki, the Minister of War, on the financial situation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- No basic change in the industrial and business situation abroad was pictured in the weekly summary of business condi- tions issued today by the Depart- ment of Commerce.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25. -- Georgia and Georgia Tech will meet on the gridiron tomorrow for the twenty-eighth time.

A dinner dance was given last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton by Mr. and Mrs. Van Santvoord Merlesmith for their debutante niece, Miss Sally Van S. Pyle, daughter of Mrs. Augustus S. Knight of Brandon Lodge, Far Hills, N.J., and of James McAlpin Pyle of Noroton, Conn.

Reflecting the deepening pessimism in the foreign exchange market over the effect upon Great Britain's financs of either a default of cash payment of the December war debt instalment, the pound sterling fell 4 5/8 cents yesterday to $3.20 1/2, the lowest price since 1920.

Erno Rapes will be the general music director for Roxy at the Radio City Theatres and will have two symphony orchestras under his direction, the Radio City Music Hall orchestra of 100 pieces and the R.K.O. Roxy orchestra of fifty players, it was announced yesterday.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- Dr. Hermanus L. Baer, philanthropist and worker for the poor in Mount Vernon, died today at the age of 59. He was active for twentythree years in charity work.
Most of yesterday's realty convey- ances in New Jersey were housing properties.

James E. Finegan, the independent Brooklyn Democrat who sponsored the "No Deal Judiciary party" in the Second Judicial District two years ago, attacked yesterday the record of Acting Mayor McKee in a statement on the fusion movement for the 1933 Mayoralty election.

The exciting experience of riding through the centre of a cyclone into a 110-mile wind was told yesterday by Captain R.E. Teague, master of the Ellerman Line freighter City of Bagdad, which arrived from Calcutta and other Eastern ports.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25. -- Pitt and Stanford will meet tomorrow in the Pitt Stadium before a crowd of 50,000, the game marking the first appearance of a Pacific Coast football team in Pittsburgh. The contest will start at 2 o'clock.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 25 (AP). -- A first degree murder charge was filed today against Julian Marcelino, a slightly built Filipino, who, angered by the theft of his savings, killed six men and wounded thirteen persons yesterday.

Police Sergeant Julian Rhodes charged in the West Brighton police court yesterday that Ralph Werner, alleged to be a speakeasy proprietor of 360 Delaware Avenue, Dongan Hills, S.I., had told him that he was paying protection money to Inspector Edward M. Shelvey, in command of police on Staten Island, and Lieutenant Charles A. Powell, in command of the Staten Island liquor squad for the last three years.

BROOKSVILLE, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP). -- Colonel Raymond Robins was in seclusion at his Chinsegut Hill estate today and his wife said he would see no one until he has recovered completely from a recent attack of amnesia.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 25. -- The censorship has forbidden from Belgrade the publication of a resolution adopted at a conference of Roman Catholic Bishops just concluded at Zagreb against attacks of non-Catholic that is to say, Serbian Orthodox] circles in Yugoslavia on the Pope and Catholic sacred objects.

The Rev. Dr. G. Campbell Morgan, internationally known Bible teacher and preacher, will deliver his farewell sermons in New York next week. He has resigned the pastorate of the Tabernacle Presbyterian Church, Philadelphia, which he has held for the last three years, and accepted a call to return as the special preacher at Westminster Congregational Chapel, Buckingham Gate, London, where before coming to America he was for many years the pastor.

Two important games postponed from last Saturday because of rain, the Erasmus Hall-Boys High and New Rochelle-Mount Vernon contests, head today's program of scholastic football in the metropolitan district. Only nine games are listed for the final Saturday of the regular season, six of them to be played in New York City.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa, Nov. 25. -- Charged with murdering her two former husbands and her 20-year-old son to collect their insurance, Mrs. Daisy Louisa de Melker, wife of a noted South African rugby player, was found guilty today of killing the son and was sentenced to death.

The gold holdings of the Federal Reserve System advanced $26,083,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new high for the year to date at $3,053,152,000, a net recovery of $491,957,000 from the year's low of $2,561,195,000 reached on June 15 when the gold outflow came to an end.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25. -- Protoplasm, the very stuff of which man and the plants and animals about him are made, was described today by Dr. George W. Crile, Cleveland scientist, as a structural copy in miniature of the stars in the sky.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Athletic relations which have existed between the Long Branch and Asbury Park High Schools for more than twenty years were broken today when Melvin T. Rahn, faculty manager of athletics at the Long Branch High School, announced that the Board of Education had recommended that games be discontinued with the Asbury Park High School.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Prince Gustaf Adolf, eldest son of the Swedish Crown Prince, today brought home his bride, Princess Sibylle of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, and Stockholm accorded them a royal welcome.

MANILA, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Alfred E. Smith, former New York Governor and 1928 Democratic candidate for President of the United States, would be a "most excellent" selection for Governor General of the Philippines, President Manuel L. Quezon of the Philippine Senate said today in commenting on a rumor here that Mr. Smith might receive that appointment.

The Manhattan Prep basketball team opened its home season yesterday with a victory over the St. Simon Stock School quintet of the Bronx, 35 to 23. Duffy left forward for the victors, was the high scorer with 14 points. At half time Manhattan led, 20 to 16.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- Formation of a psychiatric clinic in the Criminal Courts Building in New York City is praised in a report of an inspection made by John S. Kennedy to the State Department of Correction.

A call upon the city to make provision in its budget for direct financial aid to Catholic, Jewish and Protestant schools to guard against their being forced by the depression to close their doors and transfer their thousands of pupils to the public schools is sounded in an editorial on the first page of this week's number of The Tablet, Catholic newspaper of BrooKlyn, issued yesterday.

Possibly from habit Wall Street continued yesterday to attribute the flurries of selling to uncertainties growing out of the conversations relating to the war-debt problem. It is still felt that the discussions on the subject, as well as the repercussions, have done much to confuse the market situation.

With both coaches pessimistic and the players and adherents of the two teams confident to an extreme, Army and Notre Dame squads concluded their practices yesterday for their nineteenth annual meeting at the Yankee Stadium today.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The government crisis is in its last phase, and its final settlement now rests solely in the hands of President von Hindenburg. He will act promptly and decisively, presiding tomorrow at a Cabinet council, a thing he has done only on the rarest occasions.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Mayor J. Hampton Moore has sent a warning to all judges in the City Hall advising them to be on guard against attack from radicals, Judge Raymond MacNeille of Common Pleas Court No. 3 said today.

Mayor-elect John P. O'Brien made his debut in the conduct of the city government last night by moving to appoint three committees to recommend new sources of city revenue, survey city departments under the Mayor and recommend charter changes that would be advantageous to the city.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 25. -- Robert C. Critz, a cousin of Smith Reynolds, who wan fatally shot July 6, was in City Hospital tonight in a serious condition from a pistol wound in the head, apparently self-inflicted.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The Essex County delegation in the State Assembly, which bolted a Republican caucus in Trenton Tuesday over what its members considered lack of recognition, announced today that they would nominate George V. Bradley for Speaker of the Assembly.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 22 -- The revolution in Honduras was not unlocked for in fact, it was expected to occur either at the time of the elections, because both sides in the contest were heavily armed, or immediately after the result was announced.

The Merchants' Association of New York has informed the Senate committee investigating the proposed treaty between the United States and Canada which would authorize the development of the St. Lawrence waterway as a deep-water canal that it opposes the project because of the potential cost to American taxpayers, the resulting loss of trade to American ports and the absence of any real need of the transportation and power services that would be developed.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C.Z., Nov., 23 -- Shark and crocodile scares have driven away patrons of the swimming beaches at Bella Vista, adjoining Panama City, and Fort Amador and Farfan Beach on the Pacific side of the Canal Zone. Numbers of the monsters have been seen close inshore, drawn perhaps by hunger or possibly by the disturbance of the waters due to the recent hurricane in the Caribbean.

THE protest recently by automobile owners in Rio de Janeiro against a decree requiring the mixture of gasoline and alcohol lends point to a situation by no means confined to Brazil. It seems that, under pressure of economic necessity, and with the double view of aiding domestic agriculture and reducing petroleum imports, a number of nations have been encouraging or compelling the use of home products for motor fuel.

THE number of poets turning from shorter forms and from the lyric mood to essay sustained flight in narrative, or in narrative drama, seems suddenly to be increasing. It would be interesting to speculate on the causes of such a movement although it is probable that in the end one would have to be content in accepting the speculation as its own reward.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- The Boerse continued generally firm today, but business remained small. There was much talk again of large transactions being effected outside of the Stock Exchange by standstill creditors buying up large lots of German securities for five-year investment in accordance with Article 10 of the standstill agreement.
THE air transport lines of the country appear to be on the verge of a period of further change and movement.

PARIS, Nov. 10. HENRI DUVERNOIS'S new sentimental comedy, "Jeanne," will surely and deservedly be a success. His tender and intimate touch upon emotion and suffering, his humorous sense of character, the unerring reality of his picture of the trivialities of life in modest bourgeois homes -- all these qualities he has shown before now.

HOLLYWOOD. EXTRAS who have been idle because of the cinema's flair for drawing-room dramas which used only a few players other than the principals are now busy. All studios are using big sets; supervisors no longer limit directors to 100 extras when 1,000 are needed.

WHEN our economic system suffers from a severe cyclical or periodic disease, we face a problem not unlike an attack of typhoid on the human body. Shall we resign ourselves to its consequences as though inevitable, letting it run its course without alleviation and take the chance of recovery, or death with philosophical fortitude, or shall we figrht it every inch to diminish our suffering, to lessen its weakening effects, possibly to save our lives?

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- In the course of a speech at Retford tonight, Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald expressed the opinion that with real effort on the part of Great Britain and the United States a way could be found to permit the war debt payment due Dec. 15 to be passed.

More than 200 pairs are expected to compete in the sixth annual national championship bridge tournament of the American Bridge League, which will open tomorrow afternoon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel and continue through Saturday. It is the first time that the league has ever held its tournament in New York, the event being held in Philadelphia last year and in Hanover, N.H., the previous year.

Facing a potential market "conservatively estimated at $5,000,000,000," the department store is making steady progress in both the scientific appraisal and development of the potentialities inherent in the sale of electrical appliances. This is indicated in the survey just completed by the Electrical Merchandising Joint Committee, composed of retailers, appliance manufacturers and the public utilities.

MEN ARE LIKE STREET CARS. By Grarme and Surah Lorimer. 223 pp. Boston: Little, Brown Co. $1.50. THIS little volume is one of the most genuinely light-hearted books that have appeared in anything like recent seasons. It is a rollicking comedy of the younger generation -- that group which was once so conspicuous in light fiction, but which lately has been allowed to lapse into comparative obscurity.

NEWKIRK, Okla., Nov. 26 -- Colonel Zack Miller, grizzled 101-Ranch pioneer, went to jail here today for failure to pay a $100 attorney fee and $40 a month separate maintenance to Margaret Blevins-Miller, his estranged wife, who lives in the same house with him.
NEW YORK. The Countess de Faramond de Lafojole, who is with Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Pavenstedt, will sail Tuesday on the Bremen and will go to her home at 7 Avenue Frederic Le Play, Paris.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 24 -- Mixed reactions have resulted from the suggestion Toy Governor Julius L. Meier that Oregon adopt a selective form of sales tax to eliminate the necessity of restoring a State levy on real property.

PARIS. THE buyer reigns supreme over the big Summer and Winter couture collections; but, in the midseason showings the private client comes into her own. The couturiers are not so preoccupied by putting over a new fashion and they are not obliged to keep such a worried weather eye on eventual mass production, with the result that a restful simplicity is apt to be the midseason's sartorial keynote.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 26 -- Texas Christian University wound up an undefeated season today and clinched the Southwest Conference football championship by defeating the 1931 champions, the Southern Methodist University Mustangs, 8 to 0.

Advance purchasing of main floor, gift and toy items for the holidays have been practically completed and reorders have begun to come in for small fill-in quantities, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Fowler and Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fowler gave a dinner and dance last night at the River Club to introduce their daughters, Miss Jane Fowler and Miss Mollie Flagg. Miss Fowler is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Cryder.

BAZAARS and sales of useful articles suitable for Christmas gifts have been arranged in behalf of a number of charitable organizations. Prominent women interested in the work of the Barat Settlement among the adults and children in a congested district of the city will hold a bazaar in aid of that organization on Thursday in the small ballroom of the Plaza.

A crowd of 10,000, the largest of its current campaign, saw Flushing High vanquish its traditional rival, Jamaica Hgh, 6-0, yesterday at Memorial Field, Flushing, in a bitterly waged football encounter which brought an end to both schools regular schedule.

LET us be gay! So says Fashion as she ranges from gown to hat. There is nothing clumsy or heavy in the touch of her hand -- that is, if one knows how to discriminate between her deft manipulations and their poor imitations. Take hats, for example.

ONE of the paradoxes of longrange weather prediction, as its activities are recorded in the daily press, is that autumnal forecasts of Winter weather outnumber springtime forecasts of Summer weather at least ten to one -- when we should expect it to be the other way round.

Under prevailing conditions there is no possibility that the American Kennel Club will be able to follow the lead of the British governing body in the reduction of registration fees. On the other side the Kennel Club voted at its bi-annual meeting to cut the fee of a dog, both of whose parents are registered, from the present fee of 3s. to 2s. 6d.

Acting on affidavits and other data presented by Walter S. Mack Jr., defeated Republican candidate for the State Senate, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, began yesterday an inquiry into charges of widespread fraud at the polls in the Seventeenth Senatorial District.

THERE was much to interest the aviation industry in the speech of Claude R. Porter, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, delivered the other day before the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners at Hot Springs, Ark, Mr. Porter first paid tribute to the growing competition for the railroads to be found in air transport.

In view of the fact that the best gain in price of any of the United States Government issues last week, aside from the registered bonds of these issues, was in the First Liberty 4 /14 s, amounting to 6-32 point, specialists in government securities were inclined yesterday to believe that opinion was veering toward an expectation that this issue would not be refunded on the next call date, June 15, 1933.

FUTURE dances that have been inspired by the pressing needs of various philanthropic organizations continue to attract the interest and cooperation of members of society, including many debutantes of the Winter.

WARSAW, Nov. 25--Before going to Geneva to represent Poland at the League Council meeting, the new Foreign Minister, Colonel Joseph Beck, sent an undersecretary, Count Szembek, to explain in the chief European capitals the recent change in the Polish Foreign Office and pave the way for his chief's first contacts with other statesmen in Geneva.

In the convention of the National Council of Teachers of English at Memphis last week there was an interesting and a lively discussion of English as she is spoke and English as the severe grammar-writers tell us that she should be written. One soon learns the baselessness of some of the rules that these pedants have made.
STOCKHOLM. ANALYZING the balance sheet has been one of the tasks undertaken by Dr. Poul Bjerre. Swedish psychoanalyst, for his interpretive study of Ivar Kreuger, which has just been published.

For the first time in American history, so far as the precedent-hunters know, the President and the President-elect of the United States sat down in conference last week to discuss a problem which carries over from the administration of one to the administration of the other.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., Nov. 1 -- There seems to be a general idea that whatever fails the farmer remains a good conservative. Any one who still holds these notions after the "farmers' holiday" and who sees the farmer as the prop of the social order should look over New Zealand.

I BEGAN to know and like the Alcotts about seventy-two years ago, and Louisa of that iik in particular -- though she was born just a hundred years ago and was even in 1860 fourteen years my elder. But my attachment was not what we call sentimental or romantic; it was just a boy-and-young-woman friendship, happy and wholesome.

IF the truth were spoken at centennial celebrations they would be admirable milestones of history. Unfortunately, they are often misused, either by those who let a polite gesture make up for a century of neglect, or by others who try to discover in the perspective of the past a prophet for their own party.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -- The Naval Academy closed its cross-country season today by defeating Duke, 26 to 29, over a five-mile course.

JAMES DUNN and Sally Eilers, who are best remembered for their success in "Bad Girl," are to be brought together once more by Fox. The film is "Sailor's Luck." While on the subject of "Bad Girl," the local Fox office seizes the opportunity to point out a few of that film's achievements.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 26 -- Eight Philadelphia players were named on the All-America field hockey team at the conclusion of the national tournament that terminated three days of play at Bosemary Hall Field today.
DETROIT, Nov. 26--Henry Ford, stricken suddenly with the first serious illness of his sixty-nine years, underwent an emergency operation this afternoon at Henry Ford Hospital.

OMAHA, Nov. 24 -- The farmers' strike may be dead, but its restless soul goes marching on in projects conceived in the spirit of that queen of Kansas populism who once urged her followers to raise less corn and more hell.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- A drive upon Congress, aimed at modification of the Volstead act to provide for legalization of "non-intoxicating'" beer with acoholic content of 2.75 per cent by weight (3.46 per cent by volume) was opened today by the Associated Producers of Cereal Beverages, an organization of near-beer manufacturers representing an investment of $250,000,000.

Yale, Harvard and Princeton games of this and other years were discussed, along with other matters, at a dinner given last night at the Harvard Club by Arthur E. French, captain of the Harvard eleven of 1928. It was the fourth dinner of the kind given by Mr. French, and was in honor of the football teams of the three universities.

MANCHURIA is an old country; it is also a new country. But the new in Manchuria has almost no connection with the old, Just as in Colorado and New Mexico the civilization of the white newcomers is different from that of the Pueblo Indians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The text of the United States reply to Poland concerning her debts to this country was as follows:

THE characters of "Public Affaires" belong to the category of the very rich; they are also people obsessed with "having fun," with trying to act "natural instead of social" and as a result toeing discourteous on principle while at the same time trying to be considerate too.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Commenting in THE TIMES on Ephriam Cheever's assertion that "the first white child born in North America was Virginia Dare, on Aug. 18, 1597, in Roanoke," I said that probably the first white child was born in St. Augustine in the period from 1565 to 1597.

DUBLIN, Nov. 26--Donal Buckley, a shopkeeper and veteran of the Easter rebellion of 1916, took the oath of office today as Governor-General and the King's personal representative in the Irish Free State. His appointment, announced earlier in the day, came as a complete surprise to the whole country and even to members of his own family.

THE closer supervision which the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce hereafter will exercise over preparations for flights by American airmen to foreign countries should be regarded as a service to airmen who carefully plan such projects, and not as a restriction on future transoceanic or other long-distance flights to foreign lands.

THE following are some excerpts from the diary I kept during my collaboration with my good friend Fowler on "The Great Magoo." This document was not meant for prying eyes, but having heard that Fowler is around town making remarks and dickering with a well-known newspaper syndicate, I am releasing the excerpts on the theory that in the long run the truth about a matter is always the best for everybody concerned.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- This week has been one of forceful reminder to every one in France and in most of the rest of the world that war and even victory in war is not worth while.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 24 -- There is one man in the country at least who does not seek Cabinet rank. He is William E. Gonzales, editor and publisher of The State. Mentioned recently by THE NEW YORK TIMES as a Cabinet possibility, Mr. Gonzales in an editorial entitled "Personal and Confidential" makes this comment:

WHEN we declare that the stage should be the forum of poets we should define our terms. To many people poetry is verse. It is easy to see that Sophocles and Shakespeare were poets since they wrote in metrical form.

SEVERAL organizations that conduct sewing classes for the relief of the ill and needy have begun their work this Autumn, due to the great demand for aid, instead of waiting for the Lenten season as has been the custom in previous years. Members of the Daughters of the Cincinnati have started their classes in sewing and knitting for the American Red Cross and are meeting on Friday mornings at the Pierre.

The italics mark the divergencies in the diplomatic text.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Giving his views on repeal action to reporters today, Speaker Garner said that "a good many gentlemen in Congress in both parties favor a vote on repeal before presentation of a beer bill, and it seems to me to be the natural order of things to vote on repeal and then on beer later."

AS usually happens at this time of the year, several recent letters contain requests for lists of recordings from the Wagner music dramas, one correspondent suggesting that "a resume of what has been done of the remaining Wagner operas, such as you gave us last Spring from 'Parsifal,' would be of interest to many."

What is disability allowance? So much confusion has arisen in connection with, the discussion of this monetary benefit now being paid to World War veterans that a clear statement of what it is and the history leading up to its adoption seems desirable. Disability allowance is a pension paid to World War veterans for disabilities acquired subsequent to their leaving the military service.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 26 -- Winston Guest's Meadow Brook four, representing the United States, handed Argentina's polo aces a 12-10 defeat in the third and decisive game of the series for the Cup of the Americas today.

Exporters are going to be hard pressed to win back any part of the 50 per cent or more of this country's foreign trade which has "slipped away" since 1929, C.M. Peter, export manager of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company of Towson, Md., said yesterday in the course of an interview in which he called upon exporters to organize into a militant group and bring their plight before officials in Washington.

THE second week of the opera season will feature the debut of two American singers at the Metropolitan. Rose Bampton, contralto, will he heard tomorrow night in "Gioconda," and Richard Bonelli, baritone, will sing the role of the elder Germont in "La Traviata" on Thursday night.

Following a partial recovery in late trading on Friday, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 10 points more in early dealings yesterday, only to meet an increase in selling pressure toward the close. After almost all the day's business had been transacted at a slight advance, weakness in the stock markets and hedge selling left the list at the bottom, with losses of 1 to 5 points on the day.
PARIS, Nov. 28 -- Premier Herriot spent a busy day today, first with his Cabinet and then with treasury experts discussing all possible combinations and arguments in the war debt discussion.

Lawyers representing twenty-seven Glen Cove (L.I.) taxpayers, including the owners of some of Long Island's finest country estates, reached a tentative settlement with Glen Cove tax authorities yesterday, resulting in a reduction of about $2,100,000 in assessments for a three-year period.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 26 -- Hope that Congress will enact at the coming short session farm relief legislation setting up machinery that he can set in motion immediately after his inauguration on March 4 was expressed today by President-elect Roosevelt at a conference with the executive committee of the National Grange at the "Little White House."

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: In her letter to the editor, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW on Nov. 6. 1932. Princess Catherine Radziwlll takes issue with my review of her recently published book. "It Really Happened."

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Far-sighted citizens of Chicago began to realize more than twenty years ago that planless growth in the metropolitan area was developing a jungle of government which would presently be intolerable from any standpoint of efficiency or economy.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Nov. 24 -- As the clouds of political smoke drift away Arkansas emerges tranquilly from one of the most staid and conservative elections in its history. With party lines and prophecies smashed on several adjacent fronts, with neighboring States still considerably dazed from the aftermath of their ballot revolutions, Arkansas goes demurely on its Democratic way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES published recently an article by John R. Palendetchitch which contained not only erroneous information about myself but also about the political situation in Yugoslavia. Mr. Palendetchitch affirms that my martyrdom is an invention and that I am not an exile of Yugoslavia.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- The recent investment of a large amount of American standstill credits, apparently nearly 1,000,000 marks [$238,000], in German public utility securities has called the attention of financial circles to this kind of transaction, which is said to be increasing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Today's issue of THE TIMES abounds in meaty material which renders it difficult to play favorites when it comes to topics. However, the letters to the editor division opens the session with a letter that incites more than passing interest, from Edward Adams Richardson.

Commodity prices have experienced a much more severe decline from the peaks reached early in September than have stocks or bonds, considered respectively as groups. Virtually no classification in the commodity list escaped the drop which has wiped out almost all the advances made in July, August and the first lew days of September.

The foundation of the whole structure of wild-life conservation is education, according to Major L.W.T. Waller Jr. of Meadowbrook, Pa., who will address the American Game Conference this week at the Hotel Pennsylvania. His paper will be read on Tuesday.

No known method exists whereby the price of any commodity may be raised or stabilized if its supply be constantly in excess of demand, Kenneth S. Guiterman, engineer and merchant, declared in a review of futile attempts made in the last fifty years to stabilize the price of copper.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 20 -- Once again the Nanking Ministry of Industry announces ambitious plans involving the expenditure of millions of dollars, the industrialization of a portion of China and the founding of vast enterprises.

Among the passengers who sailed yesterday for Havre on the French liner Champlain was Countess Aldebert de Chambrun, sister of the late Nicholas Longworth, who was Speaker of the House of Representatives. She said a biography of her brother, which she had written, would be published next February under the title "The Making of Nicholas Longworth."
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 26 -- Georgia and Georgia Tech battled to a scoreless football tie today before a crowd of more than 17,000.

NEW YORK CITY, unlike some other municipalities, is still capable of shame and hot indignation when her officials outrage the instincts of public honesty and decency. She is still shocked and horrified over the disclosures of the investigation of the magistrates' courts of which Judge Seabury served as a referee and has

THE Arnold Bennett who manifested himself in the first volume of the "Journal" reappears again in this second volume, but with several changes in disposition and in attitude toward the world. He is more sure of himself (almost cocky, in fact) and more than ever concerned with material success.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Hygro, the brilliant 3-year-old son of the French racer, Epinard, out of Ruddy Light, brought $12,000, top price, in the dispersal sale today of the Nevada Stock Farm.
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- Is Senator George Higgins Moses done? Who can tell? Only the Senator himself, and it is a question whether even he knows.

LOUIS GRUENBERG will conduct a performance of his "Daniel Jazz" at the MacDowell Festival Concert at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 7, a concert which, opens a nation-wide celebration in honor of the founding of the MacDowell Colony at Peterboro, N.H.

DETROIT NOVEMBER, now drawing to a close, may mark the turning point in the depression so far as the automotive industry is concerned. It is certain that production for the month la going to step vigorously upward, possibly doubling October's 50,000 passenger cars and trucks.

A World Need. What the world needs today is not a good five-cent cigar, nor even good beer -- though this is blasphemy. What it needs -- and needs badly -- is an economist who -- in words of one syllable -- can make the gold standard, the tariff, the war debts and such-like trifling subjects which are affecting the lives of every worker in the world clear and understandable to the common people.

The proverb that "charity begins at home," as applied in the economic crisis, may be found to have an injurious effect within the nation that utters it, Dr. Friedrich Wilhelm von Prittwitz und Graffon, the German Ambassador, suggested yesterday in an address here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States Ship Constitution (Old Ironsides) will leave Washington Dec. 7 for a trip via the Panama Canal to the Pacific Coast, the Navy Department announced today.
WHEELING, W.Va., Nov. 26--Washington and Jefferson College swept through the air to a 13-0 victory over West Virginia University in their thirty-first meeting on the gridiron today.

THE concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony this afternoon at the Metropolitan is the last in Arturo Toscanini's first eight-week period with the orchestra. He expects to sail Tuesday on the S.S. Bremen and to return in time for his second eight-week period, beginning March 1.

PARIS. ART objects, paintings, sculpture and furniture that have adorned the Paris residence of George Blumenthal, American philanthropist and collector, will be put up for auction at the Georges Petit Galeries here on Dec. 1 and 2.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Prime Minister MacDonald will meet the leaders of his Cabinet at 10 Downing Street tomorrow night in an all-important consultation on the American debt problem.

THAT the study of evolution today, and of its causes and trends,. is largely a problem of genetics, of chromosomes and genes, the mechanism of heredity, is generally recognized even by lay students of biology and sociology. Since the rediscovery of Mendel's laws of heredity, thirty-three years ago, innumerable experiments with representative species of organisms have been successfully conducted by workers in all parts of the world.
IN 1929 more dollars flowed into the pockets of the American peaple than in any previous year. The total of our 1929 nationAl income has been estimated competently at $85,000,000,000.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 24 -- The Insular Board of Elections is going through the necessary formality of counting the ballots cast on Nov. 8, the quietest election the island has had in the more than thirty years since civil government was established under the American regime.

Preparations for the city-wide drive to bring small contributions into the $15,000,000 fund sought by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee were completed yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The small-gifts campaign is to open tomorrow with the erection of 500 booths in railroad stations, hotels and other public buildings.

THERE are no signs on the Princeton campus at the present time of any marked change in student attitude toward intercollegiate football. The appearance of a new football coach this year, Herbert O. Crisler, and the virtual rebirth of the gridiron game here make Princeton's situation somewhat unique.

LONDON, Nov. 7, 1932. LONDON musicians are divided into two camps: some are for Sir Thomas Beecham and his new London Philharmonic Orchestra and some for Dr. Adrian Boult and the B.B.C. players. Both sides admit that the opponents are not to be despised, but neither side will admit that possible grounds for comparison between the two forces exist.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 26 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, served notice today on the "die-hards" among the delegates to the American Federation of Labor convention who are opposing compulsory unemployment insurance that if they persisted in their attitude he would lead the fight against them on the floor of the convention.

SINCE January, 1930, THE NEW YORK TIMES has reported sixty-four cases of memory lapses as serious as that of Colonel Robins. There must have been hundreds more of which the press never heard. Men and women who forget who they are and who wander about pathetically -- totally new personalities so far as the world is concerned -- are commoner than many of us suppose.

The consideration of war debts has now swung back to nationalistic bases, and just so long as the problem remains there just so long will a final solution be postponed. The complicated issue of intergovernmental indebtedness will be solved only by international cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Washington today massed its forces to discourage and resist expected hunger marchers during the coming Winter, particularly the communistic gathering scheduled to arrive here next Saturday or Sunday to stage a demonstration at the Capitol when Congress convenes for the short session.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Frank Kelly of the Meadowbrook Club won the individual title in the annual Middle Atlantic A.A.U. Junior Cross-Country Championship run today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The movement for a swift and forthright vote on the question of prohibition repeal picked up high support in the Senate today, while Speaker Garner was announcing definitely that he would permit in the House the most drastic procedure possible on a repeal resolution.

THE depression seems to have had some effect on the attitude of the Harvard undergraduates toward football spectacles, though to what degree it is to be separated from other forces is impossible to de- termine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The contest for the Speakershlp in the next Congress was intensified today by the announced candidacy of Representative Joseph W. Byrns of Tennessee and a statement by Representative William B. Bankhead that he would support his Alabama colleague, Representative John McDuffie.

Had it not been for the perplexing war-debt problem, which Wall Street was bound to put ahead of everything else, the consent decree of the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., in the celebrated Radio case would have commanded more attention than it did.

FOR her large and faithful audience Mrs. Hill has written nearly forty romances of virtue rewarded and love triumphant. But surely none of her other romances could be more elevating or more didactic -- than "The Patch of Blue."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Edwin A. Van Valkenburg, former newspaper editor and adviser of two Presidents, who was referred to by the late Theodore Roosevelt in 1916 as "the most useful American citizen," died of heart disease in the Jefferson Hospital here tonight after a long illness.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The most scathing denunciation yet made of the government's delay in balancing France's budget has been issued by the Assembly of the Presidents of the Chambers of Commerce in France and Algeria.

Fifteen hundred gallons of unrefined oil were spilled in Woodhaven Boulevard and Ninety-first Avenue, Woodhaven. Queens, at 8:10 o'clock last night when two large buses filled with passengers, a tank truck and another truck loaded with drums of gasoline were involved in a series of crashes.

With Thanksgiving Day gone, the churches will begin to look toward Christmas by preaching sermons on "Preparation for the Coming of the King." At St. Patrick's Cathedral and other Catholic churches preachers will deliver a series of Advent sermons.

A valuable collection of Egyptian papyri, including a letter from a fourth-century Bishop to the churches in his diooese and a slave contract of the late second or early third century, have been added to the collection ot the Columbia University Library, it was announced yesterday by Professor William Linn Westermann, Curator of Papyri at the university.

Acting Mayor Joseph V. McKee, questioned yesterday on his attitude toward the formation of three committees to survey the city administration by Mayor-elect John P. O'Brien, said that municipal department heads would comply as a matter of course with Mr. O'Brien's request that they cooperate with the committee and show how their departmental budget expenses might be reduced.

Editor, The New York Times Bokk Review: Without doubt there will be more than one indignant rejoinder from Roman Catholics to Mr. Charles Marshall's false and foolish objec- tion to a paragraph in Mr. German's review a propos the Elizabethan persecutions of their coreligionists.

AS one of the world organizers of the W.C.T.U., Miss Tinling went all the way round the globe, spending much time in each of several countries, and in the course of this tour she visited many of the important leper colonies, observing conditions, methods and results with keen interest and warm human sympathy.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 -- Southern California is chattering like a herd of magpies. So long was her conversational activity confined to matters political, solid and liquid, that she revels in new-found subjects. We are, after all, a neighborly community, and the long view into national and international affairs proved wearing.

THE Metropolitan Opera premiere of Richard Strauas's "Elektra" will be broadcast in entirety from the stage of the opera house on Saturday at 2:15 P.M. The WJZ network will be linked with the microphones.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 26 -- Belgium tomorrow will elect a new Parliament, which will face the immediate task of organizing the budget to cover the deficit resulting from the Hoover moratorium on debt payments and the decline in tax receipts.

MATISSE is famous over two continents -- or more -- for his color. To speak of him is to speak nine times out of ten concerning his mastery of color. Unless you happen to be with a group dedicated to the graphic arts. Then his etchings will form the subject of the hour.

AFTER various works dealing with the follies, the absurdities and the endearing qualities of mankind, Mr. Morley in this book continues to write of human beings in general terms, for his hero is no more than a particular who is a composite of all the strange and contradictory qualities supposed to be the common heritage of every one.

ROMe. OUR council has been given the responsible task of expressing its opinion on all regulations which must be submitted for approval to the Cabinet Council whenever such regulations have a technical, scientific character.

The National 4-H clubs poultry judging contest was the principal feature of the closing program of the National Pet Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. Teams of boys from six Eastern States appraised eight classes of birds, including four breeds.

Three life insurance companies have reduced the dividends apportioned to holders of policies containing disability annuity benefts, compared with dividends paid to holders of similar policies without disability benefits, because of the disproportionately large claims on disability policies which have arisen from the depression.

Upon the completion of a few minor items by the contractors this week, the new Breakneck Mountain vehicular tunnel near Cold Spring, N.Y., will be turned over to the State as one of New York's unique highway projects.

While the changes in the radio industry which will result from the igreement reached last week to terminate the government's anti-trust suit against the Radio Corporation of America will leave the corporation without the financial and general support of the General Electric and the Westinghouse Electric and Manfacturing companies, it is believed in Wall Street that the corporation really will be stronger than it has been.

VIENNA, Nov. 25 -- The visit to Rome of the Hungarian Premier, Julius Goemboes, followed by the visit to Budapest of the Austrian Chancellor, Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss, and his conference with the Bavarian Premier, Dr. Heinrich Held, in Salzburg, have stirred up a hornets' nest of rumors which have been buzzing these days in the newspapers of Paris and Berlin and Southeastern Europe itself.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Premier Edouard Harriot, whose continuance in office is threatened by the American debt issue, and Norman H. Davis, representative of the Washington State Department, spent an hour this evening discussing granting arms equality to Germany.
MOSCOW, Nov. 26 -- An interesting illustration of the function of the Soviet press as the mouthpiece of the government is given by its treatment of the present food shortage.

MASTER of a vivacious, staccato style, possessing an instinct for the colorful and the dramatic and a striking ability to express them in apt language. Harry Carr always turns out a taking sort of book, for those who want entertainment not too much diluted with serious matters.
BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Time expired while the Ottawa Senators were putting on a thrilling hockey rally tonight and the Boston Bruins managed to leave the ice with a 6-to-4 victory.

To expedite the interpretation and application of the Federal anti-trust statutes, the rendering of written opinions by the Federal Trade Com- mission to accompany its formal findings of facts and orders was urged yesterday by Gilbert H. Montague, New York lawyer and trust-law authority.

Several hundred persons, chatting in the corridor of Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, after a meeting of the Jewish Committee to Help Palestine, were thrown into commotion at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon when four members discovered that their pocketbooks had been stolen by pickpockets.

IN November of 1832, Amos Bronson Alcott, a schoolmaster extraordinary, teaching then in Gennantown, Pa., wrote to his father-in-law, Colonel Joseph May of Boston, announcing in stately sentences the birth, on his own birthday, of a daughter, a child with "a fine foundation for health and energy of character," who should be named Louisa May.

DENVER, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Five members of the champion University of Utah team were selected on the 1932 Associated Press honorary Rocky Mountain Conference football eleven, named from a consensus of coaches, officials and sports writers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- In all the pomp and ceremony attending the opening of a world classic, thousands of neatly groomed farm animals were paraded about the gayly decorated tan-bark arena at Chicago's stock yards today, opening the annual International Live Stock Show.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 26 -- Growing tension between the Chinese and the Japanese in North China has followed the bombing of four shops at Tientsin on Thursday by anti-Japanese terrorist organizations, resulting in the wounding of sixteen persons.

Heyman Hertz of 614 West 152d Street, whose father received a medal from the Emperor Napoleon himself, will celebrate his one hundredth birthday anniversary on Tuesday by accepting a cake adorned with 100 candles from his bride of sixty years ago. Mrs. Hertz, who is only 80 years old, intends to bake the cake herself.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17 -- Bootlegging has reached Brazil and Merity is the centre of operations. The bootlegged product is gasoline. Merity is a small town just outside the jurisdiction of the Federal District and has always been respectable with its main street and that air of tranquillity which surrounds similar villages all over the world.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The United States is not exactly popular in England this week and it may expect to be still less so if the war debt instalment must be paid next month.

MR. O'BRIEN regards the stories in this collection as the cream of the yearbooks he has been editing since 1915. There are twenty-five stories in all; some of them have achieved a definite place in contemporary writing; others, once highly regarded, are all but forgotten now; still others have been wholly rescued from limbo.

MANILA, P.I., Oct. 20 -- Protection for agriculture and for industry was the keynote of Governor General Roosevelt's message this week to the Philippine Legislature. Exports have suffered, he said, through the raising of tariff barriers by other countries since the original tariff act of 1909, with the result that while foreign countries have found it easier to trade with the Philippines, the islands have found it harder to trade elsewhere.

SEVERAL performances of current theatrical attractions have been taken over this week in behalf of philanthropic organizations. The proceeds of the performance of "The Good Earth" at the Guild Theatre tomorrow night will aid the charitable enterprises of the Madison Square Boys' Club.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Nov. 26 -- The elimination of Frank Irete, co-medalist, by Norman Sickels of Llanerch, 3 and 2, in the second round, featured the first day of match play in the tenth annual Wildwood Eastern States Thanksgiving Tournament. Sickels will meet George Boyajian of Atlantic City, former Fordham golfer, in the lower half of the semi-final round tomorrow.

TOKYO, Nov. 26 -- Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's chief representative before the League of Nations on the Manchurian dispute, on instructions from Tokyo, will vary the tactics followed when the issue was last before the Assembly.

SUMTER, S.C., Nov. 24 -- For some years South Carolina has been waging a live-at-home campaign, but by far the greatest headway has been made since the advent of hard times, with the result that virtually all idle cotton mills have been converted into improvised canneries, and conservation measures involving even the Eighteenth Amendment have been resorted to in a food production program unparalleled in this section since the World War.

To the Editor of The New York Times: People of Japan feel grateful for the Lytton report. When it deals with the unspeakable lootings and slaughter of the hapless Chinese millions by their war lords and declares: "These conditions have adversely affected all nations with which China has been brought into contact and until remedied will continue the menace to world peace," nothing seems to us more fair_than this pronouncement.

GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- There are three parties to the grave conflict now before the League of Nations CouncilJapan, China and the League -- and the weakest of these is Japan, in the view of certain men who are playing an influential role now in the formulation and application of the strategy of peace.

WASHINGTON PRESIDENT HOOVER'S suggestion for the appointment of an agency which would link the war-time debts of European nations with disarmament and the deliberations at the forthcoming World Economic Conference would, in effect, result in re-creation of the World War Debt Commission, with somewhat broadened powers of investigation and a more diversified personnel of experts.

TEA-DRINKING, past and present, is the subject of this delightful series of essays by Agnes Repplier, in which she discusses "the China drink" in all its aspects, social, historical and philosophical, from the time of its first arrival in England and the installation of the teapot in its predestined place as first among the English household gods.

The habeas corpus proceedings brought for the release of Thomas Patrick Morris, claimant to the $35,000,000 Wendel estate, who has been held in the Harlem prison under $10,000 bail pending the District Attorney's investigation of his assertion of kinship, was adjourned yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Callahan until tomorrow because of a defect in the papers under which Morris is held.

A tendency toward scholarly conservatism in college fraternity life, as opposed to an atmosphere of mere club activities in architecturally showy houses, was noted yesterday in reports read at the closing session of the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the National Interfraternity Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Dudley Field Valentine, Deputy Tax Commissioner of Yonkers, real estate appraiser, well-known horseman and descendant of Thomas Valentine, who entertained General George Washington when he visited Yonkers just before the Battle of White Plains, died today of cancer in a private sanitarium here.

New York's fifty-third international six-day bicycle race will get under way at 9 o'clock tonight in Madison Square Garden. A field of thirty cyclists, the pick of the ranks in this country and foreign centres, will start the grind when George Allen of the vaudeville team of Burns and Allen fires the starting gun.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- The powerful New Rochelle High School football team maintained its unbeaten record for the season by conquering the Mount Vernon High eleven today, 12 to 0.

Three men were injured and several other persons barely escaped being struck yesterday afternoon when a large wooden structure in front of the Hotel New Yorker on Eighth Avenue, near Thirty-fifth Street, was loosened by the wind and crashed to the sidewalk.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 26 -- The question whether Robert C. Critz. 37, member of a prominent North Carolina family and cousin of Z. Smith Reynolds, who was fatally shot July 6, was accidentally shot or attempted suicide was not answered tonight as Critz lay in the City Hospital with an even chance to recover from a serious wound in the head.
TOTAL national income has been astimated for our banner year, 1929, at $85,000,000,000. For 1932 it is perhaps $50,000,000,000, a shrinkage of 41 per cent.

Disclosure that R.H. Aishton, chairman of the Association of Rail- way Executives, was preparing a statement to be filed with the National Transportation Committee was interpreted yesterday as meaning that the railroads would urge a closer supervision of commercial trucking and other highway traffic.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- The probability of amendment of the prohibition laws in consequence of the impending change in administration in the United States appeals most strongly to those European countries which are looking forward to a profitable trade in light wines and beer as soon as the Volstead act is modified.

NEW American liners coming off the ways are as different from other vessels as could well be Imagined. Not only in outer lines, which have a distinct beauty, but in interior appolntments do they depart from hitherto accepted practice.

MILAN, Italy, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Police were endeavoring tonight to ascertain the whereabouts of Miss Anna Dersherl of Syracuse, N.Y., in connection with the attempt to solve the mysterious arrival in two cities of suitcases containing a dismembered body of a woman.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 26 -- Cecil Kittredge Bancroft, registrar and member of the faculty at Phillips Academy since 1906, died today at Isham Infirmary at the academy after an illness of three months. He was in his sixty-fourth year. He was the son of the late Rev. Dr. Cecil F.P. Bancroft, principal of Phillips Academy for more than a quarter of a century.

With about 75 per cent of the trade of the retail fiscal year now done, estimates made here yesterday indicated that the average expense ratio of department stores for 1932, to be shown in the Harvard report, is likely, to move up to about 36 1/2 per cent.

RUMSON, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Senator W. Warren Barbour of Locust was guest of honor at a victory dinner given tonight at the Rumson Coun- try Club by a number of his neighbors. Robert H. McCarter was the speaker.

BOOKS about books and the people who write them average a higher content of dullness and stupefied repetition of their predecessors in the same field than any other department of literature, save those endless volumes of collected sermons which were spewed forth from the presses in the eighteenth century and upon which Dr. Samuel Johnson nourished his immortal soul.

THE author of this autobiographical novel (written in collaboration with his brother, Walton Van Clute) has for years been a charity patient on Welfare Island, a victim of arthritis. Ankylosia, which has destroyed his power of muscular movement by knitting together the bone joints, is not, however, his only affliction; he has become stone blind.
A CINDERELLA story in modern dress offering light and pleasant entertainment.

Katherine Bacon's first piano recital of the season was given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. In accordance with her previous programs, which have presented several significant works of one composer, her list yesterday comprised four Brahms selections, the three Intermezzi and the rhapsody in E flat; the four Chopin Ballades, Cesar Frank's prelude, chorale and fugue, and Ravel's toccata, pavane and "Jeux d'Eau."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 26 -- Marquette University closed its football season today with a smashing 45-to-0 victory over Drake. The Bulldogs' gains amounted to only seven yards, while Marquette amassed 382 yards on running plays and 155 more on passes.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Bernard Shaw's new play will tell Londoners what might happen if St. Augustine returned to earth, descended upon Piccadilly and began preaching a sermon.

The Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants will clash at Ebbets Field this afternoon in a National Football League game. A crowd of 25,000 persons is expected to witness the struggle, which will mark the first meeting of the teams in Brooklyn this year.

The competitive golf events for the 1932 season in the North have been virtually completed, and the championships of nearly all the New York clubs have been decided for another year. A summary of the titleholders at the Westchester clubs shows that a number of them retained their crowns after bristling competition.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- Dispatches and comment in the United States press indicate, it is being pointed out here, a curious confusion of mind as to the origin and intent of the State-owned radio system which the new Canadian Broadcasting Commission is to make effective by easy stages.

To the Dramatic Editor: As an outsider still trying to break in, I should like to discuss with my fellow-strugglers what might he termed the "psychology of the curtain." Eminent professors of playwriting will mention this, but they will mention it along with a thousand and one other rules and regulations which, if the playwright endeavors to incorporate them into his particular theme, will drive him slowly but surely mad.

THE Winter season for debutantes is well under way -- the Thanksgiving holidays last week brought the first formal parties for them. The first large entertainment, however, which the young women anticipate for weeks, is the first of the season's Junior Assemblies, which comes on Friday at the Ritz-Carlton.

The results of the survey conducted by the women's committee of the A.A.U. reveal, some interesting facts. With Mrs. Richard Folsom of Chicago as chairman, questionnaires were sent by the group to 850 women who since 1912 have been distinguished either as A.A.U. or Olympic titleholders.

LONDON. J.G. WILSON, the managing director of Bumpus's, was one day trying to help a lady who wanted a book for a child of 11. He inquired if the little girl had read "Alice in Wonderland." "No," was the reply, "and I hope she never will.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- After a lapse of ten years and for the fifteenth time in football history, the Army and Navy return to Franklin Field next Saturday for their annual clash.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- Brookline, the famous town of 48,000 with a voting population of 22,000, which persists in operating on the limited town meeting plan, is in the way of abolishing its caucus system. The term is likely to bewilder the uninstructed.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The appointment of a small-town shopkeeper and a former Sinn Feiner, Donal Buckley as Governor-General of the Irish Free State, announced simultaneously in Dublin and London today, caused considerable surprise. Entirely unknown in England, his name had not even been mentioned as a possible choice as the representative of the crown in Dublin.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The following letter received from Dr. Helen Keller, who visited the Scottish Highlands not long ago, seems to me so remarkable that I think the readers of THE TIMES would like to read it. I "showed" her Titania's Palace -- my construction which has been seen in the United States, and my book "Yvette in the U.S.A. With Titania's Palace" was read to her.

The library of the late Ida O. Folsom of Boston, containing many rare books, is to be auctioned next Tuesday and Wednesday nights at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The first editions include some of the rarest of Barrle, Kipling, Mrs. Browning, Conrad, Thackeray, Dickens, Thoreau and Whitman.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Lynn Hunt won the final registered shoot of the year over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He took the high scratch cup by breaking 91 out of a possible 100 targets. T.B. Pettit Jr. captured the high handicap prize with 84 7 .
That seems to be in general true, with an outstanding exception to be made in the case of the "Odyssey," of which the best translation leaves something uncaught.

Projects to aid unemployed women, messages from prominent women, music, the dance, fashion shows and the presentation of household information, will be features of the week's program of the annual exposition of Women's Arts and Industries which opens tomorrow at the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- An organization known as Grith Fyrd Camps has come into existence in response to the present industrial situation. A chain of permanent camp communities is being formed in which young men of all classes can live a worthwhile life, even if precluded from earning a living.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent issue of THE TIMES contained a suggestive editorial on "Invention in Retrospect." It reproduced W.J. Wyman's list, compiled in 1913, of the ten greatest inventions during the preceding quarter of a century.

Transportation services on inland waterways should be considered a branch of ocean shipping and controlled by the ship lines to which they carry freight at seaboard, said H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders in a discussion last week of the problems of coordinated rail and water services.

A Notre Dame juggernaut of the old Rockne mold, as irresistible with its passes, spinners and blocking and as devastating on the defense as any to invade, this city, trampled over an Army eleven feted among the greatest in West Point history yesterday, inflicting the most crushing defeat suffered by the cadets at the hands of their South Bend rivals since 1921.

WITH the issuance of application blanks tomorrow will begin the period of registration for approximately 600,000 automobiles in New York City and 1,900,000 in the State. The present license plates on passenger cars expire on Dec. 31, after which date those who wish to make use of their cars must have the 1933 plates.

ALTHOUGH the orchidaceous Peggy Fears and her husband, A.C. Blumenthal, have decided against producing "Saint Wench," as was reported, here last Sunday, this is not to be construed as indicating that John Colton's play has suffered another set back in the course of its long and rather tortuous trip to Broadway.

The possibility which arose for a moment that the present Congress, in its three remaining months of life and with a shift of political control due to occur on March 4, might have to pass on the highly important question of the inter- national war debts, has revived discus- sion as to whether "lame-duck sessions" have ever left their mark on legislative history.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 26 -- Duke University closed the most successful football season in its history today by scoring a 13-to-0 victory over Washington, and Lee in the local stadium. The game was played on a muddy field and a high wind made punting and passing hazardous.

IN the Spring of 1314 John Tickhill, the scribe and illuminator who made the famous Psalter which bears his name, was removed from the office of Prior of the monastery of Worksop, near Nottingham, for "Incontinence and dilapidation."

Owing to the rapid development of research and the increase in the number of laboratories in the country, the obsolescence of machinery, patents and products will be speeded up during the next few years, according to Lewis W. Waters, vice president of the General Foods Corporation.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 26 -- With a portion of General Liu Chen-nien's Shantung army already at sea on the way to Chekiang Province and the remainder marching toward Chefoo to embark, China today affords the amazing spectacle of the central government removing a defeated army more than 30,000 strong some 800 miles at the behest of General Han Fu-chu, who was victorious in the provincial warfare.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- After an initial decline to $3.20 3/4 , sterling exchange on New York rallied today to $3.22. The price of gold, however, continued to soar, reaching a new high record of 127s 11d an ounce.

Substantial increases in membership, rapid expansion of chapters and the appointment of an advisory council for the New York area were an- nounced yesterday by the American Veterans, an organization recently formed to oppose prepayment of the bonus and all veterans benefits arisinging from disabilities not resulting from military service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The report of the committee on governmental debts due the United States appointed by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, made public by the chamber today, follows:

EIGHT days hence the final, the lame duck, session of the Seventy-second Congress will open at Washington with staggering problems pressing for solution. Not even when the last Democratic National Legislature met for its ultimate session in December, 1918, was there more anxiety in the country over the activities of its law-making group.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 26 -- A favored Holy Cross football team played a scoreless tie with Boston College today, the Crusaders failing to make a first down and gaining only fifteen yards by rushing the ball.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 26 -- The Rice Institute Owls defeated Baylor today by the score of 12 to 0, Rice presenting a tight defense against which the Bears could do nothing.

At Princeton University this year there is a new club which has to do with sports and which is known as the Princeton Sports Managers Club. It has at present a membership of the twenty-three undergraduate managers of the various sports teams and groups, and the club serves to bring into the foreground a little-recognized fact, that the undergraduate managers are vitally important members of their teams.

The use of Colonial interiors as "museum trophies" was denounced and compared to the South Sea Is- lenders' former habit of exhibiting the heads of captured chieftains, in a statement by Dr. Leicester B. Holland, chairman of the committee on preservation of the historic buildings of the American Institute of Architects, in a statement issued by the institute yesterday.

Miss Donna Schuyler Beekman, daughter of Mrs. W. Schuyler Beekman and the late Colonel Beekman, was introduced to society yesterday by her mother at a reception with dancing in the Egyptian Room of the St. Regis.

OUT of the tea gown of yester- day has grown the hostess gown of today. At one and the same time it is elegant, formal and gracious. Its regal sim- plicity -- we are speaking of the host- ess gown -- fits it for more extended uses than the tea gown had or has -- for that soft, lacy affair has not altogether vanished into the cases of costume museums.

THE only European woman who has ever been made a lama, a professed Buddhist and for fourteen years a traveler in Tibet, whose language she speaks fluently, Mme. Alexandra David-Neel is peculiarly well equipped to write of the strange things which happen in the "Land of Snow."

HARTFORD, Nov. 24 -- When the new Connecticut General Assembly convenes in January it will find this State, which has made the "pay-as-you-go" idea a fundamental of its fiscal policy, facing a deficit for the first time since 1921. The size of the deficit, for which business conditions, resulting in a reduced income and a greater demand for relief expenditures, are blamed, is variously estimated, the highest guess so far being $8,000,000.

LINKED with Merian Cooper's knowledgeful supervision, the capable direction of Ernest Schoedsack and Irving Pichel, and the highly creditable adaptation of Richard Connell's prize short story by James Ashmore Creelman, there is in the RKO production, "The Most Dangerous Game."
An exhibition entitled "Rembrandt, Rubens and Their Followers" has opened at the Ehrich Galleries, 36 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will remain until the end of the month.

A DIGNIFIED and readable biography of a man with a sufficient touch of romance both in his character and in the circumstances of his life to appeal to young readers. Young people do not read Hawthorne's short stories and novels as they did a generation ago, but any boy or girl interested in writing will enjoy this account of Hawthorne's struggle to become an author and his ultimate success.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- The shadow of unemployment in Germany is once more lengthening. The official enumeration, Nov. 15, counted 5,265,000 jobless -- 156,000 more than on Oct. 31.

BESIDE the point, manifestly is one's approval or disapproval surrealism has got a firm football in American art and the fact may just as well be faced. Of course it is only to be expected that these borrowed European isms should appear "dated" over here almost from the start, since it takes time to become proficient in a style lifted from ingenious ateliers of Paris.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 -- Senbra Dona Leonor Llorente de Calles, wife of the former President, was buried this morning at Dolores Cemetery. The funeral was attended by President Rodriguez, all Cabinet Ministers, Governors of States, Senators, Deputies and all the diplomatic corps.

AS to the case for disarmament, apart from the questions of expense and the diminution of international suspicion, the strongest argument of all was our definite promise, repeated on several occsions, to disarm as soon as Germany had accepted and carried out the disarmament clauses of the Treaty of Versailles.
NEWARK Metropolitan Airport, aided by the State of New Jersey, is now more than ever securely placed at the head of the commercial airports of the world in importance and activity.

IN spite of having elected its city ticket by a handsome majority, Tammany Hall finds itself, toward the close of the 144th anniversary of its parent society, facing one of those crises which from time to time have threatened its undoing.

Passenger traffic on the Eighth Avenue subway will show an estimated rise of 30 per cent when the Fulton Street extension to Borough Hall, Brooklyn, is in operation, according to testimony given yesterday before Basil D. O'Connor, Federal special master in the Interborough receivership proceedings.

Despite the active efforts of nearly 100 trade associations of various types, the Hastings bill to amend the present bankruptcy law will not be reported out of the Congressional Judiciary Committees before adjournment of Congress on March 4, it was agreed here yesterday by various leaders interested in the law.

JACKSON, Ga., Nov. 24 -- Tom King, a well-known Butts County Negro, is about to run up a record as the "most-sentenced-to-die" man Georgia has produced King, who was convicted in 1925 of killing J.E. McNair, a county policeman, has been in jail in Atlanta since that time except when he has been motoring at the State's expense between Atlanta and Jackson, either to be retried or sentenced again to die.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Nov. 24 -- The political cataclysm which engulfed Iowa has left a shattered Republican State machine, and glum laces are being worn, in many State and Fed3ral offices. It is estimated that $1,350,000 a year of Federal patronage alone will be taken over by the victorious Democrats who for years have waited for the day when Iowa, considered the stanchest Republican State of the Midwest, would cast off its G.O.P. moorings.

BERLIN. FOLLOWING the success of his "Columbus," Jakob Wassermann has again turned to a biographical novel; this one describes the life of Henry Morton Stanley, known as "Bula Matari" (S. Fischer, Berlin).

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 26 -- Sir Otto Niemeyer, vice governor of the Bank of England, has contracted to advise Argentina on economics and finance, it was announced today by Finance Minister Alberto Hueyo.

WHEN colleges have to pull their purse strings tighter, their favorite first economy is, so to speak, to put less coal on the furnace and to turn the lights out earlier at night. But paying the professor, at least in the present emergency, is generally being considered the last place where pennies should be spared.

The first Saturday matinee of the Metropolitan season, which came to pass yesterday, brought back Miss Lily Pons in the first role that she undertook, two seasons ago, in New York's opera house. The role was Lucia of Lammermoor in Donizetti's opera of that name.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 26 -- The Harvard Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa today announced the election of thirty-two seniors and eight juniors to be initiated Dec. 5 at the dinner on the 151st anniversary of the founding of the scholastic honor fraternity.

OAXACA, Mexico, Nov. 27 -- A long mound in the centre of the great plaza which the Indians called "the patio of the sun" is now the subject of intensive excavation. A series of terraced pyramids along the north and south platform has been opened, revealing a stone stairway leading up the east side of the platform.

Happy smiles and subdued elation pervaded the Notre Dame dressing room after the smashing triumph over the Army. There was none of the boisterous back-slapping and shouts of glee usually found in the quarters of the winner.

ONE of Paramount's most interesting films of the season, "If I Had a Million," has been booked into the Rivoli for Friday. This is the story of the eccentric millionaire who distributes his fortune among nine persons whose names he has picked at random from a city directory.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- A dance was given tonight at the Bronxville Women's Club by the Bronxville League for Service. Miss Virginia Campbell served as chairman of the benefit. She had serving with her Miss Nancy Roeser, Miss Emily Whitbeck, Miss Grace Friburg, Miss Betty Betchold, Miss Shirley Owen and Miss McDowell Smith.

The greatest progress in agriculture in many years in Palestine and the successful development of a working organization to lead youth into productive activity were reported last night by Palestine delegates to the eighth national convention for Jewish workers in Palestine.

BERLIN, Nov. 5. THE feature of Furtwangler's second Philharmonic concert was the world premiere of Serge Prokofieff's brand new G major piano concerto -- his fifth of that form -- with the composer himself as soloist.

Dividend distributions by the Standard Oil group of companies for 1932 are estimated at $181,050,895, compared with $220,739,182 in 1931, a decline of $39,688,287 according to records compiled by Carl H. Pforz-Keimer Co. Disbursements for the fourth quarter are estimated at $44112,501, compared with $43,858,468 in the third quarter and $48,530,230 in the fourth quarter of 1931.
