BROADCASTERS are adding the finishing touches to their plans for radio's 1932 finale. Short waves from across the sea will bring a number of foreign presentations to American listeners. Several of the December programs listed as "outstanding" by the broadcasters follow:

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Evening-up operations on the Board of Trade here continued rapidly in December wheat, and the open interest at the close of business today was estimated to be less than 34,000,000 bushels, against a maximum of 120,000,000 on Sept. 10.

MARIE DRESSLER, fine character actress and comedienne, is at the Capitol this week in "Prosperity," her new film comedy with Polly Moran. She was born Lelia Koerber in Coburg, Canada, on Nov. 9, 1869. Her father, Alexander Koerber, was the last surviving officer of the Crimean War.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Upsets in college sports have occurred past the range of memory, but none has been more realistic than those in the sailing dinghy regatta today of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association.

PLANS for forming a countrywide organization of all those interested in chamber music will be discussed this afternoon at the County Centre, White Plains, where representatives of twenty-five chamber music groups of Westchester County are to meet under the leadership of V.L.F. Rebmann, county director of music.

GENEVA. BY Cocherel village in Normandy is its quiet churchyard. There Briand lies -- a great Frenchman who loved France but who also loved peace. It was Briand who, when Foreign Minister, from his place in the League of Nations uttered this memorable vow:

A suit for $12,059 against former Mayor James J. Walker and his wife, Mrs. Janet Allen Walker, for a balance due on $20,059 worth of wearing apparel bought by Mrs. Walker between Sept. 7, 1928, and March 5, 1931, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Hattie Carnegie, Inc., dealer in gowns and other women's apparel at 42 East Forty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 10. IN his new play, "For Services Rendered," brilliantly presented at the Globe Theatre, Somerset Maugham indicts the post-war world. We have learned nothing from the war, he tells us, and we have forgotten the debt of gratitude which we owe to its victims.

THOSE who live in a changing world seldom realize how far they have moved in a given period until some startling event causes them to look back and review the course which they have been pursuing. Such an event to most members of the Harvard faculty, was the announcement of President Lowell's resignation.

THE sponsors of "The Rise of the Goldbergs" are holding auditions for two youngsters to take the place of Alfred Corn and Roslyn Silber, who play the juvenile roles in the sketches. Their contracts were canceled after their parents objected to a second broadcast for the West Coast network without extra remuneration, according to a representative of the National Broadcasting Company.

Mrs. Willis Gemmill Mitchell and her daughter, Miss Helen Annette Mitchell, gave a dinner last night at their home, 1,388 Lexington Avenue, for Miss Harriet Tompkins, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie J. Tompkins. Among the other guests were:

IT was Edward Sheldon who first gave me the idea for my new dramatic sequence. I had read him my "Wives of Henry VIII," which I gave last year, and we were discussing the possibility of other historical and literary personages as material for solo-drama when he remarked, "Why don't your do the Empress Eugenic?"

Winter meetings of the motorboat enthusiasts will get under way this week with the gatherings of the members of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association on Wednesday at the Gas Crafts Club in the Hotel Lexington.
City College opened its varsity basketball season before 1,000 spectators at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium last night, scoring a decisive 37-18 victory over St. Francis College of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON. ON a recent morning a clerk in the mail room of the United States Treasury opened an envelope containing four halves of neatly cut $1,000 bills. These were folded inside an anonymous note that stated that the other halves of the bills would be sent later.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Dr. William Mather Lewis of Easton, Pa., president of Lafayette College, and newly elected president of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, addressing the annual convention of the organization here today, advocated a plan to infuse new hope in the unemployed of the nation by giving them free college courses along cultural and vocational lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Extension of the Interstate Commerce Commission's investigation into the effect on railroad revenues of their warehousing operations in New York Harbor to include all other competitive ports was urged by the Port of New York Authority today in a brief filed with the commission.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs tonight took a clear lead at the top of the international section of the National League by defeating the Montreal Maroons in a speedy clash, 3 -- 2. It was the first meeting of the teams this season.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Federal Judge Wilkerson announced today that he would appoint a receiver for the Illinois Life Insurance Company Monday morning. His decision followed reading of a resolution adopted by the directors, consenting to appointment of a receiver, although denying insolvency.

ATLANTA, Nov. 26 -- Wilbert Robinson, former manager and president of the Brooklyn National League team who retired from baseball a year ago, came back to the game today as president of the Atlanta Southern Association Club.

RADIO set owners in America total approximately 12,000,000. They are divided into two distinct classes. One comprises the dyed-in-the-wool fans, who enthusiastically, whether by habit or for pleasure, tune in and follow the programs day after day.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -- The Naval Academy completed the most successful soccer season in its history by defeating Bucknell today, 6 to 0. The Navy team has played seven games, winning six and tying one.

AN event unique, colorful and merry will be the International Toy Carnival, under the auspices of the Association of Music School Settlements and the music division of the National Federation of Settlements, which opens tomorrow night in the hallroom of Essex House, to continue throughout the week for the benefit of these organizations.

Bonds of foreign countries and public utility corporations predominated in the announcements last week of loans to be paid before their dates of maturity. The number, however, was small and in keeping with the falling off in retirements this year.

MAKING good its promise, retail trade in the week picked up quite sharply. Stores reported that Friday brought the best business since Columbus Day. Holiday lines moved to the front, and growing demand was indicated on main floor items and toys.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- France and Soviet Russia will sign at the Quai d'Orsay on Tuesday a pact of nonaggression covering their military, political and economic relations. The text of the agreement as submitted by Premier Herriot, was approved by the Council of Ministers today.

THE Twenty-first Annual Appeal on behalf of New York's Hundred Neediest Cases will appear in THE NEW YORK TIMES next Sunday. One hundred stories of deepest human distress will then be told, simply as they happen, without embellishment.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 26 -- Serge P. Korgueff, former concert master of the Russian Imperial Orchestra and since 1925 visiting lecturer in music at Dartmouth College, died today of carcinoma of the stomach in Dick Hall's House, the College Infirmary, after an illness of several months. He was 69.

IT is really much worse than a "lightning tour." It is a whizbang rush, a torpedo plane dash with the motive power barking you along your way while you gasp for breath and wonder what train it is you are trying to catch. The book is an English production -- whereby let it never be said again that the English are slow.

While not equal to "Older Mousie." by Golden Gorse, this is an excellent horse story. Like "Older Mousie," it is a sequel and a successful one. In fact, this second story is perhaps more interesting in plot and incident than "Jerry, The Story of An Exmoor Pony," which preceded it.

THE proposal made by Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy, that the Democratic party live up to its new dignities by retiring the donkey as its informal emblem and replacing it with the traditional rooster brings up the fascinating question of how and why party symbols are developed and what they reveal about political life in America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The State Department notified Poland and Czechoslovakia today that the United States would expect the payments on their war debts Dec. 15 and that no extension of the moratorium could be expected.

The ensuing eighteen days, in which the United States and its European debtors must settle the issue which has arisen over the request of those debtors for another postponement, will call for tolerance of opposing national viewpoints and a common appreciation of each nation's difficulties.

HERE is a tale which recounts in somewhat sensational and creaky fashion the rise to fabulous prosperity and the abysmal fall of a professional bridge master, a tale which, aside from its potential interest for the game's devotees, has little else to commend.

Asserting that American investors in European securities had been misled, not by their bankers, but by American politicians, organized propaganda and so-called investigations, Alfred O. Corbin, a banker here, a special partner in F.J. Lisman Co. and a director of the Alpine Montan Steel Corporation and of other European companies, said yesterday that European investors had bought "all that America threw overboard."

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 26 -- Captain Biff Jones's Louisiana State Tigers, showing more offensive power than at any time this season, rolled up two touchdowns in the first half to score a 14-to-0 victory over the Tulane Green Wave today before a crowd of 22,000 fans.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- A State Health Department report denouncing four Hudson River bathing beaches as menaces to public health and pointing to New Rochelle and Port Chester as dangerous sources of pollution of Long Island Sound was received today by Chairman Herbert Gerlach of the Board of Supervisors from State Health Commissioner Thomas Parran Jr.

To the Dramatic Editor: Agitation on the foreign invasion of the American theatre along with the war debts again threatens to cloud the serenity of our post-election scene. As producer of some 250 plays, most of them the works of American dramatists, I again came in for my share of criticism the other evening at a patriotic meeting where I was a speaker, due to my importation of Jacques Deval's French success "Mademoiselle."

GEORGE JEAN NATHAN, so his intimate notebooks abundantly prove, lives an exciting life. It is the life of a hunted man dodging ambush here, ducking a brick there, scurrying out from under cops' clubs, hurdling pits, and beating gunmen to the draw.

The first thirty-one railroads to report their earnings for October showed a total net operating income of $33,809,000 for that month, against $35,315,000 in October, 1931, a decrease of 4.2 per cent, and with $55,135,000 in October, 1930, a decline of 38.6 per cent.

EVENTS in the musical world in the near future will serve with dances and other entertainments to help raise funds for the welfare work of society. An event that has received a large advance subscription is the special matinee performances of "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera Dec. 8, the net proceeds of which will further the work of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission among the fishermen of Labrador.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 -- Another Fine football team concluded an undefeated season today when the University of Pittsburgh jammed through a touchdown and the point that followed it and then made those seven points carry it through to victory over Stanford.

TWENTY years have passed since Mr. Farnol's "Broad Highway" became a prodigious best seller of its day, and though the author has continued to sustain and augment his public with a score of later volumes, It has been left till now for him to provide a sequel to that famous costume romance.

A few years ago El Dorado Jones, nearing 70 but still hale and hearty, and proud of her achievements as a successful business woman, came to New York to obtain financing for an airplane muffler she had invented. Out in Moline, Ill., they called her the "Iron Woman" because she liked to tinker with metal.

GENEVA, Nov. 26 -- The Japanese delegation said tonight it had not yet received instructions from Tokyo regarding transfer of the Lytton report proceedings on Manchuria to the League of Nations Assembly, but expected them tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The session of Congress this Winter seems likely to witness an effort to reduce the size and expense of the Federal Government on a scale and of a sort unprecedented in the nation's history. The approaching campaign of retrenchment, all signs indicate, will make the effort of the last session soem feeble in comparison, not necessarily in results accomplished but in the noise and tumult accompanying the effort.

Mrs. Lucretia Jones McAnney, former dean of women at Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., and widow of the Rev. Charles H. McAnney, died yesterday afternoon at her home, 160 West Seventy-seventh Street, after a month's illness. She was in her seventy-fourth year.

Science in the Saddle Schenectady gave a Thanksgiving Eve party for the three most eminent of her distinguished collection of scientists in the laboratories of the General Electric Company. They were WHITNEY, the retiring director of research; his successor, COOLIDGE, of the X-ray tube, and LANGMUIR, to whom has just been awarded the 1932 Nobel Prize in chemistry.

Seven of the thirteen post-season scholastic football games to be played in New York City this week for the benefit of the Board of Education's School Relief Fund, the Public Schools Athletic League and the New York American Christmas Fund, will be return contests for the teams involved.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Nov. 24 -- Out of one of the most bitterly contested political campaigns in Kansas, in which taxes, tax methods, shortcomings of elected officials and other spending groups have been discussed from every angle, has come the conviction that if any remedy for the tax situation is to be found it will have to come from township and county governments.

THAT good old term "matinee idol," which seemed to have fallen into a state of desuetude, has been revived and touched up within the past week. And the gentleman to whom it has been applied by king and commoner alike is Francis Lederer, the youthful Czech actor, who disports himself so nicely, to the palpitation of many feminine hearts, in "Autumn Crocus," now playing at the Morosco Theatre.

MOSCOW, Nov. 8 -- Women are invading every walk of life in Russia as a result of the Communist party's drive to "get the women out of the kitchens." The drive was launched by Lenin who said: "Every cook should know how to run the government."

Recent news out of Soviet Russia is a help to dear thinking on the subject of Economic Planning versus a sense of proportion. At the time set for the official Completion of the Five-Year Plan this famous project is not much more than 50 per cent completed, and it has brought in its wake an acute food shortage which threatens to assume the dimensions of a famine.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 -- The 2-year-old, Projectile, which was a surprise winner at Laurel at almost 50 to 1, scored decisively in the eleventh running of the Endurance Handicap, $7,500 added feature at Bowie today.

Some nine years ago the Russian physiologist, Dr. ALEXANDER GURWITSCH, announced that an onion radiates invisible energy. By all the known tests that energy was ultra-violet radiation. It consisted of very short rays that could pass through quartz but not through glass. GURWITSCH'S associates found that yeast and cancer cells had similar properties.

The will of Mrs. Anna M. Galland, who with her daughter, Bertha Galland, retired actress, was killed last Sunday in an automobile accident on North Street, White Plains, was filed for probate yesterday, disclosing that Miss Galland was named as sole legatee of her mother's property.

AN old-fashioned, quaintly sweet and sentimental tale of Cape Cod folk, this novel has the singular semblance of an antique offered as evidence of how the obscurer fictionists practiced their art in the 1880s. Two aging spinster sisters, Prudence and Eliza Jane, embodying extreme opposites in character -- the former cheery, open-handed, diminutive, the latter angular, parsimonious, austere -- are the dubious heroines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Nov. 19 showed an increase over the preceding week, but were slightly lower on a daily average basis and for the month to te have tended to run below the level of October, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

Numbers of Star class small racing yachts have run up more than 900. The fleets of them encircle the world, a new one just having been established in Africa, the last of the continents for the Stars to shine on. It consists of three boats in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The State Department said today that if Norman H. Davis was conducting any conversations with the Japanese or other delegates to the League of Nations in connection with the Lytton report on Manchuria he was doing so personally and not on instructions from the department.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 22 -- The English will scarcely be able to retail any more stories of the thriftiness of the Scotch, after the experience of a mine worker in the Rand gold mines.

Governor-elect Herbert H. Lehman led the Democratic ticket in Kings County and defeated his Republican opponent, William J. Donovan, by the record plurality of 365,648 votes in Brooklyn, according to the official figures of the election of Nov. 8 made public yesterday by Commissioners J.A. Livingston and William J. Hefferman of the Board of Elections.

MEN without Jobs do not sit at home and sulk. Something there is about the households of the unememployed that drives them out. The street is cold, comfortless, but at least there is no reproach in the eyes of passers-by.

Notre Dame's dazzling running attack overshadowed everything else in its triumph over Army, the great Rambler backs plunging through the Cadet line virtually from the start of the game. Almost on a par with the offensive play, however, was the defense, Notre Dame's linemen and secondaries simply bottling up all the Army threats.

MEMBERS of the New York Women's League for Animals have arranged an unusual event in aid of that organization for Dec. 6 at the home of Mrs. Nelson I. Aslel, 15 East Sixty-third Street, when china and bronze dogs, cats and horses from well-known collections will be exhibited.

SANTO DOMINGO is the scene of Mr. Burks's graphic book, and he calls the place the land of "checkerboard families" because the natives are prone to have variegated colors among their progeny. It is not unusual, he says, to find families in which no two members will be of the same color, but will vary all the way from black to white through shades of brown and yellow.

PEIPING, Oct. 22 -- Central Asia, the vast and mysterious hinterland far west of the most distant gates to Peiping and known intimately to but a handful of foreign explorers, scientists, political agents and an occasional missionary or two, is the scene of a drama of the highest importance, yet practically ignored by a world too occupied with the problem of making trade at points more accessible and less baffling.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- The six men held here in $135,000 Beil on a conspiracy indictment in the theft of ballots from the City Hall basement were released from the Essex County Jail, at 6 o'clock this morning, after an all night Chancery proceedlng in which their counsel, Harry H. Weinberger, had argued for their release.

LONDON. RUMORS linking the names of Princess Ingrid of Sweden and Prince George of England had been heard so often that in all the more gilded drawing rooms of Mayfair hands, voices and ear-rings began quivering with suppressed expectancy when Ingrid made her recent visit to London.

Unless cigar smoking is stimulated the cigar industry will find itself in serious straits, it is indicated by a survey of the industry made public yesterday by the United States Cigar Manufacturers Association, an organization of some sixty manufacturers.

MANILA, Oct. 26 -- Increasing activity in the Philippine gold fields at Baguio has led to the formation of the Philippine Gold Mining Association, in which all the leading companies are represented. Its object is the cooperation for mutual benefit of the prospecting and milling units and the establishment of regulated modes of joint procedure.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Alain Gerbault, who started alone in his new sailing boat to make his home in Polynesia, refused many requests from enthusi- asts who wished to accompany him. Both men and women yachting experts of many nationalities volunteered to make the hazardous voyage with him.

TORONTO, Nov. 21. THE assertion that Canadian theatrical activity depends upon the annual movement of wheat and the fluctuations of the Canadian exchange rate may sound farfetched. Nevertheless, these two economic factors affected the number of plays presented to Canadian theatregoers by British and American producers last season.

WHEN the Roosevelts move into the White House on March 4 there will move in with them one who is related by no ties except twenty-two years of the closest association. No relative, no other friend, holds the same position in the household as Louis McHenry Howe.

ABOUT a year ago Frank H. Simonds brought out a book which asked the question: "Can Europe Keep the Peace?" On Dec. 1 his latest book, published on that date by Harpers, will ask: "Can America Stay at Home?"

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- A Supreme Court suit charging that the administration of the city of Mount Vernon had entered into a conspiracy with the property owners benefiting from the $2,000,000 improvement of Gramatan Avenue was served today on eleven city officials and forty corporate bodies and individuals.

ATHENS, Nov. 10 -- Though controversial matters may linger on, elections in Greece are usually as transitory as those in the United States. In Athens Venizelists and Royalists are now disputing over Greece's latest decision to use the plebiscite system of election against the former proportional system.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 -- M.B. Cohen's 2-year-old gelding, Col. Hatfield, won the Gulf Coast Handicap, feature at Jefferson Park today. Doris B. was second and Kilmore third.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 26 -- Mrs. Daniel H. Holmes gave a luncheon at the Cascades Club today for eighteen persons. Her guests included:
WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART -- First biennial exhibition opened with a reception on Monday and to the public on Tuesday. Remains until Jan. 5. Reviewed Nov. 22 and on art page today.

CARACAS, Nov. 21 -- The paradoxical situation of the only debt-free and self-supporting government in the world having its national currency 40 per cent below par has been remedied by the strong action of President General Gomez in placing high tariffs on luxuries and nonessentials.

Faced with a thirty-year sentence for holding up a bank, Andrew (Red Wild-Eye) McCormick, a 25-year-old ex-convict known to the police as a killer, made a desperate attempt to escape from the Brooklyn City Prison, formerly known as the Raymond Street jail, on Ashland Place, near Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, about 8 o'clock last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- A puzzled metropolis is wiping its spectacles and wondering if, perhaps, the people really can put an intrenched political organization such as the Vare machine "on the run." Or would that be just another fairy story?

THE last-minute postponement of the opening of the Dance Centre's second season from last Friday to an indefinite date in the future proved to be something more than just a suspension of public performances to allow for more rehearsals.

LONDON WHAT is this yo-yo? And whence did it come? Some say that a bell-hop in a Canadian hotel, toying idly with an egg-cup and a piece of string, casually discovered that the egg-cup could be made to run up the string as easily as down.

MADRID, Nov. 25 -- The Catalan elections, in which Colonel Francisco Macia's Esguerra party was overwhelmingly triumphant, appear to confirm Spain, as still unmistakably radical and to indicate that the day of the Bourbons is gone forever.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- Within a few months ultra-short-wave radio telephone service is likely to be in everyday commercial operation, Senator Guglielmo Marconi said today as he left for London, where, before a meeting of scientists, he will make an address in which he is expected to reveal some of the secrets of his revolutionary method of transmission.

By the largest margin ever registered in their series, an alert and powerful Erasmus Hall High School eleven, led by Sid Luckman, brilliant sophomore back, crushed Boys High, 37 to 0, before 15,000 at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Three Westchester County cross-country titles were decided today when the seventh annual runs were staged by the Westchester County Recreation Commission. Whitney Lewenden of White Plains High triumphed in the junior race, and a schoolmate, Louis Stancari, captured the intermediate events.

Bonds of domestic corporations averaged a shade higher in the two-hour trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange, representing the first gain in ten days. The sharp decline in leading foreign loans on Friday was checked, with advances and declines about even for the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Loadings or revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 19 were 575,851 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 38,758 cars more than in the preceding week, when the low level of loadings was due largely to observance of Election Day and Armistice Day, but 77,652 fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 203,901 fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- There is a feeling in London that we have come to a parting of the ways. From the decision which Congress is about to take on the issue of the war debt depends the direction taken by economic developments in Great Britain in Europe, perhaps in the whole world.

In yesterday's week-end markets, the only movement of consequence was the recovery in sterling. Having touched during Friday the low level of $3.20 3/8 and having closed that day at $3.20 7/8, it rose yesterday to $3.22 3/8 and ended at $3.21 3/8. Markets were inclined to impute the recovery to support by the British Treasury.

THE colorful football struggle between the Army and the Navy to be held next Saturday at Franklin Field in Philadelphia will doubtless attract a large delegation from New York, many of whom will go by motor to the scene of the battle.

LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Bowing before the lowly Manchester eleven, Aston Villa today surrendered the leadership in the English League first division soccer play to Arsenal, which defeated Middlesborough, 4 -- 2. Manchester City defeated the Villans, 5 to 2.

The first of this season's Knickerbocker Assemblies was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Palms, ferns and smilax provided an all-green setting for the dance, which was one of a series of many years' standing arranged for debutantes of former seasons.
THERE are times when you think you can see some way ahead, but I think the man who says he can see some way ahead is a charlatan.

JESS HARPER, athletic director at Notre Dame, came out early to look over the terrain for the Army-Notre Dame conflict. He said it was the Best turf the game had been played on in years. As a Kansas farmer, Jess is a recognized authority on the good earth.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Crime statistics issued recently by the Ministry of Justice for the year 1930 show a general tendency toward decrease despite a contrary influence traced to automobiles, social unrest and alcoholism.

OF those who gathered at the Waldorf last week at Paramount's invitation to celebrate the impending arrival of the latest Cecil B. De Mille spectacle, "The Sign of the Cross," one of the least perturbed was Mr. De Mille.

Wall Street professed yesterday to see indications of a "sold-out situation" in the share market. This was assigned as the cause of the firm and steady tone on the Stock Exchange. The volume of trading was smaller than on the previous Saturday, 376,000 shares, compared with 385,556.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--Temporary postponement of war-debt payments by countries unable to pay and revision where advisable, conditional upon reductions in armaments and compensatory trade advantages, were advocated by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in a report made public today.

What was described as, in effect, a nine months' survey of New York City's financial structure and its budget will be presented to the Hofstadter legislative committee when it reconvenes next Thursday, Samuel Seabury, its counsel, indicated yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 26--The dollar recovered in the foreign exchange market today, reaching 25.56, while sterling was firm, closing at 82.34 francs. Both the public and professionals abstained from trading to such an extent on the Bourse that long periods passed in which no transactions were recorded.

The first of the live concerts to be given for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Fund by Walter Damrosch, an orchestra of 175 and famous soloists took place, before very enthusiastic audience of 11,000 people last night in Madison Square Garden.

Rocco Zuccarello, 16 years old, of 428 West Forty-sixth Street, admitted to Inspector Charles Stilson at the police line-up yesterday that with two younger companions he had held up and attempted to rob Arthur Wes- ton, 10-year-old son of Mrs. Lillian Murphy of the Hotel Belleclaire, in Central Park on Friday afternoon.

A field of twenty-eight gunners competed in the shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday and excellent scores prevailed despite the handicap of a high wind that whirled the bluerocks into difficult shooting angles.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- While President von Hindenburg with much deliberation is making his dispositions for settling the Cabinet crisis in consultations only with persons who have his confidence and no word about them has been given out, the political atmosphere is charged with speculations.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Louis A. Johnson, National Commander of the American Legion, in an address here tonight in which he urged continuation of veterans appropriations, spoke of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd as "unwittingly and unintentionally" the "stalking horse for the one person out of 3.000 of our population who is against the veterans of America."

If the Norris amendment continues to make its way through the State Legislatures at its present rate, FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT'S successors will have only until the Jan. 20 after the day of their election to occupy the peculiar, active and parlous estate of Presidents-elect. Instead of spending nearly four months in that difficult position, their sentence will be limited to a little more than two.
NEW YORK UNIVERSITY'S attendance at games has dropped from that of previous years by as much as 40 and 50 per cent. This is due to a variety of reasons, partly general conditions.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 26 -- Mildred Kunath Roebling filed suit for divorce today against Siegfried Roebling, grandson of the builder of the Brooklyn Bridge, Cruelty is charged.

Proponents of "enlightened" capitalism and of socialism debated yesterday the question of which system offered greater hope for international peace at the second session of the United Youth Conference Against War at the Rand School.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Catholic University defeated Loyola College of Baltimore, 25 to 0, today before 5,000.

THE first two weeks of December will be devoted to nationwide observances of the twenty-fifth anniversary of founding of the MacDowell Colony and the seventieth anniversary of the birth of Edward MacDowell. These ceremonies will have a twofold purpose.

Two compaion Brussels tapestries, dated about 1680, from the atelier of I.F. van den Hecke, brought $2,025 each yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of antique furniture and decorations consigned by Frederick Bucher.

A spirited performance of "Tannhauser" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night saw the debut of a young American singer, Margaret Halstead, with that organization. It was a conspicuous success. Miss Halstead's voice is one of richness, power and beauty.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. ONE by one the derelict playhouses in Chicago's forlorn Sargasso Sea of the drama are being salvaged and put back into commission. They may be leaky vessels, incapable of long voyages, they may sink with all hands at any moment, but for the time being the battered hulks are afloat and in service.

A PIONEER at the turn of the century -- the adventurous soul who first operated his own automobile in the streets of New York -- is being sought by the management of the Automobile Show, to be held next January. To this individual is to be presented a "handsome gold watch" as a long-deferred reward for "enterprise, courage, patience and faith."

OUT of the fullness of the heart the mouth speaketh; a mind active and curious, a robust memory, a humor richly flavored of the so -- and the ready pen of the seasoned journalist has done the rest, rejoicing in freedom from journalistic restrictions. Mr. Ball is the veteran editor of The Charleston News and Courier -- that is, if any man in his middle sixties can be called a veteran.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 27 -- There was more trading in cotton here last week than in the few preceding weeks, but this was due almost altogether to liquidation and evening up or commitments rather than to investment demand for contracts. The approach of the first notice day for December contracts, which caused much switching from the near to the more distant positions;

A total of $3,093,000 in annual subscription and special donations has thus far been received in the campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies to raise its $3,923,000 budget for the support of the ninety-one philanthropic institutions affiliated with it, according to an announcement yesterday by Paul F. Warburg and Ira M. Younker, co-chairmen of the 1932 drive.

Irish News Items. A team of Fighting Irish from South Bend, Ind., played a football game with an Army team in the Yankee Stadium on Saturday, and the names in the Celtic array were KOSHY, KRAUSE, SCHIRALLI, ROBINSON, GREENEY, KURTH, HOST, VEJAR, LUKATS, SHEEKETSKI and BANAS.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 -- A treasure hunt for Russian gold is promised for next Spring by two rival groups of Japanese salvagers, who claim to have discovered the hull of the Russian cruiser Admiral Nachimov, which with u11,000,000 in British sovereigns aboard ($53,460,000) was sunk in the battle of Tsushima in the Russo-Japanese War.
